अंशु
<u>'''Aṃśu.'''</u>--I. Name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1> viii. 5, 26. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 160;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 89;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 129, suggests that he may be identical with '''[[खेल|Khela]].'''</ref> 2. '''[[धानंजय्य|Dhānaṃjayya]],''' pupil of '''Amāvāsya [[शाण्डिल्यायन|Śāṇḍilyāyana]],''' according to the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

अंहसस्-पति
<u>'''Aṃhasas-pati.'''</u>--This is the name of the intercalary month in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (vii. 30; xxii. 31). See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अक्र
<u>'''Akra.'''</u>--In several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_3> i. 143, 7;<br> 189, 7;<br> iii. 1, 12;<br> iv. 6, 3;<br> x. 77, 2.</ref> this word means, according to Geldner,<ref name=fx2_ve1_3> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 168, 169.</ref> ‘horse.’ Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_3> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 118. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 414.</ref> suggests that ‘riding horse’ is the precise sense. ''Cf.'' '''[[अश्व|Aśva]].'''

अक्ष
<u>'''1. Akṣa,'''</u> ‘axle,’ is a part of a chariot often referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_4> i. 30, 14;<br> 166, 9;<br> iii. 53, 17;<br> vi. 24, 3;<br> x. 89;<br> 4, etc.</ref> and later. It was apparently<ref name=fx2_ve1_4> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 246.</ref> fastened to the body of the chariot ('''[[कोश|Kośa]]''') by straps (''akṣā-nah,'' lit. ‘tied to the axle,’ though this word is also<ref name=fx3_ve1_4> Rv. x. 53, 7. ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> rendered ‘horse’). The heating of the axle and the danger of its breaking were known.<ref name=fx4_ve1_4> Rv. i. 164, 13.</ref> The part of the axle round which the nave of the wheel revolved was called [[आणि|Āṇi]], ‘pin.’ 

अक्ष
<u>'''2. Akṣa.'''</u>--This word occurs frequently, from the Rigveda onwards, both in the singular and plural, meaning ‘die’ and ‘dice.’ Dicing, along with horse-racing, was one of the main amusements of the Vedic Indian; but, despite the frequent mention of the game in the literature, there is considerable difficulty in obtaining any clear picture of the mode in which it was played.<br><br>(1) ''The Material.''--The dice appear normally to have been made of Vibhīdaka nuts. Such dice are alluded to in both the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_5> vii. 86, 6;<br> x. 34, 1.</ref> and the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_5> Av. Paipp. xx. 4, 6.</ref> hence being called ‘brown’ (''[[बभ्रु|babhru]]''), and ‘born on a windy spot.’<ref name=fx3_ve1_5> Rv. x. 34, 5;<br> Av. vii. 114, 7;<br> Rv. x. 34, 1.</ref> In the ritual game of dice at the Agnyādheya and the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] ceremonies the material of the dice is not specified, but it is possible that occasionally gold imitations of Vibhīdaka nuts were used.<ref name=fx4_ve1_5> Sāyaṇa on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 6, 12;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 6.</ref> There is no clear trace in the Vedic literature of the later use of cowries as dice.<ref name=fx5_ve1_5> Sāyaṇa, ''loc. cit.,'' and on Rv. i. 41, 9;<br> Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 28.</ref><br><br>(2) ''The Number.''--In the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_5> x. 34, 12.</ref> the dicer is described as ‘leader of a great horde’ (''senānīr mahato gaṇasya''), and in another passage<ref name=fx7_ve1_5> x. 34, 8.</ref> the number is given as ''tri-pañcāśaḥ,'' an expression which has been variously interpreted. Ludwig,<ref name=fx8_ve1_5> See his translation.</ref> Weber,<ref name=fx9_ve1_5> ''Über das Rājāsūya,'' 72.</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx10_ve1_5> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 284.</ref> render it as fifteen, which is grammatically hardly possible. Roth<ref name=fx11_ve1_5> Following Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 34, 8.</ref> and Grassmann<ref name=fx12_ve1_5> In his translation.</ref> render it as ‘consisting of fifty-three.’ Lüders<ref name=fx13_ve1_5> ''Das Würfelspiel im alten Indien,'' 25.</ref> takes it as ‘consisting of one hundred and fifty,’ but he points out that this may be merely a vague expression for a large number. For a small number Zimmer<ref name=fx14_ve1_5> ''Op. cit.,'' 283.</ref> cites a reference in the Rigveda<ref name=fx15_ve1_5> i. 41, 9.</ref> to one who fears ‘him who holds four’ (''caturaś cid dadamānāt''), but the sense of that passage is dependent on the view taken of the method of playing the game.<br><br>(3) ''The Method of Play.''--In several passages of the later  Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas lists are given of expressions connected with dicing. The names are [[कृत|Kṛta]], Tretā, [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]], Āskanda, and Abhibhū in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx16_ve1_5> iv. 3, 3, 1. 2.</ref> In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx17_ve1_5> xxx. 18.</ref> among the victims at the Puruṣamedha, the ''[[कितव|kitava]]'' is offered to the Akṣarāja, the ''ādinava-[[दर्श|darśa]]'' to the [[कृत|Kṛta]], the ''kalpin'' to the Tretā, the ''adhi-kalpin'' to the [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]], the ''[[सभा-स्थाणु|sabhā-sthāṇu]]'' to the Āskanda. The lists in the parallel version of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] are ''[[कितव|kitava]], [[सभाविन्|sabhāvin]], ādinavadarśa, bahiḥ-sad,'' and ''[[सभा-स्थाणु|sabhā-sthāṇu]],''<ref name=fx18_ve1_5> iii. 4, 1, 16. These must be persons conversant with dicing, but the exact sense of the names is unknown.</ref> and Aksarāja, [[कृत|Kṛta]], Tretā, [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]], and Kali. From the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx19_ve1_5> v. 4, 4, 6.</ref> it appears that another name of Kali was Abhibhū, and the parallel lists in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitās suggest that Abhibhū and Akṣarāja are identical, though both appear in the late [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] list. The names of some of these throws go back even to the Rigveda and the Atharvaveda. Kali occurs in the latter,<ref name=fx20_ve1_5> vii. 114, 1.</ref> and Lüders<ref name=fx21_ve1_5> ''Op. cit.,'' 43 ''et seq,''</ref> shows that in a considerable number of passages in the former [[कृत|Kṛta]] means a ‘throw’ (not ‘a stake’<ref name=fx22_ve1_5> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> or ‘what is won’<ref name=fx23_ve1_5> Grassmann's Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and this sense is clearly found in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx24_ve1_5> vii. 52. See Rv. x. 42, 9 (''kṛtaṃ vicinoti'');<br> 43, 5;<br> x. 102, 2;<br> v. 60, 1;<br> ix. 97, 58;<br> i. 132, 1;<br> x. 34, 6;<br> i. 100, 9;<br> viii. 19, 10.</ref> Moreover, that there were more throws (''ayāḥ'') than one is proved by a passage in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx25_ve1_5> x. 116, 9.</ref> when the gods are compared to throws as giving or destroying wealth.<br><br>The nature of the throws is obscure. The St. Petersburg Dictionary conjectures that the names given above were applied either to dice marked 4, 3, 2, or 1, or to the sides of the dice so marked, and the latter interpretation is supported by some late commentators.<ref name=fx26_ve1_5> Ānandagiri on Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 4;<br> Nīlakaṇṭha on Mahābhārata, iv. 50, 24.</ref> But there is no evidence for the former interpretation, and, as regards the latter, the shape of the Vibhīdaka nuts,<ref name=fx27_ve1_5> Lüders, ''op. cit.,'' 18.</ref> used as dice, forbids any side being properly on the top. Light is thrown on the expressions by the descrip-  tion of a ritual game<ref name=fx28_ve1_5> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 8;<br> 9;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v, 19, 4;<br> 20, 1, with Rudradatta's note, for the Agnyādheya. Āpastamba, xviii. 18, 16 ''st seq.,'' describes the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] game, and ''cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 10, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 6;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 7, 5 ''et seq.'' For [[कृत|Kṛta]] as four, see Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 2, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 11, 1.</ref> at the Agnyādheya and at the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] ceremonies. The details are not certain,<ref name=fx29_ve1_5> See Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 62, 123 ''et seq.''</ref> but it is clear that the game consisted in securing even numbers of dice, usually a number divisible by four, the [[कृत|Kṛta]], the other three throws then being the Tretā, when three remained over after division by four; the [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]], when two was the remainder; and the Kali, when one remained. If five were the dividing number, then the throw which showed no remainder was Kali, the [[कृत|Kṛta]] was that when four was left, and so on. The dice had no numerals marked on them, the only question being what was the total number of the dice themselves.<br><br>There is no reason to doubt that the game as played in the Rigveda was based on the same principle, though the details must remain doubtful. The number of dice used was certainly large,<ref name=fx30_ve1_5> Rv. x. 34, 8.</ref> and the reference to throwing fours,<ref name=fx31_ve1_5> Rv. i. 41, 9. In x. 34, 2, the loss is ascribed to ''akṣasya ekaparasya,'' which confirms the explanation of [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]] given in Pāṇiṇi, ii. 1, 10.</ref> and losing by one, points to the use of the [[कृत|Kṛta]] as the winning throw. The Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx32_ve1_5> vii. 114, 1.</ref> on the other hand, possibly knew of the Kali as the winning throw. In one respect the ordinary game must have differed from the ritual game. In the latter the players merely pick out the number of dice required--no doubt to avoid ominous errors, such as must have happened if a real game had been played. In the secular game the dice were thrown,<ref name=fx33_ve1_5> Rv. x. 34, 1. 8. 9;<br> Av. iv. 38, 3.</ref> perhaps on the principle suggested by Lüders:<ref name=fx34_ve1_5> ''Op. cit.'' 56.</ref> the one throwing a certain number on the place of playing, and the other then throwing a number to make up with those already thrown a multiple of four or five. This theory, at any rate, accounts for the later stress laid on the power of computation in a player, as in the Nala.<br><br>No board appears to have been used, but a depression on which  the dice were thrown (''[[अधि-देवन|adhi-devana]], [[देवन|devana]],''<ref name=fx35_ve1_5> ''[[अधिदेवन|Adhidevana]]'' in Av. v. 31, 6;<br> vi. 70, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā;<br> i. 6, 11;<br> iv. 4, 6, etc.;<br> ''[[देवन|devana]]'' in Rv. x. 43, 5. The falling of the dice on the ground is referred to in Av. vii. 114, 2.</ref> ''[[इरिण|iriṇa]]''<ref name=fx36_ve1_5> Rv. x. 34, 1.</ref> ), was made in the ground. No dice box was used, but reference is made to a case for keeping dice in (''[[अक्ष|akṣa]]-[[वपन|vapana]]''<ref name=fx37_ve1_5> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 11.</ref> The throw was called ''[[ग्रह|graha]]''<ref name=fx38_ve1_5> Av. iv. 38, 1 ''et seq.;<br> cf.'' vii. 114, 5.</ref> or earlier ''[[ग्राभ|grābha]].''<ref name=fx39_ve1_5> Rv. viii. 81, 1;<br> ix. 106, 3.</ref> The stake is called ''vij.''<ref name=fx40_ve1_5> Rv. i. 92, 10;<br> ii. 12, 5;<br> ''[[लक्ष|lakṣa]]'' in ii. 12, 4, and often ''[[धन|dhana]].'' So Lüders, ''op. cit.,'' 10, n. 5;<br> 62, n. 1. Roth and Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 286, render ‘he makes the dice secretly disappear’ (i. 92, 10).</ref> Serious losses could be made at dicing: in the Rigveda a dicer laments the loss of all his property, including his wife.<ref name=fx41_ve1_5> Rv. x. 34, 2. For cheating at play ''cf.'' Rv. v, 85, 8;<br> vii. 86, 6;<br> 104 14;<br> Av. vi. 118.</ref> Lüders<ref name=fx42_ve1_5> ''Op. cit.,'' 61.</ref> finds a different form of the game referred to in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx43_ve1_5> iv. 1, 4;<br> 6. According to Nīlakaṇṭha on Harivaṃśa, ii. 61, 39, the stake was divided into ten parts, and the Kali then took one, the [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]] three, the Tretā six, and the [[कृत|Kṛta]] all ten. This explanation seems harsh.<br><br>''Cf.'' Roth, Gurupūjākaumudī, 1-4;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 283-287;<br> Lüders, ''Das Würfelspiel im alten Indien;<br>'' Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 62, 123 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 823 ''et seq.''</ref>

अक्ष
<u>'''3. Akṣa.'''</u>--In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vii. 3, 1) this word seems to denote the nut of the Vibhīdaka (''Terminalia bellerica'').<br>==Foot Notes==

अक्षत
<u>'''Akṣata'''</u> or '''Akṣita.'''--In one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_7> vii. 76, 4.</ref> dealing with the '''[[जायान्य|Jāyānya]],''' mention is made of a remedy for sores designated both Akṣita and Sukṣata, or, according to the reading of the Kauṣika [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], [[अक्षत|Akṣata]] and Sukṣata, while Sāyaṇa has Akṣita and Sukṣita. Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve1_7> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 17, 562.</ref> renders ‘not caused by cutting’ and ‘caused by cutting.’ Formerly<ref name=fx3_ve1_7> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, cxvii. ''et seq.''</ref> he suggested ‘tumour’ or ‘boil.’ Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve1_7> Translation of the Atharvaveda 442.</ref> thinks that two varieties of [[जायान्य|Jāyānya]] are meant. Ludwig<ref name=fx5_ve1_7> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 500.</ref> reads with Sāyana ''akṣita,'' which he renders by ‘not firmly established’ in the invalid. Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve1_7> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 377.</ref> finds in it a disease [[क्षत|Kṣata]]. 

अक्षा-वपन
<u>'''Akṣā-vapana.'''</u> See '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अक्षु
<u>'''Akṣu.'''</u>--The word occurs in two passages of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_9> viii. 8, 18 (''akṣujālābhyām'');<br> ix. 3, 18.</ref> and one of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_9> i. 180, 5.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_9> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> renders it by ‘net,’ while Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx4_ve1_9> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> suggests ‘axle of a car.’ Geldner<ref name=fx5_ve1_9> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 136.</ref> sees in it a stake or pole used with a fishermen's net ('''[[जाल|Jāla]]'''),<ref name=fx6_ve1_9> Av. viii. 8, 18.</ref> the pole of a wagon,<ref name=fx7_ve1_9> Av. i. 180, 5.</ref> and the pole of a house, whether vertical or horizontal, he leaves uncertain (see '''[[वंश|Vaṃśa]]''').<ref name=fx8_ve1_9> ix. 3, 18.</ref> Bloomfield<ref name=fx9_ve1_9> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 598.</ref> takes it as a covering of wickerwork stretched across a beam and sloping down to both sides--like a thatched roof, and this best explains the epithet ‘thousand-eyed’ (''i.e.,'' with countless holes) ascribed to it. In the other Atharvaveda passage<ref name=fx10_ve1_9> Av. viii. 8, 18.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 153, 265;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 506, 526;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 179.</ref> he accepts the sense ‘net,’ and doubts if the word in the Rigveda is not an adjective (''a-kṣu'') as it is taken by Sāyaṇa. See also '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''

अगस्ति
<u>'''Agasti.'''</u>--This form of '''Agastya's''' name occurs once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_10> iv. 9, 3. ''Cf.'' '''Sieg,''' ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 127, n. 5.</ref> where he appears as a favourite of [[मित्र|Mitra]] and Varuṇa.

अगस्त्य
<u>'''Agastya.'''</u>--This is the name of a sage, of mythical character, who plays a great part in the later literature. He was a '''[[मान|Māna]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_11> Rv. vii. 33, 10 ([[अगस्त्य|Agastya]]), 13 ([[मान|Māna]]).</ref> and therefore is called '''[[मान्य|Mānya]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_11> Rv. i. 165, 15 = 166, 15 = 167, 11 = 168, 10;<br> 165, 14;<br> 177, 5;<br> 184, 4 ([[मान्य|Mānya]]);<br> i. 189, 8;<br> 117, 11 (''Mānasya [[सूनु|sūnu]]'').</ref> and son of [[मान|Māna]], and only once is there a reference<ref name=fx3_ve1_11> Rv. vii. 33, 13. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 138 ''et seq.''</ref> to the legend prevalent in latter times that he was a son of [[मित्र|Mitra]] and Varuṇa.<br><br>His greatest feat was the reconciliation of Indra and the Maruts after Indra had been annoyed at his proposing to give the Maruts an offering to the exclusion of Indra. This feat is the subject of three hymns of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_11> Rv. i. 165;<br> 170;<br> 171.</ref> and is often referred  to in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx5_ve1_11> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 5, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 11, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 11;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 14, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 16;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvi. 9.</ref> though the exact details and significance of the legend are variously treated by Oldenberg,<ref name=fx6_ve1_11> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 39, 60 ''et seq.''</ref> Sieg,<ref name=fx7_ve1_11> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 108-119.</ref> Hertel,<ref name=fx8_ve1_11> ''Vienna Oriental Journal,'' 18, 152-154.</ref> and von Schroeder.<ref name=fx9_ve1_11> ''Mysterium und Mimus im Rigveda,'' 91 ''et seq.''</ref><br><br>He also appears in a strange dialogue with [[लोपामुद्रा|Lopāmudrā]] in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx10_ve1_11> i. 179. ''Cf.'' Sieg, ''op. cit.,'' 120-126;<br> Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 66-68.</ref> which appears to show him as an ascetic who finally yields to temptation. Von '''Schroeder'''<ref name=fx11_ve1_11> ''Op. cit.,'' 156-172.</ref> regards it as a ritual drama of vegetation magic.<br><br>In another passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx12_ve1_11> i. 117, 11;<br> ''cf.'' i. 116, 15.</ref> he appears as helping in the Aśvins’ gift of a leg to [[विश्पला|Viśpalā]]. Sāyaṇa holds that be was the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of '''[[खेल|Khela]],''' and Sieg<ref name=fx13_ve1_11> ''Op. cit.,'' 128.</ref> accepts this view, while Pischel<ref name=fx14_ve1_11> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 171-173.</ref> thinks that [[खेल|Khela]] is a deity, Vivasvant.<br><br>Geldner<ref name=fx15_ve1_11> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 138, 143.</ref> shows from the Rigveda<ref name=fx16_ve1_11> Rv. vii. 33, 10. 13.</ref> that [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]], as brother of [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]--both being miraculous sons of [[मित्र|Mitra]] and Varuṇa-introduces '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]''' to the '''Tṛtsus.''' There are two other references to [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]] in the Rigveda, the one<ref name=fx17_ve1_11> vii. 5, 26. Sieg, 129, suggests that this refers to the [[खेल|Khela]] legend.</ref> including him in a long list of persons, the other alluding to his sister's sons (''nadbhyaḥ''),<ref name=fx18_ve1_11> x. 60, 6.</ref> apparently '''[[बन्धु|Bandhu]],''' etc. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx19_ve1_11> ii. 32, 3;<br> iv. 37, 1. Perhaps for this reason the Rigveda Anukramaṇī ascribes to him (Rv. i. 191) a magic hymn.</ref> he appears as connected with witchcraft, and in a long list of sages.<ref name=fx20_ve1_11> xviii. 3, 15.</ref> In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx21_ve1_11> iv. 2, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 117;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 106-129;<br> Macdonell, ''Bṛhaddevatā,'' 2, 136 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 221;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 110.</ref> cows, with a peculiar mark on their ears (''viṣṭya-karṇyaḥ''), are associated with him.

अगर
<u>'''Agara.'''</u>--This rare word is found as ‘house’ in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_12> ii. 15. ''Cf. āgara,'' ‘chamber’ (?), n Av. iv. 36, 3;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 407. Agāra occurs also in Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 7, 21.</ref> 

अग्नि-दग्ध
<u>'''Agni-dagdha.'''</u>--This epithet (‘burnt with fire’)<ref name=fx1_ve1_13> Rv. x. 15, 14;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 1, 7;<br> ''dagdhāḥ,'' Av. xviii. 2, 34.</ref> applies to the dead who were burned on the funeral pyre. This is one of the two normal methods of disposing of the dead, the other being burial (''an-agnidagdhāḥ,'' ‘not burnt with fire’).<ref name=fx2_ve1_13> Rv., ''loc. cit.;<br>'' = ''nikhātāḥ,'' Av. xviii. 2, 34.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_13> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> adds two further modes of disposal to those-viz., casting out (''paroptāḥ''), and the exposure of the dead (''uddhitāḥ''). The exact sense of these expressions is doubtful. Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_13> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 402.</ref> considers that the former is a parallel to the Iranian practice of casting out the dead to be devoured by beasts, and that the latter refers to the old who are exposed when helpless.<ref name=fx5_ve1_13> Rv. viii. 51, 2.</ref> Whitney<ref name=fx6_ve1_13> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 841.</ref> refers the latter expression to the exposure of the dead body on a raised platform of some sort.<br><br>Burial was clearly not rare in the Rigvedic period: a whole hymn<ref name=fx7_ve1_13> x. 18. The interpretation of v. 8 is a famous crux, see [[पत्नी|Patnī]].</ref> describes the ritual attending it. The dead man was buried apparently in full attire, with his bow in his hand, and probably at one time his wife was immolated to accompany him, in accordance with a practice common among savage tribes. But in the Vedic period both customs appear in a modified form: the son takes the bow from the hand of the dead man, and the widow is led away from her dead husband by his brother or other nearest kinsman. A stone is set between the dead and the living to separate them. In the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx8_ve1_13> xviii. 2, 25;<br> 3, 70.</ref> but not in the Rigveda, a coffin (''[[वृक्ष|vṛkṣa]]'') is alluded to. In both Saṃhitās<ref name=fx9_ve1_13> Rv. vii. 89, 1;<br> Av. v. 30, 14;<br> xviii. 2, 52.</ref> occur other allusions to the ‘house of earth’ (''[[भूमि|bhūmi]]-[[गृह|gṛha]]''). To remove the apparent discrepancy between burning and burial, by assuming that the references to burial are to the burial of the burned bones, as does Oldenberg,<ref name=fx10_ve1_13> ''Religion des Veda,'' 571.</ref> is unnecessary and improbable, as burning and burial subsisted side by side in Greece for many years.<br><br>Burning was, however, equally usual, and it grew steadily in frequency, for in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx11_ve1_13> viii. 8. 5.</ref> the adornment  of the body of the dead with curd ('''[[आमिक्षा|Āmikṣā]]'''), clothes, and ornaments, in order to win the next world, is referred to as something erroneous and wrong, and in the funeral Mantras of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx12_ve1_13> xxxv. ''Cf.'' also [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 80 ''et seq.,'' which treats the Atharvaveda hymns, xviii. 1-3, as intended for burning only.</ref> only burning seems to be contemplated; the verses which refer to burial here really alluding to the burial of the ashes in the burying-ground (''[[श्मशान|śmaśāna]]'').<ref name=fx13_ve1_13> Av. v. 31, 8;<br> x. 1, 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 8, 5;<br> 4, 11, 3.</ref> The body was wrapped in fat,<ref name=fx14_ve1_13> Rv. x. 16, 7.</ref> as we learn from the funeral hymn in the Rigveda, a goat being apparently burned with it,<ref name=fx15_ve1_13> Rv. x. 16, 4. But ''aja'' may mean ‘the unborn part,’ as Weber prefers to take it, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1895, 847.</ref> to act as a guide on the way to the next world. According to the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx16_ve1_13> xii. 2, 48.</ref> a draft-ox was burned presumably for the dead to ride with in the next world. It was expected that the dead would revive with his whole body and all his limbs (''sarva-tanūḥ sāṅgaḥ''),<ref name=fx17_ve1_13> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 1, 1;<br> xi. 1, 8, 6;<br> xii. 8, 3, 31. ''Cf.'' Av. xi. 3, 32. This fact probably explains the use of ''śeṣaḥ'' in Rv. x. 16, 5. The dead enjoy sexual pleasures in the next world;<br> see Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 307, n. 462.</ref> although it is also said<ref name=fx18_ve1_13> Rv. x. 16, 3.</ref> that the eye goes to the sun, the breath to the wind, and so forth.<br><br>Before burial or burning, the corpse was washed,<ref name=fx19_ve1_13> Av. v. 19, 14.</ref> a clog (''[[कूदी|kūdī]]'') being tied to the foot to prevent the deceased returning to earth.<ref name=fx20_ve1_13> Av. v. 19, 12;<br> see Roth, ''Festgruss an Bo7htlingk,'' 98;<br> Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 12, 416.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 401407;<br> Roth, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 8, 468 ''et seq.;<br> Siebenzig Lieder,'' 150 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 570 ''et seq.;<br>'' Caland, ''Die altindischen Todten- und Bestattungsgebräuche;<br>'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 40-42;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythology,'' 3, 413423;<br> ''Rituallitteratur,'' 87 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 165, 166;<br> Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1895, 815 ''et seq.''</ref>

अग्नि-भू काश्यप
<u>'''Agni-bhū Kāśyapa'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_14> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 374.</ref>

अग्नि-शाल
<u>'''Agni-śāla.'''</u>--This term, which designates part of the sacrificial  apparatus,<ref name=fx1_ve1_15> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 18.</ref> is applied in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_15> ix. 3, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns. of the Atharvaveda,'' 598;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 154.</ref> to a part of an ordinary house, presumably the central hall where the fireplace was.

अघा
<u>'''Aghā.'''</u>--In the wedding hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_16> x. 85, 13.</ref> it is said that cows are slain in the Aghās, and the wedding takes place at the '''Arjunīs''' (dual). The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_16> xiv. 1, 13.</ref> has the ordinary '''[[मघास्|Maghās]]''' instead. It is impossible to resist the conclusion that the reading of the Rigveda was deliberately altered because of the connection of the slaughter of kine with sin (''agha'')--possibly, too, with a further desire to emphasize the contrast with ''[[अघ्न्या|aghnyā]],'' a name for ‘cow.’ Moreover, in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_16> iii. 1, 4, 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 364;<br> Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1894, 804;<br> Jacobi, ''Festgruss an Roth,'' 69;<br> Winternitz, ''Das altindische Hochzeitsrituell,'' 32;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 742;<br> Thibaut, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 24, 95.</ref> occurs the formula ‘Svāhā to the [[मघास्|Maghās]], Svāhā to the Anaghās.’ See also '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''

अघाश्व
<u>'''Aghāśva.'''</u>--The name of a serpent in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_17> x. 4, 10. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref>

अ-घ्न्या
<u>'''A-ghnyā.'''</u>--See '''[[मांस|Māṃsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अङ्क
<u>'''Aṅka.'''</u>--The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_19> i. 7, 7, 2.</ref> and [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_19> ii. 7, 8, 1. ''Cf.'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 5.</ref> refer to two Aṅkas and two Nyaṅkas as parts of a chariot. The meaning of these terms is quite obscure. The commentators refer them to the sides or wheels. Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_19> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 251, 252.</ref> compares the Greek <ref name=fx4_ve1_19> ''Iliad,'' v. 728. ''Cf.'' Smith's ''Dictionary of Antiquities,'' 1, 578.</ref> and thinks that the Aṅkau were the upper border of the body of the chariot (''[[कोश|kośa]], [[वन्धुर|vandhura]]''), and the Nyaṅkau the lower rims for greater security. Oldenberg<ref name=fx5_ve1_19> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 29, 364, on Pāraskara [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 14, 6.</ref> confesses that the exact sense is impossible to make out, but considers that the terms at once refer to parts of the chariot and to divinities, while Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx6_ve1_19> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> takes the term as referring to divinities alone. 

अङ्ग
<u>'''Aṅga.'''</u>--The name occurs only once in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_20> v. 22, 14.</ref> in connection with the '''Gandhāris, Mūjavants,''' and '''Magadhas,''' as distinct peoples. They appear also in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_20> ii. 9.</ref> in the compound name ''[[अङ्ग|Aṅga]]-magadhāḥ.'' As in later times they were settled on the Sone and Ganges,<ref name=fx3_ve1_20> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 35;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 446, 449;<br> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 852, inclines to regard them as a non-Aryan people that came over-sea to Eastern India. There is nothing in the Vedic literature to throw light on this hypothesis.</ref> their earlier seat was presumably there also. See also '''[[वङ्ग|Vaṅga]].'''

अङ्ग वैरोचन
<u>'''Aṅga Vairocana.'''</u>--He is included in the list of anointed kings in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_21> viii. 22. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 214.</ref> His [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] was '''Udamaya,''' an [[आत्रेय|Ātreya]].

अङ्गारावक्षयण
<u>'''Aṅgārāvakṣayaṇa.'''</u>--A word of doubtful meaning found in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_22> iii. 9, 18.</ref> It is rendered ‘tongs’ by Max Müller and Bo7htlingk in their translations. The St. Petersburg Dictionary explains it as ‘a vessel in which coals are extinguished,’ and Monier-Williams as ‘an instrument for extinguishing coals.’ The smaller St. Petersburg Dictionary renders the word ‘coal-shovel or tongs.’ ''Cf.'' '''Ulmukāvakṣayaṇa.'''

अङ्गिरस्
<u>'''Aṅgiras.'''</u>--The Aṅgirases appear in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_23> ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' ii. 156-169.</ref> as semimythical beings, and no really historical character can be assigned even to those passages<ref name=fx2_ve1_23> Rv. i. 45, 3;<br> 139, 9;<br> iii. 31, 7, etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, 10.</ref> which recognize a father of the race, [[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]. Later, however, there were definite families of Aṅgirases, to whose ritual practices (''ayana, dvirātra'') references are made.<ref name=fx3_ve1_23> Av. xviii. 4, 8, but this may be mythical;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xx. 11, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 4, 1. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 142, 143.</ref>

अङ्गुष्ठ
<u>'''Aṅguṣṭha.'''</u>--As a measure of size this word appears in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 12; vi. 17). <br>==Foot Notes==

अ-च्युत्
<u>'''A-cyut.'''</u>--He acted as [[प्रतिहर्तृ|Pratihartṛ]] at the Sattra celebrated by the Vibhindukīyas and described in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_25> iii. 233. See ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 38.</ref>

अज
<u>'''Aja, Ajā.'''</u>--This is the ordinary name for goat in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_26> ''Aja'' in Rv. x. 16, 4;<br> i. 162, 2. 4;<br> Av. ix. 5, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 9, etc.;<br> ''ajā'' in Rv. viii. 70, 15;<br> Av. vi. 71, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii., 56, etc.</ref> and the later literature. The goat is also called '''[[बस्त|Basta]], [[छाग|Chāga]], Chagala.''' Goats and sheep (''ajāvayaḥ'') are very frequently mentioned together.<ref name=fx2_ve1_26> Rv. x. 90, 10;<br> Av. viii. 7, 25;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 43, etc.</ref> The female goat is spoken of as producing two or three kids,<ref name=fx3_ve1_26> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 1.</ref> and goat's milk is well known.<ref name=fx4_ve1_26> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 6, 1;<br> v. 1, 7, 4. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 364, n. 4.</ref> The goat as representative of Pūṣan plays an important part in the ritual of burial.<ref name=fx5_ve1_26> Rv. x. 16, 4, etc. ''Cf.'' p. 9.</ref> The occupation of a goatherd (''ajapāla'') was a recognized one, being distinguished from that of a cowherd and of a shepherd.<ref name=fx6_ve1_26> Vājasaneyī Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 9, 1.</ref>

अज
<u>'''Aja.'''</u>--The Ajas are named in one verse of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_27> vii. 18. 19.</ref> as having been defeated by the '''Tṛtsus''' under '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]].''' They are there mentioned with the '''Yakṣus''' and '''Śigrus,''' and Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_27> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 127, ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173.</ref> conjectures that they formed part of a confederacy under [[भेद|Bheda]] against [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. The name has been regarded as a sign of totemism,<ref name=fx3_ve1_27> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 153;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 929;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, 200, 21;<br> Risley, ''Peoples of India,'' 83 ''et seq.''</ref> but this is very uncertain, and it is impossible to say if they were or were not Āryans.

अजकव
<u>'''Ajakava.'''</u>--This name of a poisonous scorpion occurs once in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_28> vii. 50, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref>

अज-गर
<u>'''Aja-gara'''</u> (‘goat-swallower’) occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_29> xi. 2, 25;<br> xx. 129, 17.</ref> and in the list of animals at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_29> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā 5, 14, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii, 14, 19;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 38.</ref> or horse sacrifice, as the  name of the boa-constrictor. Elsewhere<ref name=fx3_ve1_29> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 13, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 34.</ref> it is called [[वाहस|Vāhasa]]. It denotes a person at the snake feast in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_29> xxv. 15, in the form of Ajagāva, with which ''cf.'' '''Ajakāva.'''</ref>

अज-मीढ
<u>'''Aja-mīḍha.'''</u>--The Ājamīḍhas, or descendants of [[अजमीढ|Ajamīḍha]], are referred to in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_30> iv. 44, 6.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_30> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 123, 135.</ref> and Oldenberg<ref name=fx3_ve1_30> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 215.</ref> deduce from the use of this patronymic that [[अजमीढ|Ajamīḍha]] was the seer of that hymn.

अज-शृङ्गी
<u>'''Aja-śṛṅgī.'''</u>--This plant (‘goat's horn’), equated by the commentator with [[विषाणिन्|Viṣāṇin]] (the ''Odina pinnata''), is celebrated as a demon-destroyer in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_31> iv. 37.</ref> Its other name is '''[[अराटकी|Arāṭakī]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_31> iv. 37, 6.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_31> ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 144. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 408, 409;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 68;<br> Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 89.</ref> suggests that it is the ''Prosopis spicigera'' or ''Mimosa suma.''

अजात-शत्रु
<u>'''Ajāta-śatru.'''</u>--He is mentioned as a King of Kāśī (Kāśya) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve1_32> ii. 1, 1.</ref> and [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_32> iv. 1.</ref> Upaniṣads, where he instructs the proud [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] [[बालाकि|Bālāki]] as to the real nature of the self. He is not to be identified with the Ajātasattu of the Buddhist texts.<ref name=fx3_ve1_32> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 213;<br> Hoernle, ''Osteology,'' 106;<br> Keith, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 62, 138.</ref>

अज्ञात-यक्ष्म
<u>'''Ajñāta-yakṣma,'''</u> the ‘unknown sickness,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_33> x. 161, 1 = Av. iii. 11, 1.</ref> Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_33> vi. 127, 3.</ref> and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx3_ve1_33> xiii. 16.</ref> It is referred to in connection with [[राजयक्ष्म|Rājayakṣma]]. Grohmann<ref name=fx4_ve1_33> ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 400.</ref> thinks that the two are different forms of disease, hypertrophy and atrophy, the purpose of the spell in the Rigveda being thus the removal of all disease. From the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_33> vi. 127. 3.</ref> he deduces its identity with '''[[बलास|Balāsa]].''' Zimmer,<ref name=fx6_ve1_33> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 377, 378.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield. ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 342;<br> Atharvaveda, 60;<br> Jolly, ''Medicin'' (in Bühler's Encyclopædia), 89.</ref> however, points out that this  conclusion is unjustified, leaving the disease unidentified, which seems to accord with its name.

अजिन
<u>'''Ajina.'''</u>--This word denotes generally the skin of an animal-''e.g.,'' a gazelle,<ref name=fx1_ve1_34> Av. v. 21, 7.</ref> as well as that of a goat ('''Aja''').<ref name=fx2_ve1_34> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 1, 21. 24.</ref> The use of skins as clothing is shown by the adjective ‘clothed in skins’ (''[[अजिन|ajina]]-vāsin'') in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_34> iii. 9, 1, 12.</ref> and the furrier's trade is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx4_ve1_34> xxx. 15 (''[[अजिन|ajina]]-saṃdha'');<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 13, 1 (''ajinasaṃdhāya'').</ref> The Maruts also wear deer-skins,<ref name=fx5_ve1_34> Rv. i. 166, 10.</ref> and the wild ascetics (''muni'') of a late Rigveda hymn<ref name=fx6_ve1_34> x. 136, 2. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262.</ref> seem to be clad in skins ('''Mala''').

अजिर
<u>'''Ajira.'''</u>--He was [[सुब्रह्मण्य|Subrahmaṇya]] priest at the snake festival of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_35> xxv. 15. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

अजीगर्त सौयवस
<u>'''Ajīgarta Sauyavasa.'''</u>--This is the name given to the father of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' in the famous legend of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_36> vii. 15;<br> 17. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 19.</ref> perhaps invented for the occasion, as Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_36> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 460;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> suggests.

अ-ज्येयता
<u>'''A-jyeyatā.'''</u> See '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अणीचिन् मौन
<u>'''Aṇīcin Mauna.'''</u>--He is mentioned as an authority on ritual, and contemporary with '''[[जाबाल|Jābāla]]''' and '''[[चित्र|Citra]] [[गौश्रायणि|Gauśrāyaṇi]]''' or '''[[गौश्र|Gauśra]],''' in the '''[[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]]''' [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_38> xxiii. 5.</ref>

अणु
<u>'''Aṇu.'''</u>--This is the designation in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_39> xviii. 12.</ref> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_39> vi. 3, 15 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]]), where see Dviveda's note.</ref> of a cultivated grain, '''apparently''' the ''Panicum miliaceum.''

अतिथि
<u>'''Atithi'''</u> (‘guest’).--A hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_40> ix. 6.</ref> celebrates in detail the merits of hospitality. The guest should be fed before  the host eats, water should be offered to him, and so forth. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_40> i. 11, 2.</ref> also lays stress on hospitality, using the expression ‘one whose deity is his guest’ (''[[अतिथि|atithi]]-deva''). In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx3_ve1_40> i. 1, 1.</ref> it is said that only the good are deemed worthy of receiving hospitality. The guest-offering forms a regular part of the ritual,<ref name=fx4_ve1_40> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 3, 2, 1.</ref> and cows were regularly slain in honour of guests.<ref name=fx5_ve1_40> ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 426;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 79.</ref>

अतिथि-ग्व
<u>'''Atithi-gva.'''</u>--This name occurs frequently in the Rigveda, apparently applying, in nearly all cases, to the same king, otherwise called '''Divodāsa.''' The identity of the two persons has been denied by Bergaigne,<ref name=fx1_ve1_41> ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 342 ''et seq.''</ref> but is certainly proved by a number of passages, when the two names occur together,<ref name=fx2_ve1_41> Rv. i. 51, 6;<br> 112, 14;<br> 130, 7;<br> iv. 26, 3;<br> vi. 47, 22.</ref> in connection with the defeat of '''[[शम्बर|Śambara]].''' In other passages<ref name=fx3_ve1_41> Rv. i. 53, 8;<br> x. 48, 8.</ref> [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]] is said to have assisted Indra in slaying [[पर्णय|Parṇaya]] and [[करञ्ज|Karañja]]. Sometimes he is only vaguely referred to, while once<ref name=fx5_ve1_41> Rv. vii. 19, 8. There is no ground for assuming the reference here to be to a later [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]].</ref> he is mentioned as an enemy of [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] and Yadu. Again<ref name=fx6_ve1_41> Rv. i. 53, 10;<br> ii. 14, 7;<br> vi. 18, 13;<br> viii. 53, 2.</ref> [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]] is coupled with '''[[आयु|Āyu]]''' and '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]]''' as defeated by '''[[तूर्वयाण|Tūrvayāṇa]].'''<br><br>A different [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]] appears to be referred to in a Dānastuti<ref name=fx7_ve1_41> Rv. viii. 68, 16. 17.</ref> (‘Praise of Gifts’), where his son, '''[[इन्द्रोत|Indrota]],''' is mentioned.<br><br>Roth<ref name=fx8_ve1_41> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 123;<br> Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 426, who renders the name ‘presenting cows to guests.’</ref> distinguishes three Atithigvas--the [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]] Divodāsa, the enemy of [[पर्णय|Parṇaya]] and [[करञ्ज|Karañja]], and the enemy of [[तूर्वयाण|Tūrvayāṇa]]. But the various passages can be reconciled, especially if it is admitted that [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]] Divodāsa was already an ancient hero in the earliest hymns, and was becoming almost mythical.<br><br><ref name=fx4_ve1_41> Rv. vi. 26, 3.</ref>

अति-धन्वन् शौनक
<u>'''Ati-[[धन्वन्|dhanvan]] Śaunaka.'''</u>--He is mentioned as a teacher in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_42> i. 9, 3.</ref> and the Vaṃsa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_42> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 384.</ref> 

अ-तृणाद
<u>'''A-tṛṇāda.'''</u>--This term (‘not eating grass’) was applied, according to the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], to a newborn calf.<ref name=fx1_ve1_43> i. 5, 2. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 268.</ref>

अत्क
<u>'''1. Atka.'''</u>--This word occurs frequently in the Rigveda, but its sense is doubtful. Roth, Grassmann, Ludwig, Zimmer,<ref name=fx1_ve1_44> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262.</ref> and others render it as ‘garment’ in several passages,<ref name=fx2_ve1_44> i. 95, 7;<br> ii. 35, 14;<br> iv. 18, 5;<br> v. 55, 6;<br> 74, 5;<br> vi. 29, 3;<br> viii. 41, 7;<br> ix. 101, 14;<br> 107, 13;<br> [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], ii. 1193.</ref> when the expressions ‘put on’ (''vyā'' or ''prati muñc'') or ‘put off’ (''muñc'') are used of it, and when it is said to be ‘woven’ (''vyuta'')<ref name=fx3_ve1_44> Rv. i. 122, 2.</ref> or ‘wellfitting’ (''surabhi'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_44> Rv. vi. 29, 3;<br> x. 123, 7.</ref> On the other hand, Pischel<ref name=fx5_ve1_44> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 193-204.</ref> denies that this sense occurs, and otherwise explains the passages. He takes the term to mean ‘axe’ in four places.<ref name=fx6_ve1_44> Rv. v. 55, 6;<br> vi. 33, 3;<br> x. 49, 3;<br> 99, 9. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 94, n. 1.</ref>

अत्क
<u>'''2. Atka.'''</u>--In two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_45> x. 49, 3;<br> 99, 9.</ref> this word is regarded as a proper name by Roth, Grassmann, and Ludwig. But Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_45> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262, 297.</ref> explains it in these passages as the ‘armour of a warrior as a whole,’ and Pischel<ref name=fx3_ve1_45> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 195.</ref> thinks that in both cases an ‘axe’ is meant.

अत्य्-अंहस् आरुणि
<u>'''Aty-aṃhas Āruṇi.'''</u>--According to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 10, 9, 3-5), this teacher sent a pupil to question '''[[प्लक्ष|Plakṣa]] Dayyāṃpati''' as to the Sāvitra (a form of Agni). For this impertinence his pupil was severely rebuked.<br>==Foot Notes==

अत्य्-अराति जानं-तपि
<u>'''Aty-arāti Jānaṃ-tapi,'''</u> though not a prince, was taught the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] by '''[[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] Satyahavya,''' and thereupon conquered the earth. When [[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] reminded him of his indebtedness, and claimed a great reward, the warrior replied irascibly that he intended to conquer the '''Uttara Kurus,''' and that [[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] would then become King of the Earth, Atyarāti himself being his general (''[[सेना|senā]]-pati''). [[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] replied that as no mortal man could conquer the Uttara Kurus he was cheated of his reward.  He consequently procured Atyarāti's defeat and death at the hands of '''[[अमित्रतपन शुष्मिण शैब्य|Amitratapana Śuṣmiṇa Śaibya]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_47> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 23. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 214.</ref>

अत्रि
<u>'''Atri.'''</u>--Neither Atri himself nor the Atris can claim any historical reality,<ref name=fx1_ve1_48> For Atri in the Rigveda, see Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 145. ''Cf.'' also Av. ii. 32, 3;<br> iv. 29, 3;<br> [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 36, etc.;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, 4.</ref> beyond the fact that Maṇḍala V. of the Rigveda is attributed, no doubt correctly, to the family of the Atris.<ref name=fx2_ve1_48> ''Cf.'' Rv. v. 39, 5;<br> 67, 5;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii, 2, 1.</ref> The Atris as a family probably stood in close relations with the '''Priyamedhas'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_48> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 45, 3;<br> 139, 9;<br> viii. 5, 25;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 22.</ref> and '''Kaṇvas,'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_48> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 118, 7;<br> v. 41, 4;<br> x. 150, 5.</ref> perhaps also with the '''Gotamas'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_48> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 183, 5.</ref> and '''Kākṣīvatas.'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_48> ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 143, 1.</ref> The mention of both the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]]''' and the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' in one hymn<ref name=fx7_ve1_48> Rv. v. 52, 9, 17. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 128, 142;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 469;<br> Oldenber, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 212215;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 310.</ref> of the fifth Maṇḍala seems to justify the presumption that the family was spread over a wide extent of territory.

अथरी
<u>'''Atharī.'''</u>--This word occurs only in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_49> iv. 6, 8.</ref> and the sense is doubtful. Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_49> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> followed by most interpreters, renders it ‘point of a lance,’ but Pischel<ref name=fx3_ve1_49> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 99.</ref> thinks that it means ‘an elephant.’

अथर्वन्
<u>'''Atharvan.'''</u>--The name in the singular denotes the head of a semi-divine family of mythical priests,<ref name=fx1_ve1_50> See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 141. In the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 6, 3, [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] [[दैव|Daiva]] is characteristically the pupil of [[मृत्यु|Mṛtyu]].</ref> of whom nothing historical can be said. In the plural the family as a whole is meant. In a few places an actual family seems to be referred to. Thus, for instance, they are mentioned as recipients of gifts in the Dānastuti<ref name=fx2_ve1_50> Rv. vi. 47, 24.</ref> (‘Praise of Gifts’), of '''Aśvattha's'''  generosity; their use of milk mingled with honey in the ritual is referred to;<ref name=fx3_ve1_50> Rv. ix. 11, 2.</ref> and a cow that miscarries (''ava-tokā'') from accident is dedicated to the Atharvans, according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_50> iii. 4, 11, 1. ''Cf.'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 15.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xxxv. ''et seq.,'' who (p. xxxviii) takes ''avatokā'' as a woman, and the Atharvans as the hymns;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 174 ''et seq.''</ref>

अथर्वाणः
<u>'''Atharvāṇaḥ.'''</u>--This expression<ref name=fx1_ve1_51> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 9, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 10, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 5 ''et seq.''</ref> is used with '''Aṅgirasaḥ,''' to denote the Atharvaveda. The compound '''[[अथर्वाङ्गिरसः|Atharvāṅgirasaḥ]]''' is employed in the same sense.

अथर्वाङ्गिरसः
<u>'''Atharvāṅgirasaḥ.'''</u>--This is the collective name of the Atharvaveda in several passages<ref name=fx1_ve1_52> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 8, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 9;<br> 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 6, 7;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 2;<br> 5, 11;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 4, 1. 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 3, 1.</ref> of the later Brāhmaṇas. It occurs once in the Atharvaveda itself,<ref name=fx2_ve1_52> x. 7, 20.</ref> while the term Atharvaveda is not found before the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period.<ref name=fx3_ve1_52> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2, 9, etc.</ref> The compound seems, according to Bloomfield,<ref name=fx4_ve1_52> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, 387 ''et seq.;<br> Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xviii. ''et seq.''</ref> to denote the two elements which make up the Atharvaveda. The former part refers to the auspicious practices of the Veda (''bheṣajāni'');<ref name=fx5_ve1_52> Av. xi. 6, 14.</ref> the latter to its hostile witchcraft, the ''yātu''<ref name=fx6_ve1_52> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5, 2, 20.</ref> or ''abhi-cāra.''<ref name=fx7_ve1_52> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 3, 19.</ref> This theory is supported by the names of the two mythic personages '''[[घोर आङ्गिरस|Ghora Āṅgirasa]]''' and '''[[भिषज् आथर्वण|Bhiṣaj Ātharvaṇa]],''' as well as by the connection of [[अथर्वाणः|Atharvāṇaḥ]] and '''Ātharvaṇāni''' with healing (''[[भेषज|bheṣaja]]'') in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx8_ve1_52> xii. 9, 10;<br> xvi. 10, 10.</ref> Moreover, the term ''bhesajā'' (‘remedies’) designates in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_52> x. 6, 14.</ref> that Veda itself, while in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx10_ve1_52> x. 5, 2, 20.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 177.</ref> ''yātu'' (‘sorcery’) conveys the same meaning. The evidence, however, being by no means convincing, it remains probable that there existed no clear differentiation between the two sages as responsible for the Atharvaveda as a whole. 

अ-दृष्ट
<u>'''A-dṛṣṭa.'''</u>--‘The unseen’ is a term used in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_53> Rv. i. 191, 4 = Av. vi. 52, 2.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_53> vi. 52, 3.</ref> to designate a species of vermin. The sun is also described as ‘the slayer of the unseen’ (''[[अदृष्ट|adṛṣṭa]]-han''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_53> Rv. i. 191, 9 = Av. vi. 52, 1;<br> Av. v. 23, 6.</ref> and as a counterpart a ‘seen’ (''[[दृष्ट|dṛṣṭa]]'') is mentioned.<ref name=fx4_ve1_53> Av. ii. 31, 2;<br> viii. 8, 15.</ref> In one passage<ref name=fx5_ve1_53> Av. v. 23, 6. 7.</ref> the epithets ‘seen’ and ‘unseen’ are applied to the worm ('''[[कृमि|Kṛmi]]'''), their use being no doubt due to the widespread theory of diseases being due to worms, whether discernable by examination or not.<ref name=fx6_ve1_53> Kuhn, ''Zeitschrift für vergleichende Sprachforschung,'' 13, 135 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 313315;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref>

अद्म-सद्
<u>'''Adma-sad.'''</u>--This expression (''lit.'' ‘sitting at the meal’), found several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_54> i. 124, 4;<br> vi. 30, 3;<br> vii. 83, 7;<br> viii. 44, 29;<br> ''adma-sadvan,'' vi. 4, 4.</ref> is usually rendered ‘guest at the feast,’ but Geldner<ref name=fx2_ve1_54> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 179, 180;<br> but ''of'' Oldenberg, ''Vedaforschung,'' 90.</ref> adduces reasons to show that it means ‘a fly,’ so called because of its settling on food.

अद्रि
<u>'''Adri.'''</u>--Zimmer<ref name=fx1_ve1_55> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 301. ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> deduces from the use of this word (‘rock,’ ‘stone’) in a passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_55> i. 51, 3.</ref> that sling-stones were used in Vedic fighting. But the passage is mythical, referring to Indra's aid, and cannot be used with any certainty as evidence for human war. More probably it merely denotes Indra's bolt. See also '''[[अशनि|Aśani]].'''

अधि-देवन
<u>'''Adhi-devana.'''</u>--The place where the dice were thrown is thus designated in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_56> v. 31, 6;<br> vi. 70, 1.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_56> v. 4, 4, 20. 22, 23.</ref> according to Lüders.<ref name=fx3_ve1_56> ''Das Würfelspiel im alten Indien,'' 11-13.</ref> Roth,<ref name=fx4_ve1_56> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> followed by Whitney, takes it to mean ‘gambling-board.’ See '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''

अधि-राज
<u>'''Adhi-rāja.'''</u>--The word occurs fairly often throughout the early literature,<ref name=fx1_ve1_57> Rv. x. 128, 9 Av. vi. 98, 1;<br> ix. 10, 24;<br> Taiturīya Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 14, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhita, iv. 12, 3;<br> Kāthaka Saṃhitā, viii. 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 2, 9 (''adhirājan'');<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 2, 2;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], viii. 2.</ref> denoting ‘overlord’ among kings or princes.  In no passage is it clear that a real over-king is meant, as the word ''[[राजन्|rājan]]'' may mean king or merely prince, a person of royal blood. On the whole it seems most probable that the word connotes no more than ‘king’ as opposed to ‘prince.’

अधि-षवण
<u>'''Adhi-ṣavaṇa.'''</u>--The two Adhiṣavaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_58> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 21;<br> Av. v. 20, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 4, 1;<br> 5, 3, 22 (''adhiṣavaṇe phalake'');<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 32 (''adhiṣavaṇaṃ carma,'' ‘the skin upon which the pressing takes place’;<br> ''adhiṣavaṇe phalake,'' ‘the boards on which the pressing takes place,’ etc.).</ref> are usually understood, as by Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_58> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve1_58> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 277.</ref> to designate the two boards between which the Soma was pressed. Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx4_ve1_58> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 148 ''et seq.''</ref> however, shows from the ritual that the boards were not placed one over the other, but were placed one behind the other, the two serving as a foundation upon which the Soma was pressed by a stone. This theory seems to account best for the etymological sense of the name ‘over-press,’ as well as for the use of the word as an adjective (‘used for pressing ''upon''’). But according to the procedure as witnessed by Haug<ref name=fx5_ve1_58> See Haug, [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 2, p. 488, n. 10.</ref> in the Deccan, the shoots of the plant are first placed on the skin, one of the boards being then laid over them and pounded with a stone. The shoots are then taken out and placed upon the board, the second board being then laid over them.

अधी¤-वास
<u>'''Adhī¤-vāsa.'''</u>--This word<ref name=fx1_ve1_59> Rv. i. 140, 9;<br> 162, 16;<br> x. 5, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 5, 22 (''pratimuñc,'' ‘put on’);<br> 4, 4, 3 (''ā-[[स्तृ|stṛ]],'' ‘spread out’), etc.</ref> denotes the ‘upper garment’ of the Vedic Indian. Its exact nature is not described, but as the king in the ritual set forth in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_59> v. 3, 5, 19 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 268.</ref> puts on first an undergarment, then a garment, and finally an upper garment, it presumably denotes some sort of cloak or mantle.

अध्याण्डा
<u>'''Adhyāṇḍā.'''</u>--This is a plant mentioned with many others in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 8, 1, 16). <br>==Foot Notes==

अध्रि-गु
<u>'''Adhri-gu.'''</u>--This is the name of a man twice referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_61> i. 112, 20;<br> viii. 12, 2. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 90.</ref> as a protégé of the Aśvins and of Indra respectively.

अध्वर्यु
<u>'''Adhvaryu.'''</u>--In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_62> iii. 7, 7.</ref> Hillebrandt<ref name=fx2_ve1_62> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 423.</ref> thinks that the five Adhvaryus who are mentioned do not designate actual priests, but refer to the five planets which move about in the heavens like the [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] priests on the sacrificial ground. See also '''[[ग्रह|Graha]].'''

अन्-अग्नि-दग्ध
<u>'''An-agni-dagdha,'''</u> ‘not burnt with fire.’ See '''[[अग्नि-दग्ध|Agni-dagdha]],''' ‘burnt with fire.’<br>==Foot Notes==

अनड्-वाह्
<u>'''Anaḍ-vāh'''</u> (lit. ‘cart-drawer’).--This is the common<ref name=fx1_ve1_64> Rv. x. 59, 10;<br> 85, 10;<br> iii. 53, 18;<br> Av. iii. 11, 5;<br> iv. 11, 1, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 14;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 4, 17, etc.</ref> name of oxen as employed for drawing carts ('''Anas'''). Such oxen were normally castrated,<ref name=fx2_ve1_64> ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 1, 5 (''anaḍvān sāṇḍaḥ'').</ref> though not always. Female draft cattle were also used (''anaḍuhī''), but rarely.<ref name=fx3_ve1_64> Av. iv. 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v, 3, 4, 11. 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 151, n.;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 226.</ref> See also '''Gō.'''

अनस्
<u>'''Anas.'''</u>--This is the term<ref name=fx1_ve1_65> Rv. iv. 30, 10;<br> x. 85, 10;<br> 86, 18, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 5, etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 15, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 8, etc.</ref> used to designate the draft wagon, as opposed to the chariot (''[[रथ|ratha]]'') for war or sport, with which it is sometimes expressly contrasted,<ref name=fx2_ve1_65> Rv. iii. 33, 9.</ref> though Indra is once said to be ‘seated in a wagon’ (''anar-[[विश्|viś]]'')<ref name=fx3_ve1_65> Rv. i. 121, 7.</ref> instead of on a chariot. Though Uṣas, Goddess of Dawn, sometimes rides on a chariot (''[[रथ|ratha]]''), the wagon is her characteristic vehicle.<ref name=fx4_ve1_65> Rv. ii. 15, 6;<br> iv. 30, 11;<br> viii. 91, 7;<br> x. 73, 6;<br> 138, 5.</ref> Of its construction we know little. The bridal wagon on which Sūryā, the daughter of the Sun, was borne in the marriage hymn in the Rigveda had a covering ('''[[छदिस्|Chadis]]''').<ref name=fx5_ve1_65> Rv. x. 85, 10.</ref> The axle-box ('''Kha''') is also  mentioned.<ref name=fx6_ve1_65> Rv. viii. 91, 7;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_65> xv. 2, 1.</ref> [[विपथ|Vipatha]] appears to denote a rough vehicle used for bad tracks. The wagon was usually drawn by oxen ('''[[अनड्वाह्|Anaḍvāh]]'''), as in wedding processions.<ref name=fx8_ve1_65> Rv. x. 85, 11</ref> The wagon of Dawn is described as drawn by ruddy cows or bulls.<ref name=fx9_ve1_65> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 47.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 246;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 4.</ref>

अनास्
<u>'''Anās.'''</u> See '''[[दस्यु|Dasyu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अनितभा
<u>'''Anitabhā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_67> v. 53. 9.</ref> is taken by Max Müller<ref name=fx2_ve1_67> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 323;<br> but ''of.'' '''[[रसा|Rasā]].'''</ref> to denote some river.

अनु
<u>'''Anu, Ānava.'''</u>--Grassmann and Roth<ref name=fx1_ve1_68> St. Petersburg Dictionary.</ref> see in these words designations of people foreign to the Aryans. But it is clear<ref name=fx2_ve1_68> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 125.</ref> that they denote a special people, the Anus, who are mentioned with the '''Yadus, Turvaśas, Druhyus,''' and '''Pūrus,'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_68> Rv. i. 108, 8.</ref> with the Druhyus,<ref name=fx4_ve1_68> Rv. vii. 18, 14.</ref> and with the Turvaśas, Yadus, and Druhyus.<ref name=fx5_ve1_68> viii. 10, 5.</ref> It is also a fair conclusion from their mention in a passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_68> Rv. viii. 74. 15, compared with vii. 18, 14.</ref> that they dwelt on the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]]. The inference that the Bhṛgus were connected with this tribe is much more doubtful,<ref name=fx7_ve1_68> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 221, n. 1.</ref> for it rests solely on the fact that in one place<ref name=fx8_ve1_68> Rv. vii. 18, 4.</ref> the Bhṛgus and Druhyus are mentioned together, and not Anus and Druhyus. [[आनव|Ānava]] is used as an epithet of Agni,<ref name=fx9_ve1_68> Rv. viii. 74, 4. ''Cf.'' Rv. v. 31, 4, where the Anus prepare the chariot of the Aśvins.</ref> but also in the sense of ‘Anu prince,’<ref name=fx10_ve1_68> Rv. vii. 18, 13.</ref> in one case in conjunction with [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]].<ref name=fx11_ve1_68> viii. 4, 1. Apparently as prince also in vi. 62, 9. ''Cf.'' '''[[कुरुङ्ग|Kuruṅga]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 205;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 153;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 154.</ref>

अनु-क्षत्तृ
<u>'''Anu-kṣattṛ.'''</u>--This word occurs in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha,<ref name=fx1_ve1_69> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> 73;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 9, 1.</ref> and means, according to Mahīdhara,<ref name=fx2_ve1_69> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> ‘an attendant on the door-keeper,’ and, according to Sāyaṇa, ‘an attendant on the charioteer’ (''[[सारथि|sārathi]]''). See also '''[[क्षत्तृ|Kṣattṛ]].'''(**  3) On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.'' 

अनु-चर
<u>'''Anu-cara.'''</u>--This is a general expression<ref name=fx1_ve1_70> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 7, 1.</ref> for an ‘attendant’ (the feminine being Anucarī),<ref name=fx2_ve1_70> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 27 (apparently slave girls are meant, 400 being enumerated).</ref> but it is not often used.

अनु-मति
<u>'''Anu-mati.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अनु-राधा
<u>'''Anu-rādhā.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अनु-वक्तृ सत्य सात्य-कीर्त
<u>'''Anu-vaktṛ Satya Sātya-kīrta'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 5, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

अनुव्या-ख्यान
<u>'''Anuvyā-khyāna'''</u> is a species of writing referred to in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_74> ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 2;<br> 5, 11.</ref> Śaṅkara interprets it as ‘explanation of the Mantras.’ As the term, in the plural, follows '''Sūtras,''' this interpretation is reasonable. Sieg,<ref name=fx2_ve1_74> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 34.</ref> however, equates the word with '''[[अन्वाख्यान|Anvākhyāna]],''' ‘supplementary narrative.’

अनु-शासन
<u>'''Anu-śāsana'''</u> in the plural denotes in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 5, 6, 8) some form of literature; according to Sāyaṇa, the Vedāṅgas.<br>==Foot Notes==

अनु-शिख
<u>'''Anu-śikha'''</u> is the name of the [[पोतृ|Potṛ]] at the snake festival in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_76> xxv. 15. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

अन्ते-वासिन्
<u>'''Ante-vāsin,'''</u> ‘dwelling near,’ is the epithet of the '''Brahmacārin''' who lives in the house of his teacher. The expression does not occur before the late [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period.<ref name=fx1_ve1_77> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 5, 17;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 7;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 11, 5;<br> iv. 10, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 3;<br> 11, 1.</ref> Secrecy is often enjoined on others than Antevāsins.<ref name=fx2_ve1_77> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 6;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, viii, 11.</ref>

अन्ध्र
<u>'''Andhra'''</u> is the name of a people, and is mentioned with the '''Puṇḍras, Śabaras, Pulindas,''' and '''Mūtibas,''' as being the outcasts resulting from the refusal of the fifty eldest sons of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' to accept his adoption of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_78> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 18;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 26, where instead of ''udāntyaḥ'' (‘beyond the borders’) the reading is ''udañcaḥ'' (‘northern’), but the former is obviously correct. The Sāṅkhāyana omits the Pulindas, and has Mūcīpas.</ref> It may fairly be deduced  from this statement that these people were recognized as nonAryan, as the Andhras certainly seem to have been.<ref name=fx2_ve1_78> Vincent Smith, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 657 ''et seq.,'' who places them originally in Eastern India between the Kṛṣṇā and Godāvarī rivers;<br> ''cf.'' Rapson, ''Catalogue of Indian Coins,'' xv., xvi.;<br> Bhandarkar, ''Bombay Gazetteer,'' 1. ii. 138.</ref>

अन्यतः-प्लक्षा
<u>'''Anyataḥ-plakṣā'''</u> (‘with wave-leafed fig-trees on one side only’) is the name of a lake in [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]] according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_79> xi. 5, 1, 4.</ref> where it occurs in the story of [[पुरूरवस्|Purūravas]] and Urvaśī. Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve1_79> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 217.</ref> places it somewhere in Sirmor.

अन्य-वाप
<u>'''Anya-vāpa'''</u> (‘sowing for others’).--The cuckoo is so called<ref name=fx1_ve1_80> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 37;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 18.</ref> from its habit of depositing its eggs in the nests of other birds

अन्वा-ख्यान
<u>'''Anvā-khyāna.'''</u>--From the literal translation (‘after-story’) the meaning of ‘supplementary narrative’ seems to follow. In two<ref name=fx1_ve1_81> vi. 5, 2, 22;<br> 6, 4, 7 (the reference is to vi. 6, 4, 8).</ref> of its three occurrences in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] this sense is hardly felt, the expression being used to indicate a subsequent portion of the book itself. But in the third<ref name=fx2_ve1_81> xi. 1, 6, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 34.</ref> passage it is distinguished from the '''[[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]''' (‘story’) proper, and there must mean ‘supplementary narrative.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[अनुव्याख्यान|Anuvyākhyāna]].'''

अप-चित्
<u>'''Apa-cit.'''</u>--This word occurs several times in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_82> vi. 25, 1;<br> 83, 1;<br> vii. 75, 1;<br> 77, 1.</ref> It is held by Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_82> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve1_82> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97. So also Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda,  342, 500.</ref> and others to denote an insect whose sting produced swellings, etc. (''glau''). But Bloomfield<ref name=fx4_ve1_82> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 320 ''et seq.;<br> Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 503, 504. ''Cf.'' Jolly, ''Medicin,'' 89;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 343.</ref> shows that the disease, scrofulous swellings, is what is really meant, as is shown by the rendering (''gaṇḍa-mālā,'' ‘inflammation of the glands of the neck’) of Keśava and Sāyaṇa, and by the parallelism of the later disease, ''apacī,'' the derivation being from ''apa'' and ''ci,'' ‘to pick off.’ 

अप-श्रय
<u>'''Apa-śraya.'''</u> See '''Upaśraya.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अप-स्कम्भ
<u>'''Apa-skambha.'''</u>--The word occurs only in one passage of the Atharvaveda, where the tip of it is mentioned as poisoned. Roth<ref name=fx1_ve1_84> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' The passage is Av. iv. 6, 4.</ref> suggests that the fastening of the arrow-point to the shaft is meant. Whitney<ref name=fx2_ve1_84> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 153.</ref> inclines to this version, but suggests corruption of text. Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_84> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 300.</ref> follows Roth. Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve1_84> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 512.</ref> renders the word by ‘barb.’ Bloomfield<ref name=fx5_ve1_84> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 375.</ref> thinks it means ‘tearing (arrow),’ a sense deduced from the etymology.

अपाच्यस्
<u>'''Apācyas.'''</u>--The kings of the ‘Westerners’ are referred to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 14) in connection with those of the '''Nīcyas.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अपान
<u>'''Apāna.'''</u>--The word appears repeatedly in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_86> Av. ii. 28, 3;<br> v. 30, 12, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 19;<br> 24, etc.</ref> and later as one of the vital breaths ('''[[प्राण|Prāṇa]]'''), usually with [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], and often with one or more of the other three. Its original sense<ref name=fx2_ve1_86> See Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' lv. 261;<br> 56, 556-558, correcting Ewing, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 22, 249 ''et seq.''</ref> appears to have been ‘inspiration.’ Its connection with the lower part of the body (''[[नाभि|nābhi]],'' ‘navel’), which is found already in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_86> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 263 ''et seq.''</ref> is not unnatural.

अपा-मार्ग
<u>'''Apā-mārga.'''</u>--A plant (''Achyranthes aspera'') used frequently<ref name=fx1_ve1_87> Atharvaveda, iv. 17, 6;<br> 18, 7;<br> 19, 4;<br> vii. 65, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxv. 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 1, 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 14;<br> xiii. 8, 4, 4.</ref> in witchcraft practices, and for medical purposes, especially against '''[[क्षेत्रिय|Kṣetriya]].''' It is described in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_87> iv. 17, 2.</ref> as ‘revertive’ (''[[पुनः-सर|punaḥ-sara]]''), either, as Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_87> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_87> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 67.</ref> think, because of its having reverted leaves (a view also accepted by Whitney<ref name=fx5_ve1_87> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 180.</ref> ),  or because, as Bloomfield<ref name=fx6_ve1_87> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 394. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 160, 161;<br> Weber ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 94.</ref> holds, it wards off a spell by causing it to recoil on its user.

अप-लम्ब
<u>'''Apa-lamba.'''</u>--By this word<ref name=fx1_ve1_88> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 13. ''Cf.'' Caland and Henry, ''L'Agniṣṭoma,'' 50;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 79.</ref> is denoted a brake or drag, let down (from ''lamb,'' ‘hang down’) to check the speed of a wagon.

अपाष्ठ
<u>'''Apāṣṭha.'''</u>--This word occurs twice in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_89> iv. 6, 5;<br> v. 18, 7 (''śatāpāṣṭha,'' ‘huṅdred-barbed’). ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 300;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 375.</ref> denoting the barb of an arrow.

अपि-शर्वर
<u>'''Api-śarvara.'''</u> See '''Anan.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अपी
<u>'''Apī.'''</u>--Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve1_91> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158, 159.</ref> finds an [[अपी|Apī]] whose sons are described as not performing sacrifice (''a-yajña-sāc'') and as breakers of the law of [[मित्र|Mitra]]-Varuṇa in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_91> vi. 67, 9.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_91> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v., apya.''</ref> and Grassmann take the expression used (''apyaḥ putrāḥ'') as referring to the sons of the waters.

अपूप
<u>'''Apūpa'''</u> is the general word from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_92> iii. 52, 7.</ref> onwards for a cake, which might be mixed with ghee (''ghṛtavant''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_92> Rv. x. 45, 9.</ref> or be made of rice (''[[व्रीहि|vrīhi]]''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_92> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 3, 12, 13.</ref> or of barley (''yava'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_92> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 5, 19.</ref> In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_92> iii. 1, 1.</ref> there is a difference of interpretation. Max Müller renders it as ‘hive,’ Bo7htlingk as ‘honeycomb,’ Little<ref name=fx6_ve1_92> ''Grammatical Index, s.v.''</ref> as ‘cake.’

अप्नवान
<u>'''Apnavāna'''</u> appears only twice in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_93> iv. 7, 1;<br> viii. 91, 4.</ref> as an ancient sage, coupled with the Bhṛgus, to whose family Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_93> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 128.</ref> conjectures him to have belonged. 

अ-प्रति-रथ
<u>'''A-prati-ratha'''</u> (‘he who has no match in fight’) is the name of an obviously invented [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], to whom is ascribed by the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_94> viii. 10.</ref> and Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_94> ix. 2, 3, 1. 5.</ref> the composition of a Rigveda hymn<ref name=fx3_ve1_94> x. 103.</ref> celebrating Indra as the invincible warrior.

अप्वा
<u>'''Apvā.'''</u>--A disease affecting the stomach,<ref name=fx1_ve1_95> Av. ix. 8, 9.</ref> possibly dysentery, as suggested by Zimmer,<ref name=fx2_ve1_95> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 389.</ref> on the ground that the disease is invoked to confound the enemy.<ref name=fx3_ve1_95> Rv. x. 103, 12 = Av. iii. 2, 5 = [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], ii. 1211 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 44.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx4_ve1_95> ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 482;<br> 17, 184.</ref> considers that it is diarrhœa induced by fear, as often in the Epic.<ref name=fx5_ve1_95> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 184.</ref> This view is supported by Bloomfield,<ref name=fx6_ve1_95> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 327.</ref> and was apparently that of [[यास्क|Yāska]].<ref name=fx7_ve1_95> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 33.<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 86, 87.</ref>

अप्सस्
<u>'''Apsas.'''</u>--This word usually refers to the body, meaning ‘front part.’<ref name=fx1_ve1_96> See Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 308-313;<br> 2, 245, 246.</ref> In one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_96> i. 122, 15. ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> however, the adjective ‘with a long front part’ (''[[दीर्घाप्सस्|dīrghāpsas]]'') is applied to the chariot ('''[[रथ|Ratha]]''').

अभि-क्रोशक
<u>'''Abhi-krośaka'''</u> designates one of the victims in the Puruṣamedha, meaning, perhaps, ‘herald.’ The commentator Mahīdhara<ref name=fx1_ve1_97> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 20. ''Cf.'' Anukrośaka, [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 15, 1.</ref> renders it as ‘reviler’ (''nindaka'').

अभि-जित्
<u>'''Abhi-jit.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अभि-पित्व
<u>'''Abhi-pitva.'''</u> See '''Ahan.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अभि-प्रतारिन् काक्ष-सेनि
<u>'''Abhi-pratārin Kākṣa-seni'''</u> is mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_100> i. 59, 1;<br> iii. 1, 21;<br> 2, 2. 13.</ref> the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_100> iv. 3, 5.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_100> x. 5, 7;<br> xiv. 1, 12. 15.</ref> as engaged in discussions on philosophy. The Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_100> iii. 156 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 61).</ref> further reports that his sons divided the property amongst themselves while he was yet alive. He was a Kuru and a prince. 

अभि-प्रश्निन्
<u>'''Abhi-praśnin.'''</u>--This term occurs after '''Praśnin,''' and followed by '''Praśnavivāka''' in the list of victims for the Puruṣamedha given in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_101> iii. 4, 6, 1.</ref> and the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_101> xxx. 10.</ref> The commentators, Sāyaṇa and Mahīdhara, see in it merely a reference to an inquisitive man. But there can be little doubt that the term must have had a legal reference of some sort-perhaps indicating the defendant as opposed to plaintiff and judge.

अभि-श्री
<u>'''Abhi-śrī'''</u> (‘admixture’).--This word<ref name=fx1_ve1_102> Rv. ix. 79, 5;<br> 86, 27. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 227;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' i. 211.</ref> designates the milk used to mingle with the Soma juice before it was offered.

अभि-षवणी
<u>'''Abhi-ṣavaṇī.'''</u>--Zimmer<ref name=fx1_ve1_103> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 277.</ref> renders the expression in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_103> ix. 6, 16.</ref> as a pressing instrument, but it appears to be merely an adjective, (waters) ‘used in pressing.’<ref name=fx3_ve1_103> ''Cf.'' Whitney's Translation of Av. ix. 6, 16.</ref>

अभि-षेक
<u>'''Abhi-ṣeka'''</u> (‘besprinkling’).--The Vedic king was consecrated after his election with an elaborate ritual, which is fully described in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_104> i. 7, 5.</ref> Pañcaviṃśa,<ref name=fx2_ve1_104> xviii. 8 ''et seq.''</ref> Śatapatha,<ref name=fx3_ve1_104> v. 3, 3 ''et seq.''</ref> and [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx4_ve1_104> viii. 5 ''et seq.''</ref> and for which the Mantras are given in the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx5_ve1_104> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 11;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 1-4.</ref> The consecration took place by sprinkling with water (''abhiṣecanīyā āpaḥ'').<ref name=fx6_ve1_104> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 5, 10-15,</ref> Only kings could be consecrated, the people not being worthy of it (''anabhiṣecanīyāḥ'').<ref name=fx7_ve1_104> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 17.</ref> The sprinkler (''abhiṣektṛ'') is mentioned in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha.<ref name=fx8_ve1_104> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 8, 1.</ref> The [[अभिषेक|Abhiṣeka]] is an essential part of the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],''' or sacrifice of royal inauguration, being the second of its component members.(**  9 ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 143-147; Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, xxvi; Weber, ''Über den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]].'' 

अभीशु
<u>'''Abhīśu'''</u> is a common Vedic word<ref name=fx1_ve1_105> Rv. i. 38, 12;<br> v. 44, 4;<br> vi. 75, 6;<br> viii. 33, 11;<br> Av. vi. 137, 2;<br> viii. 8, 22;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 3, 14 (where it = ''raśmayaḥ,'' ‘reins’), etc.</ref> denoting the ‘reins’ or ‘bridle’ of the chariot horses. The use of the plural is due to the fact that two or four horses, possibly five (''daśābhīśu'' ‘tenbridled’),<ref name=fx2_ve1_105> Rv. x. 94, 7.</ref> were yoked to the car.

अभ्य्-अग्नि ऐतशायन
<u>'''Abhy-agni Aitaśāyana.'''</u>--This man was, according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_106> vi. 33.</ref> unfortunate enough to quarrel with his father, '''[[ऐतश|Aitaśa]].''' The result was that he and his progeny were called the worst of the '''Aurvas.''' In the version of the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_106> xxx. 5. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 173.</ref> the '''Aitaśāyana Ājāneyas''' take the place of the Abhyagnis and the '''Bhṛgus''' of the '''Aurvas,''' the latter being probably a branch of the former family.

अभ्या-वर्तिन् चायमान
