<u>'''Abhyā-vartin Cāyamāna'''</u> appears in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_107> vi. 27, 8. 5.</ref> and as conqueror of the Vṛcīvants under the leader '''[[वरशिख|Varaśikha]].''' It is probable though not absolutely certain, that he is identical with the '''[[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]] [[दैववात|Daivavāta]],''' mentioned in the same hymn<ref name=fx2_ve1_107> vi. 27, 7.</ref> as having the '''Turvaśas''' and '''Vṛcīvants''' defeated for him by Indra. In this case he would be prince (''[[सम्राज्|samrāj]]'') of the Sṛñjayas. [[दैववात|Daivavāta]] is mentioned elsewhere<ref name=fx3_ve1_107> iv. 15, 4.</ref> as a worshipper of Agni.<br><br>Abhyāvartin is also referred to as a [[पार्थव|Pārthava]]. Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve1_107> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 198 ''et seq.''</ref> and Hillebrandt<ref name=fx5_ve1_107> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105;<br> 3, 268, n. 1. ''Cf.'' Grierson, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 604 ''et seq.''</ref> maintained that he is thus a Parthian, the latter using the evidence of the two places mentioned in the description<ref name=fx6_ve1_107> Rv. vi. 27, 5. 6.</ref> of Daivavāta's victories, '''[[हरियूपीया|Hariyūpīyā]]''' and '''[[यव्यावती|Yavyāvatī]],''' as proofs for the western position of Abhyāvartin's people in Arachosia, in Iran. But Zimmer<ref name=fx7_ve1_107> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 133 ''et seq.,'' 433;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 362.</ref> is probably right in holding that the name [[पार्थव|Pārthava]] merely means ‘a descendant of [[पृथु|Pṛthu]],’ and that its similarity to the Iranian Parthians is only on a par with the numerous other points of identity between the Indian and Iranian cultures. 

अ-भ्रातरः
<u>'''A-bhrātaraḥ'''</u> (‘brotherless’).--The lot of girls without brothers is referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_108> i. 124, 7;<br> iv. 5, 5. ''Cf.'' Av. i. 17, 1.</ref> as unsatisfactory--apparently they became prostitutes. The [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_108> iii. 5 (''abhrātrī'').<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 259;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 328.</ref> expressly forbids marriage with a brotherless maiden, probably because of the risk of her being made a ''[[पुत्रिका|putrikā]]'' (‘adoptive daughter’) by her father--that is, any son of hers being counted as belonging to her father's, instead of to her husband's, family. See '''[[अयोगू|Ayogū]].'''

अभ्रि
<u>'''Abhri'''</u> (‘spade’) is a Vedic word<ref name=fx1_ve1_109> Av. iv. 7, 5. 6 (''[[अभ्रि|abhri]]-khāte'' is ‘dug out with a spade,’ not ‘prepared ground’ with Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'');<br> x. 4, 14;<br> ''hiraṇyayībhir abhribhiḥ,'' ‘with golden spades’);<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 22;<br> xi. 10;<br> xxxvii. 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 2, 15, etc.</ref> of frequent occurrence. Various possible materials and forms are enumerated in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_109> vi. 3, 1, 30 ''et seq.''</ref> It may be made of bamboo or of the wood of [[विकङ्कत|Vikaṅkata]] or [[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]]. It may be a span or a cubit in size. It is hollow, and either one or both edges are sharp. From this it would appear that the handle was made of some wood, but the head of some metal.

अमत्र
<u>'''Amatra'''</u> was a vessel into which the Soma, after being pressed, was poured,<ref name=fx1_ve1_110> Rv. ii. 14, 1;<br> v. 51, 4;<br> vi. 42, 2, etc.</ref> and out of which the libation to the god was made.<ref name=fx2_ve1_110> Rv. x. 29, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 278;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]] Noten,'' 1, 61.</ref>

अमला
<u>'''Amalā.'''</u>--This plant<ref name=fx1_ve1_111> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 38, 6.</ref> is probably the ''Emblica officinalis,'' or Myrobalan tree; also called '''[[आमलक|Āmalaka]],''' or '''Āmalakā.'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_111> The reading in Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 3, 1, is ''vāmalake,'' which may give ''a¤°'' or ''ā°.''</ref>

अमा-जुर्
<u>'''Amā-jur'''</u> is an epithet<ref name=fx1_ve1_112> Rv. ii. 17, 7;<br> viii. 21, 15;<br> x. 37, 3.</ref> denoting maidens ‘who grow old at home’ without finding husbands, or, as they are elsewhere called, ‘who sit with their father’ (''[[पितृ|pitṛ]]-ṣad''). A well-known example of such was [[घोषा|Ghoṣā]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_112> Rv. i. 117, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 305.</ref> 

अमा-वास्य शाण्दिल्यायन
<u>'''Amā-vāsya Śāṇdilyāyana'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_113> ''Indische Studien,'' iv. 373.</ref> as the teacher of '''[[अंशु|Aṃśu]] [[धानंजय्य|Dhānaṃjayya]].'''

अमित्र-तपन शुष्मिण शैब्य
<u>'''Amitra-tapana Śuṣmiṇa Śaibya'''</u> is the name of him who killed '''[[अत्य्अराति जानंतपि|Atyarāti Jānaṃtapi]],''' according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 23).<br>==Foot Notes==

अ-मूला
<u>'''A-mūlā'''</u> (‘without root’) is the name in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_115> v. 314. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 286;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 279, accepts ‘rootless (plant).’</ref> of a plant (''Methonica superba''), which was used for poisoning arrows. Bloomfield,<ref name=fx2_ve1_115> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 457.</ref> however, renders it as ‘movable property.’

अम्बरीष
<u>'''Ambarīṣa'''</u> is mentioned as a [[वार्षागिर|Vārṣāgira]] in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_116> i. 100, 17. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 140.</ref> along with '''[[ऋज्राश्व|Ṛjrāśva]], [[सहदेव|Sahadeva]], [[सुराधस्|Surādhas]],''' and '''[[भयमान|Bhayamāna]].'''

अम्बष्ठ
<u>'''Ambaṣṭha.'''</u> See '''[[आम्बष्ठ्य|Āmbaṣṭhya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अय
<u>'''Aya.'''</u> See '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अयस्
<u>'''Ayas.'''</u>--The exact metal denoted by this word when used by itself, as always in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_119> Rv. i. 57, 3;<br> 163, 9;<br> iv. 2, 17;<br> vi. 3, 5.</ref> is uncertain. As favouring the sense of ‘bronze’ rather than that of ‘iron’ may perhaps be cited with Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_119> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 52.</ref> the fact that Agni is called ''ayo-[[दंष्ट्र|daṃṣṭra]],'' ‘with teeth of Ayas,’<ref name=fx3_ve1_119> Rv. i. 88, 5;<br> x. 87, 2.</ref> with reference to the colour of his flames, and that the car-seat of [[मित्र|Mitra]] and Varuṇa is called ''ayaḥ-sthūṇa,''<ref name=fx4_ve1_119> Rv. v. 62, 8 (''cf.'' 7).</ref> ‘with pillars of Ayas’ at the setting of the sun.<ref name=fx5_ve1_119> But this is not convincing, as in the same verse it is said to be ‘of golden appearance at the flush of dawn.’</ref> Moreover, in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx6_ve1_119> xviii. 13.</ref> Ayas is enumerated in a list of six metals: gold (''[[हिरण्य|hiraṇya]]''), Ayas, [[श्याम|Śyāma]], Loha, lead (''[[सीस|sīsa]]''), tin (''[[त्रपु|trapu]]''). Here ''[[श्याम|śyāma]]'' (‘swarthy’) and ''loha'' (‘red’) must mean ‘iron’ and ‘copper’ respectively; ''ayas'' would therefore seem to mean ‘bronze.’ In many passages in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_119> xi. 3, 1. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 9.</ref> and  other books, the Ayas is divided into two species--the ''[[श्याम|śyāma]]'' (‘iron’) and the ''[[लोहित|lohita]]'' (‘copper’ or ‘bronze’). In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_119> v. 4, 1, 2.</ref> a distinction is drawn between Ayas and ''[[लोहायस|lohāyasa]],'' which may either be a distinction between iron and copper as understood by Eggeling,<ref name=fx9_ve1_119> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 90</ref> or between copper and bronze as held by Schrader.<ref name=fx10_ve1_119> ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 189.</ref> In one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx11_ve1_119> v. 28, 1.</ref> the sense of iron seems certain. Possibly, too, the arrow of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx12_ve1_119> vi. 75, 15.</ref> which had a tip of Ayas (''yasyā ayo mukham''), was pointed with iron. Copper, however, is conceivable, and bronze quite likely.<br><br>Iron is called ''[[श्याम|śyāma]] ayas'' or ''[[श्याम|śyāma]]'' alone.<ref name=fx13_ve1_119> Av. ix. 5, 4.</ref> See also '''[[कार्ष्णायस|Kārṣṇāyasa]].''' Copper is '''[[लोहायस|Lohāyasa]]''' or '''[[लोहितायस|Lohitāyasa]].'''<br><br>The smelting (''dhmā'' ‘to blow’) of the metal is frequently referred to. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx14_ve1_119> vi. 1, 3, 5. ''Cf.'' vi. 1, 1, 13;<br> v. 1, 2, 14;<br> xii. 7, 1, 7;<br> 2, 10, etc.</ref> states that if ‘well smelted’ (''bahu-dhmātam'') it is like gold, referring evidently to bronze. A heater of Ayas is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx15_ve1_119> xxx. 14;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 10, 1.</ref> and bowls of Ayas are also spoken of.<ref name=fx16_ve1_119> Av. viii. 10, 22;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 13.</ref>

अय-स्थूण
<u>'''Aya-sthūṇa.'''</u>--He was Gṛhapati (‘householder,’ the sacrificer at sacrificial sessions) of those whose [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] was Śaulvāyana, and taught the latter the proper mode of using certain spoons.<ref name=fx1_ve1_120> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 4, 2, 17 ''et seq.''</ref>

अयास्य आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Ayāsya Āṅgirasa.'''</u>--This sage appears to be mentioned in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_121> x. 67, 1;<br> 108, 8. Perhaps x. 92. 15 also refers to him, but not i. 62, 7;<br> x. 138, 4.</ref> and the Anukramaṇī ascribes to him several hymns of the Rigveda (ix. 44-46; x. 67; 68). In the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] tradition he was Udgātṛ at the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] or Royal Inauguration Sacrifice, at which [[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]] was to have been slain, and his Udgītha ([[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]] chant) is referred to elsewhere.<ref name=fx3_ve1_121> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 2. 6;<br> 8, 3. ''Cf.'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, 12.</ref> He is also referred to several times as a ritual(**  2) [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 16.  authority.<ref name=fx4_ve1_121> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 3, 22;<br> xvi. 12, 4;<br> xi. 8, 10;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 8. 19. 24;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 6.</ref> In the Vaṃśas, or Genealogies of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_121> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 (in both recensions).<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 136;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 159;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 255, n.;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 204.</ref> he is named as the pupil of Ābhūti [[त्वाष्ट्र|Tvāṣṭra]].

अयोगू
<u>'''Ayogū'''</u> is a word of quite doubtful meaning, found in the list of victims in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_122> xxx. 5;<br> Taithrīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 1.</ref> It may, like the late ''[[आयोगव|āyogava]],'' denote a member of a mixed caste (theoretically a descendant of a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] by a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] wife).<ref name=fx2_ve1_122> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_122> ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 76, n. b. In the ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 18, 277, he thought it referred to dicing (''ayas''). Risley, ''Peoples of India,'' 250, regards the Āyogavas as a functional caste of carpenters (''cf.'' Manu, x. 48).</ref> rendered it as ‘unchaste woman.’<ref name=fx4_ve1_122> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 328.</ref> Zimmer thinks it denotes a brotherless maiden who is exposed to the dangers of prostitution (''cf. [[आयोगव|āyogava]]'').

अर
<u>'''Ara.'''</u> See '''[[रथ|Ratha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अरटु
<u>'''Araṭu.'''</u>--A plant<ref name=fx1_ve1_124> Av. xx. 131, 17.</ref> (''Colosanthes Indica'') from the wood of which the axle of a chariot was sometimes made.<ref name=fx2_ve1_124> Rv. viii. 46, 27.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62, 247.</ref>

अरण्य
<u>'''Araṇya.'''</u>--This term denotes the uncultivated land--not necessarily forest land--beyond the village. It is contrasted with home (''amā''),<ref name=fx1_ve1_125> Rv. vi. 24, 10.</ref> and with the plough land (''[[कृषि|kṛṣi]]''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_125> Av. ii. 4, 5.</ref> being spoken of as apart (''tiras'') from men.<ref name=fx3_ve1_125> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 6, 2, 20.</ref> It is also contrasted with the '''[[ग्राम|Grāma]],'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_125> Av. xii. 1, 56;<br> Rv. i. 163, 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45;<br> xx. 17.</ref> and it is the place where thieves live.<ref name=fx5_ve1_125> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 3, 5;<br> xiii. 2, 4, 4.</ref> The character of the forest is described in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_125> x. 146.</ref> to the forest spirit (Araṇyānī). The dead are carried there for burial,<ref name=fx7_ve1_125> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11.</ref> and hermits live there.<ref name=fx8_ve1_125> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 5, 3.</ref> Forest fires were common.<ref name=fx9_ve1_125> Rv. i. 65, 4;<br> 94, 10. 11;<br> ii. 14, 2;<br> x. 92, 1;<br> 142, 4;<br> Av. vii. 50, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 48, 142.</ref> 

अरत्नि
<u>'''Aratni.'''</u>--This word, which primarily means ‘elbow,’ occurs frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_126> Rv. viii. 80, 8;<br> Av. xix. 57, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 1, 33, etc. For Rv. viii. 80, 8, see also [[आजि|Āji]].</ref> onwards as denoting a measure of length (‘ell’ or ‘cubit’), the distance from the elbow to the tip of the hand. The exact length nowhere appears from the early texts.

अ-राजानः
<u>'''A-rājānaḥ,'''</u> ‘not princes,’ is a term used to describe persons in two passages of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_127> iii. 4, 1, 7. 8;<br> xiii. 4, 2, 17.</ref> and in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_127> viii. 23.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_127> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 199.</ref> also finds them mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_127> iii. 5, 7, where he emends ''rājānaḥ'' to ''[[अ-राजानः|a-rājānaḥ]]'' (see Whitney's note on the passage). ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveḍa,'' 333;<br> Weber, ''Über den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],'' 22 ''et seq.''</ref> and thinks that they--'''Sūtas''' (‘charioteers’) and '''Grāmaṇīs''' (‘troop-leaders’) there referred to--were called thus because, while not themselves princes, they assisted in the consecration of princes.

अराटकी
<u>'''Arāṭakī'''</u> is a plant mentioned once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_128> iv. 37, 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 68;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 408.</ref> and apparently identical with the '''[[अजशृङ्गी|Ajaśṛṅgī]].''' ''Cf.'' also '''[[अरटु|Araṭu]].'''

अराड दात्रेय शौनक
<u>'''Arāḍa [[दात्रेय|Dātreya]] Śaunaka.'''</u>--He is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_129> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 384.</ref> as the pupil of '''[[दृति ऐन्द्रोत|Dṛti Aindrota]] [[शौनक|Śaunaka]].'''

अरित्र
<u>'''Aritra'''</u> denotes the ‘oar’ by which boats were propelled. The Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_130> i. 116, 5.</ref> and the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_130> xxi. 7.</ref> speak of a vessel with a hundred oars, and a boat (''nau'') is said to be ‘propelled by oars’ (''[[अरित्र|aritra]]-paraṇa'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_130> Rv. x. 101, 2. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 5, 10.</ref> In two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_130> i. 46, 8;<br> ''daśāritra,'' ii. 18, 1.</ref> the term, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, denotes a part of a chariot. The rower of a boat is called ''aritṛ.''<ref name=fx5_ve1_130> Rv. ii. 42, 1;<br> ix. 95, 2. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 256.</ref> See '''Nau.''' 

अरिं-दम सन-श्रुत
<u>'''Ariṃ-dama Sana-śruta'''</u> is mentioned as a [[महाराज|Mahārāja]] in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 34.<br>==Foot Notes==

अरिम्-एजय
<u>'''Arim-ejaya'''</u> is mentioned as one who served as [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] at the snake feast celebrated in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_132> xxv. 15. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

अरुण आट
<u>'''Aruṇa Āṭa'''</u> was Achāvāka at the snake feast in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 15).<br>==Foot Notes==

अरुण औपवेशि गौतम
<u>'''Aruṇa [[औपवेशि|Aupaveśi]] Gautama'''</u> is the full style<ref name=fx1_ve1_134> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 9, 2;<br> 4, 5, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 10;<br> iii. 6, 4. 6;<br> 7, 4;<br> 8, 6;<br> 10, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvi. 10.</ref> of a teacher, who is repeatedly referred to in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve1_134> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 5, 11;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 2, 20;<br> xi. 4, 1, 4;<br> 5, 3, 2.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx3_ve1_134> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 5, 3 (in both recensions).</ref> and whose son was the famous '''[[उद्दालक आरुणि|Uddālaka Āruṇi]].''' He was a pupil of Upaveśa,<ref name=fx4_ve1_134> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 1, 2. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 146, n.^4</ref> and a contemporary of the prince '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]],''' by whom he was instructed. ''Cf.'' '''Āruṇa.'''

अरुन्धती
<u>'''1. Arundhatī'''</u> is the name of a plant celebrated in several passages of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_135> iv. 12, 1;<br> v. 5, 5. 9;<br> vi. 59, 1. 2;<br> viii. 7, 6;<br> xix. 38, 1.</ref> as possessing healing properties in case of wounds, as a febrifuge, and as inducing cows to give milk. The plant was a climber which attached itself to trees like the '''[[प्लक्ष|Plakṣa]], [[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]], [[न्यग्रोध|Nyagrodha]],''' and '''[[पर्ण|Parṇa]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_135> Av. v. 5, 5.</ref> It was of golden colour (''[[हिरण्य|hiraṇya]]-varṇā''), and had a hairy stem (''lomaśavakṣaṇā'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_135> Av. v. 5, 7;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 174;<br> Bloomfield, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 574.</ref> It was also called [[सिलाची|Silācī]], and the '''[[लाक्षा|Lākṣā]]''' appears to have been a product of it.<ref name=fx4_ve1_135> ''Cf.'' Whitney's note on Av. iv. 12;<br> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 61.</ref>

अरुन्धती
<u>'''2. Arundhatī,'''</u> as the name of a star, is often referred to in the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] literature, but only once in a late Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve1_136> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 9, 2.</ref> 

अर्क
<u>'''Arka,'''</u> as the name of the tree ''Colotropis gigantea,'' is perhaps found in one obscure passage of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_137> vi. 72, 1, where see Whitney's note. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

अर्गल
<u>'''Argala.'''</u>--The word which is usual later to denote the wooden pin of a door is found in the Śāṇkhāyana Āraṇyaka (ii. 16) in the compound ''argaleṣīke'' to denote the pin and bar of the door of a cow-pen. ''Cf.'' '''[[इषीका|Iṣīkā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अर्गल-काहोडि
<u>'''Argala-Kāhoḍi'''</u> is mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Samhitā (xxv. 7) as a teacher. The name may, however, be [[अर्यल|Aryala]], as suggested in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and as read by v. Schroeder in his edition. The Kapiṣṭhala (xxxix. 5) has Ayala. See below.<br>==Foot Notes==

अर्चन्त्
<u>'''Arcant'''</u> is possibly, as Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve1_140> Translation of the Ṛigveda, 3, 133.</ref> thinks, the name of the author of a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_140> x. 149, 5.</ref> ; but the word may be merely the ordinary participle ‘praising.’

अर्चनानस्
<u>'''Arcanānas.'''</u>--In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_141> v. 64, 7.</ref> the gods MitraVaruṇa are besought to protect [[अर्चनानस्|Arcanānas]]. He is also invoked with '''[[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]]''' and several other ancestors enumerated in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_141> xviii. 3, 15.</ref> He appears as father of [[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]] in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_141> viii. 5, 9.</ref> The later tradition makes him play a part in the legend of his son's wedding, which Sieg<ref name=fx4_ve1_141> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 50 ''et seq. Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 127;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 354.</ref> endeavours to show is known to the Rigveda.

अर्चा
<u>'''Arcā.'''</u> See '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अर्जुनी
<u>'''Arjunī'''</u> is, in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_143> x. 85, 13.</ref> the name of the '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]''' (‘lunar mansion’), elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve1_143> Av. xiv. 1, 13. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 11, 2.</ref> called [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]]. It occurs in the marriage hymn, with '''[[अघा|Aghā]]''' for '''[[मघा|Maghā]],''' and, like that word, is apparently a deliberate modification. 

अर्बुद
<u>'''Arbuda'''</u> is mentioned as Grāvastut priest at the snake festival described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_144> xxv. 15.</ref> He is obviously the same mythical figure as [[अर्बुद|Arbuda]] Kādraveya, a seer spoken of in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_144> vi. 1.</ref> and [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx3_ve1_144> xxix. 1. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 9.</ref> as a maker of Mantras.

अर्य
<u>'''Arya.'''</u>--This word is not common in the older literature, in places where the quantity of the first vowel is fixed as short, except in a mere adjectival sense. Geldner,<ref name=fx1_ve1_145> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 96.</ref> indeed, contends that no other sense is anywhere needed; but Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_145> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_145> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 214, 215.</ref> agree in thinking that in several passages of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_145> xiv. 30;<br> xx. 17;<br> xxiii. 21;<br> xxvi. 2. ''Cf.'' also [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 3. In Atharvaveda, xix. 32, 8, an analogous form occurs, as contrasted with ''[[ब्राह्मण|brāhmaṇa]], [[राजन्य|rājanya]],'' and ''[[शूद्र|śūdra]];<br>'' but even there Whitney renders it as ‘Āryan.’ ''Cf.'' xix. 62, 1;<br> Rv. viii. 94, 3;<br> Pischel, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 40, 125.</ref> the word has the same sense as '''[[आर्य|Ārya]],''' and this appears probable. Whether it is necessary to ascribe this sense to the word in the compound ''arya-[[पत्नी|patnī]]''<ref name=fx5_ve1_145> Rv. vii. 6, 5;<br> x. 43, 8.</ref> applied to the waters set free by Indra, is more doubtful. The commentator, Mahīdhara,<ref name=fx6_ve1_145> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 30.</ref> suggests that the word means a '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]],''' not an '''[[आर्य|Ārya]]''' generally. This view is supported by the explanation in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_145> xiii. 2, 9, 8. Contrast [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 4, 4 ''et seq.,'' where Arya appears to be taken in the wider sense.</ref> of one of the passages of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx8_ve1_145> xxiii. 30. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 212;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' x. 6;<br> Oldenberg, ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 126, 363.</ref> But though the use of Arya to denote a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] became common later, it is not clear that it was original.

अर्यम्णः पन्था
<u>'''Aryamṇaḥ Panthā,'''</u> ‘Aryaman's Way,’ an expression which occurs in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx1_ve1_146> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 6, 6;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 12, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 2.</ref> denotes, according to Weber,<ref name=fx2_ve1_146> ''Über den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],'' 48, 2.</ref> ‘the milky way,’ but, according to Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx3_ve1_146> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 79, 80.</ref> ‘the ecliptic.’ 

अर्यल
<u>'''Aryala.'''</u>--Those at whose snake feast the Gṛhapati was [[अर्यल|Aryala]], and the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] was '''[[आरुणि|Āruṇi]]''' are mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxiii. 1, 5). See also '''[[अर्गल|Argala]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अर्वन्त्
<u>'''Arvant.'''</u> See '''[[अश्व|Aśva]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अर्शस्
<u>'''Arśas'''</u> is the name of a disease mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_149> xii. 98.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 398;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> with consumption and other ailments. It appears to designate ‘hæmorrhoids,’ as in the later medical literature.

अलज
<u>'''Alaja'''</u> designates some kind of bird--one of the victims in the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_150> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 11, 1;<br> 5, 20, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 18;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 34.</ref> or Horse Sacrifice.

अलजि
<u>'''Alaji'''</u> is the name of a disease in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_151> ix. 8, 20. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 390;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> The later ''alajī'' denotes an eye-disease--a discharge at the junction of the cornea and the sclerotica.

अलम्म पारिजानत
<u>'''Alamma Pārijānata'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 4, 11; 10, 8) as a sage.<br>==Foot Notes==

अलसाला
<u>'''Alasālā.'''</u>--This word occurring only in one passage of the Atharvaveda (vi. 16, 4) is said to denote a grain-creeper.<br>==Foot Notes==

अलाण्डु
<u>'''Alāṇḍu.'''</u>--This is the reading in the text of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_154> ii. 31, 2.</ref> of the name of a species of worm. Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve1_154> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 315.</ref> shows reason to adopt the reading Algaṇḍu as the correct form of the word.

अलाबु
<u>'''Alābu.'''</u>--The bottle-gourd (''Lagenaria vulgaris''). Vessels made of it are referred to in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_155> viii. 10, 29. 30;<br> xx. 132, 1. 2. ''Cf. alāpu'' in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 13.</ref>

अलाय्य
<u>'''Alāyya'''</u> is a word occurring in an obscure verse of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_156> ix. 67, 20.</ref> and appearing to be a proper name. Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx2_ve1_156> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 418.</ref> however, amends the text so as to remove the name. The St. Petersburg Dictionary suggests that it refers to Indra. Pischel<ref name=fx3_ve1_156> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 701.</ref> holds that  it is the name of a person whose axe was stolen, and for whom the hymn was written as a spell for the recovery of the axe.

अलिक्लव
<u>'''Aliklava'''</u> is a kind of carrion bird mentioned in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_157> xi. 2, 2;<br> 9, 9. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 88.</ref>

अलिन
<u>'''Alina'''</u> is the name of a people mentioned once only in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_158> vii. 18, 7.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_158> ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 95;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 126.</ref> thought that the Alinas were allies--possibly a subdivision--of the '''Tṛtsus.''' Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve1_158> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 207.</ref> more probably thinks that they were defeated by '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' together with the '''Pakthas, [[भलानस्|Bhalānas]], Śivas,''' and '''Viṣāṇins,''' with whom they are mentioned, at the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]];''' and Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_158> ''Op. cit.,'' 431. The land is mentioned by Hiouen Thsang.</ref> suggests that they lived to the north-east of Kafiristan.

अलीकयु वाचस्-पत्य
<u>'''Alīkayu Vācas-patya'''</u> is twice mentioned as an authority in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxvi. 5; xxviii. 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

अल्प-शयु
<u>'''Alpa-śayu'''</u> is a kind of insect mentioned in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_160> iv. 36, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 408;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 210.</ref>

अवका
<u>'''Avakā'''</u> is an aquatic plant (''Blyxa octandra'') frequently referred to in the Atharvaveda as well as in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve1_161> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 1, 1;<br> v. 4, 2, 1;<br> 4, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 4;<br> xxv. 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 10, 1.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_161> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 1, 11;<br> viii. 3, 2, 5;<br> ix. 1, 2, 20. 22;<br> xiii. 8, 3, 13.</ref> The Gandharvas are said to eat it.<ref name=fx4_ve1_161> Av. iv. 37, 8.</ref> Its later name is ''śaivala,'' and it is identical with the '''[[शीपाल|Śīpāla]].'''(**  1) viii. 7, 9; 37, 8-10.(**  5) With which it is glossed in Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 8; iv. 4. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' October, 1890, xli.-xliii.; ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 349; Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.

अवत
<u>'''Avata,'''</u> a word occurring several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_162> i. 55, 8;<br> 85, 10. 11;<br> 116, 9, 22;<br> 130, 2;<br> iv. 17, 16;<br> 50, 3;<br> viii. 49, 6;<br> 62, 6;<br> 72, 10, 12;<br> x. 25, 4;<br> 101, 5. 7. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 26.</ref> denotes a well, artificially made (''khan'' ‘to dig’) in contrast with a spring  (''utsa''), though the latter expression is also applied to an artificial well. Such wells were covered by the makers,<ref name=fx2_ve1_162> Rv. i. 55, 8.</ref> and are described as unfailing (''a-kṣita'') and full of water.<ref name=fx3_ve1_162> Rv. x. 101, 6, etc.</ref> The water was raised by a wheel (''[[चक्र|cakra]]'') of stone, to which was fastened a strap (''[[वरत्रा|varatrā]]''), with a pail (''[[कोश|kośa]]'')<ref name=fx4_ve1_162> ''Aṃsatra-kośam,'' Rv. x. 101, 7, is best thus rendered. For the stone wheel (''aśma-[[चक्र|cakra]]'') which was above (''uccācakra''), see Rv. x. 101, 7;<br> viii. 72, 10. For the ''[[वरत्रा|varatrā]],'' see Rv. x. 101, 6. Perhaps ''kū-[[चक्र|cakra]]'' in Rv. x. 102, 11, is another name for the wheel, but ''cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> attached to it. When raised it was poured (''siñc'') into buckets (''[[आहाव|āhāva]]'') of wood.<ref name=fx5_ve1_162> Rv. x. 101, 6. 7.</ref> Sometimes those wells appear to have been used for irrigation purposes, the water being led off into broad channels (''sārmī suṣirā'').<ref name=fx6_ve1_162> Rv. viii. 69, 12. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 156, 157;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 14.</ref>

अवत्सार
<u>'''Avatsāra'''</u> is mentioned as a seer in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_163> v. 44. 10.</ref> as a priest in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_163> ii. 24.</ref> and as [[प्रास्रवण|Prāsravaṇa]] (or [[प्राश्रवण|Prāśravaṇa]]), son of [[प्रस्रवण|Prasravaṇa]], in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_163> xiii. 3.</ref> A hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_163> ix. 58. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 188;<br> 2, 315;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 62, ''et seq.''</ref> is incorrectly ascribed to him in the Anukramaṇī.

अ-वध्यता
<u>'''A-vadhyatā.'''</u> See '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अवस
<u>'''Avasa'''</u> in the adjective ''an-[[अवस|avasa]]'' in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_165> vi. 66, 7. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 372.</ref> may mean ‘drag.’

अव-स्कव
<u>'''Ava-skava.'''</u>--A kind of worm, mentioned along with others in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_166> ii. 31, 4. ''Cf.'' Whitney, ''ad loc.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 201;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 90;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 316.</ref>

अवात
<u>'''Avāta.'''</u> See '''[[वात|Vāta]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अवि
<u>'''Avi.'''</u>--‘Sheep’ are repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda, and later, often in conjunction with goats (''aja''). The wolf (''[[वृक|vṛka]]'') was their great enemy,<ref name=fx1_ve1_168> Av. v. 8, 4;<br> Rv. viii. 34, 3;<br> 66, 8.</ref> and they were tended by shepherds.<ref name=fx2_ve1_168> ''Avi-pāla,'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 2;<br> ''avi-pa,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 9, 1.</ref>  Sheep as well as kine were captured from the enemy.<ref name=fx3_ve1_168> Rv. viii. 86, 2.</ref> The Soma sieve was made of sheep's wool, and is repeatedly referred to (''avi, meṣī, avya, avyaya'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_168> Rv. ix. 109, 16;<br> 36, 4, etc. See Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 203.</ref> Considerable herds must have existed, as [[ऋज्राश्व|Ṛjrāśva]] is said<ref name=fx5_ve1_168> Rv. i. 116, 17.</ref> to have slain one hundred rams, and in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’)<ref name=fx6_ve1_168> Rv. viii. 67, 3.</ref> a hundred sheep are mentioned as a gift. The (''[[मेष|meṣa]],''<ref name=fx7_ve1_168> Rv. i. 43, 6;<br> 116, 16, etc.</ref> ''vṛṣṇi''<ref name=fx8_ve1_168> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 7, 4, etc.</ref> ) ram was sometimes castrated (''[[पेत्व|petva]]'').<ref name=fx9_ve1_168> Rv. vii. 18, 17;<br> Av. iv. 4, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 22, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 58;<br> 59.</ref> The main use of sheep was their wool; hence the expression ‘woolly’ (''[[ऊर्णावती|ūrṇāvatī]]'')<ref name=fx10_ve1_168> Rv. viii. 67, 3. ''Cf.'' x. 75, 8;<br> so ''[[उरा|urā]],'' x. 95, 3.</ref> is employed to designate a sheep. In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx11_ve1_168> xiii. 50.</ref> the ram is described as ‘woolly,’ and as ‘the skin of beasts, quadruped and biped,’ with reference to the use of its wool as clothing for men and shelter for animals. Pūṣan is said<ref name=fx12_ve1_168> Rv. x. 26, 6.</ref> to weave raiment from the wool of sheep. Normally the sheep stayed out at pasture; in an obscure passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx13_ve1_168> x. 106, 5.</ref> reference appears to be made to rams in stall. [[गन्धार|Gandhāra]]<ref name=fx14_ve1_168> Rv. i. 126, 7.</ref> ewes were famous for their wool. Pischel<ref name=fx15_ve1_168> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 210.</ref> considers that the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]]'''<ref name=fx16_ve1_168> Rv. iv. 22, 2;<br> v. 52, 9.</ref> was named from its richness in sheep, ''[[परुस्|parus]]''<ref name=fx17_ve1_168> Rv. ix. 15, 6;<br> ''[[पर्वन्|parvan]],'' iv. 22, 2. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 229, 230;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 348.</ref> denoting the ‘flocks’ of wool.

अशनि
<u>'''Aśani.'''</u>--Zimmer<ref name=fx1_ve1_169> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 301.</ref> cites this word from the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_169> vi. 6, 5. ''Cf.'' 1, 121, 9.</ref> as denoting a sling stone, and compares a similar use of '''Adri.'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_169> i. 51, 3.</ref> In either case, however, the weapons are mythical, being used in descriptions of Indra's deeds. Schrader<ref name=fx4_ve1_169> ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 221.</ref> also cites ''aśan'' in this sense, but no Vedic passage requires this sense.

अश्म-गन्धा
<u>'''Aśma-gandhā'''</u> (‘rock-smell’) is a plant mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_170> xiii. 8, 1, 16, with Eggeling's note in the ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 427.</ref> probably identical with the late ''aśvagandhā,'' ‘horse-smell’ (''Physalis flexuosa''). 

अश्व
<u>'''Aśva'''</u> is the commonest word for ‘horse’ in the Vedic literature. The horse is also called ‘the runner’ (''atya''), ‘the swift’ (''[[अर्वन्त्|arvant]]''), ‘the strong,’ for pulling (''[[वाजिन्|vājin]]''), ‘the runner’ (''[[सप्ति|sapti]]''), and ‘the speeding’ (''haya''). The mare is termed ''aśvā, atyā, arvatī, vaḍavā,'' etc. Horses of various colour were known, dun (''[[हरित|harita]], hari''), ruddy (''aruṇa, aruṣa, [[पिशङ्ग|piśaṅga]], [[रोहित|rohita]]''), dark brown (''[[श्याव|śyāva]]''), white (''śveta''), etc. A white horse with black ears is mentioned in the Atharvaveda as of special value.<ref name=fx1_ve1_171> Av. v. 17, 15.</ref> Horses were highly prized,<ref name=fx2_ve1_171> Rv. i. 83, 1;<br> iv. 32, 17;<br> v. 4, 11;<br> viii. 78, 2, etc.</ref> and were not rare, as Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_171> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 686.</ref> thought, for as many as four hundred mares are mentioned in one Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’).<ref name=fx4_ve1_171> Rv. viii. 55, 3. ''Cf.'' v. 33, 8;<br> vi. 47, 22-24;<br> 63, 10;<br> viii. 6, 47;<br> 46, 22, and Hopkins, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 15, 157.</ref> They were on occasion ornamented with pearls and gold.<ref name=fx5_ve1_171> Rv. x. 68, 11.</ref><br><br>Mares were preferred for drawing chariots because of their swiftness and sureness.<ref name=fx6_ve1_171> Pischel, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 712714;<br> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 10, 305. ''Cf. ratho vadhūmān,'' Rv. i. 126, 3;<br> vii. 18, 22, ''vājinīvān,'' vii. 69, 1.</ref> They were also used for drawing carts, but were not ordinarily so employed.<ref name=fx7_ve1_171> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 35.</ref> No mention is made of riding in battle, but for other purposes it was not unknown.<ref name=fx8_ve1_171> The Aśvins ride, Rv. v. 61, 1-3. An ''[[अश्व|aśva]]-sāda'' is referred to in Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 7, 1;<br> and riding is meant in Rv. i. 162, 17;<br> 163, 9. Av. xi. 10, 24. is doubtful. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 262;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 221. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 230, denies the use;<br> but see p. 295, where it is admitted for ordinary purposes.</ref><br><br>Horses were often kept in stalls,<ref name=fx9_ve1_171> ''Cf.'' the epithet of richness, ‘filling the stalls with horses’ (''[[अश्व|aśva]]-pastya''), in Rv. ix. 86, 41, and see Av. vi. 77, 1;<br> xix. 55, 1.</ref> and fed there.<ref name=fx10_ve1_171> Av. ''loc. cit.''</ref> But they were also allowed to go out to grass,<ref name=fx11_ve1_171> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 232, denies this, but it is the natural sense of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 41.</ref> and were then hobbled.<ref name=fx12_ve1_171> The expression for this is ''[[पड्बीश|paḍbīśa]],'' Rv. i. 162, 14. 16;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 2, 13;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 1, 12;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, ix. 7. ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 234-236.</ref> They were watered to cool them after racing.<ref name=fx13_ve1_171> Rv. ii. 13, 5;<br> 34, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 11, 6;<br> Pischel, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 189, 190.</ref> Their attendants  are frequently referred to (''[[अश्व|aśva]]-pāla,''<ref name=fx14_ve1_171> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 4, 5.</ref> ''[[अश्व|aśva]]-pa,''<ref name=fx15_ve1_171> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 9, 1.</ref> ''[[अश्व-पति|aśva-pati]]'').<ref name=fx16_ve1_171> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 24;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13.</ref> Stallions were frequently castrated (''vadhri'').<ref name=fx17_ve1_171> Rv. viii. 46, 30.</ref><br><br>Besides reins (''raśmayaḥ''), reference is made to halters (''aśvābhidhānī''),<ref name=fx18_ve1_171> Av. iv. 36, 10;<br> v. 14, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 35;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 1, 26;<br> xiii. 1, 2, 1.</ref> and whips (''aśvājani'').<ref name=fx19_ve1_171> Rv. v. 62, 7;<br> vi. 75, 13;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 50.</ref> See also '''[[रथ|Ratha]].'''<br><br>Horses from the Indus were of special value,<ref name=fx20_ve1_171> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 2, 13;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, ix. 7;<br> ''vājinīvatī'' as epithet of [[सिन्धु|Sindhu]], Rv. x. 75, 8, of [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], i. 3, 10;<br> ii. 41, 18;<br> vi. 61, 3. 4;<br> vii. 96, 3;<br> Pischel, ''op. cit.,'' i. 10. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 230-232.</ref> as also horses from the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].'''

अश्व-तर
<u>'''Aśva-tara, [[अश्व|Aśva]]-tarī'''</u> are respectively the masculine and feminine name of ‘mule.’ These animals are mentioned frequently from the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_172> iv. 4, 8;<br> viii. 8, 22;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 47;<br> iv. 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 1, 10, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 4.</ref> onwards. They were known not to be fruitful,<ref name=fx2_ve1_172> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 2. 3. ''Cf.'' Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40.</ref> and were probably considered inferior to horses,<ref name=fx3_ve1_172> As were asses, [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 2, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 4, 4, 7.</ref> but a mule-car was quite common.<ref name=fx4_ve1_172> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2, 1 (in both passages ''aśvatarī-[[रथ|ratha]]''). ''Cf.'' Oertel, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 175.</ref>

अश्व-त्थ
<u>'''1. Aśva-ttha'''</u> (‘horse-stand’) is one of India's greatest trees, the ''Ficus religiosa,'' later called ''[[पिप्पल|pippala]]''<ref name=fx1_ve1_173> The word ''[[पिप्पल|pippala]]'' as a neuter occurs once in the Rv. (i. 164, 20) designating the berry of the Peepal-tree.</ref> (now Peepal). Vessels made of the wood of the [[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]] are mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_173> i. 135, 8;<br> x. 97, 5.</ref> and the tree itself is constantly referred to later.<ref name=fx3_ve1_173> Atharvaveda, iii. 6, 1;<br> iv. 37, 4, etc.</ref> Its hard wood formed the upper of the two pieces of wood used for kindling fire, the lower being of '''[[शमी|Śamī]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_173> Av. vi. 11, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 13.</ref> It planted its roots in shoots of other trees, especially the '''[[खदिर|Khadira]],''' and destroyed them;<ref name=fx5_ve1_173> Av. iii. 6.</ref> hence it is called ‘the destroyer’ (''vaibādha''). Its berries  are referred to as sweet, and as eaten by birds.<ref name=fx6_ve1_173> Rv. i. 164, 20. 22.</ref> The gods are said to sit under it in the third heaven.<ref name=fx7_ve1_173> Av. v. 4, 3. ''Cf.'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 5, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3.</ref> It and '''[[न्यग्रोध|Nyagrodha]]''' are styled the ‘crested ones’ (''śikhaṇḍin'').<ref name=fx8_ve1_173> Av. iv. 37, 4. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 57, 58.</ref>

अश्व-त्थ
<u>'''2. Aśva-ttha.'''</u>--This prince is celebrated in a Dānastuti<ref name=fx1_ve1_174> Rv. vi. 47, 24.</ref> as having given gifts to [[पायु|Pāyu]]. He is identified with '''Divodāsa''' by Griffith,<ref name=fx2_ve1_174> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 611. The name is spelt Aśvatha in the text, but that is merely the usual shortened spelling of the group ''tth.''</ref> but it is impossible to be certain of this identification.

अश्व-दावन्
<u>'''Aśva-dāvan.'''</u>--Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve1_175> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 274.</ref> finds a prince of this name in a passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_175> v. 18, 3.</ref> where a gift of fifty horses is mentioned, but the word appears to be an epithet of Indra (‘bestower of horses’).

अश्व-पति
<u>'''Aśva-pati'''</u> (‘lord of horses’) is a name of a prince of the '''Kekayas,''' who instructed '''Prācīnaśāla''' and other Brahmins.<ref name=fx1_ve1_176> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 4;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 1, 2.</ref>

अश्व-मेध
<u>'''Aśva-medha'''</u> (‘offering a horse-sacrifice’) is a prince mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_177> v. 27, 4-6. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 275.</ref> which contains a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) of '''Tryaruṇa,''' and to which three verses have been added in praise of [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]. See also '''Āśvamedha.'''

अश्व-युजौ
<u>'''Aśva-yujau.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अश्वल
<u>'''Aśvala,'''</u> the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest of '''[[जनक|Janaka]],''' King of '''[[विदेह|Videha]],''' appears as an authority in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 1, 2. 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

अश्व-वार
<u>'''Aśva-vāra, [[अश्व|Aśva]]-vāla'''</u> (‘hair of a horse's tail’).--The former form occurs in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_180> iii. 7, 9.</ref> the latter in the  [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_180> xxiv. 8.</ref> and Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitās<ref name=fx3_ve1_180> xxxviii. 1.</ref> and Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_180> iii. 4, 1, 7. ''Cf.'' Von Schroeder's edition of the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i., p. xv.</ref> denoting a species of reed (''Saccharum spontaneum'').

अश्व-सूक्ति
<u>'''Aśva-sūkti'''</u> is the name of a seer to whom the Rigveda Anukramaṇī ascribes two hymns of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_181> viii. 14;<br> 15.</ref> The [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_181> xix. 4, 10. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 230, n. 4.</ref> knows a Sāman of [[अश्वसूक्ति|Aśvasūkti]].

अश्विनी
<u>'''Aśvinī.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अषाढ कैशिन्
<u>'''Aṣāḍha Kaiśin'''</u> is the name of a man referred to in a corrupt and obscure passage of the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_183> xxvi. 9;<br> Kapiṣṭhala, xli. 7. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 471.</ref> as connected with the defeat of the '''Pañcālas''' by the '''Kuntis.'''

अषाढ उत्तर पाराशर्य
<u>'''Aṣāḍha Uttara Pārāśarya'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] or Genealogy in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

अषाढा
<u>'''Aṣāḍhā.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अषाढि सौश्रोमतेय
<u>'''Aṣāḍhi Sauśromateya'''</u> was a man who is stated in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vi. 2, 1, 37) to have died because the heads for the sacrifice in connection with the laying of the bricks of the fire-altar had been obtained in an improper manner.<br>==Foot Notes==

अष्टक
<u>'''Aṣṭaka'''</u> is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_187> vii. 17. Also in the Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 26.</ref> as one of the sons of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]].'''

अष्टका
<u>'''Aṣṭakā.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अष्ट-कर्णी
<u>'''Aṣṭa-karṇī'''</u> is an expression which occurs in one passage of the Ṛigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_189> x. 62, 7.</ref> and which Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_189> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> was at first inclined to interpret  as a proper name. There can, however, be no doubt that it means a cow, not a man, as suggested by Grassmann. The exact reason why a cow should be so described is uncertain. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_189> ''Cf.'' Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> was later inclined to see in it the sense ‘having pierced ears,’ similar epithets being at a later period known to Pāṇini<ref name=fx4_ve1_189> vi. 3, 115.</ref> (''bhinna-karṇa, chinna-karṇa''). Grassmann's more obvious rendering, ‘having the sign for (the number) 8 marked on the ear,’ is supported by the similar epithets, ‘having the mark of a lute on the ear’ (''[[कर्करि|karkari]]-karṇyaḥ''), ‘having the mark of a sickle on the ear’ (''[[दात्र|dātra]]-karṇyaḥ''), ‘having the mark of a stake on the ear’ (''sthūṇākarṇyaḥ''), ‘having the ears bored’ (''chidra-karṇyaḥ''), and ''viṣtyakarṇyaḥ,'' given in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx5_ve1_189> iv. 2, 9.</ref> The simple meaning, ‘with marked ears,’ is, however, supported by the same passage of the Maitrāyaṇī, where the verb ''akṣ'' occurs in the sense ‘to mark.’ In the Atharvaveda the mark used is the Mithuna, no doubt as a magical device to secure fertility.<br><br>The marking of ears was apparently a regular practice. It is twice referred to in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx6_ve1_189> vi. 141, 1. 2;<br> xii. 4, 6.</ref> The mark is termed ''[[लक्ष्मन्|lakṣman]],''<ref name=fx7_ve1_189> Av. vi. 141, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> and was made with a copper-knife<ref name=fx8_ve1_189> Av., ''loc. cit.''</ref> (''[[लोहित|lohita]]''). The Maitrayaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx9_ve1_189> ''Loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 234, 348;<br> Delbrück, ''Gurupūjākaumudī,'' 48, 49;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 466;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 387.</ref> forbids the use of an arrow-shaft (''[[तेजन|tejana]]''), or of iron, but permits that of a stem of sugar-cane (''[[इक्षु|ikṣu]]-kāṇḍa'') or copper.

अष्टा-दंष्ट्र वैरूप
<u>'''Aṣṭā-[[दंष्ट्र|daṃṣṭra]] Vairūpa.'''</u>--To him the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 9, 21) ascribes two Sāmans.<br>==Foot Notes==

अष्ट्रा
<u>'''Aṣṭrā'''</u> is the plougher's ‘goad,’ the badge of agriculture. It is mentioned several times in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_191> iv. 57, 4;<br> vi. 53, 9;<br> 58, 2;<br> ''[[अष्ट्रा|aṣṭrā]]-vin'' occurs in x. 102, 8. See also [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 80. ''Cf.'' Roscher, ''Archiv für Religionswissenschaft,'' 1, 63;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 364, n. 8.</ref>

असमाति राथ-प्रौष्ठ
<u>'''Asamāti Rātha-prauṣṭha.'''</u>--The story of the quarrel between Asamāti, the [[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]] prince of the [[रथप्रोष्ठ|Rathaproṣṭha]] family, and  his priests, the Gaupāyanas, is found only in the later Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_192> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 167 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 41 ''et seq.'');<br> Sāṭyāyanaka, cited in Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 57, 1;<br> 60, 7;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 83 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 12, 5.</ref> It appears to be based on a misreading of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_192> x. 60, 2. 5;<br> Av. vi. 79, 1. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 499;<br> Max Müller, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1866, 426-465;<br> Bo7htlingk's Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 48, n. 1.</ref> where ''asamāti'' is merely an adjective. The later story is that the king was induced to abandon his family priests by two Asuras, [[किरात|Kirāta]] and [[आकुलि|Ākuli]], who by their magic compassed the death of [[सुबन्धु|Subandhu]], one of the brother priests, and that the others revived him by the use of the hymns (Rigveda, x. 57-60).

असि
<u>'''Asi'''</u> usually denotes the sacrificial knife,<ref name=fx1_ve1_193> Rv. i. 162, 20;<br> x. 79, 6;<br> 18;<br> Av. ix. 3, 9;<br> x. 1, 20, etc.</ref> but occasionally appears to mean a knife used in war.<ref name=fx2_ve1_193> Av. xi. 9, 1. The use of the ‘sword’ increases in the Epic period. See Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 284.</ref> Mention is made of a sheath (''vavri'')<ref name=fx3_ve1_193> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4.</ref> to which a belt (''[[वाल|vāla]]'')<ref name=fx4_ve1_193> ''Ibid.;<br>'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5.</ref> was attached. The word ''asi-[[धारा|dhārā]]''<ref name=fx5_ve1_193> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 139.</ref> also denotes ‘sheath.’

असिक्नी
<u>'''Asiknī'''</u> (‘black’) is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_194> viii. 20, 25;<br> x. 75, 5;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 26. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 12.</ref> of the river known later as [[चन्द्र|Candra]]-bhāgā, and to the Greeks as Akesines, now the Chenab in the Punjab.

असित
<u>'''1. Asita'''</u> is a name of the ‘black snake,’ referred to in the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_195> Av. iii. 27, 1;<br> v. 13, 5. 6;<br> vi. 56, 2, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 10, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 18;<br> perhaps Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 37.</ref>

असित
<u>'''2. Asita.'''</u>--(''a'') A mythical sage of this name figures as a magician in the Atharvaveda in conjunction with '''Gaya'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_196> Av. i. 14, 4.</ref> or with '''[[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_196> Av. vi. 137, 1.</ref> In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_196> xiii. 4, 3, 11.</ref> he appears as  [[असित|Asita]] [[धान्व|Dhānva]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_196> Dhānvana in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2, 19.</ref> and as [[दैवल|Daivala]] or [[देवल|Devala]] in the Pañcaviṃsa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_196> xiv. 11, 18. 19, ''Cf.'' xv. 5, 27.</ref> and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx6_ve1_196> xxii. 11. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 132.</ref><br><br>(''b'') '''[[असित|Asita]] [[वार्ष-गण|Vārṣa-gaṇa]]''' is a pupil of '''[[हरित कश्यप|Harita Kaśyapa]]''' according to the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] or Genealogy in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1b_ve1_196/>

असित-मृग
<u>'''Asita-mṛga'''</u> is the designation in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_197> vii. 27. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 345.</ref> of a family of the '''Kaśyapas''' who were excluded from a sacrifice by '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]],''' but who took away the conduct of the offering from the '''Bhūtavīras,''' whom the king employed. In the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_197> i. 75.</ref> and the Ṣaḍviṃsa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_197> i. 4.</ref> the Asitamṛgas are called ‘sons of the Kaśyapas,’ and one is mentioned as '''Kusurubindu'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_197> Variously read as Asurbinda, Kusurbinda, Kusurubinda.</ref> '''[[औद्दालकि|Auddālaki]].'''

असुर-विद्या
<u>'''Asura-vidyā,'''</u> ‘the science of the Asuras,’ the term used in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] and Āśvalāyana<ref name=fx1_ve1_198> x. 7.</ref> Śrauta Sūtras as the equivalent of the term ''māyā'' employed in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_198> xiii. 4, 3, 11. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 61, 2. 21.</ref> clearly means ‘magic,’ as it is rendered by Professor Eggeling.<ref name=fx3_ve1_198> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 368.</ref>

अस्तृ
<u>'''Astṛ,'''</u> ‘shooter,’ is a term frequently used in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_199> i. 8, 4;<br> 64, 10;<br> ii. 42, 2, etc.</ref> and Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_199> vi. 93, 1. 2;<br> xi. 2, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 296.</ref> for the archer who fought from the chariot.

अहन्
<u>'''Ahan,'''</u> ‘day.’ Like other peoples, the Indians used night as a general expression of time as well as day, but by no means predominantly.<ref name=fx1_ve1_200> Rv. iv. 16, 19;<br> viii. 26, 3;<br> i. 70, 4. ''Cf.'' Av. x. 7, 42.</ref> Night is also termed the dark (''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]''), as  opposed to the light (''arjuna''), day.<ref name=fx2_ve1_200> Rv. vi. 9. 1.</ref> Aho-rātra<ref name=fx3_ve1_200> Rv. x. 190, 2;<br> Av. xiii. 3, 8, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 41, etc.</ref> is a regular term for ‘day and night’ combined.<br><br>The day itself is variously divided. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_200> ix. 6, 45.</ref> a division into ‘the rising sun’ (''udyan sūryaḥ''), ‘the coming together of the cows’ (''[[सं-गव|saṃ-gava]]''), ‘midday’ (''[[मध्यं-दिन|madhyaṃ-dina]]''), ‘afternoon’ (''aparāhṇa''), and ‘sunset’ (''astaṃ-yan'') is found. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_200> i. 5, 3, 1;<br> 4, 9, 2.</ref> the same series appears with ‘early’ (''[[प्रातर्|prātar]]'') and ‘evening’ (''sāyāhna'') substituted for the first and last members, while a shorter list gives ''[[प्रातर्|prātar]], [[संगव|saṃgava]], sāyam.'' In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx6_ve1_200> iv. 2, 11.</ref> there is the series ‘dawn’ ''(uṣas), [[संगव|saṃgava]], [[मध्यंदिन|madhyaṃdina]],'' and ''aparāhṇa.''<br><br>The morning is also, according to Zimmer, called ''[[अपि-शर्वर|api-śarvara]],''<ref name=fx7_ve1_200> Rv. iii. 9, 7;<br> ''cf.'' Oldenberg, ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 230.</ref> as the time when the dark is just past. It is named ''[[स्वसर|svasara]],''<ref name=fx8_ve1_200> Rv. ii. 34, 8;<br> ix. 94, 2.</ref> as the time when the cows are feeding, before the first milking at the ''[[संगव|saṃgava]],'' or when the birds are awakening.<ref name=fx9_ve1_200> Rv. ii. 19, 2;<br> 34, 5.</ref> It is also called ''[[प्र-पित्व|pra-pitva]],''<ref name=fx10_ve1_200> Rv. vii. 41, 4;<br> viii. 1, 29. Sieg. ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 127 ''et seq.,'' interprets ''paritakmyāyām'' (Rv. i. 116, 15) similarly.</ref> according to Zimmer.<ref name=fx11_ve1_200> ''Altindisches Leben.'' 362.</ref> But Geldner<ref name=fx12_ve1_200> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 155-179.</ref> points out that that term refers to the late midday, which also is called ''[[अपि-शर्वर|api-śarvara]],'' as bordering on the coming night, being the time when day is hastening to its close, as in a race. From another point of view, evening is called ''[[अभि-पित्व|abhi-pitva]],''<ref name=fx13_ve1_200> Rv. i. 126, 3;<br> iv. 34, 5.</ref> the time when all come to rest. Or again, morning and evening are denoted as the dawning of the sun (''uditā sūryasya''), or its setting (''[[नि-म्रुच्|ni-mruc]]''). The midday is regularly ''madhyam ahnām,''<ref name=fx14_ve1_200> Rv. vii. 41, 4.</ref> ''madhye,''<ref name=fx15_ve1_200> Rv. viii. 27, 20.</ref> or ''[[मध्यंदिन|madhyaṃdina]]. [[संगव|Saṃgava]]''<ref name=fx16_ve1_200> ''Cf.'' Rv. v. 76, 3 (''saṃgave, [[प्रातर्|prātar]] ahno, madhyaṃdine'');<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 1, 3;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 12, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 18, 14;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 112, 113. Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 362, places it too early--before the cows are driven out.</ref> is the forenoon, between the early morning (''[[प्रातर्|prātar]]'') and midday (''[[मध्यंदिन|madhyaṃdina]]'').<br><br>The divisions of time less than the day are seldom precisely given. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx17_ve1_200> xii. 3, 2, 5. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 1, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> however, a day and  night make up 30 ''muhūrtas;'' 1 ''[[मुहूर्त|muhūrta]]'' = 15 ''kṣipra;'' 1 ''kṣipra'' = 15 ''etarhi;'' 1 ''etarhi'' = 15 ''idāni;'' 1 ''idāni'' = 15 breathings; 1 breathing = 1 spiration; 1 spiration = 1 twinkling (''nimeṣa''), etc. In the Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx18_ve1_200> vii. 20. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 78 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 92-95.</ref> the series is ''dhvaṃsayo, nimeṣāḥ, kāṣṭhāḥ, kalāḥ, kṣanā, muhūrtā, ahorātrāḥ.'' A thirtyfold division of day as well as of night is seen in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx19_ve1_200> Rv. i. 123, 8.</ref> by Zimmer, who compares the Babylonian sixtyfold division of the day and night. But the expression used-thirty Yojanas--is too vague and obscure--Bergaigne<ref name=fx20_ve1_200> ''Religion Védique.'' 3, 283 ''et seq. Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. kratu.''</ref> refers it to the firmament--to build any theory upon with safety.<br><br>The longer divisions of time are regularly ‘half month’ (''ardha-[[मास|māsa]]''), ‘month’ (''[[मास|māsa]]''), ‘season’ (''[[ऋतु|ṛtu]]''), and ‘year’ (''[[संवत्सर|saṃvatsara]]''), which often<ref name=fx21_ve1_200> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 15;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 20;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]. iii. 8, 9, etc. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 361-363.</ref> occur in this sequence after ''ahorātrāṇi'' (‘days and nights’).

अहल्या मैत्रेयी
<u>'''Ahalyā Maitreyī'''</u> is practically a mythical name, the existence of the lady whose story is alluded to in several Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_201> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 18;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 79;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1.</ref> being derived from the epithet of Indra, ‘lover of Ahalyā’ (''ahalyāyai [[जार|jāra]]'').

अहि
<u>'''Ahi.'''</u>--This word occurs frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_202> vii. 104, 7, etc. The word ''[[सर्प|sarpa]],'' which is usual in the Atharvaveda, occurs only once (x. 16, 6) in the Rv.</ref> onwards to denote ‘snake.’ Reference is several times<ref name=fx2_ve1_202> Rv. ix. 86, 44;<br> Av. i. 27;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 6, 13;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 4, 10;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9. ii. 139;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 6;<br> 17.</ref> made to its casting its slough. Mention is also made of the serpent's peculiar movement,<ref name=fx3_ve1_202> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 1, 4.</ref> which earns for it the designation<ref name=fx4_ve1_202> Av. iv. 3, 2.</ref> of ‘the toothed rope’ (''datvatī rajjuḥ''). The poisonous character  of its bite is spoken of,<ref name=fx5_ve1_202> Rv. vii. 104. 7;<br> Av. x. 4, 4 ''et seq.;<br>'' 6, 56.</ref> as well as the torpidity of the reptile in winter, when it creeps into the earth.<ref name=fx6_ve1_202> Av. xii. 1, 46.</ref> The cast skin is used as an amulet against highwaymen.<ref name=fx7_ve1_202> Av. i. 27.</ref> Mention is made of a mythical horse, [[पैद्व|Paidva]], which the Aśvins gave to Pedu as a protection against snakes,<ref name=fx8_ve1_202> Rv. i. 117-119</ref> and which is invoked as a destroyer of serpents.<ref name=fx9_ve1_202> Av. x. 4, 6. 10.</ref> The ichneumon (''[[नकुल|nakula]]'') is regarded as their deadly enemy, and as immune against their poison through the use of a healing plant,<ref name=fx10_ve1_202> Av. vi. 139, 5;<br> viii. 7, 23.</ref> while men kill them with sticks<ref name=fx11_ve1_202> Av. x. 4, 9.</ref> or strike off their heads.<ref name=fx12_ve1_202> Av. vi. 67, 2. See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94, 95.</ref><br><br>Many species of snakes are mentioned: see '''[[अघाश्व|Aghāśva]], [[अजगर|Ajagara]], [[असित|Asita]], [[कङ्कपर्वन्|Kaṅkaparvan]], [[करिक्रत|Karikrata]], [[कल्माषग्रीव|Kalmāṣagrīva]], [[कसर्णील|Kasarṇīla]], [[कुम्भीनस|Kumbhīnasa]], [[तिरश्चराजि|Tiraścarāji]], [[तैमात|Taimāta]], [[दर्वि|Darvi]], [[दशोनसि|Daśonasi]], [[पुष्करसाद|Puṣkarasāda]], [[पृदाकु|Pṛdāku]], [[लोहिताहि|Lohitāhi]], [[शर्कोट|Śarkoṭa]], [[श्वित्र|Śvitra]], [[सर्प|Sarpa]].'''

अहीना आश्वत्थ्य
<u>'''Ahīnā Āśvatthya'''</u> was a sage (''muni'') who achieved immortality by knowledge of a certain rite (''sāvitram'').<ref name=fx1_ve1_203> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 9, 10. The form of the first name is remarkable. The second may be compared with '''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]].'''</ref>

आकुलि
<u>'''Ākuli.'''</u>--This mythical priest plays, together with '''[[किरात|Kirāta]],''' a part in the later tale of '''Asamāti''' and the '''Gaupāyanas.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आक्ताक्ष्य
<u>'''Āktākṣya'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher who had peculiar views on the fire ritual (''agni-citi''), which are rejected in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_205> vi. 1, 2, 24. ''Cf.'' Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 140.</ref>

आ-क्रमण
<u>'''Ā-kramaṇa.'''</u>--In the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]^1 (i. 3) this word is used with the specific sense of ‘steps to climb trees.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

आखु
<u>'''Ākhu.'''</u>--The exact sense of this word is uncertain. Zimmer<ref name=fx1_ve1_207> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 84, 85, followed by Bloomfield. ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 142.</ref> renders it ‘mole,’ while Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_207> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' followed by Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 317, 318.</ref> prefers ‘mouse’ or ‘rat.’ It is frequently mentioned in the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx3_ve1_207> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 14, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14. 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 57;<br> xxiv. 26;<br> 28;<br> Av. vi. 50, 1.</ref> and is known to the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_207> ix. 67, 30.</ref> where, however, the word is regarded by Pischel<ref name=fx5_ve1_207> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 246;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 701.</ref> as having acquired the secondary sense of ‘thief.’ This is denied by Hillebrandt.<ref name=fx6_ve1_207> ''Zeitschrift,'' 48, 418;<br> ''Vedainterpretation,'' 7.</ref>

आ-ख्यान
<u>'''Ā-khyāna.'''</u>--In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_208> vii. 18, 10. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 27.</ref> we hear of the Śaunaḥśepa [[आख्यान|Ākhyāna]], ‘the story of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]],'''’ which is told by the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest at the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] (‘royal inauguration’). The series of stories<ref name=fx2_ve1_208> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. xiii. 4, 3, 2. 15.</ref> used at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) during the year while the sacrificial horse is allowed to wander at its will is called the ‘cyclic’ (''pari-plavam''). The [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_208> iii. 25, 1.</ref> mentions also [[आख्यान|Ākhyāna]]-vids (‘men versed in tales’), who tell the Sauparṇa legend, elswhere<ref name=fx4_ve1_208> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6. 2. 7.</ref> known as a '''[[व्याख्यान|Vyākhyāna]].''' [[यास्क|Yāska]], in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_208> v. 21;<br> vii. 7.</ref> frequently uses the term, sometimes in a pregnant sense as denoting the doctrine of the Aitihāsikas or traditional interpreters of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx6_ve1_208> xi. 19;<br> 25.<br><br>''Cf.'' Sieg. ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]].'' 16 ''et seq.''</ref>

आ-ख्यायिका
<u>'''Ā-khyāyikā.'''</u>--This word occurs apparently but once in the Vedic literature, in the late [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve1_209> i. 6. 3. ''Cf.'' Sieg. ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 20, n.</ref> where its significance is doubtful.

आगस्त्य
<u>'''Āgastya'''</u> appears as a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] (iii. 1, 1) and [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] (vii. 2) Āraṇyakas. <br>==Foot Notes==

आग्नि-वेशि शत्रि
<u>'''Āgni-veśi Śatri.'''</u>--A prince of this name appears to be referred to in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_211> v. 34, 9. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155.</ref>

आग्नि-वेश्य
<u>'''Āgni-veśya.'''</u>--Several teachers of this name are mentioned in the Vaṃśas or Genealogies of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]. In the Mādhyandina recension<ref name=fx1_ve1_212> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27.</ref> [[आग्निवेश्य|Āgniveśya]] is a pupil of '''[[सैतव|Saitava]].''' In the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension he is a pupil of '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]''' and '''[[आनभिम्लात|Ānabhimlāta]]''' in one [[वंश|Vaṃśa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_212> ii. 6, 2.</ref> and of '''[[गार्ग्य|Gārgya]]''' in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_212> iv. 6, 2.</ref>

आ-घाटि
<u>'''Ā-ghāṭi'''</u> is a musical instrument, the ‘cymbal,’ used to accompany dancing. It is known to the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_213> x. 146, 2.</ref> and Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_213> iv. 37, 4 (''āgkāṭa''). ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 289.</ref>

आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Āṅgirasa'''</u> is a title denoting a claim to be of the family of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]],''' borne by many sages and teachers, like '''[[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]], [[आजीगर्ति|Ājīgarti]], [[च्यवन|Cyavana]], Ayāsya, [[संवर्त|Saṃvarta]], Sudhanvan,''' etc.<br>==Foot Notes==

आज-केशिन्
<u>'''Āja-keśin'''</u> is the name of a family in which, according to the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 9, 3), '''Baka''' used violence against Indra.<br>==Foot Notes==

आजनि
<u>'''Ājani.'''</u>--This word is used to denote a ‘goad’ in the Atharvaveda (iii. 25, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

आजात-शत्रव
<u>'''Ājāta-śatrava.'''</u> See '''Bhadrasena.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आजि
<u>'''Āji'''</u> is constantly used in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_218> v. 37, 7;<br> vi. 24, 6, etc.</ref> and the later literature to express the sense of ‘a race,’ and only seldom denotes ‘a battle.’ '''Horse'''-racing was one of the favourite amusements of the '''Vedic''' Indian,<ref name=fx2_ve1_218> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 291;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 120;<br> 2. 1 ''seq.''</ref> the other being dicing  ('''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]'''). The racecourse, called [[काष्ठा|Kāṣṭhā]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_218> Rv. viii. 80, 8;<br> Av. ii. 14, 6.</ref> or [[आजि|Āji]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_218> Rv. iv. 24, 8;<br> Av. xiii. 2, 4.</ref> itself, appears from the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_218> ii. 14, 6;<br> xiii. 2, 4.</ref> to have been a quasi-circular one to a mark (''[[कार्ष्मन्|kārṣman]]''<ref name=fx6_ve1_218> Rv. ix. 36, 1;<br> 74, 8.</ref> ) and back again. In the Rigveda the course is described as broad (''urvī'') and the distance as measured out (''apāvṛktā aratnayaḥ'').<ref name=fx7_ve1_218> The sense is doubtful in Rv. viii. 80, 8. Zimmer suggests that it may mean ‘the course is straight,’ without twistings, for which idea ''cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 160, quoting the comparison of the courser's race with a bowstring (Rv. iii. 53, 24). It is also rendered ‘the barriers are removed.’</ref> Prizes (''[[धन|dhana]]'') were offered (''dhā''),<ref name=fx8_ve1_218> Rv. i. 81, 3;<br> 116, 15;<br> vi. 45, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' viii. 80, 8;<br> ix. 53, 2;<br> 109, 10. According to Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 120, n. 2, ''[[धन|dhana]]'' is from ''dhan,'' ‘start.’ ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''ibid.,'' 171. ''Cf. dhanasā,'' Rv. i. 112, 7. 10;<br> ii. 10, 6;<br> viii. 3, 15, etc.</ref> and eagerly competed for. Other words for victory and the prize are ''kāra''<ref name=fx9_ve1_218> Rv. v. 29, 8;<br> ix. 14, 1.</ref> and ''bhara;''<ref name=fx10_ve1_218> Rv. v. 29, 8;<br> ix. 16, 5, etc.</ref> and to ‘run a race’ is described by the expressions ''ājim aj, i, dhāv, sṛ.''<ref name=fx11_ve1_218> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 25;<br> iv. 27;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 3, 4;<br> v. 1, 1, 3;<br> 4, 1;<br> vi. 1, 2, 12;<br> vii. 1, 2, 1, etc.</ref> The person who instituted a race is referred to as ''[[आजि|āji]]-sṛt,''<ref name=fx12_ve1_218> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 5, 10. 28;<br> xi. 1, 2, 13.</ref> and Indra is called ''[[आजि|āji]]-kṛt''<ref name=fx13_ve1_218> Rv. viii. 53, 6.</ref> (‘race-maker’), and ''[[आजि|āji]]-pati''<ref name=fx14_ve1_218> ''Ibid.,'' 14.</ref> (‘lord of the race’).<br><br>The swift steeds (''[[वाजिन्|vājin]], atya'') used for the races were often washed and adorned.<ref name=fx15_ve1_218> Rv. ii. 34, 3;<br> ix. 109, 10;<br> x. 68, 11.</ref> According to Pischel<ref name=fx16_ve1_218> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 171-173. ''Cf.'' Sieg. ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 127 ''et seq.''</ref> the name of one swift mare is preserved--viz., [[विश्पला|Viśpalā]],<ref name=fx17_ve1_218> Rv. i. 116, 15. Pischel finds here a race in honour of Vivasvant, but his equation of [[खेल|Khela]] and Vivasvant is denied even by Sieg, who accepts his theory of [[विश्पला|Viśpalā]].</ref> whose broken leg was replaced by the Aśvins in a race; but the interpretation is very doubtful. Geldner<ref name=fx18_ve1_218> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> has also found a comic picture of a horse-chariot race in the [[मुद्गल|Mudgala]] hymn in the Rigveda, but Bloomfield<ref name=fx19_ve1_218> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 541 ''et seq.'' Von Schroeder, ''Mysterium und Mimus im Rigveda,'' 346 ''et seq.,'' follows Geldner. ''Cf.'' Winternitz. ''Vienna Oriental Journal,'' 23, 137.</ref> has shown that that interpretation is unsound. Pischel<ref name=fx20_ve1_218> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 172.</ref> also seeks to show that races were run in honour of gods, but the evidence for the theory is inadequate.<ref name=fx21_ve1_218> Sieg, ''op. cit.,'' 128.</ref>  A formal race, however, is a feature of the ritual of the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] or royal consecration.<ref name=fx22_ve1_218> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 19 ''et seq.;<br>'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 2;<br> 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1. 43.</ref>

आजीगर्ति
<u>'''Ājīgarti.'''</u>--See '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]],''' who bears this patronymic in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_219> vii. 17. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 11, 2.</ref> He is called an [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]] in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_219> xix. 11.</ref>

आज्य
<u>'''Ājya.'''</u> See '''[[घृत|Ghṛta]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आञ्जन
<u>'''Āñjana.'''</u>--A salve frequently referred to in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_221> iv. 9;<br> vi. 102, 3;<br> ix. 6, 11;<br> xix. 44.</ref> which came from Mount '''Trikakubh'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_221> Av. iv. 9, 9. 10;<br> xix. 44, 6.</ref> in the Himālaya, and was used to anoint the eyes.<ref name=fx3_ve1_221> ''Cf.'' Av. iv. 9, 1 (''akṣyam'');<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3. Hence the legend in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 5;<br> ''cf.'' i. 2, 1, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, 6, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 3, 15;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 3.</ref> The region of the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_221> Av. iv. 9, 10.</ref> is also given as a possible place of origin, and the ointment is declared as potent to remove jaundice, '''[[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]], [[जायान्य|Jāyānya]],''' and other diseases.<ref name=fx5_ve1_221> Av. xix. 44, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> A female ointment-maker is mentioned in the list of victims of the '''Puruṣamedha''' (‘human sacrifice’).<ref name=fx6_ve1_221> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 14 (''āñjanī-[[कारि|kāri]]'');<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 10, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 5, 69;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda'' 381 ''et seq.;<br> American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 405, 406;<br> Whitney Translation of the Atharvaveda, 159.</ref>

आटिकी
<u>'''Āṭikī'''</u> is the name of the wife of '''Uṣasti''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 10, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

अट्णार
<u>'''Aṭṇāra.'''</u>--Patronymic of '''Para.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आडम्बर
<u>'''Āḍambara'''</u> was a kind of ‘drum.’ A ‘drummer’ (''āḍambarāghāta'') is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[पुरुष|Puruṣa]]-[[मेध|medha]] (‘human sacrifice’) in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_224> xxx. 19. ''Cf.'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 4, 8, 1.</ref> 

आणि
<u>'''Āṇi.'''</u>--This word, which is found in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_225> i. 35, 6;<br> v. 43, 8.</ref> but rarely later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_225> In a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 7. See Keith's edition, pp. 266, 267, and Vānī.</ref> appears to be best taken with Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_225> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_225> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 247.</ref> as denoting the part of the axle of the chariot which is inserted into the nave of the wheel. Sāyaṇa renders it as lynch-pin, and this sense is accepted by Leumann,<ref name=fx5_ve1_225> ''Etymologisches Wo7rterbuch,'' 30.</ref> being apparently also found in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx6_ve1_225> vi. 32.</ref> In one place in the Rigveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_225> i. 63, 8. ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 96.</ref> the word appears by synecdoche to denote the whole chariot, but the passage is, according to Geldner,<ref name=fx8_ve1_225> Geldner, ''ibid.,'' 1, 141, n. 3.</ref> completely obscure.

आण्डीक
<u>'''Āṇḍīka'''</u> (‘bearing eggs’) is a term found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_226> iv. 34, 5;<br> v. 17, 16. In the first passage the Paippalāda version has ''[[पौण्डरीक|pauṇḍarīka]]'' in its place;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 207. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 138.</ref> denoting an edible plant, apparently with fruit or leaves of egg shape (''āṇḍa''), akin to the lotus.

आता
<u>'''Ātā.'''</u>--The framework of the door of a house appears to be denoted by the plural of this word in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_227> i. 56, 5;<br> 113, 14;<br> iii. 43, 6;<br> ix. 5, 5 (''ātaiḥ'').</ref> (though in all passages there it is used only by synecdoche of the doors of the sky), and in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_227> xxix. 5 ''(ātaiḥ). Cf. ātābhiḥ'' in [[दुर्ग|Durga]] on [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 18.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_227> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 154.</ref> compares the Latin ''antae,'' to which the word etymologically corresponds.<ref name=fx4_ve1_227> Brugmann, ''Grundriss,'' 1, 209;<br> 2, 214.</ref>

आति
<u>'''Āti,'''</u> an aquatic bird. The Apsarases in the legend of [[पुरूरवस्|Purūravas]] and Urvaśī appear to him like Ātis, probably swans.<ref name=fx1_ve1_228> Rv. x. 95, 9. ''Cf.'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 4.</ref> The birds appear also in the list of animals in the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’),<ref name=fx2_ve1_228> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 13, 1;<br> Maītrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 18;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 34.</ref> where Mahīdhara<ref name=fx3_ve1_228> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> renders them as the  later Āḍī (''Turdus ginginianus''), and Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx4_ve1_228> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben;<br>'' 89.</ref> quotes a view, according to which the [[आति|Āti]] was the [[चाष|Cāṣa]], or blue jay (''Coracias indica'').

आतिथि-ग्व
<u>'''Ātithi-gva.'''</u>--Patronymic of '''[[इन्द्रोत|Indrota]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आत्रेय
<u>'''Ātreya'''</u> is the patronymic of a pupil of [[माण्टि|Māṇṭi]] in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_230> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 (in both versions).</ref> An [[आत्रेय|Ātreya]] appears as a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of '''[[अङ्ग|Aṅga]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_230> viii. 22.</ref> An [[आत्रेय|Ātreya]] was regularly the priest in certain rites,<ref name=fx3_ve1_230> ''Ibid.,'' vii. 7;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 4, 21;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 2, 21 (''sadasaḥ purastāt'').</ref> and an Ātreyī occurs in an obscure passage in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_230> i. 4, 5, 13. ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

आत्रेयी-पुत्र
<u>'''Ātreyī-putra'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[गौतमीपुत्र|Gautamīputra]]''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]], or Genealogy, in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 2, in both versions).<br>==Foot Notes==

आथर्वण
<u>'''Ātharvaṇa,'''</u> a patronymic formed from the name of the mythic [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]], is found normally in the plural neuter as a designation of the hymns of the Atharvans.
