This use appears in the late nineteenth book of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_232> xix. 23, 1.</ref> and in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_232> xii. 9, 10.</ref> In the singular the expression [[आथर्वण|Ātharvaṇa]] (Veda), though not occurring till the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_232> vii. 1, 2, 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> is earlier than the term ‘Atharvaveda,’ which is first found in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx4_ve1_232> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2, 10, etc.</ref> In the [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_232> ii. 12.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xxv.;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 8 ''et seq.''</ref> Ātharvaṇikas, or ‘followers of the Atharvaveda,’ appear.<br><br>Specific but mainly mythical Ātharvaṇas are '''Kabandha, [[बृहद्दिव|Bṛhaddiva]], [[भिषज्|Bhiṣaj]], Dadhyaṅc,''' and '''Vicārin.''' 

आ-दर्श
<u>'''Ā-darśa,'''</u> ‘mirror,’ is a term found only in the Upaniṣads<ref name=fx1_ve1_233> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 9;<br> iii. 9, 15;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 7. 4;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2;<br> 11.</ref> and Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_233> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 4;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, viii. 7.</ref>

आदार
<u>'''Ādāra'''</u> was a kind of plant which was prescribed as a substitute for '''Soma.'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_234> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 10, 4.</ref> It is identified in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_234> xiv. 1, 2, 12. ''Cf.'' Kāthaka Saṃhitā, xxiv. 3;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxv. 12, 19.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 276.</ref> with '''[[पूतीक|Pūtīka]].'''

आनन्द-ज चान्धनायन
<u>'''Ānanda-ja Cāndhanāyana'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[शाम्ब|Śāmba]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_235> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

आनभि-म्लात
<u>'''Ānabhi-mlāta'''</u> is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]], or Genealogy, in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_236> ii. 6, 2 (not in the Mādhyandina version).</ref> as a pupil of [[आनभिम्लात|Ānabhimlāta]].

आनव
<u>'''Ānava.'''</u> See '''Anu.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आनूक
<u>'''Ānūka.'''</u>--Geldner<ref name=fx1_ve1_238> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 94.</ref> thinks that in its solitary occurrence in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_238> v. 33, 9.</ref> this word means an ornament. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_238> St. Petersburg Dictionary. ''s.v.''</ref> takes it adverbially, and so do Ludwig and Oldenberg.

आपया
<u>'''Āpayā'''</u> is the name of a river mentioned once only in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_239> iii. 23, 4.</ref> when it occurs between the '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]]''' and the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].''' Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_239> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200. But ''cf. ibid.,'' 4, 304.</ref> was inclined to identify it with the Āpagā as a name for the Ganges, but Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_239> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 18.</ref> correctly places it near the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], either as the small tributary which flows past Thānesar or the modern Indramatī farther west, while Pischel<ref name=fx4_ve1_239> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218.</ref> assigns it to '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' of which the [[आपया|Āpayā]] is mentioned as a famous river in the Mahābhārata.<ref name=fx5_ve1_239> Mahābhārata, iii. 83, 68.</ref> 

आबयु
<u>'''Ābayu'''</u> is apparently the name of a plant in the Atharvaveda;<ref name=fx1_ve1_240> vi. 16, 1.</ref> the mustard plant<ref name=fx2_ve1_240> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 465, following the indication of the use of the hymn in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].</ref> may have been meant, but the sense is quite uncertain.<ref name=fx3_ve1_240> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 292;<br> Zimmer. ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref>

आभि-प्रतारिण
<u>'''Ābhi-pratāriṇa.'''</u>--Patronymic of '''Vṛddhadyumna.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आ भूति त्वाष्ट्र
<u>'''Ā [[भूति|bhūti]] Tvāṣṭra'''</u> is mentioned in two Vaṃśas, or Genealogies, of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_242> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 (in both recensions).</ref> as a pupil of '''Viśvarūpa [[त्वाष्ट्र|Tvāṣṭra]],''' both teachers being no doubt equally mythical.

आमलक
<u>'''Āmalaka'''</u> (neuter), a common word later, is found in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vii. 3, 1), denoting the Myrobalan fruit. ''Cf.'' '''[[अमला|Amalā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आमिक्षा
<u>'''Āmikṣā'''</u> designates a mess of clotted curds. It is not known to the Rigveda, but occurs in all the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_244> Av. x. 9, 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 5, 4;<br> iii. 3, 9, 2;<br> vi. 2, 5, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 21;<br> 23, etc.</ref> Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve1_244> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 1, 7. 9;<br> iii. 3, 3, 2, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 8, 8;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 438 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 99, 101);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 8, 5, etc.</ref> etc., and is associated with the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx3_ve1_244> ''Loc. cit. Cf.'' [[मानव|Mānava]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 2, 40.</ref>

आम्ब
<u>'''Āmba'''</u> denotes in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_245> i. 8, 10, 1.</ref> and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_245> xv. 5.</ref> Saṃhitās a grain, called '''[[नाम्ब|Nāmba]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_245> v. 3, 3, 8.</ref>

आम्बष्ठ्य
<u>'''Āmbaṣṭhya'''</u> is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 21) as a king, whose priest for the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]], or royal inauguration, was '''[[नारद|Nārada]].''' Presumably the name is local, meaning ‘King of  the Ambaṣṭhas,’ as interpreted in the St. Petersburg Dictionary. Later the term [[अम्बष्ठ|Ambaṣṭha]] denotes ‘a man of mingled [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] parentage by father and mother’ respectively.<br>==Foot Notes==

आ-यतन
<u>'''Ā-yatana.'''</u>--The general sense of ‘abode’ or ‘home’ appears to be limited in one passage of the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vii. 24, 2) to the sense of ‘holy place,’ ‘sanctuary,’ which is found in the epic.<br>==Foot Notes==

आयवस
<u>'''Āyavasa'''</u> is mentioned apparently as a king in a corrupt and unintelligible verse of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_248> i. 122, 15. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 206;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

आयु
<u>'''Āyu'''</u> appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_249> i. 53, 10;<br> ii. 14, 7;<br> vi. 18, 3;<br> viii. 53, 2;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 1, 60.</ref> with '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]]''' and '''[[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]]''' as having been defeated, with Indra's aid, by '''[[तूर्वयाण|Tūrvayāṇa]],''' who is believed by Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve1_249> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 71-75.</ref> to have been King of the '''Pakthas.''' Possibly he is elsewhere<ref name=fx3_ve1_249> Rv. x. 49, 5;<br> but the word is possibly not a proper name.</ref> referred to as victorious, by Indra's aid, over '''[[वेश|Veśa]].''' Elsewhere he is quite mythical.<ref name=fx4_ve1_249> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 100, 135, 140.</ref>

आयुत
<u>'''Āyuta.'''</u> See '''[[घृत|Ghṛta]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आ-युध
<u>'''Ā-yudha,'''</u> ‘weapon,’ in its widest sense covers the whole of a Kṣatriya's warlike equipment, which in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_251> vii. 19, 2.</ref> is summed up as horse-chariot (''[[अश्व|aśva]]-[[रथ|ratha]]''), bow and arrows (''[[इषु|iṣu]]-dhanva''), and corselet (''[[कवच|kavaca]]''). As the bow and arrow (''[[इषु|iṣu]], [[धन्वन्|dhanvan]]'') were essential as the main weapons of the Vedic fighter, they are probably meant when [[आयुध|Āyudha]] is used specifically of weapons, as often from the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_251> i. 39, 2;<br> 61. 13;<br> 92, 1;<br> ii. 30, 9. etc.;<br> Av. vi. 133, 2, etc.</ref> onwards. The battle hymn in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_251> vi. 75.</ref> confirms this view, as it presents to us the warrior armed with bow and arrow on his chariot, and clad in armour ('''[[वर्मन्|Varman]]'''), with a guard ('''[[हस्तघ्न|Hastaghna]]''') on the left arm to avoid the friction of the bow-string. The corselet was not a single solid piece of metal, but consisted of many pieces fitted together (''syūta'');<ref name=fx4_ve1_251> Rv. i. 31, 15.</ref> it may  have been made either of metal plates or, as is more likely, of some stiff material plated with metal. In addition the warrior wore a helmet ('''[[शिप्रा|Śiprā]]'''). There is no trace of the use of a shield, nor is there any clear record of the employment of greaves or other guard for the feet.<ref name=fx5_ve1_251> Grassmann saw greaves in ''vaṭūriṇā padā'' in Rv. i. 133, 2, but this is most improbable.</ref> Skill in the use of weapons is referred to in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx6_ve1_251> i. 92, 1. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 183;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 295.</ref><br><br>It is doubtful whether sling stones ('''Adri, [[अशनि|Aśani]]''') were in ordinary use. The hook (''aṅkuśa'')<ref name=fx7_ve1_251> Rv. viii. 17, 10;<br> x. 44, 9;<br> 134, 6;<br> Av. vi. 83, 3. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts.'' 5, 87.</ref> also is merely a divine weapon, and the axe (''[[स्वधिति|svadhiti]],''<ref name=fx8_ve1_251> Rv. v. 32, 10;<br> ix. 67, 30;<br> x. 43, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 298301;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts.'' 5, 469-472;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 281 ''et seq.''</ref> ''[[वाशी|vāśī]], [[परशु|paraśu]]'') does not occur in mortal combats. For the use of the spear see '''[[ऋष्टि|Ṛṣṭi]], [[रम्भिणी|Rambhiṇī]], [[शक्ति|Śakti]], [[शरु|Śaru]];''' of the sword, '''Asi, [[कृति|Kṛti]].''' Neither weapon can be considered ordinary in warfare, nor was the club ('''[[वज्र|Vajra]]''') used. For the modes of warfare see '''[[संग्राम|Saṃgrāma]].'''

आयोगव
<u>'''Āyogava.--Marutta Āvi-kṣita,'''</u> the [[आयोगव|Āyogava]] king, is mentioned as a sacrificer in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_252> xiii. 5. 4, 6. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 9, 14-16.</ref> where also a [[गाथा|Gāthā]] (‘stanza’) celebrating his sacrifice is cited. ''Cf.'' '''[[अयोगू|Ayogū]].'''

आरङ्गर
<u>'''Āraṅgara'''</u> is one of the names of the bee found in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_253> x. 106, 10. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97.</ref> Other names are '''[[सरह्|Sarah]]''' and '''[[भृङ्गा|Bhṛṅgā]].'''

आरा
<u>'''Ārā,'''</u> a word later<ref name=fx1_ve1_254> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 365. n. 1.</ref> known as an ‘awl’ or ‘gimlet,’ occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_254> vi. 53. 8.</ref> only to designate a weapon of Pūṣan, with whose pastoral character its later use for piercing leather is consistent. ''Cf.'' '''[[वाशी|Vāśī]].'''

आराढि
<u>'''Ārāḍhi.'''</u>--Patronymic of '''Saujāta.''' ''Cf.'' '''Arāḍa.''' <br>==Foot Notes==

आरुण औप-वेशि
<u>'''Āruṇa Aupa-veśi.'''</u>--So the manuscripts let us read the former word in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, but this is doubtless an error for '''Aruṇa.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आरुणि
<u>'''Āruṇi'''</u> is the patronymic normally referring to '''Uddālaka,''' son of '''Aruṇa [[औपवेशि|Aupaveśi]].''' Uddālaka is probably also meant by [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]] Yaśasvin, who occurs as a teacher of the Subrahmaṇyā (a kind of recitation) in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_257> ii. 80.</ref> Āruṇis are referred to both in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_257> ii. 5, 1. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 204.</ref> and in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_257> xiii. 12.</ref> as well as in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx4_ve1_257> ii. 4. 1.</ref>

आरुणेय
<u>'''Āruṇeya.'''</u>--An epithet of '''[[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]],''' indicating his descent from '''[[उद्दालक आरुणि|Uddālaka Āruṇi]]''' and '''Aruṇa [[औपवेशि|Aupaveśi]].''' It is apparently confined to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_258> x. 3, 4, 1;<br> xi. 2, 7, 12;<br> 5, 4, 18;<br> 6, 2, 1;<br> xii. 2, 1, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 2, 1.</ref> and Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_258> v. 3, 1;<br> vi. 1, 1.</ref> in which [[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]] plays a great part.

आर्क्ष
<u>'''Ārkṣa.'''</u>--Patronymic of '''Śrutarvan''' and of '''Āśvamedha.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आर्जीक
<u>'''Ārjīka'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_260> Singular: Rv. viii. 7, 29;<br> ix. 113, 2. Plural: ix. 65, 23.</ref> and '''Ārjīkīya'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_260> Rv. viii. 64, 11.</ref> (masc.), '''Ārjīkīyā'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_260> Rv. x. 75, 5.</ref> (fem.).--The two masculine forms probably denote the people or land, while the feminine word designates the river of the land. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx4_ve1_260> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 126-137.</ref> locates the country in or near Kaśmir, as Arrian<ref name=fx5_ve1_260> Anabasis, v. 29, 4.</ref> mentions Arsaces, brother of Abhisares, who presumably took his name from his people, and Abhisāra bordered on Kaśmir. Pischel<ref name=fx6_ve1_260> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 209, 217.</ref> accepts [[आर्जीक|Ārjīka]] as designating a country, which he, however, thinks cannot be identified. But neither Roth<ref name=fx7_ve1_260> St. Petersburg Dictionary.</ref> nor Zimmer<ref name=fx8_ve1_260> ''Altindisches Leben.'' 12-14.</ref> recognizes the word as a proper name. On the other hand, all authorities agree in regarding Ārjīkīyā as the name of a  river. '''Roth'''<ref name=fx9_ve1_260> ''Op. cit., s.v. [[सुषोमा|suṣomā]].''</ref> does so in one passage<ref name=fx10_ve1_260> Rv. x. 75, 5.</ref> only, elsewhere seeing references to Soma vessels; but it seems necessary to treat the word alike in all passages containing it. Zimmer does not locate the river, and Pischel denies the possibility of its identification. Hillebrandt thinks it may have been the Upper Indus, or the '''[[वितस्ता|Vitastā]]''' (the Jhelum), or some other stream. Grassmann follows [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx11_ve1_260> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 26.</ref> in identifying it with the the '''[[विपाश्|Vipāś]]''' (Beäs), but this is rendered improbable by the position of the name in the hymn in praise of rivers (''nadīstuti'').<ref name=fx12_ve1_260> Rv. x. 75.</ref> Brunnhofer<ref name=fx13_ve1_260> ''Iran und Turan,'' 52.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Mūller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 398;<br> 399.</ref> identifies it with the Arghesan, a tributary of the Arghanab.

आर्जुनेय
<u>'''Ārjuneya.'''</u>--In the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_261> i. 112, 23;<br> iv. 26, 1;<br> vii. 19, 2;<br> viii. 1, 11.</ref> this name occurs as the patronymic of '''[[कौत्स|Kautsa]].'''

आर्तभागी-पुत्र
<u>'''Ārtabhāgī-putra'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[शौङ्गी-पुत्र|Śauṅgī-putra]]''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] or Genealogy in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_262> vi. 5, 2 (also in the Mādhyandina version).</ref> Ārtabhāga is a patronymic of Jaratkārava in the same [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_262> iii. 2, 1, 13.</ref>

आर्तव
<u>'''Ārtava.'''</u>--This expression denotes a portion of the year consisting of more seasons than one. But it does not bear the exact sense of ‘half-year,’ as suggested by Zimmer.<ref name=fx1_ve1_263> ''Altindisches Leben.'' 374.</ref> This is shown by the fact that it occurs regularly in the plural, not in the dual. In the Atharvaveda it occurs between seasons and years (''[[हायन|hāyana]]''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_263> iii. 10, 9.</ref> but also in the combinations, ‘seasons, Ārtavas, months, years,;<ref name=fx3_ve1_263> iii. 10, 10.</ref> ‘half-months, months, Ārtavas, seasons’;<ref name=fx4_ve1_263> xi. 7, 20. ''Cf.'' xv. 6, 6;<br> 17, 6.</ref>  ‘seasons, Ārtavas, months, half-months, days and nights, day’;<ref name=fx5_ve1_263> xvi. 8, 18.</ref> and in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā ‘months, seasons, Ārtavas, the year,’<ref name=fx6_ve1_263> xxii. 28.</ref> or simply with the seasons.<ref name=fx7_ve1_263> Av. v. 28, 2. 13;<br> x. 6, 18;<br> 7, 5;<br> xi. 3, 17;<br> 6, 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 6, 1, 3. [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i, 3. cited in this sense in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, is not so to be understood, as the word there is merely adjectival.</ref>

आर्त्नी
<u>'''Ārtnī'''</u> denotes the end of the bow to which the bow-string (''[[ज्या|jyā]]'') was attached.<ref name=fx1_ve1_264> Rv. vi. 75, 4;<br> Av. i. 1, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 9, etc.</ref> The string was not normally kept fastened to both ends of the bow, but when an arrow was to be shot it was strung taut.<ref name=fx2_ve1_264> Rv. x. 166, 3. ''Cf.'' Av. vi. 42, 1.</ref> On the other hand, the legend of the death of Viṣṇu, told in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx3_ve1_264> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5. 9.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx4_ve1_264> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5. 6;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 1, 7 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 297, 298;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 270.</ref> expressly contemplates his leaning on his strung bow, which cleaves his head by the sudden springing apart of the two ends when the bow-string is gnawed through.

आर्य
<u>'''Ārya'''</u> is the normal designation in the Vedic literature from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_265> Rv. i. 51, 8;<br> 130, 8;<br> 156, 5, etc.</ref> onwards of an Āryan, a member of the three upper classes, '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]],''' or '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]],''' as the formal division is given in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_265> iv. 1, 6 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension).</ref> The [[आर्य|Ārya]] stands in opposition to the '''[[दास|Dāsa]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_265> Rv. i. 51, 8. 9;<br> 103, 3;<br> vi. 20, 10;<br> 25, 2, 3, etc. (opposed to [[दास|Dāsa]]);<br> Av. iv. 20, 4. 8;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 30, etc. (opposed to Sūdra).</ref> but also to the '''[[शूद्र|Śūdra]].''' Sometimes<ref name=fx4_ve1_265> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 205, 215, finds this use--understanding [[आर्य|Ārya]] as meant--in Atharvaveda, xix. 32, 8, and 62, 1, as well as in passages where Śūdrāryau is found. Lanman, in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 948, 1003, quotes his view with approval;<br> but Whitney's version leaves no doubt that he read and understood the text as [[आर्य|Ārya]], the Āryan, not the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]. For Whitney's view, Av. iv. 20, 4. 8 may be cited;<br> and so Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' takes the passages. In [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 10, 8, Śūdrāryau must mean Sūdra and [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]];<br> but the Padapāṭha takes it as Arya, and so does Zimmer.</ref> the expression is restricted to the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] caste,  the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] receiving special designations; but this use is not common, and it is often uncertain also whether '''Arya''' is not meant. The phrase Śūdrāryau<ref name=fx5_ve1_265> See [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 9, 3, with Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 3, 7. 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 6, 7;<br> Lāṭyāyana [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 2, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 6, 2;<br> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 10.</ref> is especially ambiguous, but appears to have denoted originally the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] and the Āryan, for in the Mahāvrata ceremony the fight between a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] and an [[आर्य|Ārya]] is represented in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] as one between a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]], though the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] treats it as a fight between a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] and a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]].<br><br>The word [[आर्य|Ārya]] (fem. Āryā or Ārī) also occurs frequently used as an adjective to describe the Āryan classes (''viśaḥ''),<ref name=fx6_ve1_265> Rv. i. 77, 3;<br> 96, 31;<br> x. 11, 4;<br> 43, 4, etc.</ref> or name (''[[नामन्|nāman]]''),<ref name=fx7_ve1_265> Rv. x;<br> 49, 3.</ref> or caste (''[[वर्ण|varṇa]]''),<ref name=fx8_ve1_265> Rv. iii. 34, 9. ''Cf.'' '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].'''</ref> or dwellings (''[[धामन्|dhāman]]'');<ref name=fx9_ve1_265> Rv. ix. 63, 14.</ref> or again reference is made to the Āryan supremacy (''[[व्रत|vrata]]'')<ref name=fx10_ve1_265> Rv. x. 65, 11. So Agni and Indra are styled Āryan, as supporters of the Āryan people (Rv. vi. 60, 6).</ref> being extended over the land. Āryan foes (''vṛtra'')<ref name=fx11_ve1_265> Rv. vi. 33, 3;<br> vii. 83, 1;<br> x. 69, 6.</ref> are referred to beside [[दास|Dāsa]] foes, and there are many<ref name=fx12_ve1_265> Rv. i. 102, 5;<br> iii. 32, 14;<br> vi. 22, 10;<br> 25, 2. 3;<br> viii. 2, 4. 27;<br> x. 38, 3;<br> 83, 1;<br> 102, 3, etc.</ref> references to war of Āryan versus Āryan, as well as to war of Āryan against [[दास|Dāsa]]. From this it can be fairly deduced that even by the time of the Rigveda the Āryan communities had advanced far beyond the stage of simple conquest of the aborigines. In the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas the wars alluded to seem mainly Āryan wars, no doubt in consequence of the fusion of [[आर्य|Ārya]] and [[दास|Dāsa]] into one community.<br><br>Weber<ref name=fx13_ve1_265> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 288. ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[कृष्टि|kṛṣṭi]],'' and '''Pañca Janāsaḥ.'''</ref> considers that the five peoples known to the Rigveda were the Āryans and the four peoples of the quarters (''[[दिश्|diś]]'') of the earth, but this is doubtful. Āryan speech (''[[वाच्|vāc]]'')<ref name=fx14_ve1_265> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 9. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 196, 255;<br> and '''[[वाच्|Vāc]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 207 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 214 ''et seq.''</ref> is specially referred to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] and [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyakas. 

आर्य
<u>'''Ārya.'''</u> See '''[[माल्य|Mālya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अर्ष्टि-षेण
<u>'''Arṣṭi-ṣeṇa.'''</u>--Patronymic of '''Devāpi.'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_267> Rv. x. 98, 5. 6. 8;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 11;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 155.</ref>

आल
<u>'''Āla'''</u> appears to mean ‘weed’ in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_268> Av. vi. 16, 3. But Whitney takes the word as a verb, comparing v. 22, 6.</ref> and to form part of three other words,<ref name=fx2_ve1_268> Av. vi. 16, 4.</ref> denoting, according to Sāyaṇa, grass-creepers (''[[सस्य|sasya]]-vallī'')--viz., [[अलसाला|Alasālā]], Silañjālā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_268> Sāyaṇa reads Śalāñjālā, and the manuscripts of the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (vi. 16), have Śilāñjālā. But ''cf.'' '''[[सिलाची|Silācī]].'''</ref> and [[नीलागलसाल|Nīlāgalasāla]]. Whitney,<ref name=fx4_ve1_268> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 292, 293. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 466.</ref> however, does not think that the words can be given any determinate sense.

आलम्बायनी-पुत्र
<u>'''Ālambāyanī-putra'''</u> is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] or Genealogy of the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 2) as a pupil of '''[[आलम्बी-पुत्र|Ālambī-putra]].''' In the Mādhyandina recension (vi. 4, 32) the relation is reversed, for there he is teacher of [[आलम्बी-पुत्र|Ālambī-putra]] and pupil of '''[[जायन्ती-पुत्र|Jāyantī-putra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आलम्बी-पुत्र
<u>'''Ālambī-putra'''</u> is a pupil of '''[[जायन्ती-पुत्र|Jāyantī-putra]]''' according to a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 2), but of '''[[आलम्बायनी-पुत्र|Ālambāyanī-putra]]''' according to the Mādhyandina (vi. 4, 32).<br>==Foot Notes==

आलिगी
<u>'''Āligī'''</u> is the name of a kind of serpent in the Atharvaveda (v. 13, 7). ''Cf.'' '''[[विलिगी|Viligī]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आ-वसथ
<u>'''Ā-vasatha'''</u> (‘dwelling’).--The precise sense<ref name=fx1_ve1_272> Av. ix. 6, 5 (a hymn in praise of entertaining Brāhmaṇas);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 10, 6;<br> iii. 7, 4, 6;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 4, 6 (where Eggeling renders the word as if meaning ‘house’ merely);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 1, etc. Details are given in the Sūtras--''e.g.,'' Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 9, 3;<br> [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 9, 25, 4.</ref> of this term appears to be a place for the reception of guests, especially Brāhmaṇas and others on the occasion of feasts and sacrifices (somewhat like the modern meaning of [[धर्म|Dharma]]-[[शाला|śālā]] as a resthouse for pilgrims), a use derived from the more general sense of ‘abode.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_272> ''E.g.,'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 12. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 120, n. 1.</ref> 

आविक
<u>'''Āvika'''</u> (‘coming from the sheep,’ ''avi'') is a term for ‘wool,’ which occurs first in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 3, 6). ''Cf.'' '''Avi.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

अवि-क्षित
<u>'''Avi-kṣita.'''</u>--Patronymic of '''Marutta,'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_274> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 6.</ref> the '''[[आयोगव|Āyogava]].'''

आ-शरीक
<u>'''Ā-śarīka'''</u> appears to denote a disease in a hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_275> xix. 34, 10.</ref> celebrating the powers of the '''Jaṅgida''' plant. Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_275> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 65, 391.</ref> thinks that it merely denotes the pain in the limbs accompanying fever. Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve1_275> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 953. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 673.</ref> suggests taking the word as merely an epithet.

आ-शिर्
<u>'''Ā-śir'''</u> (‘admixture’) denotes the mixing, and more especially the milk mixed with the juice, of the Soma before it was offered to the gods. In this sense it is not rare from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_276> i. 134, 6;<br> iii. 53, 14;<br> viii. 2, 10. 11, etc.;<br> Av. ii. 29, 1, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 8;<br> 32.</ref> onwards. Not milk alone was employed for this purpose. The epithet ‘having three admixtures’ applied to Soma<ref name=fx2_ve1_276> Rv. v. 27, 5;<br> ''cf.'' viii. 2, 7. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 209 ''et seq.''</ref> is explained by the other epithets, ‘mixed with milk’ (''[[गवाशिर्|gavāśir]]''), ‘mixed with curds’ (''[[दध्य्-आशिर्|dadhy-āśir]]''), and ‘mixed with grain’ (''[[यवाशिर्|yavāśir]]'')--all referring to Soma.

आशी-विष
<u>'''Āśī-viṣa,'''</u> occurring only in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_277> vi. 1.</ref> is understood by Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_277> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' It is a common word in the Epic and later.</ref> as designating a particular kind of snake, and perhaps means ‘having poison (''[[विष|viṣa]]'') in its fangs’ (''āśī'').

आशु
<u>'''Āśu,'''</u> the ‘swift,’ is frequently used without '''[[अश्व|Aśva]]''' to denote the chariot steed from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_278> ii. 16, 3;<br> 31, 2;<br> 38, 3, etc.;<br> Av. ii. 14, 6;<br> iv. 27, 1;<br> xiii. 2, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 10;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 3, 3, etc.</ref> onwards. 

आशुं-ग
<u>'''Āśuṃ-ga'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_279> vi. 14, 3.</ref> seems to denote some sort of animal. It is qualified by the word ‘young’ (''[[शिशुक|śiśuka]]''), and Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_279> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> suggests that it may mean a bird (‘swift-flying’), or that the expression denotes ‘a foal going to its dam’ (''[[आशु|āśu]]-ga''). Sāyaṇa, however, reads the accompanying word as ''[[शुशुक|śuśuka]],'' which he assumes to denote an animal. Bloomfield<ref name=fx3_ve1_279> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 464.<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 291.</ref> renders the two words ‘a swift (''[[आशुंग|āśuṃga]]'') foal (''[[शिशुक|śiśuka]]''),’ thus agreeing with one of Roth's suggestions in sense, though not in the explanation of Aśuṃga.

आ-श्रम
<u>'''Ā-śrama'''</u> (‘resting-place’) does not occur in any [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] which can be regarded as pre-Buddhistic. Its earliest use as denoting the stages of a Hindu's life is found in the Śvetāśvatara [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_280> ''Atyāśramin,'' Śvetāśvatara [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 21;<br> Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, etc.</ref> In one passage<ref name=fx2_ve1_280> viii. 5.</ref> of the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] reference is made only to the '''Brahmacārin''' and householder, to whom, as a reward for study, the procreation of children, the practice of Yoga, abstention from injury to living creatures, and sacrifices, freedom from transmigration are promised. In another place<ref name=fx3_ve1_280> ii. 23, 1.</ref> three states are contemplated, but not as consecutive. The Brahmacārin may either become a householder or become an anchorite, or remain in his teacher's house all his life. Similarly, reference<ref name=fx4_ve1_280> v. 10.</ref> is made to the death of the anchorite in the forest, or the sacrifice in the village. In contrast with all three<ref name=fx5_ve1_280> ii. 23, 1.</ref> is the man who stands fast in [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] (Brahmasaṃstha). In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_280> iv. 2, 22. ''Cf.'' iii. 5.</ref> the knower of the Ātman is contrasted with those who (1) study, or (2) sacrifice and give alms, or (3) are anchorites, and in another place<ref name=fx7_ve1_280> iii. 8, 10.</ref> with those who sacrifice and make benefactions, and those who practice asceticism. This position of superiority to, and distinction from, the Āśramas became later a fourth<ref name=fx8_ve1_280> [[जाबाल|Jābāla]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], 4. ''Cf.'' Muṇḍaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 7.</ref> [[आश्रम|Āśrama]],  the '''Gṛhastha,''' or householder, who was in the second stage, being required to pass not only into the stage of '''Vānaprastha,''' but also that of the Sannyāsin ('''[[भिक्षु|Bhikṣu]], [[परिव्राजक|Parivrājaka]]'''). The first stage, that of the '''Brahmacārin,''' was still obligatory, but was no longer allowed to remain a permanent one, as was originally possible.<br><br>''Cf.'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 60, 367 ''et seq.''

आ-श्रेषा
<u>'''Ā-śreṣā, Ā-śleṣā.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

आश्व-घ्न
<u>'''Āśva-ghna.'''</u>--This name occurs in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_282> x. 61, 21.</ref> in a very obscure hymn, where it appears to denote a prince who had made offerings to Indra, and who may, as Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_282> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165.</ref> thinks, have been called '''Vitaraṇa.'''

अश्वतर आश्वि
<u>'''Aśvatara Āśvi,'''</u> or '''Āśvatarāśvi.'''--These two expressions are used<ref name=fx1_ve1_283> The first is found in [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 30;<br> the second in Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 1, 9;<br> x. 6, 1, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 15, 8;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 1;<br> 16, 1.</ref> as patronymics of '''Buḍila,''' denoting, according to Sāyaṇa,<ref name=fx2_ve1_283> On [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> that he was son of [[अश्व|Aśva]], and descendant of [[अश्वतर|Aśvatara]].

अश्व-त्थ्य
<u>'''Aśva-tthya.'''</u>--Patronymic of Ahīnā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_284> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 9, 10. Possibly to be read Āśvathya.</ref>

अश्व-मेध
<u>'''Aśva-medha'''</u> is the patronymic of an unnamed prince, who occurs in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda (viii. 68, 15. 16).<br>==Foot Notes==

आश्व-वाल
<u>'''Āśva-vāla.'''</u>--From this adjective (‘made of horse-tail grass’), applied to a strew (''[[प्रस्तर|prastara]]'') in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 4, 1, 17; 6, 3, 10), follows the existence of the Aśvavāla grass (''Saccharum spontaneum'').<br>==Foot Notes==

आश्व-सूक्ति
<u>'''Āśva-sūkti'''</u> is mentioned in [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xix. 4, 2, ''et seq.'') as an author of Sāmans (Soma chants) along with '''Gausūkti.''' <br>==Foot Notes==

आश्विन
<u>'''Āśvina,'''</u> or '''Āśvīna,''' designates, in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_288> vi. 131, 3.</ref> and two Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve1_288> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 17;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] in ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 34.</ref> the length of journey made in a day by a horseman (''aśvin''). The exact distance is not defined. In the Atharva it appears to exceed five leagues, being mentioned immediately after a distance of three or five '''Yojanas;''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] the heavenly world is placed at a distance of a thousand '''Āśvinas.'''

आषाधि सौश्रोमतेय
<u>'''Āṣādhi Sauśromateya.'''</u>--According to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_289> vi. 2, 1, 37. Eggeling has Aṣāḍhi, but as it is a patronymic of Aṣāḍha, the form Āṣāḍhi seems correct.</ref> he was ruined because the heads were put on at the Agniciti in a certain manner, and not correctly.

आष्ट्रा
<u>'''Āṣṭrā'''</u> seems in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxxvii. 1) to denote the ploughman's goad.<br>==Foot Notes==

आष्ट्री
<u>'''Āṣṭrī.'''</u>--In the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_291> x. 165, 3. ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 347.</ref> the word seems to denote a fireplace. The evil bird is entreated not to settle there on the hearth.

आसङ्ग प्लायोगि
<u>'''Āsaṅga Plāyogi'''</u> is a king who appears in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_292> viii. 1, 32. 33.</ref> as a generous patron. Owing, however, to the addition of a curious phallic verse to the hymn, and its early misunderstanding,<ref name=fx2_ve1_292> viii. 1, 34. See Hopkins, ''Religions of India,'' 150, n. 1;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, ii. 83;<br> vi. 41, with Macdonell's notes. Dyādvi. eda gives the tale at length in Vedic words taken from the Nighaṇṭu, a curious ''jeu d'esprit.'' See the extract from the Nītimañjarī given by Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 40, 41.</ref> a legend was invented that he lost his manhood and became a woman, but by the intercession of '''[[मेध्यातिथि|Medhyātithi]]''' was transformed into a man, much to the delight of his wife, '''[[शश्वती|Śaśvatī]],''' whose existence is based on a misunderstanding of the phrase ‘every woman’ (''[[शश्वती|śaśvatī]] [[नारी|nārī]]'') in the added verse.<ref name=fx3_ve1_292> viii. 1, 34.</ref> Another misunderstanding  of the Dānastuti<ref name=fx4_ve1_292> viii. 1, 31. 32. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 159;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 89;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 106, 107;<br> Oldenberg. ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 354.</ref> gives him a son [[स्वनद्-रथ|Svanad-ratha]], really a mere epithet, and makes him a descendant of Yadu.

आ-सन्दी
<u>'''Ā-sandī.'''</u>--This is a generic term for a seat of some sort, occurring frequently in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_293> Av. xiv. 2, 65;<br> xv. 3, 2 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 8, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 56;<br> xix. 16;<br> 86, etc.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_293> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5;<br> 6;<br> 12;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 26;<br> v. 2, 1, 22;<br> 4, 4, 1, etc.</ref> but not in the Rigveda. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_293> xv. 3, 2 ''et seq.''</ref> the settle brought for the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]]''' is described at length. It had two feet, lengths wise and cross-pieces, forward and cross-cords, showing that it was made of wood and also cording. It was also covered with a cushion ('''[[आस्तरण|Āstaraṇa]]''') and a pillow ('''[[उपबर्हण|Upabarhaṇa]]'''), had a seat ('''[[आसाद|Āsāda]]''') and a support ('''Upaśraya'''). Similar seats are described in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_293> i. 5. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 397;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Aranyaka,'' 19.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_293> ii. 24.</ref> The seat for the king at the royal consecration is described in very similar terms in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx6_ve1_293> viii. 5;<br> 6;<br> 12.</ref> where the height of the feet is placed at a span, and the lengthwise and cross-pieces are each to be a cubit, while the interwoven part (''[[विवयन|vivayana]]'') is to be of [[मुञ्ज|Muñja]] grass, and the seat of [[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]] wood. In another passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_293> xiv. 2, 65. See his note in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 765.</ref> Lanman seems to take the seat meant as a ‘long reclining chair.’ There also a cushion ('''[[उपधान|Upadhāna]]''') and coverlet ('''Upavāsana''') are mentioned. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] repeatedly describes the [[आसन्दी|Āsandī]] in terms showing that it was an elaborate seat. In one place<ref name=fx8_ve1_293> v. 4, 4, 1.</ref> it is said to be made of [[खदिर|Khadira]] wood, perforated (''vi-tṛṇṇā''), and joined with straps (''[[वर्ध्र|vardhra]]-yutā'') like that of the Bhāratas. At the [[सौत्रामणी|Sautrāmaṇī]] rite<ref name=fx9_ve1_293> xii. 8, 3, 4 ''et seq.''</ref> (an Indra sacrifice) the seat is of [[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]] wood, is knee-high, and of unlimited width and depth, and is covered with plaited reed-work. The  imperial seat<ref name=fx10_ve1_293> xiv. 1, 3, 8 ''et seq.''</ref> is to be shoulder-high, of [[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]] wood, and wound all over with cords of Balvaja grass (''Eleusina indica''). Elsewhere<ref name=fx11_ve1_293> vi. 7, 1, 12 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 155.</ref> the seat is a span high, a cubit in width and depth, of [[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]] wood, and covered with reed-grass cords, and daubed with clay.

आसन्दी-वन्त्
<u>'''Āsandī-vant,'''</u> ‘possessing the throne,’ is the title of the royal city of '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]] [[पारिक्षित|Pārikṣita]],''' in which the horse, for his famous [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], was bound. The authorities both cite a [[गाथा|Gāthā]] for the fact, but they differ as to the priest who celebrated the rite. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_294> xiii. 5, 4, 2.</ref> he is stated to have been [[इन्द्रोत दैवाप शौनक|Indrota <a class="pada_vei" href="दैवाप">Daivāpa]] Śaunaka», but in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_294> viii. 21. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 9, 1. Pāṇini, viii. 2, 12, knows the name.</ref> '''[[तुर कावषेय|Tura Kāvaṣeya]].'''

आ-साद
<u>'''Ā-sāda,'''</u> ‘seat,’ occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_295> xv. 3, 8.</ref> as a description of part of the settle ('''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]]''') of the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]].''' It seems best to regard it with Whitney<ref name=fx2_ve1_295> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 771.</ref> as the seat proper; Aufrecht,<ref name=fx3_ve1_295> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 131.</ref> Zimmer,<ref name=fx4_ve1_295> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 155.</ref> and Roth<ref name=fx5_ve1_295> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> render it as the ‘cushion for the seat,’ but that is sufficiently described by the word '''[[आस्तरण|Āstaraṇa]].'''

आसुरायण
<u>'''Āsurāyaṇa'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[त्रैवणि|Traivaṇi]]''' in the first two Vaṃśas<ref name=fx1_ve1_296> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3.</ref> (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] in both recensions, but as a pupil of '''[[आसुरि|Āsuri]]''' in the third [[वंश|Vaṃśa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_296> vi. 5, 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 434, n.</ref>

आसुरि
<u>'''Āsuri'''</u> occurs in the first two Vaṃśas<ref name=fx1_ve1_297> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3.</ref> (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] as a pupil of '''[[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]]''' and teacher of '''[[औपजन्धनि|Aupajandhani]],''' but in the third<ref name=fx2_ve1_297> vi. 5, 2.</ref> as a pupil of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]]''' and teacher of '''[[आसुरायण|Āsurāyaṇa]].''' He appears as a  ritual authority in the first four books of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_297> i. 6, 3, 26;<br> ii. 1, 4, 27;<br> 3, 1, 9;<br> 4, 1, 2;<br> 6, 1, 25. 33;<br> 3, 17;<br> iv. 5, 8, 14.</ref> and as an authority on dogmatic, specially noted for his insistence on truth, in the last book.<ref name=fx4_ve1_297> xiv. 1, 1, 33, and notes 1, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 430 ''et seq.,'' whose suggestion of the identity of this teacher and the founder of the Sāṃkhya system is not, however, acceptable. See Garbe, ''Sāṃkhya Philosophie,'' 29, 30.</ref>

आसुरि-वासिन्
<u>'''Āsuri-vāsin'''</u> is a name of '''[[प्राश्नी-पुत्र|Prāśnī-putra]]''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 2, in both recensions).<br>==Foot Notes==

आ-सेचन
<u>'''Ā-secana'''</u> designates a vessel to hold liquids, such as meat juice (''[[यूषन्|yūṣan]]'')<ref name=fx1_ve1_299> Rv. i. 162, 13.</ref> or ghee.<ref name=fx2_ve1_299> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 9, 5. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 271.</ref> Of its shape and make we know nothing.

आ-स्तरण
<u>'''Ā-staraṇa'''</u> denotes the coverlet of the settle ('''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]]''') of the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_300> Av. xv. 3, 7.</ref> A tiger's skin serves as the coverlet of the king's seat in the royal consecration ([[राजसूय|Rājasūya]]).<ref name=fx2_ve1_300> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5.</ref> In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_300> i. 5. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 155.</ref> the word used is '''[[उपस्तरण|Upastaraṇa]].'''

आस्त्र-बुध्न
<u>'''Āstra-budhna'''</u> is the name of a man whom Indra is said in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_301> x. 171, 3.</ref> to have assisted. It is not clear whether '''Venya,''' who is mentioned in the same line, was his friend<ref name=fx2_ve1_301> So Grassmann and Griffith in their translations.</ref> or his enemy,<ref name=fx3_ve1_301> So Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 167.</ref> whom Indra saved or defeated for him.

आ-स्थातृ
<u>'''Ā-sthātṛ.'''</u>--The warrior in the chariot is once thus designated (as ‘standing on the car’) in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_302> vi. 47, 26. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 296.</ref> Normally he is named '''[[रथिन्|Rathin]]''' or '''[[रथेष्ठा|Ratheṣṭhā]].''' 

आ-स्राव
<u>'''Ā-srāva'''</u> (‘discharge’) denotes a disease, thrice referred to in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_303> i. 2, 4;<br> ii. 3, 2;<br> vi. 44, 2.</ref> the precise nature of which is uncertain. The Scholiast<ref name=fx2_ve1_303> On Av. i. 2, 4. ''Cf.'' on ii. 3, 2.</ref> in one place interprets it as painful urination (''mūtrātisāra''), while Lanman<ref name=fx3_ve1_303> In Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 3.</ref> suggests diabetes. Bloomfield<ref name=fx4_ve1_303> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 7, 467;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, cxiii;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 233, 234.</ref> takes it to be diarrhœa, and Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve1_303> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 392.</ref> argues that as the remedy is called ‘wound healer’ (''arus-srāṇa''), the sense is ‘the flux from unhealed wounds.’ Whitney<ref name=fx6_ve1_303> ''Op. cit.,'' 3, 41.</ref> renders it ‘flux,’ and questions Bloomfield's rendering. Ludwig<ref name=fx7_ve1_303> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 507, 509.</ref> translates it vaguely by ‘sickness’ and ‘cold.’

आहनस्या
<u>'''Āhanasyā'''</u> (‘unchaste’).--This word in the plural (‘lascivious verses’) denotes a section (xx. 136) of the Kuntāpa hymns of the Atharvaveda, which are of an obscene character.<ref name=fx1_ve1_304> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 36;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 7. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 99.</ref>

आ-हाव
<u>'''Ā-hāva'''</u> denotes a pail or bucket, especially in conjunction with a well ('''[[अवत|Avata]]''').<ref name=fx1_ve1_305> Rv. i. 34, 8;<br> vi. 7, 2;<br> x. 101, 5;<br> 112, 6;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 26.</ref>

आह्नेय
<u>'''Āhneya.'''</u>--Patronymic of '''Sauca''' ([[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

इक्षु
<u>'''Ikṣu,'''</u> the generic name for the sugar-cane, is first found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_307> i. 34, 5.</ref> and the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve1_307> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 7, 9;<br> iv. 2, 9 (''[[इक्षु|ikṣu]]-kāṇḍa''). In Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhiṭā, vii. 3, 16, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], in. 8, ‘eyelash’ is meant. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Whether it grew wild, or was cultivated, does not appear from the references. 

इक्ष्वाकु
<u>'''Ikṣvāku.'''</u>--In the Rigveda this name occurs but once,<ref name=fx1_ve1_308> x. 60, 4.</ref> and in a doubtful context. It is clear, however, that it denotes a prince; later interpretations make '''Asamāti,''' whose name is read into the hymn, an [[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]] prince.<ref name=fx2_ve1_308> ''Cf.'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 167;<br> Sāṭyāyanaka in Max Müller, Rigveda, 4, c-cvii, 167;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 42;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 85 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_308> xiv. 39, 9. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 680;<br> Whitney Translation of the Atharvaveda, 961.</ref> also the name is found in only one passage, where it is uncertain whether a descendant of [[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]], or [[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]] himself, is referred to; in either case he seems to be regarded as an ancient hero. In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_308> xiii. 3, 12.</ref> mention is made of '''Tryaruṇa [[त्रैधात्व|Traidhātva]]''' [[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]], who is identical with the '''Tryaruṇa [[त्रैवृष्ण|Traivṛṣṇa]]''' of the Bṛhaddevatā,<ref name=fx5_ve1_308> v. 14 ''et seq.''</ref> and with '''Tryaruṇa [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx6_ve1_308> v. 27, 3. ''Cf.'' Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 68-75;<br> Macdonell, ''Bṛhaddevatā,'' 2, 170;<br> Oldenberg, ''Vedic Hymns,'' 366 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133, 138;<br> 4, 324.</ref> The connection of [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] with the Ikṣvākus is confirmed by the fact that '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]]''' was an [[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]], according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx7_ve1_308> xiii. 5, 4, 5.</ref> Thus the [[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]] line was originally a line of princes of the Pūrus. Zimmer<ref name=fx8_ve1_308> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 104, 130.</ref> places them on the upper Indus, but they may well have been somewhat further east.<ref name=fx9_ve1_308> ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218;<br> Geldner, ''ibid.,'' 3, 152.</ref> Later [[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]] is connected with Ayodhyā

इट
<u>'''1. Iṭa.'''</u>--This word occurs twice in the Atharvaveda. in the first passage<ref name=fx1_ve1_309> vi. 14, 3. ''Cf.'' iv. 19, 1;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 464.</ref> it seems to denote a bulrush of the sort that dies in a year; in the second<ref name=fx2_ve1_309> ix. 3, 18. ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 718.</ref> it refers to the reed work of the house.

इट
<u>'''2. Iṭa'''</u> appears as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] and a protégé of Indra in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_310> x. 171, 1.</ref> Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_310> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> however, thinks that the word is really part of a verb (''iṭ'') meaning ‘to err, wander’ (cp. ''aṭ''), and  that the name is a mere misunderstanding. It is already so regarded in the Anukramaṇī, but not apparently in the Bṛhaddevatā.<ref name=fx3_ve1_310> viii. 73. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133.</ref>

इटन्त् काव्य
<u>'''Iṭant Kāvya'''</u> is the name of a sage, contemporary with '''[[केशिन् दार्भ्य|Keśin Dārbhya]],''' in the Kauṣitaki [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_311> vii. 4. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 293;<br> 2, 308.</ref> He is also mentioned as Iḍhant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_311> xiv. 9, 16.</ref>

इतिहास
<u>'''Itihāsa,'''</u> as a kind of literature, is repeatedly mentioned along with '''[[पुराण|Purāṇa]]''' in the later texts of the Vedic period. The earliest reference to both occurs in the late fifteenth book of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_312> xv. 6, 4 ''et seq.''</ref> [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] then appears in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_312> xiii. 4, 3, 12. 13, and as compounded in xi. 5, 6, 8;<br> 7, 9.</ref> the Jaiminīya,<ref name=fx3_ve1_312> i. 53.</ref> Bṛhadāraṇyaka,<ref name=fx4_ve1_312> ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 2;<br> v. 11.</ref> and Chāndogya Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx5_ve1_312> iii. 4, 1. 2;<br> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> In the latter it is expressly declared with [[पुराण|Purāṇa]] to make up the fifth Veda, while the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_312> xvi. 2, 21. 27.</ref> makes the [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] a Veda and the [[पुराण|Purāṇa]] a Veda. The [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]-veda and the [[पुराण|Purāṇa]]-veda appear also in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx7_ve1_312> i. 10.</ref> while the Śatapatha<ref name=fx8_ve1_312> xiii. 4, 3, 12. 13.</ref> identifies the [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] as well as the [[पुराण|Purāṇa]] with the Veda. In one passage '''[[अन्वाख्यान|Anvākhyāna]]''' and [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] are distinguished<ref name=fx9_ve1_312> xi. 1, 6, 9. ''Cf.'' p. 24.</ref> as different classes of works, but the exact point of distinction is obscure; probably the former was supplementary. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx10_ve1_312> ii. 9.</ref> mentions Itihāsas and Purāṇas in the plural.<br><br>There is nothing to show in the older literature what distinction there was, if any, between [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] and [[पुराण|Purāṇa]]; and the late literature,<ref name=fx11_ve1_312> See Sāyaṇa's Introduction to the Rigveda, p. 12 (ed. Max Müller), and his commentary on Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 6, 8;<br> Śaṃkara on Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 10.</ref> which has been elaborately examined by Sieg,<ref name=fx12_ve1_312> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 31 ''et seq.''</ref> yields no consistent result. Geldner<ref name=fx13_ve1_312> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 290. ''Cf.'' Sieg, ''op. cit.,'' 33.</ref> has conjectured that there existed a single work, the [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]-[[पुराण|purāṇa]], a collection  of the old legends of all sorts, heroic, cosmogonic, genealogical; but though a work called [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]], and another called [[पुराण|Purāṇa]], were probably known to Patañjali,<ref name=fx14_ve1_312> Vārttika on Pāṇini, iv. 2, 60, and Mahābhāṣya (ed. Kielhorn), 2, 284.</ref> the inaccuracy of Geldner's view is proved by the fact that [[यास्क|Yāska]] shows no sign of having known any such work. To him the [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] may be a part of the [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] literature itself,<ref name=fx15_ve1_312> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 6.</ref> Aitihāsikas being merely people who interpret the Rigveda by seeing in it legends where others see myths.<ref name=fx16_ve1_312> ''Ibid.,'' ii. 16;<br> xii. 1.</ref> The fact, however, that the use of the compound form is rare, and that [[यास्क|Yāska]] regularly has [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]],<ref name=fx17_ve1_312> ''Ibid.,'' ii. 10;<br> 24;<br> iv. 6;<br> x. 26;<br> xii. 10.</ref> not [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]-[[पुराण|purāṇa]], is against the theory of there ever having been one work.<br><br>The relation of [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] to '''[[आख्यान|Ākhyāna]]''' is also uncertain. Sieg<ref name=fx18_ve1_312> ''Op. cit.,'' 31 ''et seq.''</ref> considers that the words [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] and [[पुराण|Purāṇa]] referred to the great body of mythology, legendary history, and cosmogonic legend available to the Vedic poets, and roughly classed as a fifth Veda, though not definitely and finally fixed. Thus, Anvākhyānas, '''Anuvyākhyānas,''' and '''Vyākhyānas''' could arise, and separate Ākhyānas could still exist outside the cycle, while an [[आख्यान|Ākhyāna]] could also be a part of the [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]-[[पुराण|purāṇa]]. He also suggests that the word [[आख्यान|Ākhyāna]] has special reference to the form of the narrative. Oldenberg,<ref name=fx19_ve1_312> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 37, 54 ''et seq.;<br>'' 39, 52 ''et seq. Cf.'' also ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1908, 67 ''et seq.''</ref> following Windisch,<ref name=fx20_ve1_312> ''Verhandlungen der dreiunddreissigsten Versammlung deutcher Philologen und Sckulmänner in Gera'' (1879), 15 ''et seq.''</ref> and followed by Geldner,<ref name=fx21_ve1_312> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 284;<br> 2, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> Sieg, and others, has found in the [[आख्यान|Ākhyāna]] form a mixture of prose and verse, alternating as the narrative was concerned with the mere accessory parts of the tale, or with the chief points, at which the poetic form was naturally produced to correspond with the stress of the emotion. This theory has been severely criticized by Hertel<ref name=fx22_ve1_312> ''Vienna Oriental Journal,'' 18, 59 ''et seq.;<br>'' 23, 273 ''et seq. Cf.'' Winternitz, ''ibid.,'' 23, 102 ''et seq.''</ref> and von Schroeder.<ref name=fx23_ve1_312> ''Mystcrium und Mimus im Rigveda,'' 3 ''et seq.''</ref> These scholars, in accordance with older suggestions of Max Müller<ref name=fx24_ve1_312> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 183.</ref> and Lévi,<ref name=fx25_ve1_312> ''Le Théâtre indien,'' 303, 307.</ref> see in the  so-called [[आख्यान|Ākhyāna]] hymns of the Rigveda, in which Oldenberg finds actual specimens of the supposed literary genus, though the prose has been lost, actual remains of ritual dramas. Elsewhere<ref name=fx26_ve1_312> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 200 ''et seq.''</ref> it has been suggested that the hymns in question are merely literary dialogues.

इद्
<u>'''Id-, Idā-, Idu- Vatsara.'''</u> See '''[[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

इन्द्र-गोप
<u>'''Indra-gopa'''</u> (‘protected by Indra’), masc., is a designation of the cochineal insect in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 3, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

इन्द्र-द्युम्न भाल्लवेय वैयाघ्र-पद्य
<u>'''Indra-[[द्युम्न|dyumna]] [[भाल्लवेय|Bhāllaveya]] Vaiyāghra-padya'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher who with others was unable to agree as to the nature of Agni Vaiśvānara, and who was instructed by '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]] [[कैकेय|Kaikeya]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_315> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 1, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> As [[भाल्लवेय|Bhāllaveya]] he is cited several times in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_315> i. 6, 1, 19;<br> xiii. 5, 3, 4. ''Cf.'' ii. 1, 4. 6.</ref> on ritual points.

इन्द्र-भू काश्यप
<u>'''Indra-bhū Kāśyapa'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[मित्रभू काश्यप|Mitrabhū Kāśyapa]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_316> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 374.</ref>

इन्द्रोत
<u>'''1. Indrota'''</u> is twice mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_317> viii. 68, 10 ''et seq.''</ref> in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Liberality’) as a giver of gifts. In the second passage he has the epithet [[आतिथिग्व|Ātithigva]], which shows conclusively that he was a son of [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]], as Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_317> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> holds, and not of [[ऋक्ष|Ṛkṣa]], as Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_317> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> states.

इन्द्रोत दैवाप शौनक
<u>'''2. Indrota [[दैवाप|Daivāpa]] Śaunaka'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_318> xiii. 5, 3, 5;<br> 4, 1;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 7, 7;<br> 8, 27.</ref> as the priest who officiated at the horse  sacrifice of '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]],''' although this honour is attributed in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_318> viii. 21.</ref> to '''[[तुर कावषेय|Tura Kāvaṣeya]].''' He also appears in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_318> iii. 40, 1.</ref> as a pupil of '''Śruta,''' and is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_318> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 384, 385.</ref> He cannot be connected in any way with '''Devāpi,''' who occurs in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx5_ve1_318> x. 98. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 240.</ref>

इभ
<u>'''1. Ibha'''</u> is a word of somewhat doubtful sense and interpretation. It is found only in the Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_319> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 2, 14, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 9.</ref> and especially in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_319> i. 84, 17;<br> iv. 4, 1;<br> ix. 57, 3, and perhaps vi. 20, 8.</ref> According to Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_319> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve1_319> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 246, 247.</ref> the sense is ‘retainer,’ and Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve1_319> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 167.</ref> thinks that it includes not only dependants and servants, but also the royal family and the youthful cadets of the chief families. In the opinion of Pischel and Geldner<ref name=fx6_ve1_319> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xv, xvi.</ref> it denotes ‘elephant.’ This view is supported by the authority of the commentators Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx7_ve1_319> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> and Mahīdhara;<ref name=fx8_ve1_319> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx9_ve1_319> vi. 12. It gives also the sense ‘retainer,’ and in Aśoka's Edicts, No. 5, Bühler, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 37, 279, finds a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] denoted by its Pāli form.</ref> too, gives ‘elephant’ as one of the senses of the word. Megasthenes<ref name=fx10_ve1_319> ''Apud'' Strabo, 704.</ref> and Nearchos<ref name=fx11_ve1_319> ''Ibid.,'' 705.</ref> tell us that elephants were a royal prerogative, and the derivative word '''[[इभ्य|Ibhya]]''' may thus be naturally explained as denoting merely ‘rich’ (lit., ‘possessor of elephants’).<ref name=fx12_ve1_319> But it may equally well be explained as ‘rich’ from the other sense of the primary word: ‘possessor of (many) retainers.’</ref>

इभ
<u>'''2. Ibha'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_320> vi. 20, 8. ''Cf.'' Pischel and Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xvi;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 380. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 167, treats it as ‘retinue,’ as does Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 246, 247.</ref> appears certainly to be intended as an abbreviation of the proper name '''[[स्मद्इभ|Smadibha]].''' 

इभ्य
<u>'''Ibhya'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_321> i. 65, 4.</ref> in the plural, when a king is said to devour his Ibhyas as the fire the forest; and twice in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_321> i. 10, 1. 2.</ref> in one passage as the first member of a compound, and in the other as either a proper name or an adjective. Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_321> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Ludwig,<ref name=fx4_ve1_321> Translation of the Rigveda 3, 247.</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve1_321> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 168.</ref> interpret the word as ‘retainers’ in the Rigveda, but in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] Roth thinks it means ‘rich.’ Pischel and Geldner<ref name=fx6_ve1_321> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xvi. ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa on Rigveda, ''loc. cit., dhaninaḥ,'' and Śaṃkara on Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit., īśvaro hastyāroho vā;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 476. ''Cf.'' also Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 35.</ref> accept the sense in all passages. Bo7htlingk in his translation of the Chāndogya treats the word as simply a proper name, ‘Ibhya's village’ (''[[इभ्य|ibhya]]-[[ग्राम|grāma]]'') and ‘Ibhya.’

इरिण
<u>'''Iriṇa'''</u> (neut.) occurs not rarely in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_322> Av. iv. 15, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 3;<br> iii. 4, 8, 5;<br> v. 2, 4, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 16.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve1_322> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 3, 2;<br> vii. 2, 1, 8.</ref> in the sense of ‘a cleft in the ground,’ usually natural (''sva-[[कृत|kṛta]]''). The same meaning is also, as Pischel<ref name=fx3_ve1_322> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 222-225.</ref> shows, to be ascribed to it in three passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_322> i. 186, 9;<br> viii. 4, 3;<br> 87, 1. 4.</ref> in one<ref name=fx5_ve1_322> viii. 4, 3.</ref> of which the hole is referred to as ‘made by water’ (''apā kṛtam''). In another passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_322> x. 34, 1. 9.</ref> the word refers to the place on which the dice are thrown. Hence Pischel<ref name=fx7_ve1_322> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 225.</ref> concludes that the dicing-board must have been so called because it contained holes into which the dice had to be thrown if possible. Lüders,<ref name=fx8_ve1_322> ''Das Würfelspiel im alben Indian,'' 14.</ref> however, points out that this assumption is not necessary; the dice ('''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]''') were merely thrown on a space dug out, which could be called '''[[इरिण|Iriṇa]],''' as being a hole in the ground, though not a natural one. This view is supported by the commentary of Sāyaṇa,<ref name=fx9_ve1_322> On Rv., ''loc. cit. (ā-sphūra).''</ref> as well as by [[दुर्ग|Durga]] in his note on the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx10_ve1_322> ix. 8 (''āsphuraka-sthāna'').</ref> 

इष श्यावाश्वि
<u>'''Iṣa Śyāvāśvi'''</u> is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (‘list of teachers’) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iv. 16, 1) as a pupil of [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]].<br>==Foot Notes==

इषीका
<u>'''Iṣīkā,'''</u> ‘a stalk of reed grass,’ occurs frequently from the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_324> Av. vii. 56, 4;<br> xii. 2, 54;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 4, 16, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9;<br> ii. 134;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 24, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 6, 17, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 8.</ref> onwards, often as an emblem of fragility. In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve1_324> ii. 16 (''v. l. ºike'').</ref> it seems to denote the pin fixed in the bar of a pen to keep cattle in (''argaleṣīke,'' ‘bolt and pin’). A basket (''[[शूर्प|śūrpa]]'') of [[इषीका|Iṣīkā]] is referred to in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_324> i. 1, 4, 19.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71;<br> Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 122, n. 3.</ref>

इषु
<u>'''Iṣu'''</u> is the usual name for ‘arrow’ from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_325> ii. 24, 8;<br> viii. 7, 4, etc.;<br> Av. i. 13, 4, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 3, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 18.</ref> onwards. Other names are '''[[शर्य|Śarya]], Śārī,''' and '''[[बाण|Bāṇa]].''' In the hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_325> vi. 75, 15.</ref> which gives a catalogue of armour, two kinds of arrows are distinctly referred to: the one is poisoned (''ālāktā''), and has a head of horn (''ruru-śīrṣṇī''); the other is copper-, bronze-, or iron-headed (''ayo-mukham''). Poisoned (''digdhā'') arrows are also referred to in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_325> iv. 6, 7;<br> v. 18, 8. 15;<br> 31, 4.</ref> The arrows were feathered.<ref name=fx4_ve1_325> Rv. x. 18, 14;<br> vi. 75, 11;<br> Av. v. 25, 1.</ref> The parts of an arrow are enumerated in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_325> iv. 6.</ref> as the shaft (''[[शल्य|śalya]]''), the feather-socket (''[[पर्ण-धि|parṇa-dhi]]''), the point (''[[शृङ्ग|śṛṅga]]''), the neck of the point in which the shaft is fixed (''[[कुल्मल|kulmala]]''), and the '''[[अपस्कम्भ|Apaskambha]]''' and '''[[अपाष्ठ|Apāṣṭha]],''' which are of more doubtful significance. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_325> i. 25.</ref> the parts of an arrow are given as the point (''anīka''), the ''[[शल्य|śalya]], [[तेजन|tejana]],'' and the feathers (''parṇāni''), where ''[[शल्य|śalya]]'' and ''[[तेजन|tejana]]'' must apparently mean the upper and lower parts of the shaft, since it is reasonable to suppose that the arrow is described as a whole consecutively. So in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_325> Av. iii. 25, 2.</ref> the arrow of Kāma is described as having feathers, a shaft  (''[[शल्य|śalya]]''), and a firm fastening (''[[कुल्मल|kulmala]]'').<ref name=fx8_ve1_325> See also Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8, 1. 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 1.</ref> The arrow was shot from the ear, and so is described in the Rigveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_325> Rv. vi. 75, 3;<br> ii. 24, 8 (''karṇayoni'').</ref> as ‘having the ear for its place of birth.’<br><br>As a measure of length, the [[इषु|Iṣu]] was five spans, say three feet.<ref name=fx10_ve1_325> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5, 2, 10.</ref> A regular profession of arrow-making existed (''[[इषु|iṣu]]-kṛt,''<ref name=fx11_ve1_325> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 46, ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 184, 3.</ref> ''[[इषु|iṣu]]-kāra'').<ref name=fx12_ve1_325> ''Ibid.,'' xxx. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 300;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 29, 286;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 275 ''et seq.;<br>'' 25, 337.</ref>

इषु त्रि-काण्डा
<u>'''Iṣu Tri-kāṇḍā'''</u> is the name given in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_326> iii. 33. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 205, n.</ref> to some constellation, perhaps Orion's girdle. It is mentioned with '''[[मृग|Mṛga]], [[मृगव्याध|Mṛgavyādha]],''' and '''[[रोहिणी|Rohiṇī]].'''

इषु-धि
<u>'''Iṣu-dhi'''</u> (‘arrow-holder’) is the name of the quiver which was carried by every bowman. The word is common from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_327> i. 33, 3;<br> vi. 75, 5;<br> x. 95, 3;<br> Av. ii. 33, 2;<br> iv. 10, 6, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 13.</ref> onwards. No trace is to be found in Vedic literature of the later practice of carrying two quivers.<ref name=fx2_ve1_327> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 274. Each quiver held from ten to twenty arrows.</ref> According to Pischel,<ref name=fx3_ve1_327> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 17. But see Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 182.</ref> the curious expression ''[[इषु|iṣu]]-kṛt'' in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_327> i. 184, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 300.</ref> means quiver.

ईषा
<u>'''Īṣā'''</u> denotes the ‘pole of a chariot.’ Normally the chariot had one pole (''ekeṣaḥ''),<ref name=fx1_ve1_328> Rv. x. 135, 3;<br> iii. 53, 17;<br> viii. 5, 29;<br> Av. viii. 8, 23.</ref> but sometimes two poles are referred to.<ref name=fx2_ve1_328> ''Cf.'' Av. ii. 8, 4;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 12 (''[[ईषा|īṣā]]-yugāni,'' but in iii. 9, 4, 3 dual);<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 9, 14, etc.</ref> The word is often<ref name=fx3_ve1_328> Av., ''loc. cit.,'' etc.</ref> compounded with '''Yuga,''' ‘yoke,’ into which it was fastened (see '''Kha'''), and tied with ropes.<ref name=fx4_ve1_328> Rv. x. 60, 8. ''Cf.'' iii. 6, 6.</ref> Exactly how it was attached to the chariot we do not know.<ref name=fx5_ve1_328> ''[[वाणी|Vāṇī]]'' in Rv. i. 119, 5 is taken by Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 249, to refer to the front part of the chariot, but it seems simply to be ‘voice.’</ref> See also '''[[रथ|Ratha]].''' 

उक्षन्
<u>'''Ukṣan.'''</u> See '''Go.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

उक्षण्यायन
<u>'''Ukṣaṇyāyana'''</u> is mentioned in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_330> viii. 25, 22.</ref> along with '''[[हरयाण|Harayāṇa]]''' and '''[[सुषामन्|Suṣāman]].''' Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_330> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 162, 270.</ref> thinks that all three are identical. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_330> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> finds a reference to [[उक्षन्|Ukṣan]] himself in the verb ''ukṣaṇyati''<ref name=fx4_ve1_330> Rv. viii. 26, 9.</ref> and in the adjective ''ukṣaṇyu.''<ref name=fx5_ve1_330> Rv. viii. 23, 16.</ref>

उक्ष्णो-रन्ध्र काव्य
<u>'''Ukṣṇo-[[रन्ध्र|randhra]] Kāvya'''</u> is mentioned as a seer in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 9, 19).<ref name=fx1_ve1_331> ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 397.</ref>

उखा
<u>'''Ukhā'''</u> is the regular word or a ‘cooking pot,’ usually mentioned in connexion with sacrifice, from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_332> i. 162, 13. 15;<br> iii. 53, 22;<br> Av. xii. 3, 23;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 6, 3, etc.</ref> onwards. It was made of clay (''mṛṇ-mayī'').<ref name=fx2_ve1_332> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 59;<br> Taitdrīya Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 5, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 253, 271.</ref> See also '''[[स्थाली|Sthālī]].'''

उग्र
<u>'''Ugra'''</u> in one passage of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_333> iv. 3, 37. 38.</ref> seems to have a technical force, denoting ‘man in authority,’ or according to Max Müller's rendering, ‘policeman.’ Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_333> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> compares a passage in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_333> vii. 38, 6.</ref> where, however, the word has simply the general sense of ‘mighty man.’ Bo7htlingk,<ref name=fx4_ve1_333> P. 66 (with ''pratyenasaḥ'').</ref> in his rendering of the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], treats the word as merely adjectival.

उग्र-देव
<u>'''Ugra-deva'''</u> is mentioned with '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]''' and '''Yadu''' in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_334> i. 36, 18 (Ugrādeva).</ref> apparently as a powerful protector. The name occurs also in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_334> xiv. 3, 17;<br> xxiii. 16, 11.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx3_ve1_334> v. 4, 12.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 147;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' who suggests that in the Rv. passage the word should be taken adjectivally.</ref> where he is styled '''[[राजनि|Rājani]]''' and called a leper (''[[किलास|kilāsa]]''). 

उग्र-सेन
<u>'''Ugra-sena'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 5, 4, 3), and in a [[गाथा|Gāthā]] there cited as being, with '''[[भीमसेन|Bhīmasena]]''' and '''[[श्रुतसेन|Śrutasena]],''' a Pārikṣitīya and a brother of '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]].''' The brothers were cleansed by the horse sacrifice from sin.<br>==Foot Notes==

उच्चैः-श्रवस् कौपयेय
<u>'''Uccaiḥ-śravas Kaupayeya'''</u> appears in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 29, 1-3) as a king of the '''Kurus''' and as maternal uncle of '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]].''' His connexion with the Kurus is borne out by the fact that '''[[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]]''' was son of '''Kuruśravaṇa,''' the names being strikingly similar.<br>==Foot Notes==

उच्-छीर्षक
<u>'''Uc-chīrṣaka.'''</u>--This word, occurring in the description of the couch (''[[पर्य्अङ्क|paryaṅka]]'') in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_337> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 403;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 155.</ref> (i. 5), apparently denotes a cushion for the head. See also '''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]].'''

उत्तर कुरु
<u>'''Uttara Kuru.'''</u>--The Uttara Kurus, who play a mythical part in the Epic and later literature, are still a historical people in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_338> viii. 14.</ref> where they are located beyond the Himālaya (''pareṇa Himavantam''). In another passage,<ref name=fx2_ve1_338> viii. 23.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 165;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 101, 102;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 75, n.</ref> however, the country of the Uttara Kurus is stated by '''[[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] [[सात्यहव्य|Sātyahavya]]''' to be a land of the gods (''deva-[[क्षेत्र|kṣetra]]''), but '''[[जानंतपि|Jānaṃtapi]] Atyarāti''' was anxious to conquer it, so that it is still not wholly mythical. It is reasonable to accept Zimmer's view that the northern Kurus were settled in Kaśmīr, especially as '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]]''' is the region where tribes advancing from Kaśmīr might naturally be found. ''Cf.'' '''[[उद्ईच्यस्|Udīcyas]].'''

उत्तर मद्र
<u>'''Uttara Madra'''</u> is the name of a tribe mentioned with the '''Uttara Kurus''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_339> viii. 14.</ref> as living beyond the Himālaya. Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_339> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 102.</ref> points out that in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_339> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 371.</ref> '''[[काम्बोज|Kāmboja]] [[औपमन्यव|Aupamanyava]]''' is a pupil of '''Madragāra,''' and thence  infers that Kambojas and Madras were not far distant in space. This conclusion is perfectly reasonable in view of the probable position of the Kāmbojas.<ref name=fx4_ve1_339> See map in Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, p. 332. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 165.</ref>

उत्-तान आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Ut-tāna Āṅgirasa'''</u> is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_340> ii. 3, 2, 5. ''Cf.'' ii. 2, 5, 3.</ref> as a quasi-mythical person who received all good things, and yet was not harmed, as he was really a form of the earth, according to Sāyaṇa's<ref name=fx2_ve1_340> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 2, 5.</ref> explanation. His name occurs also in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_340> ix. 9.</ref> the Pancaviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_340> i. 8, 11.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx5_ve1_340> iii. 10, 2. 3.</ref>

उदग्-अयन
<u>'''Udag-ayana.'''</u> See '''[[सूर्य|Sūrya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

उद्-अङ्क शौल्बायन
<u>'''Ud-[[अङ्क|aṅka]] Śaulbāyana.'''</u>--His views on [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], which he identified with the vital airs (''[[प्राण|prāṇa]]''), are mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 1, 3). He would thus have been a contemporary of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' of [[विदेह|Videha]]. He is also mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vii. 5, 4, 2) as holding that the Daśarātra ceremony was the prosperity or best part of the Sattra (‘sacrificial session’).<br>==Foot Notes==

उद्-अञ्चन
<u>'''Ud-añcana.'''</u>--This word, occurring only metaphorically in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_343> v. 44, 13 (''dhiyām udañcanaḥ,'' ‘a very well of prayers’).</ref> means a ‘pail’ or ‘bucket’ in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_343> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 32;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 5, 21.</ref>

उदमय आत्रेय
<u>'''Udamaya Ātreya'''</u> is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 22) as [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or domestic priest, of '''[[अङ्ग वैरोचन|Aṅga Vairocana]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

उदर शाण्डिल्य
<u>'''Udara Śāṇḍilya'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_345> i. 9, 3.</ref> and as a pupil of '''[[अतिधन्वन् शौनक|Atidhanvan Śaunaka]]''' in the '''[[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_345> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 384.</ref>

उदल
<u>'''Udala,'''</u> a [[वैश्वामित्र|Vaiśvāmitra]], is mentioned in the Pañcaviṃsa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 11, 33) as the seer of a Sāman. <br>==Foot Notes==

उद्-आज
<u>'''Ud-āja'''</u> is the word used in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_347> i. 10, 16;<br> iv. 3, 1.</ref> to denote the share of the booty of war taken by the king after a victory (''saṃgrāmaṃ jitvā''). This interpretation, which is that of Delbrück,<ref name=fx2_ve1_347> ''Festgruss an Bo7htlingk,'' 25.</ref> is clearly correct, as against the older version, ‘march out,’ given by von Schroeder<ref name=fx3_ve1_347> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, 1, xv.</ref> and accepted by Bo7htlingk.<ref name=fx4_ve1_347> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> The [[उद्आज|Udāja]] thus corresponds precisely with the Homeric  This sense also suits Nirāja, the variant of both the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_347> xxviii. 3.</ref> and the Kapiṣṭhala<ref name=fx6_ve1_347> xliv. 3.</ref> Saṃhitās.

उदान
<u>'''Udāna'''</u> is usually the fifth of the vital breaths ('''[[प्राण|Prāṇa]]''') when five are enumerated.<ref name=fx1_ve1_348> ''E.g.,'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, v. 4;<br> 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 2, 2, 5;<br> xi. 8, 3, 6 (in the order [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]], [[अपान|Apāna]], [[उदान|Udāna]], [[समान|Samāna]]);<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 3;<br> iii. 4, 1 ([[समान|Samāna]] is omitted);<br> iii. 9, 26;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 13, 5;<br> v. 23, 1. 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 3, 3, etc.</ref> Sometimes<ref name=fx2_ve1_348> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 20;<br> vii. 27;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4, 2, 10, etc. (with [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]]);<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 2 (with [[समान|Samāna]]).</ref> it appears as the second, coming after [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], and followed by [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]] or [[समान|Samāna]]. Again,<ref name=fx3_ve1_348> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 20;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 2, 2;<br> ix. 2, 4, 5, etc.</ref> it is found simply opposed to [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], or it simply follows [[प्राण|Prāṇa]] and [[अपान|Apāna]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_348> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 8;<br> xi. 1.</ref> In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_348> xi. 2, 4, 5.</ref> it is treated as the breath that consumes food, a notion traceable in the later Upaniṣads,<ref name=fx6_ve1_348> Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 6.</ref> while it is also regarded as the wind that rises up by the throat,<ref name=fx7_ve1_348> Amṛtabindu [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], 34.</ref> and leads the spirit forth at death.<ref name=fx8_ve1_348> [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 7. ''Cf.'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upaniṣads,'' 280.</ref>

उद्-ईच्यस्
<u>'''Ud-īcyas.'''</u>--The Brāhmaṇas of the northern parts are referred to in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_349> xi. 4, 1, 1. ''Cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6.</ref> as engaging, with '''[[स्वैदायन|Svaidāyana]] [[शौनक|Śaunaka]]''' as their spokesman, in a dispute with the Kurupañcāla [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] '''[[उद्दालक आरुणि|Uddālaka Āruṇi]],''' and as vanquishing him. Their relation to the Kurupañcālas appears also from the fact that in  the same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_349> iii. 2, 3, 15. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 191;<br> Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 35.</ref> reference is made to the speech of the north being similar to that of the Kurupañcālas.
