The speech of the Northerners was also celebrated for purity; hence Brāhmaṇas used to go to the north for purposes of study, according to the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_349> vii. 6. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 153;<br> 2, 309.</ref> while in the Buddhist texts the school of Takṣaśilā (in [[गन्धार|Gandhāra]]) is famous as a resort of students.<ref name=fx4_ve1_349> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 8, 28, 203.</ref> Possibly, too, Sanskrit was specially developed in Kaśmīr, as suggested by Franke.<ref name=fx5_ve1_349> ''Cf. Pāli und Sanskrit'' (1902), 88, 89.</ref> See also '''Kuru.'''

उदुम्बर
<u>'''Udumbara.'''</u>--This name of the ''Ficus glomerata'' does not occur in the Rigveda, but is often found from the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_350> xix. 31, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 6, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 33;<br> vii. 4, 1, 38, etc.</ref> onwards. For ritual purposes of all kinds its wood was constantly used. The sacrificial post (''[[यूप|yūpa]]'')<ref name=fx2_ve1_350> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 6.</ref> and the sacrificial ladle<ref name=fx3_ve1_350> ''Ibid.,'' v. 4, 7, 3.</ref> were made of it, and amulets of [[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]] are mentioned.<ref name=fx4_ve1_350> Atharvaveda, xix. 31, 1.</ref> Its wood, like that of other kinds of figtree-'''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]], [[न्यग्रोध|Nyagrodha]],''' and '''[[प्लक्ष|Plakṣa]]'''--was considered suitable for employment at the sacrifice.<ref name=fx5_ve1_350> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8, 4.</ref> The sweetness of its fruit is referred to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx6_ve1_350> vii. 15.</ref> where it is put on the same level as '''[[मधु|Madhu]].''' It is there also spoken of as ripening three times a year.<ref name=fx7_ve1_350> v. 24.</ref> A forest of [[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]] trees is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx8_ve1_350> xvi. 6, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 59.</ref>

उद्दालक आरुणि
<u>'''Uddālaka Āruṇi.'''</u>--Uddālaka, son of Aruṇa, is one of the most prominent teachers of the Vedic period. He was a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] of the Kurupañcālas, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_351> xi. 4, 1, 2. ''Cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6.</ref> This statement is confirmed by the fact that he was teacher of '''Proti [[कौसुरुबिन्दि|Kausurubindi]]''' of Kauśāmbī,<ref name=fx2_ve1_351> xii. 2, 2, 13.</ref> and that his son  '''Svetaketu''' is found disputing among the Pañcālas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_351> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 1;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 3, 1.</ref> He was a pupil of Aruṇa, his father,<ref name=fx4_ve1_351> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 33 (in both recensions).</ref> as well as of [[पतञ्चल काप्य|Patañcala Kāpya]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_351> ''Ibid.,'' iii. 7, 1.</ref> of [[मद्र|Madra]], while he was the teacher of the famous [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_351> ''Ibid.,'' vi. 3, 15;<br> 4, 33.</ref> [[वाजसनेय|Vājasaneya]] and of [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]],<ref name=fx7_ve1_351> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xv.</ref> although the former is represented elsewhere<ref name=fx8_ve1_351> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 7, 31.</ref> as having silenced him. He overcame in argument [[प्राचीनयोग्य|Prācīnayogya]] [[शौचेय|Śauceya]],<ref name=fx9_ve1_351> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 3, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> and apparently also [[भद्रसेन आजातशत्रव|Bhadrasena Ājātaśatrava]],<ref name=fx10_ve1_351> v. 5, 5, 14. Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 141, has Āraṇi. There is a chronological difficulty in taking [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]] as meant, since [[आजातशत्रव|Ājātaśatrava]] must presumably have been a descendant of [[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]], a contemporary of [[जनक|Janaka]] (see [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1), who again was a patron of [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]], a pupil of [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]]. But this difficulty is not fatal.</ref> though the text here seems to read the name as Āraṇi. He was a [[गौतम|Gautama]],<ref name=fx11_ve1_351> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 3, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1.</ref> and is often alluded to as such. As an authority on questions of ritual and philosophy, he is repeatedly referred to by his patronymic name [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]] in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx12_ve1_351> i. 1, 2, 11;<br> ii. 2, 1, 34;<br> iii. 3, 4, 19;<br> iv. 4, 8, 9;<br> xi. 2, 6, 12.</ref> the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx13_ve1_351> iii. 5, 1.</ref> the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx14_ve1_351> iii. 11, 4;<br> v. 11, 2;<br> 17, 1;<br> vi. 8, 1.</ref> and occasionally in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]],<ref name=fx15_ve1_351> viii. 7.</ref> the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]],<ref name=fx16_ve1_351> xxvi. 4.</ref> and the Ṣaḍviṃśa<ref name=fx17_ve1_351> i. 6.</ref> Brāhmaṇas, as well as the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx18_ve1_351> i. 1 ''et seq.''</ref> In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā he is not mentioned, according to Geldner,<ref name=fx19_ve1_351> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 146.</ref> but only his father Aruṇa; his name does not occur, according to Weber,<ref name=fx20_ve1_351> ''Indian Literature,'' 69. But ''cf.'' xxiii. 1, 5.</ref> in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], but in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx21_ve1_351> vii. 8. ''Cf.'' viii. 6.</ref> he is, as [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]], known as a contemporary of '''[[दिवोदास भैमसेनि|Divodāsa Bhaimaseni]],''' and in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx22_ve1_351> i. 42, 1.</ref> he is mentioned as serving '''[[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] [[चैकितानेय|Caikitāneya]].''' In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] tradition he seldom appears. There is an allusion in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx23_ve1_351> vii. 2, 2, 1 (a late passage).</ref> to Kusurubinda [[औद्दालकि|Auddālaki]], and according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx24_ve1_351> iii. 11, 8, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> [[नचिकेतस्|Naciketas]] was a son of [[वाजश्रवस|Vājaśravasa]] [[गौतम|Gautama]], who  is made out to be Uddālaka by Sāyaṇa.<ref name=fx25_ve1_351> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit. Cf.'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 11.</ref> But the episode of [[नचिकेतस्|Naciketas]], being somewhat unreal, cannot be regarded as of historical value in proving relationship. Aruṇa is known to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā. A real son of Uddālaka was the famous '''[[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]],''' who is expressly reported by Āpastamba<ref name=fx26_ve1_351> See Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 2, xxxviii;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 39.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170, n.;<br> 2, 201, 202;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 396, n.;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xl., xli.</ref> to have been in his time an Avara or later authority, a statement of importance for the date of [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]].

उद्दालकायन
<u>'''Uddālakāyana'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of [[जाबालायन|Jābālāyana]] in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) contained in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 6, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

उद्र
<u>'''Udra'''</u> is the name of an animal occurring only in the list of sacrificial victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] given in the Saṃhitās of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_353> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 20, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 18;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 37.</ref> According to Mahīdhara<ref name=fx2_ve1_353> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> it was a crab; but as the commentary on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_353> ''Loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95, 96;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 247. ''Udrin'' occurs in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 5.</ref> calls it a watercat, there can be no doubt that it was an otter.

उद्धि
<u>'''Uddhi'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_354> Av. viii. 8, 22;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 2, 2, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 3, 8.</ref> denotes some part of a chariot, probably the seat,<ref name=fx2_ve1_354> So Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 506;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 149.</ref> but, according to Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_354> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the frame resting on the axle.

उप-केतु
<u>'''Upa-ketu'''</u> is the name of a man mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xiii. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

उप-कोसल कामलायन
<u>'''Upa-[[कोसल|kosala]] Kāmalāyana'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher and a pupil of '''[[सत्यकाम|Satyakāma]] [[जाबाल|Jābāla]]''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 10, 1; 14, 1). <br>==Foot Notes==

उप-क्वस
<u>'''Upa-kvasa'''</u> is the name in the Atharvaveda (vi. 50, 2) of a noxious insect injurious to seed. Sāyaṇa, however, reads the word as a plural adjective (''a-pakvasaḥ = a-dagdāḥ''), but the Paippalāda recension supports the form ''upakvasaḥ.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 237; Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 486; Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 318.<br>==Foot Notes==

उप-गु सौश्रवस
<u>'''Upa-gu Sauśravasa'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 6, 8) as [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of '''[[कुत्स औरव|Kutsa Aurava]],''' by whom he was murdered because of his paying homage to Indra.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 268; Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 57.<br>==Foot Notes==

उप-चित्
<u>'''Upa-cit'''</u> occurs in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_359> xii. 97.</ref> as the name of a disease, which Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_359> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> renders as ‘swelling,’ and which Bloomfield<ref name=fx3_ve1_359> ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' October, 1887, xviii.</ref> identifies with '''[[अपचित्|Apacit]].'''

उप-जिह्विका
<u>'''Upa-jihvikā, Upa-jīkā, Upa-dīkā'''</u> are all forms of one word denoting a species of ant.<ref name=fx1_ve1_360> ''[[उपजिह्विका|Upajihvikā]]'' is the form in Rv. viii. 102, 21;<br> ''upajīkā'' in Av. ii. 3, 4;<br> vi. 100, 2;<br> but ''upacīkā'' in both passages in the Paippalāda recension;<br> ''upadīkā'' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 1, 4;<br> 10, 9;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 1, 8.</ref> To these ants is attributed in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_360> vi. 100, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 7, 482 ''et seq.;<br> Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 511;<br> Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 41, 354;<br> Bergaigne and Henry, ''Manuel Védique,'' 153.</ref> the power of penetrating to water which possesses curative properties. They were accordingly used in all sorts of spells against poisoning. The belief in their healing qualities was no doubt due to the well-known properties of the earth of ant-heaps which contains their water.

उप-धान
<u>'''Upa-dhāna'''</u> denotes the ‘cushion’ of a seat ('''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]]''') in the Atharvaveda (xiv. 2, 65). It corresponds to the '''[[उपबर्हण|Upabarhaṇa]]''' of other texts. <br>==Foot Notes==

उप-धि
<u>'''Upa-dhi'''</u> occurs once each in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_362> ii. 39, 4.</ref> and the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_362> vi. 70, 3.</ref> in conjunction with '''[[प्रधि|Pradhi]],''' denoting part of the wheel of a chariot. It is impossible to decide exactly what part is meant. Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_362> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_362> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 248 (ignoring the Atharvaveda passage).</ref> and Bloomfield,<ref name=fx5_ve1_362> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 493.</ref> agree in thinking that the word denotes the spokes collectively. Whitney,<ref name=fx6_ve1_362> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 334.</ref> considering this improbable, prefers to see in it the designation of a solid wheel, [[प्रधि|Pradhi]] being presumably the rim and [[उपधि|Upadhi]] the rest. Other possibilities<ref name=fx7_ve1_362> Bloomfield, ''loc. cit.''</ref> are that the [[उपधि|Upadhi]] is a rim beneath the felly, or the felly itself as compared with the tire (ordinarily '''Pavi''').

उप-निषद्
<u>'''Upa-niṣad'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_363> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 3, 5, 12;<br> 4, 5, 1;<br> 5, 1, 1;<br> xii. 2, 2, 23, etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1, 10;<br> 13, 4;<br> viii. 8, 4. 5;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 20;<br> iv. 2, 1;<br> v. 5, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 6;<br> 2, 5;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, etc.</ref> normally denotes the ‘secret sense’ of some word or text, sometimes the ‘secret rule’ of the mendicant. But in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_363> ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 2;<br> 5, 11.</ref> it is already used in the plural as the designation of a class of writings, no doubt actually existing and similar to the Upaniṣads in the nature of their subject-matter and its treatment. Similarly the sections of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] end with the words ''ity [[उपनिषद्|upaniṣad]].'' The [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx3_ve1_363> iii. 1, 1.</ref> commences its third part with the title ‘The [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] of the Saṃhitā,’ and the title occurs also in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx4_ve1_363> vii. 2. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 1.</ref> The exact primary sense of the expression is doubtful. The natural derivation, adopted by Max Müller<ref name=fx5_ve1_363> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 1, xxxiii ''et seq. Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 204.</ref> and usual ever since, makes the word mean firstly a session of pupils, hence secret doctrine, and secondly the title of a work on secret doctrine. Oldenberg,<ref name=fx6_ve1_363> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 457;<br> 54, 70;<br> ''Die Literatur des alten Indien,'' 72.</ref> however, traces the use of the word to the earlier  sense of ‘worship’ (''cf. upāsana''). Deussen<ref name=fx7_ve1_363> ''Philosophy of the Upaniṣads,'' 16 ''et seq.''</ref> considers the original sense to have been ‘secret word,’ next ‘secret text,’ and then ‘secret import,’ but this order of meaning is improbable. Hopkins<ref name=fx8_ve1_363> ''Religions of India,'' 218.</ref> suggests that [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] denotes a subsidiary treatise, but this sense does not account naturally for the common use as ‘secret meaning,’ which is far more frequent than any other.

उप-पति
<u>'''Upa-pati,'''</u> ‘the gallant,’ is mentioned with the [[जार|Jāra]], ‘lover,’ in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_364> xxx. 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 4, 1.</ref> as a victim in the human sacrifice (''puruṣamedha'').

उप-बर्हण
<u>'''Upa-barhaṇa'''</u> denotes a ‘pillow’ or ‘cushion,’ especially of a seat (''[[आसन्दी|āsandī]]''), occurring in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_365> x. 85, 7.</ref> the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_365> ix. 5, 28;<br> xii. 2, 19. 20;<br> xv. 3, 7.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_365> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 12;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 8, 4, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 6, 10;<br> 6, 8, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 4, etc.</ref> The feminine Upabarhaṇī is found in the Rigveda with the same sense, but used metaphorically of the earth.

उप-मन्थनी
<u>'''Upa-manthanī'''</u> is used in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_366> vi. 3, 13.</ref> to denote ‘churning sticks.’ In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_366> xxx. 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 8, 1.</ref> the ‘churner’ (''upamanthitṛ'') is included in the list of victims at the human sacrifice (''puruṣamedha''), and the verb ''upa-manth'' is often used of churning or mixing fluids.<ref name=fx3_ve1_366> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 8, 4. 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 1, 6;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 2, 4.</ref>

उप-मन्यु
<u>'''Upa-manyu'''</u> is, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx1_ve1_367> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 113.</ref> the name of a person in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_367> i. 102. 9.</ref> but is more probably explained by Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_367> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> as a mere epithet. 

उपम-श्रवस्
<u>'''Upama-śravas'''</u> is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_368> x. 33, 6. 7.</ref> as a son of '''Kuruśravaṇa,''' and grandson of '''[[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]].''' The exact force of the reference to him in however, uncertain. According to the Bṛhaddevatā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_368> vii. 35. 36, with Macdonell's notes.</ref> followed by Ludwig,<ref name=fx3_ve1_368> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165.</ref> and by Lanman,<ref name=fx4_ve1_368> ''Sanskrit reader,'' 386, 389.</ref> the poet in the hymn consoles [[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]] for the death of his grandfather, [[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]]. Geldner,<ref name=fx5_ve1_368> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 150, n.</ref> on the other hand, thinks that the poet, who was '''[[कवष|Kavaṣa]] [[ऐलूष|Ailūṣa]],''' was ill-treated by his patron's son, [[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]], and cast into a ditch or well, where he uttered his complaint and appeal for mercy. But of this there is no adequate evidence, and the tradition of the Bṛhaddevatā seems sound.

उप-मित्
<u>'''Upa-mit'''</u> occurs twice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_369> i. 59, 1;<br> iv. 5, 1.</ref> and once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_369> ix. 3, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 153;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 596;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 525.</ref> as the designation of some part of a house. The passages in the Rigveda leave little doubt that the word means an upright pillar. As it is, in the Atharvaveda, coupled with '''[[परिमित्|Parimit]]''' and '''[[प्रतिमित्|Pratimit]],''' the conclusion is natural that the latter word denotes the beams supporting the [[उपमित्|Upamit]], presumably by leaning against it at an angle, while '''[[परिमित्|Parimit]]''' denotes the beams connecting the Upamits horizontally. These interpretations, however, can only be conjectural. See also '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''

उपर
<u>'''Upara,'''</u> which, according to Pischel,<ref name=fx1_ve1_370> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 109. This is the sense of the form ''upala'' (Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 8, etc.).</ref> means ‘stone’ in general, is the technical name of the stone on which the Soma plant was laid in order to be pounded for the extraction of the juice by other stones (''adri, grāvan''). The word is rare, occurring only thrice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_370> i. 79, 3;<br> x. 94, 5;<br> 175, 3.</ref> and once in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_370> vi. 49, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 154;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 317;<br> Von Schroeder, ''Mysterium und Mimus,'' 414.</ref> 

उपल-प्रक्षिणी
<u>'''Upala-prakṣiṇī'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_371> ix. 112, 3.</ref> where it designates the occupation of a woman, as opposed to that of her son, who is a poet (''[[कारु|kāru]]''), and to that of his father, who is a physician (''[[भिषज्|bhiṣaj]]''). [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_371> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 5.</ref> renders the word by ‘maker of groats’ (''[[सक्तु|saktu]]-kārikā''), and Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_371> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Grassmann,<ref name=fx4_ve1_371> ''Ibid., s.v.,'' ‘fitting the upper (to the lower) millstone.’</ref> Zimmer,<ref name=fx5_ve1_371> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 269. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedaschrestomathie, s.v.,'' who, taking ''pṛc'' in the sense of ‘fill,’ explains the compound as ‘filling the upper millstone,’ an interpretation which as it stands is unintelligible.</ref> as well as others, connect it with the operation of grinding corn. Pischel,<ref name=fx6_ve1_371> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 308-310.</ref> however, who points out that corn was not ground between two stones, but beaten on a stone with a pestle (''[[दृषद्|dṛṣad]]''), considers that [[उपल-प्रक्षिणी|Upala-prakṣiṇī]] denotes a woman that assisted at the crushing of Soma (''cf.'' '''[[उपर|Upara]]'''). Von Schroeder,<ref name=fx7_ve1_371> ''Mysterium und Mimus,'' 412 ''et seq.'' Von Schroeder does not accept the view that the mother of the singer is alluded to;<br> but it seems impossible to draw any other conclusion from the language of the passage, and his own explanation of the word as referring to a corn-mother is very improbable;<br> ''cf.'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 204.</ref> who more correctly points out that there is no objection to regarding ''upala'' as the mortar in which the corn was placed and then beaten with the pestle, renders the word literally as ‘one who fills the (lower) stone (with corn).’

उपला
<u>'''Upalā'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_372> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 22;<br> ii. 1, 14, 17;<br> ii. 2, 2, 1, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Von Schroeder, ''Mysterium und Mimus,'' 413, n. 3.</ref> may denote the upper and smaller ‘stone,’ which was used as a pestle with the '''[[दृषद्|Dṛṣad]]''' as the mortar, whereas '''[[उपर|Upara]]''' in the Saṃhitās denotes rather the mortar, and [[दृषद्|Dṛṣad]] the pestle. But see '''[[दृषद्|Dṛṣad]].'''

उप-वाक
<u>'''Upa-vāka'''</u> occurs in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_373> xix. 22;<br> 90;<br> xxi. 30 (as ‘healing’).</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve1_373> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 1, 3;<br> 2, 9, etc.</ref> as a description of a species of grain, the ''Wrightia antidysenterica,'' known later as Indra-yava. The commentator Mahīdhara<ref name=fx3_ve1_373> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 22.</ref> simply glosses it with the more general term '''Yava.'''  According to the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, it formed the essential element of gruel (''[[करम्भ|karambha]]''), and [[उपवाक|Upavāka]] groats (''saktavaḥ'') are mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_373> xii. 9, 1, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 240, 270.</ref>

उप-वेशि
<u>'''Upa-veśi'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''Kuśri''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 3, in both recensions). See also '''[[औपवेशि|Aupaveśi]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

उप-श्री
<u>'''Upa-[[श्री|śrī]], Upa-śraya,'''</u> are two readings of the same term. The former is found in one recension of the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_375> i. 5.</ref> while the latter is probably the reading of the other recension of the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_375> See Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 20, n. 3.</ref> and certainly the reading in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_375> xv. 3, 8. ''Cf.'' Whitney's note in his Translation.</ref> though the text has ''apaśrayaḥ,'' which is accepted as possible by Roth.<ref name=fx4_ve1_375> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and still followed by Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> In both cases the term clearly means something connected with a couch ('''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]]''' in the Atharvaveda, '''[[पर्य्अङ्क|Paryaṅka]]''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]). Aufrecht,<ref name=fx5_ve1_375> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 131.</ref> Roth,<ref name=fx6_ve1_375> ''S.v. [[अपश्रय|apaśraya]].''</ref> and Max Müller<ref name=fx7_ve1_375> ''Sacred Books af the East,'' 1, 278.</ref> render it as ‘coverlet’ or ‘cushion,’ but Whitney<ref name=fx8_ve1_375> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 777.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 402;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 155.</ref> seems evidently right in holding that it must mean a ‘support’ or something similar.

उप-स्तरण
<u>'''Upa-staraṇa'''</u> denotes in the description of the couch ('''[[पर्य्अङ्क|Paryaṅka]]''') in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_376> i. 5.</ref> a ‘coverlet,’ and has this sense, used metaphorically, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_376> ix. 69, 5.</ref> also. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_376> v. 19, 12.</ref> it seems to have the same meaning. Whitney,<ref name=fx4_ve1_376> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 254.</ref> however, renders it ‘couch,’ though he translates<ref name=fx5_ve1_376> ''Ibid.,'' 776.</ref> the parallel word '''[[आस्तरण|Āstaraṇa]]''' in another passage<ref name=fx6_ve1_376> xv. 3, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 403;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 155.</ref> by ‘cushion.’ 

उप-स्ति
<u>'''Upa-sti'''</u> denotes both in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_377> x. 97, 23 (= Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 101;<br> Av. vi. 15, 1).</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_377> iii. 5, 6.</ref> a ‘dependent,’ just as later in the Epic<ref name=fx3_ve1_377> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 92.</ref> the subordination of the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] to the two superior castes is expressed by the verb ''upa-sthā,'' ‘stand under,’ ‘support.’ The word also appears, with the same sense, in the form of Sti, but only in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx4_ve1_377> vii. 19, 11;<br> x. 148, 4;<br> ''sti-pa,'' vii. 66, 3;<br> x. 69, 4.</ref> The exact nature of the dependence connoted by the term is quite uncertain. Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve1_377> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 184, 185.</ref> conjectures that the ‘dependents’ were the members of defeated Aryan tribes who became clients of the king, as among the Greeks, Romans, and Germans, the term possibly including persons who had lost their freedom through dicing.<ref name=fx6_ve1_377> Rv. x. 34.</ref> The evidence of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_377> Av. iii. 5, 6. 7.</ref> shows that among the Upastis were included the chariot-makers (''[[रथ-कार|ratha-kāra]]''), the smiths (''[[तक्षन्|takṣan]]''), and the charioteers (''[[सूत|sūta]]''), and troop-leaders (''[[ग्राम|grāma]]-ṇī''), while the Rigveda passages negative the possibility of the ‘subjects’ (''sti'') being the whole people. It is therefore fair to assume that they were the clients proper of the king, not servile, but attached in a special relation to him as opposed to the ordinary population. They may well have included among them not only the classes suggested by Zimmer, but also higher elements, such as refugees from other clans, as well as ambitious men who sought advancement in the royal service. Indeed, the [[सूत|Sūta]] and the Grāmaṇī were, as such, officers of the king's household--kingmakers, not themselves kings, as they are described in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx8_ve1_377> iii. 5, 7.</ref> The use of the word in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx9_ve1_377> vii. 2, 5, 4. ''Cf.'' vi. 5, 8, 2.</ref> the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx10_ve1_377> iii. 3, 5, 4.</ref> and the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]],<ref name=fx11_ve1_377> xxxi. 9.</ref> is purely metaphorical, as well as in the one passage of the Rigveda in which it occurs. In the Paippalāda recension of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx12_ve1_377> iii. 5, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 246;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 92;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 196 ''et seq.''</ref> [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]], [[शूद्र|Śūdra]], and [[आर्य|Ārya]] are referred to as Upastis, perhaps in the general sense of ‘subject.’ 

उप-स्तुत
<u>'''Upa-stuta'''</u> is mentioned several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_378> i. 36, 10. 17;<br> 112, 15;<br> viii. 5, 25;<br> x. 115, 8.</ref> always as a sage of old, and usually in connexion with [[कण्व|Kaṇva]], who was aided or favoured by Agni, the Aśvins, and other gods. The Upastutas, sons of [[वृष्टिहव्य|Vṛṣṭihavya]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_378> x. 115, 9.</ref> are mentioned as singers<ref name=fx3_ve1_378> viii. 103, 8;<br> x. 115, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 108;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 152, 153.</ref>

उप-ह्वर
<u>'''Upa-hvara'''</u> denotes, in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_379> i. 87, 2.</ref> according to Geldner,<ref name=fx2_ve1_379> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 40.</ref> the body of a chariot (''upa-stha'').

उपानस
<u>'''Upānasa'''</u> is in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_380> ii. 14, 2.</ref> opposed to '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]],''' and must mean something like ‘the body of the wagon,’ though Sāyaṇa suggests that it signifies either a ‘granary’ or a ‘wagon full of grain.’ In the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_380> x. 105, 4.</ref> where the word occurs only once, its sense is doubtful. Pischel<ref name=fx3_ve1_380> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 197.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 301;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 56.</ref> explains the form which occurs there not as an adjective, but as an infinitive.

उपा-नह्
<u>'''Upā-nah'''</u> is the regular word for a ‘sandal’ or ‘shoe’ from the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_381> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 4, 4;<br> 6, 6, 1, etc.</ref> onwards. Boarskin is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_381> v. 4, 3, 19.</ref> as a material of which shoes were made. The combination ‘staff and sandals’ (''daṇḍopānaha'') occurs as early as the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_381> iii. 3.</ref>

उपावि जान-श्रुतेय
<u>'''Upāvi [[जान|Jāna]]-śruteya'''</u> is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 25, 15) as an authority on the Upasads (a kind of Soma ceremony).<br>==Foot Notes==

उपोदिति गौपालेय
<u>'''Upoditi Gaupāleya'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 13, 11) as a seer of Sāmans.<br>==Foot Notes==

उभया-दन्त्
<u>'''Ubhayā-dant,'''</u> ‘having incisors in both jaws,’ is an expression employed to distinguish, among domestic animals, the horse,  the ass, etc., from the goat, the sheep, and cattle. The distinction occurs in a late hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_384> x. 90, 10.</ref> and is several times alluded to in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve1_384> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 6, 3;<br> v. 1, 2, 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 8, 1.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_384> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 30 (''ubhayato-dant'').</ref> In one passage of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_384> ii. 2, 6, 3.</ref> man is classed with the horse as ''[[उभया-दन्त्|ubhayā-dant]].'' The opposite is ''anyato-dant,'' ‘having incisors in one jaw only,’ a term regularly applied to cattle,<ref name=fx5_ve1_384> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 5;<br> v. 1, 2, 6;<br> 5, 1, 3.</ref> the eight incisors of which are, in fact, limited to the lower jaw. The ass is styled ''[[उभया-दन्त्|ubhayā-dant]]'' in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx6_ve1_384> v. 31, 3.</ref> In one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx7_ve1_384> v. 19, 2.</ref> however, the epithet is applied to a ram; but the sense here is that a marvel occurs, just as in the Rigveda<ref name=fx8_ve1_384> viii. 18, 17.</ref> a ram destroys a lioness. Bloomfield<ref name=fx9_ve1_384> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 434.</ref> suggests in the Atharvaveda passage another reading which would mean ‘horse.’ A parallel division of animals is that of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]<ref name=fx10_ve1_384> iv. 3, 10, 2.</ref> and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitās<ref name=fx11_ve1_384> xiv. 30.</ref> into ‘whole-hoofed’ (''eka-[[शफ|śapha]]'') and ‘small’ (''kṣudra'').<br><br>Zimmer<ref name=fx12_ve1_384> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 74-76.</ref> seeks to show from the Greek <ref name=fx13_ve1_384> Aristotle, ''Hist. An.,'' ii. 1, 8.</ref> and the Latin ''ambidens''<ref name=fx14_ve1_384> Festus ''apud'' Paulum Diaconum<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 58.</ref> that the Indo-European was familiar with the division of the five sacrificial animals into the two classes of man and horse on the one hand, and cattle, sheep, and goats on the other. But this supposition is not necessary.

उरा
<u>'''Urā'''</u> as a name for ‘sheep’ is confined to the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_385> viii. 34, 3.</ref> It is curious that in one of its two occurrences the wolf should be referred to as terrifying sheep, and that the epithet of the wolf, ''[[उरा|urā]]-mathi,'' ‘killing sheep,’ should occur once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_385> viii. 66, 8. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 21.</ref> both references being in one book of the Saṃhitā, a fact which suggests a dialectical origin of the word ''[[उरा|urā]].'' See also '''Avi.''' 

उरु-कक्ष
<u>'''Uru-kakṣa'''</u> occurs in only one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_386> vi. 45, 31.</ref> where the sense of the word is much disputed. The reading of the text is ''uruḥ kakṣo na gāṅgyaḥ,'' which may refer to a man, [[उरुकक्ष|Urukakṣa]], ‘dwelling on the Ganges,’<ref name=fx2_ve1_386> Grassmann;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 291.</ref> or to a man, son of [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]], or to a wood so called,<ref name=fx3_ve1_386> Ludwig's translation (''der wald [[उरुकक्ष|Urukakṣa]],'' or ''das weite dickicht'').</ref> or may simply denote the ‘broad thicket on the Ganges.’<ref name=fx4_ve1_386> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 28, n. 5;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 396.</ref>

उरु-क्षय
<u>'''Uru-kṣaya.'''</u>--A family of Urukṣayas, singers and worshippers of Agni, is referred to in one hymn of the Rigveda (x. 118, 8. 9).<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 167.<br>==Foot Notes==

उरुञ्जिरा
<u>'''Uruñjirā'''</u> is given in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (ix. 26) as one of the names of the river '''[[विपाश्|Vipāś]]''' (now Beäs).<br>==Foot Notes==

उर्वरा
<u>'''Urvarā'''</u> is with '''[[क्षेत्र|Kṣetra]]''' the regular expression, from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_389> i. 127, 6;<br> iv. 41, 6;<br> v. 33, 4;<br> vi. 25, 4;<br> x. 30, 3;<br> 142, 3, etc.;<br> Av. x. 6, 33;<br> 10, 8;<br> xiv. 2, 14, etc.</ref> onwards, denoting a piece of ‘ploughland’ (). Fertile (''apnasvatī'') fields<ref name=fx2_ve1_389> Rv. i. 127, 6.</ref> are spoken of as well as waste fields (''ārtanā'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_389> ''Ibid.''</ref> Intensive cultivation by means of irrigation is clearly referred to both in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_389> vii. 49, 2.</ref> and in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_389> i. 6, 4;<br> xix. 2, 2.</ref> while allusion is also made to the use of manure.<ref name=fx6_ve1_389> Av. iii. 14, 3, 4;<br> xix. 31, 3.</ref> The fields (''[[क्षेत्र|kṣetra]]'') were carefully measured according to the Rigveda.<ref name=fx7_ve1_389> i. 110, 5.</ref> This fact points clearly to individual ownership in land for the plough, a conclusion supported by the reference of Apālā, in a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx8_ve1_389> viii. 91, 5.</ref> to her father's field (''[[उर्वरा|urvarā]]''), which is put on the same level as his head of hair as a personal possession. Consistent with this are the epithets ‘winning fields’ (''[[उर्वरा|urvarā]]-sā, [[उर्वरा|urvarā]]-jit, [[क्षेत्र|kṣetra]]-sā''),<ref name=fx9_ve1_389> Rv. iv. 38, 1, and vi. 20, 1;<br> ii. 21, 1;<br> iv. 38, 1.</ref> while ‘lord of fields’ used of a god<ref name=fx10_ve1_389> viii. 21, 3. ''Cf.'' '''[[क्षेत्र|Kṣetra]].'''</ref> is presumably a transfer of a human epithet (''[[उर्वरा|urvarā]]-pati''). Moreover, fields are spoken of in the same  connexion as children,<ref name=fx11_ve1_389> Rv. iv. 41, 6, etc.</ref> and the conquest of fields (''kṣetrāṇi saṃ-ji'') is often referred to in the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx12_ve1_389> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 8, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, v. 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 12, 3.</ref> Very probably, as suggested by Pischel,<ref name=fx13_ve1_389> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 204-207.</ref> the ploughland was bounded by grass land (perhaps denoted by '''[[खिल|Khila]], Khilya''') which in all likelihood would be joint property on the analogy of property elsewhere. There is no trace in Vedic literature of communal property in the sense of ownership by a community of any sort,<ref name=fx14_ve1_389> ''Cf.'' Baden Powell, ''Indian Village Community'' (1899);<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236;<br> Mrs. Rhys Davids, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1901, 860.</ref> nor is there mention of communal cultivation. Individual property in land seems also presumed later on. In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx15_ve1_389> vii. 24, 2.</ref> the things given as examples of wealth include fields and houses (''āyatanāni''). The Greek evidence<ref name=fx16_ve1_389> ''Cf.'' Diodorus, ii. 40;<br> Arrian, ''Indica,'' 11;<br> Strabo, p. 703;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 87 ''et seq. Cf. ibid.,'' 20, 22, 23.</ref> also points to individual ownership. The precise nature of the ownership is of course not determined by the expression ‘individual ownership.’ The legal relationship of the head of a family and its members is nowhere explained, and can only be conjectured (see '''[[पितृ|Pitṛ]]'''). Very often a family may have lived together with undivided shares in the land. The rules about the inheritance of landed property do not occur before the Sūtras.<ref name=fx17_ve1_389> ''Cf.'' [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xviii. 5 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 2, 3;<br> Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 6, 14. Of course, the rules probably go back to the earlier period, but how far it is impossible to say. With the settlement of the country, however, inheritance of land and its partition must have become inevitable.</ref> In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx18_ve1_389> xiii. 6, 2, 18;<br> 7, 1, 13. 15.</ref> the giving of land as a fee to priests is mentioned, but with reproof: land was no doubt even then a very special kind of property, not lightly to be given away or parted with.<ref name=fx19_ve1_389> It is significant that in the famous episode ([[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 9, 4) of Manu's division of his property, from which [[नाभानेदिष्ठ|Nābhānediṣṭha]] was excluded, this exclusion is made good by the son's obtaining cattle (''paśavaḥ''). It is clear that cattle, not land, was the real foundation of wealth, just as in Ireland, Italy (''cf. pecunia''), Greece, etc. Cattle could be, and were, used individually, but land was not open to a man's free disposal;<br> no doubt, at any rate, the consent of the family or the community might be required, but we are reduced to reliance on analogy in view of the silence of the texts. ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 289;<br> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 94-96;<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 48 ''et seq.''</ref> <br><br>On the relation of the owners of land to the king and others see '''[[ग्राम|Grāma]];''' on its cultivation see '''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]].'''

उर्वारू
<u>'''Urvārū,'''</u> f., '''Urvāruka,''' n., ‘cucumber.’ The former<ref name=fx1_ve1_390> Av. vi. 14, 2.</ref> of these words denotes the plant, the latter<ref name=fx2_ve1_390> Rv. vii. 59, 12 = Av. xiv. 1, 17 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 10, 4 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 6, 2 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 60.</ref> the fruit, but both are very rare. The passages all seem to refer to the fact that the stem of the plant becomes loosened when the fruit is ripe.<ref name=fx3_ve1_390> Sāyaṇa on Av. vi. 14, 2.</ref> The fruit is also called Urvāru in a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_390> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 2. 19.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 242.</ref>

उल
<u>'''Ula'''</u> is the name of some unknown wild animal, perhaps, as Whitney<ref name=fx1_ve1_391> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 669.</ref> suggests, the ‘jackal.’ It is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_391> xii. 1, 49.</ref> and later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx3_ve1_391> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1 (as ''[[ऊल|ūla]]'');<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 13, 12;<br> 14, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 31. ''Cf. ulala'' in [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 82.</ref> but not definitely identified by the commentators.

उल वार्ष्णि-वृद्ध
<u>'''Ula Vārṣṇi-vṛddha'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

उलप
<u>'''Ulapa'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_393> x. 142, 3.</ref> is the name of a species of grass referred to in the Rigveda and the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve1_393> Av. vii. 66, 1. Adjectives derived from the word are ''ulapya'' (Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 45, etc.) and ''upolapa'' (Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 7, 2).</ref>

उलुक्य जान-श्रुतेय
<u>'''Ulukya [[जान|Jāna]]-śruteya'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 6, 3). <br>==Foot Notes==

उलूक
<u>'''Ulūka'''</u> is the ordinary word for ‘owl’ from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_395> x. 165, 4.</ref> onwards. The bird was noted for its cry,<ref name=fx2_ve1_395> Rv. ''loc. cit.''</ref> and was deemed the harbinger of ill-fortune (''nairṛta'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_395> Av. vi. 19, 2: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 18, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 38.</ref> Owls were offered at the horse sacrifice to the forest trees,<ref name=fx4_ve1_395> Vājasaneyi Samhitā, xxiv. 23;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14. 4.</ref> no doubt because they roosted there.

उलूखल
<u>'''Ulūkhala'''</u> is the regular expression for ‘mortar’ from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_396> i. 28, 6;<br> Av. x. 9, 26;<br> xi. 3, 3;<br> xii. 3, 13: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 8, 7;<br> vii. 2, 1, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 6, etc.</ref> onwards, occurring frequently also in the compound<ref name=fx2_ve1_396> Av. ix. 6, 15;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 22</ref> Ulūkala-[[मुसल|musala]], ‘mortar and pestle.’ The exact construction of the vessel is quite unkown till we reach the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period.

उल्का
<u>'''Ulkā'''</u> regularly denotes a meteor from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_397> iv. 4, 2;<br> x. 68, 4;<br> Av. xix. 9, 8, Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 8, etc.</ref> onwards. In the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve1_397> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 19.</ref> it also signifies a ‘firebrand.’ The much rarer form Ulkuṣī<ref name=fx3_ve1_397> As ‘meteor,’ Av. v. 17, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 7, 21;<br> as ‘firebrand,’ ''ibid.,'' iii. 9, 2, 9.</ref> has both senses.

उल्मुक
<u>'''Ulmuka'''</u> is the common word in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_398> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 11;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 1;<br> ii. 1, 4, 28, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 76 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 239)</ref> for ‘firebrand,’ from which a coal (''aṅgāra'')<ref name=fx2_ve1_398> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 3, 3;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 61, 1 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 23, 342).</ref> could be taken.

उल्मुकवक्षयण
<u>'''Ulmukavakṣayaṇa'''</u> is an expression that occurs several times in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_399> iv. 6. 8, 7;<br> v. 2, 4, 15;<br> xi. 6, 3, 3;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 76. ''Cf.'' Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, s.v.</ref> signifying a ‘means of extinguishing (''ava-kṣayaṇa'') a firebrand,’ or possibly more precisely ‘tongs.’ Compare '''[[अङ्गारावक्षयण|Aṅgārāvakṣayaṇa]].''' 

उशनस् काव्य
<u>'''Uśanas Kāvya'''</u> is an ancient seer, already a half-mythical figure in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_400> i. 51, 10;<br> 83. 5;<br> 121, 12;<br> iv. 16, 2;<br> vi. 20, 11;<br> viii. 23, 17;<br> ix. 87, 3;<br> 97, 7;<br> x. 40, 7;<br> probably also i. 130, 9;<br> v. 31, 8;<br> 34. 2;<br> viii. 7, 26;<br> x. 22, 6. Also in Av. iv. 29, 6.</ref> where he is often mentioned, especially as associated with [[कुत्स|Kutsa]] and Indra. Later on<ref name=fx2_ve1_400> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 8, 5: [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 20;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 27, 1.</ref> he becomes the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of the Asuras in their contests with the gods. A variant of his name is Kavi Uśanas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_400> Rv. iv. 26, 1.</ref> He appears in the Brāhmaṇas as a teacher also.<ref name=fx4_ve1_400> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 12, 5;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. ii. 7. 2, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 167 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bergaingne, ''Religiou Vidique,'' 2, 339. ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 147.</ref>

उशना
<u>'''Uśanā'''</u> occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 4, 3, 13; iv. 2, 5, 15) as the name of a plant from which Soma was prepared.<br>==Foot Notes==

उशीनर
<u>'''Uśīnara'''</u>--In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāhmaṇā<ref name=fx1_ve1_402> viii. 14.</ref> the Kuru-Pañcālas are mentioned as dwelling together in the ‘Middle Country’ with the Vaśas and the Uśīnaras. In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_402> iv. 1. See Keith ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āranyaka,'' 36.</ref> also the Uśīnaras are associated with the Kuru-Pañcālas and Vaśas, but in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_402> ii 9.</ref> the Uśīnaras and Vaśas are regarded as northerners. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_402> x. 59, 10.</ref> the people is alluded to in one passage by reference to their queen, Uśīnarāṇī. Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve1_402> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 130.</ref> thinks that the Uśīnaras earlier lived farther to the north-west, but for this there is no clear evidence. His theory is based merely on the fact that the Anukramaṇī (Index) of the Rigveda ascribes one hymn<ref name=fx6_ve1_402> Rv. x. 179.</ref> to [[शिबि|Śibi]] Auśīnara, and that the Śibis were known to Alexander's followers as ,<ref name=fx7_ve1_402> Diodorus, xvii. 19.</ref> living between the Indus and the Akesines (Chenab). But this is in no way conclusive, as the Śibis, at any rate in Epic times,<ref name=fx8_ve1_402> See Pargiter's map. ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908. p. 322.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 213, 419;<br> Hultzsch ''Indian Antiquary,'' 34, 179.</ref> occupied the land to the north of [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], and there is no reason whatever to show that in the Vedic period the Uśīnaras were farther west than the ‘Middle Country.’ 

उष
<u>'''Uṣa,'''</u> ‘salt ground,’ occurs as a variant of [[ऊष|Ūṣa]] in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (i. 6, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

उषस्त चाक्रायण
<u>'''Uṣasta Cākrāyaṇa'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka (iii. 5, 1) and Chāndogya (i. 10, 1; 11, 1) Upaniṣads, the name in the latter work appearing as Uṣasti.<br>==Foot Notes==

उष्टि
<u>'''Uṣṭi, Uṣṭra.'''</u>--Both of these words, of which the former is quite rare,<ref name=fx1_ve1_405> Perhaps in Rv. x. 106, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 21, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2.</ref> must have the same sense. Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_405> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Aufrecht<ref name=fx3_ve1_405> Cited in Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 468. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 224.</ref> hold that in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_405> i. 138, 2;<br> viii. 5, 37;<br> 6, 48;<br> 46, 22. 31;<br> Av. xx. 127, 2;<br> 132, 13;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 50.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx5_ve1_405> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 1, 2, 3, 9, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8.</ref> the sense is ‘humped bull’ or ‘buffalo,’ but the former thinks that in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx6_ve1_405> xxiv. 28. 39.</ref> the sense is doubtful, and ‘camel’ may be meant. Hopkins<ref name=fx7_ve1_405> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 83.</ref> is decidedly of opinion that the sense in every case is ‘camel.’ The animal was used as a beast of burden yoked in fours.<ref name=fx8_ve1_405> Av. xx. 127, 2;<br> Rv. viii. 6, 48.</ref>

उष्णीष
<u>'''Uṣṇīṣa'''</u> denotes the ‘turban’ worn by Vedic Indians, men and women<ref name=fx1_ve1_406> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 2, 3;<br> iv. 5, 2, 7 (used at the sacrifice to wrap the embryo in);<br> xiv. 2, 1, 8 (Indrāṇī's [[उष्णीष|Uṣṇīṣa]]), etc.;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 10.</ref> alike. The Vrātya's turban is expressly referred to in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_406> xv. 2, 1.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_406> xvii. 1, 14. ''Cf.'' xvi. 6, 13.</ref> A turban was also worn at the [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_406> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 5, 23.</ref> and the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_406> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 3.</ref> ceremonies by the king as a token of his position.

उष्यल
<u>'''Uṣyala'''</u> occurs once in the description of the couch or the bridal car in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_407> xiv. 1, 60.</ref> where it seems to mean the four ‘frame-pieces.’ The form is doubtful: ''uṣpala'' is possible.<ref name=fx2_ve1_407> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 385.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 155;<br> Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 752.</ref> 

उस्र
<u>'''Usra,'''</u> m.; '''Usrā,''' f.; '''Usrika,''' m.; '''Usriya,''' m.; '''Usriyā,''' f. All these words denote a ‘bull’ or a ‘cow,’ occurring frequently in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_408> ''Usra,'' Rv. vi. 12, 4;<br> ''usrā,'' i. 3, 8;<br> viii. 75, 8;<br> 96, 8;<br> ix. 58, 2, etc.;<br> ''usrika,'' i. 190, 5;<br> ''usriya,'' v. 58, 6 (with ''vṛṣabhaḥ'');<br> ix. 74. 3;<br> ''usriyā,'' i. 153, 4;<br> 180, 3;<br> ii. 40, 2, etc. In ix. 70, 6, ''usriya'' is applied to a calf;<br> and in ix. 68, 1;<br> 93, 2, ''usriyā'' means ‘milk.’</ref> and sometimes later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_408> ''Usrau dhūrṣāhau,'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 33;<br> ''usrā,'' Av. xii. 3, 37;<br> ''usriya,'' Av. i. 12, 1;<br> ''usriyā,'' Av. ix. 4, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxv. 2. 3. In Av. v. 20, 1;<br> 28, 3, it means ‘cowhide,’ or perhaps in v. 28, 3, ‘milk.’</ref> but usually with some reference to the morning light. In some passages the sense is doubtful. See '''Go.'''

ऊर्जयन्त् औपमन्यव
<u>'''Ūrjayant Aupamanyava'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_409> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref> as a pupil of '''[[भानुमन्त् औपमन्यव|Bhānumant Aupamanyava]].'''

ऊर्जयन्ती
<u>'''Ūrjayantī'''</u> is regarded by Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve1_410> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 152.</ref> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_410> ii. 13, 8.</ref> as the name of a fort, the stronghold of '''[[नार्मर|Nārmara]].''' The verse is, however, quite unintelligible.<ref name=fx3_ve1_410> Sāyaṇa makes Urjayantī a Piśācī;<br> Grassmann, the sun;<br> Roth, ''s.v. ūrjay,'' takes it adjectivally. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 199.</ref>

ऊर्जव्य
<u>'''Ūrjavya,'''</u> a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_411> v. 41, 20.</ref> is taken by Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_411> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155.</ref> to be the name of a sacrificer. Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_411> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> however, regards the word as an adjective meaning ‘rich in strength,’ and this is the more probable interpretation.

ऊर्ण-नाभी
<u>'''Ūrṇa-nābhī,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_412> ''Ūrṇa-[[नाभि|nābhi]]'' (‘having wool in its navel’), [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 5;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 23;<br> ''ūrṇa-vābhī'' (‘wool-spinner’), [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 5, 1, 23;<br> ''[[ऊर्णा|ūrṇā]]-vant'' (‘possessing wool’), [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xix. 3 (in a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]]).</ref> '''Ūrṇa-vābhi, [[ऊर्णा|Ūrṇā]]-vant''' are all names of the spider in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas in allusion to the insect's spinning threads of wool, as it were. 

ऊर्णा
<u>'''Ūrṇā,'''</u> ‘wool,’ is very frequently mentioned from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_413> iv. 22, 2;<br> v. 52, 9;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 5, 1, 13: 7, 2, 10, etc.;<br> ''ūrṇāyu,'' ‘woolly,’ Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 50;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 11, 10.</ref> onwards. The [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]] country was famous for its wool,<ref name=fx2_ve1_413> Rv., ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 210. But ''cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 315.</ref> like [[गन्धार|Gandhāra]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_413> Rv. i. 126, 7.</ref> for its sheep. The term for the separate tufts was ''[[पर्वन्|parvan]]''<ref name=fx4_ve1_413> Rv. iv. 22, 10.</ref> or ''[[परुस्|parus]].''<ref name=fx5_ve1_413> Rv. ix. 15, 6.</ref> ‘Soft as wool’ (''ūrṇa-mradas'')<ref name=fx6_ve1_413> Rv. v. 5, 4;<br> x. 18, 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 2: iv. 10;<br> xxi. 33, etc.</ref> is not a rare epithet. The sheep is called ‘woolly’ (''[[ऊर्णावती|ūrṇāvatī]]'').<ref name=fx7_ve1_413> Rv. viii. 56, 3.</ref> ‘Woollen thread’ (''[[ऊर्णा|ūrṇā]]-[[सूत्र|sūtra]]'') is repeatedly referred to in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx8_ve1_413> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Samhitā, xxxviii. 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 80, etc. ''Cf. [[ऊर्णा|ūrṇā]]-[[स्तुका|stukā]],'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 28;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 3.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx9_ve1_413> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 2, 11, etc.</ref> The word ''[[ऊर्णा|ūrṇā]]'' was not restricted to the sense of sheep's wool,<ref name=fx10_ve1_413> ''Cf. anaiḍakīr ūrṇāḥ'' (‘wool not coming from the ''eḍaha,''’ a species of sheep) in Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5 2, 15.</ref> but might denote goat's hair also.<ref name=fx11_ve1_413> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 83, n.</ref>

ऊर्णा-वती
<u>'''Ūrṇā-vatī.'''</u>--In the hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_414> x. 75. 8.</ref> which celebrates the rivers Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_414> Translation of the Rigveda, 3. 200.</ref> finds a reference to an affluent of the Indus called [[ऊर्णावती|Ūrṇāvatī]]. This interpretation, however, seems certainly wrong. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_414> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> renders the word merely as ‘woolly,’ and Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_414> ''Altindisches Leben.'' 429.</ref> rejects Ludwig's explanation on the ground that it throws the structure of the hymn into confusion. Pischel<ref name=fx5_ve1_414> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 210.</ref> makes the word an epithet of the Indus, ‘rich in sheep.’

ऊर्दर
<u>'''Ūrdara.'''</u>--This word occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_415> ii. 14, 11.</ref> when reference is made to filling Indra with Soma as one fills an  [[ऊर्दर|Ūrdara]] with grain ('''Yava'''). Sāyaṇa renders it granāry, but Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_415> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_415> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238.</ref> seem more correct in simply making it a measure for holding grain, or ‘garner.’

ऊल
<u>'''Ūla'''</u> is a variant of '''Ula.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

ऊष
<u>'''Ūṣa'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_417> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 3, 2, etc.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve1_417> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 27;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 1, 16, etc.</ref> denotes salt ground suited for cattle. ''Cf.'' '''[[उष|Uṣa]].'''

ऋक्ष
<u>'''1. Ṛkṣa,'''</u> ‘bear,’ is found only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_418> v. 56, 3.</ref> and seldom later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_418> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 36;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 184. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 81.</ref> the animal having evidently been scarce in the regions occupied by the Vedic Indians. Not more frequent<ref name=fx3_ve1_418> Rv. i. 24, 10;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. ii. 1, 2, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 11, 2. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 422.</ref> is the use of the word in the plural to denote the ‘seven bears,’ later called the ‘seven [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]],’<ref name=fx4_ve1_418> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 144 (D).</ref> the constellation of the ‘Great Bear’ (, ''ursa'').

ऋक्ष
<u>'''2. Ṛkṣa'''</u> is the name of a patron mentioned in one verse of a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_419> viii. 68, 15. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> his son being referred to in the next verse as '''[[आर्क्ष|Ārkṣa]].'''

ऋक्षाका
<u>'''Ṛkṣākā'''</u> is a word occurring once in an obscure passage of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_420> xviii. 2, 31.</ref> The sense is quite unknown. Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_420> ''Festgruss an Roth,'' 138, n. 2;<br> Berlin Catalogue, 2, 59, 11.;<br> ''Proccedings of the Berlin Academy,'' 1895, 856.</ref> thinks it refers to the ‘milky way,’ but his view rests on no evidence. Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve1_420> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 840.</ref> despairs of the passage. 

ऋक्षीका
<u>'''Ṛkṣīkā,'''</u> a word found in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_421> xii. 1, 49.</ref> the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_421> xxx. 8.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_421> xiii. 2, 4, 2. 4. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 307.</ref> appears to denote a demon. Harisvāmin, however, in his commentary on the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], connects the word with '''[[ऋक्ष|Ṛkṣa]],''' as meaning ‘bear.’

ऋग्-वेद
<u>'''Ṛg-veda,'''</u> the formal name of the collection of Ṛcs, first appears in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx1_ve1_422> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 32, and implied in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 9, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5, 4, 6;<br> 8, 3;<br> xii. 3, 4, 9.</ref> and thereafter frequently in the Āraṇyakas<ref name=fx2_ve1_422> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 3. 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 3. 8.</ref> and Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx3_ve1_422> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 12;<br> ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 6;<br> 5, 11;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 7;<br> iii. 1, 2. 3;<br> 15, 7;<br> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref>

ऋजिश्वन्
<u>'''Ṛjiśvan'''</u> is mentioned several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_423> i. 51, 5;<br> 53, 8;<br> 101, 1;<br> vi. 20, 7;<br> viii. 49, 10;<br> x. 99, 11;<br> 138, 3.</ref> but always in a vague manner, as if very ancient. He assists Indra in fights against demoniac figures like [[पिप्रु|Pipru]] and the dusky brood (''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]-garbhāḥ''). According to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve1_423> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 143, 149.</ref> he was called Auśija's son,<ref name=fx3_ve1_423> Rv. x. 99, 11. ''Cf.'' '''[[औशिज|Auśija]].'''</ref> but this is doubtful. He is twice<ref name=fx4_ve1_423> Rv. iv. 16, 13;<br> v. 29, 11. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 161 (C).</ref> clearly called [[वैदथिन|Vaidathina]], or descendant of Vidathin.

ऋजूनस्
<u>'''Ṛjūnas'''</u> is mentioned once only in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_424> viii. 52, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> along with six other Soma sacrificers.

ऋज्राश्व
<u>'''Ṛjrāśva'''</u> appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_425> i. 100, 16. 17.</ref> as one of the '''Vārṣāgiras,''' along with '''[[अम्बरीष|Ambarīṣa]], [[सुराधस्|Surādhas]], [[सहदेव|Sahadeva]],''' and '''[[भयमान|Bhayamāna]],''' and as apparently victorious in a race. Elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve1_425> i. 116, 17;<br> 117, 16. 17.</ref> in the  Rigveda he is celebrated as having been blinded by his father for slaying one hundred rams for a she-wolf, and as having been restored to sight by the Aśvins, a legend of quite obscure meaning.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 52.

ऋण
<u>'''Ṛṇa,'''</u> ‘debt,’ is repeatedly mentioned from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_426> ii. 27, 4, etc., usually in a metaphorical sense.</ref> onwards, having apparently been a normal condition among the Vedic Indians. Reference is often made<ref name=fx2_ve1_426> Rv. x. 34, 10;<br> Av. vi. 119, 1.</ref> to debts contracted at dicing. To pay off a debt was called ''ṛṇaṃ saṃ-nī.''<ref name=fx3_ve1_426> Rv. viii. 47, 17 = Av. vi. 46, 3.</ref> Allusion is made to debt contracted without intention of payment.<ref name=fx4_ve1_426> Av. vi. 119, 1.</ref><br><br>The result of non-payment of a debt might be very serious: the dicer might fall into slavery.<ref name=fx5_ve1_426> Rv. x. 34. ''Cf.'' Lüders, ''Das Wūrfelspiel im alten Indien,'' 61.</ref> Debtors, like other malefactors, such as thieves, were frequently bound by their creditors to posts (''[[द्रु-पद|dru-pada]]''),<ref name=fx6_ve1_426> Rv. x. 34, 4, seems to refer rather to the binding and taking away as a slave, though Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 228, explains it as the binding of a debtor for non-payment, interpreting the obscure verse i. 169, 7, in the same way. But Av. vi. 115, 2, 3, may refer to debt, and if this is the meaning the allusion to binding to a post as a punishment is clear. See, however, Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 528, n. 1;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 364, who interprets the hymn as referring only to sin. Rv. i. 24, 13. 15;<br> Av. vi. 63, 3 = 84, 4;<br> 121, 1 ''et seq.,'' are general;<br> while Rv. vii. 86, 5;<br> Av. xix. 47, 9;<br> 50, 1, refer to the binding of thieves in the stocks. ''Cf.'' '''[[तस्कर|Taskara]].'''</ref> presumably as a means of putting pressure on them or their friends to pay up the debt.<br><br>The amount of interest payable is impossible to make out. In one passage of the Rigveda and Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_426> Rv. viii. 47, 17 = Av. vi. 46, 3.</ref> an eighth (''[[शफ|śapha]]'') and a sixteenth (''[[कला|kalā]]'') are mentioned as paid, but it is quite uncertain whether interest or an instalment of the principal is meant. Presumably the interest would be paid in kind.<br><br>How far a debt was a heritable interest or obligation does not appear. The [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_426> xlvi. 36-40. See Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 154;<br> Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' 528.</ref> regards three hymns of the  Atharvaveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_426> vi. 117-119. The name for unpaid debt is in Av. vi. 117, 1, ''apamityam apratītam.'' In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 8, 1, ''kusīdam apratīttam;<br>'' in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 14, 17, and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 3, 1, 8, ''kusīdam apratītam;<br>'' in the [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3. 20, ''apradattam.''</ref> as applicable to the occasion of the payment of a debt after the creditor's decease. For the payment of a debt. by a relation of the debtor the evidence is still less clear.<ref name=fx10_ve1_426> ''Cf.'' Rv. iv. 3, 13 (a brother's sin or debt);<br> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 99, 100.</ref><br><br>Zimmer<ref name=fx11_ve1_426> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 181. This suggestion is ignored by Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' 375, and Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 304.</ref> thinks that payments of debt were made in the presence of witnesses who could be appealed to in case of dispute. This conclusion is, however, very uncertain, resting solely on a vague verse in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx12_ve1_426> vi. 32, 3 = viii. 8, 21. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 14, and see [[ज्ञातृ|Jñātṛ]].<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 181, 182;<br> 259.</ref>

ऋणं-चय
<u>'''Ṛṇaṃ-caya,'''</u> a prince of the '''Ruśamas,''' is celebrated in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) of the Rigveda (v. 30, 12. 14) for his generosity to a poet named '''[[बभ्रु|Babhru]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 129; Bṛhadevatā, ed. Macdonell, 2, 169, 174.<br>==Foot Notes==

ऋतु
<u>'''Ṛtu,'''</u> ‘season,’ is a term repeatedly mentioned from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_428> i. 49, 3;<br> 84, 18, etc.</ref> onwards, Three seasons of the year are often alluded to,<ref name=fx2_ve1_428> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 164, 2 (''tri-[[नाभि|nābhi]]''), 48 (''trīṇi nabhyāni'');<br> also perhaps the Ṛbhus as the genii of the three seasons and the three dawns. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 133;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 33 ''et seq.:'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 1, 28, and the ''cāturmāsyāni,'' or four-monthly sacrifices performed at the beginning of the seasons in the ritual (Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 329 ''et seq.'').</ref> but the names are not usually specified. In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_428> x. 90, 6. Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 35, finds in Rv. v. 14, 4: ix. 91, 6, reference to three seasons in the triad ''gāvaḥ'' (? spring), ''āpaḥ'' (rains), ''svar (= [[घर्म|gharma]]),'' and in the ritual literature (Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 4, 2) in the threefold division into ''ṛta, [[घर्म|gharma]],'' and ''[[ओषधि|oṣadhi]].''</ref> spring (''[[वसन्त|vasanta]]''), summer (''[[ग्रीष्म|grīṣma]]''), and autumn (''[[शरद्|śarad]]'') are given. The Rigveda knows also the rainy season (''[[प्रा-वृष्|prā-vṛṣ]]'') and the winter (''[[हिमा|himā]], [[हेमन्त|hemanta]]''). A more usual<ref name=fx4_ve1_428> Av. viii. 2, 22;<br> 9, 15;<br> xiii. 1, 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 2, 3;<br> iv. 3, 3, 1. 2;<br> v. 1, 10, 3;<br> 3, 1, 2;<br> 4. 12, 2;<br> 6. 10, 1;<br> 7, 2, 4;<br> vii. 1, 18, 1. 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 7, 3;<br> iii. 4, 8;<br> 13, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, iv. 14;<br> ix. 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 10-14;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 5, 11;<br> vi. 2, 2, 3. etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 4, 1;<br> 11, 10, 4, etc. ''Cf.'' Rv. i, 164, 13. See also Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 352.</ref> division (not found in the Rigveda) is into five seasons,  ''[[वसन्त|vasanta]], [[ग्रीष्म|grīṣma]], varṣā, [[शरद्|śarad]], hemama-siśira,'' but occasionally the five are otherwise divided, ''varṣā-[[शरद्|śarad]]'' being made one season.<ref name=fx5_ve1_428> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 6, 1, 10. 11.</ref> Sometimes six<ref name=fx6_ve1_428> Av. vi. 55, 2;<br> xii. 1, 36;<br> Taittīrīya Saṃhitā, v. 1, 5, 2;<br> 7, 3;<br> 2. 6, 1, etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 7, 3;<br> iii. 11, 12;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 23-28;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 2, 21;<br> ii. 4, 2, 24;<br> xii. 8, 2, 34;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 19, etc. ''Cf.'' also Rv. i. 23, 15, as interpreted by Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. indu.''</ref> seasons are reckoned, ''[[हेमन्त|hemanta]]'' and ''[[शिशिर|śiśira]]'' being divided, so that the six seasons can be made parallel to the twelve months of the year. A still more artificial arrangement<ref name=fx7_ve1_428> Av. vi. 61, 2;<br> viii. 9, 18;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5, 1, 15;<br> ix. 1, 2, 31;<br> 2, 3, 45;<br> 3, 1, 19;<br> 5, 2, 8;<br> perhaps Av. iv. 11, 9, and ''of.'' Rv. i. 164. 1.</ref> makes the seasons seven, possibly by reckoning the intercalary month as a season, as Weber and Zimmer<ref name=fx8_ve1_428> ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 44;<br> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 374.</ref> hold, or more probably because of the predilection for the number seven, as Roth<ref name=fx9_ve1_428> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[ऋतु|ṛtu]]. Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Religions of India,'' 18, 33.</ref> suggests. Occasionally the word ''[[ऋतु|ṛtu]]'' is applied to the months.<ref name=fx10_ve1_428> Av. xv. 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 11, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 25;<br> xiv. 6. 15. 26. 27;<br> xv. 57, etc.</ref> The last season, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx11_ve1_428> i. 5. 3. 13.</ref> is ''[[हेमन्त|hemanta]].''<br><br>The growth of the division of the seasons from three to five is rightly explained by Zimmer<ref name=fx12_ve1_428> ''Op. cit.,'' 373.</ref> as indicating the advance of the Vedic Indians towards the east. It is not Rigvedic, but dominates the later Saṃhitās. Traces of an earlier division of the year into winter and summer do not appear clearly in the Rigveda, where the appropriate words ''[[हिमा|himā]]'' and ''[[समा|samā]]'' are merely general appellations of the year, and where ''[[शरद्|śarad]]''<ref name=fx13_ve1_428> Hopkins, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 15, 159, 160: Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 232;<br> Bühler, ''Zcitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 41, 28.</ref> is commoner than either as a designation of the year, because it denotes the harvest, a time of overwhelming importance to a young agricultural people. The division of the year in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx14_ve1_428> viii. 9, 17. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, 372.</ref> into two periods of six months is merely formal, and in no way an indication of old tradition. 

ऋतु-पर्ण
<u>'''Ṛtu-parṇa'''</u> appears in a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]-like passage of the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_429> xx. 12.</ref> as son of [[भङ्गाश्विन|Bhaṅgāśvina]] and king of [[शफाल|Śaphāla]]. In the Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_429> xxi. 20, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 57, 745.</ref> are mentioned [[ऋतुपर्ण|Ṛtuparṇa]]-Kayovadhī Bhaṅgyaśvinau.

ऋत्व्-इज्
<u>'''Ṛtv-ij'''</u> is the regular term for ‘sacrificial priest,’ covering all the different kinds of priests employed at the sacrifice. It appears certain that all the priests were Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_430> This is assumed throughout the Vedic texts, and is accompanied by the rule that no [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] can eat of the sacrificial offering (''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 26): no doubt because only the Brāhmaṇas were sufficiently holy to receive the divine essence of the sacrifice into which, by partaking of it, the deity has entered in part.</ref> The number of priests officiating at a sacrifice with different functions was almost certainly seven. The oldest list, occurring in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_430> ii. 1, 2. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg. ''Rdigion des Veda,'' 383.</ref> enumerates their names as [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], [[पोतृ|Potṛ]], [[नेष्टृ|Neṣṭṛ]], Agnīdh, [[प्रशास्तृ|Praśāstṛ]], [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], besides the institutor of the sacrifice. The number of seven probably explains the phrase ‘seven Hotṛs’ occurring so frequently in the Rigveda, and is most likely connected with that of the mythical ‘seven [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]].’ It may be compared with the eight of Iran.<ref name=fx3_ve1_430> Darmesteter, ''Le Zend-Avesta,'' 1, lxx ''et seq.''</ref> The chief of the seven priests was the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], who was the singer of the hymns, and in the early times their composer also. The [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] performed the practical work of the sacrifice, and accompanied his performance with muttered formulas of prayer and deprecation of evil. His chief assistance was derived from the Agnīdh, the two performing the smaller sacrifices without other help in practical matters. The [[प्रशास्तृ|Praśāstṛ]], Upavaktṛ, or Maitrāvaruṇa, as he was variously called, appeared only in the greater sacrifices as giving instructions to the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], and as entrusted with certain litanies. The [[पोतृ|Potṛ]], [[नेष्टृ|Neṣṭṛ]], and [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] belonged to the ritual of the Soma sacrifice, the latter being later styled [[ब्राह्मणाच्छंसिन्|Brāhmaṇācchaṃsin]] to distinguish him from the priest who in the later  ritual acted as supervisor. Other priests referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_430> Rv. viii. 81. 5.</ref> are the singers of Sāmans or chants, the Udgātṛ and his assistant the [[प्रस्तोतृ|Prastotṛ]], while the [[प्रतिहर्तृ|Pratihartṛ]], another assistant, though not mentioned, may quite well have been known. Their functions undoubtedly represent a later stage of the ritual, the development of the elaborate series of sacrificial calls on the one hand, and on the other the use of long hymns addressed to the Soma plant. Other priests, such as the Achāvāka,<ref name=fx5_ve1_430> ''Cf.,'' for the Achāvāka, [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxviii. 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 14, 8, etc.;<br> Bergaigne, ''Recherches sur l'histoire de la liturgie védique,'' 47;<br> Oldenberg. ''Religion des Veda,'' 397, n. 2. The other three occur in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] and other Brāhmaṇas. See St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the Grāvastut, the Unnetṛ, and the [[सुब्रह्मण्य|Subrahmaṇya]], were known later in the developed ritual of the Brāhmaṇas, making in all sixteen priests, who were technically and artificially classed in four groups<ref name=fx6_ve1_430> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 1, 4-6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta Sūtras, xiii. 14, 1, etc. In the Rigveda [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] the order of the four sets is [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], Udgātṛ, and [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]]. Sometimes a seventeenth priest is mentioned, but he was not usually approved, though the Kauṣītakins maintained him as the [[सदस्य|Sadasya]]. See Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 4, 1, 19;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 348, n.;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 37;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 375.</ref> [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], Maitrāvaruṇa, Achāvāka, and Grāvastut; Udgātṛ, [[प्रस्तोतृ|Prastotṛ]], [[प्रतिहर्तृ|Pratihartṛ]], and [[सुब्रह्मण्य|Subrahmaṇya]]; [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], Pratisthātṛ, [[नेष्टृ|Neṣṭṛ]], and Unnetṛ; [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], [[ब्राह्मणाच्छंसिन्|Brāhmaṇācchaṃsin]], Agnīdhra, and Petṛ.<br><br>Apart from all these priests was the '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]],''' who was the spiritual adviser of the king in all his religious duties. Geldner<ref name=fx7_ve1_430> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 143 ''et seq.''</ref> holds that, as a rule, when the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] actually took part in one of the great sacrifices he played the part of the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], in the sense of the priest who superintended the whole conduct of the ritual. He sees evidence for this view in a considerable number of passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx8_ve1_430> Rv. i. 44, 10;<br> 94, 6;<br> viii. 27, 1, etc.</ref> and the later literature,<ref name=fx9_ve1_430> [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]] is [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of the gods, Rv. ii. 24, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 1, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 17, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 2;<br> but [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] in Rv. x. 141, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 4, 21. [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] is [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], Rv. x. 150, 5, of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] [[पैजवन|Paijavana]], [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 11, 4;<br> but [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] of the Sunaḥśepa sacrifice, ''ibid,'' xv. 21.</ref> where [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] and [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] were combined or identified. Oldenberg,<ref name=fx10_ve1_430> ''Op. cit.,'' 380 ''et seq.''</ref> however, more correctly points out  that in the earlier period this was not the case: the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] was then normally the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], the singer of the most important of the songs; it was only later that the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], who in the capacity of overseer of the rite is not known to the Rigveda, acquired the function of general supervision hitherto exercised by the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], who was ''ex officio'' skilled in the use of magic and in guarding the king by spells which could also be applied to guarding the sacrifice from evil demons. With this agrees the fact that Agni, pre-eminently<ref name=fx11_ve1_430> Agni as [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] and [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] occurs in Rv. i. 1, 1;<br> iii. 3, 2;<br> 11, 1;<br> v. 11, 2. His Purohitaship is described in terms characteristic of the Hotṛ's funcitons in Rv. viii. 27, 1;<br> x. 1, 6. Devāpi is [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] and [[होतृ|Hotṛ]]. Rv. x. 98.</ref> the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of men, is also a [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], and that the two divine Hotṛs of the Āprī hymns are called<ref name=fx12_ve1_430> Rv. x. 66, 13;<br> in x. 70, 7, ''purohitāv ṛtvijā.''</ref> the divine Purohitas. On the other hand, the rule is explicitly recognized in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx13_ve1_430> vii. 26.</ref> that a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] should have a [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] as a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]; and in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx14_ve1_430> iii. 5, 2, 1, etc.</ref> the [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] family have a special claim to the office of [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]]-[[पुरोहित|Purohita]], perhaps an indication that it was they who first as Purohitas exchanged the function of Hotṛs for that of Brahmans in the sacrificial ritual.<br><br>The sacrifices were performed for an individual in the great majority of cases. The Sattra,<ref name=fx15_ve1_430> Oldenberg, 371.</ref> or prolonged sacrificial session, was, however, performed for the common benefit of the priests taking part in it, though its advantageous results could only be secured if all the members actually engaged were consecrated (''dīkṣita''). Sacrifices for a people as such were unknown. The sacrifice for the king was, it is true, intended to bring about the prosperity of his people also; but it is characteristic that the prayer<ref name=fx16_ve1_430> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 18;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 14, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 141 ''et seq.;<br>'' 376 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 97;<br> Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 370397;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 224.</ref> for welfare includes by name only the priest and the king, referring to the people indirectly in connexion with the prosperity of their cattle and agriculture. 

ऋश्य
<u>'''Ṛśya'''</u>--This is the correct<ref name=fx1_ve1_431> It appears in Av. iv. 4. 7, as Ṛśa;<br> as Ṛṣya in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 9. 18.</ref> spelling of a word that occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_431> viii. 4, 10.</ref> and the later literature<ref name=fx3_ve1_431> Av. iv. 4. 5. 7;<br> v. 14, 3;<br> i. 18. 4 (''[[ऋश्य|ṛśya]]-pad'');<br> Vājasaneyi Samhitā, xxiv. 27.37;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 33;<br> citation in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 25, 8, etc.</ref> meaning ‘stag,’ the feminine being '''[[रोहित्|Rohit]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_431> Av. iv. 4, 7.</ref> Apparently deer were caught in pits (''[[ऋश्य|ṛśya]]-da'').<ref name=fx5_ve1_431> Rv. x. 39, 8.</ref> The procreative power of the stag (''ārśya vṛṣṇya'') was celebrated.<ref name=fx6_ve1_431> Av. iv. 4, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 18;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 82;<br> Whitney. Translation of the Atharvaveda, 150, 151.</ref>

ऋषभ
<u>'''1.
