Ṛṣabha'''</u> is the common name of the ‘bull’ from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_432> vi. 16, 47;<br> 28, 8;<br> x. 91, 14, etc.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_432> Av. iii. 6, 4;<br> 23, 4, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3, 2, etc.;<br> vajasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 22, etc.;<br> Pañcavimśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 18, etc.</ref> See also '''Go.'''

ऋषभ
<u>'''2. Ṛṣabha,'''</u> king of the Śviknas, appears in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_433> xiii. 5, 4, 15. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 9. 8-10.</ref> with the patronymic [[याज्ञतुर|Yājñatura]], as one of those who performed an [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] or horse sacrifice. He is also mentioned there<ref name=fx2_ve1_433> xii. 8, 3. 7.</ref> as having probably been the source of a saying of '''Gaurīviti Śāktya's.'''

ऋषभ
<u>'''3. Ṛṣabha'''</u> is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 17) as a son of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]].<br>==Foot Notes==

ऋषि
<u>'''Ṛṣi,'''</u> ‘seer,’ is primarily a composer of hymns to the gods. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_435> i. 1, 2;<br> 45, 3;<br> viii. 43, 13, etc.</ref> reference is often made to previous singers and to contemporary poets. Old poems were inherited and refurbished by members of the composer's family,<ref name=fx2_ve1_435> i. 89, 3;<br> 96, 2;<br> iii. 39, 2;<br> viii. 6. 11. 43;<br> 76, 6, etc.</ref> but the great aim of the singers was to produce new and approved hymns.<ref name=fx3_ve1_435> i. 109, 2;<br> ii. 18, 3;<br> iii. 62, 7;<br> vi. 50, 6;<br> vii. 14, 4;<br> 93, 1;<br> viii. 23, 14, etc.</ref> It is not till the time of the Brāhmaṇas that the  composition of hymns appears to have fallen into disuse,<ref name=fx4_ve1_435> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 151.</ref> though poetry was still produced, for example, in the form of '''Gāthās,''' which the priests were required to compose themselves<ref name=fx5_ve1_435> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 8;<br> 3, 5.</ref> and sing to the accompaniment of the lute at the sacrifice. The [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] was the most exalted of Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx6_ve1_435> Rv. ix. 96, 6, etc. ''Cf.'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 4, 6, where preeminence is assigned to a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] descended from a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]].</ref> and his skill, which is often compared with that of a carpenter,<ref name=fx7_ve1_435> Rv. i. 130, 6;<br> v. 2, 11;<br> 29, 15;<br> 73, 10;<br> x. 39, 14. So a poet is a [[कारु|Kāru]](if from ''kṛ,'' ‘make,’ but usually derived from ''kṛ,'' ‘commemorate’), and makes (''kṛ,'' Rv. ii. 39. 8;<br> viii. 62, 4) as well as creates (''jan,'' Rv. vii. 15, 4;<br> viii. 88, 4) hymns.</ref> was regarded as heaven-sent.<ref name=fx8_ve1_435> Rv. i. 37, 4;<br> vii. 36. 1. 9;<br> viii. 32, 27;<br> 57. 6, etc.</ref> The [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], whether as [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] or as [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] (see '''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]'''), was a singer.<ref name=fx9_ve1_435> Rv. i. 151, 7;<br> Geldner, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 153;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 380.</ref> No doubt the [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] were normally<ref name=fx10_ve1_435> Geldner, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 154, cites the Dānastutis as characteristic of princes in the tradition of the Bṛhaddevatā, etc.</ref> attached to the houses of the great, the petty kings of Vedic times, or the nobles of the royal household. Nor need it be doubted that occasionally<ref name=fx11_ve1_435> ''Ibid.,'' 154.</ref> the princes themselves essayed poetry: a [[राजन्यर्षि|Rājanyarṣi]], the prototype of the later Rājarṣi or ‘royal seer,’ who appears in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx12_ve1_435> xii. 12, 6, etc.</ref> though he must be mythical as Oldenberg<ref name=fx13_ve1_435> ''Zeitschrift dev Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 45, 235. n. 3.</ref> points out, indicates that kings cultivated poetry<ref name=fx14_ve1_435> Later on it was deemed quite normal and natural. See the story of [[रथवीति दार्भ्य|Rathavīti Dārbhya]], or [[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]], himself a royal seer, and [[तरन्त|Taranta]] and [[पुरुमीळ्ह|Purumīḷha]], seers and also kings, in Bṛhaddevata, v. 50 ''et seq.''</ref> just as later they engaged in philosophic disputations.<ref name=fx15_ve1_435> ''Cf.'' Garbe, ''Philosophy of Ancient India,'' 73 ''et seq.;<br>'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upaniṣads,'' 16 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 50.</ref> Normally, however, the poetical function is Brahminical, Viśāmitra and others not being kings, but merely Brāhmaṇas, in the Rigveda.<br><br>In the later literature the [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] are the poets of the hymns preserved in the Saṃhitās. a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] being regularly<ref name=fx16_ve1_435> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 25;<br> viii. 26;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 4, 4;<br> ii. 2, 3, 6;<br> 5, 1, 4;<br> vi, 1, 1, 1, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 3, etc.</ref> cited when a Vedic Saṃhitā is quoted. Moreover, the [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] become the representatives of a sacred past, and are regarded as holy sages,  whose deeds are narrated as if they were the deeds of gods or Asuras.<ref name=fx17_ve1_435> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 17;<br> ii. 19;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 2, 7, etc.</ref> They are typified by a particular group of seven,<ref name=fx18_ve1_435> ''Cf. Indische Studien,'' 8, 167.</ref> mentioned four times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx19_ve1_435> iv. 42, 8;<br> x. 109, 4;<br> 130, 7;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 144.</ref> several times in the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx20_ve1_435> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 24;<br> Av xi. 1, 1. 24;<br> xii. 1, 39, etc.</ref> and enumerated in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx21_ve1_435> ii. 2, 6.</ref> as [[गोतम|Gotama]], [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]], [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]], [[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]], [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], [[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]], and Atri. In the Rigveda itself [[कुत्स|Kutsa]],<ref name=fx22_ve1_435> i. 106, 6.</ref> Atri,<ref name=fx23_ve1_435> i. 117, 3.</ref> [[रेभ|Rebha]],<ref name=fx24_ve1_435> i. 117, 4.</ref> [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]],<ref name=fx25_ve1_435> i. 179, 6.</ref> the Kuśikas,<ref name=fx26_ve1_435> iii. 53. 10.</ref> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]],<ref name=fx27_ve1_435> vii. 33. 13.</ref> [[व्य्अश्व|Vyaśva]],<ref name=fx28_ve1_435> viii. 23, 16.</ref> and others appear as [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]]; and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx29_ve1_435> iv. 29. ''Cf.'' xviii. 3, 15. 16.</ref> contains a long list, including [[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]], Agastī, [[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]], Atri, [[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]], [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]], Gaviṣṭhira, [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]], [[कुत्स|Kutsa]], [[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]], [[कण्व|Kaṇva]], [[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]], [[त्रिशोक|Triśoka]], [[उशना|Uśanā]] [[काव्य|Kāvya]], [[गोतम|Gotama]], and [[मुद्गल|Mudgala]].<br><br>Competition among the bards appears to have been known. This is one of the sides of the riddle poetry ('''[[ब्रह्मोद्य|Brahmodya]]''') that forms a distinctive feature<ref name=fx30_ve1_435> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 345, 346;<br> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 172;<br> ''Religion des Veda,'' 216 ''et seq.''</ref> of the Vedic ritual of the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice. In the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] period such competitions were quite frequent. The most famous was that of [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]], which was held at the court of [[जनक|Janaka]] of [[विदेह|Videha]], as detailed in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx31_ve1_435> iii. 1, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> and which was a source of annoyance to '''[[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]]''' of '''Kāśī.'''<ref name=fx32_ve1_435> ''Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],'' ii. 1, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1 ''et seq.''</ref> According to an analogous practice, a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], like '''Uddālaka Aruṇi,''' would go about disputing with all he came across, and compete with them for a prize of money.<ref name=fx33_ve1_435> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 4, 1, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3. 8 ''et seq.;<br>'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 185, 344.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 340347;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 3, 120 ''et seq.''</ref>

ऋषिस्
<u>'''Ṛṣis.'''</u>--The term ‘Seven Ṛṣis’ denotes the ‘Great Bear’ (see 1. '''[[ऋक्ष|Ṛkṣa]]''') in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_436> x. 82, 2.</ref> and occasionally  later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_436> Av vi. 40, 1 (where, however, Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 310. merely renders it as ‘seven seers,’ and appears not to take it in a technical sense);<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 2, 4;<br> xiii. 8, 1, 9;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], x. 26, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 422;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 144.</ref> This is probably a secondary use, instead of the seven Ṛkṣas, brought about by the frequent mention of the seven [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]].

ऋष्टि
<u>'''Ṛṣṭi'''</u> is a term frequently employed in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_437> Rv. i. 37, 1;<br> 64, 4. 8;<br> 166, 4;<br> v. 52, 6;<br> 54, 11;<br> 57, 6;<br> viii. 20, 11. Indra has a [[ऋष्टि|Ṛṣṭi]] in Rv. i. 169, 3 (''cf.'' Av. iv. 37. 8). ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 79.</ref> to designate a weapon held in the hands of the Maruts, and doubtless meant to indicate lightning. That it denotes a spear in mortal warfare, as Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_437> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 301.</ref> thinks, is not shown by a single passage.<ref name=fx3_ve1_437> Rv. i. 167. 3;<br> vii. 55. 2;<br> viii. 28, 5;<br> x. 87, 7. 24 are all mythological or contain similes.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Preshistoric Antiquities,'' 221.</ref>

ऋष्टि-षेण
<u>'''Ṛṣṭi-ṣeṇa'''</u> is mentioned in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_438> ii. 11. ''Cf.'' Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 130, 136.</ref> as an explanation of the patronymic '''Ārṣṭiṣeṇa,''' but nothing else is known of him.

ऋष्य-शृङ्ग
<u>'''Ṛṣya-śṛṅga'''</u> appears as a teacher, pupil of Kāśyapa, and as bearing the patronymic Kāśyapa in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] Brahmaṇa<ref name=fx1_ve1_439> iii. 40, 1 (in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]], or list of teachers).</ref> and in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_439> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 374, 385.</ref> The more correct spelling of the name is [[ऋश्य|Ṛśya]]-[[शृङ्ग|śṛṅga]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_439> The later legend connected with the name may contain old elements (see Lūders, ''Die Sage von Ṛshyaśṛṅga,'' 1897;<br> Von Schroeder, ''Mysterium und Mimus,'' 292-301), but it is not known to any Vedic text.</ref>

एक-द्यू
<u>'''Eka-dyū'''</u> is mentioned as a poet in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_440> viii. 80, 10. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 112.</ref>

एक-यवन् गां-दम
<u>'''Eka-yavan Gāṃ-dama'''</u> is a man mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_441> xxi. 14, 20.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_441> ii. 7, 11 (Kāṃdama). ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' i. 32;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 69.</ref> 

एक-राज्
<u>'''Eka-rāj,'''</u> ‘sole ruler,’ ‘monarch,’ seems to mean no more than ‘king.’ In the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_442> viii. 37. 3.</ref> the term is used metaphorically only. But it is found with the literal sense in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_442> viii. 15.</ref> as well as in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_442> iii. 4, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],'' 141</ref>

एकायन
<u>'''Ekāyana'''</u> denotes some object of study in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_443> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> The St. Petersburg Dictionary renders it ‘doctrine (''ayana'') of unity’ (''eka''), ‘monotheism,’ while Max Müller prefers ‘ethics,’ and Monier-Williams in his Dicitionary ‘worldly wisdom.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_443> Max Müller and Monier-Williams thus follow Śaṅkara's interpretation as ''nīti-śāstra,'' ‘moral teaching.’ ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 267, 484;<br> Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 43.</ref>

एकाष्टका
<u>'''Ekāṣṭakā.'''</u>--That [[अष्टका|Aṣṭakā]] is the eighth day after the full moon appears clearly from the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_444> xv. 16, 2. ''Cf.'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 2, 23;<br> 4, 2, 10.</ref> [[एकाष्टका|Ekāṣṭakā]], or ‘sole [[अष्टका|Aṣṭakā]],’ must denote not merely any [[अष्टका|Aṣṭakā]], but some particular one. Sāyaṇa, in his commentary on the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_444> iii. 10.</ref> in which a whole hymn celebrates the [[एकाष्टका|Ekāṣṭakā]], fixes the date meant by the term as the eighth day in the dark half of the month of Māgha (January--February). The [[एकाष्टका|Ekāṣṭakā]], is declared in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_444> vii. 4, 8 1. ''Cf.'' iii. 3, 8, 4;<br> iv. 3, 11, 1;<br> v. 7, 2, 2;<br> Pañcaviṃśa Brāl maṇa, v. 9, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 305;<br> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 341, 342.</ref> to be the time for the consecration (''dīkṣā'') of those who are going to perform a year long sacrifice. See also '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

एजत्क
<u>'''Ejatka'''</u> is the name of an insect in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_445> v. 23, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindiches Leben,'' 98;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 262.</ref>

एडक
<u>'''Eḍaka'''</u> appears to denote a ‘vicious ram’ in the Śatapatha<ref name=fx1_ve1_446> xii. 4, 1, 4;<br> ''cf.'' ii. 5, 2, 15.</ref> and Jaiminīya<ref name=fx2_ve1_446> i. 51, 4 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 23, 332). ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacrea Books of the East,'' 44, 178.</ref> Brāhmaṇas. 

एणी
<u>'''Eṇī'''</u> denotes the ‘female antelope’ in the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_447> Av. v. 14, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 15, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 36;<br> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 82.</ref> perhaps as the feminine of '''Eta.'''

एत
<u>'''Eta'''</u> in the plural (''etāḥ'') denotes the steeds of the Maruts, being a swift species of deer, which are mentioned several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_448> i. 165. 2;<br> 169, 6, 7;<br> v. 54, 5;<br> x. 77. 2.</ref> and the skins of which are also said to be worn by the Maruts on their shoulders.<ref name=fx2_ve1_448> Rv. i. 166, 10. ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> The epithet ''pṛthubudhna,'' once applied to them in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_448> i. 169. 6.</ref> and variously interpreted as ‘broad-hoofed,’<ref name=fx4_ve1_448> By Grassman and Zimmer.</ref> ‘broad-chested,’<ref name=fx5_ve1_448> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 235.</ref> and ‘broad in the hinder part,’<ref name=fx6_ve1_448> Monier-Williams, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> seems to indicate that they were not gazelles.<ref name=fx7_ve1_448> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83.</ref>

एतश
<u>'''1. Etaśa'''</u> is in several passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_449> i. 62, 15;<br> iv. 30. 6;<br> v. 29. 5.</ref> according to Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_449> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the name of a protégé whom Indra helped against the sun-god [[सूर्य|Sūrya]]. But in all these passages [[एतश|Etaśa]] seems merely to designate the horse of the sun.<ref name=fx3_ve1_449> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 149. 150.</ref>

एतश
<u>'''2. Etaśa'''</u> is in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_450> xxx. 5.</ref> the name of a sage who is said to have cursed his children because they interrupted him in the midst of a rite; hence the Aitaśāyanas (descendants of [[एतश|Etaśa]]) are declared to be the worst of the Bhṛgus. The same story appears in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāhmaṇā<ref name=fx2_ve1_450> vi. 33. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt. ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 173.</ref> where, however, the sage's name is [[ऐतश|Aitaśa]], and the Aitaśāyanas are described as the worst of the Aurvas.

एदिधिषुः-पति
<u>'''Edidhiṣuḥ-pati'''</u> is a term occurring only in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_451> xxx. 9.</ref> where the commentator Mahīdhara interprets it as  meaning the ‘husband of a younger sister married before the elder sister.’ Though this sense is probably correct, the form is doubtless, as Delbrück<ref name=fx2_ve1_451> ''Die indogermanischen Verwandschaftsnamen,'' 569. n. 1.</ref> points out, corrupt. See '''[[दिधिषूपति|Didhiṣūpati]].'''

एरण्ड
<u>'''Eraṇḍa,'''</u> the castor-oil plant (''Ricinus communis''), is first mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (xii. 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

एवावद
<u>'''Evāvada'''</u> is regarded by Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve1_453> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138.</ref> in a very obscure passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_453> v. 44, 10.</ref> as the name of a singer beside '''[[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]], [[मनस|Manasa]],''' and '''[[यजत|Yajata]].''' The commentator Sāyaṇa also interprets the word as a proper name. Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_453> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> however, considers it to be an adjective meaning ‘truthful.’

ऐकादशाक्ष मानु-तन्तव्य
<u>'''Aikādaśākṣa Mānu-tantavya'''</u> appears in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_454> v. 30. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 223.</ref> as a king who observed the rule of sacrificing when the sun had risen (''udita-homin''), and as a contemporary of '''[[नगरिन् जान-श्रुतेय|Nagarin <a class="pada_vei" href="जान">Jāna]]-śruteya».'''

ऐक्ष्वाक
<u>'''Aikṣvāka,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]],’ is the patronymic borne by '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_455> xiii. 5, 4, 5.</ref> Another [[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]] is Vārṣṇi, a teacher mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_455> i. 5, 4.</ref> A king '''[[हरिश्चन्द्र वैधस|Hariścandra Vaidhasa]]''' [[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]] is known to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_455> vii. 13, 16.</ref> and '''Tryaruṇa''' is an [[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]] in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_455> xiii. 3, 12.</ref>

ऐतरेय
<u>'''Aitareya,'''</u> perhaps a patronymic from Itara, though the commentator Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx1_ve1_456> Cited by Aufrecht, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],'' 3.</ref> regards the word as a metronymic from  Itarā, is an epithet of '''Mahidāsa''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve1_456> ii. 1, 8;<br> 3. 7.</ref> and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_456> iii. 16, 7. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 389. The form Aitareyin occurs in the Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 1;<br> Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 3, etc.;<br> and a [[महैतरेय|Mahaitareya]] in Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 4, etc.</ref>

ऐतश
<u>'''Aitaśa, Aitaśāyana.'''</u> See '''[[एतश|Etaśa]], Etaśāyana.''' The Aitaśapralāpa, or ‘Discourse of [[ऐतश|Aitaśa]],’ is a part of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_457> xx. 129-132. ''Cf.'' Bṛhaddevatā, viii. 101, with Macdonell's note.</ref>

ऐति-हासिक
<u>'''Aiti-hāsika.'''</u>--This term was applied to the people who explained the Vedic hymns by treating them as legendary history ('''[[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]'''), as Sieg<ref name=fx1_ve1_458> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 13 ''et seq.''</ref> shows by the passages of the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_458> ii. 16;<br> xii. 1, etc.</ref> where their views are opposed to those of the '''Nairuktas,''' who relied rather on etymology. Sieg<ref name=fx3_ve1_458> ''Op. cit.,'' 29.</ref> also seems right in finding them in the Naidānas of the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]:<ref name=fx4_ve1_458> vi. 9;<br> vii. 6.</ref> it is possible that their textbook was called the [[निदान|Nidāna]].

ऐभावत
<u>'''Aibhāvata,'''</u> ‘descendant of Ibhāvant,’ is the patronymic of '''Pratīdarśa.'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_459> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 2, 3.</ref>

ऐरावत
<u>'''Airāvata,'''</u> ‘son of Irāvant,’ is the patronymic of [[धृतराष्ट्र|Dhṛtarāṣṭra]], as a snake demon,<ref name=fx1_ve1_460> In the later literature [[ऐरावत|Airāvata]] is the elephant of Indra: perhaps connected with this Vedic snake demon. as ''[[नाग|nāga]]'' means both ‘serpent’ and ‘elephant.’</ref> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_460> viii. 10, 29.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_460> xxv. 15, 3.</ref>

ऐलूष
<u>'''Ailūṣa,'''</u> ‘descendant of Ilūṣa,’ is the patronymic of '''[[कवष|Kavaṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

ऐष-कृत
<u>'''Aiṣa-kṛta.'''</u> See '''Śitibāhu.''' <br>==Foot Notes==

ऐषा-वीर
<u>'''Aiṣā-vīra.'''</u>--The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] once<ref name=fx1_ve1_463> xi. 2, 7, 32.</ref> refers to the Aiṣā-vīras as officiating at a sacrifice, with the implication that they were bad sacrificers. Sāyaṇa regards the word as a proper name (‘descendants of Eṣavīra’), denoting the members of a despised family. But Roth may be right in explaining the word both in the passage mentioned above and elsewhere as meaning ‘weak’<ref name=fx2_ve1_463> In the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> or ‘insignificant man.’<ref name=fx3_ve1_463> In Bo7htlingk's Dictionary, ''s.v.'' (‘one who wishes to be a man, but is not’). ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 5, 1, 16;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, where, however, Lindner's edition reads ''saiṣā [[वीर|vīra]] iva. Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 228;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 45.</ref>

ऐषुमत
<u>'''Aiṣumata,'''</u> ‘descendant of Iṣumant,’ is the patronymic of '''Trāta''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_464> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

ओगण
<u>'''Ogaṇa'''</u> is a word occurring only once, as a plural, in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_465> x. 89, 15</ref> where it appears to indicate persons hostile to the seer of the hymn, and apparently opposed to the Āryan religion. Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_465> Translation of the Rigveda, 5, 209.</ref> regards the terms as the proper name of a people, but Pischel<ref name=fx3_ve1_465> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 191, 192.</ref> thinks that it is merely an adjective meaning ‘weak’ (''[[ओगण|ogaṇa]] = ava-gaṇa''), as in Pāli.

ओतु
<u>'''Otu'''</u> in Vedic literature<ref name=fx1_ve1_466> Rv. vi. 9, 2. 3;<br> Av. xiv. 2, 51;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 4, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘woof’ in weaving and corresponds to '''[[तन्तु|Tantu]],''' ‘the warp,’ the roots ''vā,''<ref name=fx2_ve1_466> Rv. vi. 9, 2. etc.</ref> ‘to weave,’ and ''tan,''<ref name=fx3_ve1_466> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 80;<br> Rv. x. 130, 2;<br> Av. x. 7, 43, etc.</ref> to stretch,’ from which these two terms are derived, being used in parallel senses. In the process of weaving a shuttle ('''[[तसर|Tasara]]''') was used. The ‘weaver’ is termed ''vāya,''<ref name=fx4_ve1_466> Rv. x. 26, 6, etc.</ref> and the ‘loom’ ''veman.''<ref name=fx5_ve1_466> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 83.</ref> A wooden peg ('''[[मयूख|Mayūkha]]''') was used to  stretch the web on, while lead was employed as a weight to extend it.<ref name=fx6_ve1_466> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 80.</ref><br><br>The work of weaving was probably the special care of women.<ref name=fx7_ve1_466> Av. x. 7, 42;<br> xiv. 2, 51. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 92. 3.</ref> A metaphor in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx8_ve1_466> x. 7, 42;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 5, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 254, 255;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 465.</ref> personifies Night and Day as two sisters weaving the web of the year, the nights serving as warp, the days as woof.

ओदन
<u>'''Odana'''</u> is a common expression<ref name=fx1_ve1_467> Rv. viii. 69, 14, etc.;<br> Av. iv. 14, 7, etc.</ref> denoting a mess, usually of grain cooked with milk (''[[क्षीर|kṣīra]]-pākam odanam'').<ref name=fx2_ve1_467> Rv. viii. 77, 10.</ref> Special varieties are mentioned, such as the ‘milk-mess’ (''[[क्षीरौदन|kṣīraudana]]''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_467> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 3, 4;<br> xi. 5, 7, 5;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 13.</ref> the ‘curd-mess’ (''dadhy-[[ओदन|odana]]''),<ref name=fx4_ve1_467> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 14.</ref> the ‘bean-mess’ (''mudgaudana''),<ref name=fx5_ve1_467> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8.</ref> the ‘sesame-mess’ (''tilaudana''),<ref name=fx6_ve1_467> ''Ibid.;<br>'' Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 15.</ref> the ‘water-mess’ (''udaudana''),<ref name=fx7_ve1_467> ''Ibid.,'' vi. 4, 15.</ref> the ‘meat-mess’ (''[[मांसौदन|māṃsaudana]]''),<ref name=fx8_ve1_467> ''Ibid.,'' vi. 4, 16;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 7, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8.</ref> the ‘ghee-mess’ (''ghṛtaudana''),<ref name=fx9_ve1_467> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8.</ref> etc.

ओपश
<u>'''Opaśa'''</u> is a word of somewhat doubtful sense, occurring in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_468> x. 85. 8, ''Cf.'' i. 173, 6;<br> viii. 14, 5;<br> ix. 71. 1.</ref> the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_468> vi. 138, 1. 2;<br> ix. 3, 8, where it is applied metaphorically in describing the roof of a house.</ref> and occasionally later.<ref name=fx3_ve1_468> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 1.</ref> It probably means a ‘plait’ as used in dressing the hair, especially of women,<ref name=fx4_ve1_468> Av. vi. 138. 1, 2.</ref> but apparently, in earlier times,<ref name=fx5_ve1_468> Rv. i. 173, 6;<br> viii. 14, 5.</ref> of men also. The goddess [[सिनीवाली|Sinīvālī]] is called ''svaupaśā,''<ref name=fx6_ve1_468> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 5, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 56. The reading is uncertain. Bloomfield (see below) assumes ''sv-opaśā'' to be the correct form (‘having a fair ''[[ओपश|opaśa]]''’).</ref> an epithet of doubtful sense, from which Zimmer<ref name=fx7_ve1_468> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 264.</ref> conjectures that the wearing of  false plaits of hair was not unknown in Vedic times. What was the difference between the braic referred to in the epithets ''[[पृथु|pṛthu]] ṣṭuka,''<ref name=fx8_ve1_468> Rv. x. 86, 8.</ref> ‘having broad braids,’ and ''viṣita-ṣṭuka,''<ref name=fx9_ve1_468> Rv. i. 167, 5 (of Rodasī).</ref> ‘having loosened braids,’ and the [[ओपश|Opaśa]] cannot be made out from the evidence available. Geldner<ref name=fx10_ve1_468> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 131, quoting [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, where ''dvy-epaśāḥ'' is used of cattle;<br> but the sense may be figurative.</ref> thinks that the original sense was ‘horn,’ and that when the word applies to Indra<ref name=fx11_ve1_468> Rv. viii. 14, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 538, 539;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 348.</ref> it means ‘diadem.’

ओषधि
<u>'''Oṣadhi.'''</u>--Roughly speaking, the vegetable world is divided in Vedic literature<ref name=fx1_ve1_469> Rv. x. 97 and ''passim. Oṣadhivanaspati'' is a frequent compound, from the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vi. 1, 1, 12) onwards. The medicinal properties of plants account for the epithet ‘of manifold powers’ (''nānā-vīryā'') applied to them in Av. xii. 1, 2.</ref> between [[ओषधि|Oṣadhi]] or '''[[वीरुध्|Vīrudh]]''' ‘plants’ and '''Vana''' or '''[[वृक्ष|Vṛkṣa]]''' ‘trees.’ [[ओषधि|Oṣadhi]] is employed in opposition to [[वीरुध्|Vīrudh]] to denote plants as possessing a healing power or some other quality useful to men, while [[वीरुध्|Vīrudh]] is rather a generic term for minor vegetable growths, but sometimes,<ref name=fx2_ve1_469> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 3, 2.</ref> when occurring beside [[ओषधि|Oṣadhi]], signifies those plants which do not possess medicinal properties.<br><br>A list of the minor parts of which a plant is made up is given in the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx3_ve1_469> ''Ibid.,'' vii. 3, 19, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28.</ref> It comprises the root (''[[मूल|mūla]]''), the panicle (''tūla''), the stem (''kāṇḍa''), the twig (''[[वल्श|valśa]]''), the flower (''[[पुष्प|puṣpa]]''), and the fruit (''[[फल|phala]]''), while trees<ref name=fx4_ve1_469> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 20, 1. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 32, 5;<br> Av. x. 7, 38.</ref> have, in addition, a corona (''skandha''), branches (''[[शाखा|śākhā]]''), and leaves (''[[पर्ण|parṇa]]''). The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_469> viii. 7, 4, with Whitney's notes. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 579;<br> Henry, ''Les livres VIII. et IX. de l' Atharvavéda,'' 58 ''et seq.''</ref> gives an elaborate, though not very intelligible, division of plants into those which expand (''pra-stṛṇatīḥ''), are bushy (''stambinīḥ''), have only one sheath (''eka-śuṅgāḥ''), are creepers (''pra-tanvatīḥ''), have many stalks (''aṃśumatīḥ''), are  jointed (''kāṇḍinīḥ''), or have spreading branches (''vi-śākhāḥ''). In the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_469> x. 97. 3. 15. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben.'' 57.</ref> plants are termed ‘fruitful’ (''phalinīḥ''), ‘blossoming’ (''puṣpavatīḥ''), and ‘having flowers’ (''pra-sūvarīḥ'').

औक्ष-गन्धि
<u>'''Aukṣa-gandhi'''</u> (‘having the smell of bull's grease’) appears in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_470> iv. 37. 3.</ref> as the name of an Apsaras, beside other names, of which '''Guggulū''' and '''Naladī''' clearly indicate plants. This name, therefore, presumably also denotes some sort of fragrant plant. Aukṣa in the same Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_470> ii. 36. 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 69;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 324;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 211, 212, and on Aukṣa, ''ibid.,'' 82, 83.</ref> means ‘bull's grease’ (from ''akṣan,'' ‘bull’).

औग्र-सैन्य
<u>'''Augra-sainya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[उग्रसेन|Ugrasena]],’ is the patronymic of King '''Yuddhāmśrauṣṭi''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 21).<br>==Foot Notes==

औदन्य
<u>'''Audanya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Udanya or [[ओदन|Odana]],’ is the patronymic in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_472> xiii. 3, 5, 4.</ref> of Muṇḍibha, who is credited with inventing an expiation for the crime of slaying a Brahmin. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_472> iii. 9, 15, 3. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' [[ओदन|Odana]];<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 341, n. 1.</ref> the name appears in the form of Audanyava.

औदमय
<u>'''Audamaya'''</u> is Weber's<ref name=fx1_ve1_473> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 228.</ref> reading of the name of the [[आत्रेय|Ātreya]], who was [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of '''[[अङ्ग वैरोचन|Aṅga Vairocana]],''' according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_473> viii. 22. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' Udamaya.</ref> Aufrecht, however, in his edition more probably takes the correct form of the name to be '''Udamaya.''' 

औद-वाहि
<u>'''Auda-vāhi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Udavāha,’ appears in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_474> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26 (in the Mādhyaṃdina recension).</ref> as a teacher of [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]].

औद्-उम्बरायण
<u>'''Aud-umbarāyaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]],’ is the patronymic of a grammarian in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (i. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

औद्-दालकि
<u>'''Aud-dālaki,'''</u> ‘descendant of Uddālaka,’ is the patronymic of the teacher variously called '''Asurbinda'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_476> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 75 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 23, 327).</ref> or '''Kusurubinda,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_476> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 16;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxii. 15, 10.</ref> and of '''[[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_476> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 13;<br> iv. 2, 5, 15. He is perhaps also meant in Katha [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 11.</ref>

औद्-भारि
<u>'''Aud-bhāri,'''</u> ‘descendant of Udbhāra,’ is the patronymic in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 8, 4. 6) of '''Khaṇḍika,''' teacher of '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

औप-जन्धनि
<u>'''Aupa-jandhani,'''</u> ‘descendant of Upajandhana,’ is the patronymic of a teacher mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_478> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 (in Vaṃśas).</ref> as a pupil of '''[[आसुरि|Āsuri]],''' and also<ref name=fx2_ve1_478> iv. 5, 27 (in the Mādhyaṃdina recension)</ref> as a pupil of '''[[सायकायन|Sāyakāyana]].'''

औप-तस्विनि
<u>'''Aupa-tasvini,'''</u> ‘descendant of Upatasvina,’ is the patronymic of '''[[राम|Rāma]]''' in the Śatapatha '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]''' (iv. 6, 1. 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

औप-मन्यव
<u>'''Aupa-manyava,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[उपमन्यु|Upamanyu]],’ is the patronymic of various persons: see '''[[काम्बोज|Kāmboja]], Prācīnaśāla, [[महाशाल|Mahāśāla]].''' The best known bearer of the name is the grammarian who disagreed with the onomatopetic theory of the derivation of names, and who is mentioned by [[यास्क|Yāska]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_480> i. 1;<br> ii. 2. 6. 11, etc.</ref> An Aupamanyavīputra occurs in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_480> xxii. 1 ''et seq''</ref> as a teacher. 

औपर
<u>'''Aupara,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[उपर|Upara]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[दण्ड|Daṇḍa]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vi. 2, 9, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

औप-वेशि
<u>'''Aupa-veśi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Upaveśa,’ is the patronymic borne by '''Aruṇa,''' father of Uddālaka.<ref name=fx1_ve1_482> See [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvi. 10, and '''Aruṇa.'''</ref>

औपस्वती-पुत्र
<u>'''Aupasvatī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Upasvant’(?), is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[पाराशरीपुत्र|Pārāśarīputra]]''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_483> vi. 5, 1 (only in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension).</ref>

औपावि
<u>'''Aupāvi'''</u> (‘descendant of Upāva’) '''[[जान-श्रुतेय|Jāna-śruteya]]''' (‘descendant of Janaśruti’), appears in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_484> v. 1, 1, 5. 7.</ref> and the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_484> i. 4, 5. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 222, 223.</ref> as a sacrificer who used to offer the [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]] sacrifice and ascend to the other world.

औपोदिति
<u>'''Aupoditi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Upodita,’ is the patronymic applied in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_485> i. 7, 2, 1.</ref> to '''Tumiñja,''' and in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_485> xx. 25.</ref> to '''[[गौपालायन|Gaupālāyana]],''' son of '''Vyāghrapad,''' [[स्थपति|Sthapati]] (‘general’) of the Kurus. In the form of Aupoditeya, a metronymic from Upoditā, the name is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_485> i. 9, 3. 16.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East.'' 12, 271, n. 2.</ref> where the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] text calls him Tumiñja Aupoditeya [[वैयाघ्रपद्य|Vaiyāghrapadya]].

और्ण-वाभ
<u>'''Aurṇa-vābha,'''</u> ‘descendant of Ūrṇavābhi.’ (1) This is the name of a pupil of '''[[कौण्डिन्य|Kauṇḍinya]]''' mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_486> iv. 5, 26 (Mādhyaṃdina recension).</ref> (2) A teacher of this name is frequently referred to in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]. His explanations in two passages<ref name=fx2_ve1_486> vii. 15;<br> xii. 19.</ref> agree with those of the Nairuktas  or etymological school of interpreters of the Rigveda. In other passages<ref name=fx3_ve1_486> vi. 13;<br> xii. 1.</ref> he appears rather to belong to the school of the Aitihāsikas, who relied on traditional legends. He was thus probably, as Sieg<ref name=fx4_ve1_486> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 13, n. 1.</ref> suggests, an eclectic.

और्व
<u>'''Aurva,'''</u> ‘descendant of Uru or Urva,’ appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_487> viii. 102, 4.</ref> in close connexion with '''[[भृगु|Bhṛgu]],''' being probably a [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]] himself. As in one passage of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_487> vi. 33.</ref> the descendants of [[ऐतश|Aitaśa]] are called the worst of the Aurvas, while the parallel version of the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_487> xxx. 5.</ref> calls them the worst of the Bhṛgus, the Aurvas must have been a branch of the larger family of the Bhṛgus. [[और्व|Aurva]] himself is said in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_487> vii. 1, 8, 1.</ref> to have received offspring from Atri. In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_487> xxi. 10, 6. Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 54, reads ''ūrvau.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 173, n. 1.</ref> two Aurvas are referred to as authorities. See also '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]].'''

औलान
<u>'''Aulāna'''</u> is a word occurring in a single passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_488> x. 98, 11.</ref> where it may possibly be a patronymic of '''[[शंतनु|Śaṃtanu]]''' as a ‘descendant of Ula.’ Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve1_488> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166.</ref> however, conjectures that the reading should be ‘Kaulāna.’ Sieg<ref name=fx3_ve1_488> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 141.</ref> regards [[औलान|Aulāna]] as a later descendant<ref name=fx4_ve1_488> ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa on Rv. x, 98, 11;<br> ''Kuru kula-jātaḥ Śāṃtaṇavaḥ,'' ‘a descendant of [[शंतनु|Śaṃtanu]], born in the family of the Kurus</ref> of [[शंतनु|Śaṃtanu]], who utilized the story of Devāpi's rain-making as an introduction to his rain hymn.

औलुण्ड्य
<u>'''Auluṇḍya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Uluṇḍa,’ is the patronymic of '''Supratīta''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_489> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref> 

औशिज
<u>'''Auśija,'''</u> ‘descendant of Uśij,’ is a patronymic clearly applied to '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_490> i. 18, 1.</ref> It is also applied to '''[[ऋजिश्वन्|Ṛjiśvan]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_490> x. 99, 11.</ref> but Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve1_490> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 143, 149.</ref> thinks that the correct reading of the passage in question is ''auśijasyarjiśvā,'' ‘Ṛjiśvan, son of [[औशिज|Auśija]].’ In one verse<ref name=fx4_ve1_490> Rv. i. 112, 11.</ref> [[औशिज|Auśija]] and [[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]] are both mentioned, but in such a way that two different persons must apparently be meant. In other passages where the patronymic occurs alone, it is doubtful who is meant, or whether a proper name at all is intended.<ref name=fx5_ve1_490> Rv. i. 119, 9;<br> 122, 4;<br> iv. 21, 6, 7;<br> v. 41, 5;<br> vi. 4, 6. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> [[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]] [[औशिज|Auśija]] appears also in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_490> xiv. 11, 16. See Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' xv. 56, n., and '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]],''' n. 15.</ref> and elsewhere.

औष्ट्राक्षि
<u>'''Auṣṭrākṣi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Uṣṭrākṣa,’ occurs as the patronymic of '''Sāti''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_491> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 75.</ref>

कंस
<u>'''Kaṃsa,'''</u> a word denoting a ‘pot or vessel of metal,’ occurs in the Atharvaveda and elsewhere.<ref name=fx1_ve1_492> Av. x. 10, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 10;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 1, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 23;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8.</ref>

ककर
<u>'''Kakara'''</u> occurs in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_493> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 24.</ref> as the name of a victim at the horse sacrifice ([[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]). It probably denotes some ‘sort of bird,’ as rendered by the commentator Mahīdhara.<ref name=fx2_ve1_493> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94.</ref>

ककुठ
<u>'''Kakuṭha,'''</u> a word occurring in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_494> iii. 14, 13.</ref> presumably denotes some kind of animal. According to Bo7htlingk,<ref name=fx2_ve1_494> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> it is identical with '''[[कक्कट|Kakkaṭa]].''' 

ककुह
<u>'''Kakuha,'''</u> a word occurring several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_495> i. 46, 3;<br> 181 5;<br> 184, 3;<br> ii. 34, 11;<br> iii. 54, 14;<br> v. 73, 7;<br> 75, 4;<br> viii. 6, 48.</ref> is understood by Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_495> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> to designate part of a chariot, perhaps the seat. Ludwig,<ref name=fx3_ve1_495> Translation of the Rigveda, 2, 182;<br> 3, 160, 161;<br> 5, 142.</ref> again, regards it in one passage<ref name=fx4_ve1_495> viii. 6, 48.</ref> as the proper name of a Yādava prince who took spoil from '''[[तिरिन्दिर|Tirindira]],''' the '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]],''' but this view is hardly probable.<ref name=fx5_ve1_495> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 36, 37.</ref> It is, on the whole, most likely that the word always means ‘chief,’ ‘pre-eminent,’ being applied as an epithet to horses, chariots, princes, etc.<ref name=fx6_ve1_495> So certainly in Rv. viii. 45, 14;<br> ix. 67, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 3, 1. 2, and often in the older form ''kakubha.''</ref> This is the only sense given by Grassmann,<ref name=fx7_ve1_495> In his Lexicon, ''s.v.''</ref> and later adopted by Roth.<ref name=fx8_ve1_495> In Bo7htlingk's Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

कक्कट
<u>'''Kakkaṭa'''</u> denotes the ‘crab’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_496> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 15, 1 (where Weber has ''katkaṭa'');<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 32.</ref> being a Prākritized form of Karkaṭa, which is common in the later literature.<ref name=fx2_ve1_496> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref> Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_496> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> however, takes the word to mean a bird, and compares '''[[ककर|Kakara]].''' See also '''[[ककुठ|Kakuṭha]].'''

कक्ष
<u>'''Kakṣa'''</u> is the name of two men mentioned as teachers in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. One is [[कक्ष|Kakṣa]] [[वारक्य|Vārakya]], pupil of '''[[प्रोष्ठपद|Proṣṭhapada]] [[वारक्य|Vārakya]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_497> iii. 41, 1.</ref> and the other [[कक्ष|Kakṣa]] Vārāki<ref name=fx2_ve1_497> iii. 41, 1.</ref> or Vārakyā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_497> iv. 17, 1.</ref> pupil of '''[[दक्ष कात्यायनि आत्रेय|Dakṣa <a class="pada_vei" href="कात्यायनि">Kātyāyani]] Ātreya».''' See also '''[[उरुकक्ष|Urukakṣa]].'''

कक्षीवन्त्
<u>'''Kakṣīvant'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] mentioned frequently in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_498> i. 18, 1;<br> 51, 13;<br> 112, 11;<br> 116, 7;<br> 117, 6;<br> 126, 3;<br> iv. 26, 1;<br> viii. 9, 10;<br> ix. 74, 8;<br> x. 25, 10;<br> 61, 16.</ref> and occasionally elsewhere.<ref name=fx2_ve1_498> Av. iv. 29, 5, and passage noted below.</ref> He appears to have been a descendant of a female slave named Uśij.<ref name=fx3_ve1_498> Rv. i. 18, 1;<br> perhaps also i, 112, 11, but [[औशिज|Auśija]] may there be a separate name (see [[औशिज|Auśija]]). ''Cf.'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 11, 16.</ref> He must have been a '''[[पज्र|Pajra]]''' by family, as he bears the epithet [[पज्रिय|Pajriya]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_498> Rv. i. 116, 7;<br> 117, 6.</ref>  and his descendants are called Pajras.<ref name=fx5_ve1_498> Rv. i. 126, 4.</ref> In a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_498> i. 126.</ref> he celebrates the prince '''[[स्वनय भाव्य|Svanaya Bhāvya]],''' who dwelt on the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus), as having bestowed magnificent gifts on him; and the list of Nārāśaṃsas (‘Praises of Heroes’) in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_498> xvi. 4, 5.</ref> mentions one by [[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]] [[औशिज|Auśija]] in honour of Svanaya [[भावयव्य|Bhāvayavya]]. In his old age he obtained as a wife the maiden '''[[वृचया|Vṛcayā]].'''<ref name=fx8_ve1_498> Rv. i. 51, 13.</ref> He appears to have lived to be a hundred,<ref name=fx9_ve1_498> Rv. ix. 74, 8.</ref> the typical length of life in the Vedas. He seems always to be thought of as belonging to the past, and in a hymn of the fourth book of the Rigveda<ref name=fx10_ve1_498> iv. 26, 1.</ref> he is mentioned with the semi-mythical '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]]''' and '''Kavi Uśanas.''' Later, also, he is a teacher of bygone days.<ref name=fx11_ve1_498> Av. iv. 29, 5;<br> xviii. 3, 15;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 21, 6. 7;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 11.</ref><br><br>In Vedic literature he is not connected with '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]]''' beyond being once mentioned along with him in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx12_ve1_498> viii. 9, 10</ref> But in the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx13_ve1_498> iv. 11 ''et seq.''</ref> he appears as a son of [[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]] by a slave woman, Uśij.<br><br>Weber<ref name=fx14_ve1_498> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 22-25.</ref> considers that [[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]] was originally a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], not a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], quoting in favour of this view the fact that he is mentioned beside kings like '''[[पर आट्णार|Para Āṭṇāra]], [[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]] [[श्रायस|Śrāyasa]],''' and '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] Paurukutsya.'''<ref name=fx15_ve1_498> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 5, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 3;<br> Pancaviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 16, 3, ''Cf.'' xiv. 11, 16.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 221, 236, n. 1;<br> Ludwig Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 102;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 23, 24.</ref> But that these are all kings is an unnecessary assumption: these persons are mentioned in the passages in question undoubtedly only as famous men of old, to whom are ascribed mythical sacrificial performances, and who thus gained numerous sons.

कङ्क
<u>'''Kaṅka'''</u> is the name of a bird, usually taken to mean ‘heron,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_499> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 92.</ref> but, at any rate in some passages, rather denoting some bird of prey.<ref name=fx2_ve1_499> Roth. St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, xii. 13.</ref> It first appears in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx3_ve1_499> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 11, 1 (''[[कङ्क|kaṅka]]-cit,'' an altar ‘piled in the form of a heron’);<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 31;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 12;<br> [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], ii. 9, 3, 6, 1</ref> 

कङ्कत
<u>'''Kaṅkata'''</u> is the name of an animal mentioned once in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_500> i. 191, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref> According to Sāyaṇa it is a destructive beast; perhaps, as Grassmann renders it, a ‘scorpion.’

कङ्कतीय
<u>'''Kaṅkatīya'''</u> is the name of a family said in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_501> ix. 4, 4, 17.</ref> to have learned from '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]''' the piling up of the sacrificial firse (''agni-cayana.'') In the Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_501> xiv. 20, 4.</ref> a Kaṅkati [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], no doubt the textbook of the school, is referred to. It may have been identical with the Chāgaleya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], cited in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_501> xxv. 5. ''Cf.'' Caland, ''Über das vituclle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 40.</ref>

कङ्क-पर्वन्
<u>'''Kaṅka-parvan'''</u> (‘heron-jointed’?), a term occurring once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_502> vii. 56, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 426;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 553;<br> Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> is applied to a snake, meaning perhaps ‘scorpion.’ As the Paippalāda recension has a different reading (''[[अङ्ग|aṅga]]-parvaṇaḥ''), the passage may be corrupt.

कट
<u>'''Kaṭa'''</u> denotes a ‘mat,’ which was ‘made of reeds’ (''vaitasa''). The maker of mats from reeds (''[[बिदल-कारी|bidala-kārī]]'') is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_503> xxx. 8, with Mahīdhara's Commentary. ''Bidala-kāra'' is read in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 5, 1.</ref> and the process of splitting reeds for the purpose is referred to in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_503> vi. 138, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 255.</ref><br><br>^1) [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā. v. 3, 12, 2. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 1, 3.

कण्टकी-कारी
<u>'''Kaṇṭakī-kārī,'''</u> ‘worker in thorns,’ is one of the victims at the human sacrifice (Puruṣamedha) in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_504> xxx. 8. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 5, 1, has ''kaṇṭaka-kāra. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 255.</ref> No doubt the thorns were cut up and used to plait mats ('''[[कट|Kaṭa]]''') or to stuff cushions. 

कण्व
<u>'''Kaṇva'''</u> is the name of an ancient [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] repeatedly referred to in the Rigveda and later.<ref name=fx1_ve1_505> Rv. i. 36, 8. 10. 11. 17. 19;<br> 39, 7. 9;<br> 47, 5;<br> 112, 5;<br> 117, 18;<br> 118, 7;<br> 139, 9;<br> v. 41, 4;<br> viii. 5, 23. 25;<br> 7, 18;<br> 8, 20;<br> 49, 10;<br> 50, 10;<br> x. 71, 11;<br> 115, 5;<br> 150, 5;<br> Av. iv. 37, 1;<br> vii. 15, 1;<br> xviii. 3, 15;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 74;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 2, 2;<br> ix. 2, 6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxviii. 8, Kaṇvavat occurs in Rv. viii. 6, 11;<br> 52, 8;<br> Av. ii. 32, 3;<br> [[कण्व|Kaṇva]]-mant in Rv. viii. 2, 22.</ref> His sons and descendants,<ref name=fx2_ve1_505> As ''Kaṇvāḥ'' (in the plural), Rv. i. 14, 2. 5;<br> 37, 1. 14;<br> 44, 8;<br> 46, 9;<br> 47. 2. 4-10;<br> 49, 4;<br> viii. 2, 16;<br> 3, 16;<br> 4, 2. 3;<br> 5, 4;<br> 6, 3. 18. 21. 31. 34. 47;<br> 7, 32;<br> 8, 3;<br> 9, 14;<br> 32, 1;<br> 33, 3;<br> 34, 4;<br> as ''Kaṇvasya sūnavaḥ,'' Rv. i, 45, 5;<br> as ''putrāḥ,'' viii. 8, 4. 8;<br> as ''Kāṇvāyanāḥ,'' viii. 55, 4. ''[[काण्व|Kāṇva]]'' is found in viii. 1, 8;<br> 2, 40;<br> 4, 20;<br> 7, 19;<br> 9, 3, 9;<br> 10, 2.</ref> the Kaṇvas, are also often mentioned, especially in the eighth book of the Rigveda, the authorship of that book, as well as of part of the first, being attributed to this family. A descendant of [[कण्व|Kaṇva]] is also denoted by the name in the singular, either alone<ref name=fx3_ve1_505> ''Eg.,'' Rv. i. 48, 4;<br> viii. 34, 1, and probably elsewhere.</ref> or accompanied by a patronymic, as [[कण्व|Kaṇva]] [[नार्षद|Nārṣada]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_505> Rv. i. 117, 8;<br> Av. iv. 19, 2;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 150.</ref> and [[कण्व|Kaṇva]] [[श्रायस|Śrāyasa]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_505> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 7, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 8;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 9.</ref> besides in the plural the Kaṇvas Sauśravasas.<ref name=fx6_ve1_505> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 12. There is also [[वत्स|Vatsa]] [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 11, 20.</ref> The [[कण्व|Kaṇva]] family appears to have been connected with the Atri family,<ref name=fx7_ve1_505> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 214.</ref> but not to have been of great importance.<ref name=fx8_ve1_505> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 285. ''Cf.'' 1, 207, 438.</ref> In one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_505> Av. ii. 25. ''Cf.'' Vārttika on Pāṇini, iii. 1, 14;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 465;<br> Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 207;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 110.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 216 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ludwig, ''op. cit.,'' 3, 105.</ref> they seem to be definitely regarded with hostility.

कथा
<u>'''Kathā.'''</u>--The later use of this word<ref name=fx1_ve1_506> Colebrooke, ''Miscellaneous Essays,'' 1, 293.</ref> in the sense of a ‘philosophical discussion’ appears in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_506> i. 8, 1: ''hantodgīthe kathāṃ vadāma,'' ‘let us begin a discussion regarding the Udgītha.’</ref>

कद्रू
<u>'''Kadrū,'''</u> a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_507> viii. 45, 26.</ref> is interpreted by Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_507> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 162.</ref> as the name of a priest, but it more probably means a Soma vessel.<ref name=fx3_ve1_507> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> 

कनक्नक
<u>'''Kanaknaka,'''</u> a word occurring once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_508> x. 4, 22. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 604;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 578.</ref> either denotes a poison or is an adjective qualifying ''[[काण्डा-विष|kāṇḍā-viṣa]],'' a species of poison.

कना
<u>'''Kanā, Kanyā.'''</u>--Both these words, of which the former is very rare,<ref name=fx1_ve1_509> Rv. x. 61, 5, etc.</ref> while the latter is the normal term from the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_509> i. 123, 10;<br> 161, 5;<br> iii. 23, 10, etc.;<br> Av. i. 14, 2;<br> xi. 5, 18;<br> xii, 1, 25, etc.</ref> onwards, denote ‘maiden’ or ‘young woman.’ It is doubtful whether Kanīnakā (accented on the final syllable) has this meaning,<ref name=fx3_ve1_509> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' cites in this sense Rv. iv. 32, 23;<br> x. 40, 9;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 15;<br> but neither of the Rv. passages is at all clear.</ref> or only denotes the pupil of the eye,<ref name=fx4_ve1_509> See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 401;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyāka,'' 207. Other rare forms are ''kanyanā,'' Rv. viii. 35, 5;<br> ''kauyalā,'' Av. v. 5, 3;<br> xiv. 2, 52.</ref> which is the sense of ''kanīnakā'' or ''kanīnikā'' (both accented on the antepenultimate) in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas. See also '''[[स्त्री|Strī]].'''

कपना
<u>'''Kapanā,'''</u> from its solitary occurrence in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_510> v. 54, 6.</ref> appears to mean a ‘worm’ that destroys the leaves of trees, and is so interpreted in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_510> vi. 4. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 330.</ref>

कपर्द
<u>'''Kaparda,'''</u> ‘braid,’ '''Kapardin,''' ‘wearing braids.’ These words refer to the Vedic custom of wearing the hair in braids or plaits. Thus a maiden is said to have her hair in four plaits (''catuṣ-kapardā''),<ref name=fx1_ve1_511> Rv. x. 114, 3.</ref> and the goddess [[सिनीवाली|Sinīvālī]] is described as ‘wearing fair braids’ (''su-kapardā'').<ref name=fx2_ve1_511> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 56.</ref> Men also wore their hair in this style, for both Rudra<ref name=fx3_ve1_511> Rv. i. 114, 1. 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 10. 29. 43. 48. 59.</ref> and Pūṣan<ref name=fx4_ve1_511> Rv. vi. 55, 2;<br> ix. 67. 11.</ref> are said to have done so, while the '''Vasiṣṭhas'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_511> Rv. vii. 33, 1. ''Cf.'' 83, 8.</ref> were distinguished by wearing their hair in a plait on the right (''[[दक्षिणतस्-कपर्द|dakṣiṇatas-kaparda]]''). The opposite was to wear one's hair ‘plain’ (''[[पुलस्ति|pulasti]]'').<ref name=fx6_ve1_511> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 43. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 264, 265;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' v. 462;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 424.</ref> See also '''[[ओपश|Opaśa]].''' 

कपि
<u>'''1. Kapi,'''</u> ‘monkey,’ occurs only once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_512> x. 86. 5. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 174;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 22 ''et seq.;<br>'' von Schroeder, ''Mysterium und Mimus,'' 304 ''et seq.;<br>'' Schirmeisen, ''Die Arischen Go7ttergestalten,'' 218 ''et seq.;<br>'' Tilak, ''Orion,'' 170-197.</ref> with reference to Vṛṣā-kapi, the ‘Man-ape,’ in the dialogue of Indra and Indrāṇī in the presence of Vṛṣākapi. There the ape is termed the ‘tawny’ (''[[हरित|harita]]''). In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_512> iii. 9, 4;<br> iv. 32, 11;<br> vi. 49, 1. ''Cf.'' also Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 6, 7 (''kapy-āsa,'' ‘seat of an ape’).</ref> the monkey is mentioned several times as hairy, and an enemy of dogs. That the ape was tamed appears from its position in the Vṛṣākapi hymn, and from the mention, in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_512> iv. 2, 10, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 85, 86.</ref> of a '''Mayu''' as belonging to the forest. See also '''Mayu, [[मर्कट|Markaṭa]],''' and '''[[पुरुष हस्तिन्|Puruṣa Hastin]].'''

कपि
<u>'''2. Kapi'''</u> is, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, another name for [[लुश|Luśa]] [[खार्गलि|Khārgali]] in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxx. 2), but the name appears rather to be '''Luśākapi.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कपिञ्जल
<u>'''Kapiñjala,'''</u> the name of the ‘francoline partridge’ or ‘hazelcock,’ is found in all the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_514> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 1;<br> v. 5, 16, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 20. 38.</ref> and occasionally later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_514> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 3;<br> v. 5, 4, 4;<br> xiii. 5, 1, 13;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 154, 2 (''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 181).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 91.</ref>

कपिल
<u>'''Kapila'''</u> appears in the Śvetāśvatara [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_515> v. 2.</ref> as a teacher, according to Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_515> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 24 ''et seq.;<br>'' 5, 412;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 236.</ref> and Garbe,<ref name=fx3_ve1_515> ''Sāṅkhya Philosophie,'' 27 ''et seq.;<br>'' Translation of the Śāṅkhyatattvakaumudī, 531.</ref> who think that the expression ''[[कपिल|kapila]] ṛṣiḥ'' there refers to the founder of the Sāṅkhya philosophy. But this is doubtful.<ref name=fx4_ve1_515> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 2, xli, and Deussen, in his translation (''Sechzig Upanishads,'' 304), do not take the word as a teacher's name. The latter renders ''[[कपिल|kapila]] ṛṣiḥ,'' by ‘the red sage,’ as referring to Hiraṇyagarbha.</ref> 

कपि-वन भौवायन
<u>'''Kapi-vana Bhauvāyana'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_516> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxii. 2.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_516> xx. 13, 4.</ref> A rite called Kapivana's Dvyaha (‘ceremony lasting two days’) is also referred to in the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_516> xxv. 2, 3. ''Cf.'' Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 24, 3, 473;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 55, n. 2;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 157.</ref>

कपोत
<u>'''Kapota'''</u> is the name of a bird, probably the ‘pigeon’ (its sense in the later language), occurring from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_517> Rv. i. 30, 4;<br> Av. xx. 135, 12;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 23. 38.</ref> It is associated in some passages<ref name=fx2_ve1_517> Rv. x. 165, 1-5;<br> Av. vi. 29, 2.</ref> with the owl ('''[[उलूक|Ulūka]]''') as a messenger of Nirṛti (‘dissolution,’ ‘misfortune’). This aspect of the pigeon as a bird of evil omen is probably based on an ancient belief which is also found beyond the confines of India.<ref name=fx3_ve1_517> ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prchistoric Antiquities,'' 253.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 89;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

कबन्ध आथर्वण
<u>'''Kabandha Ātharvaṇa'''</u> is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_518> vi. 7, 1. ''Cf.'' also Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 9. 18;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 176, n. 4;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 149.</ref> along with '''[[सुधन्वन् आङ्गिरस|Sudhanvan Āṅgirasa]],''' as a teacher, but is semi-mythical. His son was '''[[विचारिन् काबन्धि|Vicārin Kābandhi]].'''

कम-द्यू
<u>'''Kama-dyū'''</u> appears once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_519> x. 65, 12.</ref> as the wife of '''[[विमद|Vimada]].''' She is probably identical with the ‘maiden’ (''yoṣā'') of '''[[पुरुमित्र|Purumitra]],''' no doubt his daughter. She is elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve1_519> i. 117, 20;<br> x. 39, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 310.</ref> referred to in connexion with [[विमद|Vimada]], who appears to have taken her for his bride against the will of her father.

कम्बल
<u>'''Kambala'''</u> denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_520> xiv. 2, 66. 67. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 2.</ref> a ‘woollen coverlet’ or ‘blanket.’ 

कम्बोज
<u>'''Kamboja.--Yāska,'''</u> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_521> ii. 2.</ref> refers to the speech of the Kambojas as differing from that of the other Āryas. The Kambojas were later settled to the north-west of the Indus, and are known as Kambujiya in the old Persian inscriptions. A teacher, '''[[काम्बोज|Kāmboja]] [[औपमन्यव|Aupamanyava]],''' pupil of '''Madragāra,''' is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_521> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 102;<br> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 2, 493;<br> 3, 384;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 7;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 45;<br> Max Müller, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 7, 373. On the relation of Indian and Iranian, see also Jacobi, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 721 ''et seq.;<br>'' 1910, 457 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''ibid.,'' 1095 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''ibid.,'' 1100 ''et seq.;<br>'' Kennedy, ''ibid.,'' 1107 ''et seq.;<br>'' and see '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]].'''</ref> This points to a possible connexion of the Madras, or more probably the '''Uttara Madras,''' with the Kambojas, who probably had Iranian as well as Indian affinities.

करञ्ज
<u>'''Karañja,'''</u> a word which in the Sūtras and later denotes the tree ''Pongamia glabra,'' occurs only twice in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_522> i. 53, 8;<br> x. 48, 8.</ref> as the name of a foe of Indra, but whether a demon or a man<ref name=fx2_ve1_522> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 63;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 149;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 292.</ref> is intended remains uncertain.

करम्भ
<u>'''Karambha'''</u> is the name, from the Rigveda onwards,<ref name=fx1_ve1_523> Rv. i. 187, 16;<br> iii. 52, 7;<br> vi. 56, 1;<br> 57, 2;<br> viii. 102, 2;<br> Av. iv. 7, 2. 3;<br> vi. 16, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 10, 2;<br> vi. 5, 11, 4, etc.</ref> of a kind of porridge made of grain ('''Yava'''), which was unhusked, parched slightly, and kneaded.<ref name=fx2_ve1_523> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 2, 14;<br> iv. 2, 4, 18. ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 317;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 395, n. 1.</ref> It was the especial sacrificial portion of Pūṣan, no doubt in his capacity of an agricultural deity. Karmabha was also made of barley ('''[[उपवाक|Upavāka]]''')<ref name=fx3_ve1_523> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 22.</ref> or of sesame ('''[[तिर्य|Tirya]]''').<ref name=fx4_ve1_523> Av. iv. 7, 3, but see Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 377;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 155.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 270.</ref> 

करिक्रत
<u>'''Karikrata'''</u> denotes, according to Zimmer,<ref name=fx1_ve1_524> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95</ref> a snake in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_524> x. 4, 13. The Paippalāda version has Kanikrada.</ref>

करीर
<u>'''Karīra,'''</u> the name of a leafless shrub, ''Capparis aphylla,'' or its fruit, first appears in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_525> ii. 4, 9, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 11;<br> xxxvi. 7;<br> Śatapatha Brahmaṇa, ii. 5, 2, 11.</ref>

करीष
<u>'''Karīṣa'''</u> denotes ‘dry cow dung’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_526> ii. 1, 1, 7.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_526> Av. iii. 14, 3. 4;<br> xix. 31, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236.</ref> shows that the value of the natural manure of animals in the fields was appreciated.

कर्कन्धु
<u>'''1. Karkandhu'''</u> is the ordinary word for ‘jujube,’ the tree (''Zizyphus jujuba'') and the fruit, from the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_527> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 23. 91;<br> xxi. 32;<br> xxiv. 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 10;<br> xii. 7, 2, 9;<br> 9, 1, 5, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 156. 5.</ref> The berry is red (''[[रोहित|rohita]]'').<ref name=fx2_ve1_527> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 242.</ref> Compare '''[[कुवल|Kuvala]]''' and '''[[बदर|Badara]],''' which denote the fruit.

कर्कन्धु
<u>'''2. Karkandhu'''</u> is only the name borne by a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda (i. 112, 6). Its identity with the word for jujube indicates that the latter, though not otherwise mentioned there, was known at the time of the Rigveda.<br>==Foot Notes==

कर्करि
<u>'''Karkari,'''</u> a musical instrument, probably the ‘lute,’ occurs from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_529> Rv. ii. 43, 3;<br> Av. iv. 37. 4. ''Cf.'' xx. 132. 3. 8.</ref> The Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_529> iv. 2, 9. ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Gurupūjākaumudī,'' 48, 49.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 289.</ref> mentions cattle branded on the ears with a mark resembling a lute (''[[कर्करि|karkari]]-karṇyaḥ''). 

कर्की
<u>'''Karkī'''</u> may denote in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_530> iv. 38, 6. 7. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 414.</ref> a white cow,’ according to the suggestion of Roth.<ref name=fx2_ve1_530> St. Petersburg Dictionary and Bo7htlingk's Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

कर्ण-शोभन
<u>'''Karṇa-śobhana'''</u> denotes an ‘ornament for the ear’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_531> viii. 78, 3.</ref> apparently for the use of men. Some deity is called ‘gold-eared’ in another passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_531> i. 122, 14. See also i. 64, 10.</ref> Hopkins<ref name=fx3_ve1_531> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 35.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262.</ref> considers the use of ear-rings later than that of necklets and wristlets.

कर्ण-श्रवस् आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Karṇa-śravas Āṅgirasa'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 11, 14) as a seer of Sāmans or chants, the same tale being told of him as of '''Dāvasu.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कर्मार
<u>'''Karmāra,'''</u> the ‘smith,’ is several times mentioned with approval in the Vedic Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_533> Rv. x. 72, 2;<br> Av. iii. 5, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;<br> xxx. 7. ''Cf. [[कर्मार|karmāra]],'' Rv. ix. 112, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 1.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_533> iii. 5, 6. The exact sense of the passage is doubtful. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 252;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 144;<br> and Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 92, take the reference to be to ‘skilled chariot-makers’ (''dhīvāno [[रथ|ratha]]-kārāḥ'') and ‘clever smiths,’ but this is perhaps less likely. The commentator interprets ''dhīvānaḥ'' as ‘fishermen’ (in the later language ''dhīvara'' means both a ‘clever man’ and a ‘fisherman’).</ref> smiths appear with fishermen (''dhīvānaḥ'') and chariot-builders (''rathakārāḥ''), all being classified as clever workers (''manīṣiṇaḥ''): possibly a quasi-caste of smiths was already developing from the guild organization that probably existed.<ref name=fx3_ve1_533> ''Cf.'' Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 182.</ref><br><br>Little is known of the smith's methods of work and of his tools. No doubt he smelted (''dhmā'') the ore in the fire; hence he is called ''[[ध्मातृ|dhmātṛ]],'' the ‘smelter.’<ref name=fx4_ve1_533> Rv. v. 9. 5.</ref> Mention is also made of  his bellows of birds' feathers.<ref name=fx5_ve1_533> Rv. ix. 112, 2.</ref> He made metal vessels (''[[घर्म|gharma]] ayasmaya'')<ref name=fx6_ve1_533> Rv. v. 30, 15.</ref> to be put on the fire: even the Soma cup could occasionally be made of hammered metal (''ayo-hata'').<ref name=fx7_ve1_533> Rv. ix. 1, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 252, 253;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 196 ''et seq.;<br> Über den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],'' 19 ''et seq.''</ref>

कर्वर
<u>'''Karvara,'''</u> a word found in one passage of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_534> x. 4, 19.</ref> seems to mean some kind of fish<ref name=fx2_ve1_534> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 96;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 578.</ref> caught by a fisherman (''[[पौञ्जिष्ठ|pauñjiṣṭha]]'').

कर्षू
<u>'''Karṣū,'''</u> a rare word found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_535> i. 8, 1, 3;<br> xiii. 8, 3, 10. ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 283.</ref> denotes a ‘furrow’ or ‘trench.’

कलविङ्क
<u>'''Kalaviṅka,'''</u> a name of the ‘sparrow,’ is found in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_536> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Samhitā, xxiv. 20. 31.</ref> and occasionally later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_536> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 4;<br> v. 5, 4, 5;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 154, 3 (''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 181). ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 91.</ref>

कलश
<u>'''Kalaśa'''</u> is, from the Rigveda onwards,<ref name=fx1_ve1_537> Rv. i. 117, 12;<br> iii. 32, 15;<br> iv. 27, 5;<br> 32, 19, etc.;<br> Av. iii. 12, 7;<br> ix. 1, 6;<br> 4, 15;<br> xviii. 4, 13, etc. In Rv. x. 32, 9, the word, according to the Śt. Petersburg Dictionary, is used as a proper name, but the passage is very doubtful.</ref> a common word for ‘pot’ or ‘jar,’ probably either formed of a gourd or made of clay (unburnt or baked), as we know that both kinds of pot were in use.<ref name=fx2_ve1_537> Av. iv. 17, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 1, 8, 1;<br> iv. 1, 5, 4;<br> v. 1, 7, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 22;<br> xi. 59. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 253;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 257;<br> Oertel, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 185, n. 3;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 183 ''et seq.''</ref> The wooden Soma tub (''[[द्रोण|droṇa]]-[[कलश|kalaśa]]'') is frequently referred to in the ritual. See also '''[[कोश|Kośa]].''' 

कला
<u>'''Kalā'''</u> denotes a fractional part, normally ‘one-sixteenth,’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_538> viii. 47, 17.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_538> Av. vi. 96, 3;<br> xix. 57, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 10, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 7, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 3, 1;<br> xii. 8, 3, 13, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xi. 12. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 278;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 259.</ref> It is often mentioned in connexion with '''[[शफ|Śapha]],''' ‘one-eighth.’

कलि
<u>'''1. Kali.'''</u> See '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कलि
<u>'''2. Kali'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda, twice in the singular<ref name=fx1_ve1_540> i. 112, 15;<br> x. 39, 8.</ref> as the name of a protégé of the Aśvins, and once in the plural.<ref name=fx2_ve1_540> viii. 66, 15.</ref> The persons meant in the latter passage seem to be different from the former one. The Kalis are once mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_540> x. 10, 13.</ref> beside the Gandharvas.<ref name=fx4_ve1_540> These Kalis may be connected with dicing, as in the Atharvaveda the Apsarases, the wives of the Gandharvas, are fond of dice, and bestow luck at play. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 135.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 89;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref>

कल्प
<u>'''Kalpa'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (ii. 10) seems to denote [[कल्प|Kalpa]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<br>==Foot Notes==

कल्माष-ग्रीव
<u>'''Kalmāṣa-grīva'''</u> (‘speckled-neck’) is the name of a snake in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_542> iii. 27, 5 (where the Paippalāda recension has ''[[कुल्माष|kulmāṣa]]-'');<br> xii. 3, 59. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 10, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94, 95.</ref>

कल्याण
<u>'''Kalyāṇa'''</u> is the name, in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_543> xii. 11, 10. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 68, n. 2.</ref> of an [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]] who saw the Aurṇāyava Sāman. 

कवच
<u>'''Kavaca'''</u> denotes a ‘corselet’ or ‘breastplate’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_544> Av. xi. 10, 22 (''kavacin'').</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_544> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 2, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 19, 2;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 25 (''[[कवच|kavaca]]'');<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 6, 3;<br> 4, 1, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 48;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 45 (''kavacin'').</ref> There is nothing to show whether it was made of metal, but that it was so is quite possible (see '''[[वर्मन्|Varman]]'''). The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_544> xi. 10, 22.</ref> refers to a ‘corselet-strap’ (''[[कवच|kavaca]]-[[पाश|pāśa]]''), which may point to a linen corselet such as those known to Herodotus.<ref name=fx4_ve1_544> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 129, and Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 659, seem to recognize coats of mail only.</ref>

कवष
<u>'''Kavaṣa'''</u> is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_545> vii. 18, 12.</ref> as one of those whom, together with the '''[[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]]''' king, Indra overthrew for the '''Tṛtsus.''' The Anukramaṇī (Index) also attributes to him the authorship of several hymns of the Rigveda, including two (x. 32. 33) that deal with a prince '''Kuruśravaṇa''' and his descendant '''[[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]].''' There seems no reason to doubt this attribution, which is accepted by both Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_545> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 127.</ref> and Geldner.<ref name=fx3_ve1_545> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 150.</ref> The former holds that [[कवष|Kavaṣa]] was the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of the joint tribes named '''[[वैकर्ण|Vaikarṇa]],''' in whom he sees the KuruKrivi ([[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]]) peoples, and that [[कवष|Kavaṣa]] in that capacity is mentioned in the Rigveda as representative of those peoples. He also suggests that the language of Rigveda x. 33, 4 is best explained by the reduced position in which the Kuru-Krivis found themselves on their defeat by the Tṛtsus. Ludwig,<ref name=fx4_ve1_545> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139.</ref> on the other hand, thinks that [[कवष|Kavaṣa]] was the priest of the five peoples. Geldner<ref name=fx5_ve1_545> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> holds that [[कवष|Kavaṣa]] was the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of Kuruśravaṇa, by whose son, [[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]], he was ill-treated, and that he composed Rigveda x. 33 to deprecate the anger of his royal master. Hopkins<ref name=fx6_ve1_545> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 261, 263.</ref> thinks that he was a king.<br><br>In the Brāhmaṇas of the Rigveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_545> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 19;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 1, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 459;<br> Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 386, 387;<br> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 50.</ref> mention is made of  [[कवष|Kavaṣa]] [[ऐलूष|Ailūṣa]], who was a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] born of a female slave, and was reproached on this ground by the other [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]]. He is possibly identical with the [[कवष|Kavaṣa]] of the Rigveda.

कश
<u>'''Kaśa'''</u> is the name of an unknown animal mentioned as a victim at the horse sacrifice in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_546> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 17, 1;<br> 18, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 26;<br> 38. ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 84.</ref>

कशीका
<u>'''Kaśīkā'''</u> is name of an animal mentioned once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_547> i. 126, 5.</ref> and interpreted as ‘weasel’ by the commentator Sāyaṇa. Fick<ref name=fx2_ve1_547> Bezzenberger, ''Beiträge,'' 3, 165;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 247. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 84;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 57.</ref> suggests that the meaning is ‘pole-cat.’ Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve1_547> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 44.</ref> takes it as ‘female ichneumon.’

कशिपु
<u>'''Kaśipu'''</u> denotes a ‘mat’ or ‘cushion’ made, according to the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_548> vi. 138, 5.</ref> by women from reeds (''[[नड|naḍa]]''), which they crushed for the purpose by means of stones. On the other hand, the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_548> xiii. 4, 3, 1.</ref> refers to a mat as made of gold.

कशु
<u>'''Kaśu'''</u> is the name of a prince mentioned in the Rigveda with the patronymic [[चैद्य|Caidya]], or descendant of '''Cedi,''' as a generous patron of the singer, who praises the liberality of the Cedis. Neither this king nor the Cedis appear again in Vedic literature.<br><br>^1) viii. 5, 37. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 129.<br>==Foot Notes==

कशो-जू
<u>'''Kaśo-jū'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda (i. 112, 14) either as a proper name or as an epithet of '''Divodāsa.''' The sense of the word is quite uncertain.<br>==Foot Notes==

कश्यप
<u>'''Kaśyapa,'''</u> a word denoting ‘tortoise,’ occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_551> iv. 20. 7.</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_551> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 18;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 37;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 1, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 86;<br> Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 403.</ref> 

कश्यप
<u>'''Kaśyapa'''</u> is the name of a sage who is mentioned only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_552> ix. 114, 2.</ref> but is a common figure in the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve1_552> [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], i. 1, 2, 4, 10;<br> 4, 2, 3, 2 (but in these passages the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' accepts the sense of a divine being, identical with Prajāpati);<br> Av. i. 14, 4;<br> ii. 33, 7;<br> iv. 20, 7;<br> 29, 3;<br> 37, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 9, Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 62.</ref> He is always of a mythical character, as belonging to the distant past.
