According to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_552> viii. 21;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 7, 1, 15.</ref> he anointed King '''[[विश्वकर्मन् भौवन|Viśvakarman Bhauvana]],''' and in the Upaniṣads<ref name=fx4_ve1_552> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, 6;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 1 (in a quotation).</ref> he is mentioned as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]]. The Kaśyapas appear in connexion with '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_552> vii. 27. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 235, n. 1.</ref>

कश्यप नैध्रुवि
<u>'''Kaśyapa Naidhruvi'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_553> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 3, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

कष्कष
<u>'''Kaṣkaṣa'''</u> designates a kind of worm in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_554> v. 23, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref>

कसर्णील
<u>'''Kasarṇīla'''</u> is the name of a kind of snake in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_555> x. 4, 5, where the Paippalāda recension has ''kvaṣarṣṇīla.''</ref> It occurs also in the form Kasarṇīra, personified as the seer Kasarṇīra Kādraveya in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Sāṃhita.<ref name=fx2_ve1_555> i. 5, 4, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 607.</ref>

क-स्तम्भी
<u>'''Ka-stambhī'''</u> denotes in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_556> i. 1, 2, 9. ''Cf.'' Caland and Henry, ''L'Agniṣṭoma,'' 49;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 14, n. 1.</ref> a piece of wood used as a prop for the end of a wagon-pole to rest on.

कहोड कौषीतकि
<u>'''Kahoḍa Kauṣītaki'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_557> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 3, 1;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, xv.</ref> or '''Kauṣītakeya'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_557> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 5, 1.</ref> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_557/> the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_557/> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve1_557/> as a teacher, contemporary with [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]]. ''Cf.'' '''[[काहोडि|Kāhoḍi]].''' 

काकम्बीर
<u>'''Kākambīra'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_558> vi. 48, 17. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62.</ref> of a useful tree of some kind.

काक्ष-सेनि
<u>'''Kākṣa-seni'''</u> is the patronymic (‘son of '''Kakṣasena’''') of '''Abhipratārin''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 1, 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

काक्षीवत
<u>'''Kākṣīvata.'''</u> See '''[[नोधस्|Nodhas]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

काठक
<u>'''Kāṭhaka,'''</u> the name of the recension of the Black [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] belonging to the school of the Kaṭhas, is mentioned in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_561> x. 4.</ref> of [[यास्क|Yāska]] and in the Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_561> iii. 11;<br> vii. 11.</ref> The Saṃhitā which bears the name has been in part edited by L. v. Schroeder.<ref name=fx3_ve1_561> Two volumes have so far appeared, the first containing i-xviii, the second xix-xxx. ''Cf. Indische Studien,'' 1, 44;<br> 3, 451;<br> von Schroeder, [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, 1900, 1909;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 145171;<br> ''Die Tübinger Kaṭha-Handschriften,'' Vienna, 1898;<br> ''Zwei Handschriften der K.K. Hofbiblliothek in Wien mit Fragmenten des [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]],'' Vienna, 1896.</ref>

काण्ठे-विद्धि
<u>'''Kāṇṭhe-viddhi'''</u> (‘descendant of Kaṇṭheviddha’) is mentioned as a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_562> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 382.</ref>

काण्ड-वीणा
<u>'''Kāṇḍa-vīṇā,'''</u> the name of a musical instrument, a kind of lute made out of joints of reed, which is mentioned as used at the Mahāvrata ceremony in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_563> xxxiv. 5 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 477). ''Cf.'' Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 2, 6;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 3, 16;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii, 3, 12.</ref>

काण्ड्विय
<u>'''Kāṇḍviya'''</u> is mentioned as an Udgātṛ in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 10, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

काण्व
<u>'''Kāṇva.'''</u> See '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]]:''' among others, '''Devātithi, [[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]], [[वत्स|Vatsa]],''' were prominent members of the [[कण्व|Kaṇva]] family. <br>==Foot Notes==

काण्वी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kāṇvī-putra'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[कापीपुत्र|Kāpīputra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_566> vi. 5, 1 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension).</ref>

काण्वायन
<u>'''Kāṇvāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of Kaṇva’) and '''Kāṇvyāyana''' (‘descendant of Kāṇvya’) are patronymics occurring in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_567> viii. 55, 4.</ref> and the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_567> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 38;<br> Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 51, 1;<br> viii. 2, 40.</ref> respectively.

कात्यायनि
<u>'''Kātyāyani.'''</u> See '''Dakṣa.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कात्यायनी
<u>'''Kātyāyanī'''</u> is the name of one of the two wives of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_569> ii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 5, 1. 2. A Kātya appears in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 15 ''et seq.'' See Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 138.</ref>

कात्यायनी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kātyāyanī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of [[कात्यायनी|Kātyāyanī]],’ is mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_570> vi. 5, 1, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> as a pupil of '''[[गोतमीपुत्र|Gotamīputra]]''' and of '''[[कौशिकीपुत्र|Kauśikīputra]].''' A [[जातूकर्ण्य|Jātūkarṇya]] [[कात्यायनीपुत्र|Kātyāyanīputra]] is named as a teacher in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve1_570> viii. 10. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 138.</ref>

कानान्ध
<u>'''Kānāndha'''</u> is mentioned in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] xxi. 10) as son of '''[[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कानीत
<u>'''Kānīta'''</u> is the patronymic (‘son of Kanīta’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_572> viii. 46, 21, 24. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 11, 23.</ref> of '''[[पृथुश्रवस्|Pṛthuśravas]].'''

कानीन
<u>'''Kānīna'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_573> v. 5, 8. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 334.</ref> apparently denotes the ‘son of a maiden.’ See '''Pati.''' 

काण्डा-विष
<u>'''Kāṇḍā-viṣa'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (x. 4, 22) denotes some kind of poison. ''Cf.'' '''[[कनक्नक|Kanaknaka]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कापटव सु-नीथ
<u>'''Kāpaṭava Su-nītha'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_575> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 383.</ref> as a pupil of '''Sutemanas [[शाण्डिल्यायन|Śāṇḍilyāyana]].'''

कापिलेय
<u>'''Kāpileya.'''</u>--The Kāpileyas and the '''Bābhravas''' are mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_576> vii. 17. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 216, n., 433.</ref> as descendants of '''[[देवरात|Devarāta]] [[वैश्वामित्र|Vaiśvāmitra]],''' the adoptive name of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]].'''

कापी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kāpī-putra'''</u> (‘son of Kāpī’) is mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 1) as a pupil of '''[[आत्रेयीपुत्र|Ātreyīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कापेय
<u>'''Kāpeya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kapi’). The Kāpeyas are mentioned as priests of '''[[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]]''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_578> xiii. 12.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_578> xx. 12, 5. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 52, 53;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 157.</ref> See also '''[[शौनक|Śaunaka]].'''

काप्य
<u>'''Kāpya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kapi’) is the patronymic of [[सनक|Sanaka]] and [[नवक|Navaka]], two obviously fictitious persons who served at the Sattra (‘sacrificial session’) of the Vibhindukīyas in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_579> iii. 233.</ref> It is also the patronymic of Patañcala in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upanisad.<ref name=fx2_ve1_579> iii. 3, 1;<br> 7, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 126, 137.</ref> See also '''Kaiśerya.'''

काबन्धि
<u>'''Kābandhi'''</u> (‘descendant of Kabandha’) is the patronymic of '''Vicārin''' in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 2, 9. 18).<br>==Foot Notes==

काम-प्रि
<u>'''Kāma-pri'''</u> (descendant of Kāmapra’) is the patronymic of '''Marutta''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 21). In the St. Petersburg Dictionary it is suggested that the reading in this passage should be ''kāmapre,'' ‘fulfilling desires,’ as an epithet of the sacrifice (''yajñe''). <br>==Foot Notes==

कामलायन
<u>'''Kāmalāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of Kamala’) is the patronymic of '''Upakosala''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 10, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

काम्पील
<u>'''Kāmpīla.'''</u>--In one passage of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_583> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 20;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], iv. 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 6;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 8, 3.</ref> the epithet [[काम्पील|Kāmpīla]]-vāsinī is applied to a woman, perhaps the king's [[महिषी|Mahiṣī]] or chief wife, whose duty it was to sleep beside the slaughtered animal at the horse sacrifice ([[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]). The exact interpretation of the passage is very uncertain, but both Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_583> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 184;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 114, 115.</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_583> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 36, 37. So also Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 204;<br> von Schroeder, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, 1, xxi;<br> ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 164;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 321, 322.</ref> agree in regarding [[काम्पील|Kāmpīla]] as the name of the town known as Kāmpīlya in the later literature, and the capital of [[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] in [[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]].

काम्बोज
<u>'''Kāmboja'''</u> (‘native of '''[[कम्बोज|Kamboja]]'''’) '''[[औपमन्यव|Aupamanyava]]''' (‘descendant of Upamanyu’) is mentioned as a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_584> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 45: Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 102.</ref>

कारपचव
<u>'''Kārapacava'''</u> is the name in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_585> xxv. 10, 23. ''Cf.'' Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 29, 25;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 6, 10;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 34.</ref> of a place on the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]].'''

कारस्कर
<u>'''Kāraskara'''</u> is the name of a people mentioned in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_586> xx. 13. (14). ''Cf.'' [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 14.</ref> and the Āpastamba<ref name=fx2_ve1_586> xxii. 6, 18.</ref> and Hiraṇyakeśi<ref name=fx3_ve1_586> xvii. 6, ''Cf.'' Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 148;<br> Caland, ''Zcitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 553.</ref> Sūtras. 

कारि
<u>'''Kāri'''</u> is the name of one of the victims of the human sacrifice (Puruṣamedha) in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_587> xxx. 6. 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 2, 1.</ref> and is there dedicated to ‘laughter.’ The commentator Mahīdhara<ref name=fx2_ve1_587> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> interprets the word as ‘worker’ (''karaṇa-śīla''), but the St. Petersburg Dictionary suggests that it means a ‘jubilant’ person (as derived from the root ''kṛ,'' ‘to praise’).

कारीरदि
<u>'''Kārīradi'''</u> is the name of persons mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 4, 4) as holding a special view of the Udgītha ([[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]] Chant).<br>==Foot Notes==

कारु
<u>'''Kāru,'''</u> ‘poet,’ is a word almost confined to the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_589> i. 148, 2;<br> 165, 12;<br> 177, 5;<br> 178, 3;<br> ii. 43, 1;<br> iii. 33, 8;<br> 39, 7;<br> v. 33, 7;<br> vii. 27;<br> 68, 9;<br> 72, 4, etc.: Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 8, 7;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 21.</ref> There is evidence that the poet was regarded as a professional man, just as much as the physician ('''[[भिषज्|Bhiṣaj]]''').<ref name=fx2_ve1_589> ix. 112. 3.</ref> The poets, no doubt, mainly lived at the courts of princes amid their retainers,<ref name=fx3_ve1_589> vii. 73. 1.</ref> though they would probably also sing the praises of rich merchants. There was probably no essential connexion between the priest and the poet. Though the priest was often a poet, yet poetry can hardly have been restricted to the priestly caste. Indeed, at the horse sacrifice ([[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]) the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_589> xiii. 1, 5, 1;<br> 4, 3, 5.</ref> expressly requires that one of the singers of panegyrics should be a [[राजन्य|Rājanya]], while the other was a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], both singing verses of their own composition. The Anukramaṇī (Index) in several cases<ref name=fx5_ve1_589> ''E.g.,'' x. 92 is attributed to [[शार्यात|Śāryāta]] [[मानव|Mānava]].</ref> attributes hymns of the Rigveda to princes; and even though this may often be merely the same sort of procedure<ref name=fx6_ve1_589> See Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 202.</ref> as has made Śūdraka the author of the Mṛcchakaṭikā, or Harṣa of the Ratnāvalī, and has given us royal teachers of the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] doctrine,<ref name=fx7_ve1_589> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 20, n. 4, sees in Av. xx. a recension of [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] character. He also finds Kṣatriyas in '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' and '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]],''' but hardly with reason. ''Cf.'' '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].'''</ref> still the Indian tradition evidently saw nothing odd in the idea of nonBrāhmaṇas as poets. Most of the non-sacred poetry has,  however, disappeared, for the epic is a product, as it stands, of a later period. See also '''[[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]].'''

कारोतर
<u>'''Kārotara'''</u> appears to denote in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_590> i. 116, 7.</ref> and occasionally later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_590> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 16, 82;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 9, 1, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 280.</ref> a ‘filter’ or ‘sieve’ for purifying the liquor called '''[[सुरा|Surā]].'''

कारोती
<u>'''Kārotī'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ix. 5, 2, 15) as a place, or perhaps a river, where '''[[तुर कावषेय|Tura Kāvaṣeya]]''' made a fire-altar--that is, as a seat of the fire-cult ''par excellence.''<br>==Foot Notes==

कार्शकेयी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kārśakeyī-putra'''</u> (‘son of Kārśakeyī’) is the name of a man mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]. In the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] (vi. 5, 2) recension he is a pupil of '''[[प्राचीनयोगीपुत्र|Prācīnayogīputra]];''' in the Mādhyaṃdina (vi. 4, 33) recension his teacher's name is '''[[प्राश्नीपुत्र|Prāśnīputra]] [[आसुरिवासिन्|Āsurivāsin]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कार्ष्णायस
<u>'''Kārṣṇāyasa'''</u> (‘black metal’), a word found in the Upaniṣads,<ref name=fx1_ve1_593> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 7;<br> vi. 1, 5;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 17, 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 52.</ref> must clearly mean ‘iron.’ See '''Ayas.'''

कार्ष्मन्
<u>'''Kārṣman,'''</u> a word meaning literally ‘furrow,’ and found only in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_594> i. 116, 17;<br> ix. 36, 1;<br> 74, 8.</ref> is the designation of the goal in the chariot race. The competitor probably turned round it and came back to the starting-place.<ref name=fx2_ve1_594> Av. ii. 14, 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 291, 292.</ref>

कार्ष्मर्य
<u>'''Kārṣmarya'''</u> is the name of a tree (''Gmelina arborea'') which is often alluded to in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_595> v. 2, 7, 3. 4;<br> vi. 2, 1, 5.</ref> the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_595> iii. 2, 6;<br> 7, 9.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_595> iii. 4, 1, 6;<br> 8, 2, 17;<br> iv. 3, 3, 6;<br> vii. 4, 1, 37. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62.</ref> 

काल
<u>'''Kāla,'''</u> the generic expression for ‘time,’ first occurs in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_596> x. 42, 9.</ref> where, however, it is used only once, in the late tenth book. It is known to the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_596> xix. 53. 54.</ref> where [[काल|Kāla]] has already developed the sense of time as fate. The word is frequent in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx3_ve1_596> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 3;<br> ii. 4, 2, 4;<br> iii. 8, 3, 36;<br> vii. 2, 2, 21, etc.</ref> superseding the earlier use of '''[[ऋतु|Ṛtu]].''' The more general division of time is into ‘past’ (''bhūta''), ‘present’ (''bhavat''), and ‘future’ (''bhaviṣyat'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_596> ''E.g.,'' Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, vii. 20.</ref> For other divisons see '''Ahan, [[मास|Māsa]], [[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]].'''

कालका
<u>'''Kālakā'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the horse sacrifice ([[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_597> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 15, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 35.</ref> variously identified with a bird<ref name=fx2_ve1_597> Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> or a chameleon.<ref name=fx3_ve1_597> Sāyaṇa on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref>

काल-काञ्ज
<u>'''Kāla-kāñja.'''</u>--In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_598> vi. 80, 2.</ref> mention is made of the Kālakāñjas as being in the sky. Both Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_598> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_598> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 353.</ref> hold that some constellation is meant. But as the defeat of the Kālakāñjas is one of Indra's exploits,<ref name=fx4_ve1_598> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 1, ''Cf.'' also Maitrāyanī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 4-6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii, 1.</ref> it is doubtful whether any stress can be laid on that interpretation of the passage in the Atharvaveda. Whitney<ref name=fx5_ve1_598> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 341.</ref> suggests that the three stars of Orion are meant, Bloomfield<ref name=fx6_ve1_598> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 500;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 163-169.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 410, 414 ''et seq.;<br>'' 3, 465;<br> Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 121.</ref> that the galaxy or the stars in general are intended. 

कावषेय
<u>'''Kāvaṣeya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kavaṣa’) is the constant patronymic of '''Tura.''' The Kāvaṣeyas are also mentioned as teachers of philosophical points in the Rigveda Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_599> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 6;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, viii. 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 391, n.;<br> 2, 418;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 257.</ref>

काव्य
<u>'''Kāvya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kavi’) is the constant<ref name=fx1_ve1_600> Rv. i. 51, 11;<br> 83, 5;<br> 121, 12;<br> vi. 20. 11;<br> viii. 23, 17;<br> Av. iv. 29, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 8, 5, etc.</ref> patronymic of '''Uśanas.''' In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] it is also applied to '''Iḍhat'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_600> xiv. 9, 16.</ref> and '''Ukṣṇorandhra.'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_600> xiii. 9, 19.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 48, 49.</ref>

काश
<u>'''Kāśa.'''</u>--Roth<ref name=fx1_ve1_601> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> finds this word, which denotes a species of grass (''Saccharum spontaneum'') used for mats, etc., in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_601> x. 100, 10.</ref> but the reading is uncertain. The word has this sense in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx3_ve1_601> vi. 9, 1.</ref>

काशि
<u>'''Kāśi, Kāśya.'''</u>--The name [[काशि|Kāśi]] denotes (in the plural<ref name=fx1_ve1_602> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 19. 21. The plural occurs also in the Paippalāda recension of the Atharvaveda, v. 22, 14.</ref>) the people of [[काशि|Kāśi]] (Benares), and Kāśya, the king of [[काशि|Kāśi]]. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_602> xiii. 5, 4, 19.</ref> tells of '''[[धृतराष्ट्र|Dhṛtarāṣṭra]],''' king of [[काशि|Kāśi]], who was defeated by '''[[शतानीक सात्राजित|Śatānīka Sātrājita]],''' with the result that the Kāśis, down to the time of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], gave up the kindling of the sacred fire. [[सात्राजित|Sātrājita]] was a '''[[भरत|Bharata]].''' We hear also of '''[[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]]''' as a king of [[काशि|Kāśi]];<ref name=fx3_ve1_602> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 1;<br> iii. 8, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1.</ref> and no doubt '''Bhadrasena Ajātaśatrava,''' a contemporary of '''Uddālaka,''' was also a king of [[काशि|Kāśi]].<br><br>The Kāśis and '''Videhas''' were closely connected, as was natural in view of their geographical position. The compound name [[काशि|Kāśi]]-[[विदेह|Videha]] occurs in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]];<ref name=fx4_ve1_602> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_602> iii. 8, 2.</ref> '''Gārgī''' describes [[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]] as either a [[काशि|Kāśi]] or a [[विदेह|Videha]] king. The [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_602> xvi. 29, 5.</ref>  mentions one [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] as acting for the kings of [[काशि|Kāśi]], [[कोसल|Kosala]], and [[विदेह|Videha]]; and the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_602> xxi. 13.</ref> mentions [[काशि|Kāśi]] and [[विदेह|Videha]] in close proximity. Weber,<ref name=fx8_ve1_602> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 212, 213.</ref> indeed, throws out the suggestion that the Kāśis and the Videhas together constitute the '''Uśīnaras,''' whose name is very rare in Vedic literature.<br><br>As [[कोसल|Kosala]] and [[विदेह|Videha]] were in close connexion, [[काशि|Kāśi]] and [[कोसल|Kosala]] are found combined in the compound name KāśiKauśalyas of the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx9_ve1_602> i. 2, 9.</ref><br><br>Though [[काशि|Kāśi]] is a late word, it is quite possible that the town is older, as the river '''[[वरणावती|Varaṇāvatī]]''' referred to in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx10_ve1_602> iv. 7. 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 20;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 376.</ref> may be connected with the later Vārāṇasī (Benares).<br><br>It is significant that while the Kāśis, Kosalas, and Videhas were united, any relations which the Kuru-Pañcala peoples may have had with them were hostile. It is a fair conclusion that between these two great groups of peoples there did exist some political conflict as well as probably a difference of culture in some degree. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx11_ve1_602> i. 4, 1, 10 ''et seq. Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170 ''et seq.;<br>'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xlii ''et seq.,'' 104, n. 1.</ref> in the story of the advance of Āryan civilization over [[कोसल|Kosala]] and [[विदेह|Videha]], preserves a clear tradition of this time, and a piece of evidence that in the Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] country lay the real centre of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] culture (see also '''Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]]'''). That the [[कोसल|Kosala]]-Videhas were originally settlers of older date than the Kuru-Pañcālas is reasonably obvious from their geographical position, but the true [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] culture appears to have been brought to them from the Kuru-Pañcala country. It is very probable that the East was less Āryan than the West, and that it was less completely reduced under Brahmin spiritual supremacy, as the movement of Buddhism was Eastern, and the Buddhist texts<ref name=fx12_ve1_602> See Fick, ''Die seciale Gliederung,'' chap. iv.</ref> reveal a position in which the Kṣatriyas rank above Brāhmaṇas. With this agrees the fact that the later Vedic texts<ref name=fx13_ve1_602> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 4, 22;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6, 28. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 99;<br> Fick, ''op. cit.,'' 140, n. 1;<br> and ''of.'' '''[[मगध|Magadha]].'''</ref> display  towards the people of [[मगध|Magadha]] a marked antipathy, which may be reasonably explained by that people's lack of orthodoxy, and which may perhaps be traced as far back as the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx14_ve1_602> xxx. 5. 22. See '''[[मगध|Magadha]].'''</ref> It is, of course, possible that the [[कोसल|Kosala]]-Videhas and Kāśis actually were merely offshoots of the tribes later known as the Kuru-Pañcālas, and that they by reason of distance and less complete subjugation of the aborigines lost their Brahminical culture. This hypothesis, however, appears less likely, though it might be supported by a literal interpretation of the legend of the Aryan migration in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx15_ve1_602> ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''loc. cit.,'' 104, n. 1. ''Cf.'' Grierson, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 837, 1143;<br> Keith, ''ibid.,'' 831, 1138;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 402 ''et seq.''</ref>

कास्यप
<u>'''Kāsyapa'''</u> (‘descendant of Kaśyapa’) is a common patronymic,<ref name=fx1_ve1_603> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 1, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 18;<br> x. 1, 8, etc.</ref> and is applied specially to '''Ṛśyaśṛṅga, Devataras [[श्यावसायन|Śyāvasāyana]], [[शूष वाह्नेय|Śūṣa Vāhneya]].'''

काश्यपी-बालाक्या-माठरी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kāśyapī-bālākyā-[[माठरी|māṭharī]]-putra'''</u> (‘son of Kāśyapī, Bālākyā, and Māṭharī’). This curious name is given in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_604> vi. 4, 31 (Mādhyaṃdina recension).</ref> to a teacher, pupil of '''[[कौत्सीपुत्र|Kautsīputra]].'''

काषायण
<u>'''Kāṣāyaṇa'''</u> is mentioned in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] as a teacher, pupil of [[सायकायन|Sāyakāyana]] according to the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] (iv. 6, 2), of [[सौकरायण|Saukarāyaṇa]] according to the Mādhyaṃdina recension (iv. 5, 27).<br>==Foot Notes==

काष्ठा
<u>'''Kāṣṭhā'''</u> seems to have the sense in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_606> i. 37, 10;<br> 65, 3;<br> iv. 58, 7;<br> vi. 46, 1;<br> vii. 93, 3;<br> viii. 80, 8;<br> ix. 21, 7.</ref> of ‘course’ for a chariot race. It also means in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_606> x. 102, 9, is perhaps so to be taken.</ref> and later<ref name=fx3_ve1_606> Av. ii. 14, 6: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 9, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 13;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 7;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 7, 2. etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 291, 292;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 77.</ref> ‘goal,’ either like the '''[[कार्ष्मन्|Kārṣman]]''' the turning place, or the final goal (''paramā [[काष्ठा|kāṣṭhā]]''). 

कास्
<u>'''Kās, Kāsa, Kāsā, Kāsikā.'''</u>--All these four forms<ref name=fx1_ve1_607> [[कास्|Kās]]: Av. i. 12, 3;<br> v. 22, 10;<br> '''Kāsa:''' Av. v. 22, 11 (probably);<br> Kāsā: Av. vi. 105, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Kāsikā: Av, v. 22, 12;<br> xi. 2, 22.</ref> of the same word denote ‘cough,’ which is mentioned in the Atharvaveda as accompanying a headache,<ref name=fx2_ve1_607> Av. i. 12, 3.</ref> as a symptom in fever ('''[[तक्मन्|Takman]]'''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_607> v. 22, 10.</ref> and as an independent disease.<ref name=fx4_ve1_607> vi. 105.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 385;<br> Grohmann, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 394;<br> Jolly, ''Medicin,'' 89.</ref>

काहोडि
<u>'''Kāhoḍi'''</u> (‘descendant of Kahoḍa’) is the patronymic of '''[[अर्गल|Argala]]''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxv. 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

किंशुक
<u>'''Kiṃśuka'''</u> is the name of a tree (''Butea frondosa'') mentioned in the wedding hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_609> x. 85, 20. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62. Sāyaṇa thinks the meaning is that the car is made of the wood of the tree.</ref> the bridal car being described as adorned with its blossoms (''su-[[किंशुक|kiṃśuka]]'').

किकि-दीवि
<u>'''Kiki-dīvi'''</u> denotes some kind of bird, perhaps the blue jay.<ref name=fx1_ve1_610> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' See Rv. x. 97, 13.</ref> According to the commentator, it means ‘partridge’ (''tittiri'') in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_610> v. 6, 22, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 92;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 251.</ref>

कितव
<u>'''Kitava,'''</u> ‘the gambler,’ is frequently referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_611> ii. 29, 5;<br> v. 85, 8;<br> x. 34, 3. 7. 10. 11. 13.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_611> Av. vii. 50, 1;<br> 109, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 8. 18. 22;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 19, etc.</ref> A father is represented as chastising his son for gambling.<ref name=fx3_ve1_611> Rv. ii. 29, 5. ''Cf.'' '''[[पितृ|Pitṛ]].'''</ref> The gambler seems at times to have fallen, along with his family, into servitude, presumably by selling himself to pay his debts.<ref name=fx4_ve1_611> Rv. x. 34. ''Cf.'' perhaps the ''bhaktadāsa,'' ‘slave for hire,’ of the [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Sāstra, viii. 415;<br> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 197.</ref> Technical names<ref name=fx5_ve1_611> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 3, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 18.</ref> for different sorts of gamblers given in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās are Ādinava-[[दर्श|darśa]],  Kalpin, Adhi-kalpin, and [[सभा-स्थाणु|Sabhā-sthāṇu]]. None of these can be safely<ref name=fx6_ve1_611> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 18, 282;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 284.</ref> explained, though the last has usually<ref name=fx7_ve1_611> So Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 18;<br> Sāyaṇa on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 16, 1.</ref> been taken as a satirical name derived from the gambler's devotion to the dicing place ('''[[सभा|Sabhā]]'''), ‘pillar of the dicing hall.’ The first literally means ‘seeing ill-luck,’<ref name=fx8_ve1_611> ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Weber, ''loc. cit.''</ref> and may refer to the quickness of the dicer to note an error on the part of his antagonist, or to his eagerness to see the defeat of his rival.

किं-पुरुष
<u>'''Kiṃ-puruṣa,'''</u> lit. ‘what sort of man,’ appears in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_612> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 3, 9;<br> vii. 5, 2, 32.</ref> to designate the ‘ape,’ which is a mimic man. Possibly the same sense should be seen in the passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_612> xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1.</ref> where it occurs, and where Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_612> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> assumes it to refer to a contemptible man. Max Müller<ref name=fx4_ve1_612> ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 420.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 246;<br> ''Omina und Portenta,'' 356;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 51, n. 3.</ref> renders it ‘savage.’

कियाम्बु
<u>'''Kiyāmbu'''</u> is the name of one of the water-plants which are to grow, according to a funeral hymn in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_613> x. 16, 13 = Av. xviii. 3, 6.</ref> on the place where the body of the dead was burned. The word seems to mean ‘having some water,’ possibly by popular etymology.<ref name=fx2_ve1_613> ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa on Rv., ''loc. cit.,'' and on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vi. 4, 1, 2, where Kyāmbu is the form.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62;<br> Bloomfield, ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' October, 1890, xl.</ref>

किरात
<u>'''1. Kirāta'''</u> is a name applied to a people living in the caves of the mountains, as appears clearly from the dedication of the [[किरात|Kirāta]] to the caves (''guhā'') in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_614> xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1.</ref> and from the reference in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_614> x. 4, 14.</ref> to a [[किरात|Kirāta]] girl (''[[कैरातिका|kairātikā]]''), who digs a remedy on the ridges of the mountains.  Later<ref name=fx3_ve1_614> Lassen, ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 1^2, 530, 534.</ref> the people called Kirātas were located in Eastern Nepal, but the name seems to have been applied to any hill folk, no doubt aborigines, though the [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra<ref name=fx4_ve1_614> x. 44.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 32;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 207;<br> V. Smith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Socicty,'' 1909, 258, n. 1;<br> Lévi, ''Le Népal,'' 2, 77.</ref> regards them as degraded Kṣatriyas.

किरात
<u>'''2. Kirāta.'''</u>--In the story of '''Asamāti''' there appear, as the two priests who are opposed to the '''Gaupāyanas,''' [[किरात|Kirāta]] and '''Akuli''' according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_615> xiii. 12, 5 (where the text reads ''[[किरात|kirāta]]-kulyau''). Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' takes the word, with Sāyaṇa, as an adjective, ''[[किरात|kirāta]]-kula,'' ‘of the family of [[किरात|Kirāta]].’ The reading in the Bṛhaddevatā (vii. 86) is ''kirātākulī.''</ref> or [[किलात|Kilāta]] and [[आकुलि|Ākuli]] according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_615> i. 1, 4, 14 (where the text reads ''kilātākulī''). ''Cf.'' also Sāṭyāyanaka [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] ''apud'' Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 57, 1;<br> 60, 1;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 167;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Socicty,'' 18, 41 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 48, n. 1.</ref> No doubt the name is chosen, not as that of a historic person, but as a suitable designation of a hostile priest; for it is probably identical with the name of the mountaineers described in the preceding article.

किलात
<u>'''Kilāta'''</u> is the form of the name 2. '''[[किरात|Kirāta]]''' that appears in the Śatapatha, Śāṭyāyanaka, and Jaiminīya Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_616> See note^2 under the preceding article.</ref>

किलास
<u>'''Kilāsa'''</u> is the name of a disease, ‘white leprosy,’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_617> i. 23, 24.</ref> and the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, etc.<ref name=fx2_ve1_617> xxx. 21;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 3, 17;<br> xxiii. 11, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 4, 12. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 391;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 266;<br> Jolly, ''Medicin,'' 98;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 68.</ref> It resulted in the appearance of grey (''[[पलित|palita]]'') and white (''[[शुक्ल|śukla]], śveta'') spots all over the skin. Haug gave the same sense to ''alasa'' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_617> vi. 33, 5.</ref> but this is doubtful. The fem. Kilāsī is taken by Max Müller to mean a ‘spotted deer’ in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx4_ve1_617> v. 53, 1.</ref> 

कीकट
<u>'''Kīkaṭa.'''</u>--The name of this people occurs only in one passage of the Rigveda, where they appear as hostile to the singer and as under the leadership of '''[[प्रमगन्द|Pramaganda]].''' [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_618> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 32.</ref> declares that [[कीकट|Kīkaṭa]] was the name of a non-Āryan country, and later<ref name=fx3_ve1_618> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> [[कीकट|Kīkaṭa]] is given as a synonym of [[मगध|Magadha]]. Hence Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_618> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 31, 118. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 58.</ref> concludes that the Kīkaṭas were a non-Āryan people living in the country later known as [[मगध|Magadha]]. Weber<ref name=fx5_ve1_618> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 186;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 79, n. *.</ref> holds that this people were located in [[मगध|Magadha]], but were Āryan, though at variance with other Āryan tribes, perhaps because of heretical tendencies, for [[मगध|Magadha]] was later a seat of Buddhism. But the identification is uncertain, and is doubted by Oldenberg<ref name=fx6_ve1_618> ''Buddha,'' 402, 403;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 253.</ref> and Hillebrandt.<ref name=fx7_ve1_618> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 14-18.</ref><br><br>^1 iii. 53, 14.

कीट
<u>'''Kīṭa'''</u> is the name of a species of worm mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_619> ix. 4, 16.</ref> and frequently in the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx2_ve1_619> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 19;<br> 2, 14;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 9. 3;<br> 10, 2;<br> vii. 2, 1;<br> 7, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref>

कीनाश
<u>'''Kīnāśa,'''</u> a name of the ploughman or cultivator of the soil, is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_620> iv. 57, 8.</ref> and the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve1_620> Av. iv. 11, 10;<br> vi. 30, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 8, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 237;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 45;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 86, n.</ref> See '''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]].'''

कीरि
<u>'''Kīri'''</u> is in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_621> i. 31, 13;<br> ii. 12, 6;<br> v. 52, 12 (''kīriṇaḥ;<br>'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 317). But see Geldner. ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 46;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 223.</ref> a regular designation of the ‘poet.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]].'''

कीर्शा
<u>'''Kīrśā,'''</u> the name of some kind of animal, or perhaps bird, is mentioned in the list of victims for the horse sacrifice ([[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]) in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_622> v. 5, 20, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> 

कीलाल
<u>'''Kīlāla,'''</u> a word denoting a ‘sweet drink,’ is found in all the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_623> Av. iv. 11, 10;<br> 26, 6;<br> 27, 5;<br> vi. 69, 1;<br> x. 6, 25;<br> xii. 1, 59;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 12, 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 12;<br> iii. 11, 3. 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 34;<br> iii. 43;<br> xx. 65;<br> xxx. 11, etc.</ref> but not in the Rigveda. As the [[सुरा-कार|Surā-kāra]], ‘maker of [[सुरा|Surā]],’ is dedicated in the list of victims in the human sacrifice<ref name=fx2_ve1_623> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 9, 1.</ref> (Puruṣamedha) to [[कीलाल|Kīlāla]], it must have been a drink of somewhat the same nature as the '''[[सुरा|Surā]]''' itself, possibly, as Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_623> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 281.</ref> suggests, a kind of rum.

कीश्मील
<u>'''Kīśmīla'''</u> denotes, according to Bo7htlingk,<ref name=fx1_ve1_624> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> a certain disease in the Paippalāda recension of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_624> xix. 8, 4.</ref>

कीस्त
<u>'''Kīsta'''</u> in two passages of the '''Rigveda'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_625> i. 127, 7;<br> vi. 67, 10. ''Cf.'' [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 15.</ref> means ‘poet,’ like '''[[कीरि|Kīri]].'''

कुक्कुट
<u>'''Kukkuṭa,'''</u> ‘cock,’ occurs in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_626> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 16. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 91.</ref> only.<ref name=fx2_ve1_626> It is common in the later language.</ref>

कुटरु
<u>'''Kuṭaru'''</u> is, according to the commentator Mahīdhara,<ref name=fx1_ve1_627> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv, 23.</ref> synonymous with '''[[कुक्कुट|Kukkuṭa]],''' ‘cock.’ The word is found in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās only.<ref name=fx2_ve1_627> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 17, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 1, 6;<br> iii. 14, 4. 20;<br> iv. 1, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 23, 39.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref>

कुण्ड-पायिन्
<u>'''Kuṇḍa-pāyin'''</u> (‘drinking from a jug’) is the name of a teacher mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_628> xxv. 4, 4.</ref> and in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_628> Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 4, 6;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 4, 21.</ref> 

कुण्ड-पाय्य
<u>'''Kuṇḍa-pāyya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kuṇḍapāyin’) is a patronymic connected with a man named '''[[शृङ्गवृष्|Śṛṅgavṛṣ]]''' in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_629> viii. 17, 13. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 161;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 90.</ref>

कुण्डृणाची
<u>'''Kuṇḍṛṇācī'''</u> is the name of an animal of unknown character occurring in the lists of victims at the horse sacrifice ([[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_630> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 16, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 18;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 37.</ref> The word also occurs in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_630> i. 29, 6.</ref> in which a bird would seem to be intended, though Sāyaṇa interprets it as meaning ‘with crooked flight’ (''kuṭila-gatyā''). In his commentary on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_630> v. 5, 16, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 89.</ref> he takes the word to denote the houselizard (''[[गृह|gṛha]]-godhikā'').

कुत्स
<u>'''Kutsa'''</u> is the name of a hero frequently mentioned in the Rigveda, which, however, gives practically no information about him, for he was no doubt already a figure of the mythic past. He is several times<ref name=fx1_ve1_631> Rv. iv. 26, 1;<br> vii. 19, 2;<br> viii. 1, 11.</ref> called [[आर्जुनेय|Ārjuneya]], ‘descendant of Arjuna,’ and is usually<ref name=fx2_ve1_631> Rv. i. 63, 3;<br> 121, 19;<br> 174, 5;<br> 175, 4;<br> iv. 30, 4;<br> v. 29, 4;<br> vi. 20, 5;<br> vii. 19, 2;<br> x. 99, 9.</ref> associated with Indra in the exploit of defeating the demon Śuṣṇa and winning the sun. He is said<ref name=fx3_ve1_631> Rv. x. 49, 4.</ref> to have defeated '''[[स्मद्इभ|Smadibha]], [[तुग्र|Tugra]],''' and the '''Vetasus,''' but, on the other hand, he is several times<ref name=fx4_ve1_631> Rv. i. 53, 10;<br> ii. 14, 7;<br> viii. 53, 2. ''Cf.'' iv. 26, 1.</ref> mentioned with '''[[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]]''' and '''[[आयु|Āyu]]''' as being vanquished by Indra, his defeat in one passage<ref name=fx5_ve1_631> Rv. i. 53, 10.</ref> being attributed to '''[[तूर्वयाण|Tūrvayāṇa]].''' Elsewhere<ref name=fx6_ve1_631> Rv. i. 51, 6;<br> vi. 26, 3.</ref> he appears with [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]] as a friend of Indra's. In the later literature he is seldom<ref name=fx7_ve1_631> ''E.g.,'' Av. iv. 29, 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 11, 26.</ref> mentioned except in connexion with the myth of his binding Indra, which is found in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx8_ve1_631> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 2, 22;<br> Śāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 38, 5;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 228;<br> Oertel. ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 31.</ref> and which is based on an obscure verse in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx9_ve1_631> x. 38, 5.</ref> <br><br>The Kutsas, or descendants of [[कुत्स|Kutsa]], are mentioned in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx10_ve1_631> vii. 25, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 113, 148;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 210, 211;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 284 ''et seq.,'' who suggests that perhaps two Kutsas--one a friend of Indra, and the other a foe --may be distinguished;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 171;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 57, n. 1.</ref>

कुत्स औरव
<u>'''Kutsa Aurava'''</u> (‘son of Uru’) is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_632> xiv. 6, 8.</ref> as having murdered his domestic priest (''[[पुरोहित|purohita]]''), '''[[उपगु सौश्रवस|Upagu Sauśravasa]],''' because the father of the latter insisted on paying homage to Indra. This fact may be compared with the hostility to Indra of '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]]''' according to certain passages of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_632> See '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]].''' ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 284;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 57;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 32.</ref>

कुन्ति
<u>'''Kunti.'''</u>--The Kuntis are referred to in an obscure and corrupt passage of the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_633> xxvi. 9. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 471, and ''cf.'' perhaps Maitrāyaṇī aṃhitā, iv. 2, 6.</ref> as having defeated the '''Pañcālas.'''

कुबेर वारक्य
<u>'''Kubera Vārakya'''</u> is mentioned in a list of teachers in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1) as a pupil of '''[[जयन्त|Jayanta]] [[वारक्य|Vārakya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कुभा
<u>'''Kubhā'''</u> is the name of a river mentioned twice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_635> v. 53, 9;<br> x. 75. 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 14;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200.</ref> and no doubt identical with the modern Kabul river, the Greek .

कुभ्र
<u>'''Kubhra'''</u> is the name of some animal in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (ii. 5, 3). <br>==Foot Notes==

कु-मुद
<u>'''Ku-muda'''</u> is the name of a plant mentioned with other water plants in one passage of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_637> iv. 34. 5. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70.</ref> It is no doubt the white water-lily (''Nymphœa esculenta''), being the name of that plant in post-Vedic Sanskrit also.

कुम्ब
<u>'''Kumba'''</u> is mentioned with '''[[ओपश|Opaśa]]''' and '''[[कुरीर|Kurīra]]''' as an ornament of women's hair in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_638> vi. 138, 3.</ref> Geldner<ref name=fx2_ve1_638> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 131.</ref> thinks that, like those two words, it originally meant ‘horn,’ but this is very doubtful. Indian tradition<ref name=fx3_ve1_638> Sāyaṇa on Av. vi. 138, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 265;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 538, 539;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 348;<br> Caland, ''Über das vituclle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 59.</ref> simply regards the term as denoting a female adornment connected with the dressing of the hair.

कुम्ब्या
<u>'''Kumbyā'''</u> or '''Kumvyā''' is a word mentioned after Ṛc, [[यजुस्|Yajus]], Sāman, and [[गाथा|Gāthā]] in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_639> xi. 5, 7, 10.</ref> to denote a form of speech. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve1_639> ii. 3, 6.</ref> it appears as one of the forms of measured speech together with Ṛc and [[गाथा|Gāthā]]. The precise meaning of the term is unknown. Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_639> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 111, n.<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 221;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44. 101.</ref> suggests the sense ‘refrain.’

कुम्भ
<u>'''Kumbha'''</u> is a word of frequent occurrence in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_640> i. 116, 7;<br> 117, 6;<br> vii. 33, 13, etc.</ref> as well as later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_640> Av. i. 6, 4;<br> iii. 12, 7, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 87, etc.</ref> and denotes a ‘pot.’ Usually no doubt made of clay, it was easily broken.<ref name=fx3_ve1_640> Rv. x. 89, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 367.</ref> See also '''[[उखा|Ukhā]].'''

कुम्भी-नस
<u>'''Kumbhī-nasa'''</u> (‘pot-nosed’) is the name of an animal mentioned in the list of victims at the horse sacrifice ([[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]) in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_641> v. 5, 14, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s. v.''</ref> Possibly some sort of snake is meant, as in the later literature. 

कुय-वाच्
<u>'''Kuya-vāc'''</u> (‘evil-speaking’) appears in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_642> i. 174, 7.</ref> to denote a demon slain by Indra, probably as a personification of the barbarian opponents of the Āryans. The expression ''[[मृध्र-वाच्|mṛdhra-vāc]]'' (‘speaking insultingly’) is similarly used of barbarians in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_642> v. 29, 10;<br> 32, 8. See [[दस्यु|Dasyu]].</ref>

कुरीर
<u>'''Kurīra,'''</u> like '''[[ओपश|Opaśa]]''' and '''[[कुम्ब|Kumba]],''' denotes some sort of female head ornament in the description of the bride's adornment in the wedding hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_643> x. 85. 8.</ref> and in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_643> vi. 138, 3.</ref> According to the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx3_ve1_643> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 5, 3: Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7. 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 56.</ref> the goddess [[सिनीवाली|Sinīvālī]] is described by the epithets ''su-kapardā, [[सु-कुरीर|su-kurīra]], sv-opaśā,'' as wearing a beautiful head-dress.<br><br>According to Geldner,<ref name=fx4_ve1_643> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 131, 132.</ref> the word originally meant ‘horn’; but this is uncertain, as this sense is not required in any passage in which the term occurs.<ref name=fx5_ve1_643> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 21 (= vaitāna [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xi. 22), cited by Geldner, is quite vague.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 265;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharanaveda,'' 539;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 348;<br> Caland, ''Über das vituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 59.</ref>

कुरीरिन्
<u>'''Kurīrin'''</u> (‘having a '''[[कुरीर|Kurīra]]'''’) is a word occurring in an ambiguous passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_644> v. 31, 2.</ref> in which it may be taken either as a noun meaning a ‘crested animal,’ perhaps as Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_644> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 91.</ref> suggests the ‘peacock,’ or as an epithet of the word '''Aja,''' ‘goat,’ in which case it might mean ‘horned.’ But even in the latter alternative a metaphorical application of the word seems sufficient, just as in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_644> xiii. 4, 3.</ref> '''[[ओपश|Opaśa]]''' is used of the horns of cattle, and thus renders unnecessary the adoption of Geldner's<ref name=fx4_ve1_644> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 130.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 457, 539;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 285;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 279.</ref> view that the original meaning of '''[[कुरीर|Kurīra]]''' is ‘horn.’ 

कुरु
<u>'''Kuru.'''</u>--The Kurus appear as by far the most important people in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] literature. There is clear evidence that it was in the country of the Kurus, or the allied KuruPañcālas, that the great Brāhmaṇas were composed.<ref name=fx1_ve1_645> For the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 49, 50, with Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 67, 68;<br> for the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], Weber, ''loc. cit.,'' 45;<br> for the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] and Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyakas, Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 387;<br> for the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], Weber, ''loc. cit.,'' 132, ''Transactions of the Bcrlin Academy,'' 1895, 859. The Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] refers repeatedly to the Kuru-Pañcālas, whose name also occurs in the late and confused Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. For the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], see i. 8, 4, 1. 2, and for the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 6.</ref> The Kurus are comparatively seldom mentioned alone, their name being usually coupled with that of the Pañcālas on account of the intimate connexion of the two peoples. The Kuru-Pañcālas are often expressly referred to as a united nation.<ref name=fx2_ve1_645> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 6;<br> 8, 7;<br> iv. 7, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 1. 2, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 3, 3 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension).</ref> In the land of the Kuru-Pañcālas speech is said to have its particular home;<ref name=fx3_ve1_645> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 3, 15.</ref> the mode of sacrifice among the Kuru-Pañcālas is proclaimed to be the best;<ref name=fx4_ve1_645> ''Ibid.,'' i. 7, 2, 8;<br> ''cf. Kuru-[[वाजपेय|vājapeya]]'' in Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 3, 15;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 11, 18.</ref> the Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] kings perform the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] or royal sacrifice;<ref name=fx5_ve1_645> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 2, 3. 5.</ref> their princes march forth on raids in the dewy season, and return in the hot season.<ref name=fx6_ve1_645> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 1. 8, 4. 1, 2.</ref> Later on the Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] Brahmins are famous in the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx7_ve1_645> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 78;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 30, 6;<br> iv. 6, 2;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, 1;<br> 9, 20, etc.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx8_ve1_645> ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 470;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 114.</ref> and Grierson<ref name=fx9_ve1_645> ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 602-607;<br> 837-844.</ref> have sought to find traces in Vedic literature of a breach between the two tribes, the latter scholar seeing therein a confirmation of the theory that the Kurus belonged to the later stream of immigrants into India, who were specially Brahminical, as opposed to the Pañcālas, who were anti-Brahminical. In support of this view, Weber refers to the story in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx10_ve1_645> x. 6. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xli.</ref> of a dispute between '''[[वक दाल्भ्य|Vaka Dālbhya]]''' and '''[[धृतराष्ट्र वैचित्रवीर्य|Dhṛtarāṣṭra Vaicitravīrya]],''' the former being held to be by origin a [[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]], while the latter is held  to be a Kuru. But there is no trace of a quarrel between Kurus and Pañcālas in the passage in question, which merely preserves the record of a dispute on a ritual matter between a priest and a prince: the same passage refers to the Naimiṣīya sacrifice among the Kuru-Pañcālas, and emphasizes the close connexion of the two peoples.<ref name=fx11_ve1_645> See Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 831-836;<br> 11381142.</ref> Secondly, Weber conjectures in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx12_ve1_645> xxiii. 18.</ref> that '''[[सुभद्रिका|Subhadrikā]]''' of '''Kāmpila''' was the chief queen of the king of a tribe living in the neighbourhood of the clan, for whose king the horse sacrifice described in the Saṃhitā was performed. But the interpretation of this passage by Weber is open to grave doubt;<ref name=fx13_ve1_645> Eggeling. ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 322.</ref> and in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Saṃhitā<ref name=fx14_ve1_645> xi. 3, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 114, note *.</ref> a passage used at the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] shows that the Kuru-Pañcālas had actually one king. Moreover, there is the evidence of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx15_ve1_645> xiii. 5, 4, 7.</ref> that the old name of the Pañcālas was '''[[क्रिवि|Krivi]].''' This word looks very like a variant of Kuru, and Zimmer<ref name=fx16_ve1_645> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 103.</ref> plausibly conjectures that the Kurus and Krivis formed the '''[[वैकर्ण|Vaikarṇa]]'''<ref name=fx17_ve1_645> vii. 18, 11.</ref> of the Rigveda, especially as both peoples are found about the [[सिन्धु|Sindhu]] and the [[असिक्नी|Asiknī]].<ref name=fx18_ve1_645> Keith, ''loc. cit.,'' 835.</ref><br><br>The Kurus alone are chiefly mentioned in connexion with the locality which they occupied, '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' We are told, however, of a domestic priest ('''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]]''') in the service of both the Kurus and the '''Sṛñjayas,'''<ref name=fx19_ve1_645> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 5.</ref> who must therefore at one time have been closely connected.<ref name=fx20_ve1_645> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 123.</ref> In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] reference is made to the Kurus being saved by a mare (''aśvā''),<ref name=fx21_ve1_645> iv. 17, 9: for ''aśvā'' Bo7htlingk in his edition reads ''akṣṇā,'' followed by Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 1.</ref> and to some disaster which befel them owing to a hailstorm.<ref name=fx22_ve1_645> i. 10, 1.</ref> In the Sūtras, again, a ceremony ([[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]]) of the Kurus is mentioned.<ref name=fx23_ve1_645> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 3, 15.</ref> There also a curse, which was pronounced on them and led to their being driven from [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], is alluded to.<ref name=fx24_ve1_645> ''Ibid.,'' xv. 16, 11. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literathre,'' 136.</ref>  This possibly adumbrates the misfortunes of the Kauravas in the epic tradition.<br><br>In the Rigveda the Kurus do not appear under that name as a people. But mention is made of a prince, '''Kuruśravaṇa''' (‘Glory of the Kurus’),<ref name=fx25_ve1_645> Rv. x. 33, 4.</ref> and of a '''[[पाकस्थामन् कौरयाण|Pākasthāman Kaurayāṇa]].'''<ref name=fx26_ve1_645> Rv. viii. 3, 21.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx27_ve1_645> xx. 127, 7 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[खिल|Khila]], v. 10.</ref> there occurs as a king of the Kurus '''[[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]],''' whose son, '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]],''' is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx28_ve1_645> xiii. 5, 4.</ref> as one of the great performers of the horse sacrifice.<br><br>It is a probable conjecture of Oldenberg's<ref name=fx29_ve1_645> ''Buddha,'' 403, 404.</ref> that the Kuru people, as known later, included some of the tribes referred to by other names in the Rigveda. Kuruśravaṇa, shown by his name to be connected with the Kurus, is in the Rigveda called [[त्रासदस्यव|Trāsadasyava]], ‘descendant of '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],'''’ who is well known as a king of the '''Pūrus.''' Moreover, it is likely that the [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]]'''Bharatas,''' who appear in the Rigveda as enemies of the Pūtus, later coalesced with them to form the Kuru people.<ref name=fx30_ve1_645> ''Ibid.,'' 406-409.</ref> Since the Bharatas appear so prominently in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] texts as a great people of the past, while the later literature ignores them in its list of nations, it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that they became merged in some other tribe. Moreover, there is evidence that the Bharatas occupied the territory in which the Kurus were later found. Two of them are spoken of in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx31_ve1_645> iii. 23.</ref> as having kindled fire on the '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]],''' the '''[[आपया|Āpayā]],''' and the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]'''--that is to say, in the sacred places of the later [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]]. Similarly, the goddess Bhāratī (‘belonging to the Bharatas’) is constantly mentioned in the Āprī (‘propitiatory’) hymns together with [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].<ref name=fx32_ve1_645> ''Cf.'' Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokṛyphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 145.</ref> Again, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], one [[भरत|Bharata]] king was victorious over the Kāśis,<ref name=fx33_ve1_645> xiii. 5, 4, 11.</ref> and another made offerings to [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]] and [[यमुना|Yamunā]],<ref name=fx34_ve1_645> ''Ibid.,'' 21.</ref> while raids of the Bharatas against the '''Satvants''' are mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx35_ve1_645> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 25 (''cf.'' Haug's edition, 2, 128, n. 3);<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 407, note*.</ref> Nor is it  without importance that the Bharatas appear as a variant for the Kuru Pañcālas in a passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx36_ve1_645> xi. 3, 3. See note 14;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 408, 409.</ref> and that in the list of the great performers of the horse sacrifice the names of one Kuru and two [[भरत|Bharata]] princes are given without any mention of the people over which they ruled, while in other cases that information is specifically given.<ref name=fx37_ve1_645> Oldenberg, 409, note*.</ref><br><br>The territory of the Kuru-Pañcālas is declared in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] to be the middle country ('''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]]''').<ref name=fx38_ve1_645> viii. 14. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, 392, 393.</ref> A group of the Kuru people still remained further north--the '''Uttara Kurus''' beyond the Himālaya. It appears from a passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] that the speech of the Northerners-that is, presumably, the Northern Kurus--and of the KuruPañcālas was similar, and regarded as specially pure.<ref name=fx39_ve1_645> iii. 2, 3, 15. This is the sense which it appears to bear, as the KuruPañcālas can bardly be reckoned as being northerly (Oldenberg, 395), and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 6 (''Indische Studien,'' 2, 309) in independent evidence for the puro speech of the north. ''Cf.'' Eggeeling Sacred ''Books of the East,'' 12. xiii. Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 45;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 191.</ref> There seems little doubt that the Brahminical culture was developed in the country of the Kuru-Pañcālas, and that it spread thence east, south, and west. Traces of this are seen in the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] Stomas (sacrifices for the admission of non-Brahminical Āryans) of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx40_ve1_645> xvii. 1, 1. See also Av. xv. with Whitney's and Lanman notes;<br> Weber, ''Ind the Studien,'' 1, 33 ''et seq.;<br> Indian Literature,'' 67, 78, 80.</ref> and in the fact that in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka it is unusual for a Brahmin to dwell in the territory of '''[[मगध|Magadha]].'''<ref name=fx41_ve1_645> vii. 13. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 400, note*;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 112, n. 126.</ref> The repeated mention of KuruPañcāla Brahmins is another indication of their missionary activity.<ref name=fx42_ve1_645> See ''e.g.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 4, 1, 2, and note 6.</ref><br><br>The geographical position of the Kuru-Pañcālas renders it probable that they were later immigrants into India than the '''[[कोसल|Kosala]]-[[विदेह|Videha]]''' or the '''Kāśis,'''<ref name=fx43_ve1_645> This is recognized, ''e.g.,'' by Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 9, 391, 398, 399;<br> Lanman, ''Sanskrit Keader,'' 297, etc. The narrative of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 1, 10 ''et seq.'' (Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170), rather implies that the KosalaVidehas are offshoots of the KuruPañcālas, but Oldenberg and Macdonell (''Sanskrit Literature,'' 214 interpret this as referring to the spread of Vedic tradition and culture, not of nationality.</ref> who must have been pushed  into their more eastward territories by a new wave of Āryan settlers from the west. But there is no evidence in Vedic literature to show in what relation of time the immigration of the latter peoples stood to that of their neighbours on the west. It has, however, been conjectured,<ref name=fx44_ve1_645> ''Cf.'' Grierson, ''Languages of India,'' 52 ''et seq.;<br> Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 837 ''et seq.'' On the other hand, it is probably an error to assume that the Bharatas were originally situated far west of [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], and that the main action of the Rigveda was confined to the Panjab. When [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] celebrates the crossing of the [[विपाश्|Vipāś]] and [[शुतुद्री|Śutudrī]] (Rv. iii. 33), he probably came from the east, as Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218, points out, and not from the west. Adopting the ordinary view, Hopkins, ''India, Old and New,'' 52, finds it necessary to suggest that [[यमुना|Yamunā]] is only another name in the Rv. for the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]]. But the necessity for this suggestion, which is not in itself plausible, disappears when it is realized that the Bharatas held a territory roughly corresponding to [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], and bounded on the east by the [[यमुना|Yamunā]]. On the other hand, Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 142, 143. places the Kurus near the Ārjīkīyā in Kaśmīr, which puts them too far north. So also Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 103, and Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xlii. It seems probable that the Kurus were at a very early period widely scattered to the north of the Himālaya, in [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], and about the [[सिन्धु|Sindhu]] and [[असिक्नी|Asiknī]].<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 400 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 152-157;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literature und Cultur,'' 164 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 187 ''et seq.;<br> Indian Literature,'' 114, 135, 136;<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 27;<br> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 333 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 205, n.</ref> mainly on the ground of later linguistic phenomena, which have no cogency for the Vedic period, that the Kurus were later immigrants, who, coming by a new route, thrust themselves between the original Āryan tribes which were already in occupation of the country from east to west. ''Cf.'' also '''[[कृत्वन्|Kṛtvan]].''' For other Kuru princes see '''[[कौरव्य|Kauravya]].'''

कुरु-क्षेत्र
<u>'''Kuru-kṣetra'''</u> (‘land of the Kurus’) is always regarded in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] texts<ref name=fx1_ve1_646> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 13;<br> xi. 5, 1, 4;<br> xiv. 1, 1, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 30;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 4;<br> iv. 5, 9;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 126 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, cxlvi);<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 16, 11, etc.</ref> as a particularly sacred country. Within its boundaries flowed the rivers '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]]''' and '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],''' as well as the '''[[आपया|Āpayā]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_646> ''Cf.'' Rv. iii. 23;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218.</ref> Here, too, was situated '''[[शर्यणावन्त्|Śaryaṇāvant]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_646> See Pischel, ''loc. cit.,'' and ''cf.'' '''Ārjīkīyā.'''</ref> which  appears to have been a lake, like that known to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] by the name of '''[[अन्यतः-प्लक्षा|Anyataḥ-plakṣā]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_646> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 4.</ref> According to Pischel, there was also in [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]] a stream called '''[[पस्त्या|Pastyā]],'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_646> Pischel, ''loc. cit.,'' 219.</ref> which he sees in certain passages of the Rigveda. The boundaries of [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]] are given in a passage of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx6_ve1_646> v. 1, 1. These places cannot be further identified. See also '''Mara.'''<br><br>''Cf.'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 164, 165;<br> Max Mūller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 398, 399;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78, 79;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 174. Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xli., seems to place [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], as lying between the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] and [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]], too far east.</ref> as being [[खाण्डव|Khāṇḍava]] on the south, the [[तूर्घ्न|Tūrghna]] on the north, and the [[परीणह्|Parīṇah]] on the west. Roughly speaking, it corresponded to the modern Sirhind.

कुरुङ्ग
<u>'''Kuruṅga'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_647> viii. 4, 19;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 22.</ref> as a prince and a patron. Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_647> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 160.</ref> suggests that he was a king of the '''Anus,''' but for this theory there seems no good ground. As the '''Turvaśas''' are mentioned in the same verse, he may possibly have been one of their kings. The name suggests a connexion with the '''Kurus,''' and it may be noted that in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_647> xi. 5, 4, 16. See Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 404.</ref> the Turvaśas are connected with the '''Pañcālas (Krivis).'''

कुरु
<u>'''Kuru'''</u>-[[श्रवण|śravaṇa]] '''[[त्रासदस्यव|Trāsadasyava]]''' is alluded to as dead in a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_648> x. 33, 4. ''Cf.'' Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 35, 36.</ref> which refers also to his son '''[[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]],''' and his father '''[[मित्रातिथि|Mitrātithi]].''' In another hymn<ref name=fx2_ve1_648> x. 32, 9. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165: Geldner, ''Vediscke Studien,'' 2, 150, 184;<br> Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 386.</ref> he is mentioned as still alive. His name connects him on the one hand with the '''Kurus,''' and on the other with '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]]''' and the '''Pūrus.'''

कुरूरु
<u>'''Kurūru,'''</u> apparently the name of a species of worm, is mentioned twice in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_649> ii. 31, 2;<br> ix. 2, 22. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref> 

कुर्कुर
<u>'''Kurkura'''</u> is an onomatopoetic name for the dog in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_650> vii. 95, 2. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 233.</ref> See also '''[[श्वन्|Śvan]].'''

कुल
<u>'''Kula, Kula-pā.'''</u>--As an uncompounded word, Kula does not occur before the period of the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_651> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 22;<br> ii. 1, 4, 4;<br> 4, 1, 14;<br> xi. 5, 3, 11;<br> 8, 1, 3;<br> xiii. 4, 2, 17;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 32;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii., 13, 6, etc.</ref> It denotes the ‘home’ or ‘house of the family,’ and by metonymy the family itself, as connected with the home. The Kula-pā (lit. ‘house protector’), or chief of the family, is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_651> x. 179, 2.</ref> as inferior to and attendant on the '''[[व्राजपति|Vrājapati]]''' in war, the latter being perhaps the leader of the village contingent of the clan. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_651> i. 14, 3. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 15;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Athcrvaveda,'' 252, correcting Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 314.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 162.</ref> a girl is ironically called Kulapā, because she is left without a husband in the world, and has only Yama (the god of death) for a spouse.<br><br>The use of the term Kula points clearly to a system of individual families, each no doubt consisting of several members under the headship of the father or eldest brother, whose Kula the dwelling is. As distinct from '''[[गोत्र|Gotra]],''' Kula seems to mean the family in the narrower sense of the members who still live in one house, the undivided family. ''Cf.'' '''[[गृह|Gṛha]], [[ग्राम|Grāma]], Jana, [[विश्|Viś]].'''

कुलाल
<u>'''Kulāla,'''</u> the word denoting a ‘potter,’ occurs in the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]], or litany to Rudra in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_652> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27. ''Cf. [[कुलाल|kulāla]]-[[कृत|kṛta]],'' ‘made by a potter,’ Maitrāyaṇi Saṃhitā, i. 8. 3, and '''[[कौलाल|Kaulāla]].'''</ref>

कुलिश
<u>'''Kuliśa,'''</u> ‘axe,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda as used for the making of chariots,<ref name=fx1_ve1_653> iii. 2, 1.</ref> and also in warfare,<ref name=fx2_ve1_653> i. 32. 5.</ref> while the Atharvaveda refers to its employment in cutting down trees.<ref name=fx3_ve1_653> ii. 12, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 252.</ref> 

कुलीकय
<u>'''Kulīkaya'''</u> is the form in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_654> v. 5, 13, 1.</ref> of the name of an animal, apparently a kind of fish, as explained by Mahīdhara in his commentary, which is called Kulīpaya in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_654> xxiv. 21. 35.</ref> and [[पुरीकय|Purīkaya]] in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_654> xi. 2, 25. The commentator reads [[पुलीकय|Pulīkaya]], as in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 2. See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 624.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 96.</ref> variants probably due to the faulty tradition of an unfamiliar. name.

कुलीका
<u>'''Kulīkā'''</u> is the name of a bird mentioned in the list of victims at the horse sacrifice in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_655> xxiv. 24.</ref> The Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_655> iii. 14, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94.</ref> has [[पुलीका|Pulīkā]] instead.

कुलुङ्ग
<u>'''Kuluṅga'''</u> is the name of an animal, perhaps a gazelle, mentioned in the list of victims at the horse sacrifice in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_656> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 9, 13 (with the variant Kulaṅga);<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 27. 32.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83.</ref>

कुल्मल
<u>'''Kulmala'''</u> seems, in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_657> iv. 6, 5;<br> v. 18, 15.</ref> the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_657> iii. 8, 1. 2.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_657> iii. 4, 4, 14.</ref> to denote the neck of an arrow in which the shaft is fixed.

कुमल-बर्हिस्
<u>'''Kumala-barhis'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xv. 3, 21) as the seer of a Sāman or Chant.<br>==Foot Notes==

कुमार हारित
<u>'''Kumāra Hārita'''</u> is mentioned in the first [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_659> ii. 5, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> as a pupil of '''[[गालव|Gālava]].'''

कुल्माष
<u>'''Kulmāṣa,'''</u> a word mentioned by the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_660> i. 10, 2. 7.</ref> in the plural, is interpreted by the commentator as ‘bad beans’ (''kutsitā māṣāḥ''), a version adopted by Bo7htlingk in his  Dictionary.<ref name=fx2_ve1_660> ''Cf.'' Bhāgavata [[पुराण|Purāṇa]], v. 9. 12. where it is glossed ‘worm-eaten beans.’</ref> Little<ref name=fx3_ve1_660> ''Grammatical Index,'' 52.</ref> renders it ‘sour gruel’ in accordance with the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_660> i. 4.</ref>

कुल्या
<u>'''Kulyā'''</u> in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_661> iii. 45, 3;<br> x. 43, 7.</ref> according to Muir,<ref name=fx2_ve1_661> ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 465, 466.</ref> possibly refers to artificial watercourses flowing into a reservoir (''[[ह्रद|hrada]]''). See '''[[अवत|Avata]].'''

कुवय
<u>'''Kuvaya.'''</u> See '''Kvayi.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कुवल
<u>'''Kuvala'''</u> is a name of the jujube fruit (''Zizyphus jujuba'') occurring frequently in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_663> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 22, 89;<br> xxi. 29;<br> Kāthaka Saṃhitā, xii. 10.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve1_663> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 10;<br> xii. 7, 1, 2;<br> 2, 9;<br> 9, 1, 5, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 242.</ref> in connexion with '''[[कर्कन्धु|Karkandhu]]''' and '''[[बदर|Badara]].''' See also '''Kola.'''

कुश
<u>'''Kuśa,'''</u> a word later denoting the ‘sacred grass’ (''Poa cynosuroides''), is taken by the St. Petersburg Dictionary to mean simply ‘grass’ in the passages of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in which it occurs.<br><br>^1) ii. 5, 2, 15; iii. 1, 2, 16; v. 3, 2, 7, etc. Kuśā and Kuśī occur in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 7; Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6, 2, 9; [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 10, 1. 2, 7, apparently denoting pins of wood or metal, used as a mark in a special mode of recitation.<br>==Foot Notes==

कु-सर
<u>'''Ku-sara'''</u> is mentioned with '''[[शर|Śara]]''' and other grasses in one hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_665> i. 191, 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref> as affording lurking places for serpents.

कुशिक
<u>'''Kuśika'''</u> is the probably mythical forefather<ref name=fx1_ve1_666> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 25.</ref> of the Kuśikas, and especially the father of the most important member of that family, '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_666> Rv. iii. 33, 5.</ref> The Kuśikas are repeatedly referred  to in the third Maṇḍala of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_666> iii. 26, 1;<br> 29, 15;<br> 30, 20;<br> 33, 5;<br> 42, 9;<br> 50, 4;<br> 53, 9. 10.</ref> and figure in the legend of [[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]] in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_666> vii. 18;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 27.</ref> They were clearly a family of priests who attached themselves to the service of the princes of the '''Bharatas.''' They were especially devoted to the worship of Indra; hence he is styled [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] even in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx5_ve1_666> i. 10, 11, with Sāyaṇa's note. ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 12, 4;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 62, 63. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' i, 38;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 342 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 101, 121;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 155;<br> Oldenberg. ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 209.</ref>

कुश्रि वाज-श्रवस
<u>'''Kuśri [[वाज|Vāja]]-śravasa'''</u> appears as a teacher concerned with the lore of the sacred fire in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_667> x. 5, 5. 1.</ref> and in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_667> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 3, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> he is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[वाजश्रवस्|Vājaśravas]].''' It is not clear whether he is identical with the Kuśri of the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka<ref name=fx3_ve1_667> vi. 5, 4 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] only).</ref> in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension, and of the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] in the tenth book of the Śatapatha,<ref name=fx4_ve1_667> x. 6, 5, 9. In the Vaṃśas the name is accented Kúśri, but in x. 5, 5, 1, as Kuśrī;<br> no stress can, however, be laid on this. ''Cf.''
