Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 70;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xxxiii.</ref> who is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[यज्ञवचस् राजस्तम्बायन|Yajñavacas Rājastambāyana]].'''

कु-षण्ड
<u>'''Ku-ṣaṇḍa'''</u> is mentioned with '''[[षण्ड|Ṣaṇḍa]]''' as a priest at the snake festival described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_668> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 34;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śranta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 20, 10.</ref>

कुषीतक
<u>'''1. Kuṣītaka'''</u> denotes, according to the commentary on the one passage of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_669> v. 5, 13. 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref> in which it is found, the sea crow (''[[सम्उद्र|samudra]]-kāka'')

कुषीतक साम-श्रवस
<u>'''2. Kuṣītaka Sāma-śravasa'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_670> xvii. 4. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 34.</ref> as the Gṛhapati, or householder at a sacrificial session, of the Kauṣītakis. 

कुषुम्भक
<u>'''Kuṣumbhaka'''</u> seems in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_671> i. 191, 16. The sense of ‘poisonbag’ is possible in i. 191, 15, and is accepted there by Bo7htlingk in his Dictionary.</ref> to mean a poisonous insect, Kuṣumbha in th Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_671> ii. 32, 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 257.</ref> clearly having the sense of a poison bag. Sāyaṇa renders it as ‘ichneumon’ (''[[नकुल|nakula]]'').

कुष्ठ
<u>'''1. Kuṣṭha'''</u> is the name of a plant (''Costus speciosus'' or ''arabicus'')<ref name=fx1_ve1_672> Or ''Saussurea auriculata,'' Hillebreandt. ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 65.</ref> which is prominent in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_672> v. 4;<br> vi. 102;<br> xix. 139.</ref> It grew especially on the mountains, along with the Soma, on the high peaks of the Himālaya (''[[हिमवन्त्|Himavant]]'') where the eagles nest, and was thence brought east to men.<ref name=fx3_ve1_672> v. 4, 1. 2. 8;<br> xix. 39, 1.</ref> Like Soma, it is said to have grown in the third heaven under the famous '''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]]''' tree, where the gods were wont to assemble, and thence it was brought in a golden ship.<ref name=fx4_ve1_672> v. 4, 3-6;<br> vi. 75, 1. 2;<br> xix. 39, 6-8.</ref> As a remedy, it held the highest place among herbs, being called by the auspicious names [[नघ-मार|Nagha-māra]] and Naghā-riṣa, and styled the offspring of Jīvala and Jīvalā, the ‘lively’ ones.<ref name=fx5_ve1_672> v. 4, 1;<br> xix. 39, 4.</ref> It cured headache (''[[शीर्षामय|śīrṣāmaya]]''), diseases of the eyes, bodily affliction,<ref name=fx6_ve1_672> v. 4, 10.</ref> but especially fever--hence called ‘feverdestroyer’ (''takma-nāśana'')--and consumption ('''[[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]]'''). From its general properties it was also named ‘all-healing’ (''viśvabheṣaja'').<ref name=fx7_ve1_672> xix. 39, 9.</ref> Its aromatic qualities were apparently known, as it is classed with ‘salve’ ('''[[आञ्जन|Āñjana]]''') and ‘nard’ ('''[[नलद|Nalada]]''').<ref name=fx8_ve1_672> vi. 102, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Grohmann, ''Indische, Studien,'' 9, 420 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 63, 64;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 415, 680;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 227, 228.</ref>

कुष्ठ
<u>'''2. Kuṣṭha.'''</u>--In one passage of the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_673> iii. 7, 7. ''Cf.'' Bōhtlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> there is a series of fractions, '''[[कला|Kalā]], [[कुष्ठ|Kuṣṭha]], [[शफ|Śapha]], Pad,''' which appear to denote one-sixteenth, one-twelfth, one-eighth, and one-fourth respectively. 

कुसीदिन्
<u>'''Kusīdin'''</u> is a designation of the ‘usurer’ found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_674> xiii. 4, 3, 11.</ref> and the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_674> vi. 32.</ref> and often in the Sūtras. Jolly,<ref name=fx3_ve1_674> ''Recht und Sitle,'' 98, 99.</ref> referring doubtless to the expression ''kusīda apratītta,''<ref name=fx4_ve1_674> iii. 3, 8, 1. 2.</ref> ‘a loan not yet repaid,’ occurring in connexion with ''an-[[ऋण|ṛṇa]],'' ‘free from debt,’ appears to be right in taking Kusīda to have the sense of ‘loan’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā. The rate of interest on loans is not specified before the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period.<ref name=fx5_ve1_674> ''E.g.,'' [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 29 ''et seq. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 259.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[ऋण|Ṛṇa]].'''

कुसुरुबिन्द औद्दलकि
<u>'''Kusurubinda Auddalaki'''</u> appears as an authority on ritual matters in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_675> xxii. 15, 1. 10.</ref> the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_675> vii. 2, 2, 1.</ref> the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_675> i. 75 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 23, 327), where the reading seems to be Asurbinda.</ref> and the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_675> i. 16. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 39. The name is there read as Kusurubindu;<br> in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 22, 14 it is Kusurabindu.</ref> He may have been the brother of '''[[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]],''' as suggested by Weber.<ref name=fx5_ve1_675> ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 61, n.</ref>

कुहू
<u>'''Kuhū.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कूचक्र
<u>'''Kūcakra'''</u> is a word occurring only once in an obscure verse of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_677> x. 102, 11.</ref> where Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_677> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 157. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 14.</ref> suggests that it has the sense of the wheel by which water is raised from a well. Much more probable is the interpretation of Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_677> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> who understands it to mean the female breast.

कूट
<u>'''Kūṭa,'''</u> a word found in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_678> x. 102, 4.</ref> the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_678> viii. 8, 16.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx3_ve1_678> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 24;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 1, 15;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 49, 9;<br> 50, 2 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 114).</ref> is of doubtful signification. On the whole,  the most probable sense is hammer,<ref name=fx4_ve1_678> So Bloomfield, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 546;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 585.</ref> which suits every passage adequately. The St. Petersburg Dictionary renders it ‘horn,’ which is the sense accepted by Whitney<ref name=fx5_ve1_678> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 505.</ref> for the Atharvaveda passage where it occurs. Geldner<ref name=fx6_ve1_678> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 138;<br> 2, 7. ''Cf.'' von Bradke, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 46, 458;<br> Kuhn's ''Zeitschrift,'' 34, 156;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 222.</ref> thinks that it means ‘trap.’

कूदी
<u>'''Kūdī,'''</u> written also Kūṭī in the manuscripts, occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_679> v. 19, 12.</ref> and the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_679> Bloomfield's edition, xliv. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 355;<br> 12, 416;<br> Roth, ''Festgrnss an Bo7htlingk,'' 98;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 254;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 165.</ref> denoting a twig--identified by the scholiast with '''Badarī,''' the jujube--which was tied to the bodies of the dead to efface their traces, presumably in order to render the return of the spirit to the old home difficult.

कूप
<u>'''Kūpa'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_680> i. 105, 17.</ref> and later literature<ref name=fx2_ve1_680> Av. v. 31, 8;<br> Satapatha Brahmaṇa, iii. 5, 4, 1;<br> iv. 4, 5, 3;<br> vi. 3, 3. 26, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 184. etc. The adjective ''kūpya,'' ‘being in a hole,’ occurs frequently in the later Saṃhitās.</ref> denoting an artificial hollow in the earth, or pit. In some cases they must have been deep, as [[त्रित|Trita]] in the myth is said to have fallen into one from which he could not escape unaided.<ref name=fx3_ve1_680> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 67.</ref>

कूबर
<u>'''Kūbara'''</u> in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (ii. 1, 11) and '''Kūbarī''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iv. 6, 9, 11. 12) and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxvii. 6) denote the pole of a cart.<br>==Foot Notes==

कूर्च
<u>'''Kūrca'''</u> is found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_682> vii. 5, 8, 5.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_682> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 3, 4. 7;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 11, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v, 1, 4.</ref> denoting a bundle of grass used as a seat. In one passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_682> xiii. 4, 3, 1.</ref> a golden [[कूर्च|Kūrca]] is referred to. 

कूर्म
<u>'''Kūrma,'''</u> the ‘tortoise,’ is mentioned frequently in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_683> Av. ix. 4, 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 3, 3;<br> v. 2, 8, 4. 5;<br> 7, 13, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 15, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 34, etc.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve1_683> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 2, 3;<br> vi. 1, 1, 12, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 153.</ref> but nothing is said of its characteristics. See also '''[[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]].'''

कूशाम्ब स्वायव लातव्य
<u>'''Kūśāmba [[स्वायव|Svāyava]] Lātavya'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_684> viii. 6, 8.</ref> as a priest. His name apparently means<ref name=fx2_ve1_684> The form is peculiar, as Kuśāmba would be expected.</ref> Kūśāmba,<ref name=fx3_ve1_684> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 55, n. 2.</ref> of the [[लातव्य|Lātavya]] clan, son of Svāyu.

कृकलास
<u>'''Kṛkalāsa'''</u> denotes the ‘chameleon’ mentioned in the list of sacrificial victims at the horse sacrifice in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_685> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 19, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 21;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 40.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_685> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 22.</ref> The female chameleon, Kṛkalāsī, is also referred to in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_685> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 221 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 29), Sāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. viii. 91.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref> See '''[[गोधा|Godhā]]''' and '''[[शयण्डक|Śayaṇḍaka]].'''

कृक-वाकु
<u>'''Kṛka-vāku,'''</u> the ‘cock,’ being named in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_686> v. 31, 2. ''Cf.'' x. 136, 10.</ref> with sheep, goats, and other domesticated animals, was presumably tamed.<ref name=fx2_ve1_686> ''Cf.,'' however, Sāyaṇa on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 18, 1, who says that it is a ‘forest’ [[कुक्कुट|Kukkuṭa]].</ref> In the list of victims at the horse sacrifice in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_686> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 15;<br> Vājasaneyi;<br> Saṃhitā, xxiv. 35.</ref> it appears as dedicated to Savitṛ: [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_686> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xii. 3.</ref> explains this by the fact that it declares the time of day (''kālānuvāda''). The commentator Mahīdhara<ref name=fx5_ve1_686> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> explains the name by ''tāmra-cūḍa,'' ‘red-crested.’ It is of course onomatopoetic (‘calling kṛka’).<ref name=fx6_ve1_686> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 251;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18. 285.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 91.</ref> See also '''[[कुक्कुट|Kukkuṭa]].''' 

कृत
<u>'''Kṛta.'''</u> See 2. '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]''' and 2. '''Yuga.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कृति
<u>'''Kṛti.'''</u>--From one passage in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_688> i. 168, 3.</ref> where the Maruts are described as having Kṛtis, Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_688> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 301. ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 221.</ref> concludes that the word means a dagger used in war. But there is no evidence that [[कृति|Kṛti]] was ever a human weapon. See '''Asi.'''

कृत्तिकास्
<u>'''Kṛttikās.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कृत्वन्
<u>'''Kṛtvan.'''</u>--In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_690> ix. 65, 23.</ref> the word [[कृत्वन्|Kṛtvan]] in the plural is mentioned with the '''Ārjīkas''' and the five peoples. Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve1_690> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 209.</ref> thinks that it means a people, and Sāyaṇa expressly says that the Kṛtvans designate a country.<ref name=fx3_ve1_690> ''Kṛtvāna iti deśābhidhānam.''</ref> The name in that case would point to some connexion with the '''Kurus''' or '''Krivis.''' Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx4_ve1_690> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 136, 137</ref> however, thinks that the word is an adjective which qualifies Ārjīkas and designates this people as magicians, being applied to them by an opponent. In favour of this view, he quotes Hiouen Thsang's statement<ref name=fx5_ve1_690> Cunningham, ''Aneient Gevgraphy of India,'' 93.<br><br>''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> that the neighbouring kings held the base Kaśmīrians in such scorn as to refuse all alliance with them, and to give them the name of Ki-li-to, or Kṛtyas. He suggests that the Ārjīkas settled in Kasmīr in ancient times already had the same evil reputation as their successors in later days.

कृप
<u>'''Kṛpa'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_691> viii. 3, 12;<br> 4, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> along with [[रुशम|Ruśama]] and '''[[श्यावक|Śyāvaka]],''' as a protégé of Indra.

कृमि
<u>'''Kṛmi,'''</u> ‘worm.’ In the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_692> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30;<br> [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 36;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 1, 2;<br> and ''of.'' Rv. i. 191.</ref> and especially in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_692> ii. 31. 32;<br> v. 23.</ref> worms play a considerable part. They are  regarded as poisonous, and are spoken of as found in the mountains, in forests, in waters, in plants, and in the human body. In accordance with widespread primitive ideas, they are considered to be the causes of disease in men and animals. The Atharvaveda contains three hymns<ref name=fx2_ve1_692/> as charms directed against them. The first of these hymns is of a general character, the second is meant to destroy worms in cattle, and the third is intended to cure children of worms. When found in men, worms are said to have their place in the head and ribs,<ref name=fx3_ve1_692> Av. ii. 31, 4.</ref> and to creep into the eyes, nose, and teeth.<ref name=fx4_ve1_692> Av. v. 23, 3.</ref> They are described as dark brown, but white in the fore part of the body, with black ears, and as having three heads.<ref name=fx5_ve1_692> Av. v. 23, 4 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98, 393;<br> Kuhn, ''Zeitschrift für vergleichende Sprachforschung,'' 13, 49 ''et seq.;<br>'' 113 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 313 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 199;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 73.</ref> They are given many specific names: '''[[अलाण्डु|Alāṇḍu]], [[एजत्क|Ejatka]], [[कष्कष|Kaṣkaṣa]], [[कीट|Kīṭa]], [[कुरूरु|Kurūru]], [[नीलङ्गु|Nīlaṅgu]], [[येवाष|Yevāṣa]], [[वघा|Vaghā]], [[वृक्षसर्पी|Vṛkṣasarpī]], [[शलुन|Śaluna]], [[शवर्त|Śavarta]], [[शिपवित्नुक|Śipavitnuka]], [[स्तेग|Stega]].'''

कृमुक
<u>'''Kṛmuka'''</u> is the name in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_693> xix. 10.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_693> vi. 6, 2, 11.</ref> of a species of wood used for fuel.<ref name=fx3_ve1_693> ''Ibid.'' (''Krāmuha'' as applied to ''[[सम्इध्|samidh]]'').</ref>

कृश
<u>'''Kṛśa'''</u> is mentioned with '''[[संवर्त|Saṃvarta]]''' as a pious sacrificer to Indra in one of the [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymns of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_694> viii. 54, 2.</ref> and in another<ref name=fx2_ve1_694> viii. 59, 3.</ref> as a speaker of truth, while a third is traditionally<ref name=fx3_ve1_694> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 293, n.</ref> ascribed to his authorship. He seems also to be mentioned with '''[[शयु|Śayu]]''' as a protégé of the Aśvins in another hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_694> x. 40, 8.</ref> but here the word may merely denote the ‘feeble man.’<ref name=fx5_ve1_694> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 132, 164.</ref> 

कृशन
<u>'''Kṛśana,'''</u> ‘pearl.’ In the Rigveda pearls are mentioned as adorning the car of Savitṛ<ref name=fx1_ve1_695> i. 35, 4.</ref> as well as being used for the adornment of a horse.<ref name=fx2_ve1_695> x. 68, 1.</ref> Hence the horse is spoken of as the ‘pearled one’ (''kṛśanāvant'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_695> i. 126, 4. ''Cf. kṛśanin,'' vii. 18, 23.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_695> x. 1, 7.</ref> also refers to pearls, and mentions that ‘pearl shell’ (''śañkhaḥ kṛśanaḥ'') won from the sea was used as an amulet.<ref name=fx5_ve1_695> iv. 10, 1. 3.</ref> The Nighaṇṭu<ref name=fx6_ve1_695> i. 2. ''Cf.'' Sāma [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 1, 6, 22.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'', 53, 54;<br> Lanman in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 161.</ref> renders the word as ‘gold.’

कृशानु
<u>'''Kṛśānu'''</u> appears in the Rigveda as a mythological personage.<ref name=fx1_ve1_696> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 74, 112, 137;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 448.</ref> In one verse,<ref name=fx2_ve1_696> i. 112, 21.</ref> however, Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_696> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' 4.</ref> sees in this word the name of a bowman, but there seems no reason to dissociate this passage from the rest.

कृषि
<u>'''Kṛṣi,'''</u> ‘ploughing.’ The cultivation of the soil was no doubt known to the Indians before they separated from the Iranians, as is indicated by the identity of the expressions ''yavaṃ kṛṣ'' and ''[[सस्य|sasya]]'' in the Rigveda with ''yao karesh'' and ''hahya'' in the Avesta, referring to the ploughing in of the seed and to the grain which resulted.<ref name=fx1_ve1_697> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 235;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 85.</ref> But it is not without significance that the expressions for ploughing occur mainly in the first<ref name=fx2_ve1_697> Forms of the root ''kṛṣ,'' ‘to plough,’ occur in Rv. i. 23, 15;<br> 176, 2.</ref> and tenth<ref name=fx3_ve1_697> Rv. x. 34, 13;<br> 117, 7. In x. 146, 6, ''akṛṣīvala,'' ‘not agricultural,’ occurs. ''Cf.'' x. 101, 4.</ref> books of the Rigveda, and only rarely in the so-called ‘family’ books (ii.-vii.).<ref name=fx4_ve1_697> ''Kṛṣ'' is also found in viii. 20, 19;<br> 22, 6;<br> in the family books only in iv. 57, 4, and as ''vi-kṛṣ'' in iv. 57, 8.</ref> In the Atharvaveda '''Pṛthī [[वैन्य|Vainya]]''' is credited with the origination of ploughing,<ref name=fx5_ve1_697> viii. 10, 24.</ref> and even in the Rigveda the Aśvins are spoken of as concerned with the sowing of grain by means of the plough.<ref name=fx6_ve1_697> i. 117, 21.</ref> In the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas ploughing is repeatedly referred to.<ref name=fx7_ve1_697> ''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]]'' is found, ''e.g.,'' in Av. ii. 4, 5;<br> viii. 2, 19;<br> 10, 24;<br> x. 6, 12;<br> xii. 2, 27, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 11;<br> 1, etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 2, 2;<br> iii. 6, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 10;<br> ix. 27;<br> xiv. 19. 21, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 2, 2, 7;<br> viii. 6, 2, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 2, 5, etc. In Av. vi. 116, 1, ''kārṣīvaṇa'' denotes a ‘plougher.’ See also [[कार्ष्मन्|Kārṣman]].</ref> <br><br>Even in the Rigveda<ref name=fx8_ve1_697> x. 34, 13;<br> 117, 7. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''India, Old and New,'' 208.</ref> there is clear proof of the importance attached to agriculture. In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve1_697> xvii. 1.</ref> the '''Vrātyas,''' Hindus without the pale of Brahminism, are described as not cultivating the soil.<br><br>The plough land was called '''[[उर्वरा|Urvarā]]''' or '''[[क्षेत्र|Kṣetra]];''' manure ('''[[शकन्|Śakan]], [[करीष|Karīṣa]]''') was used, and irrigation was practised ('''[[खनित्र|Khanitra]]'''). The plough ('''[[लाङ्गल|Lāṅgala]], [[सीर|Sīra]]''') was drawn by oxen, teams of six, eight, or even twelve being employed.<ref name=fx10_ve1_697> Av. vi. 91, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2. ''Cf.'' Rv. viii. 6, 48;<br> x. 101, 4.</ref> The operations of agriculture are neatly summed up in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx11_ve1_697> i. 6, 1, 3.</ref> as ‘ploughing, sowing, reaping, and threshing’ (''kṛṣantaḥ, vapantaḥ, lunantaḥ, mṛṇantaḥ''). The ripe grain was cut with a sickle ('''[[दात्र|Dātra]], Sṛṇi'''), bound into bundles<ref name=fx12_ve1_697> viii. 78, 10;<br> x. 101, 3;<br> 131, 2.</ref> ('''[[पर्ष|Parṣa]]'''), and beaten out on the floor of the granary ('''[[खल|Khala]]''').<ref name=fx13_ve1_697> Rv. x. 48, 7.</ref> The grain was then separated from the straw and refuse either by a sieve ('''Titau''') or a winnowing fan ('''[[शूर्प|Śūrpa]]''').<ref name=fx14_ve1_697> Rv. x. 71, 2;<br> Av. xii. 3, 19. The technical terms are ''tuṣair vi-vic,'' Av. xi. 1, 12;<br> ''palāvān apa-vic,'' xii. 3, 19.</ref> The winnower was called '''Dhānyākṛt,'''<ref name=fx15_ve1_697> Rv. x. 94, 13.</ref> and the grain was measured in a vessel called '''Urdara.'''<ref name=fx16_ve1_697> Rv. ii. 14, 11. See also '''[[स्थिवि|Sthivi]].'''</ref><br><br>The Rigveda leaves us in doubt as to the kind of grain grown, for '''Yava''' is a word of doubtful signification, and '''[[धाना|Dhānā]]''' is also vague. In the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx17_ve1_697> See Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 12, for a list.</ref> things are different. Rice ('''[[व्रीहि|Vrīhi]]''') appears, Yava means barley, with a species styled '''[[उपवाक|Upavāka]].''' Beans ('''[[मुद्ग|Mudga]], [[माष|Māṣa]]'''), sesamum ('''Tila'''), and other grains ('''[[अणु|Aṇu]], [[खल्व|Khalva]], [[गोधूम|Godhūma]], [[नीवार|Nīvāra]], [[प्रियङ्गु|Priyaṅgu]], [[मसूर|Masūra]], [[श्यामाक|Śyāmāka]]''') are mentioned, while cucumbers ('''[[उर्वारू|Urvārū]], Uryārūka''') were known. It is uncertain whether fruit trees ('''[[वृक्ष|Vṛkṣa]]''') were cultivated, or merely grew wild;<ref name=fx18_ve1_697> The pulling of ripe fruit is referred to in Rv. iii. 45, 4. ''Cf. pakvā [[शाखा|śākhā]],'' Rv. i. 8, 8;<br> ''[[वृक्ष|vṛkṣa]] [[पक्व|pakva]],'' Rv. iv. 20, 5;<br> Av. xx. 127, 4. But that does not prove arboriculture.</ref> but frequent mention is made of the jujube ('''[[कर्कन्धु|Karkandhu]], [[कुवल|Kuvala]], [[बदर|Badara]].''').<br><br>The seasons for agriculture are briefly summed up in a passage of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā:<ref name=fx19_ve1_697> vii. 2, 10, 2.</ref> barley ripened in summer, being no doubt sown, as in modern India, in winter; rice  ripened in autumn, being sown in the beginning of the rains; beans and sesamum, planted at the time of the summer rains, ripened in the winter and the cool season. There were two harvests ('''[[सस्य|Sasya]]''') a year according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā;<ref name=fx20_ve1_697> v. 1, 7, 3.</ref> the winter crop was ripe by the month of [[चैत्र|Caitra]] (March-April) according to the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx21_ve1_697> xix. 3. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 81, n. 1.</ref><br><br>The farmer had plenty of trouble of his own: moles destroyed the seed, birds and various kinds of reptiles ('''[[उपक्वस|Upakvasa]], [[जभ्य|Jabhya]], [[तर्द|Tarda]], [[पतङ्ग|Pataṅga]]''') injured the young shoots, excessive rain or drought might damage the crops. The Atharvaveda contains spells to prevent these evils.<ref name=fx22_ve1_697> See Av. vi. 50. 142;<br> vii. 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 235243.</ref>

कृष्टि
<u>'''Kṛṣṭi'''</u> denotes ‘people’ in general from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_698> i. 52, 11;<br> 100, 10;<br> 160, 5;<br> 189, 3;<br> iii. 49, 1;<br> iv. 21, 2, etc.;<br> Av. xii. 1, 3. 4.</ref> onwards. Its common and regular use in this sense appears to show that the Āryans, when they invaded India, were already agriculturists, though the employment of the words referring to ploughing mentioned under '''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]]''' indicates that not all of the people devoted themselves equally to that occupation. Indra and Agni are ''par excellence'' the lords of men ([[कृष्टि|Kṛṣṭi]]).<ref name=fx2_ve1_698> i. 177, 1;<br> iv. 17, 5;<br> vii. 26, 5;<br> viii. 13, 9 (Indra);<br> i. 59, 5;<br> vi. 18, 2;<br> vii. 5, 5 (Agni).</ref> Sometimes the word is further defined by the addition of an adjective meaning ‘belonging to mankind,’ ‘of men’ (''mānuṣīḥ,''<ref name=fx3_ve1_698> Rv. i. 59, 5;<br> vi. 18, 2.</ref> ''mānavīḥ'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_698> Av. iii. 24, 3.</ref><br><br>Special mention is frequently<ref name=fx5_ve1_698> Rv. ii. 2, 10;<br> iii. 53, 16;<br> iv. 38, 10;<br> x. 60, 4;<br> 119, 6;<br> 178, 3;<br> Av. iii. 24, 2;<br> xii. 1, 42.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 141.</ref> made of the ‘five peoples’ (''pañca kṛṣṭayaḥ''). The exact sense of this expression is doubtful. See '''Panca Janāsaḥ.'''

कृष्ण
<u>'''1. Kṛṣṇa'''</u> (‘black’) denotes a dark-coloured animal or bird. In some passages,<ref name=fx1_ve1_699> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 6, 5;<br> vi. 1, 3, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 1;<br> iii. 2, 1, 28. So ''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]-[[विषाणा|viṣāṇā]],'' ‘horn of the black antelope,’ ''ibid.,'' iii. 2, 1, 18, 28;<br> 2, 20;<br> iv. 4, 5, 2;<br> v. 4, 2, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 3, 7. See also the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] passages, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 36 (''cf.'' ii. 1).</ref> as the context shows, an antelope is certainly  meant. In a few others<ref name=fx2_ve1_699> Rv. x. 94, 5;<br> Av. xi. 2, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 27.</ref> a bird of prey seems indicated. See also '''[[कृष्णाजिन|Kṛṣṇājina]].'''

कृष्ण
<u>'''2. Kṛṣṇa'''</u> appears as the name of a seer in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_700> viii. 85, 3. 4.</ref> Tradition assigns to him or to [[विश्वक|Viśvaka]], son of [[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]] (''Kārṣṇi''), the authorship of the following hymn.<ref name=fx2_ve1_700> viii. 86.</ref> The word Kṛṣṇiya may be a patronymic<ref name=fx3_ve1_700> i. 116, 23;<br> 117, 7.</ref> formed from the same name in two other hymns of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_700> As a patronymic, it would be an isolated formation (''cf.'' however ''[[पज्रिय|Pajriya]]''), instead of ''Kārṣṇya. Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 228''a'' and 200.</ref> where the Aśvins are said to have restored '''Viṣṇāpū''' to [[विश्वक|Viśvaka]] Kṛṣṇya. In that case [[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]] would seem to be the grandfather of Viṣṇāpū. This [[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]] may be identical with [[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]] [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]] mentioned in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_700> xxx. 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 108;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedia Mythology,'' p. 52.</ref>

कृष्ण देवकी-पुत्र
<u>'''3. Kṛṣṇa Devakī-putra'''</u> is mentioned in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_701> iii. 17, 6.</ref> as a pupil of the mythical '''[[घोर आङ्गिरस|Ghora Āṅgirasa]].''' Tradition,<ref name=fx2_ve1_701> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 169.</ref> and several modern writers like Grierson, Garbe, and von Schroeder, recognize in him the hero [[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]], who later is deified. In their view he is a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] teacher of morals, as opposed to Brahminism.<ref name=fx3_ve1_701> Von Schroeder, ''Vienna Oriental Journal,'' 19, 414, 415;<br> Grierson, ''Encyclopadia of Religions,'' article ‘Bhakti’;<br> Garbe, ''Bhagavadgītā.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 71;<br> 148;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1905, 386.</ref> This is extremely doubtful. It appears better either to regard the coincidence of name as accidental, or to suppose that the reference is a piece of Euhemerism. To identify this [[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]] with the preceding, as does the St. Petersburg Dictionary, seems to be quite groundless.

कृष्ण हारीत
<u>'''4. Kṛṣṇa Hārīta'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve1_702> iii. 2. 6.</ref> The [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve1_702> viii. 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 391, n.;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 50.</ref> has Kṛtsna in the parallel passage. 

कृष्ण-दत्त लौहितय
<u>'''Kṛṣṇa-datta Lauhitaya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1) as a pupil of '''[[श्यामसुजयन्त लौहित्य|Śyāmasujayanta Lauhitya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कृष्ण-धृति सात्यकि
<u>'''Kṛṣṇa-dhṛti Sātyaki'''</u> (‘descendant of Satyaka’) is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1) as a pupil of '''[[सत्यश्रवस्|Satyaśravas]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कृष्ण-रात लौहित्य
<u>'''Kṛṣṇa-rāta Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1) as a pupil of '''Śyāmaiajayanta [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कृष्णल
<u>'''Kṛṣṇala'''</u> denotes the berry of the ''Abrus precatorius,'' used as a weight according to the later authorities, one [[माष|Māṣa]] (‘bean’) being equated to four Kṛṣṇalas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_706> Manu, viii. 134.</ref> In the sense of a weight it occurs in the Taittirīva<ref name=fx2_ve1_706> ii. 3, 2, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> and other Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx3_ve1_706> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 4 (''[[हिरण्य|hiraṇya]] [[कृष्णल|kṛṣṇala]]'').</ref> and later.<ref name=fx4_ve1_706> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6, 7;<br> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 6. In the later language it is also called ''raktikā'' or ''guñjā'' (being a smooth red berry with a black spot at one end).<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber's edition of the [[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]], 82 ''et seq.;<br> Indische Strcifen,'' 1, 102, 103.</ref>

कृष्णाजिन
<u>'''Kṛṣṇājina'''</u> is the skin (''[[अजिन|ajina]]'') of the black antelope ('''[[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]].''') It is repeatedly referred to in the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_707> Av. ix. 6, 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 9, 2;<br> v. 4, 4, 4: Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 22;<br> 4, 1;<br> 9, 2, 35, etc.</ref> with regard to its ritual use.

कृष्णायस
<u>'''Kṛṣṇāyasa'''</u> (‘black metal’), ‘iron,’ is referred to in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 1, 6). See also '''Ayas''' and '''[[कार्ष्णायस|Kārṣṇāyasa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कृसर
<u>'''Kṛsara,'''</u> a term denoting a mess of rice and sesamum, often mentioned in the Sūtras, occurs in the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_709> v. 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Omina und Portenta,'' 315 ''et seq.''</ref>

केकय
<u>'''Kekaya'''</u> is the name of a tribe which in later days, and probably also in Vedic times, was settled in the north-west,  oetween the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus) and '''[[वितस्ता|Vitastā]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_710> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 317, 332.</ref> In the Vedic texts the Kekayas are mentioned indirectly only in the name of their prince '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]] [[कैकेय|Kaikeya]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_710> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 1, 2. ''et seq.;<br>'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Litenature,'' 120;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 126.</ref>

केतु
<u>'''1. Ketu'''</u> is a term which Weber<ref name=fx1_ve1_711> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 41. The ''aruṇāḥ ketavaḥ'' (Av. xi. 10, 1. 2. 7), referred to in this sense in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, are not so treated by Bo7htlingk in his Dictionary.</ref> understands in the sense of ‘meteor’ or ‘comet’ in the late Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].

केतु वाज्य
<u>'''2. Ketu Vājya'''</u> (‘descendant of Vāja’) is mentioned as a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_712> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

केवर्त
<u>'''Kevarta, Kaivarta'''</u> are two variant forms denoting ‘fisherman’ in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_713> xxx. 16, with Mahīdhara's note.</ref> and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_713> iii. 4, 12, 1, with Sāyaṇa's note.</ref> lists of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human sacrifice.

केश
<u>'''Keśa,'''</u> ‘hair of the head,’ is repeatedly mentioned in the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_714> Av. v. 19, 3;<br> vi. 136, 3, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 22;<br> xx. 5;<br> xxv. 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 2, 48, etc.</ref> The hair was a matter of great care to the Vedic Indian, and several hymns of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_714> vi. 136. 137. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 68;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 536, 537.</ref> are directed to securing its plentiful growth. Cutting or shaving (''vap'') the hair is often referred to.<ref name=fx3_ve1_714> Av. viii. 2, 17;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 3, 1, etc. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 425 ''et seq.''</ref> For a man to wear long hair was considered effeminate.<ref name=fx4_ve1_714> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 2, 14. But ''cf.'' Vincent Smith, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 34, 203.</ref> As to modes of dressing the hair see '''[[ओपश|Opaśa]]''' and '''[[कपर्द|Kaparda]];''' as to the beard see '''[[श्मश्रु|Śmaśru]].'''

केशिन्
<u>'''1. Keśin'''</u> is the name of a people occurring in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_715> xi. 8, 4, 6. ''Cf.'' Pānini, vi. 4, 165;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 131, 134.</ref> where their king is mentioned as learning from '''Khaṇḍika''' the atonement for a bad omen at the sacrifice. 

केशिन् दार्भ्य
<u>'''2. Keśin Dārbhya'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_716> This is the form of the name in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]];<br> also later in the Bṛhaddevatā.</ref> or '''[[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_716> This is the form in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]. It also appears later in the Rigveda Anukramaṇī.</ref> (‘descendant of Darbha’) is a somewhat enigmatic figure. According to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_716> xi. 8, 4, 1 ''et seq.,'' as explained by Sāyaṇa.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] Brāhmana<ref name=fx4_ve1_716> iii. 29, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> he was a king, sister's son of '''Uccaiḥśravas,''' according to the latter authority. His people were the '''Pañcālas,''' of whom the Keśins must therefore have been a branch, and who are said to have been threefold (''tryanīka'').<ref name=fx5_ve1_716> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxx. 2 (Weber ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 471);<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.;<br>'' [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xx. 25.</ref> A story is told of his having a ritual dispute with '''[[षण्डिक|Ṣaṇḍika]]''' in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx6_ve1_716> i. 4, 12 (von Schroeder gives no variant reading;<br> but ''ṣ'' and ''kh'' are constantly confused in manuscripts).</ref> this appears in another form in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_716/> He was a contemporary of a fellow sage, '''[[केशिन् सात्यकामि|Keśin Sātyakāmi]],''' according to the Maitrāyaṇī<ref name=fx7_ve1_716> i. 6, 5.</ref> and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_716> ii. 6, 2, 3.</ref> Saṃhitās. The [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve1_716> xiii. 10, 8.</ref> attributes to him a Sāman or chant, and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx10_ve1_716> vii. 4.</ref> tells how he was taught by a golden bird.<br><br>In view of the fact that the early literature always refers to [[दार्भ्य|Dārbhya]] as a sage, it seems doubtful whether the commentator is right in thinking that the Śatapatha refers to a king and a people, when a sage alone may well be meant, while the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is of no great authority. The latter work may have assumed that the reference in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx11_ve1_716> xxx. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 193, 209;<br> 2, 308;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 58, 59;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 62, n. 2.</ref> to the [[केशिन्|Keśin]] people signifies kingship, but this is hardly necessary.

केशिन् सात्य-कामि
<u>'''3. Keśin Sātya-kāmi'''</u> (‘descendant of Satyakāma’) is mentioned as a teacher and contemporary of '''[[केशिन् दार्भ्य|Keśin Dārbhya]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] (ii. 6, 2, 3) and Maitrāyaṇī (i. 6, 5) Saṃhitās. <br>==Foot Notes==

केसर-प्राबन्धा
<u>'''Kesara-prābandhā.'''</u>--In the list of the crimes of the '''Vaitahavyas''' narrated in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_718> v. 18, 11.</ref> is the cooking of the last she-goat (''caramājām'') of [[केसरप्राबन्धा|Kesaraprābandhā]], who may presumably be deemed to have been a woman, ‘having braided hair.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_718> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 432, 433.</ref> Ludwig,<ref name=fx3_ve1_718> Translation of the Rigveda, 2, 447.</ref> followed by Whitney,<ref name=fx4_ve1_718> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 252.</ref> appears to amend the passage (''carama-jām'') as meaning ‘the last-born calf’ of [[केसरप्राबन्धा|Kesaraprābandhā]], a cow. But this interpretation does not suit the name so well.

कैकेय
<u>'''Kaikeya,'''</u> ‘king of the Kekayas,’ is an epithet of '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_719> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 1, 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 4.</ref>

कैरात
<u>'''Kairāta'''</u> is the name of a snake in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_720> v. 13, 5. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 243</ref>--possibly, but not probably, the modern Karait.

कैरातिका
<u>'''Kairātikā,'''</u> a ‘maiden of the '''[[किरात|Kirāta]]''' people,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda (x. 4, 14) as digging up roots for medicinal use.<br>==Foot Notes==

कैरिशि
<u>'''Kairiśi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Kiriśa,’ is the patronymic of '''Sutvan''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 28).<br>==Foot Notes==

कैवर्त
<u>'''Kaivarta.'''</u> See '''[[केवर्त|Kevarta]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कैशिनी
<u>'''Kaiśinī.'''</u>--The ''Kaiśinyaḥ prajāḥ,'' ‘offspring or people<ref name=fx1_ve1_724> So Sāyaṇa.</ref> of [[केशिन्|Keśin]],’ are mentioned in an obscure passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_724> xi. 8, 4, 6.</ref> either as still existing at the date of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_724> ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 134.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 208.</ref> or as extinct.

कैशोर्य
<u>'''Kaiśorya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Kaiśori,’ is the patronymic of '''[[काप्य|Kāpya]]''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_725> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> 

कोक
<u>'''1. Koka,'''</u> a word occurring in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_726> vii. 104, 22 (''koka-yātu,'' a ghost in the shape of a cuckoo).</ref> and the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_726> v. 23, 4;<br> viii. 6, 2.</ref> seems to denote the ‘cuckoo.’ In all the three passages in which it is found, Sāyaṇa explains it as the '''[[चक्रवाक|Cakravāka]].''' Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_726> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 454;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 262;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 49;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 92.</ref> renders it in the Atharvaveda passages as a certain destructive parasitic animal. ''Cf.'' '''[[अन्यवाप|Anyavāpa]].'''

कोक
<u>'''2. Koka'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 5, 4, 17) as a son of the [[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] king, '''[[सात्रासाह|Sātrāsāha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कोकिल
<u>'''Kokila,'''</u> a very frequent word in the Epic and later, denoting the cuckoo, is only inferred for the Vedic period from its being the name of a [[राजपुत्र|Rājaputra]] in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Anukramaṇī.<ref name=fx1_ve1_728> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 460.</ref>

कोणेय
<u>'''Koṇeya, Kauṇeya.'''</u> See '''Rajana.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कोल
<u>'''Kola,'''</u> another form of '''[[कुवल|Kuvala]],''' the ''Zizyphus jujuba,'' is mentioned in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vii. 3, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

कोश
<u>'''1. Kośa'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_731> i. 130, 2;<br> iii. 32, 15;<br> iv. 17, 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 156.</ref> for the ‘bucket’ used in drawing water by means of a rope from a well ('''[[अवत|Avata]]'''). In the ritual<ref name=fx2_ve1_731> Rv. ix. 75. 3;<br> Av. xviii. 4. 30, etc. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 183 ''et seq.''</ref> it denotes a large vessel to hold Soma, as opposed to '''[[कलश|Kalaśa]].'''

कोस
<u>'''2. Kosa'''</u> denotes the body of a chariot.<ref name=fx1_ve1_732> Rv. i. 87, 2;<br> x. 85, 7, etc.</ref> Presumably it was fastened to the axles, but it was probably not very secure, as the body of Pūṣan's chariot is said not to fall.<ref name=fx2_ve1_732> Rv. vi. 54, 3.</ref> The ropes<ref name=fx3_ve1_732> ''Gāvaḥ,'' Rv. viii. 48, 5.</ref> used to fasten the [[कोश|Kośa]] are perhaps referred to in the word ''akṣā-nah.''<ref name=fx4_ve1_732> See under 1. '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''</ref> By synecdoche this word also denotes the whole chariot.<ref name=fx5_ve1_732> Rv. viii. 20, 8;<br> 22, 9. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 246.</ref> See also '''[[वन्धुर|Vandhura]], [[रथ|Ratha]].''' 

कोश
<u>'''3. Kośa.'''</u>--The exact sense of this word in '''[[कोश|Kośa]]-kārī,''' the designation of a female victim at the Puruṣamedha, or human sacrifice,<ref name=fx1_ve1_733> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 14;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 10, 1.</ref> is uncertain. It may be ‘sheath.’

कोष
<u>'''Koṣa.'''</u>--The Koṣas appear as a priestly family in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], where one of them, '''[[सुश्रवस्|Suśravas]],''' is mentioned by name.<ref name=fx2_ve1_734> x. 5, 5, 1.</ref><br><br>^1 x. 5, 5, 8.

कोसल
<u>'''Kosala'''</u> is the name of a people not occurring in the earliest Vedic literature. In the story of the spread of Āryan culture told in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_735> i. 4, 1, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> the [[कोसल|Kosala]]-Videhas, as the offspring of '''[[विदेघ|Videgha]] [[माथव|Māthava]],''' appear as falling later than the Kuru-Pañcālas under the influence of Brahminism. The same passage gives the '''[[सदानीरा|Sadānīrā]]''' as the boundary of the two peoples--[[कोसल|Kosala]] and [[विदेह|Videha]]. Elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve1_735> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 4. ''Cf.'' [[हिरण्य-नाभ|Hiraṇya-nābha]], a [[राजपुत्र|Rājaputra]], in [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 2, and [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 9, 13, as a [[कौसल्य|Kausalya]], while ''ibid.,'' 11, Para is styled [[वैदेह|Vaideha]].</ref> the [[कौसल्य|Kausalya]], or [[कोसल|Kosala]] king, '''[[पर आट्णार|Para Āṭṇāra]] [[हैरण्यनाभ|Hairaṇyanābha]],''' is described as having performed the great [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice. Connexion with '''[[काशि|Kāśi]]''' and '''[[विदेह|Videha]]''' appears also from a passage of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_735> xvi. 29, 5.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx4_ve1_735> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 182, 441.</ref> points out that Āśvalāyana, who was very probably a descendant of '''[[अश्वल|Aśvala]],''' the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest of [[विदेह|Videha]], is called a [[कोसल|Kosala]] in the [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_735> vi. 1.</ref> The later distinction of North and South [[कोसल|Kosala]] is unknown to both Vedic and Buddhist literature.<ref name=fx6_ve1_735> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 393, n.<br><br>''Cf.'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 167;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xlii;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 39, 132 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 213-215;<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 25.</ref><br><br>[[कोसल|Kosala]] lay to the north-east of the Ganges, and corresponded roughly to the modern Oudh.

कौकूस्त
<u>'''Kaukūsta'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_736> iv. 6, 1, 13.</ref> as a giver of a Daksiṇā, or gift to the priests officiating at a sacrifice. The [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension reads the name '''Kaükthasta.'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_736> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 426, n. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 134.</ref> 

कौणेय
<u>'''Kauṇeya.'''</u> See '''Rajana.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कौण्ठ-रव्य
<u>'''Kauṇṭha-ravya'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_738> iii. 2, 2.</ref> and [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_738> vii. 14;<br> viii. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 249.</ref>

कौण्डिनी
<u>'''Kauṇḍinī.'''</u> See '''[[पाराशरीकौण्डिनीपुत्र|Pārāśarīkauṇḍinīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कौण्डिन्य
<u>'''Kauṇḍinya'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_740> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 1;<br> iv. 6, 1, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> See also '''Vidarbhīkauṇḍinya,''' and the following.

कौण्डिन्यायन
<u>'''Kauṇḍinyāyana'''</u> is mentioned in the first [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_741> ii. 5, 20.</ref> as a pupil of [[कौण्डिन्य|Kauṇḍinya]], pupil of [[कौण्डिन्य|Kauṇḍinya]] and [[आग्निवेश्य|Āgniveśya]]; in the second<ref name=fx2_ve1_741> iv. 5, 26.</ref> as a pupil of the two Kauṇḍinyas, pupil of [[कौण्डिन्य|Kauṇḍinya]] and [[आग्निवेश्य|Āgniveśya]]. Neither [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] is of much value.<ref name=fx3_ve1_741> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xxxiv.</ref>

कौतस्त
<u>'''Kautasta,'''</u> a word occurring once in the dual, is apparently a patronymic of '''[[अरिम्एजय|Arimejaya]]''' and '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]],''' two [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] priests at the snake sacrifice described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_742> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

कौत्स
<u>'''Kautsa'''</u> (‘descendant of Kutsa’) is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_743> x. 6, 5, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 5, 4 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension only).</ref> as a pupil of '''[[माहित्थि|Māhitthi]].''' A [[कौत्स|Kautsa]] is also attacked in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_743> i. 15.</ref> as denying the value of the Vedas, and there is a strong ritual tradition of hostility to the Kautsas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_743> ''E.g.,'' Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 20, 12;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 285. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 77, 140.</ref> 

कौत्सी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kautsī-putra'''</u> (‘son of a female descendant of '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]]'''’) is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[बौधीपुत्र|Baudhīputra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] in the Mādhyaṃdina recension (vi. 4, 31).<br>==Foot Notes==

कौपयेय
<u>'''Kaupayeya'''</u> is the patronymic of '''Uccaiḥśravas.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कौम्भ्य
<u>'''Kaumbhya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kumbhya’) is the patronymic of '''[[बभ्रु|Babhru]]'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कौरम
<u>'''Kaurama.'''</u> See '''[[कौरव|Kaurava]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कौरयाण
<u>'''Kaurayāṇa'''</u> is apparently a patronymic of '''Pākasthāman''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_748> viii. 3, 21. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 25.</ref> Hopkins<ref name=fx2_ve1_748> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 90, n. 2.</ref> suggests that Kaurāyaṇa may be meant.

कौरव
<u>'''Kaurava'''</u> is the reading of the text of the Khilas<ref name=fx1_ve1_749> v. 8, 1 (Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 155).</ref> and of some manuscripts of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_749> xii. 14, 1.</ref> for the [[कौरम|Kaurama]] of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_749> xx. 127, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 689.</ref> who appears in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) as a generous donor among the '''Ruśamas.'''

कौरव्य
<u>'''Kauravya'''</u> (‘belonging to the '''Kurus’'''). A man of the Kuru people, is described in the Atharvaveda as enjoying prosperity with his wife under the rule of King '''[[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_750> xx. 127, 8;<br> [[खिल|Khila]], v. 10, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 17, 2. ''Cf.'' a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in the Vaitāna [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxxiv. 9.</ref> Mention is also made of the [[कौरव्य|Kauravya]] king '''[[बल्हिक प्रातिपीय|Balhika Prātipīya]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_750> xii. 9, 3, 3.</ref> and in the later legend '''Ārṣṭiṣeṇa''' and '''Devāpi''' are alleged to have been Kauravyas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_750> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 10.</ref>

कौरव्यायणी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kauravyāyaṇī-putra'''</u> (‘son of a female descendant of '''Kuru'''’) is mentioned as a teacher in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (v. 1, 1). <br>==Foot Notes==

कौरु-पञ्चाल
<u>'''Kauru-pañcāla,'''</u> ‘belonging to the Kuru-Pañcālas,’ is an epithet of '''[[आरुणि|Āruṇi]]''' in the Śatapatha Brāhmana (xi. 4, 1, 2), and a practice of those tribes is designated by this word in the same work (i. 7, 2, 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

कौलकावती
<u>'''Kaulakāvatī'''</u> are two persons mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (ii. 1, 3) as having given advice, in the capacity of priests, to '''[[रथप्रोत दार्भ्य|Rathaprota Dārbhya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कौलाल
<u>'''Kaulāla'''</u> is a word denoting a hereditary potter (‘son of a ''[[कुलाल|kulāla]]'' or potter’) according to the commentator Mahīdhara on the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_754> xxx. 7.</ref> The other Samhitās<ref name=fx2_ve1_754> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13, and ''cf.'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27.</ref> have '''[[कुलाल|Kulāla]].'''

कौलितर
<u>'''Kaulitara'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_755> iv. 30. 14.</ref> as a '''[[दास|Dāsa]].''' Apparently the name is an epithet of '''[[शम्बर|Śambara]],''' meaning ‘son of Kulitara’: this points to [[शम्बर|Śambara]] having been a terrestrial foe, and not a mere demon.<ref name=fx2_ve1_755> ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 273;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 64, 161.</ref>

कौलीक
<u>'''Kaulīka,'''</u> like '''[[कुलीका|Kulīkā]],''' is the name of some sort of bird in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_756> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 24;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 5.</ref>

कौशाम्बेय
<u>'''Kauśāmbeya'''</u> is the patronymic (‘descendant of Kuśāmba’) of a teacher '''Proti''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_757> xii. 2, 2, 13;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 24.</ref> according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary: a view supported by the fact that '''Kūśāmba''' actually occurs as the name of a man in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_757> viii. 6, 8. The name is also found later (in the Epic) in the form of Kuśāmba.</ref> It is, however, possible that the word means a ‘native of the town Kauśāmbī’ as understood by Harisvāmin in his commentary on the Śatapatha Brāhmana.<ref name=fx3_ve1_757> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 153, n. 5. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 193;<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 3, 36;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 397.</ref> 

कौशिक
<u>'''Kauśika'''</u> is an epithet of Indra as ‘connected with the Kuśikas,’ and also of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' as ‘son of [[कुशिक|Kuśika]].’<ref name=fx1_ve1_758> In a late [[खिल|Khila]], Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 104.</ref> A teacher named [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[कौण्डिन्य|Kauṇḍinya]]''' in the first two Vaṃśias (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_758> ii. 6, 1;<br> iv. 6, 1 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension).</ref>

कौशिकायनि
<u>'''Kauśikāyani'''</u> (‘descendant of Kauśika’) is mentioned as a teacher and a pupil of '''[[घृतकौशिक|Ghṛtakauśika]]''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_759> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

कौशिकी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kauśikī-putra'''</u> (‘son of a female descendant of Kuśika’) is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 1) as a pupil of '''[[आलम्बीपुत्र|Ālambīputra]]''' and '''[[वैयाघ्रपदीपुत्र|Vaiyāghrapadīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कौश्रेय
<u>'''Kauśreya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kuśri’) is the patronymic of '''Somadakṣa''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xx. 8; xxi. 9).<br>==Foot Notes==

कौषारव
<u>'''Kauṣārava'''</u> (‘descendant of Kuṣāru’) is the patronymic of '''[[मैत्रेय|Maitreya]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 28).<br>==Foot Notes==

कौषीतकि
<u>'''Kauṣītaki'''</u> (‘descendant of Kuṣītaka’) is the patronymic of a teacher, or series of teachers, to whom the doctrines set forth in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_763> ii. 9;<br> vii. 4, 10;<br> viii. 8;<br> xi. 5. 7;<br> xiv. 3. 4;<br> xv. 2;<br> xvi. 9;<br> xviii. 5;<br> xxii. 1. 2;<br> xxiii. 1. 4;<br> xxiv. 8. 9;<br> xxv. 8. 10. 14. 15, etc.</ref> and in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve1_763> ii. 17: xv. 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1. 7.</ref> and the Śrauta and [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras,<ref name=fx3_ve1_763> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 15, 11;<br> vii. 21, 6;<br> ix. 20, 33;<br> xi. 11, 3. 6, etc.</ref> are referred. He is rarely mentioned elsewhere.<ref name=fx4_ve1_763> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 3, 1;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 2.</ref> The doctrine of [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] is called the Kauṣītaka.<ref name=fx5_ve1_763> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1;<br> xix. 3;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 2, 13;<br> xi. 14, 26;<br> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 7: vii. 11 viii. 5, etc.</ref> The pupils of [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] are known as the Kauṣītakis in the [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx6_ve1_763> vi. 12.</ref> and in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_763> xvii. 4, 3.</ref>  they with [[कुषीतक|Kuṣītaka]] are stated to have been cursed by '''Luśākapi.''' Elsewhere<ref name=fx8_ve1_763> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 1. 10;<br> Āśvalāvana Grhya [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 23.</ref> they are called Kauṣītakins. If the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx9_ve1_763> ''Cf'' Kelth, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 14, 24, 71</ref> can be trusted, there were among them at least two leading teachers, '''Kahoḍa''' and '''Sarvajit,''' the former of whom is mentioned elsewhere.<ref name=fx10_ve1_763> Sarapatna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 3, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 4, 1;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 259;<br> 2, 289 ''et seq.;<br> Indian Literature,'' 44 ''et seq.;<br>'' Lindner, ''[[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],'' ix.</ref>

कौष्य
<u>'''Kauṣya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[कोष|Koṣa]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[सुश्रवस्|Suśravas]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कौसल्य
<u>'''Kausalya,'''</u> ‘prince of [[कोसल|Kosala]],’ is the designation of '''[[पर आट्णार|Para Āṭṇāra]]''' in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_765> xiii 5, 4, 4.</ref> and of '''[[हिरण्यनाभ|Hiraṇyanābha]]''' in the Sāṅkhāvana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_765> xvi. 9, 13. ''Cf.'' xvi. 29, 5.</ref> Āśvalāyana is styled [[कौसल्य|Kausalya]], as ‘belonging to the [[कोसल|Kosala]] country,’ in the [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_765> i. 1.</ref> and the Kaśī-Kausalyāḥ, or the ‘Kāśis and people of [[कोसल|Kosala]],’ are mentioned in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_765> i. 2, 9 (spelt ''Kauśalyāḥ'').</ref>

कौसित
<u>'''Kausita'''</u> appears in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (ii. 1, 11) in connexion with the demon Kusitāyin as the name of a lake. The [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (x. 5) has Kausida instead.<br>==Foot Notes==

कौसुरुबिन्दि
<u>'''Kausurubindi,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Kusurubinda,'''’ is the patronymic of '''Proti [[कौशाम्बेय|Kauśāmbeya]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 2, 2, 13). In the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 4, 24) the form is Kausuravindu.<br>==Foot Notes==

कौहड
<u>'''Kauhaḍa,'''</u> ‘descendant of Kohaḍa,’ is the patronymic of a teacher, '''Mitravinda,''' mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_768> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372, 382 ''et seq.'' A school of Kauhaḍīyas is known in the Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 34.</ref> as well as of '''[[श्रवणदत्त|Śravaṇadatta]].'''

क्रतु-जित् जानकि
<u>'''Kratu-jit Jānaki'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]'''’) is mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_769> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 8, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 474.</ref> as the priest of '''Rajana [[कौणेय|Kauṇeya]].''' See also '''Kratuvid.''' 

क्रतु-विद् जानकि
<u>'''Kratu-vid Jānaki'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]'''’) is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 34) as having learned a certain doctrine regarding Soma from Agni.<br>==Foot Notes==

क्रय
<u>'''Kraya,'''</u> ‘sale,’ is a word which does not actually occur in the Rigveda, though the verb ''krī,'' from which this noun is derived, is found there.<ref name=fx1_ve1_771> iv. 24, 10.</ref> Both noun and verb are common in the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve1_771> ''[[क्रय|Kraya]]:'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 2, 1;<br> vi. 1, 3, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 55;<br> xix. 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 2, 10, etc.;<br> ''krī:'' Av. iii. 15, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 10, 3;<br> vii. 1, 6, 2, etc.;<br> ''apa-krī:'' Av. viii. 7, 11;<br> ''pari-krī:'' Av. iv. 7, 6, etc.;<br> ''vi-krī:'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 49, etc.</ref> Sale appears to have regularly consisted in barter in the Rigveda:<ref name=fx3_ve1_771> iv. 24, 10.</ref> ten cows are regarded as a possible price for an (image of) Indra to be used as a fetish, while elsewhere not a hundred, nor a thousand, nor a myriad are considered as an adequate price (''[[शुल्क|śulka]]'') for the purchase of Indra.<ref name=fx4_ve1_771> Rv. viii. 1, 5.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_771> iv. 7, 6.</ref> mentions, as possible objects of commerce, garments (''[[दूर्श|dūrśa]]''), coverlets (''[[पवस्त|pavasta]]''), and goatskins (''[[अजिन|ajina]]''). The haggling of the market was already familiar in the days of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx6_ve1_771> iv. 24, 9. See Oldenberg, ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 419, 420, correcting Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 91, and Geldner's ''Kommentar'' on iv. 24.</ref> and a characteristic hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_771> iii. 15. See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 352;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 111, 112.</ref> is directed to procuring success in trade. The ‘price’ was called '''[[वस्न|Vasna]],''' and the ‘merchant’ '''[[वणिज्|Vaṇij]].''' his greed being well known.<ref name=fx8_ve1_771> Rv. i. 33, 3, and See '''[[पणि|Paṇi]].'''</ref><br><br>There is little evidence of a standard of value in currency having been adopted. When no specific mention is made of the standard, the unit was probably the cow.<ref name=fx9_ve1_771> ''Cf.'' Harisvāmin on Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 1, where he renders ''sahasrārha'' as equal to ‘worth a thousand cows,’ in which Eggeling follows him;<br> Saṃkṣiptasāra on Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 10, 33.</ref> In a considerable number of passages of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx10_ve1_771> xii. 7, 2, 13;<br> 9, 1, 4;<br> xiii. 1, 1, 4;<br> 2, 3, 2;<br> 4, 1, 13;<br> xiv. 3, 1, 32. ''Cf.'' v. 5, 5, 16;<br> xiii. 4, 1, 6.</ref> and elsewhere,<ref name=fx11_ve1_771> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 3, 2, where a long series of compounds of numerals with ''-[[मान|māna]]'' occurs;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 5;<br> xiv. 8;<br> xxii. 8.</ref> however, the expression ''hiraṇyaṃ śata-mānam'' suggests that there must have been some standard other than  cows, though it might in all these passages be rendered as ‘gold worth a hundred cows.’ But the use of the '''[[कृष्णल|Kṛṣṇala]]''' as a measure of weight<ref name=fx12_ve1_771> ''Cf.'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6, 7;<br> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 6: Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 99-103.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 255260. Barter had for the most part passed away by the time of the Jātakas, an illustration of the modern character of the society they represent. See Mrs. Rhys Davids, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1901, 874 ''et seq.''</ref> suggests that the meaning is ‘gold weighing a hundred Kṛṣṇalas,’ and this seems the more probable explanation. This unit seems not to be known in the Rigveda, where the meaning of the term '''[[मना|Manā]],''' which occurs once, is mysterious, and where necklets ('''[[निष्क|Niṣka]]''') seem to have been one of the more portable forms of wealth, like jewellery in modern India, and may perhaps have served as a means of exchange.

क्रवण
<u>'''Kravaṇa,'''</u> a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_772> v. 44. 9.</ref> is understood by Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_772> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138.</ref> as the name of the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest or the sacrificer. Roth considered it an adjective without at first<ref name=fx3_ve1_772> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> assigning a sense, but afterwards<ref name=fx4_ve1_772> Bo7htlingk's Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> as meaning ‘timid.’ Sāyaṇa interprets it as ‘worshipping.’ Oldenberg<ref name=fx5_ve1_772> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 342.</ref> considers the meaning uncertain, suggesting as possible ‘the slayer of the victim.’

क्रव्य
<u>'''Kravya,'''</u> ‘raw flesh,’ is never mentioned in Vedic literature as eaten by men. Demons alone are spoken of as consuming it,<ref name=fx1_ve1_773> Rv. vii. 104, 2;<br> x. 87, 2. 19;<br> 162, 2;<br> Av. iii. 28, 2;<br> iv. 36, 3: v. 29 10, etc.</ref> apart from Agni being called ''kravyād,'' ‘eating raw flesh,’ as consumer of the bodies of the dead.<ref name=fx2_ve1_773> Rv. x. 16, 9. 10. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 97, 165.</ref> The man who in the Rigveda is compelled by starvation to eat dog's flesh, nevertheless cooks it.<ref name=fx3_ve1_773> iv. 18, 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 270, 271.</ref>

क्रातु-जातेय
<u>'''Krātu-jāteya'''</u> is a patronymic of '''[[राम क्रातुजातेय|Rāma Krātujāteya]] [[वैयाघ्रपद्य|Vaiyāghrapadya]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 2; iv. 16, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

क्रिमि
<u>'''Krimi.'''</u> See '''[[कृमि|Kṛmi]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

क्रिवि
<u>'''Krivi'''</u> is asserted in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_776> xiii. 5, 4, 7.</ref> to have been the older name of the '''Pañcālas.''' This statement is supported by the name of the king there mentioned, '''[[क्रैव्य|Kraivya]] [[पाञ्चाल|Pāñcāla]],''' The Krivis appear in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_776> viii. 20, 24;<br> 22, 12. ElsewhereKrivi is doubtful in sense. In several passages (i. 30, 1;<br> viii. 87, 1;<br> ix. 9, 6, and perhaps i. 166, 6, where ''krivir-datī'' is an epithet of lightning) Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' i. 166, 341, understands the word to mean ‘horse.’ Elsewhere (ii. 17, 6;<br> 22, 2;<br> viii. 51, 8) he takes it to be a proper name, while in v. 44, 4, he is doubtful. In the passages last cited this view may very well be correct.</ref> as settled on the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' and the '''[[असिक्नी|Asiknī]].''' It is a plausible conjecture of Zimmer's<ref name=fx3_ve1_776> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 103.</ref> that with the '''Kurus''' they made up the '''[[वैकर्ण|Vaikarṇa]]''' people.<ref name=fx4_ve1_776> ''Cf.'' '''[[कवष|Kavaṣa]].'''</ref> The importance of the Pañcālas, and the insignificance of the Krivis, may be explained in part by the fact that the later Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] alliance included the '''Bharatas.''' It is also probable, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx5_ve1_776> ''Buddha,'' 404.</ref> suggests, from the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx6_ve1_776> xiii. 5, 4, 16.</ref> that the '''Turvaśas''' were included in the Pañcālas, and as the latter name indicates, probably other tribes also. Or, if Hopkins' view<ref name=fx7_ve1_776> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 258 ''et seq.'' This view is hardly convincing, while the disappearance of the Turvaśas is easily to be accounted for by their being merged, along with the Krivis, in the Pañcālas. The name of [[क्रिवि|Krivi]] is lost in the Epic as completely as that of [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] (Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 48, notes 4, 5).<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 155, 157;<br> Grierson, ''Journal of the Royal Astatic Society,'' 1908, 602-607;<br> Keith, ''ibid.,'' 831 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 152, 153;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xli.;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 407.</ref> is accepted that [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] was king of the Yadus, the latter may in part have been allied with the Krivis to form the Pañcālas.

क्रीत वैत-होत्र
<u>'''Krīta Vaita-hotra'''</u> (‘descendant of Vītahotra’) is mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iv. 2, 6) in connexion with the '''Kurus.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

क्रुञ्च्
<u>'''1. Kruñc,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_778> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 73 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 2, 1-3.</ref> '''Kruñca,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_778> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 22. 31 (in xxv. 6 the sense is quite uncertain);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 3.</ref> '''[[क्रौञ्च|Krauñca]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_778> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1.</ref> are variant forms denoting the ‘curlew’ or ‘snipe.’ To it is attributed in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_778/>  the faculty, later assigned to the '''[[हंस|Haṃsa]],''' of extracting milk from water when the two fluids are mixed.<ref name=fx4_ve1_778> Lanman, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 151-158;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 150.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 91, 92.</ref>

क्रुन्च् आङ्गिरस
<u>'''2. Krunc Āṅgirasa'''</u> is in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_779> xiii. 9, 11;<br> 11, 20.</ref> the name of the seer of a Sāman or Chant called the [[क्रौञ्च|Krauñca]]. It is doubtless invented to explain the name of the Chant on the ordinary principle that Sāmans are called after their authors, though this rule has many exceptions.<ref name=fx2_ve1_779> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 68. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160.</ref>

क्रुमु
<u>'''Krumu'''</u> is the name of a stream mentioned twice in the Rigveda--once in the fifth book<ref name=fx1_ve1_780> v. 53, 9.</ref> and once in the last, in the [[नदी|Nadī]]-[[स्तुति|stuti]], or ‘praise of rivers.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_780> x. 75, 6.</ref> There can be little doubt that this river is identical with the modern Kurum, a western tributary of the Indus.<ref name=fx3_ve1_780> Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erläuterungen,'' 43;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 14: Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200.</ref>

क्रुमुक
<u>'''Krumuka'''</u> as the name of ‘wood’ appears to be a variant form of [[कृमुक|Kṛmuka]].<br><br>^1) [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 9, 3; [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 7, 3.<br>==Foot Notes==

क्रैव्य। पाञ्चाल
<u>'''Kraivya. Pāñcāla,'''</u> the king of the '''Krivis,'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_782> So the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 125, n.;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 409, n.</ref> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_782> xiii. 5, 4, 7.</ref> as having performed the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, on the '''[[परिवक्रा|Parivakrā]].''' Eggeling,<ref name=fx3_ve1_782> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 397 (but ''cf.'' p. 398, top).</ref> however, takes the word as a proper name, ‘Kraivya, the [[पाञ्चाल|Pāñcāla]] king.’

क्रोश
<u>'''Krośa,'''</u> as a measure of distance (lit. ‘a shout,’ as expressing the range of the voice), is found in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_783> xvi. 13, 12. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 8, 432 ''et seq.'' In the later literature it is equivalent to about two miles. The word still survives in the vernacular form of Kos as the most popular measure of distance in India.</ref> 

क्रोष्टृ
<u>'''Kroṣṭṛ'''</u> (lit. ‘howler’), the ‘jackal,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_784> x. 28, 1.</ref> as by nature cowardly compared with the wild boar ('''[[वराह|Varāha]]'''). In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_784> xi. 2, 2.</ref> it is spoken of as devouring corpses. The word also occurs in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_784> xxiv. 32.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 84.</ref> where the commentator glosses it with [[सृगाल|Sṛgāla]], another name of the jackal. See also '''[[लोपाश|Lopāśa]].'''

क्रौञ्च
<u>'''1. Krauñca.'''</u> See '''[[क्रुञ्च्|Kruñc]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

क्रौञ्च
<u>'''2. Krauñca,'''</u> as the name of a mountain, occurs only in the latest Vedic literature.<ref name=fx1_ve1_786> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 31, 2. See Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 93;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78.</ref>

क्रौञ्चिकी-पुत्र
<u>'''Krauñcikī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of [[क्रौञ्च|Krauñca]],’ is mentioned as a pupil of '''Vaiṭṭabhatīputra'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_787> [[वैदभृती-पुत्र|Vaidabhṛtī-putra]] in the Mādhyaṃdina recension, vi. 4, 32.</ref> in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_787> vi. 5, 2 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

क्रौष्टुकि
<u>'''Krauṣṭuki,'''</u> ‘descendant of Kroṣṭuka,’ is mentioned as a grammarian in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_788> viii. 2.</ref> the Bṛhaddevatā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_788> iv. 137. ''Cf. Indische Studien,'' 1, 105.</ref> and the [[छन्दस्|Chandas]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_788> 5.</ref> but as an astrologer in a Pariśiṣṭa of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx4_ve1_788> Weber, Berlin Catalogue of Sanskrit MSS., 1, 94. See Bolling and von Negelein. ''The Pariśiṣṭas of the Atharvaveda,'' 2, 438 ''et seq.,'' where in Pariśiṣṭa lxviii (Svapnādhyāyaḥ), i. 2;<br> ii. 8, the name appears as Kroṣṭuki.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''[[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]],'' 12;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 61.</ref>

क्वयी
<u>'''Kvayī'''</u> is the name of some species of bird in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_789> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 17, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 29.</ref> occurring in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice. The form in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_789> iii. 14, 18.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99</ref> is [[कुवय|Kuvaya]]. 

क्वल
<u>'''Kvala'''</u> is a substance, perhaps<ref name=fx1_ve1_790> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> identical with '''[[कुवल|Kuvala]],''' the fruit of the jujube, used to coagulate milk according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_790> ii. 5, 3, 5. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 227.</ref>

क्षत
<u>'''Kṣata'''</u> is regarded by Zimmer<ref name=fx1_ve1_791> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 377.</ref> as denoting a special disease (a sort of ''Phthisis pulmonalis'') in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_791> vii. 76, 4 (where the reading is doubtful, the text having ''akṣita.'' See '''[[अक्षत|Akṣata]]''').</ref> but the word is probably only an adjective.<ref name=fx3_ve1_791> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 509;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 442.</ref>

क्षत्तृ
<u>'''Kṣattṛ'''</u> is a word of frequent occurrence in the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas, denoting a member of the royal entourage, but the sense is somewhat uncertain. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_792> vi. 13, 2.</ref> it is used of a god as the ‘distributor’ of good things to his worshippers; the same sense seems to be found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_792> iii. 24, 7;<br> v. 17, 4.</ref> and elsewhere.<ref name=fx3_ve1_792> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 9, 16.</ref> In one passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_792> xxx. 13. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 5.</ref> the interpretation ‘doorkeeper’ is given by the commentator Mahīdhara, a sense which seems possible in other passages,<ref name=fx5_ve1_792> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 4, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xix. 1, 4.</ref> while Sāyaṇa ascribes to it in one passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_792> v. 3, 1, 7. ''Cf.'' on xiii. 4, 2, 5 (''āyavyayādhyakṣa''), and Harisvāmin on xiii. 5, 4, 6 (''kośādhyakṣa''). The scholiast on the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 3, 9. has ''mantrī dūto vā;<br>'' on xx. 1, 16, ''pratīhāro dūto vā.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 61, etc., renders it ‘chamberlain.’</ref> the more dignified meaning of ''antaḥpurādhyakṣa,'' ‘a chamberlain.’ In other passages,<ref name=fx7_ve1_792> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 26;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 7, 1, with the scholiast's note, and ''ibid., [[अनुक्षत्तृ|anukṣattṛ]],'' rendered as ''sārather [[अनुचर|anucara]],'' ‘the attendant of the charioteer’;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 1, 20, with the scholiast's note.</ref> again, the sense of ‘charioteer’ is not unlikely. Later the [[क्षत्तृ|Kṣattṛ]] was regarded as a man of mixed caste.<ref name=fx8_ve1_792> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 481.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 36;<br> 17, 290;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> 

क्षत्र
<u>'''1. Kṣatra,'''</u> in the general sense of ‘dominion,’ ‘rule,’ ‘power,’ as exercised by gods and men, occurs frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_793> i. 24, 11;<br> 136, 1. 3;<br> iv. 17. 1;<br> v. 62, 6, etc.;<br> Av. iii. 5, 2;<br> v. 18, 4, etc. So ''[[क्षत्र|kṣatra]]-[[श्री|śrī]],'' Rv. i. 25, 5;<br> vi. 26. 8;<br> ''[[क्षत्र|kṣatra]]-bhṛt,'' ‘bringers of lordship.’ [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 7, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 6, 12;<br> 7, 6, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxvii. 7, etc.</ref> onwards. The word is also found in the concrete sense of ‘rulers’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_793> Singular: i. 157, 2;<br> viii. 35, 17.</ref> and later;<ref name=fx3_ve1_793> Plural: Av. iv. 22, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 6, 3.</ref> but in no case does it in the Rigveda certainly<ref name=fx4_ve1_793> See Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].'''</ref> mean what it regularly denotes in the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx5_ve1_793> Av. ii. 15, 4: ix. 7, 9;<br> xii. 5, 8;<br> xv. 10, 5, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 1, 2;<br> ii. 2, 11, 2, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 27;<br> xiv. 24;<br> xviii. 38, etc. See other citations under '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].'''</ref> the ruling class as opposed to the priests ('''[[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]]'''), the subject people ('''[[विश्|Viś]], [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]'''), and the servile class ('''[[शूद्र|Śūdra]]'''). See also '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]].''' A [[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]]-pati is several times mentioned<ref name=fx6_ve1_793> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 14, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 8, 5;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 2, 2.</ref> as an equivalent of ‘king.’

क्षत्र
<u>'''2. Kṣatra'''</u> seems to be the name of a man mentioned with others, including '''[[मनस|Manasa]], [[यजत|Yajata]],''' and '''[[अवत्सार|Avatsāra]],''' in one quite obscure passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_794> v. 44, 10. ''Cf.'' Ludwig. Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138.</ref>

क्षत्र-विद्या
<u>'''Kṣatra-vidyā,'''</u> ‘the science of the ruling class,’ is mentioned in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_795> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> Śaṅkara glosses the term with ''dhanur-veda,'' ‘the science of the bow,’ which is the most probable sense.<ref name=fx2_ve1_795> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 104.</ref>

क्षत्रिय
<u>'''Kṣatriya.'''</u>--As the origin of caste, the relation of the castes, intermarriage, and cognate matters may most conveniently be discussed under '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]],''' this article will be confined to determining, as far as possible, the real character of the class called Kṣatriyas, or collectively '''[[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]].'''<br><br>The evidence of the Jātakas<ref name=fx1_ve1_796>See Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung im nordo7stlichen Indien zu Buddhas Zoit,'' 59 ''et seq.;<br>'' Rhys Davids, ''Dialogues of the Buddha,'' 1, 95 ''et seq.;<br> Buddhist India,'' 52 ''et seq.''</ref> points to the word Khattiya  denoting the members of the old Āryan nobility who had led the tribes to conquest, '''as well''' as those families of the aborigines who had managed to maintain their princely status in spite of the conquest.
