In the epic<ref name=fx2_ve1_796> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 73 ''et seq.''</ref> also the term [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] seems to include these persons, but it has probably a wider signification than Khattiya, and would cover all the royal military vassals and feudal chiefs, expressing, in fact, pretty much the same as the ''barones'' of early English history. Neither in the Jātakas<ref name=fx3_ve1_796> Fick, ''op. cit.,'' 52, n. 2.</ref> nor in the epic<ref name=fx4_ve1_796> Hopkins, ''op. cit.,'' 184 ''et seq.,'' 190.</ref> is the term co-extensive with all warriors; the army contains many besides the Kṣatriyas, who are the leaders or officers, rather than the rank and file.<br><br>In the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx5_ve1_796> Av. vi. 76, 3. 4;<br> xii. 5, 5. 44. 46, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5, etc. See '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''' and '''[[राजन्य|Rājanya]].'''</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx6_ve1_796> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 24, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 2, 15;<br> iv. 1, 4, 5. 6, etc. See '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].'''</ref> the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] stands as a definite member of the social body, distinct from the priest, the subject people, and the slaves, '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]],''' and '''[[शूद्र|Śūdra]].''' It is significant that [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] is a variant to [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], and an earlier one. Hence it is reasonable to suppose that the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] and [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] are both of similar origin, being princely or connected with royalty. Moreover, the early use of [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] in the Rigveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_796> iv. 12, 3;<br> 42, 1;<br> v. 69, 1;<br> vii. 64, 2;<br> viii. 25, 8;<br> 56, 1;<br> x. 109, 3. ''Cf.'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 19;<br> x. 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 7, 7.</ref> is exclusively connected with royal authority or divine authority.<br><br>It is impossible to say exactly what persons would be included in the term [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]. That it covered the royal house and the various branches of the royal family may be regarded as certain. It, no doubt, also included the nobles and their families: this would explain the occasional opposition of [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] and [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], as in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx8_ve1_796> vii. 20. ''Cf.'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 18, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xx. 1.</ref> where a [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] asks a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] for a place for sacrifice (''deva-yajana''). Thus, when strictly applied, [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] would have a wider denotation than [[राजन्य|Rājanya]]. As a rule, however, the two expressions are identical, and both are used as evidence in what follows. That [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] ever included the mere fighting  man has not been proved: in the Rigveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_796> In the following passages there is reference to the people (''[[विश्|viś]]'') fighting: i. 69, 3;<br> 126, 5 (''cf.,'' however, Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 121);<br> iv. 24, 4;<br> vi. 26, 1;<br> vii. 79, 2;<br> viii. 18, 18;<br> 96, 15;<br> probably also vii. 33, 6, where the ''Tṛtsūnāṃ viśaḥ'' means ‘the subjects of the [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]] princes,’ as Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 136, thinks. In vi. 41, 5, on the other hand, the people and wars (''pṛtanāsu'') are contrasted, the normal rule of the common folk being peace.</ref> and later<ref name=fx10_ve1_796> In Av. ix. 7, 9, the people are clearly designated as ''balam,'' or ‘force,’ a regular term later for an armed force. The later law books (''e.g.,'' [[गौतम|Gautama]], vii. 6;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], ii. 22) allow even Brahmins to maintain themselves by the occupation of Kṣatriyas in case of need. For the Epic, ''cf.'' Hopkins, ''op. cit.,'' 94, 95;<br> 184 ''et seq.''</ref> others than Kṣatriyas regularly fought; but possibly if the nobles had retinues as the kings had, [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] would embrace those retainers who had military functions. The term did not apply to all members of the royal entourage; for example, the '''Grāmaṇī''' was usually a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]].<br><br>The connexion of the Kṣatriyas with the Brahmins was very close. The prosperity of the two is repeatedly asserted<ref name=fx11_ve1_796> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 10, 3;<br> Maitrayaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 3;<br> iii. 1, 9;<br> 2, 3;<br> iv. 3, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 27;<br> vii. 21;<br> xviii. 14;<br> xix. 5;<br> xxxviii. 14, etc.;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 11, 9;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 22;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 7;<br> iii. 5, 2, 11;<br> 6, 1, 17;<br> vi. 6, 3, 14. The superiority of the [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] to all other castes is asserted in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 10, 1, etc. The superiority of the Brahmin to the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] is sometimes asserted--''e.g.,'' in the Atharvaveda hymns, v. 18. 19;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 21;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 9, 1;<br> 3, 7, 8. So the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] sacrifice of the king is inferior to the highest sacrifice (the [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]]) of the priest (''ibid.,'' v. 1, 1, 12), and though the Brahmin goes after the king, he is yet stronger than he (v. 4, 2, 7, and v. 4, 4, 15). ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''op. cit.,'' 76.</ref> to be indissolubly associated, especially in the relation of king ('''[[राजन्|Rājan]]''') and domestic priest ('''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]]'''). Sometimes there was feud between [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] and Brahmin.<ref name=fx12_ve1_796> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 5;<br> Av. v. 18. 19.</ref> His management of the sacrifice then gave the Brahmin power to ruin the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] by embroiling him with the people<ref name=fx13_ve1_796> ''E.g.,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 11, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 5;<br> ii. 1, 9;<br> iii. 3, 10;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 8, etc.</ref> or with other Kṣatriyas.<ref name=fx14_ve1_796> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 10, etc.</ref><br><br>Towards the common people, on the other hand, the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] stood in a relation of well-nigh unquestioned superiority.<ref name=fx15_ve1_796> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 4;<br> xxi. 10;<br> xxii. 9;<br> xxix. 9. 10;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 33;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 7, 15. 16, etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 9. 10;<br> 6, 8, etc.</ref> There are, however, references to occasional feuds between  the people and the nobles,<ref name=fx16_ve1_796> ''Cf.'' note 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 6, 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 7.</ref> in which no doubt the inferior numbers of the latter were compensated by their superior arms and prowess. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx17_ve1_796> vii. 29. ''Cf.'' '''[[राजन्|Rājan]].'''</ref> the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] is described as tributary to another (''anyasya bali-kṛt''), to be devoured by another (''anyasyādya''), and to be oppressed at will (''yathākāma-jyeya''). Probably these epithets apply most strictly to the relation of the king and his people, but the passage shows that the people were greatly at the mercy of the nobles. No doubt the king granted to them the right, which may have been hereditary, to be supported by the common people, whose feudal superiors they thus became. In return for these privileges the Kṣatriyas had probably duties of protection to perform, as well as some judicial functions, to judge from an obscure passage of the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx18_ve1_796> xxvii. 4 (''tasmād rājanyenādhyakṣeṇa vaiśyaṃ ghnanti,'' ‘so with a [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] as a supervisor[?] they smite a Vaiśya’). It is not clear whether ''han'' here means ‘kill’ or ‘beat.’</ref><br><br>The main duty of the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] in the small states<ref name=fx19_ve1_796> See Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 30, n. 2.</ref> of the Vedic period was readiness for war. The bow is thus his special attribute,<ref name=fx20_ve1_796> Av. xviii. 2, 60;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xviii. 9;<br> xxxvii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 5, 30;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vi. 1, 3. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 19, the list is longer--chariot, breastplate ('''[[कवच|Kavaca]]'''), bow and arrow (''[[इषु|iṣu]]-[[धन्वन्|dhanvan]]'')--and in the prayer for the prosperity of the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] (called, as usual in the older texts, [[राजन्य|Rājanya]]), at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], the Rājanva is to be an archer and a good chariot-fighter;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 18, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], v. 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 2. So Indra is the god of the Kṣatriyas, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 1;<br> iv. 5, 8, etc.</ref> just as the goad is that of the agriculturist; for the bow is the main weapon of the Veda. Whether the Kṣatriyas paid much attention to mental occupations is uncertain. In the latest stratum of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] literature there are references to learned princes like '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' of '''[[विदेह|Videha]],''' who is said to have become a Brahmin (''brahmā''), apparently in the sense that he had the full knowledge which a Brahmin possessed.<ref name=fx21_ve1_796> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 2, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1. See Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Litcrature,'' 421 ''et seq.;<br>'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 426 ''et seq.'' Similarly at the Dīkṣā a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] becomes temporarily a Brahmin, [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 23.<br><br>''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 3.</ref> Other learned Kṣatriyas of this period were  '''[[प्रवाहण जैवलि|Pravāhaṇa Jaivali]],'''<ref name=fx22_ve1_796> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 1;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 8, 1;<br> v. 3, 1;<br> Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 433-435;<br> 515;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 117;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 1, lxxv.</ref> '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]] [[कैकेय|Kaikeya]],'''<ref name=fx23_ve1_796> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 1, 2 ''et seq.''</ref> and [[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]].<ref name=fx24_ve1_796> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1.</ref> Garbe,<ref name=fx25_ve1_796> ''Beiträge zur indischen Kulturgeschichte,'' 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 17 ''et seq.;<br>'' Winterniz, ''Geschichte der indischen Litteratur,'' 1, 199.</ref> Grierson,<ref name=fx26_ve1_796> Article ‘Bhakti’ in ''Encyclopœdia of Religion and Ethics;<br> Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 843.</ref> and others believe they are justified in holding the view that the Ksatriyas developed a special philosophy of their own as opposed to Brahminism, which appears later as Bhakti, or Faith. On the other hand, there is clear evidence<ref name=fx27_ve1_796> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 1, 4, 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg. ''Buddha,'' 73, n. 1;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āranyaka,'' 50, 257;<br> ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 868, 883, 1140-1142. Professor Eggeling concurs in the view that the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] share in the religious movement was not substantially real.</ref> that the opinion of Ksatriyas on such topics were held in little respect, and it must be remembered that to attribute wisdom to a king was a delicate and effective piece of flattery. There are earlier references to royal sages (''[[राजन्यर्षि|rājanyarṣi]]''),<ref name=fx28_ve1_796> ''E.g.,'' in Pañcavimśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 12, 6;<br> but see on this Oldenberg. ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlandischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 235, n., and '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].'''</ref> but it is very doubtful if much stress can be laid on them, and none can be laid on the later tradition of Sāyaṇa.<ref name=fx29_ve1_796> Cited in Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 12, 265 ''et seq.''</ref> Again, the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx30_ve1_796> ii. 10.</ref> gives a tradition relating how '''Devāpi,''' a king's son, became the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of his younger brother '''[[शंतनु|Śaṃtanu]];''' but it is very doubtful if the story can really be traced with Sieg<ref name=fx31_ve1_796> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 91 ''et seq.'' See '''Devāpi.'''</ref> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx32_ve1_796> x. 98. The case of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' may also be cited;<br> but his royal rank, which is attested by the mention of him as a [[राजपुत्र|Rājaputra]] in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17, is at most merely a matter of descent, and is of very doubtful authenticity. See under '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].'''</ref> itself. In any case, the stories refer only to a few selected Kṣatriyas of high rank, while there is no evidence that the average [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] was concerned with intellectual pursuits. Nor is there any reference to Kṣatriyas engaging in agriculture or in trade or commerce. It may be assumed that the duties of administration and war were adequate to absorb his attention. On the other hand, we do hear of a [[राजन्य|Rājanya]]  as a lute player and singer at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] or horse sacrifice.<ref name=fx33_ve1_796> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 5. This mention is proof of the existence of a class of [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] bards (as opposed to priestly reciters), from whose productions the Epic naturally grew up.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 258.</ref><br><br>Of the training and education of a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] we have no record; presumably, as in fact if not in theory later on, he was mainly instructed in the art of war, the science of the bow, and the rudimentary administrative functions which would devolve on him. At this early state of the development of the nobility which appears to be represented in the Rigveda, it was probably not unusual or impossible for a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] to become a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]; at least, this assumption best explains the phrase<ref name=fx34_ve1_796> vii. 104, 13. ''Cf.'' for a similarly false claim to be a Brahmin, x. 71, 8.</ref> ‘claiming falsely a Kṣatriya's rank’ (''kṣatriyaṃ mithuyā dhārayantam'').<br><br>The king and the Kṣatriyas must have stood in a particularly close relation. The former being the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] ''par excellence,'' it is to him rather than to the ordinary [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] that we must refer passages like that in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx35_ve1_796> vii. 1, 1, 8.</ref> where it is said that the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], with the consent of the clansmen, gives a settlement to a man: clearly a parallel to the rule found among many peoples that the chief, but only with the consent of the people, can make a grant of unoccupied land. In the same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx36_ve1_796> xii. 8, 3, 19;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 254, n. 1.</ref> it is said that a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] consecrates a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], a clear reference, as the commentator explains, to the practice of the old king consecrating the prince (''kumāra'') who is to succeed him; and again,<ref name=fx37_ve1_796> ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''ibid.,'' 41, 259.</ref> the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] and the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] are regarded as alone complete in contrast with other people, the parallel with the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] here suggesting that the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] ''par excellence'' is meant. On the other hand, the king is sometimes contrasted with the [[राजन्य|Rājanya]].<ref name=fx38_ve1_796> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 17, and see '''[[राजन्य|Rājanya]].'''</ref><br><br>The [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] literature contains elaborate rules<ref name=fx39_ve1_796> See references in Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 395, 396.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 212 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 231 ''et seq.;<br>'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 151 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 4 ''et seq.'' (where practically every passage on the subject is cited or referred to);<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 98 ''et seq.'' (for the Epic parallels).</ref> for the educa-  tion and occupations of Kṣatriyas, but their contents cannot always be traced in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] literature, and their value is questionable.

क्ष-पावन्
<u>'''Kṣa-pāvan,'''</u> ‘protector of the earth,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_797> The word occurs only in the nominative singular as ''kṣapāvān,'' which would be the regular form from a stem ''kṣapāvant;<br>'' but it is probably an irregularity for ''kṣapāvā. Cf.'' Oldenberg. ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 72.</ref> is an epithet of a king,<ref name=fx2_ve1_797> iii. 55, 17.</ref> or denotes a king<ref name=fx3_ve1_797> i. 70, 5;<br> vii. 10, 5;<br> viii. 71, 2;<br> x. 29, 1. ''Cf. [[क्षिति|kṣiti]]-pa,'' ‘guardian of earth,’ ‘king,’ in later Sanskrit.</ref> in the Rigveda. The word is significant, as showing the function of the king as the protector of the tribal territory.

क्षिति
<u>'''Kṣiti'''</u> is in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_798> i. 65, 3;<br> iii. 13, 4;<br> v. 37. 4, etc.</ref> a regular word for ‘dwelling,’ and in particular the ''kṣitir [[ध्रुवा|dhruvā]],'' ‘the secure dwelling,’ is mentioned<ref name=fx2_ve1_798> i. 73, 4 (''cf.'' 2);<br> vii. 88, 7. See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 142.</ref> in a context that shows it, to be equivalent to the '''[[वृजन|Vṛjana]]''' or '''[[ग्राम|Grāma]]''' regarded as a stronghold. From this sense is developed that of the peoples occupying the settlements,<ref name=fx3_ve1_798> Rv. iii. 38, 1;<br> iv. 24, 4;<br> 38, 5;<br> v. 1, 10, etc.</ref> and in particular the five peoples<ref name=fx4_ve1_798> i. 7, 9;<br> 176, 3;<br> v. 35, 2;<br> vi. 46, 7;<br> vii. 75, 4;<br> 79, 1.</ref> (for whom see '''Pañca Janāsaḥ''').

क्षिप्त
<u>'''Kṣipta,'''</u> ‘a wound’ (caused by shooting), or ‘bruise’ (caused by throwing), is mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_799> vi. 109, 1. 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 389.</ref> together with a remedy for it, the '''Pippalī.'''

क्षिप्र-श्येन
<u>'''Kṣipra-śyena,'''</u> ‘swift falcon,’ is the name of a bird in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iii. 14, 11) and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] x. 5, 2, 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

क्षीर
<u>'''Kṣīra,'''</u> ‘milk,’ also called '''Go''' or '''[[पयस्|Payas]],''' played a large part in the economy of the Vedic Indians.<ref name=fx1_ve1_801> The word ''[[क्षीर|kṣīra]]'' does not occur in Rv. ii. vii. It is found in i. 109, 3;<br> 164, 7;<br> viii. 2, 9;<br> ix. 67, 32;<br> x. 87, 16 (= Av. viii. 3, 15). See Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 64, 73 ''et seq.'' See also Av. ii. 26, 4;<br> v. 19, 5;<br> x. 9, 12, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8, 7, etc.</ref> It was taken warm (''[[पक्व|pakva]]''  as it came from the cow,<ref name=fx2_ve1_801>i. 62, 9;<br> 180, 3;<br> iii. 30, 4.</ref> or was used with grain to make a ‘mess cooked with milk’ (''[[क्षीर|kṣīra]]-pākam odanam'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_801>Rv. viii. 77, 10;<br> Av. xiii. 2, 20. ''Cf. [[क्षीर|kṣīra]]-[[श्री|śrī]],'' ‘milk-mixed,’ [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 0, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 57, etc.</ref> It was also used for mixing with Soma ('''[[अभिश्री|Abhiśrī]], [[आशिर्|Āśir]]'''). From it butter ('''[[घृत|Ghṛta]]''') was made. Milk was also curdled, the '''Pūtīkā''' and '''[[क्वल|Kvala]]''' plants, among others, being used for the purpose.<ref name=fx4_ve1_801> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 3, 5.</ref> The curdled milk ('''[[दधि|Dadhi]]''') was undoubtedly used for food; and a kind of cheese is perhaps referred to in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx5_ve1_801> vi. 48, 18.</ref> Goat's milk (''aja-[[क्षीर|kṣīra]]'') is also mentioned.<ref name=fx6_ve1_801> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 2, 13;<br> see '''Aja.'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 63, 226, 226, 268.</ref>

क्षीरौदन
<u>'''Kṣīraudana,'''</u> ‘rice cooked with milk,’ is mentioned frequently in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 5, 3, 4; xi. 5, 7, 5, etc.).<br>==Foot Notes==

क्षुद्र-सूक्तस्
<u>'''Kṣudra-sūktas,'''</u> ‘makers of short hymns,’ is the name given in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve1_803> ii. 2, 2. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 212, and Macdonell, ''Bṛhaddevatā.'' notes on iii. 116.</ref> to the authors of certain hymns of the Rigveda. ''Cf.'' '''[[महासूक्त|Mahāsūkta]].'''

क्षुम्प
<u>'''Kṣumpa'''</u> is a word occurring only in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_804> i. 84, 8.</ref> where it seems to mean a ‘bush.’ The [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_804> v. 16. ''Cf.'' Benfey, ''[[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], Glossar,'' 53.</ref> identifies it with the Ahichatraka, a ‘mushroom.’

क्षुर
<u>'''Kṣura'''</u> occurs three times in the Rigveda. The word appears to have the general sense of ‘blade’<ref name=fx1_ve1_805> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 61, 69. ''Cf.'' 13, 292 (as ‘knife’ in the Epic).</ref> in one passage,<ref name=fx2_ve1_805> i. 166, 10 (''paviṣu kṣurāḥ'' on the fellies of the Maruts' car;<br> possibly ‘razors’ may be meant, as Max Müller says in his note on this passage, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 235, n. 4).</ref> possibly also in another,<ref name=fx3_ve1_805> x. 28, 9, where Sāyaṇa renders it as meaning ‘having claws.’ The later tradition ascribes the swallowing to a goat.</ref> where it is said that the hare swallowed a  [[क्षुर|Kṣura]], and where the sense ‘blade’ is adequate. In the third passage<ref name=fx4_ve1_805> viii. 4, 16 (''saṃ naḥ śiśīhi bhurijor iva kṣuram,'' ‘sharpen us like a razor on a grindstone or stropping apparatus’).</ref> there seems to be a reference to the sharpening of a razor on a grindstone<ref name=fx5_ve1_805> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> (''bhurijos,'' the dual denoting precisely, as Pischel<ref name=fx6_ve1_805> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 243.</ref> points out, the two sides of the apparatus, between which the stone revolved like the modern grindstone). But Muir,<ref name=fx7_ve1_805> ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 466.</ref> following another view of Roth,<ref name=fx8_ve1_805> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[भुरिज्|bhurij]].''</ref> adopts the sense ‘the edge of scissors,’ which, however, hardly suits the other passage, one in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx9_ve1_805> xx. 127, 4.</ref> where a [[क्षुर|Kṣura]] is described as moving about on the ''bhurijos,''<ref name=fx10_ve1_805> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 197, translates ''bhurijos'' by ‘on a strop.’</ref> as the tongue on the lip. The meaning ‘razor’ is perfectly clear in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx11_ve1_805> vi. 68, 1. 3;<br> viii. 2, 7.</ref> where shaving by means of it is mentioned; in many other passages<ref name=fx12_ve1_805> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 4, 5;<br> iii. 1, 2, 7;<br> ''[[क्षुर|kṣura]]-pavi,'' Av. xii. 5, 20. 55;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 5, 7;<br> 5, 5, 6;<br> v. 6, 6, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6, 2, 9. etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 10, 14;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 8;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 5.</ref> either sense is adequate. A ''kṣuro bhṛjvān'' occurs in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]:<ref name=fx13_ve1_805> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 12, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 8, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5, 2, 4.</ref> it seems to denote, as Bloomfield<ref name=fx14_ve1_805> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 418.</ref> suggests, a razor with a strop (in the shape of a small grinding apparatus). [[क्षुर|Kṣura]]-[[धारा|dhārā]]<ref name=fx15_ve1_805> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 13, 9.</ref> denotes ‘the edge of a razor,’ like ''kṣurasya [[धारा|dhārā]].''<ref name=fx16_ve1_805> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 3, 2.</ref> In the Upaniṣads<ref name=fx17_ve1_805> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 20.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 266;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 239-243;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 38 ''et seq.''</ref> a razor-case ([[क्षुर|Kṣura]]-dhāna) is mentioned. See also '''[[श्मश्रु|Śmaśru]].'''

क्षेत्र
<u>'''Kṣetra,'''</u> ‘field.’ The use of this word in the Rigveda points clearly to the existence of separate fields<ref name=fx1_ve1_806> x. 33, 6. ''Cf.'' iii. 31, 15;<br> v. 62, 7.</ref> carefully measured off,<ref name=fx2_ve1_806> i. 110, 5.</ref> though in some passages the meaning is less definite,  indicating cultivated land generally.<ref name=fx3_ve1_806> i. 100, 18;<br> ix. 85, 4;<br> 91, 6;<br> ''Kṣetrajeṣa,'' i. 33, 15, ‘acquisition of land’;<br> ''kṣetrā-sā,'' iv. 38, 1, ‘gaining land’;<br> ''kṣetraṃ-jaya,'' ‘conquering cultivated land,’ Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 11. The wider sense of ‘place’ also occurs, v. 2, 3;<br> 45, 9;<br> vi. 47, 20, etc., and often later.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_806> iv. 18, 5;<br> v. 31, 4;<br> x. 1, 18;<br> xi. 1, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 1, 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 24, 2, etc.</ref> and later the sense of a separate field is clearly marked, though the more general use is also found.<ref name=fx5_ve1_806> Av. ii. 29, 3;<br> xiv. 2, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 1, 15. 16, etc.</ref> The deity Kṣetrasya Pati,<ref name=fx6_ve1_806> Rv. iv. 37, 1, 2;<br> vii. 35, 10;<br> x. 66, 13;<br> Av. ii. 8, 5;<br> ''kṣetrasya [[पत्नी|patnī]],'' ‘Mistress of the Field,’ 12, 1;<br> ''kṣetrāṇāṃ patiḥ,'' ‘Lord of Fields,’ Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 18.</ref> ‘Lord of the Field,’ should probably be understood as the god presiding over each field, just as Vāstoṣ Pati presides over each dwelling.<ref name=fx7_ve1_806> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 138.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 1, 1, 8, where the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], with the consent of the people, gives a settlement to a man: that is, presumably assigns to him a definite [[क्षेत्र|Kṣetra]] for his own, probably measured out as recorded in Rv. i. 110, 5.</ref> It is a fair conclusion from the evidence that the system of separate holdings already existed in early Vedic times.^8 See also '''[[उर्वरा|Urvarā]], Khilya.'''

क्षेत्रिय
<u>'''Kṣetriya'''</u> is a disease which is mentioned several times in the Atharvaveda, and against which three hymns are specially directed.<ref name=fx1_ve1_807> ii. 8. 10;<br> iii. 7. ''Cf.'' ii. 14, 5;<br> iv. 18, 7.</ref> It is also mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_807> xv. 1.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_807> ii. 5, 6, 1-3, where the form is Kṣetrī, explained as a demon causing illness, merely an incorrect version of Av. iii. 10.</ref> The commentators on the Atharvaveda agree in taking it to be a hereditary disease. The word may mean ‘organic,’<ref name=fx4_ve1_807> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> or possibly ‘produced in the field,’ as a theory of its origin. What disease is really intended is quite uncertain. Weber<ref name=fx5_ve1_807> ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 145;<br> 13, 150 ''et seq.:'' 17, 208;<br> ''Naxatra,'' 2, 292.</ref> considered that the aim of the [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] hymns was to drive away injury threatening the fields, but this is improbable. Bloomfield<ref name=fx6_ve1_807> ''Atharvaveda,'' 60.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 286 ''et seq.;<br>'' Whitney, Transiation of the Atharvaveda, 48, 49;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 391, 392;<br> Speijer, ''De ceremonia apud Indos quœ jātakarma vocatur,'' 76-83;<br> Pāṇini, v. 2, 92, with the Kāśikā Vṛtti.</ref> suggests ‘scrofula’ or ‘syphilis.’ The remedies mentioned throw no light on the symptoms. 

क्षेम-धृत्वन् पौण्डरीक
<u>'''Kṣema-dhṛtvan Pauṇḍarīka'''</u> (‘descendant of Puṇḍarīka’) is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_808> xxii. 18, 7. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 32. Later, the name is Kṣema-[[धन्वन्|dhanvan]], Harivaṃśa, 824, etc.</ref> as having sacrificed on the bank of the river '''[[सुदामन्|Sudāman]].'''

क्षैमि
<u>'''Kṣaimi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Kṣema,’ is the patronymic of '''Sudakṣiṇa''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 6, 3; 7, 1, etc.; 8, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

क्षोणी
<u>'''Kṣoṇī.'''</u>--This word, when used in the plural, denotes, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary and Ludwig,<ref name=fx1_ve1_810>Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 247.</ref> in several passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_810> i. 57, 4;<br> 173, 7;<br> viii. 3, 10;<br> 13, 17;<br> x. 95. 19. In ii. 34, 13;<br> x. 22, 9, the sense is doubtful.</ref> the free retainers of the king. Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve1_810> Bezzenberger, ''Beiträge,'' 11, 327.</ref> at one time thought it referred to the wives of the king, pointing to polygamy; but later<ref name=fx4_ve1_810> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 279, 283.</ref> he concluded that it means certain divine wives.

क्षौम
<u>'''Kṣauma,'''</u> ‘a linen garment,’ is mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iii. 6, 7, etc.) and in the Sūtras.<br>==Foot Notes==

क्ष्विङ्का
<u>'''Kṣviṅkā'''</u> is mentioned once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_812> x. 87, 7.</ref> as a bird of '''prey.''' The word also occurs in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_812> v. 5, 15, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> where the commentary absurdly explains it as ‘a red-mouthed female ape’ (''rakta-mukhī vānarī''). 

ख
<u>'''Kha'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_813> Rv. viii. 77, 3;<br> 91, 7;<br> x. 156, 3, where only the Kha is referred to.<br><br>''Cf.'' the adjective ''[[सु-ख|su-kha]],'' ‘having a good axle-hole,’ ‘running easily’;<br> later, ‘agreeable.’</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_813> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 12, 1 (Mādhyaṃdina;<br> v. 10, 1 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> the hole in the nave of the wheel in which the axle is inserted. There was a difference, it seems, in the size of the hole in the wheel of a cart ('''Anas''') and of a chariot ('''[[रथ|Ratha]]''').<ref name=fx3_ve1_813> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 1, 3, 6;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 333.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 247.</ref> See also 1. '''Yuga.'''

खङ्ग
<u>'''Khaṅga.'''</u> See '''[[खड्ग|Khaḍga]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

खड्ग
<u>'''Khaḍga'''</u> is the reading in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_815> iii. 14, 21.</ref> of the name of an animal which, in the text of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_815> xxiv. 40.</ref> variously appears as [[खङ्ग|Khaṅga]] and [[खड्ग|Khaḍga]]. The rhinoceros seems clearly to be meant.<ref name=fx3_ve1_815> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 86.</ref> In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_815> xiv. 33, 26 (''khāḍga-[[कवच|kavaca]] aśvaratha'')</ref> a rhinoceros hide is mentioned as the covering of a chariot.

खण्डिक औद्भारि
<u>'''Khaṇḍika Audbhāri'''</u> (‘descendant of Udbhāra’) is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_816> xi. 8, 4, 1.</ref> as a teacher of '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]],''' and in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_816> i. 4, 12, where [[षण्डिक|Ṣaṇḍika]] is the reading of the MSS.</ref> as having been defeated by [[केशिन्|Keśin]] as a sacrificer. A Khāṇḍika appears in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_816> Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 20.</ref> as an enemy of [[केशिन्|Keśin]].

खदिर
<u>'''Khadira'''</u> is mentioned frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_817> iii. 53, 19.</ref> onwards<ref name=fx2_ve1_817> Av. iii. 6, 1;<br> v. 5, 5;<br> viii. 8, 3;<br> x. 6, 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 9, 3, etc. So ''khādira,'' ‘made of [[खदिर|Khadira]] wood,’ [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 7, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 3, 20;<br> iii. 6, 2, 12 etc.</ref> as a tree with hard wood<ref name=fx3_ve1_817> Av. x. 6, 6.</ref> --the ''Acacia catechu.'' The '''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]]''' is referred to as engrafting itself upon it in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_817> iii. 6, 1. ''Cf.'' viii. 8, 3.</ref>  and from it the climbing plant '''[[अरुन्धती|Arundhatī]]''' is said to have sprung.<ref name=fx5_ve1_817> Av. v. 5. 5.</ref> The ''[[स्रुव|sruva]]'' or sacrificial ladle is spoken of as having been made from it,<ref name=fx6_ve1_817> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 7, 1.</ref> no doubt because of its hardness. It is in the same passage also said to have sprung from the sap (''rasa'') of the Gāyatrī. There is no clear reference to Catechu having been prepared from its core,<ref name=fx7_ve1_817> It is called ''bahu-sāra,'' ‘of great strength,’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 4, 9.</ref> as it was later. The core (''sāra'') was used for making amulets.<ref name=fx8_ve1_817> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 58, 58.</ref>

ख-द्योत
<u>'''Kha-dyota'''</u> (‘sky-illuminator’), ‘the firefly,’ is mentioned in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 7, 3. 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

खनित्र
<u>'''Khanitra,'''</u> a ‘shovel’ or ‘spade’ for digging, is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_819> i. 179, 6 (possibly metaphorical: see Oldenberg. ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 172;<br> the passage is obscure).</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_819> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 2, 4, etc.</ref>

खनित्रिम
<u>'''Khanitrima,'''</u> ‘produced by digging,’ as an epithet of ''āpaḥ,'' ‘waters,’ clearly refers to artificial water channels used for irrigation, as practised in the times of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_820> vii. 49, 2.</ref> and the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_820> i. 6, 4;<br> xix. 2, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 466.</ref>

खर
<u>'''Khara,'''</u> ‘ass,’ is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve1_821> iii. 2, 4.</ref> where a team of asses is alluded to. Probably the passages in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_821> v. 1, 2, 15;<br> xiv. 1, 2, 17;<br> 2, 2, 30.</ref> where the word is used to denote an earth mound on which the sacrificial vessels were placed, presuppose the sense of ‘ass,’ the mound being shaped in this form.<ref name=fx3_ve1_821> ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> 

खर्गला
<u>'''Khargalā'''</u> is an ‘owl’ or other nocturnal bird mentioned in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_822> vii. 104, 17. ''Cf.'' [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 107;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref>

खर्जूर
<u>'''Kharjūra'''</u> is the name of a tree (''Phœnix silvestris'') which is mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_823> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 9, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 10;<br> xxxvi. 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 63.</ref>

खल
<u>'''Khala,'''</u> the ‘threshing-floor,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_824> x. 48, 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 10.</ref> and the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_824> xi. 3, 9;<br> ''[[खल|khala]]-ja,'' ‘produced on a threshing-floor,’ viii. 6, 15;<br> ''khalya,'' ‘being on a threshing-floor,’ Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238.</ref> See '''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]].'''

खल-कुल
<u>'''Khala-kula'''</u> is a word occurring in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_825> vi. 3. 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]). ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien'' 1, 355.</ref> where Sāyaṇa glosses it by Kulattha, a kind of pulse (''Dolichos uniflorus'').

खल्व
<u>'''Khalva'''</u> is some sort of grain or leguminous plant, perhaps, as Weber<ref name=fx1_ve1_826> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 355.</ref> thinks, the ''Phaselus radiatus.'' It is mentioned with other grains of all sorts in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_826> xviii. 12, where Mahīdhara glosses it by ''caṇaka,'' ‘chick-pea.’</ref> and as being crushed with the '''[[दृषद्|Dṛṣad]]''' in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_826> ii. 31. 1;<br> v. 23, 8.</ref> It occurs also in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_826> vi. 3. 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 241.</ref> where Śaṅkara glosses it with ''niṣpāva.''

खाण्डव
<u>'''Khāṇḍava'''</u> is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve1_827> v. 1, 1.</ref> as one of the boundaries of '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]].''' There seems no reason to doubt its identity with the famous [[खाण्डव|Khāṇḍava]] forest of the Mahābhārata. The name occurs also in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_827> xxv. 3, 6.</ref> and the Śāṭyāyanaka.<ref name=fx3_ve1_827> Max Müller, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' ^2 iv. ci.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78.</ref> 

खादि
<u>'''Khādi'''</u> occurs frequently in the Rigveda denoting either anklets<ref name=fx1_ve1_828> v. 54, 11, and perhaps 53, 4.</ref> or armlets,<ref name=fx2_ve1_828> This is what Khādis on the shoulders must mean, i. 166, 9;<br> vii. 56, 13.</ref> or sometimes rings on the hands.<ref name=fx3_ve1_828> i. 168, 3;<br> ''[[खादि|khādi]]-[[हस्त|hasta]],'' ‘with rings on the hands,’ 5, 58, 2. So Roth takes Khādin in vi. 16, 40;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' Khādin occurs also in ii. 34, 2;<br> x. 38, 1.</ref> Max Müller<ref name=fx4_ve1_828> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 120, 230.</ref> considers that the word means quoits, the later [[चक्र|Cakra]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_828> ''Cf. [[वृष-खादि|vṛṣa-khādi]],'' Rv. i. 64, 10.</ref> The rings were sometimes of gold.<ref name=fx6_ve1_828> ''[[हिरण्य|Hiraṇya]]-[[खादि|khādi]],'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śranta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 5, 12;<br> viii. 23, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 149.</ref>

खारी
<u>'''Khārī'''</u> designates a measure of Soma in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_829> iv. 32, 17. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 280.</ref>

खार्गलि
<u>'''Khārgali,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[खर्गला|Khargalā]] or [[खृगल|Khṛgala]],’ is the metronymic or patronymic of Luśākapi.<ref name=fx1_ve1_830> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxx. 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 4, 3.</ref>

खिल
<u>'''1. Khila,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_831> Av. vii. 115, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 3, 4, 1.</ref> '''Khilya'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_831> Rv. vi. 28, 2;<br> x. 142, 3.</ref> appear to have the same meaning. According to Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_831> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' So Whitney on Av., ''loc. cit.''</ref> these terms denote the waste land lying between cultivated fields; but he admits that this sense does not suit the passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_831> vi. 28, 2.</ref> in which it is said that the god places the worshipper on an unbroken Khilya (''abhinne khilye''), and he accordingly conjectures the reading ''akhilyabhinne,'' ‘land unbroken by barren strips.’ Pischel<ref name=fx5_ve1_831> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 205.</ref> thinks that the meaning intended is broad lands, which were used for the pasturing of the cattle of the community, and were not broken up by cultivated fields. Oldenberg,<ref name=fx6_ve1_831> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 385, 386.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236;<br> Ludwig. Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 499;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiutic Society,'' 1910, 228.</ref> however, points out that the sense is rather the land which lay between cultivated fields, but which need not be deemed to have been unfertile, as Roth thought. This agrees with the fact that in Vedic times separate fields were already known: see '''[[क्षेत्र|Kṣetra]].''' 

खिल
<u>'''2. Khila'''</u> as a designation of certain hymns appended to the received text of the Rigveda occurs only in the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period.<ref name=fx1_ve1_832> See Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 16 ''et seq.''</ref> The term is a metaphorical application of the preceding word, ‘a space not filled up,’ ‘a supplement.’

खृगल
<u>'''Khṛgala,'''</u> or, as the Paippalāda recension of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_833> iii. 9. 3.</ref> has it, Khugila, is an obscure expression found in two passages only--once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_833> ii. 39, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 340;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 98.</ref> and once in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_833/> In the former the meaning ‘crutch’ seems required; in the latter Sāyaṇa glosses it by ‘armour’ (''tanu-trāṇa''), but the sense is quite uncertain.

खेल
<u>'''Khela'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_834> i. 116, 15.</ref> where Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve1_834> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 171-173.</ref> considers that a god, Vivasvant, is meant, and that races were run in his honour, explaining thus the phrase ''ājā khelasya,'' as ‘in the race of [[खेल|Khela]].’ Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_834> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> thinks that a man is meant, and Sieg,<ref name=fx4_ve1_834> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 127, 128.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 4. 28.</ref> following Sāyaṇa, sees in him a king whose [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] was [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]]. See also '''[[अंशु|Aṃśu]].'''

गङ्गा
<u>'''Gaṅgā,'''</u> the modern Ganges, is mentioned directly in the Rigveda only once, in the [[नदी|Nadī]]-[[स्तुति|stuti]] or ‘Praise of Rivers.’<ref name=fx1_ve1_835> x. 75, 5.</ref> But it is also referred to in the derivative form ''gāṅgyaḥ'' as an epithet of '''[[उरुकक्ष|Urukakṣa]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_835> The reference to the [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]] remains, even if with Oldenberg (''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 396) we assume that a thicket i meant, and not a proper name (''cf.'' Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 2, 288). See also Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1898, 563, n. 1.</ref> The name of this river does not occur<br><br><ref name=fx2_ve1_835> vi. 45, 31.</ref>  in the other Saṃhitā, but appears in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_835> xiii. 5, 4, 11. The victory on the [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]] represents the farthest extent of [[भरत|Bharata]] or Kuru rule. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 23, and a verse in the Vaitāna [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxxiv. 9, where the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] is also referred to.</ref> where victories of '''[[भरत|Bharata]] [[दौःषन्ति|Dauḥṣanti]]''' on both [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]] and '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' are referred to, and in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx5_ve1_835> ii. 20.</ref> especial honour is assigned to those who dwell between the [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]] and the [[यमुना|Yamunā]], this being. To doubt, the region in which that text originated. The identification of the [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]] with the Apayā<ref name=fx6_ve1_835> Rv. iii. 23, 4.</ref> made by Ludwig<ref name=fx7_ve1_835> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 4. 5.</ref> must be rejected: see '''[[आपया|Āpayā]].'''

गज
<u>'''Gaja,'''</u> the common name of the elephant in Epic<ref name=fx1_ve1_836> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 265, 269.</ref> and later Sanskrit, is only found in the late Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_836> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 39.</ref> See '''[[हस्तिन्|Hastin]].'''

गणक
<u>'''Gaṇaka,'''</u> ‘an astrologer,’ occurs in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_837> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 15, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber. ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 78.</ref> See also [[नक्षत्रदर्श|Nakṣatradarśa]].

गन्धर्वायण बालेय
<u>'''Gandharvāyaṇa Bāleya'''</u> (‘descendant of Bali’) '''[[आग्निवेश्य|Āgniveśya]]''' is mentioned as a [[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xx. 25).<br>==Foot Notes==

गन्धार
<u>'''Gandhāra'''</u> is a later form of the name of the people called '''[[गन्धारि|Gandhāri]]''' in the Rigveda and Atharvaveda. In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_839> vi. 14, 1. 2. See Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 399, n.;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 219, n. On the other hand, Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 15. 106, thought the passage meant that the Gandhāras were near the writer.</ref> the Gandhāras are referred to as being distant from the writer. See also '''[[गान्धार|Gāndhāra]].''' 

गन्धारि
<u>'''Gandhāri'''</u> is the name of a people in the north-west of India. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_840> i. 126, 7.</ref> the good wool of the sheep of the Gandhāris is referred to. The Gandhāris are also mentioned with the '''Mūjavants, Angas,''' and '''Magadhas''' in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_840> v. 22, 14. The latter two tribes are apparently the Eastern limit of the poet's knowledge, the two former the Northern.</ref> Gandhāris<ref name=fx3_ve1_840> Hiraṇyakeśi Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 6;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 6, 18.</ref> or Gāndhāris<ref name=fx4_ve1_840> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxi. 13.</ref> are also spoken of in the Śrauta Sūtras.<ref name=fx5_ve1_840> See Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 553.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve1_840> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 30, 31.</ref> considers that they were settled in Vedic times on the south bank of the '''[[कुभा|Kubhā]]''' up to its mouth in the Indus, and for some distance down the east side of the Indus itself. They later formed a portion of the Persian empire, and detachments of Gandarians accompanied Xerxes in his expedition against Greece.<ref name=fx7_ve1_840> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 23.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 206.</ref>

गभस्ति
<u>'''Gabhasti'''</u> denotes, according to Roth,<ref name=fx1_ve1_841> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the pole of a chariot in the epithet ''[[स्यूम-गभस्ति|syūma-gabhasti]],'' ‘having reins as a pole,’ used of the car of the gods in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_841> i. 122, 5;<br> vii. 71, 3.</ref> and independently in the plural in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_841> ii. 7, 13, 4.</ref> The meaning is, however, doubtful.<ref name=fx4_ve1_841> See Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 55.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx5_ve1_841> ''Op. cit., s.v.''</ref> himself suggests that ''[[स्यूम-गभस्ति|syūma-gabhasti]]'' may refer to a sort of double reins.

गय
<u>'''1. Gaya,'''</u> ‘house,’ is a common word in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_842> i. 74, 2;<br> v. 10, 3;<br> 44, 7;<br> vi. 2, 8, etc.</ref> and sometimes occurs later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_842> Av. vi. 3, 3;<br> 84, 1;<br> '''Vājasaneyi''' Saṃhitā, xxvii. 3.</ref> As its sense includes the inmates as well as their belongings, it is equivalent to ‘household.’

गय प्लात
<u>'''2. Gaya Plāta'''</u> (‘son of Plati’) is referred to in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_843> x. 63, 17;<br> 64, 17 (as son of [[प्लति|Plati]]).</ref> two hymns of which he clearly claims to have composed, and which are attributed to him in the Sarvānukramaṇī and the  [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_843> v. 2.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_843> i. 14, 4. ''Cf.'' also the [[खिल|Khila]] after Rv. v. 51, 15;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 214.</ref> he appears with [[असित|Asita]] and [[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]] as a half-mythical magician.<ref name=fx4_ve1_843> Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 403.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 460.</ref>

गर
<u>'''1. Gara,'''</u> ‘poison,’ is referred to in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_844> v. 18, 13. ''Cf. gara'' alone, [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xix. 4, 2 (see ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 33);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 9, 10;<br> ''gara-gir,'' ‘poisoned,’ [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1, 9;<br> xix. 4, 2. 10.</ref> in the compound ''gara-gīrṇa,'' ‘poisoned.’ In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_844> xi. 5, 8, 6.</ref> it means simply a ‘fluid.’

गर
<u>'''2. Gara'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_845> ix. 2, 16. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 52.</ref> as the author of a Sāman or Chant, and as a friend of Indra.

गर्ग
<u>'''Garga'''</u> is the name of a sage who is not mentioned in any of the Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_846> The authorship of Rv. vi. 47 is attributed to [[गर्ग|Garga]] [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]] in the Anukramaṇī.</ref> but his descendants, the ''Gargāḥ Prāvareyāḥ,'' are referred to in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_846> xiii. 12. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 374.</ref> [[गर्ग|Garga]] himself does not occur till the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period.<ref name=fx3_ve1_846> [[गर्ग|Garga]]-trirātra, [[गर्ग|Garga]]-tryaha, a three-night or three-day feast of [[गर्ग|Garga]]. See Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 22. 2;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiii. 2, 8.</ref>

गर्गर
<u>'''Gargara,'''</u> apparently the designation of a musical instrument, is mentioned once in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_847> viii. 69, 9. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 144, n. 1;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 289.</ref>

गर्त
<u>'''Garta'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_848> vi. 20, 9. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 246, 247. Zimmer wrongly takes this passage to refer to standing in the car. See Hopkins. ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 238, 239;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 48, and ''cf. [[गर्त|garta]]-sad,'' ‘sitting on the car seat,’ in Rv. ii. 33. 11.</ref> primarily denotes the seat of the chariot on which the archer sat. It seems to have been of considerable  size, being described as ''bṛhant,''<ref name=fx2_ve1_848> v. 62, 8;<br> 68, 5.</ref> ‘large.’ The word then comes to denote the chariot<ref name=fx3_ve1_848> So probably in v. 62, 5;<br> ''gartā-ruh,'' ‘mounting the chariot,’ in Rv. i. 124, 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 5, may refer merely to mounting the seat. The passage is obscure;<br> see Geldner, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 22.</ref> itself, either really or metaphorically.<ref name=fx4_ve1_848> vii. 64, 4 (of the hymn).</ref>

गर्दभ
<u>'''Gardabha,'''</u> ‘the ass,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_849> iii. 53, 23. A car drawn by asses is referred to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 9;<br> see also '''[[खर|Khara]].'''</ref> as inferior to the horse. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā he again appears as inferior to the horse,<ref name=fx2_ve1_849> v. 1, 2, 1. 2.</ref> but at the same time as the best bearer of burdens (''bhāra-bhāritama'') among animals.<ref name=fx3_ve1_849> v. 1, 5, 5.</ref> The same authority styles the ass ''[[द्वि-रेतस्|dvi-retas]],'' ‘having double seed,’<ref name=fx4_ve1_849> v. 1, 5, 5;<br> vii. 1, 1, 2;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 57, 4 (Oertel, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 177-180): of the [[रासभ|Rāsabha]], Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 1, 23.</ref> in allusion to his breeding with the mare as well as the she-ass. The smallness of the young of the ass, and his capacity for eating, are both referred to.<ref name=fx5_ve1_849> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 5, 5.</ref> The disagreeable cry of the animal is mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx6_ve1_849> viii. 6, 10.</ref> and in allusion to this the term ‘ass’ is applied opprobriously to a singer in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx7_ve1_849> i. 29, 5.</ref> A hundred asses are spoken of as a gift to a singer in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn.<ref name=fx8_ve1_849> viii. 56, 3.</ref> The mule (''[[अश्वतर|aśvatara]]'') is the offspring of an ass and a mare, the latter, like the ass, being called ''[[द्विरेतस्|dviretas]],''<ref name=fx9_ve1_849> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 2. 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 6;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 57, 4.</ref> ‘receiving double seed,’ for similar reasons. The male ass is often also termed '''[[रासभ|Rāsabha]].''' The female ass, Gardabhī, is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx10_ve1_849> x. 1, 4.</ref> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx11_ve1_849> i. 4, 8. For other references to the ass as [[गर्दभ|Gardabha]], see Av. v. 31, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 34;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 1, 9;<br> xii. 7, 1, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 232, 233.</ref>

गर्दभी-मुख
<u>'''Gardabhī-mukha'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_850> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 384.</ref> 

गर्दभी-विपीत
<u>'''Gardabhī-vipīta,'''</u> or '''Gardabhī-vibhīta,''' is the name of a teacher who was a [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]] and a contemporary of '''[[जनक|Janaka]],''' mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].(**  1) iv. 1, 11 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 1, 5 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).<br>==Foot Notes==

गर्मुत्
<u>'''Garmut'''</u> is the name of a kind of wild bean mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_852> ii. 4, 4, 1. 2.</ref> The [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_852> x. 11.</ref> has the form Ganmut, which is probably a false reading. The adjective ''gārmuta,'' ‘made from the [[गर्मुत्|Garmut]] bean,’ is found in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx3_ve1_852> ii. 2, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.</ref>

गलुन्त
<u>'''Galunta'''</u> is a word occurring only once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_853> vi. 83, 3.</ref> apparently in the sense of ‘swelling,’<ref name=fx2_ve1_853> Bloomfield, ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' October, 1887, xvi;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 505.</ref> but Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve1_853> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 343.</ref> translates it by ‘neck.’

गलूनस आर्क्षाकायण
<u>'''Galūnasa Ārkṣākāyaṇa'''</u> (‘descendant of Ṛkṣāka’) is mentioned as a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 38, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

गवय
<u>'''Gavaya,'''</u> the name of a species of ox (''Bos gavacus'') occurs frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_855> iv. 21, 8.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_855> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 10;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 28;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8;<br> iii. 34;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 3, 9;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 3, 14, etc.</ref> It is mentioned with '''[[गौर|Gaura]]''' and '''[[महिष|Mahiṣa]]''' in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_855> xxiv. 28.</ref> where also a wild [[गवय|Gavaya]] is spoken of.<ref name=fx4_ve1_855> xiii. 49;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Samhitā, iv. 2, 10, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 17;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 17.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83, 84.</ref>

गवाशिर्
<u>'''Gavāśir,'''</u> ‘mixed with milk,’ is a frequent epithet of '''Soma''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_856> i. 137, 1;<br> 187, 9;<br> ii. 41, 3;<br> iii. 32, 2;<br> 42, 1. 7;<br> viii. 52, 10;<br> 101, 10. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 279.</ref> 

गव्-इष्टि
<u>'''Gav-iṣṭi'''</u> (lit. ‘desire of cows’) in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_857> i. 91, 23;<br> iii. 47, 4;<br> v. 63, 5;<br> vi. 31, 3;<br> 47, 20;<br> 59, 7;<br> viii. 24, 2;<br> ix. 76, 2. So Av. iv. 24, 5.</ref> denotes ‘conflict’ or ‘battle,’ evidently with reference to cattle raids. [[गव्या|Gavyā]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_857> Rv. vii. 18, 7.</ref> is similarly used.

गवि-ष्ठिर आत्रेय
<u>'''Gavi-ṣṭhira Ātreya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Atri'''’) is mentioned as a '''[[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]],''' or seer, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_858> v. 1, 12;<br> x. 150, 5.</ref> and the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_858> iv. 29, 5. See also Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 14. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 126.</ref>

गवीधुका
<u>'''Gavīdhukā,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_859> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 3, 2.</ref> '''Gavedhukā,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_859> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 13;<br> 3, 1, 10;<br> xiv. 1, 2, 19.</ref> is the name of a species of grass (''Coix barbata''). It is also referred to in the adjectival forms ''gāvīdhuka''<ref name=fx3_ve1_859> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 7, 1;<br> 9, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5;<br> iv. 3, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 5.</ref> and ''gāvedhuka.''<ref name=fx4_ve1_859> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 11. 13;<br> 3, 1, 10;<br> 3, 7.</ref> It was boiled with rice<ref name=fx5_ve1_859> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 3, 2.</ref> (''gavīdhukāyavāgā'') or barley<ref name=fx6_ve1_859> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 1, 1, 8.</ref> (''gavedhukā-saktavaḥ'') in preparing gruel.

गव्य
<u>'''Gavya.'''</u> See '''[[गव्यूति|Gavyūti]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गव्या
<u>'''Gavyā.'''</u> See '''[[गव्इष्टि|Gaviṣṭi]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गव्यूति
<u>'''Gavyūti'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_862> i. 25, 16;<br> iii. 62, 16;<br> v. 66, 3;<br> vii. 77, 4, etc.</ref> means, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_862> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> grass land for the pasturing of cattle, in which sense [[गव्य|Gavya]] is also found.<ref name=fx3_ve1_862> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 28;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 3b.</ref> Thence it derives the sense of a measure of distance found in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_862> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 13, 12.</ref> Geldner, on the other hand, takes the original meaning to be ‘road,’ real<ref name=fx6_ve1_862> Rv. i. 25, 16.</ref> or metaphorical,<ref name=fx7_ve1_862> Rv. vi. 47, 20;<br> x. 14, 2.</ref> thence a measure of distance,<ref name=fx8_ve1_862> Rv. viii. 60, 20, and n. 4.</ref> and finally ‘land.’<ref name=fx9_ve1_862> Rv. iii. 62, 16;<br> vii. 62, 5;<br> 65, 4;<br> viii. 5, 6.</ref>(**  5) ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 290, 291. 

गाङ्ग्य
<u>'''Gāṅgya,'''</u> ‘being on the Ganges,’ is the epithet of '''[[उरुकक्ष|Urukakṣa]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_863> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 2, 288;<br> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 28.</ref> or of a thicket<ref name=fx2_ve1_863> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 398.</ref> in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_863> vi. 45, 31.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 291, n.</ref>

गाङ्ग्यायनि
<u>'''Gāṅgyāyani,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[गाङ्ग्य|Gāṅgya]],’ occurs as the patronymic of '''[[चित्र|Citra]]''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_864> i. 1. There is a ''v.l.'' [[गार्ग्यायणि|Gārgyāyaṇi]]. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 395.</ref>

गातु
<u>'''Gātu.'''</u> See '''[[गाथा|Gāthā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गाथा
<u>'''Gāthā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_866> viii. 32, 1;<br> 71, 14;<br> 98, 9;<br> ix. 99, 4;<br> ''gātha,'' i. 167, 6;<br> ix. 11, 4;<br> ''gātha-pati,'' ‘lord of song,’ i. 43, 4;<br> ''[[गाथा|gāthā]]-nī,'' ‘leading a song,’ i. 190, 1;<br> viii. 92, 2;<br> ''ṛjugātha,'' ‘singing correctly,’ v. 44, 5;<br> ''[[गाथिन्|gāthin]],'' ‘singer,’ i. 7, 1. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 65.</ref> usually means only ‘song,’ ‘verse,’ like [[गातु|Gātu]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_866> i. 151, 2;<br> ii. 20, 5;<br> iii. 4, 4;<br> iv. 4, 6;<br> v. 87, 8;<br> x. 20, 4;<br> 122, 2.</ref> In one passage,<ref name=fx3_ve1_866> x. 85, 6.</ref> however, it already has a more special sense, as it is classed with '''[[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]]''' and '''[[रैभी|Raibhī]],''' a collocation repeatedly found later.<ref name=fx4_ve1_866> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 11, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], v. 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 32;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 6, 8, where [[रैभी|Raibhī]] does not occur;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 12.</ref> The commentators identify the three terms with certain verses of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_866> Viz., [[गाथा|Gāthā]] = Av. xx. 127, 12 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]] = Av. xx. 127, 1-3;<br> [[रैभी|Raibhī]] = Av. xx. 127, 4-6;<br> while ''ibid.,'' 7-10, are known as Pārikṣityaḥ (''scil., ṛcaḥ'').</ref> but Oldenberg<ref name=fx6_ve1_866> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 238. Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 689 ''et seq.,'' seems to accept the identification even for the Rigveda.</ref> has shown that this identification is incorrect for the Rigveda. Gāthās are often mentioned elsewhere,<ref name=fx7_ve1_866> Av. x. 10, 20;<br> xv. 6, 4 (distinct from [[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]]);<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 4, 16;<br> xi. 5, 7, 10;<br> xiii. 1, 5, 6;<br> 4, 2, 8;<br> 5, 4, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 10 (distinct from [[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]]);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 9, etc.</ref> and are referred to as metrical in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx8_ve1_866> ii. 3, 6, with Keith's note;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 7, 10.</ref> where the '''Ṛc, [[कुम्ब्या|Kumbyā]],''' and [[गाथा|Gāthā]] are classed as forms of verse. The [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve1_866> vii. 18. The story of [[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]] is described as ''śata-gātham,'' ‘told in a hundred Gāthās.’</ref> distinguishes between Ṛc and [[गाथा|Gāthā]] as divine and human respectively. According to the usage of the  Brāhmaṇas and the liturgical literature, as stated by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, the Gāthās are, though religious in content, distinguished from Ṛc, [[यजुस्|Yajus]], and Sāman as nonVedic--that is, are not Mantras. This view is consistent with the fact that the phrase '''[[यज्ञ-गाथा|Yajña-gāthā]],''' meaning a verse summarizing a sacrificial usage, is not rare. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx10_ve1_866> xiii. 5, 4, etc., and see xiii. 4, 2, 8, where the Gāthās are plainly Dānastutis, or ‘praises of gifts,’ just as the [[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]] verses are declared to be in the Bṛhaddevatā, iii. 154.</ref> preserves several Gāthās, which generally accord with this description as epitomizing the sacrifices of famous kings, and the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx11_ve1_866> iii. 7, 3.</ref> states that a [[गाथा|Gāthā]] is sung at a wedding. Sometimes<ref name=fx12_ve1_866> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 2, 6. So Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 98, takes Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 6, 8, where Sāyaṇa hesitates between identifying the two and distinguishing them. It seems reasonable to regard [[गाथा|Gāthā]] as the wider term which covers, but is not coextensive with, [[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]].<br><br>''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa's example of a [[गाथा|Gāthā]] in his commentary on [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 3, 6: ''prātaḥ [[प्रातर्|prātar]] anṛtaṃ te vadanti,'' ‘they every morning tell an untruth,’ which is clearly not a [[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]].<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 689 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Episches im Vedischen Ritual,'' 4 ''et seq.;<br>'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 493.</ref> [[गाथा|Gāthā]] is qualified as [[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]], where it must be a eulogy of a generous donor.

गाथिन्
<u>'''Gāthin'''</u> is mentioned as the son of '''[[कुशिक|Kuśika]]''' and father of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' in the Sarvānukramaṇī. It is difficult to say whether this tradition is correct; it derives some support from the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 18), where reference is made to the divine lore (''[[दैव|daiva]] veda'') of the Gāthins, which is said to be shared by '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' as a result of his adoption by '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]].''' See '''[[गाथिन|Gāthina]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गाथिन
<u>'''Gāthina.'''</u>--The sons of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] are described in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_868> vii. 18. ''Cf.'' Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 18;<br> Weber, ''Episches im Vedischen Ritual,'' 16, n. 3.</ref> as Gāthinas, or descendants of [[गाथिन्|Gāthin]], who, according to tradition, was their grandfather;<ref name=fx2_ve1_868> ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 348 ''et seq.;<br>'' Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 32 ''et seq.''</ref> and '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' himself is styled [[गाथिन|Gāthina]] in the Sarvānukramaṇī. 

गां-दम
<u>'''Gāṃ-dama'''</u> is the form in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_869> xxi. 14, 20.</ref> of the name of '''Ekayāvan,''' which in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_869> ii. 7, 11, 2. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transac tions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 69.</ref> is read as Kāṃdama.

गान्धार
<u>'''Gāndhāra,'''</u> ‘a king of Gandhāra’ named '''[[नग्नजित्|Nagnajit]],''' is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_870> vii. 34. in the list of teachers who handed down the knowledge of the substitute for Soma.</ref> In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_870> viii. 1, 4, 10.</ref> he or some descendant figures as '''[[स्वर्जित् नाग्नजित|Svarjit Nāgnajita]]''' or [[नग्नजित्|Nagnajit]], and as giving an opinion on the ritual, which is rejected with the observation that the author was merely a princely person (''[[राजन्य-बन्धु|rājanya-bandhu]]'').

गार्गी वाचक्नवी
<u>'''Gārgī Vācaknavī'''</u> is referred to in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_871> iii. 6, 1;<br> 8, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 118.</ref> as a female contemporary and rival of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]].'''

गार्गी-पुत्र
<u>'''Gārgī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of Gargī,’ occurs as the name of three teachers in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30). The earliest of these three was the pupil of '''[[बाडेयीपुत्र|Bāḍeyīputra]]''' and the teacher of the second [[गार्गीपुत्र|Gārgīputra]]. The latter was the teacher of '''[[पाराशरीकौण्डिनीपुत्र|Pārāśarīkauṇḍinīputra]],''' the teacher of the third [[गार्गीपुत्र|Gārgīputra]].<br>==Foot Notes==

गार्ग्य
<u>'''Gārgya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[गर्ग|Garga]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[बालाकि|Bālāki]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve1_873> ii. 1, 1.</ref> and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_873> iv. 1.</ref> Upaniṣads. Two Gārgyas are mentioned in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]:<ref name=fx3_ve1_873> iv. 6, 2 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]])</ref> one of them is the pupil of [[गार्ग्य|Gārgya]], who again is the pupil of [[गौतम|Gautama]]. Others occur in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx4_ve1_873> i. 7, 3.</ref> and in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_873> i. 3. 12;<br> iii. 13.</ref> as well as later in the ritual Sūtras. Thus the family was evidently long connected with the development of liturgy and grammar. 

गार्ग्यायण
<u>'''Gārgyāyaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[गार्ग्य|Gārgya]],’ is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[उद्दालकायन|Uddālakāyana]]''' in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 6, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).<br>==Foot Notes==

गार्ग्यायणि
<u>'''Gārgyāyaṇi,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[गार्ग्य|Gārgya]],’ is a variant reading for '''[[गाङ्ग्यायनि|Gāṅgyāyani]]''' as the patronymic of '''[[चित्र|Citra]]''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

गालव
<u>'''Gālava'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''Vidarbhīkauṇḍinya''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_876> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> It is possibly the same man that is referred to regarding a point of ritual in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve1_876> v. 3, 3.</ref> A grammarian of this name is mentioned in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_876> iv. 3. ''Cf.'' Pāṇini, vi. 3, 61;<br> vii. 1, 74;<br> 3, 99;<br> viii. 4, 67.</ref>

गिरि
<u>'''Giri,'''</u> ‘mountain’ or ‘height,’ is a word that occurs repeatedly in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_877> i. 56, 3;<br> 61, 14;<br> 63, 1;<br> iv. 20, 6;<br> vi. 24, 8, etc.</ref> Thus reference is made to the trees on the hills, hence called ‘tree-haired’ (''[[वृक्ष|vṛkṣa]]-keśāḥ''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_877> Rv. v. 41, 11.</ref> and to the streams proceeding from the hills to the sea (''[[सम्उद्र|samudra]]'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_877> Rv. vii. 95, 2.</ref> The term is frequently coupled with the adjectival ''[[पर्वत|parvata]].''<ref name=fx4_ve1_877> Rv. i. 56, 4;<br> viii. 64, 5;<br> Av. iv. 7, 8;<br> vi. 12, 3;<br> 17, 3;<br> ix. 1, 18, etc.</ref> The Rigveda mentions the waters from the hills,<ref name=fx5_ve1_877> Rv. vi. 66, 11, on which passage, see Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 411;<br> viii. 32, 4;<br> x. 68, 1, etc.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_877> xii. 1, 11. See '''[[हिमवन्त्|Himavant]].'''</ref> refers to the snowy mountains. Actual names of mountains, as '''[[मूजवन्त्|Mūjavant]], [[त्रिककुद्|Trikakud]], [[हिमवन्त्|Himavant]],''' are very rare. References to '''[[क्रौञ्च|Krauñca]], [[महामेरु|Mahāmeru]],''' and '''Maināga,''' are confined to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, while '''[[नावप्रभ्रंशन|Nāvaprabhraṃśana]]''' can no longer be considered a proper name.<ref name=fx7_ve1_877> Av. xix. 37, 8, with Whitney's note in his Translation;<br> Macdonell, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 1107.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 47.</ref>

गिरि-क्षित् औच्चा-मन्यव
<u>'''Giri-kṣit Auccā-manyava,'''</u> ‘descendant of Uccāmanyu,’ is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 5, 7) as a contemporary of '''Abhipratārin Kākṣaseṇi''' <br>==Foot Notes==

गिरि-ज बाभ्रव्य
<u>'''Giri-ja Bābhravya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[बभ्रु|Babhru]],’ is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 1) as having been taught by '''Śrauta''' the method of dividing the sacrificial animal (''paśor vibhakti'').<br>==Foot Notes==

गुग्गुलु
<u>'''Guggulu,'''</u> ‘bdellium,’ is referred to in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_880> xix. 38, 2.</ref> as produced by the [[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_880> Or ‘from streams’ (''[[सैन्धव|saindhava]]''), as Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[गुग्गुलु|guggulu]],'' suggests.</ref> and by the sea. The latter source presumably alludes, as Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_880> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 28.</ref> assumes, to seaborne trade, bdellium being the gum of a tree, not a product of the sea. It is, however, possible that in this passage some other substance may be meant. The word in this form also occurs elsewhere in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_880> ii. 36, 7.</ref> and later;<ref name=fx5_ve1_880> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 28.</ref> it is often<ref name=fx6_ve1_880> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 8, 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8, 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 2, 16.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 675;<br> Lassen, ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 12, 339;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 957, 958.</ref> mentioned in the older form of '''[[गुल्गुलु|Gulgulu]],''' between which and [[गुग्गुलु|Guggulu]] the manuscripts constantly vary

गुङ्गु
<u>'''Guṅgu.'''</u>--The descendants of [[गुङ्गु|Guṅgu]] are referred to as Guṅgus in a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_881> x. 48, 8. ''Cf.'' Ludwig. Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165.</ref> apparently as friends of '''[[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]].''' Possibly a people may be meant.

गुप्त
<u>'''Gupta'''</u> is the name in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42) of '''[[वैपश्चित|Vaipaścita]] [[दार्ढजयन्ति|Dārḍhajayanti]] [[गुप्त|Gupta]] [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]].''' All the three other names being patronymics show that he was descended from the families of Vipaścit, [[दृढजयन्त|Dṛḍhajayanta]], and [[लोहित|Lohita]].<br>==Foot Notes==

गुल्गुलु
<u>'''Gulgulu.'''</u> See '''[[गुग्गुलु|Guggulu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गृत्स-मद
<u>'''Gṛtsa-mada'''</u> is the name of a seer to whom the Sarvānukramaṇī attributes the authorship of the second Maṇḍala of the Rigveda. This tradition is supported by the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāh-  maṇa<ref name=fx1_ve1_884> v. 2, 4.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Araṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve1_884> ii. 2, 1.</ref> The [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_884> xxii. 4. ''Cf.'' Gārtsamadī, xxviii. 2.</ref> speaks of him as a '''[[भार्गव|Bhārgava]],''' ‘descendant of [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]],’ with a variant '''[[बाभ्रव|Bābhrava]],''' ‘descendant of [[बभ्रु|Babhru]],’ but the later tradition keeps to the former patronymic.<ref name=fx4_ve1_884> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 226 ''et seq.''</ref> The Gṛtsamadas are often mentioned in the second Maṇḍala of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_884> ii. 4, 9;<br> 19, 8;<br> 39, 8;<br> 41, 18.</ref> and are also called Śunahotras,<ref name=fx6_ve1_884> ii. 18, 6;<br> 41, 14. 17.</ref> but never Gārtsamadas or Śaunahotras, and [[गृत्समद|Gṛtsamada]] himself never occurs there.<ref name=fx7_ve1_884> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 200, 201.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 118;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 287.</ref>

गृध्र
<u>'''Gṛdhra,'''</u> ‘the vulture,’ is often mentioned from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_885> i. 118, 4;<br> ii. 39, 1;<br> vii. 104, 22;<br> x. 123, 8.</ref> downwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_885> Av. vii. 95, 1;<br> xi. 2, 2;<br> 9, 9;<br> 10. 8. 24;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 7, 1;<br> v. 5, 20, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 9, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 29;<br> Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40;<br> etc.</ref> The swiftness of its flight<ref name=fx3_ve1_885> Rv. ii. 39, 1.</ref> and its fondness for devouring carrion are especially noticed.<ref name=fx4_ve1_885> Av. xi. 10, 8. 24;<br> Maitrāyaṃ Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> More generally the word is used to designate any bird of prey, the eagle ('''[[श्येन|Śyena]]''') being classed as the chief of the Gṛdhras.<ref name=fx5_ve1_885> Rv. ix. 96, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 88;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 225.</ref>

गृष्टि
<u>'''Gṛṣṭi,'''</u> ‘a young cow,’ which has only calved once, occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_886> iv. 18, 10.</ref> and the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_886> ii. 13, 3;<br> viii. 9, 24;<br> xix. 24, 5.</ref> as well as in the later [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] literature.<ref name=fx3_ve1_886> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 19. 24, etc.</ref>

गृह
<u>'''Gṛha'''</u> is used in the singular,<ref name=fx1_ve1_887> Rv. iii. 53, 6;<br> iv. 49, 6;<br> viii. 10. 1, etc.;<br> Av. vii. 83, 1;<br> x. 6, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21.</ref> or oftener in the plural,<ref name=fx2_ve1_887> Rv. ii. 42, 3;<br> v. 76, 4;<br> x. 18, 12;<br> 85, 26;<br> 142, 4;<br> 165, 2;<br> Av. i. 27, 4;<br> iii. 10, 11;<br> vi. 137, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 31;<br> viii. 26;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 32;<br> iv. 33;<br> xviii. 44;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 22;<br> 6, 1, 19, etc.</ref> to denote the ‘house’ of the Vedic Indian. '''Dama''' or '''Dam''' has  the same sense, while '''[[पस्त्या|Pastyā]]''' and '''[[हर्म्य|Harmya]]''' denote more especially the home with its surroundings, the family settlement. The house held not only the family, which might be of considerable size, but also the cattle<ref name=fx3_ve1_887> Rv. vii. 56, 16;<br> Av. i. 3, 4;<br> ix. 3, 13.</ref> and the sheep<ref name=fx4_ve1_887> Rv. x. 106, 5;<br> Av. iii. 3.</ref> at night. It was composed of several rooms, as the use of the plural indicates, and it could be securely shut up.<ref name=fx5_ve1_887> Rv. vii. 85, 6.</ref> The door ('''[[द्वार्|Dvār]], Dvāra''') is often referred to, and from it the house is called '''[[दुरोण|Duroṇa]].''' In every house the fire was kept burning.<ref name=fx6_ve1_887> Rv. i. 69, 2. ''Cf.'' the Gārhapatya Agni, Av. v. 31, 5;<br> vi. 120, 1;<br> 121, 2;<br> viii. 102;<br> ix. 6, 30;<br> xii. 2, 34;<br> xviii. 4, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā. iii. 39;<br> xix. 18;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 6. 12;<br> Kauṣīt taki [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6, 1, 28;<br> vii. 1, 1, 6, etc.</ref><br><br>Very little is known of the structure of the house. Presumably stone was not used,<ref name=fx7_ve1_887> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 153. Muir's view, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 461, that clay was used can only apply to the minor finishing of the walls of a house.</ref> and houses were, as in Megasthenes' time,<ref name=fx8_ve1_887> Arrian, ''Indica,'' x. 2.</ref> built of wood. The hymns of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_887> iii. 12;<br> ix. 3. See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 343 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 234 ''et seq.;<br>'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 525 ''et seq.''</ref> give some information about the construction of a house, but the details are extremely obscure, for most of the expressions used do not recur in any context in which their sense is clear. According to Zimmer,<ref name=fx10_ve1_887> ''Op. cit.,'' 153. No certainty can attach to the rendering of the words.</ref> four pillars ('''[[उपमित्|Upamit]]''') were set up on a good site, and against them beams were leant at an angle as props ('''[[प्रतिमित्|Pratimit]]'''). The upright pillars were connected by cross beams ('''[[परिमित्|Parimit]]''') resting upon them. The roof was formed of ribs of bamboo cane (''[[वंश|vaṃśa]]''),<ref name=fx11_ve1_887> It seems likely that, as the ribs were of bamboo and were probably fixed in the ridge, the roof was wagon headed, like the huts of the Todas at the present day (see illustrations in Rivers, ''The Todas,'' pp. 25, 27, 28, 51), and the rock-cut Chaityas, or Assembly Halls, of the Buddhists in Western India, in some of the earliest of which the wooden ribs of the arched roof are still preserved.
