See Fergusson, ''History of Indian Architecture,'' 22, 135, ''cf.'' 126.</ref> a ridge called '''[[विषूवन्त्|Viṣūvant]],''' and a net ('''[[अक्षु|Akṣu]]'''), which may mean a thatched covering<ref name=fx12_ve1_887> Av. ix. 3, 8, where Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' 598, thinks of a wickerwork roof;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 136, of a pole with countless holes.</ref> over the bamboo ribs. The walls were filled up with grass in bundles (''[[पलद|palada]]''), and the whole structure was held together with ties of  various sorts (''nahana, prāṇāha, [[संदंश|saṃdaṃśa]], pariṣvañjalya'').<ref name=fx13_ve1_887> Av. ix. 3, 4. 5.</ref> In connexion with the house, mention is made of four terms which, though primarily sacrificial in meaning, seem to designate parts of the building: [[हविर्धान|Havirdhāna]], ‘oblation-holder’; [[अग्निशाल|Agniśāla]],<ref name=fx14_ve1_887> Zimmer conjecturally identifies the [[अग्निशाल|Agniśāla]] with the central room, the [[हविर्धान|Havirdhāna]] with a place for keeping the grain, etc. (''e.g.,'' Av. iii. 3, 4), the Patnīnāṃ [[सदन|Sadana]] with the women's apartments, and the [[सदस्|Sadas]] with the subsidiary buildings.</ref> ‘fireplace’; Patnīnāṃ [[सदन|Sadana]], ‘wives’ room’; and [[सदस्|Sadas]], ‘sitting room.’ Slings or hanging vessels ('''[[शिक्य|Śikya]]''') are also mentioned.<ref name=fx15_ve1_887> Av. ix. 3, 6. See Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 526;<br> Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' 597.</ref> Reedwork (''[[इट|iṭa]]'') is spoken of, no doubt as part of the finishing of the walls of the house.<ref name=fx16_ve1_887> Av. ix. 3, 17.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 148-156.</ref> The sides are called '''[[पक्ष|Pakṣa]].''' The door with its framework was named '''[[आता|Ātā]].'''

गृह-प
<u>'''Gṛha-pa'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_888> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11.</ref> or '''[[गृह|Gṛha]]-pati'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_888> Rv. vi. 53, 2;<br> Av. xiv. 1, 51;<br> xix. 31, 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 8, 5;<br> viii. 6, 1, 11, and repeatedly as an epithet of Agni, Rv. i. 12, 6;<br> 36, 5;<br> 60, 4;<br> vi. 48, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 27;<br> iii. 39;<br> ix. 39;<br> xxiv. 24, etc.</ref> is the regular name, from the Rigveda onwards, of the householder as master of the house. Similarly the mistress is called [[गृह|Gṛha]]-[[पत्नी|patnī]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_888> Rv. x. 85, 26;<br> Av. iii. 24, 6. ''Cf'' Gārhapatya, Rv. i. 15, 12;<br> vi. 15, 19 x. 85, 27. 36.</ref> For the powers and position of the Gṛhapati see '''[[पितृ|Pitṛ]].'''

गृह्य
<u>'''Gṛhya'''</u> denotes the members of the house or family in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].(**  1) ii. 5, 2, 14; 3, 16; 6, 2, 4; iii. 4, 1, 6; xii. 4, 1, 4. ''Cf. gṛhāḥ,'' i. 7, 4; 12.<br>==Foot Notes==

गैरि-क्षित
<u>'''Gairi-kṣita,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Girikṣit,'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]]''' in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_890> v. 33, 8;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155, 174.</ref> and of the '''Yaskas''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_890> xiii. 12;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 474, 475.</ref>

गो
<u>'''1. Go'''</u> (''a''), ‘ox’ or ‘cow.’<ref name=fx1_ve1_891> i. 83, 1;<br> 135, 8;<br> ii. 23, 18, etc.;<br> ''gāva ukṣaṇaḥ,'' i. 168, 2;<br> Av. iii. 11, 8;<br> '''Vājasaṇeyi''' Saṃhitā, xxi. 20;<br> ''gāvo dhenavaḥ,'' Rv. i. 173. 1;<br> vi. 45. 28;<br> x. 95, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 19. etc.</ref> These were among the chief sources of wealth to the Vedic Indian, and are repeatedly  referred to from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_891> The five sacrificial animals are man, goat, sheep, ox, horse, Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 23, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 3, 13;<br> iii. 1, 2, 13;<br> iv. 5, 5, 10;<br> xiv. 1, 1, 32.</ref> The milk ('''[[क्षीर|Kṣīra]]''') was either drunk fresh or made into butter ('''[[घृत|Ghṛta]]''') or curds ('''[[दधि|Dadhi]]'''), or was mixed with '''Soma''' or used for cooking with grain ('''[[क्षीरौदन|Kṣīraudana]]'''). The cows were milked thrice a day, early (''[[प्रातर्|prātar]]-doha''), in the forenoon ('''[[संगव|Saṃgava]]'''), and in the evening (''sāyaṃ-doha'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_891> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 3, 1.</ref> Thrice a day they were driven out to graze, according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_891> i. 4, 9, 2. The exact sense of this notice is obscure. Strictly speaking the cows were driven out from the cattleshed in the morning, spent the heat of the day in the [[संगविनी|Saṃgavinī]], were then driven out during the evening to graze, and finally came or were driven home, as is often mentioned: Rv. i. 66, 5;<br> 149, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 41.</ref> (''prātaḥ, saṃgave, sāyam''). The first milking was productive, the last two scanty.<ref name=fx3_ve1_891/> According to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_891> iii. 18, 14.</ref> among the Bharatas the herds in the evening are in the '''[[गोष्ठ|Goṣṭha]],''' at midday in the '''Saṃgavīnī.''' This passage Sāyaṇa expands by saying that the herds go home to the [[शाला|Śālā]], or house for animals, at night so far as they consist of animals giving milk, while the others stayed out in the [[गोष्ठ|Goṣṭha]], or open pasturage; but both were together in the cattle-shed during the heat of the day. The time before the [[संगव|Saṃgava]], when the cows were grazing freely on the pastureland, was called '''[[स्वसर|Svasara]].'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_891> Rv. ii. 2, 2;<br> 34, 8;<br> v. 62, 2;<br> viii. 88, 1;<br> ix. 94, 2. The going of the cows to their pasture in the morning is often referred to--''e.g.,'' Rv. i. 25, 16;<br> x. 97, 8.</ref> When the cows were out feeding they were separated from the calves, which were, however, allowed to join them at the [[संगव|Saṃgava]],<ref name=fx7_ve1_891> Rv. ii. 2, 2;<br> viii. 88, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 1, 3;<br> Śankara on Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 9, 4;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 12, 4;<br> Nārāyaṇa on Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 12, 2.</ref> and sometimes in the evening.<ref name=fx8_ve1_891> Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 8, 7;<br> Rv. ii. 2, 2. See Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 111-114.</ref><br><br>While grazing the cattle were under the care of a herdsman ('''[[गोपा|Gopā]], Gopāla''') armed with a goad,<ref name=fx9_ve1_891> ''Pavīravān,'' Rv. x. 60, 3, is probably so meant. The usual name was '''[[अष्ट्रा|Aṣṭrā]],''' the significant mark of a '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]].''' ''Cf.'' Rv. vii. 33, 6.</ref> but they were liable to all sorts of dangers, such as being lost, falling into pits, breaking limbs,<ref name=fx10_ve1_891> Rv. i. 120, 8;<br> vi. 54, 5-7. Also Pūṣan was the special deity expected to guard cattle, and hence is called ''anaṣṭapaśu,'' ‘losing no kine.’ See Rv. x. 17, 2. and Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 36.</ref>  and being stolen. The marking of the ears of cattle was repeatedly adopted, no doubt, to indicate ownership.<ref name=fx11_ve1_891> Rv. vi. 28, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 9, and ''cf.'' '''[[अष्टकर्णी|Aṣṭakarṇī]]''' and '''[[स्वधिति|Svadhiti]].'''</ref><br><br>Large herds of cattle were well-known, as is shown by the Dānastutis, or ‘praises of gifts,’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx12_ve1_891> Rv. viii. 5, 37, etc. ''Cf.'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 14, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21. 23;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 8 ''et seq.''</ref> even when allowances are made for the exaggeration of priestly gratitude. The importance attached to the possession of cattle is shown<ref name=fx13_ve1_891> Rv. i. 43, 2;<br> 162, 22;<br> v. 4, 11;<br> ix. 9, 9, etc.;<br> Av. i. 31, 4;<br> ii. 26, 4;<br> v. 29, 2;<br> vi. 68, 3;<br> viii. 7, 11;<br> x. 1, 17. 29;<br> xi. 2, 9. 21, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 3, 1;<br> v. 5, 5, 1;<br> vi. 5, 10, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 59.</ref> by the numerous passages in which the gods are asked to prosper them, and by the repeated prayers<ref name=fx14_ve1_891> Rv. i. 83, 1;<br> iv. 32, 17;<br> v. 4, 11;<br> viii. 89, 2, etc.</ref> for wealth in kine. Hence, too, forays for cattle ('''[[गव्इष्टि|Gaviṣṭi]]''') were well known; the [[भरत|Bharata]] host is called the ‘horde desiring cows’ (''gavyan grāmaḥ'') in the Rigveda;<ref name=fx15_ve1_891> iii. 33, 11.</ref> and a verbal root ''gup,''<ref name=fx16_ve1_891> Rv. vii. 103, 9;<br> Av. x. 9, 7, 8;<br> xix. 27, 9. 10. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 358, n. 13</ref> ‘to protect,’ was evolved as early as the Rigveda from the denominative ''go-pāya,'' ‘to guard cows.’ The Vedic poets<ref name=fx17_ve1_891> Rv. vii. 32, 22;<br> viii. 95, 1;<br> 106, 1;<br> ix. 12, 2, etc.</ref> do not hesitate to compare their songs with the lowing of cows, or to liken the choir of the singing Apsarases to cows.<ref name=fx18_ve1_891> Rv. x. 95, 6. It is, however, uncertain whether the names of Apsarases are meant in this passage. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 5, 517.</ref><br><br>The cattle of the Vedic period were of many colours: red (''[[रोहित|rohita]]''), light (''[[शुक्र|śukra]]''), dappled (''pṛśni''), even black (''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]'').<ref name=fx19_ve1_891> Rv. i. 62, 9. Various other colours are mentioned in the lists of animals at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or human sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]], but apparently as exceptional.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx20_ve1_891> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 226.</ref> sees a reference to cows with blazes on the face in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx21_ve1_891> i. 87, 1. It is also rendered as ‘the heavens with stars.’</ref> but this is uncertain.<br><br>Oxen were regularly used for ploughing or for drawing wagons (''[[अनड्वाह्|anaḍvāh]]''), in which case they were, it seems, usually castrated.<ref name=fx22_ve1_891> Av. iii. 9, 2;<br> vi. 138, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8. 9, 1;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 151, n. See '''[[महानिरष्ट|Mahāniraṣṭa]].'''</ref> Cows were not properly used for drawing carts, hough they at times did so.<ref name=fx23_ve1_891> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 13.</ref> The flesh of both cows and bulls was sometimes eaten ('''Māmsa'''). Cattle were certainly the  objects of individual ownership, and they formed one of the standards of exchange and valuation (see '''[[क्रय|Kraya]]''').<br><br>(''b'') The term '''Go''' is often applied to express the products of the cow. It frequently means the milk,<ref name=fx1b_ve1_891/> but rarely the flesh<ref name=fx2b_ve1_891/> of the animal. In many passages it designates leather used as the material of various objects, as a bowstring,<ref name=fx3b_ve1_891/> or a sling,<ref name=fx4b_ve1_891/> or thongs to fasten part of the chariot,<ref name=fx5b_ve1_891/> or reins,<ref name=fx6b_ve1_891/> or the lash of a whip.<ref name=fx7b_ve1_891/> See also '''[[चर्मन्|Carman]],''' with which Go is sometimes synonymous.<ref name=fx8b_ve1_891/><br><br>(''c'') '''Gāvaḥ''' means the stars of heaven in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1c_ve1_891/> according to Roth.<ref name=fx2c_ve1_891/>

गो आङ्गिरस
<u>'''2. Go Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the reputed author of a Sāman or Chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_892> xvi. 7, 7. ''Cf.'' Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vi. 11, 3.</ref> There is little doubt that he is mythical.<ref name=fx2_ve1_892> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 68.</ref>

गो-घात
<u>'''Go-ghāta,'''</u> ‘a cow-killer,’ is enumerated in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_893> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 16, 1.</ref> See '''[[मांस|Māṃsa]].'''

गोतम
<u>'''Gotama'''</u> is mentioned several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_894> Rv. i. 62, 13;<br> 78, 2;<br> 84, 5;<br> 85, 11;<br> iv. 4, 11.</ref> but never in such a way as to denote personal authorship of any hymn.<ref name=fx2_ve1_894> Oldenberg. ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 215.</ref> It seems clear that he was closely connected with the  Aṅgirases, for the Gotamas frequently refer to '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_894> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 62, 1;<br> 71, 2;<br> 74, 5;<br> 75, 2;<br> 78, 3;<br> iv. 2, 5;<br> 16, 8, etc.</ref> That he bore the patronymic [[राहूगण|Rāhūgaṇa]] is rendered probable by one hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_894> Rv. i. 78, 5. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''loc. cit.,'' 236, n. 1.</ref> and is assumed in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_894> i. 4, 1, 10 ''et seq.;<br>'' xi. 4, 3, 20. The former passage is wrongly cited by Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 81, 3. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 9, n.</ref> where he appears as the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or domestic priest, of '''[[माथव|Māthava]] [[विदेघ|Videgha]],''' and as a bearer of Vedic civilization. He is also mentioned in the same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_894> xi. 4, 3, 20.</ref> as a contemporary of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' of '''[[विदेह|Videha]],''' and '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]],''' and as the author of a [[स्तोम|Stoma]].<ref name=fx7_ve1_894> xiii. 5, 1, 1;<br> Āśvalāvana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 5, 6;<br> 10, 8, etc.</ref> He occurs, moreover, in two passages of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx8_ve1_894> iv. 29, 6;<br> xviii. 3, 16. See also Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 38;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, 6.</ref><br><br>The Gotamas are mentioned in several passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx9_ve1_894> i. 60, 5;<br> 61, 16;<br> 63, 9;<br> 77, 5;<br> 78, 1;<br> 88, 4;<br> 92, 7;<br> iv. 32, 9. 12;<br> viii. 88, 4. ''Cf.'' Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 110, 123;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170, 180;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 151, 152.</ref> '''[[वामदेव|Vāmadeva]]''' and '''[[नोधस्|Nodhas]]''' being specified as sons of [[गोतम|Gotama]]. They include the '''Vājaśravases.''' See also '''[[गौतम|Gautama]].'''

गोतमी-पुत्र
<u>'''Gotamī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of Gotamī,’ is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[भारद्वाजी-पुत्र|Bhāradvājī-putra]]''' in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 1). See also '''[[गौतमी-पुत्र|Gautamī-putra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गोत्र
<u>'''Gotra'''</u> occurs several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_896> i. 51, 3;<br> ii. 17, 1;<br> 23, 18;<br> iii. 39, 4;<br> 43, 7;<br> viii. 74, 5;<br> x. 48, 2;<br> 103, 7.</ref> in the account of the mythic exploits of Indra. Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_896> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> interprets the word as ‘cowstall,’ while Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve1_896> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 275, 276, where he divides the passages according as real or mythical herds are meant.</ref> thinks ‘herd’ is meant. The latter sense seems to explain best the employment which the term shows in the later literature as denoting the ‘family’ or ‘clan,’ and which is found in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_896> iv. 4, 1. So [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]];<br> i. 4, 16, etc.;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 4, etc.;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 15.</ref><br><br>In the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras<ref name=fx5_ve1_896> Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 4;<br> Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 5, 11, 15. 16, in Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 387. For ''sapiṇḍa,'' see [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 13;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 17-19.</ref> stress is laid on the prohibition of  marriage within a [[गोत्र|Gotra]], or with a Sapiṇḍa of the mother of the bridegroom--that is to say, roughly, with agnates and cognates. Senart<ref name=fx6_ve1_896> ''Les Castes dans l'Inde,'' 210 ''et seq. Cf.'' De la Vallée Poussin, ''Le Védisme,'' 15.</ref> has emphasized this fact as a basis of caste, on the ground that marriage within a ''curia, phratria,'' or caste ('''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''') was Indo-European, as was marriage outside the circle of agnates and cognates. But there is no evidence at all<ref name=fx7_ve1_896> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 471, 472.</ref> to prove that this practice was Indo-European, while in India the Śatapatha<ref name=fx8_ve1_896> i. 8, 3, 6.</ref> expressly recognizes marriage within the third or fourth degree on either side. According to Sāyaṇa, the Kāṇvas accepted marriage in the third degree, the Saurāṣṭras only in the fourth, while the scholiast on the Vajrasūcī<ref name=fx9_ve1_896> See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 73-76.</ref> adḍs to the Kāṇvas the Andhras and the Dākṣiṇātyas, and remarks that the Vājasaneyins forbade marriage with the daughter of the mother's brother. All apparently allowed marriage with the daughter of a paternal uncle, which later was quite excluded. Change of [[गोत्र|Gotra]] was quite possible, as in the case of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' and '''[[गृत्समद|Gṛtsamada]],''' who, once an Aṅgirasa, became a [[भार्गव|Bhārgava]].<ref name=fx10_ve1_896> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 157;<br> ''Festgruss an Roth,'' 108.<br><br>''Cf.'' Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 61 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 323.</ref>

गो-दान
<u>'''Go-dāna'''</u> appears to mean ‘the whiskers’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_897> iii. 1, 2, 5, 6.</ref> where the person, being consecrated, first shaves off the right and then the left ‘whisker.’ Later on the Godānavidhi, or ceremony of shaving the head, is a regular part of the initiation of a youth on the attainment of manhood and on marriage;<ref name=fx2_ve1_897> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 19;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 28, etc.</ref> but though the ceremony is recognized in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_897> vi. 68. See [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], liii. 1720. But Av. ii. 13 is not to be classed here as in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]];<br> it refers to the giving of a new garment to a child, and the removal of its first wrap. See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 56, 57, correcting Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 173, and Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 322, 323. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 306, 574, 665.</ref> the name<ref name=fx4_ve1_897> The meaning ‘whisker’ is a secondary one, derived, doubtless, from the ‘gift of a cow’ (''[[गो-दान|go-dāna]]''), accompanying the ceremony of shaving the whiskers or hair.</ref> does not occur there. 

गोधा
<u>'''Godhā.'''</u>--(''a'') The sense of ‘bowstring’ seems certain in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_898> x. 28, 10. 11.</ref> and possible in another.<ref name=fx2_ve1_898> viii. 69, 9. See Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 53.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_898> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1.</ref> also adopts this meaning in the only passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_898> iv. 3, 6.</ref> where the word occurs.<br><br>(''b'') In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1b_ve1_898/> the sense of ‘musical instrument’ is recognized by Roth and by Hillebrandt<ref name=fx2b_ve1_898/> for this word.<br><br>(''c'') Elsewhere<ref name=fx1c_ve1_898/> an animal seems to be meant, perhaps the ‘crocodile,’ as Ludwig<ref name=fx2c_ve1_898/> and Weber<ref name=fx3c_ve1_898/> think; perhaps a large ‘lizard,’ as Roth and Zimmer<ref name=fx4c_ve1_898/> assume. An animal is probably also meant in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx5_ve1_898> iv. 3, 6, where Whitney offers no rendering at all.</ref>

गो-धूम
<u>'''Go-dhūma,'''</u> ‘wheat,’ is frequently referred to in the plural in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_899> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 2, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 12;<br> xix. 22. 89;<br> xxi. 29, etc.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve1_899> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 1, 2;<br> 2, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]), etc.</ref> and is expressly distinguished from ‘rice’ ('''[[व्रीहि|Vrīhi]]''') or ‘barley’ ('''Yava''').<ref name=fx3_ve1_899> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 7, 2.</ref> ‘Groats’ (''saktavaḥ'') made of this grain are also mentioned.<ref name=fx4_ve1_899> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 9, 1, 5.</ref> The word occurs in the singular in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_899> v. 2, 1, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 241.</ref>

गो-पति
<u>'''Go-pati,'''</u> ‘lord of cows,’ is freely used in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_900> i. 101, 4;<br> iv. 24, 1;<br> vi. 45, 21;<br> vii. 18, 4, etc. Av. iii. 14, 6, etc.</ref> to denote any lord or master, a natural usage considering that cattle formed the main species of wealth. 

गोप-वन
<u>'''Gopa-vana'''</u> is the name of a poet of the race of Atri in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_901> viii. 74, 11. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 215;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 107.</ref> See '''[[गौपवन|Gaupavana]].'''

गो-पा
<u>'''Go-pā'''</u> and '''Go-pāla,''' ‘protector of cows,’ occur in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_902> ''[[गोपा|Gopā]]:'' Rv. i. 164, 21;<br> ii. 23, 6;<br> iii. 10, 2;<br> v. 12, 4, etc.;<br> ''Gopāla:'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 4. ''[[गोपा|Gopā]],'' in the sense of ‘guardian,’ occurs in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 18, in a compound. ''Gopītha,'' in the sense of ‘protection,’ occurs in Rv. v. 65, 6;<br> x. 35, 14, etc. ''Goptṛ,'' ‘protector,’ first occurs in Av. x. 10, 5, and is thereafter common.</ref> and later, but the former is usually metaphorical in sense, applying to any protector, while the latter has the literal force of ‘cow-herd.’

गो-बल
<u>'''Go-bala'''</u> (‘ox-strength’) '''[[वार्ष्ण|Vārṣṇa]]''' (‘descendant of Vṛṣṇi’) is mentioned as a teacher in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (iii. 11, 9, 3) and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 6, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

गो-मती
<u>'''Go-matī,'''</u> ‘possessing cows,’ is mentioned as a river in the [[नदी|Nadī]]-[[स्तुति|stuti]], or ‘Praise of Rivers,’ in the tenth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_904> x. 75, 6.</ref> In that hymn a river flowing into the Indus must be meant, and its identification<ref name=fx2_ve1_904> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 14;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200.</ref> with the Gomal, a western tributary of the Indus, cannot be doubted. In one other passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_904> viii. 24. 30.</ref> the accentuation of Gomati shows that a river is meant. It is possible that in a third passage<ref name=fx4_ve1_904> v. 61, 19. See Oldenberg, ''ṚgvedaNoten.'' 1, 355, 356.</ref> the reading should be changed to ''gomatír'' from ''gómatīr.'' Geldner<ref name=fx5_ve1_904> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 152, n. 2.</ref> suggests that in the two last passages the Gumti, or rather its four upper arms (hence the use of the plural) is meant: this accords well with the later use of the name and with the general probability of the river here intended being in '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' as the centre of Vedic civilization.<ref name=fx6_ve1_904> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 19 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 174;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 1141.</ref> 

गो-मायु
<u>'''Go-māyu,'''</u> ‘lowing like a cow,’ does not occur as the name of the ‘jackal’ till the late Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_905> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40.</ref>

गो-मृग
<u>'''Go-mṛga,'''</u> a species of ox, now called Gayal (''Bos gavaeus''), is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_906> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 1. 30.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_906> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 4, 3;<br> 5, 2, 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 20, 5.</ref> In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_906> ii. 1, 10, 2</ref> it is declared to be neither a wild nor a tame animal; this presumably means that it was semidomesticated, or perhaps that it was both tamed and found wild. With the name of this animal may be compared the [[मृग|Mṛga]] [[महिष|Mahiṣa]], which is clearly mentioned as wild in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx4_ve1_906> ix. 92, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83, 84;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 338, n. 1.</ref> See also '''Gayava.'''

गोलत्तिका
<u>'''Golattikā'''</u> is the name of some unknown animal in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_907> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 16, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 18;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 37. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref>

गो-विकर्तन
<u>'''Go-vikartana'''</u> (‘cow-butcher’) designates the ‘huntsman’ in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 3, 1, 10).<ref name=fx1_ve1_908> ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 16, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 18;<br> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 82.</ref> See '''[[गोघात|Goghāta]].'''

गो-व्यच
<u>'''Go-vyaca.'''</u> See '''Vyaca.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गोशर्य
<u>'''Gośarya'''</u> is the name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda (viii. 8, 20; 49, 1; 50, 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

गो-श्रु जाबाल
<u>'''Go-śru Jābāla'''</u> is mentioned as a sage in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 7, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

गो-श्रुति वैयाघ्र-पद्य
<u>'''Go-śruti Vaiyāghra-padya'''</u> (‘descendant of Vyāghrapad’) is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[सत्यकाम|Satyakāma]]''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (v. 2, 3). In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (ix. 7) the name appears as Gośruta. <br>==Foot Notes==

गो-षादी
<u>'''Go-ṣādī'''</u> (‘sitting on a cow’) is the name of a bird in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_913> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 24. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94.</ref>

गो-षूक्तिन्
<u>'''Go-ṣūktin'''</u> is mentioned in the Sarvānukramaṇī as the author of Rigveda viii. 14 and 15, and a Sāman or Chant of his seems to be referred to in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xix. 4, 9), under the title of Gauṣūkta. But see '''[[गौषूक्ति|Gauṣūkti]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गो-ष्ठ
<u>'''Go-ṣṭha,'''</u> ‘standing-place for cows,’ denotes not so much a ‘cowstall’ as the ‘grazing ground of cows,’ as Geldner<ref name=fx1_ve1_915> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 112, 113.</ref> shows from a passage of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_915> iii. 18, 14.</ref> and from a note of Mahīdhara on the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx3_ve1_915> iii. 21.</ref> This sense suits adequately all the passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_915> i. 191, 4;<br> vi. 28, 1;<br> viii. 43, 17.</ref> where it occurs, and it greatly improves the interpretation of a hymn of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_915> iii. 14, 1. 5. 6, where Whitney's rendering ‘stall’ is very unsatisfactory, and Bloomfield's ‘stable’ is no better.</ref> besides being acceptable elsewhere.<ref name=fx6_ve1_915> Av. ii. 26, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 21;<br> v. 17;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 8, 3, 2, etc.;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, vii. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 11.</ref> See also '''Go.'''

गौतम
<u>'''Gautama,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[गोतम|Gotama]],’ is a common patronymic, being applied to '''Aruṇa,'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_916> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 1, 4.</ref> '''[[उद्दालक आरुणि|Uddālaka Āruṇi]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_916> ''Ibid.,'' xi. 4, 1, 3;<br> 5, 1, 2;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 7;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 3, 6 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 42, 1.</ref> '''Kuśri,'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_916> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5, 5, 1.</ref> '''Sāti,'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_916> [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref> '''[[हारिद्रुमत|Hāridrumata]].'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_916> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], 1. 4, 3.</ref><br><br>Several Gautamas are mentioned in the Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] as pupils of '''[[आग्निवेश्य|Āgniveśya]],'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_916> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 6, 1 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> of '''[[सैतव|Saitava]]''' and '''[[प्राचीनयोग्य|Prācīnayogya]],'''<ref name=fx7_ve1_916> ''Ibid.,'' ii. 6, 2.</ref> of '''[[सैतव|Saitava]],'''<ref name=fx8_ve1_916> ''Ibid.,'' iv. 6, 2.</ref> of '''Bhārad-  [[वाज|vāja]],'''<ref name=fx9_ve1_916> ''Ibid.,'' ii. 6, 2 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 27 Mādhyaṃdina).</ref> of '''[[गौतम|Gautama]],'''<ref name=fx10_ve1_916> ''Ibid.,'' ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 Mādhyaṃdina).</ref> and of '''[[वात्स्य|Vātsya]].'''<ref name=fx11_ve1_916> ''Ibid.,'' ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = ii. 5, 20. 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 Mādhyaṃdina). The Mādhyaṃdina, ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26, knows a [[गौतम|Gautama]], pupil of '''Vaijavāpāyana''' and '''[[वैष्ठपुरेय|Vaiṣṭhapureya]].'''</ref> A [[गौतम|Gautama]] is also referred to elsewhere.

गौतमी-पुत्र
<u>'''Gautamī-putra'''</u> (‘son of a female descendant of Gotama’) is mentioned in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 2) as a pupil of '''[[भारद्वाजीपुत्र|Bhāradvājīputra]].''' In the Mādhyaṃdina (vi. 4, 31) a [[गौतमीपुत्र|Gautamīputra]] is a pupil of '''[[आत्रेयीपुत्र|Ātreyīputra]],''' pupil of a [[गौतमीपुत्र|Gautamīputra]], pupil of '''[[वात्सीपुत्र|Vātsīputra]].''' See also '''[[गोतमीपुत्र|Gotamīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गौप-वन
<u>'''Gaupa-vana'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[गोपवन|Gopavana]]'''’) is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[पौतिमाष्य|Pautimāṣya]]''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 6, 1; iv. 6, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

गौपायन
<u>'''Gaupāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of Gopa’). The Gaupāyanas appear in the legend of '''Asamāti, [[किरात|Kirāta]],''' and '''[[आकुलि|Ākuli]],''' which is first met with in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_919> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 12, 5;<br> Jaiminīva [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 167 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 41);<br> Sāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 57 (Max Müller's edition, 4^2, c ''et seq.'');<br> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 83 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref>

गौपालायन
<u>'''Gaupālāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of Gopāla’) is the patronymic of '''Śucivṛkṣa''' in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_920> iii. 10, 4 (p. 135, line 9). ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 48, 9, where Aufrecht reads ''Gaupalāyana.''</ref> It is also the patronymic of '''[[औपोदिति|Aupoditi]],''' [[स्थपति|Sthapati]] of the '''Kurus,''' in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_920> xx. 25.</ref> and, as Gaupāleya, of Upoditi or [[औपोदिति|Aupoditi]] in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_920> xii. 13, 11, where the edition has ''Upoditi.''</ref>

गौर
<u>'''Gaura,'''</u> a species of ox (''Bos gaurus''), is frequently mentioned with the '''[[गवय|Gavaya]]''' from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_921> i. 16, 5;<br> iv. 21, 8;<br> 58, 2;<br> v. 78, 2;<br> vii. 69, 6;<br> 98, 1, etc.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_921> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 28;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 34, etc.</ref> As the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_921> xiii. 48.</ref> expressly mentions wild (''āraṇya'') Gauras, they  must usually have been tame. The female, Gaurī, is also often referred to.<ref name=fx4_ve1_921> Rv. i. 84, 10;<br> iv. 12, 6;<br> ix. 12, 3;<br> and in the obscure verse i. 164, 11.</ref> The compound term [[गौर|Gaura]]-[[मृग|mṛga]] (‘the [[गौर|Gaura]] wild beast’) is sometimes met with.<ref name=fx5_ve1_921> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 32;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83, 224.</ref>

गौरि-वीति शाक्त्य
<u>'''Gauri-vīti Śāktya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[शक्ति|Śakti]]'''’) or '''Gaurīviti,''' as the name is also spelt,<ref name=fx1_ve1_922> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 3, 7;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5;<br> xii. 13;<br> xxv. 7.</ref> is the [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], or Seer, of a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_922> v. 29, 11.</ref> and is frequently mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_922> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 19;<br> viii. 2 and see n. 1.</ref> According to the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_922> ii. 233 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 38).<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 126;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 215.</ref> he was [[प्रस्तोतृ|Prastotṛ]] at the Sattra, or sacrificial session, celebrated by the '''Vibhindukīyas''' and mentioned in that [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].

गौश्र
<u>'''Gauśra'''</u> (‘descendant of Guśri’) is the name of a teacher mentioned in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xvi. 9; xxiii. 5). See '''[[गौश्ल|Gauśla]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

गौश्रायणि
<u>'''Gauśrāyaṇi'''</u> (‘descendant of Gauśra’) is the patronymic of a teacher, '''[[चित्र|Citra]],''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxiii. 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

गौश्ल
<u>'''Gauśla,'''</u> a variant of '''[[गौश्र|Gauśra]],''' is the name of a teacher represented as in disagreement with '''Buḍila Āśvatara Āśvi''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_925> vi. 30. ''Cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 9 (Gośla).</ref>

गौ-षूक्ति
<u>'''Gau-ṣūkti'''</u> is the name of a pupil of '''[[इष श्यावाश्वि|Iṣa Śyāvāśvi]]''' according to the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_926> iv. 16, 1.</ref> in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers). It is also the name, in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_926> xix. 4, 9. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 30.</ref>  of a teacher who appears to have been needlessly invented to explain the Gauṣūkta Sāman (chant), which is really the Sāman of '''[[गोषूक्तिन्|Goṣūktin]].'''

ग्रह
<u>'''Graha'''</u> (‘seizing’) is a term applied to the sun in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_927> iv. 6, 5, 1.</ref> most probably not in the later sense of ‘planet,’ but to denote a power exercising magical influence.<ref name=fx2_ve1_927> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 432, n. 2.</ref> The sense of ‘planet’ seems first to occur in the later literature, as in the Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_927> vi. 16. See Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 98, n.</ref> The question whether the planets were known to the Vedic Indians is involved in obscurity. Oldenberg<ref name=fx4_ve1_927> ''Religion des Veda,'' 185 ''et seq.;<br> Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 56 ''et seq.''</ref> recognizes them in the Ādityas, whose number is, he believes, seven; sun, moon, and the five planets. But this view, though it cannot be said to be impossible or even unlikely, is not susceptible of proof, and has been rejected by Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx5_ve1_927> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 102 ''et seq.''</ref> Pischel,<ref name=fx6_ve1_927> ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anxeigen,'' 1895. 447.</ref> von Schroeder,<ref name=fx7_ve1_927> ''Vienna Oriental Journal,'' 9, 109.</ref> Macdonell,<ref name=fx8_ve1_927> ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 44.</ref> and Bloomfield,<ref name=fx9_ve1_927> ''Religion of the Veda,'' 133 ''et seq.''</ref> among others. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx10_ve1_927> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 423.</ref> sees the planets in the five Adhvaryus mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx11_ve1_927> iii. 7, 7.</ref> but this is a mere conjecture. The five bulls (''ukṣāṇaḥ'') in another passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx12_ve1_927> i. 105, 10. ''Cf.'' also i. 105, 16, with Oldenberg's note.</ref> have received a similar interpretation with equal uncertainty,<ref name=fx13_ve1_927> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 24, 36.</ref> and [[दुर्ग|Durga]], in his commentary on the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx14_ve1_927> i. 14.</ref> even explains the term ''bhūmija,'' ‘earth-born,’ which is only mentioned by [[यास्क|Yāska]], as meaning the planet Mars.<ref name=fx15_ve1_927> See Weber, ''[[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]],'' 10, n. 2.</ref> Thibaut,<ref name=fx16_ve1_927> ''Astronomie, Astrologie, und Mathematik,'' 6.</ref> who is generally sceptical as to the mention of planets in the Veda, thinks that [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]] there refers to Jupiter; but this is extremely improbable, though in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx17_ve1_927> iv. 4 10, 1. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 102-104.</ref> [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]] is made the regent of [[तिष्य|Tiṣya]]. A reference to the  planets is much more probable in the seven suns (''[[सप्त सूर्याः|sapta sūryāḥ]]'') of the late [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx18_ve1_927> i. 7. See on them Weber, ''Omina und Portenta,'' 339;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 238;<br> 9, 363;<br> 10, 240, 271;<br> ''[[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]],'' 10;<br> ''Rāmāyaṇa,'' 28, n. 2.</ref> On the other hand, Ludwig's efforts to find the five planets with the sun, the moon, and the twenty-seven Nakṣatras (lunar mansions) in the Rigveda, as corresponding to the number thirty-four used in connexion with light<ref name=fx19_ve1_927> x. 55, 3.</ref> (''jyotis'') and the ribs of the sacrificial horse,<ref name=fx20_ve1_927> i. 162, 18.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 183 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 354 ''et seq.;<br>'' Max Müller, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' iv. 2, xxx. ''et seq.;<br>'' Whitney, ''Oriental and Linguistic Essays,'' 2, 412, n. ''Journal of the American Oriental Society'' 16, lxxxviii.</ref> is farfetched. See also '''[[शुक्र|Śukra]], [[मन्थिन्|Manthin]], Vena.'''

ग्राभ
<u>'''Grābha'''</u> (lit. ‘grasping’) designates the ‘throw’ of dice in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_928> viii. 81, 1;<br> ix. 106, 3. ''Cf.'' Lüders, ''Das Wūrfelspiel im alten Indien,'' 49, 50.</ref> See also '''[[ग्लह|Glaha]].'''

ग्राम
<u>'''Grāma.'''</u>--The primitive sense of this word, which occurs frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_929> i. 44, 10;<br> 114, 1;<br> ii. 12, 7 (perhaps to be taken as in n. 10);<br> x. 146, 1;<br> 149, 4, etc.;<br> Av. iv. 36, 7, 8;<br> v. 17, 4;<br> vi. 40, 2, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45;<br> xx. 17, etc.</ref> onwards, appears to have been ‘village.’ The Vedic Indians must have dwelt in villages which were scattered over the country, some close together,<ref name=fx2_ve1_929> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 4, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 44.</ref> some far apart, and were connected by roads.<ref name=fx3_ve1_929> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 6, 2.</ref> The village is regularly contrasted with the forest (''[[अरण्य|araṇya]]''), and its animals and plants with those that lived or grew wild in the woods.<ref name=fx4_ve1_929> Animals: Rv. x. 90, 8;<br> Av. ii. 34, 4;<br> iii. 10, 6;<br> 31, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 2, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, vii. 7;<br> xiii. 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 32;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 1, 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8. 4, 16, etc. Plants: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 5, 5;<br> vii. 3, 4, 1, etc.</ref> The villages contained cattle, horses, and other domestic animals, as well as men.<ref name=fx5_ve1_929> Av. iv. 22, 2;<br> viii. 7, 11, etc.</ref> Grain was also stored in them.<ref name=fx6_ve1_929> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 13 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = 22, Mādhyaṃdina).</ref> In the evening the cattle regularly returned thither from the forest.<ref name=fx7_ve1_929> Rv. x. 149, 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 1.</ref> The villages were probably open, though perhaps a fort ('''Pur''') might on  occasion be built inside.<ref name=fx8_ve1_929> As nowadays. See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 144, citing Hügel, Kashmir, 2, 45.</ref> Presumably they consisted of detached houses with enclosures, but no details are to be found in Vedic literature. Large villages (''mahāgrāmāḥ'') were known.<ref name=fx9_ve1_929> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 13. 4.</ref><br><br>The relation of the villagers is difficult to ascertain with precision. In several passages<ref name=fx10_ve1_929> Rv. i. 100, 10;<br> iii. 33, 11;<br> x. 27, 1;<br> 127, 5;<br> Av. iv. 7, 5;<br> v. 20, 3 (where, however, ‘villages’ is quite probable);<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 2;<br> vi. 7, 4, 9;<br> xii. 4, 1, 3. ''Cf.'' n. 1.</ref> the word occurs with what appears to be the derivative sense of ‘body of men.’ This sense presumably started from the use of the word to denote the ‘village folk,’ as when '''[[शर्यात|Śaryāta]] [[मानव|Mānava]]''' is said in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx11_ve1_929> iv. 1, 5, 2. 7.</ref> to have wandered about with his ‘village’ (''grāmeṇa''); but, as Zimmer<ref name=fx12_ve1_929> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 161.</ref> observes, this restricted sense nowhere appears clearly in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx13_ve1_929> See passages cited in n. 10.</ref> where indeed the ‘folk’ (''jana'')<ref name=fx14_ve1_929> Rv. iii. 53, 12.</ref> of the Bharatas is in one passage<ref name=fx15_ve1_929> Rv. iii. 33, 11.</ref> called the ‘horde seeking cows’ (''gavyan grāmaḥ''). Zimmer<ref name=fx16_ve1_929> ''Op. cit.,'' 159, 160, where, however, his language is not very clear. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Religions of India,'' 27, who points out that Zimmer is inaccurate in identifying the tribe with [[विश्|Viś]]. It is the clan, a division below that of the tribe ('''Jana''').</ref> tends to regard the [[ग्राम|Grāma]] as a clan, and as standing midway between the family and the tribe ('''[[विश्|Viś]]'''). The [[ग्राम|Grāma]] may, however, perhaps be regarded more correctly<ref name=fx17_ve1_929> A village might contain a whole clan, but probably it contained at most a section of a clan. By family is meant a Hindu joint family;<br> but the extent to which such families existed, and the number of persons included, cannot even be conjectured from the avail able evidence. ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prchistoric Antiquities,'' 393;<br> Leist, ''Altarisches Jos Gentium,'' 34.</ref> as an aggregate of several families, not necessarily forming a clan, but only part of a clan ('''[[विश्|Viś]]'''), as is often the case at the present day.<ref name=fx18_ve1_929> ''Cf.'' Baden Powell, ''Village Communities in India,'' 85 ''et seq.''</ref><br><br>Vedic literature tells us very little about the social economy of the village. There is nothing to show that the community as such held land. What little evidence there is indicates that individual tenure of land was known (see '''[[उर्वरा|Urvarā]], [[क्षेत्र|Kṣetra]]'''), but this, in effect though not in law, presumably meant tenure by a family rather than by an individual person. The expression  ‘desirous of a village’ (''[[ग्राम|grāma]]-kāma''), which occurs frequently in the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx19_ve1_929> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 2;<br> 3, 2;<br> 3, 9, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 9;<br> 2, 3;<br> iv. 2, 7, etc.;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 32, thinks that ''[[ग्राम|grāma]]'' here means ‘herd’ (of cattle).</ref> points, however, to the practice of the king's granting to his favourites his royal prerogatives over villages so far as fiscal matters were concerned. Later<ref name=fx20_ve1_929> ''Cf.'' Baden Powell, ''Indian Village Community,'' 207 ''et seq.'' Whether or not the idea is already found in Manu, ix. 34, is disputed and uncertain. See [[राजन्|Rājan]]. The germ of it lies in a different sphere--the right of the '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]],''' with the consent of the clan, to apportion land (Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 1, 1, 8).</ref> the idea developed that the king was owner of all the land, and parallel with that idea the view that the holders of such grants were landlords. But of either idea there is no vestige in Vedic literature beyond the word ''[[ग्राम|grāma]]-kāma,'' which much more probably refers to the grant of regalia than to the grant of land, as Teutonic parallels show.<ref name=fx21_ve1_929> ''Cf.'' Pollock and Maitland, ''History of English Law,'' 2, 237 ''et seq.;<br>'' Baden Powell, ''Village Communities in India,'' 83;<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 48. It may be mentioned that we have no Vedic evidence as to the non-sale of land by the members of a family, except the indications mentioned under '''[[उर्वरा|Urvarā]].''' The later evidence is overwhelming for ''[[ग्राम|grāma]],'' meaning ‘village.’<br><br>''Cf.'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 14;<br> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 94.</ref> Such grants probably tended to depress the position of the actual cultivators, and to turn them into tenants, but they can hardly have had this effect to any appreciable extent in early times.<br><br>The village does not appear to have been a unit for legal purposes in early days,<ref name=fx22_ve1_929> ''Cf.'' Foy, ''Die ko7nigliche Gewalt,'' 20, n.;<br> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 93;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 78, 128.</ref> and it can hardly be said to have been a political unit. The village no doubt, as later, included in its members various menials, besides the cultivating owners, and also the Brāhmaṇas and Kṣatriyas who might hold interest in it by royal grant or usage without actually cultivating land, such as chariot-makers ('''[[रथ-कार|Ratha-kāra]]'''), carpenters ('''[[तक्षन्|Takṣan]]'''), smiths ('''[[कर्मार|Karmāra]]'''), and others, but they did not presumably, in any sense, form part of the brotherhood.<ref name=fx23_ve1_929> ''Cf.'' Baden Powell, ''Indian Village Community,'' 17, 18.</ref> All alike were politically subject to the king, and bound to render him food or service or other tribute, unless he had transferred his rights to  others of the royal family or household, as was no doubt often the case, either in whole or part. The king's share in a village is referred to as early as the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx24_ve1_929> iv. 22, 2. ''Cf.'' n. 20.</ref><br><br>At the head of the village was the [[ग्राम|Grāma]]-ṇī, or ‘leader of the village,’ who is referred to in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx25_ve1_929> x. 62, 11;<br> 107, 5.</ref> and often in the later Saṃhitās and in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx26_ve1_929> Av. iii. 5, 7;<br> xix. 31, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 4, 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 5 (''[[ग्राम|grāma]]-ṇīthya,'' ‘the rank of Grāmaṇī’: ''cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 5, 2);<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 4;<br> x. 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 15;<br> xxx. 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 8;<br> 7, 3, 4;<br> ii. 7, 18, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 7;<br> v. 4, 4, 8;<br> viii. 6, 2, 1 (''grāmaṇīthya'');<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 37. 38, etc.</ref> The exact meaning of the title is not certain. By Zimmer<ref name=fx27_ve1_929> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 171.</ref> the Grāmaṇī is regarded as having had military functions only, and he is certainly often connected with the '''[[सेनानी|Senānī]],''' or ‘leader of an army.’ But there is no reason so to restrict the sense: presumably the Grāmaṇī was the head of the village both for civil purposes and for military operations. He is ranked in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx28_ve1_929> v. 4, 4, 18.</ref> as inferior to the '''[[सूत|Sūta]],''' or ‘charioteer,’ with whom, however, he is associated<ref name=fx29_ve1_929> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 5.</ref> as one of the '''Ratnins,''' the ‘jewels’ of the royal establishment. The post was especially valuable to a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]], who, if he attained it, was at the summit of prosperity (''gataśrī'').<ref name=fx30_ve1_929> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 4, 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 5. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 20, n. 2.</ref> The Grāmaṇī's connexion with the royal person seems to point to his having been a nominee of the king rather than a popularly elected officer. But the post may have been sometimes hereditary, and sometimes nominated or elective: there is no decisive evidence available. The use of the singular presents difficulties: possibly the Grāmaṇī of the village or city where the royal residence was situated was specially honoured and influential.<ref name=fx31_ve1_929> Presumably, there must have been many Grāmaṇīs in a kingdom, but the texts seem to contemplate only one as in the royal entourage. ''Cf.'' also Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 60, n.;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 96;<br> Rhys Davids, ''op. cit.,'' 48, thinks that he was elected by the village council or a hereditary officer, because the appointment is only claimed for the king in late authorities like Manu, vii. 115. But there is not even so much authority for election or heredity, and we really cannot say how far the power of the early princes extended: it probably varied very much. ''Cf.'' '''[[राजन्|Rājan]]''' and '''[[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]].'''</ref> 

ग्राम्य-वादिन्
<u>'''Grāmya-vādin'''</u> apparently means a ‘village judge’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_930> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 1, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 4;<br> Maitrāyanī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 1.</ref> His '''[[सभा|Sabhā]],''' ‘court,’ is mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.

ग्राह
<u>'''Grāha,'''</u> ‘the seizer,’ is the name of a disease in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_931> iii. 5, 3, 25;<br> 6, 1, 25.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_931> xi. 9, 12.</ref> it perhaps means ‘paralysis’ of the thigh.<ref name=fx3_ve1_931> If the reading of the commentary ''ūru-grāhaiḥ'' be adopted;<br> but Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 653, retaining the reading of the text ''urugrāhaiḥ,'' renders the compound as an adjective, ‘wide-gripping.’ ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 635.</ref>

ग्राहि
<u>'''Grāhi,'''</u> ‘the seizer,’ appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_932> x. 161, 1.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_932> ii. 9, 1;<br> 10, 6. 8;<br> vi. 112, 1;<br> 113, 1;<br> viii. 2, 12;<br> 3, 18;<br> xvi. 7, 1;<br> 8, 1;<br> xix. 45, 5.</ref> as a female demon of disease. Her son is sleep (''[[स्वप्न|svapna]]'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_932> xvi. 5, 1;<br> or perhaps ‘dream’ is meant.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 154.</ref>

ग्रीष्म
<u>'''Grīṣma.'''</u> See '''[[ऋतु|Ṛtu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

ग्रैव्य
<u>'''Graivya,'''</u> in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_934> vi. 25, 2;<br> vii. 76, 2. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' October, 1887, xix.;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 472.</ref> appears to denote ‘tumours on the neck’ (''grīvāḥ'').

ग्लह
<u>'''Glaha'''</u> denotes the ‘throw’ at dice, like '''[[ग्राभ|Grābha]],''' of which it is a later form, occurring in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_935> iv. 28, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' Lüders, ''Das Würfelspiel im alten Indien,'' 49.</ref>

ग्लाव मैत्रेय
<u>'''Glāva Maitreya'''</u> (‘descendant of Maitrī’) is mentioned in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_936> i. 12, 1. 3. ''Cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 31.</ref> where he is said to be the same as '''[[वक दाल्भ्य|Vaka Dālbhya]].''' He appears as Pratistotṛ at the snake festival of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_936> xxv. 15, 3.</ref> and is referred to in the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_936> i. 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35, 38.</ref> 

ग्लौ
<u>'''Glau'''</u> occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_937> vi. 83, 3.</ref> and in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_937> i. 25.</ref> as the name of some symptom of a disease, probably, as Bloomfield<ref name=fx3_ve1_937> ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' October, 1887, xv.;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 17, 503;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 343.</ref> thinks, ‘boils.’ In the one passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhita,<ref name=fx4_ve1_937> xxv. 8;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 15, 7.</ref> where it is found the sense is obscure, some part of the sacrificial victim being perhaps meant.<ref name=fx5_ve1_937> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 500, takes ''glau'' as ‘owl.’</ref><br><br>''Cf.'' '''[[गलुन्त|Galunta]].'''

घर्म
<u>'''Gharma'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_938> iii. 53, 14;<br> v. 30, 15;<br> 43, 7;<br> 76, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_938> Av. vii. 73, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 61;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 18. 22, etc.</ref> the pot used for heating milk, especially for the offering to the Aśvins. It hence often<ref name=fx3_ve1_938> Rv. i. 119, 2;<br> 180, 4;<br> vii. 70, 2;<br> viii. 9, 4, etc.;<br> Av. iv. 1, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 6, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 32;<br> xi. 42;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 271;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> denotes the hot milk itself, or some other hot drink.

घास
<u>'''Ghāsa'''</u> means ‘fodder’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_939> Av. iv. 38, 7;<br> viii. 7, 8;<br> xi. 5, 18, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_939> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 75;<br> xxi. 43;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 9, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 10, etc.</ref> In the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_939> i. 162, 14.</ref> Ghāsi is used of the fodder of the horse victim at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]].

घृणीवन्त्
<u>'''Ghṛṇīvant'''</u> is the name of some animal in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_940> xxiv. 39.</ref> In the parallel passage of the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_940> iii. 14, 20.</ref> Ghṛṇāvant is the reading. Elsewhere the word is adjectival.<ref name=fx3_ve1_940> Rv. x. 176, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref> 

घृत
<u>'''Ghṛta,'''</u> the modern Ghee or ‘clarified butter,’ is repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_941> i. 134, 6;<br> ii. 10, 4;<br> iv. 10, 6;<br> 58, 5. 7. 9;<br> v. 12, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_941> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 22, etc.;<br> Av. iii. 13, 5, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 1, 7 (with [[दधि|Dadhi]], [[मस्तु|Mastu]], Amikṣā);<br> ix. 2, 1, 1 ([[दधि|Dadhi]], [[मधु|Madhu]], [[घृत|Ghṛta]]), etc.</ref> both as in ordinary use and as a customary form of sacrifice. According to a citation in Sāyaṇa's commentary on the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_941> i. 3 (p. 240, edition Aufrecht).</ref> the distinction between [[घृत|Ghṛta]] and '''[[सर्पिस्|Sarpis]]''' consisted in the latter being butter fully melted, while the former was butter melted and hardened (''ghanī-bhūta''), but this distinction cannot be pressed. Because the butter was thrown into the fire, Agni is styled ‘butter-faced’ (''[[घृत|ghṛta]]-pratīka''),<ref name=fx4_ve1_941> Rv. i. 143, 7;<br> iii. 1, 18;<br> v. 11, 1;<br> x. 21, 7, etc.</ref> ‘butter-backed’ (''[[घृत|ghṛta]]-pṛṣṭha''),<ref name=fx5_ve1_941> Rv. i. 164, 1;<br> v. 4, 3;<br> 37, 1;<br> vii. 2, 4, etc.</ref> and ‘propitiated with butter’ (''[[घृत|ghṛta]]-prasatta''),<ref name=fx6_ve1_941> Rv. v. 15. 1.</ref> and ‘found of butter’ (''[[घृत|ghṛta]]-prī'').<ref name=fx7_ve1_941> Av. xii. 1, 20;<br> xviii. 4, 41.</ref> Water was used to purify the butter: the waters were therefore called ‘butter-cleansing’ (''[[घृत|ghṛta]]-pū'').<ref name=fx8_ve1_941> i. 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 227.</ref> In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]^9 it is said that [[आज्य|Ājya]], [[घृत|Ghṛta]], [[आयुत|Āyuta]], and [[नवनीत|Navanīta]] pertain to gods, men, Pitṛs, and embryos respectively.

घृत-कौशिक
<u>'''Ghṛta-kauśika'''</u> is mentioned in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_942> ii. 5. 21;<br> iv. 5, 27. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 384.</ref> as a pupil of '''[[पाराशर्यायण|Pārāśaryāyaṇa]].'''

घोर आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Ghora Āṅgirasa'''</u> is the name of a mythical teacher in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_943> xxx. 6. ''Cf.'' Āśvalāyana Śrauta Sütra, xii. 10.</ref> and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_943> iii. 17, 6.</ref> where he is teacher of the strange '''[[कृष्ण देवकीपुत्र|Kṛṣṇa Devakīputra]].''' That the name is certainly a mere figment is shown by the fact that this ‘dread descendant of the Aṅgirases’ has a counterpart in '''[[भिषज् आथर्वण|Bhiṣaj Ātharvaṇa]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_943> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 459.</ref> ‘the healing descendant of the Atharvans,’ while in the Rigveda Sūtras<ref name=fx4_ve1_943> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society.'' 17, 181.</ref> the ''Atharvāṇo vedaḥ'' is connected  with ''bheṣajam'' and the ''Āṅgiraso vedaḥ'' with ''ghoram.'' He is accordingly a personification of the dark side of the practice of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx5_ve1_943> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xx, xxi, xxxviii;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 8, 23;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 189, 190;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160, n. 4.</ref> He is also mentioned in the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] section of the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx6_ve1_943> i. 1.</ref>

घोष
<u>'''Ghoṣa.'''</u> See '''[[घोषा|Ghoṣā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

घोषवन्त्
<u>'''Ghoṣavant.'''</u> See '''[[स्वर|Svara]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

घोषा
<u>'''Ghoṣā'''</u> is mentioned as a protégée of the Aśvins in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_946> i. 117, 7;<br> x. 40, 5. ''Cf.'' x. 39, 3. 6.</ref> probably as the recipient of a husband, who is perhaps referred to in another passage<ref name=fx2_ve1_946> i. 122, 5. See Oldenberg, ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 123.</ref> as Arjuna, though this is not likely. Sāyaṇa finds a reference there to a skin disease, which is considered in the later tradition of the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx3_ve1_946> vii. 41-48, with Macdonell's notes.</ref> to have been the cause of her remaining unwed, but this view is not tenable. According to Sāyaṇa, her son, Suhastya, is alluded to in an obscure verse of the Rigveda;<ref name=fx4_ve1_946> i. 120, 5.</ref> Oldenberg,<ref name=fx5_ve1_946> ''Op. cit.,'' 119. Suhastya is apparently invented from x. 41, 3, probably assisted by the fact that [[वध्रिमती|Vadhrimatī]] was given a son, '''[[हिरण्यहस्त|Hiraṇyahasta]],''' by the Aśvins (Rv. i. 117, 24).</ref> however, here sees a reference to [[घोषा|Ghoṣā]] herself, while Pischel<ref name=fx6_ve1_946> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 4;<br> 2, 92.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 143;<br> ''Über Methode bei Interpretation des Rigveda,'' 43;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 247;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 52.</ref> thinks that the form (''ghoṣe'') is not a noun at all, but verbal.

चक
<u>'''Caka'''</u> is mentioned with [[पिशङ्ग|Piśaṅga]] as one of the two Unnetṛ priests at the snake festival in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_947> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35. who reads ''Cakka;<br>'' 10, 142. n. 3, 144</ref> 

चक्र
<u>'''Cakra,'''</u> the ‘wheel’ of a chariot or wagon, is repeatedly mentioned from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_948> i. 130, 9;<br> 155, 6;<br> 164, 2. 11. 14;<br> 174, 5;<br> iv. 1, 3, etc.</ref> onwards, often in a metaphorical sense. The wheel was fixed on the axle ('''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]''') when the chariot was required for use; this required considerable strength, as is shown by a reference in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_948> Av. xi. 7, 4;<br> xix. 53, 1. 2, etc.</ref> The wheel consisted normally of spokes ('''Ara'''), and a nave ('''[[नाभि|Nābhi]]'''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_948> Rv. viii. 41, 6.</ref> in the opening ('''Kha''') of which the end of the axle ('''[[आणि|Āṇi]]''') was inserted. An indication of the importance attached to the strength of the wheel is the celebration of the car of the god Pūṣan as having a wheel that suffers no damage.<ref name=fx4_ve1_948> Rv. vi. 54, 3.</ref> The usual number of wheels was two,<ref name=fx5_ve1_948> Rv. viii. 5, 29;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 16, 5;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4.</ref> but in seven passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_948> i. 118, 2;<br> 157, 3;<br> 183, 1;<br> viii. 58, 3;<br> x. 41, 1;<br> 85, 14 (all of the Aśvins' chariot);<br> iv. 36, 1 (of a chariot made by the Ṛbhus, who are three in number).</ref> a chariot is called ‘three-wheeled,’ in a few others ‘sevenwheeled,’<ref name=fx7_ve1_948> Rv. i. 164, 3, 12;<br> ii. 40, 3.</ref> while in one of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx8_ve1_948> xi. 4, 22.</ref> it is styled ‘eightwheeled.’ Zimmer<ref name=fx9_ve1_948> ''Altindisches Leben,'' viii., ix.</ref> argues that these epithets do not refer to real chariots, pointing out that in all the passages where ''tri-[[चक्र|cakra]],'' ‘three-wheeled,’ occurs there is a mythical reference. On the other hand, Weber<ref name=fx10_ve1_948> ''Proceedings of the Berlin Acadcmy,'' 1898, 564, quoting Virchow, ''Zeistchrift für Ethnologie,'' 5, 200.</ref> thinks that there might have been chariots with three wheels, one being in the centre between the two occupants. This is not very conclusive; at any rate, the seven-wheeled and the eight-wheeled chariots can hardly be regarded as indicating the existence of real vehicles with that number of wheels.<br><br>In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx11_ve1_948> xi. 8, 1, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 247.</ref> the potter's wheel (''kaulālacakra'') is referred to.

चक्र-वाक
<u>'''Cakra-vāka'''</u> is the name, apparently derived from the nature of its cry, of a species of gander (''Anas casarca''), the modern Chakwā, as it is called in Hindī, or Brahmany duck in English.<ref name=fx1_ve1_949> Criffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 309, n. 4.</ref> It is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_949> ii. 39, 3.</ref> and in the list of victims at the  [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_949> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 3. 13;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 22. 32;<br> xxv. 8.</ref> while in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_949> xiv. 2, 64.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 89.</ref> it already appears as the type of conjugal fidelity, its characteristic in the classical literature.

चक्षुस्
<u>'''Cakṣus,'''</u> ‘eye.’ The ‘evil eye’ (''ghoraṃ [[चक्षुस्|cakṣus]]'') was well known in the Atharvaveda, which contains spells to counteract its influence.<ref name=fx1_ve1_950> ii. 7;<br> xix. 45, are so employed in the ritual.</ref> As remedies against it are mentioned salve from Mount '''Trikakubh'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_950> Av. iv. 9, 6.</ref> and the '''[[जङ्गिड|Jaṅgiḍa]]''' plant.<ref name=fx3_ve1_950> Av. xix. 35, 3.</ref> In the wedding ceremony the wife is entreated not to have the evil eye (''aghoracakṣus'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_950> Pāraskara [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 16.</ref> The structure of the eye, and its division into white (''[[शुक्ल|śukla]]''), dark (''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]''), and the pupil (''kanīn ikā'') are repeatedly referred to in the later Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx5_ve1_950> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 2, 26;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 254. 324;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 26, 1;<br> 34, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 1, 5, etc. So the man ('''puru 1''') in the eye is repeatedly mentioned: Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 7, 5;<br> iv. 15, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 3, 5;<br> iv. 2, 2;<br> v. 5, 2. 4, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 27, 2. The Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, 3, adds the water (''āpaḥ'') in the eye, the upper and the lower lids (''vartanī''), and seven red lines (''lohinyo rājayaḥ'').<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 149.</ref> The desease '''[[अलजि|Alaji]]''' appears to have been an affection of the eyes.

चण्डाल
<u>'''Caṇḍāla,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_951> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 10, 7;<br> 14, 4;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 9;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 12;<br> vi. 1, etc.</ref> '''[[चाण्डाल|Cāṇḍāla]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_951> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 21;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 17, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 22.</ref> are the variant forms of the name of a despised caste, which in origin was probably a tribal body,<ref name=fx3_ve1_951> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung.'' 204 ''et seq.''</ref> but which in the Brahminical theory was the offspring of [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] athers and Brahmin mothers.<ref name=fx4_ve1_951> Apparently accepted for the Vedic period by Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 217.<br><br>''Cf.'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Litcratur und Cultur,'' 433.</ref> The references to the caste in he [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās and in the Upaniṣads show clearly hat it was a degraded one, but they yield no particulars. 

चतुष्-पद्
<u>'''Catuṣ-pad,'''</u> ‘quadruped,’ is a regular name for animals from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_952> Rv. i. 49, 3;<br> 94, 5;<br> 119, 1;<br> iii. 62, 14, etc.;<br> Av. iv. 11, 5;<br> x. 8, 21;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 30;<br> ix. 31;<br> xiv. 8. 25, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2;<br> viii. 20, etc.</ref> onwards, being frequently contrasted with '''Dvipad,''' ‘biped.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_952> Rv. x. 117, 8;<br> Av. vi. 107, 1, etc.</ref> Catuṣ-[[पाद|pāda]], as an adjective applying to ''paśavaḥ,'' ‘animals,’ is also found.<ref name=fx3_ve1_952> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 18;<br> vi. 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 3, 2;<br> vi. 8, 2, 17, etc.</ref>

चन्द्र
<u>'''1. Candra,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_953> Av. ii. 15, 2;<br> 22, 1;<br> iii. 31, 6, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28;<br> xxxix. 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 2, 16, etc.</ref> '''[[चन्द्र|Candra]]-mas,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_953> Rv. i. 105, 1;<br> viii. 82, 8;<br> x. 64, 3;<br> 85, 19;<br> Av. xi. 6, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 28;<br> xxiii. 10. 59, etc.</ref> are the names of the ‘moon,’ the latter occurring from the Rigveda onwards, but the former being first used in this sense by the Atharvaveda. Very little is said about the moon in Vedic literature, except as identified with '''Soma,'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_953> See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 112, 113. The identification is clearly found in the later parts of the Rigveda.</ref> both alike being described as waxing and waning. Reference is, however, made to the regular changes of the moon, and to its alternation with the sun,<ref name=fx5_ve1_953> Rv. x. 68, 10. ''Cf.'' i. 62, 8;<br> 72, 10.</ref> to which it, as Soma, is declared in the Rigveda to be married.<ref name=fx6_ve1_953> x. 85, 18. 19.</ref> Mention is also made of its disappearance at the time of new moon,<ref name=fx7_ve1_953> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 4, 18;<br> iv. 6, 7, 12;<br> xi. 1, 6, 19;<br> xiv. 4, 2, 13;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 28, 8;<br> perhaps Rv. x. 138, 4.</ref> and of its birth from the light of the sun.<ref name=fx8_ve1_953> Rv. ix. 71, 9;<br> 76, 4;<br> 86, 32;<br> [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], ii. 9, 2, 12, 1;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 463 ''et seq. Cf.'' [[सूर्य|Sūrya]].</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_953> xix. 9, 10. Av. vi. 128 is also regarded by the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], c. 3, as referring to an eclipse of the moon. See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 533.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 349, 350, 352.</ref> reference is made to demons eclipsing the moon (''grahāś cāndramāsāḥ'').<br><br>For the phases of the moon, and the month as a measure of time, see '''[[मास|Māsa]].''' For the moon and its mansions, see '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br><br>^4) Rv. x. 55, 5. ''Cf.'' Av. x. 8, 32.

चन्द्र
<u>'''2. Candra'''</u> appears to denote ‘gold’ in a certain number of passages from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_954> Rv. ii. 2, 4;<br> iii. 31, 5;<br> Av. xii. 2, 53;<br> Jaittirīya Saṃhitā, i. 2, 7, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 26;<br> xix. 93;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 3, 4, etc. ''Cf.'' the adjective ''candrin'' in Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 37;<br> xxxi. 31.</ref> 

चप्य
<u>'''Capya'''</u> is found in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_955> xix. 88;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 3.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_955> xii. 7, 2, 13;<br> 9, 1, 3.</ref> as the name of a sacrificial vessel.

चमस
<u>'''Camasa'''</u> denotes a ‘drinking vessel,’ usually as employed for holding '''Soma''' at the sacrifice. It is frequently mentioned from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_956> Rv. i. 20, 6;<br> 110, 3;<br> viii. 82, 7;<br> x. 16, 8;<br> 68, 8;<br> 96, 9, etc.;<br> Av. vii. 73, 3;<br> xviii. 3, 54;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 13, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xi. 2;<br> xii. 38.</ref> It was made of wood (''[[वृक्ष|vṛkṣa]]''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_956> Rv. x. 68, 8.</ref> and is hence called ''dru.''<ref name=fx3_ve1_956> Rv. i. 161, 1.</ref> According to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_956> vii. 2, 11, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 280;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 167, 168.</ref> it was made of '''[[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]]''' wood.

चमू
<u>'''Camū'''</u> is a term of somewhat doubtful sense occurring repeatedly in the Rigveda, and connected with the preparation of Soma. Zimmer<ref name=fx1_ve1_957> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 277, 278.</ref> considers that in the dual it denotes the two boards between which, in his opinion, the Soma was crushed (''cf.'' '''[[अधिषवण|Adhiṣavaṇa]]'''). Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_957> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Grassmann, ''Rigveda,'' 1, 15.</ref> however, appears to be right in taking the normal sense to designate a vessel into which the Soma was poured from the press, and Hillebrandt<ref name=fx3_ve1_957> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 164-175.</ref> shows clearly that when it occurs in the plural<ref name=fx4_ve1_957> Rv. iii. 48, 5;<br> viii. 2, 8;<br> 82, 7. 8;<br> ix. 20, 6;<br> 62, 16;<br> 63, 2;<br> 92, 2;<br> 93, 3;<br> 97, 21. 37. 46;<br> 99, 6. 8.</ref> it always has this sense, corresponding to the [[ग्रह|Graha]]-pātras of the later ritual, and that sometimes it is so used in the singular<ref name=fx5_ve1_957> Rv. ix. 107, 18;<br> x. 91, 15.</ref> or dual<ref name=fx6_ve1_957> Rv. ix. 69, 5;<br> 71, 1;<br> 72, 5;<br> 86, 47;<br> 96, 20. 21;<br> 97 2. 48;<br> 103, 4;<br> 107, 10;<br> 108. 10.</ref> also. In some cases,<ref name=fx7_ve1_957> Singular: Rv. v. 51, 4;<br> viii. 4, 4;<br> 76, 10;<br> ix. 46, 3;<br> x. 24, 1. Dual: i. 28, 9;<br> iv. 18, 3;<br> vi. 57, 2;<br> ix. 36, 1.</ref> however, he recognizes its use as denoting the mortar in which the Soma was pressed: he may be right here, as this mode of preparation was probably Indo-Iranian.<ref name=fx8_ve1_957> Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 158-164.</ref><br><br>In a derivative sense [[चमू|Camū]] appears in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve1_957> xiii. 8, 2, 1;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 430, n. 1. In [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 22, 19, the sense is doubtful.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 105 ''et seq.''</ref> to denote a trough, either of solid stone or consisting of  bricks, used by the Eastern people to protect the body of the dead from contact with the earth, like modern stone-lined graves or vaults.

चरक
<u>'''Caraka'''</u> primarily denotes a ‘wandering student,’ a sense actually found in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_958> iii. 3, 1.</ref> More especially it denotes the members of a school of the Black [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]], the practices of which are several times referred to with disapproval in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_958> iii. 8, 2, 24 (where the reference is to [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā vi. 3, 9, 6;<br> 10, 2, or some parallel passage);<br> iv. 1, 2, 19;<br> 2, 3, 15;<br> 4, 1, 10;<br> vi. 2, 2, 1. 10;<br> viii. 1, 3, 7;<br> 7, 1, 14. 24.</ref> In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_958> xxx. 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 16, 1. Its occurrence in the latter text renders improbable von Schroeder's view, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 188, that [[चरक|Caraka]] included all the Black [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] schools.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 287, n. 2;<br> 3, 256, 257, 454;<br> ''Indian Literature.'' 87;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 212.</ref> the [[चरक|Caraka]] teacher (''Carakācārya'') is enumerated among the sacrificial victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human sacrifice. His dedication there to ill-doing is a clear hint of a ritual feud.

चरक-ब्राह्मण
<u>'''Caraka-brāhmaṇa'''</u> is the name of a work from which Sāyaṇa quotes in his commentary on the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_959> viii. 66, 10;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 41.</ref>

चराचर
<u>'''Carācara'''</u> (‘running about’), a term found classed with '''[[सरीसृप|Sarīsṛpa]]''' in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_960> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 13, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 29.</ref> must apparently denote some kind of animal.

चरु
<u>'''Caru'''</u> designates a ‘kettle’ or ‘pot’ from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_961> Rv. i. 7, 6;<br> vii. 104, 2;<br> ix. 52, 3;<br> x. 86, 18;<br> 167, 4;<br> Av. iv. 7, 4;<br> ix. 5, 6;<br> xi. 1, 16;<br> 3, 18;<br> xviii. 4, 16 ''et seq.,'' etc. It is called ''pañca-bild,'' ‘with five openings,’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 1, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, v. 6;<br> xxxii. 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 4. 9, etc.</ref> It had a lid (''apidhāna'') and hooks (''[[अङ्क|aṅka]]'') by which it could be hung over a fire.<ref name=fx2_ve1_961> Rv. i. 162, 13;<br> Av. xviii. 4, 53.</ref> It was made of iron or bronze<ref name=fx3_ve1_961> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 4, 5<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 271.</ref>  (''ayasmaya''). The word is also secondarily used<ref name=fx4_ve1_961> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 10, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 4, 7;<br> ii. 5, 3, 4;<br> iii. 2, 3, 1, etc. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Ināische Studien,'' 9, 216.</ref> to denote the contents of the pot, the mess of grain which was cooked in it.

चर्मन्
<u>'''Carman,'''</u> denoting ‘hide’ in general, is a common expression from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_962> Rv. i. 85, 5;<br> 110, 8;<br> 161, 7;<br> iii. 60, 2;<br> iv. 13, 4, etc.;<br> Av. v. 8, 13;<br> x. 9, 2;<br> xi. 1, 9, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 7, 1;<br> vi. 1, 9, 2, etc. The stem ''carma,'' neuter (loc., ''carme''), is found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 2, 2.</ref> The oxhide was turned to many uses, such as the manufacture of bowstrings, slings, and reins (see '''Go'''). It was especially often employed to place above the boards<ref name=fx2_ve1_962> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 148-150;<br> 181-183.</ref> on which the Soma was pressed with the stones.<ref name=fx3_ve1_962> Rv. x. 94, 9;<br> 116, 4.</ref> It was possibly also used for making skin bags.<ref name=fx4_ve1_962> Rv. x. 106, 10, is so taken by Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben.'' 228, who compares ''Odyssey,'' x. 19.</ref> Carmaṇya denotes leather-work generally in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_962> v. 32. ''Cf. [[परिचर्मण्य|paricarmaṇya]],'' Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, ii. 1.</ref><br><br>The art of tanning hides (''mlā'') was known as early as the Rigveda,<ref name=fx6_ve1_962> viii. 55, 3 (a late hymn).</ref> where also the word for ‘tanner’ (''carmamna'') occurs.<ref name=fx7_ve1_962> viii. 5, 38;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 13, 1. For the form, ''cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 38, n. 1;<br> p. 249, n. 4.</ref> Details of the process are lacking, but the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_962> ii. 1, 1, 9.</ref> refers to stretching out a hide with pegs (''śañkubhiḥ''), and the Rigveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_962> i. 85, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 228, 253.</ref> mentions the wetting of the hide.

चर्षणि
<u>'''Carṣaṇi,'''</u> used in the plural, denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_963> Rv. i. 86, 5;<br> 184, 4;<br> iii. 43, 2;<br> iv. 7, 4;<br> v. 23, 1;<br> vi. 2, 2;<br> x. 180, 3, etc.</ref> ‘men’ in general or ‘people,’ conceived either as active beings<ref name=fx2_ve1_963> If derived from ''car,'' ‘move,’ which is probable.</ref> or as cultivators<ref name=fx3_ve1_963> If derived from ''kṛṣ,'' ‘plough or ‘till.’</ref> in opposition to nomads. The expression ‘king of men’ (''rājā carṣaṇīnām'') is frequently found.<ref name=fx4_ve1_963> Rv. iii. 10, 1;<br> v. 39, 4;<br> vi. 30, 5;<br> viii. 70, 1;<br> x. 139, 1, etc.</ref> The ‘people’ are  also mentioned in connexion with war.<ref name=fx5_ve1_963> Rv. i. 55, 1;<br> 109, 6;<br> iv. 31, 4;<br> 37, 8;<br> vi. 31, 1, etc.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_963> xiii. 1, 38.</ref> ‘animals’ (''[[पशु|paśu]]'') and ‘men’ (''[[चर्षणि|carṣaṇi]]'') are spoken of together.<br><br>For the five ''carṣaṇayaḥ,''<ref name=fx7_ve1_963> Rv. v. 86, 2;<br> vii. 15, 2;<br> ix. 101, 9.
