For the derivation, see Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 185, and especially 122, 2''a'' (from ''car,'' ‘move’);<br> Monier Williams, Dictionary, ''s.v.'' (from ''kṛṣ,'' ‘plough’).</ref> see '''Pañca Janāsaḥ.'''

चषाल
<u>'''Caṣāla,'''</u> the mortar-shaped top-piece of the sacrificial post ('''[[यूप|Yūpa]]'''), is mentioned from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_964> Rv. i. 162, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 4, 2, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvi. 4, etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 11, 8, etc.</ref> In one passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_964> v. 2, 1, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 168, n. 1;<br> 41, 31, n. 1.</ref> it is directed to be made of wheaten dough (''gaudhūma'').

चाक्र
<u>'''Cākra'''</u> is the name of a man, variously styled [[रेवोत्तरस्|Revottaras]] [[स्थपति|Sthapati]] [[पाटव|Pāṭava]] [[चाक्र|Cākra]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_965> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. xii. 8, 1, 17.</ref> and [[रेवोत्तरस्|Revottaras]] [[पाटव|Pāṭava]] [[चाक्र|Cākra]] [[स्थपति|Sthapati]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_965> ''Ibid.,'' xii. 9, 3, 1 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 205207;<br> 10, 85. n. 1;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 123;<br> Eggeling. ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 269 ''et seq.,'' whose version is followed above.</ref> who is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] only. He is there said to have been expelled by the '''Sṛñjayas,''' but to have restored to them their prince '''[[दुष्टरीतु|Duṣṭarītu]]''' despite the opposition of the [[कौरव्य|Kauravya]] king '''[[बल्हिक प्रातिपीय|Balhika Prātipīya]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_965/> He must have been a sage rather than a warrior, as the first passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_965/> shows him in the capacity of a teacher only. ''Cf.'' '''[[स्थपति|Sthapati]].'''

चाक्रायण
<u>'''Cākrāyaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[चक्र|Cakra]],’ is the patronymic of '''Uṣasta''' or '''Uṣasti.'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_966> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 5, 1;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 10, 1;<br> 11, 1.</ref>

चाण्डाल
<u>'''Cāṇḍāla.'''</u> See '''[[चण्डाल|Caṇḍāla]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

चाक्षुष
<u>'''Cākṣuṣa,'''</u> a word occurring once only in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_968> xvi. 7, 7.</ref> is, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, a patronymic (of Suyāman, a personification). Whitney<ref name=fx2_ve1_968> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 800.</ref> treats it as probably a simple adjective (‘of sight’). 

चातुर्-मास्य
<u>'''Cātur-māsya,'''</u> ‘four-monthly,’ denotes the festival of the Vedic ritual held at the beginning of the three seasons of four months each, into which the Vedic year was artificially divided.<ref name=fx1_ve1_969> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 5, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 9, 5;<br> ii. 2, 2, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 36;<br> ii. 5, 2, 48;<br> 6, 4, 1;<br> v. 2, 3, 10;<br> xiii. 2, 5, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, etc.</ref> It is clear that the sacrifices commenced with the beginning of each season,<ref name=fx2_ve1_969> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 36 (''cf.'' xiv. 1, 1, 28);<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1.</ref> and it is certain that the first of them, the Vaiśvadeva, coincided with the Phālgunī full moon,<ref name=fx3_ve1_969> In the month Phālguna, or February-March.</ref> the second, the Varuṇa-praghāsas, with the Āṣāḍhī full moon,<ref name=fx4_ve1_969> In the month Āṣāḍhā, or JuneJuly.</ref> and the third, the Sāka-[[मेध|medha]], with the Kārttikī full moon.<ref name=fx5_ve1_969> That is, in the month Kārttika, when the moon is in the asterism Kṛttikā: Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 3, 13;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, etc.</ref> There were, however, two alternative datings: the festivals could also be held in the Caitrī, the Śrāvaṇī, and Āgrahāyaṇī (Mārgaśīrṣī) full moons,<ref name=fx6_ve1_969> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 13, 1;<br> 14, 1. 2;<br> 15, 1. These are the fullmoon days in the months [[चैत्र|Caitra]] (March-April), Śrāvaṇa (July-August), and Mārgaśīṛṣa (November-December) respectively.</ref> or in the Vaiśākhī, Bhādrapadī, and Pauṣī full moons.<ref name=fx7_ve1_969> Deva's Paddhati on Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], pp. 430, 450, 497. These are the full-moon days in the months Vaiśākha (April-May), Bhādrapada (August-September), and Pauṣa (December-January) respectively.</ref> Neither of the later datings is found in a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] text, but each may well have been known early, since the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx8_ve1_969> vii. 4, 8, 1. 2.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve1_969> v. 9, 8. 11.</ref> both recognize the full moon in the month [[चैत्र|Caitra]] as an alternative to the full moon in the month Phālguna, for the beginning of the year.<br><br>Jacobi considers that the commencement of the year with the full moon in the asterism [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]], which is supported by other evidence,<ref name=fx10_ve1_969> ''Indian Antiquary,'' 23, 156 ''et seq.;<br> Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 223 ''et seq.;<br>'' 50, 72-81.</ref> indicates that the year at one time began with the winter solstice with the moon in [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]], corresponding to the summer solstice when the sun was in [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]]. These astronomical conditions, he believes, existed in the time of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx11_ve1_969> vii. 103, 9;<br> x. 85, 13. ''Cf. Festgruss an Rudolf von Roth,'' 68 ''et seq.''</ref> and prevailed in the fourth millennium B.C. The alternative  dates would then indicate periods when the winter solstice coincided with the Caitrī or the Vaiśākhī full moon. But Oldenberg<ref name=fx12_ve1_969> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 630 ''et seq.;<br>'' 49, 475, 476;<br> 50, 453-457.</ref> and Thibaut<ref name=fx13_ve1_969> ''Indian Antiquary,'' 24, 86 ''et seq.''</ref> seem clearly right in holding that the coincidence of Phālgunī with the beginning of spring,<ref name=fx14_ve1_969> See [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 6, 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 1, 2-4. So the Phālgunī full moon is called ‘the mouth of the seasons (''ṛtūnāṃ mukham'')--''e.g.,'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 15, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 9;<br> and the first season is always spring: Śatapaṭha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 3, 8-14;<br> ii. 1, 3, 1;<br> vii. 2, 4, 26;<br> xi. 2, 7, 32;<br> xii. 8, 2, 34;<br> xiii. 5, 4, 28;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 2, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 1. 7, etc. See Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 352.</ref> which is certain, is fatal to this view, and that there is no difficulty in regarding this date as consistent with the date of the winter solstice in the new moon of Māgha, which is given by the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx15_ve1_969> xix. 3.</ref> and which forms the basis of the calculations of the [[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]].<ref name=fx16_ve1_969> Thibaut, ''Astronomie, Astrologie, und Mathematik,'' 17, 18.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 329 ''et seq.;<br>'' Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, lxxxvi., lxxxvii.;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 1101-1104.</ref> The full moon in Phālguna would be placed about one month and a half after the winter solstice, or, say, in the first week of February, which date, according to Thibaut, may reasonably be deemed to mark the beginning of a new season in India about 800 B.C. At the same time it must be remembered that the date was necessarily artificial, inasmuch as the year was divided into three seasons, each of four months, and the Indian year does not in fact consist of three equal seasons. The variations of the other datings would then not be unnatural if any school wished to defer its spring festival, the Vaiśvadeva, to the time when spring had really manifested itself. See also '''[[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]].'''

चान्धनायन
<u>'''Cāndhanāyana'''</u> is the patronymic of '''Ānandaja''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_970> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372, 383.</ref>

चायमान
<u>'''Cāyamāna'''</u> is the patronymic in the Rigveda (vi. 27, 5. 8) of '''Abhyāvartin.''' <br>==Foot Notes==

चाष
<u>'''Cāṣa,'''</u> the ‘blue woodpecker’ (''Coracias indica''), is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_972> x. 97, 13.</ref> as well as in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_972> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 4;<br> 15, 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 23;<br> xxv. 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 92.</ref>

चिच्चिक
<u>'''Ciccika'''</u> is a bird mentioned with the equally unknown '''[[वृषारव|Vṛṣārava]]''' in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_973> x. 146, 2.</ref> It may perhaps be compared with the Ciṭaka mentioned by Dārila in his commentary on the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_973> xxvi. 20;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 266.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 90;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 589.</ref>

चित्र
<u>'''Citra'''</u> is the name of several persons. (''a'') The Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_974> viii. 21, 18.</ref> contains a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) of a prince [[चित्र|Citra]]. The later legend<ref name=fx2_ve1_974> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 58 ''et. seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> attributes this panegyric to [[सोभरि|Sobhari]], and describes [[चित्र|Citra]] as king of the rats.<br><br>(''b'') [[चित्र|Citra]] [[गाङ्ग्यायनि|Gāṅgyāyani]] or Gārgyāyaṃ is mentioned in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_974/> as a contemporary of '''[[आरुणि|Āruṇi]]''' and '''[[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]].'''<br><br>(''c'') [[चित्र|Citra]] [[गौश्रायणि|Gauśrāyaṇi]] is mentioned as a teacher in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1b_ve1_974/>

चित्र-रथ
<u>'''Citra-ratha'''</u> (‘having a brilliant car’) is the name of two persons.<br><br>(''a'') It designates an Āryan prince, who, with Arṇa, was defeated by Indra for the [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]-Yadus on the '''[[सरयु|Sarayu]]''' (perhaps the modern Sarju in Oudh), according to the Rigveda (iv. 30, 18). The locality would accord with the close connexion of [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] and '''[[क्रिवि|Krivi]]''' or '''[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]].''' <br><br>(''b'') [[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]] is also the name of a king for whom the '''Kāpeyas''' performed a special kind of sacrifice (''dvirātra''), with the result, according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_975> xx. 12, 5. ''Cf.'' Hopkins. ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 52, 53;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 32;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 68, n.</ref> that in the [[चैत्ररथि|Caitrarathi]] family only one member was a [[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]]-pati, the rest dependents. Apparently this must mean that the Caitrarathis were distinguished from other families of princes by the fact that the chief of the clan received a markedly higher position than in most cases, in which probably the heads of the family were rather an oligarchy than a monarch and his dependents. See '''[[राजन्|Rājan]].'''

चित्रा
<u>'''Citrā.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

चिल्वटि
<u>'''Cilvaṭi'''</u> is the name of an unknown animal in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 2, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

चीपुद्रु
<u>'''Cīpudru'''</u> designates some substance mentioned in a hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_978> vi. 127, 2.</ref> as of use in healing. The commentator Sāyaṇa reads Cīpadru, and explains the word as a kind of tree. This interpretation is supported by the fact that the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_978> xxvi. 34.</ref> refers to the employment of splinters of [[पलाश|Palāśa]] wood in the ritual application of this hymn.<ref name=fx3_ve1_978> Av. vi. 127.</ref> Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve1_978> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 376.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 350-352;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 62;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 386. The text of Roth and Whitney reads by error ''[[शीपुद्रु|Śīpudru]].''</ref> suggests that the form of the word should be Cīpuḍu.

चुमुरि
<u>'''Cumuri'''</u> is the name of an enemy of '''[[दभीति|Dabhīti]],''' for whom he, along with his friend '''[[धुनि|Dhuni]],''' is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_979> vi. 20, 13;<br> x. 113, 9. In vi. 26, 6, [[चुमुरि|Cumuri]] alone is mentioned, and Dāsas or Dasyus generally are stated to have been subdued for [[दभीति|Dabhīti]] in iv. 30, 21;<br> ii. 13, 9. See also ii. 15, 9;<br> vii. 19, 4.</ref> as having been defeated by Indra. Elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve1_979> Rv. vi. 18, 8.</ref> the two are spoken of, along with '''[[शम्बर|Śambara]], [[पिप्रु|Pipru]],''' and Śuṣṇa, as having been crushed by Indra, who destroyed their castles. It is impossible to say whether real men or demons are meant, but in favour of  a man being denoted by [[चुमुरि|Cumuri]] is the form of the name, which seems not to be Āryan.<ref name=fx3_ve1_979> Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, xxii.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 275;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology'' p. 162.</ref>

चूड भागवित्ति
<u>'''Cūḍa Bhāgavitti'''</u> (‘descendant of Bhagavitta’) is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaṇiṣad<ref name=fx1_ve1_980> vi. 3, 9 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]]=vi. 3, 17. 18 Mādhyaṃdina). The text of the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] has, as usual, Cūla.</ref> as a pupil of '''[[मधुक पैङ्ग्य|Madhuka Paiṅgya]].'''

चूर्ण
<u>'''Cūrṇa'''</u> appears to denote an aromatic powder in the phrase ''[[चूर्ण|cūrṇa]]-[[हस्त|hasta]],'' used of the Apsarases in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

चेदि
<u>'''Cedi'''</u> is the name of a people who, with their king '''[[कशु|Kaśu]],''' the [[चैद्य|Caidya]], are mentioned only in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’), occurring at the end of one hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_982> viii. 5, 37-39.</ref> where their generosity is celebrated as unsurpassed. They occur later in the Epic with the '''Matsyas,''' and lived in Bandela Khaṇḍa (Bundelkhand).<ref name=fx2_ve1_982> Lassen, ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 12, 688, n. 3;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 129;<br> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 332;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 402.</ref> In Vedic times they were probably situated in much the same locality.

चेलक शाण्डिल्यायन
<u>'''Celaka Śāṇḍilyāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]'''’) is mentioned as a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 4, 5, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

चैकितानेय
<u>'''Caikitāneya'''</u> (‘descendant of Cekitāna’) is mentioned as a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_984> i. 37, 7;<br> ii. 5, 2.</ref> The Caikitāneyas are also referred to there<ref name=fx2_ve1_984> i. 42, 1.</ref> in connexion with the Sāman which they worshipped. '''Brahmadatta''' [[चैकितानेय|Caikitāneya]] is brought into connexion with the Sāman in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_984> i. 3, 24.</ref> and '''[[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]]''' [[चैकितानेय|Caikitāneya]] is known to the Ṣaḍviṃśa<ref name=fx4_ve1_984> iv. 1.</ref> and [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx5_ve1_984> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373, 384.</ref> The word is a patronymic, formed from  Caikitāna, according to Śaṅkara,<ref name=fx6_ve1_984> On Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> but more probably from Cekitāna,<ref name=fx7_ve1_984> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> a name found in the Epic.

चैकितायन
<u>'''Caikitāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Cikitāyana<ref name=fx1_ve1_985> Śaṅkara on Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 8, 1.</ref> or Cekita,’<ref name=fx2_ve1_985> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> is the patronymic of '''[[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]]''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_985> i. 8, 1.</ref>

चैत्र
<u>'''Caitra'''</u> is the patronymic of '''[[यज्ञसेन|Yajñasena]]''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxi. 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

चैत्र-रथि
<u>'''Caitra-rathi.'''</u> See '''[[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]]''' and '''Satyādhivāka.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

चैत्रियायण
<u>'''Caitriyāyaṇa'''</u> is the patronymic or metronymic of the teacher '''[[यज्ञसेन|Yajñasena]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (v. 3, 8, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

चैद्य
<u>'''Caidya.'''</u> See '''Cedi.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

चैलकि
<u>'''Cailaki,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Celaka,'''’ is the patronymic of Jīvala in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 3, 1, 34).<br>==Foot Notes==

चोर
<u>'''Cora,'''</u> ‘thief,’ is only found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, a late work, in its last book (x. 65). The Vedic terms are '''[[तस्कर|Taskara]] [[तायु|Tāyu]], [[स्तेन|Stena]],''' and '''[[परिपन्थिन्|Paripanthin]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

च्यवतान मारुताश्व
<u>'''Cyavatāna Mārutāśva'''</u> (‘descendant of Marutāśva’) is apparently the name of a prince in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’), in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_992> v. 33, 9. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3. 155.</ref> Two distinct persons may, however, be meant.

च्यवन
<u>'''Cyavana,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_993> This form is found even in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (iv. 19), regularly in all the Vedic texts other than the Rigveda, and in the Epic.</ref> '''Cyavāna,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_993> The Rv. has this form throughout.</ref> are variant forms of the name of an ancient [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], or seer. The Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_993> i. 116, 10;<br> 117, 13;<br> 118, 6;<br> v. 74, 5;<br> vii. 68, 6;<br> 71, 5;<br> x. 39, 4.</ref> represents him as an old decrepit man, to whom the Aśvins restored youth and strength, making him acceptable to his wife, and a husband of maidens.  The legend is given in another form in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_993> iv. 1, 5, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> where [[च्यवन|Cyavana]] is described as wedding [[सुकन्या|Sukanyā]], the daughter of '''[[शर्यात|Śaryāta]].''' He is there called a [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]] or [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]], and is represented as having been rejuvenated by immersion in a pond--the first occurrence of a motive, later very common in Oriental literature. Another legend about Cyavāna is apparently alluded to in an obscure hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_993> x. 61, 1-3.</ref> where he seems to be opposed to the '''[[पक्थ|Paktha]]''' prince '''[[तूर्वयाण|Tūrvayāṇa]],''' an Indra worshipper, while Cyavāna seems to have been specially connected with the Aśvins. This explanation of the hymn, suggested by Pischel,<ref name=fx6_ve1_993> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 71-77;<br> accepted by Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 465.</ref> is corroborated by the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx7_ve1_993> iii. 121-128;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, cxlvi;<br> 26, 43 ''et seq.''</ref> which relates that '''Vidanvant,''' another son of [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]], supported [[च्यवन|Cyavana]] against Indra, who was angry with him for sacrificing to the Aśvins; it is also noteworthy that the Aśvins appear in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_993> iv. 1, 5, 13 ''et seq.''</ref> as obtaining a share in the sacrifice on the suggestion of [[सुकन्या|Sukanyā]]. But a reconciliation of Indra and [[च्यवन|Cyavana]] must have taken place, because the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve1_993> viii. 21, 4;<br> Pischel, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 75.</ref> relates the inauguration of '''[[शार्यात|Śāryāta]]''' by [[च्यवन|Cyavana]] with the great Indra consecration (''aindreṇa mahābhiṣekeṇa''). In the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇā<ref name=fx10_ve1_993> xiii. 5, 12;<br> xix. 3, 6;<br> xiv. 6, 10;<br> xi. 8, 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 243, 250-254;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 156;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 51, 52;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 43 ''et seq.;<br> Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 56, 57.</ref> [[च्यवन|Cyavana]] is mentioned as a seer of Sāmans or Chants.

छग
<u>'''Chaga'''</u> is the name of the ‘goat’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (v. 6, 22, 1). ''Cf.'' '''Aja''' and '''[[छाग|Chāga]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

छदिस्
<u>'''Chadis'''</u> is used once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_995> x. 85, 10 (of Sūryā's bridal car).</ref> and not rarely later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_995> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 9, 4;<br> 10, 5. 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 28;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 29;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 3, 9, etc.</ref> to denote the covering of a wagon or the thatch of a house, or  something analogous to these. Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_995> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 208.</ref> thinks that in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_995> iii. 7, 3.</ref> the word designates a constellation, and Whitney,<ref name=fx5_ve1_995> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 95.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 336.</ref> who does not decide whether that interpretation is necessary, suggests that the constellation  Aquarii may be meant, sicne the next verse mentions '''[[विचृतौ|Vicṛtau]],''' which is the constellation  and  Scorpionis, and is not far from Aquarius. See also '''[[छर्दिस्|Chardis]].'''

छन्दस्
<u>'''1. Chandas'''</u> in the Rigveda usually denotes a ‘song of praise’ or ‘hymn.’<ref name=fx1_ve1_996> Rv. x. 85, 8 (an obscure verse);<br> 114, 5;<br> Av. iv. 34, 1;<br> v. 26, 5;<br> vi. 124, 1;<br> xi. 7, 8, etc.</ref> The original sense of the word, as derived from the verb ''chand,'' ‘to please,’ was probably ‘attractive spell,’ ‘magic hymn,’<ref name=fx2_ve1_996> ''Cf.'' Roth in St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> which prevailed on the gods. In a very late hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_996> Rv. x. 90, 9.</ref> as well as in one of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_996> Av. xi. 7, 24.</ref> the word is mentioned in the plural (''chandāṃsi''), beside Ṛc (''ṛcaḥ''), Sāman (''sāmāni''), and [[यजुस्|Yajus]], and seems to retain its original meaning, not improbably with reference to the magical subject-matter of the Atharvaveda. From denoting a (metrical) hymn it comes to mean ‘metre’ in a very late verse of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_996> x. 14, 16.</ref> in which the ‘Gāyatrī, the Triṣṭubh, and all (''sarvā'') the metres (''chandāṃsi'') are mentioned. In the later Saṃhitās three<ref name=fx6_ve1_996> Av. xviii. 1, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 27, etc.</ref> or seven<ref name=fx7_ve1_996> Av. viii. 9, 17. 19, etc.</ref> metres are enumerated, and in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_996> viii. 3, 3, 6, etc.</ref> eight. By the time of the Rigveda Prātiśākhya<ref name=fx9_ve1_996> xvi. 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, xcv. ''et seq.''</ref> the metres were subjected to a detailed examination, though much earlier references are found to the number of syllables in the several metres.<ref name=fx10_ve1_996> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 4;<br> Jaittirīya Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 2, 7.</ref> Later the word definitely denotes a Vedic text generally, as in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx11_ve1_996> xi. 5, 7, 3. So Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 3, 4. 15, etc.</ref> 

छन्दस्
<u>'''2. Chandas'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_997> iii. 12, 3.</ref> in the adjectival compound ''[[बृहच्-छन्दस्|bṛhac-chandas]],'' which is used of a house, and must mean ‘having a large roof.’ Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve1_997> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 345;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 150.</ref> accepts the reading as correct, but Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve1_997> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 105.</ref> considers emendation to '''[[छदिस्|Chadis]]''' necessary.

छन्दो-ग
<u>'''Chando-ga,'''</u> ‘metre-singing,’ is the term applied to reciters of the Sāmans, no doubt because these chants were sung according to their order in the Chandaārcika of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]]. It is only found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_998> x. 5, 2, 10.</ref> and often in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_998> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 2;<br> xxii. 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 8, 33;<br> xiii. 1, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1908, 720.</ref>

छर्दिस्
<u>'''Chardis'''</u> occurs often in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_999> i. 48, 15;<br> 114, 5;<br> vi. 15, 3;<br> 46, 9. 12, etc.</ref> and occasionally later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_999> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 9, 2;<br> 3, 6, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 19;<br> xiv. 12.</ref> denoting a secure dwelling-place. The word appears to be incorrectly written, because the metre shows that the first syllable is always short. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_999> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Prolegomena,'' 477.</ref> accordingly suggested that '''[[छदिस्|Chadis]]''' should be read instead. But [[छदिस्|Chadis]] means ‘roof,’ while [[छर्दिस्|Chardis]] never has that sense. Bartholomae<ref name=fx4_ve1_999> ''Studien,'' 1, 47;<br> 2, 58. ''Cf.'' Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, xii., n. 2;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 312.</ref> is therefore probably right in suggesting some other form, such as Chaḍis.

छाग
<u>'''Chāga,'''</u> ‘goat,’ is found in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1000> i. 162, 3.</ref> and not rarely later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1000> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 89;<br> xxi. 40. 41;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 3, 4;<br> v. 1, 3, 14;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 2.</ref> See '''Aja''' and '''[[छग|Chaga]].''' 

जगत्
<u>'''Jagat,'''</u> ‘moving,’ is applied sometimes in the Atharvaveda, and later to the domestic animals in particular, as opposed to wild animals (''śvapad'').<ref name=fx1_ve1_1001> Av. viii. 5, 11, etc.</ref> Occasionally the cow is mentioned separately, when the word ''[[जगत्|jagat]]'' covers the rest of the domesticated animals.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1001> Av. i. 31, 4;<br> x. 1, 29;<br> xix. 47, 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 59. In the Rv. the sense of animal in general is usually sufficient;<br> but ''cf. jagatī'' in i. 157, 5;<br> vi. 72, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 150, n.</ref>

जङ्गिड
<u>'''Jaṅgiḍa'''</u> is the name of a healing plant mentioned in the hymns of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1002> ii. 4;<br> xix. 34. 35.</ref> It was used as an amulet against the diseases, or symptoms of disease, '''[[तक्मन्|Takman]], [[बलास|Balāsa]], [[आशरीक|Āśarīka]], Viśarīka, [[पृष्ट्य्आमय|Pṛṣṭyāmaya]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1002> Av. xix. 34, 10.</ref> fevers and rheumatic pains, '''[[विष्कन्ध|Viṣkandha]]''' and '''[[संस्कन्ध|Saṃskandha]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1002> Av. ii. 4, 1;<br> xix. 34, 1. 5.</ref> '''[[जम्भ|Jambha]],''' and so on. But it is also regarded as a specific against all diseases, and as the best of healing powers.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1002> Av. xix. 34, 9. 7.</ref> It is said to be produced from the juices (''rasa'') of ploughing (''[[कृषि|kṛṣi]]''),<ref name=fx5_ve1_1002> Av. ii. 4, 5.</ref> but this need only mean that it grew in cultivated land, not that it was itself cultivated. What plant the name designates is quite uncertain, for it disappears in the later literature. Caland<ref name=fx6_ve1_1002> ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 15, rendering [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 15.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 433;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 42;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 141;<br> Grohmann, ''ibid.,'' 9, 417;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 65, 66, 390.</ref> takes it in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] to be the ''Terminalia arjuneya.''

जतू
<u>'''Jatū,'''</u> the ‘bat,’ occurs in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1003> ix. 2, 22.</ref> and is mentioned as one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1003> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 25. 26.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 86.</ref> 

जन
<u>'''Jana,'''</u> besides meaning ‘man’ as an individual, with a tendency to the collective sense, commonly denotes a ‘people’ or ‘tribe’ in the Rigveda and later. Thus, the ‘five tribes’ ('''Panca Janāḥ''' or '''Janāsaḥ''') are frequently referred to, and in one hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1004> viii. 6, 46. 48.</ref> the ‘people of Yadu’ (''[[याद्व|yādva]] jana'') and the '''Yadus''' (''yādvāḥ'') are synonymous. Again, the king (''[[राजन्|rājan]]'') is described as ‘protector (''[[गोपा|gopā]]'') of the people (''janasya''),’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1004> Rv. iii. 43, 5. So Soma is called ''[[गोपति|gopati]] janasya,'' ‘protector of the people,’ Rv. ix. 35, 5.</ref> and there are other references to king and Jana.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1004> Rv. v. 58, 4.</ref> The people of the '''Bharatas''' (''[[भारत|bhārata]] jana'') is also mentioned;<ref name=fx4_ve1_1004> Rv. iii. 53, 12. See also '''[[भरत|Bharata]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' also x. 174, 5 = Av. i. 29, 6.</ref> there is no ground to assume with Hopkins<ref name=fx5_ve1_1004> ''Religions of India,'' 26, 27. It is true that the Bharatas are called a ''gavyan grāmaḥ,'' ‘a horde eager for booty,’ in Rv. iii. 33, 11;<br> but [[ग्राम|Grāma]] has there merely a general application. Seen. 10.</ref> that Jana in this case means a clan or horde ('''[[ग्राम|Grāma]]'''), as distinguished from a people.<br><br>It is difficult to say exactly how a people was divided. Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve1_1004> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 159, 160.</ref> argues from a passage in the Rigveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_1004> ii. 26, 3.</ref> that a people was divided into cantons ('''[[विश्|Viś]]'''), cantons into joint families or clans, or village communities ('''[[ग्राम|Grāma]], [[वृजन|Vṛjana]]'''), and these again into single families. He thinks that the four divisions are reflected in the passage in question. by Jana, [[विश्|Viś]], [[जन्मन्|Janman]], and Putrāḥ, or sons, and argues that each village community was originally founded on relationship. But it is very doubtful whether this precise division of the people can be pressed. The division of the Jana into several [[विश्|Viś]] may be regarded as probable, for it is supported by the evidence of another passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1004> x. 84, 4. ''Viśaḥ'' may have the same sense in several other passages--iv. 24, 4;<br> v. 61, 1;<br> vi. 26, 1;<br> vii. 79, 2;<br> viii. 12, 29--but it need not necessarily bear this sense. But in x. 91, 2, there is a clear contrast between [[विश्|Viś]] and Jana.</ref> which mentions the [[विश्|Viś]] as a unit of the fighting men, and thus shows that, as in Homeric times and in ancient Germany, relationship was deemed a good principle of military arrangement. But the subdivision of the [[विश्|Viś]] into several Grāmas is very doubtful. Zimmer<ref name=fx9_ve1_1004> ''Op. cit.,'' 161. He also relies on Rv. v. 53, 11, where the Maruts are divided into ''[[शर्ध|śardha]], [[व्रात|vrāta]],'' and ''gaṇa;<br>'' but these words are vague.</ref> admits that neither [[ग्राम|Grāma]]<ref name=fx10_ve1_1004> Rv. iii. 33. 11. See n. 5.</ref>  nor '''[[वृजन|Vṛjana]]'''<ref name=fx11_ve1_1004> Rv. vii. 32, 27;<br> x. 42, 10.</ref> has the special sense of a subdivision of the [[विश्|Viś]] when used for war, for both words only denote generally an armed host. He finds other designations of the village host in '''Vrā'''<ref name=fx12_ve1_1004> Rv. i. 126, 5 (''viśyā iva vrāḥ'').</ref> and in '''Vrāja,'''<ref name=fx13_ve1_1004> Rv. x. 179, 2=Av. vii. 72, 2.</ref> but it is sufficient to say that the former passage is of extremely doubtful import,<ref name=fx14_ve1_1004> ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 121, 319.</ref> and that the latter has no reference to war at all. It is therefore impossible to state in what exact relation the [[ग्राम|Grāma]] in Vedic times stood to the [[विश्|Viś]] or to the family (Kula or [[गोत्र|Gotra]]). The confusion is increased by the vagueness of the sense of both [[ग्राम|Grāma]] and [[विश्|Viś]]. If the latter be regarded as a local division, then no doubt the [[ग्राम|Grāma]] must have been a part of a district; but if a [[विश्|Viś]] was a unit of relationship, then a [[ग्राम|Grāma]] may have contained families of different Viśes, or may have sometimes coincided with a [[विश्|Viś]], or have contained only a part of a [[विश्|Viś]]. But in any case the original state of affairs must have been greatly modified by the rise of the system of caste, and the substitution of a hierarchical for a political point of view. The elements of the people were represented by the family--either as an individual family inhabiting one home ('''Kula'''), and consisting often, no doubt, of a joint family of brothers, or as a patriarchal family of sons who still lived with their father--and by the clan, the later '''[[गोत्र|Gotra]],''' which included all those who claimed a common ancestor. The [[गोत्र|Gotra]] may be regarded as roughly corresponding to the Latin ''gens'' and the Greek , and possibly the [[विश्|Viś]] may be the equivalent of the ''curia'' and, and the Jana of the ''tribus'' and  or .<ref name=fx15_ve1_1004> ''Cf. Iliad,'' 2, 362.</ref> These three divisions may also be seen in the [[विश्|Viś]], Zantu, and Daqyu of the Iranian world, where the use of [[विश्|Viś]] suggests that in the Indian [[विश्|Viś]] a relationship based on blood rather than locality is meant--and perhaps even in the ''vicus, pagus,'' and ''civitas'' of the old German polity described in the Germania<ref name=fx16_ve1_1004> Chap. vii. Zimmer gives other equations, for which ''cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 393 ''et seq.'' The exact parallelism cannot in any case be pressed.</ref> of Tacitus. The family in some form appears as the third element of the Jana in a passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx17_ve1_1004> x. 91, 2, where ''janaṃ janam'' and ''viśaṃ viśam'' occur, and where a contrast must be meant.</ref> where the house (''[[गृह|gṛha]]'') is  contrasted with the Jana and the [[विश्|Viś]]. Possibly, too, another passage<ref name=fx18_ve1_1004> Rv. vii. 82, 1.</ref> contrasts the ''adhvara,'' or family sacrifice, with that of the Jana or [[विश्|Viś]], rather than, as Zimmer<ref name=fx19_ve1_1004> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 435.</ref> thinks, the village with the two larger units. But it is significant of the particularism of the Vedic Indians that while the king maintained a fire which might be regarded as the sacred fire of the tribe, there is no sure trace<ref name=fx20_ve1_1004> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 126.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 158;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 32, 33;<br> Jolly, ''Zeitschrift der Dcutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 512 ''et seq.''</ref> of any intermediate cult between that of the king and that of the individual householder. The real elements in the state are the [[गोत्र|Gotra]] and the Jana, just as ultimately the ''gens'' and ''tribus,'' the  and  are alone important. It may be that [[विश्|Viś]] sometimes represents in the older texts what later was known as the [[गोत्र|Gotra]]. See '''[[विश्|Viś]].'''<br><br>This appears clearly when the constitution of society in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period is considered. The tribe or people still exists, and is presupposed, but the division into [[विश्|Viś]] disappears. The real division is now the separate castes ('''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]'''), but the numerous sections into which each of them is divided appear to be based in part on the ancient [[गोत्र|Gotra]].

जन शार्करक्ष्य
<u>'''2. Jana Śārkarakṣya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Śarkarakṣa'''’) is mentioned as a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 6, 1, 1 ''et seq.'') and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (v. 11, 1; 15, 1). He was a contemporary of '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]] [[कैकेय|Kaikeya]],''' and of '''Aruṇa [[औपवेशि|Aupaveśi]]''' and his son '''[[उद्दालक आरुणि|Uddālaka Āruṇi]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जनक
<u>'''Janaka,'''</u> king of [[विदेह|Videha]], plays a considerable part in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1006> xi. 3, 1, 2;<br> 4, 3, 20;<br> 6, 2, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1006> iii. 1, 1;<br> iv. 1, 1;<br> 2, 1;<br> 4, 7;<br> v. 14, 8.</ref> as well as in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1006> i. 19, 2 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 23, 329);<br> ii. 76 (''ibid.,'' 15, 238).</ref> and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1006> iv. 1.</ref> He was a contemporary of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] [[वाज|Vāja]]-  saneya,'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1006> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 1, 2;<br> 4, 3, 20;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> of '''[[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]] [[आरुणेय|Āruṇeya]],''' and of other sages.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1006> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 2, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> He had become famous for his generosity and his interest in the discussion of the nature of [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], as ultimate basis of reality, in the life-time of '''[[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]]''' of [[काशि|Kāśi]].<ref name=fx7_ve1_1006> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 1.</ref> It is significant that he maintained a close intercourse with the Brahmins of the Kuru-Pañcālas, such as [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] and [[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]]; for this indicates that the home of the philosophy of the Upaniṣads was in the Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] country rather than in the east. There is a statement in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_1006> xi. 6, 2, 10.</ref> that he became a Brahmin (''brahmā''). This does not, however, signify a change of caste, but merely that in knowledge he became a Brahmin (see '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]'''). [[जनक|Janaka]] is occasionally mentioned in later texts: in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve1_1006> iii. 10, 9, 9.</ref> he has already become quite mythical; in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx10_ve1_1006> xvi. 26, 7.</ref> a ''sapta-rātra'' or seven nights' rite is ascribed to him.<br><br>It is natural to attempt to date [[जनक|Janaka]] by his being a contemporary of [[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]], and by identifying the latter with the Ajātasattu of the Pāli texts:<ref name=fx11_ve1_1006> Vincent Smith, ''Early History of India,'' 26 ''et seq.''</ref> this would make the end of the sixth century B.C. the approximate date of [[जनक|Janaka]].<ref name=fx12_ve1_1006> Hoernle, ''Osteology,'' 106.</ref> But it is very doubtful whether this identification can be supported: [[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]] was king of [[काशि|Kāśi]], whereas Ajātasattu was king of [[मगध|Magadha]], and his only connexion with [[काशि|Kāśi]] was through his marriage with the daughter of Pasenadi of [[कोसल|Kosala]].<ref name=fx13_ve1_1006> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 3 ''et seq.''</ref> Moreover, the acceptance of this chronology would be difficult to reconcile with the history of the development of thought; for it would make the rise of Buddhism contemporaneous with the Upaniṣads, whereas it is reasonably certain that the older Upaniṣads preceded Buddhism.<ref name=fx14_ve1_1006> See ''e.g.,'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur and Cultur,'' 243;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 224;<br> Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upaniṣads,'' 23 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 25, 29.</ref> Nor do the Vedic texts know anything of Bimbisāra or Pasenadi, or any of the other princes famed in Buddhist records. <br><br>The identification<ref name=fx15_ve1_1006> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 135;<br> Von Schroeder, ''op. cit.,'' 189;<br> Macdonell, ''op. cit.,'' 214.</ref> of [[जनक|Janaka]] of [[विदेह|Videha]] and the father of [[सीता|Sītā]] is less open to objection, but it cannot be proved, and is somewhat doubtful. In the Sūtras [[जनक|Janaka]] appears as an ancient king who knew of a time when wifely honour was less respected than later.<ref name=fx16_ve1_1006> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 48.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 426 ''et seq.;<br>'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 421 ''et seq.;<br>'' Von Schroeder, ''op. cit.,'' 187-189;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 175, 231;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 31, n., who properly emphasizes the difficulty of attaching much importance to the names of the leaders of the thought of the Upaniṣads.</ref>

जनता
<u>'''Janatā,'''</u> a word frequently found in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1007> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 1, 4;<br> 6, 4;<br> 3, 4, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 17;<br> Av. v. 18, 12, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1007> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 6, 1;<br> ii. 3, 1, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7. 9;<br> iii. 31;<br> v. 9, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 153, n.</ref> denotes the people as a community (''cf.'' '''[[सभा|Sabhā]]''') or as a religious unit.

जन-पद
<u>'''Jana-pada'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas denotes both the ‘people,’ as opposed to the king,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1008> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 14 (plural);<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 17.</ref> and the ‘land’ or ‘relam.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1008> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 9, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 20;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 5;<br> viii. 1, 5.</ref> The ‘subjects’ are also denoted by the adjectival ''[[जानपद|jānapada]].''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1008> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 5, 1, 20.</ref>

जनम्-एजय
<u>'''1. Janam-ejaya'''</u> (‘man-impelling’) is the name of a king, a '''[[पारिक्षित|Pārikṣita]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1009> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 34;<br> viii. 11. 21;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 8, 27, etc.</ref> famous towards the end of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period. He is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1009> xi. 5, 5, 13.</ref> as owning horses which when wearied were refreshed with sweet drinks, and as a performer of the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1009> xiii. 5, 4, 1-3.</ref> His capital, according to a [[गाथा|Gāthā]] quoted in the Śatapatha<ref name=fx4_ve1_1009> xiii. 5, 4, 2.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1009> viii. 21.</ref> was '''[[आसन्दीवन्त्|Āsandīvant]].''' His brothers '''[[उग्रसेन|Ugrasena]], [[भीमसेन|Bhīmasena]],''' and '''[[श्रुतसेन|Śrutasena]]''' are mentioned as having  by the horse sacrifice purified themselves from sin. The priest who performed the sacrifice for him was '''[[इन्द्रोत|Indrota]] Daivāpi [[शौनक|Śaunaka]].'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1009> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 1;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ''loe. cit.''</ref> On the other hand the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx7_ve1_1009> viii. 21. ''Cf.'' iv. 27;<br> vii. 34.</ref> which also mentions his [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], names '''[[तुर कावषेय|Tura Kāvaṣeya]]''' as his priest. It also contains an obscure tale stating that at one sacrifice of his he did not employ the '''Kaśyapas,''' but the '''Bhūtavīras,''' being, however, induced by the '''Asitamṛgas''' to have recourse to the Kaśyapas again.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1009> vii. 27. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 204;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 438, n. 229;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 345, n.</ref> He was a '''Kuru''' prince; see '''[[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]].''' The Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve1_1009>i. 2, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 123125;<br> 134-136;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 37, 65 ''et seq.;<br>'' 42, 239;<br> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 28 ''et seq.''</ref> tells an absurd tale about him, evidently as of an ancient hero.

जनम्-एजय
<u>'''2. Janam-ejaya'''</u> is in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1010> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref> the name of a priest who officiated at the snake sacrifice.

जन-श्रुत
<u>'''Jana-śruta'''</u> (‘famed among men’) '''[[काण्ड्विय|Kāṇḍviya]]''' is the name of a pupil of '''Hṛtsvāśaya,''' mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 2), and of [[वारक्य|Vārakya]], a pupil of '''[[जयन्त|Jayanta]],''' referred to in the same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1; iv. 17, 1). ''Cf.'' '''[[जानश्रुति|Jānaśruti]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जनि
<u>'''Jani, Janī.'''</u>--These words appear to denote ‘wife,’ usually applying to her in relation to her husband ('''Pati'''). The more general sense of ‘woman’ is doubtful; for when Uṣas is called a fair '''Janī,'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1012> Rv. iv. 52, 1.</ref> ‘wife’ may be meant, and the other passage<ref name=fx2_ve1_1012> v. 61, 3.</ref> cited for this sense by Delbrück,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1012> ''Die indogermanischen Verwandschaftsnamen,'' 413.</ref> which refers to the begetting of childern, seems to demand the sense of ‘wives.’ Since the words usually appear in the plural,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1012> i. 85, 1;<br> iv. 5, 5;<br> 19, 5;<br> vii. 18, 2;<br> 26, 3;<br> ix. 86, 32;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 35;<br> xx. 40. 43, etc. ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 43, 1. In x. 110, 5, the phrase is ''patibhyo na janayaḥ,'' where both plurals may be generic</ref> it is possible they may  refer not to ‘wives’ proper, but to Hetairai. This is, however, rendered unlikely because the Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_1012> x. 18, 8. ''Cf. janitvana'' in viii. 2, 42.</ref> uses the phrase ''patyur janitvam,'' denoting ‘wifehood to a husband,’ as well as the expression ''janayo na patnīḥ,''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1012> i. 62, 10;<br> 186, 7.</ref> ‘like wives (who are) mistresses,’<ref name=fx7_ve1_1012> The distinction of sense was probably this: ''jani'' meant ‘wife,’ as bearing children (from ''jan,'' ‘beget’), while ''[[पत्नी|patnī]]'' was ‘wife,’ as being mistress of the house (feminine of ''pati,'' ‘lord,’ ‘husband’).</ref> besides containing passages in which the word has reference to marriage.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1012> v. 61, 3. So in x. 40, 10, the word seems certainly to refer to marriage.</ref> The singular occurs in the dialogue of Yama and Yamī.<ref name=fx9_ve1_1012> x. 10, 3.</ref>

जनितृ
<u>'''Janitṛ'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1013> Rv. i. 129, 11;<br> 164, 33;<br> iii. 1, 10;<br> 54, 9, etc.;<br> Av. iv. 1, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 87, etc.</ref> and '''Janitrī'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1013> Rv. iii. 48, 2;<br> 54, 14;<br> Av. vi. 110, 13;<br> ix. 5, 30, etc.</ref> are frequent words, in the Rigveda and later, for ‘father’ and ‘mother’ regarded as the ‘begetter’ and the ‘bearer’ respectively of the child. See '''[[पितृ|Pitṛ]], [[मातृ|Mātṛ]].'''

जन्तु
<u>'''Jantu,'''</u> besides the general sense of ‘man,’ has also in a few passages<ref name=fx1_ve1_1014> Rv. 1. 94, 5;<br> x. 140, 4.</ref> the more restricted sense of ‘follower’ or ‘subject.’ The ‘followers of '''[[श्वैत्रेय|Śvaitreya]]'''’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1014> Rv. v. 19, 3.</ref> may be compared with the ‘subjects (''viśaḥ'') of '''[[तृणस्कन्द|Tṛṇaskanda]].'''’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1014> Rv. i. 172, 3.</ref>

जन्मन्
<u>'''Janman'''</u> appears to have the sense of ‘relations’ in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1015> iii. 15, 2;<br> ii. 26, 3 (where ''janena, viśā, janmanā, putraiḥ,'' is the series).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 160, and see '''Jana''' and '''[[विश्|Viś]].'''</ref> being used collectively in the second of them.

जन्य
<u>'''Janya'''</u> has in the Rigveda (iv. 38, 6) and the Atharvaveda (xi. 8, 1) the special sense of bridesman.’<br>==Foot Notes==

जबाला
<u>'''Jabālā'''</u> is the name of the mother of an illegitimate son, '''[[सत्यकाम|Satyakāma]],''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 4, 1. 2. 4). <br>==Foot Notes==

जभ्य
<u>'''Jabhya,'''</u> ‘snapper,’ denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1018> vi. 50, 2. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 237.</ref> an insect destructive to grain.

जमद्-अग्नि
<u>'''Jamad-agni'''</u> is one of the somewhat mythical sages of the Rigveda, where he is frequently mentioned. In some passages<ref name=fx1_ve1_1019> Rv. iii. 62, 18;<br> viii. 101, 8;<br> ix. 62, 24;<br> 65, 25.</ref> his name occurs in such a way as to indicate that he is the author of the hymn; once<ref name=fx2_ve1_1019> Rv. x. 167, 4.</ref> he is thus associated with '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]].''' In other passages<ref name=fx3_ve1_1019> Rv. vii. 96, 3;<br> ix. 97, 51.</ref> he is merely referred to, and the Jamadagnis are mentioned once.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1019> Rv. iii. 53, 15. 16.</ref> In the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1019> ii. 32, 3 (''cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 36;<br> [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 1);<br> iv. 29, 3;<br> v. 28, 7;<br> vi. 137, 1;<br> xviii. 3, 15. 16.</ref> as well as the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx6_ve1_1019> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 12, 4;<br> iii. 1, 7, 3;<br> 3, 5, 2;<br> v. 2, 10, 5;<br> 4, 11, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 19;<br> iv. 2, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 19;<br> xx. 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 62;<br> xiii. 56.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1019> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4, 14;<br> xiii. 5, 15;<br> xxi. 10, 5-7;<br> xxii. 7, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 16;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 2, 14;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 9, 7;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, 4;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 11;<br> iv. 3, 1, etc.</ref> he is quite a frequent figure. Here he appears as a friend of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_1019> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 7, 3;<br> v. 4, 11, 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 15.</ref> and a rival of '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]].'''<ref name=fx9_ve1_1019> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> He owed his prosperity to his ''catūrātra,'' or ‘four-night’ ritual, with which his family were also very successful.<ref name=fx10_ve1_1019> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 10, 5-7.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx11_ve1_1019> ii. 32, 3;<br> vi. 137, 1.</ref> [[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]] is connected with '''Atri''' and '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]],''' as well as '''[[असित|Asita]]''' and '''Vitahavya.''' He was [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] priest at the proposed sacrifice of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]].'''<ref name=fx12_ve1_1019> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 16.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connscticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 53, 54;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 319;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 95.</ref>

जम्भ
<u>'''Jambha'''</u> occurs twice in the Atharvaveda as the name of a disease or a demon of disease. In one passage<ref name=fx1_ve1_1020> ii. 4, 2.</ref> it is said to be cured by the '''[[जङ्गिड|Jaṅgiḍa]]''' plant; in the other<ref name=fx2_ve1_1020> viii. 1, 16.</ref> it is described as ''samhanuḥ,'' ‘bringing the jaws together.’ Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_1020> ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 142.</ref> argued from  the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1020> xxxii. 1.</ref> that it was a child's ailment, especially ‘teething.’ Bloomfield<ref name=fx5_ve1_1020> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 283.</ref> considers it to mean ‘convulsions,’ while Caland<ref name=fx6_ve1_1020> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgen ländischen Gesellschaft,'' 53, 224;<br> ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 103.</ref> thinks it denotes ‘tetanus.’ Whitney<ref name=fx7_ve1_1020> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 42.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 392.</ref> decides for ‘lockjaw’ or ‘convulsions.’

जम्भक
<u>'''Jambhaka,'''</u> as the name of a demon, presumably identical with the demon causing '''[[जम्भ|Jambha]],''' is mentioned in the [[वाज|Vāja]] saneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1021> xxx. 16.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1021> xii. 25. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āranyaka,'' 67, n. 7.</ref>

जयक लौहित्य
<u>'''Jayaka Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1) as a pupil of '''[[यशस्विन् जयन्त लौहित्य|Yaśasvin <a class="pada_vei" href="जयन्त">Jayanta]] Lauhitya».'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जयन्त
<u>'''Jayanta'''</u> is the name of several teachers in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]:<br><br>(''a'') [[जयन्त|Jayanta]] [[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]] (‘descendant of '''[[पराशर|Parāśara]]'''’) is mentioned as a pupil of '''Vipaścit''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers).<ref name=fx1_ve1_1023> iii. 41, 1.</ref><br><br>(''b'') [[जयन्त|Jayanta]] [[वारक्य|Vārakya]] (‘descendant of Varaka’) appears in the same [[वंश|Vaṃśa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1023/> as a pupil of '''[[कुबेर वारक्य|Kubera Vārakya]].''' His grandtather is also mentioned there as a pupil of '''[[कंस|Kaṃsa]] [[वारक्य|Vārakya]].'''<br><br>(''c'') A [[जयन्त|Jayanta]] [[वारक्य|Vārakya]], pupil of '''[[सुयज्ञ शाण्डिल्य|Suyajña Śāṇḍilya]],''' perhaps identical with the preceding, is found in another [[वंश|Vaṃśa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1023> iv. 17, 1.</ref><br><br>(''d'') [[जयन्त|Jayanta]] is a name of '''Yaśasvin [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1023> iii. 42, 1. Not only is the formation of the name a late one (''cf.'' Whitney, ''Sanskrit Grammar,'' 1209d, and Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar'' 191''a''), but the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] in which it occurs is also a late one.</ref><br><br>See also '''Dakṣa [[जयन्त|Jayanta]]''' [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]].

जरा-बोध
<u>'''Jarā-bodha,'''</u> a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1024> i. 27, 10.</ref> is of doubtful meaning. It is held by Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1024> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 103.</ref> to be the name of  a seer. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1024> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], x. 8.</ref> regards it as a mere adjective meaning ‘attending to the invocation,’ which is perhaps the most probable interpretation. Oldenburg,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1024> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 23. He compares the ''ṛṣī [[बोध|bodha]]-pratibodhau'' of Av. v. 30, 10.</ref> however, thinks that the word is a proper name, the literal sense being ‘alert in old age.’

जरायु
<u>'''Jarāyu'''</u> is found once in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1025> i. 27, 1.</ref> in the sense of a ‘serpent's skin.’ Usually<ref name=fx2_ve1_1025> Rv. v. 78, 8;<br> Av. i. 11, 4;<br> vi. 49, 1;<br> ix. 4, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 6, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 8;<br> xix. 76;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 11, etc;<br> Chāndogya Upanisad, iii. 10. 2, etc.</ref> it denotes the outer covering (chorion) of the embryo, as opposed to the ''ulva,'' the inner covering (amnion).<br><br>Living things are occasionally classified according to their mode of origin. In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1025> vi. 3, 1.</ref> they are divided into ''(a) āṇḍa-ja,'' ‘egg-born’; ''(b) [[जीव-ज|jīva-ja]],'' ‘born alive,’ or born from the womb; ''(c) udbhij-ja,'' ‘propagated by sprouts.’ In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx4_ve1_1025> ii. 6.</ref> the division is fourfold: ''(a) āṇḍa-ja; (b) [[जारु|jāru]]-ja,'' that is, ''[[जरायु|jarāyu]]-ja'' (found in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1025> i. 12, 1.</ref> and needlessly read here by Bo7htlingk);<ref name=fx6_ve1_1025> See ''[[जारु|jāru]]'' in Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 430, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 196, 292;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 235.</ref> ''(c) udbhij-ja;'' and ''(d) svcda-ja,'' ‘sweat-born,’ explained as ‘insects.’

जरितृ
<u>'''1. Jaritṛ'''</u> is the regular term in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1026> i. 2, 2;<br> 165, 14;<br> ii. 33, 11;<br> iii. 60, 7, etc.</ref> and occasionally later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1026> Av. v. 11, 8;<br> xx. 135, 1, etc.</ref> for a singer of hymns of praise or worshipper.

जरितृ
<u>'''2. Jaritṛ.'''</u> According to Sieg,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1027> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 44 ''et seq.''</ref> mention is made in one hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1027> x. 142.</ref> of [[जरितृ|Jaritṛ]], one of the Śārṅgas. That hymn he seeks to bring into connexion with the epic<ref name=fx3_ve1_1027> Mahābhārata, i. 222, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> tradition  of the [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] Mandapāla, who wedded Jaritā, a female [[शार्ङ्ग|Śārṅga]] bird--apparently a hen sparrow (''caṭakā'')--and had four sons. These being abandoned by him and exposed to the danger of being consumed by a forest fire, prayed to Agni with the hymn Rigveda x. 142. This interpretation is very doubtful, though Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx4_ve1_1027> On Rv. x. 142, 7. 8.</ref> appears to have adopted it.

जरूथ
<u>'''Jarūtha,'''</u> mentioned in three passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1028> vii. 1, 7;<br> 9, 6;<br> x. 80. 3.</ref> appears to denote a '''demon''' defeated by Agni.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1028> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 17.</ref> Ludwig, however, followed by Griffith,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1028> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 11, n.</ref> sees in him a foe slain in a battle in which '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]],''' the traditional author of the seventh Maṇḍala of the Rigveda, was [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or domestic priest.

जर्तिल
<u>'''Jartila,'''</u> ‘wild sesamum,’ is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (v. 4, 3, 2) as an unsuitable sacrificial offering. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ix. 1, 1, 3) sesamum seeds are regarded as combining the qualities of cultivation (viz., edibility) with those of wild growth (because they are produced on unploughed land).<br>==Foot Notes==

जर्वर
<u>'''Jarvara'''</u> was Gṛhapati or ‘householder’ at the snake festival described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1030> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

जल जातूकर्ण्य
<u>'''Jala Jātūkarṇya'''</u> (‘descendant of Jātūkarṇa’), is mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xvi. 29, 6) as having obtained the position of [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or domestic priest, of the three peoples or kings of '''[[काशि|Kāśi]], [[विदेह|Videha]],''' and '''[[कोसल|Kosala]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जलाष-भेषज
<u>'''Jalāṣa-bheṣaja,'''</u> ‘whose remedy is Jalāṣa,’ is an epithet of Rudra in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1032> i. 43, 4;<br> viii. 29, 5.</ref> and the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1032> ii. 27, 6. It also occurs in the Nīlarudra [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (a very late work), 3, and ''jalāṣa'' as an adjective is found in Rv. ii. 33, 7;<br> viii. 33, 6.</ref> The word  '''[[जालाष|Jālāṣa]]''' occurs in a hymn of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1032> vi. 57.</ref> where it denotes a remedy, perhaps, for a tumour or boil.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1032> Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 321 ''et seq.;<br>'' ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 489.</ref> The commentator on this passage and the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1032> xxxi. 11.</ref> regard [[जालाष|Jālāṣa]] as meaning ‘urine,’ which seems a probable interpretation.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1032> Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 12, 425 ''et seq.''</ref> But Geldner<ref name=fx7_ve1_1032> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 139, n. 2.</ref> thinks that rain-water, conceived as urine, is meant; and the Naighaṇṭuka<ref name=fx8_ve1_1032> i. 12.<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 323, 324;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 76, 77;<br> Hopkins, ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' 1894, cl.</ref> identifies ''jalāṣa'' and ''udaka'' ‘water.’

जष
<u>'''Jaṣa'''</u> is the name of some aquatic animal or fish in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1033> xi. 2, 25. There are various readings: ''[[झष|jhaṣa]], jakha, jagha.''</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1033> v. 5, 13, 1.</ref> The commentary on the latter text explains it by ''[[मकर|makara]],'' probably meaning ‘dolphin.’ The word also occurs in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1033> ii. 2, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 96;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 624</ref><br><br>''Cf.'' '''[[झष|Jhaṣa]].'''

जहका
<u>'''Jahakā,'''</u> the ‘polecat,’ is mentioned as a victim at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1034> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 18, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 36. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 86.</ref> Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx2_ve1_1034> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> thinks it means a jackal living in holes (''vila-vāsī kroṣṭā'').

जह्नु
<u>'''Jahnu'''</u> occurs only in the plural in the legend of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]],''' who is said to have obtained, as [[देवरात|Devarāta]], both the lordship of the Jahnus and the divine lore of the Gāthins.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1035> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 18 (''Jahnūnām cādhipatye daive vede ca Gāthinām'');<br> Asvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 14;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 27 (p. 195, 1. 21, ed. Hillebrandt, where the reading is different and the sense altered: ''Jahnūnāṃ cādhitasthire daive vede ca Gāthinaḥ.'' The two ''ca'''s cannot be justified, and the text must be incorrect).</ref> A '''[[जाह्नव|Jāhnava]],''' or descendant of [[जह्नु|Jahnu]], was, according to the Pañcaviṃśa  [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1035> xxi. 12. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 54, who correctly explains the passage which Sāyaṇa misunderstands.</ref> '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],''' who is said, by means of a certain ''catū-rātra'' or ‘four-night’ ritual, to have secured the kingdom for the Jahnus in their conflict with the '''Vṛcīvants.''' He is here described as a king. Again, in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1035> vii. 17, 6, 7.</ref> [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] is addressed as a ''[[राज-पुत्र|rāja-putra]],'' ‘prince,’ and ''Bharatarṣabha,'' ‘bull of the Bharatas.’ It is therefore clear that the Brāhmaṇas, though not the Saṃhitās, saw in him at once a priest and a prince by origin, though there is no trace whatever of their seeing in him a prince who won Brahmanhood as in the version of the later texts.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1035> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1, 337 ''et seq.''</ref><br><br>A Jahnāvī is mentioned twice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1035> i. 116, 19;<br> iii. 58, 6. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 153.</ref> being either the wife of [[जह्नु|Jahnu]], or, as Sāyaṇa thinks, the race of [[जह्नु|Jahnu]]. The family must clearly once have been a great one, later merged in the Bharatas.

जात शाकायन्य
<u>'''Jāta Śākāyanya'''</u> (‘descendant of Śāka’) is mentioned as a ritual authority and contemporary of '''[[शङ्ख|Śaṅkha]]''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxii. 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

जात-रूप
<u>'''Jāta-rūpa,'''</u> ‘possessing native beauty,’ is the name of ‘gold’ in the later Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_1037> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 13 (''[[जातरूप|jātarūpa]]-maya,'' ‘composed of gold’);<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 25;<br> Naighaṇṭuka, i. 2.</ref> and the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1037> ''[[रजत|Rajata]]-jātarūpe,'' ‘silver and gold,’ Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 6, 24. ''Cf.'' viii. 1, 3;<br> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 16;<br> xiii. 3, etc.;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 19, 9.</ref>

जाति
<u>'''Jāti,'''</u> which in the Pāli<ref name=fx1_ve1_1038> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 22, n. 4.</ref> texts is the word denoting ‘caste,’ does not occur at all in the early Vedic literature; when it is found, as in the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1038> xv. 4, 14. So ''jātīya,'' xx. 2, 11, etc.</ref> it has only the sense of ‘family’ (for which ''cf.'' '''Kula, [[गोत्र|Gotra]],''' and '''[[विश्|Viś]]'''). For the influence of the family system on the growth of caste, see '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].''' To assume that it was the basis of caste, as does  Senart,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1038> ''Les Castes dans l'Inde'' (1896).</ref> is difficult in face of the late appearance of words for family and of stress on family.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1038> Fick, ''op. cit.,'' 3;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 51, 267 ''et seq.''</ref>

जातू-कर्ण्य
<u>'''Jātū-karṇya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Jātūkarṇa,'''’ is the patronymic of several persons.<br><br>(''a'') A pupil of '''[[आसुरायण|Āsurāyaṇa]]''' and '''[[यास्क|Yāska]]''' bears this name in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1039> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3.</ref> In the Mādhyaṃdina<ref name=fx2_ve1_1039> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27.</ref> he is a pupil of '''[[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]].'''<br><br>(''b'') A [[कात्यायनी-पुत्र|Kātyāyanī-putra]], ‘son of [[कात्यायनी|Kātyāyanī]],’ bears this name in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1039> viii. 10.</ref><br><br>(''c'') A [[जातूकर्ण्य|Jātūkarṇya]] is mentioned in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1039> xxvi. 5 (Jātukarṇya in Lindner's index, 159, is a misprint).</ref> as a contemporary of '''[[अलीकयु वाचस्पत्य|Alīkayu Vācaspatya]]''' and other sages.<br><br>(''d'') [[जातूकर्ण्य|Jātūkarṇya]] is in the Sūtras<ref name=fx5_ve1_1039> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 3, 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 17;<br> iii. 16, 14;<br> 20, 19;<br> xvi. 29, 6 ('''Jala''');<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 1, 27;<br> xx. 3, 17;<br> xxv. 7, 34, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 138140.</ref> frequently a patronymic of teachers whose identity cannot be determined. The same person or different persons may here be meant.

जातू-ष्ठिर
<u>'''Jātū-ṣṭhira'''</u> occurs in one verse of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1040> ii. 13, 11.</ref> where Sāyaṇa and Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1040> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 152.</ref> interpret the word as a proper name. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1040> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' (with a wrong reference, ii. 23, 11).</ref> renders it as an adjective meaning ‘naturally powerful.’<ref name=fx4_ve1_1040> ''Urkräftig.'' Grassmann, ''Wo7rterbuch,'' similarly explains the word as ‘powerful by nature or birth’ (''jātū'').</ref>

जान
<u>'''Jāna,'''</u> ‘descendant of Jana,’ is the patronymic of '''Vṛśa''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1041> xiii. 3, 12.</ref> and apparently in the Śāṭyāyanaka.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1041> In Sāyaṇa on Rv. v. 5. ''Cf.'' Bṛhaddevatā, v. 14 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 64 ''et seq.''</ref> 

जानक
<u>'''Jānaka,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[जनक|Janaka]],’ is the patronymic of '''Kratuvid''' in some MSS. of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1042> vii. 34.</ref> In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1042> ii. 3, 8, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 1.</ref> the name appears instead as '''[[क्रतुजित् जानकि|Kratujit Jānaki]].''' [[जानक|Jānaka]] is also, according to some manuscripts of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1042> vi. 3, 10 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> the patronymic of '''Āyasthūṇa,''' but is here no doubt a misreading of '''[[जानकि|Jānaki]].'''

जानकि
<u>'''Jānaki,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[जनक|Janaka]],’ is the patronymic of '''Kratujit''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1043> ii. 3, 8, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 1.</ref> of '''Kratuvid''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1043> vii. 34.</ref> and of '''Āyasthūṇa''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1043> vi. 3, 10 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = vi. 3, 18. 19, Mādhyaṃdina).</ref> where he is mentioned as a pupil of '''[[चूड भागवित्ति|Cūḍa Bhāgavitti]],''' and as teacher of '''[[सत्यकाम|Satyakāma]] [[जाबाल|Jābāla]].'''

जानं-तपि
<u>'''Jānaṃ-tapi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Janaṃtapa,’ is the patronymic of '''Atyarāti''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 23).<br>==Foot Notes==

जान-पद
<u>'''Jāna-pada.'''</u> See '''[[जनपद|Janapada]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जान-श्रुति
<u>'''Jāna-śruti,'''</u> ‘descendant of Jānaśruta,’ is the patronymic of '''Pautrāyaṇa''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 1, 1; 2, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

जान-श्रुतेय
<u>'''Jāna-śruteya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Jānaśruti’ or of ‘Janaśrutā.’ is the patronymic or metronymic of several persons--'''Upāvi'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1047> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 25, 115.</ref> or '''[[औपावि|Aupāvi]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1047> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 1, 5. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 5.</ref> '''Ulukya,'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1047> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3.</ref> '''Nagarin,'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1047> ''Ibid.,'' iii. 40, 2.</ref> and '''[[सायक|Sāyaka]].'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1047> ''Ibid.''</ref>

जाबाल
<u>'''Jābāla,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Jabāla,'''’ is the metronymic of '''[[महाशाल|Mahāśāla]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1048> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 3, 3, 1;<br> 6, 1, 1.</ref> and '''[[सत्यकाम|Satyakāma]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1048> ''Ibid.,'' xiii. 5, 3, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 14;<br> vi. 3, 19;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 4, 1, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 7.</ref> [[जाबाल|Jābāla]] is also mentioned as a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1048> iii. 9, 9.</ref> which refers to the  Jābālas<ref name=fx4_ve1_1048> iii. 7, 2.</ref> as well. The [[जाबाल|Jābāla]] Gṛhapatis are spoken of in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_1048> xxiii. 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 395.</ref>

जाबालायन
<u>'''Jābālāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[जाबाल|Jābāla]],’ is the patronymic of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[माध्यंदिनायन|Mādhyaṃdināyana]],''' who is mentioned in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 6, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

जामदग्निय
<u>'''Jāmadagniya'''</u> is the patronymic of two ‘descendants of Jamadagni’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1050> vii. 1, 9, 1.</ref> It appears from the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1050> xxi. 10, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 12, 251, n.;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 54.</ref> that the '''Aurvas''' are meant, and that Jamadagni's descendants were ever prosperous.

जामातृ
<u>'''Jāmātṛ'''</u> is a rare word denoting ‘son-in-law’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1051> viii. 2, 20. Vāyu is called the ''[[जामातृ|jāmātṛ]]'' of [[त्वष्टृ|Tvaṣṭṛ]] in viii. 26, 21. 22.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 517;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 78, 79.</ref> where also occurs the word '''[[विजामातृ|Vijāmātṛ]],''' denoting an ‘unsatisfactory son-in-law,’ as one who does not pay a sufficient price, or one who, having other defects, must purchase a bride. Friendly relations between son-in-law and father-in-law are referred to in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1051> x. 28, 1. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 255.</ref>

जामि
<u>'''Jāmi,'''</u> a word which appears originally to have meant ‘related in blood,’ is not rarely used as an epithet of ‘sister’ ('''[[स्वसृ|Svasṛ]]'''), and sometimes even denotes ‘sister’ itself, the emphasis being on the blood-relationship.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1052> ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Dic indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 463, 464. As ‘relation,’ it occurs, ''e.g.,'' Rv. i. 31, 10;<br> 75, 3. 4;<br> 100, 11;<br> 124, 6, etc.;<br> as ‘sister,’ Rv. i. 65, 7;<br> x. 10, 10, etc.;<br> with ''svasā,'' i. 123, 5;<br> 185, 5;<br> iii. 1, 11;<br> ix. 65, 1;<br> 89, 4, etc.</ref> So it appears in a passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1052> i. 17, 1.</ref> where ‘brotherless sisters’  (''abhrātara iva jāmayaḥ'') are referred to. The word is similarly used in the dispute occurring in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1052> iii. 37.</ref> as to the precedence of [[राका|Rākā]], or of the wives of the gods, in a certain rite. One party is there described as holding that the sister should be preferred (''jāmyai vai pūrva-peyam'')--apparently at a ceremonial family meal--to the wife, presumably as being of one blood with the husband, while the wife is not (being ''anyodaryā,'' ‘of another womb’).<ref name=fx4_ve1_1052> Delbrück, ''loc. cit.''</ref> In the neuter<ref name=fx5_ve1_1052> Rv. iii. 54, 9;<br> x. 10, 4;<br> ''[[जामि|jāmi]]-kṛt,'' ‘making relationship,’ Av. iv. 19, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Altareya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> the word means ‘relationship,’ like ''[[जामि|jāmi]]-tva,'' which also occurs in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1052> i. 105, 9;<br> 166, 13;<br> x. 55, 4;<br> 64, 13.</ref>

जामि-शंस
<u>'''Jāmi-śaṃsa,'''</u> the ‘imprecation by a sister’ or ‘relation,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1053> ii. 10, 1 (= [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 6, 3), and personified in ix. 4, 15.<br><br>''Cf. jāmyāḥ śapathaḥ,'' Av. ii. 7, 2;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 362.</ref> showing that family disputes were not rare. This is also indicated by the word '''[[भ्रातृव्य|Bhrātṛvya]],''' which, while properly meaning ‘father's brother's son,’ regularly denotes simply ‘enemy.’

जाम्बिल
<u>'''Jāmbila,'''</u> ‘hollow of the knee,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1054> Perhaps for ''jānu-bila. Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 11, n. 4.</ref> occurs once in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1054> iii. 15, 3.</ref> The word also occurs in the form of Jāmbīla in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1054> v. 13, 1.</ref> and the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1054> xxv. 3.</ref> Mahīdhara, in his commentary on the latter text, interprets the word as ‘knee-pan,’ which he says is so named because of its resemblance to the citron, ''jāmbīra.''

जायन्ती-पुत्र
<u>'''Jāyantī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of Jāyantī,’ is mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1055> vi. 5, 2 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = vi. 4, 32 Mādhyaṃdina).</ref> as a pupil of '''[[माण्डूकायनीपुत्र|Māṇḍūkāyanīputra]].'''

जाया
<u>'''Jāyā'''</u> regularly denotes ‘wife,’ and, as opposed to '''[[पत्नी|Patnī]],''' wife as an object of marital affection, the source of the continuance  of the race.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1056> Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 411, 412. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 105, 2;<br> 124, 7;<br> iii. 53, 4;<br> iv. 3, 2;<br> 18, 3;<br> ix. 82, 4;<br> x. 10, 7;<br> 17, 1;<br> 71, 4, etc.;<br> Av. iii. 30, 2;<br> vi. 60, 1, etc.</ref> So it is used of the wife of the gambler, and of the wife of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in the Rigveda;<ref name=fx2_ve1_1056> x. 34, 2. 3. 13, and x. 109.</ref> it is also frequently combined with '''Pati,''' ‘husband,’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1056> Rv. iv. 3, 2;<br> x. 149, 4.</ref> both there and in the later literature.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1056> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 23, 1. ''Cf.'' vii. 13, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 7, 9. ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 12.</ref> [[पत्नी|Patnī]], on the other hand, is used to denote the wife as partner in the sacrifice;<ref name=fx5_ve1_1056> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9, 2, 14.</ref> when no share in it is assigned to her, she is called [[जाया|Jāyā]].<ref name=fx6_ve1_1056> i. 1, 4, 13.</ref> The distinction is, of course, merely relative; hence one text<ref name=fx7_ve1_1056> ''Ibid.,'' i. 1, 4, 16.</ref> calls Manu's wife [[जाया|Jāyā]], another<ref name=fx8_ve1_1056> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 8, 1.</ref> [[पत्नी|Patnī]]. Later on [[जाया|Jāyā]] is superseded by [[दार|Dāra]].

जायान्य
<u>'''Jāyānya,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1057> Av. vii. 76, 3-5;<br> xix. 44, 2.</ref> '''Jāyenya,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1057> ii. 3, 5, 2;<br> 5, 6, 5.</ref> are variant forms of the name of a disease mentioned in the Atharvaveda and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā. In one passage of the former text<ref name=fx3_ve1_1057> xix. 44, 2.</ref> it is mentioned with jaundice (''harimā'') and pains in the limbs (''[[अङ्ग|aṅga]]-bhedo visalpakaḥ''). Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_1057> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 377, following Wise, ''Hindu System of Medicint,'' 321, describing [[अक्षत|Akṣata]].</ref> thinks these are its symptoms, and identifies it with a kind of [[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]], or disease of the lungs. Bloomfield<ref name=fx5_ve1_1057> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 320 ''et seq.;<br> Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 559-561.</ref> prefers to identify it with syphilis, in accordance with certain indications in the ritual of the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx6_ve1_1057> xxxii. 11. ''Cf.'' also the commentary on Av. vii. 76, and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> Roth conjectures ‘gout,’ but Whitney<ref name=fx7_ve1_1057> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 442.<br><br>''Cf.'' Henry, ''Lelivre vii de l' Atharvavéda,'' 98.</ref> leaves the nature of the disease doubtful.

जार
<u>'''Jāra,'''</u> ‘lover,’ has no sinister sense in the early texts<ref name=fx1_ve1_1058> Rv. i. 66, 8;<br> 117, 18;<br> 134, 3;<br> 152, 4;<br> ix. 32, 5, etc. The word is often used mythologically, as, ''e.g., [[जार|jāra]] uṣasām,'' ‘lover of the dawns,’ vii. 9, 1. ''Cf'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 308.</ref> generally, where the word applies to any lover. But it seems probable that the [[जार|Jāra]] at the Puruṣamedha, or human sacrifice,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1058> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 4. 1.</ref>  must be regarded as an illegitimate lover; this sense also appears in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1058> vi. 4, 11.</ref> and Indra is styled the lover of '''Ahalyā,''' wife of '''[[गौतम|Gautama]]'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1058> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 65.</ref>

जारत्-कारव
