<u>'''Jārat-kārava'''</u> (‘descendant of Jaratkāru’) '''Ārtabhāga''' (‘descendant of Ṛtabhāga’) is the name of a teacher mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (vii. 20) and the Bṛhadāranyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 2, 1, in both recensions).<br>==Foot Notes==

जारु
<u>'''Jāru.'''</u> See '''[[जरायु|Jarāyu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जाल
<u>'''Jāla'''</u> occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1061> viii. 8. 5. 3 (as used against foes);<br> x. 1, 30.</ref> and the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve1_1061> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 4, 7. etc.</ref> in the sense of ‘net.’ Jālaka is used in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1061> iv. 2, 3.</ref> of a reticulated membrane resembling a woven covering.

जालाष
<u>'''Jālāṣa.'''</u> See '''Jalāṣa,''' which is read by Sāyaṇa in the Atharvaveda (vi. 57, 2) for [[जालाष|Jālāṣa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1062> ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 320.</ref>

जाष्कमद
<u>'''Jāṣkamada'''</u> is the name of an unknown animal in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1063> xi. 9, 9. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 88.</ref>

जास्-पति
<u>'''Jās-pati'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1064> i. 135. 8.</ref> in the sense of the ‘head of the family.’ The abstract formed from this word, Jās-patya, apparently denoting ‘lordship of children,’ is also found there.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1064> Rv. v. 28, 3;<br> x. 85, 23.</ref>

जाहुष
<u>'''Jāhuṣa'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1065> i. 116, 10;<br> vii. 71, 5 ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 159.</ref> of a protégé of the Aśvins. 

जाह्नव
<u>'''Jāhnava,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[जह्नु|Jahnu]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1066> xxi. 12. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 32;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 54.</ref> This fact is of some importance as disproving Aufrecht's theory<ref name=fx2_ve1_1066> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 424.</ref> that the Jahnus were the clan of '''Ajīgarta''' the father of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]].'''

जित्वन् शैलिनि
<u>'''Jitvan Śailini'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1067> iv. 1, 2 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = iv. 1, 5 Mādhyaṃdina, which has [[शैलिन|Śailina]] as the patronymic).</ref> a contemporary of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' and '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]].''' He held that speech (''[[वाच्|vāc]]'') was [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]].

जिह्वावन्त् बाध्योग
<u>'''Jihvāvant Bādhyoga'''</u> is the name, in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1068> vi. 5, 3 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = vi. 4, 33 Mādhyaṃdina).</ref> of a teacher, pupil of '''[[असित|Asita]] Vārṣāgaṇa.'''

जीव-गृभ्
<u>'''Jīva-gṛbh,'''</u> ‘seizing alive,’ is, according to Roth,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1069> St Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br> Siebenzig Lieder,'' 174.</ref> the term for a police official in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1069> x. 97, 11.</ref> But although this sense is rendered possible by the mention of '''[[मध्यमशी|Madhyamaśī]],''' perhaps ‘arbitrator,’ in the same passage,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1069> Rv. x. 97, 12.</ref> it is neither necessary nor probable.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1069> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 180.</ref>

जीव-ज
<u>'''Jīva-ja.'''</u> See '''[[जरायु|Jarāyu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जीवन्त्
<u>'''Jīvant'''</u> appears to denote a certain plant in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1071> xix. 39, 3. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 960.</ref> where the edition of Roth and Whitney has the unjustified emendation '''Jīvala.'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1071> With this conjectural form, ''cf.'' Jīvalā, an epithet of a plant in Av. vi. 59, 3;<br> viii. 2, 6;<br> 7, 6;<br> xix. 39. 3.</ref> 

जीवल चल्लकि
<u>'''Jīvala Callaki,'''</u> ‘descendant of Celaka,’ is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1072> ii. 3, 1, 31-35. ''Cf.'' Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 140.</ref> as reproving '''[[तक्षन्|Takṣan]].'''

जुहू
<u>'''Juhū'''</u> is the regular name in the Rigveda and later for the tongue-shaped ladle in which butter was offered to the gods.(**  1) Rv. viii. 44, 5; x. 21, 3; Av. xviii. 4, 5. 6, etc.<br>==Foot Notes==

जूर्णि
<u>'''Jūrṇi,'''</u> ‘firebrand,’ is regarded by Zimmer<ref name=fx1_ve1_1074> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 301.</ref> as one of the weapons of the Vedic Indians. But since it is only mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1074> i. 129, 8. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 4.</ref> as a weapon used by demons, its employment in normal war cannot be safely assumed.

जूर्णी
<u>'''Jūrṇī'''</u> is one of the names given to serpents in a hymn of the Atharvaveda (ii. 24, 5), perhaps from their habit of casting their slough. See '''Ahi.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जेतृ
<u>'''Jetṛ.'''</u> See '''Sṛṇi.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जैत्रायण सहो-जित्
<u>'''Jaitrāyaṇa Saho-jit'''</u> is apparently in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1077> xviii. 5.</ref> the name of a prince who celebrated the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]], or ‘royal consecration.’ Von Schroeder<ref name=fx2_ve1_1077> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 168.</ref> quotes in support of Jaitrāyaṇa as a proper name the derivative Jaitrāyaṇi, ‘descendant of Jaitra,’ formed according to the Gaṇa ''karṇādi,'' which is referred to by Pāṇini;<ref name=fx3_ve1_1077> iv. 2, 80.</ref> but it should be noted that in the parallel passage of the Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_1077> xxviii. 5, cited by von Schroeder ''[[काठक|Kāṭhaka]],'' 1, p. 269.</ref> the reading is different, and no proper personal name appears, the subject being Indra, the god. This reading seems much more probable, for the verse should be general, and suit every king performing the rite. 

जैमिनि
<u>'''Jaimini'''</u> does not appear till the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1078> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10;<br> vi. 6, etc. He appears also as a pupil of Vyāsa, Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''ad fin.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 377. ''Cf.'' his ''Indian Literature,'' 56.</ref> But a Jaiminīya Saṃhitā of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]] is extant, and has been edited and discussed by Caland;<ref name=fx2_ve1_1078> As part ii. of Hillebrandt's ''Indische Forschungen, Breslau,'' 1907. See Oldenberg, ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1908, 712 ''et seq.''</ref> and a Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], of which a special section is the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1078> Edited by Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 79-260.</ref> is known and has formed the subject of several articles by Oertel.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1078>''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 15 ''et seq.;<br>'' 19, 97;<br> 23, 325, 26, 176, 306;<br> 28, 81;<br> ''Actes du onzieme Congres International des Orientalistes,'' 1, 225;<br> ''Transactions of the Connectieut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 155 ''et seq.''</ref>

जैवन्तायन
<u>'''Jaivantāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Jīvanta,’ is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1079> iv. 5, 26 (Mādhyaṃdina). The name is recognised by Pāṇini, iv. 1, 103.</ref> as a teacher, with '''[[शौनक|Śaunaka]]''' and '''[[रैभ्य|Raibhya]],''' of '''[[रौहिणायन|Rauhiṇāyana]].'''

जैवल
<u>'''Jaivala'''</u> or '''Jaivali,''' ‘descendant of Jīvala,’ is the patronymic of '''Pravāhaṇa''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve1_1080> vi. 2, 1 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = vi. 1, 1 Mādhyaṃdina), where the form is [[जैवल|Jaivala]].</ref> and Chāndogya Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1080> i. 8, 1. 2. 8;<br> v. 3, 1.</ref> Jaivali, the king, in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1080> i. 38, 4.</ref> is the same person.

ज्ञातृ
<u>'''Jñātṛ'''</u> occurs in two passages of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1081> vi. 32, 3;<br> viii. 8, 21.</ref> and one of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve1_1081> xii. 14. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 66, n. 4.</ref> with a somewhat obscure sense. Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_1081> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 181.</ref> conjectures not unnaturally that the word is a technical term taken from law, meaning ‘witness.’ The reference is, perhaps, to a custom of carrying on transactions of business before witnesses as practised in other primitive societies.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1081> In Manu, viii. 57, the word is a various reading for ''sākṣin,'' ‘witness.’<br><br>''Cf.'' Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 140.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx5_ve1_1081> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> suggests that the word has the sense of  ‘surety.’ But Bloomfield<ref name=fx6_ve1_1081> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 475.</ref> and Whitney<ref name=fx7_ve1_1081> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 306.</ref> ignore these interpretations.

ज्ञाति
<u>'''Jñāti'''</u> (masc.), a word which originally seems to have meant ‘acquaintance,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1082> Being in all probability derived from ''jñā,'' ‘know,’ not from ''jan,'' ‘beget,’ as would at first sight seem more likely on account of the sense. ''Cf.'' the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1082> vii. 55, 5, seems to refer to the members of the joint family sleeping in the paternal house;<br> x. 66, 14;<br> 85, 28 (the kinsmen of the bride are meant);<br> 117, 9 (perhaps ‘brother and sister’ are meant by ''jñātī'' here, but ‘kinsfolk’ will do;<br> ''of.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 432).</ref> and later<ref name=fx3_ve1_1082> Av. xii. 5, 44 (where Whitney in his Translation renders the word by ‘acquaintances,’ which seems too vague and feeble);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 5, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 4, 3 (''jñātibhyāṃ vā sakhibhyāṃ, vā,'' ‘where ‘relations’ are contrasted with ‘friends’ or ‘companions’);<br> ii. 2, 2, 20;<br> 5, 2, 20;<br> xi. 3, 3, 7, etc.</ref> a ‘relation,’ apparently one who was connected by blood on the father's side, though the passages do not necessarily require the limitation. But this sense follows naturally enough from the patriarchal basis of Vedic society.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1082> For the transition from the etymological meaning, ''cf.'' , which in Homer designate ‘brother’ and ‘sister’;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

ज्या
<u>'''Jyā'''</u> is the regular word for ‘bowstring’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1083> iv. 27, 3;<br> vi. 75, 3;<br> x. 51, 6, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1083> Av. i. 1, 3;<br> v. 13, 6;<br> vi. 42, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 9;<br> xxix. 51, etc.</ref> The making of bowstrings was a special craft, as is shown by the occurrence of the [[ज्या|Jyā]]-kāra, or ‘maker of bowstrings,’ among the victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1083> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 1.</ref> The bowstring consisted of a thong of ox-hide.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1083> Rv. vi. 75, 3;<br> Av. i. 1, 3. In the Epic the bowstring is made of hemp (''maurvī'');<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 271.</ref> It was not usually kept taut,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1083> Av. vi. 42, 1.</ref> but was specially tightened when the bow was to be used.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1083> Rv. x. 166, 3.</ref> The sound of the bowstring (''[[ज्या|jyā]]-[[घोष|ghoṣa]]'') is referred to in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1083> v. 21, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 298 299.</ref><br><br>''Cf.'' '''[[आर्त्नी|Ārtnī]].''' 

ज्याका
<u>'''Jyākā'''</u> means ‘bowstring,’ with a contemptuous sense, in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1084> x. 133, 1, where ''anyakeṣāṃ jyākāḥ'' is unmistakably contemptuous. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 137.</ref> and in the simple sense in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1084> i. 2, 2.</ref>

ज्या-पाश
<u>'''Jyā-pāśa'''</u> means ‘bowstring’ in the Atharvaveda (xi. 10, 22).<br>==Foot Notes==

ज्या-ह्रोड
<u>'''Jyā-hroḍa'''</u> occurs in the description of the arms of the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1086> xvii. 1, 14 (spelt ''-hṇoḍa'' in text, ''-hnoḍa'' in comm.).</ref> and is also mentioned in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1086> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 4, 11 (spelt ''-hroḍa'');<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6, 8 (spelt ''-hnoḍa:'' the editor notes that the Drāhyāyaṇa [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] has the same reading).</ref> The sense is somewhat obscure, for one [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] describes it as a ‘bow not meant for use’ (''ayogyaṃ [[धनुस्|dhanus]]''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_1086> Kātyāyana, ''loc. cit.''</ref> while the other speaks of it as a ‘bow without an arrow’ (''dhanuṣka aniṣu'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_1086> Lāṭyāyana, ''loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 38;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Acad my of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 32;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 33, 52.</ref> Some sort of a bow, therefore, seems to be meant.

ज्येष्ठ
<u>'''Jyeṣṭha,'''</u> ordinarily meaning ‘greatest,’ has further the specific sense of ‘eldest’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1087> With changed accent, ''jyeṣṭhá. Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 83, 14.</ref> brother in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1087> iv. 33, 5;<br> x. 11, 2.</ref> It also means the eldest among sons, which is another side of the same sense.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1087> Av. xii. 2, 35;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 3, 8, ''and cf.'' Jyaiṣthineya.</ref>

ज्येष्ठ-घ्नी
<u>'''Jyeṣṭha-ghnī,'''</u> ‘slaying the eldest,’ is the name of a '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]],''' or lunar mansion, usually called '''[[ज्येष्ठा|Jyeṣṭhā]],''' in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1088> vi. 110, 2. ''Cf.'' vi. 112, 1.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1088> i. 5, 2, 8. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 361.</ref> It is Antares or ''Cor Scipionis.''

ज्येष्ठा
<u>'''Jyeṣṭhā.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

ज्यैष्ठिनेय
<u>'''Jyaiṣṭhineya'''</u> denotes, in combination with '''[[ज्येष्ठ|Jyeṣṭha]],''' the eldest,’ a ‘son of the father's first wife’ (''[[ज्येष्ठा|jyeṣṭhā]]''), in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1090> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 8, 1 (opposed to ''haniṣṭha'' and ''hāniṣṭhineya'');<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 2;<br> xx. 5, 2.</ref>

ज्योतिष
<u>'''Jyotiṣa,'''</u> ‘astronomy.’ It is important to note that no reference to any work on astronomy occurs in the Saṃhitās or Brāhmaṇas. The text which claims to represent the astronomical science of the Veda has been edited by Weber,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1091> ''Ueber den Vedakalender namens Jyotiṣam'' (1862).</ref> and has frequently been discussed since.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1091> See references in Thibaut, ''Astrenomie, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 20, 29.</ref> Its date is unknown, but is undoubtedly late, as is shown alike by the contents and form of the work.

ज्वालायन
<u>'''Jvālāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Jvāla,’ is the name of a man, a pupil of '''[[गौषूक्ति|Gauṣūkti]],''' mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iv. 16, 1), in a list of teachers.<br>==Foot Notes==

झष
<u>'''Jhaṣa'''</u> is mentioned in the story of Manu told in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1093> i. 8, 1, 4.</ref> where it means a ‘great fish’ (''[[महा-मत्स्य|mahā-matsya]]'') according to the commentator. Eggeling<ref name=fx2_ve1_1093> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 217, n. 3;<br> 26, xxxi.</ref> suggests that a horned fish is meant, because in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1093> i. 7, 1;<br> ii. 6, 7.</ref> the Iḍā, or personified libation, is represented as a cow, and this may have brought in the idea of a horned fish in the later form of an old legend. But ''cf.'' '''[[जष|Jaṣa]].''' 

तकवान
<u>'''Takavāna'''</u> appears to be a patronymic from Taku,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1094> ''Cf.'' [[भृगवाण|Bhṛgavāṇa]], from [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]];<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Taku,'' as an adjective(?), occurs in Rigveda, ix. 97, 52.</ref> and to be the name of a seer in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1094> i. 120, 6.</ref> presumably a descendant of Taku [[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]], for his name occurs in a group of hymns composed by the Kākṣīvatas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1094> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 221.<br><br>''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 92;<br> Ludwig, ''Über Methode bei Interpretation des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 47.</ref>

तक्मन्
<u>'''Takman'''</u> is a disease repeatedly mentioned in the Atharvaveda, but later not known under this name. It is the subject of five hymns<ref name=fx1_ve1_1095> i. 25;<br> v. 22;<br> vi. 20;<br> vii. 116;<br> xix. 39 (''cf.'' v. 4).</ref> of the Atharvaveda, and is often mentioned elsewhere.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1095> Av. iv. 9, 8;<br> v. 4. 1. 9;<br> 30, 16;<br> ix. 8, 6;<br> xi. 2, 22. 26, etc.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_1095> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 119;<br> Roth, ''Zur Litteratur und Geschishte des Weda,'' 39, had, from the use of [[कुष्ठ|Kuṣṭha]] as a remedy, regarded it as denoting ‘leprosy,’ and was followed by Pictet, Kuhn's ''Zeitschrift'' 5, 337. Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 4, 280, thought ‘consumption’ was meant.</ref> first identified it with ‘fever,’ and Grohmann<ref name=fx4_ve1_1095> ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 381 ''et seq.''</ref> showed that all the symptoms pointed to that ailment.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1095> See also Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 451 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 379-385, and compare the ''jvara'' (a non-Vedic word) of the classical medicine, Wise, ''Hindu System of Medicine,'' 219 ''et seq.;<br>'' Jolly, ''Medicin,'' 70-72. Dārila and Keśava, the commentators on the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], everywhere equate ''[[तक्मन्|takman]]'' and ''jvara.''</ref> Reference is made to the alternate hot and shivering fits of the patient,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1095> Av. i. 25, 2-4;<br> v. 22, 2. 7. 10;<br> vi. 20, 3;<br> vii. 116, 1.</ref> to the yellow colour of the jaundice which accompanies the fever,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1095> Av. i. 25, 2;<br> v. 22, 2;<br> vi. 20, 3.</ref> and to its peculiar periodicity. The words used to describe its varieties are ''anye-dyuḥ,''<ref name=fx8_ve1_1095> Av. i. 25, 4;<br> vii. 116, 2.</ref> ''ubhaya-dyuḥ,''<ref name=fx9_ve1_1095> ''Ibid.''</ref> ''[[तृतीयक|tṛtīyaka]],''<ref name=fx10_ve1_1095> Av. i. 25, 4;<br> v. 22, 13;<br> xix. 39, 10.</ref> ''vi-tṛtīya,''<ref name=fx11_ve1_1095> Av. v. 22, 13.</ref> and ''sadaṃ-di,''<ref name=fx12_ve1_1095> Av. v. 22, 13;<br> xix. 39, 10.</ref> the exact sense of most of which terms is somewhat uncertain. It is agreed<ref name=fx13_ve1_1095> Grohmann, ''op. cit.,'' 387;<br> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 382;<br> Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' 274.</ref> that the first epithet designates the fever known as ''quotidianus,'' which recurs each day at the same hour, though the word is curious (lit.  ‘on the other--''i.e.,'' next, day’). The ''ubhaya-dyuḥ'' (‘on both days’) variety appears to mean a disease recurring for two successive days, the third being free; this corresponds to the ''rhythmus quartanus complicatus.''<ref name=fx14_ve1_1095> Grohmann, 388;<br> Zimmer, 382;<br> Bloomfield, 274. It may conceivably be the form styled Cāturthaka Viparyaya (Wise, ''op. cit.,'' 232), in which the paroxysm occurs every fourth day, and lasts for two days.</ref> But Sāyaṇa considers that it means a fever recurring on the third day, the ‘tertian.’ The ''[[तृतीयक|tṛtīyaka]],'' however, must be the ‘tertian’ fever,<ref name=fx15_ve1_1095> Sāyaṇa on Av. i. 25, 4;<br> Bloomfield, 451. It is the ''jvara [[तृतीयक|tṛtīyaka]]'' of Suśruta (2, 404, 7).</ref> though Zimmer<ref name=fx16_ve1_1095> ''Op. cit.,'' 383, quoting Hügel, Kashmir, 1, 133.</ref> suggests that it may mean a fever which is fatal at the third paroxysm. Grohmann<ref name=fx17_ve1_1095> ''Op. cit.,'' 388.</ref> regards the ''vi-[[तृतीयक|tṛtīyaka]]'' as equivalent to the ''tertiana duplicata,'' a common form in southern countries, in which the fever occurs daily, but with a correspondence in point of time or severity of attack on alternate days. Bloomfield<ref name=fx18_ve1_1095> ''Op. cit.,'' 451.</ref> suggests that it is identical with the ''ubhaya-dyuḥ'' variety. The ''sadaṃ-di''<ref name=fx19_ve1_1095> Of doubtful derivation: either ‘always cutting’ (''of'' Sāyaṇa on Av. xix. 39, 10), or ‘always fastening upon’ (Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''), or ‘belonging to every day’ = ''sadaṃdina'' (Zimmer, 383, n.;<br> Bloomfield, 452).</ref> type appears to be the kind later known as ''saṃtata-jvara'' (‘continuous fever’), in which there are attacks of several days’ duration, with an interval followed by a fresh period of attack. Fever occurred at different seasons, in the autumn (''[[शारद|śārada]]''), in the hot weather (''graiṣma''), in the rains (''vārṣika''),<ref name=fx20_ve1_1095> Av. v. 22, 13.</ref> but was especially prevalent in the first, as is indicated by the epithet ''viśva-[[शारद|śārada]],'' ‘occurring every autumn.’<ref name=fx21_ve1_1095> Av. ix. 8, 6;<br> xix. 34, 10.</ref><br><br>The disease is said to arise when Agni enters the waters.<ref name=fx22_ve1_1095> Av. 1, 25. 1.</ref> From this Weber<ref name=fx23_ve1_1095> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 119.</ref> deduced that it was considered to be the result of a chill supervening on heat, or the influence of heat on marshy land. Grohmann<ref name=fx24_ve1_1095> ''Ibid.,'' 9, 493.</ref> preferred to see in this connexion of the origin of the disease with Agni's entering the waters<ref name=fx25_ve1_1095> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p.</ref> an allusion to the fact that fever arises in the rainy season, the time when Agni, as lightning, descends to earth with the rain. Zimmer.<ref name=fx26_ve1_1095> ''Of. cit.,'' 384.</ref> who accepts this view, further refers to the prevalence  of fever in the Terai, and interprets ''vanya,'' an epithet of fever found in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx27_ve1_1095> Av. vi. 20, 4.</ref> as meaning ‘sprung from the forest,’ pointing out that fever is mentioned as prevalent among the '''Mūjavants''' and '''Mahāvṛṣas,''' two mountain tribes of the western Himālaya.<ref name=fx28_ve1_1095> Av. v. 22, 5.</ref> There is no trace of fever having been observed to be caused by the bite of the ''anopheles'' mosquito, which breeds in stagnant water: this theory has without reason been held to be known to classical Indian medicine.<ref name=fx29_ve1_1095> Jolly, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1906, 222.</ref><br><br>Among the symptoms of [[तक्मन्|Takman]], or among complications accompanying it, are mentioned ‘itch’ ('''[[पामन्|Pāman]]'''), ‘headache’ (''śīrṣa-śoka''),<ref name=fx30_ve1_1095> Av. xix. 39, 10.<br><br>For the present position of the disease in India, ''cf.'' the Report of the Simla Conference of 1909.</ref> ‘cough’ ('''Kāsikā'''), and ‘consumption,’ or perhaps some form of itch ('''[[बलास|Balāsa]]''').<br><br>It is perhaps significant that the [[तक्मन्|Takman]] does not appear until the Atharvaveda. It is quite possible that the Vedic Āryans, when first settled in India, did not know the disease, which would take some generations to become endemic and recognized as dangerous. What remedies they used against it is quite uncertain, for the Atharvaveda mentions only spells and the '''[[कुष्ठ|Kuṣṭha]],''' which can hardly have been an effective remedy, though still used in later times. Fever must, even in the [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] period, have claimed many victims, or it would not be mentioned so prominently.

तक्वन्
<u>'''Takvan,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1096> Rv. i. 66, 2. ''Cf.'' i. 134, 5, and '''[[त्सारिन्|Tsārin]].'''</ref> '''Takvarī,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1096> ''Ibid.,'' i. 151, 5;<br> x. 91, 2. But in both places the word may be adjectival.</ref> seem in the Rigveda to denote a ‘swiftflying bird.’ Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx3_ve1_1096> On Rv. i. 66, 2.</ref> explains [[तक्वन्|Takvan]] as a swift steed.

तक्षक वैशालेय
<u>'''Takṣaka Vaiśāleya'''</u> (‘descendant of Viśālā’) is a mythical figure, mentioned as the son of [[विराज्|Virāj]] in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1097> vii. 10, 29.</ref> and as [[ब्राह्मणाच्छंसिन्|Brāhmaṇācchaṃsin]] priest at the snake sacrifice in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1097> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref> 

तक्षन्
<u>'''1. Takṣan,'''</u> ‘carpenter,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1098> ix. 112, 1.</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1098> Av. x. 6, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> xviii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;<br> xxx. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 2, 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 12;<br> iii. 6, 4, 4, etc.</ref> He was employed to do all sorts of work in wood, such as the making of chariots ('''[[रथ|Ratha]]''') and wagons ('''Anas'''). Carved work of a finer type seems also to have fallen to his lot.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1098> Rv. x. 86, 5;<br> Av. xix. 49, 8. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 161, 9;<br> iii. 60. 2.</ref> The axe (''[[कुलिश|kuliśa]],''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1098> Rv. iii. 2, 1.</ref> ''[[परशु|paraśu]]'')<ref name=fx5_ve1_1098> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10.</ref> is mentioned as one of his tools, and perhaps the '''[[भुरिज्|Bhurij]],''' a word which is, however, uncertain in sense. In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_1098> Rv. i. 105, 18. ''Cf.'' Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erläuterungen,'' 67;<br> Oldenberg. ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 100.</ref> reference seems to be made to the pains of the carpenter in bending over his work. That the carpenters were a low caste, or formed a separate class of the people, is certainly not true of Vedic times.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1098> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 210, n. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 245, 253.</ref>

तक्षन्
<u>'''2. Takṣan'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1099> ii. 3, 1, 31-35. ''Cf.'' Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 140.</ref> as a teacher whose view of a certain formula was not accepted by '''Jīvala [[चैलकि|Cailaki]].'''

तक्षन्
<u>'''3. Takṣan.'''</u> See '''[[बृबु|Bṛbu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

तण्डुल
<u>'''Taṇḍula,'''</u> ‘grain,’ especially ‘rice grain,’ is mentioned very often in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1101> x. 9, 26;<br> xi. 1, 18;<br> xii. 3, 18. 29. 30.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1101> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 1, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 3;<br> ii. 5, 3, 4;<br> v. 2, 3, 2;<br> vi. 6, 1, 8, etc.;<br> ''[[श्यामाक|śyāmāka]]-[[तण्डुल|taṇḍula]],'' ‘millet grain,’ ''ibid.,'' x. 6, 3, 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 14, 3;<br> ''[[अपामार्ग|apāmārga]]-[[तण्डुल|taṇḍula]],'' ‘grain of the ''Achyranthes aspera,''’ v. 2, 4, 15, etc.</ref> but not in the Rigveda. This accords with the fact that rice cultivation seems hardly known in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1101> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 239. See [[व्रीहि|Vrīhi]].</ref> Husked (''karṇa'') and unhusked (''akarṇa'') rice is referred to in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1101> i. 8, 9, 3. See Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 190.</ref> 

तत
<u>'''Tata,'''</u> ‘dada,’ is the pet name for ‘father’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1102> viii. 91, 6;<br> ix. 112, 3.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1102> Av. v. 24, 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 5, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 9, 7;<br> in the vocative as a form of address, Av. viii. 4, 77;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 14;<br> vii. 15;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 3, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 449.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[तात|Tāta]]''' and '''[[पितृ|Pitṛ]].'''

ततामह
<u>'''Tatāmaha,'''</u> ‘grandfather,’ is found in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1103> v. 24, 17;<br> viii. 4, 76. It seems to mean literally ‘great father,’ and to be an analogical formation following ''[[पितामह|pitāmaha]];<br>'' Delbrück, ''op. cit.,'' 473, 474.</ref>

तनय
<u>'''Tanaya,'''</u> n., denotes ‘offspring,’ ‘descendants’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1104> i. 96, 4;<br> 183, 3;<br> 184, 5;<br> ii. 23, 19;<br> vii. 1, 21, etc.;<br> ''tokaṃ ca tanayaṃ ca,'' i. 92, 13;<br> ix. 74, 5. ''Cf.'' vi. 25, 4;<br> 31, 1;<br> 66, 8;<br> and i. 31, 12, as explained by Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 193.</ref> where also it is often used adjectivally with '''Toka.'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1104> Rv. i. 64, 14;<br> 114, 6;<br> 147, 1;<br> 189, 2;<br> ii. 30, 5, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7.</ref> There seems no ground for the view<ref name=fx3_ve1_1104> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], x. 7;<br> xii. 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Tan, tana,'' and ''tanas,'' have the same sense as [[तनय|Tanaya]]. See Rv. vi. 46, 12;<br> 49, 13;<br> vii. 104, 10;<br> viii. 68, 12, etc. (''tan'');<br> viii. 25, 2 (''tana'');<br> v. 70, 4 (''tanas'').</ref> that ''toka'' means ‘sons,’ ‘children,’ and ''[[तनय|tanaya]]'' ‘grandchildren.’

तन्ति
<u>'''Tanti'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1105> vi. 24, 4.</ref> where Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_1105> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> renders the plural of the word by ‘files’ of calves. But it seems rather to have the sense which it has in the later literature, of ‘cords,’ here used to fasten the calves.

तन्तु
<u>'''Tantu'''</u> appears properly to mean ‘thread,’ and in particular the ‘warp’ of a piece of weaving, as opposed to '''Otu,''' the ‘woof.’ Both senses are found in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1106> xiv. 2, 51 (opposed to ''otu'');<br> xv. 3, 6 (the ''prāñcaḥ'' and ''tiryañcaḥ'' threads or cords of the throne of the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] ['''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]]''']).</ref> In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1106> iii. 1, 2, 18;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 8, 9.</ref> the ‘warp’ is called ''anuchāda,'' the ‘woof’ ''[[पर्य्आस|paryāsa]],'' the ''tantavaḥ'' being the ‘threads.’ In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1106> vi. 1, 1, 4.</ref>  on the other hand, the ‘warp’ is ''[[प्राचीन-तान|prācīna-tāna]],'' the ‘woof’ ''otu.'' The threads or cords of the throne ('''Pary ṅka''') are referred to in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1106> i. 5;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 20, n. 2.</ref><br><br>In the Rigveda the word is used only metaphorically, and this is its most frequent use even in the Brāhmanas.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1106> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' It is applied to the filaments of plants in Rv. x. 134, 5;<br> to the spider's web in Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upanisad. ii. 1, 23.</ref> See also '''[[वाण|Vāṇa]].'''

तन्त्र
<u>'''Tantra'''</u> means, like '''[[तन्तु|Tantu]],''' the ‘warp’ of a piece of weaving, or more generally the ‘web’ itself. It is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1107> x. 71, 9.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1107> Av. x. 7, 42;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 5, 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5;<br> Śatapa ha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 2, 2, 22.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 254.</ref>

तपस्
<u>'''Tapas, Tapasya.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

तपो-नित्य
<u>'''Tapo-nitya'''</u> (‘constant in penance’) [[पौरु-शिष्टि|Pauru-śiṣṭi]] (‘descendant of Puruśiṣṭa’) is the name of a teacher in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 9, 1) who believed in the value of penance (''[[तपस्|tapas]]'').<br>==Foot Notes==

तयादर
<u>'''Tayādara'''</u> is the name of an animal only mentioned in the adjectival form ''[[तायादर|tāyādara]]'' along with '''[[परस्वन्त्|Parasvant]],''' ‘wild ass’(?) in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1110> vi. 72, 2. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 335.</ref>

तरक्षु
<u>'''Tarakṣu,'''</u> the ‘hyæna,’ is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1111> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 19, 1, where Sāyaṇa explains the animal to be ‘a kind of tiger with an ass's appearance’ (''[[व्याघ्र|vyāghra]]-viśeṣo gardabhākāraḥ'');<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 21;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 40.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 81.</ref> 

तरन्त
<u>'''Taranta'''</u> appears, along with '''Purumīḍha,''' as a patron of '''[[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1112> v. 61, 10.</ref> In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1112> xiii. 7, 12.</ref> and other Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx3_ve1_1112> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 139;<br> Śāṭyāyanaka ''apud'' Sāyaṇa on Rv. ix. 38, 3 = [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], ii. 410.</ref> he, together with Purumīḍha, is described as receiving gifts from '''[[ध्वस्र|Dhvasra]]'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1112> Rv. ix. 58, 3.</ref> and '''[[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]];''' but since the receipt of gifts was forbidden to Kṣatriyas, they for the nonce became [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]], and composed a passage in honour of the donors.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1112/> He, like Purumīḍha, was a [[वैदद्अश्वि|Vaidadaśvi]], or son of Vidadaśva.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1112> ''Cf.'' Rv. v. 61, 10;<br> notes 2 and 3. This is merely a misunderstanding of the Rv. ''Cf.'' Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 39;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 50 ''et seq.;<br>'' 62, 63;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 232, n. 1;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 353, 354, where he points out that the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] tradition, and that of the Bṛhaddevatā (v. 50-81, with Macdonell's notes), are not to be accepted as real explanations of the Rigveda.</ref>

तरु
<u>'''Taru,'''</u> the usual term for ‘tree’ in classical Sanskrit, never occurs in Vedic literature, except perhaps in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1113> v. 44, 5.</ref> where Sāyaṇa finds it, and where it can be so translated. But the form (''tarubhiḥ'') is probably to be interpreted otherwise.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1113> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' cites ''tarobhiḥ'' in Rv. ii. 39, 3, as a parallel, and so Oldenberg, ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 341.</ref>

तरुक्ष
<u>'''Tarukṣa'''</u> is the name of a man in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1114> viii. 46, 32. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 391;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 117.</ref> who is mentioned along with '''[[बल्बूथ|Balbūtha]],''' the '''[[दास|Dāsa]],''' in a [[दान|Dāna]]-[[स्तुति|stuti]], or ‘Praise of Gifts.’

तर्कु
<u>'''Tarku,'''</u> ‘spindle,’ is known only in Vedic literature from the mention of it in Yāska's [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (ii. 1) as an example of the transposition of letters, the word being derived, according to him, from the root ''kart,'' ‘to spin.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

तर्द
<u>'''Tarda,'''</u> ‘borer,’ occurs in a hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1116> vi. 50, 1. 2.</ref> enumerating insects that injure grain. Whitney<ref name=fx2_ve1_1116> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 318.</ref> suggests that a kind of mouse or rat may be meant. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1116> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 485.</ref> thought a bird was denoted.

तर्द्मन्
<u>'''Tardman'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1117> xiv. 1, 40.</ref> applies to the hole in the yoke ('''Yuga'''). In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1117> iii. 2, 1, 2;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 26, n. 1.</ref> it designates a hole in a skin.

तर्य
<u>'''Tarya'''</u> is, according to Sāyaṇa, the name of a man in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1118> v, 44, 12. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158, 159.</ref> But the verse is hopelessly obscure.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1118> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 342.</ref>

तलाश
<u>'''Talāśa'''</u> is the name of a tree in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1119> vi. 15, 3.</ref> Whitney<ref name=fx2_ve1_1119> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 291.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62.</ref> suggests that it may be the same as ''tālīśa (Flacourtia cataphracta).''

तल्प
<u>'''Talpa'''</u> is the regular term for ‘bed’ or ‘couch’ from the Rigveda and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1120> Rv. vii. 55, 8;<br> Av. v. 17, 12;<br> xiv. 2, 31. 41.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1120> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 6, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 5, 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiii. 4, 2;<br> xxv. 1, 10.</ref> One made of '''[[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]]''' wood is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1120> i. 2, 6, 5.</ref> The violation of the bed of a Guru, or teacher, is already mentioned in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_1120> v. 10, 9.</ref> while the adjective ''talpya,'' ‘born in the nuptial couch,’ denotes ‘legitimate’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_1120> xiii. 1, 6, 2. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 154.</ref> 

तलव
<u>'''Talava'''</u> in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or human sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1121> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 15, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 83, n. 15.</ref> denotes a ‘musician’ of some kind.

तष्टृ
<u>'''Taṣṭṛ'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1122> i. 61, 4;<br> 105, 18;<br> 130, 4;<br> iii. 38, 1;<br> vii. 32, 20;<br> x. 93, 12;<br> 119, 5. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 21.</ref> in the sense of ‘carpenter,’ like '''[[तक्षन्|Takṣan]],''' which is from the same root ''takṣ,'' ‘to fashion.’

तसर
<u>'''Tasara'''</u> denotes the weaver's ‘shuttle’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1123> x. 130, 2.</ref> and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1123> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 83;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 4, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 254.</ref>

तस्कर
<u>'''Taskara'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1124> i. 191, 5;<br> vi. 27, 3;<br> vii. 55, 3;<br> viii. 29, 6.</ref> and frequently later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1124> Av. iv. 3, 2;<br> xix. 47, 7;<br> 50, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 77-78;<br> xii. 62;<br> xvi. 21, etc;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 14.</ref> denoting ‘thief’ or ‘robber.’ It appears to be practically synonymous with '''[[स्तेन|Stena]],''' in connexion with which it is often mentioned.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1124> Rv. vii. 55. 3;<br> Av. xix. 47, 7;<br> 50, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 79;<br> xvi. 21, etc.</ref> The [[स्तेन|Stena]] and the [[तस्कर|Taskara]] are contrasted in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_1124> xi. 79 (the [[मलिम्लु|Malimlu]] is ''janeṣu,'' ‘among men’;<br> the others ''vane,'' ‘in the forest’). ''Cf.'' for the [[मलिम्लु|Malimlu]], [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 2, 6;<br> Atharvaveda, xix. 49, 10.</ref> with the '''[[मलिम्लु|Malimlu]],''' who is a burglar or house-breaker, while they are highwaymen, or, as the Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_1124> x. 4, 6.</ref> puts it, ‘men who haunt the woods and risk their lives’ (''tanū-tyajā vanar-gū''). In another passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1124> vii. 55, 3.</ref> however, the dog is told to bark at the [[तस्कर|Taskara]] or the [[स्तेन|Stena]], which clearly points to an attempt at house-breaking. The thief goes about at night,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1124> Rv. i. 191, 5.</ref> and knows the paths<ref name=fx8_ve1_1124> Rv. viii. 29, 6.</ref> on which he attacks his victim. In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_1124> x. 4, 6.</ref> the use of cords is mentioned, but whether to bind the thieves when captured, or to bind the  victim, is not clear.<ref name=fx10_ve1_1124> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 178, n.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx11_ve1_1124> xix. 50, 5. ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 97, 10 (''[[स्तेन|stena]]'').</ref> refers to the [[स्तेन|Stena]] and the [[तस्कर|Taskara]] as cattle and horse thieves.<ref name=fx12_ve1_1124> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 984.</ref>

तायु
<u>'''Tāyu'''</u> was another name for thief, perhaps of a less distinguished and more domestic character than the highwayman, for though he is referred to as a cattle-thief,<ref name=fx13_ve1_1125> Rv. i. 65, 1;<br> vii. 86, 5.</ref> he is also alluded to as a stealer of clothes (''[[वस्त्र|vastra]]-mathi'')<ref name=fx14_ve1_1125> Rv. iv. 38, 5.</ref> and as a debtor.<ref name=fx15_ve1_1125> Rv. vi. 12, 5. No doubt this theft is the result of despair at being in debt, which might lead to loss of liberty ([[ऋण|Ṛṇa]]).</ref> In one passage the Tāyus are said to disappear at the coming of dawn (which is elsewhere called ''yāvayad-dveṣas,'' ‘driving away hostile beings,’ and ''ṛta-pā,'' ‘guardian of order’), like the stars of heaven (''[[नक्षत्र|nakṣatra]]'').<ref name=fx16_ve1_1125> Rv. i. 50, 2. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 47.</ref><br><br>In the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]] litany of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx17_ve1_1125> xvi. 20, 21. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 4, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 4.</ref> Rudra is called lord of assailers (''ā-vyādhin''), thieves (''[[स्तेन|stena]]''), robbers (''[[तस्कर|taskara]]''), pickpockets (''stāyu''), stealers (''muṣṇant''), and cutters (''vi-kṛnta''); and designations of sharpers (''gṛtsa'') and bands (''gaṇa, [[व्रात|vrāta]]''), apparently of robbers, are mentioned.<ref name=fx18_ve1_1125> xvi. 25.</ref> It is therefore not surprising that the Rigveda<ref name=fx19_ve1_1125> i. 129, 9;<br> ii. 23, 16;<br> vi. 24, 10;<br> 41, 5;<br> 51, 15;<br> x. 63, 16.</ref> should contain many prayers for safety at home or on the way, or that the Atharvaveda should devote several hymns to night<ref name=fx20_ve1_1125> Av. xix. 47-50.</ref> chiefly for protection against the evil doings of thieves and robbers.<br><br>Pischel<ref name=fx21_ve1_1125> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 55, 56. Contrast 1, 106.</ref> suggests that in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx22_ve1_1125> Rv. vii. 55.</ref> '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]''' is represented as a burglar, but the admits that, since [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] was attacking the house of his father Varuṇa, he was only seeking to obtain what he may have regarded as his own. But the interpretation of the hymn is not certain.<ref name=fx23_ve1_1125> ''Cf.'' Aufrecht, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 337 ''et seq.;<br>'' Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 370;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 308;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 11 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref><br><br>Sāyaṇa's explanation of one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx24_ve1_1125> vi. 54, 1.</ref> as  referring to professional cattle-trackers, like the Khojis of the Panjab, seems quite probable.<ref name=fx25_ve1_1125> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 182, 183, citing Elliot, ''Memoirs,'' 1, 276;<br> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 123.</ref><br><br>The punishment of thieves appears primarily to have been left to the action of the robbed. The practice of binding them in stocks<ref name=fx26_ve1_1125> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 24, 13, 15;<br> vii. 86, 5;<br> Av. vi. 63, 3 = 84, 4;<br> 115, 2. 3;<br> 121;<br> xix. 47, 9;<br> 50, 1, all of which passages are cited by Zimmer, 181, 182, to prove this practice. But it must be noted that Rv. vii. 86, 5, alone is not at all conclusive evidence, though Av. xix. 47, 9;<br> 50, 1 (''drupade āhan''), probably mean the same thing. Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 976, 983, renders the passages as referring to casting a thief into a snare, and Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 106, makes Rv. vii. 86, 5, refer to the cattle-thief (''[[पशु|paśu]]-tṛp'') taking away the rope from the calf he means to steal. For Rv. x. 4, 6, see above, n. 10. The German and Slavonic parallels cited by Zimmer, 182, n., support his view. See also for a similar punishment in case of debt, '''[[ऋण|Ṛṇa]].'''</ref> seems clearly referred to. But later, at any rate-and in all probability earlier also, as in othe countries--a more severe penalty could be exacted, and death inflicted by the king.<ref name=fx27_ve1_1125> [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 4345;<br> Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 9, 25, 4. 5;<br> Jolly, ''op. cit.,'' 124.</ref> There is no hint in Vedic literature of the mode of conviction; a fire ordeal is not known to the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx28_ve1_1125> Av. ii. 12 was so interpreted by Schlagintweit, ''Die Gottesurtheile der Inder,'' 9 ''et seq.'' (1866);<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 164 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 445;<br> Zimmer, 183 ''et seq.;<br>'' but see Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 330 ''et seq.;<br> Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 294-296;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 54;<br> Grill, ''Hundert Lieder,''^2 47, 85;<br> Jolly, ''op cit.,'' 146.</ref> and the ordeal known to the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx29_ve1_1125> vi. 16;<br> Jolly, ''loc. cit.''</ref> is not said to be used in the case of theft. No doubt the stolen property was recovered by the person robbed if he could obtain it. Nothing is known as to what happened if the property had passed from the actual thief into the possession of another person.

तस्तुव
<u>'''Tastuva,'''</u> or '''Tasruva,''' as the Paippalāda recension has it, is the name of a remedy against snake poison, and is mentioned along with '''[[ताबुव|Tābuva]]''' in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1126> v. 13, 10, 11. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 428;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 244.</ref> 

ताजद्-भङ्ग
<u>'''Tājad-bhaṅga'''</u> (‘easily broken’) is apparently the name of a tree or plant in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1127> viii. 8, 3 (a battle hymn).</ref> The [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1127> xvi 14. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield's edition, xliv;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 583, 584;<br> Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 35;<br> Lanman in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 502;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref> treats it as a compound word, and its commentator makes it out to be the castor-oil plant (''[[एरण्ड|eraṇḍa]]''). Whitney,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1127> ''Op. cit.,'' 504.</ref> however, treats the expression as two separate words, and thinks that the passage means ‘may they be broken suddenly (''tājat'') like hemp (''bhañga'').’

ताण्ड
<u>'''Tāṇḍa'''</u> seems to be the name of a sage to whose school belonged the [[ताण्ड|Tāṇḍa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] mentioned in the Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1128> vii. 10, 17. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 49.</ref>

ताण्ड-विन्द
<u>'''Tāṇḍa-vinda,'''</u> or '''[[ताण्ड|Tāṇḍa]]-vindava,''' is the name of a teacher mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1129> viii. 10. The manuscripts differ as to the form of the name.</ref>

ताण्डि
<u>'''Tāṇḍi'''</u> occurs as the name of a pupil of '''[[बादरायण|Bādarāyaṇa]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1130> See Konow's Translation, 80, n. 2.</ref>

ताण्ड्य
<u>'''Tāṇḍya'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1131> vi. 1, 2, 25. ''Cf.'' Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 140.</ref> quoted on a point bearing on the Agniciti, or piling of the sacred fire. He is also mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1131> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373, 384.</ref> The [[ताण्ड्य|Tāṇḍya]] [[महाब्राह्मण|Mahābrāhmaṇa]] or [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1131> Edited in the ''Bibliotheca Indica'' Series, 1869-74. See Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 66 ''et seq.,'' 74, 133;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 203, 210;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 23 ''et seq.''</ref> of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]] represents the school of the Tāṇḍins. 

तात
<u>'''Tāta,'''</u> apparently ‘dada's boy,’ an affectionate term of address by a father (''cf.'' '''Tata''') to a son, is found in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1132> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 14, 4;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 6;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 4, 2.</ref> occurring in the vocative only. But in the sense of ‘father,’ through confusion with Tata, it occurs also as early as the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1132> i. 3, 3, where Tata and [[तात|Tāta]] are given as variant forms of the address of the child to the father. Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 75, takes [[तात|Tāta]] to mean ‘father’ primarily, but this seems unlikely.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 449, 454.</ref>

तादुरी
<u>'''Tādurī'''</u> is mentioned in a verse of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1133> iv. 15, 14.</ref> together with the female frog ('''Maṇḍūkī'''). Some similar animal must be meant,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1133> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 175.</ref> but Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1133> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' where he suggests ''tāḍurī,'' from the root ''taḍ,'' ‘beat,’ with the sense of ‘splashing.’</ref> with the commentator [[दुर्ग|Durga]] on the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_1133> ix. 7.</ref> regards the word as an adjective describing the frog.

तान्व
<u>'''1. Tānva'''</u> in an obscure passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1134> iii. 31, 2.</ref> seems to mean a ‘legitimate son,’ who is said not to leave the heritage (''[[रिक्थ|riktha]]'') of his father to his sister (''[[जामि|jāmi]]''). The exact meaning is probably unascertainable,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1134> ''Cf.'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 348;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]] Noten,'' 1, 240;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 34.</ref> but the passage may convey a statement of what was no doubt the fact, that the daughter had no share in the paternal inheritance; her brother had to provide for her during her life if she remained unmarried, but she had no independent portion.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1134> ''Cf.'' Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 87, for the modern law of the Panjab.</ref> (See '''[[दाय|Dāya]].''')

तान्व
<u>'''2. Tānva'''</u> appears to be a patronymic, ‘descendant of Tanva,’ in a verse of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1135> x. 93, 15.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1135> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166.</ref> thinks that it is the patronymic of '''[[दुःशीम|Duḥśīma]],''' who is mentioned in the preceding verse, but this is uncertain. 

तापस
<u>'''1. Tāpasa,'''</u> ‘ascetic,’ is not found in Vedic literature till the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1136> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 22. ''Cf.'' Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 40.</ref>

तापस
<u>'''2. Tāpasa'''</u> is a name of '''Datta''' who was [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest at the snake festival described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 15).<br>==Foot Notes==

ताबुव
<u>'''Tābuva'''</u> is the name in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1138> v. 13, 10.</ref> of a remedy against snake poison. The Paippalāda recension has Tāvuca instead. Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_1138> Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1896, 681.</ref> thinks that the original form was Tāthuva, from the root ''sthā,'' ‘stand,’ and that it meant ‘stopping’; but this is hardly probable.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1138> Barth. ''Revne del'Histoire des Religions,'' 39, 26. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 244;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 428.</ref>

तायादर
<u>'''Tāyādara,'''</u> ‘belonging to the '''[[तयादर|Tayādara]]'''’ (Av. vi. 72, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

तायु
<u>'''Tāyu,'''</u> ‘thief,’ is mentioned several times in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1140> i. 50, 2;<br> 65, 1;<br> iv. 38, 5;<br> v. 15, 5;<br> 52, 12;<br> vi. 12, 5;<br> vii. 86, 5 (''[[पशु|paśu]]-tṛṭ,'' ‘cattle-thief,’ see Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 106).</ref> See '''[[तस्कर|Taskara]].'''

तारका
<u>'''Tārakā'''</u> is found several times in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1141> ii. 8, 1;<br> iii. 7, 4;<br> vi. 121, 3;<br> xix. 49, 8.</ref> denoting a star. The masculine form Tāraka occurs in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1141> i. 5, 2, 5.</ref>

तारुक्ष्य
<u>'''Tārukṣya'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1142> iii. 1, 6.</ref> and [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1142> vii. 19.</ref> In the former passage [[तार्क्ष्य|Tārkṣya]] is a variant reading, and in the latter [[तार्क्ष्य|Tārkṣya]] is read, but this is probably only due to confusion with [[तार्क्ष्य|Tārkṣya]], the reputed author of a Rigvedic hymn.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1142> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 5, 2, with Keith's note;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] xi. 14, 28;<br> xii. 11, 12, Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 1.</ref> 

तार्क्ष्य
<u>'''Tārkṣya'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1143> i. 89, 6;<br> x. 178.</ref> as a divine steed, apparently the sun conceived as a horse.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1143> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 149.</ref> But Foy,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1143> Kuhn's ''Zeitschrift,'' 11, 366, 367.</ref> judging by the name, apparently a patronymic of '''[[तृक्षि|Tṛkṣi]],''' who is known from the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1143> viii. 22, 7.</ref> onwards as a descendant of '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],''' thinks that a real steed, the property of [[तृक्षि|Tṛkṣi]], is meant; but this is not very probable.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1143> In [[खिल|Khila]], ii. 4, 1, [[तार्क्ष्य|Tārkṣya]] is represented as a bird (''[[वायस|vāyasa]]''), also a symbol of the sun. In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 18, he is mentioned with Ariṣṭanemi, originally an epithet of his (Rv. i. 89, 6;<br> x. 178, 1), as a person, and in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 13, he appears as Vaipaśyata ([[वैपश्चित|Vaipaścita]] in Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7), king of the birds (''cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 369).</ref> See also '''[[तारुक्ष्य|Tārukṣya]].'''

तार्प्य
<u>'''Tārpya'''</u> denotes, in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1144> xviii. 4, 31.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1144> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 11, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 7, 1;<br> 7, 6, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 5, 20;<br> Kātyāyana Śranta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 5, 7 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 12, 19.</ref> a garment made of some material, the nature of which is uncertain. The commentators on the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1144> v. 3, 5, 20. ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Sāyaṇa on Av., ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 879.</ref> suggest that a linen garment, or one thrice soaked in ghee, or one made of the ''tṛpā'' or of the ''triparṇa'' plant, is meant: it is doubtful whether the sense was known even to the author of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] himself. Goldstücker's<ref name=fx4_ve1_1144> Dictionary, ''s.v. abhiṣecanīya.''</ref> rendering of the word is ‘silken garment,’ which Eggeling<ref name=fx5_ve1_1144> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 85, n. 1.</ref> is inclined to accept.^6

तार्ष्टाघ
<u>'''Tārṣṭāgha,'''</u> a species of tree, is mentioned in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1145> xxv. 23.</ref> while the adjective formed from it, ''tārṣṭāghī,'' ‘derived from the [[तार्ष्टाघ|Tārṣṭāgha]] tree,’ is found in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1145> v. 29, 15. ''Cf.'' Whitney's note in his Translation of the Atharvaveda.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_1145> ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 280.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62.</ref> thinks that the ''[[सर्षप|sarṣapa]],'' or mustard plant, is meant. 

तितü
<u>'''Titaü'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1146> On the peculiar form of this word, ''of.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 20, 3.</ref> is found once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1146> x. 71, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238.</ref> denoting a ‘sieve,’ or perhaps ‘winnowing fan,’ which was used for purifying corn (''[[सक्तु|saktu]]'').

तित्तिर
<u>'''Tittira, Tittiri,'''</u> is the name of the partridge in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1147> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 2;<br> v. 5, 16, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30, 36. The form [[तित्तिर|Tittira]] occurs in the Maitrāyaṇī Samhitā, iii. 14, 1.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1147> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 5;<br> v. 5, 4, 6;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 154, 6 (Oertel, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 181).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 91;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 251.</ref> being presumably an onomatopoetic formation. The bird is described as having variegated plumage (''bahu-rūpa''). It is usually associated with the '''[[कपिञ्जल|Kapiñjala]]''' and '''[[कलविङ्क|Kalaviṅka]].'''

तिथि
<u>'''Tithi,'''</u> as the name of a lunar day, the thirtieth part of a lunar month of rather over twenty-seven days, is only found in the later Sūtras,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1148> Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 13;<br> ii. 8, 12, 20;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 25;<br> v. 2, etc.</ref> being completely unknown to the Brāhmaṇas, in which the only day is the natural one.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1148> Thibaut, ''Astronomie, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 7, 8.</ref> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

तिमिर्घ दौरे-श्रुत
<u>'''Timirgha Daure-śruta'''</u> (‘descendant of Dūreśruta’) is mentioned as Agnīdh (‘fire-kindling’) priest at the snake sacrifice described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1149> xxv. 15. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

तिरश्च
<u>'''Tiraśca'''</u> is read in some manuscripts of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1150> xv. 3, 5. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 776;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Araṇyaka,'' 19, n. 3.</ref> in the description of the Vrātya's throne ('''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]]'''), meaning ‘the cross-pieces.’ But the reading should be ''tiraścye,'' which is adjectival, and is used in the same sense. 

तिरश्च-राजि
<u>'''Tiraśca-rāji,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1151> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 10, 2;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94, 95, reports this form from the Av., but the text and Roth (St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'') read ''tiraści-rāji'' there.</ref> '''Tiraści-rāji,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1151> Av. iii. 27, 2;<br> vi. 56, 2;<br> vii. 56, 1;<br> x. 4, 13;<br> xii. 3, 56.</ref> '''Tiraścīna-rāji,'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1151> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 13, 21;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 27.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 488, 553;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 68, n. 2;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 295-297.</ref> are variant forms of a name for ‘snake’ (lit., ‘striped across’), found in the later Saṃhitās.

तिरश्ची
<u>'''Tiraścī'''</u> is, according to the Anukramaṇī, the author of a Rigvedic hymn<ref name=fx1_ve1_1152> viii. 95, 4.</ref> in which he appeals to Indra to hear his call. The [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1152> xii. 6, 12.</ref> adopts this view of the name, and mentions a [[तिरश्ची|Tiraścī]] [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]]. But Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1152> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 115. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 5, 187;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 90;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 273.</ref> thinks that the word is not a proper name at all.

तिरश्चीन-वंश
<u>'''Tiraścīna-vaṃśa,'''</u> ‘cross-beam,’ is used to denote a ‘beehive’ in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1153> iii. 1, 1. ''Cf.'' Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 75.</ref> See also '''[[वंश|Vaṃśa]].'''

तिरिन्दिर
<u>'''Tirindira'''</u> is mentioned in a Dānastuti, or ‘Praise of Gifts,’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1154> viii. 6, 46-48.</ref> as having, along with '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]],''' bestowed gifts on the singer. In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1154> xvi. 11. 20.</ref> this statement is represented by a tale that the [[कण्व|Kaṇva]] [[वत्स|Vatsa]] obtained a gift from [[तिरिन्दिर|Tirindira]] [[पारशव्य|Pāraśavya]], [[तिरिन्दिर|Tirindira]] and [[पर्शु|Parśu]] being in this version thus treated as one and the same man. Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve1_1154> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 160, 161;<br> 5, 142.</ref> sees in the Rigvedic passage a proof that the Yadus had gained a victory over [[तिरिन्दिर|Tirindira]], and gave a part of the booty to the singers; but there is no proof whatever of the correctness of this interpretation, which Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_1154> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 136, 137.</ref> shows to be most unlikely. Yadu princes must be meant by [[तिरिन्दिर|Tirindira]] and  [[पर्शु|Parśu]], though Weber<ref name=fx5_ve1_1154> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 356, n.;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 3, 4;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 37, 38.</ref> thinks that the singers were Yadus, not the princes. The latter he holds to have been Iranian (''cf.'', and see '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]]'''), and he thinks that in this there is evidence of continual close relations between India and Iran. This is perfectly possible, but the evidence for it is rather slight.(**  6 For the recent controversy as to Iranian names found at Boghaz-kio7i, ''cf.'' Jacobi, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 721 ''et seq.;'' Oldenberg, ''ibid.,'' 1095-1100; Keith, ''ibid.,'' 1100-1106; Sayce, ''ibid.,'' 1106, 1107; Kennedy, ''ibid.,'' 1107-1119. Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 94 ''et seq.,'' argues in favour of an early connexion of Iranians and Indians in Arachosia, where he places part of the action of the Rigveda. Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 16, 277, holds that traces of Iranian connexion are signs of late date; Arnold, ''ibid.,'' 18, 205 ''et seq.,'' opposes this view.

तिरीट
<u>'''Tirīṭa'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1155> Meaning, according to later native lexicographers, ‘head-dress’ or ‘diadem.’</ref> is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1155> viii. 6, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 265;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 495.</ref> in the adjectival derivative ''tirīṭin'' used of a demon, and presumably meaning ‘adorned with a tiara.’

तिर्य
<u>'''Tirya'''</u> occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1156> iv. 7, 3.</ref> as an epithet of '''[[करम्भ|Karambha]],''' ‘gruel.’ It is probably equivalent to ''tilya,'' ‘made of sesamum,’ as rendered by Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_1156> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Whitney,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1156> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 155.</ref> but ''tiriya'' is read by Roth<ref name=fx4_ve1_1156> See Whitney, ''loc. cit.,'' with Lanman's additional note. Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 377, construes the adjective with ''viṣam,'' and renders ‘the poison which comes in a horizontal direction’ (''cf. tiryañc''). Grill, ''Hundert Lieder,''^2 121, amends to ''atiriya,'' ‘overflowing.’<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 270;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 201.</ref> in the Rāja-nighaṇṭu as a kind of rice.

तिर्यञ्च् आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Tiryañc Āṅgirasa'''</u> is mentioned as a seer of Sāmans, or Chants, in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1157> xii. 6, 12. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160.</ref> The name is doubtless feigned. 

तिल
<u>'''Tila'''</u> denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1158> ii. 8, 3;<br> vi. 140, 2;<br> xviii. 3, 69;<br> 4, 32.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1158> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 10, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 12;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 1, 1, 3, etc.</ref> the sesamum plant, and particularly its grains, from which a rich oil ('''[[तैल|Taila]]''') was extracted. It is often<ref name=fx3_ve1_1158> Av. vi. 140, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 22;<br> Chāndogva [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 10, 6, etc.</ref> mentioned in connexion with '''[[माष|Māṣa]],''' ‘kidney bean.’ The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_1158> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> attributes the bean and the sesamum to the winter (''[[हेमन्त|hemanta]]'') and the cool (''[[शिशिर|śiśira]]'') seasons. The stalk of the sesamum plant (''tila-piñjī,''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1158> Av. ii. 8, 3.</ref> ''til-piñja''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1158> Av. xii. 2, 54.</ref>) was used for fuel, and the seed was boiled in the form of porridge (''tilaudana''<ref name=fx7_ve1_1158> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 16;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 240.</ref>) for food.

तिल्वक
<u>'''Tilvaka'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1159> xiii. 8, 1, 16.</ref> as a tree (''Symplocos racemosa''), near which it is inauspicious to construct a grave. The adjectival derivative ''tailvaka,'' ‘made of the wood of the [[तिल्वक|Tilvaka]],’ is found in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1159> iii. 1, 9.</ref> and is employed to describe the ''[[यूप|yūpa]],'' or sacrificial post, in the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1159> iii. 8.</ref>

तिष्य
<u>'''Tiṣya'''</u> occurs twice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1160> v. 54, 13;<br> x. 64, 8 (with [[कृशानु|Kṛśānu]] as in archer).</ref> apparently as the name of a star,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1160> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 290;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 355;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 331;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 77, n. 1.</ref> though Sāyaṇa takes it to mean the sun. It is doubtless identical with the Avestan Tistrya. Later it is the name of a lunar mansion: see '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''

तिसृ-धन्व
<u>'''Tisṛ-dhanva,'''</u> ‘a bow with three (arrows),’ is mentioned as a gift to the priest at the sacrifice in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1161> i. 8, 19, 1.</ref> and in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1161> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 3, 4;<br> ii. 7, 9, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 5, 10;<br> xiv. 1, 1, 7.</ref> 

तुग्र
<u>'''Tugra'''</u> appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1162> i. 116, 3;<br> 117, 14;<br> vi. 62, 6.</ref> as the name of the father of '''[[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]],''' a protégé of the Aśvins, who is accordingly called [[तुग्र्य|Tugrya]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1162> Rv. viii. 3, 23;<br> 74, 14.</ref> or [[तौग्र्य|Taugrya]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1162> Rv. i. 117, 15;<br> 118, 6;<br> 182, 5. 6;<br> viii. 5, 22;<br> x. 39, 4.</ref> A different [[तुग्र|Tugra]] seems to be referred to in other passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1162> vi. 20, 8;<br> 26, 4;<br> x. 49, 4. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 328, 329;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 157.</ref> as an enemy of Indra.

तुग्र्य
<u>'''Tugrya'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda as a patronymic of '''[[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1163> Who is also called ''Tugrasya [[सूनु|sūnu]],'' Rv. vi. 62, 6. ''Cf.'' the use of ''[[पज्रिय|Pajriya]]'' and perhaps ''Kṛṣṇiya'' in the patronymic sense without Vṛddhi.</ref> but also in a passage<ref name=fx2_ve1_1163> viii. 32, 20.</ref> in which no reference to [[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]] appears to be meant, and in which it may mean ‘a man of the house of [[तुग्र|Tugra]].’ A similar sense seems to occur in the locative plural feminine in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1163> i. 33, 15. ''Cf.'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 47.</ref> where (supplying ''vikṣu'') the meaning must be ‘among the Tugrians.’ This explanation may also apply to the epithet of Indra<ref name=fx4_ve1_1163> viii. 45, 29;<br> 99, 7.</ref> or Soma,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1163> viii. 1, 15, where, however, Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' suggests an alteration to make it refer to Indra.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 128.</ref> ''tugryā-vṛdh,'' ‘rejoicing among the Tugrians.’

तुच्
<u>'''Tuc'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1164> viii. 18, 18;<br> 27, 14;<br> vi. 48, 9.</ref> occasionally occurs denoting ‘children.’ Tuj occurs rather more often in the same sense.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1164> iii. 45, 4;<br> iv. 1, 3;<br> v. 41, 9;<br> viii. 4, 15.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[तनय|Tanaya]]''' and '''Toka.'''

तुजि
<u>'''Tuji'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1165> vi. 26, 4;<br> x. 49, 4.</ref> of a protégé of Indra, who in another hymn<ref name=fx2_ve1_1165> vi. 20, 8. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 156;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 328.</ref> appears to be called [[तूतुजि|Tūtuji]].

तुमिञ्ज औपोदिति
<u>'''Tumiñja Aupoditi'''</u> is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (i. 7, 2, 1) as a [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest at a Sattra, or ‘sacrificial session,’ and as having been engaged in a discussion with '''[[सुश्रवस्|Suśravas]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

तुर कावषेय
<u>'''Tura Kāvaṣeya'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the tenth book of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1167> x. 6, 5, 9.</ref> as the source of the doctrine set forth in that book, and as separated, in the succession of teachers, from '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]''' by '''Yajñavacas''' and '''Kuśri.''' In the same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1167> ix. 5, 2, 15.</ref> he is quoted by [[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]] as having erected a fire-altar on the '''[[कारोती|Kārotī]].''' In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1167> iv. 27;<br> vii. 34;<br> viii. 21.</ref> he appears as a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or ‘domestic priest,’ of '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]] [[पारिक्षित|Pārikṣita]],''' whom he consecrated king. In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1167> vi. 5, 4 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]], not in Mādhyaṃdina).</ref> and a [[खिल|Khila]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1167> i. 9, 6;<br> Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 65, 190.</ref> he appears as an ancient sage. Oldenberg,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1167> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 239.</ref> no doubt rightly, assigns him to the end of the Vedic period. He is probably<ref name=fx7_ve1_1167> So the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> identical with Tura, the ''[[देव-मुनि|deva-muni]],'' ‘saint of the gods,’ who is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx8_ve1_1167> xxv. 14, 5. See Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 68.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 203, n.;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 120, 131;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, xviii.</ref>

तुर-श्रवस्
<u>'''Tura-śravas'''</u> is the name of a seer mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1168> ix. 4, 10. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 53;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 316.</ref> as having pleased Indra by two Sāmans (Chants) of his composition. Indra in return appears to have given him the oblation of the '''Pārāvatas''' on the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]].'''

तुर्य-वाह्
<u>'''Turya-vāh,'''</u> masc.; '''Turyauhī,''' fem., ‘a four-year-old ox or cow,’ is mentioned in the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1169> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 3, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 11;<br> 13, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 10;<br> xviii. 26, etc.</ref>

तुर्व
<u>'''Turva'''</u> occurs only once in the Rigveda (x. 62, 10), doubtless as a name of the '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]''' people or king. <br>==Foot Notes==

तुर्वश
<u>'''Turvaśa'''</u> occurs frequently in the Rigveda as the name of a man or of a people, usually in connexion with '''Yadu.''' The two words usually occur in the singular without any connecting particle, ''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] Yadu'' or ''Yadu [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]].''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1171> v. 31, 8.</ref> In a plural form the name [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] occurs once with the Yadus,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1171> i. 108, 8.</ref> and once alone<ref name=fx4_ve1_1171> viii. 4, 18;<br> singular with [[आनव|Ānava]] in viii. 4, 1.</ref> in a hymn in which the singular has already been used. In one passage<ref name=fx5_ve1_1171> iv. 30, 17.</ref> the dual ''Turvaśā-Yadū'' actually occurs, and in another<ref name=fx6_ve1_1171> x. 62, 10. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 220, n. 1.</ref> ''Yadus Turvaś ca,'' ‘Yadu and [[तुर्व|Turva]].’ In other passages<ref name=fx7_ve1_1171> i. 4, 77;<br> vi. 27, 7. ''Cf.'' viii. 4, 1.</ref> [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] appears alone, while in one<ref name=fx8_ve1_1171> vii. 19, 8.</ref> [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] and [[याद्व|Yādva]] occur.<br><br>From these facts Hopkins<ref name=fx9_ve1_1171> ''Op. cit.,'' 258 ''et seq.''</ref> deduces the erroneousness of the ordinary view,<ref name=fx10_ve1_1171> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 122, 124;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 404;<br> Ludwig, ''op. cit.,'' 153;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 64;<br> ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 153 ''et seq.,'' etc.</ref> according to which [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] is the name of a tribe, the singular denoting the king, and regards [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] as the name of the Yadu king. But the evidence for this is not conclusive. Without laying any stress on the argument based on the theory<ref name=fx11_ve1_1171> Zimmer, 122, 124;<br> Macdonell, 153, 154.</ref> that the ‘five peoples’ of the Rigveda are the '''Anus, Druhyus,''' Turvaśas, Yadus, and '''Pūrus,''' it is perfectly reasonable to hold that the Turvaśas and Yadus were two distinct though closely allied tribes. Such they evidently were to the seers of the hymns which mention in the dual the ''Turvaśā-Yadū'' and speak of ''Yadus Turvaś ca.'' This explanation also suits best the use of the plural of [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] in two Rigvedic hymns.<br><br>In the Rigveda the chief exploit of [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] was his participation in the war against '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' by whom he was defeated.<ref name=fx12_ve1_1171> vii. 18, 6.</ref> Hopkins<ref name=fx13_ve1_1171> ''Op. cit.,'' 264.</ref> suggests that he may have been named [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] because of his fleet (''tura'') escape from the battle. His escape(**  1 i. 36, 18; 54, 6; 174, 9; vi. 20, 12; 45, 1; viii. 4, 7; 7, 18; 9, 14; 45, 27; x. 49, 8. In vii. 18, 6, [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] is joined with [[यक्षु|Yakṣu]], apparently a contemptuous variant of Yadu (Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 261). ''Cf.'' '''[[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]].'''  may have been assisted by Indra, for in some passages<ref name=fx14_ve1_1171> Rv. i. 174, 9;<br> iv. 30, 17;<br> v. 31, 8;<br> viii. 4, 7.</ref> Indra's aid to [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] (and) Yadu is referred to; it is also significant that the Anu, and apparently the [[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]], kings are mentioned as having been drowned in the defeat, but not the [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] and Yadu kings, and that [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] appears in the eighth book of the Rigveda as a worshipper of Indra with the Anu prince, the successor, presumably, of the one who was drowned.<ref name=fx15_ve1_1171> Hopkins, 265.</ref> Griffith,<ref name=fx16_ve1_1171> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 433, n.</ref> however, proposes to refer these passages to a defeat by [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] and Yadu of Arṇa and [[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]] on the '''[[सरयु|Sarayu]];'''<ref name=fx17_ve1_1171> The hymn is a late one, and the connexion of verse 18, where Arṇa and [[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]] are mentioned, is obscure. ''Cf.'' Hopkins. 259.</ref> but the evidence for this is quite inadequate.<br><br>Two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx18_ve1_1171> vi. 45, 1;<br> ix. 61, 2 (where Divodāsa is mentioned);<br> vii. 19, 8 (where he appears as [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]]).</ref> seem to refer to an attack by [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] and Yadu on '''Divodāsa,''' the father of [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. It is reasonable to suppose that this was an attack of the two peoples on Divodāsa, for there is some improbability of the references being to the [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], who was concerned in the attack on [[सुदास्|Sudās]], the son.<br><br>Zimmer<ref name=fx19_ve1_1171> ''Op. cit.,'' 124.</ref> considers that the Turvaśas were also called '''Vṛcīvants.''' This view is based on a hymn<ref name=fx20_ve1_1171> vi. 27, 5-7.</ref> in which reference is made to the defeat of the Vṛcīvants on the '''[[यव्यावती|Yavyāvatī]]''' and '''[[हरियूपीया|Hariyūpīyā]]''' in aid of Daivarāta, and of [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] in aid of '''[[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]],''' the latter being elsewhere<ref name=fx21_ve1_1171> iv. 15, 4.</ref> clearly the son of [[देवरात|Devarāta]]. But as this evidence for the identification of the Turvaśas with the Vṛcīvants is not clear, it seems sufficient<ref name=fx22_ve1_1171> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 404, n. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105.</ref> to assume that they were allies.<br><br>Later, in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx23_ve1_1171> xiii. 5, 4, 16.</ref> the Turvaśas appear as allies of the Pañcālas, [[तौर्वश|Taurvaśa]] horses, thirty-three in number, and armed men, to the number of 6,000, being mentioned.<ref name=fx24_ve1_1171> The sense is obscure. The St. Petersburg Dictionary takes it apparently as 6,033 horses (of armed warriors);<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 400, prefers to understand it as 33 horses and 6,000 men;<br> Oldenberg, ''loc. cit.,'' takes it as 6,033 warriors. Harisvāmin's Commentary, cited by Eggeling, is obscure.</ref> But otherwise the name disappears: this lends  probability to Oldenberge's conjecture<ref name=fx25_ve1_1171> ''Buddha,'' 404.</ref> that the Turvaśas became merged in the '''[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]]''' people. Hopkins<ref name=fx26_ve1_1171> ''Op. cit.,'' 258, n. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 220.</ref> considers that in the Śatapatha passage the horses were merely named from the family of [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]; but this view is less likely, since it ignores the difficulty involved in the reference to the men.<br><br>It is impossible to be certain regarding the home of the Turvaśas at the time of their conflict with [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. They apparently crossed the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]],'''<ref name=fx27_ve1_1171> Rv. vii. 18.</ref> but from which side is disputed.
