The view of Pischel<ref name=fx28_ve1_1171> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218, ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 126.</ref> and Geldner,<ref name=fx29_ve1_1171> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 152. If in Rv. viii. 20, 24, 1 ''rvaśa'' is read with Ludwig for ''tūrvath'' hey are connected with the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 167;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Text,'' 5, 286;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 354 ''et seq.''</ref> that they advanced from the west towards the east, where the '''Bharatas''' were (see '''Kuru'''), is the more probable.

तुर्वीति
<u>'''Turvīti'''</u> is mentioned several times in the Rigveda, both in association with [[वय्य|Vayya]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1172> i. 54, 6;<br> ii. 13, 12;<br> iv. 19, 6.</ref> and alone.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1172> Rv. i. 36, 18;<br> 61, 11;<br> 112, 23.</ref> In three passages<ref name=fx3_ve1_1172> i. 61, 11;<br> ii. 13, 12;<br> iv. 19, 6.</ref> reference is made to Indra aiding him over a flood. Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve1_1172> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 147;<br> 4, 254. ''Cf.'' '''Turvas1a,''' and Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 358;<br> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 42, 36.</ref> has conjectured that he was king of the Turvaśas and Yadus. But there is no sufficient evidence for this view, though presumably he was of the [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] tribe.

तुला
<u>'''Tulā,'''</u> ‘scales,’ is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1173> xxx. 17.</ref> The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1173> xi. 2, 7, 33.</ref> also speaks of the balance in connexion with the weighing of a man's good and evil deeds in the next and in this world. This differs very considerably from the later balance<ref name=fx3_ve1_1173> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 145.</ref> ordeal, in which a man was weighed twice, and was pronounced guilty or innocent according as, on the second occasion, he was more or less heavy than on the  first. It is not possible to read the later practice into the earlier.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1173> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 21;<br> 2, 363, quotes Schlagintweit as giving this passage as an example of the balance ordeal. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 45, n. 4.</ref>

तुष
<u>'''Tuṣa,'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1174> ix. 6, 16;<br> xi. 1, 12, 29;<br> 3, 5;<br> xii. 3, 19.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1174> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 5, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 9, etc.</ref> regularly denotes the ‘husk’ of grain, often used for a fire.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1174> ''[[तुष|Tuṣa]]-[[पक्व|pakva]],'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 4, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 2, 1, 7.</ref>

तूणव
<u>'''Tūṇava'''</u> denotes in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1175> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Samhitā, vi. 1, 4, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 4;<br> xxxiv. 5 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 477).</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve1_1175> Pañcavimśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5, 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 13, 1;<br> 15, 1;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xiii. 9.</ref> a musical instrument of wood, probably the ‘flute.’ A ‘fluteblower’ is enumerated among the victims of the Puruṣamedha, or ‘human sacrifice.’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1175> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 19, 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 289.</ref>

तूतुजि
<u>'''Tūtuji.'''</u> See '''Tuji.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

तूपर
<u>'''Tūpara,'''</u> ‘hornless,’ is a frequent description of animals intended for the sacrifice, especially of the goat, in the Atharvaveda and later.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1177> Av. xi. 9, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 4, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 1, 15;<br> xxix. 59, etc.;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 3, 7, etc.</ref>

तूर्घ्न
<u>'''Tūrghna'''</u> is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyak (v. 1) as the northern part of [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1178> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78.</ref> Its exact position, however, cannot be ascertained.

तूर्णाश
<u>'''Tūrṇāśa,'''</u> in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1179> viii. 32, 4. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 16.</ref> seems to denote a ‘mountain torrent.’ 

तूर्वयाण
<u>'''Tūrvayāṇa'''</u> is the name of a prince mentioned in the Rigveda. He appears by name in two passages,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1180> i. 53, 10;<br> vi. 18, 13.</ref> and is clearly alluded to in a third,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1180> ii. 14, 7 (as a comparison of the two preceding passages shows);<br> perhaps also viii. 53, 2. In i. 174, 3, [[तूर्वयाण|Tūrvayāṇa]] seems also to be a proper name, though Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' here regards the word as an adjective.</ref> as an enemy of '''[[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]], [[आयु|Āyu]],''' and '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]].''' With this accords the fact that the '''Pakthas''' were opposed in the battle of the ten kings to the Tṛtsus,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1180> vii. 18.</ref> and that [[तूर्वयाण|Tūrvayāṇa]]  is shown by another passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1180> x. 61, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 71-77.</ref> to have been a prince of the Pakthas. He is there represented as having been a protégé of Indra, who aided him against '''Cyavāna''' and his guardians, the Maruts. It is not probable that he is identical with '''[[सुश्रवस्|Suśravas]].'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1180> Mentioned in i. 53, 9. 10. ''Cf.'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 75, n.</ref>

तूष
<u>'''Tūṣa'''</u> is found in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_1181> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 1, 1;<br> ii. 4, 9, 1;<br> vi. 1, 1, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 1, 8;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262.</ref> denoting the ‘fringe’ or ‘trimming’ of a garment.

तृक्षि
<u>'''Tṛkṣi'''</u> is, in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1182> viii. 22, 7.</ref> the name of a prince who was a [[त्रासदस्यव|Trāsadasyava]], ‘descendant of '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]].'''’ He also appears with the [[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]] and the [[पूरु|Pūru]] peoples in another hymn.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1182> vi. 46, 8. It is not certain that the two persons are identical (''cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologic,'' 1, 113, notes 3, 4), but it is probable.</ref> It has been conjectured, but it is not probable, that the steed '''[[तार्क्ष्य|Tārkṣya]]''' (as ‘belonging to Tṛkṣi’) was his.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1182> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 149.</ref>

तृण
<u>'''Tṛṇa,'''</u> ‘grass,’ is often mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1183> i. 161, 1;<br> 162, 8, 11;<br> x. 102, 10, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1183> Av. ii. 30, 1;<br> vi. 54, 1, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 22;<br> viii. 24, etc.</ref> It was used as straw to roof in a house or hut.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1183> Av. iii. 12, 5;<br> ix. 3, 4, 7.</ref> 

तृण-जलायुक
<u>'''Tṛṇa-jalāyuka,'''</u> ‘caterpillar,’ is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 2, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

तृण-स्कन्द
<u>'''Tṛṇa-skanda'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1185> i. 172, 3.</ref> as the name of a prince, his subjects (''viśaḥ'') being referred to.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1185> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 159, takes ''viśaḥ'' as ‘cantons,’ but see [[विश्|Viś]].</ref> The word may originally have meant ‘grasshopper.’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1185> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

तृतीयक
<u>'''Tṛtīyaka,'''</u> ‘the tertian (fever),’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda (i. 25, 4; v. 22, 13; xix. 39, 10). See '''[[तक्मन्|Takman]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

तृत्सु
<u>'''Tṛtsu'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda, once in the singular<ref name=fx1_ve1_1187> vii. 18, 13.</ref> and several times in the plural,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1187> vii. 18, 7. 15. 19;<br> 33, 5. 6;<br> 83, 4. 6. 8.</ref> as a proper name. The Tṛtsus were clearly helpers of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' in the great battle against the ten kings, '''[[शिम्यु|Śimyu]],''' the '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]],''' the '''[[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]], [[कवष|Kavaṣa]],''' the '''[[पूरु|Pūru]],''' the '''Anu, [[भेद|Bheda]], [[शम्बर|Śambara]],''' the two '''Vaikarṇas,''' and perhaps the '''Yadu,''' who led with them as allies<ref name=fx3_ve1_1187> They were regarded as enemies of the kings by Roth, ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 95, and by Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 126, The latter, however, altered his view (see pp. 430, 431, which Hopkins, ''op. cit.,'' 260, has overlooked), and there is no doubt that the later opinion is correct. ''Cf.'' also Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173;<br> Hopkins, 260, 261. Of these tribes the Pakthas, Alinas, [[भलानस्|Bhalānas]], Viṣāṇins, and Śivas, were probably settled in the north-west, to the west of the Indus, and around the Kabul River. The Anus, Pūrus, Turvaśas, Yadus, and Druhyus, were probably tribes of the Panjab;<br> the Ajas, Śigrus, and Yakṣus, tribes of the east, under [[भेद|Bheda]];<br> [[शम्बर|Śambara]] may also have been a native of the east;<br> [[शिम्यु|Śimyu]] and [[कवष|Kavaṣa]] are doubtful;<br> and the Vaikarṇau probably belonged to the north-west.</ref> the '''Matsyas, Pakthas, [[भलानस्|Bhalānas]], Alinas, Viṣāṇins, Śivas, Ajas, Śigrus,''' and perhaps Yakṣus.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1187> This is uncertain;<br> the text of the Rigveda, vii. 18, 6, has [[यक्षु|Yakṣu]], and the same word recurs in verse 19. On the other hand, the word Yadu would naturally be expected in verse 6, as [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] is mentioned. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 122, says that Yadu occurs in vii. 18, but on p. 126 he cites [[यक्षु|Yakṣu]] in both places, evidently by oversight. Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 261, n., considers that [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], the [[यक्षु|Yakṣu]], is a sarcastic expression, instead of [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], the Yadu, making [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], whom he regards as king of the Yadus, ridiculous as a member of an insignificant people, and alluding to him also as a sacrificial victim (as it were, ''yaṣṭavya,'' ‘to be offered’;<br> ''of [[पुरोडाश्|puroḍāś]],'' ‘cake of sacrifice,’ in verse 6, as a pun on ''purogās,'' ‘leader’). Whether [[यक्षु|Yakṣu]] is used contemptuously for Yadu or not, it seems hard not to believe that the Yadus are referred to.</ref> The defeat of the ten kings is celebrated in one  hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1187> vii. 18.</ref> and is evidently alluded to in two others.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1187> vii. 33 and 83.</ref> The great battle took place on the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]],''' but there was also a fight on the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' with [[भेद|Bheda]], the Ajas, Śigrus, and Yakṣus. As the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] and the Parusṇī represent opposite ends of the territory of the Tṛtsus (for we cannot with Hopkins<ref name=fx7_ve1_1187> ''India, Old and New,'' 52. No such conjecture was made by him in the ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 259 ''et seq.''</ref> safely identify the streams), it is difficult to see exactly how the ten kings could be confederated, but it should be noted that the references to the ten kings occur in the two later hymns,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1187/> and not in the hymn<ref name=fx5_ve1_1187/> describing the battle itself; besides, absolute numerical accuracy cannot be insisted upon.<br><br>It is difficult exactly to determine the character of the Tṛtsus; especially in their relation to the Bharatas, who under Viśvāmitra's guidance are represented as prospering and as advancing to the '''[[विपाश्|Vipāś]]''' and '''[[शुतुद्री|Śutudrī]].'''<ref name=fx8_ve1_1187> Rv. iii. 33;<br> 53, 9-12.</ref> Roth ingeniously brought this into connexion with the defeat of his enemies by [[सुदास्|Sudās]], which is celebrated in the seventh book of the Rigveda--a book attributed to the [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] family--and thought that there was a reference in one verse<ref name=fx9_ve1_1187> vii. 33, 6. See Roth, ''op. cit.,'' 90, 121: Muir. ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 320;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 154, 155;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur and Cultur,'' 35, 36;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 110, 111;<br> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society.'' 16, 41.</ref> to the defeat of the Bharatas by [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. But it seems certain that the verse is mistranslated, and that the Bharatas are really represented as victors with [[सुदास्|Sudās]].<ref name=fx10_ve1_1187> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 406: Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 34.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx11_ve1_1187> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 175.</ref> accordingly identifies the Tṛtsus and the Bharatas. Oldenberg,<ref name=fx12_ve1_1187> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 207. ''Cf.'' Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 362.</ref> after accepting this view at first,<ref name=fx13_ve1_1187> ''Buddha,'' 405, 406.</ref> later expressed the opinion that the Tṛtsus were the priests of the [[भरत|Bharata]] people, and therefore identical with the Vasiṣṭhas. This view is supported by the fact that in one passage<ref name=fx14_ve1_1187> Rv. vii. 33, 1 (''śvityañco dakṣiṇataskaparainaḥ'').</ref> the Tṛtsus are clearly described as wearing their hair in the peculiar manner affected by the Vasiṣṭhas,<ref name=fx15_ve1_1187> Rv. vii. 83. (''śvityañco dakṣiṇataskaparainaḥ'').</ref> and would in that passage thus seem to represent the Vasiṣṭhas.  But Geldner<ref name=fx16_ve1_1187> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 136;<br> ''ṚgvedaGlossar,'' 74.</ref> has suggested with great probability that [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]], who is once mentioned in the singular,<ref name=fx17_ve1_1187> Rv. vii. 18, 13.</ref> means the [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]] king--that is, [[सुदास्|Sudās]].<ref name=fx18_ve1_1187> ''Cf.'' Rv. vii. 18, 24. The parallelism of verses 13 and 24 is quite beyond question. Moreover, the praise of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] and of the Bharatas is found coupled in Rv. iii. 53, 9. 12. 24, and in Rv. vi. 16, 4, 5, Divodāsa is coupled with the Bharatas in such a way as to suggest irresistibly that Divodāsa was a [[भरत|Bharata]].</ref> This explanation alone justifies the description<ref name=fx19_ve1_1187> Rv. vii. 33, 6.</ref> of the Bharatas as ''Tṛtsūnāṃ viśaḥ,''<ref name=fx20_ve1_1187> That this is the sense of ''viśaḥ'' is almost certain. See Geldner, ''Vedische Studien, loc. cit.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 159, and Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 111, render it ‘cantons,’ but see Vīś.</ref> ‘subjects of the Tṛtsus,’ meaning the [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]] [[गोत्र|Gotra]] or family, for the people could not be said to be subjects of a body of priests. The Vasiṣṭhas might be called Tṛtsus because of their close connexion with the royal house of that people. The reverse process is also quite possible, but is rendered improbable by the fact that the '''Pratṛdaḥ''' are referred to as receiving [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]].<ref name=fx21_ve1_1187> Rv. vii. 33, 14. Geldner (''op. cit.,'' 138, 139) ingeniously suggests that [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], being miraculously born, needed a [[गोत्र|Gotra]], and so became a [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]].</ref> This name of the [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]] dynasty is probably older than its connexion with [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] in the time of [[सुदास्|Sudās]], a conclusion supported by the name of '''[[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]],''' who is mentioned later as a descendant of Divodāsa,<ref name=fx22_ve1_1187> [[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]] is mentioned in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvi. 5, as [[दैवोदासि|Daivodāsi]], ‘descendant of Divodāsa.’</ref> an ancestor of [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. The [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]] dynasty could therefore hardly have been referred to as Vasiṣṭhas. For the further history of the dynasty and its relation with [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] and [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]], see '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]].'''<br><br>If the Tṛtsus and their subjects, the Bharatas, were in the Rigvedic period at war with the tribes on either side of the territory between the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]] and the [[यमुना|Yamunā]], it is clear<ref name=fx23_ve1_1187> ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 406 ''et seq.,'' and see '''Kuru.'''</ref> that later on they coalesced with the Pūrus and probably others of those tribes to form the '''Kuru''' people. Already in the Rigveda<ref name=fx24_ve1_1187> See Rv. vi. 47, where Divodāsa and [[सार्ञ्जय|Sārñjaya]] are both praised. In vi. 27, 5, the Turvaśas are opposed to the Sṛñjayas, and in vii. 18, 6;<br> 19, 8, the Tṛtsus are opposed to the Turvaśas.</ref> the Tṛtsus are allied with the '''Sṛñjayas,''' and in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx25_ve1_1187> ii. 4, 4, 5.</ref> one [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] serves both Kurus and Sṛñjayas. <br><br>Hillebrandt<ref name=fx26_ve1_1187> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 98 ''et seq.''</ref> considers that the Tṛtsus cannot be identified with the Bharatas, but that [[सुदास्|Sudās]] and the Bharatas represent an invading body, which, however, became allied with the Tṛtsus and the [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] priests. He also thinks that the Rigveda reveals a time when '''Divodāsa,''' the grandfather or ancestor of [[सुदास्|Sudās]], was living in Arachosia, on the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],''' and warring against the '''Paṇis,''' whom he identifies with the Parnians. But this conjecture<ref name=fx27_ve1_1187> ''Cf.'' also Grierson, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 837 ''et seq.''</ref> cannot be regarded as probable. In the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]<ref name=fx28_ve1_1187> Rv. vi. 61, 3. Brunnhofer, ''Iran und Turan,'' 127, identifies this river with the Oxus, but Hillebrandt identifies it with the Haraqaiti.</ref> it is not necessary to see any other river than the later [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], in the middle country, which flowed within the boundaries of the Tṛtsus: it is also significant that there are references<ref name=fx29_ve1_1187> Rv. ix. 61, 2. ''Cf.'' vi. 45, 1;<br> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 124.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 424.</ref> to contests between '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] Yadu''' and [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]] or Divodāsa. Thus there is no reason to doubt that Divodāsa and the Bharatas were in the middle country, and not in Iran.

तृष्ट
<u>'''Tṛṣṭa'''</u> is mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī<ref name=fx1_ve1_1188> iv. 8, 1. The reading is uncertain;<br> it may be ''Tṛṣṭhā-varutrī.'' See von Schroeder's edition, p. 106, n.</ref> and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve1_1188> xxx. 1, where again the reading is uncertain. The Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvi. 4, has ''Tvaṣṭā-varutrī'' (von Schroeder's edition of the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]], 2, 181, n.).<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 190, 191;<br> Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 119.</ref> as being along with '''Varutri''' the priest of the Asuras.

तृष्टामा
<u>'''Tṛṣṭāmā'''</u> is mentioned as a stream in the [[नदी|Nadī]]-[[स्तुति|stuti]], or ‘praise of rivers,’ in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1189> x. 75, 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 14.</ref> There seems to be no means of identifying it.

तेजन
<u>'''Tejana'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1190> i. 110, 5.</ref> a rod or staff of reed used for measuring a field. In the Atharvaveda the sense of ‘bamboo’ is found twice,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1190> i. 2, 4;<br> xx. 136, 3 (= [[खिल|Khila]], v. 22, 3). ''Cf. taijana'' as an adjective in [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 10.</ref> the bamboo being specified in the  second passage as ‘of the spring’ (''vāsantika''); more particularly it denotes the shaft of an arrow,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1190> Av. vi. 49, 1 (Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 317);<br> ''[[इषु|iṣu]] eka-tejanā,'' ‘an arrow with one shaft,’ vi. 57, 1.</ref> a sense often found in later Vedic texts.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1190> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 25;<br> iii. 26;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 1 (with ''[[शृङ्ग|śṛṅga]]'' and ''[[शल्य|śalya]]'' as the three parts of an arrow;<br> in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8, 1, ''[[कुल्मल|kulmala]]'' takes the place of ''[[तेजन|tejana]];<br> cf. ibid.,'' 2). The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 3, 1, has ''anīka, [[शल्य|śalya]],'' and ''[[तेजन|tejana]]. Cf.'' '''[[इषु|Iṣu]].'''</ref>

तेजनी
<u>'''Tejanī'''</u> denotes in the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas a bundle of reeds,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1191> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 8, 3, 12;<br> perhaps [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 9.</ref> and in some cases such a bundle twisted into a rope,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1191> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 13;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 11, as rendered by Sāyaṇa.</ref> for the two ends of the [[तेजनी|Tejanī]] are mentioned.

तेजस्
<u>'''Tejas'''</u> is regarded by Schrader<ref name=fx1_ve1_1192> ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 221.</ref> as having in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1192> ''Cf.'' vi. 3, 5;<br> 8, 5;<br> 15, 19.</ref> the specific sense of ‘axe.’ But in all the passages the sense of the ‘bolt’ of the god is adequate.

तैत्तिरीय
<u>'''Taittirīya'''</u> is the name of one of the divisions of the Black [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]], which is, however, not found thus described until the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1193> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 6;<br> vii. 7. 10, etc. See Weber ''Indian Literature,'' 87 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 175 ''et seq.;<br>'' von Schroeder, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, 1, x ''et seq.''</ref> The school is represented by a Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1193> Edited by Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' xi, xii, and in the ''Bibliotheca Indica,'' 1854-1899.</ref> a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1193> Edited in the ''Bibliotheca Indica,'' 1855-1870, and in the Ānandāśrama Series, 1898.</ref> and an Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1193> Edited in the ''Bibliotheca Indica,'' 18641872, and in the Ānandāśrama Series, 1898.</ref> besides an [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_1193> Edited by Roer, 1850, and in the Ānandāśrama Series, 1889.</ref> which forms a part of the Āraṇyaka.

तैमात
<u>'''Taimāta'''</u> is twice mentioned as a species of snake in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1194> v. 13, 6;<br> 18, 4. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 243;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 425;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref> 

तैल
<u>'''Taila,'''</u> ‘sesamum oil,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1195> i. 7, 2 (all the manuscripts have ''[[तौल|taula]],'' which must be wrong;<br> the Paippalāda MS has ''tūla:'' see Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 7).</ref> where<ref name=fx2_ve1_1195> xx. 136, 16.</ref> reference is made to keeping such oil in jars. In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1195> xi. 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben.'' 240, 241.</ref> reference is made to anointing with sesamum oil.

तोक
<u>'''Toka'''</u> denotes ‘children’ or ‘descendants’ generally in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1196> i. 43, 2;<br> ii. 2, 11;<br> 9, 2;<br> vii. 62, 6;<br> viii. 5, 20;<br> 67, 11, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1196> Av. i. 13, 2;<br> 28, 3;<br> v. 19, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 7 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 466);<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 2, 39, etc.</ref> The word is often joined with '''[[तनय|Tanaya]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1196> Rv. i. 31, 12;<br> 64, 14;<br> 114, 6;<br> 147, 1;<br> ii. 33, 14;<br> v. 53, 13;<br> vi. 1, 12, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7.</ref>

तोक्मन्
<u>'''Tokman,'''</u> neut., denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1197> x. 62, 8.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1197> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 13, 81;<br> xxi. 30. 42;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 11;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5, etc.</ref> the green shoots of any kind of grain. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1197> viii. 16. ''Cf.'' for its use at the [[सौत्रामणी|Sautrāmaṇī]], Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 160.</ref> reference is made to the shoots of rice (''[[व्रीहि|vrīhi]]''), large rice (''mahāvrīhi''), panic seed (''[[प्रियङ्गु|priyaṅgu]]''), and barley (''yava'').

तोत्त्र
<u>'''Tottra,'''</u> a ‘goad’ for driving cattle, is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 4, 1, 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

तोद
<u>'''Toda'''</u> appears once to denote a ‘goad’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1199> iv. 16, 11;<br> [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 107.</ref> but more often<ref name=fx2_ve1_1199> Rv. vi. 6, 6;<br> 12, 1, 3, are probably so to be understood.</ref> it is an agent noun meaning ‘impeller.’ Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve1_1199> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 74.</ref> considers that in one passage<ref name=fx4_ve1_1199> Rv. i. 150, 1.</ref> the sense is ‘wielder of the rod of punishment’ (later ''[[दण्ड|daṇḍa]]-dhara'')--that is, ‘prince.’ 

तौग्र्य
<u>'''Taugrya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[तुग्र|Tugra]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1200> i. 117, 16;<br> 118, 6;<br> 182, 5. 6;<br> viii. 5, 22;<br> x. 39, 4.</ref>

तौदी
<u>'''Taudī'''</u> in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1201> x. 4, 24. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 578, leaves the word untranslated. Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 608, suggests that it is a fanciful name, ‘the piercer,’ since it is associated with ''ghṛtācī,'' ‘dripping with ghee,’ which is clearly such a word.</ref> appears to denote a plant.

तौर्वश
<u>'''Taurvaśa.'''</u> See '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

तौल
<u>'''Taula,'''</u> the reading of the text of the Atharvaveda (i. 7, 2), and a form which is otherwise unknown and cannot be satisfactorily explained, must doubtless be meant for '''[[तैल|Taila]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

तौविलिका
<u>'''Tauvilikā,'''</u> occurring once in a hymn of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1204> vi. 16, 3.</ref> is a word of quite uncertain sense. Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_1204> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> thinks it means some kind of beast; Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_1204> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref> and Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve1_1204> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 292.</ref> regard it as a sort of plant; Sāyaṇa explains it as a disease-causing demon, while Bloomfield<ref name=fx5_ve1_1204> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 30, 466.</ref> leaves the sense doubtful.

त्रपु
<u>'''Trapu'''</u> denotes ‘tin’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1205> xi. 3, 8.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1205> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xviii. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 11, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 13 (all in enumerations of metals);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 6, 5;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 17, 3;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 7. In [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 5, 1, the form is ''trapus.''</ref> Its quality of being easily smelted, which Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1205> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 53.</ref> thinks is indicated by the name (as derived from the root ''trap,'' ‘be ashamed’), is clearly alluded to in the Atharvaveda passage. 

त्रस-दस्यु
<u>'''Trasa-dasyu,'''</u> son of '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1206> Rv. v. 33, 8;<br> vii. 19, 3;<br> viii. 19, 36;<br> iv. 42, 8 ''et seq.''</ref> is mentioned in the Rigveda as king of the Pūrus.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1206> Rv. iv. 38, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' vii. 19, 3. He is merely alluded to in i. 63, 7;<br> 112, 4;<br> viii. 8, 21;<br> 36, 7;<br> 37, 7;<br> 49, 10.</ref> He was born to [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] by his wife, '''[[पुरुकुत्सानी|Purukutsānī]],''' at a time of great distress;<ref name=fx3_ve1_1206> Rv. iv. 42, 8 ''et seq.''</ref> this, according to Sāyaṇa, refers to Purukutsa's captivity: possibly his death is really meant. [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] was also a descendant of Girikṣit,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1206> Rv. v. 33, 8.</ref> and [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] was a descendant of [[दुर्गह|Durgaha]]. The genealogy, therefore, appears to be: [[दुर्गह|Durgaha]], Girikṣit, [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]], [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]]. [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] was the ancestor of '''[[तृक्षि|Tṛkṣi]],'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1206> Rv. viii. 22, 7. He was a [[पूरु|Pūru]] king. See vi. 46, 8.</ref> and, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1206> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155, with reference to Rv. v. 33, 7 ''et seq.''</ref> had a son [[हिरणिन्|Hiraṇin]]. Trasadasyu's chronological position is determined by the fact that his father, [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]], was a contemporary of [[सुदास्|Sudās]], either as an opponent<ref name=fx7_ve1_1206> So Ludwig, 3, 174, who alters ''Sudāsam'' to ''Sudāse,'' in support of this view, in Rv. i. 63, 7. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 204, 205, 219, ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 63;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 153;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 112, n. 1. Foy, Kuhn's ''Zeitschrift,'' 34, 242, denies that the word in this passage is a proper name at all.</ref> or as a friend.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1206> ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''loc. cit.''</ref> That [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] was an enemy of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] is more probable, because the latter's predecessor, Divodāsa, was apparently<ref name=fx9_ve1_1206> Rv. i. 130, 7;<br> Ludwig, 3, 114;<br> but see Hillebrandt, 1, 113, 114.</ref> at enmity with the Pūrus, and in the battle of the ten kings Pūrus were ranged against [[सुदास्|Sudās]] and the Tṛtsus. [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] himself seems to have been an energetic king. His people, the Pūrus, were settled on the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],'''<ref name=fx10_ve1_1206> Rv. vii. 95, 96;<br> Ludwig, 3, 175;<br> Hillebrandt, 1, 115.</ref> which was, no doubt, the stream in the middle country, that locality according well with the later union of the Pūrus with the '''Kuru''' people, who inhabited that country. This union is exemplified in the person of '''Kuruśravaṇa,''' who is called [[त्रासदस्यव|Trāsadasyava]], ‘descendant of [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx11_ve1_1206> x. 33, 4. ''Cf.'' Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 386 ''et seq.;<br>'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 150, 184.</ref> whose father was '''[[मित्रातिथि|Mitrātithi]],''' and whose son was '''[[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]].''' The relation of [[मित्रातिथि|Mitrātithi]] to [[तृक्षि|Tṛkṣi]] does not appear.<br><br>Another descendant of [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] was '''Tryaruṇa [[त्रैवृष्ण|Traivṛṣṇa]],''' who is simply called [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx12_ve1_1206> v. 27.</ref>  He was not only a ‘descendant of Trivṛṣan,’ but, according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx13_ve1_1206> xiii. 3, 12. The Tāṇḍaka, cited by Sāyaṇa (Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 67), has [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]], like the Rv.</ref> he was also [[त्रैधात्व|Traidhātva]], ‘descendant of Tridhātu.’ The order of these two predecessors of Tryaruṇa cannot be determined in any way from Vedic literature. According to the later tradition,<ref name=fx14_ve1_1206> Harivaṃśa, 714 ''et seq.,'' where the name (716) is also misread as Tridharman. [[त्रैधात्व|Traidhātva]] cannot reasonably be taken as representing a patronymic from Tridhanvan, as Sieg, ''op. cit.,'' 7476, seems to do. Trivṛṣan has entirely disappeared from the Epic tradition;<br> there is thus no way of assigning a relative priority to either Trivṛṣan or Tridhanvan.</ref> a prince named Tridhanvan preceded Tryaruṇa in the succession. Vedic tradition further fails to show in what precise relation [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] stood to Trivṛṣan or Tryaruṇa.<br><br>Trasdasyu [[पौरुकुत्स|Paurukutsa]] appears in several Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx15_ve1_1206> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 16;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 3 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 473);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 5, 3.</ref> as a famous sacrificer of ancient times, together with '''[[पर आट्णार|Para Āṭṇāra]], [[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]] [[श्रायस|Śrāyasa]],''' and '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]] [[औशिज|Auśija]],''' who in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx16_ve1_1206> ii. 6, 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 217 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 111-116;<br> 2, 165, n. 4;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 25;<br> Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 386.</ref> are called ‘ancient great kings’ (''pūrve mahārājāḥ'').

त्रात ऐषुमत
<u>'''Trāta Aiṣumata'''</u> (‘descendant of Iṣumant’) is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1207> i. 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref> as a pupil of '''Nigaḍa [[पार्णवल्कि|Pārṇavalki]].'''

त्रायमाणा
<u>'''Trāyamāṇā'''</u> denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1208> viii. 2, 6.</ref> a plant of an unknown species. The word is possibly only an epithet, retaining its participial sense of ‘preserving,’ though this interpretation is not favoured by the accent.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1208> ''[[त्रायमाणा|Trāyamāṇā]]. Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 477.</ref>

त्रासदस्यव
<u>'''Trāsadasyava,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],'''’ is the patronymic in the Rigveda of '''[[तृक्षि|Tṛkṣi]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1209> viii. 22, 7.</ref> and of '''Kuruśravaṇa.'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1209> x. 33, 4.</ref> The  word is also applied to Agni as ‘protector of, or worshipped by, Trasadasyu’ and his line.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1209> viii. 19, 32;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 96.</ref>

त्रि-ककुद्
<u>'''Tri-kakud'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1210> Av. iv. 9, 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 3, 12.</ref> or '''Tri-kakubh,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1210> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxii. 14.</ref> ‘having three peaks,’ occurs in the Atharvaveda and later as the name of a mountain in the Himālaya, the modern Trikota. From it came the salve ([[आञ्जन|Āñjana]]),<ref name=fx3_ve1_1210> Hence called ''[[त्रैककुद|Traikakuda]],'' Av. iv. 9, 9, 10;<br> xix. 44, 6, etc.</ref> which tradition made out to be derived from Vṛtra's eye.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1210> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Maitrāyaṇī and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitās, ''loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 198;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 5, 29, 30;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 239, n. 4;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 381.</ref>

त्रि-कद्रुक
<u>'''Tri-kadruka,'''</u> a term used in the plural only, appears to denote three vessels of some kind for holding Soma.<br><br>^1 i. 32, 3; ii. 11, 17; 15, 1; 22, 1; x. 14, 16.<br>==Foot Notes==

त्रि-खर्व
<u>'''Tri-kharva'''</u> is the name of a school of priests mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 8, 3) as practising a special rite with success.<br>==Foot Notes==

त्रित
<u>'''Trita'''</u> is clearly a god<ref name=fx1_ve1_1213> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 67-69.</ref> in Vedic literature, but [[यास्क|Yāska]] in one passage of the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1213> iv. 6.</ref> already explains the name as that of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] or seer.

त्रि-पुर
<u>'''Tri-pura,'''</u> ‘a threefold stronghold,’ is alluded to in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_1214> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 3, 25;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 11;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 310. See also [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiv. 10, etc., and Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 46, n 1.</ref> as a secure protection. But as the passages are mythical no stress can be laid on them as evidence for the existence of forts with three concentric walls. 

त्रि-प्लक्ष
<u>'''Tri-plakṣa,'''</u> masc. plur., ‘the three fig-trees,’ is the name of the place where the '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]]''' disappeared, near the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]],''' according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1215> xxv. 13, 4. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 29, 33;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 19, 9;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 6, 39.</ref>

त्रिय्-अवि
<u>'''Triy-avi.'''</u> See '''[[त्र्य्अवि|Tryavi]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

त्रि-युग
<u>'''Tri-yuga,'''</u> neut., is an expression occurring in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1217> x. 97, 1 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 6, 1, and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā;<br> xii. 75.</ref> where it is said that the plants (''[[ओषधि|oṣadhi]]'') were born ‘three ages’ before the gods (''devebhyas triyugaṃ purā''). The commentator on the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1217> ix. 28.</ref> thinks that the ages here meant are the Yugas of the later Indian chronology, the sense of the passage being that the plants were born in the first Yuga. The author of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1217> vii. 2, 4, 26.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 340.</ref> understands three seasons--spring, the rains, and autumn--to be meant in the verse, taking the two words ''triyugaṃ purā'' separately as ‘formerly, in the three seasons.’ The vague sense ‘three ages’ is quite adequate: the use of ‘three’ in such cases is a favourite feature in folklore. ''Cf.'' '''Yuga.'''

त्रि-वत्स
<u>'''Tri-vatsa,'''</u> ‘three years old,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1218> As regards the form and meaning of this compound, ''cf.'' '''[[त्र्य्अवि|Tryavi]].'''</ref> is an expression applied to cattle in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1218> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 10;<br> xviii. 26;<br> xxviii. 27;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 13;<br> xviii. 9;<br> xxi. 14, etc. ''Cf.'' Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 3, 9 ''et seq.,'' where one explanation of the word is ''tri-[[वर्ष|varṣa]].''</ref>

त्रि-वृत्
<u>'''Tri-vṛt,'''</u> ‘threefold,’ is the designation of an amulet in the Atharvaveda (v. 28, 2. 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

त्रि-वेद कृष्ण-रात लौहित्य
<u>'''Tri-veda [[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]]-rāta Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[श्यामजयन्त लौहित्य|Śyāmajayanta Lauhitya]],''' according to a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1). <br>==Foot Notes==

त्रि-शङ्कु
<u>'''Tri-śaṅku'''</u> is in Vedic literature the name of a sage mentioned as a teacher in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1221> i. 10, 1.</ref> There is no trace of the later legend by which he becomes the victim of '''Vasiṣṭha's''' curse and the object of '''Viśvāmitra's''' solicitude, being eventually fixed in the sky as a constellation.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1221> See Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 362, 375 ''et seq.''</ref> The confusion of the chronology in the tales of [[त्रिशङ्कु|Triśaṅku]] is a good example of the worthlessness of the supposed epic tradition.

त्रि-शोक
<u>'''Tri-śoka'''</u> is the name of an ancient mythical seer who is mentioned both in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1222> i. 112, 13;<br> viii. 45, 30. In x. 29, 2, the word seems merely to be an adjective, meaning ‘with triple splendour.’</ref> and the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1222> iv. 29, 6.</ref> A Sāman, or chant, named after him is referred to in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1222> viii. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 107, 162;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 33.</ref>

त्रै-ककुद
<u>'''Trai-kakuda.'''</u> See '''[[त्रिककुद्|Trikakud]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

त्रैतन
<u>'''Traitana'''</u> appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1224> i. 158, 5.</ref> as a '''[[दास|Dāsa]],''' an enemy of '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]],''' who seems to have engaged him in single combat and defeated him. The St. Petersburg Dictionary suggests that he is rather a supernatural being allied to [[त्रित|Trita]] (''cf.'' the Avestan Thrita and Thraetaona).<ref name=fx2_ve1_1224> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 68. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 151;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 144.</ref>

त्रै-धात्व
<u>'''Trai-dhātva'''</u> (‘descendant of Tridhātu,’) is the patronymic of '''Tryaruṇa''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 3, 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

त्रै-पद
<u>'''Trai-pada,'''</u> neut., occurs as a measure of distance, ‘threequarters’ of a '''[[योजन|Yojana]],''' in the Pañcāviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], where half a [[योजन|Yojana]] is termed '''[[गव्यूति|Gavyūti]]''' and a quarter '''[[क्रोश|Krośa]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1226> xvi. 13. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 41, 12.</ref> 

त्रैवणि
<u>'''Traivaṇi'''</u> is mentioned as a pupil of '''Aupacandhani''' or '''[[औपजन्धनि|Aupajandhani]]''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1227> ii. 6, 3 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = ii. 5, 21 Mādhyaṃdina);<br> iv. 6, 3 (= iv. 5, 27).</ref> In the Mādhyaṃdina recension<ref name=fx2_ve1_1227> iv. 5, 27.</ref> his name occurs twice in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]], in both cases as a pupil of [[औपजन्धनि|Aupajandhani]].

त्रै-वृष्ण
<u>'''Trai-vṛṣṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of Trivṛṣan,’ is the patronymic of '''Trayaruṇa''' in the Rigveda (v. 27, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

त्र्य्-अरुण त्रै-वृष्ण त्रसदस्यु
<u>'''Try-aruṇa [[त्रै-वृष्ण|Trai-vṛṣṇa]] Trasadasyu'''</u> is the name of a prince whose generosity to a singer is celebrated in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1229> v. 27, 1-3.</ref> In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1229> xiii. 3, 12. ''Cf.'' the Tāṇḍaka recension, cited in Sāyaṇa, on Rv. v. 2, where [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] is given as the king's name.</ref> he appears as '''Tryaruṇa [[त्रैधात्व|Traidhātva]] [[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]],''' and is the hero of the following story. He was out in his chariot with his [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or domestic priest, '''[[वृश जान|Vṛśa Jāna]],''' and by excessive speed in driving killed a Brahmin boy. This sin was atoned for by the Purohita's using his Vārśa Sāman (chant). The [[शाट्यायन|Śāṭyāyana]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], cited by Sāyaṇa,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1229> On Rv., ''loc. cit.'' See also the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] version in Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 20.</ref> elaborates the tale. As Vṛśa had held the reins, king and priest accused each other of the murder. The Ikṣvākus being consulted threw the responsibility for the crime on Vṛśa, who thereupon revived the boy by the Vārśa Sāman. In consequence of this unfairness of theirs--being Kṣatriyas they were partial to a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]--Agni's glow ceased to burn in their houses. In response to their appeal to restore it, Vṛśa came to them, saw the Piśācī (demoness), who, in the form of Trasadasyu's wife, had stolen the glow, and succeeded in restoring it to Agni. This version with some variations occurs also in the Bṛhaddevatā,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1229> v. 14 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> which connects the story with a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1229> v. 2.</ref> Sieg's attempt<ref name=fx6_ve1_1229> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 64-76. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Festtgruss an Roth,'' 192.</ref> to show that the hymn really refers to this tale is not at all successful.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1229> See Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 366 ''et seq.;<br> [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 312;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1903, 240 ''et seq.''</ref> <br><br>It is clear that [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] must here mean ‘descendant of [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],’ and not King [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] himself. The difference of the patronymics, [[त्रैवृष्ण|Traivṛṣṇa]] and [[त्रैधात्व|Traidhātva]], by which he is referred to can best be explained by assuming that there were two kings, Trivṛṣan and Tridhātu (or possibly Tridhanvan), from whom Tryaruṇa was descended.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1229> See Sieg, ''op. cit.,'' 74-76, and '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]].'''</ref> The connexion with the Ikṣvākus is important (see '''[[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]]''').

त्र्य्-अवि
<u>'''Try-avi'''</u> designates a calf eighteen months old<ref name=fx1_ve1_1230> The etymological meaning is apparently ‘having three sheep (periods)’ -that is, ‘having periods of thrice six months,’ just as the adjective ''[[पञ्चावि|pañcāvi]]'' means ‘having five periods of six months,’ or ‘thirty months old.’</ref> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1230> iii. 55, 14.</ref> and later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1230> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 2;<br> xviii. 12, etc. (in the form ''[[त्रिय्अवि|triyavi]]'');<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 10;<br> xviii. 26, etc.</ref>

त्र्य्-आशिर्
<u>'''Try-āśir,'''</u> ‘with three admixtures,’ is an epithet of Soma in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1231> v. 27, 5. ''Cf.'' perhaps viii. 2, 7 (''traya Indrasya somāḥ sutāsaḥ,'' ‘three kinds of Soma pressed for Indra’).</ref> According to Sāyaṇa this means mixed with curds ('''[[दधि|Dadhi]]'''), meal ('''[[सक्तु|Saktu]]'''), and milk ('''[[पयस्|Payas]]'''). More accurately it would seem<ref name=fx2_ve1_1231> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologic,'' 1, 209;<br> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 422.</ref> to denote the milk (''[[गवाशिर्|gavāśir]]''), the barley (''[[यवाशिर्|yavāśir]]''), and the curds (''[[दध्य्आशिर्|dadhyāśir]]''), which were used to mix with the Soma.

त्वच्
<u>'''Tvac,'''</u> ‘skin,’ ‘hide,’ (''a'') denotes specially in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1232> i. 79, 3;<br> iii. 21, 5;<br> ix. 65, 25;<br> 66, 29;<br> 70, 7;<br> 79, 4;<br> 101, 11, 16, etc.</ref> the hide used in the process of extracting the '''Soma''' juice from the plant. The Soma was pounded with stones (''adri'') upon the skin laid on the pressing boards (''adhiṣavaṇe phalake''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_1232> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologic,'' 1, 181-183, and '''Adhisavaṇa.'''</ref> which, however, are not mentioned in the Rigveda. Or if a pestle and mortar were used, the skin was still placed underneath them to catch the drops of juice, not above, as Pischel<ref name=fx3_ve1_1232> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 110.</ref> thought. <br><br>(''b'') Tvac also denotes the rind of the Soma plant that remains after the juice has been extracted.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1232> Rv. ix. 86, 44;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 13, 1;<br> Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 52.</ref><br><br>(''c'') Metaphorically the term ''kṛṣṇā tvac,'' ‘the black skins,’ is applied to the aboriginal enemies of the invading Āryans.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1232> Rv. i. 130, 8, and probably ix. 41, 1, for which, however, ''cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 51, n. 2, and see '''[[दास|Dāsa]].'''</ref>

त्वष्टृ
<u>'''Tvaṣṭṛ'''</u> is employed once in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1233> xii. 3, 33. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 688;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 651.</ref> to denote a ‘carpenter,’ with a deliberate play on the name of the god [[त्वष्टृ|Tvaṣṭṛ]]. He is there mentioned as using an axe (''[[स्वधिति|svadhiti]]'') to fashion (from wood) ‘a well-made form’ (''rūpaṃ sukṛtam''). See '''[[तष्टृ|Taṣṭṛ]].'''

त्वाष्ट्र
<u>'''Tvāṣṭra,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[त्वष्टृ|Tvaṣṭṛ]],’ is the patronymic, in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1234> ii. 6, 3 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]] = ii. 5, 22 Mādhyaṃdina);<br> iv. 6, 3 (= iv. 5, 28).</ref> of the mythical teacher '''Ābhūti.'''

त्सरु
<u>'''Tsaru,'''</u>--(''a'') This word seems to denote some sort of crawling animal in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1235> vii. 50, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref><br><br>(''b'') In the later literature the word means a ‘handle,’ as of a beaker ('''[[चमस|Camasa]]''').<ref name=fx1b_ve1_1235/> In this sense also it seems to occur in the description of the plough ('''[[लाङ्गल|Lāṅgala]]''') in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1235> iii. 17, 3, where the ordinary text has ''soma-satsaru'' (so the Pada text), and the Paippalāda recension has ''somapitsalam.''</ref> and the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1235> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 5, 6, has ''[[सुमति-त्सरु|sumati-tsaru]];<br>'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 12;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 71;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 34, have ''[[सोमपित्सरु|somapitsaru]],'' which [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] renders as ‘provided with a handle for the drinker of Soma’ (''i.e., [[सोमपि-त्सरु|somapi-tsaru]]''). Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 255, suggests ''soma-sa-[[त्सरु|tsaru]],'' ‘with (''sa-'') strap (''uman,'' a conjectural word) and handle’ (''[[त्सरु|tsaru]]''). Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 116, prefers to read throughout ''[[सुमति-त्सरु|sumati-tsaru]],'' ‘with well-smoothed handle,’ from the root seen in ''matī-kṛ,'' etc. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236;<br> Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 13.</ref> 

त्सारिन्
<u>'''Tsārin'''</u> denotes, in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1236> i. 134, 5.</ref> a ‘hunter’ engaged in the chase of the ''takva'' (an unknown beast), according to Ludwig and Max Müller.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1236> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 448.</ref> But this explanation is quite conjectural.

दंश
<u>'''Daṃśa'''</u> (lit., ‘biter’), ‘gad-fly,’ is mentioned in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 9, 3; 10, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

दंष्ट्र
<u>'''Daṃṣṭra,'''</u> denoting a prominent tooth, ‘tusk,’ or ‘fang’ of an animal, occurs often from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1238> Rv. ii. 13, 4;<br> x. 87, 3;<br> Av. iv. 36, 2;<br> x. 5, 43;<br> xvi. 7, 3, etc.</ref>

दक्ष कात्यायनि आत्रेय
<u>'''Dakṣa [[कात्यायनि|Kātyāyani]] Ātreya'''</u> (‘descendant of Atri’) is mentioned in the Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1; iv. 17, 1) as a pupil of '''[[शङ्ख बाभ्रव्य|Śaṅkha Bābhravya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दक्ष जयन्त लौहित्य
<u>'''Dakṣa [[जयन्त|Jayanta]] Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1) as a pupil of '''[[कृष्णरात लौहित्य|Kṛṣṇarāta Lauhitya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दक्ष पार्वति
<u>'''Dakṣa Pārvati'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]'''’) is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1241> ii. 4, 4, 6.</ref> as having performed a certain rite which his descendants, the Dākṣāyaṇas, still maintained, thus enjoying royal dignity down to the time of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] itself. He appears in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1241> iv. 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 223;<br> 4, 358;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 374 ''et seq.;<br>'' Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 138.</ref> also.

दक्षिणतस्-कपर्द
<u>'''Dakṣiṇatas-kaparda'''</u> is an epithet of the '''Vasiṣṭhas''' in the Rigveda (vii. 33, 1) referring to their mode of ‘wearing the hair in a braid on the right side.’ See '''[[कपर्द|Kaparda]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

दक्षिणा
<u>'''Dakṣiṇā'''</u> appears repeatedly in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1243> A whole hymn, Rv. x. 107, is devoted to its praise. ''Cf.'' i. 168, 7;<br> vi. 27, 8;<br> viii. 24, 29;<br> 39, 5;<br> x. 62, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1243> Av. iv. 11, 4;<br> v. 7, 11;<br> xi. 7, 9;<br> 8, 22;<br> xiii. 1, 52;<br> xviii. 4, 8, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 3, 1;<br> 8, 1, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 19, 23;<br> xix. 30;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 3 ''et seq.;<br>'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9, 3, 1 ''et seq.'' The verses (''[[गाथा|gāthā]] [[नाराशंसी|nārāśaṃsī]],'' either as a single expression or as two separate terms) used to win these Dakṣiṇās were notoriously false. See [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 2, 6. 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], i. 7;<br> xi. 2.</ref> as the designation of the gift presented to priests at the sacrifice, apparently because a cow--a prolific (''[[दक्षिणा|dakṣiṇā]]'') one--was the usual ‘fee’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1243> The transition of meaning is similar in the use of the English word ‘fee’;<br> ‘cattle,’ ‘money,’ ‘payment for service’ (see Murray's English Dictionary, ''s.v.'' ‘fee’). ''Cf.'' also '''[[गो-दान|Go-dāna]],''' n. 4.</ref> on such an occasion.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1243> ''Cf.'' the rule that when nothing is specified a cow is the [[दक्षिणा|Dakṣiṇā]], Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 2, 13;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 1, 2.</ref> The later [[दान|Dāna]]-stutis, or ‘Praises of Gifts,’ in the Rigveda immensely exaggerate these donations, and the exaggeration grows in the Brāhmaṇas. It is important to notice that these enumerations of gifts in the main include nothing but articles of personal property, such as kine, horses, buffaloes, or camels (''uṣṭra''), ornaments, and so forth, but not land.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1243> So, ''e.g.,'' Rv. i. 126, 1-4;<br> v. 30, 12-15;<br> viii. 1, 32. 33;<br> 3, 21 ''et seq.;<br>'' 4, 19-21;<br> 5, 37-39;<br> 6, 46-48;<br> 55;<br> 56;<br> vii. 18, 21-24, and the full list in Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 273-277. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 49 ''et seq.'' Clothes (''[[वासस्|vāsas]]'') and gold are mentioned as a [[दक्षिणा|Dakṣiṇā]] in Av. ix. 5, 14. The four Dakṣiṇās, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 4, 7, are gold, a cow, clothes, and a horse. This is practically exhaustive if the trappings of the horse and ornaments are included.</ref> Reference is, however, made in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_1243> xiii. 7, 1, 13, with which compare xiii. 6, 2, 18, where the Brahmin's land is excluded;<br> and see xiii. 7, 1, 15, where the gift of land is disapproved.</ref> to land as a [[दक्षिणा|Dakṣiṇā]], but with disapproval, probably because the land came to be regarded as inalienable without the consent of the clansmen.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1243> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 1, 1, 4. ''Cf.'' above, pp. 100, n. 19, 246;<br> below, pp. 351, 352.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 169171;<br> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 104, 105;<br> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 96-98;<br> Bloomfield, ''Religion of the Veda,'' 69-74;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 76 ''et seq.,'' 100, 121.</ref>

दक्षिणा-पथ
<u>'''Dakṣiṇā-patha'''</u> (lit., ‘the road to the south’), ‘the south country,’ is found, probably as a designation of the Deccan, as early as the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1244> i. 1, 2, 13. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 394, n., and [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 13.</ref> coupled with  Surāṣṭra. A similar expression is ''[[दक्षिणा|dakṣiṇā]] padā,'' ‘with southward foot,’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1244> x. 61, 8.</ref> referring to the place where the exile (''[[परा-वृज्|parā-vṛj]]'') goes on being expelled. This no doubt simply means ‘the south’ beyond the limits of the recognized Āryan world, which even as late as the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1244> ii. 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 185;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 408;<br> Rhys Davids, Buddhist India, 30;<br> Keith ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 28, n. 1;<br> ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 200.</ref> appears as bounded by the Vindhyas on the south.

दक्षिणा-प्रष्टि
<u>'''Dakṣiṇā-praṣṭi'''</u> denotes ‘the side horse on the right.’ It appears from two passages of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1245> v. 1, 4, 9;<br> ix. 4, 2, 11 (this passage appears to speak of three horses only, but ''of.'' v. 4, 3, 17). ''Cf.'' also [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 13, 12.</ref> that there were at times four horses yoked to the chariot, the right and the left yoke horse (''[[दक्षिणा-युग्य|dakṣiṇā-yugya]], savyā-yugya'') in the middle, flanked by one on each side, the two latter of course not being fastened to the yoke at all, but presumably by traces alongside of the yoke horses. See '''[[रथ|Ratha]].'''

दक्षिणायन
<u>'''Dakṣiṇāyana.'''</u> See '''[[सूर्य|Sūrya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दक्षिणा-युग्य
<u>'''Dakṣiṇā-yugya,'''</u> ‘the yoke horse on the right,’ is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 1, 4, 6; 4, 3, 8; ix. 4, 2, 11). See '''[[रथ|Ratha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दण्ड
<u>'''Daṇḍa,'''</u> ‘staff.’ (''a'') This word is often mentioned in the ordinary sense; for example, when used for driving cattle<ref name=fx1_ve1_1248> Rv. vii. 33, 6.</ref> (''go-ajanāsaḥ''), or as a weapon.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1248> Av. v. 5, 4. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 35;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 4, 6, etc.</ref> A staff was given to a man on consecration for driving away demons, according to the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1248> iii. 2, 1, 32.</ref> The staff also played a part in the initiation (''upanayana'') of a youth on attaining manhood.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1248> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 19;<br> 22;<br> Sāṅkhāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 1, 6, 11, etc.</ref> In a modified sense the word is used to denote the handle of a ladle or similar implement.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1248> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4, 1, 36. Of a musical instrument, Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, viii. 9;<br> Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 3, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> <br><br>(''b'') The ‘staff’ as the symbol of temporal power, implying punishment, is applied by the king (''rāja-preṣito daṇḍaḥ'').<ref name=fx1b_ve1_1248/> The king, in modern phraseology, was the source of criminal law; and he clearly retained this branch of law in his own hands even in later times.<ref name=fx2b_ve1_1248/> The punishment of the non-guilty (''a-daṇḍya'') is given as one of the characteristics of the nonBrahminical '''Vrātyas''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3b_ve1_1248/> See also '''[[धर्म|Dharma]].'''

दण्ड औपर
<u>'''Daṇḍa Aupara'''</u> (‘descendant of Upara’) is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vi. 2, 9, 4) and the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iii. 8, 7) as having performed a certain rite.<br>==Foot Notes==

दण्डन
<u>'''Daṇḍana'''</u> occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1250> xii. 2, 54. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 682.</ref> among other names of ‘reed’ or ‘cane.’

दत्त तापस
<u>'''Datta Tāpasa'''</u> was [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest at the snake festival described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1251> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

दधि
<u>'''Dadhi,'''</u> ‘sour milk,’ is repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1252> viii. 2, 9;<br> ix. 87, 1, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1252> Av. iii. 12, 7;<br> iv. 34, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 3, 4, etc.;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 5, 12, etc.</ref> The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1252> i. 8, 1, 7. ''Cf.'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 348.</ref> mentions in order '''Ghrta''' (‘clarified butter’), [[दधि|Dadhi]], '''[[मस्तु|Mastu]],''' which Eggeling<ref name=fx4_ve1_1252> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 218.</ref> renders ‘whey,’ and '''[[आमिक्षा|Āmikṣā]],''' ‘curds.’ [[दधि|Dadhi]] often has the meaning of ‘curds’ also. It was used for mixing with '''Soma.'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1252> ''[[दध्य्आशिर्|Dadhyāśir]],'' ‘mixed with sour milk,’ is an epithet of Soma in Rv. i. 5, 5;<br> 137, 2;<br> v. 51, 7;<br> vii. 32, 4. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 219 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 227.</ref>

दध्यञ्च् आथर्वण
<u>'''Dadhyañc Ātharvaṇa'''</u> is a purely mythical sage. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1253> i. 80, 16;<br> 84, 13, 14;<br> 116, 12;<br> 117, 22;<br> 119, 9, etc. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 141, 142;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 176.</ref> he is clearly a divinity of some kind, but in the later  Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve1_1253> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 4, 4;<br> 6, 6, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xix. 4.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx3_ve1_1253> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 18;<br> vi. 4, 2, 3;<br> xiv. 1, 1, 18. 20. 25;<br> 4, 13;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28, etc.</ref> he is metamorphosed into a teacher. In the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmana<ref name=fx4_ve1_1253> xii. 8, 6. So also Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 21.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xxxv;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 23, 116, 118, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> he is by oversight called an [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]].

दध्य्-आशिर्
<u>'''Dadhy-āśir.'''</u> See '''[[दधि|Dadhi]]''' and '''Soma.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दन्त्
<u>'''Dant, Danta,'''</u> ‘tooth,’ is frequently mentioned from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1255> Rv. vii. 55, 2;<br> x. 68, 6;<br> Av. v. 23, 3;<br> 29, 4;<br> vi. 56, 3, etc. The more usual form is Danta, Rv. iv. 6, 8;<br> vi. 75, 11;<br> Av. iv. 3, 6, etc.</ref> Cleansing (''dhāv'') the teeth was an ordinary act, especially in preparation for a sacrifice, and accompanied bathing, shaving of the hair and beard (''[[केश|keśa]]-[[श्मश्रु|śmaśru]]''), and the cutting of the nails.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1255> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 2 (not exactly paralleled in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 2 ''et seq.'').</ref> A hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1255> vi. 140.</ref> celebrates the appearance of the first two teeth of a child, though its exact interpretation is doubtful.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1255> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 321;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 224;<br> Grill, ''Hundert Lieder,''^2 176;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 540, 541;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 71;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 386.</ref> In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1255> vii. 14;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 18.</ref> there is a reference to a child's first teeth falling out. The word seems in the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_1255> iv. 6, 8;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 99;<br> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 341, 342.</ref> once to denote an elephant's tusk. Whether dentistry was practised is doubtful. The occurrence in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx7_ve1_1255> ii. 1, 5.</ref> of '''[[हिरण्य-दन्त्|Hiraṇya-dant]],''' ‘gold-toothed,’ as the name of a man, is perhaps significant, especially as it is certain that the stopping of teeth with gold was known at Rome as early as the legislation of the Twelve Tables.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1255> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 206. See Wordsworth, ''Fragments and Specimens of Early Latin,'' 537.</ref>

दभीति
<u>'''Dabhīti'''</u> appears several times in the Rigveda as a hero or sage. Indra overcomes on his behalf '''[[चुमुरि|Cumuri]]''' and '''[[धुनि|Dhuni]];'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1256> x. 113, 9;<br> ii. 15, 9;<br> vii. 19, 4.</ref>  he pressed Soma for Indra,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1256> vi. 20, 13.</ref> who rewarded him.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1256> vi. 26, 6.</ref> For him 30,000 '''Dāsas''' were sent to sleep,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1256> iv. 30, 21.</ref> and for him the '''Dasyus''' were bound without cords.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1256> ii. 13, 9.</ref> [[दभीति|Dabhīti]] also appears, with '''[[तुर्वीति|Turvīti]],''' as a protégé of the Aśvins.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1256> i. 112, 23.</ref> There seems no reason to deny that he was a real person.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1256> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 155, 157, 158.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 162.</ref>

दम
<u>'''Dama,'''</u> ‘house,’ is a word that occurs several times in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1257> i. 1, 8;<br> 61, 9;<br> 75, 5;<br> 143, 4;<br> ii. 1, 2, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 24.</ref> It denotes, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1257> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' But this seems very doubtful in view of the apparent connexion of  and , ‘build,’ in Greek.</ref> the place in which a man wields uncontrolled power (from the root ''dam,'' ‘control’).

दम्-पति
<u>'''Dam-pati'''</u> denotes ‘the master of the house’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1258> For the form, ''cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 37, n. 9. Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2. 307 ''et seq.,'' argues in favour of the spelling ''daṃpati'' (adopted by Geldner in his ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], Glossar''). ''Cf. patir dan.'' Rv. i. 149, 2;<br> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 176, 177.</ref> in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1258> i. 127, 8;<br> ii. 39, 2;<br> v. 22, 4;<br> viii. 69. 16;<br> 84, 7.</ref> but is more often used in the dual to designate ‘the master and the mistress,’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1258> Rv. v. 3, 2;<br> viii. 31, 5;<br> x. 10, 5;<br> 68, 2;<br> 85, 32;<br> 95, 12, etc.;<br> Av. vi. 123, 3;<br> xii. 3, 14;<br> xiv. 2, 9, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 418, 420.</ref> an expression that may legitimately be deemed to show the high status of women at the time of the Rigveda. See '''[[स्त्री|Strī]].'''

दर्भ
<u>'''Darbha'''</u> is the name of a grass in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1259> i. 191, 3 (with '''[[शर|Śara]]''' and '''Kuśara,''' varieties of grass).</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1259> Av. vi. 43, 2;<br> viii. 7, 20;<br> x. 4, 13;<br> xi. 6, 15;<br> xix. 28, 1. etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 1, 4, etc.</ref> In the Atharvaveda it is used for the calming of anger (''manyuśamana''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_1259> Av. vi. 43.</ref> and as an amulet for protection against the scattering of one's hair or the striking of one's breast.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1259> xix. 32, 2. ''Cf.'' xix. 30.</ref> It is also said to be ‘rich in roots’ (''bhūri-[[मूल|mūla]]''),<ref name=fx5_ve1_1259> Av. vi. 43, 2.</ref> to possess a thousand leaves (''sahasra-[[पर्ण|parṇa]]'') and a hundred stalks (''śata-kāṇḍa'').<ref name=fx6_ve1_1259> Av. xix. 32, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70.</ref> 

दर्वि
<u>'''Darvi,'''</u> or '''Darvī,''' properly denotes a ‘ladle,’ in which sense it is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1260> v. 6, 9;<br> x. 105, 10.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1260> Av. iii. 10, 7;<br> iv. 14, 7;<br> ix. 6, 17, etc.</ref> But the word also means a serpent's ‘hood’ in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1260> x. 1, 13. See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 577. Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 153.</ref> though Zimmer regards it as the name of a serpent.<br><br>^4 ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95, where he takes '''[[करिक्रत|Karikrata]]''' also as the name of a snake.

दर्विदा
<u>'''Darvidā,'''</u> the ‘woodpecker,’ is mentioned as a victim at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1261> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 13, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 15, Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93. The St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' suggests ‘woodpiercer’ (''[[दारु|dāru]]-vidha'') as the literal sense. On the etymology, ''cf.'' F. W. Thomas's article. ‘The D.Suffix,’ p. 121, in ''Transactions of the Cambridge Philological Society,'' 5, part ii.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[दार्व्आघात|Dārvāghāta]].'''

दर्श
<u>'''Darśa'''</u> (‘appearance’) denotes the new moon day,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1262> Av. vii. 81, 3, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 14;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 2, 1.</ref> usually in opposition to the day of full moon (''[[पूर्ण-मास|pūrṇa-māsa]]'').<ref name=fx2_ve1_1262> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 4, 1, etc.</ref> Most frequently the word occurs in the compound<ref name=fx3_ve1_1262> ''Ibid.,'' i. 6, 7, 1;<br> 9, 3;<br> ii. 5, 6, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 2, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 5, 11, etc.</ref> ''[[दर्श|darśa]]-pūrṇamāsau,'' ‘new and full moon,’ the days of special ritual importance.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1262> Hillebrandt, ''Das altindische Neuund Vollmondsopfer,'' Jena, 1880;<br> ''Rituallitteratur,'' 111-114;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 439.</ref> The order of the first two words here is worthy of note, for it distinctly suggests, though it does not conclusively prove, that the month was reckoned from new moon to new moon, not from full moon to full moon. See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

दश-ग्व
<u>'''Daśa-gva'''</u> appears in one hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1263> viii. 12, 2</ref> as the name of a person who was assisted by Indra. The other references in that work,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1263> They are mentioned with the Navagvas in i. 62, 4;<br> iii. 39, 5;<br> iv. 51, 4;<br> v. 29, 12;<br> x. 62, 6, and alone in ii. 34, 12. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 144 (C).</ref> however, clearly show the mythical character of the Daśagvas, and of any individual among them. 

दशतयी
<u>'''Daśatayī'''</u> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1264> vii. 8. 20;<br> xi. 16;<br> xii. 40.</ref> frequently denotes the text of the Rigveda as divided into ten Maṇḍalas.

दश-द्यु
<u>'''Daśa-dyu'''</u> appears twice in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1265> i. 33, 14;<br> vi. 26, 4. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 328.</ref> as the name of a hero, but nothing can be made out regarding him or his relation to '''[[वेतसु|Vetasu]],''' who is mentioned in one passage along with him.

दशन्
<u>'''Daśan,'''</u> ‘ten,’ forms the basis of the numerical system of the Vedic Indians, as it does of the Āryan people generally. But it is characteristic of India<ref name=fx1_ve1_1266> Thibaut, ''Astronomie, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 70.</ref> that there should be found at a very early period long series of names for very high numerals, whereas the Āryan knowledge did not go beyond 1,000. In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1266> xvii. 2 ''et seq. Cf.'' xxii. 34;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 1, 2, 16.</ref> the list is 1; 10; 100; 1,000; 10,000 (''ayuta''); 100,000 (''niyuta''); 1,000,000 (''prayuta''); 10,000,000 (''[[अर्बुद|arbuda]]''); 100,000,000 (''nyarbuda''); 1,000,000,000 (''[[सम्उद्र|samudra]]''); 10,000,000,000 (''madhya''); 100,000,000,000 (''anta''); 1,000,000,000,000 (''parārdha''). In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1266> xxxix. 6. In xvii. 10 the number ''badva'' disappears, and the list corresponds with that of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, except for the fact that ''niyuta'' and ''prayuta'' change places.</ref> the list is the same, but ''niyuta'' and ''prayuta'' exchange places, and after ''nyarbuda'' a new figure (''badva'') intervenes, thus increasing ''[[सम्उद्र|samudra]]'' to 10,000,000,000, and so on. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā has in two places<ref name=fx4_ve1_1266> iv. 4, 11, 4;<br> vii. 2, 20, 1.</ref> exactly the same list as the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā. The Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx5_ve1_1266> ii. 8, 14.</ref> has the list ''ayuta, prayuta,'' then ''ayuta'' again, ''[[अर्बुद|arbuda]], nyarbuda, [[सम्उद्र|samudra]], madhya, anta, parārdha.'' The [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_1266> xvii. 14, 2.</ref> has the Vājasaneyi list up to ''nyarbuda'' inclusive, then follow ''nikharvaka, badva, akṣita,'' and apparently ''go'' = 1,000,000,000,000. The Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_1266> i. 10, 28, 29. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 3, 2;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 30, n. 2;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka'' 293, 294.</ref> list  replaces ''nikharvaka'' by ''nikharva, badva'' by ''padma,'' and ends with ''akṣitir vyomāntaḥ.'' The [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_1266> xv. 11, 7.</ref> continues the series after ''nyarbuda'' with ''nikharvāda, [[सम्उद्र|samudra]], salila, antya, ananta'' (= 10 billions).<br><br>But beyond ''ayuta''<ref name=fx9_ve1_1266> ''Cf.'' Rv. iii. 6, 15;<br> viii. 1, 5;<br> 2, 41, 21, 18;<br> 34, 15;<br> 46, 22;<br> Av. viii. 2, 21;<br> 8, 7;<br> x. 8, 24;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xix. 13, 6;<br> xxi. 18, 3, etc. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 348, considers that it has not any definite sense in the Rigveda;<br> this cannot be either proved or disproved. The Rv. has the phrase ''śatā sahasrāṇi'' several times (iv. 32, 18;<br> viii. 32, 18, etc.) = 100,000;<br> and ''ayuta'' may easily have been already specialized, though it may also have retained a vague sense.</ref> none of these numbers has any vitality. ''Badva,'' indeed, occurs in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx10_ve1_1266> vii. 21. 23.</ref> but it cannot there have any precise numerical sense;<ref name=fx11_ve1_1266> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 96.</ref> and later on the names of these high numerals are very much confused.<br><br>An arithmetical progression of some interest is found in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx12_ve1_1266> xviii. 3. ''Cf.'' Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 10, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 9, 1-6.</ref> where occurs a list of sacrificial gifts in which each successive figure doubles the amount of the preceding one. It begins with ''[[द्वादश|dvādaśa]]-mānaṃ hiraṇyam,'' ‘gold to the value of 12’ (the unit being uncertain, but probably the '''[[कृष्णल|Kṛṣṇala]]'''),<ref name=fx13_ve1_1266> ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 9, 1;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 102, 103.</ref> followed by ‘to the value of 24, 48, 96, 192, 384, 768, 1,536, 3072,’ then ''dve aṣṭāviṃśati-śata-māne,'' which must mean 2×128×24 (the last unit being not a single ''[[मान|māna]],'' but a number of 24 ''mānas'') = 6,144, then 12,288, 24,576, 49,152, 98,304, 196,608, 393, 216. With these large numbers may be compared the minute theoretical subdivision of time found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx14_ve1_1266> xii. 3, 2, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' also [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 1, 1, where a series of names of the divisions of the ''[[मुहूर्त|muhūrta]]'' is given, apparently as alternatives, not as successive stages (''idānīm, tadānīm, etarhi, kṣipram, ajiram, āśuḥ (? [[आशु|āśu]]), nimeṣaḥ, phaṇaḥ, dravan, atidravan, tvaran, tvaramāṇaḥ, āśuḥ, āśīyān, javaḥ''). See Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 92-94.</ref> where a day is divided into 15 ''muhūrtas''--1 ''[[मुहूर्त|muhūrta]]'' = 15 ''kṣipras,'' 1 ''kṣipra'' = 15 ''etarhis,'' 1 ''etarhi'' = 15 ''idānis,'' 1 ''idāni'' = 15 ''prāṇas.'' The [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx15_ve1_1266> xiv. 75 ''et seq. Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Araṇyaka, vii. 20.</ref> has a decimal division of the day into 15 ''muhūrtas''-1 ''[[मुहूर्त|muhūrta]]'' = 10 ''nimeṣas,'' 1 ''nimeṣa'' = 10 ''dhvaṃsis.''<br><br>Few fractions are mentioned in Vedic literature. ''Ardha, [[पाद|pāda]], [[शफ|śapha]],'' and ''[[कला|kalā]]'' denote (1/2), (1/4), (1/8), (1/16) respectively, but only  the first two are common. ''Tṛtīya'' denotes the third part.<ref name=fx16_ve1_1266> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 4;<br> v. 2, 6, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 6, 1;<br> 7, 1, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 4, 4, etc.</ref> In the Rigveda<ref name=fx17_ve1_1266> vi. 69, 8 = Av. vii. 44, 1 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 11, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 15;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 1, 13.</ref> Indra and Viṣṇu are said to have divided 1,000 by 3, though how they did so is uncertain. ''Tri-pād'' denotes ‘three-fourths.’<ref name=fx18_ve1_1266> Rv. x. 90, 4.</ref><br><br>There is no clear evidence that the Indians of the Vedic period had any knowledge of numerical figures, though it is perfectly possible.<ref name=fx19_ve1_1266> If ''[[अष्ट-कर्णी|aṣṭa-karṇī]]'' means in Rv. x. 62, 7, having the figure 8 marked on the ears' of cattle, then the mention of numerical signs would be certain. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 234, 235, 348. But this is doubtful. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 309, n. 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 308;<br> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 90-103;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 349;<br> Kaegi, ''Rigveda,'' n. 65;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 275 ''et seq.''</ref>

दश-पुरुषं-राज्य
<u>'''Daśa-puruṣaṃ-rājya,'''</u> occurring in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1267> xii. 9, 3, 1. 3.</ref> doubtless<ref name=fx2_ve1_1267> ''Cf.'' Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 14, 18. So ''tri-[[पुरुष|puruṣa]],'' ‘three generations,’ [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 7. The St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and Eggeling ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 269, have the correct rendering.</ref> means ‘sovereignty inherited through ten ancestors,’ a striking case of hereditary rule. Weber<ref name=fx3_ve1_1267> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 209. But see 10, 75, n. 1.</ref> once rendered the word as the ‘kingdom<ref name=fx4_ve1_1267> This would be ''[[साम्राज्य|sāmrājya]],'' which is always spelt with ''m,'' not ''ṃ;<br> cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 75, 3.</ref> of Daśapuru,’ comparing the Daśapura of Kālidāsa's Meghadūta<ref name=fx5_ve1_1267> i. 48.</ref> and the Daśārṇa of the ‘middle country.’

दश-मास्य
<u>'''Daśa-māsya,'''</u> ‘ten months old,’ describes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1268> v. 78, 7-8.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1268> Av. i. 11, 6;<br> iii. 23, 2. There are several references in Vedic literature to birth in the tenth month, as Rv. x. 184, 3, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 366;<br> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 313, n. 1.</ref> the embryo immediately before birth. See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

दशमी
<u>'''Daśamī'''</u> denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1269> iii. 4, 7.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1269> xxii. 14.</ref> the period of life between 90 and 100 years  which the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1269> i. 158, 6.</ref> calls the ''daśama yuga,'' ‘the tenth stage of life.’ Longevity seems not to have been rare among the Vedic Indians, for the desire to live a ‘hundred autumns’ (''śaradaḥ śatam'') is constantly expressed.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1269> Rv. i. 89, 9;<br> x. 18, 10, and ''passim.''
