See Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 384;<br> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 62, 63.</ref> '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]]''' is said to have lived 100 years,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1269> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 17.</ref> and '''[[महिदास ऐतरेय|Mahidāsa Aitareya]]''' is credited with 116.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1269> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 16, 7;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 11;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 17.</ref> Onesikritos<ref name=fx7_ve1_1269> In Strabo, p. 701.</ref> reported that they sometimes lived 130 years, a statement with which corresponds the wish expressed in the Jātaka<ref name=fx8_ve1_1269> Ed. Fausbo7ll, ii. 16.</ref> for a life of 120 years. Probably the number was always rather imaginary than real, but the comparative brevity of modern life in India<ref name=fx9_ve1_1269> ''Indian Empire,'' 1, 513 ''et seq.''</ref> may be accounted for by the cumulative effect of fever, which is hardly known to the Rigveda. See '''[[तक्मन्|Takman]].'''

दश-वृक्ष
<u>'''Daśa-vṛkṣa'''</u> is the name of a tree, according to Roth,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1270> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1270> ii. 9, 1.</ref> But Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve1_1270> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 50.</ref> treats the word as a mere adjective meaning ‘of ten trees.’

दश-व्रज
<u>'''Daśa-vraja'''</u> is the name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda (viii. 8, 20; 49, 1; 50, 9).<br>==Foot Notes==

दश-शिप्र
<u>'''Daśa-śipra'''</u> is the name of a sacrificer mentioned in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1272> viii. 52, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref>

दशा
<u>'''Daśā'''</u> denotes the ‘fringe’ or ‘border’ of a garment (''vāsaḥ'') in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1273> iii. 3, 2, 9, and often in the Sūtras.</ref> The word also occurs in the compound ''[[दशा|daśā]]-[[पवित्र|pavitra]],''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1273> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 32;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 2, 11. ''Cf.'' iv. 1, 1. 28.</ref> which means ‘a filtering cloth with a fringe.’ 

दशोणि
<u>'''Daśoṇi'''</u> appears in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1274> vi. 20, 4, 8.</ref> apparently as a favourite of Indra and as opposed to the '''Paṇis,''' who fell in hundreds for his benefit. The view of Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1274> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 156;<br> 5, 107.</ref> that he is here the priest of the Paṇis is very improbable. Elsewhere his name is simply mentioned.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1274> x. 96, 12, where, however, the word may be merely an epithet of Soma.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 92, n. 1;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 328.</ref> See also '''[[दशोण्य|Daśoṇya]].'''

दशोण्य
<u>'''Daśoṇya'''</u> is the name of a sacrificer mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1275> viii. 52, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> along with '''[[दशशिप्र|Daśaśipra]]''' and others. Whether he is identical with '''[[दशोणि|Daśoṇi]]''' cannot be decided.

दशोनसि
<u>'''Daśonasi'''</u> is the name of a kind of snake in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1276> x. 4, 17. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 577.</ref> The reading of the Paippalāda recension is Naśonaśī.

दस्यवे वृक
<u>'''Dasyave vṛka,'''</u> ‘wolf to the '''[[दस्यु|Dasyu]],'''’ is the name of a man mentioned four times in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1277> viii. 51, 2;<br> 55, 1;<br> 56, 1. 2.</ref> In one hymn<ref name=fx2_ve1_1277> viii. 51.</ref> he is called a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], but in two others<ref name=fx3_ve1_1277> viii. 55. 56.</ref> he is clearly a prince victorious over the Dasyus, and a generous patron of the singer. It is hardly necessary to assume different persons,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1277> Especially as the name occurs only in the small collection of [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] hymns forming the [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] group in the eighth Maṇḍala.</ref> for the term [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] is not altogether inconsistent with royalty. He was son of '''[[पूतक्रतु|Pūtakratu]]'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1277> viii. 56, 2. ''[[पौतक्रत|Pautakrata]]. Cf.'' viii. 68, 17.</ref> and '''[[पूतक्रता|Pūtakratā]],'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1277> viii. 56, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139, 164;<br> 5, 552.</ref> his wife.

दस्यवे सह
<u>'''Dasyave saha'''</u> is, according to Roth,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1278> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the name of a man or a clan in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1278> i. 36, 18.</ref> But he admits that the words may  be an epithet of Agni. This is the interpretation given to them by Oldenberg.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1278> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 33.</ref>

दस्यु
<u>'''Dasyu,'''</u> a word of somewhat doubtful origin, is in many passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1279> i. 34, 7;<br> 100, 18;<br> ii. 13, 9, etc. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 157, 158.</ref> clearly applied to superhuman enemies. On the other hand, there are several passages in which human foes, probably the aborigines, are thus designated. This may be regarded as certain in those passages where the [[दस्यु|Dasyu]] is opposed to the Āryan, who defeats him with the aid of the gods.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1279> Rv. i. 51, 8;<br> 103, 3;<br> 117, 21;<br> ii. 11, 18, 19;<br> iii. 34, 9;<br> vi. 18, 3;<br> vii. 5, 6;<br> x. 49, 3. Probably also in v. 70, 3;<br> x. 83, 6, people are meant.</ref> The great difference between the Dasyus and the Āryans was their religion: the former are styled ‘not sacrificing,’ ‘devoid of rites,’ ‘addicted to strange vows,’ ‘godhating,’ and so forth.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1279> The [[दस्यु|Dasyu]] is called ''a-karman,'' ‘riteless,’ x. 22, 8;<br> ''a-devayu,'' ‘indifferent to the gods,’ viii. 70, 11;<br> ''a-[[ब्रह्मन्|brahman]],'' ‘without devotion,’ iv. 16, 9;<br> ''a-yajvan,'' ‘not sacrificing,’ viii. 70, 11;<br> ''a-yajyu, id.,'' vii. 6, 3;<br> ''a-[[व्रत|vrata]],'' ‘lawless,’ i. 51, 8;<br> 175, 3;<br> vi. 14, 3;<br> ix. 41, 2;<br> ''anyavrata,'' ‘following strange ordinances,’ viii. 70, 11;<br> ''deva-pīyu,'' ‘reviling the gods,’ Av. xii. 1, 37. It is impossible in all cases to be certain that people are meant.</ref> As compared with the '''[[दास|Dāsa]],''' they are less distinctively a people: no clans (''viśaḥ'') of the Dasyus are mentioned, and while Indra's ''[[दस्यु|dasyu]]-hatya,'' ‘slaughter of the Dasyus,’ is often spoken of, there is no corresponding use of ''[[दास|dāsa]]-hatya.'' That the Dasyus were real people is, however, shown by the epithet ''[[अनास्|anās]]'' applied to them in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1279> Rv. v. 29, 10.</ref> The sense of this word is not absolutely certain: the Pada text and Sāyaṇa both take it to mean ‘without face’ (''an-ās''),<ref name=fx6_ve1_1279> This sense allows of two interpretations: ‘misfeatured,’ which seems that of Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and Grassmann, ''Wo7rterbuch;<br>'' or ‘speechless’ (that is, unable to speak the language of the Āryans), which is that of Bollensen, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 41, 496.</ref> but the other rendering, ‘noseles’ (''a-nās''), is quite possible,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1279> This view is supported by Megasthenes' report as to natives who were: see Strabo, p. 711;<br> Pliny, ''Nat. Hist.,'' vii. 2, 18, cited by Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 430. See also Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 2, 109;<br> 5, 95;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 277;<br> Knauer, Kuhn's ''Zeitschrift,'' 29, 52;<br> Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 2, 293 (accent).</ref>(**  4 Rv. i. 51, 5, 6; 103, 4; x. 95, 7; 99, 7; 105, 11. ''Cf. [[दस्यु|dasyu]]-han.'' ‘Dasyuslaying,’ i. 100, 12; vi. 45, 24; viii. 76, 11; 77, 3; x. 47, 4 (all of Indra); vi. 16, 15; viii. 39, 8 (of Agni), etc.  and would accord well with the flat-nosed aborigines of the Dravidian<ref name=fx8_ve1_1279> The suggestion in the ''Indian Empire,'' 1, 390, that the modern Brahui type is the true Dravidian, while the modern Dravidian is the result of fusion with Muṇḍā-speaking tribes, would render this theory improbable. But it seems more probable that the Brahuis in speech preserve the tradition of Dravidian settlements in North India.</ref> type, whose language still persists among the Brahuis, who are found in the north-west. This interpretation would receive some support from Vṛtra's being called ‘broken-nosed’ if this were a correct explanation of the obscure word ''rujānās.''<ref name=fx9_ve1_1279> See Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 415 (who takes ''rujānāḥ'' of Rv. i. 32, 8, as = ''rujāna-nāḥ'');<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 31, 32 (who suggests as possible the analysis of the word as ''rujā-anāḥ''). But ''cf.'' Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 361, who suggests the emendation ''rujānaḥ'' as nominative singular of the simple participle ‘broken’;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 59, n. 1.</ref><br><br>The other epithet of the Dasyus is ''[[मृध्र-वाच्|mṛdhra-vāc]],'' which occurs with ''[[अनास्|anās]],''<ref name=fx10_ve1_1279> Rv. v. 29, 10.</ref> and which has been rendered<ref name=fx11_ve1_1279> ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, 393 ''et seq.''</ref> ‘of stammering, or unintelligible speech.’ This version is by no means certain, and since the epithet is elsewhere<ref name=fx12_ve1_1279> The expression is used of the Āryan Pūrus in vii. 18, 13;<br> of the Paṇis in vii. 6, 3;<br> and of hostile persons in i. 174, 2;<br> v. 32, 8;<br> x. 23, 5. Roth, ''Erläuterungen zum [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],'' 97, thinks the sense is ‘of insulting speech,’ and Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 114, 115, strongly supports this view. But Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 89, 90, 114, prefers to see in it ‘speaking an enemy's speech,’ and thinks that the Pūrus were dialectically different from the Bharatas--a view which can be supported from the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 23, 24, where the Asuras say ''he'lavo'' (= ''he'rayo,'' ‘ho, enemies,’ in Sanskrit). See Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 2^2, 114;<br> Davidson, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 37, 23 (the Mahābhāṣya version);<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 31, n. 3. The word could thus apply to the Dasyus also, as the strange speech of the enemy could be either Āryan or aboriginal.</ref> applied to Āryans, its correct meaning is more probably ‘of hostile speech.’<br><br>[[दस्यु|Dasyu]] corresponds with the Iranian ''daṅhu, daqyu,'' which denotes a ‘province.’ Zimmer<ref name=fx13_ve1_1279> ''Op. cit.,'' 110 ''et seq.'' So Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 158.</ref> thinks that the original meaning was ‘enemy,’ whence the Iranians developed the sense of ‘hostile country,’ ‘conquered country,’ ‘province,’ while the Indians, retaining the signification of ‘enemy,’ extended it to include demon foes. Roth<ref name=fx14_ve1_1279> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> considers that the meaning of human enemy is a transfer from the strife of gods  and demons. Lassen<ref name=fx15_ve1_1279> ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 1^2, 633 ''et seq.'' This theory is now generally discredited. ''Cf.'' Justi, ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1866, 1446 ''et seq.;<br>'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 142;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 162 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 156.</ref> attempted to onnect the contrast ''daqyu: [[दस्यु|dasyu]]'' with that of ''daeva: deva,'' and to see in it a result of the religious differences which, according to Haug's theory, had separated the Iranians and the Indians. The word may have originally meant ‘ravaged land’<ref name=fx16_ve1_1279> Both this word and [[दास|Dāsa]] appear to be derived from the root ''das,'' which, according to Whitney, ''Roots,'' means ‘lay waste’;<br> but, according to Roth, ‘suffer want,’ ‘waste away.’</ref> as a result of invasion; hence ‘enemies’ country,' then ‘hostile people,’ who as human foes were more usually called by the cognate name of '''[[दास|Dāsa]].'''<br><br>Individual Dasyus are '''[[चुमुरि|Cumuri]], [[शम्बर|Śambara]], Śuṣṇa,''' etc.<br><br>In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx17_ve1_1279> vii. 18, where the descendants of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] are called ''dasyūnāṃ bhūyiṣṭhāḥ;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],'' xv. 26, 7.</ref> the word has, as later,<ref name=fx18_ve1_1279> Manu, v. 131;<br> x. 32. 45;<br> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 118.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 3, 276 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 101 ''et seq.''</ref> the sense of uncivilized peoples generally.

दाक्षायण
<u>'''Dākṣāyaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of Dakṣa.’ The Dākṣāyaṇas are mentioned in the Atharvaveda and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1280> Av. i. 35, 1, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 51, 52;<br> Kaṭha, cited by von Schroeder, ''Tūbinger Kaṭha-Handschriften,'' 36;<br> [[खिल|Khila]], iv. 7, 7, 8.</ref> as having given gold to '''Śatānīka.''' In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1280> vi. 7, 4, 2: ''[[दाक्षायण|dākṣāyaṇa]]-[[हस्त|hasta]],'' ‘goldenhande.’ Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 283, n. 2, seems unnecessarily doubtful as to this.</ref> the word is actually used to denote ‘gold.’ The Dākṣāyaṇas appear there<ref name=fx3_ve1_1280> ii. 4, 4, 6. ''Cf.'' Artareya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 40.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 224;<br> 4, 358;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 195;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 35;<br> Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 138.</ref> as a race of princes who, because of performing a certain rite, prospered down to the time of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] itself.

दात्यौह
<u>'''Dātyauha,'''</u> a ‘gallinule,’ is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or horse sacrifice, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1281> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 17, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 25. 39. Pāṇini, vii. 3. 1, derives the word from ''ditya-vah. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 91.</ref> The  word is clearly a variant of ''dātyūha,'' which occurs in the epics and law books.

दात्र
<u>'''Dātra'''</u> (‘cutter’), denoting a ‘sickle,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1282> viii. 78, 10;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 1.</ref> Cows ‘with sickle-shaped marks on their ears’ (''[[दात्र|dātra]]-karṇyaḥ'') are referred to in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1282> iv. 2, 9.</ref> Otherwise the expression is only found later, occurring in the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] and epic literature.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1282> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 86.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238.</ref> See also '''Sṛṇi.'''

दात्रेय
<u>'''Dātreya'''</u> is the patronymic of '''Arāḍa [[शौनक|Śaunaka]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1283> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref> Possibly [[दार्तेय|Dārteya]], ‘descendant of [[दृति|Dṛti]],’ should be read,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1283> ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> but the word may have the same derivation as the latter form with metathesis.

दाधीच
<u>'''Dādhīca,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Dadhyanc,'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[च्यवन|Cyavana]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

दान
<u>'''1. Dāna,'''</u> ‘giving,’ ‘gift,’ is a word of frequent occurrence in the Rigveda, especially in the [[दान|Dāna]]-stutis<ref name=fx1_ve1_1285> The term seems first to occur in the Bṛhaddevatā, vi. 45, 92, and in similar works.</ref> (‘Praises of Gifts’) of generous patrons (see '''[[दक्षिणा|Dakṣiṇā]]'''). One of the characteristics of the '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]''' is his right to receive gifts, which it is obligatory on the other castes to present.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1285> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 7, 1;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 47-61.</ref> The gift of a daughter (''kanyāyā dānam'') was a form of marriage<ref name=fx3_ve1_1285> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 4.</ref> (see '''[[विवाह|Vivāha]]'''), because in it the girl was ‘given’ away by her father or brother.

दान
<u>'''2. Dāna'''</u> (‘distribution’)<ref name=fx1_ve1_1286> From ''dā,'' ‘divide.’</ref> seems in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1286> i. 55, 7;<br> 48, 4;<br> 180, 5;<br> viii. 46, 26;<br> 60, 8;<br> 99, 4, etc. ''Cf.,'' however, Pischel ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 100.</ref> to be a designation of the sacrificial feast to which  the god is invited (''cf.'' ). In one passage<ref name=fx3_ve1_1286> Rv. viii. 33, 8;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 5, 157.</ref> Sāyaṇa thinks that it denotes the ''mada-jalāni,'' ‘drops of water falling from the temples of a rutting elephant,’<ref name=fx4_ve1_1286> [[दान|Dāna]] in this sense, so common in the post-Vedic language, is probably derived from ''dā,'' ‘divide,’ meaning originally ‘secretion.’</ref> but this is doubtful. In another passage<ref name=fx5_ve1_1286> ii. 13, 7.</ref> Roth thinks that ‘pasture land’ is meant.

दान
<u>'''3. Dāna'''</u> is in three passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1287> v. 27, 5;<br> vii. 18, 23;<br> viii. 46, 24. But in all these cases ‘gifts’ seems an adequate version, ‘horses’ being understood.</ref> held by Roth to designate a chariot horse.

दामन्
<u>'''Dāman,'''</u> a ‘rope’ or ‘girdle,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1288> Originally ‘bond,’ from ''dā,'' ‘bind.’</ref> is often mentioned in the Rigveda and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1288> Rv. i. 56, 3, etc.;<br> Av. vi. 63, 1;<br> 103, 2;<br> vii. 103, 1. 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 13, 1, etc.</ref> Reference is made to the rope of the sacrificial horse,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1288> Rv. i. 162, 8.</ref> as well as to the practice of tying calves with ropes.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1288> Rv. ii. 28, 7.</ref> The word occurs in the sense of a ‘band’ of horse hair in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_1288> v. 3, 1, 10. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 62, n. 2.</ref>

दाय
<u>'''Dāya'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1289> x. 114, 10.</ref> only in the sense of ‘reward’ of exertion (''śrama''), but later it means ‘inheritance’--that is, a father's property which is to be divided among his sons either during his lifetime or after his death. The passages all negative the idea that the property of the family was legally family property: it is clear that it was the property of the head of the house, usually the father, and that the other members of the family only had moral claims upon it which the father could ignore, though he might be coerced by his sons if they were physically stronger.<br><br>Thus '''Manu''' is said in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1289> iii. 1, 9, 4 ''et seq. Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 191-194;<br> Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 67, 68.</ref> to have divided his property among his sons. He omitted '''[[नाभानेदिष्ठ|Nābhānediṣṭha]],'''  whom he afterwards taught how to appease the Aṅgirases, and to procure cows. This is a significant indication that the property he divided was movable property, rather than land ('''[[उर्वरा|Urvarā]]'''). In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1289> v. 14.</ref> the division is said to have been made during Manu's lifetime by his sons, who left only their aged father to [[नाभानेदिष्ठ|Nābhānediṣṭha]]. According to the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_1289> iii. 156 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 61, 62).</ref> again, four sons divided the inheritance while their old father, Abhipratārin, was still alive. It is, of course, possible to regard [[दाय|Dāya]] as denoting the heritable property of the family, but the developed ''patria potestas'' of the father, which was early very marked, as shown by the legend of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]],''' is inconsistent with the view that the sons were legally owners with their father, unless and until. they actually insisted on a division of the property.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1289> The same question has been raised as to the origin of English or Teutonic property in land generally. Against any idea even of family ownership in a strict sense of the word, see Fustel de Coulanges, ''Recherches sur quelques Problèmes d'Histoire,'' 322 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ashley, in Fustel de Coulanges, ''Origin of Property in Land,'' xvi-xxi;<br> Pollock and Maitland, ''History of English Law,'' 2, 237 ''et seq.'' The older view, which accepted family and communal ownership, represented in different forms by Maine (''Village Communities in the East and West''), Stubbs, Green, and others, is defended in a new form by Vinogradoff, ''Villanage in England.'' See also Keith, ''Journal of the African Society,'' 6, 201 ''et seq.'' Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 93-96, does not accept the communal ownership of land, but, ''ibid.,'' 80, is inclined to believe in the joint ownership of a family. He admits that this is inconsistent with the strict rule of ''patria potestas,'' which still exists in Bengal;<br> Baden Powell, ''Village Communities in India,'' 133 ''et seq.,'' doubts the existence in early India of such a ''patria potestas.'' But the facts seem clearly to show that there was such a power, and that the father owned the property. His sons, as they grew up, came to claim the property, and he might have to divide it;<br> hence the idea naturally developed that every child on birth had a legal share in the property. No doubt also from the first the right to part with land was one which grown-up sons and the rest of the community could object to, once the village had acquired a fixed existence. This would account adequately for the later system. ''Cf.'' also pp. 100, n. 19;<br> 336, n. 7, and '''[[राजन्य|Rājanya]].'''</ref> Probably-there is no evidence of any decisive character--land was not divided at first, but no doubt its disposal began to follow the analogy of cattle and other movable property as soon as the available supply of arable land became limited.<br><br>As for the method of division, it is clear from the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx6_ve1_1289> ii. 5, 2, 7.</ref> that the elder son was usually preferred; perhaps  this was always the case after death. During the father's lifetime another might be preferred, as appears from a passage of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx7_ve1_1289> xvi. 4, 4.</ref> Women were excluded from partition or inheritance, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_1289> iv. 4, 2, 13.</ref> and the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx9_ve1_1289> iii. 4.</ref> They were, no doubt, supported by their brothers; but if they had none they might be reduced to prostitution.<ref name=fx10_ve1_1289> ''Cf.'' '''Ztrī.'''</ref> Detailed rules of inheritance appear in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx11_ve1_1289> Inheritance is also alluded to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 27, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 2, 22;<br> iii. 2, 1, 18. For the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] rules, see Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 80 ''et seq.''</ref><br><br>The heir is called Dayada,<ref name=fx12_ve1_1289> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 3, 9;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 4;<br> metaphorically, Av. v. 18, 6, 14.</ref> ‘receiver (''ā-da'') of inheritance.’

दार
<u>'''Dāra,'''</u> ‘wife,’ is found in the Sūtras (usually as a plural masculine), and once (as a singular) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1290> vi. 4, 12 (where ''dvāreṇa'' is a ''varia lectio;<br>'' see St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''). ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 415, 416, who igneres the Bṛhadāraṇyaka passage.</ref>

दारु
<u>'''Dāru,'''</u> ‘wood,’ is frequently mentioned in the Rigveda and later,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1291> Rv. vi. 3, 4;<br> x. 145, 4, etc.;<br> Av. x. 4, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 8, 3, etc.</ref> denoting amongst other things the pole of a chariot,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1291> Rv. x. 102, 8.</ref> logs as fuel,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1291> Rv. viii. 102, 20.</ref> the wooden parts of a car,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1291> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 6, 2, 14.</ref> possibly wooden stocks,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1291> Av. vi. 121, 2. But this is doubtful. ''Cf.'' '''Tāya''' and '''[[द्रुपद|Drupada]].'''</ref> and so forth.

दार्ढ-जयन्ति
<u>'''Dārḍha-jayanti,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[दृढजयन्त|Dṛḍhajayanta]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[वैपश्चित|Vaipaścita]] [[गुप्त|Gupta]] [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]]''' and of '''[[वैपश्चित|Vaipaścita]] [[दृढजयन्त|Dṛḍhajayanta]] [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

दार्तेय
<u>'''Dārteya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[दृति|Dṛti]].'''’ The Dārteyas are mentioned as authorities on sacrificial matters in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1293> xxxi. 2 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 473).</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1293> xxv. 3, 6.</ref> 

दार्भ्य
<u>'''Dārbhya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[दर्भ|Darbha]],’ is mentioned in a verse of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1294> v. 61, 17.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_1294> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> identifies him with '''[[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]],''' but the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1294> v. 50. 77.</ref> with '''Rathavīti.''' The same patronymic is frequently<ref name=fx4_ve1_1294> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 2, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 12;<br> 6, 5;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4. ''Cf.'' Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 62, n. 2.</ref> connected with '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]],''' and is also applied to '''Rathaprota.'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1294> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3.</ref> See also '''[[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]].'''

दार्व्-आघात
<u>'''Dārv-āghāta,'''</u> the ‘woodpecker,’ is included in the list of sacrificial victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1295> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 15, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 35. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 92.</ref>

दार्व्-आहार
<u>'''Dārv-āhāra,'''</u> a ‘gatherer of wood,’ is included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or ‘human sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1296> Vājasaneyī Saṃhitā, xxx. 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 8, 1.</ref>

दाल्भि
<u>'''Dālbhi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Dalbha,’ is the patronymic of '''Vaka''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (x. 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

दाल्भ्य
<u>'''Dālbhya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Dalbha,’ is a variant of '''[[दार्भ्य|Dārbhya]].''' It is the patronymic of (''a'') '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]];<ref name=fx1_ve1_1298> xiii. 10, 8. ''Cf.'' the [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]], reported by Ṣaḍguruśiṣya (Sarvānukramaṇī, ed. Macdonell, 118). The St. Petersburg Dictionary quotes the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4, for [[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]] (but also for [[दार्भ्य|Dārbhya]], which is the reading of Lindner's edition).</ref> (''b'') '''[[चैकितायन|Caikitāyana]]''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1298> i. 8, 1.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]];<ref name=fx3_ve1_1298> i. 38, 1;<br> 56, 3.</ref> (''c'') '''Vaka''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1298> i. 2, 13;<br> 12, 1, 3.</ref> and the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1298> xxx. 2, where [[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]] is read, not [[दाल्भि|Dālbhi]], as stated in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' The Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvi. 5, has ''Darbhasya.'' [[दाल्भि|Dālbhi]] is found, however, in [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 6.</ref> 

दाव
<u>'''Dāva,'''</u> ‘forest fire,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1299> vii. 45, 2.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1299> xi. 2, 7, 32.</ref> In the latter work such fires are referred to as occurring in spring. According to Sieg,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1299> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 44 ''et seq.''</ref> a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1299> x. 142. Sieg's interpretation of this hymn is not at all probable.</ref> describes a forest fire. Watchers were employed to guard against surprise from such conflagrations (''[[दाव|dāva]]-pa'').<ref name=fx5_ve1_1299> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 11, 1.</ref>

दाव-सु आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Dāva-su Āṅgirasa,'''</u> a seer of Sāmans, or chants, is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1300> xxv. 5, 12, 14. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160.</ref>

दाश
<u>'''Dāśa,'''</u> ‘fisherman,’ is mentioned in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or ‘human sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1301> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1. Weber, ''Indische Streifen'' 1, 81, renders the word by ''Fischerknecht,'' perhaps regarding it as equivalent to ''[[दास|dāsa]],'' ‘servant.’ ''Cf.'' Manu, x. 34;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' [[दाश|Dāśa]], 2. 3.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[धैवर|Dhaivara]].'''

दाशतय
<u>'''Dāśataya,'''</u> ‘belonging to the (Rigveda text) divided into ten (books),’ is an epithet of Adhyāya, ‘section,’ in the [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1302> ii. 11 (''Indische Studien,'' 1, 45)</ref> The feminine form of the word is also found in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1302> viii. 7.</ref> and later<ref name=fx3_ve1_1302> [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]] Prātiśākhya, xvi. 54;<br> xvii. 30;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 2, 16, 22, etc.;<br> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxvi. 13;<br> xxvii. 4, etc.</ref>

दाश-राज्ञ
<u>'''Dāśa-rājña'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1303> vii. 33, 2, 5;<br> 83, 8.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1303> x. 128, 12.</ref> of '''Sudās'''' famous ‘battle with the ten kings.’ It is somewhat difficult to make out exactly who the kings were (see '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]'''), but the number is probably a round one, and cannot be pressed. The actual battle hymn<ref name=fx3_ve1_1303> 8, 18</ref> does not contain  the word, and the passages in which it is found may reasonably be considered late.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1303> ''Cf.'' for the late date of vii. 33, Bergaigne, ''L'histoire de la Saṃhita,'' 38, 72;<br> Oldenberg, ''Prolegomena,'' 198, 200, 265, n. 1;<br> Arnold, ''Vedic Metre,'' 309;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 130, opposes this view, but not convincingly.</ref>

दाशर्म
<u>'''Dāśarma'''</u> appears in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1304> vii. 6. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 472.</ref> as a teacher and a contemporary of '''[[आरुणि|Āruṇi]].'''

दास
<u>'''Dāsa,'''</u> like '''[[दस्यु|Dasyu]],''' sometimes denotes enemies of a demoniac character in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1305> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 157.</ref> but in many passages<ref name=fx2_ve1_1305> ''Cf.'' Rv. v. 34, 6;<br> vi. 22, 10;<br> 33, 3;<br> 50, 6;<br> vii. 83, 1;<br> x. 38, 3;<br> 69, 6;<br> 3, 1;<br> Av. v. 11, 3.</ref> the word refers to human foes of the Āryans. The Dāsas are described as having forts (''puraḥ''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_1305> ii. 20, 8 (called ''āyasīḥ,'' ‘made of iron’);<br> i. 103, 3;<br> iii. 12, 6;<br> iv. 32, 10. They are called ''śāradīḥ,'' ‘autumnal,’ in 1. 131, 4;<br> 174, 2;<br> vi. 20, 10. ''Cf.'' also ''dehyaḥ,'' ‘ramparts,’ in vi. 47, 2.</ref> and their clans (''viśaḥ'') are mentioned.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1305> ii. 11, 4;<br> iv. 28, 4;<br> vi. 25, 2.</ref> It is possible that the forts, which are called ‘autumnal’ (''śaradīḥ''),<ref name=fx5_ve1_1305> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 60.</ref> may be mythical, but it is not essential, for the epithet may allude to their being resorted to in the autumn season. The [[दास|Dāsa]] colour ('''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''')<ref name=fx6_ve1_1305> ii. 12, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 25, 6. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 101, 1;<br> 130, 8;<br> ii. 20, 7;<br> iv. 16, 13;<br> vi. 47, 21;<br> vii. 5, 3. The [[आर्य|Ārya]] colour is mentioned in iii. 34, 9, and the [[दास|Dāsa]] is contrasted with the [[वर्ण|Varṇa]] (of the singers) in i. 104, 2. The ‘white-hued (''śvitnya'') friends’ who, in i. 100, 18, aid in the conquest of the [[दस्यु|Dasyu]] and Siṃyu are doubtless Āryans. In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30, the day and night (''ahorātre'') are paralleled with the Śūdrāryau--that is, probably with the Āryan and [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] (the compound is not to be taken as giving the words in the correct order;<br> ''cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 268). See also Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 140;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 10, 11.</ref> is probably an allusion to the black skin of the aborigines, which is also directly mentioned.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1305> ''kṛṣṇā tvac,'' ‘black skin,’ i. 130, 8;<br> ix. 41, 1.</ref> The aborigines (as Dasyus) are called ''[[अनास्|anās]],'' ‘noseless’(?),<ref name=fx8_ve1_1305> ''Cf.'' '''[[दस्यु|Dasyu]],''' notes 6, 7.</ref> and ''[[मृध्र-वाच्|mṛdhra-vāc]],'' ‘of hostile speech,’<ref name=fx9_ve1_1305> v. 29, 10. दास-वेश
<u>'''Dāsa-veśa,'''</u> occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1306> ii. 13, 8. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 209.</ref> probably designates a [[दास|Dāsa]] named '''[[वेश|Veśa]].''' Sāyaṇa's interpretation of the word as ‘destruction of foes’ can hardly be correct. 

दास्य
<u>'''Dāsya'''</u> occurs once in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 2. 30 Mādhyaṃdina = 23 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]) in the sense of ‘slavery.’<br>==Foot Notes==

दित्य-वाह्
<u>'''Ditya-vāh,'''</u> m.; '''Dityauhī,''' f., ‘a two-year-old bull or cow.’ is mentioned in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmanas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1308> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 3, 1;<br> v. 6, 15, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 10;<br> xviii. 26;<br> xxviii. 25;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 1, etc.</ref>

दिद्यु
<u>'''Didyu, Didyut,'''</u> both<ref name=fx1_ve1_1309> [[दिद्यु|Didyu]]: i. 71, 5, iv. 41, 4;<br> vii. 56, 9;<br> 85, 2, etc.;<br> Av. i. 2, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 20;<br> x. 17, etc. Didyut: Rv. i. 66, 7;<br> v. 86, 3;<br> vii. 25, 1, etc.;<br> certainly divine in ii. 13, 7.</ref> denote in the Rigveda ‘missile,’ ‘arrow,’ whether divine or human.

दिधिषु
<u>'''Didhiṣu'''</u> in the Rigveda denotes a ‘wooer.’ It is applied<ref name=fx1_ve1_1310> x. 18, 18 = Av. xviii. 3, 2 (where ''didhiṣus'' is merely a bad reading) = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vi. 1, 3.</ref> to the relative, probably brother-in-law,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1310> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 2, 18, where are mentioned the brother-in-law (''[[देवृ|devṛ]]''), a representative of the husband (there is nothing to show whether he is identical with the preceding or not), a pupil, or an aged servant (''jarad-[[दास|dāsa]]'').</ref> who takes the place of the husband at the funeral rite, and who, as in the Hebraic levirate, is to beget a child by the brother's wife if there is no son.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1310> ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 40, 2;<br> Kaegi, ''Der Rigveda,'' n. 51.</ref> Hillebrandt<ref name=fx4_ve1_1310> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 40, 708 ''et seq.''</ref> and Lanman<ref name=fx5_ve1_1310> ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 385.</ref> consider that the word originally meant only ‘wooer,’ and applied to the king who, after the chief queen had lain beside the dead victim in the Puruṣamedha or ‘human sacrifice,’ claimed her again; but this view is hardly plausible.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1310> See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 848, 849;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 946.</ref> The term is also applied to the god Pūṣan<ref name=fx7_ve1_1310> vi. 55, 5.</ref> as the wooer of his mother, apparently Sūryā.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1310> ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 21;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 35.<br><br>''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 154.</ref>

दिधिषू-पति
<u>'''Didhiṣū-pati'''</u> occurs in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1311> xxxi. 7, quoted in Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 579.</ref> and Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1311> xlvii. 7, quoted ''ibid.,'' 579, 580.</ref> as well as in the Āpastamba,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1311> ii. 5, 12, 22.</ref> [[गौतम|Gautama]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_1311> xv. 16.</ref> and [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]  [[धर्म|Dharma]] Sūtras,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1311> i. 18;<br> xx. 7 ''et seq.''</ref> in lists of people who have committed sin (''enas''). The traditional rendering<ref name=fx6_ve1_1311> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[दिधिषु|didhiṣu]],'' 3.</ref> is ‘husband of a woman married a second time’; Manu<ref name=fx7_ve1_1311> iii. 173.</ref> seems to apply the term to the brother-in-law who is ‘married’ to his sister-in-law after his brother's death for the purpose of begetting a child, if he displays conjugal affection to her (''anurajyate kāmataḥ'').<ref name=fx8_ve1_1311> ''Cf.'' Leist, ''Altarisches Jus Gentium,'' 106.</ref> This sense would be possible, since '''[[दिधिषु|Didhiṣu]]''' denotes a ‘wooer,’ and a widow could be regarded as a ‘wooer’ when able to control her own choice of a spouse. But another tradition<ref name=fx9_ve1_1311> Laugākṣi, quoted by Kullūka on Manu, iii. 160;<br> Commentary on Āpastamba, ''loc. cit.''</ref> holds that Didhiṣū means the elder sister whose younger sister has married before her. This view is supported by a passage in the [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx10_ve1_1311> xx. 7 ''et seq.''</ref> and by the use of the word ''agredidhiṣū-pati,''<ref name=fx11_ve1_1311> ''Cf. agre-[[दिधिषु|didhiṣu]],'' ‘one who woos (a younger sister) before (her elder sister is married),’ in Āpastamba, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' [[गौतम|Gautama]], xv. 16;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], i. 18;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]], ''loc. cit.;<br> agre-dadhus,'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 9;<br> ''agre-dadhiṣu,'' Kapiṣṭhala, ''loc. cit.;<br> agra-[[दिधिषु|didhiṣu]],'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 11.</ref> which must mean the ‘husband of a younger sister married before the elder.’ In this case also Didhiṣū would mean ‘wooer,’ the elder sister being so called because, if her parents do not arrange a marriage for her, she is, according to Viṣṇu,<ref name=fx12_ve1_1311> Viṣṇu [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 40.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''op. cit.,'' 579-586.</ref> to make her own choice of a husband (''kuryāt svayaṃvaram''). See also '''[[एदिधिषुःपति|Edidhiṣuḥpati]]''' and '''[[दैधिषव्य|Daidhiṣavya]].'''

दिव्
<u>'''Div,'''</u> ‘sky.’ The world as a whole is regarded as divided into the three domains of ‘earth,’ ‘air’ or ‘atmosphere,’ and ‘heaven’ or ‘sky’ (''div''),<ref name=fx1_ve1_1312> Rv. ii. 40;<br> viii. 6, 15;<br> 10, 6;<br> 90, 6, etc.</ref> or alternatively into ‘heaven and earth’ (''dyāvā-[[पृथिवी|pṛthivī]]''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_1312> Rv. i. 143, 2;<br> 159, 1;<br> 160, 1;<br> iv. 14, 2, etc.;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 8, 3, 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 4, 2;<br> viii. 1, 3. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 2, and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 3, it is said that when heavy and constant rain falls people say. ‘Heaven and earth have united.’</ref> which two are then considered as comprising the universe, the atmosphere being included in the sky. Lightning, wind, and rain belong to the atmosphere, solar and  similar phenomena to the sky. In some passages<ref name=fx3_ve1_1312> Av. iv. 14, 3 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 67.</ref> the vault (''[[नाक|nāka]]'') of the sky is added after the usual triad, and before the celestial light (''svar, jyotis'').<br><br>The threefold division of the universe is reflected in a threefold division of the three elements--earth, air, and sky. Thus a highest (''uttama,''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1312> Rv. v. 60, 6.</ref> ''uttara,''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1312> Rv. iv. 26, 6.</ref> ''pārya''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1312> Rv. vi. 40, 5. In Rv. v. 4, 3, it is called ''tṛtīya.''</ref> ), a middle, and a lowest heaven are specified.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1312/> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_1312> xviii. 2, 48.</ref> the three heavens are distinguished as ‘rich in water’ (''udanvatī''), as ''[[पीलुमती|pīlumatī]]'' (of uncertain meaning), and as the ''pradyaus,'' where the Fathers sit. Heaven is frequently called ''vyoman'' as well as ''rocana''<ref name=fx8_ve1_1312> ''Trīṇi'' or ''trī rocanā,'' Rv. i. 102, 8;<br> 149, 4;<br> v. 69, 1, etc.</ref> (properly the ‘luminous space’ of heaven), and the dividing firmament which separates the visible upper world from the highest heaven is called, besides ''[[नाक|nāka]],'' ‘vault,’ ''sānu,'' ‘summit,’ ''viṣṭap,'' ‘surface,’ and ''pṛṣṭha,'' ‘ridge,’ and even ‘ridge of the vault,’<ref name=fx9_ve1_1312> Rv. i. 125, 5. ''Cf.'' iii. 2, 12.</ref> or ‘summit of the vault.’<ref name=fx10_ve1_1312> Rv. viii. 103, 2. ''Cf.'' also ix. 86, 27.</ref><br><br>Similarly three atmospheres (''[[रजस्|rajas]]''), or oftener two, are alluded to,<ref name=fx11_ve1_1312> Rv. iv. 53, 5;<br> v. 69, 1. ''Cf.'' also the references to the ‘highest’ atmosphere, ''uttama,'' ix. 22, 5;<br> ''parama,'' iii. 30, 2;<br> ''tṛtīya,'' ix. 74, 6;<br> x. 45, 3;<br> 123, 8. The ‘lower’ (''[[उपर|upara]]'') or ‘terrestrial’ (''pārthiva'') is contrasted with the ‘heavenly’ (''[[दिव्य|divya]]'') space. See i. 62, 5;<br> iv. 53, 3.</ref> but the division here is merely artificial. In one passage<ref name=fx12_ve1_1312> Rv. i. 164, 6. ''Cf.'' vii. 87, 5.</ref> six ''rajāṃsi,'' ‘regions,’ are referred to, the heavens and the earths no doubt being meant. The usual name for the atmosphere is ''antarikṣa.''<br><br>The three earths are equally artificial, the origin of the triad being probably the use of ''[[पृथिवी|pṛthivī]]'' in the plural<ref name=fx13_ve1_1312> Rv. i. 188, 9. 10;<br> vii. 104, 11.</ref> to denote the three divisions of the universe (just as ''pitarau,'' ‘two fathers,’ denotes ‘father and mother’).<ref name=fx14_ve1_1312> ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Altindische Syntax,'' p. 98;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Grammar,'' 183''c'' (p. 158).</ref> The earth is called ''kṣam, kṣā, gmā,'' or designated by the epithets ''mahī,'' ‘the great,’ ''[[पृथिवी|pṛthivī]]'' or ''urvī,'' ‘the broad,’ ''uttānā,'' ‘the extended,’ and is regularly contrasted as ''idam,'' ‘this world here,’ with the upper sphere.<ref name=fx15_ve1_1312> Rv. i. 22, 17;<br> 154, 1. 3;<br> and regularly in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.</ref>  The shape of the earth is compared with a wheel in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx16_ve1_1312> x. 89, 4. On the other hand, the earth is regarded as ''catur-bhṛṣṭi,'' ‘four-cornered,’ in Rv. x. 58, 3.</ref> and is expressly called ‘circular’ (''pari-maṇḍala'') in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx17_ve1_1312> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 9.</ref> When earth is conjoined with heaven, the two are conceived as great bowls (''camvā'') turned towards each other.<ref name=fx18_ve1_1312> Rv. iii. 55, 20.</ref> In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx19_ve1_1312> iii. 1, 2;<br> Śāṅkhāvana Āraṇyaka, vii. 3.</ref> the two are regarded as halves of an egg. The distance of heaven from the earth is given by the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx20_ve1_1312> x. 8, 18 = xiii. 2, 38;<br> 3, 14.</ref> as a thousand days' journey for the sun-bird, by the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx21_ve1_1312> ii. 17. ''Cf.'' '''[[आश्विन|Āśvina]].'''</ref> as a thousand days' journey for a horse, while the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx22_ve1_1312> xvi. 8, 6;<br> in xxi. 1, 9, with the alternatives of 1,000 days of the journey of a horse, or of the sun, or 1,000 leagues.</ref> whimsically estimates the distance as equivalent to a thousand cows standing one on the top of the other.<br><br>According to Zimmer,<ref name=fx23_ve1_1312> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 357, 358.</ref> the Vedic poets conceived the atmosphere to be above the earth in its upper division only, but below it in its lower stratum. The evidence,<ref name=fx24_ve1_1312> Rv. v. 81, 4;<br> vi. 9, 1;<br> vii. 80, 1.</ref> however, for the latter assumption is quite insufficient.<ref name=fx25_ve1_1312> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 10.</ref> The theory of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx26_ve1_1312> iii. 44, 4. Speyer's interpretation of this passage, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1906, 723-727, is anticipated and supplemented by Macdonell, ''loc. cit.''</ref> is that the sun merely reverses its bright side at night, turning its light on the stars and the moon while it retraverses its course to the east; and it has been shown<ref name=fx25_ve1_1312/> that this is probably the doctrine of the Rigveda also.<ref name=fx27_ve1_1312> i. 115, 5;<br> x. 37, 3.</ref> literature. [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 10, 16;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 31, n. 2. ''Cf.'' दिवोदास अतिथिग्व
<u>'''Divodāsa Atithigva'''</u> is one of the leading princes of the early Vedic age. He was a son of [[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1313> Rv. vi. 61, 1.</ref> and father, or more probably grandfather, of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' the famous king of the '''[[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]]''' family, among the '''Bharatas.''' Probably [[पिजवन|Pijavana]] was the son and [[सुदास्|Sudās]] the grandson. Divodāsa was naturally a '''[[भरत|Bharata]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1313> Rv. vi. 16, 4, 5, 19. For [[सुदास्|Sudās]] as his descendant, see vii. 18, 25, with verse 23, where [[पैजवन|Paijavana]] is an epithet of [[सुदास्|Sudās]].</ref> and, like [[सुदास्|Sudās]], was an opponent of the '''Turvaśas''' and '''Yadus.'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1313> As [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]], Rv. vii. 19, 8;<br> as Divodāsa, ix. 61, 2.</ref> His great enemy was '''[[शम्बर|Śambara]],''' the '''[[दास|Dāsa]],''' who was apparently chief of a mountain people,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1313> Rv. i. 130, 7;<br> ii. 12, 11;<br> vi. 26, 5;<br> vii. 18, 20. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 161.</ref> and whom he repeatedly defeated.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1313> See Rv. i. 112, 14;<br> 116, 18;<br> 119, 4;<br> 130, 7-10;<br> ii. 19, 6;<br> iv. 26, 3;<br> 30, 20;<br> vi. 26, 3. 5;<br> 43, 1;<br> 47, 21. 22;<br> ix. 61, 2.</ref> He was also, it seems, like his father [[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]],<ref name=fx6_ve1_1313> Rv. x. 69, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 176;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologic,'' 1, 96, n. 2.</ref> an energetic supporter of the fire ritual, for Agni is once called by his name in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1313> Daivodāsa, ‘worshipped by Divodāsa’;<br> viii. 103, 2. ''Cf.'' vi. 16, 5. 19;<br> 31, 1. For the defeat by Indra, ''cf.'' Rv. i. 53, 10;<br> ii. 14, 7;<br> vi. 18, 13;<br> viii. 64, 2;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 337, 344.</ref> On the other hand, he was defeated, with '''[[आयु|Āyu]]''' and '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]],''' by Indra's aid. In several passages he seems closely connected with the singer family, the '''Bharadvājas.'''<ref name=fx8_ve1_1313> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 112, 13, 14;<br> 116, 18;<br> vi. 16, 5;<br> 31, 4;<br> 47, 22 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 3, 7;<br> Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 104.</ref><br><br>From one passage,<ref name=fx9_ve1_1313> vi. 61, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> where Divodāsa is said to have fought against the '''Paṇis,''' the '''Pārāvatas,''' and '''[[बृसय|Bṛsaya]],''' Hillebrandt<ref name=fx10_ve1_1313> ''Op. cit.,'' 1, 97 ''et seq.''</ref> has inferred that he was engaged in conflicts with the tribes of Arachosia, and interpreting the name as the ‘heavenly Dāsa’<ref name=fx11_ve1_1313> This is very improbable. See Bergaigne, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 209;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 155;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 175;<br> 51, 272.</ref> conjectures that he was himself a [[दास|Dāsa]]. This conclusion is not probable, for the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' on which the battle in question took place, and which can hardly be the Haraqaiti of Arachosia, would naturally designate the later [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], while the Pārāvatas are mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx12_ve1_1313> ix. 4, 11. See '''[[पारावत|Pārāvata]].'''</ref> as in the east, about the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]].''' Bergaigne's  opinion<ref name=fx13_ve1_1313> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 342 ''et seq.''</ref> that Divodāsa and [[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]] were different people cannot be supported in view of the complete parallelism in the acts of the two persons.<ref name=fx14_ve1_1313> Compare, ''e.g.,'' vii. 19, 8, with ix. 61, 2 (opposed to [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] and Yadu);<br> i. 51, 6;<br> vi. 26, 3, with ii. 19, 6;<br> vi. 31, 4 (defeat of [[शम्बर|Śambara]]);<br> and see Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 3, 268;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 210 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''op. cit.,'' p. 161.</ref> See also '''[[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]].'''<br><br>The people of Divodāsa are referred to in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx15_ve1_1313> i. 130, 10 (one of the series attributed to [[परुच्छेप|Parucchepa]]).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 126;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 406;<br> Ludwig, ''op. cit.,'' 3, 114, 176;<br> Grierson, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 604, 837;<br> Keith, ''ibid.,'' 831 ''et seq.;<br>'' 1138 ''et seq.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' distinguishes two Divodāsas, one being the ancestor or father of [[सुदास्|Sudās]], the other the enemy of [[शम्बर|Śambara]]. Divodāsa is not mentioned in Maṇḍalas, iii, v. viii, x.</ref>

दिवो-दास भैम-सेनि
<u>'''Divo-[[दास|dāsa]] Bhaima-seni'''</u> (‘descendant of Bhīmasena’) is mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1314> vii. 1, 8. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 472.</ref> as a contemporary of '''[[आरुणि|Āruṇi]].'''

दिव्य
<u>'''Divya,'''</u> ‘ordeal,’ is a term not found until the later literature, but several references to the practice of ordeals have been seen in Vedic literature. The fire ordeal seen in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1315> ii. 12.</ref> by Schlagintweit,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1315> ''Die Gottesurtheile der Indier,'' 13 ''et seq.''</ref> Weber,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1315> ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 168.</ref> Ludwig,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1315> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 445.</ref> Zimmer,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1315> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 184.</ref> and others, has been disproved by Grill,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1315> ''Hundert Lieder,''^2 45, 87.</ref> Bloomfield,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1315> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, ccxxi;<br> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 334, 335;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 294.</ref> and Whitney.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1315> Translation of the Atharvaveda. 54.</ref> But such an ordeal appears in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx9_ve1_1315> xiv. 6, 6.</ref> and an ordeal with a glowing axe<ref name=fx10_ve1_1315> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 16.</ref> occurs in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] as applied in an accusation of theft. Geldner<ref name=fx11_ve1_1315> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 150.</ref> suggests that this usage is referred to even in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx12_ve1_1315> iii. 53, 22.</ref> but this is most improbable.<ref name=fx13_ve1_1315> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 254.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx14_ve1_1315> ''Op. cit.,'' 4, 44.</ref> and Griffith<ref name=fx15_ve1_1315> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 210.</ref> discover in another  passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx16_ve1_1315> i. 158, 4 ''et seq.''</ref> references to '''Dīrghatamas'''' having been subjected to the fire and water ordeals, but this view cannot be supported. According to Weber,<ref name=fx17_ve1_1315> ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 21;<br> 2, 363.</ref> the ‘balance’ ordeal is referred to in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx18_ve1_1315> xi. 2, 7, 33.<br><br>''Cf.'' Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 145;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 44, 347, 348;<br> Stenzler, ''ibid.,'' 9, 669 ''et seq.''</ref> but see '''[[तुला|Tulā]].'''

दिव्य श्वन्
<u>'''Divya Śvan,'''</u> the ‘divine dog,’ in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1316> vi. 80, 1.</ref> appears to denote Canis major or Sirius. But Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve1_1316> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 163;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 500, 501.</ref> thinks that the two divine dogs referred to in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1316> i. 6, 9.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1316> i. 1, 2, 4-6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 353;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 341.</ref> are the sun and moon, and that the sun is meant in the Atharvaveda.

दिश्
<u>'''Diś,'''</u> ‘direction,’ is a word very frequently used in the Rigveda and later<ref name=fx1_ve1_1317> Rv. i. 124, 3;<br> 183, 5;<br> iii. 30, 12;<br> Av. iii. 31, 4;<br> xi. 2, 12, etc.</ref> to denote a quarter of the sky. As a general rule, four quarters are mentioned--east, south, west, north.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1317> Rv. vii. 72, 5;<br> x. 36, 14;<br> 42, 11;<br> Av. xv. 2, 1 ''et seq.,'' etc.</ref> But the number of the ‘directions’ is sometimes increased up to ten by the addition to these four of various others. The five points include the zenith (''ūrdhvā'');<ref name=fx3_ve1_1317> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 15;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 8, 9.</ref> the six, the zenith and the nadir (''ūrdhvā'' and ''avācī'');<ref name=fx4_ve1_1317> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 24;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2, 4.</ref> the seven, the zenith, the ground on which one stands (''[[ध्रुवा|dhruvā]]''), and the air (''antarikṣa'') between these two (''vyadhvā'');<ref name=fx5_ve1_1317> Rv. ix. 114, 3;<br> Av. iv. 40, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4, 1, 20;<br> ix. 5, 2, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 7.</ref> the eight include the intermediate quarters (S.E., S.W., N.E., N.W.);<ref name=fx6_ve1_1317> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 15;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 1, 40, etc.</ref> the nine add to these the zenith;<ref name=fx7_ve1_1317> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 28, 2.</ref> the ten, zenith and nadir.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1317> Rv. i. 164, 14;<br> viii. 101, 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 2, 34;<br> viii. 4, 2, 13, etc.</ref> The number  five is sometimes made up by the ground beneath the observer's feet (''[[ध्रुवा|dhruvā]]''),<ref name=fx9_ve1_1317> Av. viii. 9, 15;<br> xiii. 3, 6;<br> xv. 14, 1-5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 32;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4, 3, 10, and ''cf.'' '''[[ध्रुवा|Dhruvā]].'''</ref> and the number six by that point (''[[ध्रुवा|dhruvā]]'') and the zenith (''ūrdhvā'');<ref name=fx10_ve1_1317> Av. iii. 27, 1;<br> iv. 14, 8;<br> xii. 3, 55;<br> xv. 4, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' xviii. 3, 34;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 14, etc. ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 14, 16.</ref> the ‘lofty’ (''bṛhatī'')<ref name=fx11_ve1_1317> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 13, [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 359;<br> Weber, ''Proceedings of the Berlin Academy,'' 1895, 846;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 293. 294;<br> 18, 153;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> sometimes taking the place of the ‘vertical’ (''ūrdhvā'').

दीर्घ-तमस्
<u>'''Dīrgha-tamas'''</u> (‘long darkness’) '''[[मामतेय|Māmateya]]''' (‘son of Mamatā’) '''Aucathya''' (‘son of Ucatha’) is mentioned as a singer in one hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1318> i. 158, 1. 6.</ref> and is referred to in several passages<ref name=fx2_ve1_1318> i. 147, 3;<br> 152, 6;<br> iv. 4, 13. In viii. 9, 10, [[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]] is mentioned with [[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]], but not as a relative.</ref> by his metronymic, [[मामतेय|Māmateya]], alone. He is said, both in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1318/> and in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1318> ii. 17;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaha,'' 14.</ref> to have attained the tenth decade of life. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1318> viii. 23.</ref> he appears as the priest of '''[[भरत|Bharata]].''' The Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx5_ve1_1318> iv. 11-15;<br> 21-25, with Macdonell's notes.</ref> contains a preposterous legend made up of fragments of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1318> From i. 140-164, which hymns are traditionally attributed to [[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]]. But see Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischn Gesellschaft,'' 42, 221.</ref> according to which [[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]] was born blind, but recovered his sight; in old age he was thrown into a river by his servants, one of whom, '''[[त्रैतन|Traitana]],''' attacked him, but killed himself instead. Carried down by the stream, he was cast up in the [[अङ्ग|Aṅga]] country, where he married Uśij, a slave girl, and begot '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]].''' The two legends here combined are not even consistent, for the second ignores Dīrghatamas' recovery of sight. To attach any historical importance to them, as does Pargiter,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1318> ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society.'' 1910, 44.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rig veda, 3, 164, 165;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 226, 232, 247, 268, 279.</ref> would seem to be unwise. 

दीर्घ-नीथ
<u>'''Dīrgha-nītha'''</u> appears to be the proper name of a sacrificer in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1319> viii. 50, 10. ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' Ludwig understands the word as an adjective, meaning ‘of long duration.’</ref>

दीर्घ-श्रवस्
<u>'''Dīrgha-śravas'''</u> (‘far-famed’) is the name of a royal seer who, according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1320> xv. 3, 25.</ref> having been banished from his kingdom, and suffering from actual hunger, ‘saw’ a certain Sāman (chant), and thus obtained food. In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1320> i. 112, 11.</ref> an [[औशिज|Auśija]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1320> A metronymic, ‘descendant of Uśij,’ according to Sāyaṇa;<br> but an adjective, meaning ‘desirous,’ according to Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> a merchant (''[[वणिज्|vaṇij]]''), is mentioned as ''[[दीर्घ-श्रवस्|dīrgha-śravas]],'' which may be a proper name, as Sāyaṇa holds, or an adjective, as it is understood by Roth.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1320> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 114.</ref>

दीर्घाप्सस्
<u>'''Dīrghāpsas,'''</u> used in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1321> i. 122, 15.</ref> as an epithet of a chariot, means, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1321> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 312.</ref> ‘having a long front part.’

दीर्घायुत्व
<u>'''Dīrghāyutva,'''</u> ‘longevity,’ is a constant object of the prayers of the Vedic Indians,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1322> Rv. x. 62, 2;<br> Av. i. 22, 2, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9, 1, 13, etc. So the adjective ''dīrghāyus,'' Rv. iv. 15, 9. 10;<br> x. 85, 39;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 100, etc. The Brāhmaṇas regularly express the reward for ritual actions by the phrase ''sarvam āyur eti,'' ‘he lives all his days.’ The ideal of life is 100 years. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 193;<br> ''Festgruss an Roth,'' 137;<br> Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 384.</ref> and length of life is never deprecated in the Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas, while the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1322> ii. 13;<br> 28;<br> 29;<br> vii. 32, and many other hymns. See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 49 ''et seq.;<br> Atharvaveda,'' 63-65.</ref> is full of spells intended to prolong existence (''āyuṣyāṇi'').

दीर्घारण्य
<u>'''Dīrghāraṇya,'''</u> ‘wide tract of forest,’ in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1323> iii. 44;<br> vi. 23.</ref> and Śatapatha<ref name=fx2_ve1_1323> xiii. 3, 7, 10.</ref> Brāhmanas refers to the extensive jungles which  must clearly then have covered Northern India. In one of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] passages<ref name=fx3_ve1_1323> iii. 44.</ref> it is said that in the east the villages are close together and frequent, while in the west there are forests.

दीव्
<u>'''Dīv'''</u> (fem.) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1324> x. 27, 17.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1324> vii. 50, 9;<br> 109, 5.</ref> denotes the ‘game of dice.’ See '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''

दुघा
<u>'''Dughā,'''</u> ‘yielding milk,’ denotes ‘cow’ in a few passages in the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1325> Rv. viii. 50, 3;<br> x. 67, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxviii. 16, 39, etc.</ref>

दुन्दुभि
<u>'''Dundubhi,'''</u> apparently an onomatopoetic word, means ‘drum,’ as used in both war and peace. It is often mentioned from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1326> i. 28, 5;<br> vi. 47, 29. 31.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1326> Av. v. 20, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' 21, 7;<br> 31, 7;<br> vi. 38, 4;<br> xii. 1, 41;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 5, 6;<br> ''dundubhya,'' ‘connected with the drum,’ Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 35.</ref> A special sort of drum was the ‘earth drum,’ made by digging a hole in the ground and covering it with a hide. This was employed in the Mahāvrata, a rite performed at the winter solstice, for the purpose of driving away influences hostile to the return of the sun.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1326> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 477);<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 14, 11;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 1, 5, with Keith's notes;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 148, n. 2;<br> Friedlaender, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 29, 45.</ref> A ‘drumbeater’ is included in the list of sacrificial victims at the Puruṣamedha or ‘human sacrifice.’<ref name=fx4_ve1_1326> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 13, 1 (not in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā). ''Cf.'' Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 289;<br> and for the epic drum in battle, Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 318.</ref>

दुर्
<u>'''Dur'''</u> is used several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1327> i. 68, 10;<br> 113, 4;<br> 121, 4;<br> 188, 5;<br> ii. 2, 7, etc.</ref> to denote ‘door,’ both literally and metaphorically. 

दुरोण
<u>'''Duroṇa'''</u> is used in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1328> iii. 1, 18;<br> 25, 5;<br> iv. 13, 1;<br> v. 76, 4, etc.</ref> and sometimes later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1328> Av. vii. 17, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiii. 71, etc.</ref> to denote ‘home,’ both literally and metaphorically. See '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''

दुर्-ग
<u>'''Dur-ga,'''</u> ‘hard to approach,’ occurs in the Rigveda as a neuter substantive only, sometimes in the sense of ‘fort,’ ‘stronghold.’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1329> v. 34, 7;<br> vii. 25, 2.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Pur.'''

दुर्-गह
<u>'''Dur-gaha'''</u> is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1330> viii. 65, 12.</ref> where his grandsons are lauded for their generosity, though Sāyaṇa renders the word adjectivally.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1330> ‘Plunged in distress’ (''duḥkhaṃ gāhamāna'').</ref> In another passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1330> iv. 42, 8.</ref> however, Sāyaṇa sees in the epithet [[दौर्गह|Daurgaha]] a description of '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]]''' as Durgaha's son, who was either captured by the enemy or slain, and whose wife, '''[[पुरुकुत्सानी|Purukutsānī]],''' then obtained a son, '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],''' to restore the line; he also quotes a story, not found in the Bṛhaddevatā,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1330> As Roth. St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' says it is.</ref> to support this interpretation. On the other hand, the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1330> xiii. 5, 4, 5. According to the Naighaṇṭuka (i. 14), [[दौर्गह|Daurgaha]] is a synonym of ‘horse.’</ref> seems to take [[दौर्गह|Daurgaha]] as meaning a horse. Sieg<ref name=fx6_ve1_1330> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 96-102.</ref> thinks that the same sense should be adopted in the Rigveda passage, which he interprets as referring to the sacrifice of a horse, [[दौर्गह|Daurgaha]], by King [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] to gain a son; he also sees in Dadhikrāvan, with Pischel<ref name=fx7_ve1_1330> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 124.</ref> and Ludwig,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1330> Translation of the Rigveda, 4, 79. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 71.</ref> a real horse, the charger of [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]]. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa's interpretation of [[दौर्गह|Daurgaha]] is, however, doubtful, and cannot be regarded as receiving support from the case of Dadhikrāvan, who was probably a divinity, and not a real horse at all.<ref name=fx9_ve1_1330> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 148, 149.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, ''op. cit.,'' 3, 163, 174;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 301, 302.</ref> 

दुर्-णामन्
<u>'''Dur-ṇāman,'''</u> ‘of evil name,’ is the designation in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1331> x. 162, 2.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1331> ii. 25, 2;<br> viii. 6, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' xvi. 6, 7;<br> xix. 36, 1 ''et seq.'' So also the feminine Durṇāmnī, iv. 17, 5;<br> xix. 36, 6.</ref> of a demon causing disease, or the disease itself. The [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1331> vi. 12.</ref> explains the words as meaning a ‘worm,’ an interpretation which accords with the widespread belief in disease-causing worms.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1331> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 61;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 314 ''et seq.,'' 351.</ref> Later Durnāman denotes ‘hæmorrhoids.’<ref name=fx5_ve1_1331> Suśruta, 1, 177, 10, etc.</ref>

दुर्-मुख
<u>'''Dur-mukha,'''</u> ‘ugly-faced,’ is the name, in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1332> viii. 23. The reading may be ''a-rājā,'' ‘not a king,’ but this is not necessary.</ref> of a [[पाञ्चाल|Pāñcāla]], that is, [[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] king, who conquered the world, and whose priest was '''[[बृहद्उक्थ|Bṛhaduktha]].'''

दुर्य
<u>'''Durya,'''</u> ‘belonging to the door or house,’ appears in several passages of the Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1333> Masculine plural, Rv. i. 91, 19;<br> x. 40, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 3, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 11;<br> feminine plural, Rv. iv. 1, 9. 18;<br> 2, 12;<br> vii. 1, 11.</ref> as a plural substantive denoting the ‘door-posts,’ or more generally ‘dwelling.’

दुर्योण
<u>'''Duryoṇa'''</u> occurs a few times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1334> i. 174, 7;<br> v. 29, 10;<br> 32, 8.</ref> in the sense of ‘house.’

दुर्-वराह
<u>'''Dur-varāha'''</u> probably denotes a ‘wild boar.’ It is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1335> xii. 4, 1, 4.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1335> i. 51, 4 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 23, 332).</ref>

दुला
<u>'''Dulā.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] ([[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]]).'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दुश्-चर्मन्
<u>'''Duś-carman,'''</u> ‘afflicted with a skin disease,’ occurs in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1337> ii. 1, 4, 3;<br> 5, 1, 7.</ref> and [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1337> i. 7, 8, 3.</ref> The disease meant is probably leprosy, the usual name of which is '''[[किलास|Kilāsa]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1337> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 3, 17;<br> xxiii. 16, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka v. 4, 12.</ref> 

दुः-शासु
<u>'''Duḥ-śāsu'''</u> is possibly a proper name in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1338> x. 33, 1.</ref> and would then denote an enemy of '''Kuruśravaṇa.''' Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1338> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165.</ref> thinks that he was a '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]]''' or Persian, but this is most improbable, and the word may simply be an adjective meaning ‘malignant.’

दुः-शीम
<u>'''Duḥ-śīma'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1339> x. 93, 14.</ref> as a generous donor, his patronymic perhaps being '''[[तान्व|Tānva]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1339> x. 93, 15.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166.</ref>

दुष्-टरीतु
<u>'''Duṣ-ṭarītu,'''</u> ‘hard to defeat,’ is the name of a king of the '''Sṛñjayas,''' who was deposed from a principality that had existed for ten generations, but was re-instated by '''[[चाक्र|Cākra]] [[स्थपति|Sthapati]]''' in spite of the resistance of '''[[बल्हिक प्रातिपीय|Balhika Prātipīya]],''' according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1340> xii. 9, 3, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 205-207.</ref>

दुः-षन्त
<u>'''Duḥ-ṣanta.'''</u> See '''[[दौःषन्ति|Dauḥṣanti]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दुहितृ
<u>'''Duhitṛ'''</u> is the regular designation of ‘daughter’ from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1342> Rv. viii. 101, 15;<br> x. 17, 1;<br> 40, 5;<br> 61, 5, 7;<br> Av. ii. 14, 2;<br> vi. 100, 3;<br> vii. 12, 1;<br> x. 1, 25;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 4, 1;<br> 8, 1, 8, etc.</ref> The word appears to be derived from ''duh,'' ‘milk,’ in the sense of one who nourishes a child, rather than as the ‘milker’ of the primitive family or the suckling.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1342> Delbrück, ''Dic indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 454.</ref> See also '''[[स्त्री|Strī]], Pati, [[पितृ|Pitṛ]], [[भ्रातृ|Bhrātṛ]].'''

दूत
<u>'''Dūta,'''</u> ‘messenger’ or envoy,' is found several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1343> iii. 3, 2;<br> vi. 8, 4;<br> vii. 3, 3;<br> x. 14, 12.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1343> Av. viii. 8, 10, etc.;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 1, 6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, etc. The feminine form Dūtī is found in Rv. x. 108, 2, 3, in the story of Saramā's mission to the Paṇis. Dūtya, ‘mission,’ occurs in Rv. 1, 12, 4;<br> 161, 1;<br> iv. 7, 8;<br> 8, 4, etc.</ref> used metaphorically. The '''[[सूत|Sūta]]''' seems to have performed the duties later assigned to the [[दूत|Dūta]]. 

दूर्वा
<u>'''Dūrvā,'''</u> a species of grass (''Panicum dactylon''), is mentioned frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1344> x. 16, 13;<br> 134, 5;<br> 142, 8.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1344> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 9, 2;<br> v. 2, 8, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 20;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5. 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 10, 5;<br> vii. 4, 2, 10, 12, etc.</ref> It grew in damp ground.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1344> Rv. x. 16, 13;<br> 142, 8.</ref> A simile occurring in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1344> x. 134, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70.</ref> seems to indicate that the ears lay horizontal with the stem. ''Cf.'' '''[[पाकदूर्वा|Pākadūrvā]].'''

दूर्श
<u>'''Dūrśa,'''</u> denoting some kind of garment, is mentioned twice in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1345> iv. 7, 6;<br> viii. 6, 11.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_1345> ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 29.</ref> thinks that it was worn by the aborigines.

दूषीका
<u>'''Dūṣīkā,'''</u> ‘rheum of the eyes,’ is mentioned as a disease in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1346> xvi. 6, 8.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1346> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 3, 10.</ref>

दृढ-च्युत् आगस्ति
<u>'''Dṛḍha-cyut Āgasti'''</u> (‘descendant of Agastya’) is mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1347> iii. 233 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 38). He is given in the Anukramaṇī (where the form of the patronymic is [[आगस्त्य|Āgastya]]) as the author of Rv. ix. 25. ''Cf. Indische Studien,'' 3, 219.</ref> as having been Udgātṛ priest at the Sattra (‘sacrificial session’) of the Vibhindukīyas.

दृढ-जयन्त
<u>'''Dṛḍha-jayanta.'''</u> See '''Vipaścit''' and '''[[वैपश्चित|Vaipaścita]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दृति
<u>'''1. Dṛti,'''</u> a ‘leather bag to hold fluids,’ is frequently mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1349> i. 191, 10;<br> iv. 51, 1, 3;<br> v. 83, 7;<br> vi. 48, 18;<br> 103, 2;<br> viii. 5, 19;<br> 9, 18.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1349> Av. vii. 18, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 19, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxvi. 18, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 3, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 10, 2, etc.</ref> In one passage<ref name=fx3_ve1_1349> Rv. vii. 89, 2. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 20, 30.</ref> it is called ''dhmāta,'' ‘inflated,’ the man afflicted with dropsy being compared with such a bag. Milk ('''[[क्षीर|Kṣīra]]''') and intoxicating liquor ('''[[सुरा|Surā]]''') are mentioned as kept in bags.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1349> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 11, 26;<br> xvi. 13, 13.</ref> 

दृति ऐन्द्रोत
<u>'''2. Dṛti Aindrota'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[इन्द्रोत|Indrota]]'''’) is mentioned in the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1350> xiv. 1, 12. 15.</ref> as a contemporary of '''[[अभिप्रतारिन् काक्षसेनि|Abhipratārin Kākṣaseni]]''' and as a pupil of '''[[इन्द्रोत|Indrota]] [[दैवाप|Daivāpa]]''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Jaīminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1350> iii. 40, 2.</ref> Possibly the same [[दृति|Dṛti]] is meant in the compound [[दृति|Dṛti]]-Vātavantau, which is found in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1350> xxv. 3, 6. So a Sattra of a year's duration is later called ''[[दृति|Dṛti]]-vātavator ayana,'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 4, 16;<br> 6, 25;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 23, 1;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 10, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 52, 53.</ref> The former is here said to have continued, after the Mahāvrata was over, the sacrificial session in which both had been engaged, with the result that his descendants prospered more than the Vātavatas.

दृप्त-बालाकि गार्ग्य
<u>'''Dṛpta-[[बालाकि|bālāki]] Gārgya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[गर्ग|Garga]]'''’) is the name of a teacher who is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 1, 1) as a contemporary of '''[[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]]''' of '''[[काशि|Kāśi]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दृभीक
<u>'''Dṛbhīka'''</u> is the name of a man<ref name=fx1_ve1_1352> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 152, 207, who compares the Derbikes;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 162.</ref> or a demon,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1352> Grassmann, ''Wo7rterbuch, s.v.;<br>'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 85.</ref> who, according to the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1352> ii. 14, 3.</ref> was slain by Indra.

दृशान भार्गव
<u>'''Dṛśāna Bhārgava'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[भृगु|Bhṛgu]]'''’) is mentioned as a seer in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1353> xvi. 8. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 459.</ref>

दृषद्
<u>'''Dṛṣad'''</u> appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1354> vii. 104, 22;<br> viii. 72, 4.</ref> and Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1354> ii. 31, 1;<br> v. 23, 8.</ref> to denote not a millstone,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1354> Roth. St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 269.</ref> but merely a stone used to pound grain, which was placed on another stone as a support. When used later<ref name=fx4_ve1_1354> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 8, 3;<br> 9, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 22;<br> ii. 6, 1, 9, etc.</ref>  in connexion with '''[[उपला|Upalā]],''' the lower and the upper millstone, or mortar and pestle may be meant; but this is not certain. Eggeling<ref name=fx5_ve1_1354> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 11 (''[[दृषद्|dṛṣad]]-upale,'' which are here distinguished from ‘mortar and pestle,’ ''[[उलूखल|ulūkhala]]-musale'').<br><br>''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 108, 109.</ref> renders them as the large and small millstones. See also '''[[उपर|Upara]]''' and '''[[उपला|Upalā]].'''

दृषद्वती
<u>'''Dṛṣadvatī,'''</u> ‘stony,’ is the name of a river which flows into the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' after running for a time parallel to it. It is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1355> iii. 23, 4.</ref> along with the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] and the '''[[आपया|Āpayā]],''' as the scene of action of the [[भरत|Bharata]] princes. In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1355> xxv. 10, 13.</ref> and later<ref name=fx3_ve1_1355> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 6, 6, 38;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 19, 4.</ref> the [[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]] and the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] are the scene of special sacrifices. In Manu<ref name=fx4_ve1_1355> ii. 17.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 18;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 34;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 67, 102;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 87.</ref> these two rivers form the western boundary of the Middle Country.

दृष्ट
<u>'''Dṛṣṭa.'''</u> See '''[[अदृष्ट|Adṛṣṭa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

देवक मान्यमान
<u>'''Devaka Mānyamāna'''</u> (‘descendant of Manyamāna’) appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1357> vii. 18, 20 (''devakaṃ cin mānyamānam'').</ref> as an opponent of the Tṛtsus, and as connected with [[शम्बर|Śambara]]. Possibly, however, as Grassmann suggests, the words should be understood as denoting [[शम्बर|Śambara]], ‘who deemed himself a god,’ ''devaka'' being used contemptuously.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1357> ''Cf.'' Rv. ii. 11. 2 (''amartyaṃ cid dāsam manyamānam'').<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173.</ref>

देवकी-पुत्र
<u>'''Devakī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of Devakī,’ is the metronymic of '''[[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]]''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1358> iii. 17, 6.</ref> According to the Epic,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1358> Mahābhārata, i. 4480;<br> v. 80, etc.</ref> a Devaka was father of Devakī, Kṛṣṇa's mother; the St. Petersburg Dictionary suggests that he was the ‘king of the Gandharvas’, also referred to in the Epic.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1358> ''Ibid.,'' i. 2704.</ref> 

देव-जन-विद्या
<u>'''Deva-jana-vidyā,'''</u> ‘knowledge of divine beings,’ is one of the sciences enumerated in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1359> xiii. 4, 3, 10. ''Cf.'' x. 5, 2, 20.</ref> and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1359> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref>

देव-तरस् श्यावसायन काश्यप
<u>'''Deva-taras [[श्यावसायन|Śyāvasāyana]] Kāśyapa'''</u> (‘descendant of Kaśyapa’) is mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1360> iii. 40, 2.</ref> as a pupil of '''Rsyasṛṅga.''' In the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1360> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref> as Śāvasāyana, he is a pupil of his father [[शवस्|Śavas]], who again was a pupil of Kāśyapa.

देवत्या
