<u>'''Devatyā'''</u> occurs in the text of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1361> i. 22, 3.</ref> where it must, if the reading is correct, denote some animal.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1361> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> But the reading should no doubt be ''[[रोहिणी|rohiṇī]]-devatyās,'' ‘having the red one as deity.’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1361> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 23.</ref>

देवन
<u>'''Devana'''</u> is mentioned once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1362> x. 43, 5.</ref> in connexion with dicing. The word must designate the place on which the dice are thrown (elsewhere called '''[[अधिदेवन|Adhidevana]]'''), and it is so explained by [[दुर्ग|Durga]] in his commentary on the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1362> v. 22.<br><br>''Cf.'' Lüders, ''Das Würfelspiel im alten Indien,'' 14.</ref>

देव-नक्षत्र
<u>'''Deva-nakṣatra,'''</u> ‘asterism of the gods,’ is the name applied in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1363> i. 5, 2, 6, 7. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 309, 310.</ref> to the first fourteen lunar mansions, which are said to be south, while the others are called [[यमनक्षत्र|Yamanakṣatra]], ‘asterisms of Yama,’ and are said to be north. See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''

देव-भाग श्रौतर्ष
<u>'''Deva-bhāga Śrautarṣa'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1364> ii. 4, 4, 5. This passage is misquoted by Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 81, 3. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 9. n.;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 152.</ref> as the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or ‘domestic priest,’ of both the  '''Sṛñjayas''' and the '''Kurus.''' In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1364> vii. x.</ref> he is said to have taught '''[[गिरिज बाभ्रव्य|Girija Bābhravya]]''' the science of the dissection of the sacrificial animal (''pasor vibhakti''). In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1364> iii. 10, 9, 11.</ref> he is an authority on the Sāvitra Agni.

देव-मलिम्लुच्
<u>'''Deva-malimluc,'''</u> ‘robber of the gods,’ is the epithet of Rahasya,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1365> Or Rahasyu.</ref> who is said in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1365> xiv. 4, 7. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 51, 52.</ref> to have slain the pious '''Vaikhānasas''' at '''[[मुनिमरण|Munimaraṇa]]''' (‘saint's death’). He was apparently an Asura, but may have been a real person.

देव-मुनि
<u>'''Deva-muni,'''</u> ‘divine saint,’ is the epithet of '''Tura''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 14, 5). The name is given in the Anukramaṇī to the author of a hymn of the Rigveda (x. 146).<br>==Foot Notes==

देव-राजन्
<u>'''Deva-rājan'''</u> apparently denotes a king of Brahminical descent in the phrase ‘Sāmans of Devarājans’ in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xviii. 10, 5). ''Cf.'' '''[[राजन्यर्षि|Rājanyarṣi]]''' and '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

देव-रात
<u>'''Deva-rāta'''</u> (‘god-given’) '''[[वैश्वामित्र|Vaiśvāmitra]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]'''’) is the name given to [[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]] after his adoption by [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1368> vii. 17. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 27.</ref>

देवल
<u>'''Devala'''</u> is mentioned as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxii. 11). See also '''[[दैवल|Daivala]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

देववन्त्
<u>'''Devavant'''</u> is mentioned in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1370> vii. 18, 22. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 171;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 138.</ref> as the ancestor of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' apparently his grandfather; or if '''[[पिजवन|Pijavana]]''' be accepted as Sudās' father, and '''Divodāsa''' as his grandfather, then his great-great-grandfather, and father of '''[[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]].''' The succession in the latter case would then be [[देववन्त्|Devavant]], [[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]], Divodāsa, [[पिजवन|Pijavana]], [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. 

देव-वात
<u>'''Deva-vāta'''</u> (‘desired of the gods’) is the name of a '''[[भरत|Bharata]]''' prince in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1371> iii. 23, 2. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 409;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218.</ref> where he is mentioned as sacrificing on the '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]], [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],''' and '''[[आपया|Āpayā]].'''

देव-विद्या
<u>'''Deva-vidyā,'''</u> ‘knowledge of the gods,’ is one of the sciences enumerated in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vii. 1, 2, 4; 2, 1; 7, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

देव-श्रवस्
<u>'''Deva-śravas'''</u> is the name of a '''[[भरत|Bharata]]''' prince who with '''[[देववात|Devavāta]]''' appears as a sacrificer on the '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]], [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],''' and '''[[आपया|Āpayā]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1373> iii. 23, 2. 3. In the Anukramaṇī he is called a son of Yama, and has a hymn, x. 17, ascribed to him.</ref>

देवातिथि काण्व
<u>'''Devātithi Kāṇva'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]]'''’) is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1374> ix. 2, 19.</ref> as the seer of a Sāman (chant) by which he turned pumpkins into cows for himself and his son when they were starving in the desert, whither they had been driven by rivals. He is also the reputed author of a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1374> viii. 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 61.</ref>

देवापि आर्ष्टिषेण
<u>'''Devāpi Ārṣṭiṣeṇa'''</u> (‘descendant of Ṛṣṭiṣeṇa’) is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1375> x. 98.</ref> and in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1375> ii. 10.</ref> According to the latter source there were two brothers, '''Devāpi''' and '''Śantanu,''' princes of the Kurus. The elder was Devāpi, but Śantanu got himself anointed king, whereupon no rain fell for twelve years. The drought being attributed by the Brahmins to his having superseded his elder brother, Śantanu offered the kingdom to Devāpi. The latter, however, refused, but acting as [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or domestic priest, for his brother, obtained rain. The Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1375> vii. 148 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> tells much the same tale, but adds that the reason for Devāpi's exclusion from the throne was the fact that he suffered from a skin disease. The Epic and later legends further  develop the story, presenting two somewhat discrepant accounts. According to the one version,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1375> Mahābhārata, v. 5054 ''et seq.'' (= 149, 15 ''et seq.''), where Śāntanu is (as also in the Agni, cclxxvii. 34, the Brahma, xiii. 114, 118, and the Viṣṇu Purāṇas) the form of the name;<br> [[मत्स्य|Matsya]] [[पुराण|Purāṇa]], l, 39 ''et seq.,'' in which, as well as in the Bhāgavata, ix. 22, 12, 13, and the Vāyu [[पुराण|Purāṇa]], xcix. 234, 237, the form is Śantanu.</ref> the ground of Devāpi's being passed over was leprosy, while in the other his devoting himself to asceticism in his youth was the cause of his brother's taking his place. The Epic,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1375> Mahābhārata, i. 3751 (= 94, 62);<br> ix. 2285 (= 40, 1);<br> Vāyu [[पुराण|Purāṇa]], ii. 37, 230, etc.</ref> moreover, treats him as a son of Pratīpa, and names as his brothers Bāhlīka<ref name=fx6_ve1_1375> Mahābhārata, cited in n. 4;<br> Harivaṃśa, 1819.</ref> and Āṛṣṭiṣeṇa,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1375> ''Ibid.,'' cited in n. 5.</ref> who is a new figure developed from the patronymic of Devāpi Possibly Sieg<ref name=fx8_ve1_1375> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 136.</ref> is right in holding that two stories, those of Devāpi, Pratīpa's son, and of Devāpi, Ṛṣṭiṣeṇa's son, have been confused; but in any case it is impossible to extract history from them.<ref name=fx9_ve1_1375> As does Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 52, 53.</ref><br><br>The Rigvedic hymn certainly appears to represent Devāpi as sacrificing for Śantanu, who seems to be called '''[[औलान|Aulāna]].'''<ref name=fx10_ve1_1375> Rv. x. 98, 11.</ref> But there is no trace in it of the brotherhood of the two men, nor is there anything to show that Devāpi was not a Brahmin, but a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]. Sieg,<ref name=fx11_ve1_1375> ''Op. cit.,'' 129-142.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 272 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 203;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 192 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Bṛhaddevatā,'' 1, xxix;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 131, 132.</ref> who interprets the hymn by the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], thinks that he was a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], but on this occasion was enabled by the favour of [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]] to officiate as priest, and that the hymn shows clear recognition of the unusual character of his action; but this view seems very improbable.

देवृ
<u>'''Devṛ'''</u> is a rare word denoting the wife's ‘brother-in-law’ (that is, the husband's brother). He is included with the sisters of the husband among those over whom the wife of the husband--his elder brother--rules;<ref name=fx1_ve1_1376> Rv. x. 85, 46. ''Cf.'' '''Pati.'''</ref> at the same time the wife is to be devoted to him,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1376> Rv. x. 85, 44.</ref> and friendly to him.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1376> Av. xiv. 2, 18. ''Cf.'' xiv. 1, 39.</ref> After the death  of the husband the [[देवृ|Devṛ]] could perform the duty of begetting a son for him.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1376> Rv. x. 40, 2. ''Cf.'' x. 18, 8;<br> Kaegi, ''Der Rigveda,'' n. 51;<br> Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 385;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 948. ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 516.</ref> No word occurs for the wife's brother corresponding to [[देवृ|Devṛ]].

देश
<u>'''Deśa,'''</u> ‘land,’ is a word that does not come into use till the time of the Upaniṣads and Sūtras,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1377> Where its use becomes common;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 16;<br> 2, 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 14, 6;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 4, 17, etc. So the adjective ''deśīya,'' ‘belonging to a land,’ Kātyāyana, xxii. 4, 22;<br> Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6, 28.</ref> excepting one occurrence in the latest period of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1377> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 10 (a late passage).</ref> literature, and one in a much-discussed passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1377> xxxiv. 11.</ref> where the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' is mentioned as having five tributaries. This passage militates against the view that [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] was a name of the Indus, because the use of [[देश|Deśa]] here seems to indicate<ref name=fx4_ve1_1377> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 10, who thinks that the word crept into the text, where the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] originally meant the Indus, with the five tributaries of the Panjab.</ref> that the seer of the verse placed the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] in the [[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]] or ‘Middle Country,’ to which all the geographical data of the Yajurvedas point.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1377> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 174.</ref>

देही
<u>'''Dehī'''</u> in two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1378> vi. 47, 2;<br> vii. 6, 5. ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 344;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 143.</ref> refers to defences thrown up against an enemy, apparently earthworks or dikes. ''Cf.'' '''Pur.'''

दैधिषव्य
<u>'''Daidhiṣavya'''</u> is mentioned in a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1379> iii. 2, 4, 4;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 1, 22;<br> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 3, 5;<br> 137, 37.</ref> Apparently the word (as derived from '''Didhiṣū''') denotes the son of a younger sister married before the elder sister,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1379> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 431, n.</ref> rather than the son of a woman twice married, the explanation of the St. Petersburg Dictionary. 

दैयांपाति
<u>'''Daiyāṃpāti,'''</u> ‘descendant of Dayāṃpāta,’ is the name of a teacher of the east, who was instructed by '''[[शाण्डिल्यायन|Śāṇḍilyāyana]],''' according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ix. 5, 1, 14), in the lore of the construction of the fire-altar. The same patronymic is given, in the form of Dayyāṃpāti, to '''[[प्लक्ष|Plakṣa]],''' the contemporary of '''Atyaṃhas''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 10, 9, 3-5).<br>==Foot Notes==

दैव
<u>'''1. Daiva'''</u> (masc.) appears in the list of sciences in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1381> vii. 1, 2, 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> where Śaṅkara explains it as ''utpātajñāna,'' apparently the ‘knowledge of portents.’ The St. Petersburg Dictionary suggests that the word is here used adjectivally, and this view is followed by Little<ref name=fx2_ve1_1381> ''Grammatical Index,'' 83.</ref> and by Bo7htlingk in his translation.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1381> Though he does not render it (''[[दैव|Daiva]] [[निधि|Nidhi]]'').</ref>

दैव
<u>'''2. Daiva'''</u> is the patronymic of the mythical [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1382> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina).</ref>

दैवल
<u>'''Daivala,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[देवल|Devala]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[असित|Asita]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 11, 18).<br>==Foot Notes==

दैव-वात
<u>'''Daiva-vāta,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[देववात|Devavāta]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]],''' probably the [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]] king, in the Rigveda. He is mentioned<ref name=fx1_ve1_1384> Rv. iv. 15, 4.</ref> as a devotee of the fire cult, and as victorious over the '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]''' king and the '''Vṛcīvants.'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1384> Rv. vi. 27, 7.</ref> According to Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1384> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 133, 134.</ref> his name was '''[[अभ्यावर्तिन् चायमान|Abhyāvartin Cāyamāna]] [[पार्थव|Pārthava]]''' (‘descendant of Pṛthu’), but Hillebrandt<ref name=fx4_ve1_1384> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105, 106.</ref> recognizes this as doubtful, though he none the less places the Sṛñjayas to the west of the Indus with '''Divodāsa.''' What is more important is to note that the name suggests connexion with the [[भरत|Bharata]] '''[[देववात|Devavāta]],''' and as '''Kurus''' and Sṛñjayas were closely connected<ref name=fx5_ve1_1384> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 402, 405;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 153.</ref> this is not immaterial. 

दैवाप
<u>'''Daivāpa,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Devāpi,'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[इन्द्रोत|Indrota]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1385> xiii. 5, 4, 1.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1385> iii. 40, 1.</ref> No connexion can be traced with the Devāpi of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1385> x. 98. See Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 240.</ref>

दैवावृध
<u>'''Daivāvṛdha,'''</u> ‘descendant of Devāvṛdha,’ is the patronymic of '''[[बभ्रु|Babhru]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 34).<br>==Foot Notes==

दैवो-दासि
<u>'''Daivo-dāsi,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Divodāsa,'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]]''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1387> xxvi. 5.</ref> and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1387> iii. 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 214.</ref> It is impossible to ascertain whether the famous Divodāsa is meant.

दोषा
<u>'''Doṣā,'''</u> ‘evening,’ is frequently referred to from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1388> i. 34, 3;<br> 179, 1;<br> ii. 8, 3;<br> iv. 2, 8;<br> v. 5, 6;<br> 32, 11;<br> vi. 5, 2, etc.</ref> onwards,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1388> Av. vi. 1, 1;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 17.</ref> usually as contrasted with ''uṣas,'' ‘dawn.’ In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1388> vi. 13, 1.</ref> the word is contrasted with ''[[प्रातर्|prātar]],'' ‘early.’ See also '''Ahan.'''

दोह
<u>'''Doha,'''</u> ‘milking,’ is a common word in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1389> iv. 11, 4. 9. 12;<br> v. 17, 17;<br> viii. 9, 15 (where five milkings are referred to metaphorically). In Rv. x. 42, 2, the literal sense is found.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1389> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 62;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 10, 2;<br> ii. 2, 9, 9, etc.</ref> Reference is made in the Sūtras<ref name=fx3_ve1_1389> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 2, 38, etc.</ref> to the ''sāyaṃ-doha,'' ‘evening milking,’ and the ''[[प्रातर्|prātar]]-doha,'' ‘morning milking.’ Dohana has the same sense.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1389> Rv. viii. 12, 32;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 2, 3, 30;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 2, 37, etc.</ref> See also '''Go.'''

दौरे-श्रवस्
<u>'''Daure-śravas,'''</u> ‘descendant of Dūreśravas,’ is the patronymic of the priest '''[[पृथुश्रवस्|Pṛthuśravas]],''' who officiated at the snake sacrifice described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 15, 3). <br>==Foot Notes==

दौरे-श्रुत
<u>'''Daure-śruta,'''</u> ‘descendant of Dūreśruta,’ is the patronymic of the priest '''Timirgha,''' who officiated at the snake sacrifice described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 15, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

दौर्-गह
<u>'''Daur-gaha.'''</u> See '''[[दुर्गह|Durgaha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

दौः-षन्ति
<u>'''Dauḥ-ṣanti'''</u> (‘descendant of Duḥṣanta’) is the patronymic of [[भरत|Bharata]] in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] (viii. 23) and Śatapatha (xiii. 5, 4, 11) Brāhmaṇas.<br>==Foot Notes==

द्युतान मारुत
<u>'''Dyutāna Māruta'''</u> (‘descendant of the Maruts’) is the name of a divine being invoked in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1394> v. 27.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1394> v. 5, 9, 4. ''Cf.'' vi. 2, 10, 4.</ref> and also mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1394> xv. 7.</ref> In the Śatapatha<ref name=fx4_ve1_1394> iii. 6, 1, 16.</ref> [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] the name is explained to mean Vāyu, while in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1394> xvii. 1, 7. ''Cf.'' vi. 4, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 311;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 220.</ref> he seems to be regarded as the author of a Sāman (chant). He is treated as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] by the Anukramaṇī, which credits him with the authorship of a hymn of the Rigveda (viii. 96).

द्युम्न
<u>'''Dyumna,'''</u> according to Pischel,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1395> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 720 ''et seq.''</ref> denotes ‘raft’ in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1395> viii. 19, 14.</ref>

द्यूत
<u>'''Dyūta,'''</u> ‘dicing,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1396> xii. 3, 46.</ref> and the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1396> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 6, 2;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10, 23, etc.</ref> See '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''

द्योतन
<u>'''Dyotana'''</u> is, according to Sāyaṇa, the name of a prince in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1397> vi. 20, 8.</ref> This is probably correct, though the word may also<ref name=fx2_ve1_1397> As by Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 380.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 328.</ref> be interpreted as denoting ‘glorification’ but it is not clear what relation existed between [[द्योतन|Dyotana]] and the other persons mentioned in the same passage, '''[[वेतसु|Vetasu]], [[दशोणि|Daśoṇi]], [[तूतुजि|Tūtuji]],''' and '''[[तुग्र|Tugra]].''' 

द्रप्स
<u>'''Drapsa'''</u> is a common word from the Rigveda onwards<ref name=fx1_ve1_1398> Rv. i. 94, 11 (perhaps a ‘drop’ of fire);<br> v. 63, 4 (‘rain-drop’);<br> vii. 33, 11 (= ''retas'');<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 2, 6;<br> ''drapsin'' (‘thick-flowing’), xi. 4, 1, 15.</ref> for a ‘drop’: according to Sāyaṇa,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1398> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, 1, p. 70, 7. ''Cf.'' the epithet ''uru-[[द्रप्स|drapsa]],'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 10, 2;<br> Sāyaṇa, on Av. xviii. 4, 18, takes ''[[द्रप्स|drapsa]]'' to mean ‘drops of curd’;<br> so Agnisvāmin on Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 2, 4.</ref> a ‘thick drop’ as opposed to ''stoka,'' a ‘small drop.’ Hence there frequently occurs the expression ''dadḥi-[[द्रप्स|drapsa]],''’ ‘drop of curds.’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1398> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 2, 3, 40.</ref> In the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1398> ix. 78, 4;<br> 85, 10;<br> 89, 2;<br> 97, 56;<br> 108, 8;<br> x. 11, 4;<br> 17, 11. 12. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 9. 1.</ref> the word normally denotes the thick drops of Soma or the Soma itself.<br><br>In two passages<ref name=fx5_ve1_1398> iv. 13, 2, and ''drapsin'' in i. 64, 2.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx6_ve1_1398> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[सत्वन्|satvan]];<br>'' Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v. [[द्रप्स|drapsa]], drapsin.''</ref> sees the sense of ‘banner,’ which is adopted by Oldenberg.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1398> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 357: ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 64, 65.</ref> Geldner,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1398> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 57, 58;<br> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 88.</ref> on the other hand, considers that ‘dust’ is meant, but this interpretation is not very probable. Max Müller<ref name=fx9_ve1_1398> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 104. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 80, with reference to Rv. i. 64, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''op. cit.,'' pp. 105, 113.</ref> renders the word ‘rain-drop’ in one of the passages.

द्रापि
<u>'''Drāpi'''</u> occurs several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1399> i. 25, 13;<br> 116, 10;<br> iv. 33, 2;<br> ix. 86, 14;<br> 100, 9;<br> Av. iii. 13, 1.</ref> in the sense of ‘mantle’ or ‘cloak.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1399> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 472;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 333.</ref> Sāyaṇa, however, renders the word by ‘coat of mail’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1399> ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 536;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 201, 202.</ref> (''[[कवच|kavaca]]''). This seems needless, but none of the passages are very decisive one way or the other.

द्रु
<u>'''Dru'''</u> denotes a vessel made of wood,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1400> Rv. i. 161, 1;<br> v. 86, 3;<br> viii. 66, 11;<br> in x. 101, 10, the mortar seems meant. In v. 86, 3, Bo7htlingk takes it to denote a ‘wooden handle.’</ref> and in particular the vessel used at the Soma sacrifice,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1400> ix. 1, 2;<br> 65, 6;<br> 98, 2.</ref> perhaps, as Hillebrandt<ref name=fx3_ve1_1400> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 191, 192.</ref> suggests, to catch the Soma juice when running through the sieve. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1400> i. 3, 9, 1. So often in compounds, ''e.g.,'' Rv. ii. 7, 6;<br> vi. 12, 4, etc.</ref> the word simply means ‘wood.’ 

द्रु-घण
<u>'''Dru-ghaṇa'''</u> is found in the [[मुद्गल|Mudgala]] hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1401> x. 101, 9.</ref> and in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1401> vii. 28, 1.</ref> The sense is uncertain. [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1401> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 23.</ref> renders it as a ‘''ghana'' made of wood,’ probably, as Roth<ref name=fx4_ve1_1401> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> takes it, meaning a ‘club of wood.’ Geldner<ref name=fx5_ve1_1401> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 3, 4.</ref> thinks that it was a wooden bull used by [[मुद्गल|Mudgala]] as a substitute for a second bull when he wanted to join in a race. But this interpretation of the legend is very improbable.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1401> ''Cf.'' von Bradke, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 46, 462;<br> Bloomfield, ''ibid.,'' 48, 456;<br> Franke, ''Vienna Oriental Journal,'' 8, 342.</ref> Whitney<ref name=fx7_ve1_1401> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 407.</ref> translates the word as ‘tree-smiter’ in the Atharvaveda, quoting Sāyaṇa, who explains it as a ‘cutting instrument,’ so called because trees are struck with it.

द्रु-पद
<u>'''Dru-pada,'''</u> a ‘wooden pillar’ or ‘post,’ is several times referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1402> i. 24, 13;<br> iv. 32, 23.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1402> Av. vi. 63, 3;<br> 115, 2;<br> xix. 47, 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 20.</ref> [[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]] was bound to three posts for sacrifice.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1402> Rv. i. 24, 13.</ref> Thieves, there is some evidence to show, were tied to posts as a penalty for stealing.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1402> Av. xix. 47, 9;<br> 50, 1. ''Cf.'' vi. 63, 3 = 84, 4. See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 181, 182, and [[तस्कर|Taskara]]. n. 26.</ref>

द्रुम
<u>'''Druma,'''</u> ‘tree,’ is not found until the later period in the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 11) and the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (iv. 19; v. 26; ix. 23).<br>==Foot Notes==

द्रुवय
<u>'''Druvaya,'''</u> ‘wooden,’ is used in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1404> v. 20, 2. ''Cf.'' xi. 1, 12, where it is an epithet of ''upaśvasa,'' ‘blower,’ possibly ‘bellows’;<br> but the manuscripts in part read ''dhruvaye,'' and the Paippalāda has ''druye.''</ref> as an epithet of the drum.

द्रु-हन्
<u>'''Dru-han,'''</u> ‘wood-cutter,’ seems to be meant by the word ''druhantara'' in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1405> i. 127, 2.</ref> where it is usually taken as ''druhaṃtara,'' ‘fiend-overpowering.’ But as an epithet of ''[[परशु|paraśu]],'' ‘axe,’ the other sense (‘mighty wood-cutter’)<ref name=fx2_ve1_1405> But if this explanation is correct, the word should have the accentuation of the comparative. See Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 132.</ref> is more probable.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1405> ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 130.</ref> 

द्रुह्यु
<u>'''Druhyu'''</u> is the name of a people mentioned several times in the Rigveda. In one passage<ref name=fx1_ve1_1406> i. 108, 8.</ref> it occurs, in the plural, with the '''Yadus, Turvaśas, Anus,''' and '''Pūrus,''' suggesting that these are the famous five peoples of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1406> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 122, 125;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 258 ''et seq.''</ref> Again, the [[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]] king shared in the defeat of his allies by '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' and appears to have perished in the waters.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1406> vii. 18.</ref> In a second passage [[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]], Anu, [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], and Yadu are all mentioned in the singular,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1406> viii. 10, 5.</ref> while in another [[पूरु|Pūru]] and [[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]] occur.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1406> vi. 46, 8.</ref> From the tribal grouping it is probable that the Druhyus were a north-western people,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1406> Roth, ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 131-133.</ref> and the later tradition of the Epic connects [[गान्धार|Gāndhāra]] and [[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]].<ref name=fx7_ve1_1406> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 49.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 205;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 140.</ref>

द्रोण
<u>'''Droṇa'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1407> vi. 2, 8;<br> 37, 2;<br> 44, 20;<br> ix. 93, 1;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 26.</ref> a ‘wooden trough,’ and more specifically it designates in the plural vessels used for holding Soma.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1407> ix. 3, 1;<br> 15, 7;<br> 28, 4;<br> 30, 4;<br> 67, 14, etc. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 280.</ref> The great wooden reservoir for Soma is called a [[द्रोण|Droṇa]]-[[कलश|kalaśa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1407> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 1, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 21;<br> xix. 27;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17, 32. Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 17, etc.</ref> The altar was sometimes made in the form of a [[द्रोण|Droṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1407> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 7, 2, 8.</ref>

द्रोणाहाव
<u>'''Droṇāhāva'''</u> is used as an epithet of '''[[अवत|Avata]],''' ‘well,’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1408> x. 101, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 157.</ref> apparently in the sense of ‘having wooden buckets’ with reference to the drawing up of water.

द्वादश
<u>'''Dvādaśa,'''</u> ‘consisting of twelve,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1409> ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 645 ''et seq.''</ref> is used of the year in the Rigveda (vii. 103, 9). See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''

द्वापर
<u>'''Dvāpara.'''</u> See '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]''' and '''Yuga.''' <br>==Foot Notes==

द्वार्
<u>'''Dvār'''</u> is frequently used from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1411> i. 13, 6.</ref> onwards<ref name=fx2_ve1_1411> Av. viii. 3, 22;<br> xiv. 1, 63;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 1, 2;<br> xiv. 3, 1, 13, etc.</ref> to denote the ‘door’ of a house. The later form, Dvāra, has the same sense.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1411> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 1, 19;<br> iv. 3, 5, 9;<br> 6, 7, 9;<br> xi. 4, 4, 2, etc. Av. x. 8, 43, has ''nava-dvāra,'' ‘having nine openings,’ of the body.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].''' The ‘door-fastener’ is called Dvārapidhāna in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1411> xi. 1, 1, 1. ''Cf. dvāra-bāhū,'' ‘doorposts,’ in Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 3, 1;<br> ii. 3, 9.</ref>

द्वार-प
<u>'''Dvāra-pa,'''</u> ‘door-keeper,’ is only found in a metaphorical sense in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 30), where Viṣṇu is called the ‘doorkeeper’ of the gods, and in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 13, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

द्वि-गत् भार्गव
<u>'''Dvi-gat Bhārgava'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[भृगु|Bhṛgu]]'''’) is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 9) as the seer of a Sāman or Chant, by means of which he twice went to the heavenly world.<br>==Foot Notes==

द्वि-ज
<u>'''Dvi-ja,'''</u> ‘twice-born,’ as an epithet of the Āryans generally, or of the Brahmins in particular, is not found in Vedic literature except in a quite obscure verse of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1414> xix. 71, 1. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 1008;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 204. Neither ''dvijanman'' nor ''dvi-[[जाति|jāti]]'' occurs early, and the idea is not in this form an early one.</ref>

द्वि-पाद्
<u>'''Dvi-pād,'''</u> ‘two-footed,’ ‘biped,’ denotes man, as opposed to quadrupeds, from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1415> i. 49, 3;<br> iii. 62, 14;<br> viii. 27, 12;<br> x. 97, 20;<br> 117, 8.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1415> Av. ii. 34, 1;<br> x. 1, 24;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 30;<br> ix. 31;<br> xiii. 17;<br> xiv. 8, etc.</ref>

द्वि-बन्धु
<u>'''Dvi-bandhu'''</u> is in an obscure hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1416> x. 61, 17.</ref> according to Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_1416> St. Petersburg Dictionary.</ref> and Grassmann,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1416> ''Wo7rterbuch, s.v.,'' and Translation of the Rigveda, 2, 475.</ref> the name of a man, while Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve1_1416> Translation of the Rigveda, 2, 643, and 5, 526.</ref> renders it as a simple adjective meaning ‘of double kinship.’ 

द्वि-राज
<u>'''Dvi-rāja'''</u> (neut,), ‘conflict between two kings,’ or ‘battle,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda (v. 20, 9). ''Cf.'' '''[[दाशराज्ञ|Dāśarājña]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

द्वि-रेतस्
<u>'''Dvi-retas,'''</u> ‘having double seed,’ is an epithet of both the ass<ref name=fx1_ve1_1418> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 1, 23. ''Cf.'' '''[[गर्दभ|Gardabha]].'''</ref> and the mare.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1418> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 4.</ref>

द्वीप
<u>'''Dvīpa,'''</u> ‘island,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1419> i. 169, 3.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1419> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 2, 1, 3;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta Sütra, i. 6, 10.</ref> But there is no reason to imagine that the islands referred to were other than sandbanks in the great rivers, Indus or Ganges.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1419> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 256.</ref> Vedic literature knows nothing of the system of geography according to which the earth consists of four, seven, or thirteen Dvīpas grouped round Mount Meru.

द्वीपिन्
<u>'''Dvīpin,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1420> Lit., ‘insulated’--''i.e.,'' ‘spotted.’</ref> ‘panther’ or ‘leopard,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1420> iv. 8, 7;<br> vi. 38, 2;<br> xix. 49, 4, in every case associated with the tiger.</ref> and the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1420> ii. 1. 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 80.</ref>

द्वैत-वन
<u>'''Dvaita-vana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Dvitavana,’ is the patronymic of '''Dhvasan,''' the king of the '''Matsyas,''' whose [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice,’ is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 5, 4, 9).<br>==Foot Notes==

द्व्य्-ओपश
<u>'''Dvy-opaśa.'''</u> See '''[[ओपश|Opaśa]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

धन
<u>'''Dhana,'''</u> ‘prize,’ is often found in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1423> Rv. i. 81, 3;<br> vi. 45, 2;<br> viii. 80, 8;<br> ix. 53, 2;<br> 109, 10. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 120;<br> Pischel, ''ibid.,'' 1, 171.</ref> probably the prize in racing rather than the ‘booty’ in battle. It also denotes<ref name=fx2_ve1_1423> Rv. x. 34, 10;<br> Av. iv. 38, 3.</ref> the ‘stake’ at dicing. In some passages it possibly means the ‘contest’ itself.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1423> Rv. i. 31, 6;<br> v. 35, 7;<br> vii. 38, 8;<br> viii. 5, 26;<br> 8, 21;<br> 49, 9;<br> 50, 9;<br> x. 48, 5, etc.</ref> More generally it denotes ‘wealth’ or ‘gift.’<ref name=fx4_ve1_1423> Rv. i. 42, 6;<br> x. 18, 2;<br> 84, 7;<br> Av. i. 15, 3;<br> ii. 7, 4;<br> iii. 15, 2;<br> v. 19, 9;<br> vi. 81, 1;<br> vii. 81, 4;<br> viii. 5, 16, etc.</ref> But it sometimes expresses ‘booty,’<ref name=fx5_ve1_1423> Rv. i. 74, 3;<br> 157, 2, etc.</ref> probably from the notion of ‘wealth’ rather than of ‘prize.’

धन-धानी
<u>'''Dhana-dhānī,'''</u> a ‘treasure house,’ is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (x. 67).<br>==Foot Notes==

धनिष्ठा
<u>'''Dhaniṣṭhā'''</u> (‘very rich’), used in the plural, is the later name<ref name=fx1_ve1_1425> Sāntikalpa, 13;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 26.</ref> of the lunar mansion '''([[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]) Śraviṣṭhā.'''

धनु
<u>'''Dhanu'''</u> (fem.), ‘sandbank,’ occurs several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1426> i. 33, 4;<br> 144, 5;<br> viii. 3, 19;<br> x. 4, 3;<br> 27, 17.</ref> but only metaphorically of the clouds in the atmosphere. Dhanū is found in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1426> i. 17, 4.</ref> where it seems to denote a sandbag used to prevent bleeding.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1426> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 411;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 18;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 259, 260.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[धन्वन्|Dhanvan]].'''

धनुस्
<u>'''Dhanus,'''</u> the ‘bow,’ frequently mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1427> viii. 72, 4;<br> 77, 11;<br> ix. 99, 1;<br> x. 18, 9;<br> 125, 6.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1427> Av. iv. 4, 6;<br> 6, 6;<br> v. 18, 8;<br> vii. 50. 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 10;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 14;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 4, 6;<br> v. 3, 1, 11, etc.</ref> was the chief weapon of the Vedic Indian.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1427> Rv. vi. 75, 2. Practically no other weapon plays any substantial part in Vedic warfare.</ref> The last act of the funeral rite included the removal of the bow from  the right hand of the dead man.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1427> Rv. x. 18, 9.</ref> The weapon was composed of a stout staff bent into a curved shape (''vakra''),<ref name=fx5_ve1_1427> Av. iv. 6, 4.</ref> and of a bowstring ('''[[ज्या|Jyā]]''') made of a strip of cowhide<ref name=fx6_ve1_1427> Rv. vi. 75, 11;<br> Av. i. 2, 3.</ref> which joined the ends. The tips of the bow, when the string was fastened, were called '''[[आर्त्नी|Ārtnī]].''' Relaxed when not in actual use, the bow was specially strung up when needed for shooting.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1427> Rv. x. 166, 3;<br> Av. vi. 42, 1.</ref> The stages of the process are given in detail in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā:<ref name=fx8_ve1_1427> xvi. 22.</ref> the stringing (''ā-tan'') of the bow, the placing (''[[प्रति-धा|prati-dhā]]'') of the arrow, the bending (''ā-yam'') of the bow, and the shooting (''as''). The arrow was discharged from the ear,<ref name=fx9_ve1_1427> Rv. vi. 75, 2 ''et seq.'' So also in the Epic, Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 271. The Homeric method is to draw to the breast--''e.g., Iliad,'' iv. 123.</ref> and is hence called ''karṇa-yoni,''<ref name=fx10_ve1_1427> Rv. ii. 24, 8.</ref> ‘having the ear as its point of origin.’<ref name=fx10_ve1_1427/> The making of bows was a regular profession (''dhanuṣ-kāra,''<ref name=fx11_ve1_1427> xxx. 7.</ref> ''dhanuṣ-kṛt'').<ref name=fx12_ve1_1427> xvi. 46.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 298, 299;<br> Hopkins, ''op. cit.,'' 13, 270 ''et seq.'' The Epic bow is about 5(1/2) feet, and the arrow 3 feet in length.</ref> For the arrow see '''[[इषु|Iṣu]],''' and for the handguard '''[[हस्तघ्न|Hastaghna]].'''

धन्वन्
<u>'''1. Dhanvan,'''</u> ‘bow,’ is found frequently in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1428> ii. 24, 8;<br> 33, 10;<br> vi. 59, 7;<br> 75, 2;<br> viii. 20, 2;<br> ix. 69, 1;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 17.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1428> Av. i. 3, 9;<br> iv. 4, 7;<br> xi. 9, 1, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 9, etc.</ref> It also occurs in the compounds ''[[इषु|iṣu]]-dhanva,'' ‘bow and arrow,’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1428> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 19;<br> ''iṣudhanvin,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 2.</ref> ''[[आज्य|ājya]]-dhanva,''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1428> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 25.</ref> ‘having clarified butter for its bow,’<ref name=fx5_ve1_1428> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 1, 1, 6.</ref> ''adhijya-dhanva,'' ‘bow with string fixed,’ etc. ''Cf.'' '''[[धनुस्|Dhanus]].'''

धन्वन्
<u>'''2. Dhanvan,'''</u> ‘desert,’ is repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1429> ii. 38, 7;<br> iii. 45, 1;<br> iv. 17, 2;<br> 19, 7;<br> 33, 7;<br> v. 53, 6;<br> 83, 10, etc. In i. 116, 4, the strand of the ocean ('''[[सम्उद्र|Samudra]]''') is mentioned.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1429> Av. v. 13, 1;<br> vi. 100, 1;<br> vii. 41, 1, etc.</ref> Death from thirst in the desert was not rare,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1429> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 19.</ref> and  the value of a spring in the desert was fully appreciated.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1429> Rv. x. 4, 1. ''Cf.'' vi. 34, 4, etc.;<br> Av. i. 6, 4;<br> xix. 2, 2.</ref> The great desert east of the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus) and the '''[[शुतुद्री|Śutudrī]]''' (Sutlej) is possibly referred to in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1429> x. 86, 20.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 47, 48.</ref>

धमनि
<u>'''Dhamani,'''</u> ‘reed,’ appears to denote ‘pipe’ in a passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1430> ii. 11, 8.</ref> and in a citation appearing in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1430> vi. 24.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1430> i. 17, 23;<br> ii. 33, 6;<br> vi. 90, 2;<br> vii. 35, 2. ''Cf.'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 19, 2.</ref> it denotes, perhaps, ‘artery’ or ‘vein,’ or more generally ‘intestinal channel,’ being coupled in some passages<ref name=fx4_ve1_1430> i. 17, 3;<br> vii. 35, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 259, 546.</ref> with '''[[हिरा|Hirā]].'''

धरुण
<u>'''Dharuṇa'''</u> in one passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (viii. 51) denotes a ‘sucking calf.’<br>==Foot Notes==

धर्म
<u>'''Dharma,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1432> i. 22, 18;<br> 164, 43, 50;<br> iii. 3, 1;<br> 17, 1;<br> 60, 6;<br> v. 26, 6;<br> 63, 7;<br> 72, 2, etc.;<br> Av. xiv. 1, 51;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 29, etc. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 90.</ref> '''Dharman,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1432> [[धर्म|Dharma]] is found in Av. xi. 7, 17;<br> xii. 5, 7;<br> xviii. 3, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 2, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 6;<br> xx. 9;<br> xxx. 6, etc.</ref> are the regular words, the latter in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1432/> and both later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1432/> for ‘law’ or ‘custom.’ But there is very little evidence in the early literature as to the administration of justice or the code of law followed. On the other hand, the [[धर्म|Dharma]] Sūtras<ref name=fx3_ve1_1432> See Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte;<br>'' Foy, ''Die ko7nigliche Gewalt nach den altindischen Rechtsbüchern;<br>'' Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 2 and 14.</ref> contain full particulars.<br><br>(1) ''Criminal Law.''--The crimes recognized in Vedic literature vary greatly in importance, while there is no distinction adopted in principle between real crimes and what now are regarded as fanciful bodily defects or infringements of merely  conventional practices.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1432> Compare the list in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 7;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvii. 7;<br> and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 11 (see Delbrück. ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 579 ''et seq.''), where bodily defects (bad nails and discoloured teeth), marrying a younger daughter when her elder sister was unmarried, are coupled with murder, though not equated with it. See also Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 5, where Aśvapati's list of sinners includes a drinker of intoxicating liquor, a thief, and one who does not maintain a sacrificial fire.</ref> The crimes enumerated include the slaying of an embryo (''bhrūṇa''),<ref name=fx5_ve1_1432> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 9;<br> xxxi. 7;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xli. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 7, 8;<br> 8, 3;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 22;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 27;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1. ''Cf.'' Av. vi. 112, 3;<br> 113, 2;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 481;<br> 10, 66;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 522;<br> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 430.</ref> the slaying of a man (''[[वीर|vīra]]''),<ref name=fx6_ve1_1432> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]], xxxi. 7;<br> Kapiṣṭhala, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Maitrāyaṇī, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5, and ''cf.'' '''[[वैर|Vaira]].''' For cases of justifiable homicide, see, ''e.g.,'' [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 15-18. ''Cf.'' also the story of '''[[वृश जान|Vṛśa Jāna]]''' in [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 12, where the death of a boy by careless driving is mentioned, and the king is reproached for it by his [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]. They dispute as to the guilt, and, according to one version (see Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 66, 67), the '''Ikṣvākus''' decide that the action was sinful, and required expiation.</ref> and  the slaying of a Brahmin,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1432> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 2;<br> v. 3, 12, 1;<br> vi. 5, 10, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 7 (where the Kapiṣṭhala has ''[[ब्रह्म-ज्य|brahma-jya]],'' ‘oppressor of a Brahmin’);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 12. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, x. 38, declares that the slaying of a Brahmin alone is truly murder, and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 1, 1 ''et seq.,'' states that the sin of murdering a Brahmin can be expiated only by the performance of an [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice’--the ''ne plus ultra'' of human generosity to Brahmins. See also [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 27. The later tradition also interprets ''bhrūṇa'' as Brahmin (see Saṅkara, cited in Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 410, n.;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 30, n. 5;<br> Konow, ''Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],'' 46, n. 1, and ''cf.'' [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xx. 23).</ref> a much more serious crime. Treachery is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_1432> xiv. 6, 8, the story of '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]].'''</ref> as being punishable by death, as it was punished later.<ref name=fx9_ve1_1432> Jolly, ''op. cit.,'' 127.</ref> But there is no trace of an organized criminal justice vested either in the king or in the people. There still seems to have prevailed the system of wergeld ('''[[वैर|Vaira]]'''), which indicates that criminal justice remained in the hands of those who were wronged. In the Sūtras,<ref name=fx10_ve1_1432> See references in Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 345.</ref> on the other hand, the king's peace is recognized as infringed by crimes, a penalty being paid to him, or, according to the Brahminical textbooks, to the Brahmins. It may there-  fore reasonably be conjectured that the royal power of jurisdiction steadily increased; the references in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] to the king as wielding punishment ('''[[दण्ड|Daṇḍa]]''') confirm this supposition. Whether, as the analogy of other systems suggests, the king was assisted in his judicial duties, as he undoubtedly was later, by assessors, presumably of the Brahmin caste, cannot be made out clearly.<ref name=fx11_ve1_1432> Compare the story of the death of the child killed by Tryaruṇa, and the decision of the Ikṣväkus referred to in n. 6 above, and the notice in [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 4, that a [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] is ''adhyakṣa,'' when a Sūdra is punished (''han'').</ref><br><br>The procedure adopted in deciding cases is quite uncertain. In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx12_ve1_1432> vi. 16. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 72, 73.</ref> the ordeal of the red-hot axe is mentioned as applied in an accusation of theft. It must apparently be understood to have been inflicted by the direction of the king. But no other judicial ordeal is known to Vedic literature (see '''[[दिव्य|Divya]]'''). The punishment of theft was in some cases at least death, probably when the thief was taken redhanded;<ref name=fx13_ve1_1432> [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 43;<br> Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 9, 25, 4.</ref> in other cases binding to posts was the penalty,<ref name=fx14_ve1_1432> See Av. xix. 47, 9;<br> 50, 1, and '''[[तस्कर|Taskara]].'''</ref> presumably accompanied by the return of the stolen goods. In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx15_ve1_1432> v. 10, 9. Another list is given in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, x. 65, which includes slaying a Brahmin, defiling a Guru's bed, stealing a cow, drinking [[सुरा|Surā]], and killing an embryo, along with irregularities in offering a Śrāddha, ‘water offering to the dead.’ ''Cf.'' also [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 27, for a list of seven. Many more appear in the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], but that work cannot claim to be a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] proper.</ref> the list of sins given as apparently equal in wickedness is stealing gold, drinking spirits, defiling a Guru's bed, and the murder of a Brahmin.<br><br>(2) ''Civil Law.''--There is little recorded as to civil law in Vedic literature. The relations of the family and the question of family property are dealt with under '''[[उर्वरा|Urvarā]], [[क्षेत्र|Kṣetra]], Pati;''' succession and partition of property are treated under '''[[दाय|Dāya]].''' As regards the transfer of chattels--for land as transferable ''inter vivos'' is hardly yet recognized, save exceptionally as a sacrificial fee ('''[[दक्षिणा|Dakṣiṇā]]'''), and then disapproved<ref name=fx16_ve1_1432> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 7, 1, 13.</ref> --the recognized modes are gift ('''[[दान|Dāna]]''') and barter or sale ('''[[क्रय|Kraya]]'''), which includes exchange. Original acquisition of land was no doubt brought  about by occupation and apportionment among the tribesmen,<ref name=fx17_ve1_1432> ''Cf.'' Cæsar, ''Bellum Gallicum,'' iv. 1;<br> vi. 22;<br> Tacitus, ''Germania,'' 26, for Germany;<br> Mommsen, ''Ro7misches Staatsrecht,'' 3, 1, 21, for the Roman ''hortus;<br>'' and the Greek , Lang, ''Homer and the Epic,'' 236-241;<br> Ridgeway, ''Journal of Hellenic Studies,'' 6, 319 ''et seq.;<br>'' Grote, ''History of Greece,'' 2, 36, 37. See also Pollock and Maitland, ''History of English Law,'' 2, 337 ''et seq.;<br>'' Baden Powell, ''Village Communities in India,'' 6 ''et seq.;<br>'' 131.</ref> while chattels were acquired by taking possession of them, provided that they were found on one's own land or on unoccupied land, and did not belong to any other person originally. The Sūtras<ref name=fx18_ve1_1432> [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 36 ''et seq.''</ref> contain rules for the disposal of lost property, which tend to give it to the king, with the deduction of a percentage for the finder, unless the latter is a Brahmin, who keeps it all. As for contract, save in regard to moneylending (for which see '''[[ऋण|Ṛṇa]]'''), practically nothing is to be gathered from Vedic literature, doubtless because of the primitive conditions prevailing in that early period. Much of the labour, which would in a more developed society have been done by workers for hire, would be performed by slaves (''cf.'' '''[[दास|Dāsa]], [[शूद्र|Śūdra]]'''), while the technical workers of the village--of whom long lists are given in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx19_ve1_1432> xxx.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx20_ve1_1432> iii. 4. See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 426 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 75 ''et seq.''</ref> --may have been recompensed not by any sum based on each piece of work done, but by fixed allowances, much as the village servants are in modern times.<ref name=fx21_ve1_1432> ''Cf.'' Maine, ''Village Communities,'' 127, 175;<br> Baden Powell, ''op. cit.,'' 124 ''et seq.;<br>'' Grote, ''History of Greece,'' 2, 36, n. 2.</ref> But this must remain a matter of conjecture, and it is uncertain what exact status the carpenter or smith held in the village. Similarly it is impossible to trace in the early literature any legal theory or practice as to torts, but rules as to penalties for insults appear in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx22_ve1_1432> ''Cf.'' Jolly, ''op. cit.,'' 126-128.</ref><br><br>Very little is recorded as to procedure. The list<ref name=fx23_ve1_1432> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 6, 1.</ref> of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or ‘horse sacrifice,’ includes a ''praśnin,'' an ''[[अभि-प्रश्निन्|abhi-praśnin]],'' and a ''[[प्रश्न|praśna]]-vivāka,'' in whom it is not unreasonable to see the plaintiff, the defendant, and the arbitrator or judge: the terms may refer to what is probably an early  form of judicial procedure, a voluntary arbitration. The same idea may be conveyed by the word ''[[मध्यम-शी|madhyama-śī]],'' ‘lying in the midst,’ which occurs in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx24_ve1_1432> x. 97, 12 = Av. iv. 9, 4 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 86. ''Madhyamaśīvan,'' in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 408, is of quite doubtful sense.</ref> and which Roth,<ref name=fx25_ve1_1432> ''Siebenzig Lieder,'' 174. This fact renders doubtful Lanman's view (Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 159) that the St. Petersburg Dictionary, in giving ''intercessor'' as the interpretation, did not mean ‘mediator,’ but ‘adversary.’</ref> followed by Zimmer,<ref name=fx26_ve1_1432> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 180.</ref> understood to mean an arbitrator or judge, the expression being derived from the judge acting with other judicial persons,<ref name=fx27_ve1_1432> As, apparently, in early Germany. See Cæsar, ''Bellum Gallicum,'' vi. 23;<br> Tacitus, ''Germania,'' 11, 12;<br> Coulanges, ''Recherches sur quelques problèmes d'histoire,'' 361 ''et seq.''</ref> and being surrounded by the assembly of the people. But this interpretation is uncertain; Whitney<ref name=fx28_ve1_1432> See n. 25.</ref> thinks that the word merely alludes to a chief round whom his men encamp. The king is later the chief civil judge, and may presumably have been so earlier, no doubt in conjunction with the elders of the tribe, but for this we are reduced to conjecture.<ref name=fx29_ve1_1432> ''Cf.'' the later [[परिषद्|Pariṣad]], [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxviii. 48, 49;<br> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 7-16;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xi. 5-7, 20;<br> Jolly, ''op. cit.,'' 132 ''et seq.'' The parallels from other Āryan peoples suggest the use of assessors, as in the Anglo-Saxon courts of the shire and hundred. ''Cf.'' Sohm, ''Altdeutsches Reichs-und Gerichtsverfassung,'' 6 ''et seq.''</ref><br><br>The use of witnesses as evidence is uncertain (see '''[[ज्ञातृ|Jñātṛ]]'''), and the ordeal is not recorded as deciding any civil matter except the dispute between '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]]''' and his rival as to the true Brahminical descent of the former, which was settled by his walking unharmed through the flame of a fire.<ref name=fx30_ve1_1432> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 6, 6.</ref> But it is probable on analogy that the ordeal may have been used for the purpose of deciding disputes. Whether the oath was so used cannot be certainly shown. It appears, however, that a Brahmin was preferred in legal matters to a non-Brahmin.<ref name=fx31_ve1_1432> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 11, 9, which seems to refer either to giving evidence for or passing judgment on a case when both a Brahmin and a nonBrahmin are engaged.</ref><br><br>There are very few references to police officials: no doubt the king employed some of his dependents to execute sentences and arrest offenders (see '''Ugra, [[जीवगृभ्|Jīvagṛbh]]''').<br><br>(3) ''Morality.''--It is convenient to notice under this head  several points bearing on the moral condition of the people: (''a'') the exposure of children; (''b'') the exposure of the aged; (''c'') prostitution; (''d'') adultery; (''e'') incest.<br><br>(''a'') The exposure of girl infants is asserted by Zimmer<ref name=fx32_ve1_1432> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 319, 320. ''Cf.'' also Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 54, 260;<br> Kaegi, ''Der Rigveda,'' n. 49;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 389, 390;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda. 6, 142;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 48.</ref> on the strength of a passage in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx33_ve1_1432> xxvii. 9. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 17, 12;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] iii. 4.</ref> but it seems clear that the passage has been misunderstood,<ref name=fx34_ve1_1432> Bo7htlingk, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 44, 494496. The traditional rendering of the passages is not that it refers to exposure, but to getting rid of a daughter on her marriage.</ref> and that it refers merely to laying the child aside, not exposing it, while a boy was lifted up. It is, however, true that the birth of a girl was not at all popular, not an unnatural sentiment in an early society, and paralleled among other Āryan peoples.<ref name=fx35_ve1_1432> Av. viii. 6, 25;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 15;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 409;<br> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 320;<br> Schrader, ''op. cit.,'' 390.</ref><br><br>(''b'') The exposure of the aged is also inferred by Zimmer<ref name=fx36_ve1_1432> ''Op. cit.,'' 327, 328. Strabo, pp. 513, 517, 520, reports the practice as prevailing in Iran, Bactria, and the Massagetae;<br> it prevailed among the Norsemen, Weinhold, ''Altuordisches Leben,'' 473, and conceivably among the early Romans (''depontani senes,'' Cicero, ''Pro Roscio,'' 100;<br> but this and other cases may be really instances of the ritual casting into water of the wornout vegetation spirit for the purpose of reviving it). See Kaegi, ''op. cit.,'' n. 50;<br> Schrader, ''op. cit.,'' 379, n.</ref> from a passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx37_ve1_1432> viii. 51, 2.</ref> and from the mention of persons exposed (''ud-hitāḥ'') in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx38_ve1_1432> xviii. 2, 34. See '''[[अन्अग्निदग्ध|Anagnidagdha]].'''</ref> The latter passage may well refer merely to the bodies being exposed after death to the elements (as is done by the Parsis). The former passage merely refers to the individual case of some person who may have been cast out, and proves absolutely nothing as to a habitual or recognized custom, nor can such a custom be inferred from, ''e.g.,'' the legend of '''Cyavāna.'''<br><br>(''c'') That prostitution existed in Rigvedic times is certain, but its extent is disputed. Brotherless girls were frequently reduced to becoming prostitutes;<ref name=fx39_ve1_1432> Rv. i. 124, 7;<br> iv. 5, 5;<br> Av. i. 17, 1;<br> and ''of.'' '''Ayogü.'''</ref> the putting away of an illegitimate child is referred to in the Rigveda;<ref name=fx40_ve1_1432> ii. 29, 1. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''op. cit.,'' 26.</ref> besides the  terms ''[[पुंश्चली|puṃścalī]]''<ref name=fx41_ve1_1432> Av. xv. 2, etc.</ref> and ''[[महानग्नी|mahānagnī]],''<ref name=fx42_ve1_1432> Av. xiv. 1, 36;<br> xx. 136, 5 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 27. ''Cf. [[नग्ना|nagnā]]'' in Av. v. 7, 8.</ref> which undoubtedly mean ‘harlot,’ there are other clear references to prostitution;<ref name=fx43_ve1_1432> Rv. i. 167, 4 (Wilson, Translation of the Rigveda, 2, xvii), can hardly be so interpreted;<br> see Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 332, n. Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 277, interprets it as a reference to polyandry, but this is still more doubtful;<br> but see Rv. viii. 17, 7.</ref> and expressions like ''kumārī-[[पुत्र|putra]],'' ‘son of a maiden,’<ref name=fx44_ve1_1432> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 2, 1.</ref> and the ‘son of an unmarried girl’ (''agrū''), spoken of in the Rigveda<ref name=fx45_ve1_1432> iv. 19, 9;<br> 30, 16. 19;<br> ii. 13, 12;<br> 15, 17;<br> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 334, 335.</ref> as exposed and attacked by animals, point in the same direction. The Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx46_ve1_1432> Apparently this is meant by the epithets ''atiṣkadvarī'' (''apaskadvarī'' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 11, 1), ''atītvarī, vijarjarā,'' in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 15.</ref> seems to recognize prostitution as a profession. Pischel<ref name=fx47_ve1_1432> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xxv;<br> 196, 275, 299, 309, etc.;<br> 2, 120.</ref> sees many references to Hetairai in the Rigveda, which as Geldner<ref name=fx48_ve1_1432> ''Ibid.,'' 2, 154.</ref> insists reflects in its imagery the court life of Indian princes. But the correctness of the view of these two scholars on this point is not by any means certain.<ref name=fx49_ve1_1432> ''Cf.'' Winternitz, ''Geschichte der indischen Litteratur,'' 1, 60;<br> Jolly, ''op. cit.,'' 48.</ref><br><br>(''d'') Adultery was generally regarded among Āryan peoples as a serious offence against the husband of the woman affected. We accordingly find in the legal literature of India traces of the rule that an adulterer can be slain with impunity if taken in the act.<ref name=fx50_ve1_1432> Leist, ''Altarisches Jus Gentium,'' 276 ''et seq.,'' 309.</ref> Weber,<ref name=fx51_ve1_1432> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 83 ''et seq.''</ref> however, has adduced some material indicating an indifference to these matters in Vedic times, and Ludwig<ref name=fx52_ve1_1432> ''Op. cit.,'' 5, 573.</ref> has adopted the same view. But, as Delbrück<ref name=fx53_ve1_1432> ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 545 ''et seq.''</ref> has clearly shown, the evidence is not convincing; the cited prescriptions<ref name=fx54_ve1_1432> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 8, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 7.</ref> forbidding connexion with another man's wife during a certain rite do not imply that such connexion would otherwise be allowed: the ritual of the Varuṇa-praghāsas,<ref name=fx55_ve1_1432> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 10, 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 2, 20.</ref> when a wife names her lover or lovers, seems originally to have been a solemn means of banishing the evil brought on a family by a wife's fall; '''Yājñavalkya's''' famous saying<ref name=fx56_ve1_1432> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 1, 21.</ref> that no one  cares whether a wife is ‘unchaste’ (''paraḥ-puṃsā'') or not is a mere mistranslation,<ref name=fx57_ve1_1432> So Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Delbrück, ''op. cit.,'' 548.</ref> the expression ''paraḥ-puṃsā'' really meaning ‘removed from the male persons.’ And the uncertainty asserted in some passages<ref name=fx58_ve1_1432> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 11;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], cited in Ludwig, ''loc. cit.''</ref> as to origin from a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] is not a sign of doubtful descent, but is due to the fact that Ṛṣihood was a difficult matter to ascertain. None the less woman's position was lowered by the prevalence of polygamy, and such stories as that of Ahalyā and Indra<ref name=fx59_ve1_1432> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 65.</ref> are not compatible with a very high standard of morality. A similar conclusion is pointed to by references in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx60_ve1_1432> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 2. 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 30. 31.</ref> to relations between the [[आर्य|Ārya]] man and the [[शूद्रा|Śūdrā]] woman, and by a spell given in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx61_ve1_1432> vi. 4, 11.</ref> to expiate relations with the wife of a [[श्रोत्रिय|Śrotriya]] (Brahmin theologian).<br><br>(''e'') Incest was recognized in the marriage of brother and sister as appears from the legend of Yama and Yamī in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx62_ve1_1432> x. 10.</ref> which clearly shows that such a marriage was not approved by the feeling of the Vedic age. There is also another hymn<ref name=fx63_ve1_1432> x. 162, 5.</ref> in which reference to such intercourse appears to be made. Mention is further made in the Rigveda<ref name=fx64_ve1_1432> x. 61, 5-7.</ref> to the wedlock of Prajāpati and his daughter, which is, however, interpreted mythologically in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx65_ve1_1432> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 33;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 4, 1;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 4, 46, 47;<br> Max Müller, ''op. cit.,'' 529, 530.</ref> an interpretation which may be correct. That incest, however, actually did take place is clear from the Atharvaveda;<ref name=fx66_ve1_1432> viii. 6, 7.</ref> but even though the mythological interpretation of the passage were not justified, no conclusion could be drawn from the hymn as to the normal occurrence of such relations.

धव
<u>'''1. Dhava'''</u> is the name of a tree (''Grislea tormentosa'') mentioned, together with the '''[[प्लक्ष|Plakṣa]], [[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]],''' and '''Khādira,''' in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1433> v. 5, 5;<br> xx. 137, 11. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62.</ref> 

धव
<u>'''2. Dhava,'''</u> ‘man,’ is not found before the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1434> iii. 15. ''Cf.'' Naighaṇṭuka, ii. 3.</ref> The word clearly owes its existence merely to ''[[विधवा|vidhavā]],'' ‘widow,’ wrongly interpreted as ''vi-dhavā,'' ‘without a husband.’

धवित्र
<u>'''Dhavitra,'''</u> occurring in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1435> xiv. 1, 3, 30;<br> 3, 1, 21.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1435> v. 4, 33.</ref> denotes a ‘fan’ of hide or leather for blowing the sacrificial fire.

धानं-जय्य
<u>'''Dhānaṃ-jayya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Dhanaṃ-jaya,'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[अंशु|Aṃśu]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1436> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373. Under this patronymic he is frequently named by Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 25;<br> ii. 1, 2;<br> 9, 10, etc. (misread Dhānaṃjapya in many manuscripts). ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 76, 77, 82.</ref>

धाना
<u>'''Dhānā,'''</u> always used in the plural, and frequently referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1437> i. 16, 2;<br> iii. 35, 3;<br> 52, 5;<br> vi. 29, 4, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1437> Av. xviii. 3, 69;<br> 4, 32. 34;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 21, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 11, 2, etc.</ref> means ‘grains of corn.’ They were sometimes parched (''bhṛjj''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_1437> Rv. iv. 24, 7.</ref> and were regularly mixed with Soma.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1437> Rv. iii. 43, 4;<br> 52, 1;<br> viii. 91, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 10, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 4, 3, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prchistoric Antiquities,'' 283.</ref>

धान्य
<u>'''Dhānya'''</u> (neut.), a derivative from the preceding word,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1438> Primarily as an adjective, ‘consisting of grain.’</ref> denotes ‘grain’ in general. It is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1438> vi. 13, 4.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1438> Av. iii. 24, 2. 4;<br> v. 29, 7;<br> vi. 50, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 8;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, etc.</ref> According to the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_1438> vi. 3, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> there are ten cultivated (''grāmyāṇi'') kinds of grain: rice and barley (''vrīhiyavāḥ''), sesamum and beans (''tila-māṣāḥ''), Panicum Miliaceum and Italicum (''[[अणु|aṇu]]-priyaṅgavaḥ''), maize (''godhūmāḥ''), lentils (''masūrāḥ''), Khalvāḥ and Dolichos uniflorus (''[[खल|khala]]-kulāḥ''). The  horse is called ‘corn-eating’ (''dhānyāda'') in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1438> viii. 21.</ref> and Śatapatha<ref name=fx6_ve1_1438> xiii. 5, 4, 2.</ref> Brāhmaṇas, and men are mentioned as ‘purifying corn’ (''dhānyā-kṛt'') in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1438> x. 94, 13.</ref>(**  7 Lit., ‘preparing corn.’

धान्व
<u>'''Dhānva'''</u> is the patronymic of '''[[असित|Asita]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1439> xiii. 4, 3, 11;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7.</ref> In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1439> xvi. 2, 20.</ref> the form of the name is Dhānvana.

धामन्
<u>'''Dhāman'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1440> i. 144, 1;<br> ii. 3, 2;<br> iii. 55, 10;<br> vii. 61, 4;<br> 87, 2;<br> x. 13, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1440> Av. iv. 25, 7;<br> vii. 68, 1;<br> xii. 1, 52;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 34;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 7, 2.</ref> ‘dwelling’ and ‘house,’ or sometimes<ref name=fx3_ve1_1440> Rv. viii. 101, 6;<br> ix. 63, 14;<br> x. 82, 3;<br> Av. ii. 14, 6. Many of the examples given in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v., C,'' are doubtful.</ref> its inmates. The word is also<ref name=fx4_ve1_1440> Rv. iv. 55, 2;<br> vi. 21, 3;<br> vii. 63, 3;<br> viii. 41, 10;<br> x. 48, 11.</ref> found in the sense of ‘ordinance,’ ‘law,’ expressing much the same as '''Dharman,''' especially in conjunction<ref name=fx5_ve1_1440> Rv. i. 123, 9;<br> iv. 7, 7;<br> vii. 36, 5;<br> x. 124, 3.</ref> with Rta, ‘eternal order.’ Hillebrandt<ref name=fx6_ve1_1440> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 446.</ref> sees in one passage<ref name=fx7_ve1_1440> Rv. ix. 66, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 92, 93.</ref> the sense of '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''

धारा
<u>'''Dhārā'''</u> denotes the ‘edge’ of a weapon,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1441> Rv. vi. 3, 5;<br> 47, 10. ''Cf.'' viii. 73, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 38, 1, for metaphorical applications.</ref> as of an axe (''[[स्वधिति|svadhiti]]''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_1441> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 44.</ref> or of a razor (''[[क्षुर|kṣura]]'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_1441> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 3, 2.</ref> See also '''Asi.'''

धिषणा
<u>'''Dhiṣaṇā,'''</u> according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, denotes<ref name=fx1_ve1_1442> Rv. i. 96, 1;<br> 102, 1;<br> 109, 3, 4;<br> iii. 49, 1;<br> iv. 34, 1;<br> 36, 8;<br> viii. 61, 9;<br> ix. 59, 2;<br> x. 17, 12;<br> 30, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 19;<br> vi. 26, 35, etc.</ref> an implement used in preparing the Soma, ‘bowl’ or ‘vat,’ and by metonymy also the Soma draught itself.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1442> Rv. i. 102, 7;<br> iii. 32, 14;<br> 49, 4;<br> vi. 19, 2;<br> vii. 90, 3;<br> viii. 15, 7;<br> x. 96, 10, etc.</ref> The dual, by  a metaphor,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1442> Like '''[[चमू|Camū]].'''</ref> also expresses the ‘two worlds,’ heaven and earth.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1442> Rv. i. 160, 1;<br> vi. 8, 3;<br> 50, 3;<br> 70, 3;<br> x. 44, 8;<br> in the plural, ‘the three worlds,’ Rv. v. 69, 2. In other passages, Rv. i. 22, 10;<br> iii. 56, 6;<br> v. 41, 8;<br> vi. 11, 3;<br> x. 35, 7, the sense of ‘a genius of prosperity’ was assigned to [[धिषणा|Dhiṣaṇā]] by Roth.</ref> Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1442> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 175-181.</ref> however, thinks that the word properly means earth,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1442> Rv. i. 22, 10;<br> 96, 1;<br> 102, 1;<br> iii. 31, 13;<br> 56, 6;<br> vi. 19, 2;<br> vii. 90, 3;<br> viii. 15, 7;<br> x. 30, 6;<br> 35, 7;<br> 96, 10.</ref> in the dual heaven and earth,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1442> See n. 3;<br> also Rv. viii. 61, 2;<br> ''[[निविद्|nivid]]'' in Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 19, 4.</ref> in the plural the triad, earth, atmosphere, and heaven,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1442> Rv. iv. 36, 8;<br> v. 69, 2;<br> ix. 59, 2.</ref> while in some passages<ref name=fx9_ve1_1442> Rv. i. 109, 3, 4;<br> iii. 2, 1;<br> 49, 4 (or perhaps ‘earth’);<br> iv. 34, 1;<br> v. 41, 8;<br> vi. 11, 3;<br> x. 17, 12.</ref> [[धिषणा|Dhiṣaṇā]] denotes the Vedi, the excavated ground used as an altar. This is not, however, certain, while it seems clear that the Vājasaneyi<ref name=fx10_ve1_1442> vii. 26.</ref> and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]<ref name=fx11_ve1_1442> iii. 1, 10, 1.</ref> Saṃhitās understand the Dhiṣaṇās (dual) to be the planks over which the pressing of the Soma took place (''[[अधिषवण|adhiṣavaṇa]]-phalake'').<ref name=fx12_ve1_1442> Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vii. 26;<br> Sāyaṇa on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> Pischel<ref name=fx13_ve1_1442> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 82-87. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 124;<br> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 120-122.</ref> sees in [[धिषणा|Dhiṣaṇā]] a goddess of wealth akin to Aditi and the earth.

धी
<u>'''Dhī,'''</u> ‘thought,’ is used several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1443> i. 3, 5;<br> 135, 5;<br> 151, 6;<br> 185, 8;<br> ii. 3, 8 (where it is connected with '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''');<br> 40, 5, etc.</ref> to denote the ‘prayer’ or ‘hymn of praise’ of the singer. One poet speaks of himself as ‘weaving’ such a prayer,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1443> Rv. ii. 28, 5.</ref> while another refers to his ‘ancient ancestral hymn,’ which he refurbishes presumably for use.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1443> Rv. iii. 39, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 338.</ref>

धीति
<u>'''Dhīti'''</u> has in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1444> i. 110, 1;<br> iii. 12, 7;<br> 52, 6;<br> v. 25, 3;<br> 53, 11;<br> vi. 15, 9, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 24.</ref> practically the same sense as '''[[धी|Dhī]],''' ‘prayer,’ or ‘hymn of praise.’

धीर शात-पर्णेय
<u>'''Dhīra Śāta-parṇeya'''</u> (‘descendant of Śataparṇa’) is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 3, 3, 1) as a pupil of '''[[महाशाल|Mahāśāla]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

धीवन्
<u>'''Dhīvan'''</u> occurs in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1446> iii. 5, 6.</ref> where it may either be taken with Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1446> St. Petersbuig Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Bloomfield,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1446> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 114.</ref> and Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve1_1446> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 114.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indīsche Studien,'' 17, 194 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 252.</ref> as an epithet of ‘chariot-builders’ (''[[रथ|ratha]]-kārāḥ''), meaning ‘clever,’ or be construed with the scholiast as denoting ‘fishermen’ (''dhīvara''). The Paippalāda recension has ''takṣāṇaḥ,'' ‘carpenters.’

धुङ्क्षा
<u>'''Dhuṅkṣā'''</u> is the name of some sort of bird in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1447> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 31. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> See also '''[[धूङ्क्ष्णा|Dhūṅkṣṇā]]''' and '''[[ध्वाङ्क्ष|Dhvāṅkṣa]].'''

धुनि
<u>'''Dhuni'''</u> is the name of a foe of Indra, normally mentioned along with '''[[चुमुरि|Cumuri]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1448> ii. 15, 9;<br> vi. 18, 8;<br> 20, 13;<br> vii. 19, 4.</ref> He and [[चुमुरि|Cumuri]] seem to have been opposed to '''[[दभीति|Dabhīti]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1448> Rv. x. 113. 9.</ref> His name is probably that of an aboriginal chief.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1448> Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, xxii;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 162. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 157, 158.</ref>

धुर्
<u>'''Dhur'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1449> i. 84, 16;<br> 100, 16;<br> 134, 3;<br> 164, 19;<br> ii. 18, 7;<br> iii. 35, 2;<br> v. 55. 6;<br> vii. 34, 4, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1449> Av. v. 17, 18;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] vi. 18;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2 10;<br> 4, 4, 13, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka i. 5, 2 (the Dhur is the end), etc.</ref> denotes, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, that part of the yoke which is placed on the shoulders of the animals drawing the chariot or cart, whence they are called ''dhūr-ṣāh,'' ‘yoke-bearing,’ in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1449> iv. 33. ''Cf.'' '''Uara.'''</ref> In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1449> v. 43. 8.</ref> the sense is uncertain: Roth<ref name=fx5_ve1_1449> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' 2.</ref> takes it to mean the pin at either end of the axle ('''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]''') which goes through the nave of the wheel, and would thus be equivalent to '''[[आणि|Āṇi]],''' and Oldenberg<ref name=fx6_ve1_1449> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 339;<br> Griffith. ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 508. The ''akṣadhurau'' are mentioned in the Āpastamba Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xi. 6, 5;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 3, 22. ''Cf.'' Caland and Henry. ''L'Agniṣṭoma,'' 31.</ref>  seems to adopt the same view. Monier Williams<ref name=fx7_ve1_1449> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> seems to think that ‘load’ is meant, but this is not probable. It is possible that Dhur has the sense of ‘pole,’<ref name=fx8_ve1_1449> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 246. Later, the word means the ‘end of the pole,’ a sense already found in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka (n. 2). This modification of meaning seems to be due to the fact that the yoke is at the end of the pole. See also '''[[धूर्षद्|Dhūrṣad]].'''</ref> and then more generally still the pole and the axle together regarded as the drawing part of the chariot: this might explain the use in the doubtful passage of the Rigveda.

धूङ्क्ष्णा
<u>'''Dhūṅkṣṇā'''</u> is the form in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1450> v. 5, 19, 1. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93, gives the form as Dhūṅkṣṇa. perhaps in error. ''Cf.'' also '''[[ध्वाङ्क्ष|Dhvāṅkṣa]].'''</ref> of the name of the bird elsewhere found as '''[[धुङ्क्षा|Dhuṅkṣā]].''' It is glossed as ‘white crow’ (''śveta-kākī'').

धूम-केतु
<u>'''Dhūma-ketu,'''</u> ‘smoke-bannered,’ is an epithet of [[मृत्यु|Mṛtyu]], ‘death,’ in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1451> xix. 9, 10.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve1_1451> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 358.</ref> thinks that a comet is meant, but Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve1_1451> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 914.</ref> considers this extremely improbable. Lanman<ref name=fx4_ve1_1451> ''Ibid.''</ref> plausibly suggests that the smoke of the funeral pile is referred to.

धूम्र
<u>'''Dhūmra'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (i. 8, 21, 1) denotes ‘camel’ according to Bo7htlingk's Dictionary.<br>==Foot Notes==

धूर्-षद्
<u>'''Dhūr-ṣad'''</u> means, according to Roth,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1453> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> ‘standing under the yoke’ and so ‘burden-bearing,’ and thus metaphorically ‘promoting,’ in the passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1453> i. 143, 7;<br> ii. 2, 1;<br> 34, 4 (but ''cf.'' Pischel. ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 301). In x. 132, 7, Roth renders ‘resting on the yoke.’</ref> where it occurs. More probable, however, is the view<ref name=fx3_ve1_1453> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 237 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 195.</ref> that it means ‘sitting on the pole,’ that is, ‘charioteer,’ with reference to the fact that  to get near his horses the charioteer might well go forward and sit on the pole or even on the yoke.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1453> ''Cf.'' Mahābhārata, viii. 617: ''dhuryān dhuryagatān sūtān.''</ref>

धृत-राष्ट्र
<u>'''1. Dhṛta-rāṣṭra'''</u> (‘having his kingdom firmly established’) is the name of a snake demon with the patronymic '''[[ऐरावत|Airāvata]],''' ‘descendant of '''Irāvant,'''’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1454> viii. 10, 29.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1454> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 26, 15;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17. 257.</ref>

धृतराष्ट्र वैचित्र-वीर्य
<u>'''2. Dhṛtarāṣṭra Vaicitra-vīrya'''</u> (‘descendant of Vicitravīrya’) is mentioned in a passage of the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1455> x. 6. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 469 ''et seq.''</ref> which is, unhappily, far from intelligible. But there is no ground for supposing that he was a Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] king; he seems rather to have lived at some distance from the KuruPañcālas. There is no good reason to deny his identity<ref name=fx2_ve1_1455> As does Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 90, 114, 125;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 7, 8. Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' treats them as identical.</ref> with the [[धृतराष्ट्र|Dhṛtarāṣṭra]] of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1455> xiii. 5, 4, 22.</ref> king of '''[[काशि|Kāśi]],''' who was defeated, when he attempted to offer a horse sacrifice, by '''[[सात्राजित|Sātrājita]] Śatānīka.''' The fact that the latter was a '''[[भरत|Bharata]]''' also points to Dhṛtarāṣṭra's not having been a Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] at all.
