In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā he appears as having a dispute with '''Vaka [[दाल्भि|Dālbhi]];''' but even assuming that the latter was a [[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]], there is nothing to hint that the former was a Kuru or that this dispute is a sign of an early hostility of Kuru and [[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1455> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 831 ''et seq.'' This argument is independent of the identification of the two Dhṛtarāṣṭras, but is confirmed by it.</ref> It is true that in the Epic '''Śantanu''' and Vicitravīrya and [[धृतराष्ट्र|Dhṛtarāṣṭra]] himself are all connected, but this connexion seems to be due, as so often in the Epic, to a confused derangement of great figures of the past.

धृष्टि
<u>'''Dhṛṣṭi,'''</u> found in the dual in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1456> v. 9, 8.</ref> the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1456> xiv. 3, 1, 22.</ref> and the Sūtras,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1456> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxvi. 2, 10, etc.</ref> seems to denote ‘firetongs.’ 

धेना
<u>'''Dhenā'''</u> denotes a ‘milch cow,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1457> Rv. iii. 34, 3 (Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 61);<br> v. 62, 2. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 114.</ref> or in the plural, ‘draughts of milk.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1457> Rv. iii. 1, 9;<br> iv. 58, 6, etc.</ref> In two passages<ref name=fx3_ve1_1457> i. 101, 10;<br> v. 30, 9.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx4_ve1_1457> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> takes the word to mean ‘mare,’ and in another the ‘team’ of Vāyu's chariot. Benfey,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1457> ''Orient und Occident,'' 3, 130.</ref> on the other hand, renders it ‘lips’ in one passage,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1457> Rv. i. 101. 10.</ref> with Sāyaṇa and with Durga's commentary on the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx8_ve1_1457> vi. 17. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 249.</ref> Geldner<ref name=fx9_ve1_1457> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 35-43;<br> 166;<br> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 95.</ref> assigns to the word the senses of ‘lips,’<ref name=fx10_ve1_1457> Rv. i. 101. 10;<br> iii. 1, 9.</ref> ‘speech,’<ref name=fx11_ve1_1457> Rv. iv. 58, 6;<br> i. 55, 4;<br> 141, 1;<br> viii. 32, 22;<br> x. 104, 3. 10.</ref> ‘cow,’<ref name=fx12_ve1_1457> Rv. v. 62, 2, and Vāyu's cow of plenty, i. 2, 3.</ref> ‘beloved,’<ref name=fx13_ve1_1457> Rv. v. 30, 9.</ref> and ‘streams.’<ref name=fx14_ve1_1457> Rv. vii. 21, 3;<br> iii. 34, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 441, 442.</ref>(**  5) Rv. i. 2, 3.

धेनु
<u>'''Dhenu'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1458> i. 32, 9 (''saha-vatsā,'' ‘with her calf’);<br> 134, 4;<br> ii. 2, 2;<br> 34, 8;<br> vi. 135, 8, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1458> Av. v. 17, 18;<br> vii. 104. 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 2, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 27;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 1, 21, etc.</ref> means ‘milch cow,’ which is often mentioned with special reference to the production of milk,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1458> Rv. vii. 33. 22;<br> viii. 14, 3;<br> Av. iv. 34, 8 (''kāma-[[दुघा|dughā]],'' ‘milking desires,’ the later ‘cow of plenty’ of the Epic);<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 2, 2.</ref> and is contrasted with the ‘bull’ (''[[वृषभ|vṛṣabha]],''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1458> Rv. x. 5, 7.</ref> ''[[पुमांस्|pumāṃs]],''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1458> Av. xi. 1, 34.</ref> ''[[अनड्वाह्|anaḍvāh]]'').<ref name=fx6_ve1_1458> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 27;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 2, 21.</ref> In the plural<ref name=fx7_ve1_1458> Rv. iv. 22, 6;<br> viii. 2, 6;<br> 4, 8;<br> ix. 61, 21;<br> 72, 1, etc.</ref> the word denotes ‘draughts of milk.’ The derivative, ''dhenukā,'' means merely ‘female.’<ref name=fx8_ve1_1458> Av. iii. 23, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]. xxv. 10, 23;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 6, etc.</ref>

धेनु-ष्टरी
<u>'''Dhenu-ṣṭarī'''</u> in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] (xiii. 6) and Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (ii. 5, 4) denotes a cow which has ceased to give milk.<br>==Foot Notes==

धैवर
<u>'''Dhaivara'''</u> means a ‘fisherman,’ as a member of a caste,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1460> This seems to be shown by the patronymic form, ‘descendant of a ''dhīvara.''’</ref> in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or ‘human sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1460> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16;<br> Tait tirīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 15, 1.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Dhīvara.''' 

ध्मातृ
<u>'''Dhmātṛ'''</u> (lit. ‘blower’) occurs twice in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1461> v. 9. 5.</ref> in the two forms, ''dhmātā,'' nom. ‘smelter,’ and ''dhmātarī,'' which, according to the Padapāṭha, stands for ''dhmātari,'' a locative probably meaning ‘in the smelting furnace.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1461> Macdonell, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1893, 446.</ref> Geldner,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1461> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 146, n, 1.</ref> Bartholomae,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1461> ''Indogermanische Forschungen,'' 1, 496. n. 2.</ref> and Oldenburg<ref name=fx5_ve1_1461> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 388.</ref> regard the latter form as a locative infinitive, ‘in the smelting.’ Ludwig<ref name=fx6_ve1_1461> ''Infinitiv im Veda,'' 9;<br> Translation of the Rigveda, 4, 334.</ref> and Neisser<ref name=fx7_ve1_1461> Bezzenberger's ''Beitrāge,'' 20, 40.</ref> think ''dhmātarī'' is a nom. sing. masc. used in the same sense as ''dhmātā.'' Smelting is also clearly referred to,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1461> Rv. iv. 2, 17. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 3. 5, '''Ayas''' is smelted from the ore (''aśman''), and gold from the Ayas.</ref> and the smelter is described as using the wings of birds (''[[पर्ण|parṇa]] śakunānām'') to fan the flame.<ref name=fx9_ve1_1461> Rv. ix. 112, 2.</ref> That the art was widely applied is shown by the fact that reference is made to arrows with points of '''Ayas,'''<ref name=fx10_ve1_1461> ''Cf.'' '''Īṣu.'''</ref> to kettles which were fashioned of the same metal and could be placed upon a fire,<ref name=fx11_ve1_1461> Rv. v. 30, 15.</ref> and to Soma cups of beaten Ayas.<ref name=fx12_ve1_1461> Rv. ix. 1, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 252;<br> Schrader, ''Prchistoric Antiquities,'' 159.</ref>

ध्राजि
<u>'''Dhrāji'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1462> i. 164. 44;<br> x. 97, 13;<br> 136, 2.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1462> Av. iii. 1, 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 2, 17;<br> iv. 9, 5 [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i 11, 19, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘sweep’ of the wind, referring no doubt to the violent gales which often blow in India devastating the forests, and which figure in the descriptions of the Maruts, or storm gods.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1462> ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' xxxii. xxiii ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell. ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 79.</ref>

ध्रुव
<u>'''Dhruva'''</u> in the Sūtras<ref name=fx1_ve1_1463> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 7, 22;<br> Sāṅkhāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 17, 2 ''et seq.;<br>'' Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 3, 6, etc. It is to be noted that the marriage Mantras, of which we have a great many, do not include any reference to the [[ध्रुव|Dhruva]];<br> but it is not possible to say definitely whether the practice is really an old one or not</ref> denotes the pole star, being mentioned in connexion with the marriage ritual, in which the star is pointed out to the bride as an emblem of constancy. In the  Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1463> See Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 15, 289;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 396.</ref> a late work, the movement of the [[ध्रुव|Dhruva]] (''dhruvasya pracalanam'') is mentioned, but this can hardly be interpreted as referring to an actual observed motion of the nominal pole star,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1463> As understood by Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 98, n. 103;<br> Bühler, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 23, 245, n. 21;<br> Jacobi, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 228, n. 2.</ref> but rather to an extraordinary event, such as a destruction of the world, as Cowell understood the expression.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1463> In his edition of the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], p. 244.</ref> Jacobi<ref name=fx5_ve1_1463> ''Indian Antiquary,'' 23, 157;<br> ''Zeitschrift, loc. cit.,'' 50, 69 ''et seq.;<br> Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 721 ''et seq.;<br>'' 1910, 461 ''et seq.''</ref> sees in the motion of the [[ध्रुव|Dhruva]] the possibility of fixing a date, on the ground that the only star which could have been deemed a pole star, as ‘immovable,’ was one (''a'' Draconis) of the third millenium B.C. But this attempt to extract chronology from the name of the star is of very doubtful validity.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1463> Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, xc;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 1102;<br> 1910, 465 ''et seq.''</ref>

ध्रुवा
<u>'''Dhruvā,'''</u> ‘fixed,’ as an epithet of '''[[दिश्|Diś]],''' ‘cardinal point,’ denotes the ground under one's feet.(**  1) Av. iii. 27, 5; xii. 3, 59; xv. 6, 1; [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 14 (''cf.'' '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]]'''); Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 9, 25, etc.<br>==Foot Notes==

ध्वज
<u>'''Dhvaja'''</u> occurs twice in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1465> vii. 85, 2;<br> x. 103, 11. In Epic warfare banners are of vast importance -''e.g.,'' Rāmāyaṇa, ii. 67, 26;<br> they were attached to a pole on the chariot, Mahabhārata, vii. 3332, etc. The army was called ''dhvajinī,'' ‘bannered host,’ ''ibid.,'' i. 2875, etc.</ref> in the sense of ‘banner’ used in battle. It is characteristic of Vedic fighting that in both passages reference is made to arrows being discharged and falling on the banners.

ध्वन्य
<u>'''Dhvanya'''</u> is apparently the name of a patron, son of '''Lakṣmaṇa,''' in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1466> v. 33, 10. ''Cf.'' Ludwig Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155.</ref> 

ध्वसन् द्वैत-वन
<u>'''Dhvasan Dvaita-vana'''</u> (‘descendant of Dvitavana’) is the name in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1467> xiii. 5, 4, 9. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 211;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 6.</ref> of the king of the '''Matsyas''' who celebrated an [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice,’ near the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].'''

ध्वसन्ति
<u>'''Dhvasanti'''</u> is in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1468> i. 112, 23.</ref> mentioned together with '''[[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]]''' as having been aided by the Aśvins. There can be no doubt that this is the longer form of the name '''[[ध्वस्र|Dhvasra]],''' which is found with [[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]] both in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1468> ix. 58. 3 = Sv. ii. 409.</ref> and in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1468> xiii. 7, 12 (where the dual of [[ध्वस्र|Dhvasra]] appears as a feminine ''Dhvasre'').<br><br>''Cf.'' Sieg. ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 62, 63;<br> Benfey, ''[[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]],'' 105, 126, who is inclined to think that [[ध्वसन्ति|Dhvasanti]] and [[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]] are names of women.</ref>

ध्वस्र
<u>'''Dhvasra'''</u> is named with '''[[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1469> xiii. 7, 12. ''Cf.'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 139;<br> Sāṭyāyanaka, ''apud'' Sāyaṇa, on Rv. ix. 58, 3.</ref> as giving gifts to '''[[तरन्त|Taranta]]''' and '''Purumīḍha.''' These two, being kings, could not<ref name=fx2_ve1_1469> [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra, x. 75, 77.</ref> properly accept gifts which Brāhmaṇas alone could accept, but by becoming authors of a verse of the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1469> ix. 58, 3.</ref> they qualified themselves to accept them. The verse mentions the names in the dual as ''Dhvasrayoḥ Puruṣantyoḥ,'' ‘from the two, [[ध्वस्र|Dhvasra]] and [[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]].’<ref name=fx4_ve1_1469> Both words are in the dual, as if they were members of a Dvandva compound. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 261.</ref> In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1469> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> the names occur in the dual as ''Dhvasre Puruṣantī,'' a reading which is confirmed by the [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx6_ve1_1469> ix. 9.</ref> The former is necessarily a feminine form, though Sāyaṇa, in his comment on the passage, explains it as really an irregular masculine. According to Roth,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1469> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[ध्वस्र|dhvasra]].''</ref> the feminine is a corruption based on the dual form in the verse of the Rigveda mentioned above; but the names may be those of women,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1469> The first would in that case be Dhvasrā.</ref> as Benfey<ref name=fx9_ve1_1469> ''[[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]],'' 105. 126, under [[ध्वसन्ति|Dhvasanti]] and [[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]].</ref>  inclines to believe. Weber<ref name=fx10_ve1_1469> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 27, n. 1.</ref> suggests that the two were demons, but this is, as Sieg<ref name=fx11_ve1_1469> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 62, 63.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139;<br> Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 39;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 360, points out that the sense of the Rīgveda passage is quite uncertain, and that the two, [[तरन्त|Taranta]] and [[पुरुमीळ्ह|Purumīḷha]], as they appear in Rv. v. 61, are rather donors than receivers (see, however, verse 9, ''Purumīṭhāya viprāva''). See also Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 232;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noteu,'' 1, 354.</ref> shows, quite unnecessary. [[ध्वस्र|Dhvasra]] is no doubt identical with '''[[ध्वसन्ति|Dhvasanti]].'''

ध्वाङ्क्ष
<u>'''Dhvāṅkṣa,'''</u> ‘crow,’ is mentioned twice in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1470> xi. 9, 9;<br> xii. 4, 8.</ref> and in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1470> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] xxv. 6, 9. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 88.</ref> Possibly the same bird is meant by the words '''[[धुङ्क्षा|Dhuṅkṣā]]''' and '''Dhūṅksnā.'''

ध्वान्त
<u>'''Dhvānta'''</u> is the name of some wind in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1471> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 7, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxix. 7.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1471> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 16, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 24, 1;<br> 25, 1.</ref>

नकुल
<u>'''Nakula,'''</u> ‘ichneumon,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1472> vi. 139, 5.</ref> as being able to cut a snake in two and then join it up again. Its knowledge<ref name=fx2_ve1_1472> Av. viii. 7, 23.</ref> of a remedy against snake poison is also mentioned. The animal figures in the list of sacrificial victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1472> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1;<br> 21, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 26. 2;<br> Maītrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 7 In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 18, 1;<br> [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]] Prātiśākhya, xvii. 9, ''[[नकुल|nakula]]'' denotes a colour--no doubt that of the ichneumon.</ref> 

नक्त
<u>'''Nakta,'''</u> ‘night,’ is found frequently in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1473> i. 13, 7;<br> 73, 7;<br> 96, 5;<br> vii. 2, 6;<br> x. 70, 6;<br> adverbially, i. 24, 10;<br> 90, 7;<br> v. 76, 3;<br> vii. 15, 15;<br> 104, 17;<br> viii. 96, 1.</ref> and sometimes later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1473> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 4, 2, adverbially, Av. vi. 128, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 4, 2;<br> xiii. 1, 5, 5, etc.</ref> usually in the adverbial form ''naktaṃ,'' ‘by night’

नक्षत्र
<u>'''Nakṣatra'''</u> is a word of obscure origin and derivation. The Indian interpreters already show a great divergence of opinion as to its primary meaning. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1474> ii. 1, 2, 18. 19. ''Cf.'' a citation in [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 20.</ref> resolves it into ''na-[[क्षत्र|kṣatra]]'' (‘no power’), explaining it by a legend. The [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1474> ''Loc. cit.,'' and ''of.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> refers it to the root ''nakṣ,'' ‘obtain,’ following the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1474> i. 5, 2, 5.</ref> Aufrecht<ref name=fx4_ve1_1474> Kuhn's ''Zeitschrift,'' 8, 71, 72. So Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 288, n. 2.</ref> and Weber<ref name=fx5_ve1_1474> ''Naxatra,'' 2, 268.</ref> derived it from ''[[नक्त|nakta]]-tra,'' ‘guardian of night,’ and more recently<ref name=fx6_ve1_1474> Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 74. line 8.</ref> the derivation from ''nak-[[क्षत्र|kṣatra]],'' ‘having rule over night,’ seems to be gaining acceptance. The generic meaning of the word therefore seems to be ‘star.’<br><br>''The Nakṣatras as Stars in the Rigveda and Later.''--The sense of ‘star’ appears to be adequate for all or nearly all the passages in which [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] occurs in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1474> See i. 50, 2;<br> vii. 86, 1;<br> x. 68, 11;<br> 111, 7;<br> used of the sun itself, vi. 67, 6 (as masculine);<br> vii. 81, 2;<br> x. 88, 13. The sun is allied with them, iii. 54, 19. ''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]-[[शवस्|śavas]],'' ‘equalling the multitude of the stars,’ is used as an epithet in x. 21, 10. Even in x. 85, 2, where Soma, on the lap of the Nakṣatras, is mentioned, ‘stars’ would do;<br> but, as this hymn refers to two of the later Nakṣatras, ‘lunar mansions’ may well be meant.</ref> The same sense occurs in the later Saṃhitās also: the sun and the Nakṣatras are mentioned together,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1474> Av. vi. 10, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 43;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], x. 1, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 10, 12.</ref> or the sun, the moon, and the Nakṣatras,<ref name=fx9_ve1_1474> Av. vi. 128, 3;<br> xv. 6, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 13, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 29, etc.</ref> or the moon and the Nakṣatras,<ref name=fx10_ve1_1474> Av. v. 24, 10;<br> vi. 86, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 5, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxv. 15;<br> xxxvii. 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 21;<br> xxxix. 2, etc.</ref> or the Nakṣatras alone;<ref name=fx11_ve1_1474> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 2, 2, 2;<br> ii 6, 2, 6, etc;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 21 etc.;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], v. 5, and very often elsewhere.</ref>  but there is no necessity to attribute to the word the sense of ‘lunar mansion’ in these passages.<br><br>On the other hand, the names of at least three of the Nakṣatras in the later sense occur in the Rigveda. [[तिष्य|Tiṣya]],<ref name=fx12_ve1_1474> Rv. v. 59, 13;<br> x. 64, 8;<br> Weber, 2, 290.</ref> however, does not seem to be mentioned as a lunar mansion. With '''Aghās''' (plur.) and '''[[अर्जुनी|Arjunī]]''' (dual)<ref name=fx13_ve1_1474> x. 85, 13;<br> Weber, 364-367, and see references under '''[[अघा|Aghā]]''' and '''[[अर्जुनी|Arjunī]].'''</ref> the case is different: it seems probable that they are the later lunar mansions called [[मघास्|Maghās]] (plur.) and [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]] (dual). The names appear to have been deliberately changed in the Rigveda, and it must be remembered that the hymn in which they occur, the wedding hymn of Sūryā, has no claim to great age.<ref name=fx14_ve1_1474> ''Cf.'' Arnold, ''Vedic Metre,'' 322.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx15_ve1_1474> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 184 ''et seq.''</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx16_ve1_1474> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 354. ''Cf.'' Tilak, ''Orion,'' 158.</ref> have seen other references to the Nakṣatras as 27 in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx17_ve1_1474> i. 162, 18 (the 34 ribs of the horse = moon, sun, 5 planets, 27 Nakṣatras);<br> x. 55, 3 (34 lights).</ref> but these seem most improbable. Nor do the adjectives ''[[रेवती|revatī]]'' (‘rich’) and ''punarvasā'' (‘bringing wealth again’) in another hymn<ref name=fx18_ve1_1474> x. 19, 1.</ref> appear to refer to the Nakṣatras.<br><br>''The Nakṣatras as Lunar Mansions.''--In several passages of the later Saṃhitās the connexion of the moon and the Nakṣatras is conceived of as a marriage union. Thus in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx19_ve1_1474> xi. 3 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 467).</ref> and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx20_ve1_1474> ii. 3, 5, 1-3. ''Cf.'' also iii. 4, 7. 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xviii. 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 40;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4, 1, 9;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12. The dwelling of the moon in a [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] is mentioned, Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5, 4, 17;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 21;<br> a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 135;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 11, 6;<br> v. 12, 1, etc.</ref> it is expressly stated that Soma was wedded to the mansions, but dwelt only with [[रोहिणी|Rohiṇī]]; the others being angry, he had ultimately to undertake to live with them all equally. Weber<ref name=fx21_ve1_1474> ''Op. cit.,'' 277. ''Cf.'' the later system of the Siddhāntas, Whitney, ''Oriental and Linguistic Studies,'' 2, 372, and see Tilak, ''Orion,'' 33 ''et seq.''</ref> hence deduced that the Nakṣatras were regarded as of equal extent, but this is to press the texts unduly, except in the sense of approximate equality. The number of the mansions is not stated as 27 in the story told in the two Saṃhitās: the Taittīriya has 33, and the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] no  number; but 27 appears as their number in the list which is found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx22_ve1_1474> iv. 4, 10, 1-3.</ref> and elsewhere.<ref name=fx23_ve1_1474> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxix. 13, but Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 13, 20, has 28;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 1, 1-5, in lists of Nakṣatras. See also Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5, 4, 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiii, 23;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, ii. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 2, 2;<br> [[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]], 18. 20 (verse 34 has 28, but it is interpolated);<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 78, etc.</ref> The number 28 is much less well attested: in one passage of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx24_ve1_1474> i. 5, 2, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, 1, 360, n.</ref> [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]] is practically marked as a new comer, though in a later book,<ref name=fx25_ve1_1474> iii. 1, 2, 6.</ref> in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx26_ve1_1474> ii. 13, 20.</ref> and in the Atharvaveda list,<ref name=fx27_ve1_1474> xix. 7, 1;<br> 8, 1 = Nakṣatrakalpa, 10. 26. So in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 26.</ref> it has found acceptance. It is perfectly possible that 28 is the earlier number, and that [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]] dropped out because it was faint, or too far north, or because 27 was a more mystic (3×3×3) number: it is significant that the Chinese Sieou and the Arabic Manāzil are 28 in number.<ref name=fx28_ve1_1474> Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 409-411;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 8, 390.</ref> Weber,<ref name=fx29_ve1_1474> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 280;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 446;<br> 10, 223, 224, 226, 227.</ref> however, believes that 27 is the older number in India.<br><br>The meaning of the number is easily explained when it is remembered that a periodic month occupies something between 27 and 28 days, more nearly the former number. Such a month is in fact recognized in the Lāṭyāyana<ref name=fx30_ve1_1474> iv. 8, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> and [[निदान|Nidāna]] Sūtras<ref name=fx31_ve1_1474> v. 11. 12. See Weber, 2, 281288.</ref> as consisting of 27 days, 12 months making a year of 324 days, a [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] year, or with an intercalary month, a year of 351 days. The [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx32_ve1_1474> Thibaut, ''Astronomic, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 7.</ref> makes an attempt to introduce the [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] reckoning into the civil or solar (''sāvana'') year of 360 days, for it holds that the sun spends 13(1/3) days in each [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] (13(1/3)×27 = 360). But the month of 27 or 28 days plays no part in the chronological calculations of the Veda.<ref name=fx33_ve1_1474> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''</ref><br><br>''The Names of the Nakṣatras.''--In addition to the two mentioned in the Rigveda, the earlier Atharvaveda<ref name=fx34_ve1_1474> ''l. e.,'' books i. xvi.</ref> gives the  names of [[ज्येष्ठघ्नी|Jyeṣṭhaghnī]]<ref name=fx35_ve1_1474> vi. 110, 2. This constellation, ‘the slayer of the oldest,’ was apparently of evil omen. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 2, 8. Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 361, equates it with Antares or Cor Scorpionis, with or without , Scorpionis (Jyaīṣṭhaghnī is a misreading in the edition of Whitney and Roth).</ref> (the later [[ज्येष्ठा|Jyeṣṭhā]]) and [[विचृतौ|Vicṛtau]],<ref name=fx36_ve1_1474> vi. 110, 2. It is also mentioned in ii. 8, 1;<br> iii. 7, 4;<br> vi. 121, 3. It is identified by the commentators with [[मूल|Mūla]], ‘the root,’ the two stars,  and Scorpionis, which form the sting of the Scorpion's tail;<br> Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 48.</ref> which are mentioned as in close connexion, and of Revatīs (plural) and [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]].<ref name=fx37_ve1_1474> ix. 7, 3.</ref> With reference to possible times for the ceremony of the Agnyādhāna, or ‘laying of the sacred fires,’ the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx38_ve1_1474> viii. 1.</ref> the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx39_ve1_1474> i. 6, 9.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx40_ve1_1474> i. 1, 2, 1-6.</ref> mention the Nakṣatras called [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]], [[रोहिणी|Rohiṇī]], Phalgunyas, [[हस्त|Hasta]]; the latter [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] adds [[पुनर्वसू|Punarvasū]], and in an additional remark<ref name=fx41_ve1_1474> i. 1, 2, 8.</ref> excludes Pūrve [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]] in favour of Uttare [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]]. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx42_ve1_1474> ii. 1, 2, 1.</ref> adds [[मृगशीर्ष|Mṛgaśīrṣa]] and [[चित्रा|Citrā]] as possibilities. On the other hand, [[पुनर्वसू|Punarvasū]] is recommended by all authorities<ref name=fx43_ve1_1474> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 1, 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 7, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 15;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 2, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3.</ref> as suitable for the Punarādheya, ‘relaying of the sacred fires,’ which takes place if the first fire has failed to effect the aim of its existence, the prosperity of the sacrificer.<ref name=fx44_ve1_1474> Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 109.</ref> The [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx45_ve1_1474> viii. 15;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā. i. 7, 2.</ref> however, allows Anurādhās also.<br><br>In the ceremony of the Agnicayana, or ‘piling of the firealtar,’ the bricks are assumed to be equal in number to the Nakṣatras. The bricks number 756, and they are equated to 27 Nakṣatras multiplied by 27 secondary Nakṣatras, reckoned as 720 (instead of 729), with the addition of 36 days, the length of an intercalary month. Nothing can be usefully derived from this piece of priestly nonsense.<ref name=fx46_ve1_1474> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5, 4, 5. See Weber, 2, 298, with whom Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 42, 383, n. 1, concurs. For a wild speculation, see Shamasastry, ''Gavam ayana,'' 122 ''et seq.''</ref> But in connexion with this ceremony the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx47_ve1_1474> Taittiriya Samhitā, iv. 4, 10. 1-3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 13, 20;<br> Kātnaka Saṃhitā, xxxix. 13.</ref> enumerate the 27  Nakṣatras, and these lists<ref name=fx48_ve1_1474> The forms and genders are given as accepted by Weber, 2, 300. The latter depend on references to the names of the Nakṣatras in other passages in some cases--''e.g., Anūrādheṣu,'' in [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]], viii. 15, shows that the name is a masculine in that Saṃhitā.</ref> may be given ''in extenso'' as follows:<C1>''[[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.'' <C2>''Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhita.'' <C3>''[[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.''<C1>1. [[अपभरणीस्|Apabharaṇīs]] (fem. plur.) <C2>Bharaṇīs ... ... ... <C3>[[अपभरणीस्|Apabharaṇīs]]<br><br>The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Brahmaṇa<ref name=fx49_ve1_1474> i. 5, 1</ref> has a list of the Nakṣatras which agrees generally with the list of the Saṃhitās. It runs as follows: [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]], [[रोहिणी|Rohiṇī]], Invakās, Bāhū (dual), [[तिष्य|Tiṣya]], Āśleṣās, [[मघास्|Maghās]], Pūrve [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]], Uttare [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]], [[हस्त|Hasta]], [[चित्रा|Citrā]], Niṣṭyā, [[विशाखे|Viśākhe]], [[अनूराधास्|Anūrādhās]], [[रोहिणी|Rohiṇī]], Mūlabarhaṇī, Pūrvā Aṣāḍhās, Uttarā Aṣāḍhās, [[श्रोणा|Śroṇā]], [[श्रविष्ठास्|Śraviṣṭhās]], [[शतभिषज्|Śatabhiṣaj]], Pūrve Proṣṭhapadās, Uttare Proṣṭhapadās, [[रेवती|Revatī]], [[अश्वयुजौ|Aśvayujau]], [[अपभरणीस्|Apabharaṇīs]]. In a later book,<ref name=fx50_ve1_1474> iii. 1, 4, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' iii. 1, 1-2.</ref> however, the list grows to 28,  and the full moon is inserted after number 14, and the new moon after number 28, as an attempt to bring the Nākṣatra (lunar) month into accordance with the Sāvana (solar) month of 30 days. The names in this second list are as in the Saṃhitās with the following exceptions. The seven stars of the [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]] are named as Ambā, [[दुला|Dulā]], [[नितत्नी|Nitatnī]], Abhrayantī, Meghayantī, Varṣayantī, Cupuṇīkā, names found also in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]<ref name=fx51_ve1_1474> iv. 4, 5, 1.</ref> and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx52_ve1_1474> xl. 4.</ref> Beside [[मृगशीर्ष|Mṛgaśīrṣa]], Invakās are also mentioned.<ref name=fx53_ve1_1474> iii. 1, 4, 3.</ref> Then come [[आर्द्रा|Ārdrā]], [[पुनर्वसू|Punarvasū]], [[तिष्य|Tiṣya]], [[आश्रेषास्|Āśreṣās]], [[मघास्|Maghās]] (beside which Anaghās, Agadās, and Arundhatīs are also mentioned), Phalgunyas (but elsewhere in the dual, Phalgunyau),<ref name=fx54_ve1_1474> iii. 1, 4, 9.</ref> Phalgunyas, [[हस्त|Hasta]], [[चित्रा|Citrā]], Niṣṭyā, [[विशाखे|Viśākhe]], [[अनूराधास्|Anūrādhās]], [[ज्येष्ठा|Jyeṣṭhā]], [[मूल|Mūla]], Aṣāḍhās, Aṣāḍhās, [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]], Śronā, [[श्रविष्ठास्|Śraviṣṭhās]], [[शतभिषज्|Śatabhiṣaj]], Proṣṭhapadās, Proṣṭhapadās, [[रेवती|Revatī]], [[अश्वयुजौ|Aśvayujau]], Bharaṇyas, but also [[अपभरणीस्|Apabharaṇīs]].<ref name=fx55_ve1_1474> iii. 1, 5, 14.</ref> [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]], which occurs also in an earlier part of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx56_ve1_1474> i. 5, 2, 3.</ref> is perhaps interpolated. But Weber's<ref name=fx57_ve1_1474> ''Op. cit.,'' 305, 306.</ref> argument that [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]] is out of place in this list because [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is here mentioned as the 28th [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]], loses some force from the fact (of course unknown to him) that the list in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx58_ve1_1474> ii. 13, 20.</ref> contains 28 Nakṣatras, including [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]], and adds [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] at the end as another.<br><br>In another passage<ref name=fx59_ve1_1474> i. 5, 2, 7. ''Cf.'' Tilak, ''Orion,'' 41 ''et seq.''</ref> the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] divides the Nakṣatras into two sets, the Deva Nakṣatras and the Yama Nakṣatras, being 1-14 and 15-27 (with the omission of [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]]) respectively. This division corresponds with one in the third book of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx60_ve1_1474> iii. 1, 2. ''Cf.'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 12, with Vināyaka's note.</ref> where the days of the light half of the month and those of the dark half are equated with the Nakṣatras. The [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] treats the former series as south, the latter as north; but this has no relation to facts, and can only be regarded as a ritual absurdity.<br><br>The late nineteenth book of the Atharvaveda contains a list<ref name=fx61_ve1_1474> xix. 7, 1 ''et seq.'' The number is given as 28 in xix. 7, 1 (as emended) and 8, 2. ''Cf.'' Lanman's introductory note to the former hymn in Whitney's Translation, 906, 907.</ref> of the Nakṣatras, including [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]]. The names here  given are: [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]], [[रोहिणी|Rohiṇī]], [[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]], [[आर्द्रा|Ārdrā]], [[पुनर्वसू|Punarvasū]], [[पुष्य|Puṣya]], Āśleṣās, [[मघास्|Maghās]], Pūrvā Phalgunyau (''sic''),<ref name=fx62_ve1_1474> The reading Pūrvā Phalgunyau must be wrong;<br> perhaps Dvaye (''cf.'' verse 5) or Pūrve should be read. See Lanman in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 908. The Uttare Phalgunyau are omitted.</ref> [[हस्त|Hasta]], [[चित्रा|Citrā]], Svāti (masc.),<ref name=fx63_ve1_1474> [[स्वाती|Svātī]] should, no doubt, be read;<br> but for the Svāti (''sie'') of all the manuscripts (Saṃhitā and Pada), ''cf.'' the ''navasrakti'' of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 3, 6, with Keith's note.</ref> [[विशाखे|Viśākhe]], [[अनुराधा|Anurādhā]],<ref name=fx64_ve1_1474> See Lanman in Whitney, 908.</ref> [[ज्येष्ठा|Jyeṣṭhā]], [[मूल|Mūla]], Pūrvā Aṣāḍhās,<ref name=fx65_ve1_1474> Lanman, ''ibid.,'' 909. reads Pūrvā [[अषाढा|Aṣāḍhā]] and Uttarā [[अषाढा|Aṣāḍhā]];<br> Whitney reads Pūrvā and Uttarā Aṣāḍhās. The manuscripts have Pūrvā and Uttare, which cannot stand.</ref> Uttarā Aṣāḍhās, [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]], [[श्रवण|Śravaṇa]], [[श्रविष्ठास्|Śraviṣṭhās]], [[शतभिषज्|Śatabhiṣaj]], Dvayā Proṣṭhapadā, [[रेवती|Revatī]], [[अश्वयुजौ|Aśvayujau]], Bharaṇyas.<br><br>''The Position of the Nakṣatras.''--There is nothing definite in Vedic literature regarding the position of most of the Nakṣatras, but the later astronomy precisely locates all of them, and its statements agree on the whole satisfactorily with what is said in the earlier texts, though Weber<ref name=fx66_ve1_1474> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 367 ''et seq.''</ref> was inclined to doubt this. The determinations adopted below are due to Whitney<ref name=fx67_ve1_1474> ''Oriental and Linguis'tic Essays,'' 2, 350 ''et seq.''</ref> in his notes on the [[सूर्य|Sūrya]] Siddhānta.

कृत्तिकास्
<u>'''1. Kṛttikās'''</u> are unquestionably  Tauri, etc., the Pleiades. The names of the seven stars forming this constellation, and given above from [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] texts,<ref name=fx68_ve1_1475> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 5, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xl. 4;<br> Taittīrīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 4, 1.</ref> include three--''abhrayantī,'' ‘forming clouds’; ''meghayantī,'' ‘making cloudy’; ''varṣayantī,'' ‘causing rain’--which clearly refer to the rainy Pleiades. The word ''kṛttikā'' possibly means ‘web,’ from the root ''kṛt,'' ‘spin.’

रोहिणी
<u>'''2. Rohiṇī,'''</u> ‘ruddy,’ is the name of the conspicuously reddish star, ''a'' Tauri or Aldebaran, and denotes the group of the Hyades,  Tauri. Its identification seems absolutely assured by the legend of Prajāpati in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx69_ve1_1476> iii. 33. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 2, 8;<br> Tilak, ''Orion,'' 98 ''et seq.''</ref> He is there represented as pursuing his daughter with incestuous intention, and as having been shot with an arrow ('''[[इषु त्रिकाण्डा|Iṣu Trikāṇḍā]],''' ‘the belt of Orion’) by the ‘huntsman’ ('''[[मृगव्याध|Mṛgavyādha]],''' ‘Sirius’). Prajāpati is clearly Orion ([[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]] being the name of the little group of stars in Orion's head).

मृगशीर्ष
<u>'''3. Mṛgaśīrṣa'''</u> or '''[[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]],''' also called Invakā or Invagā,  seems to be the faint stars , Orionis. They are called Andhakā, ‘blind,’ in the Śāntikalpa of the Atharvaveda, probably because of their dimness.<ref name=fx70_ve1_1477> Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 401. ''Cf.'' Tilak, 102 ''et seq.''</ref>

आर्द्रा
<u>'''4. Ārdrā,'''</u> ‘moist,’ is the name of the brilliant star,  Orionis. But the names by which it is styled, in the plural as Ārdrās in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx71_ve1_1478> i. 26.</ref> and the Nakṣatrakalpa,<ref name=fx72_ve1_1478> 10.</ref> and in the dual as Bāhū, in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx73_ve1_1478> i. 5, 1.</ref> point to a constellation of two or more stars, and it may be noted<ref name=fx74_ve1_1478> Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 352, 401, n. 1.</ref> that the corresponding Chinese Sieou includes the seven brilliant stars composing the shoulders, the belt, and the knees of Orion.

पुनर्वसू
<u>'''5. Punarvasū,'''</u> ‘the two that give wealth again,’ denotes the two stars,  and  Geminorum, on the heads of Castor and Pollux. The name is no doubt connected with the beneficent character of the Aśvins, who correspond to the Dioscuri.<ref name=fx75_ve1_1479> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 212;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 53.</ref>

तिष्य
<u>'''6. Tiṣya'''</u> or '''[[पुष्य|Puṣya]]''' includes the somewhat faint group in the body of the Crab, , and  Cancri. The singular is rather curious, as primarily one star would seem to have been meant. and none of the group is at all prominent.<ref name=fx76_ve1_1480> Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 403, n. 1.</ref>

आश्रेषास्
<u>'''7. Āśreṣās'''</u> or '''Āśleṣās,''' which in some texts<ref name=fx77_ve1_1481> Aśreṣās, [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 26;<br> Śāntikalpa;<br> Nakṣatrakalpa;<br> Aśleṣās, Śāntikalpa, 2;<br> Nakṣatrakalpa, 4. 48.</ref> is certainly to be read Aśreṣās or Aśleṣas, denotes , and perhaps also , Hydræ. The word means ‘embracer,’ a name which admirably fits the constellation.

मघास्
<u>'''8. Maghās,'''</u> the ‘bounties,’ are the Sickle, or , Leonis. The variants '''Anaghā,''' the ‘sinless one,’ etc., clearly refer to the auspicious influence of the constellation.(**  9, 10. '''[[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]], Phalgunyau, Phalgū,'''<ref name=fx78_ve1_1482> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1.</ref> '''Phalgunīs, Phalgunyas,''' is really a-double constellation, divided into Pūrve, ‘former,’ and Uttare, ‘latter.’ The former is  and  Leonis, the latter  and 93 Leonis. According to Weber, the word denotes, like '''[[अर्जुनी|Arjunī]],''' the variant of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx79_ve1_1482> x. 85, 13.</ref> a ‘brightcoloured’ constellation. 

हस्त
<u>'''11. Hasta,'''</u> ‘hand,’ is made up of the five conspicuous stars () in Corvus, a number which the word itself suggests. According to Geldner,<ref name=fx80_ve1_1483> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 177;<br> Rv. i. 105, 10. ''Cf.'' below, p. 427, n. 156.</ref> the ‘five bulls’ of the Rigveda are this constellation.

चित्रा
<u>'''12. Citrā,'''</u> ‘bright,’ is the beautiful star,  Virginis. It is mentioned in a legend of Indra in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx81_ve1_1484> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 4-6.</ref> and in that of the ‘two divine dogs’ (''divyau śvānau'') in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx82_ve1_1484> ii. 1, 2, 13-17.</ref>

स्वाती
<u>'''13. Svātī'''</u> or '''Niṣṭyā''' is later clearly the brilliant star Arcturus or  Bootis, its place in the north being assured by the notice in the Śāntikalpa,<ref name=fx83_ve1_1485> 3.</ref> where it is said to be ‘ever traversing the northern way’ (''nityam uttara-mārgagam''). The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx84_ve1_1485> i. 5, 2. ''Cf.'' Tilak, ''Orion,'' 204.</ref> however, constructs an asterismal Prajāpati, giving him [[चित्रा|Citrā]] (''a'' Virginis) for head, [[हस्त|Hasta]] (Corvus) for hand, the [[विशाखे|Viśākhe]] (''a'' and  Libræ) for thighs, and the Anurādhās (, and  Scorpionis) for standing place, with Niṣṭyā for heart. But Arcturus, being 30º out, spoils this figure, while, on the other hand, the Arabic and Chinese systems have respectively, instead of Arcturus, , and  Virginis and  Virginis, which would well fit into the Prajāpati figure. But in spite of the force of this argument of Weber's,<ref name=fx85_ve1_1485> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 307, 308.</ref> Whitney<ref name=fx86_ve1_1485> ''Op. cit.,'' 409.</ref> is not certain that Niṣṭyā here must mean a star in Virgo, pointing out that the name Niṣṭyā, ‘outcast,’ suggests the separation of this [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] from the others in question.

विशाखे
<u>'''14. Viśākhe'''</u> is the couple of stars  and  Libræ. This mansion is later called Rādhā according to the Amarakośa, and it is curious that in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx87_ve1_1486> xix. 7.</ref> the expression ''rādho [[विशाखे|Viśākhe]],'' ‘the [[विशाखे|Viśākhe]] are prosperity,’ should occur. But probably Rādhā is merely an invention due to the name of the next [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]], [[अनुराधा|Anurādhā]], wrongly conceived as meaning ‘that which is after or follows Rādhā.’<ref name=fx88_ve1_1486> Lanman in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 908. ''Cf.'' Thibaut, ''Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal,'' 63, 156.</ref>

अनूराधास्
<u>'''15. Anūrādhās'''</u> or '''[[अनुराधा|Anurādhā]],''' ‘propitious,’ is , and  (perhaps also ) Scorpionis. <br>==Foot Notes==

रोहिणी
<u>'''16. Rohiṇī,'''</u> ‘ruddy’; '''[[ज्येष्ठघ्नी|Jyeṣṭhaghnī]],''' ‘slaying the eldest’; or '''[[ज्येष्ठा|Jyeṣṭhā]],''' ‘eldest,’ is the name of the constellation , and  Scorpionis, of which the central star, , is the brilliant reddish Antares (or Cor Scorpionis).<br>==Foot Notes==

विचृतौ
<u>'''17. Vicṛtau,'''</u> ‘the two releasers’; '''[[मूल|Mūla]],''' ‘root’; or '''Mūlabarhaṇī,''' ‘uprooting,’ denote primarily  and  at the extremity of the tail of the Scorpion, but including also the nine or eleven stars from  to .(**  18, 19. '''Aṣāḍhās''' (‘unconquered’), distinguished as '''Pūrvās,''' ‘former,’ and '''Uttarās,''' ‘latter,’ are really two constellations, of which the former is composed of , and  Sagittarii, or of and  only, and the latter of , and  Sagittarii, or of two, and , only. It is probable that originally only four stars forming a square were meant as included in the whole constellation<ref name=fx89_ve1_1489> ''Cf.'' Thibaut, ''Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal,'' 63, 156.</ref> --viz.,  and , with  and .

अभिजित्
<u>'''20. Abhijit'''</u> is the brilliant star  Lyræ with its two companions  and . Its location in 60º north latitude is completely discordant with the position of the corresponding Arabian and Chinese asterisms. This fact is considered by Oldenberg<ref name=fx90_ve1_1490> ''Nachrichten der ko7nigl. Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu Go7ttingen,'' 1909, 551, 552.</ref> to support the view that it was a later addition to the system; its occurrence, however, as early as the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx91_ve1_1490> ii. 13, 20.</ref> which he does not note, somewhat invalidates<ref name=fx92_ve1_1490> It is at the same time to be noted that [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]] is wanting both in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā and in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā lists.</ref> that view. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx93_ve1_1490> i. 5, 2, 3.</ref> [[अभिजित्|Abhijit]] is said to be ‘over Aṣāḍhās, under [[श्रोणा|Śroṇā]],’ which Weber<ref name=fx94_ve1_1490> ''Op. cit.,'' 1, 320, 321;<br> 2, 307;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 224 ''et seq.''</ref> held to refer to its position in space, inferring thence that its Vedic position corresponded to that of the Arab Manāzil and the Chinese Sieou--viz., , Capricorni. Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 36;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1;<br> a Śruti passage in the commentary on Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 13;<br> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 2, 4, 23. and especially Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4. 1, 2. 4. So the Phālguna full moon is called the ‘month of the seasons’ (''ṛtūnām mukham'') in [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 9.</ref> of the correspondence of Phālguna and the beginning of spring: as we have seen above in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], the new moon in Māgha is placed at the winter solstice,<ref name=fx144_ve1_1496> xix. 2. 3.</ref> which puts the full moon of [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]] at a month and a half after the winter solstice, or in the first week of February, a date not in itself improbable for about B.C. 800, and corresponding with the February 7 of the ''veris initium'' in the Roman Calendar. This fact accords with the only natural division of the year into three periods of four months, as the rainy season lasts from June 7-10 to October 7-10, and it is certain that the second set of four months dates from the beginning of the rains (see '''[[चातुर्मास्य|Cāturmāsya]]'''). Tilak,<ref name=fx145_ve1_1496> ''Orion,'' 53 ''et seq.;<br>'' 198 ''et seq.''</ref> on the other hand, holds that the winter solstice coincided with Māghī full moon at the time of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (B.C. 2350), and had coincided with Phālgunī and Caitrī in early periods--viz., B.C. 4000-2500, and B.C. 60004000.<br><br>(5) The passages of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx146_ve1_1496> vii. 4, 8, 1.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx147_ve1_1496> v. 9. See Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 341344;<br> Thibaut, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 24, 85 ''et seq.,'' for a full discussion of the points raised by Tilak, ''Orion,'' 43 ''et seq.''</ref> which treat the full moon in Phālguna as the beginning of the year, give as an alternative the full moon in [[चैत्र|Caitra]]. Probably the latter month was chosen so as to secure that the initial day should fall well within the season of spring,<ref name=fx148_ve1_1496> Thibaut, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 24, 93. On the other side, Tilak, 198 ''et seq.''</ref> and was not, as Jacobi believes, a relic of a period  when the winter solstice corresponded with [[चैत्र|Caitra]]. Another alternative is the [[एकाष्टका|Ekāṣṭakā]], interpreted by the commentators as the eighth day after the full moon in [[मघास्|Maghās]], a time which might, as being the last quarter of the waning half of the old year, well be considered as representing the end of the year. A fourth alternative is the fourth day before full moon; the full moon meant must be that of [[चैत्र|Caitra]], as Ālekhana quoted by Āpastamba held, not of Māgha, as Āśmarathya, Laugākṣi and the Mīmāṃsists believed, and as Tilak believes.<ref name=fx149_ve1_1496> Thibaut, ''op. cit.,'' 94;<br> Tilak, 51 ''et seq. Cf.'' also Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 1. 8-10;<br> Weber, 2, 343, n. 2, 344.</ref><br><br>(6) Others, again, according to the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] ritual, began the year with the month Mārgaśīrṣa, as is shown by its other name Āgrahāyaṇa<ref name=fx150_ve1_1496> Thibaut, ''op. cit.,'' 94, 95. ''Cf.'' Weber, 2, 332-334.</ref> (‘belonging to the commencement of the year’). Jacobi and Tilak<ref name=fx151_ve1_1496> Tilak's view is given in ''Orion,'' 62 ''et seq.'' It is based mainly on Amara's (i. 2, 23) ''āgra-hāyaṇā'' as a synonym of [[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]], and on certain myths (chaps. v.-vii.);<br> he equates (221 ''et seq.'') Āgrayaṇa and Orion (!).</ref> think that this one denoted the autumn equinox in [[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]], corresponding to the winter solstice in [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]]. But, as Thibaut<ref name=fx152_ve1_1496> ''Op. cit.,'' 94, 95.</ref> shows clearly, it was selected as the beginning of a year that was taken to commence with autumn, just as some took the spring to commence with [[चैत्र|Caitra]] instead of Phālguna.<ref name=fx153_ve1_1496> A corresponding Kārttika year is not early, Thibaut, ''op. cit.,'' 96. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 334.</ref><br><br>(7) Jacobi has also argued, with the support of Bühler,<ref name=fx154_ve1_1496> ''Indian Antiquary,'' 23, 242 ''et seq.''</ref> from the terms given for the beginning of Vedic study in the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras, on the principle that study commenced with the rains (as in the Buddhist ''vassā'') which mark the summer solstice. He concludes that if Bhādrapada appears as the date of commencing study in some texts, it was fixed thus because at one time Proṣṭhapadās (the early name of Bhadrapadās) coincided with the summer solstice, this having been the case when the winter solstice was in Phālguna. But Whitney<ref name=fx155_ve1_1496> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, lxxxiv ''et seq.''</ref> has pointed out that this argument is utterly illegitimate; we cannot say that there was any necessary connexion between the rains and learning--a month like Śrāvaṇa might be preferred  because of its connexion with the word [[श्रवण|Śravaṇa]], ‘ear’--and in view of the precession of the equinoxes, we must assume that Bhādrapada was kept because of its traditional coincidence with the beginning of the rains after it had ceased actually so to coincide.<ref name=fx156_ve1_1496> Mention should here be made of the following points: (1) Jacobi's argument from the word [[ध्रुव|Dhruva]], the name of the star pointed out to the bride in the marriage ritual. The word does not occur in the literature anterior to the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras, and it must remain an undecided question whether the practice was or was not old. Jacobi urges that [[ध्रुव|Dhruva]] means ‘fixed,’ and that it must originally have referred to a real fixed pole star, and he thinks that such a star could only be found in the third millennium B.C. Whitney and Oldenberg definitely reject this view on the ground that too much must not be made out of a piece of folk-lore, and that the marriage ritual requirements would be satisfied by any star of some magnitude which was approximately polar. This conclusion seems convincing. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 1102;<br> 1910, 465;<br> ''contra,'' Jacobi, ''ibid.,'' 1909, 726 ''et seq.;<br>'' 1910, 464. (2) The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 2, 3, asserts that the [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]] do not move from the eastern quarter, which the others do;<br> and stress has been laid (by Jacobi, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 463, 464) upon this assertion as giving a date of the third millennium B.C. for the Śatapatha observation. But this notice is quite inadequate to support any such result, and its lack of trustworthiness as a chronological guide is increased by the fact that the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xviii 5, has a similar notice, coupled with another notice, which, according to Barth, would only be true somewhere in or after the sixth century A.D., the equatorial point being placed between [[चित्रा|Citrā]] and [[स्वाती|Svātī]], which in the early period were both very much north of the equator (see Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 37-39). The same passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 2, 2, in the Mādhyaṃdina recension, states that the number of the [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]] is greater than that of the stars in any of the other Nakṣatras, which consist of one, two, three, or four stars, or which, according to the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension (see Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 282, n. 2), have four stars. It is not possible to put much faith in this assertion, for [[हस्त|Hasta]] later has five stars, and its name (with reference to the fingers) suggests five (''cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 368, 381), and that number is possibly referred to in the Rigveda (i. 105, 10). See Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 177. (3) Attempts have been made to regard the names of the Nakṣatras as significant of their position in the list. Thus Bentley, ''Historical View,'' 2, thought Viśākhā was so called because the equinoctial colure divided the equator about 1426 B.C.;<br> this is refuted by Tilak, ''Orion,'' 57 ''et seq.'' [[ज्येष्ठघ्नी|Jyeṣṭhaghnī]] has been interpreted as ‘slaying the eldest’--''i.e.,'' as marking the new year by putting an end to the old year. Tilak, 90, suggests that [[मूल|Mūla]] was so called because its acronycal rising marked the beginning of the year when the vernal equinox was near [[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]]. More probable is Whitney's view, ''Sārya Siddhānta,'' 194, that it was the most southern, and so, as it were, the basis of the asterisms.</ref><br><br>''The Origin of the Nakṣatras.''--As we have seen, there is no evidence showing the process by which the Nakṣatras may  have originated in India. They are mentioned only as stars in the earlier parts of the Rigveda, then the names of three of them are found in the latest parts of that Saṃhitā, and finally in the later Atharvaveda and in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās the full list appears. It may also be noted that the Vedic Indians show (see '''[[ग्रह|Graha]]''') a remarkably small knowledge of the other astronomical phenomena; the discovery of a series of 27 lunar mansions by them would therefore be rather surprising. On the other hand, the nature of such an operation is not very complicated; it consists merely in selecting a star or a star group with which the moon is in conjunction. It is thus impossible ''a priori'' to deny that the Vedic Indians could have invented for themselves a lunar Zodiac.<ref name=fx157_ve1_1496> Max Müller, ''Rigveda,'' 4^2, xliv ''et seq.,'' maintains the Indian origin of the system. Thrbaut, ''Astronomie, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 14, 15, admits it to be possible, as does Whitney, ''Oriental and Linguistic Essays,'' 2, 418.</ref><br><br>But the question is complicated by the fact that there exist two similar sets of 28 stars or star groups in Arabia and in China, the Manāzil and the Sieou. The use of the Manāzil in Arabia is consistent and effective; the calendar is regulated by them, and the position of the asterisms corresponds best with the positions required for a lunar Zodiac. The Indians might therefore have borrowed the system from Arabia, but that is a mere possibility, because the evidence for the existence of the Manāzil is long posterior to that for the existence of the Nakṣatras, while again the Mazzaroth or Mazzaloth of the Old Testament<ref name=fx158_ve1_1496> 2 Kings xxiii. 5;<br> Job xxxviii. 32.</ref> may really be the lunar mansions.<ref name=fx159_ve1_1496> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 1, 317, 318;<br> Whitney, ''op, cit.,'' 359.</ref> That the Arabian system is borrowed from India, as Burgess<ref name=fx160_ve1_1496> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 8, 309-334. This was Weber's view also, according to Whitney, 413 ''et seq.;<br>'' but Weber himself disclaimed it (see ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 425, 426;<br> 10, 246, 247). On the other hand, Sédillot, ''Matériaux pour servir à l'histoire comparée des 'Sciences Mathématiques par les Grecs et les Orientaux'' (Paris, 1845-1849), favoured influence from Arabia on India.</ref> held, is, on the other hand, not at all probable.<br><br>Biot, the eminent Chinese scholar, in a series of papers published by him between 1839 and 1861,<ref name=fx161_ve1_1496> Summed up in his two works, ''Recherches sur l'ancienne astronomie Chinoise,'' and ''Études sur l'astronomie Indieune et l'astronomie Chinoise.''</ref> attempted to prove  the derivation of the [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] from the Chinese Sieou. The latter he did not regard as being in origin lunar mansions at all. He thought that they were equatorial stars used, as in modern astronomy, as a standard to which planets or other stars observed in the neighbourhood can be eferred; they were, as regards twenty-four of them, selecte about B.C. 2357 on account of their proximity to the equator, and of their having the same right ascension as certain circumpolar stars which had attracted the attention of Chinese observers. Four more were added in B.C. 1100 in order to mark the equinoxes and solstices of the period. He held that the list of stars commenced with Mao (= [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]]), which was at the vernal equinox in B.C. 2357. Weber,<ref name=fx162_ve1_1496> ''Naxatra,'' 1, 284 ''et seq.'' (1860).</ref> in an elaborate essay of 1860, disputed this theory, and endeavoured to show that the Chinese literary evidence for the Sieou was late, dating not even from before the third century B.C. The last point does not appear<ref name=fx163_ve1_1496> See Chavannes, cited by Oldenberg, ''Nachrichten der ko7nigl. Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu Gōttingen,'' 1909, 566, 567.</ref> to be correct, but his objections against the basis of Biot's theory were reinforced by Whitney,<ref name=fx164_ve1_1496> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 8, 1 ''et seq.;<br> Oriental and Linguistic Essays,'' 2, 385 ''et seq.'' For his controversy with Weber, see Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 424 ''et seq.;<br>'' 10, 213 ''et seq.;<br>'' Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 8, 384 ''et seq.''</ref> who insisted that Biot's supposition of the Sieou's not having been ultimately derived from a system of lunar mansions, was untenable. This is admitted by the latest defender of the hypothesis of borrowing from China, Léopold de Saussure,<ref name=fx165_ve1_1496> T'oung Pao, 1909, 121 ''et seq.;<br>'' 255 ''et seq.''</ref> , but his arguments in favour of a Chinese origin for the Indian lunar mansions have been refuted by Oldenberg,<ref name=fx166_ve1_1496> ''Nachrichten,'' 1909, 544-572.</ref> who has also pointed out<ref name=fx167_ve1_1496> ''Ibid.,'' 548, n. 9.</ref> that the series does not begin with Mao (= [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]]).<br><br>There remains only the possibility that a common source for all the three sets--[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]], Manāzil, and Sieou--may be found in Babylonia. Hommel<ref name=fx168_ve1_1496> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 45, 592 ''et seq.''</ref> has endeavoured to show that recent research has established in Babylonia the existence of a lunar zodiac of twenty-four members headed by the  Pleiades (= [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]]); but Thibaut's researches<ref name=fx169_ve1_1496> ''Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal,'' 63. 144-163. ''Cf. Astronomie,'' etc., 15;<br> Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 572.</ref> are not favourable to this claim. On the other hand, Weber,<ref name=fx170_ve1_1496> ''Naxatra,'' 1, 316 ''et seq.;<br> Indische Studien,'' 10, 246, and elsewhere. But Whitney, ''Oriental and Linguistic Essays,'' 2, 417, 418, shows that no stress can be laid on this argument, since the correspondence is only approximate, and the latitudes of the Babylonian and Chinese observations are approximately the same.</ref> Whitney,<ref name=fx171_ve1_1496> See ''op. cit.,'' 2, 418-420.</ref> Zimmer,<ref name=fx172_ve1_1496> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 356, 357, where he is quite confident of the Semitic origin of the Nakṣatras.</ref> and Oldenberg<ref name=fx173_ve1_1496> ''Op. cit.,'' 572.</ref> all incline to the view that in Babylonia is to be found the origin of the system, and this must for the present be regarded as the most probable view, for there are other traces of Babylonian influence in Vedic literature, such as the legend of the flood, perhaps the Ādityas,<ref name=fx174_ve1_1496> For the flood, see Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 101, 357, who is opposed to Weber's view (''Indische Studien,'' 1, 160;<br> ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 11) that the story preserves an old Āryan tradition, and a reminiscence of the home of the Indians beyond the Himālaya (''cf.'' Still more doubtful is Zimmer's view (''Altindisches Leben,'' 363, 364) of the division of day and night into thirty parts, which he sees in Rv. i. 123, 8, and which he thinks is based on the Babylonian division of the same period of time into sixtieths. नक्षत्र-दर्श
<u>'''Nakṣatra-darśa'''</u> (‘gazer at the lunar mansions’), an ‘astrologer,’ is mentioned in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha, or ‘human sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1497> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 4, 1.</ref> A notice in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1497> ii. 1, 2, 19, and ''cf.'' the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] text in Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' xii, 288, n. 3.</ref> indicates that that work regarded the practice of choosing a particular [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] under which to set up the sacrificial fires as an idle one, because it decides in favour of choosing the sun as one's [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].

नक्षत्र-विद्या
<u>'''Nakṣatra-vidyā,'''</u> the ‘science of the lunar mansions,’ ‘astronomy,’ is mentioned with other sciences in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vii. 1, 2. 4; 2, 1; 7, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

नख
<u>'''Nakha'''</u> denotes either the ‘nail’ of a man,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1499> Rv. i. 162, 9;<br> x. 163, 5;<br> Av. ii. 33, 6, etc.</ref> or the ‘claw’ of a wild beast, such as a tiger.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1499> Rv. iv. 3, 3. ''Cf.'' x. 28, 10, of the eagle's talon.</ref> The trimming (''nikṛntana'')<ref name=fx3_ve1_1499> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 6.</ref> of the nails was a regular part of the toilet of the Vedic Indian, especially on occasions of special sanctity, when it accompanied the cleansing of the teeth.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1499> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 2, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 3, 4.</ref>

<u>'''Na-ga'''</u> (‘not moving’), ‘mountain,’ is a word occurring only in a late book of the Atharvaveda (xix. 8, 1), and then in the Sūtras.<br>==Foot Notes==

<u>'''Nagha-māra'''</u> and '''Naghā-riṣa.''' See 1. '''[[कुष्ठ|Kuṣṭha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

न-चिकेतस्
<u>'''Na-ciketas'''</u> occurs in the well-known legend of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1506> iii. 11, 8.</ref> (where he is a [[गोतम|Gotama]], the son of '''[[वाजश्रवस|Vājaśravasa]]'''), and in the Kaṭha [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1506> i. 1, etc. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 154, n, 1;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 157;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 168.</ref> His historical reality is extremely doubtful: in the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] he is called son of [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]] [[औद्दालकि|Auddālaki]] or [[वाजश्रवस|Vājaśravasa]], an impossible attribution, and one due only to a desire to give [[नचिकेतस्|Naciketas]] a connexion with the famous [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]]. 

नड
<u>'''1. Naḍa,'''</u> ‘reed,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1507> viii. 1, 33.</ref> as growing in lakes, and in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1507> iv. 19, 1.</ref> is described as ''vārṣika,'' ‘produced in the rains.’ Reeds were used, after being split, for making mats, a work carried out by women.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1507> Av. vi. 138, 5.</ref> They are frequently mentioned elsewhere.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1507> Av. vi. 137, 2;<br> xii. 2, 1, 19. 50. 54;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vi. 7, 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.</ref> See also '''Nada.'''

नड नैषध
<u>'''2. Naḍa Naiṣadha'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1508> ii. 2, 2, 1. 2.</ref> where he seems to be<ref name=fx2_ve1_1508> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 225-227, followed by Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 338, notes 4 and 5. The printed text has [[नैषिध|Naiṣidha]] by error.</ref> a human king who is compared with Yama, the god of death, because of his conquests. Being there identified with the southern sacrificial fire, he was presumably a king of the south, just as Yama is connected with the south.

नड्वला
<u>'''Naḍvalā,'''</u> a ‘reed bed,’ is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxx. 16) and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 4, 12, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

नद
<u>'''Nada'''</u> is found in several passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1510> i. 32, 8;<br> 179, 4;<br> ii. 34, 3;<br> viii. 69, 2;<br> x. 11, 2;<br> 105, 4. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 2.</ref> but its sense is still obscure. It is identified by Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve1_1510> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 717 ''et seq.;<br> Vedische Studien,'' 1, 183 ''et seq.''</ref> with '''[[नड|Naḍa]],''' being explained by him in one passage<ref name=fx3_ve1_1510> i. 32, 8. Here Caland and Henry, ''L'Agniṣṭoma,'' 312, n., would read ''naḷam.'' See also Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, 173.</ref> as a reed boat, which is split, and over which the waters go; in another<ref name=fx4_ve1_1510> ii. 34, 3, followed by Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 301 (who, however, does not construe ''āśubhiḥ,'' ‘sharp,’ with ''karṇaiḥ'' as Pischel does in ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 190). He sees ‘reed’ also in x. 11, 2, but ‘horse’ in x. 105, 4.</ref> as a reed whip, of which the sharp points (''karṇa'') are used to urge horses on; and in others<ref name=fx5_ve1_1510> i. 179, 4;<br> viii. 69, 2.</ref> again as figuratively designating the penis. Roth<ref name=fx6_ve1_1510> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' The sense of ‘bull’ seems imperative in viii. 89, 2;<br> it is admissible in i. 179, 4, where ‘bull’ may denote a man, and in x. 11, 2, and possibly in i. 32, 8, but ‘reed’ there seems far more likely.</ref> takes the sense to be ‘bull’ (either literally or meta-  phorically) in all passages. Once at least<ref name=fx7_ve1_1510> x. 105, 4. and in x. 11, 2. The latter passage suggests that ‘river’ may, after all, be the sense there.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 32, 178, 215.</ref> the ‘neigher’ (from the root ''nad,'' ‘sound’) seems to be meant with reference to Indra's horse. In the phrase ''nadasya karṇaiḥ''^8 the sense is, perhaps, ‘through the ears of the (side) horse’ (that is, by their being ready to hear the word of command) of their chariot, the Maruts ‘hasten on with their swift steeds’ (''turayanta āśubhiḥ'').

नदी
<u>'''Nadī,'''</u> ‘stream,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1511> i. 158, 5;<br> ii. 35, 3;<br> iii. 33, 4;<br> v. 46, 6, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1511> Av. iii. 13, 1;<br> xiv. 1, 43.</ref> Reference is made to shallows (''gādha'')<ref name=fx3_ve1_1511> Rv. vii. 60, 7.</ref> in the river's bed, to the opposite bank (''[[पार|pāra]]''),<ref name=fx4_ve1_1511> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 6, 6.</ref> and to the bathing of horses in streams.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1511> Rv. viii. 2, 2.</ref> Rivers are also mentioned in close connexion with mountains.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1511> Rv. v. 55, 7;<br> x. 64, 8.</ref> The title [[नदी|Nadī]]-pati, ‘lord of rivers,’<ref name=fx7_ve1_1511> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 4, 10.</ref> is once used to express ‘ocean’ or ‘sea-water.’

नना
<u>'''Nanā'''</u> is a familiar name for mother, parallel with '''Tata,''' for father, with which it is found in a verse of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1512> ix. 112, 3. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 6, and see '''[[उपल-प्रक्षिणी|Upala-prakṣiṇī]].'''</ref> describing the occupations of the parents of the poet.

ननान्दृ
<u>'''Nanāndṛ'''</u> is a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1513> x. 85, 46.</ref> where it denotes, according to Sāyaṇa, the ‘husband's sister,’ over whom the wife is to rule. This interpretation is confirmed by the fact that the same position is ascribed to the husband's sister--no doubt while unmarried and living in her brother's care--by the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1513> iii. 22.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 516. The native lexicographers recognize the word, though its occurrence in the later literature is very rare (it has been noted in the Uttararāmacarita). See the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> 

नपात्
<u>'''Napāt'''</u> in Vedic literature apparently has both the wider sense of ‘descendant,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1514> It is equivalent to ‘son’ in a number of mythological epithets such as ''apāṃ [[नपात्|napāt]],'' ‘son of waters.’</ref> and the narrower one of ‘grandson’ in the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1514> Rv. x. 10, 1, clearly ‘son’;<br> vi. 20, 11, may be ‘grandson.’ Most passages, vi. 50, 15;<br> vii. 18, 22;<br> viii. 65, 12;<br> 102, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 61;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 2, require ‘descendant.’</ref> In the Brāhmaṇas the word seems hardly to have the sense of ‘descendant’ at all, while it denotes not only ‘grandson,’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1514> As in [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 48;<br> ''[[पुत्र|putra]]-naptāraḥ.'' ‘sons and grandsons.’ ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], viii. 5.</ref> but also ‘great-grandson’ in the sequence ‘sons, grandsons, great-grandsons’ (''putrān, pautrān, naptṝn'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_1514> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 10, 3;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 11, 5.</ref> ‘Grandson’ is also expressed by [[पौत्र|Pautra]] (‘son's son’) in the Atharvaveda and later,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1514> Av. ix. 5, 30;<br> xi. 7, 16;<br> Aitarey [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 10, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 8, 3.</ref> while the sense of ‘great-grandson’ is accurately conveyed as early as the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_1514> Rv. viii. 17, 13, with ''[[नपात्|napāt]].''</ref> by [[प्र-णपात्|Pra-ṇapāt]], used beside [[नपात्|Napāt]], ‘grandson.’ Naptī, the feminine, is practically limited to the Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1514> Rv. iii. 31, 1 ([[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 4);<br> viii. 2, 42. ''Cf.'' i. 50, 9;<br> ix. 9, 1;<br> 14, 5;<br> 69, 3;<br> Av. i. 28, 4;<br> ii. 14, 1;<br> vii. 82, 6.</ref> and denotes ‘daughter.’ The use in the Veda throws no light on the original use of the word.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1514> Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 403-405;<br> Lanmann, ''Festgruss an Bo7htlingk,'' 77.</ref>

नप्त्री
<u>'''Naptrī,'''</u> as feminine of '''[[नपात्|Napāt]],''' is found in the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], Āraṇya (v. 13).<br>==Foot Notes==

नभ(स्) नभस्य
<u>'''Nabha(s) Nabhasya.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नभाक
<u>'''Nabhāka'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] who is referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1517> viii. 40, 4. 5.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1517> vi. 24.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 107.</ref> The Anukramaṇī (Index) attributes to '''[[नाभाक|Nābhāka]]''' the composition of several hymns of the Rigveda (viii. 39-42). 

नभ्य
<u>'''Nabhya,'''</u> the ‘nave’ of the wheel, is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1518> vi. 70, 3;<br> xii. 1, 12.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1518> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 15;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 3, 20;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 23, etc.</ref> See also '''[[नाभि|Nābhi]].'''

नमी साप्य
<u>'''Namī Sāpya'''</u> is the name of a man in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1519> vi. 20, 6;<br> x. 48, 9. Simply Namī in i. 53, 7.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_1519> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 231, 232.</ref> thinks that he is mentioned as a priest, but the passages suit a king better, and in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1519> xxv. 10, 17.</ref> he appears as [[नमी साप्य|Namī Sāpya]], ''Vaidcho rājā,'' ‘King of [[विदेह|Videha]].’ In one passage<ref name=fx4_ve1_1519> Rv. i. 53, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 149;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 161;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 49. [[साप्य|Sāpya]] may be read [[साय्य|Sāyya]], but Sāyaṇa recognizes the ''p;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutscheu Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 328.</ref> he is represented as engaged in the contest against Namuci.

नर
<u>'''Nara, Nṛ.'''</u>--The general name for ‘man’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1520> i. 25, 5;<br> 167, 20;<br> 178, 3;<br> ii. 34, 6;<br> iii. 16, 4, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1520> Av. ii. 9, 2;<br> ix. 1, 3;<br> xiv. 2, 9;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 34;<br> vi. 27. 32, etc.</ref> is [[नृ|Nṛ]], while Nara<ref name=fx3_ve1_1520> This form of the word, common in the post-Vedic language, is secondary, having originated from cases like ''naram,'' understood as ''nara-m;<br>'' but its origin goes back to the Indo-Iranian period. See Brugmann, ''Grundriss,'' 2, 106. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 318, ''a'' 5.</ref> is found occasionally in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1520> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 12, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 3, 1, 3;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 1, etc.</ref>

नराची
<u>'''Narācī'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1521> v. 31, 4. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 286.</ref> perhaps meaning a poisonous plant.

नर्य
<u>'''Narya'''</u> (‘manly’) is in two passages of the Rigveda (i. 54, 6; 112, 9) understood by the commentator Sāyaṇa as the proper name of a man. See also '''[[नार्य|Nārya]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

नलद
<u>'''Nalada,'''</u> ‘nard’ (''Nardastachys Jatamansi'') is a plant mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1523> vi. 102, 3.</ref> in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1523> iii. 2, 4.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1523> xi. 4.</ref> Āraṇyakas (where it is mentioned as used for a garland), as well as in the Sūtras. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1523> iv. 37, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 68, 69;<br> Grohmann, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 420;<br> Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 177, n. 4.</ref> the feminine form of the word, Naladī, occurs as the name of an Apsaras, or celestial nymph.

नवक
<u>'''Navaka'''</u> is mentioned as having wished for a wife at the Sattra of the '''Vibhindukīyas''' in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1524> ii. 233 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 38).</ref>

नव-ग्व
<u>'''Nava-gva'''</u> occurs in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1525> iv. 51, 4;<br> ix. 108, 4;<br> x. 62, 6.</ref> as a man, an [[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]] in the highest degree (''Aṅgirastama''),<ref name=fx2_ve1_1525> x. 62, 6.</ref> apparently being the type of the Navagvas,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1525> Rv. i. 62, 4;<br> iii. 39, 5;<br> v. 29, 12;<br> 45, 7. 11;<br> vi. 22, 2;<br> x. 14, 6;<br> 61, 10;<br> 108, 8;<br> Av. xiv. 1, 56;<br> xviii. 3, 20, etc.</ref> who appear as a mystic race of olden times, coupled with, and conceived probably as related to, the Aṅgirases. They are often associated with the '''Daśagvas.'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1525> Rv. i. 62, 4;<br> iv. 51, 4;<br> v. 29, 12;<br> x. 62, 6, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig. Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 144 (B), 170.</ref>

नव-नीत
<u>'''Nava-nīta,'''</u> ‘fresh butter,’ is mentioned frequently in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1526> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā. ii. 3, 10, 1;<br> vi. 1, 1, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 4, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1526> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 3, 7. 8;<br> v. 3, 2, 6;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 3.</ref> According to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1526> i. 3.</ref> this is the kind of butter which is fitted for anointing an embryo (''garbha''), while the gods receive '''[[आज्य|Ājya]],''' men fragrant ghee ('''[[घृत|Ghṛta]]'''), and the fathers '''[[आयुत|Āyuta]].''' Elsewhere<ref name=fx4_ve1_1526> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 10, 1, etc</ref> it is contrasted with [[घृत|Ghṛta]] and '''[[सर्पिस्|Sarpis]].''' 

नव-वास्त्व
<u>'''Nava-vāstva'''</u> appears in three passages of the Rigveda. In one<ref name=fx1_ve1_1527> i. 36, 18.</ref> he seems to be a protégé of Agni; in another<ref name=fx2_ve1_1527> vi. 20, 11.</ref> as perhaps a son of '''Uśanas''' and favourite of Indra, but in the last he seems to be defeated, or even slain, by Indra.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1527> x. 49, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 223;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 581;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 128, 129;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 147;<br> ''Uber die neuesten Arbeiten auf dem Gebiete der Ṛgvedaforschung,'' 160;<br> Perry, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, 202;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 158.</ref> But he may be a mythic figure altogether. ''Cf.'' also '''[[बृहद्रथ|Bṛhadratha]].'''

नह्
<u>'''Nah'''</u> has been taken by Roth<ref name=fx1_ve1_1528> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Grassmann<ref name=fx2_ve1_1528> ''Wo7rterbuch, s.v.''</ref> to be the stem, meaning ‘bond,’ of the dative form ''nadbhyas,'' which occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1528> x. 60, 6.</ref> and which Sieg<ref name=fx4_ve1_1528> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 129.</ref> thinks means ‘sister's sons.’ But the sense of this dative is probably rather ‘to the grandsons.’<ref name=fx5_ve1_1528> Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 56, 3''b.''</ref>

नहुस्
<u>'''Nahus'''</u> occurs several times in the Rigveda, but the exact sense is not certain. Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve1_1529> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 206.</ref> sees in the [[नहुस्|Nahus]] a tribe on the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus)<ref name=fx2_ve1_1529> Rv. i. 31, 11;<br> vi. 22, 10;<br> 46, 7;<br> x. 80, 6.</ref> or '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1529> Rv. vii. 95, 2. ''Cf.'' ix. 88, 2;<br> 91, 2.</ref> rich in horses,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1529> Rv. viii. 6, 24.</ref> allied with the '''Bharatas''' and '''Śimyus,'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1529> Rv. i. 100, 18;<br> vii. 18, 5.</ref> connected with '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]]''' and the '''Vārṣāgiras,'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1529> Rv. i. 100, 16. 17.</ref> and having as kings '''[[मशर्शार|Maśarśāra]]''' and '''[[आयवस|Āyavasa]].'''<ref name=fx7_ve1_1529> Rv. i. 122, 15. ''Cf.'' also ''nahuṣo viśaḥ,'' Rv. vii. 6, 5;<br> x. 49, 8;<br> 99, 7, etc.</ref> Roth,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1529> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> on the other hand, sees in [[नहुस्|Nahus]] the general sense of ‘neighbour’ as opposed to a member of one's own people ('''[[विश्|Viś]]'''); this interpretation is supported by the occurrence of the phrase ''nahuṣo nahuṣṭara,''<ref name=fx9_ve1_1529> Rv. x. 49, 8. ''Cf.'' also viii. 8, 3.</ref> ‘closer than a neighbour.’ Nahuṣa has the same sense as [[नहुस्|Nahus]] in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx10_ve1_1529> i. 31, 11;<br> v. 12, 6.</ref> but in  one it seems to be intended for the proper name of a man.<ref name=fx11_ve1_1529> Rv. viii. 46, 27.</ref> Possibly [[नहुस्|Nahus]] was originally a man like Manu.<ref name=fx12_ve1_1529> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 28;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 324. But [[नहुस्|Nahus]], if it was originally the name of a mythic forefather, cannot have been that of a forefather recognized by all the tribes, for there is no passage in which it applies to all men. Geldner, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], Glossar,'' 92, regards [[नहुस्|Nahus]] as a tribe, Nahuṣa as a king. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 128, leaves the question open. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 165, n. 7;<br> 179 ''et seq.;<br>'' 307 ''et seq.''</ref>

नाक
<u>'''1.
