Nāka'''</u> denotes the ‘firmament’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1530> i. 60, 10;<br> 125, 5;<br> iii. 2, 12;<br> iv. 13, 5;<br> vii. 86, 1;<br> 99, 2;<br> viii. 103, 2;<br> ix. 73, 4, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1530> Av. vii. 18, 1;<br> xviii. 2, 47;<br> xiii. 1, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 10;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 7, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5, 3, 4, etc.</ref> It is often used with the epithet ‘highest’ (''uttama'')<ref name=fx3_ve1_1530> Av. iv. 14, 6;<br> xi. 1, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 10;<br> xii. 63.</ref> or ‘third’ (''tṛtīya'')<ref name=fx4_ve1_1530> Av. vi. 122, 4;<br> ix. 5, 1. 4;<br> xviii. 4, 3.</ref> referring to the threefold division of heaven, parallel to the threefold division of earth, atmosphere, and sky ('''Div'''). The [[नाक|Nāka]] is said to be on the third ridge (''pṛṣṭha''), above the luminous space (''rocana'') of the sky.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1530> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 50.</ref> Elsewhere<ref name=fx6_ve1_1530> Av. iv. 14, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 67. In Rv. x. 121, 5, the earth and sky (''dyauḥ''), and heaven (''svar''), and the firmament (''[[नाक|nāka]]''), are all mentioned.</ref> the series earth, atmosphere, sky, and the firmament (''[[नाक|nāka]]''), heaven (''svar''), the celestial light (''jyotis''), occurs. The word ''[[नाक|nāka]]'' is explained in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx7_ve1_1530> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], x. 1, 18;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 4, 1, 24;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 14;<br> and ''cf.'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 10, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 9;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 50, 56, 57.</ref> as derived from ''na,'' ‘not,’ and ''aka,'' ‘pain,’ because those who go there are free from sorrow.

नाक
<u>'''2. Nāka'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1531> iii. 13, 5.</ref> Presumably he is identical with [[नाक|Nāka]] [[मौद्गल्य|Maudgalya]] (‘descendant of Mudgala’), who is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1531> xii. 5, 2, 1.</ref> the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1531> vi. 4, 4.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1531> i. 9, 1.</ref> 

नाक्र
<u>'''Nākra'''</u> is the name of an aquatic animal included among the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1532> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 13, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 35.</ref> Perhaps the animal meant is the crocodile, which later is called Nakra.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1532> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 96, following one version given by Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 21, n. 4.</ref>

नाग
<u>'''Nāga'''</u> appears once in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1533> xi. 2, 7, 12.</ref> in the form ''[[महानाग|mahānāga]],'' where ‘great snake’ or ‘great elephant’ may be meant. In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1533> i. 3, 24.</ref> and in a citation found in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1533> viii. 22.</ref> the sense of ‘elephant’ is clearly intended. In the Sūtras<ref name=fx4_ve1_1533> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 1. ''Cf.'' Winternitz, ''Sarpabali,'' 43;<br> Mac. donell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 153.</ref> the mythic [[नाग|Nāga]] already occurs.

नाग्न-जित
<u>'''Nāgna-jita,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[नग्नजित्|Nagnajit]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Svarjit''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 1, 4, 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

नाचिकेत
<u>'''Nāciketa,'''</u> ‘connected with '''[[नचिकेतस्|Naciketas]],'''’ is the title of a narrative (''upākhyāna'') in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1535> iii. 16.</ref> The word is also applied as an epithet to a special fire in that [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1535> i. 18;<br> ii. 10.</ref> and in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1535> i. 22, 11;<br> 26, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 386. The native lexicographers give Nāchiketa and Nāciketu as synonyms of fire generally.</ref>

नाड-पित्
<u>'''Nāḍa-pit'''</u> occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1536> xiii. 5, 4, 13.</ref> as the birthplace of '''[[भरत|Bharata]].''' The word may, however, be read as Nāḍa-pitī, the name of Bharata's mother,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1536> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 6, n. 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Leumann, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 81.</ref> but this is less probable. 

नाडी
<u>'''1. Nāḍī'''</u> denotes a ‘vein’ or ‘artery’ in the human body in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1537> vi. 138, 4;<br> x. 7, 15. 16.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1537> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 4, 5, 2;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 21;<br> iv. 2, 3, etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 6, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 19.</ref> a natural extension of the literal sense of ‘reed.’

नाडी
<u>'''2. Nāḍī'''</u> means a musical instrument, a ‘reed flute,’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1538> x. 135, 7.</ref> as well as the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1538> xxiii. 4;<br> xxxiv. 5.</ref> where in one passage it is mentioned along with the '''[[तूणव|Tūṇava]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1538> xxxiv. 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 329.</ref>

नाडी
<u>'''3. Nāḍī'''</u> in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1539> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 12.</ref> seems to mean the box of the chariot wheel.

नाडीका
<u>'''Nāḍīkā'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1540> v. 18, 8. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 229;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 251;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 432.</ref> where the sense seems clearly to be ‘wind-pipe,’ with a reference also to the ‘shaft of an arrow’ made of reed.

नाथ
<u>'''Nātha'''</u> in Vedic literature<ref name=fx1_ve1_1541> Av. iv. 20, 9;<br> ix. 2, 17;<br> xviii. 1, 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 4, 1. Also in Av. xiii. 2, 37, ''[[नाथ|nātha]]-kāma,'' ‘seeking help’;<br> xi, 1, 15, ''[[नाथ|nātha]]-vid,'' ‘finding help’;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 11, 23, ''[[नाथ|nātha]]-vindu,'' ‘procuring protection,’ as the name of a Sāman, or chant.</ref> appears only as a neuter meaning ‘protection,’ and is of rare occurrence.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1541> In the post-Vedic literature, on the other hand, the word is a masculine, meaning ‘protector,’ and is very common.</ref> Generally, too, very little appears in Vedic literature of practices such as those which produced Anglo-Saxon society or the Roman ''patronatus.''

नापित
<u>'''Nāpita,'''</u> ‘barber,’ is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1542> iii. 1, 2, 2.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1542> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 2, 8. 13;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 17, etc.</ref> But the older word is [[वप्तृ|Vaptṛ]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1542> Rv. x. 142, 4.</ref> a derivative of  ''vap,'' ‘shave,’ with forms of which verb shaving is referred to as early as the Rigveda.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1542> x. 142, 4. ''Cf.'' i. 65, 4;<br> Av. vi. 68;<br> v 2, 17, etc.</ref> The dead were shaved before burial.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1542> Av. v. 19, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 266;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 265.</ref>

नाभाक
<u>'''Nābhāka,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[नभाक|Nabhāka]],’ is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], or seer, in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1543> viii. 41, 2;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], x. 5.</ref> The Anukramaṇī (Index) ascribes three or four hymns of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1543> viii. 39-41, and doubtfully 42.</ref> to him. According to Ludwig,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1543> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 107.</ref> the man was an [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_1543> viii. 40, 12.</ref> not a [[कण्व|Kaṇva]].

नाभा-नेदिष्ठ
<u>'''Nābhā-nediṣṭha'''</u> (‘nearest in descent’) '''[[मानव|Mānava]]''' (‘descendant of Manu’) is famous in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_1544> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1. 9. 4-6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 14. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 191 ''et seq.''</ref> for the way in which he was treated when his father '''Manu''' divided his property among his sons, or they divided it: [[नाभानेदिष्ठ|Nābhānediṣṭha]] was left out, but was solaced by obtaining, through his father's advice, cows from the Aṅgirases, a feat which is regarded in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1544> xvi. 11. 28-30.</ref> as on a level with the exploits of other seers who celebrated their patrons in hymns, and as giving rise to the hymn, Rigveda x. 62. Nābhānediṣṭha's hymn is repeatedly mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1544> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxviii. 4, merely refers to him as connected with the Aṅgirases. See also ''ibid.,'' xxx. 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 30. 31;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xx. 9, 4.</ref> but beyond its authorship nothing is recorded of him. In the Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_1544> x. 61, 18.</ref> itself he seems to be spoken of as a poet in one passage, which is, however, of quite uncertain meaning.<br><br>[[नाभानेदिष्ठ|Nābhānediṣṭha]] is etymologically connected in all probability with Nabānazdiṣta in the Avesta, which refers to the Fravaṣi of the paoiryō-ṭkaēsha and the Fravaṣi of the Nabānazdiṣta. Lassen<ref name=fx5_ve1_1544> ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 1, 520, and ''Addenda,'' p. lxxvii.</ref> saw in the legend a reminiscence of an Indo-Iranian split; but Roth<ref name=fx6_ve1_1544> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 6, 243 ''et seq.''</ref> showed conclusively that this was impossible, and that [[नाभानेदिष्ठ|Nābhānediṣṭha]] meant simply ‘nearest in birth,’ and  Weber<ref name=fx7_ve1_1544> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 40-50. ''Cf.'' also '''[[दाय|Dāya]].'''</ref> admits that the connexion of the words is not one of borrowing on either side, but that in the Avesta it has kept its original sense of ‘nearest relation,’ while in the Rigveda it has become a proper name.

नाभि
<u>'''1. Nābhi'''</u> develops from the literal sense of ‘navel’ the figurative meaning of ‘relationship,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1545> i. 105, 9;<br> 164, 33;<br> ii. 3, 9;<br> 40, 4, etc.;<br> Av. xii. 1, 40;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 8;<br> xi. 12;<br> xx. 1, etc.</ref> or, concretely, ‘relation.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1545> Rv. i. 163, 12;<br> vi. 47, 28;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 42-44. 50, etc.</ref>

नाभि
<u>'''2. Nābhi,'''</u> ‘nave’ of a chariot wheel, is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1546> v. 43, 8;<br> vi. 39, 4;<br> viii. 41, 6.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1546> Av. iii. 30, 6;<br> x. 8, 34;<br> xi. 7, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 4;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 5, 11;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 15, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 4;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 8.</ref> See also '''[[रथ|Ratha]],''' and ''cf.'' '''[[नभ्य|Nabhya]].'''

नाम-धेय
<u>'''Nāma-dheya,'''</u> ‘name,’ is found in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1547> x. 71, 1.</ref> and often in the later language.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1547> Av. vii. 109, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 9, 3;<br> iii. 3, 4, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 6, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 3, 11;<br> vi. 4, 25;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 2, etc.</ref> See '''[[नामन्|Nāman]].'''

नामन्
<u>'''Nāman,'''</u> ‘name,’ is a common word from the Rigveda onwards. The [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras<ref name=fx1_ve1_1548> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 316 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 46, 47;<br> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 152.</ref> give elaborate rules for the formation of the names of children, but more important is the distinction between the secret (''guhya'') and the ordinary name, though the rules as to the secret name are not at all consistent. The secret name is already recognized in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1548> ''Cf.'' x. 55, 2;<br> 71, 1, as explained in [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 3, 3.</ref> and is referred to in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1548> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 3, 9 (the name is given to a child at birth);<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 25.</ref> one secret name, that of Arjuna for Indra, being given in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1548> ii. 1, 2, 11;<br> v. 4, 3, 7;<br> Weber, 2, 317, n. 3.</ref> It is to be noted that the rule as to giving the  designation of a [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] (lunar asterism) as the secret name or otherwise is not illustrated by a single recorded name of a teacher in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1548> Weber, 2, 318, 319. See '''Aṣāḍha, [[रौहिण|Rauhiṇa]], [[रौहिणायन|Rauhiṇāyana]].'''</ref><br><br>The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_1548> iii. 6, 2, 24;<br> v. 3, 3, 14;<br> ix. 4, 3, 3, which directs that the name should be derived from a feast performed by the person in question. See also [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvi. 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 17.</ref> several times mentions the adoption of a second name with a view to securing success, and also refers to the adoption of another name for purposes of distinction.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1548> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 4. ''Cf.'' vi. 1, 3, 9.</ref><br><br>In actual practice two names are usually found in the Brāhmaṇas, the second being a patronymic or a metronymic, as in '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]] [[औशिज|Auśija]]'''<ref name=fx8_ve1_1548> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 11, 17.</ref> (if the story of the slave woman Uśij as his mother is correct), or '''[[बृहद्उक्थ|Bṛhaduktha]] Vāmneya,'''<ref name=fx9_ve1_1548> ''Ibid.,'' xiv. 9, 38.</ref> ‘son of Vāmnī,’ though the relationship may, of course, be not direct parentage, but more remote descent.<ref name=fx10_ve1_1548> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 14;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 55, n. 2.</ref> Three names are less common--for example, '''[[कूशाम्ब स्वायव लातव्य|Kūśāmba <a class="pada_vei" href="स्वायव">Svāyava]] Lātavya»,'''<ref name=fx11_ve1_1548> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 6, 8.</ref> ‘son of Svāyu, of the [[लातव्य|Lātavya]] (son of Latu) family,’ or '''[[देवतरस् श्यावसायन काश्यप|Devataras <a class="pada_vei" href="श्यावसायन">Śyāvasāyana]] Kāśyapa»,'''<ref name=fx12_ve1_1548> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 40, 2.</ref> where the patronymic and the [[गोत्र|Gotra]] name are both found. In other cases the names probably have a local reference--''e.g.,'' '''[[कौशाम्बेय|Kauśāmbeya]]''' and '''[[गाङ्ग्य|Gāṅgya]].''' Frequently the patronymic only is given, as '''[[भार्गव|Bhārgava]], [[मौद्गल्य|Maudgalya]],''' etc., or two patronymics are used. The simple name is often used for the patronymic--''e.g.,'' '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]].'''<ref name=fx13_ve1_1548> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 2, 13;<br> Hopkins, ''Religions of India,'' 201, n. 2.</ref> In a few cases the name of the wife is formed from the husband's name,<ref name=fx14_ve1_1548> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 135.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 316-320;<br> Hopkins, ''loc. cit.''</ref> as '''Uśīnarāṇī, [[पुरुकुत्सानी|Purukutsānī]], Mudgalānī.'''

नाम्ब
<u>'''Nāmba'''</u> is the name of a kind of grain mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1549> v. 3, 3, 8.</ref> [[आम्ब|Āmba]] is the form of the word in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1549> i. 8, 10, 1.</ref> and the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1549> xv. 15.</ref> 

नाय
<u>'''Nāya'''</u> in two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1550> vi. 24, 10;<br> 46, 11.</ref> is, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, probably a proper name. Sāyaṇa takes the word to mean ‘leader,’ while Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve1_1550> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 41. For other explanations, see Oldenberg, ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 123, 370.</ref> considers it a gerund with passive sense.

नारद
<u>'''Nārada'''</u> is the name of a mythical seer mentioned several times in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1551> v. 19, 9;<br> xii. 4, 16. 24. 41.</ref> In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] he appears in conjunction with '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]''' as priest of '''Hariścandra,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1551> vii. 13. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 17.</ref> as teaching '''[[सोमक साहदेव्य|Somaka Sāhadevya]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1551> vii. 34.</ref> and as anointing '''Āmbāṣṭhya''' and '''Yudhāṃśrauṣṭi.'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1551> viii. 21.</ref> In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx5_ve1_1551> i. 5, 8.</ref> he is mentioned as a teacher, and in the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve1_1551> iii. 9 (the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]], or ‘list of teachers,’ at the end).</ref> as a pupil of [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]]. In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_1551> vii. 1, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 204, n.</ref> he is coupled with [[सनत्कुमार|Sanatkumāra]].

नाराशंसी
<u>'''Nārāśaṃsī'''</u> (scil. Ṛc), ‘(verse) celebrating men,’ is mentioned as early as the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1552> x. 85, 6.</ref> and is distinguished from '''[[गाथा|Gāthā]]''' in a number of passages in the later literature.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1552> Av. xv. 6, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 11, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 32;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 10, etc.;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 78. The passage, Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 6, 8, is uncertain. See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 98, n. 5.</ref> The [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1552> xiv. 5;<br> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 98.</ref> while distinguishing the two, asserts that both are false (''anṛtam''). It is hardly probable that the two were absolutely distinct, for the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1552> i. 3, 2, 6.</ref> has the phrase ‘a [[गाथा|Gāthā]] celebrating men’ (''[[नाराशंसी|nārāśaṃsī]]''). What such verses were may be seen from the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_1552> xvi. 11, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 10 ''et seq.''</ref> which enumerates the ''Nārāśaṃsāni'' at the Puruṣamedha, or ‘human  sacrifice.’ They may legitimately be reckoned as a source of the epic.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1552> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 264, n. Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 100 (''cf. Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 688, 689), lays stress rather on their character as mere eulogies of donors, and that, no doubt, was one of their sides;<br> but the other elements may have been more prominent in reality than the priestly tradition shows.</ref><br><br>The term [[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]] is restricted in some passages<ref name=fx7_ve1_1552> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 32;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5. Possibly, in the other passages mentioned in note 2, the reference may be to the Atharvaveda verses, but this is not at all likely.</ref> to a particular group of three verses of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1552> xx. 127, 1-3 = [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 14, 1-3. ''Cf.'' Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 155.</ref> but Oldenberg<ref name=fx9_ve1_1552> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 238.</ref> must be right in holding that the restricted sense is not to be read into the Rigveda.<ref name=fx10_ve1_1552> x. 85, 6.</ref> Not even in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx11_ve1_1552> vii. 5, 11, 2.</ref> is the technical sense certain, and the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx12_ve1_1552> iii. 154.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im Vedischen Ritual,'' 4 ''et seq.''</ref> gives the word a general application.

नारी
<u>'''Nārī,'''</u> ‘woman,’ occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1553> vii. 20, 5;<br> 55, 8;<br> viii. 77, 8;<br> x. 18, 7;<br> 86, 10. 11.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1553> Av. xiv. 2, 13;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 36;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 34.</ref> The word seems in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1553> i. 73, 3 (''pati-juṣṭā,'' ‘dear to her husband’);<br> vii. 20. 5;<br> x. 18, 7 (''avidhavāḥ supatnīḥ,'' ‘not widowed, with noble husbands’), etc.</ref> to have a distinct reference to a woman as a wife, because it occurs in several passages with distinct reference to matrimonial relations,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1553/> and in the later Vedic literature, where it is not common, it sometimes<ref name=fx4_ve1_1553> [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 28.</ref> has that sense. Delbrück,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1553> ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 417, 439.</ref> however, thinks that it does not indicate marital relations, but merely the woman as the sexual complement of the man.

नार्मर
<u>'''Nārmara'''</u> occurs once in a corrupt verse of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1554> ii. 13, 8.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1554> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 152.</ref> regards the word as the proper name of the prince of a fort, '''[[ऊर्जयन्ती|Ūrjayantī]],''' but Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1554> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> as that of a demon. 

नार्मिणी
<u>'''Nārmiṇī'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1555> i. 149, 3.</ref> as an epithet of '''Pur,''' ‘fort’: it must apparently either be a proper name of the fort,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1555> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 204.</ref> or mean ‘belonging to Narmin or Narmiṇa,’ some prince.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1555> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' Possibly the expression may consist of two words--''na,'' ‘not’ or ‘like,’ and ''armiṇī,'' whatever that may mean. See Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 148;<br> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 177.</ref>

नार्य
<u>'''Nārya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[नर्य|Narya]],’''' is the name of a generous donor in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1556> viii. 24, 29. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 161, 162.</ref>

नार्षद
<u>'''Nārṣada,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[नृषद्|Nṛṣad]],’ is the patronymic of [[कण्व|Kaṇva]] (''i.e.,'' a descendant of [[कण्व|Kaṇva]]) in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1557> iv. 19, 2.</ref> and in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1557> x. 31, 11.</ref> where probably the same man is referred to in another passage<ref name=fx3_ve1_1557> i. 117, 8.</ref> as a protégé of the Aśvins, and perhaps as the husband of '''Ruśatī.''' But in a third passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1557> x. 61, 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 108, 150;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 397.</ref> the name seems applied to a demon, though this is not certain.

नाव-प्रभ्रंशन
<u>'''Nāva-prabhraṃśana,'''</u> the ‘sliding down of the ship,’ is read in Whitney and Roth's text of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1558> xix. 39, 8, where the reading ''nāvaprabhráṃśana'' is a conjectural emendātion, the manuscripts of the Saṃhitā text all having two accents, ''nāvaprabhráṃśana'' (one of them reading ''nāvaḥ-'').</ref> and has been connected by Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_1558> ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 11.</ref> and others<ref name=fx3_ve1_1558> ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 198;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 218, n.;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 30.</ref> with [[मनोर् अवसर्पण|Manor Avasarpaṇa]], the name in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1558> i. 8, 1, 6.</ref> of the northern mountain on which Manu's ship settled on the subsidence of the deluge. But both Bloomfield<ref name=fx5_ve1_1558> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 679.</ref> and Whitney<ref name=fx6_ve1_1558> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 961.</ref> point out that this interpretation is highly improbable, and this view is accepted by  Macdonell.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1558> ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 1107, where his acceptance of Weber's interpretation in his ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 144, is withdrawn.</ref> The expression is analyzed as ''na ava-prabhraṃśana'' by the Pada text and the commentator alike, and is never found elsewhere with reference to the descent of a boat or ship.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1558> The word ''nau,'' ship, never occurs as the first member of a compound in the form of ''nāva,'' while ''pra-bhraṃś,'' ‘fall down,’ is never used of the gliding down of a boat, and would be inappropriately applied in that sense.</ref>

नावा
<u>'''Nāvā,'''</u> ‘ship,’ occurs once in the Rigveda (i. 97, 8). See '''Nau.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नावाज
<u>'''Nāvāja'''</u> (‘ship-propeller’), a ‘boatman,’ is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 3, 3, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

नाव्या
<u>'''Nāvyā'''</u> is found several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1561> i. 33, 11;<br> 80, 8;<br> 121, 13.</ref> and the later literature<ref name=fx2_ve1_1561> Av. viii. 5, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5, 4, 14, etc.</ref> in the sense of a ‘navigable stream.’

नाहुष
<u>'''Nāhuṣa,'''</u> like '''[[नहुस्|Nahus]],''' means, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, in some passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1562> i. 100, 16;<br> v. 73, 3;<br> vi. 22, 10;<br> viii. 6, 24.</ref> ‘neighbouring’ as an adjective, and once<ref name=fx2_ve1_1562> viii. 95, 2.</ref> as a substantive ‘neighbour.’ If, on the other hand, [[नहुस्|Nahus]] is taken as a proper name, then [[नाहुष|Nāhuṣa]] no doubt denotes ‘belonging to the [[नहुस्|Nahus]] people,’ and, as a substantive, ‘King of the [[नहुस्|Nahus]].’

निकोथक भाय-जात्य
<u>'''Nikothaka Bhāya-jātya'''</u> (‘descendant of Bhayajāta’) is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1563> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 444.</ref> as a pupil of '''Pratithi.'''

निगद पार्ण-वल्कि
<u>'''Nigada Pārṇa-valki'''</u> (‘descendant of Parṇavalka’) is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1564> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 443.</ref> as a pupil of Giriśarman. 

नि-गुत्
<u>'''Ni-gut'''</u> occurs in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1565> ix. 97, 53, 54;<br> x. 128, 6.</ref> where Sāyaṇa takes it to mean ‘enemy,’ a possible interpretation. Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1565> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 164.</ref> suggests that non-Āryan foes are meant.

निगुस्थ
<u>'''Nigustha'''</u> is a term of unknown meaning applied in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xvi. 29, 6) to the peoples of [[काशि|Kāśi]], [[विदेह|Videha]], and [[कोसल|Kosala]].<br>==Foot Notes==

नि-तत्नी
<u>'''1. Ni-tatnī,'''</u> ‘striking downwards,’ occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1567> vi. 136;<br> probably 137 also refers to this plant. ''Cf.'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxxi. 28, with Caland's note in his translation;<br> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 61;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 536, 537;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 383.</ref> as the name of an unknown plant which was used as a means of restoring the hair.

नि-तत्नी
<u>'''2. Ni-tatnī'''</u> is the name of one of the seven '''[[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 1, 4, 1). See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नि-तान मारुत
<u>'''Ni-tāna Māruta'''</u> is the name of a man in the '''[[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]''' Saṃhitā (xxv. 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

नि-दाघ
<u>'''Ni-dāgha'''</u> (‘burning down’), ‘summer,’ is the name of one of the seasons in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 8, 1, 4). See '''[[नैदाघ|Naidāgha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नि-दान
<u>'''Ni-dāna'''</u> is the name of a [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], which is referred to in the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1571> v. 23, with Macdonell's note.</ref> apparently as containing a quotation from the [[भाल्लवि|Bhāllavi]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. The quotation cannot be verified in the existing text of the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1571> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 65.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 44;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 111, etc.</ref> 

नि-धा
<u>'''Ni-dhā,'''</u> ‘net,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1572> ix. 83, 4;<br> x. 73, 11;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 2.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1572> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 19.</ref>

नि-धि
<u>'''Ni-dhi'''</u> means primarily ‘(place of) deposit,’ ‘store,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1573> Rv. i. 183, 4;<br> v. 43, 8;<br> vii. 67, 7;<br> 69, 3, etc.</ref> and then ‘treasure’ generally.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1573> Rv. ii. 24, 6;<br> viii. 29, 6;<br> x. 68, 6;<br> Av. x. 7, 23, etc.</ref> In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1573> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1. The St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and Bo7hṭlingk in his edition, take ''daivo nidhiḥ'' as one expression. See '''[[दैव|Daiva]].''' Sāyaṇa takes each as a separate entity, and renders [[निधि|Nidhi]] as ''mahākālādinidhiśāstram,'' presumably meaning some sort of chronology.<br><br>''Cf.'' for [[निधि|Nidhi]] as ‘treasure,’ Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 103, 104.</ref> [[निधि|Nidhi]] denotes some sort of science.

नि-नाह्य
<u>'''Ni-nāhya'''</u> denotes in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 9, 2, 8) a ‘water jar,’ so called, according to the commentator, because it was buried in the ground.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1574> As meaning etymologically ‘to be fastened or fixed down.’</ref> Eggeling<ref name=fx2_ve1_1574> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 223, n. 4.</ref> explains it as ‘a vessel or cistern dug into the ground for keeping water cool.’

निन्दिताश्व
<u>'''Ninditāśva'''</u> (‘possessing contemptible steeds’) is the name of a patron in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1575> viii. 1, 30.</ref> The name may suggest connexion with Iran, but such a reference is not at all necessary.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1575> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 90. ''Cf.'' Ludwing, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 159.</ref> Sāyaṇa ingeniously turns the name--probably a nickname-into a compliment by rendering it ‘one who puts to shame the horses of his rivals.’

नि-पाद
<u>'''Ni-pāda'''</u> in the Rigveda (v. 83, 7) denotes ‘low ground,’. ‘valley,’ as opposed to ‘hill’ (''udvat''). ''Cf.'' '''[[निवत्|Nivat]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नि-म्रुच्
<u>'''Ni-mruc,'''</u> ‘sunset,’ is repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1577> i. 151, 5;<br> 161, 10;<br> viii. 27, 19;<br> x. 151, 5.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1577> Av. xiii. 3, 21;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 10, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 5, 2, etc.</ref> as a division of time. 

निर्-अष्ट
<u>'''Nir-aṣṭa,'''</u> ‘castrated,’ is found in some of the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1578> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 1;<br> 17, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4. 9.</ref> as applied to oxen, and in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1578> xiii. 4, 2, 5.</ref> to horses.

निर्-आल
<u>'''Nir-āla'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1579> vi. 16, 3.</ref> where Sāyaṇa regards it as the name of a disease. Bloomfield,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1579> ''Hymns of the Atharvavéda,'' 466.</ref> with the Padapāṭha, explains it as two words, understanding ''nir'' as an elliptical imperative, ‘(go) out,’ with the vocative ''[[आल|āla]],'' a kind of weed. Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve1_1579> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 292.</ref> at first took ''[[आल|āla]]'' to be a verbal form, but finally came to the conclusion that the expression is one word, ''[[निर्आल|nirāla]],'' of unknown sense.

निरुक्त
<u>'''Nirukta,'''</u> ‘explanation’ of a word or passage, is found in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (viii. 3, 3), but does not appear as the name of a work before the later Upaniṣads. It is, however, probable that Yāska's [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] is not later than the rise of Buddhism. ''Cf.'' '''[[निर्वचन|Nirvacana]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 13, 17; 3, 260 ''et seq.; Indian Literature,'' 25, 26, 41, 42, etc.; Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 269, 270; Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 24, 25; Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],'' xv. ''et seq.''<br>==Foot Notes==

निर्-यास
<u>'''Nir-yāsa'''</u> denotes the ‘exudation’ of trees. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (ii. 1, 5, 4) it is tabooed as food because of its red colour.<br>==Foot Notes==

निर्-वचन
<u>'''Nir-vacana'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve1_1582> i. 6, 3.</ref> and the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1582> ii. 1. ''Cf. a-nirvacanam,'' ‘not serving as an explanation,’ ''ibid.,'' vii. 24.</ref> means ‘explanation,’ especially etymological. ''Cf.'' '''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].'''

नि-वत्
<u>'''Ni-vat'''</u> denotes ‘valley’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1583> i. 161, 11;<br> iii. 2, 10;<br> vii. 50, 4;<br> x. 127, 2;<br> 142, 4.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1583> Av. vi. 22, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 4;<br> 4, etc.</ref> 

निवान्य-वत्सा
<u>'''Nivānya-vatsā'''</u> and '''Nivānyā''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1584> xii. 5, 1, 4.</ref> denotes a ‘cow with a calf to which she has to be won over,’ that is, with a calf substituted for one of her own which has died. Nivānyā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1584> ii. 6, 1, 6.</ref> is a contracted form of the compound term. Similar expressions are ''abhivānya-vatsā,''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1584> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 2.</ref> ''abhivānyā,''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1584> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 8, 4.</ref> ''vānyā,''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1584> ''Ibid.,'' ii. 6, 16, 2.</ref> and ''apivānya-vatsā.''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1584> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], lxxxii. 22.<br><br>''Cf.'' Lanman in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 880.</ref>

नि-विद्
<u>'''Ni-vid'''</u> denotes a brief invocation of the deity that is invited in a liturgy in honour of the god. The Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_1585> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 33. 34;<br> iii. 10. 11;<br> vi. 33. 35;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 3, 28;<br> xiii. 5, 1. 9, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 5, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, i. 3, etc.</ref> repeatedly mention Nivids as inserted in the Śastras (recitations), and the '''Khilas''' of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1585> See Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 137-143.</ref> preserve among them a set of Nivids. But it is doubtful<ref name=fx3_ve1_1585> The antiquity of the Nivids was asserted by Haug, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],'' 1, 26 ''et seq.,'' and often since, ''e.g.,'' by Tilak, ''Orion,'' 206;<br> Scheftelowitz, ''op. cit.,'' 3. It is shown to be most improbable by Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 265, 355, and Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 242 ''et seq.;<br> Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1907, 232, 233.</ref> whether the habit of using such brief formulas--the [[निविद्|Nivid]] is usually not more than a Pada or quarter-verse in length--is known to the Rigveda, though it has been seen even there,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1585> i. 86, 4;<br> Bezzenberger's ''Beiträge,'' 9, 192. So Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 119, 122, takes Rv. i. 96, 2, to refer to the Nivids in the technical sense, but not to the Nivids as preserved.</ref> and the word [[निविद्|Nivid]] is several times found in that Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1585> i. 89, 3;<br> 96, 2;<br> 175, 6;<br> ii. 36, 6;<br> iv. 18, 7;<br> vi. 67, 10.</ref> but hardly in the technical sense of the Brāhmaṇas. In the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx6_ve1_1585> Av. v. 26, 4;<br> xi. 7, 19;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix, 25, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 102;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 387, n. 2;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 241.</ref> the technical sense is common.

निविद्-धान
<u>'''Nivid-dhāna,'''</u> ‘containing a [[निविद्|Nivid]],’ is found several times as an epithet of a hymn or verse in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1586> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 17;<br> Kauṣīaki [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 6;<br> xxiv. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 1, 12;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 2, 2;<br> 5, 3.</ref> 

नि-वेशन
<u>'''Ni-veśana,'''</u> ‘dwelling,’ occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1587> iv. 19, 9;<br> vii. 19, 5.</ref> and the Sūtras. In the latter<ref name=fx2_ve1_1587> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 6, etc.</ref> the word is sometimes contrasted with '''[[गृह|Gṛha]]''' as the resting-place of animals.

नि-षङ्गथि
<u>'''Ni-ṣaṅgathi'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1588> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 11;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 2.</ref> or '''Niṣaṅga-dhi'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1588> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 10.</ref> is found in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās. If the second form of the word is correct, the sense may be ‘sheath of a sword’ (''niṣaṅga''), as it is taken by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, but probably the first form is the correct one, the word then having the same meaning as '''[[निषङ्गिन्|Niṣaṅgin]].'''

नि-षङ्गिन्
<u>'''Ni-ṣaṅgin'''</u> is found three times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1589> iii. 30, 15;<br> v. 57, 2;<br> x. 103, 3.</ref> where, owing to its following in one passage<ref name=fx2_ve1_1589> v. 57, 2.</ref> the words ''sudhanvāna iṣumanto,'' ‘having good bows and arrows,’ the sense of ''niṣaṅginaḥ'' as ‘having quivers’ seems quite certain. In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1589> xvi. 20. ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xx, 2, 11, with the commentator.</ref> it is taken by the commentator Mahīdhara to mean ‘having a sword,’ a sense which is quite possible both there and in the other passages<ref name=fx4_ve1_1589> [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], ii. 1199;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 12;<br> xxxvii. 11;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 3, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 274.</ref> where it occurs. But the word far more probably means ‘having a quiver,’ for the bow was the Vedic weapon, not the sword ('''Asi''').

नि-षाद
<u>'''Ni-ṣāda'''</u> is found in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1590> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 4, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 11;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 6, 8, etc.</ref> The word seems to denote not so much a particular tribe, but to be the general term for the non-Āryan tribes who were not under Āryan control, as the Śūdras were, for [[औपमन्यव|Aupamanyava]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1590> In [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 8.</ref> took the five peoples (''pañca janāḥ'') to be the four castes (''catvāro  varṇāḥ'') and the Niṣādas, and the commentator Mahīdhara explains the word where it occurs in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1590> xvi. 27. ''Cf.'' xxx. 8.</ref> as meaning a Bhilla, or Bhīl. A village of Niṣādas is mentioned in the Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_1590> viii. 2, 8.</ref> and a [[निषाद|Niṣāda]] '''[[स्थपति|Sthapati]],''' a leader of some kind, is referred to in the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1590> i. 1, 12;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 13.</ref> and in a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] cited by the scholiast on that passage. Weber<ref name=fx6_ve1_1590> ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 340. ''Cf.'' 10, 13, 16.</ref> thinks that the Niṣādas were the settled aborigines (form ''ni,'' ‘down,’ and ''sad,'' ‘settle’), a view supported by the fact that the ritual of the Viśvajit sacrifice<ref name=fx7_ve1_1590> See [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 15;<br> Lāṭyāyana, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> requires a temporary residence with Niṣādas; for the Niṣādas who would permit an Āryan to reside temporarily amongst them must have been partially amenable to Āryan influence. But the name might easily be applied to the whole body of aborigines outside the Āryan organization. Von Schroeder<ref name=fx8_ve1_1590> ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 366. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 39, 119. In the later system (Manu, x. 8) the [[निषाद|Niṣāda]] is the offspring of a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and of a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] woman, while the Bṛhatsaṃhitā of Varāhamihira (xiv. 10) recognizes a kingdom (''[[राष्ट्र|rāṣṭra]]'') of Niṣādas in the south-east of [[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]]. In the Pāli texts (Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 12, 160, 206 ''et seq.'') they are wild hunters and fishers. ''Cf.'' also Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 301, 303, 366, n. 164, 403, 481.</ref> thinks that the Niṣādas were most probably identical with the Nysæans, who, according to the Greek account, sent an embassy to Alexander when he was in the territory of the Aśvakas, but this identification is doubtful.

निष्क
<u>'''Niṣka'''</u> is frequently found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1591> ii. 33, 10;<br> viii. 47, 15. etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1591> Av. v. 14, 3;<br> vii. 99, 1;<br> xx. 131. 8;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2, 1. 2;<br> v. 13, 2;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 36, 7. 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 1, 7. 11, etc.</ref> denoting a gold ornament worn on the neck, as is shown by the two epithets ''[[निष्क|niṣka]]-kaṇṭha''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1591> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 22.</ref> and ''[[निष्क|niṣka]]-grīva,''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1591> Rv. v. 19, 3;<br> Av. v. 17, 14.</ref> ‘having a gold ornament on the neck.’ A [[निष्क|Niṣka]] of silver is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_1591> xvii. 1, 14, as worn by the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] ''Cf.'' Av. xv. 3.</ref> As early as the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_1591> i. 126, 2.</ref> traces are seen of the  use of Niṣkas as a sort of currency, for a singer celebrates the receipt of a hundred Niṣkas and a hundred steeds: he could hardly require the Niṣkas merely for purposes of personal adornment. Later the use of Niṣkas as currency is quite clear.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1591> Av. xx. 127, 3;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 9, 20, etc. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 4, 1, 1. 8;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6;<br> the sense of ‘coin’ is seen by Eggeling. ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 50, 51, and by Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 185.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 51, 259, 263;<br> Geldner, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 268, n. 2;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 40, 127.</ref> ''Cf.'' also '''[[कृष्णल|Kṛṣṇala]].'''

निष्किरीय
<u>'''Niṣkirīya'''</u> is the name of a school of priests who are mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1592> xii. 5, 14. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 58.</ref> as holding a Sattra, or ‘sacrificial session.’

निष्ट्य
<u>'''Niṣṭya'''</u> means in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1593> vi. 75, 19;<br> viii. 1, 13;<br> x. 133, 5.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1593> Av. iii. 3, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi, v. 23;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 4, 17, etc.</ref> an outsider or stranger. Hence the constellation usually known as Svāti (see '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]''') is named Niṣṭyā in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1593> i. 5, 2, 2. 3;<br> iii. 1, 1, 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 215.</ref> because it occupies a position markedly away from the ecliptic.

निहाका
<u>'''Nihākā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1594> x. 97, 13.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1594> vii. 5, 11, 1 (following ''[[नीहार|nīhāra]]'').</ref> appears to denote some phenomenon of a storm, perhaps the ‘whirlwind.’

नीक्षण
<u>'''Nīkṣaṇa.'''</u> See '''[[नेक्षण|Nekṣaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नीच्य
<u>'''Nīcya'''</u> (‘living below’) is a designation of certain nations of the west. The Nīcyas are mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 14) as distinguished from the people of '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]],''' and no doubt mean the inhabitants of the Indus and Panjab regions. <br>==Foot Notes==

नीथ
<u>'''Nītha'''</u> (‘leading’), neut., means musical ‘mode’ and then ‘hymn of praise.’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1597> Rv. iv. 3, 16;<br> vii. 26, 2;<br> x. 92, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 38. ''Cf. nīthāvid'' of singers (''[[जरितृ|jaritṛ]]'') in Rv. iii. 12, 5.</ref> The feminine form Nīthā occurs once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1597> i. 104, 5. ''Cf.'' the epithet ''śata-[[नीथ|nītha]],'' i. 100, 12;<br> 179, 3;<br> x. 69, 7;<br> ''sahasranītha,'' iii. 60, 7;<br> ix. 85, 4;<br> 96, 18 (used of the poet's art, ''padavīḥ kavīnām'').<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 241.</ref> meaning ‘artifice.’

नीनाह
<u>'''Nīnāha,'''</u> a word occurring once in the Atharvaveda (xix. 57, 4), seems to denote a ‘girdle’ or something similar, as derived from the verb ''nah,'' ‘fasten.’<br>==Foot Notes==

नीपातिथि
<u>'''Nīpātithi'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1599> viii. 49, 9, where he appears as engaged in battle;<br> viii. 51, 1, where he seems to be a sacrificer. Either a king or a seer may be meant.</ref> as the name of a man to whom a hymn<ref name=fx2_ve1_1599> viii. 34. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 140;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 90.</ref> is ascribed by the Anukramaṇī (Index). A Sāman, or Chant, of his is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1599> xiv. 10, 4.</ref>

नीलङ्गु
<u>'''Nīlaṅgu'''</u> is the name of a species of ‘worm’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1600> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 11 (''v.l. nīlāṅgu'');<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref> in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice.’

नील-शीर्ष्णी
<u>'''Nīla-śīrṣṇī,'''</u> ‘black-headed,’ is the name of an unknown animal in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice,’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1601> v. 5, 15, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref>

नीलागलसाल
<u>'''Nīlāgalasāla,'''</u> or, as the Paippalāda version reads, '''Nīlākalasālā,''' is the name, according to the commentator, of a graincreeper in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1602> vi. 16, 4. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 292, 293;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 466.</ref> 

नीवार
<u>'''Nīvāra,'''</u> ‘wild rice,’ is mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1603> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 12.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1603> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 4, 14;<br> 3, 3, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6, 7, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 240.</ref>

नीवि
<u>'''Nīvi'''</u> is the name of the ‘undergarment,’ probably a simple apron of cloth, worn by both men and women, but especially by the latter. It is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1604> viii. 2, 16;<br> xiv. 2, 50. ''Cf. nīvibhārya,'' ‘to be borne in the apron,’ viii. 6, 20.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1604> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 10;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 3, 6;<br> iii. 2, 1, 15, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 331.</ref>

नीहार
<u>'''Nīhāra,'''</u> ‘mist,’ occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1605> x. 82, 7.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1605> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 11, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 26;<br> xxv. 9;<br> Av. vi. 113, 2;<br> xviii. 3, 60;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 10, 7;<br> vi. 4, 1;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 19, 2, etc.</ref>

नृ
<u>'''Nṛ.'''</u> See '''Nara.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नृति
<u>'''Nṛti'''</u> in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1607> vi. 18, 3.</ref> seems to mean a bag of skin. But though the Paippalāda recension has the same text, it is clear that we must read '''[[दृति|Dṛti]]''' with Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_1607> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Whitney.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1607> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 294. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 235;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 468.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve1_1607> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 514.</ref> renders the word ‘dancer,’ which makes no sense in the context.

नृतू
<u>'''Nṛtū'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1608> i. 92, 4 (where Uṣas, Goddess of Dawn, is compared to a dancer).</ref> denoting a female ‘dancer.’ In another passage<ref name=fx2_ve1_1608> x. 18, 3. ''Cf.'' 29, 2.</ref> [[नृति|Nṛti]] is found coupled with ''hāsa,'' ‘laughter,’ in the description of the funeral ritual; but though it is clear that a joyful celebration is meant (like the Irish ‘wake’ or the  old-fashioned feasting in Scotland after a funeral), it is difficult to be certain that actual dancing is here meant. Dancing is, however, often referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1608> i. 10, 1;<br> 92, 4, etc. See Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 196 ''et seq.''</ref> and later. Nṛttagīta, ‘dance and song,’ are mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1608> i. 42 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 235).</ref> as found in the sixth world. See also '''[[शैलूष|Śailūṣa]].'''

नृ-पति
<u>'''Nṛ-pati,'''</u> ‘lord of men,’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1609> ii. 1, 1. 7;<br> iv. 20, 1;<br> vii. 69, 1;<br> x. 44, 2. 3.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1609> Av. v. 18, 1. 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vi. 3, 3;<br> x. 77, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘king’ or a man of the ruling class ('''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]''').

नृ-मेध
<u>'''Nṛ-medha,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1610> Rv. x. 80, 3;<br> 132, 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 8, 3.</ref> '''[[नृ|Nṛ]]-medhas,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1610> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 8, 21 ''et seq.''</ref> is the name of a protégé of Agni in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1610> x. 80, 3.</ref> where he also appears with '''Sumedhas''' in a hymn that Griffith<ref name=fx4_ve1_1610> x. 132;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 578, n.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 61.</ref> with justice declares to be unintelligible. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1610/> he is an unsuccessful rival of '''[[परुच्छेप|Parucchepa]],''' and in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1610/> he is an [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]] and a seer of Sāmans (Chants).

नृ-षद्
<u>'''Nṛ-ṣad,'''</u> ‘sitting among men,’ is the name of the father of '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]]''' in the Rigveda (x. 31, 11). ''Cf.'' '''[[नार्षद|Nārṣada]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नेक्षण
<u>'''Nekṣaṇa'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1612> ix. 6, 17. ''Cf.'' [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 11;<br> lxxxvii. 12;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 540.</ref> where a ‘spit’ seems to be meant. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1612> i. 162, 13.</ref> [[नीक्षण|Nīkṣaṇa]] occurs, and must have the same sense; Oldenberg<ref name=fx3_ve1_1612> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 155.</ref> inclines to think that this word refers to the ‘inspection’ of food, to see if it is ready (as from ''ni-īkṣ,'' ‘look into’). 

नेमि
<u>'''Nemi'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1613> i. 32, 15;<br> 141, 9;<br> ii. 5, 3;<br> v. 13, 6;<br> vii. 32, 20;<br> viii. 46, 23;<br> 75, 5, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1613> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 2, 15;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 5, 15, etc.</ref> the ‘felly’ of a chariot wheel. It was required to be of good wood (''su-drū''),<ref name=fx3_ve1_1613> Rv. vii. 32, 20.</ref> and was bent into shape.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1613> Rv. viii. 75, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 248.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[रथ|Ratha]].'''

नेष्टृ
<u>'''Neṣṭṛ,'''</u> the name of one of the chief priests at the Soma sacrifice, occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1614> i. 15, 3;<br> ii. 5, 5, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1614> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 18, 1;<br> vi. 5, 8, 5. 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 10, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 2, 1, etc.;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 15, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 250, 261, 527.</ref> See '''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]].'''

नैचा-शाख
<u>'''Naicā-śākha'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1615> vii. 53, 4.</ref> where Sāyaṇa renders it as ‘of low origin,’ but elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve1_1615> See St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> he explains it as the name of a place. The former sense is accepted by Grassmann and Ludwig in their versions, and by Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1615> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 31.</ref> but Hillebrandt<ref name=fx4_ve1_1615> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 14-18;<br> 2, 241245, where he opposes Bo7htlingk's view that it is a proper name.</ref> points out that the reference is rather to the ‘low-branched’ Soma plant. ''Cf.'' '''[[कीकट|Kīkaṭa]]''' and '''[[प्रमगन्द|Pramaganda]].'''

नैचु-दार
<u>'''Naicu-dāra'''</u> occurs in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1616> xxi. 4, 13. ''Cf.'' Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vi. 4.</ref> meaning ‘composed of the wood of the Nicudāra.’ What tree is meant by the latter name is unknown.

नैतन्धव
<u>'''Naitandhava'''</u> is mentioned as a place on the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1617> xxv. 13, 1.</ref> and the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1617> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 19, 13;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 29, 31;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 6, 23.</ref>

नै-दाघ
<u>'''Nai-dāgha'''</u> is the name of the ‘summer’ season in the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1618> Av. ix. 5, 31;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 4, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 1, 16, etc.;<br> ''naidāghīya,'' ‘belonging to the summer,’ [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiii. 16, 8, etc.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[ऋतु|Ṛtu]]''' and '''[[निदाघ|Nidāgha]].''' 

नै-दान
<u>'''Nai-dāna'''</u> is a term applied in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1619> vi. 9;<br> vii. 12.</ref> to a class of Vedic interpreters. Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_1619> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' But ''of.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ''Erlāuterungen,'' 220, 221;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, 176.</ref> takes the Naidānas to be ‘etymologists,’ but Sieg<ref name=fx3_ve1_1619> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 29.</ref> thinks they are the same as the '''Aitihāsikas''' or ‘legendarists.’<ref name=fx4_ve1_1619> The word seems to mean ‘one concerned with the original form’ (''[[निदान|nidāna]]'').</ref>

नै-ध्रुवि
<u>'''Nai-dhruvi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Nidhruva,’ is the patronymic of '''[[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1620> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyandina = vi. 5, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

नैमिशि
<u>'''Naimiśi'''</u> is the epithet of '''Śitibāhu [[ऐषकृत|Aiṣakṛta]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1621> i. 363 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 192).</ref> It is probably to be taken as an indication that Śitibāhu came from the Naimiśa forest.

नैमिशीय
<u>'''Naimiśīya,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1622> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 6, 4;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 363 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 192).</ref> '''Naimiṣīya'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1622> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvi. 5;<br> xxviii. 4;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, 13;<br> Naimiṣya, [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 6 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 469). The cerebrals seems to be universal later.</ref> denotes the dwellers in the Naimiśa forest. They are mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1622/> and the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1622/> being clearly of special sanctity. Hence in the Epic the Mahābhārata is said to have been recited to the [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] dwelling in the Naimiṣa forest.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1622> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 34, 45, 54, 68, 70, 185.</ref>

नैर्-उक्त
<u>'''Nair-ukta'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1623> ‘One concerned with etymological explanation’ (''nir-ukta'').</ref> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1623> i. 12;<br> vi. 11;<br> xi. 19. 29. 31;<br> xii. 10;<br> xiii. 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 26, 85;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 39, n.;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffc des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 10-13;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, 165 ''et seq.''</ref> denotes a man who knows the true etymology of words, and explains their meaning accordingly. Yāska's [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] is the classic work of this school, and forms a commentary on an earlier [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], the so-called Naighaṇṭuka, a glossary consisting of five collections of Vedic words. 

नै-षाद
<u>'''Nai-ṣāda,'''</u> a ‘man of [[निषाद|Niṣāda]],’ is mentioned in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 15) and the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxx. 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

नैषिध
<u>'''Naiṣidha'''</u> is the reading in the Śata atha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 3, 2, 1. 2) of the epithet of '''[[नड|Naḍa]],''' a king of the south. The later form of the name is Naiṣadha; the St. Petersburg Dictionarv suggests that its original form was Naiḥṣidha.<br>==Foot Notes==

नोधस्
<u>'''Nodhas'''</u> is the name of a poet who is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1626> i. 61, 14;<br> 62, 13;<br> 64, 1, and 124, 4, according to [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 16.</ref> and to whom certain of its hymns are ascribed.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1626> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 18;<br> Rv. i. 58-64 are ascribed to him in the Anukramaṇī (Index).</ref> In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1626> vii. 10, 10;<br> xxi. 9, 12. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 27;<br> viii. 12. 17;<br> Av. xv. 2, 4;<br> 4, 4.</ref> he is called '''[[काक्षीवत|Kākṣīvata]],''' a ‘descendant of '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]].'''’ Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve1_1626> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 110.</ref> regards him as contemporary with the defeat of '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]].''' He was a '''[[गोतम|Gotama]].'''<ref name=fx5_ve1_1626> Rv. i. 62, 13;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 125. For the controversy as to the meaning of Rv. i. 124, 4, see Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 137. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 33.</ref>

नौ
<u>'''Nau'''</u> is the regular word in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1627> i. 131, 2;<br> ii. 39, 4;<br> viii. 42, 3;<br> 83, 3, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1627> Av. ii. 36, 5;<br> v. 19. 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 3, 10, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 19;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 13;<br> vi. 6. 21;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 1, 4;<br> iv. 2, 5, 10, etc.</ref> for a ‘boat’ or ‘ship.’ In the great majority of cases the ship was merely a boat for crossing rivers, though no doubt a large boat was needed for crossing many of the broad rivers of the Panjab as well as the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' and '''[[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]].''' Often no doubt the Nau was a mere dug-out canoe (''[[दारु|dāru]]'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_1627> Rv. x. 155, 3.</ref> It is certainly against the theory<ref name=fx4_ve1_1627> Wilson, ''Rigveda,'' 1, xli.</ref> of the existence in Vedic times of an extensive sea trade that there is no mention of any of the parts of a ship, such as masts and sails, except the oar ('''[[अरित्र|Aritra]]'''), Yet there are some allusions indicating a trade more extensive than that implied by boats used for crossing rivers. The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_1627> v. 19, 8. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 19, 139. So perhaps the passage, Rv. i. 32, 8, ''nadaṃ na bhinnam,'' refers to a ship. See '''[[नड|Naḍa]].'''</ref> compares the ruin of a kingdom where Brahmins are oppressed to the  sinking of a ship which is leaking (''bhinnā''); though the language here employed can be made to fit the theory that the ship was only a canoe, it cannot naturally be so interpreted. Moreover, there is mention made in the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_1627> Rv. i. 56, 2;<br> iv. 55, 6.</ref> of men who go to the ocean ('''[[सम्उद्र|Samudra]]''') eager for gain (''saniṣyavaḥ''). It is not altogether satisfactory to restrict such references with Zimmer<ref name=fx7_ve1_1627> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 22, 23.</ref> to the broad stream of the Indus after the union of that river with the tributaries of the Panjab. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx8_ve1_1627> i. 116, 3 ''et seq.''</ref> too it is said that the Aśvins rescued '''[[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]]''' in the ocean with a ship of a hundred oars (''śatāritra''). It is not easy to refuse to recognize here the existence of larger vessels with many oars used for sea voyages. The [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx9_ve1_1627> i. 2, 4;<br> ii. 2, 2. But it is not of very early date.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 255-257.</ref> at any rate, clearly refers to maritime navigation. See also '''[[सम्उद्र|Samudra]].'''

न्यग्-रोध
<u>'''Nyag-rodha,'''</u> ‘growing downwards,’ is the name of the ''Ficus indica,'' a tree remarkable for sending down from its branches fibres which take root and form new stems. Though the tree is not mentioned by name in the Rigveda, it appears to have been known, as Pischel<ref name=fx1_ve1_1628> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 113, 114.</ref> has shown from a hymn<ref name=fx2_ve1_1628> i. 24, 7, where ''[[स्तूप|stūpa]]'' seems to denote the crest or crown of the tree above the main trunk.</ref> in which its characteristics may be recognized. It is frequently mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1628> iv. 37, 4;<br> v. 5, 5.</ref> and the later literature.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1628> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 30. 31;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 5, 13 xiii. 2, 7, 3;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 12, 1, etc.</ref> The sacrificial bowls ('''[[चमस|Camasa]]''') were made of its wood.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1628> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Samhitā, vii. 4, 12, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 58.</ref> It was doubtless of the greatest importance, as in modern times, to the Vedic village. The sister tree, the '''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]]''' (''Ficus religiosa''), already occurs in the Rigveda.

न्य्-अङ्क
<u>'''Ny-aṅka'''</u> in the dual denotes in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1629> i. 7, 7, 2.</ref> and [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1629> i. 3, 5, 4;<br> ii. 7, 8, 1.</ref> some part of the chariot, parallel with '''[[अङ्क|Aṅka]].''' The [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1629> i. 7, 5;<br> Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 8, 9.</ref> has Nyaṅkū, the dual of [[न्यङ्कु|Nyaṅku]]. 

न्यङ्कु
<u>'''Nyaṅku'''</u> is the name of an animal in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1630> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 17, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 27. 32. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83. The metre ''[[न्यङ्कु|nyaṅku]]-sāriṇī,'' ‘with a gazelle's gait,’ is already mentioned in the [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]] Prātiśākhya, xvi. 31;<br> [[छन्दस्|Chandas]], 5;<br> [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2.</ref> It seems clear that a kind a ‘gazelle’ is meant, but the commentary on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1630/> suggests ‘bear’ (''[[ऋक्ष|ṛkṣa]]'') as a variant rendering.

न्य्-अस्तिका
<u>'''Ny-astikā'''</u> seems in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1631> vi. 139, 1. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 385;<br> Bloomfield, ''ymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 539, 540.</ref> to denote a plant of some kind, identified by the scholiast with the Śaṅkhapuṣpikā (''Andropogon aciculatus'').

न्य्-ओचनी
<u>'''Ny-ocanī'''</u> is found in the marriage hymn of the Rigveda (x. 85, 6), where some kind of ornament worn by women seems to be meant. The commentator Sāyaṇa interprets it as ‘female slave.’<br>==Foot Notes==

पक्ति
<u>'''Pakti'''</u> denotes a cooked object, probably a kind of ‘cake,’ in the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1633> Rv. iv. 24, 5. 7;<br> 25, 6. 7;<br> vi. 29, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 59, etc.</ref> One who cooks food is called '''Paktṛ.'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1633> Av. x. 9, 7. 11. 25;<br> xi. 1, 17;<br> xii. 3, 17;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 17;<br> x. 4, 2, 19.</ref>

पक्थ
<u>'''Paktha'''</u> is the name of a people in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1634> vii. 18. 7.</ref> where they appear as one of the tribes that opposed<ref name=fx2_ve1_1634> Roth, ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 95, thought that the Pakthas were allies of the Trtsus, but this view is certainly incorrect. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 260.</ref> the '''[[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]]-Bharatas''' in the '''[[दाशराज्ञ|Dāśarājña]].''' or ‘battle of the ten kings.’ Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_1634> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 430, 431.</ref> compares  them with the tribe of  and their country , mentioned as in the north-west of India by Herodotus,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1634> vii. 65 ();<br> iii. 102 and iv. 44 ().</ref> and with the modern Pakhthūn in Eastern Afghanistan, holding that they were a northern tribe; this is probable, since the Bharatas seem to have occupied the [[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]], or ‘Middle Land.’ In three passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_1634> viii. 22, 10;<br> 49, 10;<br> x. 61, 1.</ref> a [[पक्थ|Paktha]] is referred to as a protégé of the Aśvins. The second connects him with '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],''' whose tribe, the '''Pūrus,''' were aided by the Pakthas in their unsuccessful onslaught on '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]].''' In the third passage he seems specified as '''Tūrvāyaṇa,''' and appears as an opponent of '''Cyavāna.'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1634> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 71-77.</ref> Probably, therefore, [[पक्थ|Paktha]] in all cases denotes the king of the [[पक्थ|Paktha]] people.

पक्व
<u>'''Pakva,'''</u> ‘cooked,’ is used substantively as meaning ‘cooked food’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1635> Rv. vi. 63, 9;<br> Av. vi. 119, 2;<br> xii. 3, 55;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 1, 26;<br> ii. 6, 1, 7, etc.</ref> or ‘cooked milk.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1635> Rv. i. 62, 9;<br> 180, 3;<br> ii. 40, 2;<br> iii. 30, 14;<br> vi. 44, 24, etc.</ref> The word is also used of ‘baked’ bricks.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1635> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 2, 22;<br> vii. 2, 1, 7.</ref>

पक्ष
<u>'''Pakṣa'''</u> is, in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1636> ix. 3, 4.</ref> applied to some part of a house, either the ‘side posts,’ according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1636> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1636> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 153.</ref> and Grill,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1636> ''Hundert Lieder^2,'' 188.</ref> or ‘sides,’ as understood by Whitney<ref name=fx5_ve1_1636> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 526.</ref> and Bloomfield.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1636> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 597.</ref> The description of the roof ('''[[छदिस्|Chadis]]''') in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_1636> iii. 7, 3.</ref> as ''catuṣ-[[पक्ष|pakṣa]],'' ‘four-sided,’ tells in favour of the second explanation. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_1636> i. 5, 12, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 210.</ref> [[पक्ष|Pakṣa]] is used of the sides of a chariot. For [[पक्ष|Pakṣa]] as the ‘half’ of a month, see '''[[मास|Māsa]].''' 

पक्षस्
<u>'''Pakṣas'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1637> viii. 8, 22.</ref> and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1637> vii. 7.</ref> meaning the ‘sides’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1637> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 506;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 117.</ref> of a chariot. In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_1637> xxx. 5.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1637> i. 2, 3, 1.</ref> it is used of the sides of a hut or chamber ('''[[शाला|Śālā]]'''). In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx6_ve1_1637> xxix. 5.</ref> it means the ‘wing’ of a door. In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_1637> ii. 9.</ref> the ‘half’ of an army is so named, and in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_1637> xxiii. 6, 6.</ref> it means the ‘half’ of a month, or ‘fortnight.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[पक्ष|Pakṣa]].'''

पक्षिन्
<u>'''Pakṣin'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1638> i. 48. 5;<br> 182, 5;<br> x. 127, 5, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1638> Av. iv. 34, 4;<br> xi. 5, 21;<br> xii. 1, 51;<br> xiii. 2, 33;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 8;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 23;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 5, 18, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘winged’ creature, more particularly a ‘bird.’

पङ्क्ति
<u>'''Paṅkti,'''</u> originally a ‘set of five,’ denotes as early as the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1639> x. 117, 8, as taken by the St. Petersburg Dictionary.</ref> a ‘series’ generally. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve1_1639> x. 38, 39.</ref> the word is used of the series of a man's ancestors whom he purifies by certain conduct.

पचत
<u>'''Pacata,'''</u> like '''[[पक्ति|Pakti]],''' denotes ‘cooked food’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1640> i. 61, 7;<br> x. 116, 8.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1640> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 60;<br> xxiii. 13;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21, etc.</ref>

पचन
<u>'''Pacana'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1641> i. 162, 6.</ref> and the Śatapatha Brāhamaṇa<ref name=fx2_ve1_1641> vi. 5, 43, 3. 4;<br> xiv. 1, 2, 21.</ref> denotes a ‘vessel for cooking’ food. 

पज्र
<u>'''Pajra'''</u> is the name of the family from which '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]]''' sprang ('''[[पज्रिय|Pajriya]]'''). It is mentioned several times in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1642> i. 117, 10;<br> 122, 7. 8;<br> 126, 4. 5.</ref> According to Pischel,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1642> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 97, 98.</ref> the epithet ''[[पृक्ष-याम|pṛkṣa-yāma]]''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1642> Rv. i. 127, 8, where Roth (St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'') thinks this compound is probably a proper name.</ref> applied to them means ‘carrying out brilliant sacrificial performances,’ which won for them '''Śrutaratha's''' generosity. In two passages<ref name=fx4_ve1_1642> Rv. viii. 4, 17;<br> 6, 47.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx5_ve1_1642> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[पज्र|pajra]].''</ref> sees a [[पज्र|Pajra]] called Sāmaṅ. This is uncertain, but in any case a [[पज्र|Pajra]] seems clearly alluded to. Elsewhere<ref name=fx6_ve1_1642> Rv. i. 190, 5, where the reference is clearly hostile and contemptuous.</ref> it is very doubtful whether the word is a proper name at all. In the [[शाट्यायन|Śāṭyāyana]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_1642> Cited by Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 51, 4.</ref> the Pajras are declared to be Aṅgirases.

पज्रा
<u>'''Pajrā'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1643> ix. 82, 14.</ref> where Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1643> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 110.</ref> sees in the word the name of the wife of the sacrificer, '''[[पज्र|Pajra]],''' while Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1643> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[पज्र|pajra]].''</ref> takes it to be an epithet (‘stout’) of the Soma plant. The sense is thus uncertain.

पज्रिय
<u>'''Pajriya'''</u> ‘descendant of [[पज्र|Pajra]],’ is the patronymic<ref name=fx1_ve1_1644> ''Cf.'' '''[[तुग्र्य|Tugrya]],''' n. 1.</ref> of '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1644> i. 116, 7;<br> 117, 6;<br> 120, 5.</ref>

पञ्च-जनाः
<u>'''Pañca-janāḥ,'''</u> the ‘five peoples,’ are mentioned under various names in Vedic literature.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1645> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 31;<br> iv. 27;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 1, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, v. 6;<br> xxxii. 6;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2, 9 (''[[पञ्च-जनाः|pañca-janāḥ]]'' as a compound). See also ''pañca mānuṣāḥ,'' Rv. viii. 9, 2;<br> ''mānavāḥ,'' Av. iii. 21, 5;<br> 24, 3;<br> xii. 1, 15;<br> ''janāḥ,'' Rv. iii. 37, 9;<br> 59, 8;<br> vi. 14, 4;<br> viii. 32, 22;<br> ix. 65, 23;<br> 92, 3;<br> x. 45, 6;<br> ''kṛṣṭayaḥ,'' ii. 2, 10;<br> iii. 53, 16;<br> iv. 38, 10;<br> x. 60, 4;<br> 119, 6;<br> Av. iii. 24, 3;<br> ''kṣitayaḥ,'' Rv. i. 7, 9;<br> 176, 3;<br> v. 35, 2;<br> vi. 46, 7;<br> vii. 75, 4;<br> 79, 1;<br> ''carṣaṇyaḥ,'' Rv. v. 86, 2;<br> vii. 15, 2;<br> ix. 101, 9. See Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 204. Every book of the Rigveda has a mention of the five peoples: one such in ii. and iv.;<br> two in i., v., vi., vii., viii.;<br> three in iii. and ix.;<br> four in x.</ref> Who are meant by the five is very uncertain. The [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1645> iii. 31.</ref> explains the five to be gods, men, Gandharvas and Apsarases, snakes, and the Fathers.  [[औपमन्यव|Aupamanyava]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1645> In [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 8.</ref> held that the four castes ('''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''') and the '''Niṣādas''' made up the five, and Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx4_ve1_1645> On Rv. i. 7, 9, etc.</ref> is of the same opinion. [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1645> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> thinks that the five are the Gandharvas, fathers, gods, Asuras, and Rakṣases. No one of these explanations can be regarded as probable. Roth<ref name=fx6_ve1_1645> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[कृष्टि|kṛṣṭi]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erläuterungen,'' 28. For his view, Av. iii. 24, 3, can be cited: ''pañca pradiśo mānavīḥ pañca kṛṣṭayaḥ,'' ‘the five directions, the five races of men.’</ref> and Geldner<ref name=fx7_ve1_1645> ''Siebenzig Lieder,'' 18. See, however, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], Glossar,'' 103, where he recognizes the use of the phrase to denote five tribes, as well as all mankind.</ref> think that all the peoples of the earth are méant: just as there are four quarters ('''[[दिश्|Diś]]'''), there are peoples at the four quarters (N. E. S. W.), with the Āryan folk in the middle. Zimmer<ref name=fx8_ve1_1645> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 119-123. His view is accepted by Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 153;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 179, is doubtful.</ref> opposes this view on the ground that the inclusion of all peoples in one expression is not in harmony with the distinction so often made between Āryan and [[दास|Dāsa]]; that neither ''janāsaḥ,'' ‘men,’<ref name=fx9_ve1_1645> ''Cf.'' its use in Rv. ii. 12, ''sa janāsa Indraḥ,'' where the address must be to Āryan men.</ref> nor ''mānuṣāḥ,'' ‘people,’<ref name=fx10_ve1_1645> ''Cf.'' Rv. viii. 9, 2, and i. 52, 9, with viii. 70, 11;<br> x. 28, 8.</ref> could be used of non-Āryans; that the Soma is referred to as being among the five tribes;<ref name=fx11_ve1_1645> Rv. ix. 65, 23.</ref> that the five tribes are mentioned as on the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],'''<ref name=fx12_ve1_1645> Rv. vi. 61, 12 ''(pañca jātā). Cf.'' x. 53, 4.</ref> and that Indra is ''[[पाञ्चजन्य|pāñcajanya]],''<ref name=fx13_ve1_1645> v. 32, 11. Agni is ‘of the five tribes,’ Rv. ix. 66, 20. Atri also is so described, Rv. i. 117, 3.</ref> ‘belonging to the five peoples.’ He concludes that Āryans alone are meant, and in particular the five tribes of the '''Anus, Druhyus, Yadus, Turvaśas,''' and '''Pūrus,''' who are all mentioned together in one or perhaps two hymns of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx14_ve1_1645> Rv. i. 108, 8. In vii. 18, cited by Zimmer, 122, the five tribes do not occur ''eo nomine,'' for '''[[यक्षु|Yakṣu]]''' replaces Yadu. But it is probable that Yadu is meant by [[यक्षु|Yakṣu]].</ref> and four of whom occur in another hymn.<ref name=fx15_ve1_1645> Rv. viii. 10, 5.</ref> But he admits that the expression might easily be used more generally later. Hopkins<ref name=fx16_ve1_1645> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 260.</ref> has combated Zimmer's view, but his own opinion rests mainly on his theory that there was no people named [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], but only a king of the Yadus called [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], and that theory is not very probable. <br><br>In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx17_ve1_1645> xiii. 5, 4, 14.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx18_ve1_1645> viii. 23.</ref> the five peoples are opposed to the Bharatas, and in the former work<ref name=fx19_ve1_1645> It is a conjecture of Weber's, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 202, that the five peoples are identical with the '''Pañcālas,''' and the seven mentioned in Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 23, with the Kuru-Pañcālas.</ref> seven peoples are alluded to.

पञ्च-दशी
<u>'''Pañca-daśī,'''</u> ‘the fifteenth day of the month,’ is already mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 5, 10, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

पञ्च-नद
<u>'''Pañca-nada,'''</u> ‘having five streams,’ is not found until the epic period as the name of the Panjāb, which has no designation in the earlier literature. The importance of the Panjāb as the home<ref name=fx1_ve1_1647> See, ''e.g.,'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 32 ''et seq.''</ref> of the Rigveda has been greatly diminished by recent research, Hopkins,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1647> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 19-28. ''Cf.''
