Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 145, 441.</ref> Pischel,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1647> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218.</ref> and Geldner<ref name=fx4_ve1_1647> ''Ibid.,'' 3, 152.</ref> having on different grounds shown reason for believing that the Rigveda, at least in great part, was composed farther east, in the '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]],''' which admittedly was the home of the later Vedic culture. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx5_ve1_1647> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 98 ''et seq.'' But see '''Divodāsa.''' ''Cf.'' also Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 189.</ref> considers that the Rigveda belongs in part to the Panjāb, or rather to Arachosia, and in part to the Middle Country. See also '''Kuru, [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]].'''

पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण
<u>'''Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa.'''</u> See '''Tāṇdya.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पञ्चाल
<u>'''Pañcāla'''</u> is the later name<ref name=fx1_ve1_1649> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 7.</ref> of the people called '''[[क्रिवि|Krivi]]''' in the Rigveda. The Pañcālas are rarely referred to except in connexion with the '''Kurus,''' and the kings of the Kuru-Pañcālas are mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1649> viii. 14</ref> In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1649> xxx. 2 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 471).</ref> the Pañcālas appear as the people of '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]] [[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]].'''  In the Upaniṣads and later<ref name=fx4_ve1_1649> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 1 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 3, 1;<br> [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]] Prātiśākhya, ii. 12, 44;<br> [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 6;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 13, 6, etc.</ref> the Brahmins of the Pañcālas figure as taking part in philosophical and philological discussions. The Saṃhitopaniṣad [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1649> 2. ''Cf. Indische Studien,'' 4, 375, n.;<br> 8, 92, n. 1.</ref> makes mention of the [[प्राच्य|Prācya]]-Pañcālas.<br><br>The Pañcālas, no doubt, included other tribes besides the Krivis. The name seems to refer to five tribes, and it has been suggested<ref name=fx6_ve1_1649> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 202;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 108, n. 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 191 ''et seq.'';<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 10, 90, 114, 115, 125, 135, 136.</ref> that the Pañcālas represent the five tribes of the Rigveda, but the suggestion is not very probable. There is no trace in Vedic literature of the Epic division of the Pañcālas into northern (''uttara'') and southern (''dakṣiṇa''). The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_1649> xiii. 5, 4, 7.</ref> mentions their town '''[[परिचक्रा|Paricakrā]];''' other towns to which allusion seems to be made were '''[[काम्पील|Kāmpīla]]''' and kauśāmbī.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1649> See '''[[कौशाम्बेय|Kauśāmbeya]].'''</ref> Of their kings and chiefs, as distinguished from kings of the Kuru-Pañcālas, we hear of '''[[क्रैव्य|Kraivya]], [[दुर्मुख|Durmukha]], [[प्रवाहण जैवलि|Pravāhaṇa Jaivali]],''' and '''Śona.'''

पञ्चाल-चण्ड
<u>'''Pañcāla-caṇḍa'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1650> iii. 1, 6.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1650> vii. 18.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 391;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 50, 315, 326.</ref> Āraṇyakas.

पञ्चावि
<u>'''Pañcāvi'''</u> occurs several times in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1651> xviii. 26;<br> xxi. 14;<br> xxiv. 12;<br> xxviii. 26.</ref> in the sense of ‘aged five lamb-periods’ (of six months), that is, ‘thirty months old.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1651> ''Cf.'' '''[[त्र्य्अवि|Tryavi]].'''</ref>

पञ्चौदन
<u>'''Pañcaudana'''</u> is an adjective in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1652> iv. 14, 7;<br> ix. 5, 8 ''et seq.''</ref> meaning ‘prepared with five rice-messes.’ The cooking of five rice dishes is referred to in the same Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1652> ix. 5, 37.</ref> 

पटल
<u>'''Paṭala'''</u> as early as the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1653> i. 21. 22.</ref> denotes ‘section’ of a work, a sense occurring in the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve1_1653> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xi. 9. 20;<br> xiii. 21, 2;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 6. 7.</ref> and later.

पठर्वन्
<u>'''Paṭharvan'''</u> appears to be the name of a man in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1654> i. 112, 17, with Sāyaṇa's note.</ref> According to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1654> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 204.<br><br>''Cf.'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 147, 148.</ref> however, the word is Paṭharu, and is the name of a fort which was saved by a rain-storm from being set on fire.

पड्गृभि
<u>'''Paḍgṛbhi,'''</u> ‘seizing by the foot,’<ref name=fx1_ve1_1655> But it may mean ‘seizing with a cord.’ ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 34 (top);<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 236.</ref> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1655> x. 49, 5.</ref> of either a man<ref name=fx3_ve1_1655> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165.</ref> or a demon. See also '''[[पड्बीश|Paḍbīśa]].'''

पड्-बीश
<u>'''Paḍ-bīśa,'''</u> the ‘foot-fetter’ of a horse in five passages, two in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1656> i. 162, 14. 16 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 9, 1. 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 38. 39.</ref> and one each in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1656> vi. 2, 13 (Mādhyaṃdina).</ref> the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve1_1656> v. 1, 12.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1656> ix. 7;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 57, n. 3.</ref> Elsewhere<ref name=fx5_ve1_1656> Rv. x. 97, 16;<br> Av. viii. 1, 4;<br> xii. 5, 15;<br> xvi. 8, 27;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 10, 3;<br> [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 10.</ref> its uses are metaphorical. According to Roth,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1656> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the literal sense is ‘foot-fastening’ (''paḍ'' being = ''pad,'' ‘foot,’ and ''bīśa,'' written ''vīśa'' in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, being connected with the Latin ''vincire,'' ‘bind’). Pischel<ref name=fx7_ve1_1656> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 233-236.</ref> objects that the sense of ‘foot-fastening’ involves the absurdity, in the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] passages, of a fine horse from the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus) being spoken of as tearing up the peg to which it is fastened. He suggests instead the meaning of ‘hobble,’ which must be right.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1656> He explains the first part of the word as derived from ''paś,'' ‘tie.’ ''Cf.'' Macdoneli, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 34 (top). But the form ''paḍ'' may be due to a false analogy, and the sense of ‘footfastener’ may express ‘hobble’ quite satisfactorily;<br> it is not confined to a rope tied to a peg in the ground.</ref> 

पण
<u>'''Paṇa,'''</u> with '''[[प्रतिपण|Pratipaṇa]],''' is found in a hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1657> iii. 15, 4. 6 (in the Paippalāda recension;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 112).</ref> denoting the process of bargaining and selling. The root ''paṇ,'' from which the word is derived, is employed in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1657> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 55;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 3, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 27. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 10, 1.</ref> while Paṇana in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1657> iii. 3, 2, 19. The root does not occur in the Rigveda, but its etymology is vouched for by the Greek , ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 84, n. 3.</ref> denotes ‘trafficking.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[वणिज्|Vaṇij]].'''

पणि
<u>'''Paṇi'''</u> in the Rigveda appears to denote a person who is rich, but who does not give offerings to the gods, or bestow '''Dakṣiṇās''' on the priests, and who is therefore an object of intense dislike to the composers of the Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1658> Rv. i. 33, 3;<br> 83, 2;<br> 151, 9;<br> 180, 7;<br> iv. 28, 7;<br> v. 34, 5-7;<br> 61, 8;<br> vi. 13, 3;<br> 53, 3;<br> viii. 64, 2;<br> 97, 2;<br> x. 60, 6;<br> Av. v. 11, 7;<br> xx. 128, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxv. 1.</ref> Hence the gods are asked to attack the Paṇis, who are also referred to as being defeated with slaughter.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1658> Rv. 1, 83, 4;<br> 184, 2;<br> iii. 58, 2;<br> v. 34, 7;<br> 61, 8;<br> vi. 13, 3;<br> 20, 4;<br> 33, 2;<br> viii. 64, 11.</ref> The [[पणि|Paṇi]] is opposed to the pious sacrificer as a niggard,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1658> Rv. i. 124, 10;<br> iv. 51, 3;<br> viii. 45, 14 (where the sense is doubtful). ''Cf.'' i. 93, 4;<br> v. 61, 1.</ref> and is spoken of as a wolf,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1658> Rv. vi. 51, 14.</ref> the symbol of enmity. In some passages<ref name=fx5_ve1_1658> Rv. i. 32, 11;<br> ii. 24, 6;<br> iv. 58, 4;<br> vi. 44, 22;<br> vii. 9, 2;<br> x. 67, 6;<br> 92, 3;<br> Av. iv. 23, 5;<br> xix. 46, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 8, 2, 3. It is impossible definitely to decide in which passages the mythical sense is meant, ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 157.</ref> the Paṇis definitely appear as mythological figures, demons who withhold the cows or waters of heaven, and to whom Saramā goes on a mission from Indra.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1658> Rv. x. 108.</ref> Among the Paṇis '''[[बृबु|Bṛbu]]''' was apparently important. In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_1658> Rv. viii. 66, 10.</ref> they are described as '''Bekanāṭas,''' or ‘usurers’ (?). In another<ref name=fx8_ve1_1658> Rv. vii. 6, 3.</ref> they are called '''Dasyus,''' and styled ''[[मृध्र-वाच्|mṛdhra-vāc]],'' probably ‘of hostile speech,’ and ''grathin,'' a word of uncertain meaning. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx9_ve1_1658> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 89.</ref> thinks that the latter epithet refers to the continuous flow of a speech which  is not understood, and that ''[[मृध्र-वाच्|mṛdhra-vāc]]'' means ‘śpeaking an enemy's speech,’ though not necessarily with reference to non-Āryans.<ref name=fx10_ve1_1658> See Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 23;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, 114;<br> Davidson, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 37, 23;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 31, n. 3.</ref> In two passages<ref name=fx11_ve1_1658> Rv. v. 34, 5-7;<br> Av. v. 11, 6.</ref> the Paṇis appear as '''Dāsas,''' and in one<ref name=fx12_ve1_1658> Rv. v. 61, 8. ''Cf.'' Roth, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 41, 673;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 361, who thinks that the [[पणि|Paṇi]] is compared unfavourably with a generous woman, but this is unlikely;<br> Hillebrandt, 1, 92, n. 3;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 58, 59 Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 364.</ref> a [[पणि|Paṇi]] is mentioned in connexion with wergeld ('''[[वैर|Vaira]]'''), being apparently regarded as equal to a man merely in the price put on his life, but in other respects as inferior.<br><br>It is difficult to be certain exactly who a [[पणि|Paṇi]] was. Roth<ref name=fx13_ve1_1658> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 17;<br> vi. 26.</ref> thinks that the word is derived from ''paṇ,'' ‘barter,’ and that the [[पणि|Paṇi]] is properly the man who will give nothing without return, hence the niggard, who neither worships the gods nor rewards their priests. This view is accepted by Zimmer<ref name=fx14_ve1_1658> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 257. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Geldner, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], Glossar,'' 103.</ref> and by Ludwig.<ref name=fx15_ve1_1658> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 213215. ''Cf.'' Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 319.</ref> The latter scholar thinks the apparent references to fights with Paṇis are to be explained by their having been aboriginal traders who went in caravans--as in Arabia and Northern Africa--prepared to fight, if need be, to protect their goods against attacks which the Āryans would naturally deem quite justified. He supports this explanation by the references to the Paṇis as Dasyus and Dāsas. It is, however, hardly necessary to do more than regard the Paṇis generally as non-worshippers of the gods favoured by the singers; the term is wide enough to cover either the aborigines or hostile Āryan tribes, as well as demons. Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx16_ve1_1658> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 83 ''et seq.;<br>'' 3, 268;<br> ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1894, 648.</ref> however, thinks that a real tribe is meant, the Parnians of Strabo, and that they were associated with the Dahae ('''[[दास|Dāsa]]'''). Moreover, he finds them associated in one passage<ref name=fx17_ve1_1658> Rv. vi. 61, 1-3.</ref> with the '''Pārāvatas,''' whom  he identifies with the  of Ptolemy,<ref name=fx18_ve1_1658> vi. 20, 3.</ref> and with '''Bṛṣaya,''' whom he connects with  of Arrian;<ref name=fx19_ve1_1658> iii. 8, 4.</ref> he also considers that the frequent<ref name=fx20_ve1_1658> The Paṇis occur twelve times in Maṇḍala vi.;<br> once each in ii. and viii.;<br> twice in v. and ix.;<br> thrice in iv. and vii.;<br> six times in viii.;<br> nine times in i.;<br> and four times in x., besides the references in the Saramā hymn, x. 108.</ref> mention of the Paṇis as opponents of '''Divodāsa''' shows that the latter was on the Arachosian Haraqaiti ('''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''') fighting against the Parnians and Dahae, as well as other Iranian tribes. But the identification of [[पणि|Paṇi]] and the Parnians is needless, especially as the root ''paṇ,'' which is found also in the Greek , shows a satisfactory derivation, while the transfer of Divodāsa to the Haraqaiti is improbable. See also '''Divodāsa''' and '''[[बेकनाट|Bekanāṭa]].'''

पण्डित
<u>'''Paṇḍita,'''</u> a ‘learned man,’ is not found until the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] period.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1659> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 4, 1;<br> vi. 4, 16. 17;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 14, 2;<br> Muṇḍaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, 8, etc.</ref>

पतङ्ग
<u>'''1. Pataṅga,'''</u> ‘flying,’ denotes a ‘winged insect’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1660> vi. 50, 1.</ref> and the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1660> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 19 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 14 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> 2, 14 (= 1, 14);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 9, 3;<br> 10, 2;<br> vii. 2, 1;<br> 7, 1;<br> 8, 1;<br> 10, 1;<br> Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5 (''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40).</ref>

पतङ्ग प्राजापत्य
<u>'''2. Pataṅga Prājāpatya'''</u> (‘descendant of Prajāpati’) is credited by the Anukramaṇī (Index) with the authorship of a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1661> x. 177, 1.</ref> in which [[पतङ्ग|Pataṅga]] means the ‘sun-bird.’ He is also mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1661> iii. 30, 1. ''Cf.'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 8;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xi. 14, 28.</ref>

पतञ्चल काप्य
<u>'''Patañcala Kāpya'''</u> is the name of a sage mentioned twice in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1662> iii. 3, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> According to Weber,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1662> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 434, 435;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 126, 137, 223, 236, 237.</ref> his  name is reminiscent of '''[[कपिल|Kapila]]''' and Patañjali of the ŚāṅkhyaYoga system, but this suggestion may be regarded as quite improbable.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1662> ''Cf.'' Garbe, ''Sāṅkhya Philosophie,'' 25, 26.</ref>

पतत्रिन्
<u>'''Patatrin'''</u> denotes a ‘flying creature’ generally in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1663> iii. 3, 3.</ref> or more particularly a ‘bird’ in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1663> viii. 7, 24;<br> x. 10, 14;<br> xiv. 2, 44.</ref>

पताका
<u>'''Patākā,'''</u> ‘banner,’ is not found until the Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1664> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 39, 41 (here erroneously mentioned as ''patāka,'' masculine).</ref> Its Vedic equivalent is '''[[ध्वज|Dhvaja]].'''

पति
<u>'''Pati, Patnī.'''</u>--Under these words denoting primarily, as the evidence collected in the St. Petersburg Dictionary shows, ‘lord’ and ‘lady,’ and so ‘husband’ and ‘wife,’ it is convenient to consider the marital relations of the Vedic community.<br><br>''Child Marriage.''--Marriage in the early Vedic texts appears essentially as a union of two persons of full development. This is shown by the numerous references<ref name=fx1_ve1_1665> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 117, 7;<br> ii. 17, 7;<br> x. 39, 3;<br> 40, 5. '''[[घोषा|Ghoṣā]]''' is the chief example of this condition. The Atharvaveda (i. 14) also refers to such a case (see Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 253). The ornaments of maidens, especially at seasons of festival, are referred to in Rv. i. 123, 11;<br> vii. 2, 5;<br> Av. ii. 36, 1;<br> xiv. 2, 59 ''et seq.''</ref> to unmarried girls who grow old in the house of their fathers (''[[अमा-जुर्|amā-jur]]''), and who adorn themselves in desire of marriage, as well as to the paraphernalia of spells and potions used in the Atharvavedic tradition<ref name=fx2_ve1_1665> ''Cf.'' Av. iii. 18 (= Rv. x. 145);<br> vi. 89;<br> 102;<br> 130;<br> 131;<br> vii. 36;<br> 37;<br> 38. Similarly there are many references to the love of the youth for the maiden, and his seeking her--''e.g.,'' Rv. i. 115, 2;<br> Av. ii. 30;<br> iii. 25;<br> vi. 8;<br> 9;<br> 82;<br> to their mutual affection--''e.g.,'' Rv. i. 167, 3;<br> ix. 32, 5;<br> 56, 3;<br> x. 34, 5;<br> and to jealousy and love philtres for the purpose of recalling wandering affections -''e.g.,'' Av. vi. 18;<br> 42;<br> 43;<br> 94;<br> 139;<br> vii. 45. The gifts of the lover are referred to in Rv. i. 117, 18. Some of these passages may, of course, refer to Hetairai, but not all.</ref> to compel the love of man or woman respectively, while even the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1665> vii. 55, 5. 8. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 134, 3;<br> Aufrecht, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 337 ''et seq.'' A different view of the passage is taken by Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 57 ''et seq.'' The Atharvaveda (iv. 5) shows that the view of Aufrecht was that early adopted in India.</ref> itself seems to present us with a spell by which a  lover seeks to send all the household to sleep when he visits his beloved. पत्ति
<u>'''Patti'''</u> is used in the Atharvaveda (vii. 62, 1) to designate the ‘foot soldier’ in war as opposed to the '''[[रथिन्|Rathin]],''' ‘charioteer,’ the latter defeating (''ji'') the former. One of the epithets of Rudra in the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]] liturgy of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xvi. 19) is ‘lord of footmen’ (''pattīnāṃ pati'').<br>==Foot Notes==

पत्नी
<u>'''Patnī.'''</u> See '''Pati.''' A part of the house is the ''Patnīnāṃ [[सदन|Sadana]],'' mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1667> ix. 3, 7.</ref> presumably the women's quarters. The phrase is borrowed from the ''Patnīśāla,'' ‘hut for the wife,’ of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1667> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 18;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 9, 8;<br> x. 2, 3, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 22 (''-[[शाला|śālā]]'');<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xix. 6, etc.</ref> ritual.

पथिन् सौभर
<u>'''Pathin Saubhara'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[सोभरि|Sobhari]]'''’) is mentioned in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1668> ii. 5, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> as the pupil of '''[[अयास्य आङ्गिरस|Ayāsya Āṅgirasa]].'''

पथि-कृत्
<u>'''Pathi-kṛt,'''</u> ‘path-maker,’ is not a rare epithet in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1669> ii. 23, 6;<br> vi. 21, 12;<br> ix. 106, 5;<br> x. 14, 15;<br> 111, 3, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1669> Av. xviii. 2, 53;<br> 3, 25, etc.</ref> showing clearly the importance naturally attached in primitive times to the finding of roads. The frequency  with which the epithet is applied to Agni<ref name=fx3_ve1_1669> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 1, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 5, 5;<br> xii. 4, 4, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, etc.</ref> suggests that there is here an allusion to fire burning the primæval forest and rendering advance possible. The god Pūṣan is ''[[पथि-कृत्|pathi-kṛt]],'' as guarding the flocks.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1669> Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 9;<br> xvi. 1, 17. The [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 1, 18, explains ''[[पथि-कृत्|pathi-kṛt]]'' merely as ''adhipati,'' ‘lord’;<br> but the sense must be more pregnant than that.</ref> The [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_1669> Rv. x. 14, 15, where the expression refers to their finding the way to the heavenly world;<br> but it is probably a transfer of an epithet of terrestrial application.</ref> or seers, as ‘path-makers,’ may be compared with the Roman Pontifices.

पद्
<u>'''Pad'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (xix. 6, 2) and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 3, 2, 3) denotes a ‘quarter.’ This sense is derived from the primary meaning of ‘foot,’ which as applied to quadrupeds would represent ‘one-fourth.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[पाद|Pāda]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पद
<u>'''Pada'''</u> in the sense of ‘quarter of a stanza’ is found as early as the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1671> i. 164, 24. 45.</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1671> Av. ix. 10, 19;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 25;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6. 10. 17, etc.;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxii. 1. 5.</ref> In the Brāhmaṇas it also denotes a ‘word’ as opposed to a ‘letter’ ('''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''').<ref name=fx3_ve1_1671> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvi. 5, where the sequence is half-stanza (''ardharca''), quarter-stanza (''[[पाद|pāda]]''), word (''pada''), and letter ''([[वर्ण|varṇa]]). Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 2, 6, 13;<br> xi. 5, 6, 9, etc.</ref>

पदि
<u>'''Padi'''</u> is found once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1672> i. 125, 2.</ref> where, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, the word probably designates some kind of animal. [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1672> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 18.</ref> explains it as equivalent to ''gantu,'' ‘a moving creature,’ but [[दुर्ग|Durga]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1672> In his commentary on [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> as meaning ‘bird.’ The passage may refer to catching the Padi in a net (''? [[मुक्षीजा|mukṣījā]]'').<ref name=fx4_ve1_1672> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 129;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 244.</ref>

पयस्
<u>'''Payas'''</u> denotes the ‘milk’ of the cow in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1673> i. 164, 28;<br> ii. 14, 10;<br> iv. 3, 9;<br> v. 85, 2;<br> x. 30, 13;<br> 63, 3, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1673> Av. iv. 11, 4;<br> xii. 1, 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 3. ''Cf.'' '''Go''' and '''[[क्षीर|Kṣīra]].'''</ref> More generally it has also the sense of ‘sap’ or ‘fluid’  found in plants,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1673> Av. iii. 5, 1;<br> x. 1, 12;<br> xiii. 1, 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 1;<br> xviii. 36, etc. So of Soma, Rv. ix. 97, 14.</ref> and giving them life and strength. In other passages it denotes the ‘water’ of heaven.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1673> Rv. i. 64, 5;<br> 166, 3;<br> iii. 33, 1. 4;<br> iv. 57, 8, etc.</ref> A vow to live for a time on milk alone occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_1673> ''Payo-[[व्रत|vrata]],'' ‘one who undergoes a vow (to subsist) on (nothing but) milk,’ ix. 5, 1, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 9. The Dīkṣita subsists on it alone.</ref>

पयस्या
<u>'''Payasyā'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve1_1674> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 13, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 11, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 22. 24;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 10. 21;<br> 5, 1, 12;<br> 2, 9, etc.</ref> denotes curds, said to consist of a mixture of sour milk and hot or cold fresh milk.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1674> See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 381, n. 2.</ref>

पर आट्णार
<u>'''Para Āṭṇāra'''</u> (‘descendant of Aṭṇāra’) appears in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1675> Taittīrīya Saṃhitā, v. 6, 5, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 3 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 473).</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve1_1675> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 16, 3;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 11.</ref> as one of the ancient great kings who won sons by performing a particular sacrifice. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1675> xiii. 5, 4, 4.</ref> he is styled [[हैरण्यनाभ|Hairaṇyanābha]], ‘descendant of [[हिरण्यनाभ|Hiraṇyanābha]],’ and in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1675> xvi. 9, 11.</ref> he is called Para Āhlāra [[वैदेह|Vaideha]], a fact testifying to the close connexion of '''[[कोसल|Kosala]]''' and '''[[विदेह|Videha]].''' A '''[[यज्ञ-गाथा|Yajña-gāthā]],''' or ‘sacrificial verse,’ there<ref name=fx5_ve1_1675> ''Ibid.,'' 13. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 7;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 7;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 165, n. 4.</ref> cited mentions '''[[हिरण्यनाभ|Hiraṇyanābha]] [[कौसल्य|Kausalya]]''' in connexion with Para.

परम-ज्या
<u>'''Parama-jyā,'''</u> ‘of supreme power,’ is understood by Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve1_1676> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 159.</ref> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1676> viii. 1, 30.</ref> as the proper name of a great man among the '''Yadus.''' But it is doubtful whether the word is more than an epithet.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1676> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 39.</ref> 

परशु
<u>'''Paraśu'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1677> i. 127, 3;<br> vii. 104, 21;<br> x. 28, 8;<br> 53, 9, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1677> Av. iii. 19, 4;<br> vii. 28, 1;<br> xi. 9, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6, 4, 10;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 35;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 11, etc.</ref> denotes the axe of the woodcutter. Of its form we know nothing. A red-hot axe was used in a form of ordeal ('''[[दिव्य|Divya]]''') applied in accusations of theft.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1677> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 16, 1.</ref> See also '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]].'''

परश्वन्
<u>'''Paraśvan.'''</u> See '''[[परस्वन्त्|Parasvant]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

परस्वन्त्
<u>'''Parasvant'''</u> denotes a large wild animal which Roth<ref name=fx1_ve1_1679> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> conjectures to be the wild ass. It is mentioned in the Vṛṣākapi hymn<ref name=fx2_ve1_1679> x. 86, 18.</ref> of the Rigveda, twice in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1679> vi. 72, 2;<br> xx. 131, 22.</ref> and in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1679> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 21, 1, where the commentator takes it to be the wild buffalo.</ref> in all of which passages the sense of ‘wild ass’ is satisfactory. More doubtful is the meaning of the word ''paraśvā(n)'' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_1679> i. 2.</ref> where the commentary explains it as ‘serpent.’ It is, of course, quite possible that the word has nothing to do with ''[[परस्वन्त्|parasvant]].'' Bühler<ref name=fx6_ve1_1679> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 63;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 17, n. 1;<br> ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 377, n. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 2, 633;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 86, 87;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 335;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 105.</ref> suggests connexion with the Pāli ''palāsāda,'' ‘rhinoceros.’

परा-वृज्
<u>'''Parā-vṛj'''</u> is a term found in four passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1680> i. 112, 8;<br> ii. 13, 12;<br> 15, 7;<br> x. 61, 8.</ref> in all of which it refers to a person in a forlorn condition, while one<ref name=fx2_ve1_1680> x. 61, 8.</ref> of them also speaks of him as going south. Sāyaṇa's<ref name=fx3_ve1_1680> On i. 112, 8, etc., ''of.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 152.</ref> view that the word is a proper name is most unlikely, while Grassmann's<ref name=fx4_ve1_1680> Translation of the Rigveda, 1, 23, and ''cf. Wo7rterbuch, s.v.''</ref> explanation of it as ‘cripple’ is still less probable.  Roth's<ref name=fx5_ve1_1680> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> interpretation of it as ‘exile’ seems clearly right in the passage which refers to the [[परावृज्|Parāvṛj]] as going south. Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve1_1680> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 185, 334, 335.</ref> accepts Roth's view for this passage, but in the others sees a reference to the child of a maiden exposed by her and in danger of being eaten by insects (''vamrī''). This view is supported by the fact that ''parāvṛkta'' seems to have the same sense,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1680> Rv. iv. 30, 19. ''Cf.'' iv. 30, 16;<br> 19, 9.</ref> and is accepted by Oldenberg.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1680> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 200. ''Cf.'' above, p. 481, n. 67.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 248;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 402.</ref>

पराशर
<u>'''Parāśara'''</u> is mentioned with '''[[शतयातु|Śatayātu]]''' and '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]''' in the Rigvedic hymn celebrating '''Sudās''''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1681> vii. 18, 21.</ref> victory over the ten kings. According to the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1681> vi. 30.</ref> he was a son of [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], but the Epic version makes him a son of '''[[शक्ति|Śakti]]''' and grandson of [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]. Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve1_1681> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 132.</ref> thinks that he is mentioned in the Rigveda along with [[शतयातु|Śatayātu]], perhaps his uncle, and his grandfather [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], as the three sages who approached Indra and won his favour for [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. He is erroneously credited with the authorship of certain hymns of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1681> i. 65-73.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 110, 111;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 324. The Parāśaras as a school appear in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Anukramaṇī (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 460).</ref> by the Anukramaṇī (Index).

परि-क्षित्
<u>'''Pari-kṣit'''</u> appears in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1682> xx. 127, 7-10. See also Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des Veda,'' 156, 157, and the verses in the Vaitāna [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxxiv. 9. The Vedic spelling is [[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]], not Parīkṣit.</ref> as a king in whose realm, that of the Kurus, prosperity and peace abound. The verses in which he is celebrated are later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1682> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 32, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 12;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 17.</ref> called ''Pārikṣityaḥ,'' and the Brāhmaṇas explain that Agni is ''[[परि-क्षित्|pari-kṣit]]'' because he dwells among men. Hence Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1682> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Bloomfield<ref name=fx4_ve1_1682> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 690, 691. but see ''Atharvaveda,'' 101, n. 9.</ref> regard [[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]] in the Atharvaveda not as a human king at all. This may be correct, but it is not certain. Both Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve1_1682> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 131.</ref> and  Oldenberg<ref name=fx6_ve1_1682> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 237;<br> ''Buddha,'' 396.</ref> recognize [[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]] as a real king, a view supported by the fact that in the later Vedic literature King '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]]''' bears the patronymic '''[[पारिक्षित|Pārikṣita]].''' If this be so, [[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]] belonged to the later period, since the [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] passage in which his name occurs is certainly late, and none of the other Saṃhitās know [[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]] at all. The Epic<ref name=fx7_ve1_1682> See Zimmer, ''loc. cit.''</ref> makes him grandfather of Pratiśravas and great-grandfather of Pratīpa, and Zimmer,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1682/> probably with justice, compares the [[प्रातिसुत्वन|Prātisutvana]] and Pratīpa found in another late [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] passage.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1682> xx. 129.</ref> But '''Devāpi''' and '''Śantanu''' cannot be brought into connexion with Pratīpa.<ref name=fx9_ve1_1682> Devāpi is really a Brahmin, son of [[ऋष्टिषेण|Ṛṣṭiṣeṇa]], and not connected directly with Śantanu. [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 10, identifies them as brothers and Kurus;<br> but the former part of the identification is, no doubt, wrong.</ref>

परि-घ
<u>'''Pari-gha'''</u> denotes an iron bolt or bar in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 24, 6. 10. 15) as often later.<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-चक्रा
<u>'''Pari-cakrā'''</u> is according to one reading the name of a '''[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]]''' town mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1684> xiii. 5, 4, 7.</ref> and identified by Weber<ref name=fx2_ve1_1684> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 192.</ref> with the later Ekacakrā, which was near '''[[काम्पील|Kāmpīla]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1684> Mahābhārata, i. 6094.</ref> There is a various reading [[परिवक्रा|Parivakrā]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1684> Accepted by the scholiast and Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 397.</ref>

परि-चर
<u>'''Pari-cara'''</u> is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1685> iv. 3, 5, 9. ''Cf. pari-caritṛ,'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 8, 1.</ref> in the sense of ‘attendant.’ In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1685> vi. 11;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 457.</ref> ''pari-caraṇa'' has the same sense metaphorically, the other two Vedas (Sāma and Yajur) being said to be subsidiary to the Rigveda.

परि-चर्मण्य
<u>'''Pari-carmaṇya'''</u> denotes a thong of leather in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vi. 12) and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (ii. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-तक्म्या
<u>'''Pari-takmyā'''</u> in a number of passages of the '''Rigveda'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1687> i. 116, 15;<br> iv. 41, 6;<br> 43, 3;<br> v. 30, 13;<br> 31, 11;<br> vi. 24, 9;<br> vii. 69, 4.</ref> denotes ‘night’ according to the St. Petersburg '''Dictionary.'''  Sieg<ref name=fx2_ve1_1687> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 128. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 36;<br> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 106.</ref> thinks that in one place<ref name=fx3_ve1_1687> i. 116, 15.</ref> at least the word signifies the decisive point of the race, something like the sense of '''[[प्रपित्व|Prapitva]].''' But this is very doubtful.

परि-दा
<u>'''Pari-dā'''</u> in a few passages of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1688> ii. 4, 1, 11;<br> ix. 2, 1, 17;<br> 4, 2, 17;<br> 4, 5;<br> 5, 1, 53.</ref> has the sense of ‘giving oneself up to the mercy or protection of another.’

परि-धान
<u>'''Pari-dhāna'''</u> denotes ‘garment,’ probably ‘under garment,’ in the Atharvaveda (viii. 2, 16) and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 1, 10). A garment of saffron is mentioned in the Śānkhāyana Āraṇyaka (xi. 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-पद्
<u>'''Pari-pad'''</u> seems in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1690> x. 28, 10;<br> metaphorically, viii. 24, 24.</ref> to denote a pitfall used to capture lions.

परि-पन्थिन्
<u>'''Pari-panthin,'''</u> ‘besetting the path,’ denotes ‘robber’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1691> i. 42, 3;<br> 103, 6;<br> x. 85, 32.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1691> Av. i. 27, 1;<br> iii. 15, 1;<br> xii. 1, 32;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 34, etc.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[तस्कर|Taskara]], [[तायु|Tāyu]], [[स्तेन|Stena]].'''

परि-पवन
<u>'''Pari-pavana'''</u> signifies in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (iv. 9. 10) an instrument for winnowing grain.<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-मित्
<u>'''Pari-mit'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1693> ix. 3, 1.</ref> in the description of a house, meaning perhaps the ‘crossbeams’ connecting the vertical posts.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1693> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 596;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 158;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 525.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''

परि-मोष
<u>'''Pari-moṣa'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1694> ii. 5, 5, 1;<br> vi. 1, 11, 5.</ref> signifies ‘theft,’ and ''parimoṣin'' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1694> xi. 6, 3, 11;<br> xiii. 2, 4, 2, etc.</ref> ‘thief.’ 

परि-रथ्य
<u>'''Pari-rathya'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1695> viii. 8, 22.</ref> meaning either ‘road’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1695> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 587, following Nīlakaṇṭha's explanation of ''[[परिरथ्य|parirathya]],'' Mahābhārata, viii. 1487.</ref> or a part of the chariot, perhaps as Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve1_1695> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 528.</ref> and Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve1_1695> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 506.</ref> render it, the ‘rim.’

परि-वक्रा
<u>'''Pari-vakrā'''</u> is the reading accepted in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 5, 4, 7) by the scholiast instead of the variant '''[[परिचक्रा|Paricakrā]],''' which is supported by the Epic Ekacakrā.<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-वत्सर
<u>'''Pari-vatsara'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1697> x. 62, 2.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1697> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] i. 5, 5, 6;<br> Mahābhārata, i. 3202, etc. So ''parivatsarīṇa,'' as an adjective, ‘relating to a full year,’ Rv. vii. 103, 8;<br> Av. iii. 10, 3.</ref> a ‘full year.’ It is often mentioned with other names of year (see '''[[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]]'''), and in the later five year cycle counts as the second year.

परि-वाप
<u>'''Pari-vāpa'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1698> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 10, 1;<br> vi. 5, 11, 4;<br> vii. 2, 10, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 21. 22.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve1_1698> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 24;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 11, 2, etc.</ref> denotes ‘fried grains of rice.’

परि-वित्त
<u>'''Pari-vitta'''</u> denotes an ‘elder brother who is not married when his younger brother is.’ The term occurs in the list of sinful persons in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1699> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 7;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvii. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 9.</ref> as well as in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1699> vi. 112, 3.</ref> where Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve1_1699> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 470.</ref> needlessly proposes to read ''parivettā,'' the ‘younger brother who marries before his eldest brother.’ The name for the younger brother in the older texts is Parivividāna.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1699> So in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]], Kapiṣṭhala, Maitrāyaṇī, and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitās, ''loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 580 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Phīlology,'' 17, 430 ''et seq.;<br> Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 522 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 315;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 362.</ref> 

परि-वृक्ता
<u>'''Pari-vṛktā, Pari-vṛktī, Pari-vṛttī,'''</u> are variant forms of the name of the rejected one among the royal wives. See '''Pati.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-वेष्टृ
<u>'''Pari-veṣṭṛ'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1701> ix. 6, 51.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1701> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 1, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 2, 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 13;<br> xxx. 12. 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 8, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 6;<br> iii. 8, 2, 3;<br> vi. 2, 13, 3, etc.</ref> denotes an ‘attendant,’ more especially one who serves up food, a ‘waiter.’ The feminine form Pariveṣṭrī signifies a ‘female attendant’ or ‘handmaid.’<ref name=fx3_ve1_1701> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 7, 4;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 21, n. 2.</ref>

परि-व्राजक
<u>'''Pari-vrājaka'''</u> (lit., ‘wandering about’) denotes in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (i. 14; ii. 8) a ‘mendicant monk.’<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-षद्
<u>'''Pari-ṣad'''</u> (lit., ‘sitting around’) denotes in the Upaniṣads<ref name=fx1_ve1_1703> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 1 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> ''daivī [[परिषद्|pariṣad]],'' Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 11, 13. 14.</ref> an ‘assemblage’ of advisers in questions of philosophy, and the Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1703> iii. 2, 40.</ref> refers to a teacher with his [[परिषद्|Pariṣad]] or ‘council.’ In the later literature the word denotes a body of advisers on religious topics, but also the assessors of a judge, or the council of ministers of a prince.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1703> ''Cf.'' Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 136, 137;<br> Foy, ''Die kōnigliche Gewalt,'' 16-19;<br> 3337;<br> 66;<br> Bühler, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 55, 56;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 124.</ref> But in none of these senses is the word found in the early literature, though the institutions indicated by it must have existed at least in embryo.

परि-ष्कन्द
<u>'''Pari-ṣkanda'''</u> (lit., ‘leaping around’) occurs in the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]]''' hymn of the Atharvaveda (xv. 2, 1 ''et seq.'') denoting, in the dual, the two footmen running beside a chariot.<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-ष्यन्द
<u>'''Pari-ṣyanda'''</u> (with water ‘flowing around’) in two passages of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ix. 1, 19; xiv. 3, 1, 14) denotes a sandbank or island in a river. <br>==Foot Notes==

परि-सारक
<u>'''Pari-sāraka'''</u> is the name of a place, an island formed by the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' ‘flowing around’ it, according to a story in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 19).<br>==Foot Notes==

परि-स्रुत्
<u>'''Pari-srut'''</u> is the name of a drink which is mentioned first in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1707> iii. 12, 7;<br> xx. 127, 9. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 68.</ref> and which was distinct from both '''[[सुरा|Surā]]''' and '''Soma,'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1707> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 2, 14. ''Cf.'' v. 5, 4, 10;<br> xi. 5, 5, 13;<br> xii. 7, 1, 7;<br> 8, 2, 15;<br> 9, 1, 1.</ref> but was intoxicating. According to Mahīdhara,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1707> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 34.</ref> the liquor was made from flowers ('''[[पुष्प|Puṣpa]]'''). Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve1_1707> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 281, 282.</ref> thinks that it was the family drink, and this is supported by the fact that in the Atharvaveda it twice occurs as a household beverage.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1707> See also Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 15;<br> xx. 59;<br> xxi. 29;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 2. Its nature is more elaborately explained in the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 1, 14;<br> xv. 10, 11;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 349, 350.</ref> Hillebrandt<ref name=fx6_ve1_1707> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 24, 8.</ref> is of opinion that it was very much the same as [[सुरा|Surā]].

परी-णह्
<u>'''1. Parī-ṇah'''</u> appears to denote a ‘box’ or something similar in the Atharvaveda (xix. 48, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

परी-णह्
<u>'''2. Parī-ṇah'''</u> is the name of a place in '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]]''' mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1709> xxv. 13, 1.</ref> the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1709> v. 1, 1.</ref> and the Sūtras.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1709> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 19, 1;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 6, 34;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 29, 32.</ref>

परी-शास
<u>'''Parī-śāsa'''</u> is the name of an instrument of the nature of tongs, used to lift the sacrificial kettle off the fire.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1710> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 3, 1;<br> 2, 1, 16;<br> 2, 54;<br> 3, 1, 20, etc.</ref>

परुच्-छेप
<u>'''Paruc-chepa'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] to whom the Anukramaṇī (Index) attributes a series of hymns<ref name=fx1_ve1_1711> Rv. i. 127-139.</ref> in the Rigveda, and whose  authorship is asserted in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1711> v. 12. 13 (where hymns Rv. i. 128, 129, 130, 133, 135, 137, 139, are attributed to him).</ref> and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1711> xxiii. 4. 5.</ref> Brāhmaṇas, as well as in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1711> x. 42.</ref> In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx5_ve1_1711> ii. 5, 8, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 116. Parucchepa's claim to authorship is very doubtful.</ref> he appears as a rival of '''Nṛmedhas.'''

परुष
<u>'''Paruṣa'''</u> seems to mean ‘reed’ in the Atharvaveda (viii. 8, 4) and ‘arrow’ in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xiv. 22, 20).<br>==Foot Notes==

परुष्णी
<u>'''Paruṣṇī'''</u> is the name of a river which is mentioned in the [[नदी|Nadī]]-[[स्तुति|stuti]] (‘Praise of Rivers’),<ref name=fx1_ve1_1713> x. 75, 5.</ref> and in the song of Sudās’ victory over the ten kings,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1713> vii. 18, 8. 9.</ref> which seems to have been made decisive by the rise of the river drowning the fugitives.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1713> It is impossible to decide precisely what part the river played in the battle. It is usually held that the enemies of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] tried to divert the stream, but failed, and were drowned in its current. So Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 11;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 154;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 103, holds that [[सुदास्|Sudās]] was caught between two opposing armies, and had to escape over the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]], that his enemies tried to divert it to render him more accessible to their attack, but failed, and were overwhelmed in the river. Hopkins, ''India, Old and New,'' 52 ''et seq.,'' may be right in rejecting ''in toto'' the theory of the attempted diversion of the waters, though in the ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 261 ''et seq.,'' he accepted the traditional view.</ref> In these passages and one of the eighth book of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1713> viii. 74, 15.</ref> where it is called a ‘great stream’ (''mahenadi''), the name is certainly that of the river later called Ravi (Irāvatī), as recognized by [[यास्क|Yāska]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_1713> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 26.</ref> Pischel<ref name=fx6_ve1_1713> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 208-210.</ref> sees a reference to it in two other passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1713> iv. 22, 2;<br> v. 52, 9.</ref> where ‘wool’ (''ūṛṇā'') is connected with the word ''[[परुष्णी|paruṣṇī]],'' and the allusion to the river is accepted by Max Müller<ref name=fx8_ve1_1713> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 315, 323.</ref> and Oldenberg,<ref name=fx9_ve1_1713> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 348.</ref> though they are not fully agreed as to the exact sense of the passages in question. Pischel suggests that the name is derived from the ‘flocks’ (''[[परुस्|parus]]'') of wool, not from the bends of the river, as understood by the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx5_ve1_1713/> or from its reeds, as Roth<ref name=fx10_ve1_1713> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 4''a.''</ref> suggests. <br><br>The mention of the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]] and the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] in the hymn celebrating the victory of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] has given rise to the conjectures of Hopkins,<ref name=fx11_ve1_1713> ''Op. cit.,'' 52.</ref> that the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] in that hymn is merely another name for the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]], and of Geldner,<ref name=fx12_ve1_1713> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], Glossar,'' 106.</ref> that the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]] there is merely a tributary of the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] (Jumna). But neither interpretation is either essential or even probable. The hymn is a condensed one, and may well be taken as celebrating two great victories of [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. There is a doubtful reference to the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]] in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx13_ve1_1713> vi. 12, 3. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 462;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 289.</ref>

परुस्
<u>'''Parus'''</u> means first a ‘limb’ or ‘member’ of the body,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1714> Rv. i. 162, 18;<br> x. 97, 12;<br> 100, 5;<br> Av. i. 12, 3;<br> iv. 12, 2. 3, etc.</ref> and is then applied metaphorically to the divisions of the sacrifice<ref name=fx2_ve1_1714> Rv. x. 53, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 9, 1.</ref> or of the year<ref name=fx3_ve1_1714> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 6, 1.</ref> (''cf.'' '''[[पर्वन्|Parvan]]''').

पर्ण
<u>'''1. Parṇa'''</u> denotes the ‘wing’ of a bird in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1715> i. 116, 15;<br> 182, 7;<br> 183, 1;<br> iv. 27, 4, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1715> Av. x. 1, 29;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 5, etc.</ref> It also means the ‘feather’ of an arrow in a late passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1715> x. 18, 14. ''Cf.'' Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 386.</ref> and more often later;<ref name=fx4_ve1_1715> Av. v. 25, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 25;<br> iii. 26, etc.</ref> and the ‘leaf’ of a tree from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1715> Rv. x. 68, 10;<br> Av. viii. 7, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 46, etc.</ref>

पर्ण
<u>'''2. Parṇa'''</u> denotes the tree ''Butea frondosa,'' later usually called '''[[पलाश|Palāśa]].''' It occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1716> x. 97, 5.</ref> in connexion with the '''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]],''' and with that tree as well as the '''[[न्यग्रोध|Nyagrodha]]''' in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1716> v. 5, 5.</ref> which mentions both amulets<ref name=fx3_ve1_1716> iii. 5, 4. 8.</ref> and the cover of sacrificial dishes<ref name=fx4_ve1_1716> xviii. 4, 53.</ref> as made from its wood. Its use for the  making of sacrificial implements like the ladle (''[[जुहू|juhū]]''),<ref name=fx5_ve1_1716> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 59, 7, 2. ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 1.</ref> or sacrificial posts,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1716> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 4, 13.</ref> or the small ladle called ''[[स्रुव|sruva]],''<ref name=fx7_ve1_1716> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2. ''Cf.'' viii. 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 11;<br> 7, 1, 9;<br> 8, 7.</ref> is mentioned. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx8_ve1_1716> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.,'' and ''cf.'' Kuhn, ''Die Herabkunft des Feuers und des Go7ttertranks,'' 148, 192;<br> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 20, 24;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 331, 332;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 91.</ref> ascribes its origin to the loss of a feather by the Gāyatrī when winning the Soma. The tree is also often mentioned elsewhere.<ref name=fx9_ve1_1716> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 10;<br> vi. 5, 1, 1;<br> xi. 1, 4, 2;<br> 7, 28;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 5, 4.</ref> Reference too is sometimes made to its bark (''[[पर्ण|parṇa]]-[[वल्क|valka]]'').<ref name=fx10_ve1_1716> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 3, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 4, 2, 18, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altinadisches Leben,'' 59;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 194, 195.</ref>

पर्णक
<u>'''Parṇaka'''</u> is the name of a man included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1717> xxx. 16.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1717> iii. 4, 12, 1.</ref> According to Mahīdhara,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1717> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> a Bhilla is meant--''i.e.,'' presumably a wild hillman, for he glosses '''[[निषाद|Niṣāda]]''' in the same way.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1717> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27.</ref> Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx5_ve1_1717> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> explains the word as meaning ‘one who catches fish by putting over the water a ''[[पर्ण|parṇa]]'' with poison,’ but this is apparently a mere etymological guess. Weber's<ref name=fx6_ve1_1717> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländiscnen Gesellschaft,'' 18, 281.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 119.</ref> rendering of the term as referring to a savage ‘wearing feathers’ is ingenious, but uncertain.

पर्ण-धि
<u>'''Parṇa-dhi'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1718> iv. 6, 5. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 300;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 375;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 154.</ref> denotes the part of the shaft in which the feather of the arrow is fastened.

पर्णय
<u>'''Parṇaya'''</u> is the name in two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1719> i. 53, 8;<br> x. 48, 2.</ref> either of a hero, as Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1719> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 149.</ref> thinks, or of a demon<ref name=fx3_ve1_1719> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> overcome by Indra. 

पर्य्-अङ्क
<u>'''Pary-aṅka'''</u> is the name of the seat of the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1720> i. 5.</ref> It seems to correspond to what is elsewhere called '''Āsandi;'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1720> Av. xv. 3, 3. ''Cf.'' xiv. 2, 65;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5, 6, 12.</ref> as used in the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], it can, however, hardly mean a long seat for reclining on, but rather a throne.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1720> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 397, 401;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 155;<br> Lanmar in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 765, 776.</ref>

पर्य्-आस
<u>'''Pary-āsa'''</u> is used in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 1, 2, 18) to denote the woof of cloth, the warp being called ''anuchāda.''<br>==Foot Notes==

पर्वत
<u>'''1. Parvata'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1722> i. 37, 7;<br> v. 56, 4.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1722> Av. iv. 6, 8;<br> vi. 12, 3;<br> 17, 3;<br> ix. 1, 18;<br> xii. 1, 11.</ref> is conjoined with ''giri'' in the sense of ‘hill’ or ‘mountain.’ From the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1722> i. 39, 5;<br> 52, 2;<br> 155;<br> 1;<br> 191, 9;<br> ii. 12, 2, 3;<br> 17, 5, etc.</ref> onwards<ref name=fx4_ve1_1722> Av. i. 14, 1;<br> iii. 21, 10;<br> iv. 9, 8;<br> viii. 7, 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 5, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 1;<br> xviii. 13, etc.</ref> it is common in this sense as connected with the waters of rivers which flow in the hills.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1722> Rv. vii. 34, 23;<br> 35, 8;<br> viii. 18, 16;<br> 31, 10;<br> x. 35, 2;<br> 36, 1, etc.;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' i. 80;<br> 2, 66.</ref> The legend of the mountains having wings is already found in the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1722> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 10, 13;<br> and Rv. iv. 54, 5, as explained by Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 174.</ref> In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx7_ve1_1722> ii. 13;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 407;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 28, n. 1.</ref> are mentioned the southern (''dakṣiṇa'') and the northern (''uttara'') mountains, evidently in allusion to the Himālaya and the Vindhya ranges. The plants (''[[ओषधि|oṣadhi]]'') and aromatic products (''añjana'') of the mountains are referred to in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1722> xix. 44, 6;<br> 45. 7.</ref> and their mineral treasures in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx9_ve1_1722> x. 69, 6.</ref>

पर्वत
<u>'''2. Parvata'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1723> vii. 87, 8</ref> denotes, according to Ludwing,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1723> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 159.</ref> a sacrificer whose generosity is praised. But it is probable that the god [[पर्वत|Parvata]], the spirit of the mountain, is meant.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1723> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> 

पर्वत
<u>'''3. Parvata'''</u> is mentioned several times in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1724> vii. 13, 34;<br> viii. 21;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 17. 4.</ref> along with '''[[नारद|Nārada]].''' The Anukramaṇī (Index) attributes to him the authorship of several hymns of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1724> viii. 12, ix, 104;<br> 105.</ref>

पर्वन्
<u>'''Parvan'''</u> denotes the knots of the reed or the joints of a plant,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1725> Av. xii. 3, 31;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i, 1, 2, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 1, 31, and ''cf.'' Rv. x. 68, 9.</ref> and more generally a part or limb of the body.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1725> Rv. i. 61, 12;<br> iv. 19, 9;<br> viii. 48, 5;<br> x. 89, 8;<br> Av. i. 11, 1;<br> 12, 2;<br> ii. 9, 1;<br> vi. 14, 1;<br> xi. 8, 12;<br> xii. 5, 71;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 31;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 35 ''et seq.;<br>'' iii. 4, 4, 2;<br> vi. 1, 2, 31;<br> x. 4, 5, 2, etc.</ref> It also designates a period of time, probably with reference to the breaks in the month at new and full moon.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1725> Rv. i. 94, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 43;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 35;<br> vi. 2, 2, 34, etc. ''Cf.'' '''[[मास|Māsa]].''' In the Sūtras the days of the four-monthly festivals (''cāturmāsaya'') are so called: Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 2, 13;<br> xxii. 7, 1. 16. 17;<br> xxiv. 4, 30;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 5, 6;<br> 10, 4. 18;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 2, 3;<br> and more often the periods of the change of moon: Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]. xxiv. 6, 4. 25. 30;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 2, 1;<br> 3, 1;<br> Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 8, 46, etc.</ref> In one passage<ref name=fx4_ve1_1725> vii. 103, 5.</ref> Geldner<ref name=fx5_ve1_1725> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], Glossar,'' 107.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 364, who quotes Tacitus, ''Germania,'' 11.</ref> thinks the word indicates a song section of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]].

पर्शान
<u>'''Parśāna,'''</u> ‘hollow,’ is mentioned several times in the Rigveda (vii. 104, 5; viii. 7, 34; 45, 41).<br>==Foot Notes==

पर्शु
<u>'''1. Parśu'''</u> denotes ‘rib’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1727> ix. 7, 6;<br> x. 9, 20;<br> xi. 3, 12.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1727> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 25, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 6, 2, 10;<br> x. 6, 4, 1;<br> xii. 3, 1, 6;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, etc.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[शरीर|Śarīra]].'''

पर्शु
<u>'''2. Parśu'''</u> seems in some passages<ref name=fx1_ve1_1728> Av. xii. 3, 31 ([[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 24. 25;<br> viii. 11;<br> lxi. 38. 39);<br> perhaps vii. 28, 1 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 4, 1. See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 407, 408;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 26 (where ''[[पर्शु|parśu]]'' is metrically needed), etc. ''Cf.'' Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> to denote a ‘sickle,’ being apparently a variant of '''[[परशु|Paraśu]].''' 

पर्शु
<u>'''3. Parśu'''</u> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1729> iv. 6.</ref> is explained in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1729> i. 105, 8;<br> x. 33, 2.</ref> as meaning the sides of a cistern (''[[कूप|kūpa]]'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_1729> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 100;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 107.</ref> But the sense of ‘ribs’ is quite adequate there.

पर्शु
<u>'''4. Parśu'''</u> occurs in one passage in a Dānastuti (‘praise of gifts’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1730> viii. 6, 46.</ref> as the name of a man. It is not certain that he is identical with '''[[तिरिन्दिर|Tirindira]],''' but the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1730> xvi. 11, 20.</ref> mentions [[तिरिन्दिर|Tirindira]] [[पारशव्य|Pāraśavya]] as the patron of '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]] [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].''' In another passage occurring in the Vṛṣākapi hymn,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1730> x. 86, 23. Apparently Vārttika 2, on Pāṇini, iv. 1, 177, where [[पर्शु|Parśu]] is explained as a feminine, Princess of the Parśus, refers to this passage. On the sense, ''cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 42;<br> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 107;<br> and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 2, 2, where the expression occurs, but where the sense is very dubious.</ref> [[पर्शु|Parśu]] [[मानवी|Mānavī]] occurs, apparently as a woman, daughter of Manu, but who is meant it is quite impossible to say. Excepting these two, there are no other occurrences in which the word has with any probability the value of a proper name in the Rigveda.<br><br>Ludwig,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1730> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 196 ''et seq.''</ref> however, sees in several other places an allusion to the Parśus. Thus in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_1730> x. 33, 2. The sense here is, no doubt, ‘ribs.’ See Geldner, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 184, n. 3;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 362, n.</ref> he finds a reference to the defeat of '''Kuruśravaṇa''' by the Parśus; in another<ref name=fx6_ve1_1730> vii. 83, 1, ''[[पृथु|pṛthu]]-parśavaḥ,'' which really means either ‘with large ribs’-''i.e.,'' ‘strong,’ as Roth, with Sāyaṇa, inclines to take it--or ‘with broad axes,’ according to Zimmer.</ref> he finds a reference to the Pṛthus and Parśus--''i.e.,'' the Parthians and the Persians. He also sees the Parthians in '''[[पार्थव|Pārthava]],''' a name found in one hymn.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1730> vi. 27, 8.</ref> The same view is taken by Weber,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1730> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 379;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 4;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 36 ''et seq.'' He confines his view to the equation of [[पर्शु|Parśu]] in Rigveda, viii. 6, 46, and the Persians. Hillebrandt, who is inclined to see relations with Iran in early times (see '''[[पणि|Paṇi]], [[पारावत|Pārāvata]], [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]]'''), does not in this connexion quote [[पर्शु|Parśu]] at all, and, though he mentions [[पार्थव|Pārthava]], does not regard it as probably referring to a Parthian (''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105). Brunnhofer, in his various works (''Iran und Turan,'' 1889;<br> ''vom Pontus bis zum Indus,'' 1890, etc.), finds constant references in the Veda to events in Iran, but his theories must be regarded as definitely unscientific. See also Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 264, n.</ref> who holds that historical connexions with the  Persians are referred to. But Zimmer<ref name=fx9_ve1_1730> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 134 ''et seq.;<br>'' 433. ''Ibid.,'' 434, 435, he refutes conclusively Ludwig's extraordinary view that [[पृथु|Pṛthu]] and [[पर्शु|Parśu]] are dialectical forms of the same word.</ref> points out that this conclusion is not justified; the Parśus were known to Pāṇini<ref name=fx10_ve1_1730> v. 3, 117.</ref> as a warrior tribe; the Pāraśavas were a tribe in south-west '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]];''' and the ''Periplus''<ref name=fx11_ve1_1730> c. 38.</ref> knows a tribe of Parthoi in north India. At most the only conclusion to be drawn is that the Indians and Iranians were early connected, as was of course the case. Actual historical contact cannot be asserted with any degree of probability.

पर्ष
<u>'''Parṣa'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1731> x. 48, 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 10. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238. Perhaps ''parṣin,'' in the compound ''[[इषु|iṣu]]-parṣin'' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 5, means ‘having a bundle (of arrows).’</ref> denoting in the plural ‘sheaves’ strewn over the threshing floor. ''Cf.'' '''[[खल|Khala]].'''

पलद
<u>'''Palada'''</u> occurs twice in one hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1732> ix. 3, 5, 17. ''Cf.'' Zimmer. ''Altindisches Leben,'' 153;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 194, 195.</ref> in the description of a house. It seems to mean bundles of straw or reeds used to thatch the house and render the sides wind and weather proof.

पलस्ति
<u>'''Palasti.'''</u> See '''[[पलित|Palita]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पलाल
<u>'''Palāla'''</u> is found with Anu-[[पलाल|palāla]] in the Atharvaveda (viii. 6, 2) as the name of a demon. The meaning of the word is ‘straw,’ in which sense it occurs in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (lxxx. 27), while the feminine form, Palālī, is found in the Atharvaveda itself (ii. 8, 3) as the straw of barley ('''Yava''').<br>==Foot Notes==

पलाव
<u>'''Palāva'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1735> xii. 3, 19, where some manuscripts read ''palāvā.''</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1735> i. 54, 1</ref> in the sense of ‘chaff.’ 

पलाश
<u>'''Palāśa,'''</u> like '''[[पर्ण|Parṇa]],''' denotes ‘leaf’ in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1736> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 4, 5;<br> v. 2, 1, 17 etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 14, 3.</ref> It also<ref name=fx2_ve1_1736> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 3, 19;<br> ii. 6, 2, 8, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 59.</ref> designates the tree ''Butea frondosa,'' of which [[पर्ण|Parṇa]] is the early name.

पलित
<u>'''Palita,'''</u> ‘grey-haired,’ occurs frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1737> i. 144, 4;<br> 164, 1;<br> iii. 55, 9;<br> x. 4, 5, etc.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1737> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 15, etc.</ref> It is the distinctive sign of old age. Those who, like certain descendants of '''[[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]],''' do not grow old,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1737> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 9, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 10, 6. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 54, and Rv. iii. 53, 16, where ''[[पलस्ति|palasti]]'' seems to mean ''[[पलित|palita]].''</ref> are said not to become grey-haired, while '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]''' is described as having in his old age become thin and grey-haired.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1737> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 49.</ref> The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1737> xi. 4, 1, 6. 14.</ref> in one passage observes that grey hairs appear first on the head, and elsewhere<ref name=fx6_ve1_1737> iii. 8, 2, 25.</ref> alludes to the hair on the arms having become grey.

पल्पूलन
<u>'''Palpūlana'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1738> xii. 4, 9. ''Cf.'' [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xi. 16.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1738> ii. 5, 5, 6.</ref> apparently meaning, properly, ‘lye,’ or water impregnated with some biting substance for washing clothes. In the [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] passage urine seems to be meant.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1738> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 695. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 74, 175.</ref> The verb ''palpūlaya,'' ‘to wash with alkaline water,’ occurs in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1738/> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]];<ref name=fx4_ve1_1738> i. 3, 5, 2. 3.</ref> and the Sūtras refer to hides (''[[चर्मन्|carman]]'')<ref name=fx5_ve1_1738> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 67.</ref> and garments<ref name=fx6_ve1_1738> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 8, 12. ''Cf.'' [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]. i. 6, 13, 15;<br> Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> so washed. ''Cf.'' also '''[[वासःपल्पूली|Vāsaḥpalpūlī]].'''

पल्लि-गुप्त लौहित्य
<u>'''Palli-[[गुप्त|gupta]] Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (‘list of teachers’) in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1) as a pupil of '''[[श्यामजयन्त लौहित्य|Śyāmajayanta Lauhitya]].'''  The name is obviously a late one, for Palli is not found in the early literature, and the name of the [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]] family is otherwise known in post-Vedic works only.<br>==Foot Notes==

पवन
<u>'''Pavana'''</u> (‘purifier’) in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1740> iv. 34, 2;<br> xviii. 3, 11. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 9.</ref> denotes an instrument for purifying grain from husks, etc.; either a ‘sieve’ or a ‘winnowing basket’ may be meant. In the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve1_1740> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 5, 7.</ref> it is mentioned as used for cleaning the bones of the dead after cremation.

पवमान
<u>'''Pavamāna'''</u> is a term very frequently applied in the Rigveda to the Soma ‘purifying itself’ by running through the sieve. Later it appears in a few passages<ref name=fx1_ve1_1741> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 20, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 17;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7.</ref> in the sense of ‘wind’ (as a purifier).

पवस्त
<u>'''Pavasta'''</u> in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1742> iv. 5, 6. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda. 156.</ref> apparently denotes ‘covers.’

पवि
<u>'''Pavi'''</u> denotes the ‘tire’ of the wheel of a chariot in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1743> i. 34, 2;<br> 88, 2;<br> 139, 3;<br> 166, 10, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 5.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1743> [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], ii. 7, 1, 15, 3, etc.</ref> Reference is made<ref name=fx3_ve1_1743> Rv. vi. 54, 3.</ref> to the necessity for fastening it on firmly, and the epithet ''su-pavi,'' ‘having a good tire,’ is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1743> Av. iv. 12, 6.</ref> with ''su-[[नाभि|nābhi]],'' ‘having a good nave,’ and ''su-[[चक्र|cakra]],'' ‘having a good wheel.’ The tires were, of course, of metal,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1743> Of gold in the case of the Aśvins and the Maruts, Rv. i. 64, 11;<br> 180, 1.</ref> and being sharp,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1743> Rv. i. 166, 10.</ref> could serve on occasion as weapons.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1743> Rv. v. 52, 9. ''Cf.'' vi. 8, 5, and x 180, 2.</ref> The St. Petersburg Dictionary in one passage of  the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx8_ve1_1743> vi. 30. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 4, 5. Mahīdhara, on the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, takes ''pavinā'' as ''vajrasadṛśena,'' ‘like a thunderbolt,’ and Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 239, 240, renders ''pavi'' by ‘bolt.’</ref> takes Pavi to mean a metal rim on the stone for pounding Soma, but this seems improbable, because no such metal attachment is elsewhere alluded to. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx9_ve1_1743> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 44.</ref> seems clearly right in accepting the sense of ‘sharp edge’ in this passage, especially as the stones in the Rigveda<ref name=fx10_ve1_1743> v. 31. 5.</ref> are, in allusion to their rolling action, styled ‘rims without horses and without chariots’ (''anaśvāsaḥ pavayo 'rathāḥ'').<br><br>The [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx11_ve1_1743> xii. 30.</ref> ascribes to Pavi the sense of arrow (''[[शल्य|śalya]]''), but this is very uncertain. The St. Petersburg Dictionary cites for this use two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx12_ve1_1743> ix. 50, 1;<br> x. 180, 2.</ref> but in one the secondary sense of sharp-edged weapon with reference to the bolt of Indra is quite likely, and in the other, where the expression ''vāṇasya pavi'' occurs, the sharp-edged pounding-stone of the ‘reed,’<ref name=fx13_ve1_1743> ''Cf.'' Rv. iv. 24, 9, where the expression ''vāṇaṃ duhanti,'' ‘they milk out the reed,’ occurs.</ref> meaning the stalk of the Soma plant, may be meant. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx14_ve1_1743> ''Op. cit.,'' 1, 43, 44.</ref> thinks a reference to the shape of the Soma plant is intended. Pavī-nasa, the name of a demon mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx15_ve1_1743> viii. 6, 21.</ref> seems to throw no light on this point, for while the St. Petersburg Dictionary takes it to mean ‘whose nose is like a spearhead,’ it is translated as ‘rim-nosed’ (presumably in allusion to the curved shape of the nose) by Whitney.<ref name=fx16_ve1_1743> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 497.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 248;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 12, n. 1.</ref>

पवित्र
<u>'''Pavitra'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1744> i. 28, 9;<br> iii. 36, 7;<br> viii. 33, 1;<br> 101, 9, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1744> Av. vi. 124, 3;<br> ix. 6, 16;<br> xii. 1, 30;<br> 3, 3. 14. 25, etc.</ref> the sieve used for purifying the Soma, the only mode of purifying it certainly<ref name=fx3_ve1_1744> ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 239, 240.</ref> known to the Rigveda. It seems clearly<ref name=fx4_ve1_1744> ''Cf.'' the names of it: ''aṇva,'' Rv. ix. 16, 2;<br> ''aṇvāni meṣyaḥ,'' 86, 47;<br> 107, 11;<br> ''avayaḥ,'' ii. 36, 1;<br> ix. 86, 11;<br> 91, 2;<br> ''tvac'' with ''avya'' or ''avyaya,'' ix. 69, 3;<br> 70, 7;<br> ''meṣyaḥ,'' ix. 8, 5;<br> ''rūpa avyaya,'' ix. 16, 6;<br> ''roman,'' alone or with ''avyaya;<br> vāra,'' alone or with ''avyaya,'' etc.</ref> to have been made of  sheep's wool, whether woven or plaited is not certain, for the expressions used are too vague to be decisive, though Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve1_1744> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 278, n.</ref> thinks ''hvarāṃsi''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1744> ix. 3, 2;<br> 63, 4.</ref> points to plaiting.

पवीर
<u>'''Pavīra,'''</u> according to the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1745> xii. 30, In Rv. i. 174, 4, ''pavīrava'' seems to mean ‘thunderbolt.’</ref> denotes a ‘lance.’ The epithet derived from this word, ''pavīravant'' or ''pavīrava,'' which is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1745> iii. 17, 3.</ref> and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1745> ''Pavīravant,'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 71;<br> ''pavīrava,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, 10, 2, 5, 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 12;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 11.</ref> is used of the plough, apparently in the sense of ‘having a metal share.’ The same epithet occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1745> x. 60, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 116.</ref> applied to a man, in the sense of ‘having a goad’ or ‘having a spear.’

पवीरु
<u>'''Pavīru'''</u> appears in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1746> viii. 51, 9 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiii. 82.</ref> as a '''[[रुशम|Ruśama]],''' being a prince or at least a wealthy noble.

पशु
<u>'''Paśu'''</u> means ‘animal’ generally, including man. There is frequent mention<ref name=fx1_ve1_1747> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 10, 1-4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 17;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 47-51, ''Cf.'' Av. xi. 2, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 10, 1-3;<br> v. 5, 1, 1. 2;<br> vi. 5, 10, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 28-31, etc.</ref> of the five sacrificial animals--the horse, the cow, the sheep, the goat, and man. Seven such domestic animals are spoken of in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1747> Av. iii. 10, 6.</ref> and later;<ref name=fx3_ve1_1747> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8, 4, 16;<br> ix. 3, 1, 20;<br> xii. 8, 3, 13 (where they are called ''jāgatāḥ,'' perhaps as numbering 12);<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], x. 2, 7.</ref> probably, as Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve1_1747> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 103.</ref> observes, merely as a sacred mystic number, not, as the commentator<ref name=fx5_ve1_1747> On Av. iii. 10, 6. The St. Petersburg Dictionary suggests ‘mule’ and ‘ass’ as the two making up seven (''cf.'' Mahābhārata, vi. 165 ''et seq.''). Zimmer's view (''Altindisches Leben,'' 76) is that ‘goat,’ ‘sheep,’ ‘ox,’ ‘horse,’ ‘dog,’ ‘ass,’ and ‘camel’ or ‘mule,’ are meant.</ref> explains, the usual five with the ass and the camel added. Animals are also referred to as ''ubhayadant''  and ''anyatodant.'' They are further<ref name=fx6_ve1_1747> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 5, 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 7 (where ''[[पुरुष|puruṣa]]'' must be read for ''[[परुष|paruṣa]]'').</ref> classified as those which take hold with the hand (''hastādānāḥ''), man (''[[पुरुष|puruṣa]]''), elephant (''[[हस्तिन्|hastin]]''), and ape (''[[मर्कट|markaṭa]]''), and those which grasp by the mouth (''mukhādānāḥ''). Another division is that of biped (''[[द्विपाद्|dvipād]]'') and quadruped (''catuṣpād'').<ref name=fx7_ve1_1747> Rv. iii. 62, 14;<br> Av. iii. 34, 1, etc. Zimmer, 73, n., suggests that the division is Indo-European, as the Inguvenic tables make a distinction between ''dupursus'' and ''peturpursus.''</ref> Man is a biped;<ref name=fx8_ve1_1747> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 10, 1, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 47, 48.</ref> he is the first (''prathama'') of the beasts;<ref name=fx9_ve1_1747> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 1, 18;<br> vii. 5, 2, 6.</ref> he alone of animals lives a hundred years (''śatāyus''),<ref name=fx10_ve1_1747> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 6, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 2, 5, 17.</ref> and he is king of the animals.<ref name=fx11_ve1_1747> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xx. 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 5, 7. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 18, 274.</ref> He possesses speech (''[[वाच्|vāc]]'') in conjunction with the other animals.<ref name=fx12_ve1_1747> Rv. viii. 100, 11.</ref> In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx13_ve1_1747> ii. 3, 2, with Keith's note.</ref> an elaborate distinction is drawn between vegetables, animals, and man in point of intellect.<br><br>Of animals apart from man a threefold division is offered in the Rigveda<ref name=fx14_ve1_1747> x. 90, 8.</ref> --into those of the air (''vāyavya''), those of the jungle (''āraṇya''), and those of the village (''grāmya''), or tame animals. The division into ''āraṇya'' and ''grāmya'' animals is quite common.<ref name=fx15_ve1_1747> Av. iii. 31, 3. ''Cf.'' ii. 34, 1, with Whitney's note, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 78;<br> xi. 2, 24;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 3;<br> 9, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 29. 32;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 1, 8;<br> 2, 8.
