''Cf.'' xi. 8, 3, 2, where there is reference to animals being tied up at night in their stalls.</ref> In the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx16_ve1_1747> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv, 3, 10, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 30.</ref> is found a division into ''eka-[[शफ|śapha]],'' ‘whole-hoofed’; ''kṣudra,'' ‘small’; and ''āraṇya,'' ‘wild,’ the two former classes denoting the tame animals.<ref name=fx16_ve1_1747/> The horse and the ass are ''eka-[[शफ|śapha]];''<ref name=fx17_ve1_1747> Zimmer, 74.</ref> the ''kṣudra'' are the sheep, the goat, and the ox: this distinction being parallel to that of ''ubhayadant'' and ''anyatodant.''<ref name=fx18_ve1_1747> ''Cf.'' Av. v. 31, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 6, 3, with [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 5: v. 1, 1, 3;<br> 2, 6.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx19_ve1_1747> ''Op. cit.,'' 77, 78.</ref> sees in a passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx20_ve1_1747> xi, 2, 24. 25, compared with xii. 1, 40, 51.</ref> a division of wild animals (''āraṇya'') into five classes: (1) those of the jungle described as the ‘dread beasts  which are in the wood’ (''mṛgā bhīmā vane hitāḥ''); (2) winged creatures, represented by the '''[[हंस|Haṃsa]],''' ‘gander,’ '''[[सुपर्ण|Suparṇa]],''' ‘eagle,’ '''[[शकुन|Śakuna]],''' ‘bird’; (3) amphibia--'''[[शिंशुमार|Śiṃśumāra]],''' ‘alligator,’ and '''[[अजगर|Ajagara]],''' ‘crocodile’ (?); (4) ‘fish,’ '''[[पुरीकय|Purīkaya]], [[जष|Jaṣa]],''' and '''[[मत्स्य|Matsya]];''' (5) insects and worms (described as ''rajasāḥ''). But this division is more ingenious than probable, and it is ignored by both Bloomfield<ref name=fx21_ve1_1747> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 631.</ref> and Whitney.<ref name=fx22_ve1_1747> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 633, 634.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72. 77.</ref>

पशु-प
<u>'''Paśu-pa'''</u> denotes ‘herdsman’ in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1748> i. 114, 9;<br> 144, 6;<br> iv. 6, 4;<br> x. 142, 2.</ref> Metaphorically the term is applied to Pūṣan.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1748> vi. 58, 2. ''Cf.'' of Pūṣan and [[रेवती|Revatī]], [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 2, 12.</ref>

पष्ठ-वाह्
<u>'''1. Paṣṭha-vāh'''</u> occurs in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1749> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 5, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 9;<br> xviii. 27;<br> xxi. 17;<br> xxiv. 13. 28. 29. etc.</ref> meaning an ox, four years old, according to the commentators. This qualification is, however, very doubtful, for Paṣṭhauhī, ‘cow,’ a word occurring quite frequently,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1749> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā vii. 1, 6, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 2;<br> xii. 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 27;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 3;<br> 8. 3, 2;<br> ii. 7, 2, 2, etc.</ref> is in one passage<ref name=fx3_ve1_1749> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 1, 11.</ref> accompanied by the adjective ''prathama-garbhāḥ,'' ‘having a first calf,’ which disproves the theory of the age adopted by the commentators.

पष्ठ-वाह्
<u>'''2. Paṣṭha-vāh'''</u> is mentioned as a seer of Sāmans in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1750> xii. 5, 11. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160.</ref>

पस्त्य-सद्
<u>'''Pastya-sad'''</u> (‘sitting in the house’) occurs in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1751> vi. 51, 9. ''Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 211.</ref> where the sense seems to be ‘inmate,’ ‘companion.’ 

पस्त्या
<u>'''Pastyā'''</u> (fem. pl.) is a word occurring in several passages of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1752> Rv. i. 25, 10;<br> 40, 7;<br> 164, 30;<br> iv, 1, 11;<br> vi, 49, 9;<br> vii. 97, 5;<br> ix, 65, 23;<br> x. 46, 6. See also iv. 55, 3;<br> viii. 27, 5, where [[पस्त्या|Pastyā]] appears as a goddess.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx2_ve1_1752> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> ascribes to it the meaning of ‘house’ or ‘dwelling,’ in the wide sense of the term, as well as that of the ‘family’ living in the house; and this view is accepted by Zimmer.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1752> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 149. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Über den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],'' 43, n. 4;<br> 63.</ref> On the other hand, Pischel<ref name=fx4_ve1_1752> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 211-22. So Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 107.</ref> finds in two of the passages<ref name=fx5_ve1_1752> vi. 49. 9;<br> vii. 97, 5, where the sense is ‘householder’ (''[[गृह|gṛha]]-stha'' or ''gṛhin,'' as Sāyaṇa renders it).</ref> usually referred to [[पस्त्या|Pastyā]] the neuter Pastya, which appears in '''[[पस्त्य-सद्|Pastya-sad]]''' and in '''[[पस्त्या-वन्त्|Pastyā-vant]]''' (where the length of the second syllable is not primitive¤), and which is certainly found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve1_1752> x. 96, 10. 11. In x. 96, 10, Roth takes ''pastyoḥ'' to denote the two parts of the Soma press, but Pischel, 2, 211, accepts Sāyaṇa's rendering ‘heaven and earth.’ In the compounds ''tripastya'' of Agni, Rv. viii. 39, 8;<br> ''vājapastya'' of Pūṣan, vi. 58, 2, of Soma, ix. 98, 12;<br> and ''[[वीर|vīra]]-pastya,'' v. 50, 4, the primitive word may very well be ''pastya,'' not ''[[पस्त्या|pastyā]].''</ref> in the metaphorical sense of ‘dwelling,’ ascribed to it in the Naighaṇṭuka.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1752> iii. 4, misquoted by Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 151, 2, as applying to ''[[पस्त्या|pastyā]],'' whereas it really refers to ''pastya.''</ref> In the other passages<ref name=fx8_ve1_1752> Rv. i. 25, 10 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 16, 1 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 2;<br> ii. 6, 12;<br> 7, 16;<br> iv. 4, 6 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 27;<br> Rv. i. 40, 7;<br> 164, 30 (used of Agni's home);<br> iv. 1, 11;<br> ix. 65, 23;<br> x. 46, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 12, 1 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 8 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 7.</ref> he thinks the word means ‘rivers’ or ‘waters’; in particular, where Soma in the middle of the Pastyās<ref name=fx9_ve1_1752> Rv. ix. 65, 23.</ref> is spoken of, the sees a reference to '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' with its several rivers,<ref name=fx10_ve1_1752> Rv. iii. 23, 4.</ref> '''[[आपया|Āpayā]], [[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]],''' and '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' (''cf.'' 2. '''[[पस्त्यावन्त्|Pastyāvant]]'''). In some passages<ref name=fx11_ve1_1752> Rv. iv. 55, 3;<br> viii. 27, 5;<br> and in ''[[पस्त्यावन्त्|pastyāvant]]'' in ix. 97, 18.</ref> he sees in [[पस्त्या|Pastyā]] the proper name of a stream, just as [[सिन्धु|Sindhu]] primarily means ‘river,’ then the ‘Indus.’

पस्त्या-वन्त्
<u>'''1. Pastyā-vant,'''</u> explained in the Pada text as Pastya-vant, occurs in several passages of the Rigveda. In two of them<ref name=fx1_ve1_1753> i. 151, 2;<br> ix. 97, 18;<br> but the latter passage is explained by Pischel as referring to '''[[पस्त्या|Pastyā]],''' the river, and by Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' as ‘kept in the stall.’</ref>  a rich householder seems meant, and in the two others reference to a ‘house’ is clear.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1753> ''[[बर्हिस्|Barhis]],'' Rv. ii. 11, 16, ‘of the house’;<br> ''kṣayān pastyāvataḥ,'' iv. 54, 5, ‘abodes having (fixed) habitations.’<br><br>''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 212.</ref>

पस्त्या-वन्त्
<u>'''2. Pastyā-vant'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1754> viii. 7, 29.</ref> in the locative parallel with '''Suṣoma, [[शर्यणावन्त्|Śaryaṇāvant]],''' and '''[[आर्जीक|Ārjīka]].''' It must apparently denote a place, as Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve1_1754> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 209.</ref> argues, probably corresponding to the locality ‘in the middle of the streams’ (''madhye pastyānām''), elsewhere<ref name=fx3_ve1_1754> Rv. ix. 65, 23.</ref> referred to as the home of Soma. Pischel<ref name=fx4_ve1_1754> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 219.</ref> suggests that Patiāla is meant, though he does not lay any stress on the similarity of name. In the north of Patiāla there are hills where the Soma might have grown. Roth<ref name=fx5_ve1_1754> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2. Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 260, 398, 399, takes [[पस्त्यावन्त्|Pastyāvant]] as a place-name, but thinks that ''[[पस्त्या|pastyā]]'' denotes ‘hamlet,’ or, as an epithet of Aditi, refers to her as a ‘housewife’ (Rv. iv. 55, 3;<br> viii. 27, 5).</ref> thought that something connected with the Soma press was meant.

पांसु
<u>'''Pāṃsu'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1755> vii. 109, 2;<br> xii. 1, 26.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1755> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 10, 2;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xii. 19, etc.</ref> denotes ‘dust’ or ‘sand,’ usually in the plural. Among the portents enumerated in the Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1755> vi. 8 (''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40). ''Cf.'' Varāhamihira, Bṛhatsaṃhitā, xxii. 6.</ref> is a rain of dust or sand (''pāṃsuvarṣa''), a phenomenon not rare in India.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1755> The adjective ''pāṃsura'' is found in Rv. i. 22, 17, with a variant, ''pāṃsula,'' [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], i. 3, 1, 3, 9. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 1, 9.</ref>

पाक-दूर्वा
<u>'''Pāka-dūrvā'''</u> is, in a verse of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1756> x. 16, 13.</ref> included with '''[[कियाम्बु|Kiyāmbu]]''' and '''[[व्यल्कशा|Vyalkaśā]]''' among the plants used for growing on the spot where the corpse of the dead man has been consumed with fire.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1756> See Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 342-350;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, xxxix.</ref> The verse is repeated in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx3_ve1_1756> vi. 4, 1, 2.</ref>  with the variant Kyāmbu. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1756> xviii. 3, 6.</ref> the word is read Śāṇḍadūrvā. [[पाकदूर्वा|Pākadūrvā]] is probably, as Sāyaṇa-understands it, ''paripakva-[[दूर्वा|dūrvā]],'' ‘ripe or edible millet.’ Śāṇḍadūrvā is explained by the commentator<ref name=fx5_ve1_1756> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 850. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70.</ref> in various ways, as millet ‘having egg-shaped roots’ (''i.e., sāṇḍa,'' not ''[[शाण्ड|śāṇḍa]]''), or as ‘having long joints,’ with the additional remark that it was called ''bṛhaddūrvā,'' ‘large millet.’ In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, on the other hand, the commentary explains [[पाकदूर्वा|Pākadūrvā]] as small millet.

पाक-स्थामन् कौरयाण
<u>'''Pāka-sthāman Kaurayāṇa'''</u> is celebrated as a generous donor  in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1757> viii. 3, 21. 24.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve1_1757> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 160.</ref> suggests, without much reason, that he may have been a king of the '''Anus.'''

पाकरु
<u>'''Pākaru'''</u> is mentioned as a disease, together with '''[[विषूचिका|Viṣūcikā]]''' and '''[[अर्शस्|Arśas]],''' ‘hæmorrhoids,’ in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1758> xii. 97 ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 393.</ref> Its nature is unknown; the etymology<ref name=fx2_ve1_1758> From ''pāka,'' ‘maturity,’ and ''aru = arus,'' ‘sore.’</ref> points to the sense of ‘developed sores,’ ‘ulcers.’

पाङ्क्त्र
<u>'''Pāṅktra'''</u> is the name of an animal mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], or ‘horse-sacrifice,’ in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1759> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 26. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 85.</ref> The ‘field-rat’ seems to be meant.

पाञ्च-जन्य
<u>'''Pāñca-janya,'''</u> ‘relating to the five peoples.’ See '''[[पञ्चजनाः|Pañcajanāḥ]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पाञ्चाल
<u>'''Pāñcāla'''</u> means a ‘king of the [[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] people,’ and is applied to '''[[दुर्मुख|Durmukha]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1761> viii. 23.</ref> and to '''Śoṇa''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1761> xiii. 5, 4, 7.</ref> The term is also found in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1761> iii. 29, 1. ''Cf.'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Anukramaṇī in ''Indische Studien,'' 3 460.</ref> See also '''[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]].''' 

पाञ्चि
<u>'''Pāñci,'''</u> ‘descendant of Pañcan,’ is the name of a teacher mentioned with disapproval in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1762> i. 2, 5, 9;<br> ii. 1, 4, 27. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 434.</ref>

पाटव
<u>'''Pāṭava,'''</u> ‘descendant of Paṭu,’ is a patronymic of '''[[चाक्र|Cākra]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 8, 1, 17; 9, 3, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

पाटा
<u>'''Pāṭā'''</u> is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1764> ii. 27, 4.</ref> and in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1764> xxxvii. 1;<br> xxxviii. 18. ''Cf.'' Ṛgvidhāna, iv. 12, 1.</ref> It is assumed by the commentator to be identical with the later Pāṭhā, the plant ''Clypea hernandifolia,'' which was much used medicinally, and is still so used at the present day according to Roth.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1764> Quoted in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 68. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 190;<br> 17, 266;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 305, n. 1;<br> ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' May, 1885, xlii-xliv.</ref> Very possibly the word should be read as Pāṭhā.

पाणि-घ्न
<u>'''Pāṇi-ghna,'''</u> ‘hand-clapper,’ is enumerated among the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1765> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 15, 1.</ref> Presumably a man who drives away birds from the fields by making a noise is intended.

पाण्ड्व
<u>'''Pāṇḍva'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 3, 5, 21) denotes an uncoloured woollen garment.<br>==Foot Notes==

पातल्य
<u>'''Pātalya'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1767> iii. 53, 17.</ref> meaning some part of the chariot. What it was is quite uncertain. Hopkins<ref name=fx2_ve1_1767> ''Journal of the American Oriental Socicty,'' 13, 242, 243;<br> 20, 224. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 251;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 108.</ref> suggests that, as in the Epic, it was possibly a piece of wood on the axle to hold the pole of the car. 

पात्र
<u>'''Pātra,'''</u> primarily a ‘drinking vessel’ (from ''pā,'' ‘to drink’) denotes a vessel generally both in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1768> i. 82, 4;<br> 110, 5;<br> 162, 13 (to hold the broth from the flesh of the horse);<br> 175, 1;<br> ii. 37, 4;<br> vi. 27, 6, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1768> Av. iv. 17, 4;<br> vi. 142, 1;<br> ix. 6, 17;<br> xii. 3, 25. 36;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 6, 2;<br> vi. 3, 4, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 62;<br> xix. 86. etc.</ref> It was made either of wood<ref name=fx3_ve1_1768> Rv. i. 175, 3.</ref> or clay.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1768> Av. iv. 17, 4.</ref> In some passages<ref name=fx5_ve1_1768> Av. x. 10, 9;<br> xii. 3, 30;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 1, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta Śūtra, xvi. 1, 7, etc.</ref> the word is, according to Roth, used to indicate a measure. The feminine Pātrī occasionally occurs<ref name=fx6_ve1_1768> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 17;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 8;<br> ii. 5, 3, 6;<br> 6, 2, 7;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 8, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 271.</ref> in the sense of ‘vessel.’

पाथ्य
<u>'''Pāthya,'''</u> a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1769> vi. 16, 15. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 4, 2, 4;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 153.</ref> is either an epithet meaning ‘being in heaven’ (''pāthas''), or a patronymic, as Sāyaṇa interprets it, of '''[[वृषन्|Vṛṣan]].'''

पाद
<u>'''1. Pāda'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1770> xiv. 1, 60.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1770> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5. 12;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 3, 6, etc.;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5.</ref> denotes the ‘foot’ of an animal, a bird, and other creatures.

पाद
<u>'''2. Pāda,'''</u> as a measure of length, denotes ‘foot’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1771> vi. 5, 3, 2;<br> vii. 2, 1, 7;<br> viii. 7, 2, 17;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vi. 10, etc.</ref> The term is occasionally<ref name=fx2_ve1_1771> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 7;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, 2.</ref> used to express a measure of weight. As a fraction it means a ‘quarter,’ a sense derived from that of ‘foot’ of a quadruped (just as ''[[शफ|śapha]],'' the divided hoof, comes to mean an ‘eighth’).<br><br>^3) Rv. x. 90, 3. 4.

पाद
<u>'''3. Pāda'''</u> is the regular expression for a ‘quarter verse’ in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1772> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 4;<br> Kauṣīaki [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvi. 5;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 9;<br> xi. 6;<br> Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 1;<br> x. 6, 9, etc.</ref> This sense is merely a limitation of ‘quarter’ = the ‘foot’ of a quadruped 

पान
<u>'''Pāna,'''</u> ‘drink,’ occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1773> xiii. 4, 2, 17.</ref> and the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1773> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 43;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 2, 7, etc.</ref>

पान्त
<u>'''Pānta'''</u> occurs several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1774> i. 122, 1;<br> 155, 1;<br> viii. 92, 1;<br> ix. 65, 28 (a very doubtful passage);<br> x. 88, 1.</ref> apparently<ref name=fx2_ve1_1774> So [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 25;<br> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 122, 123.</ref> meaning ‘drink,’ ‘beverage’ (''cf.'' '''[[पान|Pāna]]'''). Geldner,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1774> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 139;<br> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 108.</ref> however, thinks that in one passage^4 [[पान्त|Pānta]] is the name of a prince.

पान्-नेजन
<u>'''Pān-nejana'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1775> iii. 8, 2, 1;<br> 9, 3, 27;<br> xiii. 5, 2, 1.</ref> denotes a ‘vessel for washing the feet.’

पाप-यक्ष्म
<u>'''Pāpa-yakṣma.'''</u> See '''[[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पाप-सम
<u>'''Pāpa-sama,'''</u> a ‘bad season,’ is in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1777> iii. 3, 8, 4. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 342.</ref> opposed to Puṇya-sama, a ‘good season.’

पामन्
<u>'''Pāman'''</u> occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1778> v. 22, 12. ''Cf.'' for the reading, Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 261. See also Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 8.</ref> as the name of a skin disease. The derivative adjective, Pāmana, ‘suffering from skin disease,’ is found in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1778> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 3, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 31.<br><br>''Cf.'' Grohmann, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 401 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 388;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 421, n.;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 450, 451;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 63.</ref> Since it is mentioned as an accompaniment of fever, probably a cutaneous eruption or scab consequent on fever is meant.

पायु
<u>'''1. Pāyu,'''</u> meaning ‘guard,’ ‘protector,’ occurs several times in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1779> i. 147, 3;<br> ii. 1, 7;<br> iv. 2, 6;<br> 4, 3. 12;<br> vi. 15, 8;<br> viii. 18, 2;<br> 60, 19;<br> x, 100, 9.</ref> 

पायु
<u>'''2. Pāyu'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1780> vi. 47, 24. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 128.</ref> as the name of a poet, a [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]]. In the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx2_ve1_1780> v. 124 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> he is credited with assisting '''[[अभ्यावर्तिन् चायमान|Abhyāvartin Cāyamāna]]''' and '''[[प्रस्तोक|Prastoka]] Sārṅjaya''' by consecrating their weapons with a hymn.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1780> vi. 75 (the ‘battle’ hymn).</ref>

पार
<u>'''Pāra,'''</u> in accordance with its derivation (''pṛ,'' ‘bring across’), denotes the ‘farther bank’ of a river or stream, in which sense<ref name=fx1_ve1_1781> It also often has the generalized sense of ‘extreme limit’ or ‘end,’ as in i. 92, 6 (''tamasas,'' ‘of darkness’);<br> v. 54, 10 (''adhavanaḥ,'' ‘of a road’).</ref> it occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1781> i. 121, 13 (''nāvyānām,'' ‘of streams’);<br> viii. 96, 11 (''nadīnām'');<br> i. 167, 2 (''samudrasya'');<br> x. 155, 3 (''sindhoḥ''), etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1781> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 1, 2. 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiii. 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6, 2, 4 (''salilasya'');<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21 (''[[पार|pāra]]-kāma,'' ‘desiring the farther bank’), etc.</ref>

पारशव्य
<u>'''Pāraśavya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[परशु|Paraśu]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[तिरिन्दिर|Tirindira]]''' in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta Śūtra (xvi. 11, 20). ''Cf.'' '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पारावत
<u>'''1. Pārāvata'''</u> occurs in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’), in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1783> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 25.</ref> meaning ‘turtle-dove.’

पारावत
<u>'''2. Pārāvata'''</u> occurs in several passages of the Rigveda. Roth<ref name=fx1_ve1_1784> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> thinks that in most places<ref name=fx2_ve1_1784> Rv. v. 52, 11;<br> viii. 100, 6;<br> Av. xx. 135, 14;<br> ''[[पारावत|pārāvata]]-ghnī'' of the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], Rv. vi. 61, 2.</ref> it means ‘coming from a distance,’ but in two passages<ref name=fx3_ve1_1784> Rv. viii. 34, 18;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4, 11. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 53.</ref> he regards it as the proper name of a people on the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' (Jumna). It is certain that in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] the Pārāvatas are a people on that river (''cf.'' '''[[तुरश्रवस्|Turaśravas]]'''). Hillebrandt<ref name=fx4_ve1_1784> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 97 ''et seq.;<br>'' 3, 310, following Brunnhofer, ''Iran und Turan,'' 99.</ref> sees in all the passages<ref name=fx5_ve1_1784> See notes 2 and 3.</ref> the name of a people, comparing the  of  Ptolemy,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1784> vi. 20, 3. It is suggested by Hillebrandt that the  of Herodotus, iii. 91, may be the same.</ref> who apparently were settled on the northern border of Gedrosia, or the , who were found in <ref name=fx7_ve1_1784> Ptolemy, vi. 17.</ref> He suggests that they were originally ‘mountaineers’ (''Cf.'' '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]'''). Ludwig<ref name=fx8_ve1_1784> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 162. 197.</ref> holds a similar view, and Geldner<ref name=fx9_ve1_1784> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 109.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 91;<br> Max Mūller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 316.</ref> recognizes a people as meant. The mention of the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' in connexion with the Pārāvatas<ref name=fx2_ve1_1784/> in the Rigveda accords generally with their position on the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve1_1784/>

पाराशरी-कौण्डिनी-पुत्र
<u>'''Pārāśarī-[[कौण्डिनी|kauṇḍinī]]-putra'''</u> is mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhādāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30), in the Mādhyaṃdina recension, as a pupil of '''[[गार्गीपुत्र|Gārgīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पाराशरी-पुत्र
<u>'''Pārāśarī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of '''[[पराशर|Parāśara]],'''’ is mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] as a pupil of '''[[कात्यायनीपुत्र|Kātyāyanīputra]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1786> vi. 5, 1, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> of '''[[औपस्वतीपुत्र|Aupasvatīputra]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1786/> of '''[[वात्सीपुत्र|Vātsīputra]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1786> vi. 5, 2, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> of '''[[वार्कारुणीपुत्र|Vārkāruṇīputra]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1786> vi. 4, 31, Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> and of '''[[गार्गीपुत्र|Gārgīputra]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve1_1786> vi. 4, 30, Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> Different men are no doubt meant.

पाराशर्य
<u>'''Pārāśarya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[पराशर|Parāśara]],'''’ is mentioned in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] as a pupil of '''[[जातूकर्ण्य|Jātūkarṇya]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1787> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]];<br> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27, Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> or of '''[[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1787> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26, Mādhyaṃdina;<br> ii. 6, 2;<br> iv. 6, 2, 3. [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> A [[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]] is also mentioned as a pupil of '''[[बैजवापायन|Baijavāpāyana]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1787> ii. 6, 2, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].<br><br>''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 9, 2.</ref> and '''[[व्यास पाराशर्य|Vyāsa Pārāśarya]]''' is the pupil of '''[[विष्वक्सेन|Viṣvaksena]]''' according to the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] at the end of the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1787> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 41. 1.</ref> See also '''Aṣāḍha, [[जयन्त|Jayanta]], Vipaścit, Sudatta.''' 

पाराशर्यायण
<u>'''Pārāśaryāyaṇa'''</u> is mentioned in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1788> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> as a pupil of [[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]].

पारिकुट
<u>'''Pārikuṭa'''</u> is an obscure word--probably corrupt--occurring in a verse cited in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 22, 7), and apparently meaning ‘attendant.’<br>==Foot Notes==

पारिक्षित
<u>'''Pārikṣita,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1790> vii. 27 and 34;<br> viii. 11.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve1_1790> xiii. 5, 4, 1. ''Cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 6;<br> ii. 6, 12.</ref> The Pārikṣitīya appear in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1790> xiii. 5, 4, 3.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1790> xvi. 9. 7.</ref> as performers of the horse sacrifice. In a [[गाथा|Gāthā]] there cited they are called Pārikṣitas. Apparently they were the brothers of [[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]], named '''[[उग्रसेन|Ugrasena]], [[भीमसेन|Bhīmasena]],''' and '''[[श्रुतसेन|Śrutasena]].''' In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx5_ve1_1790> iii. 3, 1.</ref> the question whither they have gone is made the subject of a philosophical discussion. It is clear that the family had passed away before the time of the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], and it is also clear that there had been some serious scandal mingled with their greatness which they had, in the opinion of the Brahmins, atoned for by their horse sacrifice with its boundless gifts to the priests. Weber<ref name=fx6_ve1_1790> ''Indian Literature,'' 125, 126;<br> 135, 136. The later legend of the Pārikṣitas and Vāmadeva's mares is dealt with by Weber in ''Vedische Beiträge'' (1894).</ref> sees in this the germ of the Epic stories which are recorded in the Mahābhārata.<br><br>The verses relating to [[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]] in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_1790> xx. 127, 7-10;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 17;<br> Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 156, 157.</ref> are called Pārikṣityaḥ in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1790> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 32, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 12;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 136, n. 144.</ref>

पारि-प्लव
<u>'''Pāri-plava,'''</u> ‘cyclic,’ is a term applied to the '''[[आख्यान|Ākhyāna]],''' or ‘tale,’ which is to be recited at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse  sacrifice’), and to be repeated at intervals throughout the year. It is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1791> xiii. 4, 3, 2. 15.</ref> and in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1791> Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 1, 26;<br> 2, 36;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 9, 11.</ref>

पारी-णह्य
<u>'''Pārī-ṇahya'''</u> denotes household utensils' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1792> vi. 2, 1, 1.</ref> where it is said that the wife (''[[पत्नी|patnī]]''), as mistress of the house, has charge of all these.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1792> The word occurs '''later''' in the variant form of ''pāri-ṇāhya'' in Manu, ix. 11.</ref>

पारूष्ण
<u>'''Pārūṣṇa,'''</u> occurring in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1793> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 24.</ref> appears to mean some kind of bird.

पारोवर्य-विद्
<u>'''Pārovarya-vid'''</u> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (xiii. 12) denotes ‘knowers of tradition.’<br>==Foot Notes==

पार्ण-वल्कि
<u>'''Pārṇa-valki,'''</u> ‘descendant of Parṇavalka,’ is the patronymic of '''Nigada''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1795> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 443.</ref>

पार्थव
<u>'''Pārthava,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[पृथु|Pṛthu]],'''’ occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1796> vi. 27, 8.</ref> where the Pārthavas are mentioned as generous donors. The passage is somewhat obscure, as there is a reference<ref name=fx2_ve1_1796> vi. 27, 7.</ref> to a defeat of the '''Turvaśas''' and the '''Vṛcīvants''' by '''[[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]] [[दैववात|Daivavāta]],''' followed in the next verse by the praise of the bounty to the singer of '''[[अभ्यावर्तिन् चायमान|Abhyāvartin Cāyamāna]],''' who was clearly a '''[[पार्थव|Pārthava]],''' and who, in the earlier part of the hymn, has been referred to as victorious over '''[[वरशिख|Varaśikha]].''' It is uncertain whether, as Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve1_1796> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 133, 134.</ref> suggests, the two princes, Abhyāvartin  [[चायमान|Cāyamāna]] and [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]] [[दैववात|Daivavāta]], are identical or not.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1796> ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105.</ref> That [[पार्थव|Pārthava]] has any direct connexion with the Parthians, as held by Brunnhofer, is most improbable.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1796> ''Cf.'' Ludwing, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 196 ''et seq.'' Herodotos, iii. 93, mentions the .</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]].'''

पार्थ-श्रवस
<u>'''Pārtha-śravasa,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[पृथु-श्रवस्|Pṛthu-śravas]],’ is found as the name of a demon in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1797> iv. 26, 15. This form of the name is supported by its occurrence in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 10;<br> xvii. 27. But Pārthu-is also possible.</ref>

पार्थ्य
<u>'''Pārthya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[पृथि|Pṛthi]],’ is the patronymic of some donor in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1798> x. 93. 15.</ref> The form of the name in the Aśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1798> xii. 10. ''Cf.'' the Anukramaṇī on Rv. x. 93.</ref> is Pārtha.

पार्वति
<u>'''Pārvati,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[पर्वत|Parvata]],’ is the patronymic of '''Dakṣa''' in the Śatapatha (ii. 4, 4, 6) and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] (iv. 4) Brāhmaṇas.<br>==Foot Notes==

पार्षद
<u>'''Pārṣada,'''</u> which first appears in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1800> i. 17. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 128 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Studien,'' 3, 269;<br> 4, 217.</ref> denotes a textbook recognized by a school of grammarians.

पार्षद्-वाण
<u>'''Pārṣad-vāṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of Pṛṣadvāṇa,’ is mentioned as a wonder-worker in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1801> viii. 51, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139.</ref>

पार्ष्ण शैलन
<u>'''Pārṣṇa Śailana'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 4, 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

पालागल
<u>'''Pālāgala'''</u> occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve1_1803> v. 3, 1, 11. Eggeling;<br> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 64, renders it ‘courier.’</ref> apparently in the sense of ‘messenger,’ or ‘bearer of false news.’ 

पालागली
<u>'''Pālāgalī'''</u> is the name of the fourth and least respected wife of the king.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1804> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 1, 8;<br> 5, 2, 8, etc.</ref> See '''Pati.'''

पावमानी
<u>'''Pāvamānī'''</u> means the verses (''ṛcas'') in the ninth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda ‘relating to Soma Pavamāna’ (‘purifying itself’). The name is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1805> xix. 71, 1.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1805> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 20;<br> ii. 37;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 1, 10;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xi. 2;<br> xii. 31;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 2, 2, etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇī [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 14.</ref> possibly even in one hymn of the Rigveda itself.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1805> ix. 67, 31. 32;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 99. n. 3.</ref>

पाश
<u>'''Pāśa'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1806> i. 24, 13. 15;<br> ii. 27, 16;<br> 29, 5. etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1806> Av. ii. 12, 2;<br> ix. 3, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 8. 45, etc.</ref> a ‘rope’ used for fastening or tying up. Rope and knot (''granthi'') are mentioned together in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1806> ix. 3, 2.</ref> [[पाश|Pāśa]] is in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve1_1806> i. 8, 1, 5.</ref> used of the rope by which Manu's ship was fastened to the mountain. It is often employed metaphorically of the ‘fetter’ of Varuṇa.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1806> Rv. vi. 74, 4;<br> vii. 88, 7;<br> x. 85, 24;<br> Av. iv. 16, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 5, 1, etc.</ref>

पाशिन्
<u>'''Pāśin,'''</u> ‘having a noose,’ denotes a ‘hunter’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1807> iii. 45, 1;<br> ix. 73, 4. So of Nirṛti in [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 10.</ref> and in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1807> xvii. 1, 8.</ref>

पाश-द्युम्न वायत
<u>'''Pāśa-[[द्युम्न|dyumna]] Vāyata'''</u> is the name of a king to whom the '''Vasiṣṭhas''' claim to have been preferred by Indra in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1808> vii. 33. 2.</ref> Apparently he was, as Sāyaṇa says, son of Vayat, who may be compared with the '''Vyat of another''' passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1808> i. 122, 4.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve1_1808> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173.</ref> sees in him a priest of the '''Pṛthus''' and '''Parśus,''' but this is most improbable.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1808> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 130, 139.</ref>

पाष्य
<u>'''Pāṣya'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1809> i. 56, 6.</ref> with reference to the defeat of Vṛtra, and apparently denotes ‘stone bulwarks.’  In another passage<ref name=fx2_ve1_1809> ix. 102, 2. ''Cf.'' Macdone, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1893, 457, 458.</ref> the word may mean the stones used for pressing Soma.

पिक
<u>'''Pika,'''</u> the Indian ‘cuckoo,’ is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1810> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 15, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 20;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 39. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 92.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[अन्यवाप|Anyavāpa]], Koka.'''

पिङ्गा
<u>'''Piṅgā'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1811> viii. 69, 9.</ref> where it is explained by the St. Petersburg Dictionary with Sāyaṇa as ‘bowstring,’ but where Hillebrandt<ref name=fx2_ve1_1811> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 144, n.</ref> thinks that a musical instrument of some kind is meant.

पिजवन
<u>'''Pijavana'''</u> is the name of the father of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' according to the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1812> ii. 24.</ref> Probably this statement is based on a mere conjecture from the epithet [[पैजवन|Paijavana]] used of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] in a verse of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1812> vii. 18, 19. So [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21.</ref> but may very well be correct.

पिञ्जूल
<u>'''Piñjūla'''</u> denotes a ‘bundle’ of grass or stalks, especially of '''[[दर्भ|Darbha]].''' The word is only found in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] style.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1813> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 8. It appears in the form of ''piñjula'' in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 8, 7;<br> Pāraskara [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 15;<br> of [[पुञ्जील|Puñjīla]] in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 7;<br> 2, 4, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 6, 4;<br> ii. 7, 9, 5.</ref>

पिठीनस्
<u>'''Piṭhīnas'''</u> is the name of a man, a friend of Indra, in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1814> vi. 26, 6. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 156.</ref>

पिण्ड
<u>'''Piṇḍa,'''</u> denoting specifically a ball of flour offered to the Manes, especially on the evening of new moon, occurs in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx1_ve1_1815> iii. 4.</ref> and repeatedly in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1815> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 10, 4, etc.</ref> 

पिता-पुत्र
<u>'''Pitā-putra,'''</u> ‘father and son,’ is a compound of rare occurrence.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1816> Av. vi. 112, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 4, 4.</ref>

पिता-पुत्रीय
<u>'''Pitā-putrīya'''</u> (‘relating to father and son’), used with Sampradāna (‘handing over’) means the ceremony by which a father, when about to die, bequeathes his bodily and mental powers to his son. It is described in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1817> ii. 15. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 408.</ref>

पिता-मह
<u>'''Pitā-maha,'''</u> beside '''[[ततामह|Tatāmaha]],''' denotes from the Atharvaveda onwards<ref name=fx1_ve1_1818> Av. v. 5, 1;<br> ix. 5, 30;<br> xi. 1, 19;<br> xviii. 4, 35;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 5, 1;<br> vii. 2, 7, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 36;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 5, 4.</ref> the ‘paternal grandfather,’ apparmtly as a ‘father in a higher sense.’<ref name=fx2_ve1_1818> Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 474.</ref> The great-grandfather is '''[[प्रपितामह|Prapitāmaha]]''' and '''[[प्रततामह|Pratatāmaha]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1818> Av. xviii. 4, 75.</ref> It is significant that there are no corrésponding Vedic words for maternal grandparents, and that the words used in the latter language, such as Mātāmaha, are imitations of the terms for paternal relations.<br><br>In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1818> vi. 20. 11.</ref> Delbrück<ref name=fx5_ve1_1818> ''Ibid.,'' 473.</ref> suggests that ''mahe pitre'' means ‘grandfather,’ a sense which would well suit the ''napātam,'' ‘grandson,’ following, but the sense of the whole passage is uncertain.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1818> See Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 128, n. 1. Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' also doubts the view which is accepted by Delbrück, and denies that in Rv. i. 71, 5, the sense of ‘grandfather’ can be found.</ref><br><br>We learn very little from the texts of the position of grandparents. No doubt they were entitled to marks of respect similar to those shown to parents,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1818> Delbrück, ''op. cit.,'' 480, citing Mahābhārata, ii. 1634.</ref> as the epic expressly testifies. A grandfather might easily be the head of the family, or be living with his eldest son, after he ceased to be able to control the family.<br><br>The grandmother (Pitāmahī) is not mentioned in the extant Vedic literature. 

पितु
<u>'''Pitu'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1819> i. 61, 7;<br> 132, 6;<br> 187, 1;<br> vi. 20, 4, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1819> Av. iv. 6, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 2, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 20;<br> xii. 65;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 13.</ref> has the general sense of ‘nutriment,’ whether food or drink.

पितृ
<u>'''Pitṛ,'''</u> common from the Rigveda onwards, denotes ‘father,’ not so much as the ‘begetter’ (''[[जनितृ|janitṛ]]''),<ref name=fx1_ve1_1820> ''Pitā janitā,'' is used of gods in the Rigveda--''e.g.,'' iv. 17, 12.</ref> but rather as the protector of the child, this being probably also the etymological sense of the word.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1820> As derived from ''pā,'' ‘protect.’ But, as Bo7htlingk and Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Mātar,'' footnote, suggest, ''pa'' and ''mā'' were probably the much older original onomatopoetic names for ‘father’ and ‘mother,’ which in a later reflective age influenced the formation of ''[[पितृ|pitṛ]]'' and ''[[मातृ|mātṛ]]'' (which themselves go back to the Indo-European period).</ref> The father in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1820> See, ''e.g.,'' iv. 17, 17;<br> viii. 86, 4.</ref> stands for all that is good and kind. Hence Agni is compared with a father,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1820> Rv. x. 7, 3.</ref> while Indra is even dearer than a father.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1820> Rv. vii. 32, 19;<br> viii. 1, 6.</ref> The father carries his son in his arms,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1820> Rv. i. 38, 1.</ref> and places him on his lap,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1820> Rv. v. 43, 7.</ref> while the child pulls his garment to attract attention.<ref name=fx8_ve1_1820> Rv. iii. 53, 2.</ref> In later years the son depends on his father for help in trouble,<ref name=fx9_ve1_1820> In Rv. x. 48, 1, the ''jantavaḥ'' possibly are the sons.</ref> and greets him with joy.<ref name=fx10_ve1_1820> Rv. vii. 103, 3. ''Cf.'' 1, 24, 1.</ref><br><br>It is difficult to ascertain precisely how far the son was subject to parental control, and how long such control continued. Reference is made in the Rigveda<ref name=fx11_ve1_1820> Rv. ii. 29, 5.</ref> to a father's chastising his son for gambling, and '''[[ऋज्राश्व|Ṛjrāśva]]''' is said to have been blinded by his father.<ref name=fx12_ve1_1820> Rv. i. 116, 16;<br> 117, 17. There is also the case of the sale of Sunaḥśepa, [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 12-18;<br> and ''cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 3, 3.</ref> From the latter statement Zimmer<ref name=fx13_ve1_1820> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 316.</ref> infers the existence of a developed ''patria potestas,'' but to lay stress on this isolated and semi-mythical incident would be unwise. It is, however, quite likely that the ''patria potestas'' was originally strong, for we have other support for the thesis in the Roman ''patria potestas.'' If there is no proof that a father  legally controlled his son's wedding,<ref name=fx14_ve1_1820> ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 576. ''Ibid.,'' 582, he quotes Mahābhārata, xii. 6108 ''et seq.,'' which refers in one line to the control of the marriage of the son by the father, and in the next to a case of free marriage. The fact is, no doubt, that the son could marry freely, unless his father had arranged matters for him when he was too young to object.</ref> and not much that he controlled his daughter's,<ref name=fx15_ve1_1820> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 309, assumes this as certain, but it is far from proved. See, however, Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 2, which is in favour of Zimmer's view. ''Cf.'' Kaegi, ''Dev Rigveda,'' 15, and '''Pati.'''</ref> the fact is in itself not improbable.<br><br>There is again no evidence to show whether a son, when grown up, normally continued to stay with his father, his wife becoming a member of the father's household, or whether he set up a house of his own: probably the custom varied. Nor do we know whether the son was granted a special plot of land on marriage or otherwise, or whether he only came into such property after his father's death. But any excessive estimate of the father's powers over a son who was no longer a minor and naturally under his control, must be qualified by the fact that in his old age the sons might divide their father's property,<ref name=fx16_ve1_1820> Rv. i. 70, 10;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 14;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 156 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 61, 62).</ref> or he might divide it amongst them,<ref name=fx17_ve1_1820> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 9, 4-6. ''Cf.'' the handing over from father to son in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 15. If the father recovered, he lived subject to his son.</ref> and that when the father-in-law became aged he fell under the control of his son's wife.<ref name=fx18_ve1_1820> Rv. x. 85, 46.</ref> There are also obscure traces that in old age a father might be exposed, though there is no reason to suppose that this was usual in Vedic India.<ref name=fx19_ve1_1820> ''Cf.'' Rv. viii. 51, 2;<br> Av. xviii. 2, 34. The first passage need not refer to exposure, and the second merely refers to the exposure of a dead body;<br> but Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 326-328, thinks that they prove exposure. ''Cf.'' '''[[धर्म|Dharma]].'''</ref><br><br>Normally the son was bound to give his father full obedience.<ref name=fx20_ve1_1820> Rv. i. 68, 5</ref> The later Sūtras show in detail the acts of courtesy which he owed his father, and they allow him to eat the remnants of his father's food.<ref name=fx21_ve1_1820> Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 4, 11.</ref> On the other hand, the father was expected to be kind. The story of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāh-  maṇa<ref name=fx22_ve1_1820> vii. 12 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 17 ''et seq.''</ref> emphasizes the horror with which the father's heartless treatment of his son was viewed. The Upaniṣads<ref name=fx23_ve1_1820> ''E.g.,'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 15;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 25 (Mādhyaṃdina = i. 5, 17, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> insist on the spiritual succession from father to son. The kissing of a son<ref name=fx24_ve1_1820> See Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 28, 120-134;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 26, n. 3.</ref> was a frequent and usual token of affection, even in mature years.<br><br>On the failure of natural children, adoption was possible.<ref name=fx25_ve1_1820> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 318;<br> Mayr, ''Indisches Erbrecht,'' 73;<br> Jolly, ''Die Adoption in Indien'' (Würzburg, 1910), 7 ''et seq.''</ref> It was even resorted to when natural children existed, but when it was desired to secure the presence in the family of a person of specially high qualifications, as in Viśvāmitra's adoption of [[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]].<ref name=fx26_ve1_1820> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 17. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 157.</ref> It is not clear that adoption from one caste into another was possible, for there is no good evidence that [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] was, as Weber<ref name=fx27_ve1_1820> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 33, 34.</ref> holds, a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] who adopted a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. Adoption was also not always in high favour: it may be accidental or not that a hymn of the [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] book of the Rigveda<ref name=fx28_ve1_1820> vii. 4, 7. 8.</ref> condemns the usage. It was also possible for the father who had a daughter, but no sons, to appoint her to bear a son for him. At any rate the practice appears to be referred to in an obscure verse of the Rigveda<ref name=fx29_ve1_1820> iii. 31, 1.</ref> as interpreted by [[यास्क|Yāska]].<ref name=fx30_ve1_1820> iii. 5 ''ad fin. Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 343;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 34;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 239-241.</ref> Moreover, it is possible that the difficulty of a brotherless maiden finding a husband<ref name=fx31_ve1_1820> ''Cf.'' '''[[भ्रातृ|Bhrātṛ]].'''</ref> may have been due in part to the possibility of her father desiring to make her a [[पुत्रिका|Putrikā]], the later technical name for a daughter whose son is to belong to her father's family.<br><br>There can be no doubt that in a family the father took precedence of the mother.<ref name=fx32_ve1_1820> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 1, 18;<br> a citation in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] vii. 15, 2.</ref> Delbrück<ref name=fx33_ve1_1820> ''Die indogermanischen'' Verwandtschaftsnamen, 577.</ref> explains away the apparent cases to the contrary.<ref name=fx34_ve1_1820> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 7, 5. Some passages in the Sūtras present difficulties, but they are of no importance for Vedic times proper.</ref> There is no trace of the  family as a land-owning corporation.<ref name=fx35_ve1_1820> Baden Powell, whose various works (''Indian Village Community,'' 1896;<br> ''Village Communities in India,'' 1899, etc.) have done most to combat the view of the village community in India as a land-holding institution, is prepared to recognize the family as a land-owning unit, considering that the ''patria potestas'' is a later growth, and not Indian (see, ''e.g., Village Communities in India,'' 128 ''et seq.''). Hopkins, ''India, Old and New,'' 218 ''et seq.,'' adopts a theory which allows of individual and joint family ownership side by side, the latter being apparently the earlier but the decadent stage. He expressly considers (p. 222) that the son had an indefeasible right to prevent the father from alienating the hereditary land, which could only be parted with by the consent of the village if it were a case of joint ownership (''cf.'' the verse cited by Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 94). But it must be remembered that, as is very clearly shown in the case of English law by Pollock and Maitland (''History of English Law,'' 2, 337-352), the recognition of the rights of sons may well be, not a sign of original joint or family ownership, but a development from the existence of intestate succession, and as in England, so in India, there is no trace of a corporate joint family in the early books. And, as Jolly (''op. cit.,'' 76, 80) shows, there are clear traces, both in old and modern times, of a despotic control of the family by the father even after his sons grew up, provided only that he was physically able to control them. The same state of affairs seems proved for early English law, as it is beyond question for Roman law (see Smith's ''Dictionary of Antiquities,'' 2, 351 ''et seq.''). In Greece also, which is sometimes contrasted with Rome, there is the clearest trace of both a real ''patria potestas,'' and of the absolute ownership of the land by the father as against the son, especially in the archaic laws of Gortyn (see Gardner and Jevons, ''Greek Antiquities,'' 404, 405, 563, 566).</ref> The dual form Pitarau regularly means ‘father and mother,’ ‘parents.’<ref name=fx36_ve1_1820> Rv. i. 20, 4;<br> 160, 3;<br> ii. 17, 7;<br> vii. 67, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 11, etc.</ref>

पितृ-याण
<u>'''Pitṛ-yāṇa,'''</u> the ‘way of the fathers,’ mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1821> x. 2, 7. ''Cf.'' the allusion to it in x. 18, 1, as other than the Devavāna, which appears in x. 98, 11.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1821> Av. viii. 10, 19;<br> xii. 2, 10, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 45;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 3, 2, etc.</ref> is opposed to the Deva-[[यान|yāna]], or ‘way of the gods.’ Tilak<ref name=fx3_ve1_1821> ''Orion,'' 22 ''et seq.''</ref> considers that the Devayāna corresponds with the Uttarāyaṇa, ‘northern journey’ of the sun, and the [[पितृयाण|Pitṛyāṇa]] with the [[दक्षिणायन|Dakṣiṇāyana]], its ‘southern journey.’ He concludes from a passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve1_1821> ii. 1, 3, 1-3.</ref> where three of the seasons--spring, summer, and the rains--are ascribed to the gods, but the others to the Pitṛs, or Fathers, that the Devayāna began with the vernal equinox, and the [[पितृयाण|Pitṛyāṇa]] with the autumnal equinox. With this he connects the curious  distinction of Deva- and Yama-Nakṣatras in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_1821> i. 5, 2, 6.</ref> These conclusions are, however, very improbable. ''Cf.'' '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]''' and '''[[सूर्य|Sūrya]].'''

पितृ-हन्
<u>'''Pitṛ-han,'''</u> ‘parricide,’ is found in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1822> ix. 4, 3. ''Cf.'' Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> Paippalāda recension.

पित्र्य
<u>'''Pitrya'''</u> occurs in the list of sciences given in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1823> vii. 1, 2, 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 267;<br> Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 98.</ref> Apparently it is to be taken as the science relating to the cult of the Manes, as explained by Śaṅkara in his commentary. As it is in that list followed by '''Rāśi,''' the St. Petersburg Dictionary is inclined to take [[पित्र्य|Pitrya]] Rāśi as one expression, but in what exact sense does not appear.

पित्व
<u>'''Pitva'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve1_1824> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 17, 1.</ref> or '''Pidva'''<ref name=fx2_ve1_1824> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 13;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 32. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 79;<br> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 29, 290.</ref> is the name of an animal included in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās. According to the commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1824/> it means ‘lion.’ But it may be identical with '''[[पेत्व|Petva]].'''

पिनाक
<u>'''Pināka,'''</u> ‘club,’ is found in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1825> i. 27, 2.</ref> Later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1825> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 6, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 61;<br> xvi. 51. etc.</ref> it is used to denote the club of Rudra-[[शिव|Śiva]].

पिन्वन
<u>'''Pinvana'''</u> occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 1, 2, 17; 2, 1, 11; 3, 1, 22) as the name of a vessel used in the ritual.<br>==Foot Notes==

पिपील
<u>'''Pipīla,'''</u> ‘ant,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda (x. 16, 6) as eating the flesh of the dead. <br>==Foot Notes==

पिपीलिका
<u>'''Pipīlikā'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1828> vii. 56, 7. ''Cf.'' xx. 134. 6.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1828> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 7;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 6, 10;<br> xv. 17, 8;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, 9. 29 (Mādhyaṃdina = i. 4, 4, 16 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 13;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 3, 8;<br> ii. 1, 6.</ref> denotes an ‘ant,’ the form of the word referring doubtless not so much to the small species of ant, as it is taken in the later lexicons,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1828> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> but rather to the insect's tiny size, which would naturally be expressed by a diminutive formation of the name. The form Pipīlaka<ref name=fx4_ve1_1828> ''Cf. kanīnaka'' beside ''kanīnikā,'' ‘pupil of the eye.’</ref> is found in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx5_ve1_1828> vii. 2, 1;<br> 7, 1;<br> 8, 1;<br> 10, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97;<br> Edgerton, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 31, 128.</ref>

पिप्पका
<u>'''Pippakā'''</u> is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] '''Saṃhitās.'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1829> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 19, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 21;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 40. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> Some bird seems to be meant.

पिप्पल
<u>'''Pippala,'''</u> n., is found in two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1830> i. 164, 20 = Muṇḍaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, 1;<br> Śvetāśvatara [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 6, 22;<br> v. 54, 12 (the ‘berry’ of heaven, ''[[नाक|nāka]]'').</ref> meaning ‘berry,’ used with a mystic signification, and in neither case with any certain reference to the berry of the fig-tree.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1830> The word [[पिप्पल|Pippala]] appears in the later literature as a masculine, denoting the ''Ficus veligiosa'' ('''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]]''' in Vedic literature).</ref> In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1830> iv. 1, 41.</ref> the general sense of ‘berry’ is not necessary, and the special sense of ‘berry’ of the Peepal is quite possible: the latter meaning is perhaps intended in the Satapatha Brāhmana.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1830> iii. 7, 1, 12.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve1_1830> vi. 109, 1, 2.</ref> the feminine form of the word, Pippalī, appears denoting berries used as a remedy for wounds, like '''[[अरुन्धती|Arundhatī]].'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1830> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 61;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 516;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 359, 360;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 389;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 331.</ref> 

पिप्पलाद
<u>'''Pippalāda'''</u> (‘eater of berries’) is the name of a teacher mentioned in the [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1831> i. 1.</ref> In the plural the name denotes a school of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1831> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 277;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 153, 159, 160, 164.</ref> Their (Paippalāda) recension of the text of the Saṃhitā has been reproduced in facsimile by Garbe and Bloomfield,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1831> Baltimore, 1901.</ref> and in part published.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1831> The variants of the Paippalāda are given in part in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, and the text of books i. and ii. has been edited by Barret in the ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 197-295;<br> 30, 187 ''et seq. Cf.'' also Lanman in Whitney's Translation, lxxix ''et seq.''</ref>

पिप्रु
<u>'''Pipru'''</u> is the name of a foe of Indra in the Rigveda. He was repeatedly defeated by Indra for '''[[ऋजिश्वन्|Ṛjiśvan]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve1_1832> i. 101, 1, 2;<br> iv. 16, 13;<br> v. 29, 11;<br> vi. 20, 7;<br> viii. 49, 10;<br> x. 99, 11;<br> 138, 3. In i. 103, 8;<br> ii. 14, 5;<br> vi. 18, 8, the reference is general to a defeat of [[पिप्रु|Pipru]] by Indra.</ref> Mentioned as possessing forts,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1832> Rv. i. 51, 5;<br> vi. 20, 7.</ref> he is called a [[दास|Dāsa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1832> Rv. viii. 32, 2.</ref> as well as an Asura.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1832> Rv. x. 138, 3.</ref> He is described as having a black brood,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1832> Rv. i. 101, 1.</ref> and as being allied with blacks.<ref name=fx6_ve1_1832> iv. 16, 13.</ref> It is uncertain whether he was a demon, according to Roth's<ref name=fx7_ve1_1832> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> view, which is favoured by the use of the word Asura, or a human foe, as Ludwig,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1832> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 149.</ref> Oldenberg,<ref name=fx9_ve1_1832> ''Religion des Veda,'' 155.</ref> and Hillebrandt<ref name=fx10_ve1_1832> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 273.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 161 (C).</ref> believe. The name may mean ‘resister,’ from the root ''pṛ.''

पिश
<u>'''Piśa'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1833> i. 64, 8. ''Cf.'' Av. xix. 49, 4;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 118;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 110.</ref> where '''Sāyaṇa''' takes it to mean a deer (''ruru'').

पिशङ्ग
<u>'''Piśaṅga'''</u> is the name of one of the two Unnetṛ priests officiating at the snake festival mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1834> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Caka.''' 

पिशाच
<u>'''Piśāca'''</u> is the name of a class of demon mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1835> ii. 18, 4;<br> iv. 20, 6. 9;<br> 36, 4;<br> 37, 10;<br> v. 29, 4. 5. 14;<br> vi. 32, 2;<br> viii. 2, 12;<br> xii. 1, 50. The word occurs once in the Rv. (i. 133, 5) in the form of Piśāci.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1835> See St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve1_1835> ii. 4, 1, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 14.</ref> they are associated with Rakṣases and Asuras, while opposed to gods, men, and fathers. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1835> v. 25, 9.</ref> they are described as ''kravyād,'' ‘eaters of raw flesh,’ which may be the etymological sense of the word [[पिशाच|Piśāca]] itself.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1835> ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 264, n.</ref> It is possible that the Piśācas were, as suggested by Grierson,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1835> ''Cf.'' Grierson, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1905, 285-288. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 164 (B).</ref> really human foes, like the north-western tribes, who even in later times were reputed eaters of raw flesh (not necessarily as cannibals, but rather as eaters of human flesh in ritual). This is, however, not at all likely, the Piśācas having in all probability only meant ‘ghouls’ originally: when they appear as human tribes, they were presumably thus designated in scorn. A science called Piśācaveda<ref name=fx7_ve1_1835> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. i. 1, 10.</ref> or [[पिशाच|Piśāca]]-[[विद्या|vidyā]]<ref name=fx8_ve1_1835> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7, 6.</ref> is known in the later Vedic period.

पिशित
<u>'''Piśita'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1836> v. 19, 5.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1836> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 11;<br> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 8;<br> xxxv. 18;<br> xxxix. 14. etc.</ref> denotes raw flesh (''of.'' '''[[पिशाच|Piśāca]]'''). In one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve1_1836> vi. 127, 1. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 531;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 376.</ref> the sense seems to be ‘small piece,’ ‘bit,’ but the St. Petersburg Dictionary suggests that [[पिशित|Piśita]] here stands for ''piṣita,'' equivalent to ''[[पिष्ट|piṣṭa]]'' (what is ‘pounded,’ then ‘particle’).

पिशील
<u>'''Piśīla'''</u> is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 5, 3, 6) as the name of a wooden vessel or dish. In the Lāṭyāyana Śrautā [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (iv. 2, 4. 5) a [[पिशील|Piśīla]]-[[वीणा|vīṇā]] is mentioned, which seems to have been a kind of guitar, with strings stretched over a body of wood. <br>==Foot Notes==

पिशुन
<u>'''Piśuna,'''</u> ‘traitor,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1838> vii. 104, 20.</ref> and occasionally later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1838> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 13;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 6, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 7, 1.</ref>

पिष्ट
<u>'''Piṣṭa'''</u> (‘pounded’), n., ‘meal,’ ‘flour,’ is mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1839> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 9;<br> Śatapatha Brāhṃaṇa, i. 1, 4, 3;<br> 2, 1, 2;<br> vi. 5, 1, 6, etc.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1839> xii. 2, 53.</ref> reference is made to pounded beans (''māṣāḥ'').

पीठ
<u>'''Pīṭha,'''</u> ‘stool,’ does not occur as an uncompounded word before the Sūtras, but the compound ''[[पीठ|pīṭha]]-sarpin'' (‘moving about in a little cart’) is found as the designation of a ‘cripple’ in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxx. 21) and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 4, 17, 1) in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’).<br>==Foot Notes==

पीतु-दारु
<u>'''Pītu-dāru'''</u> is found in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1841> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 6.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1841> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 2, 15;<br> xiii. 4, 4, 5, 17;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 13, 5.</ref> denoting the Deodar (''deva-[[दारु|dāru]]'') tree, or, according to others, the '''[[खदिर|Khadira]]''' or '''[[उदुम्बर|Udumbara]]''' tree.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1841> Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 14;<br> Sāyaṇa on [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 28.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Pūtadru.'''

पीयूष
<u>'''Pīyūṣa'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1842> ''Cf.'' ii. 35, 5, where it is applied figuratively to the mothers of Agni.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1842> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xix. 15. ''Cf.'' Av. viii. 9, 24.</ref> in the sense of the first milk of the cow after calving, ‘biestings.’ Usually the term is applied metaphorically to the sap of the Soma plant.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1842> Rv. ii. 13, 1;<br> iii. 48, 2;<br> vi. 47, 4;<br> x. 94, 8, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 110.</ref>

पीला
<u>'''Pīlā'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1843> iv. 37, 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 69;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 211.</ref> as the name of an  Apsaras, being no doubt originally a name of some fragrant  plant, like '''Naladī''' and '''Guggulū,''' two other names of Apsarases given in the same verse.

पीलु
<u>'''Pīlu'''</u> is the name in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1844> xx. 135, 12. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62;<br> Weber, ''Transactions of the Berlin Academy,'' 1895, 861.</ref> of a tree (''Careya arborea'' or ''Salvadora persica'') on the fruit of which doves fed.

पीलुमती
<u>'''Pīlumatī'''</u> is in the Atharvaveda (xviii. 2, 48) the name of the intermediate heaven lying between the ''udanuvatī,'' ‘watery,’ and the ''pra-dyauḥ,'' ‘farthest heaven.’ It presumably means ‘rich in '''[[पीलु|Pīlu]].'''’ ''Cf.'' '''Div.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पुंश्-चली
<u>'''Puṃś-calī'''</u> (‘running after men’) is found in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1846> xxx. 22.</ref> the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1846> xv. 2, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> and later,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1846> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 1, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvii. 1;<br> Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 3, 9, 11.</ref> to denote a ‘wanton woman.’ In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve1_1846> xxx. 5. 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 1;<br> 15, 1;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 3, 6.</ref> also occurs the form Puṃścalū. See also '''[[धर्म|Dharma]]''' and '''Pati.'''

पुं-सवन
<u>'''Puṃ-savana'''</u> (‘male-production’ ceremony) is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1847> vi. 11, 1.</ref> in a hymn which is obviously intended to accompany a rite aiming at securing the birth of a male child and which is so applied in the ritual.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1847> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxxv. 8. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 460;<br> whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 288. The later [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] ritual knows a special rite called [[पुंसवन|Puṃsavana]]. See Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 13;<br> Sāṅkhāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 20;<br> Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 6, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 41.</ref>

पुक्लक
<u>'''Puklaka.'''</u> See '''[[पौल्कस|Paulkasa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पुञ्जि-ष्ठ
<u>'''Puñji-ṣṭha'''</u> is found in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve1_1849> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 4, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1849> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7;<br> Pāṇini, viii. 3, 97.</ref> apparently meaning ‘fisherman,’ though Mahīdhara<ref name=fx3_ve1_1849> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27.</ref> explains it as ‘bird-catcher.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[पौञ्जिष्ठ|Pauñjiṣṭha]].''' 

पुञ्जील
<u>'''Puñjīla'''</u> is found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve1_1850> vi. 1, 1, 7;<br> 2, 4, 3.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve1_1850> i. 7, 6, 4;<br> ii. 7, 9, 5.</ref> in the sense of a ‘bundle’ of grass, being a variant of '''[[पिञ्जूल|Piñjūla]].'''

पुण्डरीक
<u>'''Puṇḍarīka'''</u> denotes the blossom of the lotus in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1851> x. 142, 8.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1851> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 5, 6;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 3, 10;<br> vi. 3, 14;<br> Chāndogya Upaṇiṣad, i. 6, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 4.</ref> The [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve1_1851> xviii. 9, 6.</ref> states that the lotus flower is born of the light of the Nakṣatras, and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve1_1851> x. 8, 43;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 1, 1.</ref> compares the human heart to the lotus.<ref name=fx5_ve1_1851> In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 18, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 1, ''puṇḍari-srajā'' denotes a ‘wreath of lotus leaves.’<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.</ref>

पुण्ड्र
<u>'''Puṇḍra'''</u> is the name of a people regarded as outcasts in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve1_1852> vii. 18;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 26.</ref> Their name occurs in the Sūtras also.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1852> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 14, ''Cf.'' Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 553;<br> Būhler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 148;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 394, n. For the later geographical position of the Puṇḍras, ''cf.'' the map in Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 333.</ref> In the Epic their country corresponds with Bengal and Bihar.

पुत्र
<u>'''Putra'''</u> is, with '''[[सूनु|Sūnu]],''' the usual name for ‘son’ from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1853> Rv. ii. 29, 5;<br> v. 47, 6;<br> vi. 9, 2, etc.;<br> Av. iii. 30, 2, etc.</ref> The original sense of the word was apparently ‘small,’ or something analogous.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1853> Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 454.</ref> The form Putraka<ref name=fx3_ve1_1853> Rv. viii. 69, 8;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 14;<br> vi. 33 (here the narrative uses [[पुत्र|Putra]];<br> the reported words have Putraka);<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 1, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 21, etc.</ref> is often used with the distinct intention of an affectionate address to a younger man, not merely a son proper. Reference is frequently made to the desire for a son.<ref name=fx4_ve1_1853> Rv. x. 183, 1;<br> Av. vi. 81, 3;<br> xi. 1, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 6, 1;<br> vii. 1, 8, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 9, 1.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Pati.''' 

पुत्र-सेन
<u>'''Putra-sena'''</u> is the name of a man in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iv. 6, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

पुत्रिका
<u>'''Putrikā'''</u> in the later literature<ref name=fx1_ve1_1855> [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra, ix. 127 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxviii. 20;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 17.</ref> has the technical sense of the daughter of a man without sons, whom he gives in marriage on the express terms that her son shall perform the funeral rites for him, and be counted as his. The thing as well as the name is recognized by [[यास्क|Yāska]] in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx2_ve1_1855> iii. 5 ''ad fin.''</ref> and traced to the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1855> i. 124, 7. ''Cf.'' iii. 31, 1.</ref> But the passages in the Rigveda are of very uncertain meaning,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1855> ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 34;<br> ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 48, 49;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 239 ''et seq.;<br>'' Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],' Erlāuterungen,'' 27;<br> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 72, 73;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, iv. 110. 111, with Macdonell's note;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 924, 925;<br> Jolly, ''Die Adoption in Indien,'' 32.</ref> and in all probability do not refer to this custom at all.

पुनर्-दत्त
<u>'''Punar-datta'''</u> (‘given again’) is the name of a teacher in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (viii. 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

पुनर्-भू
<u>'''Punar-bhū'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1857> ix. 5, 28. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 537.</ref> meaning a wife who marries again, a rite being mentioned by which she can ensure reunion with her second (not her first) husband in the next world.

पुनर्-वसु
<u>'''Punar-vasu'''</u> (‘bringing goods again’), used in the dual, denotes the fifth in the series of the Vedic '''Nakṣatras,''' or ‘Lunar Mansions.’ Roth<ref name=fx1_ve1_1858> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> takes the word to have this sense in its only occurrence in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1858> x. 19, 1.</ref> but this must be regarded as decidedly doubtful. The term is, however, found in the ordinary lists of the Nakṣatras in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1858> Av. xix. 7, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 1, 4;<br> iv. 4, 10, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 15;<br> xxxix. 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 2, 10, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 289, 290;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 355.</ref> 

पुनः-सर
<u>'''Punaḥ-sara,'''</u> ‘recurrent,’ is the epithet of the barking dog in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1859> vii. 55, 3;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 56, n. 1.</ref> which is told to bark at the thief. It refers, not doubt, to the dog's practice of running to and fro when it barks. It is also applied to a plant, '''[[अपामार्ग|Apāmārga]]''' (''Achyranthes aspera''), in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1859> iv. 17, 2;<br> vi. 129, 3;<br> x. 1, 9. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 179. Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 394, prefers the sense of ‘attacking,’ which is the meaning of ''[[प्रति-सर|prati-sara]],'' Av. viii. 5, 5. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 20.</ref> with the sense of ‘having revertent leaves.’

पुमांस्
<u>'''Pumāṃs'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1860> i. 124, 7;<br> 162, 22;<br> iii. 29, 13;<br> iv. 3, 10, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve1_1860> Av. iii. 6, 1;<br> 23, 3;<br> iv. 4, 4;<br> vi. 11, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 5, etc.</ref> man as the ‘male.’ It has no special reference to marriage like '''Pati,''' or to heroism like '''[[नृ|Nṛ]]''' or '''Nara.''' In grammar it denotes the masculine gender.<ref name=fx3_ve1_1860> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 1, 1, 8;<br> 5, 1, 3;<br> ''Cf.'' iv. 5, 2, 10, and ''puṃṣā nakṣatreṇa,'' ‘a [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] with a masculine name,’ in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 1.</ref>

पुर्
<u>'''Pur'''</u> is a word of frequent occurrence in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1861> i. 53, 7, 58, 8;<br> 131, 4;<br> 166, 8;<br> iii. 15, 4;<br> iv. 27, 1, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1861> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 7, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 23;<br> ii. 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 4, 3;<br> vi. 3, 3, 25;<br> xi. 1, 1, 2, 3;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 5, 3, etc.</ref> meaning ‘rampart,’ ‘fort,’ or ‘stronghold.’ Such fortifications must have been occasionally of considerable size, as one is called ‘broad’ (''pṛthvī'') and ‘wide’ (''urvī'').<ref name=fx3_ve1_1861> i. 189, 2.</ref> Elsewhere<ref name=fx4_ve1_1861> Rv. iv. 30, 20. Perhaps sun-dried bricks are alluded to by ''āmā'' (lit. ‘raw,’ ‘unbaked’) in Rv. ii. 35, 6.</ref> a fort ‘made of stone’ (''aśmamayī'') is mentioned. Sometimes strongholds ‘of iron’ (''āyasī'') are referred to,<ref name=fx5_ve1_1861> Rv. i. 58, 8;<br> ii. 20, 8;<br> iv. 27, 1. vii. 3, 7;<br> 15, 4;<br> 95, 1;<br> x. 101, 8. See Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, 378 ''et seq.''</ref> but these are probably only metaphorical. A fort ‘full of kine’ (''[[गोमती|gomatī]]'') is mentioned,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1861> Av. viii. 6, 23.</ref> showing that strongholds were used to hold cattle. ‘Autumnal’ (''śāradī'') forts are named, apparently as belonging to the '''Dāsas:''' this may refer to the forts in that season being  occupied against Āryan attacks or against inundations caused by overflowing rivers. Forts ‘with a hundred walls’ (''śatabhuji'') are spoken of.<ref name=fx7_ve1_1861> Rv. i. 166, 8;<br> vii. 15, 14.</ref><br><br>It would probably be a mistake to regard these forts as premanently occupied fortified places like the fortresses of the mediæval barony. They were probably merely places of refuge against attack, ramparts of hardened earth with palisades and a ditch (''cf.'' '''[[देही|Dehī]]'''). Pischel and Geldner,<ref name=fx8_ve1_1861> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xxii, xxiii, where ''[[क्षिति|kṣiti]] [[ध्रुवा|dhruvā]],'' i. 73, 4, is compared.</ref> however, think that there were towns with wooden walls and ditches ( and) like the Indian town of Pāṭaliputra known to Megasthenes<ref name=fx9_ve1_1861> Strabo, p. 702;<br> Arrian, ''Indica,'' 10.</ref> and the Pāli texts.<ref name=fx10_ve1_1861> Mahāparinibbānasutta, p. 12.  ''Cf.'' Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 262.</ref> This is possible, but hardly susceptible of proof, and it is not without significance that the word '''[[नगर|Nagara]]''' is of late occurrence. On the whole it is hardly likely that in early Vedic times city life was much developed. In the Epic, according to Hopkins,<ref name=fx11_ve1_1861> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 77;<br> 174 ''et seq.''</ref> there are found the [[नगर|Nagara]], ‘city’; '''[[ग्राम|Grāma]],''' ‘village’; and [[घोष|Ghoṣa]], ‘ranch.’ Vedic literature hardly seems to go beyond the village, no doubt with modifications in its later period.<br><br>The siege of forts is mentioned in the Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx12_ve1_1861> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 3, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 23;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 4, 3-5;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 7, etc.</ref> According to the Rigveda,<ref name=fx13_ve1_1861> vii. 5, 3. Possibly, in some cases, the palisade was no more than a hedge of thorn or a row of stakes (''cf.'' Rv. x. 101, 8), as suggested by Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 143, 145;<br> and ''cf.'' Rv. viii. 53, 5, as corrected by Roth, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 109.<br><br>''Cf.''
