Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 142148, who compares the fact that neither the Germans (Tacitus, ''Germania,'' 16) nor the Slavs (Procopius, ''De bello Gotico,'' iii. 14) lived in towns, but, like the ancient Indians, were scattered in villages, each consisting of the houses and steadings of the several families living in the village. The evidence seems pretty convincing. It is true that the Greeks, when we first find them, evidently knew castles and fortresses of the mediæval type;<br> but the Greeks were clearly an invading race, superimposed on an older and in civilization more advanced people (see, ''e.g.,'' Burrows, ''Discoveries in Crete''). But the Pur may, as Zimmer allows, have sometimes been built within the limits of the village. Whether, as he urges (144), the ''śāradī pur'' was a protection against the floods of antumn is uncertain. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 131, 4;<br> 174, 2;<br> vi. 20, 10. In particular, it is not legitimate to connect the mention of those forts with the fact that the Pūrus lived on either side of the [[सिन्धु|Sindhu]] (Indus), and to assume that Purukutsa's attack on the aborigines was directed against the forts in which they normally protected themselves on the rising of the river. No argument for the large size of cities can be drawn from the mention in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 1, of ''ekādaśa-dvāra'' as an epithet of Pura (''cf.'' Śvetāśvatara Upaniśad, iii. 18;<br> ''nava-dvāra pura,'' ‘the citadel of nine doors’), because it is used metaphorically of the body, and the number of doors depends on the nature of the body (Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 185). The evidence of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 1, 2, 3, seems rather to point to only one gate in a city.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 412;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 451;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 229;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 203, and '''Mahāpur.'''</ref> fire was used. 

पुरं-धि
<u>'''Puraṃ-dhi'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1862> i. 116, 13. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 398.</ref> possibly as the name of a woman, a protégée of the Aśvins, who gave her a son, '''[[हिरण्यहस्त|Hiraṇyahasta]].'''

पुरय
<u>'''Puraya'''</u> is the name of a patron celebrated in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1863> vi. 63, 9. ''Cf.'' Ludwing, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158.</ref>

पुराण
<u>'''1. Purāṇa,'''</u> denoting a tale ‘of olden times,’ is often found<ref name=fx1_ve1_1864> Satāpatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 6, 8;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 4, 1. 2;<br> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> in the combination [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]-[[पुराण|Purāṇa]], which is probably a Dvandva compound meaning ‘'''[[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]''' and [[पुराण|Purāṇa]].’ It sometimes<ref name=fx2_ve1_1864> Av. xv. 6, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 13;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 2;<br> 5, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 9;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 53;<br> [[पुराण|Purāṇa]]-veda: [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2, 27;<br> Purāṇavidyā: Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7, etc.</ref> occurs as a separate word, but beside [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]], no doubt with the same sense as in the Dvandva. Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx3_ve1_1864> Introduction to [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], cited by St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> defines a [[पुराण|Purāṇa]] as a tale which deals with the primitive condition of the universe and the creation of the world, but there is no ground for supposing that this view is correct, or for clearly distinguishing [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] and [[पुराण|Purāṇa]]. See '''[[इतिहास|Itihāsa]].'''

पुराण
<u>'''2. Purāṇa'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxxix. 7). <br>==Foot Notes==

पुरीकय
<u>'''Purīkaya'''</u> is the name of a water animal in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1866> xi. 2, 25.</ref> being clearly a variant of the name that appears as [[पुलीकय|Pulīkaya]] in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1866> iii. 14, 2. [[पुलीका|Pulīkā]], ''ibid.,'' 5, is a variant of [[कुलीका|Kulīkā]].</ref> and as Kulīpaya in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1866> xxiv. 21. 35.</ref> and as [[कुलीकय|Kulīkaya]] in the Taittirī, [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve1_1866> v. 5, 13, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 96;<br> Bloomfield, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 557;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 621.</ref> What animal is meant is quite unknown.

पुरीषिणी
<u>'''Purīṣiṇī'''</u> is found in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1867> v. 53, 9.</ref> apparently either as the name of a river,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1867> An alternative suggested by Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> or much more probably as an epithet of the '''[[सरयु|Sarayu]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve1_1867> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 17;<br> Geldner, ''Riveda, Glossar,'' 111.</ref> meaning, perhaps, ‘abounding in water,’ ‘swollen,’<ref name=fx4_ve1_1867> Geldner, ''loc. cit.''</ref> or ‘carrying rubble.’<ref name=fx5_ve1_1867> Roth, ''loc. cit.''</ref>

पुरु-कुत्स
<u>'''Puru-kutsa'''</u> is the name of a king who is mentioned several times in the Rigveda. In one passage<ref name=fx1_ve1_1868> i. 63, 7.</ref> he is mentioned as a contemporary of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' but whether as a foe, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1868> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 174, emending ''sudāse'' in the text to ''sudāsam,'' plausibly, but not, of course, convincingly.</ref> or merely as a contemporary, according to Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx3_ve1_1868> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 115. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 204. 205, 219.</ref> is uncertain. In two other passages<ref name=fx4_ve1_1868> i. 112, 7, 14;<br> 174, 2.</ref> he is mentioned as victorious by divine favour, and in another<ref name=fx5_ve1_1868> vi. 20, 10. ''Cf.'' i. 63, 7, where [[पूरु|Pūru]] also is mentioned. Ludwig suggests reading in vi. 20, 10, ''saudāsīḥ'' for ''dāsīḥ,'' referring to the forts of [[सुदास्|Sudās]];<br> but this must be regarded as illegitimate. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift,'' 55, 330.</ref> he appears as a king of the '''Pūrus''' and a conqueror of the '''Dāsas.''' His son was '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],'''<ref name=fx6_ve1_1868> Rv. iv. 42, 8. 9.</ref> who is accordingly called '''Paurukutsya'''<ref name=fx7_ve1_1868> Rv. v. 33, 8;<br> viii. 19, 36.</ref> or '''Paurukutsi.'''<ref name=fx8_ve1_1868> Rv. vii. 19, 3.</ref> Different conclusions have been drawn from one hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx9_ve1_1868> Rv. iv. 42, 8. 9, with Sāyaṇa's note;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 266, 267.</ref> in which the birth of Purukutsa's son,  [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]], is mentioned. The usual interpretation is that [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] was killed in battle or captured, whereupon his wife secured a son to restore the fortunes of the Pūrus. But Sieg<ref name=fx10_ve1_1868> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 96-102.</ref> offers a completely different interpretation. According to him the word '''daurgahe,''' which occurs in the hymn, and which in the ordinary view is rendered ‘descendant of [[दुर्गह|Durgaha]],’ an ancestor of [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]], is the name of a horse, the hymn recording the success of an [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) undertaken by [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] for his wife, as by kings in later times, to secure a son. This interpretation is supported by the version of ''daurgahe'' given in the Śatapatha,<ref name=fx11_ve1_1868> xiii. 5, 4, 5.</ref> but is by no means certain. Moreover, if [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] was a contemporary of [[सुदास्|Sudās]], the defeat of the Pūrus by [[सुदास्|Sudās]] in the '''[[दाशराज्ञ|Dāśarājña]]'''<ref name=fx12_ve1_1868> vii. 18. ''Cf.'' also the reference to a [[पूरु|Pūru]] defeat in vii. 8, 4.</ref> might well have been the cause of the troubles from which '''[[पुरुकुत्सानी|Purukutsānī]],''' by the birth of [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]], rescued the family. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx13_ve1_1868> xiii. 5, 4, 5. ''Cf.'' '''[[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]], Tryaruṇa,''' and Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 403.</ref> [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] is called an [[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]].

पुरुकुत्सानी
<u>'''Purukutsānī,'''</u> ‘wife of '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]],'''’ is mentioned as the mother of '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]]''' in one hymn of the Rigveda (iv. 42, 9).<br>==Foot Notes==

पुरु-णीथ शात-वनेय
<u>'''Puru-ṇītha Śāta-vaneya'''</u> (‘descendant of Śatavani’) is the name of a sacrificer, or perhaps a priest, a [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]], in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve1_1870> i. 59, 7.</ref> It is doubtful whether he is also mentioned as a singer in another passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve1_1870> vii. 9. 6. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 160;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 60.</ref> In both places Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1870> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> sees in Puru-ṇītha merely a word meaning ‘choral song.’

पुरु-दम
<u>'''Puru-dama'''</u> occurs in the plural in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve1_1871> vii. 73, 1.</ref> where, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve1_1871> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, xxv.</ref> it is probably the proper name of the singers, but by Roth<ref name=fx3_ve1_1871> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> and Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve1_1871> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 437.</ref> is understood as merely an adjective meaning ‘possessed of many houses’ 

पुरु-पन्था
<u>'''Puru-panthā'''</u> is mentioned as a generous donor to a '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]''' in one hymn of the Rigveda (vi. 63, 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

पुरु-माय्य
<u>'''Puru-māyya'''</u> occurs in one hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1873> viii. 68, 10. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> as a protégé of Indra. It is quite possible that he was the father of, or at least connected with, '''[[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]], [[ऋक्ष|Ṛkṣa]],''' and '''[[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]],''' who are celebrated in the hymn.

पुरु-मित्र
<u>'''Puru-mitra'''</u> is mentioned twice in the Rigveda (i. 117, 20; x. 39, 7) as the father of a maiden who wedded '''[[विमद|Vimada]],''' apparently against her father's will.<br>==Foot Notes==

पुरु-मीळ्ह
<u>'''Puru-mīḷha'''</u> is mentioned twice in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve1_1875> i. 151, 2;<br> 183. 5.</ref> as an ancient sage, in which capacity he appears in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve1_1875> iv. 29, 4;<br> xviii. 3, 15.</ref> also. Perhaps the same<ref name=fx3_ve1_1875> See, however, Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 27, n. 3;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 62, n. 3</ref> [[पुरुमीळ्ह|Purumīḷha]] is intended in an obscure hymn in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1875> v. 61, 9.</ref> where, according to the legends reported in the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx5_ve1_1875> v. 49 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> and by Ṣaḍguruśiṣya in his commentary on the Sarvānukramaṇī,<ref name=fx6_ve1_1875> Edition Macdonell, pp. 118 ''et seq.''</ref> and by Sāyaṇa in his commentary on the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve1_1875/> he as well as '''[[तरन्त|Taranta]]''' was a son of Vidadaśva, and a patron of the singer '''[[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]].''' The correctness of the legend has been shown to be most improbable by Oldenberg,<ref name=fx7_ve1_1875> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 353, 354. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 359.</ref> who points out<ref name=fx8_ve1_1875> ''Op. cit.,'' 354, n. 1.</ref> that the legend misinterprets the Rigveda by making [[पुरुमीळ्ह|Purumīḷha]] a [[वैदद्अश्वि|Vaidadaśvi]], for he is there only compared in generosity to one.<br><br>In another legend found in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx9_ve1_1875> xiii. 7, 12.</ref> and based on a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx10_ve1_1875> ix. 58, 3.</ref> [[पुरुमीळ्ह|Purumīḷha]] and [[तरन्त|Taranta]] appear as persons who received gifts from '''[[ध्वस्र|Dhvasra]]''' and '''[[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]],''' and as sons of Vidadaśva. The legend, which also occurs in the Śāṭyāyanaka,<ref name=fx11_ve1_1875> Cited by Sāyaṇa on Rv., ''loc. cit.''</ref> is apparently best explained by  Sieg,<ref name=fx12_ve1_1875> ''Op, cit.,'' 63.</ref> who says that as the two were kings they could not under the rules of caste accept gifts, unless for the nonce they became singers. The legend has no claim at all, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx13_ve1_1875> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 232, n. 1. He points out, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 354, that the legend is not accepted by the Anukramaṇī (Index), since its list of authors gives [[अवत्सार|Avatsāra]] as the [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], not the two [[तरन्त|Taranta]] and [[पुरुमीळ्ह|Purumīḷha]].</ref> shows, to validity. 

पुरुष
<u>'''Puruṣa,'''</u> or '''[[पूरुष|Pūruṣa]],''' is the generic term for ‘man’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1> vii. 104, 15;<br> x. 97. 4. 5. 8;<br> 165, 3.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1> Av. iii. 21, 1;<br> v. 21, 4;<br> viii. 2, 25;<br> 7, 2;<br> xii. 3, 51;<br> 4, 25;<br> xiii. 4, 42, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 5;<br> 2, 2, 8;<br> v. 2, 5, 1, etc.</ref> Man is composed of five parts according to the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1> xii. 3, 10;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 5, 26;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 14;<br> vi. 29.</ref> or of six according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_1> ii. 39.</ref> or of sixteen,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 4, 16.</ref> or of twenty,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiii. 14, 5.</ref> or of twenty-one,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 8, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 1, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 18;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 2, 4, etc.</ref> or of twenty-four,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 1, 23.</ref> or of twenty-five,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 12, 10;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, i. 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 2, 4.</ref> all more or less fanciful enumerations. Man is the first of animals,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 1, 18;<br> vii. 5, 2, 17. He is the master of animals, [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xx. 10.</ref> but also essentially an animal (see '''[[पशु|Paśu]]'''). The height of a man is given in the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx11_ve2_1> xvi. 8, 21. 25.</ref> as four Aratnis (‘cubits’) , each of two Padas (‘feet’), each of twelve Aṅgulis (‘finger's breadths’); and the term [[पुरुष|Puruṣa]] itself is found earlier<ref name=fx12_ve2_1> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 5, 14;<br> xiii. 8, 1, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 5, 1.</ref> as a measure of length.<br><br>[[पुरुष|Puruṣa]] is also applied to denote the length of a man's life, a ‘generation’;<ref name=fx13_ve2_1> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 5, 5;<br> v. 4, 10, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 3, 6;<br> ''dvi-[[पुरुष|puruṣa]]'' (‘two generations’), [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 7, etc.</ref> the ‘pupil’ in the eye;<ref name=fx14_ve2_1> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5, 2. 7. 8;<br> xii. 9, 1, 12;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 3, 9.</ref> and in the grammatical literature the ‘person’ of the verb.<ref name=fx15_ve2_1> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 1, 2.</ref> 

पुरुष मृग
<u>'''Puruṣa Mṛga'''</u> the ‘man wild beast,’ occurs in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_2> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 15, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 35.</ref> Zimmer's<ref name=fx2_ve2_2> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 85.</ref> view that the ape is meant seems probable. According to him also, the word [[पुरुष|Puruṣa]] alone, in two passages of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_2> vi. 38, 4;<br> xix. 39, 4.</ref> refers to the ape and its cry (''[[मायु|māyu]]''); but this sense is not necessary, and it is not adopted by Bloomfield,<ref name=fx4_ve2_2> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda.'' 117.</ref> though Whitney<ref name=fx5_ve2_2> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 309.</ref> does not think the rendering ‘cry of a man’ satisfactory, the term ''[[मायु|māyu]]'' not being properly applicable to the noise made by human beings.

पुरुष हस्तिन्
<u>'''Puruṣa Hastin'''</u> (‘the man with a hand’) is found in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_3> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 29;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 8.</ref> It must be the ‘ape.’

पुरुषन्ति
<u>'''Puruṣanti'''</u> is a name that occurs twice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_4> i. 112, 23;<br> ix. 58, 3.</ref> in the first passage denoting a protégé of the Aśvins, in the second a patron who gave presents to one of the Vedic singers. In both cases the name is joined with that of '''[[ध्वसन्ति|Dhvasanti]]''' or '''[[ध्वस्र|Dhvasra]].''' The presumption from the manner in which these three names are mentioned is that they designate men, but the grammatical form of the words might equally well be feminine. Females must be meant, if the evidence of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_4> xiii. 7, 12. Roth thinks the feminine form ''Dhvasre'' here is a corruption, based on the dual form occurring in the Rigveda, ''Dhvasrayoḥ,'' which might be feminine as well as masculine.</ref> is to be taken as decisive, for the form of the first of the two names there occurring, ''Dhvasre Puruṣantī,'' ‘Dhvasrā and [[पुरुषन्ति|Puruṣanti]],’ is exclusively feminine, though '''here''' as well as elsewhere Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx3_ve2_4> Also on the Śāṭyāyanaka, cited on Rv. ix. 58, 3, and on Rv. i. 112, 23.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 27, n. 1;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 62, 63;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 232, n. 1.</ref> interprets the names as masculines. See also '''[[तरन्त|Taranta]]''' and '''[[पुरुमीळ्ह|Purumīḷha]].''' 

पुरु-हन्मन्
<u>'''Puru-hanman'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_5> viii. 70,</ref> an '''[[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]],''' according to the Rigvedic Anukramaṇī (Index), but according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_5> xiv. 9, 29. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 107.</ref> a '''[[वैखानस|Vaikhānasa]].'''

पुरू-रवस्
<u>'''Purū-ravas'''</u> is the name of a hero in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_6> x. 95.</ref> containing a curious dialogue between him and a nymph, Urvaśī, an Apsaras. He is also mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_6> xi. 5, 1, 1. ''Cf.'' iii. 4, 1, 22;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 10;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], x. 46.</ref> where several verses of the Rigvedic dialogue find a setting in a continuous story. In the later literature he is recognized as a king.<ref name=fx3_ve2_6> See Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 283 ''et seq.''</ref> His name is perhaps intended in one other passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx4_ve2_6> i. 31, 4.</ref> It is impossible to say whether he is a mythical figure pure and simple, or really an ancient king. His epithet, Aiḷa,<ref name=fx5_ve2_6> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 196;<br> Max Müller, ''Chips,'' 42, 109 ''et seq.;<br>'' Kuhn, ''Die Herabkunft des Feuers,'' 85 ''et seq.;<br>'' Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erläuterungen,'' 153;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 124, 135;<br> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 28, 323.</ref> ‘descendant of Iḍā’ (a sacrificial goddess), is certainly in favour of the former alternative.

पुरूरु
<u>'''Purūru'''</u> is the name of a poet, an '''[[आत्रेय|Ātreya]],''' in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_7> v. 70, 1.</ref> according to Ludwig.<ref name=fx2_ve2_7> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 126. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 215, n. 1;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 360.</ref> But the only form of the word found, ''purūruṇā,'' seems merely an adverb meaning ‘far and wide.’

पुरू-वसु
<u>'''Purū-vasu'''</u> (‘abounding in wealth’) is the name of a poet, an '''[[आत्रेय|Ātreya]],''' according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx1_ve2_8> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 126.</ref> in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_8> v. 36, 3. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 215, n. 1;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 333.</ref> But this is very doubtful. 

पुरो-डाश्
<u>'''Puro-ḍāś'''</u> is the name of the sacrificial cake in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_9> iii. 28, 2;<br> 41, 3;<br> 52, 2;<br> iv. 24, 5;<br> vi. 23, 7;<br> viii. 31, 2, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_9> Av. ix. 6, 12;<br> x. 9, 25;<br> xii. 4, 35;<br> xviii. 4, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 2, 8;<br> vii. 1, 9, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 85;<br> xxviii. 23, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 270.</ref>

पुरो-धा
<u>'''Puro-dhā'''</u> denotes the office of [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], ‘domestic priest.’ Its mention as early as the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_10> v. 24, 1.</ref> and often later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_10> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 2, 9;<br> vii. 4, 1, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 1, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 12;<br> 9, 27;<br> xv. 4, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 31;<br> viii. 24, 27;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 4, 5.</ref> shows that the post was a fully recognized and usual one.

पुरो-'नुवाक्या
<u>'''Puro-'nuvākyā'''</u> (‘introductory verse to be recited’) is the technical term for the address to a god inviting him to partake of the offering; it was followed by the '''[[याज्या|Yājyā]],''' which accompanied the actual oblation.<ref name=fx1_ve2_11> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 387, 388.</ref> Such addresses are not unknown, but are rare, according to Oldenberg,<ref name=fx2_ve2_11> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 243 ''et seq.,'' against Bergaigne, ''Recherches surl'llistoire de la liturgie védique,'' 13 ''et seq.''</ref> in the Rigveda; subsequently they are regular, the word itself occurring in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx3_ve2_11> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 10, 4;<br> ii. 2, 9, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 12, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx4_ve2_11> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 17;<br> ii. 13, 26;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 1, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 2, 21, etc.</ref>

पुरो-रुच्
<u>'''Puro-ruc'''</u> is the technical description of certain '''[[निविद्|Nivid]]''' verses which were recited at the morning libation in the [[आज्य|Ājya]] and Praüga ceremonies before the hymn (''[[सूक्त|sūkta]]'') of the litany or its parts. It occurs in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_12> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 13;<br> vii. 2, 7, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 39;<br> iii. 9;<br> iv. 5;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 4, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 3, 15;<br> 2, 1, 8;<br> v. 4, 4, 20, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 102.</ref> 

पुरो-वात
<u>'''Puro-vāta,'''</u> the ‘east wind,’ is mentioned in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_13> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 11, 3;<br> ii. 4, 7, 1;<br> iv. 3, 3, 1;<br> 4, 6, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 2, 18;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 3, 1, etc.</ref> Geldner<ref name=fx2_ve2_13> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 120, n. 2.</ref> thinks it merely means the wind preceding the rains.

पुरो-हित
<u>'''Puro-hita'''</u> (‘placed in front,’ ‘appointed’) is the name of a priest in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_14> i. 1, 1;<br> 44, 10. 12;<br> ii. 24, 9;<br> iii. 2, 8;<br> 3, 2;<br> v. 11, 2;<br> vi. 70, 4, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_14> Av. viii. 5, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 23;<br> xi. 81;<br> xxxi. 20;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 24, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 12;<br> vii. 15.</ref> The office of [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] is called Purohiti<ref name=fx3_ve2_14> Rv. vii. 60, 12;<br> 83, 4.</ref> and '''[[पुरोधा|Purodhā]].''' It is clear that the primary function of the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] was that of ‘domestic priest’ of a king, or perhaps a great noble; his quite exceptional position is shown by the fact that only one [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] seems ever to be mentioned in Vedic literature.<ref name=fx4_ve2_14> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 144, thinks that several Purohitas were possible, quoting Sāyaṇa, on Rv. x. 57, 1, who gives the tale of the Gaupāyanas and King Asamāti from the Śāṭyāyanaka, and comparing the case of [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] and [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] as Purohitas, probably contemporaneously, of [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. But that the two were contemporaneous is most unlikely, especially if we adopt the very probable view of Hopkins (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 260 ''et seq.'') that [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] was with the ten kings (Rv. vii. 18) when they unsuccessfully attacked [[सुदास्|Sudās]]. The other narrative has, as Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 375, n. 3, observes, a markedly fictitious character;<br> while every other passage that mentions a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] speaks of him in the singular, and as there was only one [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] priest at the sacrifice, so the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] acted as [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]].</ref> Examples of Purohitas in the Rigveda are '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]'''<ref name=fx5_ve2_14> iii. 33. 53. ''Cf.'' vii. 18.</ref> or '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]'''<ref name=fx6_ve2_14> Rv. vii. 18. 83.</ref> in the service of the '''[[भरत|Bharata]]''' king; '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' of the '''[[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]]''' family; the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of '''Kuruśravaṇa;'''<ref name=fx7_ve2_14> Rv. x. 33. See Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 150, 184.</ref> and '''Devāpi,''' the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of '''Śantanu.'''<ref name=fx8_ve2_14> Rv. x. 98.</ref> The [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] was in all religious matters the ''alter ego'' of the king. In the ritual<ref name=fx9_ve2_14> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 24.</ref> it is laid down that a king must have a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], else the gods will not accept his offerings. He ensures the king's safety and victory in battle by his prayers;<ref name=fx10_ve2_14> See Av. iii. 19;<br> Rv. vii. 18, 13, from which Geldner, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 135, n. 3, concludes that the priest prayed in the '''[[सभा|Sabhā]],''' ‘house of assembly,’ while the king fought on the field of battle. See Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 12. 19. 20. ''Cf.'' '''[[पूरु|Pūru]],''' n. 2.</ref> he procures  the fall of rain for the crops;<ref name=fx11_ve2_14> Rv. x. 98.</ref> he is the flaming fire that guards the kingdom.<ref name=fx12_ve2_14> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 24. 25.</ref> Divodāsa in trouble is rescued by [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]];<ref name=fx13_ve2_14> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 3, 7.</ref> and King '''Tryaruṇa [[त्रैधात्व|Traidhātva]] [[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]]''' reproaches his [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], '''[[वृश जान|Vṛśa Jāna]],''' when his car runs over a Brahmin boy and kills him.<ref name=fx14_ve2_14> ''Ibid.,'' xiii. 3, 12. See Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 64, ''et seq.''</ref> The close relation of king and [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] is illustrated by the case of '''[[कुत्स औरव|Kutsa Aurava]],''' who slew his [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], '''[[उपगु सौश्रवस|Upagu Sauśravasa]],''' for disloyalty in serving Indra, to whom [[कुत्स|Kutsa]] was hostile.<ref name=fx15_ve2_14> ''Ibid.,'' xiv. 6, 8.</ref> Other disputes between kings and priests who officiated for them are those of '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]]''' and the '''Kaśyapas,''' and of '''Viśvantara''' and the '''Śyāparṇas;'''<ref name=fx16_ve2_14> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 27. 35.</ref> and between '''Asamāti''' and the '''Gaupāyanas.'''<ref name=fx17_ve2_14> See Śāṭyāyanaka, cited by Sāyaṇa, on Rv. x. 57, 1;<br> and ''cf.'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 167 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 41).</ref> In some cases one [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] served more than one king; for example, '''[[देवभाग श्रौतर्ष|Devabhāga Śrautarṣa]]''' was the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of the '''Kurus''' and the '''Sṛṅjayas''' at the same time,<ref name=fx18_ve2_14> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 5. According to Sāyaṇa, on Rv. i. 81, 3. is was '''[[राहूगण|Rāhūgaṇa]] [[गोतम|Gotama]]''' who was [[पुरोहित|Purohita]];<br> but this is hardly more than a mere blunder. See Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 152;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 9, n.</ref> and '''[[जल जातूकर्ण्य|Jala Jātūkarṇya]]''' was the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of the kings of '''[[काशि|Kāśi]], [[विदेह|Videha]],''' and '''[[कोसल|Kosala]].'''<ref name=fx19_ve2_14> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 29, 5.</ref><br><br>There is no certain proof that the office of [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] was hereditary in a family, though it probably was so.<ref name=fx20_ve2_14> See Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 375, who compares the permanent character of the relation of the king and the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] with that of husband and wife, as shown in the ritual laid down in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 27.</ref> At any rate, it seems clear from the relations of the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] with King '''Kuruśravaṇa,''' and with his son '''[[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]],'''<ref name=fx21_ve2_14> See Rv. x. 33, and n. 7.</ref> that a king would keep on the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of his father.<br><br>Zimmer<ref name=fx22_ve2_14> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 195, 196.</ref> thinks that the king might act as his own [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], as shown by the case of King Viśvantara, who sacrificed without the help of the Śyāparṇas,<ref name=fx23_ve2_14> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 27;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 436-440.</ref> and that a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] need not be a priest, as shown by the case of Devāpi and Śantanu.<ref name=fx24_ve2_14> Rv. x. 98.</ref> But neither opinion seems to be justified. It is not said that  Viśvantara sacrificed without priests, while Devāpi is not regarded as a king until the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx25_ve2_14> ii. 10.</ref> and there is no reason to suppose that Yāska's view expressed in that work is correct.<br><br>According to Geldner,<ref name=fx26_ve2_14> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 144;<br> 3, 155. ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Go7ttingisehe Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1894, 420;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 13. Rv. i. 94, 6, does not prove that the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] was a [[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]: it merely shows that he could be one when he wished.</ref> the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] from the beginning acted as the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] priest in the sacrificial ritual, being there the general superintendent of the sacrifice. In favour of this view, he cites the fact that [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] is mentioned both as [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]<ref name=fx27_ve2_14> Rv. x. 150, 5.</ref> and as [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]]:<ref name=fx28_ve2_14> Rv. vii. 33, 11. But this need mean no more than Brahmin.</ref> at the sacrifice of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' he served as [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]],<ref name=fx29_ve2_14> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 16, 1;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 21, 4.</ref> but he was the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of [[सुदास्|Sudās]];<ref name=fx30_ve2_14> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 11 14.</ref> [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]] is called the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]<ref name=fx31_ve2_14> Rv. ii. 24, 9;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 17, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 1, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 23, 1</ref> and the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]]<ref name=fx32_ve2_14> Rv. x. 141, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 4, 21;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 6, 9.</ref> of the gods; and the Vasiṣṭhas who are Purohitas are also the Brahmans at the sacrifice.<ref name=fx33_ve2_14> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 2, 1. This point is not in the parallel versions, [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 17 (but ''cf.'' xxvii. 4: ''brahma-purohitaṃ kṣatram,'' unless this means ‘the [[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]] is inferior to the Brahma’);<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 5, 24, and ''cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 13. The [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] literature (Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' lx, lxi) requires a follower of that Veda to act as [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], and the spells of the [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] are, in fact, closely allied to the spells of the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] as represented in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 24-28. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 193, 195.</ref> It is thus clear that the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] was often the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]; and it was natural that this should be the case when once the Brahman's place became, as it did in the later ritual, the most important position at the sacrifice.<ref name=fx34_ve2_14> See Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' lviii, lxii, lxv, lxviii ''et seq.''</ref> But the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] can hardly be said to have held this place in the earlier ritual; Oldenberg<ref name=fx35_ve2_14> ''Religion des Veda,'' 380, 381.</ref> seems to be right in holding that the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] was originally the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest, the singer ''par excellence,'' when he took any part at all in the ritual of the great sacrifices with the '''Ṛtvijs.''' So Devāpi seems clearly to have  been a [[होतृ|Hotṛ]];<ref name=fx36_ve2_14> Rv. x. 98;<br> and ''cf.'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 6, 8;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 12, 7.</ref> Agni is at once [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]<ref name=fx37_ve2_14> Rv. i. 1, 1;<br> iii. 3, 2;<br> 11, 1;<br> v. 11, 2. In viii. 27, 1;<br> x. 1, 6, he is called [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], and credited with the characteristic activities of the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest.</ref> and [[होतृ|Hotṛ]];<ref name=fx38_ve2_14> Rv. i. 1, 1;<br> iii. 3, 2;<br> 11, 1;<br> v. 11, 2. etc.</ref> and the ‘two divine Hotṛs’ referred to in the Āprī litanies are also called the ‘two Purohitas.’<ref name=fx39_ve2_14> Rv. x. 66, 13;<br> 70, 7.</ref> Later, no doubt, when the priestly activity ceased to centre in the song, the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], with his skill in magic, became the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], who also required magic to undo the errors of the sacrifice.<ref name=fx40_ve2_14> ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 26.</ref><br><br>There is little doubt that in the original growth of the priesthood the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] played a considerable part. In historical times he represented the real power of the kingship, and may safely be deemed to have exercised great influence in all public affairs, such as the administration of justice and the king's conduct of business. But it is not at all probable that the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] represents, as Roth<ref name=fx41_ve2_14> ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 117 ''et seq.''</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx42_ve2_14> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 195.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 168, 169;<br> 195 ''et seq.;<br>'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 485;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 31-35;<br> 138;<br> Haug, ''Brahma und die Brahmanen,'' 9 ''et seq.;<br>'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 144;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 374-383;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' lxx ''et seq.''</ref> thought, the source which gave rise to caste. The priestly class is already in existence in the Rigveda (see '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''').

पुलस्ति
<u>'''Pulasti'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_15> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 9, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 43.</ref> or '''Pulastin'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_15> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhītā, xvii. 15. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 265.</ref> in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās denotes ‘wearing the hair plain,’ as opposed to ''kapardin,'' ‘wearing the hair in braids.’

पुलिन्द
<u>'''Pulinda'''</u> is the name of an outcast tribe mentioned with the '''Andhras''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_16> vii. 18.</ref> but not in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_16> xv. 26.</ref> in connexion with the story of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]].''' The Pulindas again appear associated with the Andhras in the time of Aśoka.<ref name=fx3_ve2_16> Vincent Smith, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 652.</ref> 

पुलीकय
<u>'''Pulīkaya.'''</u> See '''[[पुरीकय|Purīkaya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पुलीका
<u>'''Pulīkā'''</u> seems to designate some kind of bird in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iii. 14, 5). The name appears in the form of [[कुलीका|Kulīkā]] in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxiv. 24).<br>==Foot Notes==

पुलुष प्राचीन-योग्य
<u>'''Puluṣa Prācīna-yogya'''</u> (‘descendant of Prācīnayoga’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[दृति|Dṛti]] Aindroti [[शौनक|Śaunaka]],''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 2). He taught '''[[पौलुषि|Pauluṣi]] [[सत्ययज्ञ|Satyayajña]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पुष्कर
<u>'''Puṣkara'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_20> vi. 16, 13;<br> vii. 33, 11, may be so taken, though Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 3, and Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 112, prefer to see in these passages a reference to the bowl of the sacrificial ladle.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_20> Av. xi. 3, 8;<br> xii. 1, 24;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 4, 1;<br> 2, 6, 5;<br> 6, 4, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 29;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 1, 16;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 5.</ref> of the blue lotus flower. The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_20> Av. xii. 1, 24.</ref> mentions its sweet perfume. The lotus grew in lakes, which were thence called ''puṣkariṇī,'' ‘lotus-bearing.’<ref name=fx4_ve2_20> Rv. v. 78, 7;<br> x. 107, 10;<br> Av. iv. 34, 5;<br> v. 16, 17;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 11, etc.</ref> That the flower was early used for personal adornment is shown by an epithet of the Aśvins, ‘lotuscrowned’ (''[[पुष्कर|puṣkara]]-sraj'').<ref name=fx5_ve2_20> Rv. x. 184, 2;<br> Av. iii. 22, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 16, etc.</ref><br><br>Presumably because of its likeness in shape to the flower of the lotus, the bowl of the ladle is called [[पुष्कर|Puṣkara]], perhaps already in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx6_ve2_20> Rv. viii 72, 11, where the sense is doubtful, and the bowl of the ladle is not particularly appropriate. See also note 1.</ref> and certainly in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx7_ve2_20> vii. 5.</ref> Moreover, according to the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx8_ve2_20> v. 14.</ref> [[पुष्कर|Puṣkara]] means ‘water,’ a sense actually found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx9_ve2_20> vi. 4, 2, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.</ref>

पुष्कर-साद
<u>'''Puṣkara-sāda,'''</u> ‘sitting on the lotus,’ is the name of an animal in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’)  in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_21> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 14, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 5.</ref> It can hardly be a ‘snake,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_21> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95, so takes it.</ref> but rather either, as Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_21> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> thinks, a ‘bird,’ or perhaps, according to the commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve2_21/> a ‘bee.’

पुष्टि-गु
<u>'''Puṣṭi-gu'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] mentioned in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_22> viii. 51, 1. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 140, 141.</ref>

पुष्प
<u>'''Puṣpa'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_23> viii. 7, 12. ''Cf.'' x. 8, 34.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_23> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 4, 1;<br> xv. 3, 23;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 4, 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, 2;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 1, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘flower’ generally.

पुष्य
<u>'''Puṣya'''</u> is the name in the Atharvaveda (xix. 7, 2 for the '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]''' called '''[[तिष्य|Tiṣya]]''' elsewhere.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 371. On [[तिष्य|Tiṣya]], see also ''Journal of the Royal Asatic Society,'' 1911, 514-518; 794-800.<br>==Foot Notes==

पूत-क्रता
<u>'''Pūta-kratā'''</u> is the name of a woman in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_25> viii. 64, 4.</ref> perhaps the wife of '''[[पूतक्रतु|Pūtakratu]],''' but this is doubtful, since the more regular form would be Pūtakratāyī,<ref name=fx2_ve2_25> Pāṇini, iv. 1, 36.</ref> which Scheftelowitz<ref name=fx3_ve2_25> ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 41, 42.</ref> reads in the hymn.

पूत-क्रतु
<u>'''Pūta-kratu'''</u> (‘of clear insight’) is the name of a patron in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_26> viii. 68, 17. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163. Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 41, reads [[पूतक्रतु|Pūtakratu]] for [[पौतक्रत|Pautakrata]] in Rv. viii. 56, 2, but this is improbable. See Oldenberg, ''Go7ttingische Gelekrte Anzeigen,'' 1907, 237, 238;<br> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 39, n. 4.</ref> apparently the son of '''[[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]].''' 

पूति-रज्जु
<u>'''Pūti-rajju'''</u> is the name of a certain plant of unknown kind in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_27> viii. 8, 2.</ref> according to Roth.<ref name=fx2_ve2_27> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> The [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_27> xvi. 10.</ref> treats it as a ‘putrid rope,’ but Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve2_27> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 527. ''Cf.'' Whitney's Translation of the Rigveda, 503;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 583.</ref> suggests that a snake is meant.

पूतीक
<u>'''Pūtīka'''</u> is the name of a plant often mentioned<ref name=fx1_ve2_28> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 3 (''pūtika,''  as quoted in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'');<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 2, 12. ''Cf.'' iv. 5, 10, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 4, 1;<br> ix. 5, 3, etc.</ref> as a substitute for the Soma plant. It is also given in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_28> ii. 5, 3, 5.</ref> as a means of making milk curdle, being an alternative to the bark of the ''Butea frondosa ([[पर्ण|parṇa]]-[[वल्क|valka]]).'' It is usually identified with the ''Guilandina Bonduc,'' but Hillebrandt<ref name=fx3_ve2_28> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 24, n. 3. ''Cf.'' Roth, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 689;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 63, 276.</ref> makes it out to be the ''Basella Cordifolia.''

पूतु-द्रु
<u>'''Pūtu-dru'''</u> is another name for the Deodar (''deva-[[दारु|dāru]]'') in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_29> viii. 2, 28.</ref> and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_29> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 8, 4 (in 6 the fruit is meant);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8, 5.</ref> The longer form, Pūtu-[[दारु|dāru]], is found in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_29> viii. 15;<br> lviii. 15. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 59.</ref>

पूरु
<u>'''Pūru'''</u> is the name of a people and their king in the Rigveda. They are mentioned with the '''Anus, Druhyus, Turvaśas,''' and '''Yadus''' in one passage.<ref name=fx1_ve2_30> i. 108. 8.</ref> They also occur as enemies of the '''Tṛtsus''' in the hymn of '''Sudās’''' victory.<ref name=fx2_ve2_30> vii. 18, 13. ''Cf.'' '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]].''' Apparently, as Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 263, n., and Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 135, think, in this verse the words ''jeṣma Pūruṃ vidathe mṛdhravācam'' refer to the [[पूरु|Pūru]] king and to the priest '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],''' who prayed for the defeat of [[सुदास्|Sudās]], though in vain. Hopkins seems to take the words ''vidathe mṛdhravācam'' generally as ‘the false speaker in the assembly’;<br> but, according to Geldner, the meaning intended is that, while the king fought, the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] prayed in the [[सभा|Sabhā]], or meeting house of the people.</ref> In another  hymn<ref name=fx3_ve2_30> Rv. vii. 8, 4.</ref> Agni of the '''Bharatas''' is celebrated as victorious over the Pūrus, probably a reference to the same decisive overthrow. On the other hand, victories of the Pūrus over the aborigines seem to be referred to in several passages.<ref name=fx4_ve2_30> i. 59, 6;<br> 131, 4;<br> 174, 2;<br> iv. 21, 10;<br> 38, 1;<br> vi. 20, 10;<br> vii. 5, 3;<br> 19, 3. ''Cf.'' note 13.</ref><br><br>The great kings of the Pūrus were '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]]''' and his son '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],''' whose name bears testimony to his prowess against aboriginal foes, while a later prince was '''[[तृक्षि|Tṛkṣi]] [[त्रासदस्यव|Trāsadasyava]].'''<br><br>In the Rigveda the Pūrus are expressly<ref name=fx5_ve2_30> vii. 96, 2. Perhaps they are also meant as living on the [[शर्यणावन्त्|Śaryaṇāvant]] in Rv. viii. 64, 10. 11.</ref> mentioned as on the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].''' Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve2_30> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 124.</ref> thinks that the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus) is meant in this passage. But Ludwig<ref name=fx7_ve2_30> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 175.</ref> and Hillebrandt<ref name=fx8_ve2_30> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 50, 115;<br> 3, 374.</ref> with much greater probability think that the eastern [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] in [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]] is meant. This view accords well with the sudden disappearance of the name of the Pūrus from Vedic tradition, a disappearance accounted for by Oldenberg's<ref name=fx9_ve2_30> ''Buddha,'' 404. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, 3, 205.</ref> conjecture that the Pūrus became part of the great Kuru people, just as '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]''' and '''[[क्रिवि|Krivi]]''' disappear from the tradition on their being merged in the '''[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]]''' nation. [[त्रासदस्यव|Trāsadasyava]], the patronymic of '''Kuruśravaṇa''' in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx10_ve2_30> x. 33, 4.</ref> shows that the royal families of the Kurus and the Pūrus were allied by intermarriage.<br><br>Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx11_ve2_30> ''Op. cit.,'' 1, 114 ''et seq.''</ref> admitting that the Pūrus in later times lived in the eastern country round the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], thinks that in earlier days they were to be found to the west of the Indus with '''Divodāsa.''' This theory must fall with the theory that Divodāsa was in the far west. It might, however, be held to be supported by the fact that Alexander found a --that is, a Paurava prince on the Hydaspes,<ref name=fx12_ve2_30> Arrian, ''Indica,'' viii. 4;<br> ix. 1;<br> xix. 3, etc. See Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 132, 133.</ref> a sort of half-way locality between the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] and the West. But it is quite simple to suppose either that the Hydaspes was the earlier home of the Pūrus, where some remained after the others had  wandered east, or that the later Paurava represents a successful onslaught upon the west from the east.<br><br>In several other passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx13_ve2_30> In Rv. i. 36, 1, ''Pūrūṇām'' might be read for ''purūṇām,'' with improvement in the sense. In i. 63, 7, there is a reference to the [[पूरु|Pūru]] king, [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]], and [[सुदास्|Sudās]], but in what relation is uncertain (see '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]]'''). In i. 130, 7. the [[पूरु|Pūru]] king and [[दिवोदास अतिथिग्व|Divodāsa Atithigva]] are both mentioned, apparently as victorious over aboriginal foes. See also i. 129, 5;<br> iv. 39, 2;<br> v. 17, 1;<br> vi. 46, 8;<br> x. 4, 1;<br> 48, 5.</ref> the Pūrus as a people seem to be meant. The [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx14_ve2_30> vii. 23;<br> Naighaṇṭuka, ii. 3.</ref> recognizes the general sense of ‘man,’ but in no passage is this really necessary or even probable. So utterly, however, is the tradition lost that the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx15_ve2_30> vi. 8, 1, 14.</ref> explains [[पूरु|Pūru]] in the Rigveda<ref name=fx16_ve2_30> vii. 8, 4.</ref> as an Asura [[रक्षस्|Rakṣas]]; it is only in the Epic that [[पूरु|Pūru]] revives as the name of a son of [[ययाति|Yayāti]] and Śarmiṣṭhā.<ref name=fx17_ve2_30> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 26, etc. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 110 ''et seq.;<br>'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 398.</ref>

पूरुष
<u>'''Pūruṣa'''</u> has in several passages<ref name=fx1_ve2_31> Rv. vi. 39, 5 (''cf.,'' however, Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 43);<br> x. 97, 4;<br> Av. iv. 9, 7;<br> x. 1, 17;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 1, 22, etc. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 383.</ref> the sense of ‘menial’ or ‘dependent,’ like the English ‘man.’

पूर्ण-मास
<u>'''Pūrṇa-māsa'''</u> denotes the full moon and the festival of that day, occurring frequently in the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_32> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 7, 2;<br> ii. 2, 10, 2;<br> 5, 4, 1;<br> iii. 4, 4, 1;<br> vii. 4, 8, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 14;<br> iii. 5, 7, 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 4, 8, etc.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

पूर्त
<u>'''Pūrta,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_33> Rv. vi. 16, 18;<br> viii. 46, 21;<br> Av. vi. 123, 5;<br> ix. 5, 13;<br> 6, 31;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 64;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 21, 24, etc.</ref> or '''Pūrti,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_33> Rv. vi. 13, 6;<br> x. 107, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 2, 3, 2;<br> ii. 4, 7, 1, etc.</ref> occurs in the Rigveda and later denoting the reward to the priest for his services. ''Cf.'' '''[[दक्षिणा|Dakṣiṇā]].'''

पूर्-पति
<u>'''Pūr-pati,'''</u> ‘lord of the fort,’ occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_34> i. 173. 10.</ref> is of somewhat doubtful interpretation. The term-  may denote a regular office,<ref name=fx2_ve2_34> ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa's note, on Rv. i. 173, 10;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 456. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 204.</ref> similar to that of the '''Grāmaṇī:''' the '''Pur''' would then be a permanently occupied settlement. The expression may, however, merely mean the chief over a fort when it was actually occupied against hostile attack. The rarity of the word seems to favour the latter sense.

पूर्व-पक्ष
<u>'''Pūrva-pakṣa'''</u> denotes the first half of the month. See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पूर्व-वयस
<u>'''Pūrva-vayasa,'''</u> the ‘first period of life,’ is a term used in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_36> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xix. 4, 3;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 2, 3, 4;<br> 9, 1, 8;<br> ''pūrva-vayasin,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 13, 3. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 3, 3, where ''[[वत्स|vatsa]]'' and ''tṛtīya,'' ‘the third (stage),’ are used to cover ‘youth’ and ‘old age,’ as opposed to manhood, when the knowledge of the doctrines of the Āraṇyaka is to be imparted.</ref> to denote ‘youth.’

पूर्व-वह्
<u>'''Pūrva-vah'''</u> is a term applied to the horse ('''[[अश्व|Aśva]]''') in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_37> i. 1, 5, 6</ref> and elsewhere.<ref name=fx2_ve2_37> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 4, 17;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 3. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> It may either refer to a horse fastened in front as a ‘leader,’ or merely mean ‘drawing (a chariot) for the first time,’ as understood by the commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].

पूर्वाह्ण
<u>'''Pūrvāhṇa,'''</u> ‘the earlier (part of the) day,’ ‘forenoon,’ is a common designation of time from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_38> x. 34, 11.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve2_38> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 20;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 12;<br> iii. 4. 4, 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], viii. 9, etc.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Ahan.'''

पूल्य
<u>'''Pūlya,'''</u> or '''Pūlpa,''' in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_39> xiv. 2, 63. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 765.</ref> seems to mean ‘shrivelled grain’ (''cf.'' '''Lājā'''). 

पृक्ष
<u>'''Pṛkṣa'''</u> (literally, perhaps ‘swift’) is the proper name of a man in an obscure verse of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_40> ii. 13, 8. ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 97.</ref>

पृक्ष-याम
<u>'''Pṛkṣa-yāma'''</u> occurs once in the plural in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_41> i. 122, 7.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_41> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> suggests the sense of ‘faring with swift steeds,’ and thinks a proper name is meant. Pischel<ref name=fx3_ve2_41> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 97, 98.</ref> holds that the word is an epithet of the '''Pajras,''' and that it means ‘performing splendid sacrifices.’

पृड
<u>'''Pṛḍa.'''</u> See '''[[मृड|Mṛḍa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पृत्
<u>'''Pṛt'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_43> Only in the locative, Rv. ii. 27, 15;<br> 26, 1;<br> iii. 49, 3;<br> vi. 20, 1, etc.;<br> ''pṛtsuṣn,'' i. 129, 4 (with double case-ending).</ref> and Pṛtanā<ref name=fx2_ve2_43> Rv. i. 85, 8;<br> 91, 21;<br> 119, 10;<br> 152. 7;<br> ii. 40, 5;<br> iii. 24, 1;<br> vi. 41, 5;<br> x. 29, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 76;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 1, 6;<br> 2, 6, etc.</ref> denote, in the Rigveda and later, ‘contest,’ whether in arms or in the chariot race. Pṛtanā has also the concrete sense of ‘army’ in some passages;<ref name=fx3_ve2_43> Rv. vii. 20, 3;<br> viii. 36, 1;<br> 37, 2;<br> Av. vi. 97, 1;<br> viii. 5, 8;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 24;<br> perhaps also as neuter in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 7, 5.</ref> in the Epic system<ref name=fx4_ve2_43> Mahābhārata, i. 291.</ref> it denotes a definite body of men, elephants, chariots, and horses. Pṛtanājya<ref name=fx5_ve2_43> Rv. iii. 8, 10;<br> 37, 7;<br> vii. 99, 4;<br> viii. 12, 25;<br> ix. 102, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 4, 1.</ref> has only the sense of ‘combat.’

पृथ
<u>'''Pṛtha,'''</u> the ‘palm’ of the hand in the sense of its breath, is used as a measure of length in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Brāhmaṇā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_44> i. 6, 4, 2, 3;<br> ''cf.'' Kātyāyana Śrauṭa [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vi. 1, 28;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 2, 7;<br> viii. 5, 10.</ref>

पृथवान
<u>'''Pṛthavāna'''</u> is in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_45> x. 93, 14. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 433.</ref> the name of a man, perhaps also called '''[[दुःशीम|Duḥśīma]],''' but this is uncertain. ''Cf.'' '''[[पृथि|Pṛthi]].''' 

पृथि
<u>'''Pṛthi,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_46> Rv. i. 112, 15, as a seer;<br> as [[वैन्य|Vainya]], [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 7, 4, and perhaps ii. 7, 5, 1 (''Pṛthaye'').</ref> '''Pṛthī,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_46> As [[वैन्य|Vainya]], Rv. viii. 9, 10;<br> Av. viii. 10, 24;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 19;<br> as [[पृथि|Pṛthi]] or Pṛthī, [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 5, 1;<br> as [[वैन्य|Vainya]], Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 5, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 4 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 463). Venya mentioned with Pṛthī in Rv. x. 148, 5, may be meant for his patronymic (= [[वैन्य|Vainya]]): ''cf.'' '''[[तुग्र्य|Tugrya]],''' n. 1.</ref> or '''[[पृथु|Pṛthu]]'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_46> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 186 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 125);<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 10, 9;<br> 34, 6;<br> 45, 1.</ref> is the name of a semi-mythical personage who is mentioned in the Rigveda and later as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], and more specially as the inventor of agriculture<ref name=fx4_ve2_46> Av., ''loc. cit.''</ref> and the lord of both worlds, of men and of animals.<ref name=fx5_ve2_46> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit. Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 5, 1.</ref> He bears in several passages<ref name=fx6_ve2_46> See notes 1-3.</ref> the epithet [[वैन्य|Vainya]], ‘descendant of Vena,’ and must probably be regarded as a culture hero rather than as a real man. According to other accounts,<ref name=fx7_ve2_46> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.;<br>'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 7, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 221, 222;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 50, n. 2;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 134. Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 81, gives the name as Pṛthin [[वैन्य|Vainya]];<br> but the oblique cases, when found, are all in favour of [[पृथि|Pṛthi]] or Pṛthī as the stem.</ref> he was the first of consecrated kings. ''Cf.'' '''Pārthiva.'''

पृथिवी
<u>'''Pṛthivī'''</u> denotes the ‘earth’ as the ‘broad’ one in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_47> Rv. vii. 7, 2, 5;<br> 99, 3;<br> v. 85, 1, 5;<br> viii. 89, 5, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_47> Av. xii. 1, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 53, etc.</ref> being often personified as a deity<ref name=fx3_ve2_47> Rv. iv. 3, 5;<br> 51, 11;<br> v. 49, 5;<br> 84, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' vi. 50, 13, 14;<br> vii. 34, 23, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 103, etc.</ref> both alone and with '''Div,''' ‘heaven,’ as Dyāvā-[[पृथिवी|Pṛthivī]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_47> Rv. iv. 56, 1;<br> vii. 53, 1, etc. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 20, 21, 123, 126.</ref> Mention is often made of three earths,<ref name=fx5_ve2_47> Rv. i. 34, 8;<br> iv. 53, 5;<br> vii. 104, 11;<br> Av. iv. 20, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 9, etc.</ref> of which the world on which we live is the highest.<ref name=fx6_ve2_47> Av. vi. 21, 1;<br> xix. 27, 3;<br> 32, 4;<br> 53, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 1, 31;<br> v. 1, 5, 21.</ref> The earth is girdled by the ocean, according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx7_ve2_47> viii. 20. This idea is not found in the Saṃhitās, Macdonell, ''op. cit.,'' p. 9.</ref> The [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx8_ve2_47> ix. 31;<br> xi. 36;<br> xii. 30;<br> Naighaṇṭuka, v. 3, 5, 6. ''Cf.'' Bruce, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 19, 321 ''et seq.''</ref> places one of the three earths in each of the worlds into which the universe is divided  (see '''Div'''). In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve2_47> xiv. 1, 2, 10.</ref> the earth is called the ‘firstborn of being,’ and its riches (''[[वित्त|vitta]]'') are referred to;<ref name=fx10_ve2_47> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 6, 3.</ref> hence in a late passage of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx11_ve2_47> xiii. 1.</ref> the earth is styled ''vasu-matī,'' ‘full of wealth.’ The word also occurs in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx12_ve2_47> vi. 12, 5;<br> x. 187, 2. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''op. cit.,'' 34.</ref> though rarely, in the form of Pṛthvī.<ref name=fx13_ve2_47> The regular adjectival feminine form of ''[[पृथु|pṛthu]],'' ‘broad.’</ref>

पृथु
<u>'''Pṛthu.'''</u> See '''[[पृथि|Pṛthi]].''' Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve2_48> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 196 ''et seq.''</ref> also finds a mention of the Pṛthus as a tribe, allied with the '''Parśus,''' in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_48> vii. 83, 1.</ref> as opponents of the '''[[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]] Bharatas.''' But this interpretation is certainly incorrect.<ref name=fx3_ve2_48> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 134 ''et seq.;<br>'' 433, 434;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 184, n. 3;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 362, n.</ref> See '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]].'''

पृथु-श्रवस्
<u>'''1. Pṛthu-śravas'''</u> (‘far-famed’) is mentioned in connexion with '''[[वश|Vaśa]]''' in two hymns<ref name=fx1_ve2_49> i. 116, 21;<br> viii. 46, 21. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 162.</ref> of the Rigveda. In the second passage the generosity of [[पृथुश्रवस्|Pṛthuśravas]] [[कानीत|Kānīta]] to [[वश अश्व्य|Vaśa Aśvya]] is celebrated, and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_49> xvi. 11, 13.</ref> refers to the episode.

पृथु-श्रवस् दौरे-श्रवस
<u>'''2. Pṛthu-śravas Daure-śravasa'''</u> (‘descendant of Dūreśravas’) is the name of the Udgātṛ priest at the snake festival mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_50> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

पृदाकु
<u>'''Pṛdāku,'''</u> the name of a ‘snake’ in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_51> i. 27, 1;<br> iii. 27, 3;<br> vi. 38, 1;<br> vii. 56, 1;<br> x. 4, 11 ''et seq.;<br>'' xii. 3, 57.</ref> is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’), in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx2_ve2_51> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 10, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 33.</ref> and occasionally else-  where.<ref name=fx3_ve2_51> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 12;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, xii. 27.</ref> Its skin was specially valuable, according to the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx4_ve2_51> i. 27. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94.</ref>

पृदाकु-सानु
<u>'''Pṛdāku-sānu,'''</u> ‘having the surface of a snake,’ is taken by Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve2_52> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 161.</ref> and Griffith<ref name=fx2_ve2_52> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 141.</ref> as the name of the institutor of a sacrifice in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_52> viii. 17, 15.</ref>

पृशन
<u>'''Pṛśana'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_53> ix. 97, 54.</ref> is considered by Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_53> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 16.</ref> to denote a place where a battle was fought.

पृश्नि-गु
<u>'''1. Pṛśni-gu'''</u> is the name of a man who is mentioned with '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]]''' and '''[[शुचन्ति|Śucanti]]''' as a protégé of the Aśvins in one hymn of the Rigveda (i. 112, 7). Possibly the word is only an epithet of [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]].<br><br>''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 114.<br>==Foot Notes==

पृश्नि-गु
<u>'''2. Pṛśni-gu,'''</u> pl., is taken in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_55> vii. 18, 10.</ref> by Geldner<ref name=fx2_ve2_55> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 114.</ref> as denoting the name of a people. But this is not probable.

पृश्नि-पर्णी
<u>'''Pṛśni-parṇī'''</u> (‘having a speckled leaf’) is the name of a plant mentioned in a hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_56> ii. 25, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> as a protection against evil beings procuring abortion, called Kaṇvas (presumably a sign of hostility to the '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]]''' family).<ref name=fx2_ve2_56> ''Cf.'' Lanman in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 65;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 465;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 207.</ref> It also appears in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_56> xiii. 8, 1, 10.</ref> being identified with ''Hermionitis cordifolia'' by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, but  Roth<ref name=fx4_ve2_56> Cited by Whitney, ''loc. cit.''</ref> in a subsequent contribution suggests that it is the same as a plant later called ''lakṣmaṇā,'' and regarded as curing barrenness. The scholiast on the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_56> xxv. 7, 17.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 187;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 69;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 302.</ref> thinks that the ''Glycine debilis'' is meant.

पृषत
<u>'''Pṛṣata'''</u> is the name of an animal mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_57> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 17, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 9. 21;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 27. 40.</ref> The dappled antelope or gazelle seems to be meant.<ref name=fx2_ve2_57> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83.</ref>

पृषती
<u>'''Pṛṣatī'''</u> in some passages<ref name=fx1_ve2_58> Rv. viii. 64, 10. 11, where ‘deer’ is nonsense, and ‘mares’ is improbable. The regular donation is ‘cows’;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 2, 9 (see Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 125);<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 2 (though this is not certain);<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 14, 23, etc.</ref> clearly means a ‘speckled’ cow. The term is, however, generally<ref name=fx2_ve2_58> Rv. i. 37, 2;<br> 39, 6;<br> 64, 8;<br> 85, 4, 5;<br> ii. 34, 3;<br> 36, 2;<br> iii. 26, 4;<br> v. 55, 6;<br> 58, 6;<br> 60, 2;<br> i. 162, 21.</ref> applied to the team of the Maruts, when its sense is doubtful. The commentators usually explain it as ‘speckled antelope.’ But Mahīdhara,<ref name=fx3_ve2_58> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 16.</ref> followed by Roth,<ref name=fx4_ve2_58> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' He had earlier (''ibid.,'' 1, 1091) been inclined to follow the usual interpretation given by Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 37, 2, etc., which Benfey, ''Orient und Occident,'' 2, 250, accepted.</ref> prefers to see in it a ‘dappled mare’: it is true that the Maruts are often called<ref name=fx5_ve2_58> Rv. i. 87, 4;<br> 89, 7;<br> 186, 8;<br> ii. 34, 4;<br> iii. 26, 6;<br> v. 42, 15;<br> vii. 40, 3</ref> ''pṛṣad-[[अश्व|aśva]],'' which is more naturally interpreted as ‘having dappled steeds,’ than as ‘having Pṛṣatīs as steeds.’<ref name=fx6_ve2_58> So Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 87, 4. This view is far-fetched, but is supported, in so far as the interpretation of [[पृषती|Pṛṣatī]] and [[अश्व|Aśva]] is concerned, by such passages as v. 55, 6, where the Maruts are said to yoke the Pṛṣatīs as ''aśvān'' to their chariots;<br> but the sense may be ‘horses (and) dappled (mares).’ See, however, Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 226.</ref> In the later literature, which Grassmann<ref name=fx7_ve2_58> ''Wo7rterbuch, s.v.''</ref> prefers to follow, the word means the female of the dappled gazelle.  Aufrecht<ref name=fx8_ve2_58> See Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 152.</ref> concurs in the view of Roth, but Max Müller<ref name=fx9_ve2_58> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 70;<br> 184.</ref> is inclined to accept the traditional interpretation, while Muir<ref name=fx10_ve2_58> ''Op. cit.,'' 5, 151, 152.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83.</ref> leaves the matter open.

पृषद्-आज्य
<u>'''Pṛṣad-ājya'''</u> denotes ‘sprinkled butter’--that is, butter ('''[[आज्य|Ājya]]''') mixed with sour milk, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_59> x. 90, 8.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_59> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 6, 2;<br> vi. 3, 9, 6;<br> 11, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 2, 41;<br> 4, 2;<br> iii. 8, 4, 8, etc. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 404, n. 1.</ref>

पृषध्र
<u>'''Pṛṣadhra'''</u> occurs in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_60> viii. 52, 2.</ref> as the name of a man. He is also mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_60> xvi. 11, 25-27.</ref> as a patron of '''[[प्रस्कण्व|Praskaṇva]],''' and called [[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]] [[मेध्य|Medhya]] [[मातरिश्वन्|Mātariśvan]] (or Mātariśva); but for once there is a discrepancy between the statement of the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] and the text of the Rigveda, for the hymns<ref name=fx3_ve2_60> viii. 55. 56.</ref> there attributed to [[प्रस्कण्व|Praskaṇva]] as in praise of [[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]] have nothing in them connected with [[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]], while the Anukramaṇī (Index) ascribes to [[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]] himself the authorship of one of them.<ref name=fx4_ve2_60> viii. 56.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 39.</ref> On the other hand, '''[[मेध्य|Medhya]]''' and '''[[मातरिश्वन्|Mātariśvan]]''' appear as separate persons in the '''Rigveda'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_60/> along with [[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]].

पृषातक
<u>'''Pṛṣātaka'''</u> is the name of a mixture like '''[[पृषद्आज्य|Pṛṣadājya]],''' and consisting, according to the late Gṛhyasaṃgraha,<ref name=fx1_ve2_61> ii. 59.</ref> of curds ('''[[दधि|Dadhi]]'''), honey ('''[[मधु|Madhu]]'''), and '''Ajya.''' It is mentioned in a late passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_61> xx. 134, 2.</ref> and in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx3_ve2_61> [[मानव|Mānava]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 3, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 580.</ref>

पृष्ट्या
<u>'''Pṛṣṭyā'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_62> So Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.'' Pṛṣṭhyā is read in the St. Petersburg Dictionary. See, however, Grill, ''Hundert Lieder,''^2 169;<br> Bloomfield;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 513.</ref> denotes in the Atharvaveda (vi. 102, 2) the side horse (mare). 

पृष्ट्य्-आमय
<u>'''Pṛṣṭy-āmaya'''</u> denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_63> xix. 34, 10. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 65, 391.</ref> a pain in the sides or ribs.<ref name=fx2_ve2_63> The derivative adjective ''Pṛṇṭyāmayin,'' ‘suffering from a pain in the side,’ occurs in Rv. i. 105, 18.</ref> It appears to be mentioned there merely as an accompaniment of fever ('''[[तक्मन्|Takman]]''').

पेत्व
<u>'''Petva'''</u> is found twice in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_64> iv. 4, 8;<br> v. 19, 2.</ref> In the first passage reference is made to its ''[[वाज|vāja]],'' which Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_64> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 229, 230.</ref> argues can only mean ‘strength,’ ‘swiftness,’ though naturally the sense of ‘male power’ would seem more appropriate in a spell intended to remove lack of virility. In the second passage the [[पेत्व|Petva]] is mentioned as overcoming the horse (see '''[[उभयादन्त्|Ubhayādant]]'''), a miracle which has a parallel in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_64> vii. 18, 17.</ref> where the [[पेत्व|Petva]] overcomes the female<ref name=fx4_ve2_64> ''Siṃhyam'' in the text. Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 264, takes it as masculine, and as a play on ''śiṃyum,'' the name of one of the kings or peoples defeated in the battle of the ten kings. But, admitting the play, ''siṃhī'' as fem. seems to be still more pointed than ''[[सिंह|siṃha]],'' contrasting with the masculine ''[[पेत्व|petva]].''</ref> lion. The animal also occurs in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx5_ve2_64> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 22;<br> 1. Though not in the parallel passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, it appears to be found in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]], according to Weber's note in his edition of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.</ref> and occasionally elsewhere.<ref name=fx6_ve2_64> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 8, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 58. 59;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 5, 3. etc.</ref> It appears to be the ‘ram’ or the ‘wether,’ the latter<ref name=fx7_ve2_64> ''Galita-retasko meṣaḥ.''</ref> being the sense given to it by the commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā. But there is no conclusive evidence in favour of this meaning, while on the whole the passage of the Atharvaveda, in which ''[[वाज|vāja]]'' is found, accords best with the sense of ‘ram.’ Hopkins,<ref name=fx8_ve2_64> ''Loc. cit.;<br> India, Old and New,'' 58. He thinks the born of the goat pierced the lion. Curiously enough, Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 253. renders the word a ‘goat’ in Av. v. 19, 2, but (p. 151) as ‘ram’ in iv. 4, 8;<br> and Bloomfield ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 434, speaks Both of a ‘ram’ and a ‘goat’ in connexion with v. 19, 2.</ref> however, renders the word as ‘goat,’ though for what reason is not clear. Whether it is connected in any way with '''[[पित्व|Pitva]]''' or '''Pidva''' is quite uncertain. 

पेदु
<u>'''Pedu'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_65> Rv. i. 117, 9;<br> 118, 9;<br> 119, 10;<br> vii. 71, 5;<br> x. 39, 10.</ref> of a protégé of the Aśvins, who gave him, in order, as it seems, to replace a bad steed, a mythical horse, hence called [[पैद्व|Paidva]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_65> Rv. ix. 88, 4;<br> Av. x. 4, 5 ''et seq.''</ref> which probably represents the horse of the sun.<ref name=fx3_ve2_65> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 52, 149.</ref>

पेरुक
<u>'''Peruka'''</u> occurs in an obscure verse of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_66> vi. 63, 9. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158.</ref> as the name of a patron of the poet.

पेसस्
<u>'''Pesas'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_67> ii. 3, 6;<br> iv. 36, 7;<br> vii. 34, 11;<br> 42, 1.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_67> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 82. 89;<br> xx. 40;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 19, etc.</ref> an embroidered garment such as a female dancer would wear.<ref name=fx3_ve2_67> Rv. i. 92, 4. 5.</ref> The fondness of the Indians for such raiment is noted by Megasthenes<ref name=fx4_ve2_67> See S¤trabo, p. 509, where he refers to a .</ref> and by Arrian,<ref name=fx5_ve2_67> ''Indica,'' 5, 9.</ref> who refer to their . So in one passage<ref name=fx6_ve2_67> Rv. x. 1, 6.</ref> a garment (''[[वस्त्र|vastra]]'') is called ''peśana,'' with which Roth<ref name=fx7_ve2_67> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> happily compares the Roman ''vestis coloribus intexta.'' The making of such garments was a regular occupation of women, as is indicated by the Peśas-kārī, the ‘female embroiderer,’ figuring in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx8_ve2_67> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 5, 1.</ref> though the, commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] interprets the word as ‘wife of a maker of gold.’<ref name=fx9_ve2_67> ''Cf.'' perhaps ''suvarṇaṃ hiraṇyaṃ peśalam'' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 5, where ''peśala'' probably refers to cunningly-worked gold. But this does not suit the compound ''peśas-kārī,'' which must denote a ‘maker of ''peśas,''’ and ''peśas'' has not the sense of wrought gold in any passage. ''Cf.'' also Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 4, 5;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 261.</ref> Pischel,<ref name=fx10_ve2_67> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 113-125.</ref> however, thinks that Peśas never means anything but colour or form.

पेसितृ
<u>'''Pesitṛ'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_68> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Bṛāhmaṇa, iii. 4, 8, 1.</ref> The sense is quite  uncertain. The word is rendered by the St. Petersburg Dictionary and by Weber<ref name=fx2_ve2_68> ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 75, n. 5.</ref> as ‘one who cuts in pieces,’ a ‘carver,’ but Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx3_ve2_68> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> thinks that it means one who causes an enmity which has been lulled to rest to break out again.

पैङ्ग-राज
<u>'''Paiṅga-rāja'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_69> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 13, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 34. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref> That a bird is meant is certain, but what particular kind is quite unknown.

पैङ्गी-पुत्र
<u>'''Paiṅgī-putra'''</u> (‘son of a female descendant of Piṅga’) is the name of a teacher, pupil of '''[[शौनकीपुत्र|Śaunakīputra]],''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30 Mādhyaṃdina).<br>==Foot Notes==

पैङ्ग्य
<u>'''Paiṅgya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Piṅga,’ is the name of a teacher who is repeatedly mentioned as an authority in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_71> viii. 9;<br> xvi. 9;<br> xxvi. 3, 4, 14;<br> xxviii. 7. 9;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2.</ref> where<ref name=fx2_ve2_71> iii. 1;<br> xix. 9;<br> xxiv. 4. ''Cf. Paiṅgī saṃpad,'' xxv. 7. [[पैङ्ग्य|Paiṅgya]] is found also in the Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 2, 11;<br> xi. 11, 5;<br> 14, 9;<br> xv. 3, 1;<br> xvii. 7, 1, 3;<br> 10, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 11.</ref> also his doctrine is called the [[पैङ्ग्य|Paiṅgya]]. This teacher is further referred to in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_71> xii. 2, 2, 4;<br> 4, 8. (Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 17.)</ref> which also speaks of '''Madhuka''' [[पैङ्ग्य|Paiṅgya]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_71> xi. 7, 2, 8;<br> 16.</ref> It is, of course, impossible to say whether there was only one [[पैङ्ग्य|Paiṅgya]] or several Paiṅgyas. The followers of [[पैङ्ग्य|Paiṅgya]] are called Paiṅgins in the [[निदान|Nidāna]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_71> iv. 7.</ref> and Anupada<ref name=fx6_ve2_71> i. 8;<br> ii. 2, 4, 10;<br> vi. 7;<br> xi. 8.</ref> Sūtras. His text-book is called Paiṅga in the Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx7_ve2_71> ii. 4;<br> iii. 12;<br> iv. 5.</ref> while the Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx8_ve2_71> v. 15, 8;<br> 29, 4.</ref> mentions a Paiṅgāyani [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. It is clear that [[पैङ्ग्य|Paiṅgya]] was a teacher of a Rigveda school allied to the Kauṣītakis. Paiṅgi is a patronymic of '''[[यास्क|Yāska]]''' in the Anukramanī of the Ātreyī [[शाखा|Śākhā]].<ref name=fx9_ve2_71> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 71, n.;<br> 3, 396.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 44, 45, 404 ''et seq.;<br>'' 2, 295;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 41, 46, 47, 56, 81, 90, 130, etc.</ref> 

पैजवन
