<u>'''Paijavana,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[पिजवन|Pijavana]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_72> Rv. vii. 18, 22. 25;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 24. 25;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 34;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 11, 14.</ref> It seems most probable that [[पिजवन|Pijavana]] intervened in the line of succession between '''Divodāsa''' and [[सुदास्|Sudās]], because the two kings have, according to tradition, quite different Purohitas, the former being served by the '''Bharadvājas''' as his priests, the latter by '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]''' and '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]];'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_72> See Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie'' 1, 104 ''et seq.''</ref> this is more natural if they were divided by a period of time than if they had been, as is usually supposed, father and son. Geldner,<ref name=fx3_ve2_72> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 115.</ref> however, identifies Divodāsa and [[पिजवन|Pijavana]].

पैद्व
<u>'''Paidva.'''</u> See '''Pedu.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पोतृ
<u>'''Potṛ'''</u> is the name of one of the priests ('''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]''') of the sacrificial ritual. Already known to the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_74> i. 94, 6;<br> ii. 5, 2;<br> iv. 9, 3;<br> vii. 16, 5;<br> ix. 67, 22.</ref> he is frequently mentioned later in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_74> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 10 ''et seq.;<br>'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 4, 22;<br> v. 4, 5, 22;<br> xii. 1, 1, 8, etc.</ref> But as Oldenberg<ref name=fx3_ve2_74> ''Religien des Veda,'' 383, 391, 395.</ref> observes, the [[पोतृ|Potṛ]] is not in the later literature a priest of any importance, but is practically a mere name. Judging by the derivation of the name from the root ''pū,'' ‘purify,’ it would seem that he was properly engaged in the purification of the ''Soma [[पवमान|pavamāna]],'' ‘Soma purifying itself,’ and was perhaps employed to sing hymns to this Soma. Potra<ref name=fx4_ve2_74> Rv. ii. 1, 2, and probably i. 76, 4, though the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' gives this as an example of the second use.</ref> denotes both the office and the Soma vessel of the [[पोतृ|Potṛ]].<ref name=fx5_ve2_74> Rv. i. 15, 2;<br> ii. 36, 2;<br> 37, 2. 4.</ref>

पौंश्चलेय
<u>'''Pauṃścaleya'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 8, 4, 2) denotes the son of a courtesan (Puṃśealī).<br>==Foot Notes==

पौंसायन
<u>'''Pauṃsāyana'''</u> is the patronymic of '''[[दुष्टरीतु|Duṣṭarītu]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 9, 3, 1). <br>==Foot Notes==

पौञ्जि-ष्ठ
<u>'''Pauñji-ṣṭha'''</u> is the form in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_77> x. 4, 9.</ref> the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_77> xxx. 8.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_77> iii. 4, 5, 1, where Sāyaṇa glosses it with the word ''[[कैवर्त|kaivarta]],'' also probably the name of a functional caste.</ref> of the word '''[[पुञ्जिष्ठ|Puñjiṣṭha]],''' denoting ‘fisherman.’ It is probably a caste name, ‘son of a [[पुञ्जिष्ठ|Puñjiṣṭha]],’ as the designation of a functional caste.

पौण्डरीक
<u>'''Pauṇḍarīka'''</u> is the patronymic of '''Kṣemadhṛtvan''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxii. 18, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

पौत-क्रत
<u>'''Pauta-krata,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[पूतक्रता|Pūtakratā]],'''’ is the metronymic of a man, apparently '''[[दस्यवे वृक|Dasyave Vṛka]],''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_79> viii. 56, 2.</ref> Scheftelowitz<ref name=fx2_ve2_79> ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 41, 42.</ref> proposes to read [[पूतक्रतु|Pūtakratu]] with the Kashmir MS. of the Rigveda, arguing that in the same hymn Pūtakratāyī, the wife of [[पूतक्रतु|Pūtakratu]], is referred to, and that therefore [[पूतक्रतु|Pūtakratu]] is appropriate, Pūtakratāyī<ref name=fx3_ve2_79> See Pāṇini, iv. 1, 36.</ref> being the feminine, like Manāyī,<ref name=fx4_ve2_79> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 8, 6;<br> Pāṇini, iv. 1, 38. Perhaps also Vasāvī, Rv. x. 73, 4.</ref> for [[मनावी|Manāvī]]. But the ordinary reading in the sense of descendant is perfectly legitimate, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx5_ve2_79> ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1907, 237.</ref> has pointed out.

पौतिमाषी-पुत्र
<u>'''Pautimāṣī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Pūtimāṣa,’ is the metronymic of a teacher in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

पौति-माष्य
<u>'''Pauti-māṣya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Pūtimāṣa,’ is the patronymic of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[गौपवन|Gaupavana]],''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 6, 1; iv. 6, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

पौतिमाष्यायण
<u>'''Pautimāṣyāyaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[पौतिमाष्य|Pautimāṣya]]'''’ is the patronymic of a teacher, who, with '''[[कौण्डिन्यायन|Kauṇḍinyāyana]],''' taught '''[[रैभ्य|Raibhya]],''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26). <br>==Foot Notes==

पौत्र
<u>'''Pautra'''</u> (‘descended from a son’) is the regular term for a ‘grandson’ from the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_83> ix. 5, 30;<br> xi. 7, 16;<br> xviii. 43, 9.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve2_83> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 8, 3, etc.</ref> When it is used beside '''Naptṛ,'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_83> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 3, 18;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 11, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 10, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrūck, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 478.</ref> the latter word must denote ‘great-grandson.’

पौर
<u>'''Paura,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[पूरु|Pūru]],’ is the name of a man, presumably a [[पूरु|Pūru]] prince helped by Indra, in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_84> viii. 3, 12.</ref> The Greek  the name of Alexander's rival, is probably the representative of this word. Oldenberg<ref name=fx2_ve2_84> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 362;<br> as also Grassmann, ''Wo7rterbuch, s.v.''</ref> sees the same name in another passage also.<ref name=fx3_ve2_84> v. 74, 4.</ref>

पौरु-कुत्स
<u>'''Pauru-kutsa,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_85> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 16, 3.</ref> '''Pauru-kutsi,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_85> Rv. vii. 19, 3.</ref> '''Pauru-kutsya,'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_85> Rv. v. 33, 8;<br> viii. 19, 36;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 5, 3.</ref> are variant forms of the patronymic of '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]],''' the descendant of '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]].'''

पौरु-शिष्टि
<u>'''Pauru-śiṣṭi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Puruśiṣṭa,’ is the patronymic of '''[[तपोनित्य|Taponitya]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 9, 1 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 8, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

पौर्ण-मासी
<u>'''Paurṇa-māsī,'''</u> denoting the ‘night of the full moon,’ is celebrated in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_87> vii. 80.</ref> as sacred, while it is repeatedly mentioned later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_87> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 9, 1;<br> ii. 2, 2, 1;<br> iii. 4, 9, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 2, 4, etc.</ref> Gobhila<ref name=fx3_ve2_87> i. 5, 7. Three sorts of full moon are distinguished by Gobhila--that which occurs when the full moon rises at the meeting of day and night (''sandhyā''), when it rises shortly after sunset, or when it stands high in the sky. The two former alternatives are apparently those described in the passage ([[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 11 = [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1) as ''pūrvā'' and ''uttarā.'' See Weber, [[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]], 51;<br> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 30, 26, n.</ref> defines it as the greatest separation (''vikarṣa'') of the sun and the moon. ''Cf.'' '''[[मास|Māsa]].''' 

पौलुषि
<u>'''Pauluṣi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Puluṣa,’ is the patronymic of '''[[सत्ययज्ञ|Satyayajña]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 6, 1, 1) and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (v. 11, 1). In the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 39, 1) the form is Pauluṣita, which is perhaps merely an error.<br>==Foot Notes==

पौल्कस
<u>'''Paulkasa'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_89> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 14, 1.</ref> The name also occurs in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_89> iv. 3, 22.</ref> as that of a despised race of men, together with the [[चाण्डाल|Cāṇḍāla]]. The Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_89> i. 6, 11.</ref> has the variant [[पुक्लक|Puklaka]] or Pulkaka, clearly the same as Pulkasa, of which [[पौल्कस|Paulkasa]] is a derivative form, showing that a caste is meant (''cf.'' '''[[कौलाल|Kaulāla]], [[पौञ्जिष्ठ|Pauñjiṣṭha]]'''). In the accepted theory<ref name=fx4_ve2_89> ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v., Pukkaśa.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 217, takes [[पौल्कस|Paulkasa]] as a mixed caste.</ref> the Pulkasa is the son of a [[निषाद|Niṣāda]] or [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] by a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] woman, but this is merely speculative; the [[पौल्कस|Paulkasa]] may either have been a functional caste, or, as Fick<ref name=fx5_ve2_89> ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 206. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 416, n. 6.</ref> believes, an aboriginal clan living by catching wild beasts, and only occasionally reduced to menial tasks.

पौष्कर-सादि
<u>'''Pauṣkara-sādi'''</u> (‘descendant of Puṣkarasādi’) is the name of a teacher mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve2_90> vii. 17. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 371.</ref> as well as the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Prātiśākhya.<ref name=fx2_ve2_90> i. 5;<br> ii. 1, 2, 5;<br> Pāṇini, viii. 4, 48;<br> Vārttika, 3;<br> Kielhorn, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 16, 103;<br> Pischel, ''ibid.,'' 34, 26.</ref> A Puṣkarasādi is mentioned in the [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_90> i. 6, 19, 7;<br> 10, 28, 1.</ref> of Āpastamba and elsewhere.

पौष्पिण्ड्य
<u>'''Pauṣpiṇḍya'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[जैमिनि|Jaimini]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_91> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 377.</ref>

प्युक्ष्ण
<u>'''Pyukṣṇa'''</u> is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 3, 1, 11) denoting the ‘covering’ for a bow ('''[[धनुस्|Dhanus]]'''), presumably made of skin. <br>==Foot Notes==

प्रौउग
<u>'''Praūga'''</u> is apparently equivalent to ''pra-yuga,'' denoting the fore part of the pole of the cart, the part in front of the yoke. It is mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_93> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 11, 1, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 4.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_93> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 9;<br> iii. 5, 3, 4, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 248;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 14, n. 1.</ref> where it is said to be the part of the pole behind the '''[[कस्तम्भी|Kastambhī]],''' or prop on which the pole rests.

प्र-कङ्कत
<u>'''Pra-kaṅkata'''</u> is the name of some noxious insect in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_94> i. 191, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref>

प्र-करितृ
<u>'''Pra-karitṛ'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_95> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 8, 1. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 315, n. 1;<br> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 79, n. 6.</ref> The exact sense is uncertain; the commentator Sāyaṇa on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] explains it to mean the ‘divider of dear ones by producing enmity,’ but the sense of ‘sprinkler’--that is, ‘seasoner’--is more likely.

प्र-कश
<u>'''Pra-kaśa'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (ix. 1, 21) seems to mean either the ‘thong’ or the ‘lash’ of a whip.<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-क्रम
<u>'''Pra-krama,'''</u> ‘stride,’ is mentioned as a measure of distance in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 2, 3, 1 ''et seq.''), but its exact length in unknown.<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रक्ष
<u>'''Prakṣa'''</u> is the form in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_98> vi. 3, 10, 2.</ref> of the usual name, '''[[प्लक्ष|Plakṣa]],''' of a tree, being merely a phonetic alteration for the sake of the etymology. According to Aufrecht,<ref name=fx2_ve2_98> ''Rigveda,'' 2, xlvi. n.</ref> the same word is found in two passages of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_98> i. 444;<br> ii. 465.</ref> the same reading occurring in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx4_ve2_98> v. 2, 2, with Keith's notes.</ref> Oldenberg,<ref name=fx5_ve2_98> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 344.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 59.</ref> however, questions the correctness of the reading [[प्रक्ष|Prakṣa]], both in the latter passage and in the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]]. 

प्रगाथ
<u>'''Pragātha'''</u> is the name given in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka (ii. 2, 2) to the poets of the eighth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda, so called because they composed [[प्रगाथ|Pragātha]] strophes (that is, verses consisting of a Bṛhatī or Kakubh followed by a Satobṛhatī).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-घात
<u>'''Pra-ghāta'''</u> is found in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_100> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 1. The word does not occur in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 2, 3.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_100> iii. 1, 2, 18.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 10, n. 1.</ref> in the sense of the closely woven ends of a cloth from which depend the loose threads of the '''[[नीवि|Nīvi]],''' or unwoven fringe.

प्र-चलाका
<u>'''Pra-calākā'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vii. 5, 11, 1) and the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā ([[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], v. 2) seems to mean a ‘cloudburst.’<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रजावन्त् प्राजापत्य
<u>'''Prajāvant Prājāpatya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Prajāpati,’ is, according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 21), the author of a hymn of the Rigveda (x. 183).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-णपात्
<u>'''Pra-ṇapāt'''</u> in the Rigveda (viii. 17, 13) denotes ‘greatgrandson.’<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-णेजन
<u>'''Pra-ṇejana'''</u> is the word used in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 2, 2, 18) to denote the ‘water used for washing.’<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-ततामह
<u>'''Pra-tatāmaha,'''</u> ‘great-grandfather,’ is found in the Atharvaveda (xviii. 4, 75).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-तर्दन
<u>'''Pra-tardana'''</u> is the name in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_106> xxi. 10.</ref> of a king who had a '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]''' for his [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]. In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_106> xxvi. 5.</ref> he appears as arriving at the sacrifice of the [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] in the Naimiṣa forest, and asking them how errors in the sacrifice could be remedied; and as finding '''Alīkayu Vācaspata,''' the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] priest at the sacrifice, unable to say what was to be  done. In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_106> iii. 1.</ref> it is said that [[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]] [[दैवोदासि|Daivodāsi]] went to Indra's world through his death in battle. The patronymic connects him with '''Divodāsa,''' the ancestor or father of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' and the mention of [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]] (probably ‘a Bharadvāja’ is meant) as his priest supports the patronymic, for Divodāsa is a special favourite of the singers of the [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]] family. The name, moreover, is reminiscent of the Tṛtsus (the root ''tard'' appears in both) and of the ''Pratṛdaḥ'' (see '''[[प्रतृद्|Pratṛd]]'''). But he is not in Vedic literature a king of [[काशि|Kāśi]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_106> As in the Epic;<br> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 38</ref> Geldner<ref name=fx5_ve2_106> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 138.</ref> regards him as Divodāsa's son, but this is not likely. ''Cf.'' '''[[प्रातर्दनि|Prātardani]].'''

प्र-तिथि देव-तरथ
<u>'''Pra-[[तिथि|tithi]] Deva-taratha'''</u> is the name of a teacher, pupil of '''Devataras Śāvasāyana''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_107> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373, 385;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 444.</ref>

प्रति-दीवन्
<u>'''Prati-dīvan'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda (x. 38, 6) and the Atharvaveda (vii. 109, 4) ‘opponent in the game of dice.’<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रति-दुह्
<u>'''Prati-duh'''</u> has the specific sense of ‘fresh milk,’ warm from the cow, in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_109> Av. ix. 4, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 3, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 6, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_109> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 5, 5;<br> xviii. 4, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 3, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 6, 2, etc.</ref>

प्रति-धा
<u>'''Prati-dhā'''</u> apparently means ‘draught’ or ‘pull’ in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_110> viii. 77, 4;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 11.</ref> where Indra is said to have drunk thirty streams (''sarāṃsi'') with one [[प्रतिधा|Pratidhā]].

प्रति-धि
<u>'''Prati-dhi'''</u> is mentioned in the Sūryā hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_111> x. 85, 8.</ref> as part of the chariot on which the bride is taken home. It is  impossible to determine with certainty exactly what is meant; Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_111> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> understands it to mean a cross-piece of wood fastened to the pole.

प्रति-पण
<u>'''Prati-paṇa'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda (iii. 15, 4) denoting ‘barter’ or ‘exchange.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[पण|Paṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रति-प्रश्न
<u>'''Prati-praśna'''</u> occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_113> i. 4, 5, 11;<br> iv. 1, 3, 14;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 131, and 26, 267, renders ''pratipraśnam'' by ‘(went to Prajāpati) for his decision,’ which leaves it ambiguous how he took the passages.</ref> applied to Prajāpati as the decider of doubts; it may have been a technical term for an ‘arbitrator’ (''cf.'' '''[[मध्यमशी|Madhyamaśī]]''' and '''harma''').

प्रति-प्र-स्थातृ
<u>'''Prati-pra-sthātṛ'''</u> is the name of a priest ('''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]'''), one of the assistants of the [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_114> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 3, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 29;<br> vii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 2, 2;<br> 3, 13, 22, etc.</ref> He is not mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_114> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 384, n. 2.</ref> but mention is once made in that Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_114> ii. 16, 5.</ref> of the two Adhvaryus. These may have meant, as later, the [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] and the [[प्रतिप्रस्थातृ|Pratiprasthātṛ]]. Oldenberg,<ref name=fx4_ve2_114> ''Op. cit.,'' 390, n. 2.</ref> however, thinks that the [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] and the Agnīdh are intended, a conjecture for which there is some authority.<ref name=fx5_ve2_114> ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 41, 3;<br> [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 6, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 97.</ref>

प्रति-प्राश्
<u>'''Prati-prāś.'''</u> See '''[[प्राश्|Prāś]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रतिबोधी-पुत्र
<u>'''Pratibodhī-putra'''</u> is a wrong reading for '''Prātībodhī-[[पुत्र|putra]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_116> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 391;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 244, 310,</ref>

प्रति-मित्
<u>'''Prati-mit'''</u> is found in the description of a house in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_117> ix. 3, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 153;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 596.</ref> The sense must be ‘support’ of some sort, probably beams leaning up at an angle against the '''Upamits.''' 

प्रति-वेश
<u>'''Prati-veśa,'''</u> ‘neighbour,’ occurs, often metaphorically, from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_118> x. 66, 13.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve2_118> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 97;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 75;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, 3.</ref>

प्रति-वेश्य
<u>'''Prati-veśya'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (xv. 1) as the pupil of '''[[बृहद्दिव|Bṛhaddiva]].''' ''Cf.'' '''[[प्रातिवेश्य|Prātiveśya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रति-श्रुत्का
<u>'''Prati-śrutkā,'''</u> ‘echo,’ shows that this phenomenon had already received a name as early as the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_120> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 14, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 13;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], vii. 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 32;<br> xxx. 19.</ref> and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 13).

प्रति-ष्ठा
<u>'''Prati-ṣṭhā'''</u> is found in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_121> vi. 32, 3 = viii. 8, 21 = [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 14.</ref> where Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_121> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 181.</ref> thinks the word is used as a technical term of law; possibly a ‘sanctuary’ may be meant, but it is more than doubtful whether the sense of ‘home’ or ‘abode,’ as given by Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve2_121> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' 3. So a ''[[प्रतिष्ठा|pratiṣṭhā]]-kāma,'' ‘one desirous of a fixed abode,’ [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiii. 18, 1, etc.</ref> is not quite adequate. ''Cf.'' '''[[ज्ञातृ|Jñātṛ]].'''

प्रति-सर
<u>'''Prati-sara'''</u> is used in several passages of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_122> ii. 11, 2;<br> iv. 40, 1;<br> viii. 5, 1. 4.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_122> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 20;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 30, etc.</ref> to denote an amulet, according to Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve2_122> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' followed by Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 53, n. 2.</ref> because it was a band, and so returned on itself (''prati-sṛ,'' ‘go back’). The sense is doubtful; perhaps ‘attacking’ may really be the root idea.<ref name=fx4_ve2_122> ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, cxxxiii;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 576.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 263;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 345;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 164.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[पुनःसर|Punaḥsara]].''' 

प्रति-हर्तृ
<u>'''Prati-hartṛ'''</u> is the name of the assistant of the Udgātṛ in the list of the sixteen priests ('''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]'''). It is found in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_123> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 2, 1.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve2_123> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 4, 22;<br> xii. 1, 1, 8;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 15, 3;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 10, 11;<br> 11, 8.</ref> but not in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_123> ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 227.</ref>

प्रती-दर्श श्वैक्न
<u>'''Pratī-[[दर्श|darśa]] Śvaikna'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_124> ii. 4, 4, 3.</ref> as sacrificing with the [[दाक्षायण|Dākṣāyaṇa]] offering, and as teaching '''[[सुप्लन् सार्ञ्जय|Suplan Sārñjaya]],''' who thence became '''[[सहदेव|Sahadeva]] [[सार्ञ्जय|Sārñjaya]].''' In a second passage<ref name=fx2_ve2_124> xii. 8, 2, 3.</ref> he is called Pratīdarśa [[ऐभावत|Aibhāvata]], and again brought into connexion with [[सुप्लन् सार्ञ्जय|Suplan Sārñjaya]]. According to Eggeling,<ref name=fx3_ve2_124> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 239, n. 2.</ref> he is to be deemed a king of the Śviknas; apparently, too, he was a descendant of Ibhāvant. A Pratīdarśa is also mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_124> iv. 8, 7.</ref>

प्रतीप प्रातिसत्वन
<u>'''Pratīpa Prātisatvana,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_125> So [[खिल|Khila]], v. 15, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 33, 2.</ref> or '''[[प्रातिसुत्वन|Prātisutvana]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_125> So Av. xx. 129, 2. ''Cf.'' Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 161;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 18, 1.</ref> is the name of a man mentioned in a hymn of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_125/> Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve2_125> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 131.</ref> with great ingenuity, compares the fact that '''[[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]]''' is mentioned as a '''Kuru''' king in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx4_ve2_125> xx. 127.</ref> and that, according to the Epic genealogies, his grandson was Pratiśravas, with which name [[प्रातिसुत्वन|Prātisutvana]], as very possibly a Prākritized version of Prātiśrutvana may be compared, and his great-grandson was Pratīpa. The identification cannot, however, be regarded as at all certain, and while the Epic may have derived its genealogy from the Atharvaveda, it may have preserved an independent tradition. Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx5_ve2_125> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> renders ''prātisatvanam'' as ‘in the direction opposed to the Satvans’, and this may be right. 

प्रती-बोध
<u>'''Pratī-bodha'''</u> is mentioned with '''[[बोध|Bodha]]''' in two passages of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_126> v. 30, 10;<br> viii. 1, 13. ''Cf.'' [[मानव|Mānava]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 15, 1.</ref> apparently as the name of a very mythic [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], ‘Intelligence.’

प्रतृद्
<u>'''Pratṛd'''</u> occurs once in the plural in a hymn of the [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_127> vii. 33, 14.</ref> where it is clearly a variant of the word '''[[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]].''' Moreover, the name of King '''[[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]],''' a descendant of the [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]] king, '''Divodāsa,''' confirms the identification of [[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]] and [[प्रतृद्|Pratṛd]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_127> See Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 159;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 138.</ref>

प्र-तोद
<u>'''Pra-toda'''</u> denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_128> xv. 2, 1.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_128> xvii. 1, 14. See [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 4, 10;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6, 7;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 72, 3. The rendering ‘lance’ seems to have no authority. But see Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 67.</ref> the ‘goad’ of the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]],''' the non-Brahminical Āryan or aborigine. Later the word is regularly used for ‘goad’ in general.

प्रत्यक्ष-दर्शन
<u>'''Pratyakṣa-darśana,'''</u> n., means ‘seeing with one's own eyes,’ as opposed to seeing in a vision (''[[स्वप्न|svapna]]''). A section on such visions appears in the Rigveda Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_129> Aitareva Āranyaka, iii. 2, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 7.</ref>

प्रत्य्-एनस्
<u>'''Praty-enas'''</u> is found with '''Ugra''' and '''[[सूत|Sūta]]-grāmaṇī''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_130> iv. 3, 43. 44 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 3, 37. 38 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> clearly denoting an officer of police. The sense must be that of the humbler ‘servants’ of the king<ref name=fx2_ve2_130> Bo7htlingk's Translation, p. 66, where he takes ''ugra'' as an adjective.</ref> rather than ‘magistrates,’ as Max Müller, in his translation, takes it. In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_130> viii. 4 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 463).</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_130> iv. 16, 16. 17.</ref> the word means, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, the next heir, who is responsible for the debts of a dead man. 

प्र-दर
<u>'''Pra-dara'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_131> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 35, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 10, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 3, 8;<br> xiii. 8, 3, 10, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘cleft’ in the ground.<br><br>^1 [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8, 5; v. 2, 4, 3; Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 7.

प्र-दिव्
<u>'''Pra-div'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (xviii. 2, 48) is the third and highest heaven, in which the Fathers dwell. In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xx. 1) it is the fifth of a series of seven heavens.<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-दिश्
<u>'''Pra-diś,'''</u> like '''[[दिश्|Diś]],''' normally designates only a ‘quarter’ of the sky, or ‘point’ of the compass. Four,<ref name=fx1_ve2_133> Rv. i. 164, 42;<br> vii. 35, 8;<br> x. 19, 8;<br> Av. i. 11, 2;<br> ii. 10, 3.</ref> five,<ref name=fx2_ve2_133> Rv. ix. 86, 29;<br> Av. i. 30, 4;<br> iii. 4, 2;<br> 20, 9.</ref> six,<ref name=fx3_ve2_133> Av. iv. 11, 1;<br> 20, 2;<br> x. 7, 35.</ref> and seven<ref name=fx4_ve2_133> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 32.</ref> such points are enumerated, or more generally ‘all’ are mentioned.<ref name=fx5_ve2_133> Rv. vi. 75, 2;<br> x. 121, 4.</ref> In some passages,<ref name=fx6_ve2_133> Av. v. 28, 2;<br> ix. 2, 21;<br> xix. 20, 2, etc.</ref> on the other hand, the word has the definite sense of an ‘intermediate quarter,’ which is more precisely denoted by ''avāntara-[[दिश्|diś]].''

प्र-धन
<u>'''Pra-dhana'''</u> denotes ‘contest,’ whether the real conflict of war or the competition of the chariot race, in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_134> i. 116, 2;<br> 154, 3;<br> 169, 2;<br> x. 102, 5, etc.</ref>

प्र-धि
<u>'''Pra-dhi'''</u> is the name of some part of the wheel of a chariot, probably the ‘felly.’ In one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_135> ii. 39, 4.</ref> and in one of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_135> vi. 70, 3.</ref> the ‘nave’ ('''[[नभ्य|Nabhya]]''') and the ‘felly’ (''[[प्रधि|pradhi]]'') are mentioned along with the '''[[उपधि|Upadhi]],''' which must then be either a collective name for the spokes or an inner rim within the felly and binding the spokes. In the riddle hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_135> i. 164, 48.</ref> twelve Pradhis are mentioned with three naves, one wheel, and three hundred and sixty spokes; what exactly is here meant by this particular term it would be useless to conjecture, though it is clear that the passage as a whole symbolizes  the year with three seasons, twelve months, and three hundred and sixty days. Elsewhere<ref name=fx4_ve2_135> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 11, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 15;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 23.</ref> the nave and the [[प्रधि|Pradhi]] alone are mentioned, or the [[प्रधि|Pradhi]] occurs by itself.<ref name=fx5_ve2_135> Rv. iv. 30, 15;<br> x. 102, 7, etc. In Av. xviii. 2, 14, ''Pradhāv adhi'' is merely an incorrect variant of the ''pradhāvati'' of Rv. x. 154, 1. The same corruption is seen by Lanman (in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, xcii) in Av. vi. 70, 3 (n. 2).<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 334;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 248.</ref>

प्र-ध्वंसन
<u>'''Pra-dhvaṃsana.'''</u> See '''[[प्राध्वंसन|Prādhvaṃsana]]'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-पण
<u>'''Pra-paṇa'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (xii. 15, 4. 5) denotes ‘barter’ or ‘exchange,’ balanced by '''[[प्रतिपण|Pratipaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-पथ
<u>'''Pra-patha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_138> x. 17, 4. 6;<br> 63, 16.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_138> vii. 15.</ref> denotes a ‘long journey.’ Wilson<ref name=fx3_ve2_138> Translation of the Rigveda, 2, 151.</ref> has seen in one passage<ref name=fx4_ve2_138> Rv. i. 166, 9.</ref> the sense of ‘resting-place,’ where travellers can obtain food (''[[खादि|khādi]]''). Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_138> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 231.</ref> shows that this is impossible, and the reading (''prapatheṣu'') in the passage in question is not improbably<ref name=fx6_ve2_138> Roth. St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br> Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 108;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 166. Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' does not follow Roth.</ref> an error for ''prapadeṣu.'' In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx7_ve2_138> xxxvii. 14 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 466).</ref> the word means a ‘broad road.’

प्र-पथिन्
<u>'''Pra-pathin'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_139> ''Prapathī'' might be the stem, the word occurring as a proper name in the nominative singular only (''cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammer,'' 377, 3);<br> but this is not probable, the stem ''[[प्रपथिन्|prapathin]]'' being otherwise found as an adjective</ref> is the name of a patron, perhaps a Yādava, in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_139> viii. 1, 30. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 159;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 90.</ref> 

प्र-पा
<u>'''Pra-pā'''</u> seems to denote a ‘spring’ in the desert in the only Rigveda passage where it occurs.<ref name=fx1_ve2_140> x. 4, 1.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_140> iii. 30, 6. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 1, 2.</ref> it has merely the sense of ‘drinking,’ or a ‘drink.’

प्र-पितामह
<u>'''Pra-pitāmaha,'''</u> ‘great-grandfather,’ is found in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_141> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 5, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 36;<br> Av. xviii. 4, 35.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_141> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 2, 16;<br> xii. 8, 1, 7.</ref>

प्र-पित्व
<u>'''Pra-pitva'''</u> is found in several passages of the Rigveda as a designation of time. In one passage<ref name=fx1_ve2_142> viii. 1, 29.</ref> the sense is made clear by the context: ‘at the rising of the sun’ (''sūra udite''), ‘at midday’ (''madhyaṃdine divaḥ''), and ‘at the [[प्रपित्व|Prapitva]], bordering on the night’ (''apiśarvare''). In another passage<ref name=fx2_ve2_142> vii. 41, 4.</ref> the sense of ‘late in the day’ also seems adequate, while the phrase<ref name=fx3_ve2_142> iv. 16, 12.</ref> ''abhipitve ahnaḥ,'' ‘at the close of day,’ also denotes the evening. According to Geldner,<ref name=fx4_ve2_142> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 174 ''et seq.''</ref> the sense of the word is the ‘decisive moment’ in a race or a battle, and so the ‘end of the day.’<ref name=fx5_ve2_142> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' took it to mean ‘daybreak’;<br> so also Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 362. Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' on the other hand, gives the meaning as ‘decline of day,’ ‘evening.’ See also Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 24 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 183 ''et seq.''</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Ahan.'''

प्र-प्रोथ
<u>'''Pra-protha'''</u> is the name in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 4, 1) of a plant used as a substitute for Soma.<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-फर्वी
<u>'''Pra-pharvī'''</u> denotes a ‘wanton woman’ in the Rigveda (x. 85, 22), the Atharvaveda (v. 22, 7), and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_144> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 5, 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 12;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 71.</ref>

प्र-बुध्
<u>'''Pra-budh,'''</u> occurring in one passage of the Rigveda (viii. 27, 19), is used in the locative parallel with ''nimruci,'' ‘at the setting (of the sun),’ and clearly means ‘at the rising (of the sun).’ <br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-मगन्द
<u>'''Pra-maganda'''</u> is the name of a prince in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_146> iii. 53, 14.</ref> where he is mentioned as the king of the '''Kīkaṭas,''' and where he seems to be designated by the epithet ''[[नैचाशाख|naicāśākha]],'' ‘belonging to a low branch or race.’ On the other hand, [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_146> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 32.</ref> takes [[प्रमगन्द|Pramaganda]] to mean the ‘son of a usurer,’ an explanation that is hardly probable. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx3_ve2_146> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 14-16. 241-245.</ref> thinks that ''[[नैचाशाख|naicāśākha]]'' refers not to [[प्रमगन्द|Pramaganda]], but to the Soma plant, the plant being called ''nīcāśākha,'' ‘having shoots turned downwards,’ and that the passage refers to a raid against the Kīkaṭas, who were not observers of the milk cult or the Soma cult, with the intention of winning their lands where the Soma grew and where there were cows. Bo7htlingk,<ref name=fx4_ve2_146> ''Proceedings of the Saxon Academy,'' December 12, 1891.</ref> however, questions this view, which is not very probable. A place name is possibly meant by [[नैचाशाख|Naicāśākha]].<ref name=fx5_ve2_146> Sāyaṇa, in his introduction to his commentary on the Rigveda, p. 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 31;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 6, 153;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 58.</ref> The name [[प्रमगन्द|Pramaganda]] seems un-Āryan.

प्र-मन्दनी
<u>'''Pra-mandanī'''</u> is the name of an Apsaras in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_147> iv. 37, 3.</ref> Probably the word primarily denoted a certain sweet-scented plant, which seems to be the sense of ''pra-manda'' in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_147> viii. 17;<br> xxv. 11;<br> xxxii. 29;<br> ''niṣpramanda,'' xxxvi. 15. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 69;<br> Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 15, n. 11.</ref>

प्र-मर
<u>'''Pra-mara'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_148> x. 27, 20.</ref> is taken by Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_148> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165.</ref> to be a proper name.

प्र-मोत
<u>'''Pra-mota'''</u> is the name of some sort of disease in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_149> ix. 8, 4.</ref> according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary. Zimmer,<ref name=fx2_ve2_149> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 378, n.</ref> however, thinks that the word must be an adjective meaning ‘dumb.’ This view is accepted, though with doubt, by Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve2_149> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 550.</ref> and by Bloomfield.<ref name=fx4_ve2_149> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 601.</ref> 

प्र-योग
<u>'''Pra-yoga'''</u> is the name of a seer in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_150> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 10, 1;<br> '''[[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,''' xix. 10 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 478).</ref>

प्र-योग्य
<u>'''Pra-yogya'''</u> denotes in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (viii. 12, 3) an animal yoked to a carriage, ‘draught animal.’<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-लाप
<u>'''Pra-lāpa,'''</u> ‘prattle,’ is found with other words of similar import in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_152> xi. 8, 25.</ref> and in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_152> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 33;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 17, 6, etc.</ref> of the Rigveda. The phrase '''[[ऐतश|Aitaśa]]-[[प्रलाप|pralāpa]],''' ‘Discourse of [[ऐतश|Aitaśa]],’ occurs as a designation of certain passages of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_152> See Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' pp. 98, 101, n. 12;<br> Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 159 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Bṛhaddevatā,'' 2, 323.</ref> The name has no justification in the text itself.

प्र-वचन
<u>'''Pra-vacana'''</u> means ‘oral instruction,’ ‘teaching,’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_153> xi. 5, 7, 1.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_153> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1, 3, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 23;<br> Muṇḍaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 2, 3, etc.</ref>

प्र-वत्
<u>'''Pra-vat,'''</u> ‘height,’ is contrasted with '''[[निवत्|Nivat]],''' ‘valley,’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_154> vii. 50, 4.</ref> where it occurs several times.<ref name=fx2_ve2_154> Rv. ii. 13, 2;<br> iv. 17, 7;<br> 22, 4;<br> vi. 17, 12;<br> vii. 32, 27;<br> x. 14, 1;<br> 57, 12;<br> 75, 4.</ref> The word is also found later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_154> Av. i. 13, 2;<br> 26, 3;<br> vi. 28, 3;<br> x. 10, 2;<br> xii. 1, 2;<br> xviii. 4, 7.</ref>

प्र-वर
<u>'''1. Pra-vara'''</u> denotes properly the ‘summons’ addressed to Agni at the beginning of the sacrifice to perform his functions. But as Agni was then invoked by the names of the ancestors of the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_155> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 25. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 78.</ref> the term [[प्रवर|Pravara]] denotes the series of ancestors invoked.<ref name=fx2_ve2_155> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 1, 1. 20;<br> iii. 7, 4, 9;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 31, etc.</ref> 

प्र-वर
<u>'''2. Pra-vara,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_156> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 10. in the Mādhyaṃdina recension.</ref> or '''[[प्र-वार|Pra-vāra]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_156> Sāyaṇa on Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit.;<br>'' and [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension, vi. 2, 7.</ref> denotes a ‘covering’ or ‘woollen cloth’ in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].

प्र-वर्त
<u>'''Pra-varta,'''</u> occurring in the description of the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]]''' in the Atharvaveda (xv. 2, 1, ''et seq.''), is explained by the St. Petersburg Dictionary as a ‘round ornament.’ According to the commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (2, 453 ''Bibl. Ind.''), it means an ‘ear-ring.’<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-वल्हिका
<u>'''Pra-valhikā,'''</u> a ‘riddle,’ is the name given in the Brāhmaṇas of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_158> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 33;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 7.</ref> to certain verses of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_158> xx. 133;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 22;<br> [[खिल|Khila]], v. 16.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 98-100.</ref>

प्र-वात
<u>'''Pra-vāta,'''</u> ‘a windy spot,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_159> x. 34, 1;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 8. Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 119, thinks the reference here is to nuts being blown down in a storm of wind.</ref> as the place where the '''[[विभीतक|Vibhītaka]]''' nuts, used as dice ('''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]''') grow. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_159> vi. 4, 7, 2.</ref> reference is made to the exposure of decaying matter in such a place.

प्र-वार
<u>'''Pra-vāra.'''</u> See 2. '''[[प्रवर|Pravara]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-वा¤स
<u>'''Pra-vā¤sa,'''</u> ‘dwelling abroad,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_161> viii. 29, 8.</ref> Ceremonies applicable to one who has returned from foreign residence are given in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve2_161> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 15;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 17, etc.</ref>

प्र-वाहण जैवलि
<u>'''Pra-vāhaṇa Jaivali'''</u> or '''[[जैवल|Jaivala]]''' (‘descendant of '''Jīvala'''’) is the name of a prince, contemporary with '''Uddālaka,''' who  appears in the Upaniṣads<ref name=fx1_ve2_162> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 1. 7 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 8, 1;<br> v. 3, 1.</ref> as engaged in philosophical discussions. He is probably identical with the Jaivali of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_162> i. 38, 4.</ref>

प्र-शस्
<u>'''Pra-śas'''</u> in a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_163> ii. 6, 5. ''Cf.'' [[दुर्ग|Durga]] on [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 11.</ref> denotes, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, an ‘axe,’ or some similar instrument for cutting.<ref name=fx2_ve2_163> From ''śas,'' ‘to cut.’</ref>

प्र-शास्तृ
<u>'''Pra-śāstṛ'''</u> is the name of one of the priests ('''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]''') at the Vedic sacrifice. In the lesser sacrifices he plays no part at all, but he appears in the animal (''[[पशु|paśu]]'') and Soma sacrifices, in the former as the only, in the latter as the main, assistant of the '''[[होतृ|Hotṛ]]''' priest in the singing of the litanies. He is mentioned by name in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_164> i. 94, 6;<br> ii. 5, 4;<br> ''praśāstra,'' ‘the Soma bowl of the [[प्रशास्तृ|Praśāstṛ]],’ 36, 6;<br> ''praśāstra,'' ‘the office of the [[प्रशास्तृ|Praśāstṛ]],’ ii. 1, 2 = x, 91, 10.</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_164> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 21;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 34;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 6, 6;<br> xi. 5, 5, 9, etc.</ref> He is also in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_164> iv. 9, 5;<br> vi. 71, 5;<br> ix. 95, 5. According to Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 226, the Upavaktṛ is the earliest equivalent of the Ashāvāka.</ref> called '''Upavaktṛ,''' this name, like [[प्रशास्तृ|Praśāstṛ]], being derived from the fact that one of his chief functions was to issue directions (''[[प्रैष|praiṣa]]'') to the other priests. Another name for him was Maitrāvaruṇa, because his litanies were mainly addressed to [[मित्र|Mitra]] and Varuṇa, a connexion already visible in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx4_ve2_164> ii. 36, 6.</ref> The ‘two divine Hotṛs’ of the Āprī litanies denote, according to Oldenberg,<ref name=fx5_ve2_164> ''Religion des Veda,'' 391. Ludwig, ''op. cit.,'' 3, 227, identifies the [[प्रशास्तृ|Praśāstṛ]] with the '''[[प्रस्तोतृ|Prastotṛ]],''' but this is most improbable.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 383, 390, 391;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 141 ''et seq.''</ref> the heavenly counterparts of the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] and the [[प्रशास्तृ|Praśāstṛ]].

प्रश्न
<u>'''Praśna'''</u> denotes generally ‘enquiry’ or ‘disputed question,’ the phrase ''praśnam eti'' having the sense ‘he asks a person for  the decision of a disputed point’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_165> ii. 5, 8, 5;<br> 11, 9.</ref> and elsewhere.<ref name=fx2_ve2_165> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 6, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 28.</ref> Thus [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] comes to have the definite meaning of ‘decision in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_165> v. 14.</ref> In the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_165> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 6, 1.</ref> are included the Praśnin, the [[अभि-प्रश्निन्|Abhi-praśnin]], and the [[प्रश्न|Praśna]]-vivāka; it is quite likely that here the three parties to a civil case are meant--the plaintiff, the defendant, and the arbitrator or judge ('''[[मध्यमशी|Madhyamaśī]]''').

प्रष्टि
<u>'''Praṣṭi,'''</u> like '''[[पृष्ट्या|Pṛṣṭyā]],''' denotes a ‘side horse,’ which, however, possibly<ref name=fx1_ve2_166> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> did not necessarily mean a horse running beside the yoke-horses, but may also have meant a third horse yoked in front as a leader. This seems to be indicated by the reference in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_166> i. 39, 6;<br> viii. 27, 8. In i. 100, 17, ''praṣṭibhiḥ'' seems to refer to the assistants or comrades of '''[[ऋज्राश्व|Ṛjrāśva]]''' (''cf.'' Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 12, 14);<br> but Ludwig thinks that the word refers to the steeds by which a victory was won.</ref> to the [[प्रष्टि|Praṣṭi]]--here applied to the Maruts’ team--leading (''vahati'') the team (''rohitaḥ''). In an obscure passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_166> x. 8, 8. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 597.</ref> there is a reference to the Praṣṭis in connexion with a ''pañca-vāhī,'' ‘drawn by five,’ but it is impossible to gain any clear idea of what is meant. The [[प्रष्टि|Praṣṭi]] is not rarely referred to elsewhere.<ref name=fx4_ve2_166> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 21, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 3, 9, etc.</ref> In one passage<ref name=fx5_ve2_166> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 12, 5.</ref> the ''dhuryau'' and the ''praṣṭyau'' are mentioned together; this probably means the two horses yoked to the pole, with two others fastened in some way one on each side. The adjectives ''praṣṭimant,''<ref name=fx6_ve2_166> Rv. vi. 27, 24.</ref> ''[[प्रष्टि|praṣṭi]]-[[वाहन|vāhana]],''<ref name=fx7_ve2_166> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 9.</ref> ''[[प्रष्टि|praṣṭi]]-vāhin,''<ref name=fx8_ve2_166> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6, 4;<br> 7, 1, 5;<br> 9, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 13, 12 (where ''praṣṭhi-vāhin'' and ''[[प्रष्टि|praṣṭi]]-vāhin'' are confused).<br><br>Geldner's conjecture, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 119, that [[प्रष्टि|Praṣṭi]] denotes a horse yoked in the middle, is withdrawn by himself, ''Kommentar,'' 97.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 250;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 102.</ref> are all used of '''[[रथ|Ratha]],''' ‘chariot,’ meaning ‘drawn by a side horse (or horses)’ in addition to the yoke-horses. ''Cf.'' '''[[रथ|Ratha]].''' 

प्र-सिति
<u>'''Pra-siti'''</u> in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (ii. 19) and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 7, 13, 4) denotes a divine ‘missile,’ but does not seem to be used of human combatants.<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-सू
<u>'''Pra-sū'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_168> i. 95, 10;<br> iii. 5, 8;<br> vii. 9, 3;<br> 35, 7;<br> viii. 6, 20.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_168> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 1, 18.</ref> denotes the young shoots of grass or herbs used at the sacrifice.

प्र-सृत
<u>'''Pra-sṛta'''</u> is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_169> iv. 5, 10, 7;<br> xiii. 4, 1, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 1, 7.</ref> as a measure of capacity, meaning a ‘handful.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_169> Primarily, the word designates the hollowed hand ‘stretched out’ to receive what is offered.</ref>

प्र-स्कण्व
<u>'''Pra-skaṇva'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] who is credited by the Anukramaṇī (Index) with the authorship of certain hymns of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_170> i. 44-50;<br> viii. 49;<br> ix. 95.</ref> where<ref name=fx2_ve2_170> i. 44, 6;<br> 45, 3;<br> viii. 3, 9;<br> 51, 2;<br> 54, 8. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 17.</ref> he is mentioned several times. The statement in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_170> xvi. 11, 26.</ref> that he obtained bounty from '''[[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]] [[मेध्य|Medhya]] [[मातरिश्वन्|Mātariśvan]]''' is apparently a blunder.<ref name=fx4_ve2_170> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 39.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 104 ''et seq.''</ref>

प्र-स्तर
<u>'''Pra-stara'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_171> x. 14, 4.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_171> Av. xvi. 2, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 7, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 18;<br> xviii. 63;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 26;<br> ii. 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 3, 5, etc.</ref> denotes the grass strewn as a sacrificial seat.

प्र-स्तोक
<u>'''Pra-stoka'''</u> is the name of a generous donor in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_172> vi. 47, 22.</ref> where Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_172> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158.</ref> identifies him with '''[[दिवोदास अतिथिग्व|Divodāsa Atithigva]]''' and  '''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]]''' or Aśvatha. According to the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_172> xvi. 11, 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 30, 31;<br> Macdonell, ''Bṛhaddevatā,'' 2, 198 ''et seq.''</ref> '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]''' obtained gifts from [[प्रस्तोक|Prastoka]] '''[[सार्ञ्जय|Sārñjaya]],''' ‘descendant of [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]].’

प्र-स्तोतृ
<u>'''Pra-stotṛ'''</u> is the name of an assistant of the Udgātṛ priest who sings the Prastāva,<ref name=fx1_ve2_173> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 10, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 23;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 7, 4, 6;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 10, 9;<br> ii. 2, 1, etc.</ref> or prelude of the Sāman chant. His not being mentioned by name in the Rigveda is merely an accident, for he is clearly referred to in one passage,<ref name=fx2_ve2_173> viii. 81, 5 (''pra stoṣat''). See Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 393, n. 3.</ref> and in the later literature<ref name=fx3_ve2_173> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 2, 1;<br> vi. 6, 3, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 34;<br> vii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 5, 3;<br> v. 4, 5, 22;<br> xii. 1, 1, 6, etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 10, 8, etc.</ref> he is a frequent figure. Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve2_173> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 227.</ref> erroneously thinks that '''[[प्रशास्तृ|Praśāstṛ]]''' is the earlier name of the [[प्रस्तोतृ|Prastotṛ]].

प्रस्रवण
<u>'''Prasravaṇa.'''</u> See '''[[प्लक्ष|Plakṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्र-हा
<u>'''Pra-hā'''</u> in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_175> x. 42, 9.</ref> the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_175> iv. 38, 3.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_175> xvi. 14, 2;<br> xx. 11, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 241, and ''prahāvant,'' Rv. iv. 20, 8, meaning ‘acquiring gain,’ according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> denotes a ‘winning throw’ at dice, or, generally, any ‘gain’ or ‘advantage.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_175/>

प्रा-कार
<u>'''Prā-kāra'''</u> in the Śaṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xvi. 18, 14) denotes a walled mound supporting a raised platform (''[[प्रासाद|prāsāda]]'') for spectators.<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रा-काश
<u>'''Prā-kāśa'''</u> is found several times in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_177> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 9, 10;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 5, 22. etc.</ref> denoting an ornament of metal or a metal mirror. According to Geldner,<ref name=fx2_ve2_177> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 120.</ref> [[प्रावेप|Prāvepa]] has the same sense in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx3_ve2_177> iv. 4, 8.</ref> 

प्रा-गहि
<u>'''Prā-gahi'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxvi. 4) according to Lindner's edition. ''Cf.'' '''[[प्रावहि|Prāvahi]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्राचीन-तान
<u>'''Prācīna-tāna'''</u> denotes the ‘warp’ of a piece of cloth in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vi. 1, 1, 4). ''Cf.'' '''[[प्राचीनातान|Prācīnātāna]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्राचीन-योगी-पुत्र
<u>'''Prācīna-yogī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Prācīnayoga,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[सांजीवीपुत्र|Sāṃjīvīputra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 32).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्राचीन-योग्य
<u>'''Prācīna-yogya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Prācīnayoga,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]],''' in the first [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_181> ii. 6, 2 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]]) .</ref> A [[प्राचीनयोग्य|Prācīnayogya]] is mentioned also in the Chāndogya<ref name=fx2_ve2_181> v. 13, 1.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_181> i. 6, 2.</ref> Upaniṣads, and the same patronymic is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_181> (Of '''[[सत्ययज्ञ|Satyayajña]] [[पौलुषि|Pauluṣi]]''') x. 6, 1, 5;<br> (of '''[[शौचेय|Śauceya]]''') xi. 5, 3, 1. 8 (''cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 11). ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 61;<br> 2, 213;<br> 3, 274.</ref> and in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (see '''Puluṣa, [[सत्ययज्ञ|Satyayajña]],'''<ref name=fx5_ve2_181> Called Prācīnayoga in i. 39, 1, but this is probably merely a blunder of the manuscript.</ref> '''Somaśuṣma''').

प्राचीन-वंश
<u>'''Prācīna-vaṃśa'''</u> as an adjective denotes ‘having the supporting beam of the roof facing the east’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_182> iii. 1, 1, 6. 7;<br> 6, 1, 23;<br> iv. 6, 8, 20.</ref> and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_182> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 3. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 3, n. 2.</ref> The reference is to the central beam running from the middle of the western end of a hall to the middle of the eastern end. This beam was possibly higher than those at the side.

प्राचीन-शाल औपमन्यव
<u>'''Prācīna-śāla Aupamanyava'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[उपमन्यु|Upamanyu]]'''’) is the name of a householder and theologian in the Chāndogya  [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_183> v. 11, 1. See '''[[महाशाल|Mahāśāla]].'''</ref> A Prācīnaśāli appears as an Udgātṛ priest in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_183> iii. 7, 2;<br> 10, 2.</ref> and the Prācīnaśālas are mentioned in the same [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_183> iii. 10, 1.</ref>

प्राचीनातान
<u>'''Prācīnātāna,'''</u> denoting the ‘warp’ of a piece of cloth, is found in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_184> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 12, 3;<br> 17, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5 (''cf.'' Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 20, n. 2).</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[प्राचीनतान|Prācīnatāna]].'''

प्राचीनावीत
<u>'''Prācīnāvīta'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_185> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 11, 1.</ref> denotes the wearing of the sacred thread of the Āryan over the right shoulder and under the left arm, Prācīnāvītin<ref name=fx2_ve2_185> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 6, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 2, 2. 9;<br> 6, 1, 8;<br> xii. 5, 1, 6;<br> ''prācīnopavīta'' has the same sense in Av. ix. 1, 24.</ref> being the name for the man so wearing the thread. Tilak,<ref name=fx3_ve2_185> ''Orion,'' 146, citing [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 1.</ref> however, thinks that these terms do not imply the wearing of a thread, but of a garment.

प्राच्य
<u>'''Prācya'''</u> denotes in the plural ‘dwellers in the east.’ They are mentioned in the list of peoples in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_186> viii. 14.</ref> It is very probable that the '''Kāśis, Kosalas, Videhas,''' and perhaps '''Magadhas,''' are meant, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx2_ve2_186> ''Buddha,'' 393, n.</ref> supposes. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_186> i. 7, 3, 8.</ref> the Easterns are said to call Agni by the name of Śarva, and their mode of making tombs is there<ref name=fx4_ve2_186> xiii. 8, 1, 5;<br> 2, 1. ''Cf.'' also ix. 5, 1, 64. These passages render improbable the earlier view of Weber (''Indian Literature,'' 132, 133) that this [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is a product of the Eastern peoples, and support his later view that the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], like the other great Brāhmaṇas, belongs to the [[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]] (see '''Kuru,''' n. 1).</ref> referred to with disapproval. The Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_186> viii. 6, 9.</ref> explains the '''[[विपथ|Vipatha]],''' ‘rough car,’ of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_186> xvii. 1.</ref> as a car of the Easterns (''[[प्राच्य|prācya]]-[[रथ|ratha]]''). In the Saṃhitopaniṣad [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve2_186> 2;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 34, n. 25.</ref> reference is made to the PrācyaPāñcālas. 

प्रजापत्य
<u>'''Prajāpatya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Prajāpati,’ is only a patronymic of mythical persons like [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]] Suparṇeya (‘descendant of Suparṇā’) in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (x. 79), or of '''Prajāvant''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 21).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्राण
<u>'''Prāṇa,'''</u> properly denoting ‘breath,’ is a term of wide and vague significance in Vedic literature. It is frequently mentioned from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_188> i. 66, 1;<br> x. 59, 6;<br> 90, 13, etc.</ref> onwards; in the Āraṇyakas and Upaniṣads it is one of the commonest symbols of the unity of the universe.<ref name=fx2_ve2_188> Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 89 ''et seq.''</ref> In the narrow sense [[प्राण|Prāṇa]] denotes one of the vital airs, of which five are usually<ref name=fx3_ve2_188> See '''[[उदान|Udāna]],''' n. 1.</ref> enumerated--[[प्राण|Prāṇa]], '''[[अपान|Apāna]], [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]], [[उदान|Udāna]],''' and '''[[समान|Samāna]];''' but often only two, [[प्राण|Prāṇa]] and [[अपान|Apāna]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_188> Av. ii. 28, 3;<br> v. 4, 7 (Paipp.);<br> vii. 53, 4 (in vii. 53, 3, [[अपान|Apāna]], [[प्राण|Prāṇa]]);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 1, 4, etc.</ref> or [[प्राण|Prāṇa]] and [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_188> Av. v, 4, 7;<br> vi. 41, 2, etc.</ref> or [[प्राण|Prāṇa]] and [[उदान|Udāna]];<ref name=fx6_ve2_188> See '''[[उदान|Udāna]],''' n. 3.</ref> or three, [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], [[अपान|Apāna]], and [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]],<ref name=fx7_ve2_188> Av. xiii. 2, 46;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 6, 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 23;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 29;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 10;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, etc.</ref> or [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], [[उदान|Udāna]], and [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]],<ref name=fx8_ve2_188> See '''[[उदान|Udāna]],''' n. 2.</ref> or [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], [[उदान|Udāna]], and [[समान|Samāna]];<ref name=fx9_ve2_188> ''Ibid.''</ref> or four, [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], [[अपान|Apāna]], [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]], and [[समान|Samāna]],<ref name=fx10_ve2_188> Av. x. 2, 13.</ref> or [[प्राण|Prāṇa]], [[अपान|Apāna]], [[उदान|Udāna]], [[व्य्आन|Vyāna]].<ref name=fx11_ve2_188> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] iii. 4, 1.</ref> The exact sense of each of these breaths when all are mentioned cannot be determined.<ref name=fx12_ve2_188> ''Cf.'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 273 ''et seq.''</ref>

प्राण
<u>'''Prāṇa'''</u> is also used in a wider sense to denote the organs of sense,<ref name=fx13_ve2_189> Colebrooke, ''Miscellaneous Essays,'' 1, 339, 355;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1.</ref> or as Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx14_ve2_189> On [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 3, 7.</ref> puts it, the ‘orifices of the head,’ etc. These are given as six in one passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx15_ve2_189> xiv. 1. 3, 32;<br> 4, 1.</ref> presumably the eyes, ears, and nostrils. More frequently there are stated to be seven in the head, the mouth being then included.<ref name=fx16_ve2_189> Av. ii. 12, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 17;<br> iii. 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 3, 21;<br> vi. 4, 2, 5;<br> xiii. 1, 7, 2;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 9, 10;<br> 6, 8, etc.</ref> Sometimes again they are mentioned  as nine,<ref name=fx17_ve2_189> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 10, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 7, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 2, 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxii. 12, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 4, 1;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 2;<br> Av. v. 28, 1;<br> x. 8, 43 (''navadvāram''), etc.</ref> or as seven in the head and two below.<ref name=fx18_ve2_189> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 9, 10;<br> 6, 8.</ref> Ten are counted in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx19_ve2_189> xi. 6, 3, 17, where the eleventh is given as the Ātman.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx20_ve2_189> ii. 77 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 240).</ref> while even eleven are mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx21_ve2_189> v. 1.</ref> and twelve in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx22_ve2_189> xxxiii. 3.</ref> where the two breasts are added. Exactly what organs are taken to make up the numbers beyond seven is not certain.<ref name=fx23_ve2_189> ''Cf.'' Deussen, ''op. cit.,'' 269;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaha,'' 185, 187.</ref> The tenth is the navel (''[[नाभि|nābhi]]'') in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā;<ref name=fx24_ve2_189> iv. 6, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 16.</ref> when eleven are named the Brahma-[[रन्ध्र|randhra]]<ref name=fx25_ve2_189> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3.</ref> (suture in the crown) may be included; in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx26_ve2_189> x. 8, 9.</ref> as interpreted by the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx27_ve2_189> ii. 2, 3, 4.</ref> the seventh and eighth are the organs of taste and speech respectively. But usually these make one only, and the eighth and ninth are either in the breast<ref name=fx28_ve2_189> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiii. 3.</ref> or below (the organs of evacuation).<ref name=fx29_ve2_189> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 9, 10;<br> 6, 8.</ref><br><br>The word [[प्राण|Prāṇa]] has sometimes merely the general sense of breath, even when opposed to [[अपान|Apāna]].<ref name=fx30_ve2_189> Av. v. 4, 7 (Paippalāda) . See Blloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 552.</ref> But its proper sense is beyond question ‘breathing forth,’ ‘expiration,’ and not as the St. Petersburg Dictionary explains it, ‘the breath inspired,’ a version due to the desire to interpret [[अपान|Apāna]] as ‘expiration,’ a meaning suggested by the preposition ''apa,'' ‘away.’ This being clearly shown both by the native scholiasts<ref name=fx31_ve2_189> Rudradatta on Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 8, 8;<br> xiv. 11, 1;<br> Sāyaṇa on Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 6, 4;<br> Śaṅkara on Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 2;<br> Ānartīya on [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vi. 8, 1, 2, etc.</ref> and by other evidence,<ref name=fx32_ve2_189> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 2, 15, as compared with Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 8, 29;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 2, 2;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 60, 5;<br> ii. 1, 16. 19;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 1, 4. See Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 261-265;<br> 56, 556-558;<br> and '''[[अपान|Apāna]].'''</ref> Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx33_ve2_189> ''Zeitschrift,'' 55, 518.</ref> later accepted the new view. 

प्राण-भृत्
<u>'''Prāṇa-bhṛt'''</u> denotes a ‘living being’ or ‘man’ in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_190> i. 5, 22;<br> iii. 1, 12.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_190> xi. 2, 6, 2.</ref> Prānin has the same sense.<ref name=fx3_ve2_190> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 13;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4, 2, 2;<br> x. 4, 2, 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 11, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]. iii. 3, 3;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 36.</ref>

प्रातर्
<u>'''Prātar'''</u> as a denotation of time signifies the ‘early morning’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_191> i. 125, 1;<br> ii. 18, 1;<br> iii. 41, 2;<br> 52, 1;<br> iv. 35, 7;<br> v. 76, 3, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_191> Av. iv. 11, 12;<br> vi. 128, 2;<br> vii. 101, 1;<br> xi. 2, 16;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxii. 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 31;<br> iii. 22. 44;<br> iv. 20;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 12;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 7, etc.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Ahan.'''

प्रातर्-अनुवाक
<u>'''Prātar-anuvāka'''</u> occurs in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_192> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 9, 7;<br> ii. 2, 3, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 15. 17. 18;<br> iv. 10;<br> v. 33;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 3, 7;<br> iv. 3, 4, 21;<br> xi. 5, 5, 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 24, 3;<br> iv. 16, 2, etc.</ref> as the name of the litany which begins the morning Soma libation.

प्रातर्-अह्न कौहल
<u>'''Prātar-ahna Kauhala'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[केतु वाज्य|Ketu Vājya]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_193> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 443.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[कौहड|Kauhaḍa]].'''

प्रा-तर्दनि
<u>'''Prā-tardani,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]],'''’ is the name of a prince in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_194> vi. 27, 8. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 157, 159.</ref>

प्राति-पीय
<u>'''Prāti-pīya'''</u> is the patronymic of '''[[बल्हिक|Balhika]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 9, 3, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्राति-वेश्य
<u>'''Prāti-veśya'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (xv. 1) as a pupil of '''[[प्रतिवेश्य|Prativeśya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्राति-सुत्वन
<u>'''Prāti-sutvana.'''</u> See '''Pratīpa.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रति-बोधी-पुत्र
<u>'''Prati-bodhī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Pratī-  [[बोध|bodha]],’ is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] (iii. 1, 5) and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] (vii. 13) Āraṇyakas.<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 244, 310.<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रा-तृद
<u>'''Prā-tṛda,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[प्रतृद्|Pratṛd]],'''’ is the patronymic of a teacher called '''[[भाल्ल|Bhālla]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 31, 4), and of another teacher in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (v. 13, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रा-देश
<u>'''Prā-deśa'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_200> ‘Formed with the ''pradeśa''’ (probably ‘indicator,’ as a name of the forefinger;<br> ''cf. pradeśinī,'' ‘forefinger,’ Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 7;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 10, 1;<br> ii. 9, 14).</ref> frequently occurs in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_200> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 4, 5;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 18, 1, etc.</ref> as a measure of length, a ‘span.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_200> That is, between thumb and forefinger.</ref>

प्रा-ध्वंसन
<u>'''Prā-dhvaṃsana,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[प्रध्वंसन|Pradhvaṃsana]],’ is the patronymic, in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_201> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28. Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> of the mythical '''[[मृत्यु|Mṛtyu]],''' who is there said to be the pupil of [[प्रध्वंसन|Pradhvaṃsana]].

प्रायश्-चित्त
<u>'''Prāyaś-citta'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_202> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 1, 6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 9;<br> vi. 12, etc.</ref> or '''Prāyaś-citti'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_202> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 4, 1;<br> iii. 1, 3, 2;<br> v. 1, 9, 3;<br> 3, 12, 1;<br> Av. xiv. 1, 30;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxix. 12;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 11, 46;<br> v. 27;<br> vii. 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 9;<br> iv. 5, 7, 1;<br> xi. 5, 3, 8, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘penance’ or ‘expiation,’ both words occurring frequently in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas. The penances are prescribed for every conceivable sort of ritual, social or moral; a complete list of them is included in the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_202> See Konow's Translation, p. 43 ''et seq.''</ref>

प्रा-वरेय
<u>'''Prā-vareya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[प्रवर|Pravara]],’ is the patronymic of the '''Gargas''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_203> xiii. 12 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 474).</ref>

प्रा-वहि
<u>'''Prā-vahi'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxvi. 4), where, however, Lindner's edition has '''[[प्रागहि|Prāgahi]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

प्रा-वाहणि
<u>'''Prā-vāhaṇi,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Pravāhaṇa,'''’ is the patronymic of a man called '''Babara''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vii. 1, 10, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रा-वृष्
<u>'''Prā-vṛṣ'''</u> is the name of the ‘rainy season’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_206> vii. 103, 3. 9.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_206> Av. xii. 1, 46;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 4, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 2, 3;<br> vii. 2, 4, 26, etc.</ref>

प्रा-वेप
<u>'''Prā-vepa.'''</u> See '''[[प्राकाश|Prākāśa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्राश्
<u>'''Prāś'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_208> ii. 27, 1, 7.</ref> denotes a ‘debater’ or a ‘debate,’ while [[प्रतिप्राश्|Pratiprāś]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_208> ii. 27, 1. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 7, 479 ''et seq.;<br> Atharvaveda,'' 73;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 305, 306, who completely disproves the theory that [[प्राश्|Prāś]] meant ‘means of life,’ ‘victuals’ (''cf.'' Bo7htlingk, ''s.v. [[प्रतिप्राश्|pratiprāś]]'').</ref> denotes an ‘opponent in debate.’

प्राश्नी-पुत्र
<u>'''Prāśnī-putra'''</u> (‘son of Prāśnī’) '''[[आसुरि-वासिन्|Āsuri-vāsin]]''' is mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_209> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> as a pupil of '''[[आसुरायण|Āsurāyaṇa]].'''

प्रा-श्रवण
<u>'''Prā-śravaṇa.'''</u> See '''[[प्रास्रवण|Prāsravaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रा-सच
<u>'''Prā-saca,'''</u> m., in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_211> vii. 5, 11, 1;<br> according to the commentator, ‘congealing.’</ref> denotes a ‘cloudburst,’ while in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_211> iii. 12, 7, 4;<br> according to the commentator, ‘congealed’ (water).</ref> the adjective ''prāsacyaḥ (āpaḥ)'' means ‘(waters) produced by torrential rain.’

प्रा-साद
<u>'''Prā-sāda'''</u> in the sense of ‘palace’ does not occur until the late Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_212> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[प्राकार|Prākāra]].''' 

प्रा-स्रवण
<u>'''Prā-sravaṇa'''</u> occurs as part of the local name '''[[प्लक्ष प्रास्रवण|Plakṣa Prāsravaṇa]].''' It also appears as a patronymic ‘descendant of [[प्रस्रवण|Prasravaṇa]],’ applied to '''[[अवत्सार|Avatsāra]]''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_213> xiii. 3. There is also a various reading, [[प्राश्रवण|Prāśravaṇa]].</ref>

प्रियङ्गु
<u>'''Priyaṅgu'''</u> denotes ‘panic seed’ (''Panicum italicum'') in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_214> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 11, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 11;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 12.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_214> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 14, 6 [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 16;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]), with Śaṅkara's note.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 241.</ref>

प्रिय-मेध
<u>'''Priya-medha'''</u> is the name of a seer in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_215> i. 139, 9;<br> viii. 5, 25;<br> ''Priyamedhavat,'' i. 45, 3;<br> ''[[प्रियमेध|Priyamedha]]-stuta,'' viii. 6, 45.</ref> where his family, the Priyamedhas, are also repeatedly alluded to.<ref name=fx2_ve2_215> i. 45, 4;<br> viii. 2, 37;<br> 3, 16;<br> 4, 20;<br> 8, 18;<br> 69, 8;<br> 87, 3;<br> x. 73, 11.</ref> It is not probable that any hymns are really Priyamedha's own composition.<ref name=fx3_ve2_215> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 217.</ref> See also '''[[प्रैयमेध|Praiyamedha]].'''

प्रिय-रथ
<u>'''Priya-ratha'''</u> is the name of a patron of the '''Pajras''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_216> i. 122, 7. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 150.</ref>

प्रिय-व्रत सोमापि
<u>'''Priya-[[व्रत|vrata]] Somāpi'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_217> vii. 34.</ref> or '''[[सौमापि|Saumāpi]]''' is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_217/> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve2_217> xv. 1.</ref> in which he is said to be the son of '''Somapa.''' The name Priyavrata is also found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_217> x. 3, 5, 14.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 8, 136, n.</ref> where a '''[[रौहिणायन|Rauhiṇāyana]]''' of that name is mentioned as a teacher.

प्रेङ्ख
<u>'''Preṅkha,'''</u> ‘swing,’ is mentioned in the description of the Mahāvrata rite, given in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve2_218> xxxiv. 5.</ref> the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]  Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve2_218> i. 2, 3. 4;<br> v. 1, 3, etc.</ref> the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_218> v. 5, 7.</ref> and elsewhere.<ref name=fx4_ve2_218> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, ii. 17, etc.</ref> As far as can be judged from the notices available,<ref name=fx5_ve2_218> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 1 11;<br> 7, 2, etc.</ref> the swing was made just like a modern swing. See also '''[[प्लेङ्ख|Pleṅkha]].'''

प्रेत
<u>'''Preta,'''</u> ‘departed,’ is used to denote a ‘dead man’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_219> x. 5, 2, 13;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 1, etc.</ref> but not in the sense of ‘ghost,’ which only appears later, in post-Vedic literature.

प्रेदि
<u>'''Predi.'''</u> See '''Proti.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रेष्य
<u>'''Preṣya'''</u> (‘to be sent’ on an errand) denotes a menial servant or slave, being applied in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_221> vii. 29. See also [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1.</ref> to the '''[[शूद्र|Śūdra]].''' In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_221> v. 22, 14.</ref> the adjective ''praiṣya,'' ‘menial,’ occurs.

प्रैय-मेध
<u>'''Praiya-medha,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[प्रियमेध|Priyamedha]],'''’ is a patronymic of the priests who sacrificed for the '''[[आत्रेय|Ātreya]] Udamaya''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_222> viii. 22.</ref> They appear in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve2_222> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 474);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 8, 7;<br> Lévi, ''La doctrine du sacrifice,'' 150.</ref> as priests who ‘knew all’ (sacrificial lore).
