Three Praiyamedhas are referred to in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_222> ii. 1, 9, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> In the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_222> i. 3, 15. The name is also written Prayyamedha and, incorrectly, Praiyyamedha.</ref> they are called '''Bharadvājas.'''

प्रैष
<u>'''Praiṣa'''</u> is a liturgical term meaning ‘direction’ or ‘invitation,’ repeatedly found in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_223> Av. v. 26, 4;<br> xi. 7, 18;<br> xvi. 7, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 11, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 19, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_223> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 13;<br> iii. 9;<br> v. 9, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 3, 15;<br> xiii. 5, 2, 23;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxviii. 1, etc.</ref> 

प्रोति कौशाम्बेय कौसुरु-बिन्दि
<u>'''Proti [[कौशाम्बेय|Kauśāmbeya]] Kausuru-bindi'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Kusurubinda'''’) is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_224> xii. 2, 2, 13. In the parallel passage, Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 24, [[प्रेदि|Predi]] [[कौशाम्बेय|Kauśāmbeya]] Kausuravinda is the form of the name.</ref> as a pupil and contemporary of '''Uddālaka.''' In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_224> vii. 2, 2, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' p. 115.</ref> on the other hand, Kusurubinda is called '''[[औद्दालकि|Auddālaki]],''' ‘descendant of Uddālaka,’ a fact which seems to indicate that little value is to be attached to these patronymics and allegations of contemporaneousness.

प्रोष्ठ
<u>'''Proṣṭha,'''</u> denoting perhaps a ‘bench,’ is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_225> vii. 55, 8.</ref> in the adjective ''proṣṭhaśaya,'' ‘lying on a bench,’ used of women, and uncompounded in the Taittīriya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_225> ii. 7, 17, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 154.</ref> In the first passage it is distinguished from '''[[तल्प|Talpa]]''' and '''[[वह्य|Vahya]],''' but what the exact difference was there is not sufficient evidence to show.

प्रोष्ठ-पद
<u>'''Proṣṭha-pada,'''</u> m., '''-padā,''' f. (‘foot of a bench’), is the name of a double '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रोष्ठ-पाद वारक्य
<u>'''Proṣṭha-[[पाद|pāda]] Vārakya'''</u> is mentioned in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1) as a pupil of [[कंस|Kaṃsa]] [[वारकि|Vāraki]].<br>==Foot Notes==

प्लक्ष
<u>'''1. Plakṣa'''</u> is the name of the waved leaf fig-tree (''Ficus infectoria''), a large and beautiful tree with small white fruit. It is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_228> v. 5, 5.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_228> vii. 4, 12, 1. ''Cf.'' iii. 4, 8, 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 10, 2.</ref> along with the '''[[न्यग्रोध|Nyagrodha]]''' and the '''[[पर्ण|Parṇa]].''' Its name is altered in the latter Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_228> vi. 3, 10, 2.</ref> to '''[[प्रक्ष|Prakṣa]]''' for the sake of an etymology. It is also mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx4_ve2_228> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 32;<br> viii. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 19, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 3, 10, 12, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 58.</ref> 

प्लक्ष दय्यांपाति
<u>'''2. Plakṣa Dayyāṃpāti'''</u> (‘descendant of Dyāṃpati’ or Dyāṃpāta) was a contemporary of '''[[अत्य्अंहस् आरुणि|Atyaṃhas Āruṇi]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 10, 9, 3. 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्लक्ष प्रा-स्रवण
<u>'''3. Plakṣa Prā-sravaṇa'''</u> is the name of a locality, forty-four days’ journey from the spot where the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' disappears. It is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_230> xxv. 10, 16. 22;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 6, 7;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 17, 12. 14.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_230> iv. 26, 12.</ref> In the latter text it is said that the middle of the earth is only a span ('''[[प्रादेश|Prādeśa]]''') to the north of it. In the Rigveda Sūtras<ref name=fx3_ve2_230> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 6, 1;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 29, 24.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 31, n. 2.</ref> the locality is called Plākṣa [[प्रस्रवण|Prasravaṇa]], and is apparently meant to designate the source of the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] rather than the place of its reappearance.

प्लति
<u>'''Plati'''</u> is the name of a man, the father of the seer of two hymns of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_231> x. 63, 17;<br> 64, 17. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133.</ref>

प्लव
<u>'''1. Plava'''</u> (‘float’) denotes a ‘boat’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_232> i. 182, 5.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_232> Av. xii. 2, 48;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 3, 10, 2;<br> vii. 3, 5, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 10, 17, etc.</ref>

प्लव
<u>'''2. Plava'''</u> is the name of an aquatic bird mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_233> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 20, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 15;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 34.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> Perhaps the ‘pelican’ is meant.

प्लाक्षि
<u>'''Plākṣi,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[प्लक्ष|Plakṣa]],'''’ is the name of a man mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve2_234> i. 7, 2.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]  Prātiśākhya.<ref name=fx2_ve2_234> i. 5. 9;<br> ii. 2. 6.</ref> In the same Prātiśākhya<ref name=fx3_ve2_234> i. 9;<br> ii. 2. 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref> a Plākṣāyaṇa, or ‘descendant of Plākṣa,’ is mentioned.

प्लात
<u>'''Plāta,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[प्लति|Plati]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Gaya''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

प्ला-योगि
<u>'''Plā-yogi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Playoga,’ is the patronymic of '''Āsaṅga''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_236> viii. 1, 33.</ref> According to the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_236> xvi. 11, 17.</ref> Āsaṅga was a woman, but became a man. This version, repeated by Sāyaṇa in his commentary on the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_236> viii. 1, 34. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Religions of India,'' 150.</ref> is a mere blunder based on the fact that an additional verse, tacked on to the hymn,<ref name=fx3_ve2_236/> contains the expression ''[[शश्वती|śaśvatī]] [[नारी|nārī]],'' which has been taken to mean ‘his wife [[शश्वती|Śaśvatī]],’<ref name=fx4_ve2_236> So even Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 107. But see Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 354.</ref> instead of merely ‘every woman.’

प्लाशुक
<u>'''Plāśuka'''</u> is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v, 3, 3, 2) as an epithet of '''[[व्रीहि|Vrīhi]],''' ‘rice,’ in the sense of ‘shooting up rapidly.’<br>==Foot Notes==

प्लीहा-कर्ण
<u>'''Plīhā-karṇa'''</u> as an epithet of cattle in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_238> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 13, 5 (''cf.'' iv. 2, 9);<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 24.</ref> probably denotes ‘having a spleen-shaped mark branded on the ear,’ not as Mahīdhara in his commentary on the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_238> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> takes it, ‘having a disease called Plīhan in the ear.’

प्लुष्
<u>'''Pluṣ'''</u> is the name of some noxious insect in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_239> i. 191, 1.</ref> It is also included in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]  (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx2_ve2_239> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 20.</ref> and is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_239> i. 3, 24.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref> Possibly a species of ant may be meant.

प्लेङ्ख
<u>'''Pleṅkha'''</u> is a variant form of '''[[प्रेङ्ख|Preṅkha]],''' ‘swing,’ found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vii. 5, 8, 5) and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 2, 6, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

फण
<u>'''Phaṇa'''</u> occurs in some manuscripts of the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_241> i. 4. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 398;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 19, n. 1.</ref> and is explained as meaning an ‘ornament.’ But it is merely a misreading of the correct word ''[[फल|phala]]'' in the compound ''phalahastāḥ,'' ‘bearing fruits in their hands.’

फर्वर
<u>'''Pharvara,'''</u> a word occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_242> x. 106, 2.</ref> cannot be interpreted with certainty. It may mean a ‘field in bloom.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_242> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 260.</ref> Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx3_ve2_242> In his commentary on Rv. x. 106, 2. He explains the intensive form ''parpharat,'' occurring in the same hymn (x. 106, 7), as from a verb meaning to ‘fill.’</ref> explains it as ‘filler,’ and Grassmann as perhaps a ‘sower.’<ref name=fx4_ve2_242> ''Wo7rterbuch, s.v.''</ref>

फल
<u>'''Phala,'''</u> denoting ‘fruit’ generally, especially the fruit of a tree, occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_243> iii. 45, 4;<br> x. 146, 5.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_243> Av. vi. 124, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 14, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 13;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 4, 8;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 1, etc., and see '''[[फण|Phaṇa]].'''</ref>

फलक
<u>'''Phalaka'''</u> denotes ‘plank,’ as applied in the construction of a cart or chariot, or as used for pressing Soma (''adhi-ṣavaṇe phalake''),<ref name=fx2_ve2_244> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] vii. 30.</ref> or for any other purpose.<ref name=fx3_ve2_244> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 9;<br> xiii. 4, 3, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 2, 3 (of the swing), etc.</ref><br><br>^1Pañcaviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1, 14 (''cf. Indische Studien,'' 1, 33, 44). 

फलवती
<u>'''Phalavatī,'''</u> ‘fruitful,’ is the name of a plant in the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_245> v. 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Omina und Portenta,'' 315.</ref> identified by the scholiast with the '''[[प्रियङ्गु|Priyaṅgu]].'''

फल्गु
<u>'''Phalgu.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

फल्गुनी
<u>'''Phalgunī.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

फाण्ट
<u>'''Phāṇṭa'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_248> iii. 1, 3, 8. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 14, n. 1.</ref> is said to denote the first particles of butter produced by churning, ‘creamy butter.’

फाल
<u>'''Phāla,'''</u> ‘ploughshare,’ occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_249> iv. 57, 8;<br> x. 117, 7.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_249> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xix. 1. ''Cf. suphāla,'' Av. iii. 17, 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 12;<br> ''[[फाल|phāla]]-kṛṣṭa,'' ‘growing on ploughed land,’ as opposed to ''āraṇya,'' ‘wild,’ [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 7;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 15.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[लाङ्गल|Lāṅgala]].'''

बक दाल्भ्य
<u>'''Baka Dālbhya'''</u> (‘descendant of Dalbha’) is the name of a person mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] as constraining Indra for the '''Ājakeśins''' (i. 9, 2), and as a '''KuruPañcāla''' (iv. 7, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

बकुर
<u>'''Bakura'''</u> is mentioned in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_251> i. 117, 21.</ref> where it is said that the Aśvins made light for the Āryan by blowing their [[बकुर|Bakura]] against the '''Dasyus.''' According to the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_251> vi. 25. ''Cf.'' Naighaṇṭuka, iv. 3.</ref> the thunderbolt<ref name=fx1_ve2_251/> is meant; but much more probable is Roth's<ref name=fx3_ve2_251> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 290;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 466.</ref> view, that the object blown was a musical instrument. See also '''[[बाकुर|Bākura]].''' 

बज
<u>'''Baja'''</u> is the name in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_252> viii. 6, 3. 6. 7. 24.</ref> of a plant used against a demon of disease. Some sort of mustard plant may be meant.<ref name=fx2_ve2_252> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 494.</ref>

बदर
<u>'''Badara'''</u> denoting, like '''[[कर्कन्धु|Karkandhu]]''' and '''[[कुवल|Kuvala]],''' a kind of jujube, is mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_253> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 22, 90;<br> xxi. 30.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_253> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 5, 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 10;<br> xii. 7, 1, 3;<br> 2, 9;<br> 9, 1, 8, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 156, 5.</ref>

बद्वन्
<u>'''Badvan'''</u> seems in one passage of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_254> i. 1, 4. ''Cf.'' Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 23.</ref> to denote a ‘causeway.’ It is said to be firmer than an ordinary road.

बन्धन
<u>'''Bandhana'''</u> denotes a ‘rope’ or other fastening in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_255> Av. iii. 6, 7 (of a boat, '''Nau''');<br> vi. 14, 2.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_255> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 6, 2 (of a horse);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 9, 4;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 8, 2;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xii. 38, etc.</ref>

बन्धु
<u>'''Bandhu,'''</u> denoting ‘relationship’<ref name=fx1_ve2_256> Rv. v. 73, 4;<br> vii. 72, 2;<br> viii. 73, 12, etc.;<br> Av. v. 11, 10, 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 22;<br> x. 6, etc.</ref> in the abstract and ‘relation’<ref name=fx2_ve2_256> Rv. i. 164, 33;<br> vii. 67, 9;<br> Av. x. 10, 23;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 5, 5, etc.;<br> ''bandhumant,'' ‘having relations,’ Rv. viii. 21, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 1, 4, etc.</ref> in the concrete, occurs in the Rigveda and later.

बबर प्रा-वाहणि
<u>'''Babara Prā-vāhaṇi'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Pravāhaṇa'''’) is the name of a man who, according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve2_257> vii. 1, 10, 2. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 148.</ref> wished to become an orator, and obtained rhetorical power by the use of the Pañcarātra sacrifice. 

बभ्रु
<u>'''1. Babhru'''</u> is the name, in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_258> v. 30, 11. 14.</ref> of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] who received gifts from King '''[[ऋणंचय|Ṛṇaṃcaya]].''' The same [[बभ्रु|Babhru]] may be meant in another passage,<ref name=fx2_ve2_258> viii. 22, 10.</ref> where he is mentioned as a protégé of the Aśvins; but it is doubtful whether the word is a proper name at all in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_258> iv. 29, 2. It is here taken as a proper name by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 126. But Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 199, denies that a proper name is meant.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 214.</ref>

बभ्रु कौम्भ्य
<u>'''2. Babhru Kaumbhya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kumbha’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman or Chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xv. 3, 13).<br>==Foot Notes==

बभ्रु दैवा-वृध
<u>'''3. Babhru Daivā-vṛdha'''</u> is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 34) as a pupil of '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]''' and '''[[नारद|Nārada]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

बम्ब आज-द्विष
<u>'''Bamba Āja-dviṣa'''</u> (‘descendant of Aja-dviṣ’) is mentioned as a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 7, 2). [[बिम्ब|Bimba]] is a various reading.<br>==Foot Notes==

बम्बा-विश्ववयसौ
<u>'''Bambā-Viśvavayasau'''</u> are the names, in the form of a compound, of two [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] who, according to the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve2_262> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6, 8, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā xxix. 7, where the reading adopted in the text is Bambhā, though the reading of the Berlin manuscript is Bambhār. The name is taken to be Bambā by the St. Petersburg Dictionary;<br> but Bamba is possible, the Dvandva compound accounting for the form with ''ā.'' The Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 3, has Bamba-.</ref> invented a certain rite.

बरासी
<u>'''Barāsī'''</u> is found in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_263> xv. 4.</ref> and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmana<ref name=fx2_ve2_263> xviii. 9, 16 (where the commentator explains it as made of bark);<br> xxi. 3, 4.</ref> denoting a garment of some kind.

बरु
<u>'''Baru'''</u> is the name of the author of a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_264> x. 96.</ref> according to the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_264> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 25;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 8.</ref> of that Veda. 

बर्कु वार्ष्ण
<u>'''Barku Vārṣṇa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[वृषन्|Vṛṣan]]'''’) is the name of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_265> i. 1, 1, 10;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 8 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 1, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

बर्हिस्
<u>'''Barhis'''</u> is found repeatedly in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_266> i. 63, 7;<br> 108, 4;<br> iii. 4, 4, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_266> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 4, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 1;<br> xviii. 1, etc.</ref> denoting the litter of grass strewn on the sacrificial ground on which the gods are summoned to seat themselves.

बलाका
<u>'''Balākā,'''</u> ‘crane,’ is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_267> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 16, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 3, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 22, 23. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 92.</ref>

बलाय
<u>'''Balāya'''</u> is the name of an unknown animal mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_268> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 38;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 19.</ref>

बलास
<u>'''Balāsa'''</u> is the name of a disease mentioned several times in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_269> iv. 9, 8;<br> v. 22, 11;<br> vi. 14;<br> 1;<br> 127, 1;<br> ix. 8, 8;<br> xix. 34, 10.</ref> and occasionally later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_269> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 97.</ref> Mahīdhara<ref name=fx3_ve2_269> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> and Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx4_ve2_269> On Av. xix. 34, 10.</ref> interpret the term as ‘consumption.’ Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_269> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 385-387.</ref> supports this view on the ground that it is mentioned<ref name=fx6_ve2_269> Av. ix. 8, 10.</ref> as a kind of '''[[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]],''' makes the bones and joints fall apart (''asthi-sraṃsa, paruḥ-sraṃsa''),<ref name=fx7_ve2_269> Av. vi. 14, 1.</ref> and is caused by love, aversion, and the heart,<ref name=fx8_ve2_269> ix. 8, 8.</ref> characteristics which agree with the statements of the later Hindu medicine.<ref name=fx9_ve2_269> Wise, ''Hindu System of Medicine,'' 321, 322.</ref> It is in keeping with a demon of the character of consumption that [[बलास|Balāsa]] should appear as an accompaniment of [[तक्मन्|Takman]].<ref name=fx10_ve2_269> Av. iv. 9, 8;<br> xix. 34, 10.</ref> Grohmann,<ref name=fx11_ve2_269> ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 396 ''et seq.''</ref> however, thought  that a ‘sore’ or ‘swelling’ (in the case of fever caused by dropsy) was meant. Bloomfield<ref name=fx12_ve2_269> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 450.</ref> considers that the question is still open. Ludwig<ref name=fx13_ve2_269> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 510.</ref> renders the word by ‘dropsy.’<br><br>As remedies against the disease the salve ('''Āñjasa''') from '''[[त्रिककुद्|Trikakud]]'''<ref name=fx14_ve2_269> Av. iv. 9, 8.</ref> and the '''[[जङ्गिड|Jaṅgiḍa]]'''<ref name=fx15_ve2_269> Av. xix. 34, 10.</ref> plant are mentioned.

बलि
<u>'''Bali'''</u> occurs several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_270> To a god, Rv. i. 70, 9;<br> v. 1, 10;<br> viii. 100, 9;<br> to a king, in the compound ''bali-hṛt,'' ‘paying tribute,’ vii. 6, 5;<br> x. 173, 6.</ref> and often later<ref name=fx2_ve2_270> Metaphorically: Av. vi. 117, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 3, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 3, etc.;<br> ''bali-hṛt,'' Av. xi. 4, 19;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.;<br> bali-hāra,'' Av. xi. 1, 20;<br> literally: Av. iii. 4, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 18, 3;<br> iii. 12, 2, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 2, 15;<br> 5, 3, 18;<br> 6, 3, 17;<br> xi 2, 6, 14;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 7, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 29 (''cf.'' vii. 34);<br> ''bali-hṛt,'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 2, 1.</ref> in the sense of tribute to a king or offering to a god. Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_270> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 166, 167.</ref> thinks that the offerings were in both cases voluntary. He compares the notices of the Germans in Tacitus,<ref name=fx4_ve2_270> ''Germania,'' 15.</ref> where the kings of the tribes are said to receive gifts in kind as presents, but not a regular tribute. There seems to be no ground whatever for this view. No doubt in origin the prerogatives of monarchy were due to voluntary action on the part of the tribesmen,<ref name=fx5_ve2_270> Later, too, benevolences (''praṇayākriyā'') were known. See Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 760762.</ref> but that the Vedic peoples, who were essentially a body of conquering invaders, were in this state is most improbable, and the attitude of the Vedic Indian to his gods was at least as compatible with tribute as with voluntary gifts. Zimmer admits that in the case of hostile tribes<ref name=fx6_ve2_270> See Rv. vii. 6, 5;<br> 18, 19.</ref> tribute must be meant even in the Rigveda. See also '''[[राजन्|Rājan]].'''

बल्कस
<u>'''Balkasa'''</u> denotes impure matter given off in the process of fermentation in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_271> xii. 8, 1, 16;<br> 9, 1, 2.</ref> The exact sense  may be either ‘scum,’ ‘sediment,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_271> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v., Flocken'' (‘flakes’).</ref> or perhaps more probably vegetable matter in the form of ‘husks.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_271> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 236, n. 1.</ref>

बल्बज
<u>'''Balbaja'''</u> is the name of the grass called ''Eleusine indica.'' It is mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_272> xiv. 2, 22. 23.</ref> and is said in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve2_272> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 8, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 5.</ref> to be produced from the excrements of cattle. In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_272/> it is stated to be used for the sacrificial litter ('''[[बर्हिस्|Barhis]]''') and for fuel. Baskets or other products made from this grass are referred to in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_272> viii. 55. 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 69, 70.</ref>

बल्हिक
<u>'''1. Balhika'''</u> is the name of a people in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_273> v. 22, 5. 7. 9.</ref> where the fever ('''[[तक्मन्|Takman]]''') is called upon to go to the '''Mūjavants,''' the '''Mahāvṛṣas,''' and the Balhikas. The Mūjavants are quite certainly a northern tribe, and though, as Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve2_273> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 446.</ref> suggests, the passage may contain a pun on [[बल्हिक|Balhika]] as suggesting ‘outsider’ (from ''bahis,'' ‘without’), still no doubt the name was chosen from a northern tribe. But the view of Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_273> ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 41.</ref> and Weber,<ref name=fx4_ve2_273> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 205;<br> ''Proceedings of the Berlin Academy,'' 1892, 985-995.</ref> which Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_273> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 130.</ref> once accepted, that an Iranian tribe is referred to (''cf.'' Balkh), is not at all probable. Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve2_273> ''Op. cit.,'' 431-433.<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 260;<br> Hopkins, ''Great Epic of India,'' 373.</ref> shows that there is no need whatever to assume Iranian influence. See also '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]].'''

बल्हिक प्रातिपीय
<u>'''2. Balhika Prātipīya'''</u> is the name of a '''Kuru''' king in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_274> xii. 9, 3, 3.</ref> where he appears as having been opposed to the restoration of '''[[दुष्टरीतु|Duṣṭarītu]] [[पौंसायन|Pauṃsāyana]]''' to his hereditary sovereignty over the '''Sṛñjayas,''' but as having failed to prevent  the restoration being carried out by '''[[रेवोत्तरस्|Revottaras]] [[पाटव|Pāṭava]] [[चाक्र|Cākra]] [[स्थपति|Sthapati]].''' The epithet [[प्रातिपीय|Prātipīya]] is curious: if it connects him with '''Pratīpa''' (whose son he is in the Epic), the form is remarkable, Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_274> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 432.</ref> indeed tacitly altering it to Prātīpīya. In the Epic and the Purāṇas<ref name=fx3_ve2_274> See Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 273 ''et seq.;<br>'' Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 131-136.</ref> he is in the form of Vāhlīka made a brother of '''Devāpi''' and '''Śantanu,''' and a son of Pratīpa. To base chronological conclusions on this<ref name=fx4_ve2_274> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 52.</ref> would be utterly misleading, for the facts are that Devāpi was son of [[ऋष्टिषेण|Ṛṣṭiṣeṇa]] and a priest, while Śantanu was a Kuru prince of unknown parentage, but not probably a son of Pratīpa, who seems to be a late figure in the Vedic age, later than '''[[परिक्षित्|Parikṣit]],''' being his great-grandson in the Epic. Very possibly [[बल्हिक|Balhika]] was a descendant of Pratīpa. Why he bore the name [[बल्हिक|Balhika]] must remain uncertain, for there is no evidence of any sort regarding it.

बल्बूथ
<u>'''Balbūtha'''</u> is mentioned in one hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_275> viii. 46, 32.</ref> along with '''[[तरुक्ष|Tarukṣa]]''' and '''[[पृथुश्रवस्|Pṛthuśravas]],''' as a giver of gifts to the singer. He is called a '''[[दास|Dāsa]],''' but Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_275> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[दास|dāsa]].''</ref> was inclined to amend the text so as to say that the singer received a hundred Dāsas from [[बल्बूथ|Balbūtha]]. Zimmer's<ref name=fx3_ve2_275> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 117.</ref> suggestion that he may have been the son of an aboriginal mother, or perhaps an aboriginal himself, seems probable.<ref name=fx4_ve2_275> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 30;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 196.</ref> If this was the case, it would be a clear piece of evidence for the establishment of friendly relations between the Āryans and the Dāsas.

बस्त
<u>'''1. Basta'''</u> denotes the ‘goat’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_276> i. 161, 13. The passage is unintelligible;<br> for a guess, see Tilak, ''Orion,'' 166 ''et seq.,'' and ''cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 145, n. 2.</ref> and the later literature.<ref name=fx2_ve2_276> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 7, 4;<br> v. 3, 1, 5;<br> 7, 10, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 7, 7;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, 9 (Mādhyaṃdina = i. 4, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]), etc., and ''cf.'' Av. viii. 6, 12;<br> xi. 9, 22.</ref> 

बस्त रामकायन
<u>'''2. Basta Rāmakāyana'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iv. 2, 10). The patronymic is variously read Samakāyana.<br>==Foot Notes==

बहु-वचन
<u>'''Bahu-vacana'''</u> denotes in grammatical terminology the ‘plural’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_278> xiii. 5, 1, 18.</ref> and the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_278> v. 23;<br> xi. 16;<br> xii. 7 (which recognises the plural ''majestatis'').</ref> So ''dvivat, bahuvat,'' in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_278> ii. 24. 27;<br> xi. 16.</ref> means ‘in the dual and the plural.’

बह्व्-ऋच
<u>'''Bahv-ṛca'''</u> denotes an adherent of the Rigveda. The term is found in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_279> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 36;<br> v. 2;<br> vi. 18;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 11;<br> xvi. 9.</ref> of the Rigveda, in the Śatapatha<ref name=fx2_ve2_279> x. 5, 2, 20;<br> xi. 5, 1, 10.</ref> and the Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx3_ve2_279> v. 6, 6.</ref> and in the Āraṇyakas of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx4_ve2_279> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 4.</ref>

बाकुर
<u>'''Bākura'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda (ix. 1, 8) is used as an epithet of '''[[दृति|Dṛti]],''' the combined words denoting a wind instrument of some kind. ''Cf.'' '''[[बकुर|Bakura]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

बाडेयी-पुत्र
<u>'''Bāḍeyī-putra'''</u> (‘son of Bāḍeyī’) is mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30) as a pupil of '''[[मौषिकीपुत्र|Mauṣikīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

बाण
<u>'''Bāṇa'''</u> denotes ‘arrow’ in the Rigveda (vi. 75, 17) and later (Av. iii. 23, 2; vi. 105, 2, etc.).<br>==Foot Notes==

बाणवन्त्
<u>'''Bāṇavant'''</u> in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 8, 2) denotes an ‘arrow’ like '''[[बाण|Bāṇa]].''' Its more normal sense is ‘quiver’ (lit., ‘containing arrows’), which is its sense in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xvi. 10) and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 3, 1, 11). <br>==Foot Notes==

बादरायण
<u>'''Bādarāyaṇa'''</u> (‘descendant of Badara’) is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_284> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 377. Bādari is found in the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 3, 18;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 34, n.</ref>

बाध्योग
<u>'''Bādhyoga'''</u> (‘descendant of Badhyoga’) is the patronymic of '''Jihvāvant,''' a pupil of '''[[असित|Asita]] [[वार्षगण|Vārṣagaṇa]],''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 33).<br>==Foot Notes==

बाध्व
<u>'''Bādhva'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka (iii. 2, 3). The reading in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (viii. 3) is '''[[वात्स्य|Vātsya]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_286> See Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 249, n. 1.</ref>

बाभ्रव
<u>'''Bābhrava,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[बभ्रु|Babhru]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Vatsanapāt''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_287> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> In the legend of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_287> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17. The [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] version omits the words.</ref> the '''Kāpileyas''' and the Bābhravas are enumerated as the descendants of [[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]] under his adoptive name of '''[[देवरात|Devarāta]] [[वैश्वामित्र|Vaiśvāmitra]].''' A Sāman, or Chant, of [[बभ्रु|Babhru]] is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_287> xv. 3, 12.</ref>

बाभ्रव्य
<u>'''Bābhravya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[बभ्रु|Babhru]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Girija''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 1), and of '''[[शङ्ख|Śaṅkha]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1; iv. 17, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

बार्हत्-सामा
<u>'''Bārhat-sāmā'''</u> is an anomalously formed word meaning ‘daughter of Bṛhatsāman’ in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_289> v. 25, 9. ''Cf'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 267.</ref> where her name occurs in a hymn for easy conception. 

बार्हस्-पत्य
<u>'''Bārhas-patya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]],’ is the patronymic of the mythical '''[[शंयु|Śaṃyu]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_290> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 10, 1;<br> v. 2, 6, 4;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9, 1, 24;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 21, etc.</ref>

बाल
<u>'''Bāla'''</u> denotes ‘boy,’ ‘young child,’ in the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx1_ve2_291> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 1, 11;<br> 24, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 6.</ref> The later definition<ref name=fx2_ve2_291> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> makes childhood extend to the sixteenth year.

बालन्दन
<u>'''Bālandana'''</u> is a variant of '''[[भालन्दन|Bhālandana]],''' the patronymic of '''Vatsaprī.'''<br><br>^1 See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 459, 478.<br>==Foot Notes==

बालाकि
<u>'''Bālāki, Bālākyā.'''</u> See '''Dṛpta-[[बालाकि|bālāki]]''' and '''Kāśyapī-bālākyāmāṭharī-[[पुत्र|putra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

बालेय
<u>'''Bāleya'''</u> is a patronymic (‘descendant of Bali’) of '''Gandharvāyaṇa''' in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xx. 25).<br>==Foot Notes==

बाष्कल
<u>'''Bāṣkala.'''</u> See '''[[वार्कलि|Vārkali]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

बाष्किह
<u>'''Bāṣkiha,'''</u> ‘descendant of Baṣkiha,’ is the patronymic of '''[[शुनस्कर्ण|Śunaskarṇa]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_296> xvii. 12, 6.</ref> In the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_296> xxi. 17. See Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 28.</ref> he is a descendant of '''[[शिबि|Śibi]].'''

बाहीक
<u>'''Bāhīka'''</u> is applied in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_297> i. 7, 3, 8.</ref> to the people of the west, of the Panjab,<ref name=fx2_ve2_297> ''Cf.'' Mahābhārata, viii. 2030 ''et seq.,'' where the Bāhīkas are defined as the people of the Panjab and the Indus. This coincides exactly with what seems to be meant by the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], which regards as the middle the land to the east of the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 189;<br> 2, 37;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 201, n 2.</ref> as opposed to the '''Prācyas''' or easterns. They are said to have called Agni by the name of Bhava. 

बाहु
<u>'''Bāhu,'''</u> ‘arm,’ as a measure of length, is found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vi. 2, 11, 1) and often in the Sūtras.<br>==Foot Notes==

बाहु-वृक्त
<u>'''Bāhu-vṛkta'''</u> is the name of a man, apparently a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], who overcame foes in battle, according to the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_299> v. 44, 12. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138, 139. The Anukramaṇī (Index) attributes to him two hymns of the Rigveda, v. 71 and 72.</ref>

बिदल-कारी
<u>'''Bidala-kārī,'''</u> ‘female splitter of bamboos,’ is the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_300> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 8;<br> ''bidalakāra,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 5, 1.</ref> Eggeling<ref name=fx2_ve2_300> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 414.</ref> renders the word as ‘basket-maker.’

बिम्ब
<u>'''Bimba'''</u> appears in one passage of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 5, 6) to denote the plant ''Momordica monadelpha.''<br>==Foot Notes==

बिल्व
<u>'''Bilva'''</u> is the name of the wood-apple tree (''Aigle marmelos''). It is mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_302> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 4, 8, etc. ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 9, 3.</ref> and in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_302> xx. 136, 13.</ref> where a reference to its valuable fruit may be intended. According to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve2_302> ii. 1, 8, 1. 2. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 3, 20 (''paridhayaḥ'');<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> the sacrificial post was made of [[बिल्व|Bilva]] wood in some cases. The [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx4_ve2_302> xii. 20 ''et seq.''</ref> contains a hymn in praise of the virtues of an amulet of [[बिल्व|Bilva]] (''irā-[[मणि|maṇi]] bailva'').<ref name=fx5_ve2_302> At the present day the tree is called Bel, and its leaves are used in the ritual of Siva worship.</ref>

बिस
<u>'''Bisa'''</u> denotes the radical fibres of the lotus, which seem to have been eaten as a delicacy as early as the times of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_303> iv. 34, 5.</ref> It is mentioned also in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_303> v. 30.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx3_ve2_303> iii. 2, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xi. 4. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70.</ref> 

बीज
<u>'''Bīja'''</u> denotes ‘seed,’ the operation of sowing seed (''vap'') being several times referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_304> x. 94, 13;<br> 101, 3. ''Cf.'' metaphorically, x. 85, 37. In v. 53, 13, ''[[धान्य|dhānya]] [[बीज|bīja]]'' means the ‘seed which produces corn.’</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_304> Av. x. 6, 33;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 2, 2, 4, etc.</ref> In a metaphorical sense the term is used in the Upaniṣads of the classes of beings according to origin, of which the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_304> vi. 3, 1.</ref> enumerates three, the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_304> iii. 3. See Keith. ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 235.</ref> four. The former list includes ''aṇḍa-ja,'' ‘egg-born,’ ''[[जीव-ज|jīva-ja]],'' ‘born alive,’ and ''udbhij-ja,'' ‘produced from sprouts,’ ‘germinating,’ while the latter adds ''[[स्वेद-ज|sveda-ja]],'' ‘sweat-born’--that is, ‘generated by hot moisture,’ an expression which is glossed to comprise flies, worms, etc. ''Cf.'' '''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]].'''

बुडिल आश्वतराश्वि
<u>'''Buḍila Āśvatarāśvi'''</u> or '''Āśvatara Āśvi''' is mentioned several times in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] literature as a teacher. According to the Chāndogya<ref name=fx1_ve2_305> v. 11, 1;<br> 16, 1.</ref> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve2_305> v. 15, 11 (Mādhyaṃdina = v. 14, 8 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> Upaniṣads, he was a contemporary of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' of '''[[विदेह|Videha]],''' and, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_305> x. 6, 1, 1. ''Cf.'' iv. 6, 1, 9. vi. 30.</ref> of '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]],''' the '''[[केकय|Kekaya]]''' king. He is also mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].^4

बुध सौमायन
<u>'''Budha Saumāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Soma,'''’ is the name of a teacher mentioned in a verse in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_306> xxiv. 18, 6. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 55, n. 2.</ref>

बुन्द
<u>'''Bunda'''</u> means ‘arrow’ in a few passages of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_307> viii. 45, 4;<br> 77, 6. 11. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 32.</ref>

बृबु
<u>'''Bṛbu'''</u> is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_308> vi. 45, 31. 33.</ref> where he is described as a most generous giver (''sahasra-dātama''), and as at the head of the '''Paṇis.''' According to the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_308> xvi. 11, 11.</ref> '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]''' received gifts from [[बृबु|Bṛbu]] '''[[तक्षन्|Takṣan]]''' and  '''[[प्रस्तोक|Prastoka]] [[सार्ञ्जय|Sārñjaya]],''' a fact alluded to in the [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra,<ref name=fx3_ve2_308> x. 107.</ref> where ''[[तक्षन्|takṣan]]'' is treated as a descriptive attribute, ‘a carpenter.’ Apparently [[बृबु|Bṛbu]] was a [[पणि|Paṇi]], though the words of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_308/> might be taken to mean that he was one who had overthrown them entirely. If so, [[पणि|Paṇi]] must here certainly mean a merchant in a good sense, [[बृबु|Bṛbu]] being then a merchant prince.<ref name=fx4_ve2_308> ''Cf.'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 606, n.</ref> According to Weber,<ref name=fx5_ve2_308> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 28 ''et seq.;<br> Proceedings of the Berlin Academy,'' 1898, 563, n. 1;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 198. The Bāveru Jātaka, on which stress is laid in connexion with the Indian knowledge of Babylon, being of quite unknown date, has no cogency as evidence for any early period. ''Cf.'' Bühler, ''Indische Palœographie,'' 17-19;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 79 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indian Literature'' 3;<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 201 ''et seq.''</ref> the name suggests connexion with Babylon, but this conjecture must be regarded as quite improbable. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx6_ve2_308> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 93, 104, 107.</ref> sensibly expresses no opinion as to [[बृबु|Bṛbu]], while Brunnhofer's<ref name=fx7_ve2_308> ''Iran und Turan,'' 127.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 275;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, v. 108, 109, with Macdonell's notes;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 316.</ref> attempt to recognize a people named , and to connect them with the Vedic word ''[[तक्षन्|takṣan]],'' is valueless, especially considering the fact that [[तक्षन्|Takṣan]] is not found as an epithet of [[बृबु|Bṛbu]] in the Rigveda.

बृसय
<u>'''Bṛsaya'''</u> is mentioned twice in the Rigveda, being in the first passage<ref name=fx1_ve2_309> i. 93, 4.</ref> connected with the '''Paṇis,''' and in the second<ref name=fx2_ve2_309> vi. 61, 3.</ref> with the '''Pārāvatas''' and the Paṇis. According to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, the word is the name of a demon,<ref name=fx3_ve2_309> ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa on Rv., ''loc., cit.''</ref> but is in the second passage<ref name=fx2_ve2_309/> used as an appellative, perhaps meaning ‘sorcerer.’<ref name=fx4_ve2_309> Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' following Grassmann.</ref> Hillebrandt<ref name=fx5_ve2_309> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 97-104.</ref> thinks that a people is meant locating them in Arachosia or Drangiana with the Pārāvatas and the Paṇis, and comparing , satrap of Arachosia and Drangiana in the time of Darius.<ref name=fx6_ve2_309> Arrian, ''Indica,'' viii. 4;<br> xxi. 1;<br> xxv. 8.</ref> But this theory is not probable. 

बृसी
<u>'''Bṛsī,'''</u> denoting a ‘cushion’ of grass, is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve2_310> i. 2, 4;<br> v. 1, 3, with Keith's note;<br> 3, 2.</ref> and the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve2_310> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 4, 7;<br> 6, 6;<br> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 3, 1.</ref> The incorrect forms Vṛśī and Vṛṣī also occur occasionally.

बृहच्-छन्दस्
<u>'''Bṛhac-chandas'''</u> is found in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_311> iii. 12, 3.</ref> as an epithet of '''[[शाला|Śālā]],''' ‘house.’ It is apparently<ref name=fx2_ve2_311> ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 105.</ref> an error for ''bṛhad-[[छदिस्|chadis]],'' ‘broad-roofed,’ which in any case is the sense.<ref name=fx3_ve2_311> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 345.</ref>

बृहत्-सामन्
<u>'''Bṛhat-sāman'''</u> is mentioned in the Atharvaveda (v. 19, 2) as an '''[[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]]''' who was oppressed by Kṣatriyas. The latter are said to have been ruined in consequence. ''Cf.'' '''[[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]]''' and '''[[बार्हत्सामा|Bārhatsāmā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

बृहद्-उक्थ
<u>'''Bṛhad-uktha'''</u> is mentioned in an obscure hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_313> v. 19, 3, where Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' treats it as adjectival. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft.'' 42, 214;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 126.</ref> as a priest; in two hymns of the tenth Maṇḍala<ref name=fx2_ve2_313> x. 54, 6;<br> 56, 7.</ref> he is definitely a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]]. He is also mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_313> viii. 23.</ref> as having consecrated '''[[दुर्मुख|Durmukha]] [[पाञ्चाल|Pāñcāla]],''' and is called '''Vāmadeva's''' son in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_313> xiii. 2, 2, 14.</ref> In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_313> xiv. 9, 37, 38.</ref> he appears as '''Vāmneya,''' ‘descendant of Vāmnī.’ Hopkins<ref name=fx6_ve2_313> ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 55, n. 2.</ref> suggestion that he may have been there thought of as Vāmadevya also is quite probable.<ref name=fx7_ve2_313> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 9, 27, is parallel with xiv. 9, 38.</ref>

बृहद्-गिरि
<u>'''Bṛhad-giri'''</u> is said in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 1, 4) to have been one of the three '''Yatis''' who survived the slaughter of them by Indra. A Sāman, or Chant, of his is mentioned in the same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 4, 15-17). <br>==Foot Notes==

बृहद्-दिव
<u>'''Bṛhad-diva'''</u> appears in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_315> x. 120, 8. 9.</ref> as its author, calling himself an [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]]. He is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_315> iv. 14.</ref> and is named in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx3_ve2_315> xv. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 141.</ref> as a pupil of '''[[सुम्नयु|Sumnayu]].'''

बृहद्-रथ
<u>'''Bṛhad-ratha'''</u> is mentioned twice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_316> i. 36, 18;<br> x. 49, 6. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 147, 148.</ref> in both cases beside '''[[नववास्त्व|Navavāstva]].''' The name may thus be an epithet of [[नववास्त्व|Navavāstva]].

बृहद्-वसु
<u>'''Bṛhad-vasu'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_317> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 374.</ref>

बृहस्पति
<u>'''Bṛhaspati,'''</u> ‘lord of prayer,’ is the name of a god in the Vedic texts. The view of Thibaut,<ref name=fx1_ve2_318> ''Astronomie, Astrologie und Mathematik.'' 6.</ref> that the name designates the planet Jupiter, is certainly not supported by good evidence. Oldenberg<ref name=fx2_ve2_318> ''Nachrichten der ko7niglichen Gesellschaft der Wessenschaften zu Go7ttingen,'' 1909, 568, n. 3;<br> Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, xciv, correcting Tilak, ''Orion,'' 101. See also Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1911, 514-518;<br> Keith, ''ibid.,'' 794-800.</ref> seems clearly right in rejecting it.

बृहस्पति-गुप्त शायस्थि
<u>'''Bṛhaspati-[[गुप्त|gupta]] Śāyasthi'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_319> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref> as a pupil of '''[[भवत्रात शायस्थि|Bhavatrāta Śāyasthi]].'''

बृहस्पति-सव
<u>'''Bṛhaspati-sava'''</u> is the name of a sacrifice by which, according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_320> ii. 7, 1, 2. ''Cf.'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 7;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 11, 4;<br> xxv. 1, 1, 7.</ref> the priest who desired to become a '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]]''' obtained that office. According to the Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_320> ix. 9. 5.</ref> it was the sacrifice to be performed by a priest after the '''[[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]],''' while the king performed the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]].''' In  the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_320> v. 2, 1, 19.</ref> on the other hand, the [[बृहस्पतिसव|Bṛhaspatisava]] is identified with the [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]]; but such identity is clearly not primitive.<ref name=fx4_ve2_320> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, xxiv, xxv;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 107, 108.</ref>

बेकनाट
<u>'''Bekanāṭa'''</u> occurs only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_321> viii. 16, 10.</ref> when Indra is said to overcome all the Bekanāṭas and the Paṇis. The natural sense, therefore, seems to be ‘usurer,’ the explanation given by [[यास्क|Yāska]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_321> Nirūkta, vi. 26.</ref> The word has a foreign appearance, but its provenance can hardly be determined: it might just as well be aboriginal as Babylonian.<ref name=fx3_ve2_321> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 44.</ref> Hillebrandt<ref name=fx4_ve2_321> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 268, n. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 259.</ref> thinks Brunnhofer is right in identifying [[बेकनाट|Bekanāṭa]] with Bikanir.

बेकुरा
<u>'''Bekurā'''</u> occurs in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_322> i. 3, 1;<br> vi. 7, 6;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 82.</ref> where it may mean ‘voice’ or ‘sound,’ the sense assigned to the word in the Naighaṇṭuka.<ref name=fx2_ve2_322> i. 11.</ref> It is, however, possibly, like '''[[बकुर|Bakura]],''' the name of a musical instrument. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_322> iii. 4, 7, 1.</ref> and the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_322> xviii. 14.</ref> Saṃhitās the words Bekuri and Vekuri occur as epithets of Apsarases, or celestial nymphs, meaning, perhaps, ‘melodious’; in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx5_ve2_322> xviii. 42.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_322> ix. 4, 1, 9.</ref> the variations Bhakuri and [[भाकुरि|Bhākuri]] are found.

बैज-वाप
<u>'''Baija-vāpa,'''</u> ‘descendant of Bījavāpa,’ is the name of a teacher in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26).<br>==Foot Notes==

बैज-वापायन
<u>'''Baija-vāpāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[बैजवाप|Baijavāpa]],'''’ is the name of a teacher in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26). The name is also spelt Vaijavāpāyana. <br>==Foot Notes==

बैज-वापि
<u>'''Baija-vāpi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Bījavāpa, or Bījavāpin,’ is the name of a teacher in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (i. 4, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

बैन्द
<u>'''Bainda'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_326> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1.</ref> According to the commentator Mahīdhara, the word denotes a [[निषाद|Niṣāda]], but according to Sāyaṇa a catcher of fish. See '''[[मृगयु|Mṛgayu]].'''

बोध
<u>'''Bodha'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] Pāṭha.<ref name=fx1_ve2_327> ii. 16, 14. ''Cf.'' Winternitz, ''Mantrapāṭha,'' xiv.</ref> He is mentioned with '''Pratibodha''' in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_327> v. 30, 10;<br> viii. 1, 13.</ref> but Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve2_327> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 474.</ref> thinks that in the second passage, at least, the word is an ordinary noun meaning ‘the wakeful one.’

बौधायन
<u>'''Baudhāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Budha''' or '''[[बोध|Bodha]],'''’ is the name of a teacher who is mentioned in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_328> iv. 11, etc.</ref> and under whose name are current a Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] described<ref name=fx2_ve2_328> ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 1903.</ref> and in part edited by Caland,<ref name=fx3_ve2_328> ''Bibliotheca Indica,'' 1904, etc.</ref> and a [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] which has been edited<ref name=fx4_ve2_328> By Hultzsch, Leipzig, 1884.</ref> and translated,<ref name=fx5_ve2_328> Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14. See his Introduction, xxix ''et seq.,'' where, however, he tends to overestimate considerably the age of [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]].</ref> while the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] is still unedited.

बौधी-पुत्र
<u>'''Baudhī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of '''[[बोध|Bodha]],'''’ is the name of a pupil of '''[[शालङ्कायनीपुत्र|Śālaṅkāyanīputra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāranyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 31).<br>==Foot Notes==

ब्रह्म-चर्य
<u>'''Brahma-carya'''</u> denotes the condition of life of the '''Brahmacārin'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_330> Rv. x. 109, 5;<br> Av. vi. 108, 2;<br> 133, 3;<br> xi. 5, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 3, 1, etc.</ref> or religious student. The technical sense is first found in  the last Maṇḍala of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_330> Rv., ''loc. cit.''</ref> The practice of studentship doubtless developed, and was more strictly regulated by custom as time went on, but it is regularly assumed and discussed in the later Vedic literature, being obviously a necessary part of Vedic society<br><br>The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_330> xi. 5. ''Cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1-8, which contains an independent account of the Brahmacārin (Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 110);<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 3, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 10, 5.</ref> has in honour of the Brahmacārin a hymn which already gives all the characteristic features of religious studentship. The youth is initiated (''upa-nī'') by the teacher<ref name=fx4_ve2_330> Av. xi. 5, 3. It is used in the ritual of the Upanayana, according to the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], lv. 18.</ref> into a new life; he wears an antelope skin, and lets his hair grow long;<ref name=fx5_ve2_330> Av. xi. 5, 6.</ref> he collects fuel,<ref name=fx6_ve2_330> Av. xi. 5, 4, 6.</ref> and begs,<ref name=fx7_ve2_330> Av. xi. 5, 9.</ref> learns, and practises penance. All these characteristics appear in the later literature. The student lives in the house of his teacher (''ācārya-kula-vāsin;''<ref name=fx8_ve2_330> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 23, 2. So regularly ''brahma-caryeṇa vas,'' Av. vii. 109, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 14, etc.;<br> or ''car,'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 3, 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 6, 3, etc.</ref> ''[[अन्ते-वासिन्|ante-vāsin]]'');<ref name=fx9_ve2_330> ''Ibid.,'' iii. 11, 5;<br> iv. 10, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 15 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 7 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 3;<br> 11. 1.</ref> he begs,<ref name=fx10_ve2_330> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 5. ''Cf.'' Av. vi. 133, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 3, 5.</ref> looks after the sacrificial fires,<ref name=fx11_ve2_330> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 10, 2 ''et seq.;<br>'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. xi. 3, 3, 4.</ref> and tends the house.<ref name=fx12_ve2_330> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6, 2, 15. A [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in the Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 22, 1. 2, and elsewhere, sums up the duties of the Brahmacārin as ‘thou art a Brahmacārin: eat water;<br> perform thy duty;<br> sleep not in the daytime;<br> obedient to thy teacher study the Veda (''brahmacāry asy;<br> apo ‘śāna;<br> karma kuru;<br> divā mā svāpsīr;<br> ācāryāyādhīno vedam adhīṣva'').’ One duty specially referred to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 19, and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 5, 5, was the guarding of the teacher's cattle when they were grazing on their pasture grounds. From these grounds, too, the pupil would, no doubt, bring dried dung for fuel, as well as any available sticks. As regards obedience to the teacher, ''cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 3, 6.</ref> His term of studentship might be long extended: it was normally fixed at twelve years,<ref name=fx13_ve2_330> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 10;<br> vi. 1, 2.</ref> but much longer periods, such as thirty-two years, are mentioned.<ref name=fx14_ve2_330> ''Ibid.,'' viii. 7, 3 (thirty-two years);<br> 15 (for life), etc.</ref> The  age at which studentship began varied.<ref name=fx15_ve2_330> See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 21. The Sūtras allowed for a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] the ages 8-16;<br> for a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], 11-22;<br> for a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]], 12-24. The difference between the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], compared with that between the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] and the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]], shows that the two latter castes were in a different position from the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].</ref> '''[[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]]''' commenced at twelve and studied for twelve years.<ref name=fx16_ve2_330> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 2.</ref><br><br>It is assumed in the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras that the three Āryan castes were all required to pass through a period of studentship. But that this is much more than priestly schematism is uncertain. No doubt individuals of the '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]''' or '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]''' caste might go through part of the period of studentship, just as Burmese boys of all classes now pass some time in a monastery as students. This is borne out by the reference in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx17_ve2_330> xv. 5, 17. ''Cf.'' Lanman in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 639.</ref> to the king guarding his country by [[ब्रह्मचर्य|Brahmacarya]]--though that is susceptible of a different interpretation--and more clearly by the reference in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx18_ve2_330> ix. 16 (reading ''abrāhmaṇa'') .</ref> to a rite intended to benefit one who, although not a Brahmin, had studied (''vidyām anūcya''), but had not gained renown, and by references in the Upaniṣads to kings who like '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' studied the Vedas and the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx19_ve2_330> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2, 1.</ref> Normally, however, the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] studied the art of war.<ref name=fx20_ve2_330> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 106-113.</ref><br><br>One of the duties of the Brahmacārin was chastity. But reference is in several places<ref name=fx21_ve2_330> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, x. 65;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 10, 9.</ref> made to the possibility of misconduct between a student and the wife of his preceptor, nor is any very severe penance imposed in early times--later it is different--for such a sin. In certain cases the ritual required a breach of chastity, no doubt as a magic spell to secure fertility.<ref name=fx22_ve2_330> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 9, 4;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 125, n. 1;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 79.</ref><br><br>Even an old man might on occasion become a pupil, as the story of '''[[आरुणि|Āruṇi]]''' shows.<ref name=fx23_ve2_330> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 6 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).<br><br>''Cf.'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 202, 203;<br> Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 151;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 10, 121 ''et seq.;<br>'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 370, 371, and see '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].'''</ref> 

ब्रह्म-ज्य
<u>'''Brahma-jya,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_331> v. 19, 7. 12;<br> xii. 5, 15 ''et seq.;<br>'' xiii. 3, 1. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 9, 2.</ref> ‘oppressor of a Brahmin,’ and '''Brahma-jyeya,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_331> Av. xii. 4, 11.</ref> ‘oppression of a Brahmin,’ are terms mentioned several times in the Atharvaveda as expressing a heinous crime which involves its perpetrator in ruin. See '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].'''

ब्रह्म-दत्त चैकितानेय
<u>'''Brahma-datta Caikitāneya'''</u> (‘descendant of Cekitāna’) is the name of a teacher in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 3, 26). He is mentioned also in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 38, 1; 59, 1) as patronized by '''Abhipratārin,''' the Kuru king.<br>==Foot Notes==

ब्रह्मन्
<u>'''1. Brahman'''</u> (neut.) denotes the priestly class as opposed to the warrior class and the people ('''[[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]]''' and '''[[विश्|Viś]]'''). The term is found in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_333> ii. 15, 4;<br> ix. 7, 9;<br> xii. 5, 8;<br> xv. 10, 3, 4.</ref> and repeatedly later on.<ref name=fx2_ve2_333> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 1, 1, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 3;<br> vii. 21, etc. See also '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''' and '''[[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]].'''</ref> For the position, etc., of this class, see '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].'''

ब्रह्मन्
<u>'''2. Brahman'''</u> is found in many passages of the Rigveda and later in the sense of ‘priest.’ In many passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_334> i. 80, 1;<br> 164, 34;<br> ii. 2, 6;<br> vi. 45, 7;<br> vii. 33, 11;<br> viii. 16, 7;<br> x. 71, 11;<br> 77, 1;<br> 85, 3, 16. 34;<br> 107, 6;<br> 117, 7;<br> 125, 5;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 244-246.</ref> he is referred to as praising the gods; in others<ref name=fx2_ve2_334> i. 10, 1;<br> 33, 9;<br> 101, 5;<br> 108, 7;<br> 158, 6;<br> ii. 39, 1;<br> iv. 50, 8, 9;<br> 58, 2;<br> v. 29, 3;<br> 31, 4;<br> 32, 12;<br> 40, 8;<br> vii. 7, 5;<br> 42, 1;<br> viii. 7, 20;<br> 17, 2;<br> 31, 1;<br> 32, 16;<br> 33 19;<br> 45, 39;<br> 64, 7;<br> 77, 5;<br> 92, 30;<br> 96, 5;<br> ix. 96, 6;<br> 112, 1;<br> 113, 6;<br> x. 28 11;<br> 71, 11;<br> 85, 29;<br> 141, 3;<br> Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 12, 246-251.</ref> the sense of ‘priest’ is adequate. In not a few cases<ref name=fx3_ve2_334> i. 108, 7;<br> iv. 50, 8, 9;<br> viii. 7, 20;<br> 45, 39;<br> 64, 7;<br> 92, 30;<br> ix. 112, 1;<br> x. 85, 29;<br> Muir, 12, 258.</ref> the priesthood as a profession is clearly alluded to, nor is there any reason to doubt<ref name=fx4_ve2_334> ''Loc. cit. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 190 ''et seq.''</ref> that in all cases the word has the technical sense of a member of the priesthood. There is, however, considerable doubt as to the number of cases in the Rigveda, where it has the technical  sense of the priest who guides the sacrifice generally. It is undoubtedly found in that sense, both Muir<ref name=fx5_ve2_334> ''Op. cit.,'' 12, 251, citing ii. 1, 2 (= ix. 91, 10);<br> iv. 9, 4;<br> x. 52, 2.</ref> and Roth<ref name=fx6_ve2_334> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2, citing ii. 1, 2;<br> ix. 96, 6;<br> x. 71, 11;<br> 107, 6. In none of the last three passages is the specific sense cogently required.</ref> recognizing instances of its being used thus. Geldner,<ref name=fx7_ve2_334> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 145 ''et seq.;<br>'' 3, 155. He thinks that the sense of ‘superintending priest’ is the older, and sees it in i. 158, 6;<br> iv. 9, 4;<br> 50, 7. 8;<br> vii. 7, 5;<br> 33, 11;<br> x. 141, 3, etc.</ref> however, is anxious to find that sense in a large number of passages, and insists that the '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]]''' was normally a [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] in the narrower sense. Oldenberg,<ref name=fx8_ve2_334> ''Religion des Veda,'' 396, 397, who thinks that the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] priest known to the Rigveda was the '''[[ब्राह्मणाच्छंसिन्|Brāhmaṇācchaṃsin]]''' and who in most passages (''e.g.,'' iv. 50, 7. 8) sees only the sense of ‘priest.’ ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 376, 377.</ref> on the other hand, holds with greater probability that in most of the passages adduced [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] means simply ‘priest,’ and that the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], who was essentially not a member of the ordinary body of sacrificing priests ('''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]'''), was, when he officiated at the sacrifice, more usually the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest, and only later became the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]]. This change he regards as having taken place when the importance of the hymns declined, and most weight was laid on the functions of the priest who superintended the sacrifice as a whole, and by his magic repaired the flaws in the sacrifice.<ref name=fx9_ve2_334> ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1894, 420;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 13;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' lxviii;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 32;<br> and see '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]].'''</ref> In the later literature both senses of the word are quite common.<ref name=fx10_ve2_334> As ‘priest,’ Av. ii. 7, 2;<br> iv. 35, 1. 2;<br> v. 8, 5;<br> 17, 8;<br> 18, 7;<br> 19, 8;<br> vi. 122, 5;<br> viii. 9, 3;<br> x. 1, 3;<br> 4, 30. 33;<br> 7, 24;<br> xi. 1, 25;<br> xii. 1, 38;<br> xix. 32, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 7, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxvi. 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, etc. As ‘superintending priest,’ Av. xviii. 4, 15;<br> xx. 2, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 1;<br> ii. 3, 11, 4;<br> iii. 5, 2, 1, etc.;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 17;<br> and see Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 34, 35;<br> 114;<br> 135-138;<br> 327;<br> 330-337.</ref>

ब्रह्म-पुत्र
<u>'''Brahma-putra'''</u> in a few passages is used in the sense of a ‘priest's son.’<br><br>^1 Rv. ii. 43, 2; Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 4, 1, 2. 9. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 43, 69; Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 252. <br>==Foot Notes==

ब्रह्म-पुरोहित
<u>'''Brahma-purohita'''</u> is found in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_336> xix. 10;<br> xxvii. 4.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_336> xii. 8, 3, 29.</ref> where the St. Petersburg Dictionary gives the sense as ‘having the priesthood as its [[पुरोहित|Purohita]].’ This seems rather doubtful; more probably the sense should be ‘having a [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] priest as [[पुरोहित|Purohita]],’ unless the word merely means ‘having the priesthood superior to it,’ as an epithet of '''[[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]],''' the ‘warrior caste,’ which seems to be Weber's view.<ref name=fx3_ve2_336> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 30.</ref>

ब्रह्म-बन्धु
<u>'''Brahma-bandhu'''</u> (‘priest fellow’) denotes, in a deprecatory sense, an ‘unworthy priest,’ ‘priest in name only,’ in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_337> vii. 27.</ref> and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_337> vi. 1, 1. ''Cf.'' Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6, 28;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 4, 22;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 29, 9;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 99, 100.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[राजन्यबन्धु|Rājanyabandhu]].'''

ब्रह्मर्षि-देश
<u>'''Brahmarṣi-deśa.'''</u> See '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

ब्रह्म-वद्य
<u>'''Brahma-vadya.'''</u> See '''[[ब्रह्मोद्य|Brahmodya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

ब्रह्म-वादिन्
<u>'''Brahma-vādin'''</u> (‘expounder of the Veda’) in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_340> Av. xi. 3, 26;<br> xv. 1, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 1, 4;<br> ii. 6, 2, 3;<br> 3, 1;<br> v. 2, 7, 1;<br> 5, 3, 2;<br> vi. 1, 4, 5.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_340> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 10, 6;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 13;<br> vi. 4, 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka. i. 22, 9;<br> v. 2, 2;<br> 4, 6;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 24, 1, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘theologian.’ Brahma-vid (‘knowing what is sacred’) has the same sense.<ref name=fx3_ve2_340> Av. x. 7, 24. 27;<br> 8, 43;<br> xix. 43, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 8, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 7, 4;<br> iv. 4, 11, 12, etc.</ref>

ब्रह्म-विद्या
<u>'''Brahma-vidyā,'''</u> ‘knowledge of the Absolute,’ is the name of one of the sciences enumerated in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_341> vii. 1, 2, 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> It is also mentioned elsewhere.<ref name=fx2_ve2_341> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, 20, etc.</ref>

ब्रह्म-वृद्धि
<u>'''Brahma-vṛddhi'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_342> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372, 382.</ref> as a pupil of '''Mitravarcas.''' 

ब्रह्म-हत्या
<u>'''Brahma-hatyā,'''</u> the ‘murder of a Brahmin,’ is mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_343> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 2;<br> v. 3, 12, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxix. 13, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_343> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 1, 1;<br> 5, 3;<br> 5, 4, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, x. 38;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 27, etc.</ref> as a heinous crime. The murderer is called Brahma-han.<ref name=fx3_ve2_343> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 2;<br> vi. 5, 10, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 7;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvii. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 12;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 5, 4, etc. ''Cf.'' '''[[धर्म|Dharma]].'''</ref>

ब्रह्मावर्त
<u>'''Brahmāvarta.'''</u> See '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

ब्रह्मोद्य
<u>'''Brahmodya'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_345> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 9, 20;<br> xi. 4, 1, 2;<br> 5, 3, 1;<br> 6, 2, 5;<br> xiii. 2, 6, 9;<br> 5, 2, 11;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 8, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 25.</ref> denotes a ‘theological riddle,’ such as formed an essential part of various ceremonies in the Vedic ritual, as at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] or the Daśarātra. [[ब्रह्म-वद्य|Brahma-vadya]] is the form found in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_345> xxvii. 4.</ref> and Brahma-vādya in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_345> ii. 5, 8, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 172;<br> ''Religion of the Veda,'' 216 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 118, 119;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 390 ''et seq.;<br>'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 452, 453.</ref> probably has the same sense.

ब्रह्मोपनिषद्
<u>'''Brahmopaniṣad,'''</u> a ‘secret doctrine regarding the Absolute,’ is the name of a discussion in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 11, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

ब्रह्मौदन
<u>'''Brahmaudana'''</u> denotes in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_347> Av. iv. 35, 7;<br> xi. 1, 1, 3, 20. 23 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8, 7;<br> v. 7, 3, 4;<br> vi. 5, 6, 1, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_347> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 1, 1. 4;<br> 3, 6, 6;<br> 4, 1, 5, etc.</ref> the ‘rice boiled ('''[[ओदन|Odana]]''') for the priests’ officiating at the sacrifice.

Brāhmaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of a Brahman’ (''i.e.,'' of a priest), is found only a few times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_348> i. 164, 45;<br> vi. 75, 10;<br> vii. 103, 1. 7. 8;<br> x. 16, 6;<br> 71, 8. 9;<br> 88, 19;<br> 90, 12;<br> 97, 22;<br> 109, 4. '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]].'''</ref> It is admitted<ref name=fx11_ve2_348> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 8, 7;<br> Pañcavimśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 10, 8;<br> Av. v. 1719;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 2, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 5, 4.</ref> that the king or the nobles might at times oppress the Brahmins, but it is indicated that ruin is then certain swiftly to follow. <br><br>The Brahmins are gods on earth,<ref name=fx12_ve2_348> Av. v. 3, 2;<br> vi. 13, 1;<br> 44, 2;<br> xix. 62, 1 (compared with xix. 32, 8), and probably v. 11, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 3, 1;<br> ii. 5, 9, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 2, 6;<br> 4, 3, 14;<br> iii. 1, 1, 11;<br> iv. 3, 4, 4.
