The other two epithets applied, ''āvasāyī'' and ''yathākāma-prayāpya,'' are more obscure; the former denotes either ‘dwelling everywhere’<ref name=fx15_ve2_348> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 326.</ref> or ‘seeking food’;<ref name=fx16_ve2_348> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 439.</ref> the latter is usually taken as ‘moving at pleasure,’ but it must rather allude to the power of the king to assign a place of residence to the Brahmin.<br><br>In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx17_ve2_348> xi. 5, 7, 1 ''et seq.'' See Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 10, 41 ''et seq.''</ref> the prerogatives of the Brahmin are summed up as (1) [[अर्चा|Arcā]], ‘honour’; (2) [[दान|Dāna]], ‘gifts’; (3) [[अज्येयता|Ajyeyatā]], ‘freedom from oppression’; and (4) [[अवध्यता|Avadhyatā]], ‘freedom from being killed.’ On the other hand, his duties are summed up as (5) Brāhmaṇya, ‘purity of descent’; (6) Pratirūpa-caryā, ‘devotion of the duties of his caste’; and (7) Loka-[[पक्ति|pakti]], ‘the perfecting of people’ (by teaching).<br><br>1. ''Respect paid to Brahmins.''--The texts are full<ref name=fx18_ve2_348> ''E.g.,'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā;<br> xxv. 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 10, 6;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 1, 10;<br> 3, 4, 6, etc.</ref> of references to the civilities to be paid to the Brahmin. He is styled ''bhagavant,''<ref name=fx19_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 6, 1, 2.</ref> and is provided with good food<ref name=fx20_ve2_348> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xix. 12.</ref> and entertainment wherever he goes. Indeed, his sanctity exempts him from any close inquiry into his real claim to Brahminhood according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx21_ve2_348> vi. 5, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 2.</ref><br><br>2. ''Gifts to Brahmins.''--The Dānastuti (‘Praise of gifts’) is a recognized feature of the Rigveda, and the greed of the poets for '''Dakṣiṇās,''' or sacrificial fees, is notorious. Vedic texts<ref name=fx22_ve2_348> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 2, 6, 7.</ref> themselves recognize that the literature thence resulting ('''Nārā-  śaṃsī''') was often false to please the donors. It was, however, a rule<ref name=fx23_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 1, 25. ''Cf.'' also Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 15, 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 14, etc.</ref> that Brahmins should not accept what had been refused by others; this indicates a keen sense of the danger of cheapening their wares. So exclusively theirs was the right to receive gifts that the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx24_ve2_348> xiii. 7, 12.</ref> has to explain how '''[[तरन्त|Taranta]]''' and '''[[पुरुमीळ्ह|Purumīḷha]]''' became able to accept gifts by composing a Rigvedic hymn.<ref name=fx25_ve2_348> ix. 58, 3.</ref> The exaggerations in the celebration of the gifts bestowed on the priests has the curious result of giving us a series of numerals of some interest ('''[[दशन्|Daśan]]'''). In some passages<ref name=fx26_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 12, 1. 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 6, etc.</ref> certain gifts--those of a horse or sheep--are forbidden, but this rule was not, it is clear, generally observed.<br><br>3. ''Immunities of Brahmins.''--The Brahmin claimed to be exempt from the ordinary exercise of the royal power. When a king gives all his land and what is on it to the priests, the gift does not cover the property of the Brahmin according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx27_ve2_348> xiii. 5, 4, 29;<br> 6, 2, 18;<br> 7, 1, 13.</ref> The king censures all, but not the Brahmin,<ref name=fx28_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' v. 4, 2, 3.</ref> nor can he safely oppress any Brahmin other than an ignorant priest.<ref name=fx29_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' xiii. 4, 2, 17.</ref> An arbitrator (or a witness) must decide (or speak) for a Brahmin against a non-Brahmin in a legal dispute.<ref name=fx30_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 11, 9.</ref><br><br>The Brahmin's proper food is the '''Soma,'''<ref name=fx31_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 2, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 29. ''Cf.'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 40;<br> x. 18, etc.</ref> not '''[[सुरा|Surā]]'''<ref name=fx32_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 1,--5.</ref> or '''[[परिस्रुत्|Parisrut]],'''<ref name=fx33_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' xii. 9, 1, 1.</ref> and he is forbidden to eat certain forms of flesh.<ref name=fx34_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' 1, 2, 3, 9;<br> vii. 5, 2, 37;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8.</ref> On the other hand, he alone is allowed to eat the remains of the sacrifice,<ref name=fx35_ve2_348> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 1, 39;<br> 5, 3, 16, etc. On the food of the Brahmins, ''cf.'' also [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], x. 4, 5;<br> xvii. 1, 9;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 11.</ref> for no one else is sufficiently holy to consume food which the gods have eaten. Moreover, though he cannot be a physician,<ref name=fx36_ve2_348> ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 8-14, where the Aśvins, who are famous as physicians (viii. 2, 1, 3;<br> xii. 7, 1, 11). are treated as impure.</ref> he helps the physician by being beside him  while he exercises his art.<ref name=fx37_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 9, 3. Contrast Rv. x. 97, 22, where no discredit attaches to the profession.</ref> His wife<ref name=fx38_ve2_348> Av. v. 17.</ref> and his cow<ref name=fx39_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' v. 18.</ref> are both sacred.<br><br>4. ''Legal Position of Brahmins.''--The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx40_ve2_348> ii. 6, 10. 2.</ref> lays down a penalty of a hundred (the unit meant is unknown) for an insult to a Brahmin, and of a thousand for a blow; but if his blood is drawn, the penalty is a spiritual one. The only real murder is the slaying of a Brahmin according to the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx41_ve2_348> xiii. 3, 5, 3.</ref> The crime of slaying a Brahmin ranks above the sin of killing any other man, but below that of killing an embryo (''bhrūṇa'') in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]];<ref name=fx42_ve2_348> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 7;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvii. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 12.</ref> the crime of slaying an embryo whose sex is uncertain is on a level with that of slaying a Brahmin.<ref name=fx43_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 9;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 481;<br> 10, 66.</ref> The murder of a Brahmin can be expiated only by the horse sacrifice,<ref name=fx44_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 1, 1;<br> 5, 4, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> or by a lesser rite in the late [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx45_ve2_348> x. 38.</ref> The ritual slaying of a Brahmin is allowed in the later ceremonial,<ref name=fx46_ve2_348> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 10, 10;<br> 12, 16-20;<br> Weber, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 18, 268, 269.</ref> and hinted at in the curious legend of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]];'''<ref name=fx47_ve2_348> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 15;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 20.</ref> and a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] might be punished with death for treachery to his master.<ref name=fx48_ve2_348> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 6, 8.</ref><br><br>5. ''Purity of Birth.''--The importance of pure descent is seen in the stress laid on being a descendant of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] (''ārṣeya'').<ref name=fx49_ve2_348> See [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6, 1, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vii. 46;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 4, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 4, 19;<br> xii. 4, 4, 6.</ref> But, on the other hand, there are clear traces of another doctrine, which requires learning, and not physical descent, as the true criterion of Ṛṣihood.<ref name=fx50_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6, 1, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxx. 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 8, 1.</ref> In agreement with this is the fact that '''[[सत्यकाम|Satyakāma]] [[जाबाल|Jābāla]]''' was received as a pupil, though his parentage was unknown, his mother being a slave girl who had been connected with several men,<ref name=fx51_ve2_348> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 4.</ref> and that in the Śatapatha  [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx52_ve2_348> xi. 5, 4, 1;<br> and ''cf.'' a citation in the scholiast on Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 6, 14;<br> ‘Whoever studies the Stomabhāgas (a peculiarity of the Vasiṣṭhas) is a Vasiṣṭha’;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 73.</ref> the ceremony on acceptance as a pupil required merely the name of the pupil. So '''[[कवष|Kavaṣa]]''' is taunted in the Rigveda Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx53_ve2_348> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 19;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 3;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 311.</ref> as being the son of a female slave ('''Dāsī'''), and '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]]''' cleared himself of a similar imputation by a fire ordeal.<ref name=fx54_ve2_348> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 6, 6.</ref> Moreover, a very simple rite was adequate to remove doubts as to origin.<ref name=fx55_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 6, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiii. 4, 2.</ref> In these circumstances it is doubtful whether much value attaches to the '''[[प्रवर|Pravara]]''' lists in which the ancestors of the priest were invoked at the beginning of the sacrifice by the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] and the [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]] priests.<ref name=fx56_ve2_348> See Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 9, 321;<br> 10, 8. 81;<br> Max Müller. ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 380 ''et seq.''</ref> Still, in many parts of the ritual the knowledge of two or more generations was needed,<ref name=fx57_ve2_348> ''Cf., e.g.,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 5, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 5.</ref> and in one ceremony<ref name=fx58_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 5, 4;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 10, 85-88.</ref> ten ancestors who have drunk the Soma are required, but a literal performance of the rite is excused. Moreover, there are clear traces of ritual variations in schools, like those of the '''Vasiṣṭhas''' and the '''Viśvāmitras.'''<br><br>6. ''The Conduct of the Brahmin.''--The Brahmin was required to maintain a fair standard of excellence.<ref name=fx59_ve2_348> Weber, 10, 88-96;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 407 ''et seq.''</ref> He was to be kind to all<ref name=fx60_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. ii. 3, 2, 12.</ref> and gentle,<ref name=fx61_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' ii. 3, 4, 6.</ref> offering sacrifice and receiving gifts.<ref name=fx62_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' xiii. 1, 5, 6.</ref> Especial stress was laid on purity of speech;<ref name=fx63_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' iii. 2, 1, 24. ''Cf.'' iv. 1, 3, 17;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xiii. 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 5;<br> xxxvii. 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 62.</ref> thus '''Viśvantara's''' excuse for excluding the '''Śyāparṇas''' from his retinue was their impure (''apūtā'') speech.<ref name=fx64_ve2_348> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 27;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 438.</ref> Theirs was the craving for knowledge<ref name=fx65_ve2_348> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 8, 8;<br> v. 1, 1.</ref> and the life of begging.<ref name=fx66_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' iii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 4, 26.</ref> False Brahmins are those who do not fulfil their duties<ref name=fx67_ve2_348> ''Ibid.,'' vi. 4, 4.</ref> (''cf.'' '''[[ब्रह्मबन्धु|Brahmabandhu]]''') .  But the penances for breach of duty are, in the Sūtras, of a very light and unimportant character.<ref name=fx68_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 18, etc.</ref><br><br>7. [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 13, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 11, 6-9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 6, 10;<br> x. 3, 5, 16;<br> xi. 4, 4, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 5.</ref> Such distinction is not indeed confined to the Brahmin: the king has it also, but it is not really in a special manner ''Cf.'' also Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upanisad, vi. 4, 29.</ref> <br><br>8. ''The Functions of the Brahmin.''--The Brahmin was required not merely to practise individual culture, but also to give others the advantage of his skill, either as a teacher or as a sacrificial priest, or as a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]].<br><br>As a teacher the Brahmin has, of course, the special duty of instructing his own son in both study and sacrificial ritual.<ref name=fx96_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 2, 4.</ref> The texts give examples of this, such as [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]] and '''[[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]],'''<ref name=fx97_ve2_348> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 1. (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> or mythically Varuṇa and [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]].<ref name=fx98_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 1, 1.</ref> This fact also appears from some of the names in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx99_ve2_348> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 376.</ref> of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]] and the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx100_ve2_348> xv. 1.</ref> On the other hand, these Vaṃśas and the Vaṃśas of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] show that a father often preferred to let his son study under a famous teacher. The relation of pupil and teacher is described under '''[[ब्रह्मचर्य|Brahmacarya]].''' A teacher might take several pupils,<ref name=fx101_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 3.</ref> and he was bound to teach them with all his heart and soul.<ref name=fx102_ve2_348> See [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 4 (''Indische Studien,'' 2, 211).</ref> He was bound to reveal everything to his pupil, at any rate to one who was staying with him for a year (''[[संवत्सर|saṃvatsara]]-vāsin''),<ref name=fx103_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 1, 26. 27. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 3, 3.</ref> an expression which shows, as was natural, that a pupil might easily change teachers. But, nevertheless, certain cases of learning kept secret and only revealed to special persons are enumerated.<ref name=fx104_ve2_348> So the Vasiṣṭhas and the Stomabhāgas, [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 5, 24;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 2, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 17;<br> [[प्रवाहण जैवलि|Pravāhaṇa Jaivali]] and his knowledge of [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 11;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 3, where the claim is made that the ''praśāsana'' belongs to the Kṣatriyas. Śaṅkara, in his commentary, takes the word to mean the ‘giving of instruction,’ but this must be regarded as improbable, ‘rule’ being more probably the sense. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 128;<br> Bo7htlingk, Translation of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 8, 9.</ref> The exact times and modes of teaching are elaborately laid down in the Sūtras,<ref name=fx105_ve2_348> Rigveda Prātiśākhya, xv. 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 3, 3;<br> and see Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 10, 129-135.</ref> but not in the earlier texts.<br><br>As priest the Brahmin operated in all the greater sacrifices; the simple domestic (''[[गृह्य|gṛhya]]'') rites could normally be performed without his help, but not the more important rites (''śrauta'').  The number varied: the ritual literature requires sixteen priests to be employed at the greatest sacrifices (see '''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]'''), but other rites could be accomplished with four,<ref name=fx106_ve2_348> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 6, 1-4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 4, 2. The four are the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], Agnīdh, and Upavaktṛ: Weber, 10, 139, n. 4.</ref> five,<ref name=fx107_ve2_348> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 13;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 4, 2, with a second [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], as well as the four enumerated in the previous note.</ref> six,<ref name=fx108_ve2_348> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 2, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 4, 6;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 7, 2, 6, where the list has [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], with the [[प्रतिप्रस्थातृ|Pratiprasthātṛ]], Maitrāvaruṇa, Āgnīdhra.</ref> seven,<ref name=fx109_ve2_348> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 2, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 4, 2. The number seems to be made up of the five of note 107 and the Abhigarau--''i.e.,'' probably the Abhigara and the Apagara.</ref> or ten<ref name=fx110_ve2_348> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhita, ix. 8, 13-16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 4, 1;<br> 3, 6, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 25;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 4, 2. What ten are meant is uncertain;<br> the four of note 106 are enumerated.</ref> priests. Again, the Kauṣītakins<ref name=fx111_ve2_348> ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 4, 2, 19;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 37.</ref> had a seventeenth priest beside the usual sixteen, the [[सदस्य|Sadasya]], so called because he watched the performance from the [[सदस्|Sadas]], ‘seat.’ In one rite, the Sattra (‘sacrificial session’) of the serpents, the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx112_ve2_348> xxv. 14, 3.</ref> adds three more to the sixteen, a second Unnetṛ, an Abhigara, and an Apagara. The later ritual places the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] at the head of all the priests, but this is probably not the early view (see '''[[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]]''').<br><br>The sacrifice ensured, if properly performed, primarily the advantages of the sacrificer (''yajamāna''),<ref name=fx113_ve2_348> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 1, 20;<br> 9, 1, 12;<br> ii. 2, 2, 7;<br> iii. 4, 2, 15;<br> iv. 2, 5, 9, 10;<br> viii. 5, 3, 8;<br> ix. 5, 2, 16;<br> xii. 8, 1, 17, etc.</ref> but the priest shared in the profit, besides securing the '''Dakṣiṇās.''' Disputes between sacrificers and the priests were not rare, as in the case of '''Viśvantara''' and the '''Śyāparṇas,'''<ref name=fx114_ve2_348> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 27 ''et seq.;<br>'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 436 ''et seq.''</ref> or '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]]''' and the '''Asitamṛgas;'''<ref name=fx115_ve2_348> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 27.</ref> and the '''Aiṣāvīras''' are referred to as undersirable priests.<ref name=fx116_ve2_348> ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 7, 32, where Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 153, n. 1, interprets [[ऐषावीर|Aiṣāvīra]], not as a proper name, but as meaning ‘contemptible’;<br> but Sāyaṇa thinks a proper name is meant, a view accepted by Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 45, n. 2.</ref> Moreover, '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' once held the post of [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] to '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' but gave place to '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]].''' <br><br>The position of '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]]''' differed considerably from that of the ordinary priest, for the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] not merely might officiate at the sacrifice, but was the officiator in all the private sacrifices of his king. Hence he could, and undoubtedly sometimes did, obtain great influence over his master in matters of secular importance; and the power of the priesthood in political as opposed to domestic and religious matters, no doubt rested on the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]].<br><br>There is no recognition in Vedic literature of the rule later prevailing by which, after spending part of his life as a Brahmacārin, and part as a householder, the Brahmin became an ascetic<ref name=fx117_ve2_348> See Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 372 ''et seq.''</ref> (later divided into the two stages of Vānaprastha, ‘forest-dweller,’ and Saṃnyāsin, ‘mystic’). Yājñavalkya's case<ref name=fx118_ve2_348> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 5, 1. See iii. 5, 1, for his teaching, of which his action is a logical consequence.</ref> shows that study of the Absolute might empty life of all its content for the sage, and drive him to abandon wife and family. In Buddhist times the same phenomenon is seen<ref name=fx119_ve2_348> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 40 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,''^5 72 ''et seq.''</ref> applying to other than Brahmins. The Buddhist texts are here confirmed in some degree by the Greek authorities.<ref name=fx120_ve2_348> Arrian, ''Indica,'' xii. 8. 9;<br> Strabo, xv. 1, 49, 60.</ref> The practice bears a certain resemblance to the habit of kings, in the Epic tradition,<ref name=fx121_ve2_348> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 179 ''et seq.''</ref> of retiring to the forest when active life is over.<br><br>From the Greek authorities<ref name=fx122_ve2_348> See Fick, ''loc. cit.''</ref> it also appears--what is certainly the case in the Buddhist literature<ref name=fx123_ve2_348> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 57.</ref> --that Brahmins practised the most diverse occupations. It is difficult to say how far this was true for the Vedic period. The analogy of the Druids<ref name=fx124_ve2_348> Cæsar, ''Bellum Gallicum,'' vi. 14. The Druids did not fight, did not pay tribute, studied for many years, observed secrecy as to matters of ritual and learning, did not use writing, and had a certain belief in transmigration. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 19.</ref> --in some respects very close--suggests that the Brahmins may have been mainly confined to their professional tasks, including all the learned professions such as astronomy<ref name=fx125_ve2_348> Hence the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] is the 28th '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]:''' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 3, 3;<br> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 306, 311;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 40.</ref>  and so forth. This is not contradicted by any Vedic evidence, for instance, the poet of a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx126_ve2_348> ix. 112.</ref> says he is a poet, his father a physician ('''[[भिषज्|Bhiṣaj]]'''), and his mother a grinder of corn ('''[[उपल-प्रक्षिणी|Upala-prakṣiṇī]]'''). This would seem to show that a Brahmin could be a doctor, while his wife would perform the ordinary household duties. So a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] could perhaps take the field to assist the king by prayer, as [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],<ref name=fx127_ve2_348> Rv. iii. 33. 53.</ref> and later on [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]<ref name=fx128_ve2_348> Rv. vii. 18.</ref> do, but this does not show that priests normally fought. Nor do they seem normally to have been agriculturists or merchants. On the other hand, they kept cattle: a Brahmacārin's duty was to watch his master's cattle.<ref name=fx129_ve2_348> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 4, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 6.</ref> It is therefore needless to suppose that they could not, and did not, on occasion turn to agricultural or mercantile pursuits, as they certainly did later. But it must be remembered that in all probability there was more purity of blood, and less pressure of life, among the Brahmins of the Vedic age than later in Buddhist times, when the Vedic sacrificial apparatus was falling into grave disrepute.<br><br>It is clear that the Brahmins, whatever their defects, represented the intellectual side of Vedic life, and that the Kṣatriyas, if they played a part in that life, did so only in a secondary degree, and to a minor extent. It is natural to suppose that the Brahmins also composed ballads, the precursors of the epic; for though none such have survived, a few stanzas of this character, celebrating the generosity of patrons, have been preserved by being embedded in priestly compositions. A legend in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx130_ve2_348> i. 4, 1, 14-17. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 257, 277, 278, and [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 44.<br><br>Almost all that can be said of the Brahmins is collected in Weber's ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 40-158. ''Cf.'' also Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 220-226;<br> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung'' (for Buddhist times;<br> the evidence is, however, of uncertain, and much of it probably of late, date);<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 82, 182, etc. (for notices of the Brahmins in the Epic): ''The Mutual Relations of the Four Castes according to the Mānavadharmacāstram'' (for the [[धर्म|Dharma]] view). Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 248 ''et seq.,'' discusses the priesthood in the Rigveda, and Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 197212, gives an excellent summary of the facts.</ref> shows clearly that the Brahmins regarded civilization as being spread by them only:  '''[[कोसल|Kosala]]''' and '''[[विदेह|Videha]],''' no doubt settled by Āryan tribes, are only rendered civilized and habitable by the influence of pious Brahmins. We need not doubt that the non-Brahminical tribes (see '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]]''') had attained intellectual as well as material civilization, but it is reasonable to assume that their civilization was inferior to that of the Brahmins, for the history of Hinduism is the conquest by the Brahmins--not by arms, but by mind--of the tribes Āryan and non-Āryan originally beyond the pale.

Brāhmaṇa,'''</u> ‘religious explanation,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_349> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 25, 15;<br> iii. 45, 8;<br> vi. 25, 1, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 9, 5;<br> 5, 2, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 4, 1, etc. In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, i. and ii., the use is constant.</ref> is the title of a class of books which as such are only mentioned in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_349> ii. 16;<br> xiii. 7.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx3_ve2_349> ii. 10.</ref> and then in the Sūtras, where the names of the Brāhmaṇas occur, showing that literary works were in existence.

ब्राह्मणाच्-छंसिन्
<u>'''Brāhmaṇāc-chaṃsin'''</u> (‘reciting after the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]--''i.e.,'' Brahman’) is the name of a priest in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_351> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 4, 2;<br> 6, 3. 4;<br> 10, 1;<br> 18, 5;<br> vii. 1, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxviii. 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 6, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 3, 13, etc.</ref> In the technical division of the sacrificial priests ('''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]''') he is classed with the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_351> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 144.</ref> but it is clear that he was really a [[होत्रक|Hotraka]] or assistant of the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_351> ''E.g.,'' Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 10, 10;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 9, 374-376.</ref> According to Oldenberg,<ref name=fx4_ve2_351> ''Religion des Veda,'' 396.</ref> he was known to the Rigveda as '''[[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]].''' This is denied by Geldner,<ref name=fx5_ve2_351> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 145 ''et seq. Cf.'' '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]].'''</ref> who sees in [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] merely the ‘superintending priest’ or the ‘priest.’

भगिनी
<u>'''Bhaginī,'''</u> ‘sister,’ literally the ‘fortunate one’ in so far as she has a brother, occurs in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (iii. 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

भगी-रथ ऐक्ष्वाक
<u>'''Bhagī-[[रथ|ratha]] Aikṣvāka'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]]'''’) is the name of a king in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iv. 6, 1. 2). It is important to note that he is regarded as being on friendly terms with the '''Kuru-Pañcālas,''' which points to the Ikṣvākus being allied to that people, and not belonging (as is the case in the Buddhist books) to the east of India.<br>==Foot Notes==

भङ्ग
<u>'''Bhaṅga,'''</u> ‘hemp,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_356> xi. 6, 15;<br> conceivably in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 14, but not probably.</ref> In the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_356> ix. 61, 13.</ref> it is an epithet of Soma, presumably<ref name=fx3_ve2_356> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 299.</ref> in the sense of ‘intoxicating,’ which then came to designate hemp.<ref name=fx4_ve2_356> Hence the modern ‘Bang’ or Bhang,’ an intoxicant made from the dried leaves and small stalks of hemp, taken either by smoking or by eating when mixed up into a sweetmeat.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 68;<br> Grierson, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 23, 260;<br> Yule and Burnell, ''Hobson-Jobson, s.v. Bang.''</ref>

भङ्गाश्विन
<u>'''Bhaṅgāśvina'''</u> is the name of the father of '''Ṛtuparna''' in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_357> xx. 12.</ref> In the Mahābhārata<ref name=fx2_ve2_357> iii. 2745.</ref> he is called Bhāṅgāsuri. In the Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_357> xxi. 20;<br> Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 57, 745.</ref> mention is made of [[ऋतुपर्ण|Ṛtuparṇa]]-Kayovadhī as the Bhaṅgyaśvinau. 

भङ्ग्य-श्रवस्
<u>'''Bhaṅgya-śravas'''</u> is the name of a man in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_358> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78.</ref>

भजे-रथ
<u>'''Bhaje-ratha'''</u> is mentioned in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_359> x. 60, 2.</ref> where Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_359> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138, 165.</ref> thinks a place-name is meant. Griffith<ref name=fx3_ve2_359> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 463.</ref> is doubtful whether the word is the name of a place or a man. Roth<ref name=fx4_ve2_359> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> was inclined to see a corruption of the text.<ref name=fx5_ve2_359> Grassmann, ''Wo7rterbuch, s.v.,'' thinks that the compound should be read as two words: ''bhaje rathasya (satpatim),'' ‘to win (the lord) of the car.’</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Bhagīratha.'''

भद्र-पदा
<u>'''Bhadra-padā.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

भद्र-सेन आजातशत्रव
<u>'''Bhadra-sena Ājātaśatrava'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अजातशत्रु|Ajātaśatru]]'''’) is the name of a man, presumably a prince, whom '''Uddālaka''' is said in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 5, 5, 14) to have bewitched.<br>==Foot Notes==

भय-द आसमात्य
<u>'''Bhaya-da Āsamātya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Asamāti'''’) is the name of a king in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_362> iv. 8, 7.</ref> Oertel,<ref name=fx2_ve2_362> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 247.</ref> however, seems to take the name as Abhayada, but this is not probable, for Bhayada is a name in the Purāṇas.

भयमान
<u>'''Bhayamāna'''</u> is, according to Sāyaṇa, the name of a man in one hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_363> i. 100, 17. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 266.</ref> which is ascribed by the Anukramaṇī (Index) to his authorship. The interpretation is, however, uncertain.

भरत
<u>'''Bharata'''</u> is the name of a people of great importance in the Rigveda and the later literature. In the Rigveda they appear prominently in the third and seventh Maṇḍalas in connexion  with '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' and the '''Tṛtsus,'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_364> iii. 53, 9. 12, 24;<br> 33, 11, 12 (Viśvā [[मित्र|mitra]], who is accordingly hailed as ''[[भरत|Bharata]]-[[ऋषभ|ṛṣabha]],'' ‘bull of the Bharatas,’ in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17, 7);<br> vii. 8, 4;<br> 33, 6, in which passage a defeat of the Bharatas, and their rescue by the aid of [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], is clearly referred to;<br> not, as was formerly thought (''e.g.,'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 354;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 127), a defeat of the Bharatas by the Tṛtsus.</ref> while in the sixth Maṇḍala they are associated with '''Divodāsa.'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_364> vi. 16, 4. 5. ''Cf.'' verse 19.</ref> In one passage<ref name=fx3_ve2_364> vii. 8, 4.</ref> the Bharatas are, like the Tṛtsus, enemies of the '''Pūrus:''' there can be little doubt that Ludwig's view of the identity of the Bharatas and and Tṛtsus is practically correct. More precisely Oldenberg<ref name=fx5_ve2_364> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 207. In ''Buddha,'' 405 ''et seq.,'' he accepted the identification of Ludwig.</ref> considers that the Tṛtsus are the '''Vasiṣṭhas,''' the family singers of the Bharatas; while Geldner<ref name=fx6_ve2_364> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 136 ''et seq.''</ref> recognizes, with perhaps more probability, in the Tṛtsus the royal family of the Bharatas. That the Tṛtsus and Bharatas were enemies, as Zimmer<ref name=fx7_ve2_364> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 127. This is also Bloomfield's view (see ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 41, 42).</ref> holds, is most improbable even on geographical grounds, for the Tṛtsus in Zimmer's view<ref name=fx8_ve2_364> ''Op. cit.,'' 124.</ref> occupied the country to the east of the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]]''' (Ravi), and the Bharatas must therefore be regarded as coming against the Tṛtsus from the west, whereas the Rigveda<ref name=fx9_ve2_364> iii. 23, 4: in verse 2 '''Devasravas''' and '''[[देववात|Devavāta]]''' are mentioned as Bhāratas, Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 410, n., mentions that in the Mahābhārata, iii. 6065, a tributary of the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] is called Kauśikī, and the Kuśikas are, of course, the family of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]], whose connexion with the Bharatas is beyond question.</ref> recognizes two [[भरत|Bharata]] chiefs on the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], [[आपया|Āpayā]],''' and '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]]'''--that is, in the holy land of India, the '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]].''' Hillebrandt<ref name=fx10_ve2_364> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 111. His view is that [[सुदास्|Sudās]] and the Bharatas were later comers than the Tṛtsus, who joined them as one people, the Vasiṣṭhas becoming the priests of the Bharatas. He suggests that the Vasiṣṭhas were not originally adherents of the IndraSoma cult, but were specially devoted to the Varuṇa cult;<br> but there is no decisive evidence for either suggestion. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, as cited in n. 7.</ref> sees in the connexion of the Tṛtsus and the Bharatas a fusion of two tribes; but this is not supported by any evidence beyond the fact that in his opinion some such theory is needed to explain Divodāsa's appearing in connexion with the '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]''' family, while [[सुदास्|Sudās]], his son,<br><br>^4 Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 172 ''et seq.''  or perhaps grandson (''cf.'' '''[[पिजवन|Pijavana]]'''), is connected with the Vasiṣṭhas and the '''Viśvāmitras.'''<br><br>In the later literature the Bharatas appear as especially famous. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx11_ve2_364> xiii. 5, 4.</ref> mentions [[भरत|Bharata]] [[दौःषन्ति|Dauḥṣanti]] as a king, sacrificer of the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) and '''[[शतानीक सात्राजित|Śatānīka Sātrājita]],''' as another [[भरत|Bharata]] who offered that sacrifice. The [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx12_ve2_364> viii. 23 and 21.</ref> mentions [[भरत|Bharata]] [[दौःषन्ति|Dauḥṣanti]] as receiving the kingly coronation from '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]] [[मामतेय|Māmateya]],''' and Śatānīka as being consecrated by '''[[सोमशुष्मन् वाजरत्नायन|Somaśuṣman Vājaratnāyana]],''' a priest whose name is of quite late origin. The geographical position of the [[भरत|Bharata]] people is clearly shown by the fact that the [[भरत|Bharata]] kings win victories over the '''Kāśis,''' and make offerings on the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' (Jumna) and '''[[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]]''' (Ganges).<ref name=fx13_ve2_364> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 11. 21.</ref> Moreover, in the formula of the king's proclamation for the people, the variants recorded<ref name=fx14_ve2_364> In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 10, 2, and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 4, 2, the phrase is ''eṣa vo, Bharatā, rājā;<br>'' the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension, xi. 3, 3;<br> 6, 3, has ''Kuravaḥ, Pañcālāḥ'' (evidently as a joint people);<br> Āpastamba, xviii. 12, 7, gives ''Bharatāḥ, Kuravaḥ, Pañcālāḥ, Kuru-Pañcālāḥ,'' and ''janatāḥ,'' as alternatives, according to the people to whom the king belongs;<br> the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 7, and the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 7, read ''esa te janate rājā.'' See Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 114, n.;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 465.</ref> include ''Kuravaḥ, Pañcālāḥ, Kuru-Pañcālāḥ,'' and ''Bharatāḥ;'' and the Mahābhārata consistently recognizes the royal family of the '''Kurus''' as a [[भरत|Bharata]] family.<ref name=fx15_ve2_364> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 409.</ref> It is therefore extremely probable that Oldenberg<ref name=fx16_ve2_364> ''Op. cit.,'' 408. He points out (409, n.) that in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, only the Kuru king. '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]],''' and the [[भरत|Bharata]] kings are mentioned without specification of the peoples over whom they ruled.</ref> is right in holding that the Bharatas in the times of the Brāhmaṇas were merging in the Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] people.<br><br>The ritual practices of the Bharatas are repeatedly mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx17_ve2_364> xiv. 3, 13;<br> xv. 5, 24, and perhaps xviii. 10, 8, on which see Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 28, n. 2;<br> below, p. 98.</ref> the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx18_ve2_364> ii. 25;<br> iii. 18. The sense ‘mercenary soldier,’ here seen by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2 (no longer mentioned in the Dictionary of Bo7htlingk), cannot be accepted. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 254;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 407, n. On the other hand, there is no mention of the Bharatas in the geographical lists of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 14). in the [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra, or in the Buddhist texts. This means that the Bharatas were no longer a people, but a family or sub-tribe in a larger people.</ref> the  Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx19_ve2_364> v. 4, 4, 1.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx20_ve2_364> i. 27, 2.</ref> Already in the Rigveda<ref name=fx21_ve2_364> ii. 7, 1. 5;<br> iv. 25, 4;<br> vi. 16, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 9, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 2, 2. Roth thinks this epithet of Agni perhaps means ‘warlike,’ but this is unlikely.</ref> there is mention made of Agni [[भारत|Bhārata]] (‘of the Bharatas’). In the Āprī hymns<ref name=fx22_ve2_364> Rv. i. 22, 10;<br> 142, 9;<br> 188, 8;<br> ii. 1, 11;<br> 3, 8;<br> iii. 4, 8, etc.</ref> occurs a goddess Bhāratī, the personified divine protective power of the Bharatas: her association in the hymns with [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] reflects the connexion of the Bharatas with the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx9_ve2_364/> Again, in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx23_ve2_364> i. 4, 2, 2.</ref> Agni is referred to as ''[[ब्राह्मण|brāhmaṇa]] [[भारत|Bhārata]],'' ‘priest of the Bharatas,’ and is invited to dispose of the offering ''Manuṣvat Bharatavat,'' ‘like Manu,’ ‘like [[भरत|Bharata]].’<ref name=fx24_ve2_364> i. 5, 1, 7.</ref><br><br>In one or two passages<ref name=fx25_ve2_364> i. 112, 14;<br> vii. 19, 8.</ref> [[सुदास्|Sudās]] or Divodāsa and, on the other hand, [[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]] or [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] appear in a friendly relation. Possibly this points, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx26_ve2_364> ''Op. cit.,'' 410.</ref> suggests, to the union of Bharatas and Pūrus with the Kurus.<br><br>A [[भरत|Bharata]] is referred to in the fifth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda:<ref name=fx27_ve2_364> v. 54, 14.<br><br>For a later legend of [[भरत|Bharata]], ''cf.'' Leumann, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 80 ''et seq.;<br>'' von Bradke, ''ibid.,'' 498-503;<br> and see Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 13, 338, 340, etc.</ref> who he was is uncertain.

भरद्-वाज
<u>'''Bharad-vāja'''</u> is the name of the reputed<ref name=fx1_ve2_365> ''Cf.'' Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, v. 102 ''et seq.,'' where he is said to be a son of [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]], and a grandson of [[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]] (''cf.'' Rv. vi. 2, 10;<br> 11, 3, etc.);<br> Arnold, ''Vedic Metre,'' 61, 62.</ref> author of the sixth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda. The attribution is so far correct that [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_365> Rv. vi. 15, 3;<br> 16, 5. 33;<br> 17, 4;<br> 31, 4;<br> 48, 7. 13;<br> 63, 10;<br> 65, 6. See also Rv. i. 112, 13;<br> 116, 18;<br> x. 150, 5;<br> 181, 2.</ref> and the Bharadvājas<ref name=fx3_ve2_365> Rv. vi. 10, 6;<br> 16, 33;<br> 17, 14;<br> 23, 10;<br> 25, 9;<br> 35, 4;<br> 47, 25;<br> 59, 15. See also Rv. i. 59, 7.</ref> are repeatedly mentioned as singers in that Maṇḍala. Judging by the tone of the references to [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]], he can hardly be deemed to have been a contemporary of any of the hymns.<ref name=fx4_ve2_365> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 210 212.</ref> According to the Pañcaviṃśa  [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_365> xv. 3, 7.</ref> he was the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of '''Divodāsa.''' This interpretation is to be preferred to that of Roth,<ref name=fx6_ve2_365> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' See Rv. i. 116, 18;<br> vi. 16, 5;<br> 31, 4.</ref> who suggests that he and Divodāsa were identical. His connexion with the house of Divodāsa also appears from the statement of the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx7_ve2_365> xxi. 10 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 478).</ref> that [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]] gave '''[[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]]''' the kingdom. It is unnecessary to suppose that the same [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]] was meant in both cases, and that [[प्रतर्दन|Pratardana]] was a son of Divodāsa: the later Saṃhitās refer to [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]], like the other great sages, irrespective of chronology.<br><br>The Bharadvājas in their poems mention '''[[बृबु|Bṛbu]], [[बृसय|Bṛsaya]],''' and the '''Pārāvatas.'''<ref name=fx8_ve2_365> vi. 61, 1-3.</ref> Hillebrandt<ref name=fx9_ve2_365> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 104.</ref> has pointed out that they are also connected with the '''Sṛñjayas.''' In particular, the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx10_ve2_365> xvi. 11, 11.</ref> mentions that [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]] gained largesse from '''[[प्रस्तोक|Prastoka]] [[सार्ञ्जय|Sārñjaya]]''' and [[बृबु|Bṛbu]]. But it is very doubtful if it is correct to place all these people and Divodāsa in Arachosia and Drangiana.<br><br>[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]] as an author and a seer is frequently referred to in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx11_ve2_365> Av. ii. 12, 2;<br> iv. 29, 5;<br> xviii. 3, 16;<br> xix. 48, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 19;<br> xx. 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 19;<br> iv. 8, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 55, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx12_ve2_365> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 18;<br> viii. 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 11, 13;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 2, 2;<br> 4, 2;<br> ii. 2, 2. 4, etc.;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 1;<br> xxix. 3;<br> xxx. 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 128;<br> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 31.</ref>

भरन्त्
<u>'''Bharant,'''</u> ‘bearing,’ in the plural denotes in one passage of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_366> xviii. 10, 8.</ref> according to Bo7htlingk,<ref name=fx2_ve2_366> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> following Sāyaṇa, ‘the warrior caste,’ but the sense is not certain. Weber<ref name=fx3_ve2_366> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 28, n. 2. ''Cf.'' '''[[भरत|Bharata]],''' n. 17.</ref> was inclined to see a reference to the Bharatas, though the form of the word is that of the present participle.<ref name=fx4_ve2_366> ''Bharatām,'' interpreted by Sāyaṇa as ''bharaṇaṃ kurvatām kṣatriyāṇām.''</ref>

भरूजी
<u>'''Bharūjī'''</u> in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_367> ii. 24. 8.</ref> may denote, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_367> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> a noxious animal. 

भर्तृ
<u>'''Bhartṛ,'''</u> besides having the literal sense of ‘bearer,’ means ‘supporter’ or ‘master’ in the older literature;<ref name=fx1_ve2_368> Av. xi. 7, 15;<br> xviii. 2, 30;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 4, 7 (where ‘husband’ is possible);<br> iv. 6, 7, 21, etc.</ref> but it is doubtful whether the sense of ‘husband’ is ever found there. In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_368> v. 58, 7.</ref> ‘husband’ is certainly the most natural sense, but, as Delbrück<ref name=fx3_ve2_368> ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 415, n. 1.</ref> correctly remarks, even there ‘father’ may be meant, since ‘mother’ is here and there<ref name=fx4_ve2_368> Av. v. 5, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 1, 4.</ref> called Bhartrī.

भलानस्
<u>'''Bhalānas,'''</u> plural, is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_369> vii. 18, 7.</ref> of one of the five tribes, '''Pakthas,''' Bhalānases, '''Alinas, Viṣāṇins,''' and '''Śivas,''' who are mentioned as ranged on the side<ref name=fx2_ve2_369> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 260, 261, who takes the form of the name to be Bhalāna (but the text of the Rv. has ''bhalāna¤saḥ''), and who overlooks Zimmer's later view.</ref> of the enemies of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' in the battle of the ten kings ('''[[दाशराज्ञ|Dāśarājña]]'''), not opposed to them, as Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve2_369> ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 95.</ref> and at one time Zimmer,<ref name=fx4_ve2_369> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 126.</ref> thought. Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_369> ''Op. cit.,'' 431. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173, 207.</ref> suggests as their original home East Kabulistan, comparing the name of the Bolan pass. This seems a reasonably probable view.

भव-त्रात शायस्थि
<u>'''Bhava-trāta Śāyasthi'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_370> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 443.</ref>

भस्त्रा
<u>'''Bhastrā'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 1, 2, 7; 6, 3, 16) denotes a leathern bottle or pouch.<br>==Foot Notes==

भाकुरि
<u>'''Bhākuri.'''</u> See '''[[बेकुरा|Bekurā]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

भाग-दुघ
<u>'''Bhāga-dugha,'''</u> ‘dealer out of portions,’ ‘distributor,’ is the name of one of the king's ‘jewels’ ('''[[रत्निन्|Ratnin]]''') in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_373> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5;<br> iv. 3, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 13.</ref> and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_373> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 5;<br> iii. 4, 8, 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 17;<br> v. 3, 1, 9.</ref> What his functions exactly were is uncertain. Sāyaṇa in some places<ref name=fx3_ve2_373> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.,'' and on Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 9.</ref> renders the word by ‘tax-collector’ but in others<ref name=fx4_ve2_373> On Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 2, 17.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 63, n.</ref> as ‘carver,’ thus making this functionary either a revenue officer or a mere court official.

भाग-वित्ति
<u>'''Bhāga-vitti'''</u> (‘descendant of Bhagavitta’) is the patronymic of a teacher called Cūḍa<ref name=fx1_ve2_374> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 17, 18 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> or Cūla<ref name=fx2_ve2_374> ''Ibid.,'' vi. 3, 9 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].

भाडितायन
<u>'''Bhāḍitāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Bhaḍita,’ is the patronymic of '''Śākadāsa''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_375> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

भानुमन्त् औपमन्यव
<u>'''Bhānumant Aupamanyava'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[उपमन्यु|Upamanyu]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Ānandaja,''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_376> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

भाय-जात्य
<u>'''Bhāya-jātya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Bhayajāta,’ is the patronymic of '''Nikothaka''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_377> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 444.</ref>

भारत
<u>'''Bhārata.'''</u> See '''[[भरत|Bharata]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

भारद्-वाज
<u>'''Bhārad-vāja,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]],'''’ is the patronymic of many teachers. In the Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], Bhāradvājas are mentioned as  pupils of [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_379> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> '''[[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_379> ii. 6, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> '''Balākākauśika,'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_379> iv. 5, 27 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> '''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]],'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_379> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> '''[[आसुरायण|Āsurāyaṇa]],'''<ref name=fx5_ve2_379> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> and '''[[बैजवापायन|Baijavāpāyana]].'''<ref name=fx6_ve2_379> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> A [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]] occurs in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx7_ve2_379> v. 61, 2.</ref> and '''[[शूष वाह्नेय|Śūṣa Vāhneya]]''' is mentioned as a [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]] in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx8_ve2_379> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

भारद्वाजायन
<u>'''Bhāradvājāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]],'''’ is the patronymic of a teacher in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_380> x. 12, 1;<br> [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 9. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 61, n. 2.</ref>

भारद्वाजी-पुत्र
<u>'''Bhāradvājī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]],'''’ is the metronymic of several teachers in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], pupils of '''Pāraśarīputra,'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_381> vi. 4, 31 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> '''[[पैङ्गीपुत्र|Paiṅgīputra]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_381> vi. 4, 30 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> and '''[[वात्सीमाण्डवीपुत्र|Vātsīmāṇḍavīputra]]'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_381> ''Ibid.''</ref> respectively.

भार्गव
<u>'''Bhārgava,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[भृगु|Bhṛgu]],'''’ is the patronymic of several teachers, including '''[[च्यवन|Cyavana]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_382> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. viii. 21.</ref> and '''[[गृत्समद|Gṛtsamada]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_382> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxii. 4 (with a ''varia lectio,'' [[बाभ्रव|Bābhrava]]).</ref> Other Bhārgavas are also mentioned without dication of their personal names.<ref name=fx3_ve2_382> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 18, 1;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, vii. 15;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 2, 1. 5;<br> [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] Upanisad, i. 1 ([[वैदर्भि|Vaidarbhi]]), etc.;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 2, 23;<br> 9, 19, 39, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xxxv.</ref>

भार्गायण
<u>'''Bhārgāyaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of Bharga,’ is the patronymic of '''Sutvan''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 28).<br>==Foot Notes==

भार्म्य्-अश्व
<u>'''Bhārmy-aśva,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[भृम्य्अश्व|Bhṛmyaśva]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[मुद्गल|Mudgala]]''' in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (ix. 23) and the Brhaddevatā (vi. 46; viii. 12). <br>==Foot Notes==

भार्या
<u>'''Bhāryā,'''</u> later a common expression for ‘wife,’ does not occur in that sense at all in the Saṃhitās. It first appears, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_385> vii. 9. 8.</ref> where, however, Delbrück<ref name=fx2_ve2_385> ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 415. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 29, 20.</ref> suggests that merely a member of the household (‘who is to be maintained’) may be meant. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_385> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 5, 1.</ref> however, the two wives of [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] are so designated.

भालन्दन
<u>'''Bhālandana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Bhalandana,’ is the patronymic of '''Vatsaprī''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,’ the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_386> xix. 11.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_386> xii. 11, 25;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 59.</ref><br><br>^1 v. 2, 1, 6.

भालुकी-पुत्र
<u>'''Bhālukī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of Bhālukī,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[क्रौञ्चिकीपुत्र|Krauñcikīputra]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_387> vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> or of '''[[प्राचीनयोगीपुत्र|Prācīnayogīputra]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_387> vi. 4, 32 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].

भाल्ल
<u>'''Bhālla'''</u> is the name or patronymic of a teacher who bears the patronymic [[प्रातृद|Prātṛda]] in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 31, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

भाल्लवि
<u>'''Bhāllavi'''</u> is the name of a school mentioned as authorities in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 2, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

भाल्लविन्
<u>'''Bhāllavin,'''</u> ‘pupil of Bhallavin,’ is the name of a school of teachers mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_390> ii. 4, 7 (spelt Bhāllabin). ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 44;<br> 2, 100;<br> 390;<br> [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 1;<br> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 1;<br> vii. 12;<br> Bṛhaddevatā v. 23. 159.</ref> 

भाल्लवेय
<u>'''Bhāllaveya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[भाल्लवि|Bhāllavi]],'''’<ref name=fx1_ve2_391> x. 6, 1, 1.</ref> is the patronymic of '''Indradyumna''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_391/> and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_391> v. 11, 1.</ref> Probably the same person is meant by the [[भाल्लवेय|Bhāllaveya]], who is cited frequently as an authority in the same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_391> i. 7, 3, 19;<br> ii. 1, 4, 6;<br> xiii. 4, 2, 3;<br> 5, 3, 4.</ref>

भावयव्य
<u>'''Bhāvayavya.'''</u> See '''[[भाव्य|Bhāvya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

भाव्य
<u>'''Bhāvya'''</u> is the name of a patron, as it seems, in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_393> i. 126, 1;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 10.</ref> In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_393> xvi. 11, 5. ''Cf.'' Bṛhaddevatā, iii. 140.</ref> the form given is [[भावयव्य|Bhāvayavya]], being a patronymic of '''Svanaya,''' who is the patron of '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]].''' This combination is borne out by the Rigveda, where [[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]] and Svanaya are mentioned in the same verse,<ref name=fx3_ve2_393> i. 126, 3.</ref> while Svanaya must be meant in the verse of the same hymn,<ref name=fx4_ve2_393> i. 126, 1.</ref> where [[भाव्य|Bhāvya]] is mentioned as ‘living on the Sindhu’ (Indus). Roth's<ref name=fx5_ve2_393> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1 f.</ref> view that [[भाव्य|Bhāvya]] here is perhaps a gerundive meaning to be ‘reverenced’ is not probable. Ludwig<ref name=fx6_ve2_393> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 151.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im Vedischen Ritual,'' 22;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 128.</ref> thinks Svanaya was connected with the '''Nahuṣas.'''

भाषा
<u>'''Bhāṣā'''</u> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_394> i. 4, 5. ''Cf.'' ii. 2.</ref> and Pāṇini<ref name=fx2_ve2_394> iii. 2, 108;<br> vi. 1, 181. ''Cf.'' Franke, Bezzenberger's ''Beiträge,'' 17, 54 ''et seq.,'' who distinguishes the [[भाषा|Bhāṣā]] as the speech of conversational use from the language regulated by Pāṇini's rules. But see Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, xliv;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 179, 180.</ref> denotes the ordinary speech of the day as opposed to Vedic language. ''Cf.'' '''[[वाच्|Vāc]].'''

भास
<u>'''Bhāsa'''</u> is the name of a bird of prey in the Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_395> vi. 8, See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40.</ref> and often in the Epic. 

भिक्षा
<u>'''Bhikṣā,'''</u> ‘begging,’ is one of the duties of the '''Brahmacārin''' according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_396> xi. 3, 3, 7. ''Cf.'' a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 9, etc.;<br> and ''bhikṣācarya,'' Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 4, 26.</ref> The word has also the sense of ‘alms,’ as that which is obtained by begging, in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_396> xi. 5, 9.</ref> According to the St. Petersburg Dictionary,<ref name=fx3_ve2_396> ''s.v.'' 2.</ref> it has this sense in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_396> viii. 8, 5, where the scholiast explains the word by ‘perfumes, garlands, food,’ etc. (''gandhamālyānnādi'').</ref> also, but the correct reading there is probably '''[[आमिक्षा|Āmikṣā]].'''

भिक्षु
<u>'''Bhikṣu,'''</u> ‘beggar,’ is a term not found in Vedic literature. The begging of the '''Brahmacārin''' is quite a different thing from the duties of the [[भिक्षु|Bhikṣu]] in the later system of the Āśramas (religious stages of life), when the Brahmin in the last stage of his life, after leaving his home and family, lives on alms alone. See 1. '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

भित्ति
<u>'''Bhitti'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_398> iii. 5, 3, 9. ''Cf.'' Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 3, 24.</ref> denotes a mat made of split reeds.

भिषज्
<u>'''Bhiṣaj,'''</u> ‘physician,’ is a word of common occurrence in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_399> ii. 33, 4;<br> vi. 50, 7;<br> ix. 112, 1;<br> ''[[भेषज|bheṣaja]],'' adjective, ii. 33, 7;<br> x. 137, 6;<br> substantive, i. 23, 19. 20;<br> ii. 33, 2. 4;<br> vi. 74, 3;<br> vii. 46, 3, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_399> Av. v. 29, 1;<br> vi. 24, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 9, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 5;<br> xix. 12. 88;<br> xxx. 10, etc.;<br> ''[[भेषज|bheṣaja]],'' adjective, Av. vi. 109, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 45, etc.;<br> substantive, Av. v. 29, 1;<br> vi. 21, 2;<br> xi. 1, 9, etc.</ref> There is no trace whatever in the former text of the profession being held in disrepute: the Aśvins,<ref name=fx3_ve2_399> Rv. i. 116, 16;<br> 157, 6;<br> viii. 18, 8;<br> 86, 1;<br> x. 39, 3. 5;<br> Av. vii. 53, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 18.</ref> Varuṇa,<ref name=fx4_ve2_399> See Rv. i. 24, 9.</ref> and Rudra<ref name=fx5_ve2_399> Rv. ii. 33, 4. 7.</ref> are all called physicians. On the other hand, in the [[धर्म|Dharma]] literature<ref name=fx6_ve2_399> See Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 6, 18, 20;<br> 19, 15;<br> [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 17;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 2, 19;<br> Viṣṇu, li. 10;<br> lxxxii. 9;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 1.</ref> this profession is utterly  despised. This dislike is found as early as the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx7_ve2_399> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 9, 3. ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 14;<br> Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' xxxix, xl.</ref> where the Aśvins are condemned because of their having to do with the practice of medicine (''[[भेषज|bheṣaja]]''), on the ground that it brings them too much among men, an allusion to the caste dislike of promiscuous contact.<br><br>The Rigveda<ref name=fx8_ve2_399> x. 97.</ref> contains a hymn in which a physician celebrates his plants and their healing powers. Moreover, wonderful cures are referred to as performed by the Aśvins: the healing of the lame<ref name=fx9_ve2_399> Rv. i. 112, 8;<br> x. 39, 3, etc.</ref> and of the blind;<ref name=fx10_ve2_399> ''Cf.'' the case of [[ऋज्राश्व|Ṛjrāśva]], Rv. i. 116, 17.</ref> the rejuvenation of the aged '''[[च्यवन|Cyavana]]'''<ref name=fx11_ve2_399> Rv. x. 39, 4.</ref> and of '''Puraṃdhi's''' husband;<ref name=fx12_ve2_399> i. 116, 13.</ref> the giving of an iron leg (''jaṅghā āyasī'') to '''[[विश्पला|Viśpalā]],'''<ref name=fx13_ve2_399> Rv. i. 116, 15, etc.</ref> a deed only more wonderful if we assume that [[विश्पला|Viśpalā]] was a mare, as has been suggested by Pischel.<ref name=fx14_ve2_399> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 171 ''et seq.;<br>'' 305.</ref> It would in all probability be a mistake to assume<ref name=fx15_ve2_399> As Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 398, is inclined to do.</ref> that the Vedic Indians had any surgical skill: they no doubt applied simples to wounds,<ref name=fx16_ve2_399> ''Cf.'' Rv. ix. 112, 1.</ref> but both their medicien and their surgery must have been most primitive. All that the Atharvaveda shows in regard to medicine is the use of herbs combined with spells,<ref name=fx17_ve2_399> So it is said in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 9, 10: ''bheṣajaṃ vā Ātharvaṇāni,'' ‘the [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] hymns are medicine’;<br> xvi. 10, 10;<br> and ''cf. ibid.,'' xxiii. 16, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 5 and 2. '''[[भिषज्|Bhiṣaj]].'''</ref> and of water (''cf.'' '''Jalāṣa'''), remedies Indo-European in character, but not of much scientific value. On the other hand, the knowledge of anatomy shown (see '''[[शरीर|Śarīra]]'''), though betraying grave inaccuracies, is not altogether insignificant; but that was due no doubt mainly to the practice of dissecting animals at the sacrifice.<br><br>There is some evidence in the Rigveda<ref name=fx18_ve2_399> ix. 112, where a profession must be meant. ''Ibid.,'' 3, refers to the fees of the physician. ''Cf.'' also x. 97, 4. 8.</ref> that the practice of medicine was already a profession; this is supported by the inclusion of a physician in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx19_ve2_399> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 4, 1.</ref> According to  Bloomfield,<ref name=fx20_ve2_399> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 456.</ref> a hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx21_ve2_399> v. 30, 5. But this sense is doubtful. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 277.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 397-399;<br> Bloomfield, ''op. cit., passim'' (see references on p. 697);<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 59 ''et seq.;<br>'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 420 ''et seq.;<br>'' Jolly, ''Medicin,'' 16, 17;<br> Winternitz, ''Nature,'' 1898, 233-235;<br> Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual, passim.''</ref> contains a physician's deprecation of the use of home-made remedies instead of reliance on his professional training.

भिषज् आथर्वण
<u>'''2. Bhiṣaj Ātharvaṇa'''</u> is the name of a mythic physician mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_400> xvi. 3 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 459). ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xxi;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 181.</ref>

भीम वैदर्भ
<u>'''Bhīma Vaidarbha'''</u> (‘prince of Vidarbha’) is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 34) as having received instruction regarding the substitute for the Soma juice, through a succession of teachers, from '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]''' and '''[[नारद|Nārada]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

भीम-सेन
<u>'''Bhīma-sena'''</u> is the name of one of the brothers of '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]],''' the '''Pārikṣitīyas,''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_402> xiii. 5, 4, 3. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 9, 3.</ref>

भुज्यु
<u>'''1. Bhujyu'''</u> denotes, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, an ‘adder’ in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_403> iv. 27, 4;<br> x. 95, 8.</ref> and one of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_403> xviii. 42.<br><br>''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 126, who takes ''[[भुज्यु|bhujyu]]'' in Rv. x. 95, 8, as meaning ‘ardent,’ ‘rutting.’</ref> But the sense is uncertain in all these passages.

भुज्यु
<u>'''2. Bhujyu'''</u> is the name of a man, son of '''[[तुग्र|Tugra]],''' who is repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_404> i. 112, 6, 20;<br> 116, 3;<br> 117, 14;<br> 119, 4;<br> vi. 62, 6;<br> vii. 68, 7;<br> 69, 7;<br> x. 40, 7;<br> 65, 12;<br> 143, 5.</ref> as saved from the deep by the Aśvins. According to Bühler,<ref name=fx2_ve2_404> ''Indische Palœographie,'' 17.<br><br>''Cf.'' Baunack, Kuhn's ''Zeitschrift,'' 35, 485;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 214;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 16, n. 5;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 244, 245;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 52.</ref> the passages refer to  [[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]] being saved from shipwreck during a voyage in the Indian Ocean, but the evidence is inadequate to support this conclusion. ''Cf.'' '''[[सम्उद्र|Samudra]].'''

भुज्यु लाह्यायनि
<u>'''Bhujyu Lāhyāyani'''</u> (‘descendant of Lahyāyana’) is the name of a teacher, a contemporary of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]],''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 3, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

भुरिज्
<u>'''Bhurij'''</u> (used in the dual only) is a word of somewhat doubtful sense. Roth<ref name=fx1_ve2_406> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 466.</ref> regarded it as meaning in some passages<ref name=fx2_ve2_406> Rv. viii. 4, 16;<br> Av. xx. 127, 4.</ref> ‘scissors,’ and in others<ref name=fx3_ve2_406> Rv. iv. 2, 14;<br> ix. 26, 4;<br> 71, 5. where Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 239243, considers that the shafts of the chariot are meant (''cf.'' Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 31, whence it appears that the chariot-pole, spoken of as having two arms, was forked). The same view regarding the passages cited in n. 2 gives the sense of a stropping apparatus, consisting of two pieces of wood, between which a grindstone moves.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 252, 255.</ref> an apparatus consisting of two arms used by the chariot-maker for fixing the wood at which he worked, being of the nature of a carpenter's vice. See also '''Ksura'''

भूत-विद्या
<u>'''Bhūta-vidyā'''</u> is one of the sciences enumerated in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_407> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1. ''Cf.'' Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 115.</ref> It seems to mean the ‘science of creatures’ that trouble men, and of the means of warding them off, ‘demonology.’

भूत-वीर
<u>'''Bhūta-vīra'''</u> is the name of a family of priests who, according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_408> vii. 27. ''Cf.'' Roth, ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 118;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 344, n. 3;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 437 ''et seq.''</ref> were employed by '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]]''' to the exclusion of the '''Kaśyapas.''' A family of the latter, the '''Asitamṛgas,''' however, won back the favour of [[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]], and ousted the Bhūtavīras. 

भूतांश
<u>'''Bhūtāṃśa'''</u> is in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_409> x. 106, 11. See [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xii, 41;<br> Bṛhaddevatā. viii. 18. 19;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133.</ref> the name of a poet, a descendant of [[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]].

भूति
<u>'''Bhūti'''</u> is the term used in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_410> viii. 59, 7. ''Cf.'' i. 161, 1 (both late passages).</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_410> Av. ix. 6, 45;<br> x. 3, 17;<br> 6, 9;<br> xi. 7, 22;<br> 8, 21;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 1;<br> 3, 5, etc.;<br> ''[[भूति|bhūti]]-kāma,'' ‘desiring prosperity,’ [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 1, 1;<br> 2, 3, 3;<br> v. 1, 9, 1, etc.</ref> for ‘prosperity.’

भूमि
<u>'''Bhūmi'''</u> or '''Bhūmī''' is a common word for ‘earth’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_411> i. 64, 5;<br> 161, 14;<br> ii. 14, 7, etc. So in x. 18, 10, ‘mother earth’ receives the remains of the dead.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_411> Av. vi. 2, 1, where it is said that the [[भूमि|Bhūmi]] is the highest of the three earths ([[पृथिवी|Pṛthivī]]);<br> xi. 7, 14, where nine earths and seas are mentioned;<br> ii. 9, 4;<br> vi. 8, 2, etc.</ref> being practically a synonym of '''[[पृथिवी|Pṛthivī]].''' It is also used of the land given by the god to the Āryan,<ref name=fx3_ve2_411> Rv. iv. 26, 2. ''Cf.'' vi. 47, 20.</ref> and of grants of land.<ref name=fx4_ve2_411> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 24;<br> 6, 2, 18.</ref>

भूमि-दुन्दुभि
<u>'''Bhūmi-dundubhi,'''</u> ‘earth drum,’ denotes a pit covered with a hide used at the Mahāvrata rite, and mentioned in the Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_412> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 9, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_412> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 19;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 1, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 277, n. 14.</ref>

भूमि-पाश
<u>'''Bhūmi-pāśa,'''</u> ‘earth net,’ is the name of a plant in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], probably some sort of creeper.<br><br>^1 xiii. 8, 1, 16. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 427, n. 1.<br>==Foot Notes==

भृगवाण
<u>'''Bhṛgavāṇa'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_414> i. 120, 5.</ref> apparently<ref name=fx2_ve2_414> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' i. 4;<br> 2, 92.</ref> as a name of a man who is called '''Śobha.''' Ludwig,<ref name=fx3_ve2_414> ''Über Methode bei Interpretation,'' 4.</ref> however, thinks that his name was '''[[घोष|Ghoṣa]].''' Elsewhere the word appears as an epithet of Agni, doubtless in allusion to his cult by the '''Bhṛgus.''' 

भृगु
<u>'''Bhṛgu'''</u> is a sage of almost entirely mythical character in the Rigveda and later. He counts as a son of Varuṇa,<ref name=fx1_ve2_415> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 1, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ix. 1. ''Cf.'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 9, 2;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 17.</ref> bearing the patronymic [[वारुणि|Vāruṇi]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_415> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 34, and n. 14. For a different form of the legend, ''cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 5.</ref> In the plural the Bhṛgus are repeatedly<ref name=fx3_ve2_415> Rv. i. 58, 6;<br> 127, 7;<br> 143, 4;<br> ii. 4, 2;<br> iii. 2, 4;<br> iv. 7, 1, etc. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 51. The legend of their chariot-making (Rv. iv. 16, 20;<br> x. 39, 14) may be due, as Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' suggests, to a confusion with the Ṛbhus. It may, however, be an allusion to the historic Bhṛgus, whom we find in the battle of the ten kings.</ref> alluded to as devoted to the fire cult. They are clearly<ref name=fx4_ve2_415> As shown by the legend of fire having been brought to them by [[मातरिश्वन्|Mātariśvan]], Rv. iii. 5, 10.</ref> no more than a group of ancient priests and ancestors with an eponymous [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_415> i. 60, 1, where, however, Roth, ''loc. cit.,'' takes the singular in a collective sense, an interpretation which may be correct, but is not necessary.</ref> in the Rigveda, except in three passages,<ref name=fx6_ve2_415> Rv. vii. 18, 6;<br> viii. 3, 9;<br> 6, 18, to which list, given by Macdonell, ''loc. cit.,'' Roth adds viii. 102, 4, ''[[और्व|Aurva]]-[[भृगु|Bhṛgu]]-vat,'' ‘like [[और्व|Aurva]] and [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]].’ ''Cf.'' the fact that the '''Aurvas,''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 33, take the place of the Bhṛgus of the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5.</ref> where they are evidently regarded as an historic family. It is not clear, however, whether they were priests or warriors: in the battle of the ten kings the Bhṛgus appear with the '''Druhyus,''' perhaps as their priests, but this is not certain.<ref name=fx7_ve2_415> In viii. 3, 9;<br> 6, 18;<br> 102, 4, the reference to a priestly family is the more natural;<br> in vii. 18, 6, warriors may be meant. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 262, n., where he cites ix. 101, 13, as perhaps denoting the same thing.</ref><br><br>In the later literature the Bhṛgus are a real family, with subdivisions like the '''Aitaśāyana,''' according to the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx8_ve2_415> xxx. 5. See n. 6.</ref> The Bhṛgus are mentioned as priests in connexion with various rites, such as the Agnisthāpana<ref name=fx9_ve2_415> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 5, 2;<br> v. 6, 8, 6;<br> Av. iv. 14, 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 1 (p. 48).</ref> and the Daśapeyakratu.<ref name=fx10_ve2_415> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 5;<br> Pañcavimśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 9, 2.</ref> In many passages they are conjoined with the '''Aṅgirases.'''<ref name=fx11_ve2_415> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 1, 7, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 1, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 8;<br> iii. 2, 7, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 13, etc. ''Cf.'' Rv. viii. 35, 3;<br> 43, 13;<br> x. 14, 6, in the first and last of which passages the Atharvans also occur. See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xxvii. n. 2. Hence, in the Atharvanic ritual texts, the term ''Bhṛgvaṅgirasaḥ'' is applied to the Atharvaveda (Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 9, 10, 107 ''et seq.'').</ref> the close association of the two families is shown  by the fact that [[च्यवन|Cyavana]] is called either a [[भार्गव|Bhārgava]] or an [[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]] in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx12_ve2_415> iv. 1, 5, 1.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx13_ve2_415> v. 19, 1.</ref> the name of [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]] is selected to exemplify the dangers incurred by the oppressors of Brahmans: the '''[[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]] Vaitahavyas''' perish in consequence of an attack on [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]]. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx14_ve2_415> ii. 20. In the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 42-44 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 204), [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]] [[वारुणि|Vāruṇi]] appears as a student. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 169-173;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 140;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 443 ''et seq.''</ref> also [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]] has this representative character. ''Cf.'' '''[[भृगवाण|Bhṛgavāṇa]]''' and '''[[भार्गव|Bhārgava]].'''

भृङ्गा
<u>'''Bhṛṅgā'''</u> is the name of a species of bee, later specified as large and black, in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_416> ix. 2, 22.</ref> and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx2_ve2_416> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 29. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 96.</ref> which include it in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’).

भृम्य्-अश्व
<u>'''Bhṛmy-aśva'''</u> is the name of the father of '''[[मुद्गल|Mudgala]]''' in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (ix. 24).<br>==Foot Notes==

भेकुरि
<u>'''Bhekuri.'''</u> See '''[[बेकुरा|Bekurā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

भेद
<u>'''1. Bheda,'''</u> one of the enemies of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' and the '''TṛtsuBharatas,''' was defeated by the former in the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' (Jumna),<ref name=fx1_ve2_419> Rv. vii. 18, 18. 19;<br> 33, 3;<br> 83, 4.</ref> apparently in a second conflict fought after the battle of the ten kings, in which [[सुदास्|Sudās]] successfully defended his western frontier against the confederate foes. The '''Ajas, Śigrus,''' and '''Yakṣus,''' who are mentioned as also defeated, may have been united under his leadership if he was a king; or the Bhedas may have been a separate people, as Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_419> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 12 (the word is always used in the singular).</ref> thinks. Hopkins'<ref name=fx3_ve2_419> ''India, Old and New,'' 52.</ref> opinion that the defeat was on the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]],''' [[यमुना|Yamunā]] being another  name of that stream, is most improbable; nor is the view that [[भेद|Bheda]] was one of the ten kings essential.<ref name=fx4_ve2_419> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 260 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 20, n.;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 126;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 319, 327.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]].'''

भेद
<u>'''2. Bheda'''</u> is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_420> xii. 4, 49. 50.</ref> as having come to a bad end because he refused a cow (''[[वशा|vaśā]]'') to Indra when asked for it. That he is different from the preceding [[भेद|Bheda]], as Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_420> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 13.</ref> assumes, is not certain. Indeed, it may very well be that his defeat led to his being chosen as the representative of the evil end of the wicked man. Moreover, the irreligious character of [[भेद|Bheda]] may be ascribed to his being a leader of non-Āryan folk, if the '''Ajas''' and '''Śigrus,''' with whom in the Rigveda he is connected or associated were, as is possible, though by no means certain, un-Āryan tribes of totemists.<ref name=fx3_ve2_420> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 153, who inclines to see in them totemistic tribes, but the names furnish the sole support of this conjecture. On this supposition they were probably non-Āryan. ''Cf.'' '''Aja.'''</ref>

भेषज
<u>'''1.
