Bheṣaja,'''</u> denoting a ‘remedial agent,’ ‘medicine,’ is often mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_421> i. 89, 4;<br> ii. 33, 2, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_421> Av. v. 29, 1;<br> vi. 21, 2, etc.</ref> being also used in a figurative sense.<ref name=fx3_ve2_421> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 1, 1;<br> 5, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 41.</ref> Plants,<ref name=fx4_ve2_421> Rv. x. 97, and ''passim'' in the Atharvaveda.</ref> waters,<ref name=fx5_ve2_421> i. 23, 19. 20;<br> 34, 6, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 9, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 7, etc. Possibly there is some truth in Zimmer's view, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 399, that the reference is to the beneficial effects of bathing.</ref> and spells<ref name=fx6_ve2_421> Exemplified in the medical spells of the Atharvaveda and the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].</ref> are repeatedly enumerated as medicines. Most of the medical practices of the Atharvaveda are merely examples of sympathetic magic. For example, in one hymn<ref name=fx7_ve2_421> i. 22;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 264, ''et seq.''</ref> the yellow of jaundice is entreated to pass into yellow birds. In another<ref name=fx8_ve2_421> vii. 116;<br> Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' 565 ''et seq.''</ref> fever is to be banished by means of a frog; for the frog, being a potent means of cooling fire<ref name=fx9_ve2_421> ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 16, 14;<br> Av. xviii. 3, 60.</ref> (because of its association with water), is regarded as analogously effective in banishing the fire of fever. See '''[[भिषज्|Bhiṣaj]].''' 

भेषज
<u>'''2. Bheṣaja'''</u> in the plural is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_422> xi. 6, 14.</ref> and in the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve2_422> Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7, 3;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2, 10;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 9, 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xxxi. 628.</ref> denoting the hymns of the Atharvaveda in so far as they are regarded as having ‘healing’ powers.

भैम-सेन
<u>'''Bhaima-sena,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[भीमसेन|Bhīmasena]],'''’ is the name of a man in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iv. 6, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

भैम-सेनि
<u>'''Bhaima-seni,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[भीमसेन|Bhīmasena]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Divodāsa''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_424> vii. 8 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 460, 472).</ref>

भैषज्य
<u>'''Bhaiṣajya'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xii, 7. 1, 12) and the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (x. 7. 25) denotes ‘healing remedy’ or ‘medicine,’ like '''[[भेषज|Bheṣaja]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

भोग
<u>'''Bhoga'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_426> v. 29, 6;<br> vi. 75, 14 (where the '''[[हस्तघ्न|Hastaghna]],''' or ‘hand-guard,’ of the archer is compared to a snake).</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_426> Av. xi. 9, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 4, 5. 6;<br> v. 4, 5, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 4;<br> xxi. 8, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘coil’ of a serpent.

भोज
<u>'''Bhoja'''</u> in several passages of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 12. 14. 17) seems to be used as a king's title.<br>==Foot Notes==

भौज्य
<u>'''Bhaujya'''</u> in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_428> vii. 32;<br> viii. 6. 12. 14. 16.</ref> denotes the rank of a prince bearing the title of '''[[भोज|Bhoja]].'''

भौमक
<u>'''Bhaumaka'''</u> is the name of some animal in the late Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_429> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40.</ref>

भौमी
<u>'''Bhaumī'''</u> is the name of an animal in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_430> v. 5, 18, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref> 

भौवन
<u>'''Bhauvana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Bhuvana,’ is the patronymic of the mythical '''Viśvakarman''' in the Śatapatha (xiii. 7, 1, 15) and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] (viii. 21, 8. 10) Brāhmaṇas, and the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (x. 26).<br>==Foot Notes==

भौवायन
<u>'''Bhauvāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Bhuva,’ is the patronymic of '''Kapivana''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_432> xx. 13, 4.</ref> It is also found in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_432> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxii. 2 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 473);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 5;<br> and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 54, where Kapivana is not mentioned.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15 55, 69.</ref>

भ्रातृ
<u>'''Bhrātṛ'''</u> is the common designation of ‘brother’ from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_433> i. 164, 1;<br> iv. 3, 13;<br> v. 34, 4, etc.;<br> Av. i. 14, 2;<br> ii. 13, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 8, 4, etc.;<br> ''bhrātṛtva,'' Rv. viii. 20, 22;<br> 83, 8;<br> x. 108, 10.</ref> onwards. The word is also applied to a relation or close friend generally,<ref name=fx2_ve2_433> Bo7htlingk and Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 462.</ref> but here the persons concerned are, it should be noted, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_433> i. 161, 1;<br> 170, 2;<br> iii. 53, 5;<br> iv. 1, 2;<br> vi. 51, 5;<br> viii. 43, 16. ''Cf.'' Av. iv. 4, 5;<br> v. 22, 12.</ref> deities, who are brothers of one another or of the worshipper. Thus in the early literature the word has not really lost its precise sense. The derivation from the root ''bhṛ,'' ‘support,’ is probably correct, designating the brother as the support of his sister. This harmonizes with the fact that in Vedic literature the brother plays the part of protector of his sister when bereft of her father, and that maidens deprived of their brothers (''abhrātṛ'') meet an evil fate.<ref name=fx4_ve2_433> Rv. i. 124, 7;<br> iv. 5, 5;<br> Av. i. 17, 1;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 328. ''Cf.'' '''[[अयोगू|Ayogū]].'''</ref> The gradation of the relations in the home is shown by the order in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_433> vii. 15, 2.</ref> where father, mother, brother, and sister are successively mentioned. Strife between brothers is occasionally referred to.<ref name=fx6_ve2_433> ''Cf.'' Av. iii. 30, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 3, where it is a sign of serious confusion;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, cxlv;<br> Bloomfield ''Atharvaveda,'' 72.</ref> 

भ्रातृव्य
<u>'''Bhrātṛvya'''</u> is found in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_434> v. 22, 12, and perhaps x. 3, 9.</ref> where, being named with brother and sister, it must be an expression of relationship. The sense appears to be ‘(father's) brother's son,’ ‘cousin,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_434> The word is rendered ‘cousin’ by Whitney in his Translation of the Atharvaveda (x. 6, 1;<br> xv. 1, 8).</ref> this meaning alone accounting for the sense of ‘rival,’ ‘enemy,’ found elsewhere in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_434> ii. 18, 1;<br> viii. 10, 18. 33;<br> x. 9, 1.</ref> and repeatedly in the other Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx4_ve2_434> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 9, 2, etc.;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 7;<br> xxvii. 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 17;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 21, etc.;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 13, 2. ''Cf.'' Rv. viii. 21, 13.</ref> In an undivided family the relations of cousins would easily develop into rivalry and enmity. The original meaning may, however, have been ‘nephew,’<ref name=fx5_ve2_434> Whitney, in his Translation of the Atharvaveda (ii. 18, 1), while rendering the word by ‘adversary,’ explains it in a note as meaning literally ‘nephew,’ or ‘brother's son.’</ref> as the simple etymological sense would be ‘brother's son’; but this seems not to account for the later meaning so well. The [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx6_ve2_434> xxvii. 8.</ref> prescribes the telling of a falsehood to a [[भ्रातृव्य|Bhrātṛvya]], who, further, is often given the epithets ‘hating’ (''dviṣan'') and ‘evil’ (''apriya, pāpman'') in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx7_ve2_434> See several of the passages given in n. 4.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx8_ve2_434> ii. 18, 1;<br> x. 9, 1, etc. ''Cf.'' Tait tirīya Saṃhitā, i. 3. 2, 1, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 501, 506, 507, who thinks it means a kind of brother, and through early family conditions was restricted to cousins;<br> Bo7htlingk and Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 307.</ref> also contains various spells, which aim at destroying or expelling one's ‘rivals.’

भ्रूण-हन्
<u>'''Bhrūṇa-han,'''</u> ‘slaying an embryo’; '''Bhrūṇa-hatyā,''' ‘the slaying of an embryo,’ are terms expressing a crime which is repeatedly and severely censured in the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve2_435> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 9;<br> Kāthaka Sāṃhitā, xxxi. 7;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvii (cited in Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 579, 580);<br> Av. vi. 112, 3;<br> 113, 2. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 3, and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8;<br> 11, have ''brahma-han'' instead;<br> but see ''ibid.,'' 12.</ref> where it is said to be the greatest of all crimes, and one of which the  guilt cannot be removed. In many later passages<ref name=fx2_ve2_435> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 15, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 8, 2;<br> x. 1, 15;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 22. The substantive is found in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 20, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 7, 3;<br> 8, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 18, 19;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 27. Bhrūṇa itself occurs in Rv. x. 155. 2.</ref> the same crime is referred to, always with reprobation: this fact alone shows the erroneousness of the theory<ref name=fx3_ve2_435> See '''Pati,''' p. 487, with n. 131.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 481;<br> 10, 66;<br> Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 430;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 521, 522.</ref> that daughters could be allowed, once born, to die if their fathers so desired.

मकक
<u>'''Makaka,'''</u> a word occurring once in the Atharvaveda (viii. 6, 12), may be the name of some unknown animal; but it is possibly an adjective having some such sense as ‘bleating.’<br>==Foot Notes==

मकर
<u>'''Makara'''</u> is the name of an animal, probably the ‘crocodile,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_437> The [[मकर|Makara]], as a Hindu sculptural ornament, originally represented a crocodile. ''Cf.'' Cousen's article in the ''Annual Report of the Archaological Survey of India'' for 1903-4, pp. 227-231 (where the [[मकर|Makara]] appears as the vehicle of Varuṇa and of [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]]). ''Cf.'' also ''op. cit.,'' 1904-5, pp. 80, 83, 84.</ref> which is included in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_437> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 13, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 16;<br> [[वाज|Vāja]] saneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 35. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97.</ref>

मक्ष
<u>'''Makṣa,'''</u> ‘fly,’ is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_438> iv. 45, 4;<br> vii. 32, 2.</ref> and the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_438> ix. 1, 17.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97.</ref> where its fondness for sweet things is alluded to. ''Cf.'' '''[[अद्मसद्|Admasad]]'''

मक्षा
<u>'''Makṣā, Makṣikā,'''</u> denote both ‘fly’<ref name=fx1_ve2_439> Makṣikā, Rv. i. 162, 9;<br> Av. xi. 1, 2;<br> 9, 10;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 3, 2.</ref> and ‘bee’<ref name=fx2_ve2_439> [[मक्षा|Makṣā]], Rv. x. 40, 6;<br> Makṣikā, i. 119, 9;<br> [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, where a ‘king bee’ (''madhukara-[[राजन्|rājan]]'') is referred to.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97;<br> Hillebrandt. ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 240, n. 1.</ref> in the Rigveda and later. 

मख
<u>'''Makha'''</u> appears to designate a person in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_440> ix. 101, 13, where the '''Bhṛgus''' are mentioned as opposed to [[मख|Makha]] (''cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 51);<br> x. 171, 2.</ref> but in neither passage does the context explain who he was. Probably a demon of some kind is meant. In the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve2_440> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 57;<br> xxxvii. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 1, 8, 1;<br> iii. 2, 4, 1.</ref> mention is also made of the ‘head of [[मख|Makha]],’ an expression which has become unintelligible to the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve2_440> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 2, 17. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

मगध
<u>'''Magadha'''</u> is the name of a people who appear throughout Vedic literature as of little repute. Though the name is not actually found in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_441> See '''Kikaṭa.'''</ref> it occurs in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_441> v. 22, 14, where the Paippalāda recension has ''mayebhiḥ,'' which is a mere blunder, but substitutes the '''Kāśis''' for the Aṅgas.</ref> where fever is wished away to the '''Gandhāṛis''' and '''Mūjavants,''' northern peoples, and to the '''Aṅgas''' and Magadhas, peoples of the east. Again, in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_441> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 1.</ref> the [[मागध|Māgadha]], or man of [[मगध|Magadha]], is included as dedicated to ''ati-kruṣṭa,'' ‘loud noise’(?), while in the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]]''' hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_441> xv. 2, 1-4.</ref> the [[मागध|Māgadha]] is said to be connected with the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] as his [[मित्र|Mitra]], his [[मन्त्र|Mantra]], his laughter, and his thunder in the four quarters. In the Śrauta Sūtras<ref name=fx5_ve2_441> Lāṭyāyar Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6, 28;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 4, 22. ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa on [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1, 16. 17.</ref> the equipment characteristic of the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] is said to be given, when the latter is admitted into the Āryan Brahminical community, to a bad Brahmin living in [[मगध|Magadha]] (''[[ब्रह्म-बन्धु|brahma-bandhu]] [[मागध-देशीय|Māgadha-deśīya]]''), but this point does not occur in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx6_ve2_441> xvii. 1, 16.</ref> On the other hand, respectable Brahmins sometimes lived there, for the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx7_ve2_441> vii. 13;<br> this is not mentioned in the earlier [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.</ref> mentions '''Madhyama, Prātībodhī-[[पुत्र|putra]],''' as ''[[मगध|Magadha]]-vāsin,'' ‘living in [[मगध|Magadha]].’ Oldenberg,<ref name=fx8_ve2_441> ''Buddha,'' 400, n.;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 112, n.</ref> however, seems clearly right in regarding this as unusual. <br><br>The Magadhas are evidently a people in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] and other Sūtras,<ref name=fx9_ve2_441> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 13;<br> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xx. 13;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 6, 18;<br> Hiraṇyakeśi Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 6. See Caland, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Mergenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 553.</ref> possibly also in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx10_ve2_441> ii. 1, 1. See Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 200;<br> ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 46, n. 4.</ref> It is therefore most improbable that Zimmer<ref name=fx11_ve2_441> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 35. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' 20.</ref> can be right in thinking that in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_441/> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_441/> the [[मागध|Māgadha]] is not a man of [[मगध|Magadha]], but a member of the mixed caste produced by a '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]''' marrying a '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]''' woman.<ref name=fx12_ve2_441> Manu, x. 11;<br> [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]. iv. 17. So Sāyaṇa, on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.,'' explains [[मागध|Māgadha]], and Mahīdhara, on the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, offers this as one version.</ref> But the theory of mixed castes, in any case open to some doubt, cannot be accepted when used to explain such obviously tribal names as [[मागध|Māgadha]]. The fact that the [[मागध|Māgadha]] is often in later times a minstrel is easily accounted for by the assumption that the country was the home of minstrelsy and that wandering bards from [[मगध|Magadha]] were apt to visit the more western lands. This class the later texts recognize as a caste, inventing an origin by intermarriage of the old-established castes.<br><br>The dislike of the Magadhas, which may be Rigvedic, since the '''Kīkaṭas''' were perhaps the prototype of the Magadhas, was in all probability due, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx13_ve2_441> ''Buddha,'' 400, n.</ref> thinks, to the fact that the Magadhas were not really Brahminized. This is entirely in accord with the evidence of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx14_ve2_441> i. 4, 1, 10 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 398. [[कोसल|Kosala]] here appears as more Brahminical than [[विदेह|Videha]];<br> it is interesting to note that, while [[वैदेह|Vaideha]], like [[मागध|Māgadha]], is used in the later theory as a name of a mixed caste, [[कौसल्य|Kausalya]] is not so degraded (Oldenberg, 399, n.).</ref> that neither '''[[कोसल|Kosala]]''' nor '''[[विदेह|Videha]]''' were fully Brahminized at an early date, much less [[मगध|Magadha]]. Weber<ref name=fx15_ve2_441> See ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 52, 53;<br> 185;<br> 10, 99;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 79, n. 1;<br> 111, 112.</ref> suggests two other grounds that may have influenced the position--the persistence of aboriginal blood and the growth of Buddhism. The latter consideration is hardly applicable to the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] or the Atharvaveda; but the imperfect Brahminization of the land, if substituted for it in accordance with Oldenberg's suggestion,  would have some force. The former motive, despite Oldenberg's doubt, seems fully justified. Pargiter<ref name=fx16_ve2_441> ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, pp. 851-853.<br><br>''Cf.'' Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 6, 24, 260, 267.</ref> has gone so far as to suggest that in [[मगध|Magadha]] the Āryans met and mingled with a body of invaders from the east by sea. Though there is no evidence for this view in the Vedic texts, it is reasonable to suppose that the farther east the Āryans penetrated, the less did they impress themselves upon the aborigines. Modern ethnology confirms this ''a priori'' supposition in so far as it shows Āryan types growing less and less marked as the eastern part of India is reached, although such evidence is not decisive in view of the great intermixture of peoples in India.

मगुन्दी
<u>'''Magundī'''</u> is the name of some pest occurring in a verse of an Atharvaveda hymn<ref name=fx1_ve2_442> ii. 14, 2.</ref> employed to exorcise evil influences. By that verse the ‘daughters of the Magundī’ are to be expelled from the cowstall, the wagon, and the house. It is uncertain whether an animal, insect, or demoness is meant.<ref name=fx2_ve2_442> ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 58.</ref>

मघ
<u>'''Magha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_443> i. 11, 3;<br> 104, 5;<br> iii. 13, 3;<br> 19, 1;<br> iv. 17, 8;<br> v. 30, 12;<br> 32, 12, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 16. Very rarely later, ''e.g.,'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 67.</ref> denotes ‘bounty,’ and Maghavan<ref name=fx2_ve2_443> Rv. i. 31, 12;<br> ii. 6, 4;<br> 27, 17;<br> v. 39, 4;<br> 42, 8;<br> vi. 27, 8, etc. So [[मघ|Magha]]-tti, ‘giving of gifts,’ Rv. iv. 37, 8;<br> v. 79, 5;<br> viii. 24, 10, etc.;<br> Maghadeya, ‘giving of gifts,’ vii. 67, 9;<br> x. 156, 2;<br> Maghavat-tva, ‘liberality,’ vi. 27, 3. The word Maghavan is the epithet ''par excellence'' of Indra in the Rv. (iii. 30, 3;<br> iv. 16, 1;<br> 31, 7;<br> 42, 5, etc.), and survives in post-Vedic literature as a name of Indra;<br> otherwise, even in the later Saṃhitās, it is very rare, occurring practically as a divine epithet only (of Indra, [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 8, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 13;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 11).</ref> is the regular Vedic name for the ‘generous giver’ of bounties to priests. It is doubtful whether the Maghavans were more than this, or had any special rank as a class in Vedic society. See '''[[सभा|Sabhā]].'''

मघा
<u>'''Maghā.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]''' and '''[[अघा|Aghā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मङ्गल
<u>'''Maṅgala'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xxvi. 2). <br>==Foot Notes==

मङ्गीर
<u>'''Maṅgīra'''</u> is found in an obscure verse in the Vaitāna<ref name=fx1_ve2_446> xxxiv. 9.</ref> and other<ref name=fx2_ve2_446> [[मानव|Mānava]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 2, 7;<br> ''Mandīrasya,'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 3, 21;<br> ''Maṅkīrasya,'' Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxi. 20, 3.</ref> Sūtras with reference to cows. It is quite uncertain whether a river or a man<ref name=fx3_ve2_446> So apparently Garbe, Translation of the Vaitāna [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 97;<br> Caland. ''Das Vaitānasūtra,'' 102;<br> Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> is meant. The [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]] (Ganges) and the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] (Jumna) are mentioned in the same verse. The correct form of the word is doubtful.<ref name=fx4_ve2_446> See the variants in n. 2.</ref>

मञ्जिष्ठा
<u>'''Mañjiṣṭhā,'''</u> ‘madder,’ is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] (iii. 2, 4) and [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] (viii. 7) Āraṇyakas.<br>==Foot Notes==

मटची
<u>'''Maṭacī'''</u> occurs in a passage of the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_448> i. 10, 1.</ref> where reference is made to the '''Kurus''' being overwhelmed by Maṭacīs.<ref name=fx2_ve2_448> ''[[मटची|Maṭacī]]-hata.''</ref> Śaṅkara interprets the word by ‘thunderbolts’ (''aśanayaḥ''), while Ānandatīrtha in his commentary gives, as an alternative rendering, ''pāṣāṇa-vṛṣṭayaḥ--i.e.,'' ‘hailstones,’ which may be the sense. The Śabdakalpadruma,<ref name=fx3_ve2_448> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> agreeing with Ānandatīrtha,<ref name=fx4_ve2_448> On Brahmasūtra, iii. 4, 28.</ref> says that [[मटची|Maṭacī]] means, ‘a kind of small red bird’ (''rakta-[[वर्ण|varṇa]]-kṣudra-pakṣi-viśeṣa,'' reading ''-pakṣī-''), and Jacob<ref name=fx5_ve2_448> ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1911, p. 510.</ref> suggests that the ‘locust’ is meant.

मणि
<u>'''Maṇi'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_449> i. 33, 8.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_449> Av. i. 29, 1;<br> ii. 4, 1, 2;<br> viii. 5, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' x. 6, 24;<br> xii. 1, 44;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 4, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxv. 15;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 23, where [[दुर्ग|Durga]], in his commentary, takes [[मणि|Maṇi]] as ''āditya-[[मणि|maṇi]],'' or ‘sun-stone,’ while the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' suggests that a crystal used as a burning glass may be meant.</ref> of a ‘jewel’ used as an amulet against all kinds of evil. That either ‘pearl’<ref name=fx3_ve2_449> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> or ‘diamond’<ref name=fx4_ve2_449> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben'' 53.</ref> is denoted is not clear.<ref name=fx5_ve2_449> The expression ''[[हिरण्य|hiraṇya]] [[मणि|maṇi]]'' in Rv i. 33, 8, might possibly mean ‘gold a an ornament,’ but ‘gold (and) jewels is more probable. ''Cf.'' Av. xii. 1, 44, where ''maṇiṃ hiraṇyam'' must mean a jewel (and) gold.’</ref> It is evident that the  [[मणि|Maṇi]] could be strung on a thread (''[[सूत्र|sūtra]]''), which is referred to in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_449> xx. 16, 6.</ref> and elsewhere;<ref name=fx7_ve2_449> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 18, 8. ''Cf.'' iii. 4, 13;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 248;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 3, 4, 2.</ref> the [[मणि|Maṇi]] was certainly also worn round the neck, for in the Rigveda<ref name=fx8_ve2_449> i. 122, 14.</ref> occurs the epithet ''[[मणि|maṇi]]-grīva,'' ‘having a jewel on the neck.’ An amulet of [[बिल्व|Bilva]] is celebrated in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx9_ve2_449> xii. 18 ''et seq.''</ref> and many varieties of amulet are there enumerated.<ref name=fx10_ve2_449> xii. 8.</ref> The ‘jeweller’ (''[[मणि|maṇi]]-kāra'') is mentioned in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx11_ve2_449> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 337;<br> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 253;<br> Weber, ''Omina und Portenta,'' 317, 374;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 2, n. 4;<br> 5, 386;<br> 18, 37;<br> ''Proceedings of the Berlin Academy,'' 1891, 796. Weber is inclined to detect a Babylonian origin of [[मणि|Maṇi]] (''cf.'' '''[[मना|Manā]]'''), but the evidence is not convincing.</ref>

मणिक
<u>'''Maṇika'''</u> in the late Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_450> Weber, ''Omina und Portenta,'' 316.</ref> and the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve2_450> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 9, 3;<br> iv. 6, 4;<br> Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 26;<br> iii. 9, 6. 7, etc.;<br> Sāṅkhāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 14.</ref> denotes a large ‘water bottle.’

मण्ड
<u>'''Maṇḍa,'''</u> n., is found in the compound ''nau-[[मण्ड|maṇḍa]]'' (du.), denoting the two ‘rudders’ of a ship in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_451> ii. 3, 3, 15. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 345, n. 3, who, following the commentary, accepts ‘sides’ as the meaning;<br> Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 60.</ref>

मण्डूक
<u>'''Maṇḍūka'''</u> is the name of ‘frog’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_452> vii. 103, 1;<br> x. 166, 5.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_452> Av. vii. 112, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 4, 3;<br> 7, 11, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 1;<br> xxi. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 36;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 16;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 1, 2, 20 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 5.</ref> the feminine Maṇḍūkī also occurring.<ref name=fx3_ve2_452> Rv. x. 16, 14;<br> Av. xviii. 3, 60;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 1, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 17;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 10, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vi. 4, 1.</ref> The famous frog hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_452> vii. 103. ''Cf.'' Av. iv. 15, 12, as explained by Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 223, where reference is made to frogs in the clefts of the earth ([[इरिण|Iriṇa]]).</ref> compares with Brahmins the frogs croaking  as they awake to activity at the beginning of the rains. It has been explained by Max Müller<ref name=fx5_ve2_452> ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 494, 495.</ref> as a satire on the Brahmins. Geldner,<ref name=fx6_ve2_452> ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 117.</ref> agreeing with this view, thinks that it is directed by its '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]''' composer against rival Brahmins, probably the '''Viśvāmitras.'''<ref name=fx7_ve2_452> Geldner, ''loc. cit.,'' very plausibly points out that the last [[पाद|Pāda]] of this [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] hymn is borrowed from the most important [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] hymn (Rv. iii. 53, 7).</ref> The view, however, which interprets the hymn as a rain charm<ref name=fx8_ve2_452> [[यास्क|Yāska]], ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],'' ix. 5;<br> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 173-179. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 151;<br> ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 121, 122.</ref> seems on the whole more likely. The frog, from its connexion with water, was considered to have cooling properties. Thus after the burning of the dead body the frog is invited to come to the spot where the cremation has taken place in order to cool it down.<ref name=fx9_ve2_452> Rv. x. 16, 14. See Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 342350;<br> Lanman in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 850.</ref> Similarly the frog is invoked in the Atharvaveda against the fire of fever.<ref name=fx10_ve2_452> Av. vii. 116. See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 565.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref>

मत्स्य
<u>'''1. Matsya,'''</u> ‘fish,’ is mentioned only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_453> x. 68, 8.</ref> but frequently later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_453> Av. xi. 2, 25;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 9, 5;<br> 14, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 21, 34;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 6, 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 1, 1 (the famous fish of the deluge legend);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2;<br> ''[[महा-मत्स्य|mahā-matsya]],'' ‘great fish,’ Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 18. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 12 (''cf.'' Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7, 8;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2, 23), a [[मत्स्य|Matsya]] [[सांमद|Sāṃmada]] is personfied as the king of the fishes.</ref>

मत्स्य
<u>'''2. Matsya'''</u> appears to be the name of a people in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_454> vii. 18, 6.</ref> where they are ranged with the other enemies of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' although it is possible to see merely the sense of ‘fish’ in that passage. In the list of Aśvamedhins, ‘offerers of the horse sacrifice,’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_454> xiii. 5, 4, 9.</ref> '''[[ध्वसन् द्वैतवन|Dhvasan Dvaitavana]]''' is mentioned as a [[मत्स्य|Matsya]] king ('''[[मात्स्य|Mātsya]]'''). The Matsyas as a people occur also in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_454> iv. 1.</ref> in  connexion with the '''Vaśas,'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_454> This is the most probable reading, which results from a comparison with Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 9, where ''[[शाल्व|Śālva]]-Matsyeṣu'' is followed by ''savaśaUśīnareṣu'' (misprinted ''śavaśa-''). See Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 367. The older view was ''SatvanMatsyeṣu,'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 1, lxxvii, following Cowell;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[सत्वन्त्|Satvant]].''</ref> and in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_454> i. 2, 9.</ref> in connexion with '''Śālvas.''' In Manu<ref name=fx6_ve2_454> ii. 19;<br> vii. 193.</ref> the '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' the Matsyas, the '''Pancālas,''' and the '''Śūrasenakas''' comprise the land of the Brahmin [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] (''[[ब्रह्मर्षि-देश|brahmarṣi-deśa]]''). There is no reason to doubt that the Matsyas occupied much the same territory as in Epic times, say Alwar, Jaipur, Bharatpur.<ref name=fx7_ve2_454> See Vincent Smith, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 675.<br><br>''Cf.'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 166;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 211;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 127.</ref>

मदा-वती
<u>'''Madā-vatī,'''</u> ‘intoxicating,’ is the name of a plant in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_455> vi. 16, 2;<br> ''cf.'' iv. 7, 4. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 292;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 465;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref>

मदुघ
<u>'''Madugha,'''</u> ‘honey-plant,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_456> The literal meaning is probably ‘yielding honey,’ the word being, according to the commentator, derived from ''[[मधु|madhu]]-dugha,'' a word actually occurring in the Rigveda (vi. 70, 1. 5).</ref> is the name of a sweet herb in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_456> i. 34, 4;<br> vi. 102, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 386, n.;<br> 404;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 34, 35, 355;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 275;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 69.</ref> The spelling is somewhat uncertain, since many manuscripts read Madhugha.<ref name=fx3_ve2_456> These two forms probably stand by haplology for ''ma[dhu]-dugha'' and ''[[मधु|madhu]]-[du]gha. Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 64, 1''a.''</ref>

मद्गु
<u>'''Madgu,'''</u> ‘diver’ (from the root ''majj,''<ref name=fx1_ve2_457> See Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 38''c;<br>'' 44''a'' 3''a''.</ref> ‘dive’), is the name of some aquatic bird which is included in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx2_ve2_457> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 20, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 22. 34.</ref> and is occasionally mentioned elsewhere.<ref name=fx3_ve2_457> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 8, 1. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> 

मद्य
<u>'''Madya,'''</u> ‘intoxicating liquor,’ is not mentioned until the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_458> v. 11, 5. The word is found in the Epic and often in the Dharmaśāstras, as well as in medical texts.</ref> where it occurs in the compound ''[[मद्य|madya]]-pā,'' ‘drinking intoxicating liquor.’

मद्र
<u>'''Madra'''</u> denotes a people who are mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]];<ref name=fx1_ve2_459> iii. 3, 1;<br> 7, 1</ref> '''[[काप्य|Kāpya]] Patañcala''' was then living among them. Their name appears elsewhere in Vedic literature, only in that of a branch, the '''Uttara Madras,''' the ‘northern Madras,’ who are referred to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_459> viii. 14, 3</ref> as living beyond the Himālaya (''pareṇa Himavantam'') in the neighbourhood of the '''Uttara Kurus,''' probably, as Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_459> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 102.</ref> conjectures, in the land of Kaśmīr. The Madras mentioned in the [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] were, like the '''Kurus,''' probably settled somewhere in '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]]''' in the '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]]''' or ‘Middle Land.’ ''Cf.'' '''Madragāra.'''

मद्र-गार शौङ्गायनि
<u>'''Madra-gāra Śauṅgāyani'''</u> (‘descendant of Śuṅga’) is the name of a teacher, whose pupil was '''[[काम्बोज|Kāmboja]] [[औपमन्यव|Aupamanyava]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_460> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_460> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 102.</ref> concludes, with probability, that these names point to a connexion of the Kambojas and the Madras.

मधु
<u>'''Madhu'''</u> denotes anything sweet used as food, and especially drink, ‘mead,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_461> The word is etymologically identical with Greek , ‘intoxicating drink,’ and Anglo-Saxon ''medu,'' ‘mead.’</ref> a sense often found in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_461> Used as an adjective, ‘sweet,’ in Rv. i. 90, 6. 8;<br> 187, 2;<br> iii. 1, 8;<br> iv. 34, 2;<br> 42, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 10, etc.;<br> as a substantive, Rv. i. 154, 4;<br> ii. 37, 5;<br> iii. 39, 6;<br> iv. 38, 10, etc.;<br> Av. vi. 69, 1;<br> ix. 1, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 2, 4, 13, etc.</ref> More precisely it denotes either ‘Soma’<ref name=fx3_ve2_461> Rv. i. 19, 9;<br> ii. 19, 2;<br> 34, 5;<br> 36, 4;<br> iii. 43, 3;<br> iv. 18, 13, etc.</ref> or ‘milk,’<ref name=fx4_ve2_461> Rv. i. 117, 6;<br> 169, 4;<br> 177, 3;<br> iii. 8, 1;<br> vii. 24, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 2, etc.</ref> or less often  ‘honey,’<ref name=fx5_ve2_461> Rv. viii. 4, 8 (where the sense is made certain by the adjective ''sāragha,'' ‘derived from the bee’);<br> perhaps also iv. 45, 4;<br> vii. 32, 2;<br> viii. 24, 20, and, according to Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 239 ''et seq.,'' in many other passages;<br> Av. ix. 1, 17, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 10, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 9, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 15;<br> viii. 5. 20;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 2, 1. 2;<br> xi. 5, 4, 18;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka, ii. 5, 1;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 9, 1, etc.</ref> which, however, is the most definite sense in the later literature. Taboos against the use of honey are recorded.<ref name=fx6_ve2_461> In the case of women, Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 55, 2;<br> of students, Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 4, 18.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 321;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

मधुक पैङ्ग्य
<u>'''Madhuka Paiṅgya'''</u> (‘descendant of Piṅga’) is the name of a teacher mentioned in the Śatapatha<ref name=fx1_ve2_462> xi. 7, 2, 8;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 17. 18 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 8 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_462> xvi. 9.</ref> Brāhmaṇas.

मधु-कशा
<u>'''Madhu-kaśā,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_463> Rv. i. 22, 3;<br> 157, 4, Av. x. 7, 19;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 10, 12.</ref> or '''Madhoḥ Kasā,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_463> Av. ix. 1, 5.</ref> is the name in the Rigveda of the Aśvins’ ‘honey-whip,’ by which they impart sweetness to the sacrifice. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_463> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> ingeniously conjectures that the idea was derived from an instrument provided with thongs for whipping milk, a ‘milk-whip.’

मधु-कृत्
<u>'''Madhu-kṛt,'''</u> ‘honey-maker,’ denotes ‘bee’ in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_464> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i, 5, 6, 5;<br> iv. 2, 9, 6, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_464> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 10, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 2, 1. 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, 2;<br> vi. 9, 1, etc.</ref>

मधु-छन्दस्
<u>'''Madhu-chandas,'''</u> the reputed author of the first ten hymns of the first Maṇḍala of the Rigveda, is mentioned as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_465> xxviii. 2.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve2_465> i. 1, 3.</ref> In the  [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_465> vii. 17, 7;<br> 18, 1;<br> ''cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 26, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 167.</ref> he counts as the fifty-first son of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],''' and his Praüga (hymn at the morning service) is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_465> xiii. 5, 1, 8.</ref>

मधु-ब्राह्मण
<u>'''Madhu-brāhmaṇa,'''</u> ‘the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] of the Honey,’ is the designation of a certain mystical doctrine in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_466> iv. 1, 5, 18;<br> xiv. 1, 4, 13;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 5, 16. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 290.</ref>

मध्य-देश
<u>'''Madhya-deśa,'''</u> the ‘Middle Country,’ is, according to the [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra,<ref name=fx1_ve2_467> ii. 21.</ref> the land between the Himālaya in the north, the Vindhya in the south, '''[[विनशन|Vinaśana]]''' in the west, and Prayāga (now Allahabad) in the east--that is, between the place where the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' disappears in the desert, and the point of the confluence of the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' (Jumna) and the '''[[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]]''' (Ganges). The same authority<ref name=fx2_ve2_467> ii. 19.</ref> defines [[ब्रह्मर्षि-देश|Brahmarṣi-deśa]] as denoting the land of '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' the '''Matsyas, Pañcālas,''' and '''Śūrasenakas,''' and [[ब्रह्मावर्त|Brahmāvarta]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_467> ii. 17. 19.</ref> as meaning the particularly holy land between the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] and the '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]].''' The [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_467> i. 2, 9;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 8.</ref> defines Āryāvarta as the land east of [[विनशन|Vinaśana]]; west of the Kālaka-vana, ‘Black Forest,’ or rather Kanakhala, near Hardvār; south of the Himālaya; and north of the Pāriyātra or the Pāripātra Mountains; adding that, in the opinion of others,<ref name=fx5_ve2_467> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]], i. 2, 10;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], i. 12. See on Kanakhala, Hultzsch, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 34, 179.</ref> it was confined to the country between the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] and the [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]], while the '''Bhāllavins'''<ref name=fx6_ve2_467> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]], i. 2, 11. 12;<br> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], i. 14. 15, quoting in each case a verse of the [[निदान|Nidāna]] (what work is referred to is not certain;<br> there is similar doubt as to the quotation in the [[निदान|Nidāna]] of the [[भाल्लवि|Bhāllavi]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], according to the Bṛhaddevatā, v. 23, where see Macdonell's note, and ''cf.'' Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 3, n.).</ref> took it as the country between the boundary-river (or perhaps the [[सरस्|Saras]]-  vatī)<ref name=fx7_ve2_467> The readings are doubtful, varying between ''sindhur vidhāraṇī'' or ''vidharaṇī'' and ''sindhur vicaraṇī'' or ''visavaṇī.'' The latter expression must refer to the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]];<br> the former may, but not necessarily. Conceivably the [[सिन्धु|Sindhu]] (Indus) is meant;<br> for it was a great boundary, with Āryan tribes to the east of it.</ref> and the region where the sun rises. The [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra,<ref name=fx8_ve2_467> ii. 22.</ref> in accord with the [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx9_ve2_467> i. 9.</ref> defines Āryāvarta as the region between the Vindhya and the Himālaya, the two ranges which seem to be the boundaries of the Āryan world in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] also.<ref name=fx10_ve2_467> ii. 13. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 28, n. 1.</ref><br><br>The term [[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]] is not Vedic, but it is represented in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx11_ve2_467> viii. 14, 3. The Uśīnaras may be recognized as in the north, for the Buddhist texts give Usīragiri as the northern boundary of the middle country. See Hultzsch, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 34, 179.</ref> by the expression ''madhyamā [[प्रतिष्ठा|pratiṣṭhā]] [[दिश्|diś]],'' ‘the middle fixed region,’ the inhabitants of which are stated to be the Kurus, the Pañcālas, the '''Vaśas,''' and the '''Uśīnaras.''' The latter two peoples practically disappear later on, the [[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]] being the country of the Kuru-Pañcālas, the land where the Brāhmaṇas and the later Saṃhitās were produced, bounded on the east by the '''[[कोसल|Kosala]]-Videhas,''' and on the west by the desert. The western tribes are mentioned with disapproval both in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx12_ve2_467> ix. 3, 1, 8.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx13_ve2_467> iii. 44, 3;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 245.</ref> while the tradition of the Brahminization of the Kosalas and the Videhas from the Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]] country is preserved in the former [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx14_ve2_467> i. 4, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 2, 3;<br> 146, 147, who points out that the Pāripātra Mountains are a part of the Vindhya range in Mālvā, and who suggests that the western boundary was originally the [[आदर्श|Ādarśa]] Mountains;<br> for the reading of the manuscripts, and of the scholiast Kṛṣṇapaṇḍita, in the [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 8, is ''prāg ādarśanāt,'' not ''adarśanāt'' (corresponding with the [[विनशन|Vinaśana]] of [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 9), and the Mahābhāṣya on Pāṇini, ii. 4, 10, has ''prāg ādarśāt.'' See also for the Buddhist ‘Middle Country’ an article by Rhys Davids, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1904, 83 ''et seq.,'' with Fleet's corrections, ''ibid.,'' 1907, 657;<br> and ''cf.'' Keith, ''ibid.,'' 1908, 1143;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 58, 59;<br> ''Indian Empire,'' 1, 303, 304, where the extraordinary theory is adopted that the [[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]] was peopled by a new race of immigrant Āryans, who, travelling viâ Chitral and Gilgit, and bringing no women with them, married Dravidian women, and produced the so-called Āryo-Dravidians. It is quite impossible to find any support for this theory in Vedic literature. To say, as is there said, that the ‘Vedic hymns contain no reference to the route by which the Āryans entered India or to their earlier settlements on the Indus,’ and that this is explained by the theory of the entry of the Vedic Indians viâ Chitral, is to assert absurdities. The theory is based on the later dialects and their affinities (see Grierson, ''Indian Empire,'' 1, 357 ''et seq.'');<br> it can probably not be regarded as at all valid for any period--at any rate, it is not cogent for the eighth century, B.C.</ref> 

मध्यं-दिन
<u>'''Madhyaṃ-dina,'''</u> ‘mid-day,’ is a frequent designation of time in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_468> iv. 28, 3;<br> viii. 1, 29;<br> 13, 13;<br> 27, 19;<br> x. 151, 5, etc.</ref> the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx2_ve2_468> Av. ix. 6, 46;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 5, 4, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve2_468> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 9, 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 3, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 3, 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 9, 6;<br> 14, 1, etc. The word is sometimes used as an abbreviation for the ‘midday libation’ (like ''mittag'' in German for ‘midday meal’) in [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 2, 5;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxix. 8.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Ahan.'''

मध्यम-वह्
<u>'''Madhyama-vah'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_469> ii. 29, 4.</ref> as an epithet of the chariot. The exact interpretation is doubtful. Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_469> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 210. The context seems to require the sense of ‘keeping away’ from the sacrifice.<br><br>''Cf.'' '''[[पूर्ववह्|Pūrvavah]].'''</ref> assigns to it the expression the sense of ‘driving with a single horse between the shafts.’ According to Sāyana's explanation, it means ‘driving with middling speed.’ It might mean ‘driving in the middle’--that is, ‘only half-way.’^3

मध्यम-शी
<u>'''Madhyama-śī'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_470> x. 97, 12 = Av. iv. 9, 4 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 86.</ref> where Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_470> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> assigns to the word the meaning of ''intercessor,'' which Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_470> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 180. ''Cf.'' '''[[धर्म|Dharma]].'''</ref> accepts, in the sense of ‘mediator’ or ‘arbiter,’ as a legal term, but which Roth may, as Lanman<ref name=fx4_ve2_470> In Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 159. But see Roth, ''Siebenzig Lieder,'' 174, which Lanman may have overlooked, since he does not refer to it.</ref> suggests, have intended to express ‘adversary’ or ‘preventer’ of the disease referred to in the hymn. Whitney<ref name=fx5_ve2_470> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> thinks that it means ‘mid-  most man’ or ‘chief’ as the one round whom his followers encamp.<ref name=fx6_ve2_470> ''Madhyamaśivan,'' in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 408, is obscure.</ref> Geldner,<ref name=fx7_ve2_470> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 131;<br> ''Kommentar,'' 196 (where he seems to decide in favour of derivation from ''śī,'' not ''śṛ'').</ref> however, thinks that a third king, who is ‘neutral’ between two enemies, is intended.

मध्यम-स्थ
<u>'''Madhyama-stha,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_471> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxvii. 5.</ref> '''Madhyame-ṣṭha,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_471> Av. iii. 8, 2, and ''cf. Madhyamastheya,'' ‘position of chief,’ [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 5, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 96.</ref> in the later Saṃhitās denotes the chief in his relation to his followers ''([[सजात|sajāta]]). Cf.'' '''[[मध्यमशी|Madhyamaśī]].'''

मध्या-वर्ष
<u>'''Madhyā-varṣa,'''</u> the ‘middle of the rains,’ is specially mentioned as a time of the year in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_472> i. 3.</ref> and in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx2_ve2_472> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 5, 5. 7, etc.</ref>

मनस
<u>'''Manasa,'''</u> occurring in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_473> v. 44, 10. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139.</ref> seems clearly to be the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], in accordance with Sāyaṇa's interpretation.

मना
<u>'''Manā'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_474> viii. 78, 2.</ref> in an enumeration of gifts, where it is described as ‘golden’ (''sacā [[मना|manā]] hiraṇyayā''). It therefore seems to designate some ornament, or possibly a weight, and has accordingly been compared<ref name=fx2_ve2_474> As. ''e.g.,'' by Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 50, 51;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 386;<br> 17, 202, 203;<br> Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, xxii;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 278.</ref> with the Greek  (Herodotus has ), the Latin ''mina.'' All three words have been considered Semitic in origin, as borrowed from the Phœnicians<ref name=fx3_ve2_474> Or perhaps from Babylon viâ Asia Minor. The part played by the Phœnicians in Greek life is now reduced within narrow limits;<br> in the case of the ''mina,'' probably their commercial activities may be considered as likely to have caused the adoption of the term.</ref> in the case of Greece, from Carthage by way  of Etruria or Sicily in the case of Rome, and from Babylon in the case of India. The identification as regards [[मना|Manā]] is very conjectural, depending merely on the probabilities of Babylonian borrowing<ref name=fx4_ve2_474> See, ''e.g.,'' for borrowing, Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 276;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 43 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bühler, ''Indian Studies,'' 3, 16 ''et seq.;<br> Indische Palœographie,'' 17;<br> Vincent Smith, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 34, 230. On the other side, ''cf.'' Max Müller, ''India,'' 133-138;<br> Hopkins, ''Religions of India,'' 160;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 139 (as regards the flood legend): Bloomfield, ''Religions of India,'' 133 ''et seq.'' (as regards the Ādityas).</ref> seen--''e.g.,'' in the legend of the flood, and in the system of the '''Nakṣatras.''' On the other hand, Mahā may very well be identical with the word ''[[मना|manā]]'' which occurs several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_474> i. 173, 2;<br> iv. 33, 2, x. 6, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 19;<br> ‘jealousy, Rv. ii. 33, 5, Kanśika [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], cvii. 2. There are also the derivatives ''[[मना|manā]]-ya,'' ‘think of,’ ‘be zealous’: Rv. i. 133, 4;<br> ii. 26, 2;<br> ''[[मना|manā]]-ya,'' ‘desirous’: Rv. i. 92, 9;<br> iv. 24, 7;<br> ''[[मना|manā]]-vasu,'' ‘rich in devotion’: Rv. v. 74, 1.</ref> in the sense of ‘desire’ (from the root ''man,'' ‘think’), and which may have in this one passage the concrete sense of ‘desirable object.’ It is to be noted that in Bo7htlingk's Dictionary a single word [[मना|Manā]] appears, to which the only senses assigned are ‘wish,’ ‘desire,’ ‘jealousy.’

मनावी
<u>'''Manāvī,'''</u> ‘wife of Manu,’ is mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_475> xxx. 1 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 462).</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_475> i. 1, 4, 16.</ref> See '''Manu.'''

मनु
<u>'''Manu'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_476> i. 80, 16;<br> ii. 33. 13;<br> viii. 63. 1;<br> x. 100, 5, etc. See Macdonell, ''Velk Mythology,'' 50.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_476> Av. xiv. 2, 41;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 1, 3;<br> vii. 5. 15, 3;<br> ii. 5, 9, 1;<br> 6, 7, 1;<br> iii. 3, 2, 1;<br> v. 4, 10, 5;<br> vi. 6. 6, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā. viii. 15;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4. 14, etc. Jainiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 15, 2, etc.</ref> has no claim to historical reality. He is simply the first man, father of the race, and its guide in all matters, sacrificial and other. Hence the views of the texts on inheritance are foisted on Manu and his youngest son, '''[[नाभानेदिष्ठ|Nābhānediṣṭha]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_476> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 9, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 14, 1. 2.</ref> He also plays the part of the hero in the Vedic legend of the flood.<ref name=fx4_ve2_476> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 1, 1 ''et seq.,'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 2.</ref> <br><br>Manu is called Vivasvan<ref name=fx5_ve2_476> Rv. viii. 52, 1.</ref> or Vaivasvata,<ref name=fx6_ve2_476> Av. viii. 10, 24;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 3;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xii. 10.</ref> ‘son of Vivasvant’ (the god); [[सावर्णि|Sāvarṇi]],<ref name=fx6_ve2_476/> ‘descendant of Savarṇā’ (the substitute of Saraṇyū in the legend of her wedding); and [[सांवरणि|Sāṃvaraṇi]],<ref name=fx7_ve2_476> Rv. viii. 51, 1;<br> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 180, n., conjectures [[सावर्णि|Sāvarṇi]] instead. ''Cf.'' Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 38.</ref> ‘descendant of [[संवरण|Saṃvaraṇa]].’ The first name is, of course, mythical. The other two have been regarded as historical, [[सावर्णि|Sāvarṇi]] being taken by Ludwig<ref name=fx8_ve2_476> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 195;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, 240;<br> Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 114 ''et seq.;<br>'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Muir, ''Sanskrit texts,'' 1^2, 161 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 25, lvii ''et seq.;<br>'' Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 340 ''et seq.''</ref> as a king of the '''Turvaśas,''' but this is very doubtful.

मनोर् अवसर्पण
<u>'''Manor Avasarpaṇa'''</u> is the name, in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_477> i. 8, 1, 8.</ref> of the mountain on which the vessel of '''Manu''' rested. In the Epic the name is Naubandhana, but the view<ref name=fx2_ve2_477> See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 139;<br> Whitney, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 162;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 30;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 676.</ref> that it is alluded to as '''[[नावप्रभ्रंशन|Nāvaprabhraṃśana]]''' in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_477> xix. 39, 8.</ref> is now abandoned.<ref name=fx4_ve2_477> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 961;<br> Macdonell, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 1107.</ref>

मनुष्य-राज
<u>'''Manuṣya-rāja'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_478> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 15, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiv. 7.</ref> and '''Manuṣya-[[राजन्|rājan]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_478> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 10, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 26, 4.</ref> denote in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas a ‘king of men.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[राजन्|Rājan]].'''

मनुष्य-विश्
<u>'''Manuṣya-viś,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_479> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9, 1.</ref> '''Manuṣya-viśa,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_479> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 7, 7;<br> vi. 1, 5, 3.</ref> and '''Manuṣya-viśā'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_479> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 6;<br> xxiii. 8.</ref> denote ‘mankind,’ ‘the human race,’ in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas. 

मन्त्र
<u>'''Mantra'''</u> (from the root ''man,'' ‘think’) denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_480> i. 31, 13;<br> 40, 5;<br> 67, 4;<br> 74, 1;<br> 152, 2;<br> ii. 35, 2, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_480> Av. xv. 2, 1;<br> xix. 54, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 4, 1;<br> 5, 1, etc.</ref> the ‘hymn’ as the product of the singer's creative thought. In the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx3_ve2_480> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 14, 23;<br> vi. 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvi. 3. 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 4, 6;<br> xi. 2, 1, 6, [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 1, etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 1, 3.</ref> the word is regularly used of the poetic and prose utterances of the [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]], including not merely the verse parts of the Saṃhitās, but also the prose formulæ that betray by their style their special and archaic character.<ref name=fx4_ve2_480> Bloomfield, ''Vedic Concordance,'' viii;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 298. Macdonel's ''Vedic Grammar'' covers the [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] material of the Vedic Saṃhitās, prose as well as poetry.</ref>

मन्त्र-कृत्
<u>'''Mantra-kṛt'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_481> ix. 114, 2.</ref> and the '''Brāhmaṇas'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_481> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 24;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 1.</ref> denotes a poet as a ‘maker of Mantras.’

मन्थ
<u>'''Mantha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_482> x. 86, 15.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_482> Av. ii. 29, 6;<br> v. 29, 7;<br> x. 6, 2;<br> xviii. 4, 42;<br> xx. 127, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 5, 1, etc.</ref> denotes a drink in which solid ingredients are mixed with a fluid by stirring, usually parched barley-meal ('''[[सक्तु|Saktu]]''') with milk.<ref name=fx3_ve2_482> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 1, 2;<br> Suśruta, 1, 233, 12, in St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1''b ad fin.''</ref> All sorts of mixed beverages of this type are mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx4_ve2_482> xii. 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 268, 269;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology, 108''</ref>

मन्था
<u>'''Manthā'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_483> i. 28, 4.</ref> seems to mean a ‘churn.’ So the root ''math'' denotes to ‘churn’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_483> ii. 2, 10, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 2, 6;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 6, 1. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 161.</ref> In one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_483> xx. 127, 9. Scheftelowitz in [[खिल|Khila]], v. 10, 3, reads ''manthāṁ'' with Pluti, following the Kaśmīr MS., but misquoting the [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] text.</ref> the word is used to denote a drink like '''[[मन्थ|Mantha]].''' 

मन्थावल
<u>'''Manthāvala'''</u> is the name of an animal in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_484> iii. 26, 3.</ref> a sort of snake according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary. Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx2_ve2_484> P. 291 (ed. Aufrecht). ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 86.</ref> understands it to be a kind of animal which hangs head downwards from the branches of trees, meaning, presumably, the flying fox.<ref name=fx3_ve2_484> This is the probable meaning of the word according to Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[मान्थाल|Mānthāla]], Mānthīlava.'''

मन्थिन्
<u>'''Manthin'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_485> iii. 32, 2;<br> ix. 46, 4. Tilak's conjecture that the planets are referred to here is absurd. See ''Orion,'' 162;<br> Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, xciv.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_485> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 6, 3;<br> vi. 4, 10, 1;<br> vii. 2, 7, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vii. 18;<br> viii. 57;<br> xiii. 57;<br> xviii. 19;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 6, etc.</ref> denotes Soma juice mixed with meal ('''[[सक्तु|Saktu]]''') by stirring.

मन्दीर
<u>'''Mandīra'''</u> is perhaps the name of a man whose cattle, according to a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xiii. 3, 21), did not drink the water of the '''[[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]]''' (Ganges). See '''[[मङ्गीर|Maṅgīra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मन्धातृ
<u>'''1. Mandhātṛ'''</u> occurs in several passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_487> i. 112, 13;<br> viii. 39, 8;<br> 40, 12;<br> x. 2, 2.</ref> in all of which Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_487> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> takes the word as merely an adjective used substantively, ‘the pious man.’ In one passage<ref name=fx3_ve2_487> Rv. x. 2, 2.</ref> the word, being applied to Agni, is thus used, but in another<ref name=fx4_ve2_487> Rv. viii. 40, 12.</ref> ''Mandhātṛvat'' being parallel with ''Aṅgirasvat,'' ‘like [[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]],’ is naturally to be understood as a proper name, which is probably also the sense of the word in the preceding hymn.<ref name=fx5_ve2_487> Rv. viii. 39, 8.</ref> A different [[मन्धातृ|Mandhātṛ]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_487> Rv. i. 112, 13.</ref> may be meant in the first Maṇḍala,<ref name=fx6_ve2_487/> where he is mentioned as a protégé of the Aśvins, and evidently as a king. To equate these persons, and make a Rājarṣi out of [[मन्धातृ|Mandhātṛ]], as Ludwig<ref name=fx7_ve2_487> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 107. where he attributes Rv. viii. 39-42 to him as a '''[[नाभाक|Nābhāka]],''' ‘descendant of '''[[नभाक|Nabhāka]].'''’</ref> and Griffith<ref name=fx8_ve2_487> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 147.</ref> do, is unnecessary and improbable. 

मन्धातृ यौवनाश्व
<u>'''2. Mandhātṛ Yauvanāśva'''</u> (‘descendant of Yuvanāśva’) is in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_488> i. 2, 10 ''et seq. Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 111.</ref> the name of an emperor who was instructed by '''Vicārin,''' son of '''[[कबन्ध आथर्वण|Kabandha Ātharvaṇa]].'''

मन्या
<u>'''Manyā'''</u> (plur.), ‘nape of the neck,’ occurs in a passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_489> vi. 25, 1.</ref> directed against a disease which Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve2_489> ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' October, 1887, xix;<br> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 327 ''et seq.;<br> Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 472.</ref> regards as scrofulous swellings on the neck. He compares the disease Manskunder, ‘tumours of the neck’ (which looks like a combination of the words ''[[मन्या|manyā]]'' and ''[[स्कन्ध्या|skandhyā]],'' ‘pains of the neck and shoulders,’ both occurring in verses 1 and 3 of the [[अथर्वन्|Atharvan]] hymn), mentioned by Wise.<ref name=fx3_ve2_489> ''System of Hindu Medicine,'' 316.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 202;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 298, 299.</ref>

ममता
<u>'''Mamatā'''</u> is, according to Sāyaṇa, in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_490> vi. 10, 2. ''Cf.'' Mahābhārata, i. 4179 ''et seq.''</ref> the wife of Ucathya and the mother of '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]].''' But the word may be merely an abstract noun meaning ‘selfinterest,’ a sense which it often has in the later language. Oldenberg<ref name=fx2_ve2_490> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 212.</ref> finds a mention of Mamata (masc.) in a verse of the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_490> vi. 50, 15, where the reading of the received text is ''mama tasya.''</ref> as the name of a '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]].'''

मय
<u>'''Maya'''</u> is found once in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxii. 19) in the sense of ‘horse.’<br>==Foot Notes==

मयु
<u>'''Mayu'''</u> occurs in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_492> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1;<br> Vājasanevi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 31.</ref> The commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_492/> explains the word as meaning either an ‘ape’ (''[[किंपुरुष|kiṃpuruṣa]]'') or a ‘forest peacock’ (''āraṇya-[[मयूर|mayūra]]'').  The former sense is supported by another passage of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_492> viii. 47;<br> ''mayu āraṇya'' in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 10, 1.</ref> where the Mayu, being a substitute for the man, must be an ape. This sense also suits the word in the other passage<ref name=fx3_ve2_492> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 2, 22.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 85;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 246.</ref> where it occurs.

मयूख
<u>'''Mayūkha'''</u> denotes, from the Rigveda onwards,<ref name=fx1_ve2_493> Rv. vii. 99, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 1, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 15, 9. etc.</ref> a ‘peg,’ especially as used for keeping a web stretched.<ref name=fx2_ve2_493> Rv. x. 130, 2 (in a metaphor);<br> Av. x. 7, 42;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvi. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 5, 3, etc.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Otu.'''

मयूर
<u>'''Mayūra,'''</u> ‘peacock,’ occurs in the Rigveda in the compounds describing Indra's horses, ''[[मयूर|mayūra]]-roman,''<ref name=fx1_ve2_494> Rv. iii. 45, 1.</ref> ‘with hair like peacocks’ feathers,’ and ''[[मयूर|mayūra]]-śepya,''<ref name=fx2_ve2_494> Rv. viii. 1, 25.</ref> ‘with tails like those of peacocks.’ The peacock also appears in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx3_ve2_494> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 23. 27.</ref> The pea-hen, Mayūrī, is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_494> i. 191, 14 (a late hymn).</ref> and the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx5_ve2_494> vii. 56, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 90.</ref> in both cases with reference to the bird's efficacy against poison, a curious superstition to be compared with the modern dislike of peacocks' feathers.

मरीचि
<u>'''Marīci'''</u> in the plural denotes according to Weber,<ref name=fx1_ve2_495> ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 9, accepted by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the ‘particles of light’ or ‘shining motes’ that fill the air, as opposed to rays of light (''[[रश्मि|raśmi]]''). This meaning adequatelysuits the passages in the early Vedic literature<ref name=fx2_ve2_495> Rv. x. 57, 12;<br> 177, 1;<br> Av. iv. 38, 5 (where ''[[रश्मि|raśmi]]'' and ''[[मरीचि|marīci]]'' are opposed);<br> v. 27, 10;<br> vi. 113, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 5, 5 (''[[मरीचि|marīci]]-pa,'' ‘drinking atoms of light,’ said of the gods);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 9, 2 (where Sāyaṇa's version, ''sarvatra-prasṛtaprabhā-dravya,'' refers to the light as everywhere diffused), etc.</ref> where the  word occurs; but the sense of ‘ray’ is quite clearly found in the Upaniṣads,<ref name=fx3_ve2_495> [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1, 2;<br> 2, 1;<br> '''Maitrāyaṇī''' [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 31.</ref> as well as the older sense.<ref name=fx4_ve2_495> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2.</ref>

मरु
<u>'''Maru,'''</u> in the plural, is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve2_496> v. 1, 1.</ref> as the ''utkara'' (‘mound of earth thrown up’ from the excavation of the altar<ref name=fx2_ve2_496> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' xii. 25, 54.</ref> ) of '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]].''' This seems to mean that the Maru deserts (the later Maru-sthala)<ref name=fx3_ve2_496> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 48, and '''[[धन्वन्|Dhanvan]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78.</ref> were so called because they stood to the ‘altar,’ [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], in the same relation as the waste earth of the ''utkara'' to the altar at the sacrifice.

मरुत्त आवि-क्षित
<u>'''Marutta Āvi-kṣita'''</u> (‘descendant of Avikṣit’) '''[[काम-प्रि|Kāma-pri]]''' (‘descendant of Kāmapra’) is the name of a king who was anointed by '''[[संवर्त|Saṃvarta]]''' according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_497> viii. 21, 12.</ref> In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_497> xiii. 5, 4, 6. ''Cf.'' also [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 9, 14. 16;<br> Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4.</ref> account of the same king he is called '''[[आयोगव|Āyogava]].'''

मरुद्-वृधा
<u>'''Marud-vṛdhā'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_498> Literally, ‘rejoicing in the Maruts’ -''i.e.,'' ‘swollen by the rainy winds.’ The misspelling of the name as Marudvṛddhā in Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 80, 88, is corrected in the Index and the Addenda of that work. On the accentuation of the name, see Vārttika 2 on Pāṇini, vi. 2, 106.</ref> is the name of a stream mentioned in the Nadīstuti (‘Praise of Rivers’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_498> x. 75, 5.</ref> along with the '''[[असिक्नी|Asiknī]]''' (Akesines) and the '''[[वितस्ता|Vitastā]]''' (Hydaspes). Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_498> ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 138 ''et seq.''</ref> considers that the [[मरुद्वृधा|Marudvṛdhā]] denotes the stream formed by the combined waters of these two rivers down to its junction with the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]]''' (Ravi), a view accepted by Zimmer.<ref name=fx4_ve2_498> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 11, 12.</ref> On the other hand, Ludwig<ref name=fx5_ve2_498> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200.</ref> thinks that the [[मरुद्वृधा|Marudvṛdhā]] designates  the stream formed by the junction of the [[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]] with the combined waters of the [[असिक्नी|Asiknī]] and [[वितस्ता|Vitastā]], a view which seems less likely.

मर्क
<u>'''1. Marka'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_499> x. 27, 20.</ref> where Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_499> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' He thinks, however, that if the word means ‘eclipse,’ it cannot be derived from the root ''mṛc,'' ‘injure.’</ref> sees in the expression ''sūro markaḥ'' the ‘eclipse of the sun.’ Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx3_ve2_499> As from the root ''mṛj,'' derivation from which is not phonetically justified.</ref> thinks the meaning is ‘purifying.’<ref name=fx4_ve2_499> Ludwig cites this passage, in his essay on eclipses in the Rigveda (Proceedings of the Bohemian Academy, 1885), as a proof that the Vedic [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] knew of the moon as eclipsing the sun;<br> but see Whitney's reply, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, lxi ''et seq.,'' and [[सूर्य|Sūrya]].</ref>

मर्क
<u>'''2. Marka'''</u> is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_500> vi. 4, 10, 1.</ref> and elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve2_500> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 1, 4.</ref> as the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], along with '''[[शण्ड|Śaṇḍa]],''' of the Asuras, while [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]] is, of course, the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of the gods. [[मर्क|Marka]] is mentioned elsewhere also.<ref name=fx3_ve2_500> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vii. 16, 17.</ref> The name may quite possibly have Iranian affinities, as believed by Hillebrandt<ref name=fx4_ve2_500> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 442 ''et seq.''</ref> and by Hopkins.<ref name=fx5_ve2_500> ''Cf. Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 49, n. 1.</ref> Hillebrandt<ref name=fx6_ve2_500> ''Op. cit.,'' 1, 223 ''et seq.''</ref> also sees in a [[गृध्र|Gṛdhra]] mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx7_ve2_500> v. 77, 1.</ref> and elsewhere<ref name=fx8_ve2_500> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 29;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 9, 19.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 279 ''et seq.''</ref> a prototype of [[मर्क|Marka]].

मर्कट
<u>'''Markaṭa,'''</u> ‘ape,’ is enumerated in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_501> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30.</ref> It is classified in the same Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve2_501> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 5, 7;<br> Maitāyani Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 7.</ref> with man and the elephant as ‘taking hold by the hand’ (''[[हस्तादान|hastādāna]]'') instead of ‘taking hold by the mouth’ (''mukhādāna''). The animal is mentioned several times elsewhere also.<ref name=fx3_ve2_501> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 4;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 184;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 11, 32, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 85.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[पुरुष हस्तिन्|Puruṣa Hastin]], Mayu.''' 

मर्य
<u>'''1. Marya'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_502> iii. 31, 7;<br> 33, 10;<br> iv. 20, 5;<br> ix. 96, 20, etc.;<br> ''[[मर्य|marya]]-[[श्री|śrī]],'' ‘adorred as a lover,’ ii. 10, 5. ''Cf.'' '''Nīrukta,''' iii. 15;<br> iv. 2.</ref> denotes a ‘man’ especially regarded as young and a lover, being constantly mentioned as in company with maidens (''yuvatī'').

मर्य
<u>'''2. Marya'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_503> vii. 56, 16;<br> viii. 43, 25.</ref> in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_503/> denotes a ‘stallion.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_503> This is, of course, only a specialized sense of 1. [[मर्य|Marya]] as meaning a ‘male’ (''cf.'' Lat. ''mas, maritus''). The specialized meaning is somewhat analogous to the use of ‘sire’ in English.</ref> It is once<ref name=fx3_ve2_503> Rv. ix. 97, 18. Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2, thinks Rv. i. 91, 13, may have the same sense.</ref> described as ''[[पस्त्यावन्त्|pastyāvant]],'' ‘a stalled horse’--that is, one carefully tended, and not allowed out to graze.

मर्यक
<u>'''Maryaka,'''</u> occurring only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_504> v. 2. 5. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 313.</ref> seems to denote the bull which is described as separated from the cows.

मर्यादा
<u>'''Maryādā,'''</u> ‘boundary,’ is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_505> i. 4, 1, 17. ''Cf.'' xiii. 8, 4, 12.</ref> referring to the boundary between the '''Kosalas''' and the '''Videhas.''' Usually the word is metaphorically employed.<ref name=fx2_ve2_505> Rv. iv. 5, 13;<br> x. 5, 6;<br> Av. vi. 81, 2 (of an amulet). In the Atharvaveda passage Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 392, suggests, owing to the very curious use of the word, the emendation ''[[मर्य|marya]]-dā,'' ‘giver of a son.’</ref>

मल
<u>'''Mala'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_506> x. 136, 2.</ref> is used of the garments of the Munis. The St. Petersburg Dictionary takes it to mean a ‘leathern garment,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_506> If this were correct, the word might be derived from ''mlā'' in the sense of ‘to tan.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[चर्मन्|Carman]],''' especially notes 6 and 7.</ref> but Ludwig and Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_506> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262.</ref> think it means only ‘soiled’ raiment, which, of course, suits the ordinary sense of the word (‘dirt’) in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx4_ve2_506> vi. 115, 3;<br> vii. 89, 3;<br> x. 5, 24, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 333, n.</ref> and the character of the long-haired (''[[केशिन्|keśin]]'') hermit ('''Muni'''). ''Cf.'' '''[[मलग|Malaga]].''' 

मल-ग
<u>'''Mala-ga'''</u> in one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_507> xii. 3, 21.</ref> denotes a cleanser of clothes, a ‘washerman,’ but the origin of the word is somewhat uncertain.<ref name=fx2_ve2_507> It may, perhaps, have primarily meant ‘concerned with dirt.’ See the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. ga'' 1, on the use of ''ga'' as forming compounds;<br> and ''cf.'' '''Mala.'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 188.</ref>

मलिम्लु
<u>'''Malimlu'''</u> in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_508> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 2, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 78. 79;<br> Av. xix. 49, 10.</ref> denotes a ‘robber,’ specifically, according to the commentator Mahīdhara, a burglar or housebreaker. ''Cf.'' '''[[तायु|Tāyu]], [[तस्कर|Taskara]], [[स्तेन|Stena]],''' and '''[[देवमलिम्लुच्|Devamalimluc]].'''

मलिम्लुच
<u>'''Malimluca'''</u> is the name of an intercalary month in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_509> xxxv. 10;<br> xxxviii. 14. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''[[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]],'' 100, 102;<br> ''Naxatra,'' 2, 350.</ref> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

मशक
<u>'''1. Maśaka'''</u> denotes a ‘biting fly’ or ‘mosquito,’ being described in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_510> vii. 56, 3.</ref> as ‘quickly(?) biting’ (''tṛpradaṃśin''), and as having a poisonous sting. The elephant is mentioned<ref name=fx2_ve2_510> Av. iv. 36, 9.</ref> as particularly subject to its stings. The insect is often referred to elsewhere.<ref name=fx3_ve2_510> Av. xi. 3, 5;<br> at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’), Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 29;<br> xxv. 3;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 24 (Mādhyaṃdina = i. 3, 22 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 9, 3;<br> 10, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[दंश|Daṃśa]].'''

मशक गार्ग्य
<u>'''2. Maśaka Gārgya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[गर्ग|Garga]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[स्थिरक गार्ग्य|Sthiraka Gārgya]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_511> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373, 382.</ref> He is also mentioned in the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve2_511> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 9, 14;<br> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 75, 76;<br> 83, 84.</ref> of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], and is the reputed author of an extant [[कल्प|Kalpa]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]. 

मशर्शार
<u>'''Maśarśāra'''</u> is the name of a king, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx1_ve2_512> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 206.</ref> of the '''Nahuṣas,''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_512> i. 122, 15.</ref>

मष्णार
<u>'''Maṣṇāra'''</u> is the name of a locality, the scene of the victory of a '''Kuru''' king, in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_513> viii. 23, 3. ''Cf.'' Bhāgavata [[पुराण|Purāṇa]], v. 13, 26 ''et seq.;<br>'' Leumann, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 80, n. 2.</ref>

मसूर
<u>'''Masūra'''</u> is the name of a kind of lentil (''Ervum hirsutum'') in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_514> xviii. 12.</ref> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_514> vi. 3, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 355;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 241.</ref>

मसूस्य
<u>'''Masūsya,'''</u> occurring in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 8, 14, 6), is, according to the commentator, the name of a grain of the north country.<br>==Foot Notes==

मस्तु
