<u>'''Mastu'''</u> in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_516> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 1.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_516> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 1, 7;<br> iii. 3, 3, 2, etc.</ref> denotes ‘sour curds.’

मह-र्त्विज्
<u>'''Maha-rtvij,'''</u> ‘great priest,’ is the collective name of the four chief priests--[[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], [[होतृ|Hotṛ]], and Udgātṛ--in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_517> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 2, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 1, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 1, 7, etc.</ref>

मह-र्षभ
<u>'''Maha-rṣabha,'''</u> a ‘great bull,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda (iv. 15, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

मह-र्षि
<u>'''Maha-rṣi,'''</u> a ‘great [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]],’ is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (i. 9, 6). ''Cf.'' '''[[महाब्राह्मण|Mahābrāhmaṇa]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

महा-कुल
<u>'''Mahā-kula,'''</u> ‘sprung from a great family,’ is the designation of a bowl or cup ('''[[चमस|Camasa]]''') in the Rigveda (i. 161, 1). The metaphorical use of this word shows that the high position of certain families was already recognized in the times of the Rigveda.<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-कौषीतक
<u>'''Mahā-kauṣītaka,'''</u> the ‘Great Kauṣītaka ([[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]),’ is the name of a Vedic text in the Rigveda [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras.<ref name=fx1_ve2_521> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 4;<br> Mahākauṣītaki, the teacher, in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10;<br> vi. 1, etc. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 29, 3, 4.</ref>

महाज
<u>'''Mahāja,'''</u> a ‘great goat’ ('''Aja''') is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 4, 1, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-धन
<u>'''Mahā-dhana'''</u> in the Rigveda denotes either a ‘great fight’<ref name=fx1_ve2_523> Rv. i. 7, 5;<br> 40, 8;<br> 112, 17;<br> vi. 59, 7, etc.</ref> or a ‘great prize’<ref name=fx2_ve2_523> ix. 86, 12.</ref> as the result of a fight. In many cases the fight may mean merely the contest of the chariot race.

महा-नग्नी
<u>'''Mahā-nagnī'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_524> xiv. 1, 36;<br> xx. 136, 5 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 27, 1.</ref> denotes a ‘courtesan.’ The masculine, Mahā-nagna,<ref name=fx2_ve2_524> Av. xx. 136, 11;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 24, 14. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 747;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 280, n. 1.</ref> ‘paramour,’ is probably secondarily. derived from the feminine [[महानग्नी|Mahānagnī]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_524> As ''[[स-पत्न|sa-patna]],'' ‘rival,’ is unmistakably formed from ''[[स-पत्नी|sa-patnī]],'' ‘co-wife.’</ref>

महा-नाग
<u>'''Mahā-nāga,'''</u> a ‘great snake,’ is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 2, 7, 12), where it is plainly mythical.<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-निरष्ट
<u>'''Mahā-niraṣṭa,'''</u> a ‘great castrated’ ox, is mentioned as the '''[[दक्षिणा|Dakṣiṇā]],''' or ‘sacrificial fee,’ in the house of the '''[[सूत|Sūta]]''' at the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]]''' (‘royal consecration’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_526> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4, 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[अनड्वाह्|Anaḍvāh]]''' and '''Go.''' 

महा-पथ
<u>'''Mahā-patha'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_527> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 17, 8;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 6, 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 271, n.</ref> denotes the ‘high road’ between two villages.

महा-पुर
<u>'''Mahā-pura'''</u> in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_528> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 3, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiv. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8, 1.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_528> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 23, 2;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 7.</ref> denotes a great fortress.<ref name=fx1_ve2_528/> Probably the only difference between the '''Pur''' and the [[महापुर|Mahāpura]] was size.

महा-ब्राह्मण
<u>'''Mahā-brāhmaṇa,'''</u> a ‘great Brahmin,’ is found in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 1, 19. 22) denoting a Brahmin of great consequence. ''Cf.'' '''[[महर्षि|Maharṣi]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

महाभिषेक
<u>'''Mahābhiṣeka,'''</u> ‘great consecration,’ is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_530> viii. 14, 4;<br> 19, 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 8. The list is '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]] [[पारिक्षित|Pārikṣita]],''' whose friend was '''[[तुर कावषेय|Tura Kāvaṣeya]];<br> [[शार्यात|Śāryāta]] [[मानव|Mānava]]''' and '''[[च्यवन|Cyavana]] [[भार्गव|Bhārgava]];<br> Satānīka [[सात्राजित|Sātrājita]]''' and '''Somaśuṣma [[भार्गव|Bhārgava]];<br> [[अम्बरीष|Ambarīṣa]]''' and '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]''' and '''[[नारद|Nārada]];<br> [[युधांश्रौष्टि औग्रसैन्य|Yudhāṃśrauṣṭi Augrasainya]]''' and the same two [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]];<br> '''[[विश्वकर्मन् भौवन|Viśvakarman Bhauvana]]''' and '''[[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]];<br> [[सुदास्|Sudās]] [[पैजवन|Paijavana]]''' and '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]];<br> [[मरुत्त आविक्षित|Marutta Āvikṣita]]''' and '''[[संवर्त|Saṃvarta]];<br> [[अङ्ग वैरोचन|Aṅga Vairocana]]''' and '''[[उदमय आत्रेय|Udamaya Ātreya]];<br> [[भरत|Bharata]] [[दौःषन्ति|Dauḥṣanti]]''' and '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]] [[मामतेय|Māmateya]];<br> [[दुर्मुख|Durmukha]] [[पाञ्चाल|Pāñcāla]]''' and '''[[बृहद्उक्थ|Bṛhaduktha]];<br> [[अत्य्अराति जानंतपि|Atyarāti Jānaṃtapi]]''' and '''[[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] [[सात्यहव्य|Sātyahavya]].'''</ref> and described as a ceremony performed for great kings, a list of whom is given. It is equivalent to the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]].'''

महा-भूत
<u>'''Mahā-bhūta'''</u> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (xiv. 5, 10) and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 2, 3) denotes the ‘gross elements’ (earth, water, fire, air, ether).<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-मत्स्य
<u>'''Mahā-matsya,'''</u> a ‘great fish,’ is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 3, 18).<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-मेरु
<u>'''Mahā-meru,'''</u> ‘great Meru,’ is the name of a mountain in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_533> i. 7, 1, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78;<br> 3, 123.</ref> 

महा-रथ
<u>'''Mahā-ratha,'''</u> ‘having a great car’--''i.e.,'' ‘a great chariot fighter,’ is an epithet of the hero who is prayed for in the ritual of the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_534> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 18, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 22.</ref>

महा-राज
<u>'''Mahā-rāja,'''</u> a ‘great king,’ is frequently referred to in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_535> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 34, 9;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 4, 21;<br> ii. 5, 4, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 19 ''et seq.;<br>'' Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, etc.</ref> It seems to mean no more than a king, or rather perhaps a reigning and powerful king, as opposed to a mere prince, who would also be called '''[[राजन्|Rājan]].'''

महा-रात्र
<u>'''Mahā-rātra,'''</u> ‘advanced night,’ is a phrase found in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_536> ii. 9;<br> xi. 8.</ref> and the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve2_536> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vi. 2, 1;<br> xvii. 7, 1, etc.</ref> to denote the latter part of the night, after midnight and before dawn.

महार्णव
<u>'''Mahārṇava,'''</u> a ‘great ocean,’ is a phrase not found before the late Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 4), where the drying up of ‘great oceans’ is one of the marvels enumerated. ''Cf.'' '''[[सम्उद्र|Samudra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-वीर
<u>'''Mahā-vīra'''</u> (‘great hero’) is the name in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_538> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 14;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 2, 9, 17;<br> 3, 1, 13;<br> 4, 16;<br> 2, 2, 13. 40;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 10, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 3, 7, etc.</ref> of a large earthenware pot which could be placed on the fire, and which was especially employed at the introductory Soma ceremony called Pravargya.

महा-वृक्ष
<u>'''Mahā-vṛkṣa'''</u> a ‘great tree,’ is mentioned sometimes in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 6, 15; xiv. 1, 12) and in the Sūtras.<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-वृष
<u>'''Mahā-vṛṣa'''</u> is the name of a tribe mentioned along with the '''Mūjavants''' in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_540> v. 22, 4, 5, 8.</ref> as a locality to which fever is to be relegated. It is reasonable to suppose that they were  northerners, though Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve2_540> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 446.</ref> suggests that the name may be chosen more for its sound and sense (as ‘of mighty strength’ to resist the disease) than for its geographical position. In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_540> iv. 2, 5.</ref> the place '''[[रैक्वपर्ण|Raikvaparṇa]]''' is said to be in the [[महावृष|Mahāvṛṣa]] country. The king of the Mahāvṛṣas in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_540> iii. 40, 2.</ref> is said to be '''Hṛtsvāśaya.''' The Mahāvṛṣas are also known from a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx5_ve2_540> ii. 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 70, 147;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 129;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 259, 260.</ref>

महा-शाल
<u>'''1. Mahā-śāla'''</u> (lit., ‘having a great house’), a ‘great householder,’ is an expression applied in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (v. 11, 1) to the Brahmins who were instructed by '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]],''' no doubt to emphasize their importance. ''Cf.'' '''[[महाब्राह्मण|Mahābrāhmaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-शाल जाबाल
<u>'''2. Mahā-śāla Jābāla'''</u> is the name of a teacher twice mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], once as instructing '''[[धीर शातपर्णेय|Dhīra Śātaparṇeya]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_542> x. 3, 3, 1.</ref> and once as one of the Brahmins who received instruction from '''[[अश्वपति|Aśvapati]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_542> x. 6, 1, 1.</ref> In the parallel passage of the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_542> v. 11, 1.</ref> the name is '''[[प्राचीनशाल औपमन्यव|Prācīnaśāla Aupamanyava]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_542> ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 393, n. 1.</ref> The word must be considered a proper name rather than an adjective (1. '''[[महाशाल|Mahāśāla]]'''), as it is taken in the St. Petersburg Dictionary.<ref name=fx5_ve2_542> In Muṇḍaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1, 3, the word is used of '''[[शौनक|Śaunaka]],''' perhaps merely as an epithet. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 161.</ref>

महा-सुपर्ण
<u>'''Mahā-suparṇa'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 2, 3, 7) denotes a ‘great bird’ or ‘great eagle.’<br>==Foot Notes==

महा-सुहय
<u>'''Mahā-suhaya,'''</u> a ‘great (''i.e.,'' high-spirited) horse,’ is the description in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_544> vi. 2, 13. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, ix. 7;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 1, 12;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 234, 235;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 57, n. 3. ''Cf.'' '''Paḍhīśa.'''</ref> of the steed from  the Indus (''[[सैन्धव|saindhava]]'') which tears away the peg of its hobble (''[[पड्बीश|paḍbīśa]]-śaṅkhu'').

महा-सूक्त
<u>'''Mahā-sūkta,'''</u> m. plur., the ‘composers of the long hymns’ of the tenth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_545> x. 1-128.</ref> are mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve2_545> ii. 2, 2.</ref> and the Sūtras.<ref name=fx3_ve2_545> Aśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 115;<br> 390;<br> Roth, ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 27.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Kṣudra-[[सूक्त|sūkta]].'''

महाह्न
<u>'''Mahāhna'''</u> in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 9) denotes the ‘advanced (time of the) day’--that is, ‘afternoon.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[महारात्र|Mahārātra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

महि-दास ऐतरेय
<u>'''Mahi-[[दास|dāsa]] Aitareya'''</u> (‘descendant of Itara or Itarā’) is the name of the sage from whom the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and Āraṇyaka take their names. He is several times referred to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve2_547> ii. 1, 8;<br> 3, 7.</ref> but not as its author. He is credited with a life of 116 years in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_547> iii. 16, 7.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_547> iv. 2, 11 (''cf. Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 246).<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 16, 17.</ref>

महिष
<u>'''Mahiṣa,'''</u> the ‘strong,’ with<ref name=fx1_ve2_548> Rv. viii. 58, 15;<br> ix. 92, 6;<br> 96, 6;<br> x. 123, 4.</ref> or without<ref name=fx2_ve2_548> Rv. v. 29, 7;<br> vi. 67, 11;<br> viii. 12, 8;<br> 66, 10;<br> ix. 87, 7;<br> x. 28, 10;<br> 189, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 28, etc.</ref> '''[[मृग|Mṛga]],''' ‘wild beast,’ denotes the ‘buffalo’ in the Rigveda and the later texts. The feminine, [[महिषी|Mahiṣī]], is found in the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx3_ve2_548> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 6;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8, 5;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 7, 11.</ref>

महिषी
<u>'''1. Mahiṣī.'''</u> See '''[[महिष|Mahiṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

महिषी
<u>'''2. Mahiṣī,'''</u> ‘the powerful one,’ the name of the first of the four wives (see '''Pati''') of the king, is mentioned frequently in  the later literature.<ref name=fx1_ve2_550> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xix. 1, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5, 3, 1;<br> vii. 5, 1, 6, etc.</ref> Perhaps even in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_550> v. 2, 2;<br> 37, 3.</ref> the technical sense of ‘first wife’ is present.

महैतरेय
<u>'''Mahaitareya'''</u> is the title of a Vedic text according to the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras of the [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_551> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 4;<br> of a teacher, in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10;<br> vi. 1. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 39;<br> Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 29, 3, 4.</ref>

महोक्ष
<u>'''Mahokṣa,'''</u> a ‘great bull,’ is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 4, 1, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

मांस
<u>'''Māṃsa,'''</u> ‘flesh.’ The eating of flesh appears as something quite regular in the Vedic texts, which show no trace of the doctrine of Ahiṃsā, or abstaining from injury to animals. For example, the ritual offerings of flesh contemplate that the gods will eat it, and again the Brahmins ate the offerings.<ref name=fx1_ve2_553> So Agni is called ‘eater of ox and cow’ in Rv. viii. 43, 11 = Av. iii. 21, 6 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 3, 14, 7;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 280, 281;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 355.</ref> Again, the slaying of a ‘great ox’ (''[[महोक्ष|mahokṣa]]'') or a ‘great goat’ (''[[महाज|mahāja]]'') for a guest was regularly prescribed;<ref name=fx2_ve2_553> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 2. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 15, 2.</ref> and the name '''[[अतिथिग्व|Atithigva]]''' probably means ‘slaying cows for guests.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_553> Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 426;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, cxxiv. ''Cf. atithinīr gāḥ,'' ‘cows fit for guests,’ Rv. x. 68, 3.</ref> The great sage '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]]''' was wont to eat the meat of milch cows and bullocks (''dhenv-anaḍuha'') if only it was ''aṃsala'' (‘firm’ or ‘tender’).<ref name=fx4_ve2_553> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 2, 21. The sense of ''aṃsala'' is given as ''sthūla,'' firm,’ in the scholiast. ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 2, 23-25. Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 11, has tender.’ ‘Off the shoulder’ (''aṃsa'') is also a possible version.</ref> The slaughter of a hundred bulls (''[[उक्षन्|ukṣan]]'') was credited to one sacrificer, '''[[अगस्त्य|Agastya]].'''<ref name=fx5_ve2_553> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 11, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 14, 5.</ref> The marriage ceremony was accompanied by the slaying of oxen, clearly for food.<ref name=fx6_ve2_553> Q.v. x. 85, 13. ''Cf.'' Winternitz, ''Das altindische Hochzeitsrituell,'' 33.</ref> <br><br>That there was any general objection to the eating of flesh is most improbable. Sometimes it is forbidden, as when a man is performing a vow,<ref name=fx7_ve2_553> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 1, 8. So a '''Brahmacārin''' is not to eat flesh. See Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 468, n. 3. The blood of an animal is always a somewhat mysterious and dangerous substance;<br> hence taboos on meat-eating, which in another form arise from fear of the spirits of the dead (''cf.'' Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 414, n. 1). See also Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 1, 29;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 588, n. 4.</ref> or its use is disapproved, as in a passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx8_ve2_553> vi. 70, 1. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 493.</ref> where meat is classed with '''[[सुरा|Surā]],''' or intoxicating liquor, as a bad thing. Again, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx9_ve2_553> x. 85, 13. In the Atharvaveda, xiv. 1, 13, the ordinary word [[मघास्|Maghās]] is found, and is, no doubt, really to be preferred. See Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1894, 807.</ref> the slaying of the cows is said to take place in the '''Aghās,''' a deliberate variation for '''[[मघास्|Maghās]];''' but this may be the outcome merely of a natural association of death with gloom, even when cows alone are the victims in question. The Brāhmaṇas also contain the doctrine of the eater in this world being eaten in the next,<ref name=fx10_ve2_553> ''Cf.'' the story of '''[[भृगु|Bhṛgu]] [[वारुणि|Vāruṇi]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 1, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 42-44;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 1, 2, with Keith's notes (pp. 202, 203).</ref> but this is not to be regarded as a moral or religious disapproval of eating flesh, though it no doubt contains the germ of such a view, which is also in harmony with the persuasion of the unity of existence, which becomes marked in the Brāhmaṇas. But Ahiṃsā as a developed and articulate doctrine would seem to have arisen from the acceptance of the doctrine of transmigration, which in its fundamentals is later than the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period.<ref name=fx11_ve2_553> ''Cf.'' Deussen, ''Philosophy of the Upanishads,'' 317 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 565.</ref><br><br>On the other hand, it is to be noted that the cow was on the road to acquire special sanctity in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx12_ve2_553> viii. 101, 15. 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 19, 20;<br> Av. x. 10;<br> xii. 4, 5;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 151.</ref> as is shown by the name ''[[अघ्न्या|aghnyā]],''<ref name=fx13_ve2_553> Found sixteen times in the Rigveda, as opposed to three instances of Aghnya (masculine);<br> Macdonell, ''loc. cit.'' The sense of ‘hard to overcome,’ preferred by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, to that of ‘not to be killed,’ is, however, quite possible. Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 17, 281, tries to derive the word from ''ahanya,'' ‘bright-coloured like dya,’ a derivation that must be regarded as illegitimate.</ref> ‘not to be slain,’ applied to it in several passages. But this fact cannot be regarded as showing that  meat eating generally was condemned. Apart from mythical considerations, such as the identification of the cow with earth or Aditi (which are, of course, much more than an effort of priestly ingenuity), the value of the cow for other purposes than eating was so great as to account adequately for its sanctity, the beginnings of which can in fact be traced back to Indo-Iranian times.<ref name=fx14_ve2_553> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 68.</ref> Moreover, the ritual of the cremation of the dead required the slaughter of a cow as an essential part, the flesh being used to envelope the dead body.<ref name=fx15_ve2_553> Rv. x. 16, 7. See Oldenberg, ''op. cit.,'' 576.</ref><br><br>The usual food of the Vedic Indian, as far as flesh was concerned, can be gathered from the list of sacrificial victims: what man ate he presented to the gods--that is, the sheep, the goat, and the ox. The horse sacrifice was an infrequent exception: it is probably not to be regarded as a trace of the use of horseflesh as food, though the possibility of such being the case cannot be overlooked in view of the widespread use of horseflesh as food in different countries and times. It is, however, more likely that the aim of this sacrifice was to impart magic strength, the speed and vigour of the horse, to the god and his worshippers, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx16_ve2_553> ''Religion des Veda,'' 356, n. 4. As to meat-eating in Buddhist times, ''cf.'' the death of the Buddha from a meal of pork, Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1906, 881, 882;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,''^5 231, n. 2 (''contra'' Neumann, ''Die Reden des Gotamo Buddho,'' 1, xix). As to meat-eating in the Epic, see Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 119, 120;<br> ''Great Epic of India,'' 377-379;<br> and see for modern instances Jolly, ''Deutsche Rundschau,'' July, 1884. 118;<br> Bühler, ''Report,'' 23.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 316;<br> Hopkins, ''Religions of India,'' 156, 189.</ref> argues.

मांसौदन
<u>'''Māṃsaudana'''</u> denotes in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_554> xi. 5, 7, 5;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 18;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8.</ref> a dish consisting of ‘meat cooked with rice.’

माक्षव्य
<u>'''Mākṣavya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Makṣu,’ is the patronymic of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_555> iii. 1, 1, which is discussed in the preface to the Rigveda Prātiśākhya. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 391;<br> 2, 212.</ref> 

मागध
<u>'''Māgadha.'''</u> See '''[[मगध|Magadha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मागध-देशीय
<u>'''Māgadha-deśīya,'''</u> ‘belonging to the district of '''[[मगध|Magadha]],'''’ is the description in the Sūtras<ref name=fx1_ve2_557> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 4, 22;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6, 28.</ref> of a Brahmin of [[मगध|Magadha]].

माचल
<u>'''Mācala,'''</u> mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_558> ii. 440. ''Cf. Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 103, n. 3.</ref> apparently denotes some sort of dog found in '''[[विदर्भ|Vidarbha]].'''

माठरी
<u>'''Māṭharī,'''</u> ‘female descendant of Maṭhara,’ occurs in the curious name, '''[[काश्यपी-बालाक्या-माठरी-पुत्र|Kāśyapī-bālākyā-<a class="pada_vei" href="माठरी">māṭharī]]-putra»,''' of a teacher in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 31 Mādhyaṃdina).<br>==Foot Notes==

माण्टि
<u>'''Māṇṭi'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[गौतम|Gautama]],''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_560> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

माण्डवी
<u>'''Māṇḍavī,'''</u> ‘female descendant of Maṇḍu,’ occurs in the name of a teacher, '''[[वात्सी-माण्डवी-पुत्र|Vātsī-<a class="pada_vei" href="माण्डवी">māṇḍavī]]-putra»,''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30 Mādhyaṃdina).<br>==Foot Notes==

माण्डव्य
<u>'''Māṇḍavya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Maṇḍu,’ is mentioned as a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_562> x. 6, 5, 9.</ref> in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve2_562> vii. 2.</ref> and in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx3_ve2_562> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10;<br> vi. 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien'' 1, 482 (in the Epic a friend of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' is so named).</ref> He is also mentioned as a pupil of '''[[कौत्स|Kautsa]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_562> vi. 5, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref>

माण्डूकायनि
<u>'''Māṇḍūkāyani,'''</u> ‘descendant of Māṇḍūka,’ is mentioned as a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_563> x. 6, 5, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 5, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> 

माण्डूकायनी-पुत्र
<u>'''Māṇḍūkāyanī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Māṇḍūka,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[माण्डूकीपुत्र|Māṇḍūkīputra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Brhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_564> vi. 4, 32 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

माण्डूकी-पुत्र
<u>'''Māṇḍūkī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of [[मण्डूक|Maṇḍūka]],’ is mentioned as a teacher, a pupil of '''[[शाण्डिलीपुत्र|Śāṇḍilīputra]],''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_565> vi. 4, 32 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

माण्डूकेय
<u>'''Māṇḍūkeya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Māṇḍūka,’ is the patronymic of several teachers in the Rigveda Āraṇyakas--viz., '''Śūravīra,'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_566> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 1;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, vii. 2. 8. 9. 10.</ref> '''Hrasva,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_566> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 12;<br> viii. 11.</ref> '''Dīrgha,'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_566> ''Ibid.,'' vii. 2.</ref> '''Madhyama Prātībodhīputra.'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_566> ''Ibid.,'' vii. 13.</ref> The Māṇḍūkeyas also occur as a school in the Āraṇyakas:<ref name=fx5_ve2_566> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 1;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, vii. 2.</ref> a special form of the text of the Rigveda evidently appertained to them.<ref name=fx6_ve2_566> ''Cf.'' the ''Māṇḍākeyīya adhyāya'' of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 11;<br> Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des Rigveda,'' 12;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 227;<br> ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 239;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 391.</ref>

मातरिश्वन्
<u>'''Mātariśvan'''</u> is mentioned in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_567> Rv. viii. 52, 2.</ref> as a sacrificer along with '''[[मेध्य|Medhya]]''' and '''[[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]].''' He seems to be mentioned also in one other passage, possibly in two.<ref name=fx2_ve2_567> Rv. x. 48, 2;<br> 105, 6. The former reference is much more probable than the latter.</ref> In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_567> xvi. 11, 26;<br> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 39, 40. The manuscripts vary between [[मातरिश्वन्|Mātariśvan]] and Mātariśva.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> a patron, '''[[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]] [[मेध्य|Medhya]] [[मातरिश्वन्|Mātariśvan]]''' or '''Mātariśva''' is created by a misunderstanding of the Rigvedic text. 

मातुर्-भ्रात्र
<u>'''Mātur-bhrātra'''</u> is a curiously formed compound, occurring once in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_568> i. 6, 12.</ref> as a designation of the ‘maternal uncle,’ who in the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period bears the name of '''[[मातुल|Mātula]].''' Thus little is heard of the maternal uncle in the Vedic period: it is not till the Epic<ref name=fx2_ve2_568> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 141.</ref> that traces appear of his prominence as compared with the paternal uncle (''pitṛvya''). This fact is significant for the ‘patriarchal’ character of the early Indian family organization.<ref name=fx3_ve2_568> Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 484, 586-588. ''Cf.'' also Rivers, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 629 ''et seq.''</ref>

मातुल
<u>'''Mātula,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_569> This peculiarly formed word was presumably a dialectic form which made its way into the written speech.</ref> ‘maternal uncle,’ is found only in the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve2_569> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 24, 4, etc.</ref> and later.

मातृ
<u>'''Mātṛ'''</u> is the regular word for ‘mother’ from the Rigveda onwards,<ref name=fx1_ve2_570> i. 24, 1;<br> vii. 101, 3, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 21, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, etc.</ref> being a formation probably developed under the influence of an onomatopœtic word ''mā,''<ref name=fx2_ve2_570> Bo7htlingk and Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' note.</ref> used like Ambā<ref name=fx3_ve2_570> ''Cf.'' ''ambe ambike ambalike,'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 18, with variations in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 6, 3;<br> also ''ambā ambāyavī, ambayā,'' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3.</ref> and '''[[नना|Nanā]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_570> Rv. ix. 112, 3 ('''[[उपलप्रक्षिणी|Upalaprakṣiṇī]]'''). See von Schroeder, ''Mysterium und Mimus,'' 412.</ref><br><br>The relations of wife and husband, as well as of mother and children, are treated under '''Pati.''' It remains only to add that details are given in the Sūtras<ref name=fx5_ve2_570> ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 460, 476, 477.</ref> of the respectful attention paid to a mother, and of the ceremonies in which she is concerned. The mother also appears interested in the fate of her children as in the story of the sale of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' for adoption by '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx6_ve2_570> vii. 18 ''seq. Cf.'' also Leist, ''Altarisches Jus Gentium,'' 104;<br> Jolly, ''Die Adoption in Indien,'' 16, 17.</ref> <br><br>In the household the mother ranked after the father (see '''[[पितृ|Pitṛ]]'''). Occasionally ''mātarā'' is used for ‘parents,’ as are also ''pitarā'' and ''mātarā pitarā''<ref name=fx7_ve2_570> Rv. iii. 33, 3;<br> vii. 2, 5, etc. For ''mātarā pitarā,'' see Rv. iv. 6, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 19.</ref> and ''mātā-pitaraḥ.''<ref name=fx8_ve2_570> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 3, 10, vi. 3, 11, 3.</ref>

मातृ-वध
<u>'''Mātṛ-vadha,'''</u> ‘matricide,’ is mentioned as a very grave crime in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 1), but as one that can be expiated by the knowledge of the truth.<br>==Foot Notes==

मातृ-हन्
<u>'''Mātṛ-han,'''</u> ‘mother-killer,’ ‘matricide,’ occurs in a Vedic quotation mentioned by the commentator on Pāṇini.<ref name=fx1_ve2_572> Kāśikā Vṛtti on Pāṇīni, iii. 2, 88;<br> ''mātṛhā saptamaṃ narakaṃ praviśet.''</ref>

मात्रा
<u>'''Mātrā'''</u> in the Upaniṣads<ref name=fx1_ve2_573> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 15.</ref> denotes a mora, the length of a short vowel.

मात्स्य
<u>'''1. Mātsya,'''</u> ‘prince of the [[मत्स्य|Matsya]] people.’ See '''[[मत्स्य|Matsya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मात्स्य
<u>'''2. Mātsya'''</u> occurs in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_575> i. 5, 2, 1, where he serves [[यज्ञेषु|Yajñeṣu]] and [[शतद्युम्न|Śatadyumna]].</ref> as the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] skilled in sacrifice. Possibly,<ref name=fx2_ve2_575> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 681.</ref> but not probably, he may also be meant in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_575> xix. 39, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 306.</ref>

माथव
<u>'''Māthava,'''</u> ‘descendant of Mathu,’ is the patronymic of '''[[विदेघ|Videgha]],''' perhaps ‘king of [[विदेह|Videha]],’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_576> i. 4, 1, 10. 17. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xli, 104, n. 1;<br> 26, xxix.;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170.</ref> 

माधुकि
<u>'''Mādhuki,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Madhuka,''' is the patronymic of a teacher mentioned with disapproval in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_577> ii. 1, 4, 27. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 434.</ref>

माध्यंदिनायन
<u>'''Mādhyaṃdināyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[मध्यंदिन|Madhyaṃdina]],’ is the patronymic of a teacher mentioned in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 6, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

माध्यम
<u>'''Mādhyama'''</u> (‘relating to the middle’) is a term applied in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_579> xii. 3.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve2_579> ii. 2, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 115, 389;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10, etc.</ref> to denote the ‘authors of the middle books’ (ii.-vii.) of the Rigveda.

मान
<u>'''1. Māna'''</u> as a measure of weight is said to be the equivalent of the '''[[कृष्णल|Kṛṣṇala]]''' or Raktikā--that is, the berry of the Guñjā (''Abrus precatorius''). It occurs in compounds in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_580> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 6, 3;<br> vi. 4, 10, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 7, 7;<br> 7, 6, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 3, 24;<br> 5, 5, 16, etc.</ref>

मान
<u>'''2. Māna'''</u> is the name of a man occurring in several passages of the Rigveda. In one place<ref name=fx1_ve2_581> Rv. i. 189, 8.</ref> express mention is made of his son (''[[सूनु|sūnu]]''), by whom, despite Bergaigne's view to the contrary,<ref name=fx2_ve2_581> ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 394. ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 173;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 221, n. 5;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 110;<br> Sieg. ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 107;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 135.</ref> '''[[अगस्त्य|Agastya]]''' must be meant. In another passage,<ref name=fx3_ve2_581> vii. 33, 13. ''Cf.'' verse 10.</ref> apparently the same meaning applies to [[मान|Māna]]--that is, [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]] as ‘a [[मान|Māna]].’ In a third passage<ref name=fx4_ve2_581> i. 117, 11.</ref> the expression ''sūnave Mānena'' has been held by Sieg<ref name=fx5_ve2_581> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> to be an inversion of ''Mānasya sūnunā,'' ‘by the son of Māna’--''i.e.,'' [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]]; but it seems more likely<ref name=fx6_ve2_581> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten, loc. cit.''</ref> that either ''sūnor [[मान|Māna]]'' is the fuller form of Agastya's name (‘pride  of the son,’ with reference to his high ancestry), or that the son<ref name=fx7_ve2_581> Bergaigne, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Pischel, ''loc. cit. Cf.'' Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' where ''sūnoḥ'' is taken as dependent on ''vājam.''</ref> of [[मान|Māna]] (= [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]]) is alluded to as interested in '''[[विश्पला|Viśpalā]].'''<br><br>The Mānas--that is, the descendants of [[मान|Māna]], are in several passages alluded to as singers.<ref name=fx8_ve2_581> Rv. i. 169, 8;<br> 171, 5;<br> 182, 8;<br> 184, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 116, 117, who thinks the Mānas were settled on the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus). See Rv. i. 186,5</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[मान्य|Mānya]], Māndārya.'''

मानव
<u>'''Mānava,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Manu,'''’<ref name=fx1_ve2_582> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 14, 2.</ref> is the patronymic of '''[[नाभानेदिष्ठ|Nābhānediṣṭha]]''' and of '''[[शार्यात|Śāryāta]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_582> ''Ibid.,'' iv. 32, 7. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 2 ('''[[शर्यात|Śaryāta]]''').</ref>

मानवी
<u>'''Mānavī,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Manu,'''’ is the patronymic of the mythical Iḍā (‘oblation’) in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_583> i. 8, 1, 26;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 7, 3.</ref> and of a woman named '''[[पर्शु|Parśu]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_583> x. 86, 23.</ref>

मानु-तन्तव्य
<u>'''Mānu-tantavya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Manutantu,’ is the patronymic of '''Aikādaśākṣa''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 30, 15). The Saumāpau Mānutantavyau, ‘two Saumāpas, descendants of Manutantu,’ are mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 5, 3, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

मान्थाल
<u>'''Mānthāla'''</u> is the form in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 5, 8, 4) of the next name.<br>==Foot Notes==

मन्थालव
<u>'''Manthālava,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_586> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 19, where there is a variant Mātālava;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 38.</ref> '''Mānthīlava'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_586> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 18, 1.</ref> are the names in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās of a victim at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’). What it was is unknown: the commentator Mahīdhara<ref name=fx3_ve2_586> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> thinks it was a kind of mouse; Sāyaṇa explains it as a ‘water-cock’  (''jala-[[कुक्कुट|kukkuṭa]]''). Possiby, if Sāyaṇa's<ref name=fx4_ve2_586> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 86.</ref> version of the parallel word '''[[मन्थावल|Manthāvala]]''' is to be trusted, the ‘flying fox’ may be meant.<ref name=fx5_ve2_586> Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and also ''s.v. māndhāla.''</ref>

मान्दार्य मान्य
<u>'''Māndārya Mānya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[मान|Māna]],'''’ is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_587> i. 165, 15 = i. 166, 15 = i. 167, 11 = i. 168, 10.</ref> It seems most probable that '''[[अगस्त्य|Agastya]]''' himself is meant.<ref name=fx2_ve2_587> ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 135;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Védique,'' 2, 394;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 221;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 107;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 183 ''et seq.,'' 206.</ref>

मान्य
<u>'''Mānya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[मान|Māna]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Māndārya''' in several passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_588> See '''Māndārya,''' n. 1.</ref> being also found alone in others.<ref name=fx2_ve2_588> i. 165, 14;<br> 177, 5;<br> 184, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]'' 107.</ref> It probably denotes '''[[अगस्त्य|Agastya]].'''

मान्यमान
<u>'''Mānyamāna'''</u> occurs with the word '''Devaka''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_589> viii. 18, 20.</ref> The word seems to be a patronymic from Manyamāna, meaning ‘son of the proud one.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_589> Sāyaṇa takes Manyamāna as a proper name.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_589> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 264.</ref> renders the two words ‘the godling, the proudling (hast thou smitten).’

मामतेय
<u>'''Māmateya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[ममता|Mamatā]],’ is the metronymic of '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]]''' in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_590> i. 147, 3;<br> 152, 6;<br> 158, 6.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_590> viii. 23, 1;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 17. For [[ममता|Mamatā]], ''cf.'' Bṛhaddevatā, iii. 56;<br> iv. 11.</ref>

मायव
<u>'''Māyava,'''</u> ‘descendant of Mayu or [[मायु|Māyu]],’ is the patronymic of a patron in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_591> x. 93, 15.</ref> perhaps of '''[[राम|Rāma]],''' as Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_591> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 106.</ref> thinks. 

माय
<u>'''Māya'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 4, 3, 11) corresponds to '''[[असुरविद्या|Asuravidyā]],''' ‘magic.’<br>==Foot Notes==

मायु
<u>'''Māyu'''</u> denotes the ‘lowing’ of a cow and the ‘bleating’ of a sheep or goat in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_593> i. 164, 28 (cow);<br> vii. 103, 2 (cow);<br> x. 95, 3 (ewe);<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 9.</ref> as well as the ‘chattering’ of a monkey in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_593> vi. 38, 4;<br> xix. 49, 4 (called ''[[पुरुष|puruṣa]];<br> cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 85, 86;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[मायु|Māyu]]'').</ref>

मारुत
<u>'''Māruta,'''</u> ‘descendant of Marut,’ is the patronymic of '''Dyutāna''' and of '''Nitāna.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मारुताश्व
<u>'''Mārutāśva,'''</u> ‘descendant of Marutāśva,’ is, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx1_ve2_595> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155. It may be a patronymic of '''Cyavatāna.'''</ref> the patronymic of a patron in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_595> v. 33, 9.</ref> The word may, however, be merely an adjective ‘having windswift horses.’

मार्गवेय
<u>'''Mārgaveya'''</u> is the patronymic or metronymic of '''[[राम|Rāma]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 27, 3. 4), where he is mentioned as a '''Śyāparṇa.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मार्गार
<u>'''Mārgāra'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the Paruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_597> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1.</ref> The sense of the word is apparently ‘hunter,’ or possibly ‘fisherman,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_597> ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> as a patronymic from ''mṛgāri,'' ‘enemy of wild beasts.’

माल्य
<u>'''1. Mālya,'''</u> ‘garland,’ is found in the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx1_ve2_598> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 2, 6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, etc.</ref>

माल्य
<u>'''2. Mālya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Māla,’ is the patronymic of '''[[आर्य|Ārya]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 4, 11). <br>==Foot Notes==

माष
<u>'''Māṣa'''</u> is the name of a kind of bean (''Phaseolus radiatus'') in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_600> vi. 140, 2;<br> xii. 2, 53.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_600> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 8, 1;<br> vii. 2, 10, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 7;<br> xxxii. 7;<br> xxxvii. 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 12;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 10;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 13 ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> It is still one of the most valuable of similar plants in India. The seeds<ref name=fx3_ve2_600> Later described as marked with black and grey spots. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> were pounded (''[[पिष्ट|piṣṭa]]'') according to the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx4_ve2_600> xii. 2, 53. ''Ibid.,'' xii. 2, 4, an offering of crushed beans (''māṣājya'') is mentioned.</ref> These beans ripened in the winter (''[[हेमन्त|hemanta]]'').<ref name=fx5_ve2_600> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 10, 2.</ref> In the ritual the human head for the sacrifice is bought for twenty-one Māṣas<ref name=fx6_ve2_600> ''Ibid.,'' v. 1, 8, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xx. 8.</ref> : it does not appear that the word here means a weight of metal, as it often does later.<ref name=fx7_ve2_600> Weber, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 18, 267. According to Manu, viii. 134, one [[माष|Māṣa]] is equivalent to five (erroneously stated as four above, vol. i., p. 185) '''Kṛṣṇalas.''' ''Cf.'' also St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2.</ref> A taboo on beans is found in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx8_ve2_600> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxii. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 10. मास्
<u>'''Mās'''</u> denotes rarely ‘moon,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_601> Rv. x. 12, 7. ''Cf.'' also the compound ''sūryā-māsā,'' ‘sun and moon,’ viii. 94, 2;<br> x. 64, 3;<br> 68, 10;<br> 92, 12;<br> 93, 5, which may, however, be formed from ''[[मास|māsa]]. Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 220, n. 20.</ref> and often ‘month’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_601> Rv. i. 25, 8;<br> iv. 18, 4;<br> v. 45, 7. 11;<br> vii. 91, 2, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_601> Av. viii. 10, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 2, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 4, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 9, 1, etc.</ref> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

मास
<u>'''Māsa'''</u> denotes a ‘month,’ a period of time repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda and later.<br><br>The characteristic days (or rather nights) of the month were those of the new moon, Amā-vasyā, ‘home-staying (night),’ and ‘of the full moon,’ [[पौर्ण-मासी|Paurṇa-māsī]]. Two hymns of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_602> vii. 79 and 80. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 1, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 5, 13, etc.</ref> celebrate these days respectively. A personification of the phases of the moon is seen in the four names [[सिनीवाली|Sinīvālī]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_602> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 8, 1;<br>  iii. 4, 9, 1;<br> Rv. ii. 32, 6;<br> Av. ii. 26, 2;<br> vi. 11, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 55. 56;<br> xxxiv. 10;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 8;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 6.</ref>  the day before new moon; [[कुहू|Kuhū]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_602> Av. vii. 47;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 8, 1;<br> iii. 4, 9, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 8, etc.</ref> also called Guṅgū,<ref name=fx4_ve2_602> Rv. ii. 32, 8, where Sāyaṇa identifies it with [[कुहू|Kuhū]].</ref> the new moon day; [[अनुमति|Anumati]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_602> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 8, 1;<br> iii. 4, 9, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 60;<br> xxxiv. 8, 9;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 6.</ref> the day before full moon; and [[राका|Rākā]],<ref name=fx6_ve2_602> Rv. ii. 32, 4;<br> v. 42, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 8, 1;<br> iii. 4, 9, 1. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xi. 31;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 228 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 189.</ref> the day of new moon. The importance of the new and full moon days is seen in the [[दर्श|Darśa]]-pūrṇamāsau, or festivals of the new and full moon days respectively.<br><br>One special day in the month, the '''[[एकाष्टका|Ekāṣṭakā]],''' or eighth day after full moon, was important. In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve2_602> x. 3, 11. ''Cf.'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 2, 23;<br> Av. xv. 16, 2.</ref> there are stated to be in the year twelve such, mentioned between the twelve days of full moon and the twelve days of new moon. But one [[एकाष्टका|Ekāṣṭakā]] is referred to in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās and elsewhere<ref name=fx8_ve2_602> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 8, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 9, 1. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 8, 4;<br> iv. 3, 11, 3;<br> v. 7, 2, 2;<br> Av. iii. 10;<br> viii. 9, 10;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxix. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 13, 21, etc. See Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 1, 2, with the commentary;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.,'' with Sāyaṇa's notes;<br> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 341, 342;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 219 ''et seq.''</ref> as of quite special importance. This was, in the accordant opinion of most commentators, the eighth day after the full moon of '''Māgha.''' It marked the end of the year, or the beginning of the new year. Though the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx9_ve2_602> xix. 23.</ref> places the winter solstice in the new moon of Māgha, the latter date probably means the new moon preceding full moon in Māgha,<ref name=fx10_ve2_602> So Vināyaka on [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Ānartīya on [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 19, 1;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 345, 346, 353, 354. Weber accepts the scholiasts’ view that Māgha is here regarded as beginning with the day after full moon in Taiṣa;<br> but it is simpler to suppose the meaning to be that Māgha is regarded as commencing with, not after, the new moon and ending with the day before new moon. Several passages in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (ii. 12;<br> iii. 1;<br> xxvi. 18;<br> xxx. 3;<br> see Caland, ''Über das vituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 36, 37) and [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 1, 7, point to the full moon being the middle of the month, and the new moon being regarded as either the beginning or the end. Hopkins (n. 11) thinks [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 2, 18, point to the commencement of the month with the full moon. If this could be accepted, then the [[अष्टका|Aṣṭakā]] would fall a week before the winter solstice in Māgha.</ref> not the new moon following  full moon; but it is perhaps possible to account adequately for the importance of the [[एकाष्टका|Ekāṣṭakā]] as being the first [[अष्टका|Aṣṭakā]] after the beginning of the new year.<br><br>It is not certain exactly how the month was reckoned, whether from the day after new moon to new moon--the system known as ''amānta,'' or from the day after full moon to full moon--the ''pūrṇimānta'' system, which later, at any rate, was followed in North India, while the other system prevailed in the south. Jacobi<ref name=fx11_ve2_602> ''Zeitschrfit der Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 229, n. 1;<br> 50, 81. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 24, 20.</ref> argues that the year began in the full moon of Phālguna, and that only by the full moon's conjunction with the [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] could the month be known. Oldenberg<ref name=fx12_ve2_602> ''Ibid.,'' 48, 633, n. 1;<br> 49, 476, 477. This is the Epic rule, Hopkins, ''loc. cit.''</ref> points to the fact that the new moon is far more distinctively an epoch than the full moon; that the Greek, Roman, and Jewish years began with the new moon; and that the Vedic evidence is the division of the month into the former (''pūrva'') and latter (''apara'') halves, the first being the bright (''[[शुक्ल|śukla]]''), the second the dark (''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]'') period. Thibaut<ref name=fx13_ve2_602> ''Indian Antiquary,'' 24, 87. None of the evidence is absolutely conclusive one way or the other. It is perfectly possible that the usage of families or districts differed. ''Cf.'' Thibaut, ''Astronomie, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 12.</ref> considers that to assume the existence of the ''pūrṇimānta'' system for the Veda is unnecessary, though possible. Weber<ref name=fx10_ve2_602/> assumes that it occurs in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] as held by the scholiasts. But it would probably be a mistake to press that passage, or to assume that the ''amānta'' system was rigidly accepted in the Veda: it seems at least as probable that the month was vaguely regarded as beginning with the new moon day, so that new moon preceded full moon, which was in the middle, not the end or the beginning of the month.<br><br>That a month regularly had 30 days is established by the conclusive evidence of numerous passages in which the year is given 12 months and 360 days. This month is known from the earliest records, being both referred to directly and alluded to.<ref name=fx14_ve2_602> Rv. i. 164, 11. 14, 48;<br> x. 189, 3;<br> 190, 2;<br> Av. iv. 35, 4;<br> x. 7, 6;<br> 8, 23;<br> xiii. 3, 8, etc.</ref>  It is the regular month of the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx15_ve2_602> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 10, 8;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 12;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 2, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 1;<br> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxvi. 10;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 22. See also Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 288;<br> Thibaut, ''Astronomie, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 8.</ref> and must be regarded as the month which the Vedic Indian recognized. No other month is mentioned as such in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] literature; it is only in the Sūtras that months of different length occur. The [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]] Sūtras<ref name=fx16_ve2_602> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 8, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 11. 12;<br> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 281-288.</ref> refer to (1) years with 324 days--''i.e.,'' periodic years with 12 months of 27 days each; (2) years with 351 days--''i.e.,'' periodic years with 12 months of 27 days each, plus another month of 27 days; (3) years with 354 days--''i.e.,'' 6 months of 30 days, and 6 with 29 days, in other words, lunar synodic years; (4) years with 360 days, or ordinary civil (''sāvana'') years; (5) years with 378 days, which, as Thibaut<ref name=fx17_ve2_602> ''Op. cit.,'' 8, 9.</ref> clearly shows, are third years, in which, after two years of 360 days each, 18 days were added to bring about correspondence between the civil year and the solar year of 366 days. On the other hand, the period of ten months quite well suits the period of gestation, if birth takes place in the tenth month, so that in this sense the month of 30 days may well be meant. <br><br>The year of 12 months of 30 days each being admittedly quite unscientific, Zimmer<ref name=fx23_ve2_602> ''Op. cit.,'' 369, 370.</ref> is strongly of opinion that it was only used with a recognition of the fact that intercalation took place, and that the year formed part of a greater complex, normally the five your Yuga or cycle. This system is well known from the Jyotṣa: it consists of 62 months of 29(16/31) days each = 1, 830 days (two of these months being intercalary, one in the middle and one at the end), or 61 months of 30 days, or 60 months of 30(1/2) days, the unit being clearly a solar year of 366 days. It is not an ideal system, since the year is too long;<ref name=fx24_ve2_602> The Yuga is too long by nearly four days. The true year has 365 days, 5 hours, 48 minutes, 46 seconds. ''Cf.'' Thibaut, ''op. cit.,'' 24, 25.</ref> but it is one which cannot be claimed even for the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period, during which no decision as to the true length of the year seems to have been arrived at. The [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx44_ve2_602> xxxviii. 4.</ref> gives it the name of [[मलिम्लुच|Malimluca]], which also occurs elsewhere, along with [[संसर्प|Saṃsarpa]], in one of the lists of fanciful names.<ref name=fx45_ve2_602> ''Ibid.,'' xxxv. 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃitā, xxii. 30.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx46_ve2_602> v. 6, 4.</ref> describes it as ''[[सनिस्रस|sanisrasa]],'' ‘slipping,’ owing no doubt to its unstable condition.<br><br>The other method of naming the months is from the '''Nakṣatras.''' It is only beginning to be used in the Brāhmaṇas, but is found regularly in the Epic and later. The [[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]]<ref name=fx47_ve2_602> Verse 6 [[यजुस्|Yajus]] recension = verse 5 Ṛc recension: Weber, 2, 354 ''et seq.''</ref> mentions that Māgha and Tapa were identical: this is the fair interpretation of the passage, which also involves the identification of [[मधु|Madhu]] with [[चैत्र|Caitra]], a result corresponding with the view frequently found in the Brāhmaṇas, that the full moon in [[चित्रा|Citrā]], and not that in [[फल्गुनी|Phalgunī]], is the beginning of the year.<ref name=fx48_ve2_602> Weber's theory (359) that [[चैत्र|Caitra]] was as the first spring month secondary to Phālguna is, of course, an error;<br> for, owing to the precession of the equinoxes, Phālguna became the first month of spring ''de facto,'' while [[चैत्र|Caitra]] became virtually the last month of the preceding season. The truth is that the six seasons are an arbitrary division of the year, and that either Phālguna or [[चैत्र|Caitra]] could be regarded as the beginning of spring without much impropriety. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 457;<br> 10, 231, 232;<br> Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 8, 71, 397, 398.</ref><br><br>In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx49_ve2_602> viii. 4, 2, 12;<br> 3, 18. See Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 26. 31. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 10, 3, has the words in the form of ''[[याव|yāva]]'' and ''ayāva,'' which are explained in v. 3, 4, 5.</ref> are found two curious expressions, ''yava'' and ''ayava,'' for the light and dark halves of the month, which is clearly considered to begin with the light half. Possibly the words are derived, as Eggling<ref name=fx50_ve2_602> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 69, n.</ref> thinks, from ''yu,'' ‘ward off,’ with reference to evil spirits. The word '''[[पर्वन्|Parvan]]'''  (‘joint’ = division of time) probably<ref name=fx51_ve2_602> The months and the half months are the ''parvāṇi'' of the sacrificial horse in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1, 1. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 35;<br> vi. 2, 2, 24;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 43;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 4, where the sense is left vague.</ref> denotes a half of the month, perhaps already in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx52_ve2_602> i. 94, 4. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 189.</ref> More precisely the first half, the time of the waxing light, is called ''[[पूर्व-पक्ष|pūrva-pakṣa]],''<ref name=fx53_ve2_602> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 9, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 25, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 7, 4, 7;<br> viii. 4, 2, 11;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 11,;<br> xi. 5. 6.</ref> the second, that of the waning light, ''apara-[[पक्ष|pakṣa]],''<ref name=fx54_ve2_602> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 7, 4, 7;<br> viii. 4, 2, 11;<br> xi. 1, 5, 3;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, 5;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 11;<br> xi. 6, etc.</ref> Either of these might be called a half-month (''ardha-[[मास|māsa]]'').<ref name=fx55_ve2_602> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 5, 21;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1, 1;<br> iii. 8, 9 etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 15, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 364 ''et seq.;<br>'' Thibaut, ''Astronomie, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 7-9;<br> Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1894, 37 ''et seq.;<br> Naxatra,'' 2, ''passim.''</ref>

मासर
<u>'''Māsara'''</u> is mentioned as a beverage in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_603> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 2. 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 14. 82;<br> xx. 68;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 11, 4, etc.</ref> Its composition is described fully in the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_603> xix. 1, 20. 21;<br> Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 1, 14.<br><br>''Cf.'' Griffith, Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, 172, n.</ref> It seems to have been a mixture of rice and '''[[श्यामाक|Śyāmāka]]''' with grass, parched barley, etc.

माहकि
<u>'''Māhaki,'''</u> ‘descendant of Mahaka,’ is the patronymic of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_604> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 382.</ref>

माहा-चमस्य
<u>'''Māhā-camasya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Mahācamasa,'''’ is the patronymic of a teacher to whom the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve2_605> i. 5, 1.</ref> ascribes the addition of Mahas to the triad Bhūr '''Bhuvas''' Svar.<ref name=fx2_ve2_605> ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 180.</ref>

माहा-रजन
<u>'''Māhā-rajana,'''</u> ‘dyed with saffron’ (''mahā-rajana''), is applied to a garment ('''[[वासस्|Vāsas]]''') in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 3, 10). <br>==Foot Notes==

माहा-राज्य
<u>'''Māhā-rājya,'''</u> ‘the dignity of a great king’ (''[[महा-राज|mahā-rāja]]''), is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 6, 5; 12, 4; 15, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

माहित्थि
<u>'''Māhitthi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Mahittha,’ is the patronymic of a teacher mentioned several times in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_608> vi. 2, 2, 10;<br> viii. 6, 1, 16 ''et seq.;<br>'' ix. 5, 1, 57;<br> x. 6, 5, 9.</ref> He is said to be a pupil of '''[[वामकक्षायण|Vāmakakṣāyaṇa]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_608> vi. 5, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref>

माहीन
<u>'''Māhīna'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_609> x. 60, 1. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138.</ref> which celebrates '''Asamāti''' as a king. The word, used in the plural, may be a patronymic referring to the priests who praised Asamāti, or it may be an adjective of uncertain meaning.

मित्र
<u>'''Mitra'''</u> denotes ‘friend’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_610> Masculine: i. 58, 1;<br> 67, 1;<br> 75, 4;<br> 156, 1;<br> 170, 5;<br> ii. 4, 1. 3, etc. The neuter does not with certainty occur in the sense of ‘friend’ in the Rv.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_610> Masculine: Av. v. 19, 15;<br> xi. 9, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, x. 80. Neuter: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 8, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 8, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 20, 17;<br> viii. 27, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 4, 8;<br> v. 3, 5, 13;<br> xi. 4, 3, 20, etc.</ref> According to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_610> vi. 2, 9, 2.</ref> a wife is a man's friend, and in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_610> i. 5, 3, 17.</ref> the value of a friend is insisted upon. Treachery to a friend is reprobated.<ref name=fx5_ve2_610> ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 1, 7.</ref>

मित्र-भू काश्यप
<u>'''Mitra-bhū Kāśyapa'''</u> (‘descendant of Kaśyapa’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[विभण्डक काश्यप|Vibhaṇḍaka Kāśyapa]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_611> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 374.</ref>

मित्र-भूति लौहित्य
<u>'''Mitra-[[भूति|bhūti]] Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]''' (iii. 42, 1) as a pupil of '''Kṛṣṇadatta [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

मित्र-वर्चस् स्थैरकायण
<u>'''Mitra-varcas Sthairakāyaṇa'''</u> (‘descendant of Sthiraka’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[सुप्रतीत औलुण्ड्य|Supratīta Auluṇḍya]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_613> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

मित्र-विन्द काश्यप
<u>'''Mitra-vinda Kāśyapa'''</u> (‘descendant of Kaśyapa’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Sunītha,''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_614> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

मित्रातिथि
<u>'''Mitrātithi'''</u> is mentioned in one hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_615> x. 33, 7. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 150, 184;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 922, 923;<br> Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 384;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 35, 36, with Macdonell's notes.</ref> as the father of '''Kuruśravaṇa''' and the grandfather of '''[[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]],''' all being evidently kings.

मुक्षीजा
<u>'''Mukṣījā'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_616> i. 125, 2;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 19. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 244.</ref> where the sense seems clearly to be ‘net’ for catching animals. ''Cf.'' '''Padi.'''

मुञ्ज
<u>'''1. Muñja'''</u> denotes a grass, the ''Saccharum [[मुञ्ज|Muñja]],'' which is of luxuriant growth, attaining to a height of ten feet. It is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_617> i. 191, 3.</ref> along with other kinds of grasses as the lurking-place of venomous creatures. In the same text<ref name=fx2_ve2_617> i. 161, 8 (''[[मुञ्ज|muñja]]-nejana,'' which Sāyaṇa explains as ''apagata-[[तृण|tṛṇa]],'' ‘with the grass removed’).</ref> the [[मुञ्ज|Muñja]] grass is spoken of as purifying, apparently being used as the material of a filter for Soma. The grass is often mentioned in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx3_ve2_617> Av. i. 2, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 9, 5;<br> 10, 5, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx4_ve2_617> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 7;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 3, 16;<br> vi. 6, 1, 23;<br> 2, 15. 16, etc. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. mauñja.''</ref> It is in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_617> vi. 3, 1, 26.</ref> said to be ‘hollow’ (''suṣira'') and to be used for the plaited part of the throne ('''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]]''').<ref name=fx6_ve2_617> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 3, 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref> 

मुञ्ज साम-श्रवस
<u>'''2. Muñja Sāma-śravasa'''</u> (‘descendant of Sāmaśravas’) is the name of a man, possibly a king, mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_618> iii. 5, 2.</ref> and the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_618> iv. 1 (''Indische Studien,'' 1, 39).</ref>

मुण्डिभ औदन्य
<u>'''Muṇḍibha Audanya'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_619> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 5, 4. Apparently the word is a patronymic, ‘son of Udanya’ (so Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 341, n. 1), or ‘son of Odana’ (so St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'').</ref> or '''Audanyava'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_619> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 15, 3 (‘descendant of Udanyu’).</ref> is the name of a man in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_619/> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_619/>

मुद्ग
<u>'''Mudga,'''</u> denoting a kind of bean (''Phascolus Mungo''), occurs in a list of vegetables in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_620> xviii. 12.</ref> A ‘soup of rice with beans’ (''mudgaudana'') is mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve2_620> xii. 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 240.</ref> and the Sūtras. ''Cf.'' perhaps '''[[मुद्गल|Mudgala]].'''

मुद्गल
<u>'''Mudgala'''</u> and '''Mudgalanī,''' ‘Mudgala's wife,’ both figure in a hopelessly obscure hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_621> x. 102.</ref> variously interpreted by Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve2_621> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 124.</ref> and Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve2_621> ''Ibid.,'' 1, 138;<br> 2, 1-22.</ref> and von Bradke<ref name=fx4_ve2_621> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 46, 445 ''et seq.''</ref> as telling of a real chariot race in which, despite difficulties, [[मुद्गल|Mudgala]] won by his wife's aid. The Indian tradition is as variant as the interpretations of modern authorities. Ṣaḍguruśiṣya<ref name=fx5_ve2_621> Macdonell's edition of the Sarvānukramaṇī, p. 158.</ref> explains that Mudgala's oxen were stolen, that he pursued the thieves with the one old ox he had left, and that hurling his hammer (''[[द्रु-घण|dru-ghaṇa]]'') he caught the marauders. [[यास्क|Yāska]],<ref name=fx6_ve2_621> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 23, 24.</ref> on the other hand, says that [[मुद्गल|Mudgala]] won a race with a ''[[द्रुघण|drughaṇa]]'' and an ox instead of with two oxen. It is pretty clear that, as Roth<ref name=fx7_ve2_621> ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erlänterungen,'' 129.</ref> observed, the tradition is merely a guess, and a bad one, at the meaning of an obscure hymn, and this view is  accepted by Oldenberg.<ref name=fx8_ve2_621> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 39, 78.</ref> Bloomfield<ref name=fx9_ve2_621> ''Ibid.,'' 48, 547.</ref> has interpreted the legend as one of heavenly, not of human, events. [[मुद्गल|Mudgala]], probably a variant form of Mudgara,<ref name=fx10_ve2_621> According to Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 1, Indrasenā in x. 102, 2, is the name of Mudgalānī;<br> but its sense, ‘Indra's bolt,’ rather indicates the mythical character of the passage.</ref> which in the later language means a hammer or a similar weapon, may be meant as a personfication of the thunderbolt of Indra, rather than a real man.<ref name=fx11_ve2_621> If the name means a real man, it may be connected with '''[[मुद्ग|Mudga]],''' ‘bean.’ See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 240.</ref> Later<ref name=fx12_ve2_621> Av. iv. 29, 6;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 12;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, vi. 46;<br> viii. 12. 90.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166, 167;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 280;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society'' 1911, 1005, n. 1.</ref> [[मुद्गल|Mudgala]] is a mythical sage.

मुनि
<u>'''Muni'''</u> occurs in one hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_622> x. 136, 2. 4. 5. In verse I he is described as ‘long-haired.’</ref> where it seems to denote an ascetic of magic powers with divine afflatus (''deveṣita''), the precursor of the strange ascetics of later India. This agrees with the fact that '''[[ऐतश|Aitaśa]],''' the Muni, is in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_622> vi. 33, 3.</ref> regarded by his son as deranged, a view not unjustified if the nonsense which passes as the Aitaśapralāpa.<ref name=fx3_ve2_622> See Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 98 ''et seq.''</ref> ‘Chatter of [[ऐतश|Aitaśa]],’ was really his. The Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_622> viii. 17, 14. ''Cf.'' vii. 56, 8;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 376.</ref> calls Indra the ‘friend of Munis,’ and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_622> vii. 74, 1. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 440;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 5, 2, 15, and '''[[मुनिमरण|Munimaraṇa]].'''</ref> refers to a ‘divine Muni’ (''deva muni''), by whom a similar ascetic may be meant.<br><br>In the Upaniṣads<ref name=fx6_ve2_622> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 4, 25;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 20.</ref> the Muni is of a more restrained type: he is one who learns the nature of the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], the Absolute, by study, or sacrifice, or penance, or fasting, or faith (''śraddhā''). It must not of course be thought that there is any absolute distinction between the older Muni and the later: in both cases the man is in a peculiar ecstatic condition, but the ideal of the Upaniṣads is less material than the earlier picture of the Muni, who is more of a ‘medicine man’ than a sage. Nor would it be wise to conclude from the comparative rareness  of the mention of the Muni in the Vedic texts that he was an infrequent figure in Vedic times: he was probably not approved by the priests who followed the ritual, and whose views were essentially different from the ideals of a Muni, which were superior to earthly considerations, such as the desire for children and '''Dakṣiṇās.'''<ref name=fx7_ve2_622> ''Cf.'' Bṛhadāranyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 4, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 406;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 480;<br> ''Buddha,''^5 36.</ref>

मुनि-मरण
<u>'''Muni-maraṇa,'''</u> ‘Saints’ Death,’ is the name of the place where, according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 4, 7), the '''Vaikhanasas''' were slain.<br>==Foot Notes==

मुलालिन्
<u>'''Mulālin'''</u> (masc.) or '''Mulālī''' (fem.) is the name of some part of an edible lotus (perhaps the ''Nymphaea esculenta'') in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_624> iv. 34. 5. ''Cf.'' [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], lxvi. 10;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 138;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 207.</ref>

मुषीवन्
<u>'''Muṣīvan'''</u> denotes ‘robber’ in one passage of the Rigveda (i. 42, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

मुष्कर
<u>'''Muṣkara'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_626> vi. 14, 2.</ref> possibly in the sense of a small animal or insect, as suggested by Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_626> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> who, however, thought the passage corrupt. Bloomfield<ref name=fx3_ve2_626> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 463, 464.<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 297.</ref> suggests that the reading of the Paippalāda text ''puṣkaram,'' (‘blue lotus’) is the correct form.

मुष्टि-हन्
<u>'''Muṣṭi-han,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_627> Rv. v. 58, 4;<br> vi. 26, 2;<br> viii. 20, 20;<br> Av. v. 22, 4.</ref> '''Muṣṭi-hatyā,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_627> Rv. i. 8, 2.</ref> in the Rigveda and the Atharvaveda denote. respectively, the ‘hand to hand fighter’--that is, the ordinary warrior as opposed to the charioteer, and the  ‘fight’ itself. So also in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_627> vii. 62, 1.</ref> the charioteer (''[[रथिन्|rathin]]'') is opposed to the foot-soldier (''[[पत्ति|patti]]''), and in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_627> i. 100, 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 297.</ref> the chariots are opposed to the troops (''[[ग्राम|grāma]]'') of the infantry. The parallel of the Greek and other Āryan races shows that the Kṣatriyas were the fighters from chariots, while the ordinary host fought on foot.

मुसल
<u>'''Musala'''</u> denotes a ‘pestle’ in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_628> Av. x. 9, 26;<br> xi. 3, 3;<br> xii. 3, 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 8, 3, etc.</ref> and in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_628> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 5, 2, 7;<br> in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 42, 44 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 235, 237), ''musalin'' means a ‘man armed with a club.’</ref>

मुहूर्त
<u>'''Muhūrta'''</u> denotes a division of time, one-thirtieth of a day, or an hour of forty-eight minutes, in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_629> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 1, 1 (for the names);<br> 9, 7;<br> 12, 9, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 4, 2, 18. 25. 27;<br> 3, 20;<br> xii. 3, 2, 5;<br> x. 4, 4, 4, etc.</ref> In the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_629> iii. 33, 5;<br> 53, 8. The sense of ‘moment’ is also common in the Brāhmaṇas.<br><br>''Cf. Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 9, 139 ''et seq.;<br> Indische Streifen,'' 1, 92 ''et seq.''</ref> the sense of ‘moment’ only is found. ''Cf.'' '''Ahan.'''

मूचीप
<u>'''Mūcīpa'''</u> or '''Mūvīpa''' is the variant in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xv. 26, 6) of the '''[[मूतिब|Mūtiba]]''' of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] as the name of a barbarian tribe.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 67, n. 1.<br>==Foot Notes==

मूजवन्त्
<u>'''Mūjavant'''</u> is the name of a people who, along with the '''Mahāvṛṣas,''' the '''Gandhāris,''' and the '''Balhikas,''' are mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_631> v. 22, 5, 7, 8. 14. ''Cf.'' [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 5.</ref> as dwelling far away, and to whom fever is to be banished. Similarly in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve2_631> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 6, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 7;<br> xxxvi. 14;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 10. 20;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 61;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 2, 17.</ref> the Mūjavants are chosen as a type of distant folk, beyond  which Rudra with his bow is entreated to depart. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_631> x. 34, 1.</ref> Soma is described as [[मौजवत|Maujavata]], ‘coming from the Mūjavants,’ or, as [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_631> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 8.</ref> takes it, ‘from Mount [[मूजवन्त्|Mūjavant]].’ The Indian commentators<ref name=fx5_ve2_631> Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 161, 8;<br> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] and [[प्रयोग|Prayoga]], cited by Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 63.</ref> agree with [[यास्क|Yāska]] in taking [[मूजवन्त्|Mūjavant]] as the name of a mountain, and though Hillebrandt<ref name=fx6_ve2_631> ''Op. cit.,'' 1, 65.</ref> is justified in saying that the identification of [[मूजवन्त्|Mūjavant]] by Zimmer<ref name=fx7_ve2_631> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 29.</ref> with one of the lower hills on the south-west of Kaśmīr lacks evidence, it is not reasonable to deny that [[मूजवन्त्|Mūjavant]] was a hill from which the people took their name. [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx8_ve2_631> ''Loc. cit. Cf.'' Siddhānta Kaumudī on Pāṇini, iv. 4, 110, where instead of [[मौजवत|Maujavata]] in Rv. x. 34, 1, Mauñjavata is read.</ref> suggests that [[मूजवन्त्|Mūjavant]] is equivalent to Muñjavant, which actually occurs later, in the Epic,<ref name=fx9_ve2_631> Mahābhārata, x. 785;<br> xiv. 180.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 198.</ref> as the name of a mountain in the Himālaya.

मूत
<u>'''Mūta'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_632> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 14;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 10, 5;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 3, 8.</ref> denotes a ‘woven basket.’ Mūtaka means a ‘small basket.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_632> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 2, 17.</ref>

मूतिब
<u>'''Mūtiba'''</u> appears in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_633> vii. 18, 2.</ref> as the name of one of the barbarous peoples enumerated as nominally '''Viśvāmitra's''' outcast offspring. The [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_633> xv. 26, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 358, 483.</ref> gives the name as '''[[मूचीप|Mūcīpa]]''' or '''Mūvīpa.'''

मूल
<u>'''Mūla, Mūlabarhaṇa.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मूस्
<u>'''Mūs,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_635> Rv. i. 105, 8 = x. 33, 3;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 5.</ref> '''Mūṣikā,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_635> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 36.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 85;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 248.</ref> are the names of ‘mouse’ occurring in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_635/> and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_635/> 

मृग
<u>'''1. Mṛga'''</u> has the generic sense of ‘wild beast’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_636> i. 173, 2;<br> 191, 4;<br> viii. 1, 20;<br> 5, 36;<br> x. 146, 6, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_636> Av. iv. 3, 6;<br> x. 1, 26;<br> xii. 1, 48 (''[[सूकर|sūkara]],'' ‘boar’);<br> xix. 38, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 7, 10;<br> xxiv. 11, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 31, 2;<br> viii. 23, 3, etc.</ref> Sometimes it is qualified by the epithet ‘terrible’ (''bhīma''),<ref name=fx3_ve2_636> Rv. i. 154, 2;<br> 190, 3;<br> ii. 33, 11;<br> 34, 1;<br> x. 180, 2, etc.</ref> which indicates that a savage wild beast is meant.
