Elsewhere the buffalo is shown to be denoted by the epithet ''[[महिष|mahiṣa]],''<ref name=fx4_ve2_636> Rv. viii. 69, 15;<br> ix. 92, 6;<br> x. 123, 4.</ref> ‘powerful,’ which later becomes the name of the buffalo. More particularly the word has the sense of an animal of the gazelle type.<ref name=fx5_ve2_636> Rv. i. 38, 5;<br> 105, 7;<br> vi. 75, 11;<br> ix. 32, 4;<br> Av. v. 21, 4 (not a certain instance);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 3, 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 5 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 8, 4, 3, etc.</ref> In some passages<ref name=fx6_ve2_636> Rv. i. 182, 7;<br> x. 136, 6, and perhaps i. 145, 5;<br> vii. 87, 6.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx7_ve2_636> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' 1''e.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' i. 99;<br> 2, 122.</ref> sees the sense of ‘bird.’ See also '''[[मृग हस्तिन्|Mṛga Hastin]], [[पुरुष हस्तिन्|Puruṣa Hastin]].'''

मृग
<u>'''2. Mṛga'''</u> in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_637> iii. 33, 5.</ref> denotes, according to Sāyaṇa's commentary, the constellation '''[[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]].''' But it seems more probable<ref name=fx2_ve2_637> See Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, xcii.</ref> that [[मृग|Mṛga]] there really covers the whole of Orion, not merely the inconspicuous group of stars in the head of Orion that make up the [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] [[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]], but also the star ''a'' in his shoulder, which is reckoned as [[आर्द्रा|Ārdrā]], and  in his left shoulder. Tilak,<ref name=fx3_ve2_637> ''Orion,'' 99 ''et seq.''</ref> however, makes [[मृग|Mṛga]] or [[मृगशिरस्|Mṛgaśiras]] into a different group, consisting of the belt of Orion, with two stars in the knees and one in the left shoulder, which he deems to resemble a deer's head with an arrow through it, an implausible and unlikely theory. ''Cf.'' '''[[मृगव्याध|Mṛgavyādha]].'''

मृग हस्तिन्
<u>'''3. Mṛga Hastin,'''</u> the ‘animal with a hand,’ is mentioned in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_638> i. 64, 7;<br> iv. 16, 14.</ref> in which Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_638> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erläuterungen,'' 79.</ref> recognizes that the elephant is meant, but concludes that the compound name  is a proof of the newness of the elephant to the Vedic Indians.<ref name=fx3_ve2_638> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 99, 100, combats the view that the eler hant was new to the Vedic Indian, because of the similar use of ''[[मृग|mṛga]] [[महिष|mahiṣa]]'' and ''[[मृग|mṛga]] [[सूकर|sūkara]]'' (Av. xii. 1, 48) to denote the ‘buffalo’ and the ‘boar’ respectively. But '''[[महिष|Mahiṣa]]''' seems rather to bear out Roth's conclusion;<br> while '''[[सूकर|Sūkara]]''' appears alone in the Rigveda, and ''[[मृग|mṛga]] [[सूकर|sūkara]],'' ‘wild hog,’ seems to be used in one passage of the Av. (xii. 1, 48) to distinguish it from '''[[वराह|Varāha]],''' ‘boar,’ in the same verse.</ref> Later the adjective [[हस्तिन्|Hastin]] alone became the regular name of the animal (like '''[[महिष|Mahiṣa]]''' of the ‘buffalo’). The elephant is also denoted in the Rigveda by the descriptive term [[मृग|Mṛga]] [[वारण|Vāraṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_638> Rv. viii. 33, 8;<br> x. 40, 8.</ref> the ‘wild or dangerous animal,’ the adjective ''[[वारण|vāraṇa]]'' similarly becoming one of the names for ‘elephant’ in the later language. Pischel's view<ref name=fx5_ve2_638> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 121-123;<br> 317319. ''Cf.'' Strabo, pp. 704, 705;<br> Arrian, ''Indica,'' 13. 14 (from Megasthenes).</ref> that the catching of elephants by the use of tame female elephants is already alluded to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve2_638> viii. 2, 6;<br> x. 40, 8.</ref> seems very doubtful. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve2_638> viii. 23, 3 (''hiraṇyena parīvṛtān kṛṣṇāñ chukladato mṛgān''). See Pischel, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 122.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 80.</ref> elephants are described as ‘black, white-toothed, adorned with gold.’

मृगय
<u>'''Mṛgaya'''</u> occurs in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_639> iv. 16, 13;<br> viii. 3, 19;<br> x. 49, 5.</ref> as defeated by Indra. That he was a human foe, as Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_639> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166.</ref> thinks, seems unlikely: more probably he was a demon, as [[मृग|Mṛga]] unquestionably is.<ref name=fx3_ve2_639> Rv. i. 80, 7;<br> v. 29, 4, etc.</ref>

मृगयु
<u>'''Mṛgayu,'''</u> ‘hunter,’ occurs in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_640> Av. x. 1, 26;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;<br> xxx. 7, etc. ''Cf. mṛgaṇyu,'' Rv. x. 40, 4.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve2_640> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 1, 1;<br> iii. 4, 3, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 9, 12, etc.</ref> but not very often. The Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_640> xxx.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_640> iii. 4.</ref> however, in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) include a number of names which seem to be those of persons who make a livelihood by fishing or by hunting, such as the '''[[मार्गार|Mārgāra]],''' ‘hunter,’  the '''[[कैवर्त|Kaivarta]]''' or '''[[केवर्त|Kevarta]], [[पौञ्जिष्ठ|Pauñjiṣṭha]], Daśa, [[मैनाल|Maināla]],''' ‘fisher man,’ and perhaps the '''[[बैन्द|Bainda]]''' and the Ānda,<ref name=fx5_ve2_640> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 12, 1.</ref> who seem to have been some sort of fishermen.<br><br>It is not probable that even in the earliest Vedic period hunting formed the main source of livelihood for any of the Vedic tribes: pastoral pursuits and agriculture ('''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]]''') were, no doubt, the mainstay of their existence. But it would be unreasonable to suppose that not much hunting was done, both for recreation and for purposes of food, as well as for protection of flocks from wild beasts. The Rigveda is naturally our chief source of information in regard to hunting. The arrow was sometimes employed,<ref name=fx6_ve2_640> Rv. ii. 42, 2.</ref> but, as is usual with primitive man, the normal instruments of capture were nets and pitfalls. Birds were regularly caught in nets ('''[[पाश|Pāśa]],'''<ref name=fx7_ve2_640> '''[[पाशिन्|Pāśin]],''' ‘hunter,’ Rv. iii. 45, 1.</ref> '''[[निधा|Nidhā]],'''<ref name=fx8_ve2_640> Rv. ix. 83, 4;<br> x. 73, 11.</ref> '''[[जाल|Jāla]]'''),<ref name=fx9_ve2_640> Av. x. 1, 30.</ref> The bird-catcher being called ''[[निधा|nidhā]]-pati,''<ref name=fx10_ve2_640> Rv. ix. 83, 4.</ref> ‘master of snares.’ The net was fastened on pegs<ref name=fx11_ve2_640> Av. viii. 8, 5.</ref> (as is done with modern nets for catching birds). Another name of net is apparently '''[[मुक्षीजा|Mukṣījā]].'''<br><br>Pits were used for catching antelopes ('''[[ऋश्य|Ṛśya]]'''), and so were called ''[[ऋश्य|ṛśya]]-da,''<ref name=fx12_ve2_640> Rv. x. 39, 8.</ref> ‘antelope-catching.’ Elephants were captured as in Greek times, perhaps through the instrumentality of tame females (see '''[[मृग हस्तिन्|Mṛga Hastin]]'''). Apparently the boar was captured in the chase, dogs being used,<ref name=fx13_ve2_640> Rv. x. 86, 4.</ref> but the passage from which this view is deduced is of uncertain mythological content. There is also an obscure reference<ref name=fx14_ve2_640> Rv. x. 51, 6.</ref> to the capture of the buffalo ('''[[गौर|Gaura]]'''), but it is not clear whether the reference is to shooting with an arrow or capturing by means of ropes, perhaps a lasso, or a net. The lion was captured in pitfalls,<ref name=fx15_ve2_640> Rv. x. 28, 10.</ref> or was surrounded by the hunters and slain;<ref name=fx16_ve2_640> Rv. v. 15, 3.</ref> one very obscure passage refers to the lion being caught by ambuscade, which perhaps merely alludes to the use of the hidden pit.<ref name=fx17_ve2_640> Rv. v. 74, 4. ''Cf.'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 542, n.</ref><br><br>The modes of catching fish are little known, for the only evidence available are the explanations of the various names  mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]. Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx18_ve2_640> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 18, 281.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 243245.</ref> says that '''[[धैवर|Dhaivara]]''' is one who takes fish by netting a tank on either side; [[दाश|Dāśa]] and '''[[शौष्कल|Śauṣkala]]''' do so by means of a fish-hook (''baḍiśa''); [[बैन्द|Bainda]], [[कैवर्त|Kaivarta]], and [[मैनाल|Maināla]] by means of a net (''[[जाल|jāla]]''); [[मार्गार|Mārgāra]] catches fish in the water with his hands; Ānda by putting in pegs at a ford (apparently by building a sort of dam); '''[[पर्णक|Parṇaka]]''' by putting a poisoned leaf on the water. But none of these explanations can claim much authority.

मृग-व्याध
<u>'''Mṛga-vyādha,'''</u> ‘the hunter,’ is the name of Sirius in the legned of Prajāpati's daughter in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_641> iii. 33, 5. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 205, n. 1, 208, n. 3;<br> Tilak, ''Orion,'' 98 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[सूर्य|Sūrya]] Siddhānta, viii. 10;<br> ix. 12, preserves the name.</ref> Prajāpati (Orion) pursues his daughter ([[रोहिणी|Rohiṇī]]), and is shot by the archer Sirius. The transference of the legend of Prajāpati to the sky is no doubt secondary, caused by the obvious similarity of the constellation in question to the idea of an archer.

मृग-शिरस्
<u>'''Mṛga-śiras, [[मृग|Mṛga]]-śīrṣa.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]],''' 1. and 2. '''[[मृग|Mṛga]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मृगाखर
<u>'''Mṛgākhara'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vii. 5, 21, 1) and [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 9, 17, 3) denotes the ‘lair of wild beasts.’<br>==Foot Notes==

मृड
<u>'''Mṛḍa'''</u> is found only in compounds in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve2_644> ''Upacāya-mṛḍaṃ hiraṇyam,'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 1;<br> ''aṣṭā-mṛḍaṃ hiraṇyam, ibid.,'' xiii. 10;<br> ''aṣṭā-pruḍ-ḍhiraṇyam,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 1, 4, etc.</ref> where it seems to denote a small weight of gold. It is uncertain whether the reading should not be Pṛda, as in the grammatical tradition.<ref name=fx2_ve2_644> See Pāṇini, iii. 1, 123, with the Vārttika;<br> von Schroeder, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 164.</ref>

मृत्तिका
<u>'''Mṛttikā,'''</u> ‘clay,’ is mentioned in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_645> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 13;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 34, 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, x. 1, 8. 9.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[मृद्|Mṛd]].''' 

मृत्यु
<u>'''Mṛtyu,'''</u> ‘death,’ is repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_646> vii. 59, 12;<br> x. 13, 4;<br> 18, 1, 2;<br> x. 48, 5;<br> 60, 5. So ''[[मृत्यु|mṛtyu]]-[[बन्धु|bandhu]],'' ‘akin to death,’ Rv. viii. 18, 22;<br> x. 95, 18.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_646> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 9, 4, where the world is said to be ‘yoked with death’ (''[[मृत्यु|mṛtyu]]-saṃyuta'');<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 9, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 2;<br> 14, 1. 2. 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 5, 1, etc. So often the ‘bonds of death’ (''[[मृत्यु|mṛtyu]]-[[पाश|pāśa]]''), Av. viii. 2, 2;<br> 8, 10. 16;<br> xvii. 1, 30;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 8, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 18, etc.</ref> as a thing of terror. There are a hundred and one forms of death, the natural one by old age<ref name=fx3_ve2_646> Av. ii. 13, 2;<br> 28, 2.</ref> (''jarā''), and a hundred others, all to be avoided.<ref name=fx4_ve2_646> Av. i. 30, 3;<br> ii. 28, 1;<br> iii. 11, 5;<br> viii. 2, 27;<br> xi. 6, 16, etc.</ref> To die before old age (''purā jarasaḥ'')<ref name=fx5_ve2_646> Rv. viii. 67, 20;<br> Av. v. 30, 17;<br> x. 2, 30;<br> xiii. 3, 56.</ref> is to die before the allotted span (''purā āyuṣaḥ''),<ref name=fx6_ve2_646> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 4, 1.</ref> the normal length of life being throughout Vedic literature spoken of as a hundred years.<ref name=fx7_ve2_646> Rv. i. 64, 14;<br> 89, 9;<br> ii. 33, 2, etc. ''Cf.'' Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 384;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 193;<br> ''Festgruss an Reth,'' 137.</ref> On the other hand, the evils of old age in the loss of physical strength were clearly realized.<ref name=fx8_ve2_646> Rv. i. 71, 10;<br> 179, 1.</ref> one of the feats of the Aśvins was to restore old '''Cyavāna''' to his former youth and powers, and another was the rejuventation of '''Kali.'''<ref name=fx9_ve2_646> x. 39, 8. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 243.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx10_ve2_646> See Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 62 ''et seq.''</ref> is full of charms of all sorts to avert death and secure length of years (''āyuṣya'').<br><br>The modes of disposing of the dead were burial and cremation (see '''[[अग्निदग्ध|Agnidagdha]]'''). Both existed in the early Vedic period,<ref name=fx11_ve2_646> See Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, clii;<br> Winternitz, ''Geschichte der indischen Literatur,'' 1, 84, 85.</ref> as in Greece;<ref name=fx12_ve2_646> See Lang, ''Homer and his Age,'' 82 ''et seq.;<br> cf.'' Burrows, ''Discoveries in Crete,'' 209-213.</ref> but the former method was on the whole less favoured, and tended to be regarded with disapproval. The bones of the dead, whether burned or not, were marked by the erection of a tumulus ('''[[श्मशान|Śmaśāna]]'''): the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx13_ve2_646> xiii. 8, 2, 1.</ref> preserves traces of strong differences of opinion as to the mode in which these tumuli should be constructed. There is little or no trace<ref name=fx14_ve2_646> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 410;<br> Weinhold, ''Altnordisches Leben,'' 483 ''et seq.''</ref> of the custom common in northern lands of sending the dead man to sea in a burning ship: the reference  to a ship<ref name=fx15_ve2_646> Rv. x. 63, 10;<br> 135, 4;<br> Av. vii. 6, 3, and ''cf.'' Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1895, 856.</ref> seems to point to mythical perils after death, not to the mode of burial.<br><br>The life after death was to the Vedic Indian a repetition of the life in this world. He passed into the next world ''sarvatanuḥ sāṅgaḥ,'' ‘with whole body and all his members,’<ref name=fx16_ve2_646> Av. v. 6, 11;<br> xviii. 4, 64;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 6, 1, 1;<br> xi. 1, 8, 6;<br> xii. 8, 3, 31, and ''cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 3, 5, 2;<br> 6, 3;<br> 6, 6, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 20, 5;<br> 10, 11, 1.</ref> enjoying there the same pleasures as he had enjoyed on earth. Even in the Rigveda<ref name=fx17_ve2_646> Rv. ii. 29, 6;<br> iii. 26, 8;<br> iv. 5, 5;<br> 25, 6;<br> vii. 104, 3. 11. 17;<br> x. 152, 4.</ref> there are hints of evil awaiting evil-doers, but it is not until the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx18_ve2_646> ii. 14, 3;<br> v. 19, 3;<br> 30, 11;<br> viii. 2, 24;<br> xii. 4, 36;<br> xviii. 3, 3. ''Cf.'' also v. 19;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx19_ve2_646> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 1, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 9, 240 ''et seq.;<br>'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 42-44 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 236 ''et seq.'').</ref> that a hell of punishment is set out, and it is in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx20_ve2_646> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 2, 27;<br> x. 6, 3, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 3, etc.</ref> that good and evil deeds are said to produce happiness or hell hereafter. But there is no hint of extinction<ref name=fx21_ve2_646> ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 169.</ref> in the Rigveda as the fate of the wicked, as Roth<ref name=fx22_ve2_646> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 3, 329-347;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 238 ''et seq.''</ref> inclined to think. The Vedic poet not being deeply moral, his verses do not convey, as would those of a man convinced of sin, warnings of future judgment.

मृद्
<u>'''Mṛd'''</u> denotes ‘clay’ in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_647> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 9, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xi. 55.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_647> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 1, 13;<br> 2, 34;<br> 3, 3;<br> 3, 1, 22, 32;<br> 3, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] vi. 27, etc.</ref> (''cf.'' '''[[मृत्तिका|Mṛttikā]]'''). A ‘lump of clay’ also occurs in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx3_ve2_647> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 4, 2, 1;<br> 5, 2, 1;<br> xiv. 2, 1, 8;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 4.</ref> and a Mṛt-paca, ‘potter,’ in the Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_647> ii. 6;<br> iii. 3.</ref> A ‘clay vessel,’ Mṛtpātra,<ref name=fx5_ve2_647> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 2.</ref> and vessels (''[[पात्र|pātra]]'') made of clay (''mṛn-maya''),<ref name=fx6_ve2_647> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 1, 3, 4, etc.</ref> are mentioned, and the grave is called the ‘house of clay.’<ref name=fx7_ve2_647> Rv. vii. 89, 1 (''mṛnmaya [[गृह|gṛha]]'').</ref> 

मृध्
<u>'''Mṛdh'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_648> i. 131, 6;<br> 138, 2;<br> 182, 4;<br> ii. 22, 3;<br> 23, 13;<br> 28, 7;<br> iii. 47, 2;<br> v. 30, 7, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_648> Av. v. 20, 12;<br> vi. 2, 2;<br> viii. 5, 8;<br> xiii. 1, 5, 27;<br> xviii. 2, 59;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 7, 4;<br> 5, 3, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 37;<br> xi. 10 72, etc.</ref> denotes ‘enemy.’

मृध्र-वाच्
<u>'''Mṛdhra-vāc.'''</u> See '''[[दस्यु|Dasyu]]''' and '''[[दास|Dāsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मेक्षण
<u>'''Mekṣaṇa'''</u> is the name in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_650> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 10, 4;<br> iii. 7, 4, 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 2, 13, etc.</ref> of a wooden ladle used for stirring up the oblation ('''Caru''').

मेखला
<u>'''Mekhalā'''</u> denotes ‘girdle’ in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_651> Av. vi. 133, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 3, 3, 5;<br> vi. 2, 2, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 4;<br> xxiv. 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 7, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_651> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 10;<br> iv. 4, 5, 2;<br> vi. 2, 2, 39, etc.</ref> The '''Brahmacārin''' wore a girdle.<ref name=fx3_ve2_651> In the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras the girdle of the Brahmin is of [[मुञ्ज|Muñja]], that of the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] of a bowstring, and that of the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] of wool or hemp. See Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 19, 12, etc.</ref>

मेघ
<u>'''Megha'''</u> denotes ‘cloud’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_652> i. 181, 8.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_652> Av. iv. 15, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 2, 5;<br> xii. 3, 2, 6;<br> ''mahā-[[मेघ|megha]],'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 3;<br> viii. 7. The verb ''meghay,'' ‘to make cloudy weather,’ is found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 5, 1, and ''meghayantī'' is the name of one of the seven '''[[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]],''' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 4, 1;<br> Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 301, 368.</ref>

मेथि
<u>'''Methi'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_653> viii. 5, 20.</ref> denoting ‘post.’ The word is also found in the marriage ritual,<ref name=fx2_ve2_653> Av. xiv. 1, 40. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 9, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 8;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 29, 22;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 3, 21.</ref> when the sense is, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, a post to support the pole of a chariot. In one passage of the Rigveda it is perhaps used of posts forming a palisade.<ref name=fx3_ve2_653> viii. 53, 5 (''mita-methībhiḥ'' for ''medhābhiḥ,'' conjectured by Roth, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell schaft,'' 48, 109).</ref> In the Pañcaviṃśa  [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_653> xiii. 9, 17. ''Cf.'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 19, 1 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 23, 329).</ref> it appears in the form of Methī to denote the post to which the sacrificial cow is tied. The word is very variously spelt, Medhi and Meṭhī also being found.

मेध
<u>'''Medha'''</u> is a word of uncertain sense occurring in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_654> viii. 50, 10 (''cf.'' viii. 49, 10), where, as a rule, the sense of ‘sacrifice’ is accepted as adequate.</ref> According to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, the proper name of a sacrificer may be meant.

मेधातिथि
<u>'''Medhātithi,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_655> This is the form of the later texts and of Rv. viii. 8, 20, where he occurs with '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]].'''</ref> '''[[मेध्यातिथि|Medhyātithi]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_655> This is the usual form in the Rv.: i. 36, 10. 11. 17;<br> viii. 1, 30;<br> 2, 40;<br> 33, 4;<br> 49, 9;<br> 51, 1;<br> ix. 43, 3.</ref> (‘having a guest at the sacrifice’) appear to be the names of one and the same man, a descendant of '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]]''' and a famous Vedic '''[[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]],''' to whom the authorship of various hymns<ref name=fx3_ve2_655> i. 12-23;<br> viii. 1-3;<br> 22. 23;<br> ix. 4143. In the ascriptions [[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]] and [[मेध्यातिथि|Medhyātithi]] are confused.</ref> is attributed in the Anukramaṇī (Index). To him Indra is said in the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_655> viii. 2, 40. ''Cf.'' i. 51, 1, where, however, there is no mention of Medhāithi.</ref> to have come in the form of a ram: this myth is perpetuated in the Subrahmaṇyā formula<ref name=fx5_ve2_655> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 79;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 12, 3. Moreover, the legend is alluded to in the Śāṭyāyanaka. See Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 51, 1;<br> viii. 2, 40, and Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, ccxl. On the explanation of the legend, ''cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 38 ''et seq.''</ref> recited by the priest while the Soma is being carried within the sacrificial enclosure, when Indra is hailed as ‘ram of [[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]].’ He appears also as a rival of '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]],''' whom he accused of low birth, but who convinced him of his error by undergoing a fire ordeal (''cf.'' '''[[दिव्य|Divya]]''').<ref name=fx6_ve2_655> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 6, 6.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx7_ve2_655> iv. 29, 6.</ref> he is mentioned with many other sages, and occurs elsewhere<ref name=fx8_ve2_655> As a Gṛhapati at the sacrifice of the '''Vibhindukīyas,''' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 233 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 38);<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 10, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxviii. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 102, 105;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 146.</ref> also as a sage. 

मेध्य
<u>'''Medhya'''</u> is the name of a man, an ancient sacrificer, in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_656> viii. 52, 2.</ref> In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_656> xvi. 11, 26. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 39;<br> Ludwig. Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> he is erroneously transmuted into '''[[पृषध्र|Pṛṣadhra]] [[मेध्य|Medhya]] [[मातरिश्वन्|Mātariśvan]],''' the patron of '''[[प्रस्कण्व|Praskaṇva]] [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].'''

मेध्यातिथि
<u>'''Medhyātithi.'''</u> See '''[[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मेनका
<u>'''Menakā.'''</u> See 2. '''[[मेना|Menā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मेना
<u>'''1. Menā'''</u> in a few passages of the Rigveda denotes ‘woman.’<ref name=fx1_ve2_659> Rv. i. 62, 7;<br> 95, 6;<br> ii. 39, 2.</ref> The word is also used in the sense of the ‘female’ of an animal, either mare<ref name=fx2_ve2_659> Rv. i. 121, 2.</ref> or cow.<ref name=fx3_ve2_659> x. 111, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 316, 317.</ref>

मेना
<u>'''2. Menā'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_660> This is the ordinary form of the name.</ref> or '''[[मेनका|Menakā]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_660> So Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, where the masculine form Mena is the epithet of [[वृषण्अश्व|Vṛṣaṇaśva]].</ref> is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_660> Rv. i. 51, 13, where Sāyaṇa tells the legend from the Śāṭyāyanaka. ''Cf.'' Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, ccxl.</ref> and in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx4_ve2_660> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 12, 3;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]. i. 3, 17.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 16, 81, n.</ref> as the daughter, or perhaps wife, of '''[[वृषण्अश्व|Vṛṣaṇaśva]].''' The meaning of the legend connected with her is quite unknown. ''Cf.'' '''[[मैनाक|Maināka]]''' or '''Mainaga.'''

मेष
<u>'''Meṣa'''</u> denotes ‘ram’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_661> i. 43, 6;<br> 116, 16;<br> viii. 2, 40;<br> x. 27, 17, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_661> Av. vi. 49, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 59;<br> xix. 90;<br> xxiv. 30;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 12, 1;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 18, etc.</ref> while Meṣī means ‘sheep.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_661> Rv. i. 43, 6;<br> Vājasaneyī Saṃhitā, iii. 59;<br> xxiv. 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 4, 4. etc.</ref> Both words are also used to denote the  ‘wool’<ref name=fx4_ve2_661> ''[[मेष|Meṣa]],'' Rv. viii. 86, 11;<br> ''Meṣī.'' ix. 8, 5;<br> 86, 47;<br> 107, 11.</ref> of the sheep, '''especially''' as employed for the Soma filter. A wild (''āraṇya'') '''ram is''' mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx5_ve2_661> xxiv. 30.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 66, 67.</ref>

मेहत्नू
<u>'''Mehatnū'''</u> is the name of a stream in the Nadīstuti (‘Praise of Rivers’) in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_662> x. 75, 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 14;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 344.</ref> It must apparently have been a tributary of the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus), entering that river before the '''[[क्रुमु|Krumu]]''' (Kurum) and '''[[गोमती|Gomatī]]''' (Gomal). It may conceivably have been a tributary of the '''[[क्रुमु|Krumu]].'''

मैत्रायणीय ब्राह्मण
<u>'''Maitrāyaṇīya Brāhmaṇa'''</u> is the name of a text mentioned in the Śulba [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] of [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_663> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxxii. 8. ''Cf.'' Caland, ''Über das rituclle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 41, who cannot trace the citation in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.</ref>

मैत्रेय
<u>'''Maitreya'''</u> is the patronymic or metronymic<ref name=fx1_ve2_664> Patronymic from Mitrayu, according to Pāṇini, vi. 4, 174;<br> vii. 3, 2;<br> metronymic from Mitrā, according to the commentator on Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 12, 1.</ref> of '''[[कौषारव|Kauṣārava]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_664> viii. 28, 18.</ref> It is also applied to '''Glāva''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_664> i. 12, 1;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 31 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 110.</ref>

मैत्रेयी
<u>'''Maitreyī'''</u> is the name of one of the wives of '''Yājṅavalkya''' according to the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 4, 1 ''et seq.;'' iv. 5, 2 ''et seq.'').<br>==Foot Notes==

मैनाक
<u>'''Maināka,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[मेनका|Menakā]],'''’ is the name of a mountain among the Himālayas in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_666> i. 31, 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 93.</ref> There is a various reading Maināga. 

मैनाल
<u>'''Maināla'''</u> occurs in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_667> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1.</ref> It seems clearly to mean ‘fisherman’ from Mīna, ‘fish,’ as Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx2_ve2_667> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> and Mahīdhara<ref name=fx3_ve2_667> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> explain it.

मौजवत
<u>'''Maujavata.'''</u> See '''[[मूजवन्त्|Mūjavant]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मौद्गल्य
<u>'''Maudgalya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[मुद्गल|Mudgala]],'''’ is the patronymic of several persons, '''[[नाक|Nāka]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_669> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 5, 2, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 9, 1.</ref> '''Śatabalākṣa,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_669> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xi. 6.</ref> and '''[[लाङ्गलायन|Lāṅgalāyana]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_669> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 8.</ref> '''A Brahmacārin''' of the name is mentioned in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_669> i. 1, 31;<br> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 110. ''Cf.'' also Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 35.</ref> as disputing with '''[[ग्लाव मैत्रेय|Glāva Maitreya]].'''

मौन
<u>'''Mauna,'''</u> ‘descendant of Muni,’ is the patronymic of '''Aṇīcin''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxiii. 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

मौषिकी-पुत्र
<u>'''Mauṣikī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Mūṣikā,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[हारिकर्णीपुत्र|Hārikarṇīputra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30).<br>==Foot Notes==

म्लेच्छ
<u>'''Mleccha'''</u> occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_672> iii. 2, 1, 24.</ref> in the sense of a barbarian in speech. The Brahmin is there forbidden to use barbarian speech. The example<ref name=fx2_ve2_672> iii. 2, 1, 23.</ref> given of such speech is ''lie 'lavo,'' explained by Sāyaṇa as ''he 'rayaḥ,'' ‘ho, foes.’ If this is correct--the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension has a different reading<ref name=fx3_ve2_672> See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 31, n. 3.</ref> --the barbarians referred to were Āryan speakers, though not speakers of Sanskrit, but of a Prākṛta form of speech.<ref name=fx4_ve2_672> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 180;<br> ''cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āranyaka,'' 179, 180, 196.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[वाच्|Vāc]].''' 

यक्ष
<u>'''Yakṣa'''</u> is found several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_673> i. 190, 4;<br> iv. 3, 13, v. 70, 4;<br> vii. 56, 16;<br> 61, 5;<br> x. 88, 13.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_673> viii. 9, 25;<br> x. 2, 32;<br> 7, 38;<br> 8, 43;<br> xi. 2, 24, etc.</ref> in passages in which Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve2_673> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 262.</ref> sees the meaning of a feast or holy practice in accordance with the native commentators. It is, however, very doubtful whether this sense ever occurs.<ref name=fx4_ve2_673> ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and Geldner's full discussion, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 126-143.</ref>

यक्षु
<u>'''Yakṣu'''</u> is mentioned, once in the singular and once in the plural, in the hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_674> vii. 18, 6. 19.</ref> which celebrates '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' battle with the ten kings. Who they were and what part they played in that conflict is quite uncertain. They seem, from the wording of the text, to have taken part in two conflicts, as Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_674> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 126, 127.</ref> says--one on the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]]''' (Ravi), and one on the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' (Jumna)--with the aid of the '''Ajas''' and '''Śigrus,''' under the leadership of '''Bḥeda.''' It is, however, at least possible that in the former passage '''Yadu''' should be read for [[यक्षु|Yakṣu]], or, at any rate, [[यक्षु|Yakṣu]] be deemed a contemptuous substitute of the name of a possibly un-Āryan or unimportant tribe (as their allies, the Ajas and Śigrus, clearly were) for the name of the certainly famous Yadus, as is suggested by Hopkins.<ref name=fx3_ve2_674> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 259 ''et seq.'' It is not clear however, whether Hopkins thinks that the Yadus are alluded to, but it seems probable.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]].'''

यक्ष्म
<u>'''Yakṣma'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_675> i. 122, 9;<br> x. 85, 31;<br> 97, 11. 12;<br> 137, 4;<br> 163, 1-6.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_675> ii. 10, 5. 6;<br> iii. 31, 1;<br> v. 4, 9;<br> 30, 6;<br> viii. 7, 2;<br> ix. 8, 3. 7. 10;<br> xii. 2, 1. 2;<br> 4, 8;<br> xix. 36, 1;<br> 38, 1.</ref> frequently denotes ‘illness,’ in general, perhaps as rendering the body emaciated. A hundred kinds of [[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]] are referred to in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve2_675> xii. 97.</ref> and ''a-[[यक्ष्म|yakṣma]]'' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx4_ve2_675> xvii. 11.</ref>  denotes ‘free from disease.’ In the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx5_ve2_675> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 5, 2;<br> 5, 6, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 3, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 375 ''et seq.;<br>'' Grohmann, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 400;<br> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 60;<br> Jolly, ''Medicin,'' 89.</ref> an account is given of the origin of [[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]], which is distinguished as of three kinds--'''[[राज-यक्ष्म|Rāja-yakṣma]],''' ‘royal [[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]],’ [[पाप-यक्ष्म|Pāpa-yakṣma]], ‘evil [[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]],’ and '''Jāyenya,''' most probably ‘syphilis.’ The second of the series is elsewhere unknown, and can hardly be defined, for it merely means ‘serious or deadly disease.’ ''Cf.'' also '''[[अज्ञातयक्ष्म|Ajñātayakṣma]].'''

यजत
<u>'''Yajata'''</u> occurs in a hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_676> v. 44, 10, 11. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138.</ref> where he is apparently a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] or a sacrificer.

यजुर्-वेद
<u>'''Yajur-veda,'''</u> the ‘Veda of the sacrificial utterance’ ('''[[यजुस्|Yajus]]'''), is mentioned frequently in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_677> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 9, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 32, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 8, 3;<br> xii. 3, 4, 9.</ref> and Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx2_ve2_677> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 3, 5;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, viii. 3, 8;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 5;<br> ii. 4. 10;<br> iv. 1, 2;<br> 5, 11;<br> Chāndogya Upar ṣad, i. 3, 7;<br> iii. 2, 1. 2;<br> 15, 7;<br> vii. 2, 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1;<br> Āśvalāyana Sra [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7, 2;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Sra [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2, 6, etc.</ref>

यजुस्
<u>'''Yajus'''</u> is repeatedly distinguished from the Ṛc and the '''Sāman''' in Vedic literature.<ref name=fx1_ve2_678> Rv. x. 90, 9;<br> Av. v. 26, 1;<br> ix. 6, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 3, 1;<br> 9, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 30;<br> iv. 1;<br> xix. 28;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 29, 21;<br> viii. 13, 2;<br> Śatapatha Brahmaṇa, i. 2, 1, 7;<br> vi. 5, 1, 2;<br> 3, 4, etc. In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 33, there is a reference to the ''śuklāni Yajūṃṣi,'' ‘white or pure [[यजुस्|Yajus]],’ as promulgated by '''[[वाजसनेय|Vājasaneya]] [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]],''' whence the Vājasaneyi Saṃhītā is popularly known as the ‘White [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].’ The theory that this is due to the fact that in the Vājasaneyi the [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] parts of the text are not accompanied by [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] passages is, though accepted by Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 103, 104;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xxvii, and others, now to be abandoned. In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 10, the expression ''śukrayajāṃṣi'' seems to refer to books iv. and v. of that text. ''Cf.'' also Winternitz. ''Geschichte der indischen Literatur,'' 1, 149, n.</ref> The [[यजुस्|Yajus]] is the utterance accompanying the sacrifice, and may have the form of verse or prose, the tern covering both. 

यज्ञ-गाथा
<u>'''Yajña-gāthā'''</u> denotes a verse ('''[[गाथा|Gāthā]]''') containing a maxim as to the sacrifice of any kind or sort,<ref name=fx1_ve2_679> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 43, 5;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 12, 6;<br> Śānkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 8, 26;<br> 9, 6, etc.</ref> or, as it is expressed in the Mahābhārata,<ref name=fx2_ve2_679> xii. 791. 2316.</ref> a ‘verse sung regarding the sacrifice’ (''[[गाथा|gāthā]] yajña-gītā'').

यज्ञ-वचस् राजस्तम्बायन
<u>'''Yajña-vacas Rājastambāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Rājastamba,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[तुर कावषेय|Tura Kāvaṣeya]],''' according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_680> x. 4, 2, 1;<br> 6, 5, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 5, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> He is also mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_680> iii. 10, 3;<br> iv. 8, 2.</ref>

यज्ञ-सेन
<u>'''Yajña-sena'''</u> is the name of a teacher with the patronymic '''[[चैत्र|Caitra]]''' or '''[[चैत्रियायण|Caitriyāyaṇa]]''' mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_681> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 3, 8, 1 ([[चैत्रियायण|Caitriyāyaṇa]]);<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 4 ([[चैत्र|Caitra]]).</ref>

यज्ञेषु
<u>'''Yajñeṣu'''</u> is the name of a man in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_682> i. 5, 2, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 306.</ref> He was made to prosper by his priest '''[[मात्स्य|Mātsya]],''' who knew the exact moment of sacrificing.

यज्ञोपवीत
<u>'''Yajñopavīta'''</u> denotes the ‘wearing of the Brahminical thread over the left shoulder at the sacrifice,’ and is mentioned as early as the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_683> iii. 10, 9, 12. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 11, 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 2, 1;<br> 6, 1, 12;<br> and '''[[प्राचीनावीत|Prācīnāvīta]].'''</ref> Tilak,<ref name=fx2_ve2_683> ''Orion,'' 145 ''et seq.,'' quoting [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 1, and, the view of the Mīmāmsists, Jaiminīyanyāyamālāvistara, iii. 4, 1. This view is not prejudiced by the quite implausible conjectures as to Orion's belt with which it is combined. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books o the East,'' 12, 361, 424.</ref> however, urges that it was not originally a thread that was worn, but a garment of cloth ('''[[वासस्|Vāsas]]''') or of deerskin ('''[[अजिन|Ajina]]'''). This seems quite probable. 

यति
<u>'''Yati'''</u> is the name of an ancient clan which is connected with the '''Bhṛgus''' in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_684> viii. 3, 9;<br> 6, 18;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 465, n.</ref> where the Yatis certainly seem to be real persons. In another hymn,<ref name=fx2_ve2_684> x. 72, 7.</ref> however, they already appear as almost mythical. In the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx3_ve2_684> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 9, 2;<br> vi. 2, 7, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 5;<br> xi. 10;<br> xxv. 6;<br> xxxvi. 7;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 1, 4;<br> xiii. 4, 16;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 28, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, etc.;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 437 ''et seq.''</ref> and elsewhere,<ref name=fx4_ve2_684> ii. 304. In the parallel passage, Av. ii. 5, 3, the reading ''Yatīr'' is found, possibly an error for ''Yatīn,'' or merely a blunder. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 5, 49, n. 92;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 44;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vi. 3, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 146.</ref> the Yatis are a race whom Indra, in an evil moment, gave over to the hyænas ('''[[सालावृक|Sālāvṛka]]'''): exactly what is referred to is uncertain. Yati is mentioned with [[भृगु|Bhṛgu]] in a verse of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_684/>

यदु
<u>'''Yadu'''</u> is the name of a tribe and of the king of the tribe. They are mentioned repeatedly in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_685> i. 36, 18;<br> 54, 6;<br> 174, 9;<br> iv. 30, 17;<br> v. 31, 8;<br> vi. 45, 1;<br> viii. 4, 7;<br> 7, 18;<br> 9, 14;<br> 10, 5;<br> 45, 27;<br> ix. 61, 2;<br> x. 49, 8;<br> plural, i. 108, 8. See '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]],''' and Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 258 ''et seq.''</ref> normally in conjunction with '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]].''' They seem to have taken part in the great battle against '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]:'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_685> Whether Yadu should be read in Rv. vii. 18, 6, or not, the Yadus seem to be meant. ''Cf.'' '''[[यक्षु|Yakṣu]].'''</ref> the Yadu and the [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] kings seem to have escaped with their lives, while the '''Anu''' and the '''[[द्रुह्यु|Druhyu]]''' kings perished. This is at least the most natural explanation of several passages,<ref name=fx3_ve2_685> Rv. i. 174, 9;<br> iv. 30, 17;<br> v. 31, 3;<br> vi. 20, 12.</ref> though these passages possibly refer to a successful raid across the '''[[सरयु|Sarayu]],''' and a defeat of two princes, Arṇa and [[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_685> Rv. iv. 30, 18.</ref> That [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] was the Yadu king, as Hopkins<ref name=fx5_ve2_685> ''Loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 122, 124;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 205;<br> 5, 142;<br> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 37.</ref> holds, is most improbable.

यन्तृ
<u>'''Yantṛ'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_686> i. 162, 19;<br> x. 22, 5.</ref> and in the Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve2_686> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 6, 29, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘driver’ of horses or ‘charioteer.’ 

यम
<u>'''Yama'''</u> denotes ‘twins,’ the birth of which is frequently alluded to in Vedic literature.<ref name=fx1_ve2_687> Rv. i. 66, 4;<br> 164, 15;<br> ii. 39, 2;<br> iii. 39, 3;<br> v. 57, 4;<br> vi. 59, 2;<br> x. 13, 2;<br> 117, 9;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 4, 10, etc.</ref> Twins of different sex seem to be indicated by the expression ''yamau mithunau.''<ref name=fx2_ve2_687> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 4;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xii. 10.</ref> There are traces of the belief--widely spread among negro and other races--that twins are uncanny and of evil omen,<ref name=fx3_ve2_687> Av. iii. 28;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 9, 8;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxv. 4, 35;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 14, etc. ''Cf.'' '''[[यमसू|Yamasū]];<br> [[युक्ताश्व|Yuktāśva]].'''</ref> but there are also vestiges of the opposite opinion, that twins are lucky.<ref name=fx4_ve2_687> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 12, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 8, and ''cf.'' Rv. iii. 39, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 298300;<br> ''Naxatra,'' 2, 314, n.</ref>

यम-नक्षत्र
<u>'''Yama-nakṣatra.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

यम-सू
<u>'''Yama-sū,'''</u> a ‘bearer of twins,’ is one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_689> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 11, 1.</ref>

यमुना
<u>'''Yamunā,'''</u> ‘twin,’ the name of a river, so called as running parallel with the Ganges, is mentioned thrice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_690> v. 52, 17;<br> vii. 18, 19;<br> x. 75, 5.</ref> and not rarely later. According to the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_690> vii. 18, 19. See '''[[भरत|Bharata]]''' and '''Kuru.'''</ref> the '''Tṛtsus''' and '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' won a great victory against their foes on the [[यमुना|Yamunā]]; there is no reason<ref name=fx3_ve2_690> The Tṛtsus’ territory lay between the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] and the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' on the east and the west respectively.</ref> whatever to accept Hopkins'<ref name=fx4_ve2_690> ''India, Old and New,'' 52.</ref> view that the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] here was another name of the '''[[परुष्णी|Paruṣṇī]]''' (Ravi). In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_690> iv. 9, 10.</ref> the salve ('''[[आञ्जन|Āñjana]]''') of the [[यमुना|Yamunā]] (''Yāmuna'') is mentioned along with that of '''[[त्रिककुद्|Trikakud]]''' (''[[त्रैककुद|Traikakuda]]'') as of value. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_690> viii. 23.</ref> and the Śatapatha<ref name=fx7_ve2_690> xiii. 5, 4, 11.</ref> Brāhmaṇas the '''Bharatas''' are famed as victorious on the [[यमुना|Yamunā]]. Other Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx8_ve2_690> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4, 11 (''cf.'' '''[[पारावत|Pārāvata]]''');<br> xxv. 10, 24;<br> 13, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 29, 25. 33;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 6, 10. 39;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 19, 9, 10;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 6, 28, etc.</ref>  also mention this river. In the Mantrapāṭha<ref name=fx9_ve2_690> ii. 11, 12.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 5;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 323.</ref> the '''Sālvas''' are spoken of as dwelling on its banks.

ययाति
<u>'''Yayāti'''</u> is mentioned twice in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_691> i. 31, 17;<br> x. 63, 1.</ref> once as an ancient sacrificer, and once as Nahuṣya, ‘descendant of '''Nahuṣa,'''’ apparently a king. There is no trace whatever of his connexion with '''[[पूरु|Pūru]],''' as in the Epic,<ref name=fx2_ve2_691> ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 147;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts'' 12, 232.</ref> the tradition of which must be deemed to be inaccurate.

यव
<u>'''1. Yava'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_692> i. 23, 15;<br> 66, 3;<br> 117, 21;<br> 135, 8;<br> 176, 2;<br> ii. 5, 6;<br> 14, 11;<br> v. 85, 3;<br> vii. 3, 4;<br> viii. 2, 3;<br> 22, 6;<br> 63. 9;<br> 78, 10, etc.</ref> appears to be a generic term for any sort of ‘grain,’ and not merely ‘barley.’ The latter sense is probably found in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_692> ii. 8, 3;<br> vi. 30, 1;<br> 50. 1. 2;<br> 91, 1;<br> 141, 2;<br> 142, 1. 2;<br> viii. 7, 20;<br> ix. 1, 22;<br> 6, 14;<br> xii. 1, 42;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 10, 3;<br> 4, 10, 5;<br> vii. 2, 10, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 10;<br> xxvi. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 26;<br> xviii. 12;<br> xxiii. 30;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 4, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 20: ii. 5, 2, 1;<br> iii. 6, 1, 9. 10;<br> iv. 2, 1, 11;<br> xii. 7, 2, 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 14, 3, etc.;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 12.</ref> and is regular later. The barley harvest came after spring,<ref name=fx3_ve2_692> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 13.</ref> in the summer.<ref name=fx4_ve2_692> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 10, 2.</ref> That barley was cultivated in the period of the Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_692> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 86, n.</ref> is not certain, but on the whole very probable.<ref name=fx6_ve2_692> Sowing (''vap'') grain is referred to in Rv. i. 117, 21;<br> ripening of grain in 135, 8;<br> ploughing (''kṛṣ'') in i. 176, 2. Grain rejoicing in rain is alluded to in ii. 5, 6. See '''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]].'''<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 282;<br> Kuhn, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 355, 356;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238, 239.</ref>

यव
<u>'''2. Yava.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

यवस
<u>'''Yavasa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_694> i. 38, 5;<br> 91, 13;<br> iii. 45, 3;<br> iv. 41, 10;<br> 42, 5;<br> vii. 18, 10;<br> 87, 2;<br> 93, 2;<br> 102, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_694> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 43, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘grass’ on which animals feed, and which is burned by the forest fire.<ref name=fx3_ve2_694> ''Cf.'' Agni, ''yavasād,'' in Rv. i. 94, 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 47;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 87.</ref> 

यवागू
<u>'''Yavāgū'''</u> means ‘barley-gruel,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_695> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 5, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 8, 8;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 13, etc.</ref> but is also used of weak decoctions of other kinds of grain.<ref name=fx2_ve2_695> Of '''[[जर्तिल|Jartila]]''' and '''Gvīdhuka,''' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 3, 2.</ref>

यवाशिर्
<u>'''Yavāśir'''</u> is used in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_696> i. 187, 9;<br> ii. 22, 1;<br> iii. 42, 7;<br> viii. 94, 4. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 227;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 279.</ref> as an epithet of '''Soma,''' meaning ‘mixed with grain.’

यवाष
<u>'''Yavāṣa.'''</u> See '''[[येवाष|Yevāṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

यव्य
<u>'''Yavya'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 7, 2, 46) denotes ‘month’ (lit., ‘containing a first half,’ see 2. '''Yava''').<br>==Foot Notes==

यव्यावती
<u>'''Yavyāvatī'''</u> is the name of a river in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_699> vi. 27, 6.</ref> and in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_699> xxv. 7, 2.</ref> Hillebrandt<ref name=fx3_ve2_699> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 268, n. 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 18, 19;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 204;<br> Kaegi, ''Rigveda,'' n. 338;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 168, n. 1.</ref> thinks that the river is one in Iran, the Djob (Zhobe), near the Iryāb (Haliāb), but there is no reason to accept this identification.

यशस्विन् जयन्त लौहित्य
<u>'''Yaśasvin [[जयन्त|Jayanta]] Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Kṛṣṇarāta Triveda [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

यष्टि
<u>'''Yaṣṭi,'''</u> ‘staff,’ is mentioned in the latest parts of the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_701> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 2, 17 of ''[[वेणु|veṇu]],'' ‘bamboo’);<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 7;<br> Kauṣitāki Upaniṣap iv. 19. etc.</ref> 

यस्क
<u>'''Yaska'''</u> is the name of a man. The Yaskas, descendants of Girikṣit (''Gairikṣitāḥ'') are mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_702> xiii. 12. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 475 ''et seq.;<br>'' 8, 245 ''et seq.;<br> Indian Literature,'' 41, n. 30.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[यास्क|Yāska]].'''

याज्ञ-तुर
<u>'''Yājña-tura,'''</u> ‘descendant of Yajñatura,’ is the patronymic of 2. '''[[ऋषभ|Ṛṣabha]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_703> xii. 8, 3, 7;<br> xiii. 5, 4, 15;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 9, 8, 10.</ref>

याज्ञ-वल्क्य
<u>'''Yājña-valkya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Yajñavalkya,’ is repeatedly mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_704> i. 1, 1, 9;<br> 3, 1, 21. 26;<br> 9, 3, 16;<br> ii. 3, 1, 21;<br> 4, 3, 2;<br> 5, 1, 2 (where he is said to be in contradiction with the Rigveda);<br> iii. 1, 1, 4;<br> 2, 21;<br> 3, 10;<br> 8, 2, 24 (cursed by a '''[[चरक|Caraka]]''' teacher);<br> iv. 2, 1, 7;<br> 6, 1, 10;<br> 8, 7, etc. There are no references to [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] in books v-ix, which, on the contrary, owe their doctrine to '''[[तुर कावषेय|Tura Kāvaṣeya]]''' and [[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]];<br> but the fame of [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] revives in books x-xiv--''e.g.,'' xi. 3, 1, 2;<br> 4, 2, 17;<br> 3, 20;<br> 6, 2, 1;<br> 3, 1;<br> xii. 4, 1, 10, etc.</ref> as an authority on questions of ritual. He is, however, also given as an authority on questions of philosophy in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_704> iii. 1, 2 ''et seq.;<br>'' 2, 10 ''et seq.;<br>'' 3, 1;<br> 4, 1;<br> 5, 1;<br> 6, 1;<br> 7, 1, etc.</ref> but Oldenberg<ref name=fx3_ve2_704> ''Buddha,''^5 34, n. 1.</ref> is, no doubt, right in thinking that no possible importance can be attached to the mention of [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] in the latter capacity. He is said to have been a pupil of '''[[उद्दालक आरुणि|Uddālaka Āruṇi]],'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_704> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> whom he opposed successfully in a dispute.<ref name=fx5_ve2_704> iii. 7, 1.</ref> His two wives, '''[[मैत्रेयी|Maitreyī]]''' and '''[[कात्यायनी|Kātyāyanī]],''' are mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx6_ve2_704> ii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 5, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> which concludes<ref name=fx7_ve2_704> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> with a passage ascribing to [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] [[वाजसनेय|Vājasaneya]] the ‘white Yajus’ (''śuklāni yajūṃṣi''). It is remarkable that [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] is never mentioned in any other Vedic text outside the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] except the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx8_ve2_704> ix. 7;<br> xiii. 1.</ref> where, however, both reference are merely transcripts from the Śatapatha.<ref name=fx9_ve2_704> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 132, n. *;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 374.</ref> It has  been supposed by Oldenberg<ref name=fx10_ve2_704> ''Buddha,''^5 34, n. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 120 ''et seq.;<br> Indische Studien,'' 1, 173;<br> 13, 265269;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xxx ''et seq.;<br>'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 188.</ref> and others that [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]] belonged to '''[[विदेह|Videha]],''' but despite the legend of Janaka's patronage of him, his association with '''Uddālaka,''' the '''Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]],''' renders this doubtful.

याज्या
<u>'''Yājyā'''</u> (scil. ṛc, ‘verse’) denotes the words uttered at the moment of offering the sacrifice, ‘consecrating sacrificial formula,’ in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_705> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 2, 1;<br> 6, 10, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 20;<br> xx. 12, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_705> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 8;<br> 11, 10;<br> ii. 13, 2;<br> 26, 3. 5. 6;<br> 40, 8;<br> iii. 32, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 2, 19;<br> iii. 4, 4, 2;<br> vii. 2, 7, 11, etc.</ref>

यातु-धान
<u>'''Yātu-dhāna'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_706> i. 35, 10;<br> x. 87, 2. 3. 7. 10;<br> 120, 4.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_706> Av. i. 7, 1;<br> iv. 3, 4;<br> vi. 13, 3;<br> 32, 2;<br> vii. 70, 2;<br> xix. 46, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4, 1, 29, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘sorcerer,’ ‘wizard,’ or ‘magician.’ The sense of the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_706> vii. 104, 15.</ref> is clearly unfavourable to sorcery. The feminine, Yātudhānī, is also found in the Rigveda and later.<ref name=fx4_ve2_706> Rv. i. 191, 8;<br> x. 118, 8;<br> Av. i. 28, 24;<br> ii. 14, 3;<br> iv. 9, 9;<br> 18, 17;<br> xix. 37, 8, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 26, 65 ''et seq.''</ref>

यातु-विद्
<u>'''Yātu-vid,'''</u> denoting in the plural ‘those who know sorcery,’ designates the Atharvaveda in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_707> x. 5, 2, 20. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' xxii.;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 1. 8, 9, 23.</ref>

याद्व
<u>'''Yādva,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Yadu,'''’ is used of the Yadu prince in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_708> vii. 19, 8.</ref> while the largesse of the Yādvas<ref name=fx2_ve2_708> Rv. viii. 6, 46. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 5, 142.</ref> is alluded to elsewhere. In another passage a beast (''[[पशु|paśu]]'') of the Yadus or Yādvas is mentioned.<ref name=fx3_ve2_708> Rv. viii. 1, 31.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 3;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 37.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Yadu.''' 

यान
<u>'''Yāna'''</u> denotes ‘vehicle’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_709> iv. 43, 6.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_709> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 3, 7;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 10;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 12, 3, etc.</ref>

याम
<u>'''Yāma,'''</u> used in the plural, denotes in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_710> vi. 21, 2.</ref> according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_710> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1''d.''</ref> the planets among which the sun (''[[भग|bhaga]]'') wanders. But both Bloomfield<ref name=fx3_ve2_710> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 30.</ref> and Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve2_710> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 396.</ref> accept the sense--the regular one in the later language--of ‘night watches.’

यामन्
<u>'''Yāman'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_711> iv. 24. 2;<br> vii. 66, 5;<br> 85, 1;<br> ix. 64, 10;<br> x. 78, 6;<br> 80, 5.</ref> a ‘march’ or ‘expedition’ in war.

यायावर
<u>'''Yāyāvara'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_712> Literally, ‘wandering about,’ from the intensive of ''yā,'' ‘to go.’</ref> denotes a person of no fixed abode in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_712> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 1, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xix. 12.</ref>

याव
<u>'''Yāva.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

यास्क
<u>'''Yāska'''</u> (‘descendant of Yaska’) is mentioned in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_714> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]). ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 128.</ref> as a contemporary of '''[[आसुरायण|Āsurāyaṇa]]''' and a teacher of '''[[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]].''' Whether [[यास्क|Yāska]], author of the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_714> [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]] Prātiśākhya, xvii. 25;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 25, 26, etc.;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 17, 103;<br> 3, 396;<br> 8, 243, etc.;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 41, n. 30.</ref> was the same person, it is, of course, impossible to say.

यु
<u>'''Yu,'''</u> appearing in the dual in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 7, 4, 10), seems to mean ‘yoke animals.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

युक्त
<u>'''Yukta'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vi. 7, 4, 8; xii. 4, 1, 2) denotes a ‘yoke’ of oxen. ''Cf.'' 1. '''Yuga.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

युक्ताश्व
<u>'''Yuktāśva'''</u> is the name of a man who is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_717> xi. 8, 8.</ref> as the seer of a Sāman, or chant. He is said to have exposed a pair of twins,<ref name=fx2_ve2_717> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 314, n., whose view is that of Sāyaṇa on the passage. ''Cf.'' '''Yama.'''</ref> but Hopkins<ref name=fx3_ve2_717> ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 61, 62.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie.'' 2, 160.</ref> thinks that the reference is only to an exchange of children.

युग
<u>'''1. Yuga'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_718> i. 115, 2;<br> 184, 3;<br> ii. 39, 4;<br> iii. 53, 17;<br> viii. 80, 7;<br> x. 60, 8;<br> 101, 3, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_718> Av. iv. 1, 40;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 1, 24. 34;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 1, 3, etc.</ref> denotes ‘yoke.’ ''Cf.'' [[रथ|Ratha]].

युग
<u>'''2. Yuga'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_719> ''Yuge-yuge,'' ‘in every age,’ i. 139, 8;<br> iii. 26, 3;<br> vi. 8, 5;<br> 15, 8;<br> 36, 5;<br> ix. 94, 12;<br> ''uttarā yugāni,'' ‘future ages,’ iii. 33, 8;<br> x. 10, 10;<br> ''pūrvāṇi yugāni,'' vii. 70, 4;<br> ''uttare yuge,'' x. 72, 1, etc. In i. 92, 11;<br> 103, 4;<br> 115, 2;<br> 124, 2;<br> 144, 4, etc., the phrase ‘generations of men’ (''manṣyā, manuṣaḥ, janānām'') are referred to. See Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 45, 46.</ref> frequently denotes a ‘generation’; but the expression ''daśame yuge'' applied to '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]]''' in one passage<ref name=fx2_ve2_719> i. 158, 6. Wilson, Translation, 2, 104, n., suggests that ''yuga'' here means a lustrum of five years;<br> but the tenth decade is far more likely, as [[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]] is said to be ‘aged’ (''jujurvān'').</ref> must mean ‘tenth decade’ of life.<br><br>There is no reference in the older Vedic texts to the five-year cycle (see '''[[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]]'''). The quotation from the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_719> xvii. 13, 17.</ref> given in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, and by Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve2_719> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 368.</ref> and others, is merely a citation from a modern text in the commentary on that work.<br><br>Nor do the older Vedic texts know of any series of Yugas or ages such as are usual later. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_719> viii. 2, 21.</ref> there are mentioned in order a hundred years, an ''ayuta'' (10,000?), and then two, three, or four Yugas: the inference from this seems to be that a Yuga means more than an ''ayuta,'' but is not very  certain. Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve2_719> ''Op. cit.,'' 371.</ref> adduces a passage from the Rigveda,<ref name=fx7_ve2_719> viii. 101, 4 = Av. x. 8, 3.</ref> but the reference there, whatever it may be,<ref name=fx8_ve2_719> ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 1, 1, with Keith's note;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 253.</ref> is certainly not to the four ages (''cf.'' also '''[[त्रियुग|Triyuga]]''').<ref name=fx9_ve2_719> In Rv. x. 72, 2, ''devānāṃ pūrvye yuge,'' ‘in the earlier age of the gods,’ occurs.</ref> The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx10_ve2_719> iii. 12, 9, 2. ''Cf.'' Muir, 12, 42, n. 66.</ref> recognizes long periods of time--''e.g.,'' one of 100,000 years.<br><br>To the four ages, Kali, [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]], Tretā, and [[कृत|Kṛta]], there is no certain reference in Vedic literature, though the names occur as the designations of throws at dice (see '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]'''). In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx11_ve2_719> vii. 15, 4 (in the description of the merits of exertion): ‘A man while lying is the Kali;<br> moving himself, he is the [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]];<br> rising, he is the Tretā;<br> walking, he becomes the Kṛta’ (''Kaliḥ śayāno bhavati saṃjihānas tu Dvāparaḥ | uttiṣṭhaṃs Tretā bhavati, Kṛtaṃ saṃpadyate caran||'').</ref> the names occur, but it is not clear that the ages are really meant. Haug<ref name=fx12_ve2_719> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 2, 464, criticized by Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 319.</ref> thought that the dice were meant: this view is at least as probable as the alternative explanation, which is accepted by Weber,<ref name=fx13_ve2_719> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 286;<br> 9, 315 ''et seq.''</ref> Roth,<ref name=fx14_ve2_719> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 460.</ref> Wilson,<ref name=fx15_ve2_719> ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1851, 99.</ref> Max Müller,<ref name=fx16_ve2_719> ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 412.</ref> and Muir.<ref name=fx17_ve2_719> ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 48, n. 86.</ref> Roth, indeed, believes that the verse is an interpolation; but in any case it must be remembered that the passage is from a late book of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. Four ages--[[पुष्य|Puṣya]], [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]], Khārvā, and [[कृत|Kṛta]]--are mentioned in the late Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx18_ve2_719> v. 6.</ref> and the [[द्वापर|Dvāpara]] in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx19_ve2_719> i. 1, 28;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 151, n. 166;<br> Windisch, ''Buddha und Māra,'' 151.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 367371;<br> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 91. A quite different theory of the Yugas is given by Shamasastry, ''Gavām Ayana,'' 141 ''et seq.,'' but his whole theory is quite impossible. Weber once (''Indian Literature,'' 113, n. 127) found the mention of the quinquennial Yuga in Rv. iii. 55, 18, but that passage refers to the five or six seasons (see Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 382, n.), while i. 25, 8, merely alludes to the intercalary month. Weber also (''op. cit.,'' 70, 247) considers that the Yugas are derived from the phases of the moon, but this idea was long since disposed of by Roth, ''Die Lehre von den vier Weltaltern'' (Tübingen, 1860).</ref> 

युद्ध
<u>'''Yuddha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_720> x. 54, 2.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_720> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 9, 1;<br> Aitareva [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 39, 1. 2;<br> vi. 36, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 5, 6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, etc.</ref> denotes ‘battle.’ The more usual word earlier<ref name=fx3_ve2_720> Rv. i. 53, 7;<br> 59, 1;<br> v. 25, 6;<br> vi. 46, 11, etc.;<br> Av. i. 24, 1;<br> iv. 24, 7;<br> vi. 66, 1;<br> 103, 3, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 16, etc.</ref> is Yudh.

युधां-श्रौष्टि औग्र-सैन्य
<u>'''Yudhāṃ-śrauṣṭi Augra-sainya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[उग्रसेन|Ugrasena]]'''’) is the name, in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_721> viii. 21, 7. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 8. The Paurāṇic form is [[युद्ध|Yuddha]]-muṣṭi.</ref> of a king who was anointed by '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]''' and '''[[नारद|Nārada]].'''

युध्यामधि
<u>'''Yudhyāmadhi'''</u> is apparently the name of a king who was defeated by '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]].''' The mention of him occurring only in the verses added at the end of the hymn celebrating the victory of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] over the ten kings<ref name=fx1_ve2_722> Rv. vii. 18, 24. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173.</ref> can claim little authenticity as a notice of [[सुदास्|Sudās]].

युवति
<u>'''Yuvati'''</u> is the ordinary expression for a ‘young woman’ or ‘maiden’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_723> i. 118, 5;<br> ii. 35, 4;<br> iii. 54, 14;<br> iv. 18, 8;<br> v. 2, 1. 2;<br> ix. 86, 16;<br> x. 30, 5.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_723> Av. xiv. 2, 61;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 1, 9;<br> 2, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 9, 6;<br> 4, 3, 8, etc.</ref>

यूथ
<u>'''Yūtha'''</u> is the word for ‘herd’ of cows in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_724> i. 10, 2;<br> 81, 7;<br> iii. 55, 17;<br> iv. 2, 18;<br> 38, 5;<br> v. 41, 19;<br> ix. 71, 9, etc.<br><br>''Cf. yūthya,'' ‘of the herd,’ viii. 56, 4;<br> ix. 15, 4;<br> x. 23, 4.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_724> Av. v. 20, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 2, 1, etc.</ref>

यूप
<u>'''Yūpa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_725> v. 2, 7 (of '''Sunaḥśepa''').</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_725> Av. ix. 6, 22;<br> xii. 1, 38;<br> xiii. 1, 47;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 4, 1;<br> vii. 2, 1, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 17;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]];<br> ix. 10, 2, etc.</ref> means a ‘post,’ usually that to which the sacrificial victim was tied. It also designates the post to which the door of the house was attached ('''[[दुर्य|Durya]]''').<ref name=fx3_ve2_725> Rv. i. 51, 14. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 153.</ref> 

यूषन्
<u>'''Yūṣan,'''</u> occurring in the description of the horse-sacrifice in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_726> i. 162, 13.</ref> and the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx2_ve2_726> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 11, 1. 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 9.</ref> denotes the ‘broth’ which was made from the flesh of the sacrificial animal, and was no doubt used as food. Vessels employed for holding it, '''[[पात्र|Pātra]]''' and '''[[आसेचन|Āsecana]],''' are mentioned. Another form of the word, found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve2_726> vi. 3, 11, 1. 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 271;<br> Schrader, ''Prehisteric Antiquities,'' 316.</ref> is Yūs, which corresponds to the Latin ''jus.''

येवाष
<u>'''Yevāṣa'''</u> is the name of a destructive insect in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_727> v. 23, 7. 8.</ref> The form [[यवाष|Yavāṣa]] is found in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_727> xxx. 1 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 462). The same form occurs in the Gaṇas, ''kumudādi'' and ''prekṣādi'' (Pāṇini, iv. 2, 80). ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 8, 1, where [[यवाष|Yavāṣa]] should be read;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvi. 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[वृष|Vṛṣa]].'''

योक्त्र
<u>'''Yoktra'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_728> iii. 33, 13 v. 33, 2.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_728> Av. iii. 30 6;<br> vii. 78, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 4, 3, [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 3, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 1, 13;<br> vi. 4, 3, 7, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘thongs’ used for yoking the chariot or cart.

योग
<u>'''Yoga'''</u> denotes the yoke of oxen or horses drawing a car in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_729> vi. 91, 1 (yokes of six or eight);<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2, etc. ''Cf.'' '''[[सीर|Sīra]].'''</ref> and the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_729> iv. 3, 11 (''[[रथ|ratha]]-yogāḥ,'' ‘chariot teams’).</ref>

योजन
<u>'''Yojana'''</u> occurs frequently in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_730> i. 123, 8;<br> ii. 16, 3;<br> x. 78, 7;<br> 86, 20, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_730> Av. iv. 26, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 9;<br> iii. 8, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 2, 7, etc. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 363, who finds in Rv. i. 123, 8, ''[[योजन|yojana]]'' as a division of time equivalent to the '''[[मुहूर्त|Muhūrta]].''' But this is most improbable.</ref> as a measure of distance,<ref name=fx3_ve2_730> That is, the distance driven in one ‘harnessing’ (without unyoking), a ‘stage.’</ref> but there is no reference defining its real  length. Later it is reckoned at four '''Krośas,''' or about nine miles.<ref name=fx4_ve2_730> Sometimes calculated at 8 krośas, or 18 miles. The estimate of 2(1/2) miles is also found.</ref>

योध
<u>'''Yodha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_731> i. 143, 5;<br> iii. 39, 4;<br> vi. 25, 5;<br> x. 78, 3.</ref> means ‘fighter,’ ‘warrior,’ ‘soldier.’

योषन्
<u>'''Yoṣan, Yoṣaṇā, Yoṣā, Yoṣit.'''</u> all denote ‘young woman,’ ‘maiden,’ as an object of affection, and as meet for wedlock.<ref name=fx1_ve2_732> ''[[योषन्|Yoṣan]],'' Rv. iv. 5, 5;<br> ''Yoṣaṇā,'' iii. 52, 3;<br> 56, 5;<br> 62, 8;<br> vii. 95, 3. etc.;<br> ''Yoṣā,'' i. 48, 5;<br> 92, 11;<br> iii. 33, 10;<br> 38, 8, etc.;<br> Av. xii. 3, 29;<br> xiv. 1, 56, etc.;<br> ''Yoṣit,'' Rv. ix. 28, 4;<br> Av. vi. 101, 1, etc. ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 418.</ref> So these terms are often opposed in the Brāhmaṇas to '''[[वृषन्|Vṛṣan]],''' ‘male,’ in the general sense of ‘female,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_732> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 5, 15 (''yoṣā''), and often in the Brāhmaṇas.</ref> but they also occur in the sense of ‘wife,’<ref name=fx3_ve2_732> Av. xii. 3, 29 (''yoṣā'').</ref> or ‘daughter,’<ref name=fx4_ve2_732> So ''yoṣā'' in Rv. i. 117, 20. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 310.</ref> or merely ‘girl.’<ref name=fx5_ve2_732> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 1, 7.</ref> See '''[[स्त्री|Strī]].'''

यौगं-धरि
<u>'''Yaugaṃ-dhari,'''</u> ‘descendant of Yugaṃdhara,’ is the name of a king of the '''Sālvas''' in the Mantrapāṭha (ii. 11, 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

यौवन
<u>'''Yauvana,'''</u> ‘youth,’ is found in the Atharvaveda (xviii. 4, 50), where it is opposed to ‘old age.’<br>==Foot Notes==

रक्षितृ
<u>'''Rakṣitṛ,'''</u> ‘protector,’ ‘guardian,’ occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_735> i. 89, 1. 5;<br> ii. 39, 6;<br> guardian of Soma, vi. 7, 7;<br> of the dogs of Yama, x. 14, 11, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_735> Av. iii. 27, 1;<br> xii. 3, 55;<br> xix. 15, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 5, etc.</ref> usually in a metaphorical sense.

रघट्
<u>'''Raghaṭ'''</u> occurs once in the plural in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_736> viii. 7, 24.</ref> where the Paippalāda recension reads ''vaghaṭah.'' Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_736> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' 1''a.''</ref> once con-  jectured ''raghavaḥ,'' ‘swift,’ as the correct reading. Bloomfield,<ref name=fx3_ve2_736> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 580.</ref> who in his translation explains the word as ‘falcons,’ in his notes inclines to think Roth's conjecture likely. Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve2_736> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 504.</ref> suggests ‘bees’ as the meaning. Possibly some kind of bird may be intended.<ref name=fx5_ve2_736> Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 501.</ref>

रजत
<u>'''Rajata'''</u> as an adjective with '''[[हिरण्य|Hiraṇya]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_737> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 1, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 4, 7;<br> xiii. 4, 2, 10;<br> xiv. 1, 3, 4, etc.</ref> designates ‘silver,’ and ornaments ('''[[रुक्म|Rukma]]'''),<ref name=fx2_ve2_737> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 3, 11.</ref> dishes ('''[[पात्र|Pātra]]'''),<ref name=fx3_ve2_737> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 9, 7;<br> iii. 9, 6, 5.</ref> and coins ('''[[निष्क|Niṣka]]''')<ref name=fx4_ve2_737> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1, 14.</ref> ‘made of silver’ are mentioned. The word is also used alone as a substantive to denote ‘silver.’<ref name=fx5_ve2_737> Av. v. 28, 1;<br> xiii. 4, 51;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 12, 2;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 7;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 17, 3;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 180;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 56;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 151, 152;<br> Vincent Smith, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 34, 230.</ref>

रजन कोणेय
<u>'''Rajana Koṇeya,'''</u> or '''[[कौणेय|Kauṇeya]],''' is the name of a teacher mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_738> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 8, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 2 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 474).</ref> It is said in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_738> xi. 1 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 474).</ref> that '''[[क्रतुजित् जानकि|Kratujit Jānaki]]''' successfully sacrificed for him when he desired to obtain eyesight. He is also mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_738> xiii. 4, 11. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 58, n. 2.</ref> where the name of his son, '''[[उग्रदेव|Ugradeva]] [[राजनि|Rājani]],''' also occurs.<ref name=fx4_ve2_738> He was a leper, and the '''[[रजनी|Rajanī]]''' is used against leprosy, Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 266.</ref>

रजनी
<u>'''Rajanī'''</u> is found in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_739> i. 23, 1. ''Cf.'' Roth in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 24;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 267.</ref> where it denotes some sort of plant, probably so called because of its  power of ‘colouring’ (from ''rañj,'' ‘to colour’). The species cannot be identified owing to the untrustworthiness of the later authorities who attempt its identification.

रजयित्री
<u>'''Rajayitrī,'''</u> a ‘female dyer,’ is included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_740> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 7, 1.</ref>

रजस्
<u>'''1. Rajas'''</u> denotes the region of the atmosphere between heaven and earth in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_741> i. 56, 5;<br> 62, 5;<br> 84, 1;<br> 124, 5;<br> 168, 6;<br> 187, 4;<br> ii. 40, 3;<br> vi. 62, 9, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_741> Av. iv. 25, 2;<br> vii. 25, 1;<br> 41, 1;<br> x. 3, 9;<br> xiii. 2, 8. 43;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 4, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 44, etc.</ref> The atmosphere, like the sky ('''Div'''), is divided into three regions,<ref name=fx3_ve2_741> Rv. iv. 53, 5;<br> v. 69, 1;<br> ix. 74, 6;<br> x. 45, 3;<br> 123, 8;<br> Av. xiii. 1, 11, etc. In Rv. i. 164, 6, six ‘regions’ are mentioned.</ref> but more normally into two, the ‘earthly’ (''pārthiva'')<ref name=fx4_ve2_741> Rv. i. 81, 5;<br> 90, 7;<br> 154, 1;<br> vi. 49, 3;<br> viii. 88, 5;<br> ix. 72, 8, etc.</ref> and the ‘heavenly’ (''[[दिव्य|divya]]'' or ''divaḥ'').<ref name=fx5_ve2_741> Rv. iv. 53, 3;<br> i. 110, 6. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 10;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> In some passages<ref name=fx6_ve2_741> Rv. i. 166, 3;<br> iii. 62, 16;<br> x. 75. 7.</ref> the word refers in the plural to the dusty fields on earth.

रजस्
<u>'''2. Rajas'''</u> in one passage of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_742> ''Rajaḥ-śaya,'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 8;<br> ''rajāśaya,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 2, 11, 2 (Sāyaṇa on [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 23, 2);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 2, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ii. 8.</ref> clearly means ‘silver,’ like '''[[रजत|Rajata]].''' It is also taken in this sense in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_742> x. 105, 7.</ref> by Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve2_742> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 55, 56.</ref> but this interpretation is doubtful.

रजस
<u>'''Rajasa'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_743> x. 2, 25.</ref> apparently as the name of a kind of ‘fish.’ Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_743> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 621;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveḍa, 624.</ref> however, understood it as an adjective meaning ‘impure.’ 

रजि
<u>'''Raji'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_744> vi. 26, 6. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 156;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' where Roth compares a conjecture in Av. xx. 128, 13</ref> seemingly as the name of a king, or perhaps demon, slain by Indra for '''[[पिठीनस्|Piṭhīnas]].'''

रज्जव्य
<u>'''Rajjavya'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vi. 7, 1, 28) den ‘cord’ or ‘rope.’<br>==Foot Notes==

रज्जु
