<u>'''Rajju'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_746> i. 162, 8 (''śīrṣaṇyā [[रशना|raśanā]] rajjuḥ,'' referring to the horse presumably means the head harness).</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_746> Av. iii. 11, 8;<br> vi. 121, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 1, 14;<br> x. 2, 3, 8;<br> xi. 3, 1, 1, etc.</ref> denotes ‘rope.’ In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_746> iv. 3, 2;<br> xix. 47, 7, 8;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 368.</ref> the serpent is called the ‘toothed rope’ (''[[रज्जु|rajju]] datvatī'').

रज्जु-दाल
<u>'''Rajju-dāla'''</u> is the name of a tree (''Cordia myxa'' or ''latifolia'') the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_747> xiii. 4, 4, 6. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 373, n. 2.</ref>

रज्जु-सर्ज
<u>'''Rajju-sarja,'''</u> ‘rope-maker,’ is one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_748> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 1.</ref>

रण
<u>'''Raṇa'''</u> denotes properly the ‘joy’ of battle, then ‘battle,’ ‘combat’ itself in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_749> i. 61, 1. 9;<br> 74, 3;<br> 119, 3;<br> vi. 16, 15, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_749> Av. v. 2, 4, etc.</ref>

रत्न
<u>'''Ratna'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_750> i. 20, 7;<br> 35, 8;<br> 41, 6;<br> 125, 1;<br> 140, 11;<br> 141, 10;<br> ii. 38, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_750> Av. v. 1, 7;<br> vii. 14, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 1.</ref> denotes a precious object, not specifically a ‘jewel,’ as in post-Vedic literature.

रत्नि
<u>'''Ratni,'''</u> ‘ell,’ occurring in the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iv. 4) is a corruption of '''[[अरत्नि|Aratni]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रत्निन्
<u>'''Ratnin,'''</u> ‘receiving gifts,’ is the term applied to those people of the royal entourage in whose houses the [[रत्न|Ratna]]-[[हविस्|havis]], a  special rite, was performed in the course of the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]]''' or ‘royal consecration.’ The list given in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_752> i. 8, 9, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_752> i. 7, 3, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> consists of the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] (''i.e.,'' the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]), the [[राजन्य|Rājanya]], the [[महिषी|Mahiṣī]] (the first wife of the king), the '''Vāvāta''' (the favourite wife of the king), the Parivṛktī (the discarded wife), the [[सेनानी|Senānī]], ‘commander of the army’; the [[सूत|Sūta]], ‘charioteer’; the Grāmaṇī, ‘village headman’; the [[क्षत्तृ|Kṣattṛ]], ‘chamberlain’; the [[संग्रहीतृ|Saṃgrahītṛ]], ‘charioteer’ or ‘treasurer’; the [[भागदुघ|Bhāgadugha]], ‘collector of taxes’ or ‘divider of food’; and the Akṣāvāpa, ‘superintender of dicing’ or ‘thrower of dice.’ In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_752> v. 3, 1, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> the order is [[सेनानी|Senānī]]; [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]; Mahisī; [[सूत|Sūta]]; Grāmaṇī; [[क्षत्तृ|Kṣattṛ]]; Saṃgrahitṛ; [[भागदुघ|Bhāgadugha]]; Akṣāvāpa; Go-nikartana, ‘slayer of cows’ or ‘huntsman’; and [[पालागल|Pālāgala]], ‘courier’; the ‘discarded wife’ being mentioned as forbidden to stay at home<ref name=fx4_ve2_752> According to Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 3, 35, she goes to a Brahmin's house, where she shares his inviolability and exemption from jurisdiction.</ref> on the day of the ceremony of offering a pap for Nirṛti in her house. In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx5_ve2_752> ii. 6, 5;<br> iv. 3, 8.</ref> the list is [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] (''i.e.,'' [[पुरोहित|Purohita]]); [[राजन्|Rājan]]; [[महिषी|Mahiṣī]]; Parivṛktī; [[सेनानी|Senānī]]; [[संग्रहीतृ|Saṃgrahītṛ]]; [[क्षत्तृ|Kṣattṛ]]; [[सूत|Sūta]]; Vaiśyagrāmaṇī; [[भागदुघ|Bhāgadugha]]; Takṣa-Rathakārau, ‘carpenter and chariot-maker’; Akṣāvāpa; and Go-vikarta. The [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx6_ve2_752> xv. 4.</ref> substitutes Go-[[व्यछ|vyacha]] for Govikarta, and omits Takṣa-Rathakārau.<br><br>It will be seen that the list is essentially that of the royal household, and of the king's servants in the administration of the country, though the exact sense of '''[[संग्रहीतृ|Saṃgrahītṛ]], [[भागदुघ|Bhāgadugha]], [[सूत|Sūta]], Grāmaṇī, [[क्षत्तृ|Kṣattṛ]],''' is open to reasonable doubt, mainly as to whether public officers or private servants<ref name=fx7_ve2_752> Similarly Akṣāvāpa is either the man who dices for the king--''i.e.,'' a professional dicer who plays with the king or watches his play--or a public officer who superintends the gambling halls of the state and collects the revenue, as was regularly done later on. Early English history shows similar evolution of household officers into ministers of state.</ref> are meant, for the names are of uncertain significance. A briefer list of eight '''Vīras,''' ‘heroes,’ as among the friends of the king,  is given in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]:<ref name=fx8_ve2_752> xix. 1, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 200;<br> ''Über den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],'' 4;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 128;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 58-65;<br> Hopkins, ''Trañsactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 30, n. 2.</ref> brother, son, [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], [[महिषी|Mahiṣī]], [[सूत|Sūta]], Grāmaṇī, [[क्षत्तृ|Kṣattṛ]], and [[संग्रहीतृ|Saṃgrahītṛ]].

रथ
<u>'''Ratha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_753> i. 20, 3;<br> iii. 15, 5;<br> iv. 4, 10;<br> 16, 20;<br> 36, 2;<br> 43, 25, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_753> Av. v. 14, 5;<br> x. 1, 8: [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 12, 3, etc.</ref> denotes ‘chariot’ as opposed to '''Anas,''' ‘cart,’ though the distinction is not absolute. Of differences in the structure of the two we have no information, except that the '''Kha,''' or nave hole, in the wheel of the chariot was greater than in that of the cart.<ref name=fx3_ve2_753> viii. 91, 7, with Sāyaṇa's note;<br> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 333.</ref><br><br>The chariot has, as a rule, two wheels ('''[[चक्र|Cakra]]'''), to which reference is frequently made.<ref name=fx4_ve2_753> ''Cf.'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 16, 5;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 16, 7;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4.</ref> The wheel consisted of a rim ('''Pavi'''), a felly ('''[[प्रधि|Pradhi]]'''), spokes ('''Ara'''),<ref name=fx5_ve2_753> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 32, 15;<br> 141, 9;<br> v. 13, 6;<br> 58, 5;<br> viii. 20, 14;<br> 77, 3;<br> x. 78, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 4, etc.</ref> and a nave ('''[[नभ्य|Nabhya]]'''). The rim and the felly together constitute the '''Nemi.''' The hole in the nave is called '''Kha:''' into it the end of the axle was inserted; but there is some uncertainty whether '''[[आणि|Āṇi]]''' denotes the extremity of the axle that was inserted in the nave, or the lynch-pin used to keep that extremity in the wheel. Sometimes a solid wheel was used.<ref name=fx6_ve2_753> ''Cf.'' '''Pradhī.'''</ref><br><br>The axle ('''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]''') was, in some cases, made of '''[[अरटु|Araṭu]]''' wood;<ref name=fx7_ve2_753> Rv. viii. 46, 27;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 247, n.</ref> round its ends the wheels revolved. To the axle was attached the body of the chariot ('''[[कोश|Kośa]]'''). This part is also denoted by the word '''[[वन्धुर|Vandhura]],''' which more precisely means the ‘seat’ of the chariot. The epithet ''tri-[[वन्धुर|vandhura]]'' is used of the chariot of the Aśvins, seemingly to correspond with another of its epithets, ''tri-[[चक्र|cakra]]:'' perhaps, as Weber<ref name=fx8_ve2_753> ''Proceedings of the Berlin Academy,'' 1898, 564;<br> Virchow, ''Zeitschrift für Ethnologie'' 5, 200. ''Cf.'' note 21.</ref> thinks, a chariot with three seats and three wheels was a real form of vehicle; but Zimmer<ref name=fx9_ve2_753> ''Op.'' ''cit.'' iii.</ref> considers that the vehicle was purely mythical. '''[[गर्त|Garta]]''' also denotes the seat of the warrior. <br><br>At right angles to the axle was the pole of the chariot ('''[[ईषा|Īṣā]], Praüga'''). Normally there was, it seems, one pole, on either side of which the horses were harnessed, a yoke ('''Yuga''') being laid across their necks; the pole was passed through the hole in the yoke (called Kha<ref name=fx10_ve2_753> This seems to be the sense of Rv. viii. 91, 7;<br> but it has also been taken as the opening in the yoke through which the ox's head passed (the Homeric ). See Cowell's note on Wilson's translation;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 237, n.</ref> or [[तर्द्मन्|Tardman]]),<ref name=fx11_ve2_753> Av. xiv. 1, 40.</ref> the yoke and the pole then being tied together.<ref name=fx12_ve2_753> Rv. iii. 6, 6;<br> v. 56, 4;<br> x. 60, 8.</ref><br><br>The horses were tied by the neck (''grīvā''), where the yoke was placed, and also at the shoulder, presumably by traces fastened to a bar of wood at right angles to the pole, or fastened to the ends of the pole, if that is to be regarded, as it probably should, as of triangular shape, wide at the foot and coming to a point at the tip.<ref name=fx13_ve2_753> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 249, thinks that ''[[वाणी|vāṇī]]'' in Rv. i. 119, 5, denotes the two bars of wood to which the traces were fastened. This is also the view of Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' Bo7htlingk's Lexicon, and Grassmann. The word may mean ‘two voices’ (Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 162).</ref> The traces seem to be denoted by '''[[रश्मि|Raśmi]]''' and '''[[रशना|Raśanā]].''' These words also denote the ‘reins,’ which were fastened to the bit (perhaps ''[[शिप्रा|śiprā]]'') in the horse's mouth. The driver controlled the horses by reins, and urged them on with a whip (''Kaśā'').<ref name=fx14_ve2_753> Rv. v. 83, 3;<br> vi. 75, 6.</ref> The girths of the horse were called Kakṣyā.<ref name=fx15_ve2_753> Rv. x. 10, 13;<br> ''kakṣya-prā,'' ‘filling out the girths’ (''i.e.,'' ‘well fed’), is an epithet of Indra's horses, i. 10, 3.</ref><br><br>The normal number of horses seems to have been two, but three or four<ref name=fx16_ve2_753> Three horses are mentioned in Rv. x. 33, 5, and [[प्रष्टि|Praṣṭi]] in Rv. i. 39, 6;<br> viii. 7, 28, etc., may have the sense of ‘third horse.’ See also Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 4, 11;<br> 2, 4, 9, etc.;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 13, 12. For four horses, ''cf.'' Rv. ii. 18, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 3, 17;<br> 1, 4, 11;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 21, n. 1.</ref> were often used. It is uncertain whether, in these cases, the extra horse was attached in front or at the side; possibly both modes were in use. Even five steeds could be employed.<ref name=fx17_ve2_753> ''Rathaḥ pañcavāhī,'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 3. In the parallel passage the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 7, 2, has ''praṣṭivāhī.''</ref> Horses were normally used for chariots, but the ass (''[[गर्दभ|gardabha]]'')<ref name=fx18_ve2_753> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 9, 4.</ref> or mule (''aśvatarī'')<ref name=fx19_ve2_753> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 2, 1;<br> v. 13, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 9, 1.</ref> are also mentioned. The ox was employed for drawing carts, and in fact derived its  name, '''[[अनड्वाह्|Anaḍvāh]],''' from this use. Sometimes a poor man had to be content with a single steed, which then ran between two shafts.<ref name=fx20_ve2_753> Rv. x. 101, 11;<br> 131, 3, and vi. 15, 19;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 13, 12;<br> xxi. 13, 8, etc.</ref><br><br>In the chariot the driver stood on the right, while the warrior was on the left, as indicated by his name, '''Savyeṣṭha''' or '''[[सव्यष्ठा|Savyaṣṭhā]],'''<ref name=fx21_ve2_753> This is the case in Av. viii. 8, 23, with [[सव्यष्ठा|Savyaṣṭhā]], and in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 9, 1, ''savyeṣṭha-[[सारथि|sārathi]]'' occurs as a compound where the sense is certainly ‘the warrior and the charioteer.’ See also Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 8, and Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 62, n. 1. The Greek notices speak of two warriors and a charioteer. ''Cf.'' the Aśvins' car with its three seats. See von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 435.</ref> He could also sit when he wanted, for the chariot had seats, and an archer would naturally prefer to sit while shooting his arrows.<br><br>The dimensions of the chariot are given in the Śulba [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx22_ve2_753> vi. 5 (Bürk, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 344, 345).</ref> of Āpastamba at 188 Aṅgulis (finger-breadths) for the pole, 104 for the axle, and 86 for the yoke. The material used in its construction was wood, except for the rim of the wheel.<ref name=fx23_ve2_753> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 3, 16. The chariot used at the bridal procession was made of Śalmali wood, Rv. x. 85, 20.<br><br>For the chariot in the Epic, see Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 235-262;<br> and ''cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 338, 339;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 245-252;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 38, n. 1.</ref><br><br>Many other parts of the chariot are mentioned, their names being often obscure in meaning: see '''[[अङ्क|Aṅka]], [[न्य्अङ्क|Nyaṅka]], [[उद्धि|Uddhi]], [[पक्षस्|Pakṣas]], [[पातल्य|Pātalya]], [[भुरिज्|Bhurij]], [[रथोपस्थ|Rathopastha]], [[रथवाहन|Rathavāhana]].'''

रथ-कार
<u>'''Ratha-kāra,'''</u> ‘chariot-maker,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_754> iii. 5, 6.</ref> as one of those who are to be subject to the king, seeming to stand generally as an example of the industrial population. He is also referred to in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx2_ve2_754> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 17;<br> xxx. 6.</ref> and in the Brāhmaṇas:<ref name=fx3_ve2_754> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 8;<br> iii. 4, 2, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 17.</ref> in all these passages, as well a probably in the Atharvaveda also, the [[रथकार|Rathakāra]] already forms a caste. The  later system<ref name=fx4_ve2_754> [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]], i. 95. On the special position, in the later ritual, of the [[रथकार|Rathakāra]] as a caste below the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]], but superior to the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]], ''cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 12, 13, and ''cf.'' [[वर्ण|Varṇa]], see also Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 209, 210.</ref> regards the [[रथकार|Rathakāra]] as the offspring of a Māhiṣya (the son of a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] husband and a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] wife) and a Karaṇī (the daughter of a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] husband and a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] wife), but it is unreasonable to suppose that such an origin is historically accurate. The Rathakāras must rather be deemed to have been a functional caste. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx5_ve2_754> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 152, 153.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 196 ''et seq.''</ref> suggests that the '''Anu''' tribe formed the basis of the [[रथकार|Rathakāra]] caste, referring to their worship of the Ṛbhus, who are, of course, the chariotmakers ''par excellence.'' But there is little ground for this view.

रथ-गृत्स
<u>'''Ratha-gṛtsa'''</u> in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xv. 15) and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 48, 9) denotes a ‘skilled charioteer.’<ref name=fx1_ve2_755> ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 3, 1;<br> kṛtsna, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 8, 10;<br> kṛtsa, [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 9.</ref>

रथ-चक्र
<u>'''Ratha-cakra,'''</u> ‘chariot wheel,’ is often mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_756> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 43, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 6, 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 3, 12;<br> v. 1, 5, 2;<br> xi. 8, 1, 11, etc.</ref> See '''[[रथ|Ratha]]''' and '''[[चक्र|Cakra]].'''

रथ-चर्षण
<u>'''Ratha-carṣaṇa'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_757> viii. 5, 19.</ref> where the sense is doubtful. Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_757> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> thought that some part of the chariot was meant, but the sense is perhaps only the ‘pathway of the chariot.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_757> ''Cf.'' also the citation and explanation in Durga's commentary on the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 12.</ref>

रथ-जूति
<u>'''Ratha-jūti'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (xix. 44, 3) is either an adjective meaning ‘driving swiftly in a chariot,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_758> ‘Of chariot-swiftness’ according to Whitney, Translation of the Athar vaveda, 967. ''Cf.'' his note on the passage.</ref> or a proper name, as Roth in the St. Petersburg Dictionary suggests. 

रथ-नाभि
<u>'''Ratha-nābhi,'''</u> the ‘nave of the chariot-wheel,’ is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_759> xxxiv. 5.</ref> and in the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx2_ve2_759> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 5, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 4;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 8;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]. vii. 15, 1, etc.</ref>

रथ-प्रोत दार्भ्य
<u>'''Ratha-prota Dārbhya'''</u> (‘descendant of Darbha’) is mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (ii. 1, 3) perhaps as a king, but possibly as a priest.<br>==Foot Notes==

रथ-प्रोष्ठ
<u>'''Ratha-proṣṭha'''</u> occurs as the name of a princely family in the Rigveda (x. 60, 5). See '''[[सुबन्धु|Subandhu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रथ-मुख
<u>'''Ratha-mukha'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_762> Av. viii. 8, 23;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 3, 2;<br> v. 4, 9, 3, etc.</ref> denotes the fore-part of a chariot. ''Cf.'' '''[[रथशीर्ष|Rathaśīrṣa]].'''

रथर्वी
<u>'''Ratharvī'''</u> is the name of a snake in the Atharvaveda (x. 4, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

रथ-वाहन
<u>'''Ratha-vāhana'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_764> vi. 75, 8.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_764> Av. iii. 17, 3 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 5, 5 = [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 11 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 12 = [[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 34. 35. See also [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 9, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 3, 23 ''et seq.''</ref> for a movable stand to hold the chariot. According to Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve2_764> ''Festgruss an Bo7htlingk,'' 95 ''et seq.;<br>'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 116.</ref> it corresponds to the Greek , on which the chariot rested when out of use. The word [[रथवाहन|Rathavāhana]]-[[वाह|vāha]] is employed in the sense of the two horses that draw the stand.<ref name=fx4_ve2_764> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 20, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 4, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 1.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx5_ve2_764> ''Über den [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]],'' 27, n. 2, followed by Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 275. Weber, however, admits that the [[रथवाहन|Rathavāhana]] may at times have served as a mere stand, like the Homeric  while Geldner expresses the opinion that it never has that sense. The use of the term Rathavāhanavāha shows that the stand was movable.</ref> thinks it was used to convey the war chariot to the scene of action. 

रथवीति दार्भ्य
<u>'''Rathavīti Dārbhya'''</u> (‘descendant of Darbha’) is mentioned once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_765> v. 61, 17. 19.</ref> as residing in places abounding in kine (''gomatīr anu'') far away among the hills, possibly the Himālayas, and as the patron of the singer of the hymn. Later the tradition<ref name=fx2_ve2_765> See Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 50 ''et seq.,'' 62, n. 2, and the criticism in Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Neten,'' 1, 353, 354;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 359, 362.</ref> makes him the king, whose daughter '''Śyāsvāśva''' won for his wife by his father's and the Maruts' aid.

रथ-शीर्ष
<u>'''Ratha-śīrṣa,'''</u> the ‘head of the chariot’--that is, its fore-part-is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ix. 4. 1, 13).<br>==Foot Notes==

रथ-सङ्ग
<u>'''Ratha-saṅga'''</u> in the Rigveda (ix. 53, 2) denotes the hostile encounter of chariots.<br>==Foot Notes==

रथाक्ष
<u>'''Rathākṣa'''</u> in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_768> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6, 4, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 8.</ref> denotes the ‘axle of the chariot.’ Its length is given by the scholiast on the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_768> viii. 8, 6.</ref> as 104 Aṅgulas (‘finger-breadths’), which agrees with the statement in the Āpastamba Śulba [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_768> vi. 5 (Bürk, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenläudischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 344, 345).</ref> See '''[[रथ|Ratha]].'''

रथाह्न्य
<u>'''Rathāhnya'''</u> in the Śatapatha Brāhmana (xii. 2, 3, 12) denotes a ‘day's journey by chariot.’<br>==Foot Notes==

रथिन्
<u>'''Rathin'''</u> and '''Rathī''' in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_770> [[रथिन्|Rathin]], i. 122, 8;<br> v. 83, 3;<br> vi. 47, 31;<br> viii. 4, 9;<br> x. 40, 5;<br> 51, 6;<br> Rathī, i. 25, 3;<br> ii. 39, 2;<br> iii. 3, 6;<br> v. 87, 8;<br> vii. 39, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_770> [[रथिन्|Rathin]], Av. iv. 34, 4;<br> vii. 62, 1;<br> 73, 1;<br> xi. 10, 24;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 2, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 26;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 7, 3, 7, etc.;<br> Rathī, [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 15, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 296.</ref> denote ‘one who goes in a chariot,’ an expression which includes both the driver and the warrior who accompanied him. 

रथीतर
<u>'''Rathītara'''</u> (‘good charioteer’) is the name of a teacher mentioned in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_771> xxii. 11.</ref> and the Bṛhaddevatā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_771> i. 26;<br> iii. 40;<br> vii. 145 (ed. Macdonell).</ref>

रथे-ष्ठा
<u>'''Rathe-ṣṭhā,'''</u> ‘standing on the chariot,’ denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_772> i. 173, 4. 5;<br> ii. 17, 3;<br> vi. 21, 1;<br> 22, 5;<br> 29, 1;<br> viii. 4, 13;<br> 33, 14;<br> ix. 97, 49;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 32<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 296.</ref> the warrior who fights from the chariot, ‘car-fighter.’

रथोपस्थ
<u>'''Rathopastha,'''</u> ‘lap of the chariot,’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_773> viii. 8, 23.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_773> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 10, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 3, 12, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 238, n.</ref> seems to denote the ‘bottom’ or lower part on which the driver and the fighter stand.

रन्ध्र
<u>'''Randhra'''</u> seems, in the phrase Ukṣṇo [[रन्ध्र|Randhra]] occurring in one passage of the Rigveda (viii. 7, 26), to be the name of a place, but the sense is very doubtful. In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 9, 13) Ukṣṇo [[रन्ध्र|randhra]] is the name of a man.<br>==Foot Notes==

रभि
<u>'''Rabhi,'''</u> occurring once in the Rigveda (viii. 5, 29), designates some part of the chariot. The term perhaps means ‘supporting shaft.’<br>==Foot Notes==

रम्भ
<u>'''Rambha'''</u> seems to mean a ‘staff’ or ‘support’ in one passage of the Rigveda (viii. 45, 20). In another place (ii. 15, 9) a man is described as Rambhin, apparently as carrying a staff to support himself in old age; Sāyaṇa explains this word as ‘door-keeper’ (like one of the senses of ''daṇḍin,'' ‘staff-bearer,’ in later Sanskrit).<br>==Foot Notes==

रम्भिणी
<u>'''Rambhiṇī'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_777> i. 168, 3. ''Cf.'' i. 167, 3, and see Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 283.</ref> as being on the shoulders of the Maruts. A ‘spear’ seems to be meant, perhaps conceived as clinging (''rambh = rabk,'' ‘clasp’) to the shoulders of a man. 

रयि
<u>'''Rayi'''</u> is the common word for ‘wealth’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_778> i. 73, 1;<br> 159, 4;<br> ii. 21, 6;<br> iii. 1, 19;<br> iv. 2, 7;<br> 34, 10;<br> 36, 9;<br> vi. 6, 7;<br> 31, 1, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_778> Av. iii. 14, 1;<br> vi. 33, 3;<br> vii. 80, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 72;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 22;<br> xiv. 22;<br> xxvii. 6, etc.</ref> Special mention is often made of wealth in ‘heroes’ ''([[वीर|vīra]])--i.e.,'' in ‘good sons,’<ref name=fx3_ve2_778> Rv. ii. 11. 13;<br> 30, 11;<br> iv. 51, 10, etc.</ref> in horses,<ref name=fx4_ve2_778> Rv. v. 41, 5;<br> viii. 6, 9, etc.</ref> in cattle,<ref name=fx5_ve2_778> Rv. v. 4, 11, etc.</ref> etc.

रशना
<u>'''Raśanā'''</u> means generally ‘cord’ or ‘rope.’ In the Rigveda the word ofter refers to various fastenings of a horse. In one passage<ref name=fx1_ve2_779> i. 162, 8. ''Cf.'' '''[[रज्जु|Rajju]].'''</ref> the expression ''śīrṣaṇyā [[रशना|raśanā]],'' ‘head rope,’ perhaps means not so much ‘reins’ as ‘headstall.’ In others<ref name=fx2_ve2_779> Rv. i. 163, 2. 5;<br> x. 79, 7.</ref> the sense of ‘traces’ seems certain, though sometimes<ref name=fx3_ve2_779> Rv. iv. 1. 9;<br> ix. 87, 1;<br> x. 18, 14. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 4, 3.</ref> ‘reins’ or ‘traces’ may equally well be intended. Elsewhere the more general sense of ‘rope’ for stening is meant.<ref name=fx4_ve2_779> Rv. ii. 28, 5;<br> Av. viii. 78, 1;<br> x. 9, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 46;<br> xxii. 2;<br> xxviii. 33;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6. 4, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6, 3. 10, etc. ''Cf.'' the use of [[रशना|Raśanā]] as equivalent to ‘finger’ in Rv. x. 4, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 249.</ref>

रश्मि
<u>'''1. Raśmi'''</u> is not rarely found in the sense of ‘rope’<ref name=fx1_ve2_780> Rv. i. 28, 4;<br> iv. 22, 8;<br> viii. 25, 18, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 19, 3, etc.</ref> generally; but more usually it denotes either the ‘reins’ or the ‘traces’<ref name=fx2_ve2_780> Rv. viii. 7, 8;<br> x. 130, 7, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 4, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 14;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 4, 2, etc. In [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 37, 1, the two inner (''antarau'') reins or traces of the chariot are mentioned.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 249.</ref> of a chariot, either sense being equally good in most passages.

रश्मि
<u>'''2. Raśmi'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_781> i. 35, 7;<br> iv. 52, 7;<br> vii. 36, 1;<br> 77, 3, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_781> Av. ii. 32, 1;<br> xii. 1, 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 1, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 2, 3, 14, etc.</ref> regularly denotes a ‘ray’ of the sun. 

रसा
<u>'''Rasā'''</u> is found in three passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_782> i. 112, 12;<br> v. 53, 9;<br> x. 75, 6. In v. 53, 9, the phrase ''rasānitabhā'' is found. Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 202, is inclined to regard ''[[अनितभा|anitabhā]]'' as an epithet of [[रसा|Rasā]], perhaps for ''amitabhā,'' ‘of unmeasured splendour,’ but this is hardly probable. It seems better to take [[अनितभा|Anitabhā]] as the name of an otherwise unknown river. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''India,'' 166, 173, n.</ref> clearly as the name of a real stream in the extreme north-west of the Vedic territory. Elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve2_782> Rv. v. 41, 15;<br> ix. 41, 6;<br> x. 100, 1, 2 (''cf.'' Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 348;<br> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 100 ''et seq.'');<br> 121, 4.</ref> it is the name of a mythic stream at the ends of the earth, which as well as the atinosphere it encompasses. It is reasonable to assume that, as in the case of the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],''' the literal is the older sense, and to see in the river a genuine stream, perhaps originally the Araxes or Jaxartes, because the Vendidad mentions the Raṅhā, the Avestan form of [[रसा|Rasā]]. But the word seems originally to allude merely to the ‘sap’ or ‘flavour’ of the waters,<ref name=fx3_ve2_782> Rv. iv. 43, 6;<br> viii. 72, 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 15, 16;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 323;<br> Brunnhofer, ''Iran und Turan,'' 86;<br> Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1898, 567-569.</ref> and so could be applied to every river, like [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].

रसाशिर्
<u>'''Rasāśir'''</u> as an epithet of Soma in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_783> iii. 48, 1, where Sāyaṇa explains ''rasa'' as ‘milk.’ ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 211, n. 5.</ref> means ‘mixed with juice’--''i.e.,'' with milk.

रह-सू
<u>'''Raha-sū,'''</u> ‘bearing in secret,’ is a term applied in one passage of the Rigveda (ii. 29, 1) to an unmarried mother. ''Cf.'' '''Pati''' and '''[[धर्म|Dharma]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रहस्यु देव-मलिम्लुच्
<u>'''Rahasyu Deva-malimluc'''</u> is the name, in the Pañcavimśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 4, 7), of a mythical person who at '''[[मुनिमरण|Munimaraṇa]]''' slew the saintly '''Vaikhānases.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रहू-गण
<u>'''Rahū-gaṇa'''</u> is the name of a family mentioned in the plural in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_786> i. 78, 5.</ref> According to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve2_786> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 110. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen, Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 236, n. 1.</ref> they were connected with the '''Gotamas,''' as is shown by the name '''[[गोतम|Gotama]] [[राहूगण|Rāhūgaṇa]].''' 

राका
<u>'''Rākā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_787> ii. 32, 4;<br> v. 42, 12.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_787> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 8, 1;<br> iii. 4, 9, 1. 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 8;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 37, 2, 6;<br> 47, 4, etc.;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 13, 1. etc.</ref> denotes the full moon day as a personification. ''Cf.'' '''Candramās.'''

राज-कर्तृ
<u>'''Rāja-kartṛ,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_788> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 17, 5.</ref> or '''Rāja-kṛt,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_788> Av. iii. 5, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 7;<br> xiii. 2, 2, 18.</ref> ‘king-maker,’ is the term applied in the Atharvaveda and the Brāhmaṇas to those who, ‘not themselves kings,’<ref name=fx3_ve2_788> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> aid in the consecration of the king. In the Śatapatha<ref name=fx2_ve2_788/> the persons meant and specified are the '''[[सूत|Sūta]],''' ‘charioteer,’ and the '''Grāmaṇī,''' ‘village chief,’ probably a representative chief from the village nearest to the place of consecration, as Eggeling<ref name=fx4_ve2_788> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 60, n.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 199 ''et seq.''</ref> suggests. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_788/> according to the commentator's explanation, the father, brother, etc., are meant; in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_788/> also, the meaning of the expression is not stated in the text.

राज-कुल
<u>'''Rāja-kula,'''</u> a ‘kingly family,’ is mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 28, 4), where, it is to be noted, such a family is ranked after, not before, a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] Kula, a ‘Brahmin family.’<br>==Foot Notes==

राजन्
<u>'''1. Rājan,'''</u> ‘king,’ is a term repeatedly occurring in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_790> iii. 43, 5;<br> v. 54, 7, etc.</ref> and the later literature.<ref name=fx2_ve2_790> Av. iv. 22, 3. 5;<br> viii. 7, 16, etc.</ref> It is quite clear that the normal, though not universal form of government, in early India was that by kings, as might be expected in view of the fact that the Āryan Indians were invaders in a hostile territory: a situation which, as in the case of the Āryan invaders of Greece and of the German invaders of England, resulted almost necessarily in strengthening the monarchic element of the constitution.<ref name=fx3_ve2_790> ''Cf.'' Stubbs, ''Constitutional History of England,'' 59 ''et seq.''</ref> The mere patriarchal organization of society is not sufficient, as Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve2_790> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 162.</ref> assumes, to explain the Vedic kingship. <br><br>''Tenure of Monarchy.''--Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_790> ''Op. cit.,'' 162 ''et seq.'' So Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 188;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 336.</ref> is of opinion that while the Vedic monarchy was sometimes hereditary, as is indeed shown by several cases where the descent can be traced,<ref name=fx6_ve2_790> ''E.g.,'' '''[[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]], Divodāsa, [[पिजवन|Pijavana]], [[सुदास्|Sudās]];<br>''' or '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]], [[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]], [[मित्रातिथि|Mitrātithi]], Kuruśravaṇa [[उपमश्रवस्|Upamaśravas]],''' etc.;<br> Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 386. So a ‘kingdom of ten generations’ ('''[[दशपुरुषंराज्य|Daśapuruṣaṃrājya]]''') is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 9, 3, 3;<br> and ''cf.'' v. 4, 2, 8;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 12. 17.</ref> yet in others the monarchy was elective, though it is not clear whether the selection by the people was between the members of the royal family only or extended to members of all the noble clans. It must, however, be admitted that the evidence for the elective monarchy is not strong. As Geldner<ref name=fx7_ve2_790> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 303.</ref> argues, all the passages cited<ref name=fx8_ve2_790> Rv. x. 124, 8;<br> 173;<br> Av. i. 9;<br> iii. 4;<br> iv. 22.</ref> can be regarded not as choice by the cantons ('''[[विश्|Viś]]'''), but as acceptance by the subjects (''[[विश्|viś]]''): this seems the more probable sense. Of course this is no proof that the monarchy was not sometimes elective: the practice of selecting one member of the family to the exclusion of another less well qualified is exemplified by the legend in [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx9_ve2_790> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 10.</ref> of the Kuru brothers, '''Devāpi''' and '''Śantanu,''' the value of which, as evidence of contemporary views, is not seriously affected by the legend itself being of dubious character and validity.<br><br>Royal power was clearly insecure: there are several references to kings being expelled from their realms, and their efforts to recover their sovereignty,<ref name=fx10_ve2_790> The technical term is ''apa-ruddha. Cf.'' The king is regularly<ref name=fx18_ve2_790> See '''Bali,''' and ''cf.'' Rv. i. 65, 4;<br> Av. iv. 22, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 29;<br> viii. 12. 17;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 12;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 17;<br> iv. 2, 1, 3, 17;<br> v. 3, 3, 12;<br> 4, 2, 3;<br> x. 6, 2, 1;<br> xiii. 2, 9, 6, 8, etc.;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 93, n.;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 246;<br> Pischel and Geldner, ''Vedische Stadien,'' 1, xvi;<br> Winternitz, ''Geschichte der indischen Litteratur,'' 1, 173, 174;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 161. It is to this form of taxation that the share of village (''grāme''), horses (''aśveṣu''), and kine (''goṣu'') of Av. iv. 22, 2, is to be referred. It is significant that the village and cattle are put on the same footing, as tending to refute the argument that the king was supreme landowner. See n. 31 below. For the rate of taxation, which later was one sixth, ''cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 85, 86;<br> ''India, Old and New,'' 238 ''et seq.;<br>'' 333;<br> Mrs. Rhys Davids, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1901, 860.</ref> regarded as ‘devouring  the people,’ but this phrase must not be explained as meaning that he necessarily oppressed them. It is also probable that the king could assign the royal right of maintenance to a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], thus developing a nobility supported by the people. Taxation would not normally fall on [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] or Brahmin; the texts contam emphatic assertions of the exemption of the goods of the latter from the royal bounty.<ref name=fx19_ve2_790> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 6, 2, 18;<br> 7, 1, 13. See also '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]''' (above, 2, 83) for the claim of the Brahmins to serve only king Soma, not the temporal king.</ref>In the people, however, lay the strength of the king.<ref name=fx20_ve2_790> ''Cf., e.g.,'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 8;<br> iii. 11, 8;<br> iv. 4, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 5.</ref> See also '''Bali.'''<br><br>In return the king performed the duties of judge. Himself immune from punishment (''a-daṇḍya''), he wields the rod of punishment ('''[[दण्ड|Daṇḍa]]''').<ref name=fx21_ve2_790> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 7.</ref> It is probable that criminal justice remained largely in his actual administration, for the Sūtras<ref name=fx22_ve2_790> ''E.g.,'' [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 43 ''et seq.''</ref> preserve clear traces of the personal exercise of royal criminal jurisdiction. Possibly the jurisdiction could be exercised by a royal officer, or even by a delegate, for a [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] is mentioned as an overseer (''adhyakṣa'') of the punishment of a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx23_ve2_790> xxvii. 4. ''Cf.'' '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]],''' n. 18.</ref> In civil justice it may be that the king played a much less prominent part, save as a court of final appeal, but evidence is lacking on this head. The '''[[मध्यमशी|Madhyamaśī]]''' of the Rigveda was probably not a royal, but a private judge or arbitrator. A wide criminal jurisdiction is, however, to some extent supported<ref name=fx24_ve2_790> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 25, 13;<br> iv. 4, 3;<br> vi. 67, 5;<br> vii. 61, 3;<br> 87, 3;<br> x. 10, 8 (= Av. xviii. 1, 9);<br> Av. iv. 16, 4.</ref> by the frequent mention of Varuṇa's spies, for Varuṇa is the divine counterpart of the human king.<ref name=fx25_ve2_790> See Foy, ''Die kōnigliche Gewalt,'' 80 ''et seq.''</ref> Possibly such spies could be used in war also.<ref name=fx26_ve2_790> ''Cf.'' Rv. viii. 47, 11;<br> Foy, ''op. cit.,'' 84. The reference is not certain.</ref><br><br>There is no reference in early Vedic literature to the exercise of legislative activitv by the king, though later it is an essential  part of his duties.<ref name=fx27_ve2_790> See Foy, ''op. cit.,'' chap. iii.</ref> Nor can we say exactly what executive functions devolved on the king.<br><br>In all his acts the king was regularly advised by his '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]];''' he also had the advantage of the advice of the royal ministers and attendants (see '''[[रत्निन्|Ratnin]]'''). The local administration was entrusted to the '''Grāmaṇī,''' or village chief, who may have been selected or appointed by the king. The outward signs of the king's rank were his palace<ref name=fx28_ve2_790> ''Cf.'' Varuṇa's palace, Rv. ii. 41, 5;<br> vii. 88, 5. The throne, '''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]],''' is used to form the name of '''Janamejaya's''' royal city, Asandīvant. ''Cf.'' also Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 12, 3-5.</ref> and his brilliant dress.<ref name=fx29_ve2_790> See, ''e.g.,'' Rv. i. 85, 8;<br> viii. 5, 38;<br> x. 78, 1, etc. So the king is the great lord of riches (''[[धन|dhana]]-patir dhanānām''), Av. iv. 22, 3, and in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 31, he is likened to the '''[[न्यग्रोध|Nyagrodha]]''' tree.</ref><br><br>''The King as Landowner.''--The position of the king with regard to the land is somewhat obscure. The Greek notices,<ref name=fx30_ve2_790> See Diodorus, ii. 40;<br> Arrian, ''Indica,'' 11;<br> Strabo, p. 703, and Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 87 ''et seq.''</ref> in which, unhappily, it would be dangerous to put much trust, since they were collected by observers who were probably little used to accurate investigations of such matters, and whose statements were based on inadequate information, vary in their statements. In part they speak of rent being paid, and declare that only the king and no private person could own land, while in part they refer to the taxation of land. Hopkins<ref name=fx31_ve2_790> ''India, Old and New,'' 221 ''et seq.''</ref> is strongly of opinion that the payments made were paid for protection-''i.e.,'' in modern terminology as a tax, but that the king was recognized as the owner of all the land, while yet the individual or the joint family also owned the land. As against BadenPowell,<ref name=fx32_ve2_790> ''Village Communities in India,'' 145;<br> ''Indian Village Community,'' 207 ''et seq.''</ref> who asserted that the idea of the king as a landowner was later, he urges for the Vedic period that the king, as we have seen, is described as devouring the people, and that, according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx33_ve2_790> vii. 29, 3.</ref> the '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]''' can be devoured at will and maltreated (but, unlike the '''[[शूद्र|Śūdra]],''' not killed); and for the period of the legal Sūtras and Śāstras he cites [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]] and [[नारद|Nārada]] as clearly recognizing the king's overlordship, besides a passage of the [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra<ref name=fx34_ve2_790> viii. 39.</ref> which describes the king as ‘lord of all,’ a phrase which  Bühler<ref name=fx35_ve2_790> In his note on Manu, ''loc. cit., Sacred Books of the East,'' 25, 259.</ref> was inclined to interpret as a proof of landowning. The evidence is, however, inadequate to prove what is sought. It is not denied that gradually the king came to be vaguely conceived--as the English king still is--as lord of all the land in a proprietorial sense, but it is far more probable that such an idea was only a gradual development than that it was primitive. The power of devouring the people is a political power, not a right of ownership; precisely the same feature can be traced in South Africa,<ref name=fx36_ve2_790> See Keith, ''Journal of the African Society,'' 6, 202 ''et seq.'' The evidence, so far as it goes, of other Āryan peoples does not support the theory of original kingly ownership. Such ownership did not exist, as far as can be seen, in Anglo-Saxon times (''English Historical Review,'' viii. 1-7). nor in Homeric Greece (Lang, ''Homer and His Age,'' 236 ''et seq.''), nor at Rome.</ref> where the chief can deprive a man arbitrarily of his land, though the land is really owned by the native. The matter is ultimately to some extent one of terminology, but the parallel cases are in favour of distinguishing between the political rights of the crown, which can be transferred by way of a grant, and the rights of ownership. Hopkins<ref name=fx37_ve2_790> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> thinks that the gifts of land to priests, which seems to be the first sign of land transactions in the Brāhmaṇas, was an actual gift of land; it may have been so in many cases, but it may easily also have been the grant of a superiority: the Epic grants are hardly decisive one way or the other.<br><br>For the relations of the king with the assembly, see '''[[सभा|Sabhā]];''' for his consecration, see '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]].''' A-rāja-tā, ‘lack of a king,’ means ‘anarchy.’<ref name=fx38_ve2_790> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 9, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 14, 6;<br> Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 74.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 162 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 84 ''et seq.;<br>'' Foy, ''Die ko7nigliche Gewalt nach den Dharmasūtren'' (Leipzig, 1895);<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 46 ''et seq.;<br> Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1901, 860, 861.</ref>

राजनि
<u>'''Rājani,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Rajana,'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[उग्रदेव|Ugradeva]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 3, 17; xxiii. 16, 11) and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (v. 4. 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

राजन्य
<u>'''Rājanya'''</u> is the regular term in Vedic literature<ref name=fx1_ve2_793> Only once in the Rv. in the late [[पुरुष|Puruṣa]]-[[सूक्त|sūkta]], x. 90, 12;<br> but often in the Av.: v. 17, 9;<br> 18, 2;<br> vi. 38, 4;<br> x. 10, 18;<br> xii. 4, 32 ''et seq.;<br>'' xv. 8, 1;<br> xix. 32, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 13, 1;<br> 5, 4, 4;<br> 10, 1;<br> v. 1, 10, 3, etc. Even in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], where, on the whole, the later use of [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] prevails, the [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] is often mentioned. See Eggeling's index, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 561.</ref> for a man of the royal family, probably including also those who were not actually members of that family, but were nobles, though it may have been originally restricted to members of the royal family. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_793> ''Cf.'' xiii. 4, 2, 17, with xiii. 1, 6, 2.</ref> the [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] is different from the [[राजपुत्र|Rājaputra]], who is literally a son of the king. The functions and place of the [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] are described under '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]],''' which expression later normally takes the place of [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] as a designation for the ruling class. His high place is shown by the fact that in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_793> ii. 5, 4, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 258 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 191. It is quite likely that the noble families not related to the royal family were families of minor princes whose rule was merged in that of the king on the formation of a powerful tribe, as was the case in Germany.</ref> he is ranked with the learned Brahmin and the  '''Grāmaṇī''' (who was a '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]''') as having reached the height of prosperity (''gata-[[श्री|śrī]]'').

राजन्य-बन्धु
<u>'''Rājanya-bandhu'''</u> denotes a [[राजन्य|Rājanya]], but usually with a depreciating sense. Thus in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_794> xi. 6, 2, 5.</ref> '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' is called by the Brahmins, whom he defeated in disputation, ‘a fellow of a Rājanya’; the same description is applied to '''[[प्रवाहण जैवलि|Pravāhaṇa Jaivali]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_794> vi. 1, 5.</ref> for a similar reason. On the other hand, in one passage<ref name=fx3_ve2_794> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 5, 2. 10, where ''cf.'' Eggeling's note, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 370, n. 1. A similar case is apparently i. 2, 4, 2, where any special contempt cannot be meant.</ref> where reference is made to men eating apart from women, princes are said to do so most of all: the term [[राजन्यबन्धु|Rājanyabandhu]] cannot here be deemed to be contemptuous, unless, indeed, it is the expression of Brahmin contempt for princes, such as clearly appears in the treatment of '''[[नग्नजित्|Nagnajit]]''' in another passage.<ref name=fx4_ve2_794> viii. 1, 4, 10. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 515.</ref> Again, in a passage<ref name=fx5_ve2_794> i. 1, 4, 12.</ref> in which the four castes are mentioned, the '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]''' precedes the [[राजन्यबन्धु|Rājanyabandhu]], a curious inversion of the order of the second and third castes.<ref name=fx6_ve2_794> Eggeling, ''op. cit.,'' 12, 28.</ref>

राजन्य-र्षि
<u>'''Rājanya-rṣi,'''</u> ‘royal sage,’ is a term applied to '''[[सिन्धुक्षित्|Sindhukṣit]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_795> xii. 12, 6. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 235, n. 3, and see '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''' (p. 261).</ref> The story about him is, however, purely mythical.

राज-पति
<u>'''Rāja-pati,'''</u> ‘lord of kings,’ is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 4, 3, 9) as an epithet of Soma. It is not used elsewhere as a title of imperial temporal supremacy: see '''[[राज्य|Rājya]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

राज-पितृ
<u>'''Rāja-pitṛ'''</u> is one of the titles given to the king in the rite of the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]]''' (‘royal consecration’) according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 12, 5; 17, 5). It probably designates the king as ‘father of a king,’ and indicates the hereditary character of the monarchy. Possibly the later plan<ref name=fx1_ve2_797> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 139. The sense of ‘having a king as father’ is also possible.</ref> of associating the king's son in the monarchy prevailed in earlier times also.

राज-पुत्र
<u>'''Rāja-putra,'''</u> ‘king's son,’ ‘prince,’ seems to be capable of being interpreted literally in every passage of the older literature<ref name=fx1_ve2_798> Rv. x. 40, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17, 6 (of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],''' but probably in a mythical sense);<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xix. 1, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 5, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 2, 5;<br> 5, 2, 5, etc.</ref> in which it is found, though it may also be capable of a wider interpretation.<ref name=fx2_ve2_798> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 1, may be cited as identifying the '''[[राजन्य|Rājanya]]''' and the [[राजपुत्र|Rājaputra]].</ref> Later the [[राजपुत्र|Rājaputra]] degenerates into a mere ‘landowner.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_798> Jolly, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 514, who points out that in the Rājataraṅgiṇī, vii. 360, traces of the older position of the [[राजपुत्र|Rājaputra]] are seen.</ref>

राज-पुरुष
<u>'''Rāja-puruṣa'''</u> denotes a ‘royal servant’ in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (ii. 3). ''Cf.'' '''[[पूरुष|Pūruṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

राज-भ्रातृ
<u>'''Rāja-bhrātṛ,'''</u> the ‘brother of the king,’ is mentioned as one of the eight '''Vīras,''' or supporters of the monarchy, in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_800> xix. 1, 4. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 30, n. 2.</ref> He is also alluded to elsewhere.<ref name=fx2_ve2_800> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 13, 18, etc.</ref>

राज-मात्र
<u>'''Rāja-mātra'''</u> is found in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxvii. 6) and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xvii. 5, 3. 4; 15, 3), where it seems to include ‘the whole class of persons (who could be called) Rājan’--''i.e.,'' the '''Rājaputras''' and the '''Rājanyas.''' <br>==Foot Notes==

राज-यक्ष्म
<u>'''Rāja-yakṣma,'''</u> ‘royal sickness,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_802> i. 161, 1.</ref> and several times later on.<ref name=fx2_ve2_802> Av. xi. 3, 39;<br> xii. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 5, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 3;<br> xxvii. 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 7.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_802> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 375 ''et seq.''</ref> identifies it with consumption: this identification seems certain, being supported by the later view of the disease.<ref name=fx4_ve2_802> ''Cf.'' Wise, ''System of Hindu Medicine,'' 321 ''et seq.;<br>'' Jolly, ''Medicin,'' 88, 89, n. 2, who takes [[राजयक्ष्म|Rājayakṣma]] as denoting the worst of diseases, not the disease cured by the king. ''Cf.'' '''[[राजाश्व|Rājāśva]].'''</ref> Bloomfield<ref name=fx5_ve2_802> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 697. But contrast ''ibid.,'' 415.</ref> suggests ‘king's evil,’ or syphilis, as the sense, but this is not probable.

राज-सूय
<u>'''Rāja-sūya'''</u> is the name in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_803> iv. 8, 1;<br> xi. 7, 7.</ref> and the later literature<ref name=fx2_ve2_803> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 2, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 15, 8;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 1, 12, etc.</ref> of the ceremony of the ‘royal consecration.’ The rite is described at great length in the Sūtras,<ref name=fx3_ve2_803> See Weber, ''Über die Ko7nigsweihe, den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]];<br>'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 144-147;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 472, 491. The relation of the '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' episode formed part of the ritual. That this points to human sacrifice having once formed part of the ritual of the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] as supposed by Hillebrandt, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Weber, 47;<br> and Oldenberg, 366, n. 1, seems very doubtful. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 844, 845.</ref> but its main features are clearly outlined in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx4_ve2_803> Especially Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 3, 1 ''et seq.'' See also Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 1, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> while the verses used in the ceremony are preserved in the Saṃhitās of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx5_ve2_803> See [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x.</ref> Besides much mere priestly elaboration, the ritual contains traces of popular ceremonial. For example, the king is clothed in the ceremonial garments of his rank, and provided with bow and arrow as emblems of sovereignty. He is formally anointed; he performs a mimic cow raid against a relative of his;<ref name=fx6_ve2_803> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 3, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> or engages in a sham fight with a '''[[राजन्य|Rājanya]].'''<ref name=fx7_ve2_803> ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 15 with commentary;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 100, n. 1.</ref> A game of dice is played in which he is made to be the victim;<ref name=fx8_ve2_803> See 2. '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]''' (p. 3)</ref> he symbolically ascends the quarters of the sky as an indication of his universal rule; and steps on a tiger skin, thus gaining the strength and the pre-eminence of the tiger. <br><br>A list of the consecrated kings is given in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx9_ve2_803> viii. 21-23. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 8.</ref> where the royal inauguration is called the ‘great unction’ (''[[महाभिषेक|mahābhiṣeka]]'') connected with Indra. It corresponds generally with a list of Aśvamedhins, ‘performers of the horse sacrifice,’ given in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx10_ve2_803> xiii. 5, 4.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx11_ve2_803> xvi. 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, xxiv, xxv.</ref>

राज-स्तम्बायन
<u>'''Rāja-stambāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Rājastamba,’ is the patronymic of '''Yajñavacas''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_804> x. 4, 2, 1 (oxytone), 6, 5, 9 (proparoxytone). No stress need be laid on the accents of the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].</ref>

राजाधिराज
<u>'''Rājādhirāja,'''</u> ‘king of kings,’ later a title of paramount sovereignty, is only found in Vedic literature in the late [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (i. 31, 6) as a divine epithet.<br>==Foot Notes==

राजाश्व
<u>'''Rājāśva'''</u> (‘king's horse’) in the Atharvaveda (vi. 102, 2) seems merely to denote a powerful horse.<br>==Foot Notes==

राज्ञी
<u>'''Rājñī,'''</u> ‘queen,’ is found in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_807> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 6, 2;<br> 4, 2, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 8, 3, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 3, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 13;<br> xv. 10.</ref> and in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_807> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 6, 2;<br> iii. 11, 3, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 23, 2, etc.</ref>

राज्य
<u>'''Rājya'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_808> iii. 4, 2;<br> iv. 8, 1;<br> xi. 6, 15;<br> xii. 3, 31;<br> xviii. 4, 31.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_808> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3, 4;<br> 6, 6, 5;<br> vii. 5, 8, 3, etc.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 23, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 5, as emended by Roth, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, ccxliii.</ref> regularly denotes ‘sovereign power,’ from which, as the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_808> v. 1, 1, 12.</ref> notes, the Brahmin is excluded.<br><br>In addition to [[राज्य|Rājya]], the texts give other expressions of sovereign power. Thus the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_808> v. 1, 1, 3.</ref> contends  that the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] sacrifice is that of a king, the '''[[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]]''' that of a [[सम्राज्|Samrāj]] or emperor, the status of the latter ([[साम्राज्य|Sāmrājya]]) being superior to that of the former ([[राज्य|Rājya]]). The sitting on a throne ('''[[आसन्दी|Āsandī]]''') is given in the same text<ref name=fx5_ve2_808> xii. 8, 3, 4.</ref> as one of the characteristics of the [[सम्राज्|Samrāj]]. Elsewhere<ref name=fx6_ve2_808> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 11, 5. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 2, 2.</ref> [[स्वाराज्य|Svārājya]], ‘uncontrolled dominion,’ is opposed to [[राज्य|Rājya]]. In the ritual of the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]]''' the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve2_808> viii. 12, 4. 5. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 16, 3.</ref> gives a whole series of terms: [[राज्य|Rājya]], [[साम्राज्य|Sāmrājya]], [[भौज्य|Bhaujya]], [[स्वाराज्य|Svārājya]], [[वैराज्य|Vairājya]], Pārameṣṭhya, and [[माहाराज्य|Māhārājya]], while Ādhipatya, ‘supreme power,’ is found elsewhere.<ref name=fx8_ve2_808> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 3, 35;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 2, 6.</ref> But there is no reason to believe that these terms refer to essentially different forms of authority. A king might be called a '''[[महाराज|Mahārāja]]''' or a '''[[सम्राज्|Samrāj]],''' without really being an overlord of kings; he would be so termed if he were an important sovereign, or by his own entourage out of compliment, as was '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' of '''[[विदेह|Videha]].'''<ref name=fx9_ve2_808> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 1, 2. 6;<br> 2, 2, 3, etc.</ref> That a really great monarchy of the Aśoka or [[गुप्त|Gupta]] type ever existed in the Vedic period seems highly improbable.<ref name=fx10_ve2_808> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 30.</ref>

रात्री
<u>'''Rātrī'''</u> is the most usual word in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_809> i. 35, 1;<br> 94, 7;<br> 113, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_809> Av. i. 16, 1;<br> v. 5, 1, etc.</ref> for ‘night.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

राथीतर
<u>'''Rāthītara,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[रथीतर|Rathītara]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[सत्यवचस्|Satyavacas]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 9, 1), and occurs several times as the name of a teacher in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (vii. 4, etc.).<br>==Foot Notes==

राथीतरी-पुत्र
<u>'''Rāthītarī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of [[रथीतर|Rathītara]],’ is the name of a teacher in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], the pupil of '''[[भालुकी-पुत्र|Bhālukī-putra]],''' according to the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension (vi. 5, 1), of the '''Krauñcikīputras''' according to the Mādhyaṃdina (vi. 4, 32). <br>==Foot Notes==

राध गौतम
<u>'''Rādha Gautama'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[गोतम|Gotama]]'''’) is the name of two teachers in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_812> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373, 384.</ref>

राधेय
<u>'''Rādheya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Rādhā,’ is the metronymic of a teacher in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (vii. 6).<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 372.<br>==Foot Notes==

राम
<u>'''1. Rāma'''</u> is the name of a man in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_814> x. 93, 14.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_814> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166.</ref> thinks that he bore the patronymic '''[[मायव|Māyava]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_814> Rv. x. 93, 15.</ref> but this is doubtful.

राम औप-तस्विनि
<u>'''2. Rāma Aupa-tasvini'''</u> (‘descendant of Upatasvina’) is the name of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iv. 6, 1, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

राम क्रातु-जातेय
<u>'''3. Rāma Krātu-jāteya'''</u> (‘descendant of Kratu-jāta’) '''[[वैयाघ्र-पद्य|Vaiyāghra-padya]]''' (‘descendant of Vyāghrapad’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[शङ्ग शाट्यायनि|Śaṅga Śāṭyāyani]] [[आत्रेय|Ātreya]],''' who is mentioned in two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 1; iv. 16, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

राम मार्ग-वेय
<u>'''4. Rāma Mārga-veya'''</u> is the name of a man of the priestly family of the '''Śyāparṇas''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_817> vii. 27, 3. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 345, n.;<br> '''Muir''' ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 438.</ref>

रामकायन
<u>'''Rāmakāyana.'''</u> See '''[[बस्त|Basta]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रामा
<u>'''Rāmā'''</u> in a few passages<ref name=fx1_ve2_819> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 8, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 8, 13;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 7. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 74, 84.</ref> seems to have the sense of a ‘hetaera.’

रायो-वाज
<u>'''Rāyo-vāja'''</u> is the name of a seer of Sāmans or chants in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 1, 4; xiii. 4, 17; ''cf.'' xxiv. 1, 7). <br>==Foot Notes==

राष्ट्र
<u>'''Rāṣṭra'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_821> iv. 42, 1;<br> vii. 34, 11;<br> 84, 2;<br> x. 109, 3;<br> 124, 4, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_821> Av. x. 3, 12;<br> xii. 1, 8;<br> xiii. 1, 35;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 23;<br> xx. 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 10, 3;<br> iii. 5, 7, 3;<br> v. 7, 4, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 13, etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 7;<br> 7, 4;<br> 8, 6;<br> iv. 6, 3.</ref> denotes ‘kingdom’ or ‘royal territory.’

राष्ट्र-गोप
<u>'''Rāṣṭra-gopa,'''</u> ‘protector of the realm,’ is the epithet applied, in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 25), to the '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]],''' whose special charge it was to preserve the king and realm from harm by his spells and rites.<br>==Foot Notes==

रासभ
<u>'''Rāsabha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_823> i. 34, 9;<br> 116, 2;<br> 162, 21;<br> iii. 53, 5;<br> viii. 85, 7.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_823> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 5, 7;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 1 11;<br> 3, 1, 23;<br> 2, 3;<br> 4, 4, 3, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 233;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 149, who suggests ‘mule’ as a possible sense in Rv. iii. 53, 5.</ref> denotes an ‘ass.’

रास्ना
<u>'''Rāsnā'''</u> in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_824> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 30;<br> xi. 59;<br> xxxviii. 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 1, 2, 2;<br> iv. 1, 5, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, i. 2;<br> xvi. 5;<br> xix. 6, etc.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] denotes ‘girdle’ or ‘band,’ like '''[[रशना|Raśanā]]''' and '''[[रश्मि|Raśmi]].'''<br><br>vi. 2, 2, 25; 5, 2, 11, 13. ''Cf. rāsnāva,'' ‘girdled,’ iv. 1, 5, 19.

राहु
<u>'''Rāhu,'''</u> the demon that eclipses the sun, seems to be referred to in one passage of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_825> xix. 9, 10. ''Cf.'' [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 100;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 87;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 914.</ref> The reading here is somewhat uncertain, but [[राहु|Rāhu]] is probably meant.

राहू-गण
<u>'''Rāhū-gaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[रहू-गण|Rahū-gaṇa]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[गोतम|Gotama]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_826> 1. 4, 1, 10. 18;<br> xi. 4, 3, 20. ''Cf.'' also Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 81, 3;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 151, 152;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 8.</ref> 

रिक्थ
<u>'''Riktha'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_827> iii. 31, 2, on which ''cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 5;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 49, 50;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 239 ''et seq.''</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_827> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 18, 9 (of '''Śunaḥśepa's''' double inheritance, which, according to that text, is the learning of the '''Gāthins''' and the sovereignty of the '''Jahnus;<br>''' but see Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 16, who thinks the real succession was to the two houses, the '''[[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]]''' and the '''[[कुशिक|Kuśika]]''').</ref> denoting ‘inheritance.’<ref name=fx1_ve2_827/>

रिपु
<u>'''Ripu'''</u> is a common word for ‘foe,’ ‘enemy,’ in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_828> i. 36, 16;<br> 147, 3;<br> 148, 5;<br> ii. 23, 16;<br> 27, 16;<br> 34, 9, etc.</ref> It occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_828> xix. 49, 9.</ref> also.

रुक्म
<u>'''Rukma'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_829> i. 166, 10;<br> iv. 10, 5;<br> v. 53, 4;<br> 56, 1, etc. So ''[[रुक्म|rukma]]-vakṣas,'' ‘wearing golden ornaments on the breast,’ ii. 34, 2. 8;<br> v. 55, 1;<br> 57, 5, etc.;<br> ''rukmin,'' i. 66, 6;<br> ix. 15, 5. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 2, 3;<br> v. 1, 10, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 40, etc.</ref> denotes an ornament, probably of gold, usually worn on the breast. Being in several passages used of the sun, it probably had the form of a disk. In the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_829> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 1, 20;<br> v. 2, 1, 21;<br> 4, 1, 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 3;<br> 9, 1, etc. So ''rukmin'' in Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 260, 263;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 160, who suggests as a possible sense ‘gold coin’;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the;<br> East,'' 32, 112, 299.</ref> it designates a gold plate. See also '''[[रजत|Rajata]].'''

रुक्म-पाश
<u>'''Rukma-pāśa'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_830> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 7, 1, 7. 27;<br> 3, 8;<br> vii. 2, 1, 15, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘cord’ on which ‘the gold plate’ is hung.

रुद्र-ब्नुति द्राह्यायण
<u>'''Rudra-bnuti Drāhyāyaṇa'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Trāta''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_831> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

रुम
<u>'''Ruma'''</u> is mentioned in one hymn of the Rigveda (viii. 4, 2) with '''[[रुशम|Ruśama]], [[श्यावक|Śyāvaka]],''' and '''[[कृप|Kṛpa]]''' as a favourite of Indra. <br>==Foot Notes==

रुरु
<u>'''Ruru'''</u> is one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_833> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 19, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 27. 39;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14. 9.</ref> A kind of deer is meant. The Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_833> vi. 75, 15.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83.</ref> mentions ‘deer-headed’ (''ruru-śīrṣan'') arrows, meaning such as have points made of deer's horn.

रुशम
<u>'''Ruśama'''</u> is mentioned three times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_834> viii. 3, 13;<br> 4, 2;<br> 51, 9.</ref> as a protégé of Indra. The Ruśamas occur in another passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_834> v. 30, 12-15.</ref> with their generous king '''[[ऋणंचय|Ṛṇaṃcaya]];''' they are also referred to, with their king '''[[कौरम|Kaurama]],''' in a passage of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_834> xx. 127, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 129;<br> Ludwig. Translation of the Rigveda. 3, 154;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 409;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 214;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 690.</ref>

रुशमा
<u>'''Ruśamā'''</u> is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 13, 3), where she is said to have run round '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' and so to have defeated Indra, who understood her challenge to refer to the earth proper. The story indicates the connexion of the Ruśamas with the '''Kurus.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रुषती
<u>'''Ruṣatī'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_836> i. 117, 8.</ref> denotes, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve2_836> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 150.</ref> a maiden who was married to '''[[श्याव|Śyāva]].''' On the other hand, Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_836> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. ruśant.''</ref> treats the word as ''ruśatī,'' ‘white,’ and ''ruśatīm'' seems clearly to be the reading of the text. It is doubtful what the meaning is, and whether [[श्याव|Śyāva]] is a proper name at all.<ref name=fx4_ve2_836> ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 110, who suggests that Kṣoṇa may be a man's name.</ref>

रेक्णस्
<u>'''Rekṇas'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_837> i. 31, 14;<br> 121, 5;<br> 158, 1;<br> 162, 2;<br> vi. 20, 7;<br> vii. 4, 7;<br> 40, 2, etc.</ref> denotes ‘inherited property,’ and then ‘property’ in general. 

रेणु
<u>'''Reṇu'''</u> is the name of a son of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 17, 7) and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xv. 26, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

रेभ
<u>'''1. Rebha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_839> i. 127, 10;<br> vi. 3, 6;<br> 11, 3;<br> vii. 63, 3;<br> viii. 97, 11;<br> ix. 7, 6, etc. ''Cf.'' Av. xx. 127, 4.</ref> denotes a ‘singer’ of praise, a ‘panegyrist.’

रेभ
<u>'''2. Rebha'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_840> i. 112, 5;<br> 116, 24;<br> 117, 4;<br> 118, 6;<br> 119, 6;<br> x. 39, 9.</ref> as the name of a protégé of the Aśvins, who saved him from the waters and from imprisonment.<ref name=fx1_ve2_840/>

रेवा
<u>'''Revā,'''</u> a name of the Narmadā (Nerbudda) river, otherwise occurring only in post-Vedic literature, is seen by Weber<ref name=fx1_ve2_841> ''Indian Literature,'' 123 (‘a native of the country south of the Revā’). ''Cf. Indian Antiquary,'' 30, 273, n. 17.</ref> in the word '''[[रेवोत्तरस्|Revottaras]],''' which is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_841> xii. 8, 1, 17;<br> 9, 3, 1.</ref> and is certainly a man's name.

रेवती
<u>'''Revatī.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रेवोत्तरस्
<u>'''Revottaras'''</u> is the name of '''[[पाटव|Pāṭava]] [[चाक्र|Cākra]] [[स्थपति|Sthapati]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_843> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 9, 3, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' xii. 8, 1, 17.</ref> who was expelled, with '''[[दुष्टरीतु|Duṣṭarītu]] [[पौंसायन|Pauṃsāyana]],''' by the '''Sṛnjayas,''' and who was in part instrumental in the restoration of his master to power, despite the opposition of '''[[बल्हिक प्रातिपीय|Balhika Prātipīya]],''' the '''Kuru''' king.

रेष्मन्
<u>'''Reṣman'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (vi. 102, 2; xv. 2, 1), the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iii. 15, 2), and the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxv. 2) denotes a ‘whirlwind.’<br>==Foot Notes==

रैक्व
<u>'''Raikva'''</u> is the name of a man who is mentioned several times in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 1, 3. 5. 8; 2, 2. 4). <br>==Foot Notes==

रैक्व-पर्ण
<u>'''Raikva-parṇa,'''</u> masc. plur., is the name of a locality in the '''[[महावृष|Mahāvṛṣa]]''' country according to the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_846> iv. 2, 5. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 130.</ref>

रैभी
<u>'''Raibhī,'''</u> fem. plur., occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_847> x. 85, 6.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_847> vii. 5, 11, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]], [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], v. 2.</ref> together with '''[[गाथा|Gāthā]]''' and '''[[नाराशंसी|Nārāśaṃsī]],''' as a form of literature. Later on<ref name=fx3_ve2_847> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 32, 1;<br> Kanṣītaki [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5, etc.</ref> the [[रैभी|Raibhī]] verses are identified with certain verses of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx4_ve2_847> xx. 127, 4-6 = [[खिल|Khila]], v. 9.</ref> but that this identification holds<ref name=fx5_ve2_847> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 689.</ref> in the Rigveda and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā seems very doubtful.<ref name=fx6_ve2_847> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 238.</ref>

रैभ्य
<u>'''Raibhya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[रेभ|Rebha]],'''’ is the name of a teacher in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26), where he is said to be a pupil of '''[[पौतिमाष्यायण|Pautimāṣyāyaṇa]]''' and '''[[कौण्डिन्यायन|Kauṇḍinyāyana]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रोग
<u>'''Roga'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_849> i. 2, 4;<br> ii. 3, 3;<br> iii. 28, 5;<br> vi. 44, 1;<br> 120, 3;<br> of the head (''[[शीर्षण्य|śīrṣaṇya]]''), ix. 8. 1. 21 ''et seq.''</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_849> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 26, 2.</ref> denotes ‘disease’ generally.

रोपणाका
<u>'''Ropaṇākā'''</u> is the name of a bird mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_850> i. 50, 12.</ref> and the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_850> i. 22, 4. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 6, 22.</ref> The ‘thrush’ seems to be meant;<ref name=fx3_ve2_850> ''Śārikā,'' Sāyaṇa on Rv., ''loc. cit.'' On Av. i. 22, 4, he explains it as ''kāṣṭhaśuka,'' perhaps a kind of parrot.</ref> but Keśava, the commentator on the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_850> xxvi. 20.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 92;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 266;<br> Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 76, n. 13;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 23.</ref> is inclined to understand the word to mean a sort of wood. 

रोमशा
<u>'''Romaśā'''</u> is mentioned in the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx1_ve2_851> iii. 156 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> as the wife of king '''[[भावयव्य|Bhāvayavya]],''' and is credited with the authorship of a Rigvedic verse.<ref name=fx2_ve2_851> i. 126, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 128.</ref> But in reality the word ''[[रोमशा|romaśā]]'' in that verse, which is the source of the legend, is merely an adjective meaning ‘hairy.’

रोहिणी
<u>'''1. Rohiṇī'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_852> viii. 93, 13;<br> 101, 13 (reading ''rohiṇyāḥ'' with Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'').</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_852> Av. xiii. 1, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 6, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 2, 6;<br> iv. 5, 8, 2, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘red cow.’

रोहिणी
<u>'''2. Rohiṇī.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रोहित्
<u>'''Rohit'''</u> in some passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_854> i. 14, 12;<br> 100, 16;<br> v. 56, 5;<br> vii. 42, 2.</ref> denotes, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, a ‘red mare,’ while later<ref name=fx2_ve2_854> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 6, 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 11, 18;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30. 37;<br> Av. iv. 4, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 33, 1 (''cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 178, n.).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 82.</ref> it denotes a ‘red doe.’

रोहित
<u>'''1. Rohita'''</u> denotes a ‘red horse’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_855> i. 94, 10;<br> 134, 9;<br> ii. 10, 2;<br> iii. 6, 6, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_855> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 4, 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 3, 12, etc. So [[रोहित|Rohita]] in Av. xiii. 1, 1 ''et seq.,'' represents the sun as a ‘red horse.’</ref>

रोहित
<u>'''2. Rohita'''</u> is a son of '''Hariścandra''' in the famous tale of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 14) and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xv. 18, 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

रोहितक
<u>'''Rohitaka'''</u> occurs in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (iii. 9, 3) with a variant [[रोहीतक|Rohītaka]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_857> So Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 5, 8.</ref> as the name of the tree ''Andersonia [[रोहितक|Rohitaka]].''

रोहितक-कूल
<u>'''Rohitaka-kūla'''</u> is in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_858> xiv. 3, 12. ''Cf.'' xv. 11, 6;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vi. 11, 4.</ref> the name of a locality after which a Sāman or chant was called. 

रोहीतक
<u>'''Rohītaka.'''</u> See '''[[रोहितक|Rohitaka]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

रौहिण
<u>'''1. Rauhiṇa'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_860> i. 103, 2;<br> ii. 12, 12.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_860> xx. 128, 13.</ref> as a demon foe of Indra's. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx3_ve2_860> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 207.</ref> is inclined to see in the word the name of a planet (''cf.'' '''[[रोहिणी|Rohiṇī]]'''), but without any clear reason.

रौहिण
<u>'''2. Rauhiṇa'''</u> (‘born under the [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] Rohiṇī’) '''[[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]'''’), is the name of a man in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (i. 12, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

रौहिणायन
<u>'''Rauhiṇāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[रौहिण|Rauhiṇa]]'''’) is the patronymic of '''Priyavrata''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 3, 5, 14). It is also in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26) the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[शौनक|Śaunaka]]''' and others.<br>==Foot Notes==

लक्ष
<u>'''Lakṣa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_863> ii. 12, 4. ''Cf.'' Lüders, ''Das Würfelspiel im alten Indien,'' 4, n. 1;<br> Zimmer. ''Altindisches Leben,'' 287.</ref> denotes the ‘prize’ at dicing.

लक्षण
<u>'''Lakṣaṇa'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_864> Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 6, 5. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 10;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 35;<br> 13, 466.</ref> or '''[[लक्ष्मन्|Lakṣman]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_864> Av. vi. 141, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 9.</ref> denotes the ‘mark’ made on cattle by branding to distinguish ownership. According to the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx3_ve2_864> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> it was to be made under the '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] [[रेवती|Revatī]],''' clearly because of the property indicated in the name (‘wealthy’) of that [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]. See '''[[अष्टकर्णी|Aṣṭakarṇī]].''' 

लक्ष्मण्य
<u>'''Lakṣmaṇya'''</u> in one verse of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_865> v. 33, 10. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155.</ref> seems to be a patronymic of '''[[ध्वन्य|Dhvanya]],''' ‘son of Lakṣmaṇa.’

लक्ष्मन्
<u>'''Lakṣman.'''</u> See '''[[लक्षण|Lakṣaṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

लब
