<u>'''Laba,'''</u> ‘quail’ (''Perdix chinensis'') is one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_867> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 24. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 2, where Rv. x. 119 is called the Labasūkta;<br> the Anukramaṇī (Index), too, gives Aindra Laba as the author of that hymn. ''Cf.'' Bṛhaddevatā, viii. 40, with Macdonell's note. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 90.</ref>

लम्बन
<u>'''Lambana'''</u> is the reading in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension (v. 10, 1) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] for '''[[आडम्बर|Āḍambara]],''' ‘drum,’ in the Mādhyaṃdina recension (v. 12, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

लवण
<u>'''Lavaṇa,'''</u> ‘salt,’ is never mentioned in the Rigveda, only once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_869> vii. 76, 1.</ref> and not after that until the latest part of the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx2_ve2_869> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 7 = Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 17, 3. ''Cf.'' also Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 13, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 12;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 1, 16;<br> and see Strabo, xv. 1, 30.</ref> where it is regarded as of extremely high value.<ref name=fx3_ve2_869> It seems to be placed above gold in value in Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 7.</ref> This silence in the early period is somewhat surprising if the regions then occupied by the Indians were the Panjab and the Indus valley, where salt abounds; it would at first sight seem less curious if the home of the early Vedic Indian is taken to be '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_869> ''Cf.'' Map 19 in the Atlas of the ''Imperial Gazetteer of India,'' vol. 26, and see Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 21 ''et seq.;<br> India, Old and New,'' 30 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 54, 55;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 318;<br> Geiger, ''Ostiranische Kultur,'' 419;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 150.</ref> It is, however, quite conceivable that a necessary commodity might happen to be passed over without literary mention in a region where it is very common, but to be referred to in a locality where it is not found, and consequently becomes highly prized. 

लवन
<u>'''Lavana'''</u> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (ii. 2) denotes the ‘mowing’ or ‘reaping’ of corn.<br>==Foot Notes==

लाक्षा
<u>'''Lākṣā'''</u> occurs once in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_871> v. 5, 7. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 229;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 387, 421.</ref> as the name of a plant.

लाङ्गल
<u>'''Lāṅgala'''</u> is the regular word for ‘plough’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_872> iv. 57, 4.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_872> Av. ii. 8, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6, 7, 4;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 26, etc.;<br> ''lāṅgaleṣā,'' Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 4, 7.</ref> It is described in a series of passages<ref name=fx3_ve2_872> Av. iii. 17, 3 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 5, 6 = [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 11 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 12 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 71 = [[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 34. 35.</ref> as ‘lancepointed’ (''pavīravat'' or ''pavīravam''), ‘well-lying’ (''susīmam''),<ref name=fx4_ve2_872> The texts have ''suśevam;<br>'' Roth conjectures ''susīmam.'' See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 116.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236.</ref> and ‘having a well-smoothed handle’ (see '''[[त्सरु|Tsaru]]'''). See also '''[[सीर|Sīra]].'''

लाङ्गलायन
<u>'''Lāṅgalāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[लाङ्गल|Lāṅgala]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] [[मौद्गल्य|Maudgalya]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[मुद्गल|Mudgala]]'''’) in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 3, 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

लाज
<u>'''Lāja,'''</u> masc. plur., in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_874> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 2, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 13. 81;<br> xxi. 42, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_874> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 2, 7. 10;<br> 9, 1, 2;<br> xiii. 2, 1, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 269.</ref> denotes ‘fried or parched grain.’

लाजि
<u>'''Lāji'''</u> in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxiii. 8) and the Taittīrīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 9, 4, 8) is a word of uncertain meaning; according to Sāyaṇa, it is a vocative of Lājin, ‘having parched grain’; according to Mahīdhara, it denotes a ‘quantity of parched grain.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

लातव्य
<u>'''Lātavya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Latu,’ is the patronymic of '''Kūśāmba [[स्वायव|Svāyava]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_876> viii. 6, 8. ''Cf.'' Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 7;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 25 (a [[गोत्र|Gotra]] is there mentioned).</ref>

लामकायन
<u>'''Lāmakāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Lamaka,’ is often mentioned as an authority in the Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_877> iv. 9, 22;<br> vi. 9, 18, etc.;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 49.</ref> the [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_877> iii. 12. 13;<br> vii. 4, 8, etc.;<br> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 45.</ref> and the Drāhyāyaṇa Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]];<ref name=fx3_ve2_877> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 4, 384.</ref> also with the name '''Saṃvargajit''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_877> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

लाह्यायन
<u>'''Lāhyāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Lahya,’ is the patronymic of '''[[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 5, 1. 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

लिबुजा
<u>'''Libujā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_879> x. 10, 13.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_879> vi. 8, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 13, 11;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 28;<br> xi. 34.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70.</ref> denotes a creeping plant that climbs trees.

लुश
<u>'''Luśa'''</u> is represented in a series of passages in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_880> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 2, 22;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 128;<br> Śāṭyāyanaka in Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 31 ''et seq.''</ref> as a rival of '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]]''' for the favour of Indra. To [[लुश|Luśa]] Dhānāka the authorship of certain hymns<ref name=fx2_ve2_880> x. 35. 36. ''Cf.'' Bṛhaddevatā, ii. 129;<br> iii. 55, with Macdonell's notes.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 291, n. 3;<br> Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 37, 38.</ref> is ascribed by the Anukramaṇī (Index) of the Rigveda.

लुशाकपि खार्गलि
<u>'''Luśākapi Khārgali'''</u> (‘descendant of Khṛgala’) is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_881> xvii. 4, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 145, n. 3.</ref> as having cursed '''[[कुषीतक|Kuṣītaka]]''' and the '''Kauṣītakins.''' He was a contemporary of '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]] [[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]]''' according to the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_881> xxx. 2 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 471);<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xlvi. 5.</ref> 

लोक
<u>'''Loka'''</u> denotes ‘world’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_882> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2, quotes no example of this meaning for the Rigveda, where he sees the word used only in the sense of ‘place,’ ‘room,’ ‘free or open space.’ But Rv. x. 14, 9, is a fairly certain example of the wider sense.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_882> Av. viii. 9, 1. 15;<br> iv. 38, 5;<br> xi. 5, 7;<br> 8, 10, etc.;<br> in ix. 5, 14, the worlds of heaven (''[[दिव्य|divya]]'') and of earth (''pārthiva'') are distinguished;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxii. 11 ''et seq.,'' etc.</ref> Mention is often made of the three worlds,<ref name=fx3_ve2_882> Av. x. 6, 31;<br> xii. 3, 20;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 8;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 7, 3, etc.</ref> and ''ayaṃ lokaḥ,'' ‘this world,’<ref name=fx4_ve2_882> Av. v. 30, 17;<br> viii. 8, 8;<br> xii. 5, 38;<br> xix. 54, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 46, etc.</ref> is constantly opposed to ''asau lokaḥ,''<ref name=fx5_ve2_882> Av. xii. 5, 38. 57;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 9, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 28, 2;<br> viii. 2, 3, etc.</ref> ‘yonder world’-''i.e.,'' ‘heaven.’ Loka itself sometimes means ‘heaven,’<ref name=fx6_ve2_882> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 1, 7;<br> x. 5, 4, 16;<br> xi. 2, 7, 19;<br> and so probably [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 13, 12.</ref> while in other passages several different sorts of world are mentioned.<ref name=fx7_ve2_882> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvi. 4;<br> Kauṣī taki [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xx. 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 6, 1;<br> iv. 3, 36 ''et seq.;<br>'' vi. 1, 18, etc.</ref>

लोध
<u>'''Lodha'''</u> occurs in a very obscure verse of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_883> iii. 53, 23.</ref> where Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_883> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> conjectures that some sort of ‘red’ animal is meant, and Oldenberg<ref name=fx3_ve2_883> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 255.<br><br>''Cf.'' the obscure ''adhī-[[लोध|lodha]]-karṇa'' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 16, 1, perhaps meaning ‘having quite red ears.’ [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 12, equates the word with ''lubdha,'' ‘confused,’ but this does not suit the context. So also Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 84;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 160;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], Glossar,'' 151, who sees in the word the designation of a noble steed.</ref> shows some reason for thinking that a ‘red goat’ is intended.

लोपा
<u>'''Lopā'''</u> is mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve2_884> v. 5, 18, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> where Sāyaṇa explains it as a kind of bird, perhaps the carrion crow (''śmaśānaśakuni''). 

लोपा-मुद्रा
<u>'''Lopā-mudrā'''</u> appears in one hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_885> i. 179, 4.</ref> where she is seemingly the wife of '''[[अगस्त्य|Agastya]],''' whose embraces she solicits.<ref name=fx2_ve2_885> The story is differently told in the Bṛhaddevatā, iv. 57 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes. See also Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenldndischen Gesellschaft,'' 39, 68;<br> ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1909, 76 ''et seq.;<br>'' Sieg. ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 120 ''et seq.;<br>'' Winternitz, ''Vienna Oriental Journal,'' 20, 2 ''et seq.;<br>'' von Schroeder, ''Mysterium und Mimus,'' 156 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 204;<br> 1911, 997, n. 3.</ref>

लोपाश
<u>'''Lopāśa'''</u> is the name of an animal, probably the ‘jackal’ or ‘fox,’ which is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_886> x. 28, 4.</ref> and is included in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_886> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 21, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 17;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 36.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 84.</ref>

लोह
<u>'''Loha,'''</u> primarily an adjective meaning ‘red,’ is used as a neuter substantive to designate a metal, probably ‘copper,’ but possibly ‘bronze.’ It is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_887> xviii. 13.</ref> and the Taittīriya Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_887> iv. 7, 5, 1.</ref> as distinguished from '''[[श्याम|Śyāma]].''' It also occurs several times in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx3_ve2_887> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 2, 18;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 7;<br> vi. 1, 5;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 4, where Oertel takes ‘copper’ to be meant in contrast with '''Ayas,''' which he renders ‘brass.’ The sense of ‘iron’ is nowhere needed.<br><br>''Cf.'' Vincent Smith, ''Indian Antiquary,'' 34, 230;<br> and on the early history of metals;<br> Mosso, ''Mediterranean Civilization,'' 57-62.</ref> See Ayas.

लोह-मणि
<u>'''Loha-maṇi'''</u> in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 2, 5) denotes a ‘copper amulet,’ as Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx1_ve2_888> ''Cf.'' Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 134.</ref> renders it, rather than a ‘lump of gold,’ as translated by Max Müller following the scholiast.

लोहायस
<u>'''Lohāyasa,'''</u> ‘red metal,’ is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_889> v. 4, 1, 1. 2.</ref> where it is distinguished from '''Ayas''' and gold. In the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_889> iii. 17, 3.</ref> the contrast is with Kārṣṇā-  yasa, ‘iron,’ and in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_889> iii. 62, 6, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 90, n.;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 189.</ref> with [[कृष्णायस|Kṛṣṇāyasa]], ‘iron.’ ‘Copper’ seems to be meant.

लोहित
<u>'''Lohita,'''</u> often occurring as an adjective meaning ‘red,’ is used as a neuter substantive in the Atharvaveda (xi. 3, 7) to denote a metal, presumably ‘copper.’ As a proper name it is found in Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 9, 7.<br>==Foot Notes==

लोहितायस
<u>'''Lohitāyasa,'''</u> ‘red metal,’ ‘copper,’ is the variant of '''Loha''' in the Maitrāyaṇī (ii. 11, 5; iv. 4, 4) and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] (xviii. 10) Saṃhitās.<br>==Foot Notes==

लोहिताहि
<u>'''Lohitāhi,'''</u> ‘red snake,’ is the name of a variety of serpent mentioned in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_892> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 14, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 31. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref>

लौहित्य
<u>'''Lauhitya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[लोहित|Lohita]],’ is the patronymic of a large number of teachers in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], which clearly must have been the special object of study of the [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]] family. See '''Kṛṣṇadatta, Kṛṣṇarāta, Jayaka, Triveda Kṛṣṇarāta, Dakṣa [[जयन्त|Jayanta]], Palligupta, Mitrabhūti, Yaśasvin [[जयन्त|Jayanta]], Vipaścit [[दृढजयन्त|Dṛḍhajayanta]], [[वैपश्चित|Vaipaścita]] [[दार्ढजयन्ति|Dārḍhajayanti]], [[वैपश्चित|Vaipaścita]] [[दार्ढजयन्ति|Dārḍhajayanti]] [[दृढजयन्त|Dṛḍhajayanta]], Śyāmajayanta, Śyāmasujayanta, [[सत्यश्रवस्|Satyaśravas]].''' A [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]] or Lauhikya is also mentioned as a teacher in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_893> vii. 22;<br> Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 50, n. 1.</ref> The form of name ([[जयन्त|Jayanta]]) affected by the family, and the silence of the older texts, proves that they were modern. 

वंश
<u>'''1. Vaṃśa,'''</u> denoting the ‘rafters’ or ‘beams’ of the house as made of bamboo cane, is found in this sense from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_894> i. 10, 1.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve2_894> Av. iii. 12, 6;<br> ix. 3, 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 8, 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 3, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 1, 2, 25;<br> ''[[शाला|śālā]]-[[वंश|vaṃśa]],'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 1;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 1, where perhaps the main beam of the house is meant. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71, 153;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 346.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[तिरश्चीनवंश|Tiraścīnavaṃśa]], [[प्राचीनवंश|Prācīnavaṃśa]],''' and see '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''

वंश
<u>'''2. Vaṃśa'''</u> (lit. ‘bamboo’) in the sense of ‘spiritual genealogy,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_895> From the analogy of the successive joints of the bamboo. ''Cf.'' ‘familytree.’</ref> ‘list of teachers,’ is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_895> x. 6, 5, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 14.</ref> the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_895> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 374.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx4_ve2_895> xv. 1.</ref>

वंश-नर्तिन्
<u>'''Vaṃśa-nartin'''</u> is mentioned as one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_896> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 21;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 17, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 290.</ref> A ‘poledancer’ or ‘acrobat’ seems to be meant.

वंसग
<u>'''Vaṃsaga'''</u> is in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_897> i. 7, 8;<br> 55, 1;<br> 58, 4;<br> v. 36, 1, etc.;<br> Av. xviii. 3, 36.</ref> a common name of the ‘bull’ that leads the herds.

वक दाल्भ्य
<u>'''Vaka Dālbhya'''</u> (‘descendant of Dalbha’) is the name of a teacher in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_898> i. 2, 13;<br> 12, 1.</ref> According to the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_898> xxx. 2 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 471).</ref> he was engaged in a ritual dispute with '''[[धृतराष्ट्र|Dhṛtarāṣṭra]].'''

वकल
<u>'''Vakala'''</u> denotes in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_899> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 4, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 2.</ref> the ‘inner bark’ of a tree, ‘bast.’ 

वक्षणा
<u>'''Vakṣaṇā,'''</u> fem. plur. denotes in one passage of the '''Rigveda'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_900> iii. 33, 12. ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 175-181.</ref> the bed of a stream.

वघा
<u>'''Vaghā'''</u> is the name of a noxious animal the '''Atharvaveda.'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_901> vi. 50, 3;<br> ix. 2, 22. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref>

वङ्ग
<u>'''Vaṅga,'''</u> the designation of Bengal proper is not found in the earlier Vedic literature unless it is to be recognized in the curious word ''Vaṅgāvagadhāḥ,'' which occurs in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve2_902> ii. 1, 1. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 200;<br> ''[[मगध|Magadha]]-[[वङ्ग|Vaṅga]]-Matsyāḥ'' occurs in the Atharvaveda Pariśiṣṭas (i. 7, 7). but that is very late.</ref> and which suggests amendment to ''[[वङ्ग|Vaṅga]]-Magadhāḥ,'' ‘the Vaṅgas and the Magadhas,’ two neighbouring peoples. The name is certainly found in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_902> i. 1, 14. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 394, n.;<br> Calan ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 56, 553.</ref>

वङ्गृद
<u>'''Vaṅgṛda'''</u> is the name of a demon or a human foe in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_903> i. 53, 8. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 149.</ref>

वज्र
<u>'''Vajra'''</u> in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_904> vi. 24, 1.</ref> denotes, according to Geldner,<ref name=fx2_ve2_904> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 138.</ref> the ‘handle,’ while '''[[कूट|Kūṭa]]''' means the ‘head’ of the hammer.

वडव
<u>'''Vaḍava'''</u> is a common name for a ‘mare’ in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_905> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 6, 3;<br> iii. 8, 22, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5, 2. 19, etc. A derivative of this word is the masculine [[वडव|Vaḍava]], [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 8, 3.</ref>

वणिज्
<u>'''Vaṇij'''</u> denotes ‘merchant’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_906> i. 112, 11;<br> v. 45, 6.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_906> Av. iii. 15, 1, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 257.</ref> See '''[[पणि|Paṇi]]''' and '''[[क्रय|Kraya]];''' ''cf.'' also '''[[वाणिज|Vāṇija]].''' 

वणिज्या
<u>'''Vaṇijyā'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_907> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 4, 21;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1, 2.</ref> denotes the business of a merchant ('''[[वणिज्|Vaṇij]]''') ‘trade.’

वत्स
<u>'''1. Vatsa'''</u> is often found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_908> iii. 33, 3;<br> iv. 18, 10, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_908> Av. iv. 18, 2;<br> xii. 4, 7 (wolves kill them);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 11, 4 (the cow caresses the calf on birth), etc.</ref> in the sense of ‘calf.’ Reference is made to the use of a calf to induce the cow to give milk,<ref name=fx3_ve2_908> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 6, 2;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 13, 2.</ref> and to the separation of the cows from the calves at certain times.<ref name=fx4_ve2_908> Rv. v. 30, 10;<br> viii. 88, 1. See Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 11''c.''</ref>

वत्स
<u>'''2. Vatsa'''</u> occurs several times in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_909> viii. 6, 1;<br> 8, 8;<br> 9, 1;<br> 11, 7.</ref> as the name of a singer, a son or descendant of '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]].''' In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_909> xiv. 6, 6.</ref> he is said to have passed successfully through a fire ordeal to which he resorted for the purpose of proving to his rival, '''[[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]],''' the purity of his descent. He is also mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_909> xvi. 11, 20. He also occurs in Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 5, 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 105;<br> Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 36-38.</ref> as the recipient of bounty from '''Tirindara [[पारशव्य|Pāraśavya]].'''

वत्सतर
<u>'''Vatsatara, Vatsatari,'''</u> denotes a ‘young calf’ in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_910> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 17, 1;<br> 18, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiv. 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 27, 2, etc.</ref>

वत्स-नपात् बाभ्रव
<u>'''Vatsa-[[नपात्|napāt]] Bābhrava'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[बभ्रु|Babhru]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[पथिन् सौभर|Pathin Saubhara]],''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_911> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

वत्स-प्री भालन्दन
<u>'''Vatsa-prī Bhālandana'''</u> (‘descendant of Bhalandana’) is the name of a sage who ‘saw’ the Vātsapra Sāman (chant). He  is mentioned in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_912> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 1, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xix. 12 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 470);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 2.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_912> xii. 11, 25. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 7, 4, 1.</ref>

वधक
<u>'''Vadhaka'''</u> is the name of some sort of ‘reed’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_913> viii. 8, 3.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_913> v. 4, 5, 14.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

वधर्
<u>'''Vadhar'''</u> means a ‘weapon’ generally; it is used not merely of a divine,<ref name=fx1_ve2_914> i. 32, 9, etc.</ref> but also of a human<ref name=fx2_ve2_914> Rv. iv. 22, 9;<br> viii. 22, 8;<br> 24, 27.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 221.</ref> weapon in the Rigveda.

वधू
<u>'''1. Vadhū'''</u> is a frequent word for ‘woman’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_915> v. 37, 3;<br> 47, 6;<br> vii. 69, 3;<br> viii. 26, 13;<br> x. 27, 12;<br> 85, 30;<br> 107, 9.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_915> Av. i. 14, 2;<br> iv. 20, 3;<br> x. 1, 1;<br> xiv. 2, 9, 41, etc.</ref> It denotes, according to Delbrück,<ref name=fx3_ve2_915> ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 414, 439.</ref> the woman as either married or as seeking a husband, or as a bride in the wedding ceremony. The word appears to be derived from a form of the root ''vah,'' ‘to carry,’ as is ''[[वहतु|vahatu]],'' ‘the bridal procession,’ thus meaning ‘she who is to be or has been conducted home.’ Zimmer,<ref name=fx4_ve2_915> ''Altindsiches Leben,'' 108.</ref> however, objects to this explanation, regarding ''[[वधू|vadhū]]'' as a derivative from a different root meaning ‘to marry.’

वधू
<u>'''2. Vadhū'''</u> is in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_916> viii. 19, 36. ''Cf.'' also v. 47, 6, as taken by Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 319.</ref> taken by Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_916> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 3.</ref> to denote a ‘female animal,’ while Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_916> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 108, 109.</ref> urges that it means a ‘female slave.’ As far as the use of [[वधू|Vadhū]] goes, either meaning is abnormal, for if [[वधू|Vadhū]] never elsewhere  means a female animal (from ''vah,'' to ‘draw’ a cart), neither does it denote a slave: as the passage refers to a gift of fifty Vadhūs by '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]] Paurukutsya''' to the singer, the latter must have been a polygamist of an advanced type to require fifty wives. The same doubt arises in the case of ''vadhūmant,'' which is used in the Rigveda and Atharvaveda as an epithet of the chariot ('''[[रथ|Ratha]]'''),<ref name=fx4_ve2_916> i. 126, 3;<br> vii. 18, 22.</ref> of horses ('''[[अश्व|Aśva]]'''),<ref name=fx5_ve2_916> viii. 68, 17. ''Cf.'' vi. 27, 8.</ref> and of buffaloes ('''Uṣṭra''').<ref name=fx6_ve2_916> Av. xx. 127, 2.</ref> Zimmer sees in all cases a reference to slaves in the chariots or with the horses: this interpretation has the support of the Bṛhaddevatā.<ref name=fx7_ve2_916> iii. 147 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> Roth's version of the references to horses or buffaloes as ‘suitable for draught’ is not very happy; if ''[[वधू|vadhū]]'' is really a female animal ''vadhūmant'' means rather ‘together with mares,’ or ‘together with female buffaloes,’ which makes reasonable sense.<ref name=fx8_ve2_916> ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 197;<br> Pischel, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 712 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

वध्रिमती
<u>'''Vadhrimatī,'''</u> ‘having an impotent man as a husband,’ seems in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_917> i. 116, 13;<br> 117, 24;<br> vi. 62, 7;<br> x. 39, 7;<br> 65, 12.</ref> to be the name of a woman who owed the restoration of her husband's virility to the Aśvins, and obtained a son, '''[[हिरण्यहस्त|Hiraṇyahasta]].''' The word is, however, possibly only descriptive.

वध्र्य्-अश्व
<u>'''1. Vadhry-aśva,'''</u> ‘having castrated horses,’ is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_918> vi. 61, 1;<br> x. 69, 1 ''et seq.'' '''Sumitra,''' in the latter hymn, can hardly be a name of his.</ref> of a prince, the father of '''Divodāsa,''' and an energetic supporter of the fire cult, as was his son after him. He is mentioned in a long list of names in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_918> iv. 29, 4. ''Cf.'' Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 6, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie.'' 1, 97.</ref>

वध्र्य्-अश्व आनूप
<u>'''2. Vadhry-[[अश्व|aśva]] Ānūpa'''</u> (‘descendant of Anūpa’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman, or chant, in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 3, 17). <br>==Foot Notes==

वन
<u>'''Vana'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_920> i. 54, 1;<br> 65, 8;<br> iii. 51, 5;<br> v. 41, 11, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_920> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], lxxvi. 3, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘forest,’ not necessarily of trees only, but, like [[अरण्य|Araṇya]], the wild uninhabited land.<ref name=fx3_ve2_920> Rv. vii. 1, 19 (opposed to ''dama,'' ‘home’).</ref> It also means ‘wooden cup’ used in the Soma ritual,<ref name=fx4_ve2_920> Rv. i. 55, 4;<br> ii. 14, 9, etc. See Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 163, 166, 193.</ref> and in one passage perhaps a part of the chariot.<ref name=fx5_ve2_920> viii. 34, 18.</ref>

वन-प
<u>'''Vana-pa,'''</u> ‘forest-guardian,’ is included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_921> Vājasaneyi Samhitā, xxx. 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 11, 1.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Dāvapa.'''

वनर्-गु
<u>'''Vanar-gu,'''</u> ‘forest-goer,’ is used in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_922> x. 4, 6.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_922> iv. 36, 7.</ref> to designate robbers who haunt the forests. In the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_922> Āraṇya Saṃhitā, iv. 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the term is more generally opposed to civilized men (''kavayaḥ,'' ‘sages’; ''vanargavaḥ,'' ‘savages’).

वनस्-पति
<u>'''Vanas-pati,'''</u> ‘lord of the forest,’ primarily denotes ‘tree,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_923> Rv. i. 166, 5;<br> iii. 34, 10;<br> v. 7, 4;<br> 41, 8, etc.;<br> Av. xi. 6, 1 (distinguished from '''[[वीरुध्|Vīrudh]]''' and '''Oradhi''');<br> 9, 24, etc.</ref> and then ‘post’ or ‘pole.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_923> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 8, 4;<br> Av. ix. 3, 11, etc.</ref> In some passages it is applied either to a part of the chariot or to the chariot as a whole.<ref name=fx3_ve2_923> Rv. ii. 37, 3;<br> iii. 53, 20;<br> vi. 47, 26;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 11. See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 251.</ref> It also means a ‘wooden drum’<ref name=fx4_ve2_923> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 12. ''Cf.'' Av. xii. 3, 15.</ref> and a ‘wooden amulet,’<ref name=fx5_ve2_923> Av. vi. 85, 1;<br> x. 3, 8. 11.</ref> while in some passages<ref name=fx6_ve2_923> Rv. i. 91, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 23, etc.</ref> it denotes the plant ''par excellence,'' Soma.

वन्दन
<u>'''1. Vandana'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_924> vii. 50, 2 ''Cf.'' 21, 5;<br> Av. vii. 113, 2;<br> ''[[तृष्ट|tṛṣṭa]]-vandanā,'' ‘having a rough eruption,’ vii. 113, 1;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 391;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 564, 565 Whitney. Translation of the Atharvaveda, 469.</ref> as the name of a disease, apparently some sort of eruption spreading over the body. 

वन्दन
<u>'''2. Vandana'''</u> is the name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_925> i. 112, 5;<br> 116, 11;<br> 117, 5;<br> 118, 8;<br> x. 39, 8. ''Cf.'' Baunack, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 263 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''ṚgvedaNoten,'' 1, 109.</ref>

वन्धुर
<u>'''Vandhura'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_926> i. 139, 4;<br> iii. 14, 3;<br> vi. 47, 9, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_926> Av. x. 4, 2. The Aśvins' car is ''trivandhura,'' ‘having three seats,’ because the Aśvins are a pair, and the charioteer makes a third. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 47, 2;<br> 118, 1. 2;<br> 157, 3;<br> 183, 1;<br> vii. 69, 2;<br> 71. 4;<br> viii. 22, 5;<br> and ''cf.'' ix. 62, 17. See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' viii, 247;<br> Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1898, 564;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 241, n. 371.</ref> the ‘seat’ of the chariot. See '''[[रथ|Ratha]].'''

वप
<u>'''Vapa,'''</u> ‘sower,’ is mentioned in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_927> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 1.</ref>

वपन
<u>'''Vapana'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_928> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 17, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 2, 1.</ref> denotes the process of ‘shaving.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[क्षुर|Kṣura]]''' and '''[[केश|Keśa]].'''

वपा
<u>'''Vapā'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_929> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 2, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 4;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 3, 5.</ref> denotes an ant-hill.

वप्तृ
<u>'''Vaptṛ'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_930> x. 142, 4.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_930> Av. viii. 2, 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 6, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 266;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 235, n. 4.</ref> denotes a ‘shaver,’ ‘barber.’

वप्र
<u>'''Vapra,'''</u> ‘rampart,’ is a conjectural reading in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_931> vii. 71, 1. See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 435, 436.</ref> 

वम्र
<u>'''1. Vamra,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_932> Rv. i. 51, 9;<br> viii. 102, 21.</ref> '''Vamrī,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_932> Rv. iv. 19, 9 (where the son of an unmarried maiden is exposed to be eaten by ants);<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 1, 8. 14, etc. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97.</ref> are the names of the male and female ‘ant’ in the Rigveda and later. ''Cf.'' '''[[वपा|Vapā]].'''

वम्र
<u>'''2. Vamra'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the '''Rigveda.'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_933> i. 51, 9;<br> 112, 15;<br> x. 99, 5.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[वम्रक|Vamraka]].'''

वम्रक
<u>'''Vamraka'''</u> is mentioned in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_934> x. 99, 12.</ref> where Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_934> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> thinks that an ‘ant’ is meant. But Pischel,<ref name=fx3_ve2_934> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 238, 239.</ref> with more probability, thinks that it is a proper name, perhaps equivalent to '''[[वम्र|Vamra]],''' and denoting the child of a maiden who was saved from being devoured by ants.<ref name=fx4_ve2_934> Rv. iv. 19, 9;<br> 30, 16.</ref>

वयस्
<u>'''1. Vayas'''</u> is a common name for ‘bird’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_935> iii. 21, 2;<br> vi. 59, 1;<br> vii. 96, 1;<br> viii. 7, 24, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_935> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 1, 1;<br> v. 2, 5, 1;<br> 5, 3, 2. etc.</ref>

वयस्
<u>'''2. Vayas'''</u> denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_936> xii. 3, 1.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_936> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 5, 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 2, 21;<br> 3, 3, 3. etc.</ref> the ‘age of animals or men.’

वया
<u>'''Vayā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_937> ii. 5, 4;<br> v. 1, 1;<br> vi. 7, 6;<br> 13, 1;<br> viii. 13, 6, 17, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘branch’ of a tree.

वयित्री
<u>'''Vayitrī'''</u> in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 8, 9) denotes a ‘female weaver.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

वय्य
<u>'''Vayya'''</u> occurs in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_939> i. 54, 6;<br> 112, 6 (where [[तुर्वीति|Turvīti]] does not occur);<br> ii. 13, 12;<br> iv. 19, 6.</ref> in connexion with '''[[तुर्वीति|Turvīti]],''' of whom the word is, according to Sāyaṇa,<ref name=fx2_ve2_939> On Rv. i. 54, 6.</ref> a patronymic in one passage. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_939> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' quoting ix. 68, 8, as a clear case.</ref> is inclined to think that the sense of ‘companion’ would suit all passages.

वर
<u>'''Vara'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_940> i. 83, 2;<br> v. 60, 4;<br> ix. 101, 14;<br> x. 85, 8. 9.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_940> Av. ii. 36, 1. 5. 6;<br> xi. 8, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 7, 1, etc.</ref> regularly denotes a ‘wooer.’

वरण
<u>'''Varaṇa'''</u> is the name of a tree (''Crataeva Roxburghii'') in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_941> vi. 85, 1;<br> x. 3, 1, etc.;<br> xix. 32, 9.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_941> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 9. 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 8, 4, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 60, 61;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 505.</ref>

वरणावती
<u>'''Varaṇāvatī'''</u> is found in one passage of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_942> iv. 7, 1.</ref> It seems to be, as Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_942> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> thought, the name of a stream, and is regarded by Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve2_942> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 201.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 20.</ref> as the Ganges. Bloomfield,<ref name=fx4_ve2_942> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 376.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 26, 27;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 154.</ref> while considering that a plant may, as Sāyaṇa thinks, be meant, yet regards a reference to a river as probable. ''Cf.'' '''[[काशि|Kāśi]].'''

वरत्रा
<u>'''Varatrā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_943> iv. 57, 4 (of the plough), etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_943> Av. xi. 3, 10;<br> xx. 135, 13.</ref> denotes a ‘thong’ or ‘strap.’ It was used to fasten the oxen to the yoke,<ref name=fx3_ve2_943> Rv. x. 60, 8;<br> 102, 8;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 13.</ref> or perhaps to fasten the yoke to the pole.<ref name=fx4_ve2_943> This suits x. 60, 8, rather more naturally, and is so taken by Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 248, 249.</ref> Or, again, it denotes<ref name=fx5_ve2_943> Rv. x. 106, 5;<br> Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 156.</ref> the strap which was used in drawing up water from the well ('''[[अवत|Avata]]'''). 

वरशिख
<u>'''Varaśikha'''</u> is the name of a leader whose tribe is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_944> vi. 27, 4. 5. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 156;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 133, who thinks that [[वरशिख|Varaśikha]] was the leader of the '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]-Vṛcīvants,''' but this is conjectural, and not very probable. ''Cf.'' '''[[पार्थव|Pārthava]].''' In the Bṛhaddevatā, v. 124 ''et seq.,'' the form of the name is Vāraśikha (‘descendant of Varaśikha’), occurring in the plural only.</ref> as being defeated by '''[[अभ्यावर्तिन् चायमान|Abhyāvartin Cāyamāna]]'''

वराह
<u>'''Varāha,'''</u> ‘boar,’ is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_945> i. 61, 7;<br> viii. 77, 10;<br> ix. 97, 7;<br> x. 28, 4 (''cf.'' '''[[क्रोष्टृ|Kroṣṭṛ]]'''), etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_945> Av. viii. 7, 23;<br> xii. 1, 48;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 2;<br> xxv. 2, etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇi Saṃhitā, iii. 14. 19, etc.</ref> The god Rudra is described as the ‘boar of heaven.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_945> Rv. i. 114, 5. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 4, 2;<br> vii. 1, 5, 1. etc.</ref> The use of dogs to hunt the boar is once alluded to.<ref name=fx4_ve2_945> Rv. x. 86, 4, an obscure passage.</ref> The variant form of the word, Varāhu, is not used except metaphorically of divinities.<ref name=fx5_ve2_945> Rv. i. 88, 5;<br> 121, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 9, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 81, 82;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 67, who points out that, even in the Rigveda, its use is predominantly metraphorical, x. 28, 4, and x. 86, 4, being the only clear instances of the real sense, and of these x. 86, 4, is doubtful. See also Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 66 ''et seq.''</ref>

वरु
<u>'''Varu'''</u> is held by Sāyaṇa to be a proper name in several passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_946> viii. 23, 28;<br> 24, 28;<br> 26, 2.</ref> where it is accented as a vocative followed by ''suṣāmṇe.'' Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_946> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 39, 84, 85.</ref> considers that the name must be Varosuṣāman, despite its doubtful formation.

वरुण-गृहीत
<u>'''Varuṇa-gṛhīta,'''</u> ‘seized by Varuṇa,’ is found in several passages<ref name=fx1_ve2_947> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 2, 1;<br> vi. 4, 2, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 4, 5, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 4, 1, etc.</ref> as a description of a man afflicted with dropsy, which is the disease sent by Varuṇa as a punishment for sin.<ref name=fx2_ve2_947> Rv. vi. 74, 4;<br> vii. 88. 7;<br> Av. ii. 10, 1;<br> iv. 16, 6. 7;<br> xiv. 1, 57;<br> 2, 49, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 203;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 29, n. 16.</ref> 

वर्चिन्
<u>'''Varcin'''</u> is the name of a foe of Indra in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_948> ii. 14, 6;<br> iv. 30, 14. 15;<br> vi. 47, 21;<br> vii. 99, 5.</ref> Being called a '''[[दास|Dāsa]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_948> Rv. iv. 30, 15;<br> vi. 47, 21.</ref> and coupled with [[शम्बर|Śambara]], he is probably to be regarded as a terrestrial foe, though he is also spoken of as an Asura.<ref name=fx3_ve2_948> Rv. vii. 99, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 152;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 103, n. 3;<br> 3, 273;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 162 (F).</ref> He may possibly have been connected with the '''Vṛcīvants.'''

वर्ण
<u>'''1. Varṇa,'''</u> ‘colour,’ is a common word in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_949> i. 73, 7;<br> 96, 5;<br> 113, 2;<br> iv. 5. 13;<br> ix. 97, 15;<br> 104, 4;<br> 105, 1;<br> x. 3, 3, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_949> Av. i. 22, 1. 2;<br> 23, 2;<br> xi. 8, 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 26, etc.</ref> A large number of colours are enumerated in Vedic literature, but it is not possible to deduce any clear information as to the accuracy with which the Vedic Indian distinguished colours, or as to the principle on which his distinctions were based. The Rigveda seems to show that red or yellow colours were the most noticed, but this may be accidental.<ref name=fx3_ve2_949> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, cxxi ''et seq.''</ref> ‘Black’ or ‘dark’ is denoted by ''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]],'' ‘white’ or ‘light-coloured’ by ''[[शुक्ल|śukla]]'' or ''śveta.'' ‘Black’ seems to be meant in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_949> i. 140, 9. ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 8;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 250, 251.</ref> by ''śyenī'' also. ‘Dark-grey’ or ‘dusky’ is expressed by ''[[श्याम|śyāma]].''<ref name=fx5_ve2_949> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 3, 7.</ref> The sense of ''nīla''<ref name=fx6_ve2_949> The ''nīla'' of the Chāndogya Upaniśad iii. 6, 1, is replaced by ''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]'' in the Kausītaki [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] iv. to ''Cf.'' Rv. viii. 19, 31. In the post-Vedic language ''nīla'' describes the colour of dark blue objects, such as indigo, sapphire, etc. That the word already had some such sense in the Rigveda is suggested by its use in allusions to the smoke of Agni.</ref> is doubtful, perhaps ‘dark-blue,’ ‘bluish-black.’ The series of words ''hari, [[हरिण|hariṇa]], harit, [[हरित|harita]],'' seems, on the whole, to denote ‘yellow,’ but ‘green’ is also a possible rendering, since the epithet is used of the frog.<ref name=fx7_ve2_949> Rv. vii. 103, 6, and ''cf.'' iii. 44, 3;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 365, n.</ref> ‘Brown’ is certainly the meaning of ''[[बभ्रु|babhru]],'' which is used of the '''[[विभीतक|Vibhītaka]]''' nut (see '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]]'''). ‘Reddish-brown’ seems to be the tinge implied by ''[[कपिल|kapila]]''<ref name=fx8_ve2_949> Rv. x. 27, 16;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 14.</ref> (‘monkey-coloured’), while ''piṅgala'' appears to denote a shade of brown in which yellow pre-  dominates, ‘tawny.’<ref name=fx9_ve2_949> Av. xi. 5, 26;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 6, 2;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 14.</ref> ‘Yellow’ is expressed by ''pīta'' as well as ''pāṇḍu.''<ref name=fx10_ve2_949> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 3, 6.</ref> A garment of saffron (''[[माहारजन|māhārajana]]'') is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx11_ve2_949> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> ''Rudhira'' and ''[[लोहित|lohita]]'' are red, while ''aruṇa'' is ‘ruddy.’ ''Kalmāṣa'' means ‘spotted,’<ref name=fx12_ve2_949> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 58.</ref> and ''[[शिल्प|śilpa]]'' ‘dappled,’<ref name=fx13_ve2_949> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 5;<br> xxix. 58;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 22, 1;<br> 6, 13, 1;<br> 20, 1.</ref> while mingled shades like ''aruṇa-[[पिशङ्ग|piśaṅga]],'' ‘reddish brown,’ also occur.<ref name=fx14_ve2_949> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6, 11, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 119 ''et seq.''</ref>

वर्ण
<u>'''2. Varṇa'''</u> (lit. ‘colour’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_950> ''[[दास|Dāsa]],'' Rv. ii. 12, 4;<br> ''[[आर्य|ārya]] [[वर्ण|varṇa]]'' as against ''[[दस्यु|dasyu]],'' iii. 34, 9;<br> ''[[वर्ण|varṇa]]'' itself opposed to ''[[दास|dāsa]],'' i. 104, 2. ''Cf.'' ii. 3, 5. ''Cf.'' a verse in [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 25, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 14. Roth, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 113, reads ''varṇaśeṣas'' in Rv. v. 65, 5.</ref> is applied to denote classes of men, the '''[[दास|Dāsa]]''' and the Āryan [[वर्ण|Varṇa]] being contrasted, as other passages<ref name=fx2_ve2_950> See '''[[दस्यु|Dasyu]], [[दास|Dāsa]];<br>''' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 113, 114. There is no trace in Vedic literature of any real distinction of colour save this main one. In the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 23, the Brahman's colour is white (''[[शुक्ल|śukla]]'');<br> the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 6, calls the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] ‘white’ (''[[शुक्ल|śukla]]''), the [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] ‘swarthy’ (''[[धूम्र|dhūmra]]'');<br> and the later view makes the four castes black, yellow (''pīta''), red (''rakta''), and white respectively. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 10, 11;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 153, etc., 176. ''Cf.'' also Av. iii. 4, 6, where Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 90, with hesitation suggests the reading ''varṇaiḥ,'' ‘castes.’</ref> show, on account of colour. But this use is confined to distinguishing two colours: in this respect the Rigveda differs fundamentally from the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx3_ve2_950> ''Catvāro varṇāḥ,'' ‘four castes,’ Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 9;<br> vi. 4, 4, 13;<br> ''śaudra [[वर्ण|varṇa]],'' ‘Śūdra caste,’ ''ibid.,'' vi. 4, 4, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, 25;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 4. ''Cf.'' also ''[[आर्य|ārya]] [[वर्ण|varṇa]]'' opposed to [[शूद्र|Śūdra]], [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 17, and see [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 6, 7. ''Vaṇṇa'' appears in this sense sometimes in Pāli. See Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 22, n. 4;<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 53.</ref> where the four castes (''varṇāḥ'') are already fully recognized.<br><br>''(a) Caste in the Rigveda.''--The use of the term [[वर्ण|Varṇa]] is not, of course, conclusive for the question whether caste existed in the Rigveda. In one sense it must be admitted to have existed: the [[पुरुष|Puruṣa]]-[[सूक्त|sūkta]], ‘hymn of man,’ in the tenth  Maṇḍala<ref name=fx4_ve2_950> Rv. x. 90, 12 = Av. xix. 6, 6 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxi. 11 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 12, 5. ''Cf.'' Muir, 12, 7-15, and references.</ref> clearly contemplates the division of mankind into four classes--the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], [[राजन्य|Rājanya]], [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]], and [[शूद्र|Śūdra]]. But the hymn being admittedly late,<ref name=fx5_ve2_950> Max Müller, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 570 ''et seq.;<br>'' Muir, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 3 ''et seq.;<br>'' Colebrooke, ''Essays,'' 1, 309;<br> Arnold, ''Vedic Metre,'' p. 167.</ref> its evidence is not cogent for the bulk of the Rigveda. Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve2_950> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 185-203.</ref> has with great force combatted the view that the Rigveda was produced in a society that knew the caste system. He points out that the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx7_ve2_950> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1. ''Cf.'' Av. xv., and see '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]].'''</ref> show us the Vedic Indians on the Indus as unbrahminized, and not under the caste system; he argues that the Rigveda was the product of tribes living in the Indus region and the Panjab; later on a part of this people, who had wandered farther east, developed the peculiar civilization of the caste system. He adopts the arguments of Muir,<ref name=fx8_ve2_950> ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 239 ''et seq.,'' especially 258.</ref> derived from the study of the data of the Rigveda, viz.: that (''a'') the four castes appear only in the late Puruṣasūkta; (''b'') the term [[वर्ण|Varṇa]], as shown above, covers the three highest castes of later times, and is only contrasted with [[दास|Dāsa]]; (''c'') that [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is rare in the Rigveda, [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] occurs seldom,<ref name=fx9_ve2_950> Rv. viii. 104, 13;<br> x. 109, 3, and ''cf.'' '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]].'''</ref> [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] only in the Puruṣasūkta, where too, alone, [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] and [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] are found; (''d'') that [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] denotes at first ‘poet,’ ‘sage,’ and then ‘officiating priest,’ or still later a special class of priest; (''e'') that in some only of the passages<ref name=fx10_ve2_950> Rv. i. 108, 7;<br> iv. 50, 8 ''et seq.;<br>'' viii. 7, 20;<br> 45, 39;<br> 53, 7;<br> 81, 30;<br> ix. 112, 1;<br> x. 85, 29.</ref> where it occurs does [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] denote a ‘priest by profession,’ while in others it denotes something peculiar to the individual, designating a person distinguished for genius or virtue, or specially chosen to receive divine inspiration.<ref name=fx11_ve2_950> Rv. x. 107, 6;<br> 125, 5.</ref> [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], on the other hand, as Muir admits,<ref name=fx12_ve2_950> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 259.</ref> already denotes a hereditary professional priesthood.<br><br>Zimmer connects the change from the casteless system of the Rigveda to the elaborate system of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] with the  advance of the Vedic Indians to the east, comparing the Germanic invasions that transformed the German tribes into monarchies closely allied with the church. The needs of a conquering people evoke the monarch; the lesser princes sink to the position of nobles; for repelling the attacks of aborigines or of other Āryan tribes, and for quelling the revolts of the subdued population, the state requires a standing army in the shape of the armed retainers of the king, and beside the nobility of the lesser princes arises that of the king's chief retainers, as the Thegns supplemented the Gesiths of the Anglo-Saxon monarchies.<ref name=fx13_ve2_950> Maitland, ''Domesday Book,'' 164 ''et seq.''</ref> At the same time the people ceased to take part in military matters, and under climatic influences left the conduct of war to the nobility and their retainers, devoting themselves to agriculture, pastoral pursuits, and trade. But the advantage won by the nobles over the people was shared by them with the priesthood, the origin of whose power lies in the Purohitaship, as Roth first saw.<ref name=fx14_ve2_950> ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 117 ''et seq.''</ref><br><br>Originally the prince could sacrifice for himself and the people, but the Rigveda<ref name=fx15_ve2_950> Rv. iii. 33, 8;<br> vii. 18;<br> 83.</ref> itself shows cases, like those of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' and '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]''' illustrating forcibly the power of the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], though at the same time the right of the noble to act as [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] is seen in the case of '''[[देवापि आर्ष्टिषेण|Devāpi Ārṣṭiṣeṇa]].'''<ref name=fx16_ve2_950> [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 10, explaining Rv. x. 98.</ref> The Brahmins saw their opportunity, through the Purohitaship, of gaining practical power during the confusion and difficulties of the wars of invasion, and secured it, though only after many struggles, the traces of which are seen in the Epic tradition.<ref name=fx17_ve2_950> Lassen, ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 1^2, 705 ''et seq.;<br>'' Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 2^2, 296479.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx18_ve2_950> v. 17-19;<br> Muir, 22, 280-289.</ref> also preserves relics of these conflicts in its narration of the ruin of the '''Sṛñjayas''' because of oppressing Brahmins, and besides other hymns of the Atharvaveda (viiixii), the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]] litany of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx19_ve2_950> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 1-11 = [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 11-16 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9. 1-10.</ref> reflects the period of storm and stress when the aboriginal population was  still seething with discontent, and Rudra was worshipped as the patron god of all sorts of evil doers.<ref name=fx20_ve2_950> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 2, 22 ''et seq.;<br> Indian Literature,'' 110, 111.</ref><br><br>This version of the development of caste has received a good deal of acceptance in its main outlines, and it may almost be regarded as the recognized version.<ref name=fx21_ve2_950> See, ''e.g.,'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 152 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 159 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Kaegi, ''Rigveda,'' n. 58.</ref> It has, however, always been opposed by some scholars, such as Haug,<ref name=fx22_ve2_950> ''Brahma und die Brahmanen,'' 1871.</ref> Kern,<ref name=fx23_ve2_950> ''Indische Theorien over de Standenverdeeling,'' 1871. ''Cf.'' for this, and the preceding work, Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 22, 454 ''et seq.''</ref> Ludwig,<ref name=fx24_ve2_950> ''Die Nachrichten des Rig und Atharvaveda über Geographie, Geschichte und Verfassung des alten Indien,'' 36 ''et seq.;<br>'' Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 237-243, etc.</ref> and more recently by Oldenberg<ref name=fx25_ve2_950> ''Religion des Veda,'' 373 ''et seq.,'' and ''cf. Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 51, 267 ''et seq.''</ref> and by Geldner.<ref name=fx26_ve2_950> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 146, n.</ref> The matter may be to some extent simplified by recognizing at once that the caste system is one that has progressively developed, and that it is not legitimate to see in the Rigveda the full caste system even of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]; but at the same time it is difficult to doubt that the system was already well on its way to general acceptance. The argument from the nonbrahminical character of the '''Vrātyas''' of the Indus and Panjab loses its force when it is remembered that there is much evidence in favour of placing the composition of the bulk of the Rigveda, especially the books<ref name=fx27_ve2_950> iii. and vii.</ref> in which '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' appears with [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] and [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]], in the east, the later '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]],''' a view supported by Pischel,<ref name=fx28_ve2_950> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 218.</ref> Geldner,<ref name=fx29_ve2_950> ''Ibid.,'' 3, 152.</ref> Hopkins,<ref name=fx30_ve2_950> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 18.</ref> and Macdonell.<ref name=fx31_ve2_950> ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 145.</ref> Nor is it possible to maintain that [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] in the Rigveda merely means a ‘poet’ or ‘sage.’ It is admitted by Muir that in some passages it must mean a hereditary profession; in fact, there is not a single passage in which it occurs where the sense of ‘priest’ is not allowable, since the priest was of course the singer. Moreover, there are traces in the Rigveda of the threefold<ref name=fx32_ve2_950> Rv. viii. 35, 16-18.</ref> or fourfold<ref name=fx33_ve2_950> Rv. i. 113, 6. More doubtful are the references seen by Ludwig to the three castes in ii. 27, 8;<br> vi. 51, 2;<br> vii. 66, 10.</ref> division of the people  into ''brahma, kṣatram,'' and ''viśaḥ,'' or into the three classes and the servile population. Nor even in respect to the later period, any more than to the Rigveda, is the view correct that regards the Vaiśyas as not taking part in war. The Rigveda evidently<ref name=fx34_ve2_950> See Ludwig, ''op. cit.,'' 3, 231 ''et seq.,'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 94, 95, and see '''[[विश्|Viś]], [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]].'''</ref> knows of no restriction of war to a nobility and its retainers, but the late Atharvaveda<ref name=fx35_ve2_950> iii. 19, 1;<br> ix. 7, 9;<br> xv. 9, 2. 3.</ref> equally classes the folk with the ''bala,'' ‘power,’ representing the [[विश्|Viś]] as associated with the '''[[सभा|Sabhā]], [[सम्इति|Samiti]],''' and '''[[सेना|Senā]],''' the assemblies of the people and the armed host. Zimmer<ref name=fx36_ve2_950> ''Op. cit.,'' 194.</ref> explains these references as due to tradition only; but this is hardly a legitimate argument, resting, as it does, on the false assumption that only a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] can fight. But it is (see '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]''') very doubtful whether [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] means anything more than a member of the nobility, though later, in the Epic, it included the retainers of the nobility, who increased in numbers with the growth of military monarchies, and though later the ordinary people did not necessarily take part in wars, an abstention that is, however, much exaggerated if it is treated as an absolute one. The Kṣatriyas were no doubt a hereditary body; monarchy was already hereditary (see '''[[राजन्|Rājan]]'''), and it is admitted that the Śūdras were a separate body: thus all the elements of the caste system were already in existence. The [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], indeed, was a person of great importance, but it is clear, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx37_ve2_950> ''Religion des Veda,'' 382, 383.</ref> urges, that he was not the creator of the power of the priesthood, but owed his position, and the influence he could in consequence exert, to the fact that the sacrifice required for its proper performance the aid of a hereditary priest in whose possession was the traditional sacred knowledge.<br><br>Nor can any argument for the non-existence of the caste system be derived from cases like that of '''Devāpi.''' For, in the first place, the Upaniṣads show kings in the exercise of the priestly functions of learning and teaching, and the Upaniṣads are certainly contemporaneous with an elaborated caste system. In the second place the Rigvedic evidence is very weak, for Devāpi, who certainly acts as [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], is not stated in the  Rigveda to be a prince at all, though [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx38_ve2_950> ii. 10.</ref> calls him a [[कौरव्य|Kauravya]]; the hymns attributed to kings and others cannot be vindicated for them by certain evidence, though here, again, the Brāhmaṇas do not scruple to recognize Rājanyarṣis, or ‘royal sages’; and the famous [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] shows in the Rigveda no sign of the royal character which the Brāhmaṇas insist on fastening on him in the shape of royal descent in the line of '''[[जह्नु|Jahnu]].'''<ref name=fx39_ve2_950> See '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' and '''[[जह्नु|Jahnu]].'''</ref><br><br>''(b) Caste in the later Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas.''--The relation between the later and the earlier periods of the Vedic history of caste must probably be regarded in the main as the hardening of a system already formed by the time of the Rigveda.<br><br>1. ''Cf.'' also ''ibid.,'' i. 1, 4, 12. The scholiast on Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 6, refers these notices to the [[रथकार|Rathakāra]] alone, but this is obviously secondary.</ref> and in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx61_ve2_950> i. 1, 4, 8.</ref> there are given formulæ for the placing of the sacrificial fire not only for the three upper castes, but also for the '''[[रथकार|Rathakāra]],'''  ‘chariot-maker.’ Again, in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx62_ve2_950> vii. 19, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 6;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 6;<br> Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 81.</ref> the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is opposed as ‘eater of the oblation’ to the members of the other three castes.<br><br>The characteristics of the several castes are given under '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]''' and '''[[राजन्|Rājan]], [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]], [[शूद्र|Śūdra]]:''' they may be briefly summed up as follows: The [[विश्|Viś]] forms the basis of the state on which the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] and [[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]] rest;<ref name=fx63_ve2_950> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 7, 16;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 4.</ref> the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] and [[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]] are superior to the [[विश्|Viś]];<ref name=fx64_ve2_950> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8, 2;<br> xi. 11, 9;<br> xv. 6, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 33, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 10;<br>  [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 10, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 4, 4, 13, etc.</ref> while all three classes are superior to the Śūdras. The real power of the state rested with the king and his nobles, with their retainers, who may be deemed the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] element. Engaged in the business of the protection of the country, its administration, the decision of legal cases, and in war, the nobles subsisted, no doubt, on the revenues in kind levied from the people, the king granting to them villages (see '''[[ग्राम|Grāma]]''') for their maintenance, while some of them, no doubt, had lands of their own cultivated for them by slaves or by tenants. The states were seemingly small:<ref name=fx65_ve2_950> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 32, for the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and the later parts of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], with their traditions of Aśvamedhas, ‘horse sacrifices,’ and their recollections of the glories of the '''Bharatas,''' represent a more advanced stage of social relations and of city life, but even they hardly know really great kingdoms.</ref> there are no clear signs of any really large kingdoms, despite the mention of '''Mahārājas.''' The people, engaged in agriculture, pastoral pursuits, and trade ('''[[वणिज्|Vaṇij]]'''), paid tribute to the king and nobles for the protection afforded them. That, as BadenPowell suggests,<ref name=fx66_ve2_950> ''Indian Village Community'' and ''Village Communities in India,'' where much stress is laid on the idea of a settlement of Āryans on lands already occupied by Dravidian clans, much as Anglo-Saxon invaders on one theory occupied lands already held by Britons who became serfs, while the invaders were a landholding aristocracy, a theory supported by the fact that the normal holding of a hide is estimated at 120 acres.</ref> they were not themselves agriculturists is probably erroneous; some might be landowners on a large scale, and draw their revenues from [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] tenants, or even Āryan tenants, but that the people as a whole were in this  position is extremely unlikely.<ref name=fx67_ve2_950> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''India, Old and New,'' 222. The point is much the same as that at issue between the different schools of opinion as to early English history. Did the Āryans in India occupy the land as a people, driving out or exterminating or enslaving the Dāsas, and themselves carrying on the occupations of a people, or did they merely form a small aristocracy of superior military force, and were the Kṣatriyas the true Āryans? The evidence of the Rigveda is really fatal to the latter alternative hypothesis.</ref> In war the people shared the conflicts of the nobles, for there was not yet any absolute separation of the functions of the several classes. The priests may be divided into two classes--the Purohitas of the kings, who guided their employers by their counsel, and were in a position to acquire great influence in the state, as it is evident they actually did, and the ordinary priests who led quiet lives, except when they were engaged on some great festival of a king or a wealthy noble.<ref name=fx68_ve2_950> For the superiority of the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] to the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] or [[राजन्य|Rājanya]], see [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 11, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 21;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 1, 12;<br> 4, 4, 15;<br> xiii. 1, 9, 1;<br> 3, 7, 8;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 15, 8;<br> viii. 9, 6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 20, 12. The [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is, in his turn, dependent on the king (Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 3, 3;<br> v. 4, 2, 7), and at the [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]] sits beside him, but is none the less superior (Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, 23). The [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 5, says the [[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]] is over the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], but this is not a usual view. ''Cf.'' xxvii. 4. A [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] can get along without a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]], but not ''vice versa'' (Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 4, 6), and a [[राजन्य|Rājanya]] with a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] surpasses all other Rājanyas ([[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 10, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xix. 10;<br> xxvii. 4, etc.).</ref><br><br>The relations and functions of the castes are well summed up in a passage of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx69_ve2_950> vii. 29. See Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 1^2, 436 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 14.</ref> which treats of them as opposed to the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]. The [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is a receiver of gifts (''ā-dāyī''), a drinker of Soma (''ā-pāyī''), a seeker of food (''āvasāyī''),<ref name=fx70_ve2_950> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 9, 326;<br> 10, 14, prefers ‘moving’ or ‘dwelling’ everywhere.</ref> and liable to removal at will (''yathākāma-prayāpyaḥ'').<ref name=fx71_ve2_950> Muir, Haug, and Weber take the word as active in sense, ‘moving at will.’ But both the parallelism of the passage and the formation of the word require a passive causative sense. Hopkins, ''India, Old and New,'' 222, 223.</ref> but who is still free, and whom he cannot maim or slay without due process. Another side of the picture is presented in the Pāli literature,<ref name=fx80_ve2_950> Fick, ''Dic sociale Gliederung,'' 107 ''et seq.;<br>'' Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 53 ''et seq.;<br>'' 158.</ref> which, belonging to a later period than the Vedic, undoubtedly underestimates the position of the priests; while the Epic,<ref name=fx81_ve2_950> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 984 ''et seq.''</ref> more nearly contemporaneous with the later Vedic period, displays, despite all priestly redaction, the temporal superiority of the nobility in clear light.<br><br>Although clear distinctions were made between the different castes, there is little trace in Vedic literature of one of the leading characteristics of the later system, the impurity communicated by the touch or contact of the inferior castes,<ref name=fx82_ve2_950> See, ''e.g.'' Manu, iii. 239;<br> v. 85;<br> Fick, ''op. cit.,'' 26 ''et seq.''</ref> which is seen both directly in the purification rendered necessary in case of contact with a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]], and indirectly in the prohibition of eating in company with men of lower caste.<ref name=fx83_ve2_950> [[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 17;<br> Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 6, 18, 16 ''et seq.;<br>'' ii. 4, 9, 7, with Bühler's note;<br> Manu, iv. 210 ''et seq.;<br>'' Viṣṇu, 41, 7 ''et seq.;<br>'' Fick, ''op. cit.,'' 30-33, who points out that the Jātakas cohtain little evidence on the practice. But this is not conclusive;<br> a caste is not a ''gens,'' and the ''gens'' excluded strangers only at a solemn festival, when the whole ''gens'' renewed its blood kinship. If we have no evidence exactly establishing this for the [[गोत्र|Gotra]] in early Vedic literature, we need not nesitate to believe that in the earliest Vedic period the [[गोत्र|Gotra]] had solemn festivals of union, and of communication with the dead, but that again does not explain or amount to the caste prohibition of taking food from an inferior.</ref> It is true that prohibition of eating in company with others does appear,<ref name=fx84_ve2_950> ''E.g.,'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 3, 3. with Keith's note.</ref> but not in connexion with caste: its purpose is to preserve the peculiar sanctity of those who perform a certain rite or believe in a certain doctrine; for persons who eat of the same food together, according to primitive thought, acquire the same characteristics and enter into a sacramental communion. The process can be seen to day when new tribes fall under the caste system: each class tries to elevate itself in the social scale by refusing to intermarry with inferior classes on equal terms--hypergamy is often allowed--and so those Vaiśyas who acquired wealth in trade ('''[[श्रेष्ठिन्|Śreṣṭhin]]''') or agriculture (the Pāli Gahapatis) would become distinct, as sub-castes, from the ordinary Vaiśyas. In the Āryan view a marriage of Śūdras could hardly be regulated by rules; any [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] could wed another, if such a marriage could be called a marriage at all, for a slave cannot in early law be deemed to be capable of marriage proper. But what applied in the early Vedic period became no doubt less and less applicable later when many aboriginal tribes and princes must have come into the Āryan community by peaceful means, or by conquest, without loss of personal liberty, and when the term [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] would cover many sorts of people who were not really slaves, but were freemen of a humble character occupied in such functions as supplying the numerous needs of the village, like the '''Caṇḍālas,''' or tribes living under Āryan control, or independent, such as the '''Niṣādas.'''<br><br>But it is also probable that the Śūdras came to include men of Āryan race, and that the Vedic period saw the degradation of Āryans to a lower social status.
