''Origin of the Castes.''--The question of the origin of the castes presents some difficulty. The ultimate cause of the extreme rigidity of the caste system, as compared with the features of any other Āryan society, must probably be sought in the sharp distinction drawn from the beginning between the Āryan and the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]]. The contrast which the Vedic Indians felt as existing between themselves and the conquered population, and which probably rested originally on the difference of colour between the upper and the lower classes, tended to accentuate the natural distinctions of birth, occupation, and locality which normally existed among the Āryan Indians, but which among other Āryan peoples never developed into a caste system like that of India. The doctrine of hypergamy which marks the practical working of the caste system, seems clearly to point to the feeling that the Āryan could marry the [[शूद्रा|Śūdrā]], but not the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] the Āryā. This distinction probably lies at the back of all other divisions: its force may be illustrated by the peculiar state of feeling as to mixed marriages, for example, in the Southern States of America and in South Africa, or even in India itself, between the new invaders from Europe and the mingled population which now peoples the country. Marriages between persons of the white and the dark race are disapproved in principle, but varying degrees of condemnation attach to (1) the marriage of a man of the white race with a woman of the dark race;  (2) an informal connexion between these two; (3) a marriage between a woman of the white race and a man of the dark race; and (4) an informal connexion between these two. Each category, on the whole, is subject to more severe reprobation than the preceding one. This race element, it would seem, is what has converted social divisions into castes. There appears, then, to be a large element of truth in the theory, best represented by Risley,<ref name=fx158_ve2_950> Best stated and summed up in ''The Peoples of India.'' See also the summary in ''The Indian Empire,'' 1, chap. 6.</ref> which explains caste in the main as a matter of blood, and which holds that the higher the caste is, the greater is the proportion of Āryan blood.<br><br>The chief rival theory is undoubtedly that of Senart,<ref name=fx159_ve2_950> ''Les Castes dans l'Inde.''</ref> which places the greatest stress on the Āryan constitution of the family. According to Senart the Āryan people practised in affairs of marriage both a rule of exogamy, and one of endogamy. A man must marry a woman of equal birth, but not one of the same ''gens,'' according to Roman law as interpreted by Senart and Kovalevsky;<ref name=fx160_ve2_950> ''Famille et Propriété Primitives,'' 19, ''et seq. Cf.'' L. de la Vallée Poussin, ''Le Védisme,'' 15 ''et seq.,'' with ''Le Brahmanisme,'' 7.</ref> and an Athenian must marry an Athenian woman, but not one of the same . In India these rules are reproduced in the form that one must not marry within the '''[[गोत्र|Gotra]],''' but not without the caste. The theory, though attractively developed, is not convincing; the Latin and Greek parallels are not even probably accurate;<ref name=fx161_ve2_950> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1909, 472.</ref> and in India the rule forbidding marriage within the [[गोत्र|Gotra]] is one which grows; in strictness as the evidence grows later in date.<ref name=fx162_ve2_950> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 74 ''et seq.''</ref><br><br>On the other hand, it is not necessary to deny that the development of caste may have been helped by the family traditions of some ''gentes,'' or , or Gotras. The Patricians of Rome for a long time declined intermarriage with the plebeians; the Athenian Eupatridai seem to have kept their pure from contamination by union with lower blood; and there may well have been noble families among the Vedic Indians who intermarried only among themselves. The  Germans known to Tacitus<ref name=fx163_ve2_950> ''Germania,'' 7, 13, etc.</ref> were divided into ''nobiles'' and ''ingenui,'' and the Anglo-Saxons into eorls and ceorls, noble and non-noble freemen.<ref name=fx164_ve2_950> Medley, ''English Constitutional History,''^2 21 ''et seq.,'' and authorities there cited. In the formation of a kingdom minor chiefs, once petty kings, would become nobles.</ref> The origin of nobility need not be sought in the Vedic period proper, for it may already have existed. It may have been due to the fact that the king, whom we must regard as originally elected by the people, was as king often in close relation with, or regarded as an incarnation of, the deity;<ref name=fx165_ve2_950> ''E.g.,'' Frazer, ''Early History of the Kingship'' and ''The Golden Bough'' (ed. 3), Part 1., ''The Magic Art and the Evolution of Kings.'' The traces of this conception in Āryan peoples are clear--''e.g.,'' the ''rex sacrificulus'' in Rome, the sacred functions of the Archon Basileus in Athens;<br> ''cf.'' Ridgway, ''Origin of Tragedy,'' p. 29.</ref> and that hereditary kingship would tend to increase the tradition of especially sacred blood: thus the royal family and its offshoots would be anxious to maintain the purity of their blood. In India, beside the sanctity of the king, there was the sanctity of the priest. Here we have in the family exclusiveness of king and nobles, and the similar exclusiveness of a priesthood which was not celibate, influences that make for caste, especially when accompanying the deep opposition between the general folk and the servile aborigines.<br><br>Caste, once created, naturally developed in different directions. Nesfield<ref name=fx166_ve2_950> ''Brief View of the Caste System of the North-Western Provinces and Oudh,'' Allahabad, 1885.</ref> was inclined to see in occupation the one ground of caste. It is hardly necessary seriously to criticize this view considered as an ultimate explanation of caste, but it is perfectly certain that gilds of workers tend to become castes. The carpenters ('''[[तक्षन्|Takṣan]]'''), the chariot-makers ('''[[रथकार|Rathakāra]]'''), the fishermen ('''[[धैवर|Dhaivara]]''') and others are clearly of the type of caste, and the number extends itself as time goes on. But this is not to say that caste is founded on occupation pure and simple in its first origin, or that mere difference of occupation would have produced the system of caste without the interposition of the fundamental difference between Āryan and [[दास|Dāsa]] or [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] blood and colour. This difference rendered increasingly important what the history of the Āryan peoples shows us to be declining, the distinction between the noble and the non-noble  freemen, a distinction not of course ultimate, but one which seems to have been developed in the Āryan people before the separation of its various branches.<br><br>It is well known that the Iranian polity presents a division of classes comparable in some respects<ref name=fx167_ve2_950> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 243, 244.</ref> with the Indian polity. The priests (Atharvas) and warriors (Rathaesthas) are unmistakably parallel, and the two lower classes seem to correspond closely to the Pāli Gahapatis, and perhaps to the Śūdras.<ref name=fx168_ve2_950> Senart, ''op. cit.,'' 141.</ref> But they are certainly not castes in the Indian sense of the word. There is no probability in the view of Senart<ref name=fx169_ve2_950> ''Ibid.'' 140.</ref> or of Risley<ref name=fx170_ve2_950> ''Indian Empire,'' 1, 336-348.</ref> that the names of the old classes were later superimposed artificially on a system of castes that were different from them in origin. We cannot say that the castes existed before the classes, and that the classes were borrowed by India from Iran, as Risley maintains, ignoring the early [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] evidence for the four Varṇas, and treating the transfer as late. Nor can we say with Senart that the castes and classes are of independent origin. If there had been no [[वर्ण|Varṇa]], caste might never have arisen; both colour and class occupation are needed for a plausible account of the rise of caste.<ref name=fx171_ve2_950> The Indian theories of the origin of caste are merely religious or philosophical, and have no value. See for them, Rv. x. 90 (which is repeated in other Saṃhitās);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 4 ''et seq.;<br> ibid.,'' iv. 3, 10, 1-3 = [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 5 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 28-30;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 4, 3, 1 ''et seq.'' For the origin of the Brahmins, see Av. iv. 6, 1;<br> xv. 9, 1;<br> of the [[राजन्य|Rājanya]], Av. xv. 8, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 13, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Muir, 12, 8 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 217-220.<br><br>The most important collection of texts on caste are those of Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, and of Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, where practically all the data of the Brāhmaṇas are extracted;<br> there have to be added only the data of the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, which are merely confirmatory of those of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitās, The Epic materials concerning caste are given by Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, who has also analyzed the caste relations of the Mānavadharmaśāstra in ''The Mutual Relation of the Four Castes according to the Mānavadharmaśāstram. Cf.'' also Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 212 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 185 ''et seq.;<br>'' Senart, ''Les Castes dans l'Inde;<br>'' Barth, ''Revue de l'Histoire des Religions,'' 1894, 75 ''et seq.;<br>'' Jolly, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 507 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''ibid.,'' 51, 267-290, a valuable criticism of Senart's views;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 152 ''et seq.;<br>'' 425 ''et seq.;<br>'' Schlagintweit, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 33, 549;<br> Shridhar V. Katkar, ''History of Caste in India.'' The Jātaka evidence is all collected by Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung im nordo7stlichen Indien zu Buddha's Zeit'' (1897);<br> its value is considerable, but its date is extremely doubtful, and it certainly cannot be regarded as really contemporary with Buddha (fifth century B.C.). The [[धर्म|Dharma]] Sūtras also give full details, but the¤ir date likewise is uncertain.</ref>

<u>'''Varta.'''</u> See '''[[वर्त्र|Vartra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

Vārttika on Pāṇini, vii. 3, 45 where it is said to be ‘northern,’ as opposed to the eastern Vartakā. ''Cf.'' also Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 45, n.;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 90</ref>

In the former passage the commentator and some manuscripts have [[वर्त|Varta]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_954> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 4.</ref>

<u>'''Vardhra'''</u> denotes a ‘thong’ or ‘strap’ with which a woven couch is fastened. It is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_955> xiv. 1, 60, where the Paippalāda recension has ''varadhrā.''</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_955> v. 4, 4, 1.</ref>

वर्मन्
<u>'''Varman'''</u> denotes ‘body armour,’ ‘coat of mail,’ ‘corselet,’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_956> i. 31, 15;<br> 140, 10;<br> vi. 75, 1. 8. 18. 19;<br> viii. 47, 8;<br> x. 107, 7, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_956> Atharvaveda, viii. 5, 7 ''et seq.;<br>'' ix. 5, 26;<br> xvii. 1, 27, etc.</ref> Of what material it was made is  uncertain; there are references to sewing (''syūta'')<ref name=fx3_ve2_956> Rv. i. 31, 15;<br> x. 101, 8.</ref> which may be reckoned in favour of the use of linen corselets such as those recorded by Herodotus,<ref name=fx4_ve2_956> ''Cf.'' Hehn, ''Kulturpflanzen,''^6 167 ''et seq.;<br>'' Lang, ''Homer and his Age,'' 150 ''et seq.''</ref> but there is a later reference<ref name=fx5_ve2_956> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 298;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 222;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 34.</ref> to corselets of '''Ayas, Loha,''' or '''[[रजत|Rajata]],''' on which it is doubtful whether much stress can be laid. They may, however, have been either of metal or of leather covered with metal.

<u>'''Varṣa'''</u> denotes primarily ‘rain,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_957> Neuter: Rv. v. 58, 7;<br> 83, 10;<br> Av. iii. 27, 6;<br> iv. 15, 2, etc.</ref> then ‘rainy season’<ref name=fx2_ve2_957> Feminine plural;<br> Av. vi. 55, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 2, 3;<br> ii. 6, 1, 1;<br> v. 6, 10, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 12, etc.</ref> and ‘year.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_957> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 17, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9, 3, 19, etc.</ref>

वलग
<u>'''Valaga'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_958> v. 31, 4;<br> x. 1, 18;<br> xix. 9, 9.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_958> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 3, 2, 1 (where see Sāyaṇa's note);<br> vi. 2, 11, 1. 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ii. 11;<br> xxv. 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 23;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 4, 2.</ref> seems to denote a ‘secret spell.’

<u>'''Valśa'''</u> denotes ‘twig,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_961> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 9, 1.</ref> usually in the compounds ''śata-[[वल्श|valśa]],'' ‘having a hundred twigs,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_961> Rv. iii. 8, 11;<br> Av. vi. 30, 2, etc.</ref> or ''sahasra-[[वल्श|valśa]],'' ‘having a thousand twigs,’<ref name=fx3_ve2_961> Rv. iii. 8, 11;<br> vii. 33, 9, etc.</ref> which is applied metaphorically of ‘offspring.’<ref name=fx4_ve2_961> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 3, 5, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, etc.</ref>

''Cf. Sa-[[वश|Vaśa]]-Uśīnarāṇām'' in [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 14, 3. and n. 2.</ref> the names<ref name=fx4_ve2_963> As both derived from the root ''vaś,'' ‘desire.’<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 393, n.;<br> 407, n.</ref> seem to indicate that the Vaśas and Uśīnaras were connected.

वशा
<u>'''Vaśā'''</u> denotes ‘cow’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_964> ii. 7, 5;<br> vi. 63, 9;<br> x. 91, 14, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_964> Av. iv. 24, 4;<br> x. 10, 2;<br> xii. 4, 1, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 4, 4. 5;<br> iii. 4, 2, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 4, etc.</ref> According to the commentators, the word means a ‘barren cow,’ but this is not a necessary sense except in a few passages.<ref name=fx3_ve2_964> Av. vii. 113, 2, where the '''[[परिवृक्ता|Parivṛktā]],''' ‘rejected wife,’ is compared with a [[वशा|Vaśā]]. <u>'''Vasāvi'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_968> x. 73, 4.</ref> denotes, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_968> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> a ‘treasure house.’

वसिष्ठ
<u>'''Vasiṣṭha'''</u> is the name of one of the most prominent priestly figures of Vedic tradition. The seventh Maṇḍala of the Rigveda is ascribed to him; this ascription is borne out by the fact that the Vasiṣṭhas<ref name=fx1_ve2_969> Rv. vii. 7, 7;<br> 12, 3;<br> 23, 6;<br> 33, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' 37, 4;<br> 39, 7;<br> 40, 7;<br> 76, 6. 7;<br> 77, 6;<br> 80, 1;<br> 90, 7;<br> 91, 7;<br> x. 15, 8;<br> 66, 14;<br> 122, 8.</ref> and [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_969> Rv. vii. 9, 6;<br> 13, 4. 21;<br> 22, 3;<br> 23, 1;<br> 26, 5;<br> 33, 11 ''et seq.;<br>'' 42, 6;<br> 59, 3;<br> 70, 6;<br> 73, 3;<br> 86, 5;<br> 88, 1;<br> 95, 6;<br> 96, 1;<br> x. 65, 15;<br> 150, 5;<br> i. 112, 9.</ref> are frequently mentioned in that Maṇḍala, besides being sometimes referred to elsewhere. That by the name [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] a definite individual is always meant is most improbable, as Oldenberg<ref name=fx3_ve2_969> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 204 ''et seq. Cf.'' vii. 23, 1 (singular) with verse 6 (plural).</ref> shows; [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] must normally mean simply ‘a [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]].’ But it is not necessary to deny that a real [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] existed, for one hymn<ref name=fx4_ve2_969> Rv. vii. 18. As to vii. 33, Oldenberg and Geldner differ. See ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 130. But it is rather doubtful whether it can possibly be said to be as early as vii. 18, or to have any claim to be really an utterance of [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]].</ref> seems to show clear traces of his authorship, and of his assistance to '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' against the ten kings.<br><br>The most important feature of Vasiṣṭha's life was apparently  his hostility to '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]].''' The latter was certainly<ref name=fx5_ve2_969> See Rv. iii. 33. 53;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 328 ''et seq.''</ref> at one time the '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]]''' (‘domestic priest’) of [[सुदास्|Sudās]], but he seems to have been deposed from that post, to have joined Sudās' enemies, and to have taken part in the onslaught of the kings against him, for the hymn of Sudās' triumph<ref name=fx4_ve2_969/> has clear references to the ruin [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] brought on his allies.<ref name=fx6_ve2_969> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 260 ''et seq.''</ref> Oldenberg,<ref name=fx7_ve2_969> ''Op. cit.,'' 204, n. 3.</ref> however, holds that the strife of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] and [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] is not to be found in the Rigveda. On the other hand, Geldner<ref name=fx8_ve2_969> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 158 ''et seq.''</ref> is hardly right in finding in the Rigveda<ref name=fx9_ve2_969> iii. 53, 15. 16. 21-24, the last four verses being the famous ''Vasiṣṭhadveṣiṇyaḥ,'' which [[दुर्ग|Durga]], the commentator on the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], declines to explain, because he was a Kāpiṣṭhala [[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] (see Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 12, 344;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, iv. 117 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes). What the verses really mean is not at all certain. See Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 254 ''et seq.''</ref> a compressed account indicating the rivalry of '''[[शक्ति|Śakti]],''' Vasiṣṭha's son, with [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]], the acquisition by [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] of special skill in speech, and the revenge of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]], who secured the death of [[शक्ति|Śakti]] by Sudās' servants, an account which is more fully related by Ṣaḍguruśiṣya,<ref name=fx10_ve2_969> ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa on Rv. vii. 32, and Macdonell's edition of the Sarvānukramaṇī, 107;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 119.</ref> which appeared in the Śāṭyāyanaka,<ref name=fx11_ve2_969> See the note in the Anukramaṇī on vii. 32, where both the Tāṇḍaka and the Śāṭyāyanaka are quoted (Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 12, 328).</ref> and to which reference seems to be made in the brief notices of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx12_ve2_969> vii. 4, 7, 1. In iii. 1, 7, 3;<br> v. 4, 11, 3, also [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] is a foe of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]].</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx13_ve2_969> iv. 7, 3;<br> viii. 2, 3;<br> xix. 3, 8;<br> xxi. 11, 2. The story is alluded to in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 8, and in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 150;<br> iii. 26. 83. 149. 204. In ii. 390 it is definitely stated, as in the Śāṭyāyanaka (n. 10), that [[शक्ति|Śakti]] was cast into the fire by the Saudāsas.</ref> regarding Vasiṣṭha's sons having been slain, and his overcoming the Saudāsas. But it is important to note that no mention is made in these authorities of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] himself being actually opposed to [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], while in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx14_ve2_969> vii. 34, 9;<br> viii. 21, 11. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 11, 14.</ref> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] appears as the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] and consecrator of [[सुदास्|Sudās]] [[पैजवन|Paijavana]]. [[यास्क|Yāska]]<ref name=fx15_ve2_969> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 24;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxvi. 12, 13.</ref> recognizes [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] as the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of [[सुदास्|Sudās]]; this accords with what seems to have been the fact  that [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] originally held the post. Probably, however, with the disappearance of [[सुदास्|Sudās]], [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] recovered his position, whereupon [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] in revenge for the murder of his sons secured in some way unspecified the defeat of the Saudāsas.<ref name=fx16_ve2_969> Roth, ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 121 ''et seq.,'' considered that the Vasiṣṭhas were finally successful in the effort to remove the Viśvāmitras from favour. Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 120;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 34, doubted this, and Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 12, 371-375, held the problem to be insoluble. Roth and Muir, however, both complicated the question by regarding the Bharatas as enemies of the Tṛtsus, which (see '''[[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]]''') is not at all probable, though it is still the view of Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 41, 42.</ref><br><br>At any rate it is hardly necessary to suppose that the enmity of the Saudāsas and Vasiṣṭhas was permanent. There is evidence<ref name=fx17_ve2_969> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 4, 24;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 34.</ref> that the Bharatas had the Vasiṣṭhas as Purohitas, while other versions<ref name=fx18_ve2_969> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 2, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 17.</ref> regard them as Purohitas for people (''prajāḥ'') generally. It seems that the Vasiṣṭhas were pioneers in adopting the rule that Purohitas should act as [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] priest<ref name=fx19_ve2_969> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] was [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] at the sacrifice of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]],''' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 16;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 21, 4.</ref> at the sacrifice: the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx20_ve2_969> xii. 6, 1, 41. ''Cf.'' iv. 6, 6, 5.</ref> states that the Vasiṣṭhas were once the only priests to act as Brahmans, but that later any priest could serve as such.<ref name=fx21_ve2_969> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 35.</ref> A rivalry with Jamadgni and [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] is reported in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx22_ve2_969> iii. 1, 7, 3. ''Cf.'' n. 11.</ref> [[पराशर|Parāśara]] and [[शतयातु|Śatayātu]] are associated with [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx23_ve2_969> vii. 18, 21.</ref> being apparently, as Geldner<ref name=fx24_ve2_969> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 132.</ref> thinks, the grandson and a son of [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]. According to Pischel,<ref name=fx25_ve2_969> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 55 ''et seq.''</ref> in another hymn,<ref name=fx26_ve2_969> vii. 55. Aufrecht, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 337, took the hymn to refer to a lover's visit to a maiden. ''Cf.'' Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 370;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, vi. 11, with Macdonell's notes.</ref> [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] appears as attempting to steal the goods of his father Varuṇa; Geldner<ref name=fx27_ve2_969> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 138. So also [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 13;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 231, n. 97;<br> Bṛhaddevatā, v. 150. 151.</ref> also shows that the Rigveda<ref name=fx28_ve2_969> vii. 33, 11.</ref> contains a clear reference to Vasiṣṭha's being a son of Varuṇa and the nymph Urvaśī. Perhaps this explains the fact that the Vasiṣṭhas are called the '''Tṛtsus''' in one passage  of the Rigveda;<ref name=fx29_ve2_969> vii. 83, 8.</ref> for being of miraculous parentage, [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] would need adoption into a [[गोत्र|Gotra]], that of the princes whom he served, and to whom [[अगस्त्य|Agastya]] seems to have introduced him.<br><br>There are numerous other references to [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in Vedic literature,<ref name=fx30_ve2_969> Rv. i. 112, 9;<br> vii. 88, 4;<br> 96, 3;<br> x. 95, 17;<br> 181, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 19;<br> xx. 9;<br> xxxii. 2 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 478);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 12;<br> ii. 7, 9;<br> iv. 2, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 10, 5;<br> Av. iv. 29, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 18, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvi. 14;<br> xxix. 2. 3;<br> xxx. 3;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 13;<br> 15, 2;<br> 18, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 2, 2;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, 4, etc.</ref> in the Sūtras,<ref name=fx31_ve2_969> See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 89-92;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 35.</ref> and in the Epic, where he and [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] fight out their rivalry.<ref name=fx32_ve2_969> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 12, 375-414.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 131 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 31-34;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 31, 37, 53, 79, 123, 162;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 204-207.</ref>

वसु
<u>'''Vasu'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_970> iv. 17, 11. 13;<br> 20, 8;<br> vi. 55, 3;<br> viii. 13, 22, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_970> Av. vii. 115, 2;<br> ix. 4, 3;<br> x. 8, 20;<br> xiv. 2, 8, etc.</ref> denotes ‘wealth,’ ‘property.’

वसुक्र
<u>'''Vasukra'''</u> and his wife are the reputed composers of certain hymns of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_971> x. 27-29.</ref> The ascription goes back to the Rigveda Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_971> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 2, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, i. 3.</ref>

वसु-रोचिस्
<u>'''Vasu-rocis'''</u> is a name occurring only once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_972> viii. 34, 16.</ref> in a form which may be interpreted as either plural or singular. In the former alternative it denotes a family of singers;<ref name=fx2_ve2_972> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 162.</ref> in the latter a patron.<ref name=fx3_ve2_972> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 175, n.</ref>

वस्तु
<u>'''Vastu'''</u> as a designation of time is the ‘early morning’ in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_973> i. 79, 6;<br> 104, 1;<br> 179, 1, etc. So Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxviii. 12. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 361.</ref> 

वस्त्र
<u>'''Vastra'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_974> i. 26, 1;<br> 134, 4;<br> iii. 39, 2;<br> v. 29, 15, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_974> Av. v. 1, 3;<br> ix. 5. 25;<br> xii. 3, 21, etc.</ref> denotes ‘dress,’ ‘clothing.’ See '''Yāsas.'''

वस्न
<u>'''Vasna'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_975> iv. 24, 9. where the phrase ''bhūyasā vasnam acarat kanīyaḥ'' must mean ‘with a greater price he obtained a lesser value.’ For the exact sense, ''cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 419, 420.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_975> Av. xii. 2, 36 (‘price’) = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 49 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 4, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 10, 2, where the sense seems to be ‘let us barter food and drink like wares.’ ''Cf.'' also ''vasnikā,'' ‘worth a price,’ in [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 3, 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 247;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 382.</ref> denotes the ‘price’ paid for anything or its ‘value,’ or the thing itself as an object of purchase, ‘ware.’

वहतु
<u>'''Vahatu'''</u> is the regular name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_976> i. 184, 3;<br> iv. 58, 9;<br> x. 17, 1 (= Av. iii. 31, 5);<br> 32, 3;<br> 85, 13 ''et seq.''</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_976> Av. x. 1, 1;<br> xiv. 2, 9, 12, 66, 73;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 7, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 1, 2.</ref> for the ceremonial conducting of the bride from the house of her parents to that of her husband.

वह्नि
<u>'''Vahni,'''</u> ‘carrier,’ denotes any draught animal--''e.g.,'' a ‘horse,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_977> Rv. ii. 24, 13;<br> 37, 3;<br> iii. 6, 2, etc.</ref> a ‘goat,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_977> Rv. vi. 57, 3.</ref> or an ‘ox.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_977> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 5, etc.</ref>

वह्य
<u>'''Vahya'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_978> vii. 55, 8.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_978> iv. 5, 3;<br> 20, 3;<br> xiv. 2, 30.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 154.</ref> a ‘couch’ or ‘bed’ of a comfortable kind used by women.

वाको-वाक्य
<u>'''Vāko-vākya,'''</u> ‘dialogue,’ is the name given in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_979> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 9, 20;<br> xi. 5, 6, 8;<br> 7, 5;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 1, 2, 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1.</ref> to certain portions of the Vedic texts. In one place<ref name=fx2_ve2_979> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 9, 20.</ref> the '''[[ब्रह्मोद्य|Brahmodya]]''' is said to be a dialogue; very probably in all the passages the [[ब्रह्मोद्य|Brahmodya]] is meant by this term. Geldner's  view<ref name=fx3_ve2_979> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 291.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 267;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 98, n. 3. It is certain that ‘logic’ is not meant, though Max Müller so renders it in his translation of the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].</ref> is different: he sees in the [[वाकोवाक्य|Vākovākya]] an essential part of the '''[[इतिहास|Itihāsa]]-[[पुराण|Purāṇa]],''' the dialogue or dramatic element as opposed to the narrative portion.

वाच्
<u>'''Vāc,'''</u> ‘speech,’ plays a great part in Vedic speculation, but only a few points are of other than mythological significance. Speech is in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_980> iv. 1, 3, 16. There are quite different accounts in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 11, 5. Oldenberg finds traces of the origin of the legend in Rv. viii. 100;<br> but see v. Schroeder, ''Mysterium und Mimus,'' 339 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1911, 993 ''et seq.''</ref> divided into four kinds-that of men, of animals, of birds (''vayāṃsi''), and of small creeping things (''kṣudraṃ sarīsṛpam''). The discrimination or making articulate of speech is ascribed to Indra by the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_980> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 7, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 8.</ref> The ‘speech’ of the following musical instruments-'''[[तूणव|Tūṇava]], [[वीणा|Vīṇā]], [[दुन्दुभि|Dundubhi]]'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_980> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5, 1013;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 4, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 4.</ref> --is mentioned, and in one Saṃhitā<ref name=fx4_ve2_980> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> also that of the axle of a chariot. The speech of the '''Kuru-Pañcālas''' was especially renowned,<ref name=fx5_ve2_980> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 3, 15. The difficult phrase has caused some doubt as to the sense, for ''uttarāhi vāg vadati Kurupañcālatrā'' seems to mean ‘speech in the north among the KuruPañcālas,’ this version being slightly supported by the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the passage quoted by Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xlii. n. 1. That recension, however, is not merely obscure, but it seems to couple the Kurus with the northern '''Mahāvṛṣas''' (so we must emend ''Mahāviṣeṣu''), and it cannot be relied on. Eggeling's attempt to remove the difficulty by taking ''uttarāhi'' as ‘higher’ in tone is not satisfactory. The most probable solution is that of Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 191, who takes ''Kurupañcālatrā'' to be ‘as among the Kuru-Pañcālas,’ which gives a good sense, especially when it is remembered that the northerners were probably the '''Uttara-Kurus''' in Kaśmīr, which seems to have been a home of Sanskrit (''cf.'' Franke, ''Pāli und Sanskrit,'' 89).</ref> as well as that of the northern country, according to the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx6_ve2_980> vii. 6.</ref> so that men went there to study the language. On the other hand, barbarisms in speech were known, and were to be avoided.<ref name=fx7_ve2_980> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 23. 24, where the Asuras are described as saying ''he 'lavaḥ,'' perhaps for ''he 'rayaḥ'' But the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] version is different See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East'' 26, 31, n. 3.</ref> <br><br>One division of speech referred to<ref name=fx8_ve2_980> See [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 11, 5 (where the words ''yaś ca veda vaś ca na'' replace the ordinary distinction of ''daivī'' and ''mānuṣī:'' perhaps ''vedo'' should be read);<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 2, 1, 34;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 18, 13;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 3, 1;<br> a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xiii. 9, etc.</ref> is that of the divine (''daivī'') and the human (''mānuṣī''), of which some specimens are given, such as ''om,'' the divine counterpart of ''tathā,'' and so forth. The Brahmin is said to know both;<ref name=fx9_ve2_980> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.,'' etc.</ref> it seems best to regard the distinction not as between Sanskrit and Apabhraṃśa, as Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx10_ve2_980> See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 200, n.</ref> suggests, but as between the Sanskrit of the ritual and the hymns and that of ordinary life.<br><br>Reference is also made to Āryan<ref name=fx11_ve2_980> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 9.</ref> and to Brahmin<ref name=fx12_ve2_980> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 5, 2.</ref> speech, by which Sanskrit, as opposed to non-Āryan tongues, seems to be meant. The '''Vrātyas''' are described as speaking the language of the initiated (''dīkṣita-[[वाच्|vāc]]''), though not themselves initiated (''a-dīkṣita''), but as calling that which is easy to utter (''a-durukta''), difficult to utter.<ref name=fx13_ve2_980> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 34, 35;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 175-180;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 179, 180;<br> 196.</ref> This may mean that the non-Brahminical Indians were advancing more rapidly than the Brahminical tribes to Prākrit speech, especially if it is legitimate to connect the Vrātyas with the barbarians in speech alluded to in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx7_ve2_980/>

वाचक्नवी
<u>'''Vācaknavī,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vacaknu,’ is the patronymic of a woman with the further patronymic of '''Gārgī,''' who appears as a student of '''[[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_981> iii. 6, 1;<br> 8, 1. ''Cf.'' Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10;<br> Atharvaveda Parisiṣṭa, xliii. 4, 23.</ref>

वाज
<u>'''Vāja'''</u> from the meaning of ‘strength,’ ‘speed,’ in its application to horses derives the sense of ‘race’<ref name=fx1_ve2_982> Rv. ii. 23, 13;<br> iii. 11, 9;<br> 37, 6;<br> 42, 6;<br> v. 35, 1;<br> 86, 2, etc.</ref> and ‘prize,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_982> Rv. i. 64, 13;<br> ii. 26, 3;<br> 31, 7;<br> iii. 2, 3;<br> viii. 103, 5, etc.</ref> or  merely ‘prosperity.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_982> Rv. i. 27, 5;<br> 92, 7;<br> vi. 45, 21. 23, etc.;<br> Av. xiii. 1, 22;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 7, 1. 12.</ref> That it ever means ‘horse’ is most improbable, that sense being given by '''[[वाजिन्|Vājin]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_982> See Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 10 ''et seq.,'' where he explains otherwise all the passages cited for the sense by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 8.</ref>

वाजपेय
<u>'''Vājapeya'''</u> is the name of a ceremony which, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_983> v. 1, 5, 2. 3.</ref> and later authorities,<ref name=fx2_ve2_983> See Weber, ''Über den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]];<br>'' Hillebrandt, ''Rituallitteratur,'' 147 ''et seq.''</ref> is only performed by a Brahmin or a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]. The same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_983> v. 1, 1, 13;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 1, 1, 2.</ref> insists that this sacrifice is superior to the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],''' but the consensus of other authorities<ref name=fx4_ve2_983> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 2, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 6, 1;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 9, 19;<br> Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 11, 1, etc.</ref> assigns to it merely the place of a preliminary to the '''[[बृहस्पतिसव|Bṛhaspatisava]]''' in the case of a priest, and to the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]]''' in the case of a king, while the Śatapatha<ref name=fx5_ve2_983> v. 2, 1, 2. ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 1, 2.</ref> is compelled to identify the [[बृहस्पतिसव|Bṛhaspatisava]] with the [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]]. The essential ceremony is a chariot race in which the sacrificer is victorious. There is evidence in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_983> xv. 1. See Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 41 ''et seq.''</ref> showing that once the festival was one which any Āryan could perform. Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx7_ve2_983> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 247.</ref> indeed, goes so far as to compare it with the Olympic games; but there is hardly much real ground for this: the rite seems to have been developed round a primitive habit of chariot racing, transformed into a ceremony which by sympathetic magic secures the success of the sacrificer. In fact<ref name=fx8_ve2_983> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, xxiv, xxv.</ref> Eggeling seems correct in holding that the [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]] was a preliminary rite performed by a Brahmin prior to his formal installation as a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], or by a king prior to his consecration. The Kuru [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]] was specially well known.<ref name=fx9_ve2_983> Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 3, 14 ''et seq.;<br>'' Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xviii. 3, 7.</ref>

वाज-बन्धु
<u>'''Vāja-bandhu'''</u> in one verse of the Rigveda (viii. 68, 19) may be a proper name. It may, however, merely be an adjective meaning ‘ally in conflict.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

वाज-रत्नायन
<u>'''Vāja-ratnāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vājaratna,’ is the patronymic of '''Somaśuṣman''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 21, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

वाज-श्रवस्
<u>'''Vāja-śravas'''</u> is mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_986> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> as a pupil of '''[[जिह्वावन्त् बाध्योग|Jihvāvant Bādhyoga]].'''

वाज-श्रवस
<u>'''Vāja-śravasa,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[वाजश्रवस्|Vājaśravas]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Kuśri''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_987> x. 5, 5, 1.</ref> It is also the patronymic of the father of '''[[नचिकेतस्|Naciketas]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_987> iii. 11, 8, 1. ''Cf.'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1, with different names, on which see Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 157, n.</ref> where the name is apparently Uśant, though it is understood by Sāyaṇa as a participle in the sense of ‘desiring.’ The Vājaśravases are in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] said to have been sages.<ref name=fx3_ve2_987> i. 3, 10, 3.</ref> They were '''Gotamas.'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_987> ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 11, 8.</ref>

वाजसनेय
<u>'''Vājasaneya'''</u> is the patronymic of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_988> vi. 3, 15;<br> 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 7;<br> 5, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_988> ii. 76 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 238).</ref> His school, the Vājasaneyins, are mentioned in the Sūtras.<ref name=fx3_ve2_988> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 12;<br> viii. 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 44, 53, 83, 283;<br> 2, 9;<br> 4, 140, 257, 309;<br> 10, 37, 76, 393, etc.</ref>

वाजिन्
<u>'''Vājin'''</u> in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_989> ii. 5, 1;<br> 10, 1;<br> 34, 7;<br> iii. 53, 23;<br> vi. 75, 6;<br> x. 103, 10, etc.</ref> denotes ‘steed’ with reference to its swiftness and strength. In one passage<ref name=fx2_ve2_989> x. 56, 2.</ref> it is perhaps, as Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve2_989> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133.</ref> thinks, a proper name, that of a son of '''[[बृहद्उक्थ|Bṛhaduktha]],''' but this view seems forced.

वाजिन
<u>'''Vājina'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_990> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 3, 10;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 21. 23.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_990> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 21;<br> iii. 3, 3, 2;<br> ix. 5, 1, 57, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 381, n. 2;<br> Garbe, Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 3, 445, calls it ‘whey.’</ref> denotes a mixture of hot fresh milk with sour milk. 

वाज्य
<u>'''Vājya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[वाज|Vāja]],’ is the patronymic of '''Ketu''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_991> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372, 383.</ref>

वाडेयी-पुत्र
<u>'''Vāḍeyī-putra.'''</u> See '''[[बाडेयीपुत्र|Bāḍeyīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वाण
<u>'''Vāṇa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_993> i. 85, 10;<br> viii. 20, 8;<br> ix. 97, 8;<br> x. 32, 4. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 67.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_993> x. 2, 17.</ref> denotes ‘instrumental music’ according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary; but in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx3_ve2_993> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 9, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx4_ve2_993> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 6, 12;<br> xiv. 7, 8;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 1, 4, etc.</ref> a ‘harp’ or ‘lyre’ with a hundred strings (''śata-[[तन्तु|tantu]]''), used at the Mahāvrata ceremony. The Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_993> x. 32, 4.</ref> clearly refers to the seven ‘notes’ (''dhātu'') of the instrument, which are called elsewhere<ref name=fx6_ve2_993> i. 164, 24;<br> iii. 1, 6;<br> 7, 1;<br> ix. 103, 3, etc.</ref> the seven Vāṇīs, unless the latter expression be taken as referring to the metres.<ref name=fx7_ve2_993> Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 64.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 289, who thinks the meaning is ‘flute’ in Rv. i. 85, 10, but not necessarily. Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 138, render it ‘voice’ in i. 85, 10;<br> ix. 97, 8, and ‘arrow’ in viii. 20, 8;<br> ix. 50, 1, and this sense is accepted in Bo7htlingk's Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1 ''[[वाण|vāṇa]]'' for ix. 50, 1.</ref>

वाणिज
<u>'''Vāṇija'''</u> denotes a ‘merchant’ as a hereditary profession (‘son of a '''[[वणिज्|Vaṇij]]'''’) in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_994> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 14, 1.</ref>

वाणी
<u>'''Vāṇī.'''</u> See '''[[वाण|Vāṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वाणीची
<u>'''Vāṇīcī'''</u> occurs in a verse of the Rigveda (v. 75, 4), where the St. Petersburg Dictionary ascribes to it the sense of ‘musical instrument.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

वात
<u>'''Vāta'''</u> is the regular word for ‘wind’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_997> i. 28, 6;<br> ii. 1, 6;<br> 38, 3;<br> iii. 14, 3, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_997> Av. iv. 5, 2;<br> v. 5, 7;<br> xii. 1, 51, etc.</ref> Five winds are mentioned.<ref name=fx3_ve2_997> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6;<br> 1, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxii. 6.</ref> In one passage<ref name=fx4_ve2_997> Rv. v. 53, 8.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_997> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 45, who compares also Rv. x. 137, 2, which refers to two winds.</ref> sees a reference to the north-east monsoon. ''Cf.'' '''[[सलिलवात|Salilavāta]].'''

वात-पान
<u>'''Vāta-pāna'''</u> (‘wind guard’) apparently means some sort of garment as protecting against wind in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vi. 1, 1, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

वात-रशन
<u>'''Vāta-raśana,'''</u> ‘wind-girt,’ is applied to the '''Munis''' in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_999> x. 136, 2.</ref> and to the [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve2_999> i. 23, 2;<br> 24, 4;<br> ii. 7, 1. Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78, was inclined, though without sufficient reason, to take the word as a proper name.</ref> Naked ascetics, such as are known throughout later Indian religious history, are evidently meant

वातवन्त्
<u>'''Vātavant'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 3, 6). He and '''[[दृति|Dṛti]]''' performed a certain Sattra or sacrificial session, but by stopping at a particular time he came to grief, and his descendants, the Vātavatas, were less prosperous than the '''Dārteyas.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वातवत
<u>'''Vātavata,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[वातवन्त्|Vātavant]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Vṛṣaśuṣma''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1001> v. 29. ''Cf. Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref> The [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1001> ii. 9.</ref> has the same form with a variant [[वाधावत|Vādhāvata]].

वात्सि
<u>'''Vātsi,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Sarpi''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vi. 24, 16).<br>==Foot Notes==

वात्सी-पुत्र
<u>'''Vātsī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]],'''’ as the name of a teacher mentioned in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers)  of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] as a pupil of '''[[पाराशरीपुत्र|Pārāśarīputra]]''' according to the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension (vi, 5, 2), as a pupil of '''[[भारद्वाजीपुत्र|Bhāradvājīputra]]''' according to the Mādhyaṃdina (vi. 4, 31).<br>==Foot Notes==

वात्सी-माण्डवी-पुत्र
<u>'''Vātsī-[[माण्डवी|Māṇḍavī]]-putra'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[पाराशरीपुत्र|Pārāśarīputra]],''' according to the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30).<br>==Foot Notes==

वात्स्य
<u>'''Vātsya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]],'''’ is the name of one or more teachers. One is mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1005> viii. 3.</ref> where the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve2_1005> iii. 2, 3.</ref> in the parallel passage has '''[[बाध्व|Bādhva]].''' Others occur in the Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] as pupils of '''Kuśri,'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1005> vi. 5, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]],'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1005> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 5, 9.</ref> or another [[वात्स्य|Vātsya]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_1005> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> while a [[वात्स्य|Vātsya]] is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx6_ve2_1005> ix. 5, 1, 62.</ref>

वात्स्यायन
<u>'''Vātsyāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[वात्स्य|Vātsya]],'''’ is the name of a teacher in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (i. 7, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

वादन
<u>'''Vādana'''</u> denotes the plectrum of a harp in the Āraṇyakas of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1007> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 9;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 3, 14, etc.</ref>

वादित
<u>'''Vādita'''</u> is found denoting ‘music’ in the compound ''gītavādita,'' ‘song and music,’ in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (viii. 2, 8), and uncompounded in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxix. 5) along with '''Nṛtya,''' ‘dance,’ and Gīta, ‘song.’ See '''[[शिल्प|Śilpa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वाधावत
<u>'''Vādhāvata'''</u> is a various reading in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1009> ii. 9. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 215, n.;<br> 2, 293, n.</ref> for '''[[वातावत|Vātāvata]].''' 

वाधूय
<u>'''Vādhūya'''</u> denotes the garment of the bride worn at the marriage ceremony and afterwards given to a Brahmin.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1010> Rv. x. 85, 34;<br> Av. xiv. 2, 41. ''Cf.'' [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], lxxix. 21;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 8, 12, etc.</ref>

वाध्र्यश्व
<u>'''Vādhryaśva,'''</u> ‘connected with '''[[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]],'''’ is apparently the epithet of Agni in a hymn of the Rigveda (x. 69, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

वानस्पत्य
<u>'''Vānaspatya'''</u> (as a masculine) in one or two passages of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1012> viii. 8, 14;<br> xi. 9, 24. ''Cf.'' xii. 1, 27.</ref> seems to denote a ‘small tree.’ Elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve2_1012> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 7, 2;<br> 3, 1, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 16, 1.</ref> (as a neuter) it has the sense of the ‘fruit of a tree’ ('''[[वनस्पति|Vanaspati]]''').

वाम-कक्षायण
<u>'''Vāma-kakṣāyaṇa'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[वात्स्य|Vātsya]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1013> x. 6, 5, 9. ''Cf.'' vii. 2, 1, 11.</ref> or '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1013> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 5, 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]. ''Cf.'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 4, 1, 11.</ref> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].

वाम-देव
<u>'''Vāma-deva'''</u> is credited<ref name=fx1_ve2_1014> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 2, 1, etc.</ref> by tradition with the authorship of the fourth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda, and he is once mentioned in that Maṇḍala.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1014> iv. 16, 18.</ref> He is, moreover, credited with the authorship of the fourth hymn of the Maṇḍala by the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1014> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 11;<br> iii. 2, 6.</ref> He there appears as a son of '''[[गोतम|Gotama]],''' while in one hymn of the fourth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1014> iv. 4, 11.</ref> [[गोतम|Gotama]] is mentioned as the father of the singer, and in another<ref name=fx5_ve2_1014> iv. 32, 9. 12.</ref> the Gotamas occur as praising Indra. In the Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx6_ve2_1014> iv. 126 131 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell' notes.</ref> two absurd legends are narrated of [[वामदेव|Vāmadeva]]. One describes Indra as revealing himself in the form of an eagle to the seer as he cooked the entrails of a dog; the other tells of his successful conflict with Indra, whom he sold among the seers. Sieg<ref name=fx7_ve2_1014> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 76 ''et seq.''</ref> has endeavoured to trace these tales in the  Rigveda,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1014> Rv iv. 27 and iv. 24 respectively. On the former hymn, see Oldenberg, ''Ṛigveda-Noten,'' 1, 291 ''et seq.;<br>'' on the latter, ''ibid.,'' 419 ''et seq.''</ref> but without any success. Moreover, though [[वामदेव|Vāmadeva]] is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx9_ve2_1014> See Av. xviii. 3, 15. 16.</ref> and often in the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1014> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 30, 2;<br> vi. 18, 1. 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 5, 1 (= [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 5, where [[वामदेव|Vāmadeva]] is credited with knowledge before birth);<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = i. 4, 10 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 9, 27.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 123, 124;<br> Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1894, 789 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 215.</ref> he never figures there as a hero of these legends.

वायत
<u>'''Vāyata,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vayant,’ is the patronymic of '''Pāśadyumna''' in the Rigveda (vii. 33, 2). ''Cf.'' '''Vyant.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वायस
<u>'''Vāyasa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1016> i. 164, 32.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1016> In a Vedic citation in [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 17;<br> and in verse 1 of [[खिल|Khila]] after Rv. v. 51.</ref> denotes a ‘large bird.’ The sense of ‘crow’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1016> The only sense of the word in the post-Vedic language.</ref> occurs in the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] only.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1016> vi. 8.</ref>

वायो-विद्यिक
<u>'''Vāyo-vidyika,'''</u> ‘bird-catcher,’ is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1017> xiii. 4, 3, 13. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 369, n. 5.</ref>

वाय्य
<u>'''Vāyya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[वय्य|Vayya]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[सत्यश्रवस्|Satyaśravas]]''' in the Rigveda (v. 79, 1. 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

वार्
<u>'''Vār'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1019> i. 116, 22;<br> ii. 4, 6;<br> x. 12, 3;<br> 99, 4;<br> 105, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1019> Av. iii. 13, 8;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 1, 9, etc.</ref> denoting ‘water.’ In some passages<ref name=fx3_ve2_1019> Rv. iv. 19, 4;<br> viii. 98, 8;<br> ix. 112, 4.</ref> ‘stagnant water,’ ‘pond,’ is meant.

वारकि
<u>'''Vāraki,'''</u> ‘descendant of Varaka,’ is the patronymic of '''[[कंस|Kaṃsa]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1). <br>==Foot Notes==

वारक्य
<u>'''Vārakya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Varaka,’ is the patronymic, in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], of '''[[कंस|Kaṃsa]], Kubera, [[जनश्रुत|Janaśruta]], [[जयन्त|Jayanta]],''' and '''Proṣṭhapad.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वारण
<u>'''Vāraṇa'''</u> in two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1022> viii. 33, 8;<br> x. 40, 4.</ref> is taken by Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1022> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1''c.''</ref> as an adjective with '''[[मृग|Mṛga]],''' meaning ‘wild beast.’ But the sense intended must have been ‘elephant,’ the usual sense of [[वारण|Vāraṇa]] in the classical literature. Probably the feminine Vāraṇī in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1022> v. 14, 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Pischel and Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xv. 100-102;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 296;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 467;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 80.</ref> likewise denotes a ‘female elephant.’

वारुणि
<u>'''Vāruṇi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Varuṇa,’ is the patronymic of '''[[भृगु|Bhṛgu]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1023> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 34, 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 1, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, etc.</ref>

वार्कलि
<u>'''Vārkali,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vṛkalā,’ is the metronymic of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1024> xii. 3, 2, 6.</ref> The name in the form of Vārkalin has been seen in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1024> iii. 2, 2, and Keith's note;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 33, 123, who thinks [[वार्कलि|Vārkali]] is equivalent to Vāṣkali.</ref> but wrongly.

वार्कारुणी-पुत्र
<u>'''Vārkāruṇī-putra'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[आर्तभागीपुत्र|Ārtabhāgīputra]],''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1025> vi. 4, 31 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]], where also [[वार्कारुणीपुत्र|Vārkāruṇīputra]] is duplicated, one being the pupil of the other).</ref>

वार्ध्रा-णस
<u>'''Vārdhrā-ṇasa,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1026> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 20, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 20.</ref> '''Vārdhrī-nasa'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1026> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 39 (Prātiśākhya, iii. 89;<br> vi. 28).</ref> is the name of an animal in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the  [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās. The meaning seems to be, as taken by Sāyaṇa,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1026> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> ‘rhinoceros.’ Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx4_ve2_1026> Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 80.</ref> quotes as other interpretations ‘an old white he-goat’ or ‘a kind of crane.’

वार्ष-गण
<u>'''Vārṣa-gaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[वृषगण|Vṛṣagaṇa]],’ is the patronymic of '''[[असित|Asita]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1027> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

वार्षगणी-पुत्र
<u>'''Vārṣagaṇī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of [[वृषगण|Vṛṣagaṇa]],’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[गौतमी-पुत्र|Gautamī-putra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 31).<br>==Foot Notes==

वार्ष-गण्य
<u>'''Vārṣa-gaṇya,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[वृषगण|Vṛṣagaṇa]],’ is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1029> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372;<br> [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 9;<br> vi. 7, etc. ''Cf.'' Garbe. ''Sāṃkhya Philosophie,'' 36.</ref>

वार्षा-गिर
<u>'''Vārṣā-gira,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vṛṣāgir,’ is the patronymic of '''[[अम्बरीष|Ambarīṣa]], [[ऋज्राश्व|Ṛjrāśva]], [[भयमान|Bhayamāna]]. [[सहदेव|Sahadeva]],''' and '''[[सुराधस्|Surādhas]],''' in the Rigveda (i. 100, 17).<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 113.<br>==Foot Notes==

वार्ष्ण
<u>'''Vārṣṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[वृषन्|Vṛṣan]] or Vṛṣṇi or Vṛṣṇa,’ is the patronymic of '''[[गोबल|Gobala]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1031> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 11, 9, 3;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 1.</ref> and '''Barku,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1031> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 10;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 8, where the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension (iv. 1, 4) has a ''varia lectio'' '''[[वार्ष्म|Vārṣma]].'''</ref> and of '''[[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1031> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 4.</ref>

वार्ष्णि-वृद्ध
<u>'''Vārṣṇi-vṛddha,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vṛṣṇivṛddha,’ is the patronymic of '''Ula''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

वार्ष्णेय
<u>'''Vārṣṇeya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vṛṣṇi,’ is the patronymic of '''Śūṣa''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 10, 9, 15). <br>==Foot Notes==

वार्ष्ण्य
<u>'''Vārṣṇya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vṛṣṇi, is the patronymic of a man in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1034> iii. 1, 1, 4. The [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension omits the name. See Eggeling ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 2, n. 2.</ref>

वार्ष्म
<u>'''Vārṣma.'''</u> See '''[[वार्ष्ण|Vārṣṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वाल
<u>'''Vāla'''</u> denotes a ‘hair sieve’ in the later Saṃhitās and he Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1036> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 88;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 3, 11;<br> 8, 1. 14, etc.</ref>

वाल-खिल्य
<u>'''Vāla-khilya'''</u> is the term applied in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1037> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 15, 1, 3, 4;<br> vi. 24, 1. 4. 5. 10. 11;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 4. 8;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 11, 3;<br> xiv. 5, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, v. 2, 4, etc.;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 9.</ref> to the supplementary hymns inserted after Rigveda viii. 48. The [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] of these hymns are so named in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1037> i. 23.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 220;<br> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, xlvi ''et seq.;<br>'' Bṛhaddevatā, vi. 84 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes;<br> Scheftelowitz, ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 35 ''et seq.''</ref> ''Cf.'' 2. '''[[खिल|Khila]].'''

वाल-दामन्
<u>'''Vāla-dāman'''</u> denotes a ‘horse-hair strap’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 3, 1, 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

वालिशिखायनि
<u>'''Vāliśikhāyani'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1039> vii. 21. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 49, n. 5.</ref>

वावाता
<u>'''Vāvātā'''</u> is in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1040> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 22, 1. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 15 4, 1, 8;<br> 5, 2, 6, etc.</ref> the name of the king's ‘favourite’ wife. inferior to the '''[[महिषी|Mahiṣī]]''' only. 

वाशिता
<u>'''Vāśitā'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1041> v. 20, 2.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1041> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 9, 9;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 18, 10;<br> 21, 14, etc.</ref> denotes a cow desiring the bull.

वाशी
<u>'''Vāśī'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda both as a weapon of the Maruts<ref name=fx1_ve2_1042> i. 37, 2;<br> 88, 3;<br> v. 53, 4.</ref> and as held by the god [[त्वष्टृ|Tvaṣṭṛ]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1042> viii. 29, 3.</ref> as well as in other mythical surroundings.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1042> viii. 12, 12;<br> x. 53, 10;<br> 101, 10 (of the stones with which the Soma plant is manipulated), all doubtful passages.</ref> It is used, however, in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1042> x. 6, 3 (where the manuscripts all have ''vāsyā:'' perhaps this is really a different word).</ref> of the carpenter's knife; here it may mean ‘awl,’ in accordance with Sāyaṇa's view.(**  5 Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 301.

वासः-पल्पूली
<u>'''Vāsaḥ-palpūlī,'''</u> ‘washer of clothes,’ is the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1043> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 7, 1.</ref>

वासस्
<u>'''Vāsas'''</u> is the most usual word in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1044> i. 34, 1;<br> 115, 4;<br> 162, 16;<br> viii. 3, 24;<br> x. 26, 6;<br> 102, 2, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1044> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 9, 7;<br> 11, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 32;<br> xi. 40;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, etc. A garment of [[कुश|Kuśa]] grass is mentioned in Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 1, 8, as worn by the wife of the sacrificer at the consecration, but it is doubtful whether such dresses were normally worn. ''Cf.'' also ''kausumbha-[[परिधान|paridhāna]],'' ‘a silken garment,’ [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xi. 4.</ref> for ‘clothing.’ Clothes were often woven of sheep's wool (''cf.'' '''[[ऊर्णा|Ūrṇā]]'''); the god Pūṣan is called a ‘weaver of garments’ (''vāsevāya'')<ref name=fx3_ve2_1044> Rv. x. 26, 6.</ref> because of his connexion with the fashioning of forms. The garments worn were often embroidered (''cf.'' '''Peśas'''), and the Maruts are described as wearing mantles adorned with gold.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1044> Rv. v. 55, 6 (''hiraṇyayān athān'').</ref> When the ‘giver of garments’ (''vāso-dā'')<ref name=fx5_ve2_1044> Rv. x. 107, 2. ''Cf. [[वस्त्र|vastra]]-dā,'' v. 24, 8.</ref> is mentioned along with the giver of horses and gold, ornamental garments are probably meant. There are several references in the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve2_1044> Rv. i. 85, 1;<br> 92, 4;<br> ix. 96, 1, x. 1, 6.</ref> to the Indians' love of ornament, which is attested by Megas-  thenes for his day.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1044> See Strabo, p. 709;<br> Arrian, ''Indica,'' v. 9.</ref> The Rigveda also presents epithets like ''[[सु-वसन|su-vasana]]''<ref name=fx8_ve2_1044> Rv. ix. 97, 50.</ref> and ''su-[[रभि|rabhi]],''<ref name=fx9_ve2_1044> With ''atka,'' vi. 29, 3;<br> x. 123, 7. this word may possibly indicate that early Vedic dress was fitted like the Minoan style of dress, and unlike the later Achæan style as seen in Homer (''cf.'' Lang, ''The World of Homer,'' 60 ''et seq.'').</ref> implying that garments were becoming or well-fitting.<br><br>The Vedic Indian seems often to have worn three garments-an undergarment (''cf.'' '''[[नीवि|Nīvi]]'''),<ref name=fx10_ve2_1044> Av. viii. 2, 16;<br> xiv. 2, 50. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 1, 3;<br> Vājasanevi Saṃhitā, iv. 10, etc.</ref> a garment,<ref name=fx11_ve2_1044> [[वासस्|Vāsas]] in the narrower sense, Av. viii. 2, 16.</ref> and an overgarment (''cf.'' '''Adhīvāsa'''),<ref name=fx12_ve2_1044> Rv. i. 140, 9;<br> 162, 16;<br> x. 5, 4.</ref> which was presumably a mantle, and for which the names '''Atka''' and '''[[द्रापि|Drāpi]]''' also seem to be used. This accords with the description of the sacrificial garments given in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx13_ve2_1044> v. 3, 5, 20 ''et seq.'' See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 85 ''et seq.''</ref> which comprise a '''[[तार्प्य|Tārpya]],''' perhaps a ‘silken undergarment’; secondly, a garment of undyed wool, and then a mantle, while the ends of the turban, after being tied behind the neck, are brought forward and tucked away in front. The last point would hardly accord with the usual practice in ordinary life, but seems to be a special sacrificial ritual act. A similar sort of garments in the case of women appears to be alluded to in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx14_ve2_1044> viii. 2, 16;<br> xiv. 2, 50.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx15_ve2_1044> v. 2, 1, 8.</ref> There is nothing to show exactly what differences there were between male and female costume, nor what was exactly the nature of the clothes in either case.<br><br>It is important to note that the Vedic Indian evidently assumed that all civilized persons other than inspired Munis would wear clothing of some sort.<ref name=fx16_ve2_1044> ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 1;<br> and iii. 1, 2, 13-17, where the fact that man alone wears clothes is accounted for by a silly legend.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 261, 262.</ref><br><br>See also '''[[वसन|Vasana]], [[वस्त्र|Vastra]], Otu, [[तन्तु|Tantu]].''' For the use of skin garments, see '''Mala.'''

वासिष्ठ
<u>'''Vāsiṣṭha,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[सात्यहव्य|Sātyahavya]],''' a teacher mentioned several times in the later  Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1045> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6, 2, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 17 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 474);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 9;<br> iv. 8, 7. For his enmity to '''Atyarāti,''' see [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 23, 9, 10.</ref> of '''Rauhina''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1045> i. 12, 7.</ref> and of '''[[चैकितानेय|Caikitāneya]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1045> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 42, 1;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 384. ''Cf.'' Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 10.</ref> Moreover, reference is made to the claim of the Vāsiṣṭhas to be [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] priest at the sacrifice.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1045> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 2, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 17;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 6, 1, 41. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 34;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 212, n. (correcting the rendering of Delbrück, ''Altindische Syntax,'' 570).</ref> A [[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] is mentioned as a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1045> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx6_ve2_1045> iii. 15, 2.</ref>

वास्तु-पश्य
<u>'''Vāstu-paśya,'''</u> according to Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx1_ve2_1046> Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' supplement 6.</ref> a name of a [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], is a mere error for ''Vāstupasya''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1046> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 61.</ref> in the Jaiminiya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1046> iii. 120.</ref>

वाह
<u>'''Vāha'''</u> is found in the Rigveda (iv. 57, 4. 8) and the Atharvaveda (vi. 102, 1) apparently denoting an ox for ‘drawing’ the plough. See also '''[[रथवाहन|Rathavāhana]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वाहन
<u>'''Vāhana'''</u> (neut.) in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1048> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 9, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 9;<br> ii. 1, 4, 4;<br> iv. 4, 4, 10.</ref> denotes a ‘beast of burden,’ or occasionally<ref name=fx2_ve2_1048> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4, 2, 11.</ref> a ‘cart.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[रथवाहन|Rathavāhana]].'''

वाहस
<u>'''Vāhasa,'''</u> ‘boa constrictor,’ is included in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1049> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 13, 1;<br> 14, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 15;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 34. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94.</ref> 

वि
<u>'''Vi'''</u> in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1050> ii. 29, 5;<br> 38, 7;<br> vi. 64, 6, etc.</ref> and sometimes later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1050> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 6, 15, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 87.</ref> denotes ‘bird.’

वि-ककर
<u>'''Vi-kakara'''</u> is the name of some bird, a victim at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) according to the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1051> xxiv. 20. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94;<br> in Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xx. 14, 5, ''vikira'' (with variants ''vikikira, [[विककर|vikakara]]'') is read.</ref>

वि-कङ्कत
<u>'''Vi-kaṅkata'''</u> is the name of a tree (''Flacourtia sapida''), often mentioned in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1052> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 7, 3;<br> vi. 4, 10, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xix. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 9. ''Cf.'' Av. xi. 10, 3.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1052> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 4, 10;<br> v. 2, 4, 18, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 59.</ref>

वि-क्रय
<u>'''Vi-kraya'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda (iii. 15, 4) and the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (iii. 4) denoting ‘sale.’ See '''[[क्रय|Kraya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वि-क्लिन्दु
<u>'''Vi-klindu'''</u> is the name of a disease in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1054> xii. 4. 5.</ref> Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve2_1054> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 658.</ref> suggests ‘catarrh.’

वि-घन
<u>'''Vi-ghana'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1055> iii. 2, 4, 1. The Av., vii. 28, 1, has ''[[द्रुघण|drughaṇa]].''</ref> seems to denote ‘club.’

वि-चक्षण ताण्ड्य
<u>'''Vi-cakṣaṇa Tāṇḍya'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[गर्दभीमुख|Gardabhīmukha]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1056> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

वि-चारिन् काबन्धि
<u>'''Vi-cārin Kābandhi'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Kabandha'''’) is the name of a mythical teacher in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1057> i. 2, 9, 18. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 176, n. 4;<br> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 111, 112.</ref> 

वि-चृत्
<u>'''Vi-cṛt'''</u> in the dual is found in three passages of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1058> ii. 8, 1;<br> vi. 110, 2;<br> 121, 3. See also iii. 7, 4.</ref> where Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1058> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> sees in the term the name of two stars, while in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_1058> iv. 4, 10, 2.</ref> he thinks they mean the '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]''' called [[मूल|Mūla]]. There can, however, be no doubt that the asterism is intended in all the passages.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1058> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 356;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 361, points out that [[विचृतौ|Vicṛtau]] are and  Scorpionis, while [[मूल|Mūla]] includes the tail as a whole.</ref>

विज्
<u>'''Vij.'''</u> See 2. '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वि-जामातृ
<u>'''Vi-jāmātṛ.'''</u> See '''[[जामातृ|Jāmātṛ]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वितस्ता
<u>'''Vitastā,'''</u> the most westerly of the five rivers of the Panjab, is only mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1061> x. 75, 5;<br> '''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],''' ix. 26;<br> ''cf.'' Kāśikā Vṛtti on Pāṇini, i. 4, 31. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 12;<br> ''Imperial Gazetteer of India,'' 14, 160.</ref> in the Nadīstuti (‘Praise of Rivers’).<ref name=fx2_ve2_1061> The rareness of the name in the Rigveda points to the Panjab not having been the seat of the activity of the greater part of the Vedic Indians.</ref> It is the Hydaspes of Alexander's historians, more correctly reproduced by Ptolemy as Bidaspes. The name appears in the Mohammedan historians corrupted to Bihat or Wihat, and survives in the modern Kashmīrī form of Veth.

वित्त
<u>'''Vitta'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1062> v. 42, 9;<br> x. 34, 13.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1062> Av. xii. 3, 52;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 9, 2;<br> vi. 2, 4, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 11. 14, etc.</ref> denotes ‘wealth,’ ‘possessions.’ The earth is referred to in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1062> ii. 8. ''Cf.'' the name ''vasumatī'' found in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xiii. 1.</ref> as full of riches (''vittasya pūrṇā''). The doctrine that a man's greatness depends on his wealth is found as early as the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_1062> i. 4, 7, 7.</ref> The striving after wealth (''vittaiṣaṇā'') is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1062> iii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 4, 26.</ref> as one of the things abandoned by the sage. 

विदग्ध शाकल्य
<u>'''Vidagdha Śākalya'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a contemporary and rival of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]]''' at the court of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' of '''[[विदेह|Videha]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1063> iii. 9, 1;<br> iv. 1, 17 (Mādhyaṃdina = 7 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1063> ii. 76 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 239).</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1063> xi. 6, 3, 3.</ref>

विदथ
<u>'''Vidatha'''</u> is a word of obscure sense, confined mainly to the Rigveda. According to Roth,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1064> Rv. i. 31, 6;<br> 117, 25;<br> iii. 1, 18;<br> 27, 7;<br> iv. 38, 4;<br> vi. 8, 1;<br> x. 85, 26;<br> 92, 2;<br> Av. iv. 25, 1;<br> v. 20, 12;<br> xviii. 3, 70, etc.</ref> the sense is primarily ‘order,’ then the concrete body which gives orders, then ‘assembly’ for secular<ref name=fx2_ve2_1064> ii. 1, 4;<br> 27, 12, 17;<br> iii. 38, 5, 6;<br> v. 63, 2;<br> vii. 66, 10;<br> viii. 39, 1;<br> x. 12, 7;<br> Av. xvii. 1, 15. So Whitney renders the word in Av. i. 13, 4, as ‘council,’ Translation of the Atharvaveda, 15.</ref> or religious ends,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1064> Rv. i. 60, 1;<br> ii. 4, 8;<br> 39, 1;<br> iii. 1, 1;<br> 56, 8, etc.</ref> or for war.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1064> Rv. i. 166, 2;<br> 167, 6;<br> v. 59, 2, etc.</ref> Oldenberg<ref name=fx5_ve2_1064> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 26 ''et seq.'' But in ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft,'' 54, 609-611, he falls back on the derivation from ''vidh,'' ‘worship.’ ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 23, n. 10.</ref> once thought that the main idea is ‘ordinance’ (from ''vi-dhā,'' ‘dispose,’ ‘ordain’), and thence ‘sacrifice.’ Ludwig<ref name=fx6_ve2_1064> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 259 ''et seq.''</ref> thinks that the root idea is an ‘assembly,’ especially of the '''Maghavans''' and the Brahmins. Geldner<ref name=fx7_ve2_1064> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 147;<br> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 52, 757;<br> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 161.</ref> considers that the word primarily means ‘knowledge,’ ‘wisdom,’ ‘priestly lore,’ then ‘sacrifice’ and ‘spiritual authority.’ Bloomfield,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1064> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 12 ''et seq.''</ref> on the other hand, insists that [[विदथ|Vidatha]] refers to the ‘house’<ref name=fx9_ve2_1064> See Rigveda, x. 85, 26. 27 (of the wife in the marriage ritual);<br> i. 117, 25;<br> ii. 1, 6;<br> Av. xviii. 3, 70.</ref> in the first place (from ''vid,'' ‘acquire’), and then to the ‘sacrifice,’ as connected with the house; this interpretation, at any rate, appears to suit all the passages. The term ''vidathya,'' once<ref name=fx10_ve2_1064> iv. 27, 2. In i. 91, 20;<br> 167, 3;<br> Av. xx. 128, 1, ''vidathya,'' ‘having an establishment,’ seems adequate.</ref> applied to the king (''samrāṭ''), might seem to be against this view, but it may refer to his being ‘rich in homesteads’; and the connexion of the woman with the [[विदथ|Vidatha]], as opposed to  the '''[[सभा|Sabhā]],''' tells in favour<ref name=fx11_ve2_1064> ''Cf.'' Av. vii. 38, 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 4.</ref> of Bloomfield's explanation. That the word ever denotes an asylum, like the house of the Brahmin,<ref name=fx12_ve2_1064> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 13, with Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 3, 35.</ref> as Ludwig<ref name=fx13_ve2_1064> ''Op. cit.,'' 3, 261.</ref> suggests, is doubtful.<ref name=fx14_ve2_1064> Rv. i. 31, 6;<br> v. 62, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 30, 27, 28, certainly does not show this clearly.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 177, who suggests that [[विदथ|Vidatha]] sometimes means (''e.g.,'' in ''vidatheṣu praśastaḥ,'' Rv. ii. 27, 12) a smaller assembly than the [[सम्इति|Samiti]]. But we have no ground to be certain that such smaller assemblies ever existed at an early date either in India or elsewhere among Āryan peoples.</ref>

विदन्वन्त् भार्गव
<u>'''Vidanvant Bhārgava'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[भृगु|Bhṛgu]]'''’) is mentioned as the seer of a Sāman or chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1065> xiii. 11, 10.</ref> and in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1065> iii. 159 ''et seq.'' (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 64).</ref>

विदर्भ
<u>'''Vidarbha'''</u> occurs in the earlier Vedic literature as the name of a place only in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1066> ii. 440 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 103, n. 3).</ref> where its '''Mācalas''' (perhaps a species of dog) are said to kill tigers.

विदर्भी-कौण्डिनेय
<u>'''Vidarbhī-Kauṇḍineya'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Vatsanapāt''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1067> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]])</ref>

वि-दिश्
<u>'''Vi-diś'''</u> denotes<ref name=fx1_ve2_1068> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vi. 19;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 4.</ref> an ‘intermediate quarter.’ See '''[[दिश्|Diś]].'''

विदीगय
<u>'''Vidīgaya'''</u> is the name of an animal in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1069> v. 6, 22, 1.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1069> iii. 9, 9, 3;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xx. 22, 13.<br><br>''Cf.''
