Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94.</ref> The commentary on the former takes it as a kind of cock (''[[कुक्कुट|kukkuṭa]]-viśeṣa''), that on the latter as a white heron (''śveta-baka''). 

विदेघ
<u>'''Videgha'''</u> is the name of a man, '''[[माथव|Māthava]],''' in the Śatapatha Brāhmana.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1070> i. 4, 1, 10 ''et seq.''</ref> It is legitimate to assume<ref name=fx2_ve2_1070> ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xli, n. 4;<br> 104, n.;<br> Weber ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170;<br> ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 13;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 134.</ref> that it is a name given to him as king of the Videghas who are the later '''Videhas.'''

विदेह
<u>'''Videha'''</u> is the name of a people who are not mentioned before the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1071> i. 4, 1, 10 ''et seq.''</ref> the legend of '''[[विदेघ|Videgha]] [[माथव|Māthava]]''' preserves clearly a tradition that in [[विदेह|Videha]] culture came from the Brahmins of the West, and that '''[[कोसल|Kosala]]''' was brahminized before [[विदेह|Videha]]. The Videhas, however, derived some fame later from the culture of their king '''[[जनक|Janaka]],''' who figures in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1071> iii. 8, 2. ''Cf.'' iv. 2, 6;<br> 9, 30;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 1, 2;<br> 6, 2, 1;<br> 3, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 9, 9.</ref> as one of the leading patrons of the [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]] doctrine. In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1071> iv. 1.</ref> the Videhas are joined with the '''Kāśis;''' in the list of peoples in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1071> viii. 14.</ref> the Videhas are passed over, probably because, with [[कोसल|Kosala]] and [[काशि|Kāśi]], they are included in the term '''Prācyas,''' ‘easterners.’ Again, in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1071> xvi. 29. 5.</ref> it is recorded that the [[काशि|Kāśi]], [[कोसल|Kosala]], and [[विदेह|Videha]] kingdoms had each the one [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], '''[[जल जातूकर्ण्य|Jala Jātūkarṇya]];''' and in another passage of the same text<ref name=fx6_ve2_1071> xvi. 9, 11. 13.</ref> the connexion between the [[विदेह|Videha]] king, '''[[पर आट्णार|Para Āṭṇāra]],''' and the [[कोसल|Kosala]] king, '''[[हिरण्यनाभ|Hiraṇyanābha]],''' is explained, while the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve2_1071> xiii. 5, 4, 4.</ref> speaks of [[पर आट्णार|Para Āṭṇāra]] as the [[कोसल|Kosala]] king, descendant of [[हिरण्यनाभ|Hiraṇyanābha]].<br><br>Another king of [[विदेह|Videha]] was '''[[नमी साप्य|Namī Sāpya]],''' mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx8_ve2_1071> xxv. 10, 17.</ref> In the Saṃhitās of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx9_ve2_1071> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 4, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 5.</ref> ‘cows of Videha’ seem to be alluded to, though the commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā merely takes the adjective ''vaidehī'' as ‘having a splendid body’ (''viśiṣṭa-deha-sambandhinī''), and the point of a place name in the expression is not very obvious. The Videhas also occur in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx10_ve2_1071> ii. 5;<br> xxi. 13.</ref> in [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]-like passages.<br><br>The boundary of [[कोसल|Kosala]] and [[विदेह|Videha]] was the '''[[सदानीरा|Sadānīrā]],'''  probably the modern Gandak<ref name=fx11_ve2_1071> ''Cf. Imperial Gaxetteer of India,'' 12, 125.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 10, 33, 53, 127, 129, etc.;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xli;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 398, 399;<br> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 26, 37;<br> Pargiter, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 19 ''et seq.''</ref> (the Kondochates of the Greek geographers), which, rising in Nepal, flows into the Ganges opposite Patna. [[विदेह|Videha]] itself corresponds roughly to the modern Tirhut.

विद्या
<u>'''Vidyā'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1072> vi. 116, 1;<br> xi. 7, 10;<br> 8, 3.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1072> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 2, 8;<br> v. 1, 7, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 23, 8. 9, etc.</ref> denotes ‘knowledge,’ especially that of the three Vedas, which are called the ''trayī [[विद्या|vidyā]],'' ‘the threefold knowledge,’ as early as the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1072> iii. 10, 11, 5. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 5, 6, etc.</ref> In a more special sense [[विद्या|Vidyā]] occurs in lists of objects of study in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_1072> xi. 5, 6, 8;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 5, 11.</ref> What exactly the expression here means is uncertain: Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx5_ve2_1072> On Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 6, 8.</ref> suggests the philosophic systems; Geldner<ref name=fx6_ve2_1072> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 290, n. 4.</ref> the first Brāhmaṇas; and Eggeling,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1072> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 98, n. 2.</ref> more probably, special sciences like the '''[[सर्पविद्या|Sarpavidyā]]''' or the '''[[विषविद्या|Viṣavidyā]].'''

विद्रध
<u>'''Vidradha'''</u> denotes a disease, ‘abscesses,’ in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1073> vi. 127, 1;<br> ix. 8, 20.</ref> According to Zimmer,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1073> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 386.</ref> it was a symptom accompanying '''[[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]].''' Later it is called Vidradhi. Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve2_1073> Translation of the Rigveda, 5, 93. ''Cf.'' Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erläuterungen,'' 42, 43.</ref> compares the obscure [[विद्रध|Vidradha]] of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1073> iv. 32, 23.</ref> where, however, the sense of the word is very uncertain.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1073> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 295.<br><br>''Cf.'' Wise, ''System of Hindu Medicine,'' 210;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 531, 602;<br> ''Atharvaveda,'' 60;<br> Grohmann, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 397;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 376.</ref>

विधवा
<u>'''Vidhavā'''</u> denotes ‘widow’ as the ‘desolate one,’ from the root ''vidh,'' ‘be bereft.’ The masculine ''vidhava'' is conjectured  by Roth<ref name=fx1_ve2_1074> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' so also Grassmann.</ref> in a difficult passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1074> x. 40, 8.</ref> where the received text presents the apparent false concord ''vidhantaṃ vidhavām,'' in which he sees a metrical lengthening for ''vidhavam,'' ‘the sacrificing widower.’ Ludwig in his version takes ''vidhantam'' as equivalent to a feminine, while Delbrück<ref name=fx3_ve2_1074> ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 443.</ref> prefers ‘the worshipper and the widow.’ Possibly ‘the widower and the widow’ may be meant; but we know nothing of the mythological allusion in question, the feat being one of those attributed to the Aśvins, and the natural reference to '''[[घोषा|Ghoṣā]]''' as ‘husbandless’ being rendered unlikely because their feat in regard to her has already been mentioned a few verses before in the same hymn.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1074> x. 40. 5.</ref> The word [[विधवा|Vidhavā]] is not of common occurrence.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1074> Rv. iv. 18, 12;<br> x. 40, 2;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 15.</ref>

विधु
<u>'''Vidhu'''</u> seems clearly to mean (as it does in the post-Vedic language) the ‘moon’ in a passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1075> x. 55, 5;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xiv. 18. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 465. That the ‘many’ are the '''Nakṣatras''' is neither certain nor even probable. The stars are an adequate explanation.</ref> where it is alluded to as ‘wandering solitary in the midst of many’ (''vidhuṃ dadrāṇaṃ samane bahūnām'').

वि-नशन
<u>'''Vi-naśana,'''</u> ‘disappearance,’ is the name of the place where the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' is lost in the sands of the desert. It is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1076> xxv. 10, 6;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 5, 30;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 15, 1;<br> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 2, 12. ''Cf.'' Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 2, 147.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1076> iv. 26.</ref> The locality is the Patiala district of the Panjab.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1076> ''Cf. Imperial Gazetteer of India,'' 22, 97.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[प्लक्ष प्रास्रवण|Plakṣa Prāsravaṇa]].'''

विप्
<u>'''Vip'''</u> in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1077> ix. 3, 2;<br> 65, 12;<br> 99, 1.</ref> refers, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1077> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> to the rods which form the bottom of the Soma filter,  and on which the straining cloth is stretched. But this explanation is very doubtful.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1077> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 203;<br> Bergaigne, ''Religion Vedique,'' 1, v;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellchaft,'' 54, 171;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 97-110.</ref>

वि-पथ
<u>'''Vi-patha,'''</u> in the description of the '''[[व्रात्य|Vrātya]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1078> Av. xv. 2, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1, 14;<br> Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6, 9;<br> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 4;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 4, 11;<br> Āpastamba Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 5, 5;<br> ''cf.'' vii. 3, 8. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 44.</ref> denotes a vehicle suited for rough roads. ''Cf.'' '''Anas.'''

विपश्चित् दृढ-जयन्त लौहित्य
<u>'''1. Vipaścit [[दृढ-जयन्त|Dṛḍha-jayanta]] Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1) as the pupil of '''[[दक्ष जयन्त लौहित्य|Dakṣa <a class="pada_vei" href="जयन्त">Jayanta]] Lauhitya».'''<br>==Foot Notes==

विपश्चित् शकुनि-मित्र पाराशर्य
<u>'''2. Vipaścit [[शकुनि-मित्र|Śakuni-mitra]] Pārāśarya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[पराशर|Parāśara]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, pupil of [[अषाढ उत्तर पाराशर्य|Aṣāḍha Uttara Pārāśarya]], in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] Brāhmana (iii. 41, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

वि-पाश्
<u>'''Vi-pāś'''</u> (‘fetterless’) is the name of a river mentioned twice in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1081> iii. 33, 1. 3;<br> iv. 30, 11. [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], xi. 48, sees in the latter passage an adjective ''vi-[[पाशिन्|pāśin]],'' but this is very improbable. See Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 294.</ref> It is the modern Beās in the Panjab, the Hyphasis, Hypanis or Bipasis of the Greeks. Its small importance for the Vedic Indians is indicated by the fact that it is never mentioned in the earlier Vedic literature except in two hymns of the Rigveda. The [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1081> ix. 26. The [[विपाश्|Vipāś]] is also mentioned in connexion with the '''[[शुतुद्री|Śutudrī]]''' in ii. 24;<br> ix. 36.</ref> preserves the notice that its earlier name was '''[[उरुञ्जिरा|Uruñjirā]],''' while the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1081> i. 2, 7.</ref> places in the middle of it the ''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]-śilāḥ.'' Pāṇinī<ref name=fx4_ve2_1081> iv. 2, 74.</ref> mentions the name, which otherwise in post-Vedic literature appears as Vipāśā. This river has changed its course considerably since ancient times.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1081> See ''Imperiat Gazctteer of India,'' 7, 138 (Beās).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 11.</ref> 

वि-पूजन शौराकि
<u>'''Vi-pūjana Śaurāki'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1082> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 3.</ref> or Saurāki<ref name=fx2_ve2_1082> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 5.</ref> is the name of a teacher in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.

विपृथु
<u>'''Vipṛthu'''</u> in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xiv. 72, 3) is apparently equivalent to the '''[[विपथ|Vipatha]],''' ‘rough cart,’ of other texts. It is probably a mere blunder.<br>==Foot Notes==

विप्र
<u>'''Vipra'''</u> seems to mean ‘inspired singer’ (from ''vip,'' ‘quiver’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1084> i. 129, 2. 11;<br> 162, 7;<br> iv. 26, 1, etc. Seven are spoken of in iii. 7, 7;<br> 31. 5;<br> iv. 2, 15, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1084> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 9, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 2, 7, etc.</ref> More especially in the later texts<ref name=fx3_ve2_1084> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 3, 12, etc.</ref> it denotes a ‘learned Brahmin.’ In the epic style it comes to mean no more than ‘Brahmin.’

विप्र-चित्ति
<u>'''Vipra-citti'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1085> ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]</ref> or '''[[विप्र|Vipra]]-jitti'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1085> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> is the name of a teacher in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].

विप्र-जन सौराकि
<u>'''Vipra-jana Saurāki'''</u> is the form of the name of '''Vipūjana''' given by the St. Petersburg Dictionaries for the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1086> xxvii. 5;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 477, gives this form, which is due to a misreading of the ligature for ''ū.''</ref>

विबाली
<u>'''Vibālī'''</u> is found once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1087> iv. 30, 12. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 12, 18.</ref> apparently as the name of an unknown stream.

विभण्डक काश्यप
<u>'''Vibhaṇḍaka Kāśyapa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[ऋष्यशृङ्ग|Ṛṣyaśṛṅga]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1088> ''Indische Studīen,'' 4, 374. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Vibhāṇḍaka,'' which is the more correct spelling (Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.'').</ref> 

वि-भिन्दु
<u>'''Vi-bhindu'''</u> is the name of a sacrificer in the Rigveda (viii. 2, 91).<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins. ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 59.<br>==Foot Notes==

विभिन्दुक
<u>'''Vibhinduka'''</u> occurs in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1090> xv. 10, 11.</ref> as the name of a man or a demon<ref name=fx2_ve2_1090> ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa, ''a.l.''</ref> from whom '''[[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]]''' drove away the cows. Hopkins<ref name=fx3_ve2_1090> ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 60, n. 1.</ref> is inclined to read Vaibhinduka as a patronymic of [[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]]. ''Cf.'' '''[[विभिन्दुकीय|Vibhindukīya]].'''

विभिन्दुकीय
<u>'''Vibhindukīya'''</u> is the name of a group of priests whose Sattra is mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1091> iii. 233 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 38).</ref>

विभीतक
<u>'''Vibhītaka'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1092> This form is the regular one after the Rigveda.</ref> and '''Vibhīdaka,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1092> Rv. vii. 86, 6;<br> x. 34, 1.</ref> the latter being the old form, denote a large tree, the ''Terminalia bellerica,'' the nut of which was used in dicing.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1092> Rv., ''loc. cit.'' See 2. '''[[अक्ष|Akṣa]].'''</ref> The wood was also used for making the<ref name=fx4_ve2_1092> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 5, 8;<br> 7, 3. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 8, 1, 16, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62;<br> Roth, ''Gurupūjākaumudī,'' 1-4;<br> Lüders, ''Das Wūrfelspiel im alten Indien,'' 17-19.</ref> sacrificial fire burn.

वि-मद
<u>'''1. Vi-mada'''</u> is credited by the Anukramaṇī (Index) with the authorship of a number of hymns of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1093> Rv. x. 20-26.</ref> This attribution is supported by the occurrence in this group of the name of the seer,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1093> Rv. x. 20, 10;<br> 23, 7.</ref> and once of his family, the Vimadas,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1093> Rv. x. 23, 6.</ref> besides the repeated refrain<ref name=fx4_ve2_1093> Rv. x. 21, 1-8;<br> 24, 1-3.</ref> ''vi vo made,'' ‘in your carouses.’ [[विमद|Vimada]] is occasionally alluded to later.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1093> Av. iv. 29, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 1.</ref> 

विमद
<u>'''2. Vimada'''</u> is mentioned in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1094> i. 51, 3;<br> 112, 19;<br> 116, 1;<br> 117, 20;<br> x. 39, 7;<br> 65, 12, From viii. 9, 15, Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 105, has inferred that [[विमद|Vimada]] and [[वत्स|Vatsa]] were identical.</ref> as a protégé of the Aśvins, who gave him a wife, '''[[कमद्यू|Kamadyū]].''' His identity with the preceding is improbable.

वि-मुक्ता
<u>'''Vi-muktā'''</u> (lit., ‘secreted’), ‘pearl,’ is found in the late Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

वि-मोक्तृ
<u>'''Vi-moktṛ'''</u> in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha<ref name=fx1_ve2_1096> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 14;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 10, 1 (''cf. vimoktrī,'') used metaphorically, ''ibid.,'' iii. 7. 14, 1).</ref> (‘human sacrifice’) denotes one who unharnesses horses from the chariot, as opposed to Yoktṛ, ‘one who yokes.’ The corresponding verbal noun Vimocana, ‘unyoking,’ is often found.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1096> Rv. iii. 53, 5, 20;<br> iv. 46, 7, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 1, 5, etc.</ref>

वि-राज्
<u>'''Vi-rāj'''</u> as a title of royalty is mentioned several times in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1097> i. 188, 5;<br> ix. 96, 18;<br> x. 166, 1, etc.;<br> Av. xii. 3, 11;<br> xiv. 2, 15, etc.</ref> but only in a metaphorical sense. As an actual title, it is asserted in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1097> viii. 14, 3.</ref> to be used by the '''Uttara Kurus''' and the '''Uttara Madras.'''

वि-रूप
<u>'''Vi-rūpa'''</u> is the name of an Aṅgirasa who is twice mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1098> i. 45, 3;<br> viii. 75, 6.</ref> and to whom certain hymns are attributed by the Anukramaṇī (Index).<br><br>^2 viii. 43 ''et seq.;'' 64.

विलिगी
<u>'''Viligī'''</u> denotes a kind of snake in the Atharvaveda (v. 13, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

विलिष्ट-भेषज
<u>'''Viliṣṭa-bheṣaja'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (Paippalāda, xx. 5, 2) denotes a remedy for a dislocation or a sprain. <br>==Foot Notes==

वि-लोहित
<u>'''Vi-lohita'''</u> is the name of a disease mentioned in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1101> ix. 8, 1;<br> xii. 4, 4</ref> Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve2_1101> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 657.</ref> thinks that ‘flow of blood from the nose’ is meant; Henry<ref name=fx3_ve2_1101> ''Les livres viii. et ix. de l' Atharvaveda,'' 105, 142.</ref> renders it ‘decomposition of the blood’; and Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve2_1101> Translation of the Atharvaveda 549.</ref> has ‘anæmia.’

वि-वध
<u>'''Vi-vadha'''</u> or '''Vī-vadha''' seems to denote a yoke borne on the shoulders to enable one to carry a weight. But it is found in the Brāhmaṇas used only metaphorically in such phrases as ''vi-[[विवध|vivadha]],''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1102> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 5, 2;<br> 7, 3;<br> ''vivīvadha,'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 19;<br> ''ubhayato -vīvadha,'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 10.</ref> ‘with the weight unequally distributed,’ and ''savīvadhatā,''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1102> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 1, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 10;<br> ''sa-vīvadha-tva,'' v. 1, 11: xxii. 5, 7, etc.</ref> ‘equality of burden.’

वि-वयन
<u>'''Vi-vayana'''</u> denotes in the Brāhmaṇas ‘plaited work,’ such as that used in a couch ('''Asandī''').<br><br>^1 [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5, 3; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇā, xii. 8, 3, 6. In the Sūtras ''vivāna'' has the same sense; Lāṭyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii, 12, 1, etc.<br>==Foot Notes==

वि-वाह
<u>'''Vi-vāha,'''</u> ‘marriage,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1104> xii. 1, 24;<br> xiv. 2, 65. The Rigvedic term is '''[[वहतु|Vahatu]].'''</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1104> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 8, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 10, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv, 27, 5, and often in the Sūtras.</ref> See '''Pati.'''

विश्
<u>'''Viś'''</u> is an expression of somewhat doubtful significance. In many passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1105> iv. 4, 3;<br> 37, 1;<br> v. 3. 5;<br> vi. 21, 4;<br> 48, 8;<br> vii. 56, 22;<br> 61, 3, 70, 3;<br> 104, 18;<br> x. 91, 2, etc.</ref> the sense of ‘settlement’ or ‘dwelling’ is adequate and probable, since the root ''[[विश्|viś]]'' means to ‘enter’ or ‘settle.’ In other passages, where the Viśaḥ  stand in relation to a prince, the term must mean ‘subject’;<ref name=fx2_ve2_1105> Rv. iv. 50, 8;<br> vi. 8, 4;<br> x. 124, 8;<br> 173, 6;<br> Av. iii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 8, 4;<br> 22, 1. 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 8, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 46;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2. 17;<br> iv. 2, 1, 3;<br> v. 3, 3, 12;<br> 4, 2, 3;<br> x. 6, 2, 1;<br> xiii. 6, 2, 8;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv, 12, etc. Many of the passages cited under note 11 may also belong here, while in Av. iii. 4, 1, etc., reference to the cantons as electing a king has been seen;<br> but see '''[[राजन्|Rājan]]''' and ''cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 179;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 303;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 113.</ref> so, for example, when the people of '''[[तृणस्कन्द|Tṛṇaskanda]]'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1105> Rv. i. 172, 3.</ref> or of the '''Tṛtsus''' are mentioned.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1105> Rv. vii. 33, 6;<br> Geldner, ''op. cit.,'' 136.</ref> Again, in some passages<ref name=fx5_ve2_1105> E.g., Rv. vi. 1, 8;<br> 26, 1;<br> viii. 71, 11;<br> ''manuṣo viśāḥ,'' vi. 14, 2;<br> viii. 23, 13;<br> ''mānuṣīḥ,'' x. 80, 6, etc.</ref> the general sense of ‘people’ is adequate; as when the Rigveda speaks of the ‘Āryan people,’<ref name=fx6_ve2_1105> Rv. x. 11, 4.</ref> or the ‘divine people,’<ref name=fx7_ve2_1105> Rv. iii. 34, 2;<br> Av. vi. 98, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 86.</ref> or the ‘Dāsa people,’ and so on.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1105> Rv. iv. 28, 4;<br> vi. 25, 2;<br> ''adevīḥ,'' viii. 96, 15;<br> ''asiknīḥ,'' vii. 5, 3, etc.</ref><br><br>Sometimes,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1105> Rv. ii. 26, 3, where it is opposed to ''jana, [[जन्मन्|janman]],'' and ''putrāḥ;<br>'' x. 84, 4, where in battle ''viśaṃ-viśam'' apparently refers to divisions of the host ''cf.'' also iv. 24, 4. ''viśo yudhmāḥ'');<br> x. 91, 2, where it is opposed to ''[[गृह|gṛha]]'' and ''jana;<br>'' Av. xiv. 2, 27, where ''gṛhebhyaḥ'' is followed by ''asyai sarvasyai viśe,'' which must mean a division less than a whole people. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 159, reckons here Rv. i. 172, 3;<br> vii. 33, 6;<br> ix. 7, 5;<br> x. 124, 8;<br> 173, 1;<br> but these cases and many others are rather instances of ‘subjects’ than of a division of the tribe such as ‘canton.’</ref> however, the [[विश्|Viś]] appear in a more special sense as a subdivision of the '''Jana''' or whole people. This is, however, not common, for in most passages one or other of the senses given above is quite possible. Moreover, it is very difficult to decide whether the [[विश्|Viś]] as a subdivision of the Jana is to be considered as being a local subdivision (canton) or a blood kinship equivalent to a clan in the large sense of the word, while the relation of the [[विश्|Viś]] to the '''[[ग्राम|Grāma]]''' or to the '''[[गोत्र|Gotra]]''' is quite uncertain. In one passage of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx10_ve2_1105> xv. 8, 2, 3, ''Cf.'' xiv. 2, 27, and Rv. x. 91, 2, in n. 9.</ref> the Viśaḥ are mentioned along with the ''sabandhavaḥ'' or relatives, but no definite conclusion can be drawn from that fact. Nor does the analogy of the Roman ''curia'' or the Greek  throw much light, as these institutions are themselves of obscure character, and the parallelism need not be cogent. It is, at any rate, possible that the [[विश्|Viś]] may in some cases have been no more than a [[गोत्र|Gotra]] or clan, or different clans may sometirnes  have made up a [[विश्|Viś]], while [[ग्राम|Grāma]] is more definitely, perhaps, a local designation. But the Vedic evidence is quite inconclusive.<ref name=fx11_ve2_1105> The [[विश्|Viś]] may have been oringinally a clan settled in one place: there is no passage where ‘Gotra’ would not probably make sense;<br> Rv. ii. 26, 3, cannot be pressed unduly to distinguish ''ianman'' and [[विश्|Viś]]. Compare the phrase used of the Maruts ''śardhaṃ śardham, vrātaṃ vrātam, gaṇaṃ gaṇam,'' in Rv. v. 53. 11, where no precise sense can fairly be attributed to the words, though Zimmer sees in them a threefold division of the host corresponding to Jana, [[विश्|Viś]], and [[ग्राम|Grāma]]. The rendering ‘Gau’ has therefore little foundation.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[विश्पति|Viśpati]].'''<br><br>In the later period the sense of [[विश्|Viś]] is definitely restricted in some cases<ref name=fx12_ve2_1105> Perhaps to this sense belong the numerous passages in the Brāhmaṇas and later Saṃhitās referring to strife between the [[विश्|Viś]] and the [[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]], the clansmen and the chiefs, or the peasantry and the nobles--''e.g.,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 11, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii, 1, 9;<br> iii. 3, 10;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhita, xix. 9 and often. See also [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 10, 9;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 3, 5;<br> viii. 7, 2, 3;<br> xiii. 2, 2, 17. 19;<br> 9, 6;<br> xiv. 1, 3, 27, etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 14.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Ātindisches Leben,'' 15 ''et seq.;<br>'' Schrader. ''Prehistoric Autiquities,'' 800 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 158;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literalur und Cultur,'' 32, 33;<br> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' For the Roman ''curia,'' which was apparently a collection of ''gentes,'' perhaps local, ''cf.'' Mommsen, ''History of Rome,'' 1, 72, ''et seq.;<br> Ro7mische Forschungen,'' 1. 140-150;<br> ''Ro7misches Staatsrecht,'' 3, 9;<br> Taylor, ''History of Rome.'' 11, 12;<br> Smith, ''Dictionary of Antiquities,'' 1, 576;<br> Cuq, ''Les institutions juridiques des Romains,'' 30-36, For the Greek Phratria which was probably similar in character, consisting of a union of  see ''Dictionary of Antiquities,'' 2, 876 ''et seq.;<br>'' Greenidge, ''Greek Constitutional History,'' 128 ''et seq.;<br>'' Bury, ''History of Greece,'' 69, 70;<br> Gilbert, ''Greek Constitutional Antiquities,'' 1, 104 ''et seq.,'' 210. For the English hundreds, and the supposed analogy of the ''pagi'' of Tacitus, see the references in Medley, ''English Constitutional History,^2'' 318 ''et seq.''</ref> to denote the third of the classes of the Vedic polity, the people or clansmen as opposed to the nobles ('''[[क्षत्र|Kṣatra]], [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]''') and the priests ('''[[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]'''). For the position of this class, see '''Vaiśva.'''

वि-शर
<u>'''Vi-śara'''</u> is found as the name of a disease, perhaps ‘tearing pains,’ in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1106> ii. 4, 2.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_1106> ''Altindisches Leben.'' 391.</ref> thinks that the pains in the limbs attendant on fever ('''[[तक्मन्|Takman]]''') are alluded to. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_1106> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> sees in the word the name of a demon. The view of Zimmer is supported by the use of ''viśarīka,'' ‘rending,’ beside '''[[बलास|Balāsa]]''' in another passage.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1106> xix. 34, 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymas of the Athervaveda,'' 284.</ref> 

वि-शाखे
<u>'''Vi-śākhe.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]'''<br>==Foot Notes==

विश्-पति
<u>'''Viś-pati'''</u> is a word of somewhat uncertain signification, reflecting in this respect the nature of '''[[विश्|Viś]].''' Zimmer holds that in its strict sense it denotes the head of a canton, but he admits that there is no passage requiring this sense, the only one quoted by him<ref name=fx2_ve2_1108> Rv. i. 37. 8.</ref> being certainly indecisive. In the great majority of passages the word simply means the ‘lord of the dwelling,’ whether used of a man or of the god Agni as the householder ''par excellence,'' or possibly as the fire of the '''[[सभा|Sabhā]]''' or assembly house of the people. This sense suits even the passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1108> vii. 55, 5 = Av. iv. 5, 6.</ref> in which the [[विश्पति|Viśpati]], as well as the father and the mother of a maiden,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1108> So Aufrecht, ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 337 ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 308. ''Cf.'' Lanman, ''Sanskrit Reader,'' 370. Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 55 ''et seq.,'' accepts the view of the Bṛhaddevatā, vi. 11 ''et seq.'' (where see Macdonell's note), that the hymn refers to Vasiṣṭha's approaching a house as a thief! The interpretation does not affect the sense of [[विश्पति|Viśpati]], which here is clearly not the title of a cantonal chief. [[विश्|Viś]] is sometimes equivalent to '''[[सजात|Sajāta]];<br>''' ''cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3, 2. 3.</ref> are to be lulled to sleep in order to allow her lover to approach her, for the household may well be deemed to have been a joint family, in which the [[विश्पति|Viśpati]] could easily be different from the father of the girl--''e.g.,'' a grandfather or uncle. In other passages<ref name=fx6_ve2_1108> Av. iii. 4, 1;<br> iv. 22, 3. Perhaps Rv. iii. 13, 5, is so to be taken;<br> ''cf.'' vii. 39, 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 22.</ref> the [[विश्पति|Viśpati]] is the king as ‘lord of the subject-people’ (''viśām''), though here Zimmer<ref name=fx7_ve2_1108> ''Op. cit.,'' 164, 165.</ref> thinks reference is made to the election of a king.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1108> But see '''[[राजन्|Rājan]].'''</ref> Or again,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1108/> the [[विश्पति|Viśpati]] is the chief of the [[विश्|Viś]], probably in the sense of ‘subjects.’(**  1) ''Altindisches Leben,'' 171.(**  9) ''E.g.,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 1, 3, where [[विश्|Viś]] must clearly be the people or subject class, and the [[विश्पति|Viśpati]] their chief representative; we cannot from such a passage infer a formal office of [[विश्पति|Viśpati]] even as head of the [[विश्|Viś]].

विश्पला
<u>'''Viśpalā'''</u> is, according to the tradition in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1109> i. 112, 10: 116 15;<br> 11. 11: 118. 8;<br> x. 39, 8.</ref> the name of a woman to whom the Aśvins gave an iron (''āyasī'')  limb to replace one lost by her in a contest. Pischel<ref name=fx2_ve2_1109> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1. 171-173.<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 52;<br> Muir, ''Saniskrit Texts,'' 5, 245;<br> Bloomfield, ''Religion of the Veda,'' 113;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 110, 111.</ref> considers that a racing horse miraculously cured of a broken limb by the Aśvins is meant, but this is no more than an improbable conjecture.

विश्वक
<u>'''Viśvaka,'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1110> i. 116, 23;<br> 117. 7;<br> viii. 86, 1;<br> x. 65, 12. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 52.</ref> called Kṛṣṇiya (possibly ‘son of '''[[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]]'''’) is a protégé of the Aśvins, who restored to him his lost son, '''[[विष्णापु|Viṣṇāpu]].''' See 2. '''[[कृष्ण|Kṛṣṇa]].'''

विश्व-कर्मन् भौवन
<u>'''Viśva-karman Bhauvana'''</u> (‘descendant of Bhuvana’) is the name of a quite mythical king. He is said in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] to have been consecrated by '''[[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]],''' to whom he offered the earth (''i.e.,'' presumably a piece of land) as a sacrificial fee; in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1111> xiii. 7, 1, 15.</ref> he performed the Sarvamedha (‘universal sacrifice’), and made a similar offer; in both cases the earth refused to be given. The story seems to contain a reference to the early dislike of gifts of land,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1111> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 47.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 421, n, 1;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 456, 457.</ref> but it cannot be stated with certainty that this is the meaning.<br><br>^1 viii. 21, 8.

विश्वन्-तर सौ-षद्मन
<u>'''Viśvan-tara Sau-ṣadmana'''</u> (‘descendant of Suṣadman’) is the name in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1112> vii. 27, 3, 4;<br> 34, 7, 8. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 431-440;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 344, n.</ref> of a prince who set aside the '''Śyāparṇas,''' his priests, and performed a sacrifice without their help, presumably with the aid of others. '''[[राम मार्गवेय|Rāma Mārgaveya]],''' one of the Śyāparṇas, however, succeeded in inducing the king to reinstate the Śyāparṇas, and to give him a thousand cows.

विश्व-मनस्
<u>'''Viśva-manas'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] mentioned in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1113> viii. 23, 2;<br> 24, 7.</ref> and as a frined of Indra in the Pañcaviṃśa  [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1113> xv. 5, 20.</ref> According to the Anukramaṇī (Index), he was a descendant of '''[[व्य्अश्व|Vyaśva]],''' and the author of certain hymns.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1113> Rv. viii. 23-26.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 106.</ref>

विश्व-मानुष
<u>'''Viśva-mānuṣa'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1114> viii. 45, 22. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 187.</ref> may be a proper name, but more probably merely means ‘all mankind.’

विश्व-वार
<u>'''Viśva-vāra'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1115> v. 44, 11. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138.</ref> apparently as the name of a sacrificer.

विश्वा-सामन्
<u>'''Viśvā-sāman'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], an '''Atreya,''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1116> v. 22, 1. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg. ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 215.</ref>

विश्व-सृज्
<u>'''Viśva-sṛj'''</u> is the name of certain mythical beings to whom, however, a Sattra, or sacrificial session, is ascribed in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxv. 18, 1 ''et seq.'').<br>==Foot Notes==

विश्वा-मित्र
<u>'''Viśvā-mitra'''</u> (‘friend of all’) is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] who is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1118> As son of [[कुशिक|Kuśika]] in Rv. iii. 33, 5;<br> as [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] in iii. 53, 7, 12.</ref> and to whom the third Maṇḍala is attributed by tradition. In one hymn<ref name=fx2_ve2_1118> iii. 33. Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 121, thinks the hymn too poetical to be a real composition of the reputed author.</ref> which appears to be his own composition, he praises the rivers '''[[विपाश्|Vipāś]]''' (Beas) and '''[[शुतुद्री|Śutudrī]]''' (Sutlej). There he calls himself the son of '''[[कुशिक|Kuśika]],''' and seems unquestionably to be the helper of the '''Bharatas,''' whom he mentions. The tribe, engaged in a raid, apparently came to the rivers from the east.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1118> So Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 152. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 127, 128, takes a different view: with Roth, ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 90, he assumes that the Bharatas were different from the Tṛtsus, and that they came under [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] from the West, but were defeated (see Rv. vii. 33, 6). But see Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 34, n. 1;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 136. Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 41, 42, still defends Roth's view.</ref> Anxious to cross them, they<br><br>^3 Rv. iii. 33, 5.  found them in high flood, but [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] by prayer induced the waters to subside. The same feat appears to be referred to in another passage of the same book of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1118> iii. 53, 9-11. This hymn is probably later.</ref> Curiously enough, Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx6_ve2_1118> Sāyaṇa on Rv. iii. 33.</ref> quite misunderstands the situation: according to him, [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] having obtained wealth by the exercise of his office, went off with it to the rivers, pursued by others. Yāska's<ref name=fx7_ve2_1118> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 24.</ref> version of the tale merely seems to mean that the king paid [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] to act as his '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]],''' or domestic priest. For the relations of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] to [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]] connected with their service of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]], see [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]].'''<br><br>The Viśvāmitras are mentioned in several other passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1118> iii. 1, 21;<br> 18, 4;<br> 53, 13;<br> x. 89, 17;<br> Av. xviii. 3, 6;<br> 4, 54;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 15, 1.</ref> and are also designated as a family by the term '''Kuśikas.'''<ref name=fx9_ve2_1118> Rv. iii. 26, 1. 3;<br> 29, 15;<br> 30, 20;<br> 42, 9;<br> 53, 9. 10.</ref><br><br>In the later literature [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] becomes, like [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], a mythical sage, usually<ref name=fx10_ve2_1118> ''Cf.'' Rv. iii. 53, 15. 16;<br> Ṣaḍguruśiṣya in Macdonell's edition of the Sarvānukramaṇī, p. 107;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 117;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 343;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 158 ''et seq.''</ref> mentioned in connection with '''[[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]];''' he was [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest at the sacrifice of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]],''' whom he adopted, and to whom he gave the name of '''[[देवरात|Devarāta]].'''<ref name=fx11_ve2_1118> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 16 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 17 ''et seq.''</ref> He was a protégé of Indra, with whom he had an interview according to the Rigveda Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx12_ve2_1118> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka. ii. 2, 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, i. 5.</ref> He is also often mentioned as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]].<ref name=fx13_ve2_1118> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 2, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 18, 1;<br> 20, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 1, 2;<br> iii. 1, 7, 3;<br> v. 2, 3, 4, etc.;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 19;<br> xx. 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 7, 19;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xv. 1;<br> xxvi. 14;<br> xxviii. 1. 2;<br> xxix. 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 3, 12;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 2, 4;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 13;<br> 15, 1, etc. [[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]] is often associated with him, Av. iv. 29, 5, etc.</ref><br><br>In the Epic<ref name=fx14_ve2_1118> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 388 ''et seq.''</ref> [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] is represented as a king, who becomes a Brahmin. There is no trace of his kingship in the Rigveda, but the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx15_ve2_1118> ii. 24.</ref> calls his father, [[कुशिक|Kuśika]], a king; the  [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx16_ve2_1118> vii. 18, 9. But the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 27, has a completely different version, which Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 16, n. 3, prefers, and which omits all allusion to the ‘lordship’ of the Jahnus. This shows how little stress can-be laid on this latetradition.</ref> refers to [[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]] as succeeding to the lordship of the '''Jahnus,''' as well as the ‘divine lore’ (''[[दैव|daiva]] veda'') of the '''Gāthins;''' and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx17_ve2_1118> xxi. 12, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 121;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 209, 210;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 337 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 16 ''et seq.;<br>'' ''Indian Literature,'' 31, 37, 38, 53, etc.</ref> mentions [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] as a king. But there is no real-trace of this kingship of [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]: it may probably be dismissed as a mere legend, with no more foundation at most than that [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]] was of a family which once had been royal. But even this is doubtful.

विष
<u>'''Viṣa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1119> i. 117, 16;<br> 191, 11;<br> vi. 61, 3;<br> x. 87. 18, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1119> Av. iv. 6, 2;<br> v. 19, 10;<br> vi. 90, 2, etc.</ref> regularly denotes ‘poison’ as an antidote, for which the Atharvaveda supplies spells.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1119> Bloomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 61.</ref>

विष-विद्या
<u>'''Viṣa-vidyā,'''</u> the ‘science of poison,’ is enumerated with other sciences in the Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (x. 75). ''Cf.'' '''[[विद्या|Vidyā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

विषाणा
<u>'''Viṣāṇā'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1121> iii. 7, 1. 2;<br> vi. 121, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 11, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 3, 2, 17. Primarily a deciduous horn is meant. See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 94.</ref> and later^2 denotes an animal's ‘horn.’

विषाणका
<u>'''Viṣāṇakā'''</u> is the name of a plant in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1122> vi. 44, 3. ''Cf.'' Viṣāṇikā in Wise, ''Hindu System of Medicine,'' 146, perhaps the ''Asclepias geminata;<br>'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 12, 426;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 68. But ''cf.'' Whitney. Translation of the Atharvaveda, 313.</ref> Bloomfield,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1122> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 482.</ref> however, thinks that the word may merely mean ‘horn.’ It is used as a remedy against the disease Vātīkāra.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1122> Av. ix. 8, 20;<br> Vātī-[[कृत|kṛta]], vi. 44, 3;<br> 109, 3.</ref> That  disease is of doubtful character: Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve2_1122> ''Op. cit.,'' 389. 390.</ref> thinks that it is one ‘caused by wounds,’ comparing the adjective ''a-[[वात|vāta]],'' ‘uninjured,’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1122> vi. 16, 20;<br> ix. 96, 8.</ref> but Bloomfield<ref name=fx6_ve2_1122> ''Op. cit.,'' 481 ''et seq.,'' 516.</ref> shows that ‘wind’ in the body is meant as causing the disease.

विषाणिन्
<u>'''Viṣāṇin'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1123> vii. 18, 7.</ref> as the name of a tribe in the list of the enemies of the '''Tṛtsus,''' not as Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1123> ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Weda,'' 95;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 126. But Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 430, 431, altered his view, and Hopkins' criticism, overlooking this retractation, in the ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 260, 261, is so far unjustified.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173.</ref> thought, of their allies. The word seems to mean ‘having horns,’ but in what sense is unknown; perhaps their helmets were horn-shaped or ornamented with horns. They may, like their allies, the '''Alinas, [[भलानस्|Bhalānas]], Śivas,''' and '''Pakthas,''' be reckoned as belonging to the tribes of the north-west.

विषूवन्त्
<u>'''1. Viṣūvant'''</u> denotes in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1124> xi. 7, 15.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1124> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 2;<br> 7, 1;<br> v. 9, 10;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 41, 4;<br> iv. 18, 1;<br> 22, 1. 2;<br> vi. 18, 8;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 1;<br> xxvi. 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 3, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 1, 2, 2;<br> 3, 14. 23;<br> 4, 2;<br> 2, 1, 8, etc.</ref> the middle day in the Sattra or sacrificial session of a year's duration. Tilak<ref name=fx3_ve2_1124> ''Orion,'' 21, 22.</ref> argues that the [[विषूवन्त्|Viṣūvant]] literally means the day when night and daylight are equal--''i.e.,'' the equinoctial day--and that this is the true sense of the word. But the theory is without probability.<br><br>^4 ''Cf.'' Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, ixxxiii. ''et seq.''

विषूवन्त्
<u>'''2. Viṣūvant'''</u> occurs in the description of the house in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1125> ix. 3, 8.</ref> The meaning seems to be tha ‘ridge of the roof.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1125> ''Cf.'' Zimmer. ''Altindisches Leben,'' 151 (who thinks it is a metaphor from the parting of the hair);<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 598;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 526.</ref> 

विषूचिका
<u>'''Viṣūcikā'''</u> is the name of a disease mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1126> xix. 10 = Maitrāyaḥī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 7 = [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 18 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 1, 5 = Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 3, 2.</ref> as a result of over-indulgence in '''Soma''' drinking. It seems clearly to be ‘dyser ery,’ or, as Wise calls it, ‘sporadic cholera.’ The term apparently means ‘causing evacuations in both directions.’(**  2) ''Hindu System of Medicine,'' 330.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 275, 392.

वि-ष्कन्ध
<u>'''Vi-ṣkandha'''</u> occurs severai times in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1127> i. 16, 3;<br> ii. 4, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' iii. 9, 2. 6;<br> iv. 9, 5;<br> xix. 34, 5. It is also found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 11, 1.</ref> as the name of a disease. As rem dies against it a lead amulet,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1127> Av. i. 16, 3. ''Cf.'' ii. 4;<br> iii. 9, 6.</ref> or hemp,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1127> Av. ii. 4, 5.</ref> or a salve,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1127> Av. iv. 9, 5.</ref> or the '''Ja giḍa''' plant are recommended for use.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1127> Av. ii. 4, 1. 5;<br> xix. 34. 5;<br> 35, 1.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx6_ve2_1127> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 410;<br> 13, 141;<br> 17, 215. See Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 390, 391;<br> Grill, ''Hundert Lieder,^2'' 75.</ref> suggests that the disease meant is ‘rheumatism,’ because it draws the shoulders apart (''vi-skandha''), but Bloomfield<ref name=fx7_ve2_1127> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 282, 283.</ref> thinks that it is rather the name of a demon, like the Rigvedic Vyaṃśa<ref name=fx8_ve2_1127> Rv. i. 32, 5, etc.</ref> and Vigrīva,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1127> Rv. viii. 4, 24.</ref> both of which are similarly formed and are names of demons. Possibly Karśapha and Viśapha mentioned in one hymn<ref name=fx10_ve2_1127> Av. iii. 9, 1. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''op. cit.,'' 340. Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' thinks demons are meant: this seems the more probable view.</ref> are plants used to cure the disease.

वि-ष्टारिन्
<u>'''Vi-ṣṭārin'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1128> iv. 34, 1 ''et seq.'' According to Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 206, the designation ‘outspread’ is due to the fact that the rice mess was kneaded into furrows and juices (''rasa'') were poured into them. See [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], lxvi. 6.</ref> denotes a special sort of '''[[ओदन|Odana]]''' or porridge.

विष्ठा-व्राजिन्
<u>'''Viṣṭhā-vrājin'''</u> is a word of doubtful significance in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1129> v. 1, 12.</ref> According to Sāyaṇa, it means ‘remaining in one and the same place’; if this is right, the rendering of the  St. Petersburg Dictionary and of Bo7htlingk's Dictionary, ‘one whose herd is stationary,’ seems legitimate. But, as Eggeling<ref name=fx2_ve2_1129> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 123, n. 1.</ref> points out, the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in another passage<ref name=fx3_ve2_1129> ''Ibid.,'' 50, n. 1.</ref> seems to treat the word as denoting a disease: thus [[विष्ठाव्राजिन्|Viṣṭhāvrājin]] may mean ‘one afflicted by dysentery.’

विष्णापु
<u>'''Viṣṇāpu'''</u> is the son of '''[[विश्वक|Viśvaka]]''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1130> i. 116, 23;<br> 117, 7;<br> viii. 86, 3;<br> x. 65, 12.</ref> When lost he was restored to his father by the Aśvins.

विष्फुलिङ्ग
<u>'''Viṣphuliṅga'''</u> denotes a ‘spark’ of fire in the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1131> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii, 1, 23;<br> vi. 1, 12;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 3;<br> iv. 20, etc. ''Cf. viṣpuliṅgaka,'' ‘scattering sparks of fire,’ in Rv. i. 191, 12 (Sāyaṇa, ‘a tongue of fire,’ or ‘sparrow’).</ref>

विष्वक्-सेन
<u>'''Viṣvak-sena'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[नारद|Nārada]],''' mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<br>==Foot Notes==

विसल्य
<u>'''Visalya'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1133> ix. 8, 20.</ref> and '''Visalyaka'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1133> vi. 127, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' ix. 8, 2. 5;<br> xix. 44, 2.</ref> are names of a disease in the Atharvaveda. Since Shaṅkar Paṇḍit's reciters<ref name=fx3_ve2_1133> See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 601;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 376. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 378, 384.</ref> pronounced the word as Visalpaka in all the passages, that should probably be adopted as the right reading.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1133> The commentator Sāyaṇa on vi. 127 reads ''visalpakaḥ,'' and on xix. 44, 2, ''visarpakaḥ.''</ref> Some sort of pain is meant, perhaps ‘neuralgia,’ in connexion with fever.

वि-स्रस्
<u>'''Vi-sras'''</u> denotes the ‘decay’ of old age, ‘decrepitude,’ ‘senility.’<ref name=fx1_ve2_1134> Av. xix. 34, 3, where Bohtlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' suggests for ''visrasas'' the emendation ''visruhas'' (''cf.'' Rv. vi. 7, 6);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 20, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 3, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 20, 7;<br> Kāthaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4.</ref> 

विहल्ह
<u>'''Vihalha'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1135> vi. 16, 2. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref> apparently as the name of a plant. The forms Vihaṃla and Vihahla occur as variants.

वीणा
<u>'''Vīṇā'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1136> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 4, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 6, 8.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_1136> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 4, 6;<br> xiii. 1, 5, 1;<br> ''śata-tantrī,'' ‘hundredstringed’ (like the '''[[वाण|Vāṇa]]'''), at the Mahāvrata rite, [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 3, 1, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 42 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 235).</ref> denotes a ‘lute.’ A [[वीणा-वाद|Vīṇā-vāda]], ‘lute-player,’ is included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1136> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 20;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 15, 1.</ref> and is also mentioned elsewhere.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1136> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 8;<br> iv. 5, 9.</ref> The [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1136> iii. 2, 5;<br> ''cf.'' Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, viii. 9.</ref> which states that the instrument was once covered with a hairy skin, enumerates its parts as Śiras, ‘head’ (''i.e.,'' neck); Udara, ‘cavity’; Ambhaṇa, ‘sounding board’; [[तन्त्र|Tantra]], ‘string’; and [[वादन|Vādana]], ‘plectrum.’ In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1136> xiii. 4, 2, 8. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 356, n. 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 289;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 328;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 755.</ref> the Uttaramandrā is either a tune or a kind of lute. ''Cf.'' '''[[वाण|Vāṇa]].'''

वीणा-गाथिन्
<u>'''Vīṇā-gāthin'''</u> denotes ‘lute-player’ in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1137> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 14, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 5, 1;<br> 4, 2, 8. 11. 14;<br> 3, 5.</ref> In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] Vīṇāgaṇagin denotes the ‘leader of a band.’(**  2) xiii. 4, 3, 3; 4, 2; [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 1, 29.

वीणा-वाद
<u>'''Vīṇā-vāda.'''</u> See '''[[वीणा|Vīṇā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वीत-हव्य
<u>'''Vīta-havya'''</u> is the name of a prince who is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1139> vi. 15, 2. 3.</ref> along with '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]],''' and as a contemporary of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1139> vii. 19, 3.</ref> though in both passages it is possible to understand the  word as a mere adjective. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1139> vi. 137, 1.</ref> [[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]] appears as connected with '''[[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]]''' and '''[[असित|Asita]],''' but it is clear that the legend there has no value. It is possible, though not certain, that he was a king of the '''Sṛṇjayas.'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1139> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105.</ref> In the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx5_ve2_1139> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 5, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxii. 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 16, 3. ''Ibid.,'' ix. 1, 9, he is represented as being ''niruddha,'' apparently in ‘banishment’;<br> but the scholiast explains him as not a king, but a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], which is quite possible.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 212;<br> ''Buddha,'' 405.</ref> a [[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]] '''[[श्रायस|Śrāyasa]]''' appears as a king: he may be identical with the [[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]] of the Rigveda, or belong to the same line. ''Cf.'' '''[[वैतहव्य|Vaitahavya]].'''

वीर
<u>'''Vīra'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1140> i. 18, 4;<br> 114, 8;<br> iv. 29, 2;<br> v. 20, 4;<br> 61, 5, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1140> Av. ii. 26, 4;<br> iii. 5, 8, etc.</ref> denotes ‘man’ as the strong and heroic. Collectively in the singular<ref name=fx3_ve2_1140> Rv. ii. 32, 4;<br> iii. 4, 9;<br> 36, 10;<br> vii. 34, 20, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 8, 1, etc.</ref> the word denotes ‘male offspring,’ an object of great desire (''cf.'' '''[[पुत्र|Putra]]''') to the Vedic Indian. The [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1140> xix. 1, 4. Viz., the king's brother, his son, '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]], [[महिषी|Mahiṣī]], [[सूत|Sūta]], Grāmaṇī, [[क्षत्तृ|Kṣattṛ]],''' and [[संग्रहीतृ|Saṃgrahītṛ]]. See [[रत्निन्|Ratnin]].</ref> gives a list of eight Vīras of the king, constituting his supporters and entourage.

वीरण
<u>'''Vīraṇa'''</u> is the form in the late Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 2) of the name of the plant '''[[वीरिण|Vīriṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वीर-हत्या
<u>'''Vīra-hatyā,'''</u> ‘murder of a man,’ is one of the crimes referred to in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1142> x. 40.</ref> The [[वीर|Vīra]]-han, ‘man-slayer,’ is often mentioned in the older texts.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1142> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 2, 1;<br> ii. 2, 5, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 7;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 6, 8;<br> xvi. 1, 12, etc.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[वैर|Vaira]].''' 

वीरिण
<u>'''Vīriṇa'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1143> xiii. 8, 1, 15. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70.</ref> denotes a kind of grass (''Andropogon muricatus''). See '''[[वैरिण|Vairiṇa]].'''

वीरुध्
<u>'''Vīrudh'''</u> means ‘plant’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1144> i. 67, 9;<br> 141, 4;<br> ii. 1, 14;<br> 35, 8, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1144> Av. i. 32, 3;<br> 34, 1;<br> ii. 7, 1;<br> v. 4, 1;<br> xix. 35, 4, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 57.</ref> As contrasted with '''[[ओषधि|Oṣadhi]],''' it denotes the inferior order of plants, but it often has practically the same sense as [[ओषधि|Oṣadhi]].

वृक
<u>'''1. Vṛka,'''</u> ‘wolf,’ is mentioned frequently in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1145> i. 42, 2;<br> 105, 7;<br> 116, 14;<br> ii. 29, 6;<br> vi. 51, 14;<br> vii. 38, 7, etc.</ref> and also later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1145> Av. vii. 95, 2;<br> xii. 1, 49;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 34;<br> xix. 10. 92, etc.</ref> It was an enemy of sheep<ref name=fx3_ve2_1145> Rv. viii. 34, 3;<br> '''[[उरा|urā]]-mathi,''' ‘worrying sheep,’ x. 66, 8.</ref> and of calves,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1145> Av. xii. 4. 7.</ref> being dangerous even to men.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1145> Rv. i. 105, 11, 18;<br> ii. 29, 6. In [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 21, Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 16, sees the sense of ‘dog,’ which seems needless. ''Cf. [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erlāuterungen,'' 67.</ref> Its colour is stated to be reddish (''aruṇa'').<ref name=fx6_ve2_1145> Rv. i. 105, 18.</ref> The ‘she-wolf,’ Vṛkī, is also mentioned several times in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1145> i. 116, 16;<br> 117, 17;<br> 183, 4;<br> vi. 51, 6;<br> x. 127, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 81;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 14.</ref>

वृक
<u>'''2. Vṛka'''</u> in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1146> i. 117, 21;<br> viii. 22, 6;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 26.</ref> denotes ‘plough.’

वृक-द्वरस्
<u>'''Vṛka-dvaras'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1147> ii. 30, 4.</ref> which Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_1147> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 153;<br> Griffith;<br> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 297, n.</ref> interprets as referring to a battle against [[वृकद्वरस्|Vṛkadvaras]], king of the '''Śaṇḍikas.''' But this is quite uncertain. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_1147> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br> Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gescllschaft,'' 48, 110.</ref> and Oldenberg<ref name=fx4_ve2_1147> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 211.</ref> incline to read ''vṛkadhvaras.'' Hillebrandt<ref name=fx5_ve2_1147> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 442.</ref> suggests Iranian connections, but without any clear reason. 

वृक्ष
<u>'''Vṛkṣa'''</u> is the ordinary term for tree' in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1148> i. 164, 20. 22;<br> ii. 14, 2;<br> 39, 1;<br> iv. 20, 5;<br> v. 78, 6, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1148> Av. i. 14, 1;<br> ii. 12, 3;<br> vi. 45, 1;<br> xii. 1, 27, 51, etc.</ref> In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1148> Av. xviii. 2, 25. ''Cf.'' Bṛhaddevatā, v. 83, with Macdonell's note (''d'').</ref> it denotes the coffin made from a tree, no doubt by hollowing it out. The Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1148> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40, and ''cf. Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 214.</ref> refers to the portent of a tree secreting blood.

वृक्ष-सर्पी
<u>'''Vṛkṣa-sarpī,'''</u> ‘tree-creeper,’ is the name of a species of worm or female serpent in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1149> ix. 2, 22. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref>

वृक्ष्य
<u>'''Vṛkṣya'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 1, 1, 10) denotes the ‘fruit of a tree.’<br>==Foot Notes==

वृचया
<u>'''Vṛcayā'''</u> is referred to once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1151> i. 51, 3. ''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 3, 203, who distinguishes two Kakṣīvants, but without sufficient reason, since i. 116, 17, must clearly refer to [[वृचया|Vṛcayā]].</ref> as the spouse given by the Aśvins to '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]].'''

वृचीवन्त्
<u>'''Vṛcīvant'''</u> is the name of a tribe referred to once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1152> vi. 27, 5 ''et seq.''</ref> where it is clearly stated that the '''[[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]]''' king, '''[[दैववात|Daivavāta]],''' conquered the '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]]''' king and the Vṛcīvants. Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_1152> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 124.</ref> thinks that the Vṛcīvants and the [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] people should be identified, but this is both unnecessary and improbable; it is adequate to assume that they were allied against<ref name=fx3_ve2_1152> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 404;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 153: Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105.</ref> the Sṛñjayas. The Vṛcīvants appear again only in the strange legend in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_1152> xxi. 12, 2.</ref> according to which the '''Jahnus''' and the Vṛcīvants contended for sovereignty, '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],''' the [[जह्नु|Jahnu]] king, winning it by his knowledge of a certain rite. See also '''[[हरियूपीया|Hariyūpīyā]].''' 

वृजन
<u>'''Vṛjana,'''</u> according to Roth,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1153> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2.</ref> denotes in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1153> i. 51, 15, 73, 2;<br> 91, 21;<br> 105, 19;<br> 128, 7;<br> 165, 15;<br> 166, 14, etc.</ref> the ‘settlement’ or ‘village,’ the German ‘Mark’ and its inhabitants. Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1153> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 142, 159, 161.</ref> accepting this view, sees in [[वृजन|Vṛjana]] the ‘secure abode’ (''[[क्षिति|kṣiti]] [[ध्रुवा|dhruvā]]'') where the clan lives,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1153> Rv. i. 51, 15;<br> 73, 2 (''cf.'' i. 73, 4).</ref> the clan itself as a village community (like '''[[ग्राम|Grāma]]'''), and the clan in war.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1153> Rv. vii. 32, 27;<br> x. 42, 10.</ref> Geldner,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1153> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 139 ''et seq.''</ref> on the other hand, takes the literal sense of [[वृजन|Vṛjana]] ṭo be ‘net,’ developing all the other senses from that idea, but the traditional view seems more natural.

वृत्र-घ्न
<u>'''Vṛtra-ghna'''</u> occurs in a passage of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1154> viii. 23, 5.</ref> where in a '''[[गाथा|Gāthā]]''' reciting the prowess of '''[[भरत|Bharata]]''' it is said that he bound horses on the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]]''' (Jumna) and '''[[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]]''' (Ganges) ''Vṛtraghne,'' which Sāyaṇa renders ‘at [[वृत्रघ्न|Vṛtraghna]],’ as the name of a place. Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1154> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Aufrecht, ''Aitarecya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],'' 425.</ref> however, seems right in interpreting the form as a dative, ‘for the slayer of Vṛtra’--''i.e.,'' Indra.

वृत्र-शङ्कु
<u>'''Vṛtra-śaṅku,'''</u> literally ‘Vṛtra-peg,’ found in one passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1155> xiii. 8, 4, 1.</ref> is said by the scholiast on the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1155> xxi. 3, 31.</ref> to denote a stone pillar. This improbable interpretation is based on another passage in the same [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1155> iv. 2, 5, 15. ''Cf.'' Eggeling. ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 437, n. 1.</ref>

वृद्ध-द्युम्न आभिप्रतारिण
<u>'''Vṛddha-[[द्युम्न|dyumna]] Ābhipratāriṇa'''</u> (‘descendant of Abhipratārin’) is the name of a prince (''[[राजन्य|rājanya]]'') in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 48, 9), where his priest, '''Śucivṛkṣa Gaupalāyana,''' is praised. In the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xv, 16, 10-13), on the contrary, he is said to have erred in the '''sacrifice,''' when a Brahmin prophesied that the result would be the expulsion of the '''Kurus''' from '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], an event which''' actually came to pass. <br>==Foot Notes==

वृद्ध-वाशिनी
<u>'''Vṛddha-vāśinī'''</u> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (v. 21) denotes the ‘female jackal.’<br><br>^1. '''Vṛśa.''' See '''[[वृष|Vṛṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वृश जान
<u>'''2. Vṛśa Jāna'''</u> (‘descendant of Jana’) is the name of a famous [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], who was unfortunate enough, while with his royal master, '''Tryaruṇa,''' to see a boy killed by the chariot which the king drove too fast. He thereupon recalled the boy to life. The story is told briefly in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1158> xiii. 3, 12.</ref> the Śāṭyāyanaka,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1158> See Sāyaṇa on Rv. v. 2, and the Jaiminīya version in the ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 20.</ref> the Tāṇḍaka,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1158> See Sāyaṇa, ''loc. cit.''</ref> was also narrated in the [[भाल्लवि|Bhāllavi]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_1158> Referred to in the Bṛhaddevatā, v. 23, apparently as cited in the [[निदान|Nidāna]]. The passage is not in the extant text of the [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]. See Sieg. ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]'' 65, n. 5.</ref> and is preserved in the Bṛhaddevatā,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1158> v. 14 ''et seq.,'' where see Macdonell's notes.</ref> Sieg<ref name=fx6_ve2_1158> ''Op, cit.,'' 64-76.</ref> has endeavoured to trace the story in part in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1158> v. 2.</ref> but there is a consensus of opinion<ref name=fx8_ve2_1158> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 4, 324;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 33, 248 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 46, 366 ''et seq.;<br> [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 312. On the other hand, Geldner, ''Festgruss an Roth,'' 192, supports the tradition. ''Cf.'' Weber. ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 32.</ref> against the correctness of such a view.

वृश्चिक
<u>'''Vṛścika'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1159> i. 191, 16.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1159> x. 4, 9, 15;<br> xii. 1, 46;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 27.</ref> denote ‘scorpion.’ Its poison was feared<ref name=fx3_ve2_1159> Rv., ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Av. x. 4, 9. 15.</ref> like that of serpents. It is described as lying torpid in the earth during winter.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1159> Av. xii. 1, 46.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref>

वृष
<u>'''Vṛṣa'''</u> is the name of a plant of some kind in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1160> xxx. 1.</ref> Later the ''Gendarussa vulgaris'' is so styled. Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_1160> iv. 8, 1.</ref> has Vṛśa, which Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx3_ve2_1160> Dictionary, General Inden to Supplements, 376.</ref> takes to mean a small animal, a quite possible sense. ''Cf.'' '''[[येवाष|Yevāṣa]].''' 

वृष-खादि
<u>'''Vṛṣa-khādi'''</u> is used as an epithet of the Maruts in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1161> i. 64, 10.</ref> The sense is doubtful: Bollensen<ref name=fx2_ve2_1161> ''Orient und Occident,'' 2, 461, n.</ref> thought the expression referred to the wearing of rings in the ears; Max Müller<ref name=fx3_ve2_1161> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 107, 120, ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 263.</ref> renders it ‘strong rings,’ comparing the later [[चक्र|Cakra]] or discus.

वृष-गण
<u>'''Vṛṣa-gaṇa'''</u> is the name of a family of singers mentioned in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1162> ix. 97, 8. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 132.</ref>

वृषण्-अश्व
<u>'''Vṛṣaṇ-aśva'''</u> is the name of a man referred to in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1163> i. 51, 13.</ref> where Indra is called '''[[मेना|Menā]],''' perhaps his ‘wife’ or ‘daughter.’ The same legend is alluded to in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1163> ii. 79 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 37).</ref> the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1163> iii. 3, 4, 18.</ref> the Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_1163> i. 1, 16.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1163> i. 12, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 81, n. 2.</ref> but it is clear that all of these texts had no real tradition of what was referred to.

वृष-दंश
<u>'''Vṛṣa-daṃśa,'''</u> ‘strong-toothed,’ is the name of the cat in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1164> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 21, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 31.</ref> where it figures as a victim at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’). It also appears in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]];<ref name=fx2_ve2_1164> viii. 2, 2.</ref> the fact that the sneeze of the cat is here referred to renders it likely that the animal was already tamed. Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve2_1164> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 313-315.</ref> sees a house cat in the animal alluded to in a hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1164> i. 18.</ref> by a set of curious epithets, including ''vṛṣadatī,'' ‘strong-toothed,’ but Whitney<ref name=fx5_ve2_1164> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 19, 20;<br> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 153, n.;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 261.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 86.</ref> decisively rejects the idea that the hymn refers to the domestic cat. 

वृषन्
<u>'''Vṛṣan'''</u> in two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1165> i. 36, 10;<br> vi. 16, 14. 15. ''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 152, 153;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 104.</ref> seems to denote a man, with the patronymic '''[[पाथ्य|Pāthya]]''' in one of them.

वृषभ
<u>'''Vṛṣabha'''</u> regularly denotes a ‘bull’ in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1166> i. 94, 10;<br> 160, 3;<br> vi. 46, 4;<br> of Parjanya, vii. 101, 1, 6, etc. Roth renders ''vrsabhānna,'' ii. 16, 5, ‘eating strong food’;<br> but the literal sense, ‘whose food is bulls,’ will answer. ''Cf.'' '''[[मांस|Māṃsa]].'''</ref> but usually in a metaphorical sense.

वृषल
<u>'''Vṛṣala'''</u> in the dicing hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1167> x. 34, 11. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 16.</ref> denotes an ‘outcast’; the same sense appears in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1167> vi. 4, 12 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> where the touch of either a [[वृषल|Vṛṣala]] or a Vṛṣalī is to be avoided.

वृष-शुष्म वातावत
<u>'''Vṛṣa-śuṣma Vātāvata'''</u> (‘descendant of Vātāvant’) '''[[जातूकर्ण्य|Jātūkarṇya]]''' is the name of a priest in the Brāhmaṇas of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1168> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 29, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 9 (with a ''varia lectio'' [[वाधावत|Vādhāvata]]: ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 215, n. 1).</ref> Vṛṣaśuṣma in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1168> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref> is probably intended for the same name.

वृषा-रव
<u>'''Vṛṣā-rava,'''</u> ‘roaring like a bull,’ is the name of some animal in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1169> x. 146, 2 =  [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 5, 6.</ref> In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1169> xii. 5, 2, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 426: Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 90.</ref> the word occurs in the dual, meaning perhaps ‘mallet’ or ‘drumstick.’

वृष्टि
<u>'''Vṛṣṭi'''</u> is the regular word for ‘rain’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1170> i. 116, 12;<br> ii. 5, 6, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1170> Av. iii. 31, 11;<br> vi. 22, 3, etc.</ref> 

वृष्टि-हव्य
<u>'''Vṛṣṭi-havya'''</u> is in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1171> x. 115, 9. ''Cf.'' Max Mūller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 152, 153;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 108, 109.</ref> the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], whose sons were the '''Upastutas.'''

वेणु
<u>'''Veṇu'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1172> i. 27, 3.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1172> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 5, 2;<br> vii. 4, 19, 2;<br> Kāthaka Saṃhitā, xiii. 12;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 19;<br> ii. 6, 2, 17, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘reed’ of bamboo, It is described in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_1172> v. 1, 1, 4.</ref> as ‘hollow’ (''su-ṣira''). In the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1172> viii. 55, 3.</ref> it occurs only in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn in a Dānastuti (‘praise of gifts’), where Roth<ref name=fx5_ve2_1172> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2.</ref> thinks that ‘flutes of reed’ are meant, a sense which [[वेणु|Veṇu]] has in the later texts. The [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1172> iv. 12.</ref> couples [[वेणु|Veṇu]] with '''[[सस्य|Sasya]],''' stating that they ripen in [[वसन्त|Vasanta]], ‘spring.’ Apparently bamboo reeds are meant.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1172> ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 6, 17, with the scholiast;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 343.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.</ref>

वेतस
<u>'''Vetasa'''</u> is the name of the water plant ''Calamus Rotang,'' or a similar reed, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1173> iv. 58, 5.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1173> Av. x. 7, 41;<br> xviii. 3, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 3, 12, 2;<br> 4, 4, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 4, 3, etc.</ref> It is called ‘golden’ (''hiraṇyaya'') and ‘water-born’ (''apsuja'').<ref name=fx4_ve2_1173> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 3, 12, 2, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.</ref><br><br>^3 Rv. ''loc. cit.;'' Av. x. 7, 41.

वेतसु
<u>'''Vetasu'''</u> is a name occurring in the singular in two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1174> vi. 20, 8;<br> 26, 4.</ref> and once in the plural.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1174> x. 49, 4.</ref> It seems that he was defeated by Indra, but there is no reason to assume that he was a demon. Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_1174> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 128. ''Cf.'' Kaegi, ''Die Rigveda,'' n. 337.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 55, 328.</ref> thinks that the Vetasus were probably the tribe of which '''[[दशद्यु|Daśadyu]]''' was a member, and that they defeated the '''Tugras.''' The passages are too obscure to render any version probable. 

वेतस्वन्त्
<u>'''Vetasvant,'''</u> ‘abounding in reeds,’ is the name of a place in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1175> xxi. 14, 20.</ref> not, as Weber<ref name=fx2_ve2_1175> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 32. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 69.</ref> once took it, a part of the name of '''Ekayāvan [[गांदम|Gāṃdama]].'''

वेद
<u>'''Veda'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1176> Av. vii. 54, 2;<br> x. 8, 17;<br> xv. 3, 7.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1176> ''Traya,'' ‘threefold,’ Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 5, 10;<br> xiii. 4, 3, 3;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], i. 2. 18. 20, etc.</ref> denotes ‘sacred lore.’ In the plural<ref name=fx3_ve2_1176> Av. iv. 35, 6;<br> xix. 2, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 11, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 32, 1;<br> vi. 15, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 11, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 3, 7;<br> xii. 3, 4, 11, etc. In the Brāhmaṇas the word, no doubt, has normally the sense of the extant collections, which appear under their accepted titles, '''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]], [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]],''' in the Āraṇyakas.</ref> it more definitely refers to the Vedas of the Ṛc, [[यजुस्|Yajus]], and Sāman. ''Cf.'' '''[[विद्या|Vidyā]].'''

वेदाङ्ग
<u>'''Vedāṅga,'''</u> as the name of a text subsidiary to the study of the Rigveda, is first found in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1177> i. 20.</ref> and the Rigveda Prātiśākhya.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1177> xii. 40.<br><br>''Cf.'' Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],'' xv. ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 42.</ref>

वेन
<u>'''1. Vena'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1178> x. 93, 14. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 166.</ref> as a generous patron. '''[[पृथवान|Pṛthavāna]],''' found in the same passage, may or may not be another name of his, and '''[[पार्थ्य|Pārthya]]''' in the following stanza of the hymn is perhaps his patronymic.

वेन
<u>'''2. Vena'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1179> x. 123.</ref> is thought by Tilak<ref name=fx2_ve2_1179> ''Oriea,'' 163 ''et seq''<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, xciv.</ref> to be the planet Venus. But this is certainly impossible. 

वेश
<u>'''1. Veśa'''</u> is a term of somewhat doubtful sense, apparently denoting ‘vassal,’ ‘tenant,’ in a few passages,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1180> Rv. iv. 3, 13;<br> v. 85, 7;<br> possibly x. 49, 5;<br> but ''cf.'' 2. '''[[वेश|Veśa]];<br>''' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 5 (''veśatva.'');<br> xxxi. 12;<br> xxxii. 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, [[काण्व|Kāṇva]], ii. 5, 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 8;<br> ii. 3, 7;<br> iv. 1, 13. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 204, who takes ''[[वेशस्|veśas]]'' in Av. ii. 32, 5, where ''pari-[[वेशस्|veśas]]'' also occurs in the same sense, and compares ''[[वैश्य|vaiśya]]'' in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 7, 1, as meaning ‘servitude’</ref> and, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1180> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1, ''[[वेश|veśa]],'' and ''veśatva. Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 75, who seems inclined to read ''veṣas'' in Av. ii. 32, 5;<br> but Weber's explanation of the origin of the sense of ‘servant’ is adequate. Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 135, n. 4, sees in [[वेश|Veśa]] either a neighbour or a member of the same village community. ''Cf.'' '''[[सजात|Sajāta]].'''</ref> ‘dependent neighbour.’

वेश
<u>'''2. Veśa'''</u> may be a proper name in two passages of the Rigveda;<ref name=fx1_ve2_1181> ii. 13, 8;<br> x. 49, 5. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 152, 164.</ref> if so, it is quite uncertain whether a demon is meant or not.

वेशन्ता
<u>'''Veśantā,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1182> Av. xi. 6, 10;<br> xx. 128, 8, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1.</ref> '''Veśantī,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1182> Av. i. 3, 7.</ref> '''[[वेशान्ता|Veśāntā]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1182> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 11.</ref> all denote a ‘pond’ or ‘tank.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[वैशन्त|Vaiśanta]].'''

वेशस्
<u>'''Veśas.'''</u> See 1. '''[[वेश|Veśa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वेशान्ता
<u>'''Veśāntā.'''</u> See '''[[वेशन्ता|Veśantā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वेशी
<u>'''Veśī'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1185> vii. 18, 17. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 264, n.</ref> seems to denote a ‘needle.’

वेश्मन्
<u>'''Veśman,'''</u> ‘house,’ occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1186> x. 107, 10;<br> 146, 3.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1186> Av. v. 17, 13;<br> ix. 6, 30;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 24, 6, etc. In Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 2, 14, the single house (''eka-[[वेश्मन्|veśman]]'') of the king is contrasted with the numerous dwellings of the people.</ref> It denotes the house as the place where a man is ‘settled’ (''[[विश्|viś]]''). 

वेश्य
<u>'''Veśya'''</u> in two passages of the Rigveda (iv. 26, 3; vi. 61, 14) seems to denote the relation of ‘dependence’ rather than ‘neighbourhood.’ ''Cf.'' 1. '''[[वेश|Veśa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वेष्क
<u>'''Veṣka'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 8, 1, 15) denotes the ‘noose’ for strangling the sacrificial animal. See '''[[ब्लेष्क|Bleṣka]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वेहत्
<u>'''Vehat'''</u> seems to mean a ‘cow that miscarries.’ It is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1189> xii. 4, 37 ''et seq.''
