In iii. 23, 1, a woman is called ''[[वेहत्|vehat]].''</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1189> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 27;<br> xxiv. 1, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 5, 3, etc. In Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 4, 6, Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 195, adopts the sense ‘a cow desiring the bull.’ But ''cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 127.</ref>

वैकर्ण
<u>'''Vaikarṇa'''</u> occurs but once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1190> vii. 18, 11.</ref> in the description of the '''[[दाशराज्ञ|Dāśarājña]],''' where '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' is stated to have overthrown the twenty-one tribes (''janān'') of the kings or folk of the two Vaikarṇas. Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_1190> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 103.</ref> conjectures that they were a joint people, the '''Kuru-Krivis:''' this is quite possible, and even probable. Vikarṇa as the name of a people is found in the Mahābhārata,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1190> vi. 2105.</ref> and a lexicographer<ref name=fx4_ve2_1190> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 261 ''et seq.,'' who sees in Vaikarṇau the two [[वैकर्ण|Vaikarṇa]] kings.</ref> places the Vikarṇas in Kaśmīr, a reminiscence probably of a real settlement of the Kurus in that country. ''Cf.'' '''[[उत्तर कुरु|Uttara Kuru]].'''

वैखानस
<u>'''Vaikhānasa'''</u> is the name of a mythical group of [[ऋषिस्|Ṛṣis]] who are said in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1191> xiv. 4, 7.</ref> to have been slain at '''[[मुनिमरण|Munimaraṇa]]''' by '''[[रहस्यु देवमलिम्लुच्|Rahasyu Devamalimluc]],''' and who are mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka also.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1191> i. 23, 3 (''Indische Studien,'' 1, 78).</ref> An individual [[वैखानस|Vaikhānasa]] is '''[[पुरुहन्मन्|Puruhanman]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1191> xiv. 9, 29.</ref> 

वैजान
<u>'''Vaijāna,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vijāna,’ is Sāyaṇa's version of the patronymic of '''Vṛśa''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1192> xiii. 3, 12.</ref> The real reading is ''vai Jānaḥ,'' as pointed out by Weber.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1192> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 32.</ref>

वैट्टभटी-पुत्र
<u>'''Vaiṭṭabhaṭī-putra'''</u> is the name in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 2) of a teacher, a pupil of '''Kāraśakeyīputra,''' ''Cf.'' '''[[वैदभृतीपुत्र|Vaidabhṛtīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वैडव
<u>'''Vaiḍava,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Vīḍu,'''’ is the patronymic of a '''Vaisiṣṭha''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 8, 14), where he is said to have been the seer of a Sāman or Chant.<br>==Foot Notes==

वैदूर्य
<u>'''Vaidūrya,'''</u> ‘beryl,’ is first '''found in''' the late Adbhuta [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1195> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 40;<br> ''Omina und Portenta,'' 325 ''et seq.''</ref>

वैतरण
<u>'''Vaitaraṇa'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1196> x. 61, 17.</ref> Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1196> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2.</ref> thinks the word is a patronymic, but it seems rather<ref name=fx3_ve2_1196> Ludwig, Translation of the Rig. veda, 3, 165;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 457, n.</ref> to be an adjective in the sense of ‘belonging to Vitaraṇa’ used of Agni, like Agni of '''[[भरत|Bharata]]''' or of '''[[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]].'''

वैतहव्य
<u>'''Vaitahavya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]],'''’ is the name of a family who are said in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1197> v. 18, 10. 11;<br> 19, 1.</ref> to have come to ruin because they devoured a Brahmin's cow. They are said to be '''Sṛñjayas,''' but as the exact form of the legend here referred to does not occur elsewhere, its authenticity is open to some doubt.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1197> Moomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 434.</ref> According to Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1197> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 132.</ref> [[वैतहव्य|Vaitahavya]] is a mere epithet of the Sṛñjayas, but this is not probable<ref name=fx4_ve2_1197> ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 405;<br> Weber ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 233.</ref> in view of the existence of a [[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]]. 

वैद
<u>'''Vaida,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vida,’ is the patronymic of '''[[हिरण्यदन्त्|Hiraṇyadant]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1198> iii. 6, 4;<br> Āśvalāyana Śranta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 10, 9.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1198> ii. 1, 5.</ref> The word is also written Baida.

वैदथिन
<u>'''Vaidathina,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vidathin,’ is the patronymic of '''[[ऋजिश्वन्|Ṛjiśvan]]''' in the Rigveda (iv. 16, 11; v. 29, 13).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैदद्-अश्वि
<u>'''Vaidad-aśvi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vidadaśva,’ is the patronymic of [[तरन्त|Taranta]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1200> v. 61, 10.</ref> In the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1200> xiii. 7, 12. ''Cf.'' Śāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. ix. 58, 3.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1200> i. 151;<br> iii. 139, where Vaitadaśvi is the form. ''Cf.'' Ārṣeya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], p. 54 (ed. Burnell).<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 360;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesell schaft,'' 42, 232, n.;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 354;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 62 ''et seq.''.</ref> the Vaidadaśvis are [[तरन्त|Taranta]] and '''Purumīlha.''' The latter is not a [[वैदद्अश्वि|Vaidadaśvi]] in the Rigveda, a clear sign of the worthlessness of the legends relative to these two men in the Brāhmaṇas.

वैदभृती-पुत्र
<u>'''Vaidabhṛtī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Vedabhṛt,’ is the name of a teacher in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 32). ''Cf.'' '''[[वैट्टभटीपुत्र|Vaiṭṭabhaṭīputra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वैदर्भ
<u>'''Vaidarbha,'''</u> ‘prince of [[विदर्भ|Vidarbha]],’ is applied to '''Bhīma''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 34, 9).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैदर्भि
<u>'''Vaidarbhi,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[विदर्भ|Vidarbha]],'''’ is the patronymic of a '''[[भार्गव|Bhārgava]]''' in the [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 1; ii. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैदेह
<u>'''Vaideha,'''</u> ‘prince of [[विदेह|Videha]],’ is the title of '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' and of '''[[नमी साप्य|Namī Sāpya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वैधस
<u>'''Vaidhasa,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vedhas,’ is the patronymic of '''Hariścandra''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāhmana (vii. 13, 1) and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xv. 17. 1). <br>==Foot Notes==

वैन्य
<u>'''Vainya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Vena,'''’ is the patronymic of the mythic '''[[पृथि|Pṛthi]], Pṛthī,''' or '''[[पृथु|Pṛthu]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1206> Rv. viii. 9, 10;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 20;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. v. 3, 5, 4, etc.</ref>

वैपश्चित
<u>'''Vaipaścita'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Vipaścit'''’) '''[[दार्ढ-जयन्ति|Dārḍha-jayanti]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[दृढजयन्त|Dṛḍhajayanta]]'''’) '''[[गुप्त|Gupta]] [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[लोहित|Lohita]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[वैपश्चित|Vaipaścita]] [[दार्ढजयन्ति|Dārḍhajayanti]] [[दृढजयन्त|Dṛḍhajayanta]] [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]],''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैपश्चित
<u>'''Vaipaścita'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Vipaścit'''’) '''[[दार्ढजयन्ति|Dārḍhajayanti]]''' (‘descendant of '''Dṛdhajayanta'''’) '''[[दृढजयन्त|Dṛḍhajayanta]] [[लौहित्य|Lauhitya]]''' (‘descendant of Lohita’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[विपश्चित् दृढजयन्त लौहित्य|Vipaścit <a class="pada_vei" href="दृढजयन्त">Dṛḍhajayanta]] Lauhitya»,''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैयश्व
<u>'''Vaiyaśva,'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[व्य्अश्व|Vyaśva]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[विश्वमनस्|Viśvamanas]]''' in the Rigveda (viii. 23, 24, 24, 23; 26, 11).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैयाघ्रपदी-पुत्र
<u>'''Vaiyāghrapadī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Vyāghrapad,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[काण्वी-पुत्र|Kāṇvī-putra]],''' in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 5, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैयाघ्र-पद्य
<u>'''Vaiyāghra-padya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Vyāghrapad,’ is the patronymic of '''Indradyumna [[भाल्लवेय|Bhāllaveya]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1211> x. 6, 1, 8.</ref> and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1211> v. 14, 1.</ref> of '''[[बुडिल आश्वतराश्वि|Buḍila Āśvatarāśvi]]''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1211> v. 16, 1.</ref> and of '''Gośruti''' in that [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1211> v. 2, 3.</ref> and in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1211> ix. 7 (Gośruta-[[वैयाघ्रपद्य|vaiyāghrapadya]] as a compound).</ref> In the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1211> iii. 40, 1;<br> iv. 16. 1.</ref> the patronymic is applied to '''[[राम क्रातुजातेय|Rāma Krātujāteya]].''' 

वैयास्क
<u>'''Vaiyāska'''</u> is read in one passage of the Rigveda Prātiśākhya,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1212> xvii. 25.</ref> as the name of an authority on the metres of the Rigveda. Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1212> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> is clearly right in thinking that '''[[यास्क|Yāska]]''' is meant.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1212> The name not being a patronymic from Viyāska, but standing for ''vai Yāskaḥ, Cf.'' '''[[वैजान|Vaijāna]].'''</ref>

वैर
<u>'''Vaira'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1213> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 1, 12. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 2, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 2;<br> Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā, viii. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī, Saṃhitā, i. 7, 5, all of which have ''vīram'' for ''vairam,'' perhaps wrongly.</ref> and '''[[वैर|Vaira]]-deya'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1213> Rv. v. 61, 8 (on the exact sense of which, ''cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 361;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 92;<br> Oldenberg, ''RgvedaNoten,'' 1, 354);<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā xxiii. 8;<br> xxviii. 2. 3. 6.</ref> seem to have in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas the definite and technical sense of ‘wergeld,’ the money to be paid for killing a man as a compensation to his relatives. This view is borne out by the Sūtras of Āpastamba<ref name=fx3_ve2_1213> i. 9, 24, 1-4.</ref> and [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_1213> i. 10, 19, 1, 2.</ref> Both prescribe the scale of 1,000 cows for a '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]],'''<ref name=fx5_ve2_1213> The crime of slaying a Brahmin is too heinous for a wergeld. See Āpastamba, i. 9, 24, 7 ''et seq.;<br>'' [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]], i. 10, 18, 18.</ref> 100 for a '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]],''' 10 for a '''[[शूद्र|Śūdra]],''' and a bull over and above in each case. Āpastamba leaves the destination of the payment vague, but [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] assigns it to the king. It is reasonable to suppose that the cows were intended for the relations, and the bull was a present to the king for his intervention to induce the injured relatives to abandon the demand for the life of the offender. The Āpastamba [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1213> i. 9, 24, 5.</ref> allows the same scale of wergeld for women, but the [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx7_ve2_1213> i. 10, 19, 3.</ref> puts them on a level with men of the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] caste only, except in one special case. The payment is made for the purpose of ''[[वैर|vaira]]-yātana'' or ''[[वैर|vaira]]-niryātana,'' ‘requital of enmity,’ ‘expiation.’<br><br>The Rigveda<ref name=fx8_ve2_1213> ii. 32, 4.</ref> preserves, also, the important notice that a man's wergeld was a hundred (cows), for it contains the epithet ''śata-[[दाय|dāya]],'' ‘one whose wergeld is a hundred.’ No doubt the values varied, but in the case of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' the amount is a hundred (cows) in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx9_ve2_1213> vii. 15, 7.</ref> In the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx10_ve2_1213> See n. 1. The word is not found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]].</ref> ''śata-[[दाय|dāya]]'' again appears. <br><br>The fixing of the price shows that already public opinion, and perhaps the royal authority, was in Rigvedic times diminishing the sphere of private revenge; on the other hand, the existence of the system shows how weak was the criminal authority of the king (''cf.'' '''[[धर्म|Dharma]]''').<br><br>''Cf.'' Roth, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 41, 672676; Bühler and von Schroeder, ''Festgruss an Roth,'' 44-52; Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 2, 78, 79; 14, 201 Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 402 Jolly, ''Recht und Sitte,'' 131, 132; Delbrück in Leist, ''Altarisches Jus Gentium,'' 297.

वैर-हत्य
<u>'''Vaira-hatya,'''</u> ‘manslaughter,’ is mentioned in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxx. 13) and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 5, 9, 5). ''Cf.'' '''Vīrahan.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वै-राज्य
<u>'''Vai-rājya.'''</u> See '''[[राज्य|Rājya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

वैरूप
<u>'''Vairūpa,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[विरूप|Virūpa]],’ is the patronymic of '''Aṣṭādaṃṣṭra''' in the Pañcavimśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 9, 21).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैशन्त
<u>'''Vaiśanta'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1217> vii. 33, 2.</ref> of a prince whose offering Indra is said to have deserted for that of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' through the aid of the '''Vasiṣṭhas.''' Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_1217> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173.</ref> thinks that the name is Veśanta, and that he was a priest of the '''[[पृथु|Pṛthu]]-Parśus;''' Griffith<ref name=fx3_ve2_1217> ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 24, n. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 130.</ref> says that probably a river is meant, but neither of these views is plausible.

वैशंपायन
<u>'''Vaiśaṃpāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Viśaṃpa,’ is the name of a teacher, famous later, but in the earlier Vedic literature known only to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (i. 7, 5) and the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras.<br>==Foot Notes==

वै-शालेय
<u>'''Vai-śāleya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Viśāla,’ is the patronymic of the mythic '''Takṣaka''' in the Atharvaveda (viii. 10, 29).<br>==Foot Notes==

वैशी-पुत्र
<u>'''Vaiśī-putra,'''</u> ‘the son of a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] wife,’ is mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1220> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 7, 3;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2.</ref> 

वैश्य
<u>'''Vaiśya'''</u> denotes a man, not so much of the people, as of the subject class, distinct from the ruling noble ('''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]''') and the '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],''' the higher strata of the Āryan community on the one side, and from the aboriginal '''[[शूद्र|Śūdra]]''' on the other. The name is first found in the [[पुरुष|Puruṣa]]-[[सूक्त|sūkta]] (‘hymn of man’) in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1221> x. 90, 12.</ref> and then frequently from the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1221> v. 17. 9.</ref> onwards,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1221> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5. etc. See [[वर्ण|Varṇa]].</ref> sometimes in the form of Viśya.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1221> Av. vi. 13, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 48, etc.</ref><br><br>The [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] plays singularly little part in Vedic literature, which has much to say of [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] and Brahmin. His characteristics are admirably summed up in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1221> vii. 29. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 439.</ref> in the adjectives ''anyasya bali-kṛt,'' ‘tributary to another’; ''anyasyādya,'' ‘to be lived upon by another’; and ''yathākāmajyeyaḥ,'' ‘to be oppressed at will.’ He was unquestionably taxed by the king ('''[[राजन्|Rājan]]'''), who no doubt assigned to his retinue the right of support by the people, so that the Kṣatriyas grew more and more to depend on the services rendered to them by the Vaiśyas. But the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] was not a slave: he could not be killed by the king or anyone else without the slayer incurring risk and the payment of a wergeld ('''[[वैर|Vaira]]'''), which even in the Brahmin books extends to 100 cows for a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]. Moreover, though the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] could be expelled by the king at pleasure, he cannot be said to have been without property in his land. Hopkins<ref name=fx6_ve2_1221> ''India, Old and New,'' 222 ''et seq.''</ref> thinks it is absurd to suppose that he could really be a landowner when he was subject to removal at will, but this is to ignore the fact that normally the king could not remove the landowner, and that kings were ultimately dependent on the people, as the tales of exiled kings show.<br><br>On the other hand, Hopkins<ref name=fx7_ve2_1221> ''Op. cit.,'' 210 ''et seq.''</ref> is clearly right in holding that the [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] was really an agriculturist, and that Vedic society was not merely a landholding aristocracy, superimposed upon an agricultural aboriginal stock, as Baden Powell<ref name=fx8_ve2_1221> ''Indian Village Community,'' 190 ''et seq.''</ref> urged. Without ignoring the possibility that the Dravidians were agriculturists, there is no reason to deny that the Āryans were  so likewise, and the goad of the plougher was the mark of a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] in life<ref name=fx9_ve2_1221> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 1.</ref> and in death.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1221> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], lxxx.</ref> It would be absurd to suppose that the Āryan Vaiśyas did not engage in industry and commerce (''cf.'' '''[[पणि|Paṇi]], [[वणिज्|Vaṇij]]'''), but pastoral pursuits and agriculture must have been their normal occupations.<br><br>In war the Vaiśyas must have formed the bulk of the force under the [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]] leaders (see '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]'''). But like the Homeric commoners, the Vaiśyas may well have done little of the serious fighting, being probably ill-provided with either body armour or offensive weapons.<br><br>That the Vaiśyas were engaged in the intellectual life of the day is unlikely; nor is there any tradition, corresponding to that regarding the Kṣatriyas, of their having taken part in the evolution of the doctrine of [[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]], the great philosophic achievement of the age. The aim of the Vaiśya's ambition was, according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx11_ve2_1221> ii. 5, 4, 4.</ref> to become a '''Grāmaṇī,''' or village headman, a post probably conferred by the king on wealthy Vaiśyas, of whom no doubt there were many. It is impossible to say if in Vedic times a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] could attain to nobility or become a Brahmin. No instance can safely be quoted in support of such a view,<ref name=fx12_ve2_1221> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 55 ''et seq.,'' argues to the contrarya from Buddhist evidence;<br> but this has no cogency for the Vedic period, and much, if not all, of it is hardly in point as concerns this issue.</ref> though such changes of status may have taken place (see '''[[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]]''' and '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]''').<br><br>It is denied by Fick<ref name=fx13_ve2_1221> ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 163, ''et seq.''</ref> that the Vaiśyas were ever a caste, and the denial is certainly based on good grounds if it is held that a caste means a body within which marriage is essential, and which follows a hereditary occupation (''cf.'' '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]'''). But it would be wrong<ref name=fx14_ve2_1221> ''Cf. Indian Empire,'' 1, 347.</ref> to suppose that the term [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] was merely applied by theorists to the people who were not nobles or priests. It must have been an early appellation of a definite class which was separate from the other classes, and properly to be compared with them. Moreover, though there were differences among Vaiśyas, there were equally differences among Kṣatriyas and Brāhmanas, and it is impossible to deny  the Vaiśyas' claim to be reckoned a class or caste it the other two are such, though at the present day things are different.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 213 ''et seq.;'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 1 ''et seq.;'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 7 ''et seq.;'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 242, 243; Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 76 ''et seq.'' (for the Epic [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]).

वैश्वा-मित्र
<u>'''Vaiśvā-mitra,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],'''’ is the term by which that famous priest's line is referred to in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 17 ''et seq.'').<br>==Foot Notes==

वैष्ठ-पुरेय
<u>'''Vaiṣṭha-pureya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Viṣṭhapura,’ is the name of a teacher in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] in the Mādhyaṃdina recension (ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 25). He was a pupil of '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]''' and '''[[रौहिणायन|Rauhiṇāyana]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

व्यछ
<u>'''Vyacha'''</u> in ''go-[[व्यछ|vyacha]],'' the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1224> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 16, 1. ''Cf.'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4.</ref> is of uncertain signification. According to Sāyaṇa,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1224> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> the compound denotes a ‘driver out of cows.’ Perhaps it means a ‘tormentor of cows,’ as the St. Petersburg Dictionary takes it. Weber<ref name=fx3_ve2_1224> ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 82, n. 11. This interpretation is supported by the use of the word in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]], where it replaces the '''[[गोविकर्तन|Govikartana]]''' of other texts, See '''[[रत्निन्|Ratnin]]''' (p. 200).</ref> renders it as ‘knacker of cows,’ Eggeling as ‘one who approaches cows.’<br><br>^4 ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 416.

व्य्-अद्वर
<u>'''Vy-advara,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1225> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4, 1, 27. ''Cf.'' Av. vi. 50, 2.</ref> '''Vy-advarī,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1225> Av. iii. 28, 2, where a worm is certainly not meant.</ref> are the names of a ‘gnawing’ (''ad,'' ‘eat’) animal in the Atharvaveda and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. ''Cf.'' also '''[[व्यध्वर|Vyadhvara]],''' which the St. Petersburg Dictionary would read throughout. 

व्यध्वर
<u>'''Vyadhvara,'''</u> ‘perforating,’ designates a worm in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1226> ii. 31, 4.</ref> where there seems to be no good reason to alter the reading to [[व्य्अद्वर|Vyadvara]], though Whitney<ref name=fx2_ve2_1226> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 74.</ref> thinks that it may rather be connected with ''vi-adhvan''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1226> This would mean ‘diverging from the road,’ ‘devious.’</ref> than with the root ''vyadh,'' ‘pierce.’<ref name=fx4_ve2_1226> The Padapāṭha analyzes the word as ''vi-adhvara.''</ref> The term occurs with '''[[मशक|Maśaka]],''' ‘fly,’ in the Hiraṇyakeśi [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_1226> ii. 16, 3.</ref> and perhaps also in another passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1226> vi. 50, 3.</ref> where, however, both Whitney<ref name=fx7_ve2_1226> ''Op. cit.,'' 318, ''Cf.'' 135.<br><br>''Cf.'' also Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 316, 361, 487;<br> Lanman in Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 318.</ref> and Shaṅkar Paṇḍit read '''[[व्य्अद्वर|Vyadvara]].'''

व्यल्कशा
<u>'''Vyalkaśā'''</u> is the name of a plant in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1227> x. 16, 13. ''Cf.'' Zimmer ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70.</ref>

व्य्-अश्व
<u>'''Vy-aśva'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]], a protégé of the Aśvins,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1228> Rv. i. 112, 15.</ref> mentioned in several hymns of the eighth Maṇḍala,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1228> viii. 23, 16. 23;<br> 24, 22;<br> 26, 9.</ref> which may have been the composition of a descendant of his, '''[[विश्वमनस्|Viśvamanas]].''' In two other passages<ref name=fx3_ve2_1228> Rv. viii. 9, 10;<br> ix. 65, 7.</ref> he is referred to only as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] of the past, and Oldenberg<ref name=fx4_ve2_1228> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenlāndischen Gesellschaft'' 42, 217.</ref> points out that none of his own work appears in the Saṃhitā. The Rigveda also mentions<ref name=fx5_ve2_1228> Rv. viii. 24, 28.</ref> the Vyaśvas, with whom Ludwig<ref name=fx6_ve2_1228> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 106.</ref> is inclined to connect '''[[वश अश्व्य|Vaśa Aśvya]].''' An '''[[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]]''' [[व्य्अश्व|Vyaśva]] occurs as a seer of Sāmans or Chants in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx7_ve2_1228> xiv. 10. 9.</ref>

व्य्-अष्टि
<u>'''Vy-aṣṭi'''</u> is the name of a mythical teacher in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka '''[[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1229> iv. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> 

व्या-ख्यान
<u>'''Vyā-khyāna'''</u> in one passage of the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1230> iii. 6, 2, 7.</ref> clearly denotes a ‘narrative’ merely--viz., that of the dispute of [[कद्रू|Kadrū]] and Suparṇī. In other passages<ref name=fx2_ve2_1230> vi. 1, 27. 33;<br> vii. 2, 4, 28.</ref> the word means simply ‘commentary.’ In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1230> ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 6 (Mādhyaṃdina = 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> 5, 11.</ref> used in the plural, it signifies a species of writing, apparently ‘commentaries,’ though its exact relation to '''[[अनुव्याख्यान|Anuvyākhyāna]]''' must remain obscure. Sieg<ref name=fx4_ve2_1230> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 21, 34.</ref> thinks that the Vyākhyānas were forms of narrative like '''[[अन्वाख्यान|Anvākhyāna]]''' and [[अनुव्याख्यान|Anuvyākhyāna]].

व्याघ्र
<u>'''Vyāghra,'''</u> ‘tiger,’ is never found in the Rigveda, but frequently occurs in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1231> iv. 3, 1;<br> 36, 6;<br> vi. 38, 1;<br> 103, 3;<br> 140, 1;<br> xii. 1, 49;<br> 2, 43;<br> xix. 46, 5;<br> 49, 4.</ref> as well as the lion This fact is legitimately regarded as an indication that the Atharvaveda belongs to a period when the Vedic Indian had approached and entered the territory of Bengal. Later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1231> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 5, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 9;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 9;<br> xix. 10;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 3 Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 1, 8;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 9, 3;<br> 10, 2, etc.</ref> also, mention of the tiger is quite common. The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_1231> v. 4, 10, 5.</ref> preserves a reference to the danger of waking a sleeping tiger. The destructive character of the animal is often alluded to,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1231> ''Cf.'' Av. iv. 36, 6;<br> viii. 5, 11, and see '''[[शशयु|Śaśayu]].'''</ref> the man-eater (''puruṣād'')<ref name=fx5_ve2_1231> Av. xii. 1, 49.</ref> being also mentioned. Like the lion, the tiger passes as a symbol of strength.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1231> Av. iv. 8, 4, 7. ''Cf.'' [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 18.</ref> This idea is illustrated by the fact that the king at the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]]''' (‘royal consecration’) steps<ref name=fx7_ve2_1231> Av. iv. 8, 4. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 92. He does not wear the skin, as Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 79, says.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities'' 249, 250.</ref> on a tiger's skin to win himself the strength of the animal. ''Cf.'' also '''[[शार्दूल|Śārdūla]], [[पेत्व|Petva]].'''

व्याघ्र-पद्य
<u>'''Vyāghra-padya'''</u> is a false reading in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (v. 16, 1) for '''[[वैयाघ्रपद्य|Vaiyāghrapadya]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

व्याधि
<u>'''Vyādhi,'''</u> ‘disease,’ occurs several times in Vedic literature.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1233> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 10, 3;<br> Saḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 8.</ref> The specific diseases are dealt with under the separate names, but the Vedic texts also mention innumerable bodily defects. The list of victims<ref name=fx2_ve2_1233> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 10. 17. 21;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 6, 1;<br> 14, 1;<br> 17, 1.</ref> at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) includes a ‘dwarf’ (''vāmana, kubja''), a ‘bald’ person (''khalati''),<ref name=fx3_ve2_1233> ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 6, 5.</ref> a ‘blind’ man (''andha''),<ref name=fx4_ve2_1233> ''Cf.'' Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 2, 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 1, 9;<br> 13, 2;<br> viii. 4, 2;<br> 9, 1;<br> 10, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 3.</ref> a ‘deaf’ man (''badhira''),<ref name=fx5_ve2_1233> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 2, 10;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 1, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> a ‘dumb’ man (''mūka''),<ref name=fx6_ve2_1233> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> a ‘fat’ man (''pīvan''), a ‘leper’ (''[[सिध्मल|sidhmala]], [[किलास|kilāsa]]''),<ref name=fx7_ve2_1233> ''[[किलास|Kilāsa]]'' also in [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 3, 17;<br> xxiii. 16, 11. etc.</ref> a ‘yellow-eyed’ man (''hary-[[अक्ष|akṣa]]''), a ‘tawny-eyed’ man (''piṅgākṣa''), a ‘cripple’ (''[[पीठ|pīṭha]]-sarpin''), a ‘lame’ man (''srāma''), a ‘sleepless’ man (''jāgaraṇa''), a ‘sleepy’ man (''svapana''), one<ref name=fx8_ve2_1233> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 19, 1, where are added the man who winks too much (''ati-mirmira''), has too prominent teeth (''ati-dantura'') or too small teeth (''ati-kiriṭa''). and who stares excessively (''ati-memiṣa''), ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 84, n. 4.</ref> ‘too tall’ (''ati-dīrgha''), one ‘too short’ (''ati-hrasva''), one ‘too stout’ (''ati-sthāla'' or ''aty-aṃsala''), one ‘too thin’ (''ati-[[कृश|kṛśa]]''), one ‘too white’ (''ati-[[शुक्ल|śukla]]''), one ‘too dark’ (''ati-[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]''), one ‘too bald’ (''ati-kulva''), and one ‘too hairy’ (''ati-lomaśa'').<br><br>In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx9_ve2_1233> iv. 1, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 9. ''Cf.'' Av. vii. 65, 3.</ref> the man with bad nails and the man with brown teeth are mentioned along with sinners like the '''[[दिधिषूपति|Didhiṣūpati]].''' The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx10_ve2_1233> xiii. 3, 6, 5. See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 323, n.</ref> mentions a ‘white-spotted (''[[शुक्ल|śukla]]''), bald-headed man, with projecting teeth (''viklidha'') and reddish-brown eyes.’ Interesting is Zimmer's<ref name=fx11_ve2_1233> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 428.</ref> suggestion that ''kirmira'' found in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx12_ve2_1233> xxx. 21.</ref> means ‘spotty’ as an intermixture of races, but it is only a conjecture, apparently based on a supposed connexion of the word with ''kṛ,'' ‘mix.’ In the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx13_ve2_1233> xxx. 15, especially ''avijātā'' and ''vijarjarā,'' beside ''avatokā'' and ''paryāyiṇī;<br> atītvarī'' and ''atiṣkadvarī'' are also possibly so to be understood. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 80.</ref> and the  [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx14_ve2_1233> iii. 4, 11, 1, where ''apaskadvarī'' and ''paryāriṇī'' are read.</ref> various epithets are applied to women, some of which seem to denote disease, and in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx15_ve2_1233> i. 18, 4. Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 314, understands the hymn as referring to the domestic cat, but this lacks plausibility. The sense of the other epithets there occurring is quite obscure.</ref> the feminine adjectives, ‘antelope-footed’ (''[[ऋश्य|ṛśya]]-padī'') and ‘bulltoothed’ (''[[वृष|vṛṣa]]-datī''), probably refer to bodily defects.

व्य्-आन
<u>'''Vy-āna'''</u> is the name of one of the vital airs. See '''[[प्राण|Prāṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

व्याम
<u>'''Vyāma'''</u> in the Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1235> Av. vi. 137, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 1, 4;<br> 2, 5, 1, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_1235> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 2, 3, 1. 2;<br> i. 2, 5, 14;<br> vii. 1, 1, 37, where the scholiast equates it to 4 Aratnis or cubits (while the scholiast on Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 1, 9, regards it as equal to 5 Aratnis). According to the Śulva [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] of [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]], the '''[[अरत्नि|Aratni]]''' equals 24 ''aṅgula'' (= (3/4) inch). See Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatie Society,'' 1912, 231, 233, 234.</ref> denotes the ‘span’ of the outstretched arms as a measure of length. It may be estimated at six feet or equivalent to a fathom.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1235> See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 309, n. 5.</ref>

व्यास पाराशर्य
<u>'''Vyāsa Pārāśarya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[पराशर|Parāśara]]'''’) is the name of a mythical sage who in the Vedic period is found only as a pupil of '''[[विष्वक्सेन|Viṣvaksena]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teacheres) at the end of the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and in the late [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1236> i. 9, 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 156;<br> 4, 377;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 184, n. 199.</ref>

व्र
<u>'''Vra,'''</u> according to Roth,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1237> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Bechtel, ''Nachrichten der ko7niglichen Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu Go7ttingen,'' 1894, 393.</ref> means ‘troop’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1237> i. 124, 8;<br> 126, 5;<br> iv. 1, 16;<br> viii. 2, 6;<br> x. 123, 2. He omits i. 121, 2, where Bo7litlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' treats the word as a feminine (''vrā'').</ref> and the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1237> ii. 1, 1, a confused passage, on which see Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 37, 38.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve2_1237> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 162.</ref> sees in the word (in the feminine form of ''vrā'') a designation in one passage of the village host which formed part of the '''[[विश्|Viś]],''' and was composed of relations (''[[सु-बन्धु|su-bandhu]]''). On the other hand, Pischel<ref name=fx5_ve2_1237> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 121, 313 ''et seq.''</ref> thinks that in all the passages Vrā means ‘female,’ used either of animals<ref name=fx6_ve2_1237> Rv. i. 121, 2;<br> viii. 2, 6 (female elephants).</ref> or of  women who go to the feast ('''[[समन|Samana]]'''),<ref name=fx7_ve2_1237> Rv. i. 124, 8.</ref> or courtezans (''viśyā,'' ‘of the people’),<ref name=fx8_ve2_1237> Rv. i. 126. 5.</ref> or, metaphorically,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1237> Rv. iv. 1, 16;<br> x. 123, 2;<br> Av., ''loc. cit.''</ref> the hymns compared with courtezans; these senses are perhaps adequate.

व्रज
<u>'''Vraja'''</u> denotes in the first instance, in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1238> Rv. ii. 38, 8;<br> x. 26, 3, and perhaps 97, 10;<br> 101, 8. ''Cf.'' [[मेधातिथि|Medhātithi]] on Manu, iv. 45, and Mahābhārata, i. 41, 15, where ''go-[[व्रज|vraja]]'' is equal to ''gavāṃ pracārāḥ,'' ‘the pastures of the kine,’ in i. 40, 17.</ref> the place to which the cattle resort (from ''vraj,'' ‘go’), the ‘feeding ground’ to which the milk-giving animals go out<ref name=fx2_ve2_1238> Rv. ii. 38, 8.</ref> in the morning from the village ('''[[ग्राम|Grāma]]'''), while the others stay in it all day and night.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1238> ''Cf.'' Sāyaṇa on [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 18, 14.</ref> Secondarily it denotes the ‘herd’<ref name=fx4_ve2_1238> Rv. v. 35, 4;<br> vii. 27, 1;<br> 32, 10;<br> viii. 46, 9;<br> 51, 5.</ref> itself. This is Geldner's view,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1238> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 282 ''et seq.;<br> Rigreda, Glossar,'' 174. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 77.</ref> which seems clearly better than that of Roth<ref name=fx6_ve2_1238> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' But ''cf.'' Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> who regards [[व्रज|Vraja]] as primarily the ‘enclosure’ (from ''vṛj''), and only thence the ‘herd’; for the [[व्रज|Vraja]] does not normally mean an ‘enclosure’ at all: the Vedic cattle were not stall-fed as a general rule. In some passages, however, ‘pen,’<ref name=fx7_ve2_1238> Av. iii. 11, 5;<br> iv. 38, 7;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 16. Metaohorically, in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 22, Mādhyaṃdina, it is a pen with a bolt (''sārgala'') and with a palisade (''sa-pariśraya''). The sense of ‘pen’ is also possible in Rv. x. 97, 10;<br> 101, 8, and is not radically opposed to it, for [[व्रज|Vraja]] denotes the place where the cattle are fed, and can therefore be applied to the stall where they are during the night. ''Cf.'' '''[[गोष्ठ|Goṣṭha]].'''</ref> in others ‘stall,’<ref name=fx8_ve2_1238> Rv. x. 4, 2, where the ‘warm Vraja’ to which the cows resort is alluded to, and iv. 51, 2, where the Dawns open wide the doors of the [[व्रज|Vraja]] of darkness;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]. [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 12, 2, where the [[व्रज|Vraja]] is said to be made of [[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]] wood. The sense of ‘stall’ is probable in Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 25.</ref> is certainly meant. The word is often used in the myth of the robbing of the kine.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1238> See Geldner, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 283 ''et seq.''</ref> It occasionally denotes a ‘cistern.’<ref name=fx10_ve2_1238> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, x. 4 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 11, 1 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 7.</ref> 

व्रत
<u>'''Vrata'''</u> (‘vow’) in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1239> Av. vi. 133, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 5, 3. 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iv. 11. etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_1239> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 2, 10. 14, 17;<br> 4, 2, 15;<br> ix. 2, 1, 18. ''Cf. ghṛtavrata,'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 2, 5. 6, and ''[[व्रत|vrata]]-[[दुघा|dughā]],'' the ‘cow that gives the [[व्रत|Vrata]] milk,’ Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 2, 14;<br> xiv. 3, 1, 34. etc.</ref> has the peculiar sense of the ‘milk’ used by one who is living on that beverage alone as a vow or penance.

व्रतति
<u>'''Vratati'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1240> viii. 40, 6;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], i. 14;<br> vi. 28.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1240> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 1, 3, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘creeping plant.’

व्राज-पति
<u>'''Vrāja-pati'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1241> x. 179, 2 = Av. vii. 72, 2.</ref> where it is said that comrades attend Indra, as the '''Kulapas''' the [[व्राजपति|Vrājapati]], when he goes about. Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_1241> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 171.</ref> thinks that this refers to the heads of families being subordinate in war to the village headman ('''Grāmaṇī'''), but Whitney<ref name=fx3_ve2_1241> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 436.</ref> seems to be right in seeing merely the chieftain surrounded by the leading men, the family heads, not necessarily merely a village headman. Vrāja alone occurs in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1241> i. 16, 1. ''Cf.'' Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 17.</ref> adverbially in the sense of ‘in troops.’

व्राज-बाहु
<u>'''Vrāja-bāhu'''</u> is used in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 9) of the ‘encompassing arms’ of death, Vrāja here apparently meaning a ‘pen,’ like '''[[व्रज|Vraja]].''' ''Cf.'' '''[[विष्ठा-व्राजिन्|Viṣṭhā-vrājin]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

व्रात
<u>'''Vrāta'''</u> is found in several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1243> i. 163, 8;<br> iii. 26, 2;<br> v. 53, 11;<br> ix. 14, 2 (perhaps an allusion to the five tribes);<br> x. 34, 8. 12 (of dice). In x. 57, 5, the host of the living (''jīva [[व्रात|vrāta]]'') is referred to.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1243> Av. ii. 9, 2 (‘host of the living’);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 10, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 25;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 9. 24;<br> xvii. 1, 5. 12, etc.</ref> in the sense of ‘troop.’ In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1243> v. 53, 11. ''Cf.'' iii. 26, 2, where ''[[शर्ध|śardha]]'' is not mentioned.</ref> the troops of the Maruts are referred to by three different terms--''[[शर्ध|śardha]], [[व्रात|vrāta]],'' and ''gaṇa.'' From this fact Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve2_1243> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 162.</ref> has  deduced that a Vedic host fought according to clan ('''[[विश्|Viś]]'''), village ('''[[ग्राम|Grāma]]'''), and family, but this conclusion is hardly warranted, there being nothing to show that there is any intention to present a distinct series of divisions. It is not probable that the word ever has the technical sense of ‘guild,’ as Roth<ref name=fx5_ve2_1243> In the St. Petersburg Dictionary, where this is taken to be the sense;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 9, 25;<br> xvii. 1, 5, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 25;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 10, 2.</ref> thinks. ''Cf.'' '''Vrātapati.'''

व्रात-पती
<u>'''Vrāta-patī,'''</u> ‘lord of troops,’ is an epithet included in the names of Rudra in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1244> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 4, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 25.</ref> along with the epithet Gaṇa-pati, ‘lord of groups.’ The exact sense is quite uncertain, but the term may allude to the chief of a band of robbers, as Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_1244> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 179.</ref> thinks.

व्रात्य
<u>'''Vrātya'''</u> is included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1245> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 5, 1.</ref> where, however, no further explanation of the name is given. Fuller information is furnished by the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1245> xv. 1, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1245> xvii. 1-4.</ref> and the Sūtras.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1245> Kātyāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 1;<br> xxii. 4;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 6;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 5, 4-14. See Hillebrandt, ''Ritualliteratur,'' 139, 140.</ref> which describe at length a certain rite intended for the use of Vrātyas. According to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], there are four different kinds of ‘outcasts’--viz., the ''hīna,'' who are merely described as ‘depressed’; those who have become outcasts for some sin (''nindita''); those who become outcasts at an early age, apparently by living among outcasts; and those old men who, being impotent (''śama-nīcameḍhra''), have gone to live with outcasts. The last three categories are by no means of the same importance as the first. The motive of the fourth is hard to understand: according to Rājārām Rām-  krishṇa Bhāgavat,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1245> ''Journal of the Bombay Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 19, 360.</ref> they were men who had enfeebled their constitutions by undue intercourse with women in the lands of the outcasts, and returned home in a debilitated state. But this is not stated in the text.<br><br>It seems probable that the really important Vrātyas were those referred to as ''hīna,'' and that the other classes were only subsidiary. According to Rājārām,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1245> ''Ibid.,'' 359.</ref> there were two categories of the first class: (''a'') The depressed (''hīna''), who were nonĀryan; and (''b'') degraded Āryans (''gara-gir''). This, however, is a mere guess, and devoid of probability. There seems to have been but one class of Vrātyas. That they were non-Āryan is not probable, for it is expressly said<ref name=fx7_ve2_1245> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 1</ref> that, though unconsecrated, they spoke the tongue of the consecrated: they were thus apparently Āryans. This view is confirmed by the statement that ‘they call what is easy of utterance, difficult to utter’: probable they and already a somewhat Prakritic form of speech (''cf.'' '''[[वाच्|Vāc]]'''). The Sūtras mention their Arhants (‘saints’) and Yaudhas (‘warrioes’), corresponding to the Brahminical [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]].<br><br>Other particulars accord with the view that they were Āryans outside the sphere of Brahmin culture. Thus they are said<ref name=fx8_ve2_1245> ''Ibid.,'' xvii. 1, 2.</ref> not to practise agriculture or commerce (an allusion to a nomadic life), not to observe the rules of '''[[ब्रह्मचर्य|Brahmacarya]]'''--''i.e.,'' the principle regulating the Brahminic order of life. They were also allowed to become members of the Brahminical community by performance of the ritual prescribed, which would hardly be so natural in the case of non-Āryans.<br><br>Some details are given of the life and dress of the Vrātyas. Their principles were opposed to those of the Brahmins: they beat those unworthy of correction.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1245> ''Ibid.,'' xvii. 1, 14.</ref> Their leder (Gṛhapati) or householder wore a turbrn ('''[[उष्णीष|Uṣṇīṣa]]'''), carried a whip ('''[[प्रतोद|Pratoda]]'''), a kind of bow ('''[[ज्याह्रोड|Jyāhroḍa]]'''), was clothed in a black (''kṛṣṇaśa'') garment and two skins ('''[[अजिन|Ajina]]'''), black and white (''[[कृष्ण|kṛṣṇa]]-valakṣa''), and owned a rough vagon ('''[[विपथ|Vipatha]]''') covered with planks  (''phalakāstīrṇa''). The others,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1245> ''Ibid.,'' xvii. 1, 15. The exact sense of the passages is obscure;<br> and was, as Lāṭyāyana shows, already obscure in his time and earlier;<br> the translations given are all vague. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 32 ''et seq.;<br> Indian Literature,'' 67, 68;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 31, 32;<br> Rājārām, ''loc. cit.''</ref> subordinate to the leader, had garments with fringes of red (''valūkāntāni dāmatūṣāṇi''), two fringes on each, skins folded double (''dviṣaṃhitāny ajināni''), and sandals ('''[[उपानह्|Upānah]]'''). The leader wore also an ornament ('''[[निष्क|Niṣka]]''') of silver, which Rājārām<ref name=fx11_ve2_1245> ''Op. cit.,'' 361.</ref> converts into a silver coinage. The Vrātyas, on becoming consecrated, were expected to hand over their goods to the priest. Many other details are given in the Sūtras (''e.g.,'' that the shoes or sandals were of variegated black hue and pointed), but these are not authenticated by the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<br><br>The locality in which the Vrātyas lived cannot be stated with certainty, but their nomad life<ref name=fx12_ve2_1245> Which is indicated by their name, ‘belonging to a roving band’ (''[[व्रात|vrāta]]''), ‘vagrant.’</ref> suggests the western tribes beyond the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]. But they may equally well have been in the east: this possibility is so far supported by the fact that the Sūtras make the Brahmin receiving the gift of the Vrātya's outfit an inhabitant of '''[[मगध|Magadha]].''' The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx13_ve2_1245> See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 770 ''et seq.,'' with '''Lanman's''' additions.</ref> does not help, for it treats the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] in so mystical a way that he is represented as being in all the quacters. Indeed, Roth<ref name=fx14_ve2_1245> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> believed that it was here not a case of the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] at all, but of a glorification of the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] as the type of the pious vagrant or wandering religious mendicant ('''[[परिव्राजक|Parivrājaka]]'''). This view is clearly wrong, as the occurrence of the words ''uṣṇīsa, [[विपथ|vipatha]],'' and ''pratoaa'' shows. It is probable that the 15th Book of the Atharvaveda, which deals with the [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]], and is of a mystical character, exalts the converted [[व्रात्य|Vrātya]] as a type of the perfect '''Brahmicārin,''' and, in so far, of the divinity.<ref name=fx15_ve2_1245> Boomfield, ''Atharvaveda,'' 94.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' i. 33, 52, 445, n.;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 67, 78, 110112, 14, 146;<br> Aufrecht, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 130 ''et seq.;<br>'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, xxvi ''et seq.;<br>'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 216.</ref> 

व्रीहि
<u>'''Vrīhi,'''</u> ‘rice,’ is never mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1246> To take ''[[धान्य|dhānya]] [[बीज|bīja]]'' in Rv. v. 53, 13, as ‘rice seeds’ is unnecessary and very improbable, nor is there better reason to see in ''[[धान्य|dhānya]] rasa'' in Av. ii. 26, 5. a ‘rice drink.’</ref> but is frequently alluded to in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1246> vi. 140, 2;<br> viii. 7, 20;<br> ix. 6, 14, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1246> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 10, 3, where it is said to ripen in autumn;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 6;<br> xi. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 10, 2;<br> iv. 3, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 12;<br> AitareyaBrāhmaṇa, ii. 8, 7;<br> 11, 12;<br> viii. 16, 3.4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 5, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 3, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 14, 3.</ref> Rice seems to be indigenous in the south-east of India:<ref name=fx4_ve2_1246> ii. 3, 1, 3. ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], 1, 7, 3, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 4. 5, 6, etc.</ref> this fact accounts well for the absence of any mention of it in the Rigveda. Black and white rice is contrasted in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1246> i. 8, 10, 1.</ref> where also<ref name=fx6_ve2_1246> Av. xi. 4, 13;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 43;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 10, 6, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 239.</ref> the distinctions of dark, swift-growing (''[[आशु|āśu]]''), and large rice (''mahā-[[व्रीहि|vrīhi]]'') are found. Probably the swift-growing variety is that later known as ''ṣaṣṭika,'' ‘ripening in sixty days.’ [[व्रीहि|Vrīhi]] and '''Yava,''' ‘barley,’ are normally conjoined in the texts.^7 ''Cf.'' '''[[प्लाशुक|Plāśuka]].'''

व्लेष्क
<u>'''Vleṣka.'''</u> See '''[[ब्लेष्क|Bleṣka]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शंयु
<u>'''Śaṃyu'''</u> is the name of a mythical son of [[बृहस्पति|Bṛhaspati]]. He is quoted as a teacher in the texts of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1248> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 10, 1;<br> v. 2, 6, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 8, 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9, 1, 24;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, i. 5, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 113.</ref>

शकट
<u>'''Śakaṭa,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1249> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 22;<br> xi. 47;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 8.</ref> '''Śakaṭī,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1249> Rv. x. 146, 3;<br> Saḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 7.</ref> are rare words in the older literature for a ‘cart.’ The creaking of a cart is referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1249/> as like the sound heard by night in the forest. 

शक-धूम
<u>'''Śaka-dhūma'''</u> is found in one hymn of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1250> vi. 128, 1, 3. 4, and in the [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]] [[कल्प|Kalpa]].</ref> where it is celebrated as the king of the asterisms. The word seems to mean the ‘smoke of (burning) cow-dung,’ or else the ‘smoke (rising) from (fresh) cow-dung’: it may well be, as Weber<ref name=fx2_ve2_1250> ''Omina and Portenta,'' 363;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 257;<br> 10, 65;<br> ''Naxatra,'' 2, 272, n.;<br> 293.</ref> thinks, that this was deemed to be significant of the weather. Bloomfield,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1250> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 7, 484 ''et seq.;<br> Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, cxxxiii;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 532, 533.</ref> however, considers that the word is to be rendered as ‘weather prophet,’ that is, one who foretells the weather by means of the smoke of a fire. Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve2_1250> Translation of the Atharvaveda. 377, 378.</ref> objects to this view with reason. It is not at all improbable that, as Roth<ref name=fx5_ve2_1250> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 353;<br> Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritnal,'' 175, n. 3.</ref> believed, an asterism of some sort is meant, probably the ‘milky way.’

शकन्
<u>'''Śakan.'''</u> See '''[[शकृत्|Śakṛt]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शक-पूत
<u>'''Śaka-pūta'''</u> (‘purified by cow-dung’) is the name, apparently, of a prince, in one hymn of the Rigveda (x. 132, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

शकं-भर
<u>'''Śakaṃ-bhara,'''</u> ‘bearer of dung,’ is found in one passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1253> v. 22. 4.</ref> where the sense is doubtful. Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_1253> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 510.</ref> and Grill<ref name=fx3_ve2_1253> ''Hundert Lieder^2,'' 154.</ref> see in it a tribal name, Bloomfield<ref name=fx4_ve2_1253> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 445, 446.</ref> the personification of excessive evacuation (diarrhœa), while Whitney<ref name=fx5_ve2_1253> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 259.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 253.</ref> considers that it may refer to the '''Mahāvṛṣas,''' despised as having to collect dung for fuel in the absence of wood in their country.

शका
<u>'''Śakā'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1254> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1;<br> 18, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇi Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 13;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 32.</ref> It is uncer-  tain whether a kind of bird<ref name=fx2_ve2_1254> Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> or fly,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1254> Sāyaṇa on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1;<br> 18, 1.</ref> or long-eared beast<ref name=fx4_ve2_1254> Sāyaṇa on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref> is intended.

शकुन
<u>'''Śakuna,'''</u> ‘bird,’ is mentioned frequently in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1255> iv. 26, 6;<br> ix. 85, 11;<br> 86, 13;<br> 107, 20;<br> 112, 2;<br> x. 68, 7;<br> 106, 3;<br> 123, 6;<br> 165. 2.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1255> Av. xii. 1, 51;<br> 3, 13;<br> xx. 127, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 6, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 53, etc.</ref> It usually denotes a large bird,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1255> ''Cf.'' Av. xi. 2, 24, as compared with '''[[वयस्|Vayas]];<br>''' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 18.</ref> or a bird which gives omens.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1255> ''Cf.'' [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 34, etc.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_1255> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 430.</ref> compares  which also is a bird of omen.

शकुनि
<u>'''Śakuni,'''</u> ‘bird,’ is used practically like '''[[शकुन|Śakuna]],''' but with a much clearer reference to divination. It was smaller than the '''[[श्येन|Śyena]]''' or '''[[सुपर्ण|Suparṇa]],'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1256> Rv. ii. 42, 2.</ref> gave signs,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1256> Rv. ii. 42, 1;<br> 43, 3.</ref> and foretold ill-luck.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1256> Av. x. 3, 6.</ref> When it is mentioned<ref name=fx4_ve2_1256> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 19, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 40;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 21.</ref> in the list of sacrificial victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’), a special species must be meant: later the falcon is so called, but the ‘raven’ may be intended; the commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā thinks that it is the ‘crow.’ It is mentioned several times elsewhere.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1256> Av. ii. 25, 2;<br> vii. 64, 1;<br> xi. 9, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 15, 12;<br> iv. 7, 3;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 1, 31;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 8, 2, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 88, 430.</ref>

शकुनि-मित्र
<u>'''Śakuni-mitra'''</u> is one of the names of '''Vipaścit [[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

शकुन्त
<u>'''Śakunta'''</u> is a name for ‘bird’ in the Atharvaveda (xi. 6, 8). <br>==Foot Notes==

शकुन्तक
<u>'''Śakuntaka,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1259> [[खिल|Khila]] after Rv. ii. 43;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 23.</ref> '''Śakuntikā,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1259> Rv. i. 191, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 22.</ref> are diminutives, meaning ‘little bird’ in the Saṃhitās.

शकुन्तला
<u>'''Śakuntalā'''</u> is the name of an Apsaras who bore '''[[भरत|Bharata]],''' according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1260> xiii. 5, 4, 13.</ref> at '''[[नाडपित्|Nāḍapit]].''' Weber<ref name=fx2_ve2_1260> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 6.</ref> doubtfully reads the latter word as Nāḍapitī, an epithet of [[शकुन्तला|Śakuntalā]].

शकुन्ति
<u>'''Śakunti'''</u> is found in the Rigveda (ii. 42, 3; 43, 1) denoting a ‘bird’ of omen.<br>==Foot Notes==

शकुल
<u>'''Śakula'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1262> Av. xx. 136, 1;<br> Vājasanevi Saṃhitā, xxii. 28. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97.</ref> denotes an unknown species of fish.

शकृत्
<u>'''Śakṛt,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1263> Used only in nominative and accusative: Rv. i. 161, 10;<br> Av. xii. 4, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 19, 3, etc.</ref> '''[[शकन्|Śakan]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1263> In the oblique cases [[शकन्|Śakan]] is the base, Av. xii. 4, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 23, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236.</ref> denotes ‘dung’ in the Rigveda and later. It is clear that the value of manure was early appreciated (see '''[[करीष|Karīṣa]]'''). For the use of the smoke of dung or of a dung fire for prognosticating the weather, see '''[[शकधूम|Śakadhūma]].'''

शक्ति
<u>'''1. Śakti'''</u> is said in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1264> ii. 390 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 47).</ref> to have been the son of '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]],''' and to have been cast into the fire by the '''Viśvāmitras.''' According to Ṣaḍguruśiṣya,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1264> Sarvānukramaṇī, ed. Macdonell, p. 107, and on Rv. vii. 32.</ref> who appears to follow the Śāṭyāyanaka,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1264> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 159, n. 3.</ref> the story of [[शक्ति|Śakti]] is as follows: [[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]], being defeated in a contest by [[शक्ति|Śakti]], had recourse  to '''[[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]],''' who taught him the '''[[ससर्परी|Sasarparī]];''' later he revenged himself on [[शक्ति|Śakti]] by having him burnt in the forest. The Bṛhaddevatā<ref name=fx4_ve2_1264> iv. 112 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes.</ref> relates the first part of the tale only. Geldner<ref name=fx5_ve2_1264> ''Op. cit.,'' 2, 159 ''et seq.;<br>'' more doubtfully, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 89.</ref> sees in the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve2_1264> iii. 53, 22.</ref> a description of the death struggle of [[शक्ति|Śakti]], but this interpretation is more than doubtful.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1264> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 254.</ref>

शक्ती आङ्गिरस
<u>'''2. Śaktī Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the name of a seer of a Sāman or Chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1265> xii. 5, 16, ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160.</ref>

शक्वरी
<u>'''Śakvarī,'''</u> fem. plur., denotes the [[शक्वरी|Śakvarī]] verses, known also as the Mahānāmnī verses, to which the [[शाक्वर|Śākvara]] Sāman (chant) is sung. This sense seems to occur in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1266> vii. 33, 4;<br> x. 71, 14;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], i. 8.</ref> and is certain later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1266> Av. xiii. 1, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 8, 5;<br> 6, 2, 3;<br> iii. 4, 4, 1;<br> v. 4, 12, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvi. 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 5;<br> xii. 13, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 5, 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 1, 1;<br> 9, 2, 17, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 258 ''et seq.''</ref>

शङ्कु
<u>'''Śaṅku'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1267> 1. 164. 48.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1267> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 1, 1;<br> 2, 2;<br> 6, 1, 3;<br> xiii. 8, 4, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 18, 6, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘wooden peg.’ Thus the '''term''' is used of the pags by which a skin is stretched out in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1267> ii. 1, 1, 10.</ref> and of the pin of hobbles ('''[[पड्बीश|Paḍbīśa]]''').<ref name=fx4_ve2_1267> Bṛhadāraṇyaka, vi. 2, 13 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 1, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]), etc.</ref> '''In''' the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1267> ii. 23, 4.</ref> it may mean ‘stalk’<ref name=fx6_ve2_1267> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 1, 35.</ref> or ‘fibre of a '''leaf.'''’<ref name=fx7_ve2_1267> Little, ''Grammatical Index,'' 149, But ''cf.'' Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 228, who compares ''śūcī'' in Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 10;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 10, 3.</ref> 

शङ्ख
<u>'''1. Śaṅkha'''</u> in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1268> iv. 10, 1. See Lanman in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 161.</ref> with the epithet '''[[कृशन|Kṛśana]],''' denotes a pearl-shell used as an amulet. In the later literature<ref name=fx2_ve2_1268> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 9;<br> iv. 5, 10.</ref> it denotes a ‘shell’ or ‘conch’ used for blowing as a wind instrument.

शङ्ख कौष्य
<u>'''2. Śaṅkha Kauṣya'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher whom '''[[जात शाकायन्य|Jāta Śākāyanya]]''' criticized in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxii. 7; ''cf.'' 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

शङ्ख बाभ्रव्य
<u>'''3. Śaṅkha Bābhravya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[बभ्रु|Babhru]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[राम|Rāma]],''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1; iv. 17, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

शङ्ख-धम
<u>'''Śaṅkha-dhama,'''</u> a ‘conch-blower,’ is enumerated among the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1271> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Brāhaṃa, iii. 4, 13, 1.</ref> and is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1271> ii. 4, 9;<br> iv. 5, 10.</ref>

शङ्ग शाट्यायनि
<u>'''Śaṅga Śāṭyāyani'''</u> (‘descendant of Śāṭyāyana’) '''[[आत्रेय|Ātreya]]''' (‘descendant of '''Atri'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Nagarin,''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

शचीवन्त्
<u>'''Śacīvant'''</u> is apparently the name of a man in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1273> x. 74. 5.</ref> where the vocative ''Śacīvaḥ'' occurs. But Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1273> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 108;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 489, n.</ref> perfers to read ''Śacī ca'' instead.

शण
<u>'''Śaṇa'''</u> denotes a kind of ‘hemp’ (''Cannabis sativa'' or ''Crotolaria juncea''). It is mentioned in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1274> ii. 4, 5.</ref> as growing in the forest, and as used like the '''[[जङ्गिड|Jaṅgiḍa]]''' as a remedy against '''[[विष्कन्ध|Viṣkandha]].''' It also occurs in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1274> iii. 2, 1, 11 i. 6, 1, 24;<br> 2, 15.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 68.</ref> 

शण्ड
<u>'''Śaṇḍa'''</u> is joined with '''[[मर्क|Marka]]''' as a [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of the Asuras in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1275> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 10, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vii. 12. 13 ([[मर्क|Marka]] in 16. 17).</ref> and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1275> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 1, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, i, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 223.</ref>

शण्डिक
<u>'''Śaṇḍika'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1276> iii. 30, 8,</ref> in the plural. According to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1276> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 153.</ref> the hymn is a prayer for victory over the Śaṇḍikas and their king.

शत-द्युम्न
<u>'''Śata-dyumna'''</u> (‘possessing a hundred glories’) is the name of a man who, along with '''[[यज्ञेषु|Yajñeṣu]],''' was made prosperous by the priest '''[[मात्स्य|Mātsya]]''' through his knowledge of the exact moment for sacrifice, according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 5, 2, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

शत-पति
<u>'''Śata-pati'''</u> occurs in a verse of the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1278> iv. 14, 12.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1278> ii. 8, 4, 2.</ref> as an epithet of Indra, who is described as alone the ‘lord of a hundred’ among men. To interpret the expression as ‘lord of a hundred gods,’ as does the commentary on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], is obviously impossible. It seems clear that there is a reference to an analogous human functionary--viz., the lord of a hundred villages, known in the later law<ref name=fx3_ve2_1278> See Foy, ''Die ko7nigliche Gewalt,'' 74.</ref> --who was probably at once a judicial deputy of the sovereign and a revenue collector, an ancient magistrate and collector.

शत-बलाक्ष मौद्गल्य
<u>'''Śata-balākṣa Maudgalya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[मुद्गल|Mudgala]]'''’) is the name of a grammarian in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (xi. 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

शत-मान
<u>'''Śata-māna.'''</u> See '''[[मान|Māna]]''' and '''Kṛṣṇaia.''' <br>==Foot Notes==

शत-यातु
<u>'''Śata-yātu'''</u> (‘having a hundred magic powers’) is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1281> vii. 18, 21.</ref> He is enumerated after '''[[पराशर|Parāśara]]''' and before '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]].''' Geldner<ref name=fx2_ve2_1281> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 132.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 3, 139.</ref> thinks he may have been a son of [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]].

शत-रुद्रिय
<u>'''Śata-rudriya,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1282> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 6;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 1, 1, 1;<br> 2, 1;<br> x. 1, 5, 3. 15.</ref> '''Śata-rudrīya'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1282> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 3, 1;<br> 5, 9, 4;<br> 7, 3, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 11, 9, 9, etc.</ref> (hymn ‘relating to the hundred Rudras’), is the name of a section of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1282> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 1-11;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 11-16;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 1 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 202;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 108, 111, 159, 169, 170;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 150 ''et seq.''</ref> which celebrates the god Rudra in his hundred aspects, enumerating his many epithets.

शत-शारद
<u>'''Śata-śārada'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1283> vii. 101, 6;<br> x. 161, 2.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1283> i. 35, 1;<br> viii. 2, 2;<br> 5, 21.</ref> denotes a ‘period of a hundred autumns’ or years.

शतानीक सात्राजित
<u>'''Śatānīka Sātrājita'''</u> is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāhmana<ref name=fx1_ve2_1284> viii. 21, 5.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1284> xiii. 5, 4, 9-13.</ref> as a great king who defeated '''[[धृतराष्ट्र|Dhṛtarāṣṭra]],''' the prince of '''[[काशि|Kāśi]],''' and took away his sacrificial horse. He was clearly a '''[[भरत|Bharata]].''' He is also alluded to in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1284> i. 35. 1 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 52, in connexion with the '''Dākṣāyaṇas.'''</ref>

शत्रि आग्नि-वेशि
<u>'''Śatri Āgni-veśi'''</u> (‘descendant of Agniveśa’) is the name of a generous patron in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1285> v. 34. 9. ''Cf.'' Ludwig. Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155.</ref>

शत्रु
<u>'''Śatru'''</u> denotes ‘enemy’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1286> i. 33, 13;<br> 61, 13;<br> ii. 23, 11;<br> 30, 3 ''et seq.;<br>'' iii. 16, 2;<br> iv. 28, 4, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1286> Av. iv. 3, 1;<br> vi. 4, 2;<br> x. 3, 1, etc.</ref> 

शं-तनु
<u>'''Śaṃ-tanu'''</u> is the hero of a tale told by [[यास्क|Yāska]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1287> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 10.</ref> and often found later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1287> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 155 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 129 ''et seq.''</ref> He supersedes his elder brother '''Devāpi''' as king of the '''Kurus.''' When his improper deed brings on a prolonged drought in his realm, he is compelled to ask his brother to assume the kingship; Devāpi, however, refuses, but instead performs a sacrifice which produces rain. Sieg<ref name=fx3_ve2_1287> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> endeavours to trace this story in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1287> x. 98.</ref> but all that is there stated is that Devāpi '''Ārṣṭiṣeṇa''' obtained (no doubt as priest) rain for [[शंतनु|Śaṃtanu]] (no doubt a king). There is no hint of relationship at all.

शपथ
<u>'''Śapatha'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1288> x. 87, 15;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 3.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1288> Av. iii. 9, 5;<br> iv. 9, 5;<br> 18, 7;<br> 19, 7. etc.</ref> denotes a ‘curse,’ not an ‘oath,’ as a judicial process. But that an oath of such a kind was possible as it was later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1288/> is shown by at least one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1288> vii. 104, 15.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 326, 327.</ref> where the speaker, possibly '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]],''' imprecates death on himself if he is a wizard, and death on his foes if he is not.

शफ
<u>'''1. Śapha,'''</u> ‘hoof,’ comes to be used to denote the fraction ‘one-eighth,’ because of the divided hoofs of the cow, just as '''[[पाद|Pāda]],''' the ‘foot’ of a quadruped, also means a ‘quarter.’ This sense in found as early as the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1289> viii. 47, 17.</ref> and is not rare later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1289> Av. vi. 46, 3;<br> xix. 57, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 10, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 3, 3, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 278;<br> 17, 47;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 259.</ref>

शफ
<u>'''2. Śapha'''</u> in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1290> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 22, 14;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 2, 1, 16. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 458, n. 4;<br> 476.</ref> is the name (used in the dual) of a wooden implement, acting like a pair of tongs, for lifting an iron pot from the fire. It is probably so called because it resembled a hoof in being divided. 

शफक
<u>'''Śaphaka'''</u> is the name of some plant in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1291> iv. 34, 5.</ref> It is also mentioned in the Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1291> ix. 14, 14.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 138;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda 207.</ref> where it seems to denote an edible water plant or fruit, perhaps a water nut. It may be so called from its leaves being shaped like hoofs ('''[[शफ|Śapha]]''').

शफाल
<u>'''Śaphāla'''</u> is the name of '''Ṛtuparṇa's''' kingdom in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta Sātra.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1292> xx. 12. ''Cf.'' Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 21, 36.</ref>

सबर
<u>'''Sabara'''</u> is the name of a wild tribe who in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1293> vii. 18, 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 26, 6. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 483.</ref> are classed as '''Dasyus,''' with the '''Andhras, Pulindas, Mūtibas,''' and '''Puṇḍras.'''

शमितृ
<u>'''Śamitṛ'''</u> denotes the ‘man who cuts up’ the slaughtered animal in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1294> i. 162, 9 ''et seq.;<br>'' ii. 3, 10;<br> iii. 4, 10;<br> v. 43, 4, etc.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1294> Av. x. 9, 7 (‘cook’ of the Śataudanā, or offering of a cow and a hunḍred rice-dishes);<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvii. 57;<br> xxi. 21;<br> xxiii. 39;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 2;<br> 7, 10-12;<br> vii. 1, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 18, 4, etc.</ref> sometimes having merely the sense of ‘cook.’

शमी
<u>'''Śamī'''</u> is the name of a tree in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1295> Av. vi. 11, 1;<br> 30, 2, 3.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1295> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 9, 6;<br> 4, 7, 4 (for the lower ''[[अरणी|araṇī]]'');<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 11 ''et seq.;<br>'' 6, 4, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 2, 12;<br> ix. 2, 3, 37, etc.</ref> It is described in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1295> Av. vi. 30, 2. 3.</ref> as destructive to the hair,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1295> In the Dhanvantarīya Nighaṇṭu, p. 188 (ed. Poona), the [[शमी|Śamī]] and its fruit are said to destroy the hair.</ref> as producing intoxication, and as broad-leaved. These characteristics are totally wanting in the two trees, ''Prosopis spicigera'' or ''Mimosa suma,'' with which the [[शमी|Śamī]] is usually identified.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1295> See Roth in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 302.</ref>  From the soft wood of the [[शमी|Śamī]] was formed the lower of the two sticks (''[[अरणी|araṇī]]'') used for kindling the sacred fire,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1295> Av. vi. 11, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 15;<br> ''Cf.'' 13;<br> iii. 4, 1, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 9, 6;<br> 4, 7, 4.</ref> the upper one (the drill) being of '''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]].''' The fruit of the tree is called Śamīdhānya.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1295> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 59, 60.</ref>

शम्बर
<u>'''Śambara'''</u> is the name of an enemy of Indra in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1296> i. 51, 6;<br> 54, 4;<br> 59, 6;<br> 101, 2;<br> 103, 8;<br> 112, 14;<br> 130, 7;<br> ii. 12, 11;<br> 14, 6;<br> 19, 6;<br> iv. 26, 3;<br> 30, 14;<br> vi. 18, 8;<br> 26, 5;<br> 31, 4;<br> 43, 1;<br> 47, 2. 21;<br> vii. 18, 20;<br> 99, 5.</ref> He is mentioned along with '''Śuṣṇa, [[पिप्रु|Pipru]],''' and '''[[वर्चिन्|Varcin]],''' being in one passage called a '''[[दास|Dāsa]],''' son of Kulitara.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1296> Rv. vi. 26, 5.</ref> In another passage<ref name=fx3_ve2_1296> Rv. vii. 18, 20.</ref> he is said to have deemed himself a godling (''devaka''). His forts, ninety,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1296> Rv. i. 130, 7.</ref> ninety-nine,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1296> Rv. ii. 19, 6.</ref> or a hundred<ref name=fx6_ve2_1296> Rv. ii. 14, 6.</ref> in number, are alluded to, the word itself in the neuter plural once<ref name=fx7_ve2_1296> Rv. ii. 24, 2.</ref> meaning the ‘forts of [[शम्बर|Śambara]].’ His great foe was '''[[दिवोदास अतिथिग्व|Divodāsa Atithigva]],''' who won victories over him by Indra's aid.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1296> Rv. i. 51, 6;<br> 130, 7;<br> ii. 19, 6;<br> iv. 26, 3, etc.</ref><br><br>It is impossible to say with certainty whether [[शम्बर|Śambara]] was a real person or not. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx9_ve2_1296> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 103, 108;<br> 3, 273.</ref> is strongly in favour of the theory that he was a real chief as enemy of Divodāsa: he relies on the statistics<ref name=fx10_ve2_1296> Seven times in Maṇḍala i;<br> four in ii;<br> two in iv;<br> six in vi;<br> two in vii. These references show ''primâ facis'' greater reality in Maṇḍala vi than elsewhere. The references in ii. are certainly all of the mythical kind, and those in vii are of much the same sort.</ref> of the mention of the name to show that, where as he was conceived as a real foe in the hymns of the time of Divodāsa, later texts, like those of the seventh Maṇḍala, make him into a demon, as a result of the change of scene from Arachosia to India. As a matter of fact, apart from this theory, [[शम्बर|Śambara]] was quite possibly an aboriginal enemy in India, living in the mountains.<ref name=fx11_ve2_1296> Rv. i. 130, 7;<br> iv. 30, 14;<br> vi. 26, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 177;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 161;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 210;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 178.</ref> 

शम्बिन्
<u>'''Śambin,'''</u> a word occurring only once, appears to mean ‘ferryman’ in the Atharvaveda (ix. 2, 6). The literal sense is probably ‘pole-man’ (from ''śamba,'' a word of doubtful signification found in the Rigveda, x. 42, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

शंमद् आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Śaṃmad Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman or Chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xv. 5, 11).<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologic.'' 2, 160.<br>==Foot Notes==

शम्या
<u>'''Śamyā'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1299> x. 31, 10.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1299> Av. vi. 138, 4;<br> xx. 136, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 7, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 10, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 5, 2, 7. etc.</ref> a ‘peg,’ more particularly one on the millstone;<ref name=fx3_ve2_1299> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 1, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 1, 22;<br> 2, 1, 16 ''et seq.;<br>'' v. 2, 3, 2, etc.</ref> and on the yoke,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1299> Rv. iii. 33, 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 25;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, 6, 8, 3.</ref> where it seems to mean the pin of wood attached to either end so as to keep the yoke in place on the ox's neck.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1299> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5, 20. ''Cf.'' xi. 1, 6;<br> xv. 7, 6;<br> Grierson, ''Bihar Pcasant Life,'' 194, and illustration, p. 33;<br> Cuningham, ''The [[स्तूप|Stūpa]] of Bharhut,'' Plate xxviii.;<br> Caland and Henry, ''L'Agniṣṭoma,'' 49.</ref> The [[शम्या|Śamyā]] was also used as a measure of length.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1299> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 6, 2. According to the commentary on Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 3, 20, the length was 32 Aṅgulas, or fingerbreadths This would be equivalent to 2 feet: ''cf.'' Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1912, 232.</ref>

शयण्डक
<u>'''Śayaṇḍaka.'''</u> See '''[[शयाण्डक|Śayāṇḍaka]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शयन
