<u>'''Śayana'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1301> iii. 25. 1;<br> v. 29. 8.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1301> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 2;<br> 7, 4.</ref> denotes a ‘couch.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[तल्प|Talpa]], [[वह्य|Vahya]].'''

शयाण्डक
<u>'''Śayāṇḍaka'''</u> is the form in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1302> v. 5, 14, 1.</ref> of the name of an animal which in the Maitrāyaṇī<ref name=fx2_ve2_1302> iii. 14. 14.</ref> and Vājasaneyi Saṃhitās<ref name=fx3_ve2_1302> xxiv. 33.</ref> is written as [[शयण्डक|Śayaṇḍaka]]. Some sort of bird is meant according to Roth,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1302> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref> but the commentator on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā equates the word with '''[[कृकलास|Kṛkalāsa]],''' ‘chameleon.’ 

शयु
<u>'''Śayu'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1303> i. 112, 16;<br> 116, 22;<br> 117, 20;<br> 118, 8;<br> 119, 6;<br> vi. 62, 7;<br> vii. 68, 8;<br> x. 39, 13;<br> 40, 8.</ref> of a protégé of the Aśvins, who made his cow to give milk.

शर
<u>'''1. Śara'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1304> i. 191, 3.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1304> Av. iv. 7, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 6, 2;<br> vi. 1, 3, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 5;<br> xxiii. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 4, 1;<br> iii. 1, 3, 13;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 11, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 4, etc.</ref> denotes a kind of ‘reed’ (''Saccharum Sara''). Its use for arrow shafts,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1304> Av. i. 2, 1;<br> 3, 1.</ref> and its brittleness,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1304> Av. viii. 8, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.</ref> are expressly referred to in the Atharvaveda. ''Cf.'' '''[[शर्य|Śarya]].'''

शर अर्चत्क
<u>'''2. Śara Arcatka'''</u> (‘descendant of Ṛcatka’) is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1305> i. 116, 22;<br> ''cf.'' perhaps. i. 112, 16;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 103, ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 150.</ref> It is very doubtful, however, whether Ārcatka is really a patronymic.

शर शौर-देव्य
<u>'''3. Śara Śaura-devya'''</u> (‘descendant of Śūradeva’) is the name of a generous prince in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1306> viii. 70, 13-15.</ref> who gave one calf to three singers. That this Dānastuti (‘praise of gifts’) is ironical seems certain.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1306> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 5-7;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163;<br> 5. 175.</ref>

शरद्
<u>'''Śarad.'''</u> See '''[[ऋतु|Ṛtu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शरभ
<u>'''1. Śarabha'''</u> is the name of some wild animal in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1308> ix. 5, 9. ''Cf.'' '''[[शलभ|Śalabha]].'''</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1308> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 10, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 51;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 3, 9, etc.</ref> In the '''classical''' literature it is a fabulous, eight-legged beast, dwelling in the snowy mountains, a foe of lions and elephants: the commentator Mahīdhara sees this sense, but without reason, in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā. The  animal is spoken of as akin to the goat;<ref name=fx3_ve2_1308> Av., ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 52, n. 1, accepts the traditional rendering.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 89.</ref> it was probably a kind of deer.

शरभ
<u>'''2. Śarabha'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1309> viii. 100, 6. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref>

शरव्या
<u>'''Śaravyā,'''</u> ‘arrow-shot,’ is an expression found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1310> vi. 75, 16;<br> x. 87, 13.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1310> Av. i. 19, 1. 3;<br> v. 18, 9;<br> xi. 10, 6;<br> xii. 5, 25, 29;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5. 1, 1, etc.</ref>

शराव
<u>'''Śarāva'''</u> is a measure of corn in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1311> ''Saptadaśa-[[शराव|śarāva]],'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 4, 5;<br> 6, 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 4, 12.</ref>

शरीर
<u>'''Śarīra,'''</u> ‘body,’ is a word of frequent occurrence in Vedic literature.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1312> Rv. i. 32, 10;<br> x. 16, 1, etc.;<br> Av. v. 9, 7;<br> xviii. 3, 9, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 55;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 2, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 13;<br> 14, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 1, 4, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 8.</ref> The interest of the Vedic Indians seems early to have been attracted to the consideration of questions connected with the anatomy of the body. Thus a hymn of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1312> x. 2.</ref> enumerates many parts of the body with some approach to accuracy and orderly arrangement.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1312> ''Cf.'' Hoernle, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 10-12;<br> ''Osteology,'' 109-111, 242.</ref> It mentions the heels (''pārṣṇī''), the flesh (''[[मांस|māṃsa]]''), the ankle-bones (''gulphau''), the fingers (''aṅgulīḥ''), the apertures (''kha''), the two metatarsi (''uchlakau''), the tarsus (''[[प्रतिष्ठा|pratiṣṭhā]]''), the two knee-caps (''aṣṭhīvantau''), the two legs (''jaṅghe''), the two knee-joints (''jānunoḥ sandhī''). Then comes above the two kness (''jānū'') the foursided (''catuṣṭaya''), pliant (''śithira'') trunk (''kabandha''). The two hips (''śroṇī'') and the two thighs (''ārū'') are the props of the frame  (''kusindha''). Next come the breast-bone (''uras''), the cervical cartilages (''grīvāḥ''), the two breast pieces (''stanau''), the two shoulder-blades (''kaphoḍau''), the neck-bones (''skandhau''), and the backbones (''pṛṣṭīḥ''), the collar-bones (''aṃsau''), the arms (''bāhū''), the seven apertures in the head (''sapta khāni śīrṣaṇi''), the ears (''karṇau''), the nostrils (''nāsike''), the eyes (''cakṣaṇī''), the mouth (''mukha''), the jaws (''hanū''), the tongue (''jihvā''), the brain (''mastiṣka''), the forehead (''lalāṭa''), the facial bone (''kakāṭikā''), the cranium (''kapāla''), and the structure of the jaws (''cityā hanvoḥ'').<br><br>This system presents marked similarities with the later system of [[चरक|Caraka]] and Suśruta,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1312> ''Osteology,'' 112.</ref> which render certain the names ascribed to the several terms by Hoernle. ''Kaphoḍau,'' which is variously read in the manuscripts,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1312> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 568.</ref> is rendered ‘collar-bone’ by Whitney, but ‘elbow’ in the St. Petersburg Dictionary. ''Skandha'' in the plural regularly<ref name=fx6_ve2_1312> Av. x. 7. 3 (where the Skandhas are compared with the [[कृत्तिकास्|Kṛttikās]], probably because both were seven in number, but this is not certain);<br> 9, 20;<br> vi. 135, 1;<br> xii. 5, 67;<br> Hoernle, ''Journal,'' 1906, 918;<br> 1907, 1, 2.</ref> denotes ‘neck-bones,’ or, more precisely, ‘cervical vertebræ,’ a part denoted also by ''uṣṇihā'' in the plural.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1312> Av. vi. 134, 1;<br> Rv. vi. 163, 2= Av. ii. 33, 2;<br> Av. ix. 8, 21;<br> x. 10, 20.</ref> ''Pṛṣṭī''<ref name=fx8_ve2_1312> Rv. x. 87. 10 = Av. viii. 3, 10;<br> Av. ix. 7, 5, 6;<br> x. 9, 20;<br> xii. 1, 34;<br> xviii. 4, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 6, 2, 7. See Hoernle, ''Journal,'' 1907. 2 ''et seq.;<br>'' Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 548;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44. 164. n. 2.</ref> denotes not ‘rib,’ which is ''[[पर्शु|parśu]],''<ref name=fx9_ve2_1312> Av. ix. 7, 6, etc.</ref> but a transverse process of a vertebra, and so the vertebra itself, there being in the truncal portion of the spinal column seventeen vertebræ and thirty-four transverse processes. The vertebræ are also denoted by ''kīkasā'' in the plural,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1312> Av. ix. 7, 5;<br> 8, 14.</ref> which sometimes<ref name=fx11_ve2_1312> Av. xi. 8, 15.</ref> is limited to the upper portion of the vertebral column, sometimes<ref name=fx12_ve2_1312> Av. ii. 33, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 6, 2, 10.</ref> to the thoracic portion of the spine. ''Anūka'' also denotes the vertebral column,<ref name=fx13_ve2_1312> Av. iv. 14, 8. ''Cf.'' ix. 8, 21 (the spine of the trunk).</ref> or more specially the lumbar<ref name=fx14_ve2_1312> Av. ii. 33, 2.</ref> or thoracic<ref name=fx15_ve2_1312> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 2, 4. 12. 14. ''Cf.'' the phrase ''īṣc anūkye,'' Av. xi. 3, 9, where the two shafts of a cart are compared with the transverse processes of a vertebra.</ref> portion of the spine; it is said in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx15_ve2_1312/>  that there are twenty transverse processes in the lumbar spine (''udara'') and thirty-two in the thoracic, which gives twenty-six vertebræ, the true number (but the modern division is seven cervical, twelve thoracic, five lumbar, and two false--the sacrum and the coccyx). The vertebral column is also denoted by ''karūkara,''<ref name=fx16_ve2_1312> Av. xi. 9, 8;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 124.</ref> which, however, is usually found in the plural<ref name=fx17_ve2_1312> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 2, 4, 10, 14.</ref> denoting the transverse processes of the vertebræ, a sense expressed also by ''kuntāpa.''<ref name=fx18_ve2_1312> ''Ibid.,'' xii. 2, 4, 12.</ref><br><br>''Grīvā,'' in the plural, denotes cervical vertebræ, the number seven being given by the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx19_ve2_1312> ''Ibid.'' xii. 2, 4, 10.</ref> but usually<ref name=fx20_ve2_1312> Rv. vi. 163, 2 = Av. ii. 33, 2;<br> Av. vi. 134, 1;<br> ix. 7, 3;<br> x. 9, 20;<br> xi. 8, 15;<br> Hoernle, ''Journal,'' 1906, 916 ''et seq.''</ref> the word simply means windpipe, or, more accurately, the cartilaginous rings under the skin. '''Jatru,''' also in the plural, denotes the cervical cartilages,<ref name=fx21_ve2_1312> Rv. vii. 1, 12 = Av. xiv. 2, 12.</ref> or possibly the costal cartilages, which are certainly so called in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx22_ve2_1312> xii. 2, 4, 11. ''Cf.'' vii. 6, 2, 10;<br> Hoernle, ''Journal,'' 1906, 922 ''et seq.''</ref> where their number is given as eight.<br><br>''Bhaṃsas,'' which occurs thrice in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx23_ve2_1312> Av. ii. 33, 5;<br> ix. 8, 21, with a fuller version in the Paippalāda recension (Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 77, 551). In viii. 6, 5, it denotes vulva: Hoernle, 16-18.</ref> seems to denote the pubic bone or arch rather than the ‘buttocks’ or ‘fundament,’ as Whitney<ref name=fx24_ve2_1312> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> takes it.<br><br>In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx25_ve2_1312> x. 5, 4, 12;<br> xii. 3, 2, 3, 4;<br> '''Hoernle,''' ''Osteology,'' 238, 239, and the criticism in 106-109, which shows how far removed the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is from a scientific system. ''Cf.'' Keith, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 62, 135 ''et seq.''</ref> the number of bones in the the human body is given as 360. The number of the bones of the head and trunk are given in another passage<ref name=fx26_ve2_1312> xii. 2, 4, 9-14;<br> Hoernle, ''Osteology,'' 240.</ref> as follows: The head is threefold, consisting of skin (''tvac''), bone (''asthi''), brain (''matiṣka''); the neck has 15 bones: 14 transverse processes (''karūkara'') and the strength (''vīrya'')--''i.e.,'' the bone of the centre regarded as one--as the 15th; the breast has 17: 16 cervical cartilages (''jatru''), and the sternum (''uras'') as the 17th; the abdominal portion of the spine has 21: 20 trans-  verse processes (''kuntāpa''), and the abdominal portion (''udara'') as the 21st; the two sides have 27: 26 ribs (''[[पर्शु|parśu]]''), and the two sides as the 27th; the thoracic portion of the spine (''anūka'') has 33: 32 transverse processes, and the thoracic portion as 33rd.<br><br>There are several enumerations of the parts of the body, not merely of the skeleton, in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx27_ve2_1312> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 81-93;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 9;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 4.</ref> They include the hair (''lomāni''), skin (''tvac''), flesh (''[[मांस|māṃsa]]''), bone (''asthi''), marrow (''majjan''), liver (''yakṛt''), lungs (''kloman''), kidneys (''matasne''), gall (''pitta''), entrails (''āntrāṇi''), bowels (''gudāḥ''), spleen (''plīhan''), navel (''[[नाभि|nābhi]]''), belly (''udara''), rectum (''vaniṣṭhu''), womb (''yoni''), penis (''plāśi'' and ''śepa''), face (''mukha''), head (''śiras''), tongue (''jihvā''), mouth (''āsan''), rump (''[[पायु|pāyu]]''), leech (''[[वाल|vāla]]''), eye (''[[चक्षुस्|cakṣus]]''), eyelashes (''pakṣmāṇi''), eyebrows (''utāni''), nose (''nas''), breath (''[[व्य्आन|vyāna]]''), nose-hairs (''nasyāni''), ears (''karṇau''), brows (''bhrū''), body or trunk (''ātman''), waist (''upastha''), hair on the face (''śmaśrūṇi''), and on the head (''keśāḥ''). Another enumeration<ref name=fx28_ve2_1312> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 5-13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 5.</ref> gives ''śiras, mukha, keśāḥ, śmaśrūṇi, [[प्राण|prāṇa]]'' (breath), ''[[चक्षुस्|cakṣus]], śrotra'' (ear), ''jihvā, [[वाच्|vāc]]'' (speech), ''manas'' (mind), ''aṅgulīḥ, aṅgāni'' (limbs), ''bāhū, hastau'' (hands), ''karṇau, ātmā, uras'' (sternum), ''pṛṣṭīḥ'' (vertebræ), ''udara, aṃsau, grīvāḥ, śroṇī, ūrū, aratnī'' (elbows), ''jānūni, [[नाभि|nābhi]], [[पायु|pāyu]], bhasat'' (fundament), ''āṇḍau'' (testicles), ''pasas'' (membrum virile), ''jaṅghā, pad'' (foot), ''lomāni, tvac, [[मांस|māṃsa]], asthi, majjan.'' Another set of names<ref name=fx29_ve2_1312> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxix. 8. 9. 10.</ref> includes ''vaniṣṭhu, purītat'' (pericardium), ''lomāni, tvac, [[लोहित|lohita]]'' (blood), ''medas'' (fat), ''māṃsāni, snāvāni'' (sinews), ''asthīni, majjānaḥ, retas'' (semen), ''[[पायु|pāyu]], kośya'' (flesh near the heart), ''pārśvya'' (intercostal flesh), etc.<br><br>The bones of the skeleton of the horse are enumerated in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx30_ve2_1312> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 1-9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 15. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 1.</ref><br><br>In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx31_ve2_1312> i. 2, 2.</ref> the human body is regarded as made up of one hundred and one items; there are four parts,  each of twenty-five members, with the trunk as one hundred and first. In the two upper parts there are five four-jointed<ref name=fx32_ve2_1312> This is contrary to fact: Hoernle, ''Osteology,'' 122, 123.</ref> fingers, two ''kakṣasī'' (of uncertain meaning),<ref name=fx33_ve2_1312> Perhaps the armpit regarded as in some way double;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 175.</ref> the arm (''dos''), the collar-bone (''[[अक्ष|akṣa]]''), and the shoulder-blade (''aṃsa-[[फलक|phalaka]]''). In the two lower portions there are five four-jointed toes, the thigh, the leg, and three articulations, according to Sāyaṇa's commentary.<br><br>The [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx34_ve2_1312> ii. 2.</ref> enumerates three bones in the head,<ref name=fx35_ve2_1312> ''Cf.'' Hoernle, ''Osteology,'' 172 ''et seq.;<br>'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 2, 4, 9.</ref> three joints (''parvāṇi'') in the neck,<ref name=fx36_ve2_1312> ii. 3, See Keith, ''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,'' 9, n. 4.</ref> the collar-bone (''[[अक्ष|akṣa]]''),<ref name=fx37_ve2_1312> ii. 4;<br> Hoernle, ''Osteology,'' 202 ''et seq.;<br>'' Keith, ''op. cit.,'' 9, n. 5.</ref> three joints in the fingers,<ref name=fx38_ve2_1312> ii. 5. ''Cf.'' n. 32. The later [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] here improves on the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] osteology.</ref> and twenty-one transverse processes in the spine (''anūka'').<ref name=fx39_ve2_1312> ii. 6. See Keith, ''op. cit.,'' 10, n. 4.</ref> The Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx40_ve2_1312> iii. 2, 9.</ref> enumerates four constituents in the head (''[[प्राण|prāṇa]], [[चक्षुस्|cakṣus]], śrotra, [[वाच्|vāc]]''), but there are many variations, the number going up to twelve on one calculation.<ref name=fx41_ve2_1312> See references in Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 185, 192, 195. The numbers vary and are fanciful, being of no scientific importance.</ref> In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx42_ve2_1312> i. 7, 1.</ref> an enumeration is given consisting of ''carma'' (skin), ''[[मांस|māṃsa]], snāvan, asthi,'' and ''majjan;'' and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx43_ve2_1312> vi. 29, 4.</ref> has ''lomāni, [[मांस|māṃsa]], tvac, asthi, majjan,'' and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx44_ve2_1312> iii. 2, 1. 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 1. 2.</ref> couples ''majjānaḥ, snāvāni,'' and ''asthīni.'' Other terms relating to the body are ''kaṅkūṣa,''<ref name=fx45_ve2_1312> Av. ix. 8, 2, where the Paippalāda recension has ''kaṅkukha.''</ref> perhaps a part of the ear,<ref name=fx46_ve2_1312> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 378.</ref> ''yoni'' (female organ), ''[[कक्ष|kakṣa]]''<ref name=fx47_ve2_1312> Av. vi. 127, 2. ''Cf. kakṣī,'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 9.</ref> (armpit), '''Danta''' (tooth), ''[[नख|nakha]]'' (nail), ''prapada''<ref name=fx48_ve2_1312> Av. ii. 33, 5, with Lanman's note in Whitney's Translation, p. 77;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 204. In that Āraṇyaka the passage ii. 1, 4 makes the sense ‘toe’ improbable.</ref> (forepart of the foot), ''halīkṣṇa''<ref name=fx49_ve2_1312> Av. ii. 33, 3;<br> Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 76.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hoernle, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1906, 916 ''et seq.;<br>'' 1907, 1, ''et seq.;<br> Osteology, passim.''</ref> (gall). 

शरु
<u>'''Śaru'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1313> i. 100, 18;<br> 172, 2;<br> 186, 9;<br> ii. 12, 10;<br> iv. 3, 7;<br> 28, 3, etc.</ref> and Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1313> i. 2, 3;<br> 19, 2;<br> vi. 65, 2;<br> xii. 2, 47.</ref> a missile weapon, often certainly an ‘arrow,’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1313> ''E.g.,'' Rv. x. 125, 6;<br> and x. 87, 6.</ref> but perhaps sometimes a ‘dart’ or ‘spear.’<ref name=fx4_ve2_1313> Perhaps Rv. iv. 3, 7, where ''bṛhatī'' is applied to it, and where ‘lance’ seems the best sense, the use being metaphorical.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 223;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 301.</ref>

शर्करा
<u>'''Śarkarā,'''</u> fem. plur., denotes in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1314> Av. xi. 7, 21;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 1, 6, 2;<br> 2, 6, 2;<br> 6, 4, 4, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_1314> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 7;<br> 2, 1, 4;<br> iii. 12, 6, atapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 1, 8, etc.</ref> ‘grit’ or ‘gravel.’

शर्कराख्य
<u>'''Śarkarākhya.'''</u> See '''[[शार्कराक्ष|Śārkarākṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शर्कोट
<u>'''Śarkoṭa'''</u> is the name of an animal in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1316> vii. 56, 5.</ref> either a ‘serpent,’ as Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1316> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' comparing the later Karkoṭaka.</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_1316> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref> held, or a ‘scorpion,’ as Grill,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1316> ''Hundert Lieder,^2'' 183.</ref> Henry,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1316> ''Le livre vii de l' Atharvavéda,'' 82.</ref> and Bloomfield<ref name=fx6_ve2_1316> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 554, 555.</ref> think.

शर्ध
<u>'''Śardha.'''</u> See '''[[व्रात|Vrāta]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शर्ध्य
<u>'''Śardhya'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1318> i. 119, 5.</ref> is taken by Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1318> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> as perhaps denoting a part of the chariot. The sense is, however, quite uncertain.

शर्य
<u>'''Śarya,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1319> i. 119, 10, where the sense is not certain.</ref> '''Śaryā,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1319> i. 148, 4;<br> x. 178, 3. ''Cf.'' [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] v. 4;<br> x. 29.</ref> seem in the Rigveda to denote an ‘arrow.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1319> As derived from 1. '''[[शर|Śara]],''' and meaning literally ‘made from a reed.’</ref> Perhaps, also, Śaryā<ref name=fx4_ve2_1319> Rv. ix. 110, 5;<br> x. 61, 3.</ref> and [[शर्य|Śarya]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1319> Rv. ix. 14, 4;<br> 68, 2.</ref> (neut.) mean the ‘wicker-  work’ in the Soma sieve, but the exact sense of the passages is doubtful.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1319> Hillebrandt;<br> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 52, takes ''śaryāṇi'' in Rv. ix. 68, 2, as denoting the outer husk of the Soma plant. See also Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 255, n. 1.</ref>

शर्यणावन्त्
<u>'''Śaryaṇāvant'''</u> occurs in several passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1320> i. 84, 14;<br> viii. 6, 39;<br> 7, 29;<br> 64, 11;<br> ix. 65, 22;<br> 113, 1;<br> x. 35, 2. See Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 64 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 17);<br> Śāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 84, 13.</ref> in all of which Sāyaṇa sees a local name. According to his account, Śaryaṇāḥ (masc. plur.) is a district in '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' [[शर्यणावन्त्|Śaryaṇāvant]] being a lake not far from it in the back part (''jaghanārdhe'') of [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]]. The unusual consistency of his statements on this point is in favour of the word being a place name; it is also to be noted that [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]] contained the lake '''[[अन्यतःप्लक्षा|Anyataḥplakṣā]].''' Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1320> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> however, thought that in two passages<ref name=fx3_ve2_1320> i. 84, 14;<br> x. 35, 2.</ref> the word denoted merely a ‘lake,’ literally ‘(water) covered with a thicket of reeds’ (''śaryaṇa''), and in the others a Soma vessel. Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve2_1320> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 19, 20.</ref> inclines to this rendering. On the other hand, Pischel<ref name=fx5_ve2_1320> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 217. So Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 398, 399.</ref> accepts Sāyaṇa's view. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx6_ve2_1320> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 126, ''et seq.''</ref> also sees in the word a place name, but he is inclined to locate it among the ‘five tribes,’<ref name=fx7_ve2_1320> This is deduced, not with any certainty, from Rv. ix. 65, 22.</ref> which is not quite inconsistent with its being in [[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]], for the connexion of the '''Pūrus''' with the later '''Kurus''' is known;<ref name=fx8_ve2_1320> Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 142, n. 4, Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 205.</ref> or perhaps, he suggests, [[शर्यणावन्त्|Śaryaṇāvant]] is an old name for the Wular sea of Kaśmīr, which was only a reminiscence in Vedic times. This is not probable; still less so is Ludwig's hypothesis<ref name=fx9_ve2_1320> ''Op. cit.,'' 3, 201.</ref> that the [[शर्यणावन्त्|Śaryaṇāvant]] is the later eastern '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].''' Bergaigne<ref name=fx10_ve2_1320> ''Religion Védique,'' 1, 206.</ref> regards the name as that of a celestial preparer of Soma.

शर्यात
<u>'''Śaryāta'''</u> is mentioned once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1321> i. 112, 17.</ref> as a protégé of the Aśvins. Of him in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]^2 and the  Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1321> iii. 120-122 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, cxlv).</ref> is told a story how '''[[च्यवन|Cyavana]]''' was annoyed by the '''Śāryātas,''' and appeased by the gift of '''[[सुकन्या|Sukanyā]],''' Śaryāta's daughter, as a wife, and how [[च्यवन|Cyavana]] was then restored to youth by the Aśvins. He is there called '''[[मानव|Mānava]]''' (‘descendant of Manu’). He appears also as [[शर्यात|Śaryāta]] [[मानव|Mānava]], a sacrificer, in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_1321> iv. 7, 1;<br> 8, 3, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 250 ''et seq.;<br>'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, 272 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 236, 237.</ref>

शर्व-दत्त
<u>'''Śarva-datta'''</u> (‘given by the god Śarva’) '''[[गार्ग्य|Gārgya]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[गर्ग|Garga]]'''’) is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1322> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

शल
<u>'''Śala'''</u> is explained by the St. Petersburg Dictionary as a measure of length in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1323> viii. 7, 28.</ref> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1323> xii. 10 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 464).</ref> and [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1323> i. 5, 10, 1 (where this is the interpretation of the commentator).</ref> Whitney<ref name=fx4_ve2_1323> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 501.</ref> objects that the sense in all<ref name=fx5_ve2_1323> He does not notice the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]. Against his criticism it must be noted that in every one of the passages a numeral is compounded with [[शल|Śala]], as ''tri-[[शल|śala]],'' etc.</ref> these passages is not suited by this meaning.

शलभ
<u>'''Śalabha,'''</u> ‘locust,’ appears in the Paippalāda recension of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1324> ix. 5, 9.</ref> for '''[[शरभ|Śarabha]],''' the reading of the received text, and is regarded by Whitney<ref name=fx2_ve2_1324> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 534. But the mention of the goat in the passage strongly supports Sarabha. See Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] i. 2, 3, 9.</ref> as making better sense.

शलली
<u>'''Śalalī'''</u> denotes the ‘quill’ of the porcupine, used for parting the hair and anointing the eyes.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1325> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 6, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 4, 5.</ref> 

शलुन
<u>'''Śaluna'''</u> is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1326> ii. 31, 2. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 73;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 315;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98 (Śalunna).</ref> denoting a ‘worm.’ The Paippalāda recension reads Śalūla, and Sāyaṇa Śalga.

शल्क
<u>'''Śalka'''</u> denotes in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1327> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 9, 3;<br> 4, 2, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xx. 8;<br> xxvii. 7, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_1327> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 14, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 9, 9;<br> 2, 1, 15.</ref> chip' or ‘shaving’ used for kindling a fire, etc.

शल्मल्ल्
<u>'''Śalmall'''</u> is the name of the ‘silk cotton tree’ (''Salmalia Malabarica''). Its fruit is regarded as poisonous in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1328> vii. 50, 3.</ref> but the car of the bridal procession is made of its wood.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1328> x. 85, 20.</ref> It is described as the tallest of trees.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1328> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 12, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 13;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 7, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 4, 11, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 317, n. 2.</ref>

शल्य
<u>'''Śalya.'''</u> See '''[[इषु|Iṣu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शल्यक
<u>'''Śalyaka'''</u> denotes in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1330> xxiv. 35.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1330> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 26, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 82.</ref> the ‘porcupine.’

शवर्त
<u>'''Śavarta'''</u> is the name of a species of ‘worm’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1331> ix. 4, 16, with the various reading Svavarta, Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 531.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1331> v. 7, 23, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98. Possibly Roth is right in holding that the word = ''śava-[[वर्त|varta]],'' a worm ‘living on carrion.’</ref>

शवस्
<u>'''Śavas'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[अग्निभू काश्यप|Agnibhū Kāśyapa]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1332> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref> 

शवस
<u>'''Śavasa'''</u> occurs only in the false reading ''[[शवस|Śavasa]]-Uśinareṣu'' in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i, 2, 9) for ''sa-Vaśośīnareṣu.'' See '''[[वश|Vaśa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शविष्ठ
<u>'''Śaviṣṭha'''</u> is, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1334> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> the name of a generous patron in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1334> viii. 74, 14, 15.</ref>

शश
<u>'''Śaśa,'''</u> ‘hare,’ is found once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1335> x. 28, 2. Later, a goat supplants the hare in this curious story;<br> see Bo7thling, Proceedings of the Saxon Academy, 1894, ''et seq.''</ref> where it is said to have swallowed a razor. The animal is occasionally mentioned later also.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1335> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 56;<br> xxiv. 38;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Samhitā, iii. 14, 15;<br> the hare in the moon, Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 5, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 84.</ref>

शशयु
<u>'''Śaśayu,'''</u> ‘pursuing the hare,’ is the epithet of some animal ('''[[मृग|Mṛga]]''') in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1336> iv. 3, 6.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_1336> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 79, 84.</ref> thinks the tiger is meant, but this is not likely. Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_1336> In Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 149.</ref> considers that a bird of prey is intended, while Whitney,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1336> ''Loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 368.</ref> following the commentator, renders the word by ‘lurking.’

शश्वती
<u>'''Śaśvatī.'''</u> See '''Āsaṅga.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शष्प
<u>'''Śaṣpa'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1338> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 13, 81;<br> xxi. 29;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5, 3;<br> 8, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 2, 8;<br> 9, 1, 2, etc.</ref> denotes ‘young or sprouting grass.’

शस्तृ
<u>'''Śastṛ'''</u> in the Rigveda (i. 162, 5) and the Atharvaveda (ix. 3, 3) denotes the slaughterer of an animal. <br>==Foot Notes==

शस्त्र
<u>'''Śastra'''</u> is the technical term<ref name=fx1_ve2_1340> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 7, 2, etc.;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 2, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 25. 28, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 2, 4, 20, etc. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 353, and Caland and Henry, ''L'Agniṣṭoma, passim,'' where the Śastras are set out at length.</ref> for the ‘recitation’ of the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] priest, as opposed to the '''[[स्तोत्र|Stotra]]''' of the Udgātṛ. The recitations at the morning offering of Soma are called the [[आज्य|Ājya]] and Praüga; at the midday offering, the Marutvatīya and the Niṣkevalya; at the evening offering, the Vaiśvadeva and the Āgnimāruta.

शाकटायन
<u>'''Śākaṭāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[शकट|Śakaṭa]],’ is the patronymic of a grammarian referred to by '''[[यास्क|Yāska]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1341> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], i. 3, 12 ''et. seq.''</ref> and in the Prātiśākhyas,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1341> Rigveda Prātiśakhya, i. 3;<br> xiii. 16;<br> Vājasaneyi Prātiśakhya, iii. 8, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 143, 151, 152, 217.</ref> as well as often later.

शाक-दास भाडितायन
<u>'''Śāka-[[दास|dāsa]] Bhāḍitāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of Bhaḍita’) is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1342> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373</ref> as the pupil of '''[[विचक्षण ताण्ड्य|Vicakṣaṇa Tāṇḍya]].'''

शाक-पूणि
<u>'''Śāka-pūṇi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śakapūṇa,’ is the name of a grammarian often mentioned in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1343> iii. 11;<br> viii. 5, 6, 14;<br> xii. 19;<br> xiii. 10, 11. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 85.</ref>

शाकल
<u>'''Śākala'''</u> in the Aitaṛeya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1344> iii. 43, 5 (Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 277). ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 33, n.</ref> denotes the ‘teaching of '''[[शाकल्य|Śākalya]]'''’ according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary. But Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx2_ve2_1344> Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> seems right in taking it as a kind of snake in that passage.

शाकल्य
<u>'''Śākalya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śakala,’ is the patronymic of '''Vidagdha''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1345> xi. 6, 3, 3;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 9, 1;<br> iv. 1, 7, etc.</ref> and of '''[[स्थविर|Sthavira]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1345> iii. 2, 1. 6.</ref> and [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1345> vii. 16;<br> viii. 1. 11.</ref> An undefined [[शाकल्य|Śākalya]]  is mentioned in the same Āraṇyakas,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1345> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]], iii. 1, 1;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]], vii. 1.</ref> in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_1345> vi. 28.</ref> and often later, as a teacher dealing with the text of the Rigveda. Weber<ref name=fx6_ve2_1345> ''Indian Literature,'' 32, 33.</ref> is inclined to identify Vidagdha with the [[शाकल्य|Śākalya]] who is known as the maker of the Pada Pāṭha of the Rigveda, but Oldenberg<ref name=fx7_ve2_1345> ''Prolegomena,'' 380, n.</ref> thinks that the latter was later than the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period. Geldner<ref name=fx8_ve2_1345> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 144-146.</ref> identifies the two; this view, however, is not very probable.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1345> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 239, 240.</ref>

शाकायनिन्
<u>'''Śākāyanin,'''</u> in the plural, denotes the followers of '''[[शाकायन्य|Śākāyanya]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 4, 5, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

शाकायन्य
<u>'''Śākāyanya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śāka,’ is the patronymic of '''Jāta''' in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1347> xxii. 7 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 472). ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2;<br> vi. 29.</ref>

शाकिन्
<u>'''Śākin,'''</u> plur., is believed by Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve2_1348> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 521, n.</ref> to designate a group of generous donors in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1348> v. 52, 17.</ref>

शाक्त्य
<u>'''Śāktya,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[शक्ति|Śakti]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Gaurivīti.'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1349> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 19, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 3, 7;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 14;<br> xii. 13, 10;<br> xxv. 7, 2;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiii. 11, 14;<br> xxiv. 10, 6. 8.</ref>

शाक्वर
<u>'''Śākvara.'''</u> See '''[[शक्वरी|Śakvarī]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शाखा
<u>'''Śākhā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1351> i. 8, 8;<br> vii. 43, 1;<br> x. 94, 3.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1351> Av. iii. 6, 8;<br> x. 7, 21;<br> xi. 2, 19, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘branch’ of a tree. '''[[वया|Vayā]]''' is more often used in this sense in the Rigveda. 

शाङ्खायन
<u>'''Śāṅkhāyana'''</u> as the name of a teacher is not mentioned in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], but it occurs in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1352> xv. 1. Oldenberg's suggestion (''Sacred Books of the East,'' xxix. 4, 5) that Guṇākhya is intended as the author of the Sūtras is quite unnecessary;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 328.</ref> where Guṇākhya is given as the authority for that work. In the Śrauta Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve2_1352> Hillebrandt, [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 1, viii ''et seq.''</ref> the name of [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] never occurs, but the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] Sūtras<ref name=fx3_ve2_1352> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 10;<br> vi. 10;<br> Śāmbavya Gṛhyā [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] in ''Indische Studien,'' 15, 154;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 4. ''Cf.'' Kārikā in Nārāyaṇa on [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 10;<br> Ānartīya on [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 18.</ref> seem to recognize as teacher '''Suyajña [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]].''' In later times<ref name=fx4_ve2_1352> Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 2, xxxi.</ref> the school flourished in Northern Gujarat. [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] appears in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Prātiśākhya<ref name=fx5_ve2_1352> xv. 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 32, 44, 50 ''et seq.;<br>'' 80, 313, 314;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 45, 191, 205, 245, 249.</ref> along with Kāṇḍamāyana.

शाट्यायन
<u>'''Śāṭyāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śāṭya,’ is the patronymic of a teacher mentioned twice in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1353> viii. 1, 4, 9;<br> x. 4, 5, 2.</ref> and often in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1353> i. 6, 2;<br> 30, 1;<br> ii. 2, 8;<br> 4, 3;<br> 9, 10;<br> iii. 13, 6;<br> 28, 5.</ref> In a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the latter work<ref name=fx3_ve2_1353> iv. 16, 1.</ref> he is called a pupil of '''[[ज्वालायन|Jvālāyana]],''' while in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] at the end of the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] he appears as a pupil of '''[[बादरायण|Bādarāyaṇa]].''' The Śāṭyāyanins, his followers, are frequently mentioned in the Sūtras,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1353> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 5, 18;<br> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 8;<br> ii. 9;<br> iii. 2, 11;<br> iv. 8, etc.;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 44.</ref> the Śāṭyāyani [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1353> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 23, 3.</ref> and the Śāṭyāyanaka<ref name=fx6_ve2_1353> ''Ibid.,'' x. 12, 13. 14;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 24;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 4, 13.</ref> being also referred to in them. It has been shown by Oertel<ref name=fx7_ve2_1353> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, ccxli;<br> 18, 20 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 203;<br> Aufrecht, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 151, 152.</ref> that this [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] bore a close resemblance to, and probably belonged to the same period as, the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. 

शाण्ड
<u>'''Śāṇḍa,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[शण्ड|Śaṇḍa]],'''’ is the name of a man in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1354> vi. 63, 9. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158.</ref> who is praised for his generosity. It is not likely that he is identical with '''[[पुरुपन्था|Purupanthā]]''' mentioned in the next verse.

शाण्डिल
<u>'''Śāṇḍila,'''</u> masc. plur., is the term applied to the ‘descendants of '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]'''’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (i. 22, 10).<br>==Foot Notes==

शाण्डिली-पुत्र
<u>'''Śāṇḍilī-putra,'''</u> ‘pupil of a female descendant of Śaṇḍila,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[राथीतरीपुत्र|Rāthītarīputra]],''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1356> vi. 4, 32 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

शाण्डिल्य
<u>'''Śāṇḍilya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śaṇḍila,’ is the patronymic of several teachers (see '''Udara''' and '''Suyajña'''). The most important [[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]] is the one cited several times as an authority in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1357> ix. 4, 4, 17;<br> 5, 2, 15;<br> x. 1, 4, 10;<br> 4, 1, 11;<br> 6, 3, 5;<br> 5, 9. ''Cf.'' Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 11, 4.</ref> where his Agni, or ‘sacrificial fire,’ is called [[शाण्डिल|Śāṇḍila]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1357> ix. 1, 1, 43;<br> 3, 3, 18;<br> 5, 1, 61, 68, etc.</ref> From this it appears clearly that he was one of the great teachers of the fire ritual which occupies the fifth and following books of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. In the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the tenth book<ref name=fx3_ve2_1357> x. 6, 5, 9.</ref> he is given as a pupil of '''Kuśri''' and a teacher of '''[[वात्स्य|Vātsya]];''' another list at the end of the last book in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension<ref name=fx4_ve2_1357> vi. 5, 4.</ref> gives him as a pupil of [[वात्स्य|Vātsya]], and the latter as a pupil of Kuśri. In the confused and worthless<ref name=fx5_ve2_1357> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xxxiv. n. 2.</ref> lists of teachers at the end of the second and fourth books of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] he is said to be the pupil of various persons--'''[[कैशोर्य|Kaiśorya]] [[काप्य|Kāpya]],'''<ref name=fx6_ve2_1357> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> '''Vaiṣṭapureya,'''<ref name=fx7_ve2_1357> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> '''[[कौशिक|Kauśika]],'''<ref name=fx8_ve2_1357> ii. 6, 1;<br> iv. 6, 1 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> '''[[गौतम|Gautama]],'''<ref name=fx9_ve2_1357> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 1;<br> iv. 6, 1 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> '''[[बैजवाप|Baijavāpa]],'''<ref name=fx10_ve2_1357> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> and '''Āṇa-  bhimlāta.'''<ref name=fx11_ve2_1357> ii. 6, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xxxi ''et seq.;<br>'' 43, xviii ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 71, 76 ''et seq.;<br>'' 120, 131, 132;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 213.</ref> No doubt different Śāṇḍilyas may be meant, but the lists are too confused to claim serious consideration.

शाण्डिल्यायन
<u>'''Śāṇḍilyāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]],'''’ is the patronymic of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1358> ix. 5, 1, 64.</ref> Apparently he is identical with '''Celaka,''' also mentioned in that text;<ref name=fx2_ve2_1358> x. 4, 5, 3. The name [[शाण्डिल्यायन|Śāṇḍilyāyana]], like that of Sāṇḍilya, is common in the Sūtras. See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 45, ''et seq.''</ref> it is thus reasonable to suppose that '''[[चैलकि|Cailaki]] Jīvala'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1358> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 1, 34.</ref> was his son. It is much more doubtful whether he was<ref name=fx4_ve2_1358> Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 259.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 53, 76, 120.</ref> the grandfather of '''Pravāhaṇa [[जैवल|Jaivala]],''' who was a prince rather than a Brahmin.

शात-पर्णेय
<u>'''Śāta-parṇeya'''</u> ‘descendant of Śataparṇa,’ is the patronymic of '''Dhīra''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 3, 3, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

शाद
<u>'''Śāda'''</u> denotes ‘grass’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1360> ix. 15, 6.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1360> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 1, etc.</ref> and later.

शाप
<u>'''Śāpa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1361> vii. 18, 5;<br> x. 28, 4.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1361> Av. iii. 24, 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 11.</ref> denotes the ‘drift’ brought down by streams, possibly conceived as the ‘curse’ of the waters.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1361> ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 178;<br> ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 184, 185.</ref>

शामुल्य
<u>'''Śāmulya'''</u> in the marriage hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1362> x. 85, 29. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262.</ref> denotes a collen garment’ worn at night. 

शमूल
<u>'''Śamūla'''</u> in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1363> i. 38, 4. ''Cf.'' Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 116, 233;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 4, 7;<br> [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], lxix. 3.</ref> seems to have much the same sense as '''[[शामुल्य|Śāmulya]],''' ‘a '''woollen''' shirt,’ generally. Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1363> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, ccxliii.</ref> emends to ''śamīla,'' ‘pieces of [[शमी|Śamī]] wood.’

शाम्ब
<u>'''Śāmba.'''</u> See '''[[शार्कराक्ष|Śārkarākṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शाम्बर
<u>'''Śāmbara,'''</u> properly an adjective in the sense of ‘relating to '''[[शम्बर|Śambara]],'''’ appears in one passage of the Rigveda (iii. 47, 4) to be used as a substantive denoting ‘the contest with [[शम्बर|Śambara]].’<br>==Foot Notes==

शाम्बु
<u>'''Śāmbu'''</u> occurs in the plural with the '''Aṅgirases''' in a passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1366> xix. 39, 5, where Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 960, retracts the emendation ''Bhṛgubhyaḥ'' for ''Śāmbubhyaḥ'' in the text.</ref> no doubt as the name of a family of ancient teachers. There is extant in manuscript a [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] of the Śāmbavyas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1366> Oldenberg, ''Indische Studien,'' 15, 4, 154.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 678.</ref>

शायस्थि
<u>'''Śāyasthi'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1367> ''Indische Studien.'' 4, 372.</ref>

शारद
<u>'''Śārada.'''</u> See '''Pur.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शारि
<u>'''1. Śāri'''</u> occurs in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1369> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 33.</ref> It seems clear, since it is described as ‘of human speech’ (''[[पुरुष|puruṣa]]-[[वाच्|vāc]]''), that it was some kind of bird, possibly the later Sārikā (‘starling’), as Zimmer<ref name=fx2_ve2_1369> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 90, 91.</ref> suggests. See also '''[[शारिशाका|Śāriśākā]].''' 

शारि
<u>'''2. Śāri,'''</u> occurring in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1370> i. 112, 16.</ref> is said by Sāyaṇa to mean ‘arrow.’ This is uncertain, but connexion with '''[[शर|Śara]]''' or 1. '''[[शारि|Śāri]]''' is quite possible.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1370> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 103.</ref>

शारिशाका
<u>'''Śāriśākā'''</u> is an utterly obscure expression found in one passage of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1371> iii. 14, 5.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx2_ve2_1371> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 246.</ref> thinks it means ‘dung (''[[शकन्|śakan]]'') of the [[शारि|Śāri]] bird’; Grill<ref name=fx3_ve2_1371> ''Hundert Lieder,^2'' 112.</ref> sees in the word the ''śārikā,'' ‘the hooded crow’; Roth<ref name=fx4_ve2_1371> In Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 110.</ref> suggests the emendation (''śāriḥ (= śāliḥ) śaka iva,'' ‘like rice in manure’; and Bloomfield<ref name=fx5_ve2_1371> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 351. But see Lanman's note in Whitney, ''loc. cit.''</ref> emends ''[[शारि|śāri]]-śukeva,'' ‘like starlings and parrots.’

शार्कराक्ष
<u>'''Śārkarākṣa'''</u> is found in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1372> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref> as the patronymic of a teacher, '''[[शाम्ब|Śāmba]],''' perhaps by a blunder for '''[[शार्कराक्ष्य|Śārkarākṣya]],''' ‘descendant of Śarkarākṣa.’ In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_1372> xxii. 8.</ref> a teacher, [[शर्कराख्य|Śarkarākhya]], occurs, again probably a blunder, in this case for Śarkarākṣa himself. The patronymic Śārkarākṣi is found in the Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1372> xii. 10. 10.</ref>

शार्कराक्ष्य
<u>'''Śārkarākṣya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śarkarākṣa,’ is the patronymic of '''Jana''' in the Śatapatha Brāhmana<ref name=fx1_ve2_1373> x. 6, 1, 1.</ref> and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1373> v. 11, 1;<br> 15, 1.</ref> In the plural they occur in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx3_ve2_1373> ii. 1, 4.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1373> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 382.<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 204;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 388;<br> 3, 259.</ref> It is not necessary to assume that the form is incorrect for [[शार्कराक्ष|Śārkarākṣa]].

शार्ग
<u>'''Śārga'''</u> is the name of a bird in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1374> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 19, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 33. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> Sāyana on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā calls it the ‘wild Caṭaka.’ 

शार्ङ्ग
<u>'''Śārṅga.'''</u>--The Anukramaṇī<ref name=fx1_ve2_1375> See also Sāyaṇa on Rv. x. 142;<br> Ṣaḍguruśiṣya on the Sarvānukramaṇī (ed. Macdonell), p. 163.</ref> (Index) of the Rigveda ascribes a hymn of that text<ref name=fx2_ve2_1375> x. 142.</ref> to the Śārṅgas, [[जरितृ|Jaritṛ]], [[द्रोण|Droṇa]], Sārisṛkva, and Stambamitra. The Mahābhārata<ref name=fx3_ve2_1375> i. 8334 ''et seq.''</ref> contains a tale describing how the four Śārṅgas, sons of the [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] Mandapāla, were saved from the great fire in the [[खाण्डव|Khāṇḍava]] forest by means of prayers. Sieg<ref name=fx4_ve2_1375> ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 44-50.</ref> has attempted to use this tale for the elucidation of the hymn in question, but without substantial success. As Oldenberg<ref name=fx5_ve2_1375> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 39, 79.</ref> says, the tale is based on the hymn rather than ''vice versa.''

शार्दूल
<u>'''Śārdūla,'''</u> ‘tiger,’ is mentioned in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1376> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 11;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1376> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 5, 3;<br> iv. 1, 9, 11;<br> 5, 4, 10;<br> xi. 8, 4, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 8, 1;<br> 8, 5, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 79.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[व्याघ्र|Vyāghra]].'''

शार्यात
<u>'''Śāryāta,'''</u> perhaps ‘descendant of '''[[शर्यात|Śaryāta]],'''’ is the name of a singer in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1377> i. 51, 12;<br> iii. 51, 7.</ref> A [[शार्यात|Śāryāta]] appears also in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1377> iv. 32, 7.</ref> with the patronymic '''[[मानव|Mānava]]''' as the seer of a Rigvedic hymn,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1377> x. 92.</ref> and as having been anointed by '''[[च्यवन|Cyavana]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1377> viii. 21, 4.</ref> The same man is evidently meant by [[शर्यात|Śaryāta]] in the story of [[च्यवन|Cyavana]] in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1377> iv. 1, 5, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx6_ve2_1377> iii. 121 ''et seq.'' (Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society'') 11, cxlv.;<br> Hopkins, ''ibid.,'' 26, 58.</ref> In both these passages the Śāryātas are mentioned as his descendants, and his daughter is called Śāryātī.

शालङ्कायन
<u>'''Śālaṅkāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śalaṅku,’ is the patronymic of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1378> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 383;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 10, 10;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxiv. 9, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 75;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 49.</ref> 

शालङ्कायनी-पुत्र
<u>'''Śālaṅkāyanī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Śalaṅku,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[वार्षगणीपुत्र|Vārṣagaṇīputra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 31).<br>==Foot Notes==

शाला
<u>'''Śālā'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1380> v. 31, 5;<br> vi. 106, 3;<br> viii. 6, 10;<br> ix. 3, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' xiv. 1, 63.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1380> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 3, 1;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 1, 6, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘house’ in the wide sense of the word, including such meanings as ‘stall’ for cattle, ‘shed’ for corn, etc.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1380> Av. iii. 12, 1 ''et seq.,'' and ''cf.'' ix. 3, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> See '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].''' The householder is called [[शाला|Śālā]]-pati, ‘lord of the house,’ in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1380> ix. 3, 12.</ref>

शालावत्य
<u>'''Śālāvatya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śalāvant,’ is the patronymic of '''Śilaka''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 8, 1), and of '''[[गलूनस आर्क्षाकायण|Galūnasa Ārkṣākāyaṇa]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 38, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

सालि
<u>'''Sāli,'''</u> a later word for ‘rice,’ is conjectured by Roth to be the equivalent of [[शारि|Śāri]] in the word '''[[शारिशाका|Śāriśākā]]''' in the Atharvaveda.<br>==Foot Notes==

शालूक
<u>'''Śālūka'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1383> iv. 34, 5. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 70;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 207.</ref> denotes the edible roots of the lotus.

शाल्व
<u>'''Śālva'''</u> as the name of a people is found in the Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1384> i. 2, 9. ''Cf.'' '''[[सल्व|Salva]].'''</ref> coupled with that of the '''Matsyas.'''

सावसायन
<u>'''Sāvasāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[शवस्|Śavas]],’ is the patronymic of '''Devataras''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1385> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

शास
<u>'''Śāsa'''</u> denotes in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1386> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17, 5;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 25, 1 (of the knife to be used in slaying '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''');<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 1, 4, 5;<br> xiii. 2, 3, 16.</ref> a ‘sword’ or ‘knife.’ 

शिंशपा
<u>'''Śiṃśapā'''</u> is the name of a tree (''Dalbergia Sisu'') in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1387> iii. 53, 19 (with the [[खदिर|Khadira]]).</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1387> Av. xx. 129, 7. ''Cf. śāṃśapa'' in vi. 129, 1;<br> Whiteny, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 378.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 61.</ref> It is a sately and beautiful tree.

शिंशु-मार
<u>'''Śiṃśu-māra,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1388> Rv. i. 116, 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11;<br> Av. xi. 2, 25. In [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 28, the reading is doubtful.</ref> or '''Śiśu-māra,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1388> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30, and the Paippalāda recension of the Av., ''loc. cit.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 19.</ref> is the name of an aquatic creature in the Rigveda and the later Saṃhitās. It is either the ‘crocodile,’ the ‘alligator,’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1388> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 325, and Sāyaṇa on Rv., ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Av., ''loc. cit.;<br>'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> or the ‘porpoise’<ref name=fx4_ve2_1388> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[शिशुमार|śiśumāra]];<br>'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 157;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 624.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 96;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 179.</ref> (''Delphinus Gangeticus'').

शिक्य
<u>'''Śikya'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1389> ix. 3, 6, where Whitney suggests that it may be an ornamental hanging appendage. See Lanman in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 526. Whitney's alternative rendering ‘slings’ is better. See Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 597. ''Cf.'' perhaps Av. xiii. 4, 8.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1389> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 4, 2. 3;<br> 6, 9, 1, etc.</ref> seems to mean a carrying ‘sling’ of rope.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1389> This is pretty clearly the meaning in Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 28;<br> vi. 7, 1, 16. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 268, n. 3.</ref>

शिख
<u>'''Śikha'''</u> and '''[[अनुशिख|Anuśikha]]''' are the names of two priests who served as '''[[नेष्टृ|Neṣṭṛ]]''' and '''[[पोतृ|Potṛ]]''' at the snake festival in the '''Pañca-''' viṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1390> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

शिखण्ड
<u>'''Śikhaṇḍa'''</u> denotes a ‘tuft’ or ‘lock,’ as a mode of wearing the hair, in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1391> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 3, 16, 2 (in the plural);<br> ''catuḥ-[[शिखण्ड|śikhaṇḍa]],'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 27;<br> iii. 7, 6, 4 (corresponding to ''catuḥ-[[कपर्द|kaparda]],'' Rv. x. 114, 3). So ''śikhaṇḍin'' means ‘wearing a tuft of hair,’ and is found in Av. iv. 37, 7;<br> xi. 2, 12, etc.</ref> 

शिखण्डिन् याज्ञसेन
<u>'''Śikhaṇḍin Yājñasena'''</u> (‘descendant of Yajñasena’) is mentioned in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 4) as a priest of '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]] [[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शिखर
<u>'''Śikhara'''</u> as a ‘peak’ of a mountain is found in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxvi. 1), and often in the Epic.<br>==Foot Notes==

शिखा
<u>'''Śikhā'''</u> denotes in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1394> i. 3, 3, 5.</ref> the ‘knot of hair’ worn on the top of the head. Wearing the top-knot unloosened was the sign of mourning in the case of women and men alike.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1394> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 2, 9. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 11, 340;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 634, on Av. ix. 9, 7.</ref>

शिग्रु
<u>'''Śigru'''</u> is the name of a tribe occurring in the passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1395> vii. 18, 19.</ref> in which they are mentioned with the '''Ajas''' and the '''Yakṣus''' as having been defeated by the '''Tṛtsus''' and King '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]].''' It is impossible to say whether they were or were not under the leadership of '''[[भेद|Bheda]],''' as Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_1395> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173.</ref> plausibly suggests. If Sigru is connected with the later ''[[शिग्रु|śigru]],'' ‘horse-radish’ (''Moringa pterygosperma''), which is quite probable, it is possible that the tribe was totemistic and non-Āryan, but this is a mere matter of conjecture.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1395> ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 85;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 153;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, cliv;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 929 ''et seq.;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 200, n.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 127.</ref> The '''Matsyas''' (‘Fishes’) were probably Āryan.

शिञ्जार
<u>'''Śiñjāra'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] twice mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1396> viii. 5, 25;<br> x. 40, 7. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 3, 139.</ref> along with '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]], [[प्रियमेध|Priyamedha]], [[उपस्तुत|Upastuta]],''' and '''Atri.''' Geldner<ref name=fx2_ve2_1396> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 179.</ref> takes the word either as a name of Atri or an adjective. 

शिति-कक्षी
<u>'''Śiti-kakṣī'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1397> v. 5, 20, 1. ''Cf.'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 4;<br> Av. v. 23, 5. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> is explained by Sāyaṇa as a ‘white-breasted’ (''pāṇḍarodara'') vulture. The word may, however, well be only an adjective.^2

शिति-पृष्ठ
<u>'''Śiti-pṛṣṭha'''</u> (‘white-backed’) is the name of the Maitrāvaruṇa priest at the snake festival in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1398> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref>

शिति-बाहु ऐषकृत नैमिशि
<u>'''Śiti-[[बाहु|bāhu]] [[ऐषकृत|Aiṣakṛta]] Naimiśi'''</u> is mentioned as a sacrificer in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1399> i. 363 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 26, 192).</ref> where it is recorded that a monkey an off with his sacrificial cake.

शित्पुट
<u>'''Śitpuṭa'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1400> v. 5, 17, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 86.</ref> denotes, according to the commentator, a kind of cat.

शिपद
<u>'''Śipada'''</u> occurs only in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1401> vii. 50, 4.</ref> in the negative form ''a-[[शिपद|śipada]],'' together with ''a-[[शिमिद|śimida]].'' Both [[शिपद|Śipada]] and [[शिमिद|Śimida]] are perhaps names of unknown diseases.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1401> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 394.</ref>

शिपवित्नुक
<u>'''Śipavitnuka'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1402> v. 20, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 262.</ref> seems to denote a species of worm.

शिप्रा
<u>'''Śiprā'''</u> is a word of somewhat uncertain sense: it seems to mean ‘cheeks’ in several passages;<ref name=fx1_ve2_1403> Rv. iii. 32, 1;<br> v. 36, 2;<br> viii. 76, 10;<br> x. 96, 9;<br> 105, 5, all according to Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' Geldner. ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 179, who treats the word as a neuter (''śipra''), takes it in i. 101, 10, as ‘lip’ (''cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 249, n.), and sees in iii. 32, 1;<br> viii. 76, 10;<br> x. 96, 9, the sense of ‘moustache.’ [[यास्क|Yāska]], [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 17, gives the alternative senses of ‘jaw’ and ‘nose.’</ref> in others<ref name=fx2_ve2_1403> Rv. v. 54, 11;<br> viii. 7, 25. Geldner, ''loc. cit.,'' here accepts ''[[शिप्रा|śiprā]]'' as ‘helmet.’</ref> it appears to  designate the ‘cheek-pieces’ of a helmet, or of the ‘bit’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1403> Rv. i. 101, 10;<br> Zimmer, ''loc. cit.''</ref> of a horse. In ''ayaḥ-śipra,'' used of the Aśvins,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1403> Rv. iv. 37, 4.</ref> and the other compounds, ''[[हिरण्य|hiraṇya]]-śipra,''<ref name=fx5_ve2_1403> Rv. ii. 34, 3.</ref> ''hari-śipra,''<ref name=fx6_ve2_1403> Rv. x. 96, 4.</ref> and ''hiri-śipra,''<ref name=fx7_ve2_1403> Rv. ii. 2, 3;<br> vi. 25, 9.</ref> the word probably has the extended sense of ‘helmet,’ described as ‘of iron,’ ‘of gold,’ or ‘yellow,’ Similarly ''śiprin''<ref name=fx8_ve2_1403> Rv. i. 29, 2;<br> 81, 4;<br> vi, 44, 14, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 301;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 39, n. 2.</ref> would mean ‘wearing a helmet.’

शिफा
<u>'''Śiphā'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1404> i. 104, 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 18;<br> Perry, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 11, 201.</ref> where Sāyaṇa explains the word as the name of a river, quite a possible interpretation.

शिबि
<u>'''Śibi,'''</u> son of '''[[उशीनर|Uśīnara]],''' is mentioned in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1405> xxi. 18. ''Cf.'' Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 28.</ref> as a protégé of Indra, who sacrificed for him on the Varṣiṣṭhīya plain, and saved him from fear of foreign invasion.

शिमिद
<u>'''Śimida,'''</u> occurring in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1406> vii. 50, 4. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 394.</ref> in the compound ''a-śinida,'' perhaps denotes a disease. The feminine form, Śimidā, is found as the name of a demoness in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1406> iv. 25, 4.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1406> vii. 4, 1, 27.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[शिपद|Śipada]].'''

शिम्बल
<u>'''Śimbala'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1407> iii. 53, 22. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 179;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 254.</ref> denotes, according to Sāyaṇa, the flower of the Śālmali (= '''Śalmali'''), ‘silk-cotton tree.’ 

शिम्यु
<u>'''Śimyu'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1408> vii. 18, 5.</ref> as the name of one of the peoples or kings who were defeated by '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' in the '''[[दाशराज्ञ|Dāśarājña]]''' (‘battle of the ten kings’). Since in another passage<ref name=fx2_ve2_1408> i. 100, 18, where Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' thinks that the word simply means ‘enemy.’</ref> the Śimyus are coupled with the '''Dasyus,''' Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_1408> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 118, 119.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 261.</ref> plausibly concludes that they were non-Āryans.

शिरिम्बिठ
<u>'''Śirimbiṭha'''</u> occurs in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1409> x. 155, 1.</ref> where the name of a man may possibly be meant, the Anukramaṇī (Index) ascribing the hymn in which the word occurs to his authorship. [[यास्क|Yāska]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1409> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 30. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 167.</ref> however, renders the term by ‘cloud.’

शिलक शालावत्य
<u>'''Śilaka Śālāvatya'''</u> (‘descendant of Śalāvant’) is the name of a teacher, a contemporary of '''Calkitāyana [[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]]''' and '''Pravāhaṇa [[जैवल|Jaivala]],''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 8, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

शिल्प
<u>'''1. Śilpa'''</u> means ‘art,’ of which three kinds--''nṛtya,'' ‘dance’; ''gīta,'' ‘song’; and ''[[वादित|vādita]],'' ‘instrumental music,’ are enumerated in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xxix. 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

शिल्प कश्यप
<u>'''2. Śilpa Kaśyapa'''</u> is named in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1412> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> as a teacher, a pupil of '''[[कश्यप नैध्रुवि|Kaśyapa Naidhruvi]].'''

शिव
<u>'''Śiva'''</u> as the name of a people occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1413> vii. 18, 7.</ref> where they share with the '''Alinas, Pakthas, Bhalānases,''' and '''Viṣāṇins''' the honour of being defeated by '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],''' not of being, as Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1413> ''Zur Litteratur und Geschichte des Veda,'' 95 ''et seq.;<br>'' once accepted by Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 126.</ref> thought, his allies. There can hardly be any doubt  of their identity with the <ref name=fx3_ve2_1413> Arrian, ''Indica,'' v. 12.</ref> or <ref name=fx4_ve2_1413> Diodorus, xvii. 96.</ref> of the Greeks, who dwelt between the Indus and the Akesines ('''[[असिक्नी|Asiknī]]''') in Alexander's time. The village of [[शिव|Śiva]]-pura, mentioned by the scholiast on Pāṇini<ref name=fx5_ve2_1413> iv. 2, 109. Connected with [[शिव|Śiva]] by Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 376. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 431;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 173;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 260 ''et seq.''</ref> as situated in the northern country, may also perserve the name. ''Cf.'' '''[[शिबि|Śibi]].'''

शिशिर
<u>'''Śiśira.'''</u> See '''[[ऋतु|Ṛtu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शिशु आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Śiśu Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman or Chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1415> xiii. 3, 24. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160.</ref>

शिशुक
<u>'''Śiśuka'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1416> vi. 14, 3. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 291.</ref> seems to be an adjective meaning ‘young,’ but according to Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve2_1416> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 464.</ref> it has the sense of ‘foal.’ The commentator, Sāyaṇa, reads [[शुशुक|Śuśuka]], which he explains as a ‘wild animal so called.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[आशुंग|Āśuṃga]].'''

शिशुमार
<u>'''1. Śiśumāra.'''</u> See '''[[शिंशुमार|Śiṃśumāra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शिशुमार
<u>'''2. Śiśumāra'''</u> is a term applied to '''Śarkara''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 5, 15), where he is called a Śiśumārarṣi, explained by the commentator to mean a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the form of a Siśumāra.<br>==Foot Notes==

सिश्न-देव
<u>'''Siśna-deva,'''</u> occurring twice in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1419> vii. 21, 5;<br> x. 99, 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 118;<br> Hopkins, ''Religions of India,'' 150;<br> von Schroeder, ''Vienna Oriental Journal,'' 9, 237;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' 155;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1911, 1002, n. 5.</ref> in the plural, means ‘those who have the phallus for a deity.’ The term most probably refers to the phallus worship of the aborigines. 

शीपाल
<u>'''Śīpāla'''</u> is the name of a water plant (''Blyxa Octandra'') mentioned in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1420> x. 68, 5. ''Cf.'' the derivative adjective ''śīpalya,'' ‘overgrown with [[शीपाल|Śīpāla]] plants,’ Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71.</ref> Its later name is Śaivala.

शीपाला
<u>'''Śīpālā'''</u> is found once in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1421> vi. 12, 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 71;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 289, 290;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 462.</ref> where it may mean either a ‘pool abounding in '''[[शीपाल|Śīpāla]]''' plants’ or the proper name of a river or lake.

शीपुद्रु
<u>'''Śīpudru'''</u> is merely an incorrect reading in the text of the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1422> vi. 127, 1. See Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 376.</ref> for '''[[चीपुद्रु|Cīpudru]].'''

शीर्षक्ति
<u>'''Śīrṣakti'''</u> is a common word for ‘headache’ in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1423> i. 12, 3;<br> ix. 8, 1;<br> xii. 2, 19;<br> 5, 23. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, xxxv;<br> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 252;<br> ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 416, who sees in it ''śīrṣasakti'' (''cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' 64, 2). Bo7htlingk, Proceedings of the Saxon Academy, 1897, 50, thinks the word means ‘a stiff neck, with head awry.’ See Lanman in Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 14. In Av. xix. 39, 10, ''śīrṣa-śoka'' is used for ‘headache.’</ref>

शीर्षण्य
<u>'''Śīrṣaṇya'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1424> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 5, 3;<br> 12, 3;<br> 17, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5 Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]. xvii. 2, 8.</ref> denotes the ‘head’ of a couch ('''Asandī''').

शीर्षामय
<u>'''Śīrṣāmaya,'''</u> ‘disease of the head,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda (v. 4, 10; ix. 8, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

शीष्ट
<u>'''Śīṣṭa'''</u> occurs only in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1426> viii. 53, 4. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 163.</ref> where the word seems to be the name of an unimportant clan. 

शुक
<u>'''Śuka,'''</u> ‘parrot,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1427> i. 50, 12.</ref> where a desire is expressed to transfer to the [[शुक|Śuka]] and the '''[[रोपणाका|Ropaṇākā]]''' the yellowness of jaundice. The bird is included in the list of sacrificial victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1427> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 33;<br> and ''cf. śukababhru,'' ‘reddish, like a parrot,’ ''ibid.,'' xxiv. 2.</ref> It is described as yellow and as ‘of human speech’ (''[[पुरुष|puruṣa]]-[[वाच्|vāc]]'').<ref name=fx3_ve2_1427> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] and Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitās, ''loc. cit.''</ref> According to Bloomfield,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1427> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 352.</ref> this word is the correct reading for the second half of the obscure '''[[शारिशाका|Śāriśākā]]''' of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1427> iii. 14, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 90.</ref>

शुक्ति आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Śukti Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman or Chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 5, 16).<br>==Foot Notes==

शुक्र
<u>'''1. Śukra,'''</u> according to Tilak,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1429> ''Orion,'' 162.</ref> has in two passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1429> iii. 32, 2;<br> ix. 46, 4.</ref> the sense of a planet. This is most improbable. ''Cf.'' '''[[मन्थिन्|Manthin]].'''

शुक्र जाबाल
<u>'''2. Śukra Jābāla'''</u> (‘descendant of Jabālā’) is the name of a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 7, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

शुक्ल
<u>'''Śukla.'''</u> See '''[[यजुस्|Yajus]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शुक्ल-दन्त्
<u>'''Śukla-dant,'''</u> ‘white-tusked,’ is applied as an epithet to '''[[मृग|Mṛga]],''' ‘wild beast,’ in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 23, 3). ‘Elephants’ must be meant.<br>==Foot Notes==

शुच
<u>'''Śuca'''</u> and '''Śucā''' occur in an obscure verse of the Rigveda (x. 26, 6), where a man and a woman may be meant. <br>==Foot Notes==

शुचन्ति
<u>'''Śucanti'''</u> is the name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1434> i. 112, 7. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 165.</ref>

शुचि-वृक्ष गौपालायन
<u>'''Śuci-[[वृक्ष|vṛkṣa]] Gaupālāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of Gopāla’) is the name of the priest of '''Vṛddhadyumna Abhipratāriṇa''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1435> iii. 48, 9 (Ganpalāyana in Aufrecht's edition).</ref> He is also mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1435> iii. 10, 4.</ref>

शुतुद्री
<u>'''Śutudrī,'''</u> twice mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1436> iii. 33, 1;<br> x. 75, 5;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 26.</ref> is the name of the most easterly river of the Panjab, the modern Sutlej, the Zaradros of Ptolemy and Arrian.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1436> In Arrian's time the Sutlej flowed independently into the Rann of Cutch: ''Imperial Gazetteer of India,'' 23, 179.</ref> In the post-Vedic period the name of this river appears transformed to Śatadru (‘flowing in a hundred channels’). The Sutlej has changed its course very considerably within historical times.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1436> ''Ibid.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 10, 11.</ref>

शुनः-पुच्छ
<u>'''Śunaḥ-puccha,'''</u> ‘Dog’s tail,’ is the name of a brother of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1437> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 15, 7;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 20, 1.</ref>

शुनः-शेप
<u>'''Śunaḥ-śepa,'''</u> ‘Dog’s tail,’ is the name of a man with the patronymic '''[[आजीगर्ति|Ājīgarti]].''' According to a tale told in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1438> vii. 13-18.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1438> xv. 20, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' xvi. 11, 2.</ref> he was purchased as a victim by '''[[रोहित|Rohita]],''' King '''Hariścandra's''' son, who had been promised by his father to Varuṇa as a sacrifice. He was actually bound to the stake, but was released in time through his supplications, supposed to be preserved in certain hymns of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1438> i. 24 ''et seq. Cf.'' v. 2, 7.</ref> He was adopted by '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],''' to whose advice he owed the inspiration to ask the gods to release him, and became his son as '''[[देवरात|Devarāta]],''' much to the annoyance  of some of Viśvāmitra's sons, who in consequence were cursed by their father. The Rigveda, however, contains merely the statement of Śunaḥśepa's deliverance from peril of death by the divine help, and the Yajurvedas<ref name=fx4_ve2_1438> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 1, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xix. 11. The story is not found in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 1.</ref> simply say that he was seized by Varuṇa (perhaps with dropsy),<ref name=fx5_ve2_1438> ''Cf.'' Varuna gṛhīta.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 408 ''et seq.;<br>'' 573 ''et seq.;<br>'' Roth, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 457;<br> ii. 112 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 47, 48;<br> ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 10-16;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 355 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 207;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 146;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1911, 988, 989.</ref> but saved himself from Varuṇa's bonds.

शुनस्-कर्ण
<u>'''Śunas-karṇa,'''</u> ‘Dog-ear,’ is the name of a king,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1439> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxi. 17;<br> Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 28.</ref> son of '''[[शिबि|Śibi]]''' or of Baṣkiha,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1439> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 12, 6.</ref> who performed a certain rite, the Sarvasvāra, and so died without disease.

सुन-होत्र
<u>'''Suna-hotra,'''</u> in the plural, denotes a family of seers in the Rigveda (ii. 18, 6; 41, 14. 17).<br>==Foot Notes==

शुना-सीर
<u>'''Śunā-sīra,'''</u> in the dual, occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1441> iv. 57, 5. 8.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1441> Av. iii. 17 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 7, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xii. 69, etc.</ref> as the names of two agricultural deities, the personifications, probably, of ‘the share and the plough,’ as Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_1441> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' For the native explanations, see Bṛhaddevatā, v. 8 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes. Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 116, 117, renders ''śunam'' adverbially as ‘successfully.’</ref> thinks.

शुनो-लाङ्गूल
<u>'''Śuno-lāṅgūla,'''</u> ‘Dog’s tail,’ is the name of a brother of '''[[शुनः-शेप|Śunaḥ-śepa]].'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1442> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 15, 7;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 20, 1.</ref> 

सुम्बल
<u>'''Sumbala'''</u> is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1443> xii. 5, 2. 3.</ref> The meaning of the word is uncertain: Harisvāmi in his commentary takes it to be ‘straw’; Eggeling<ref name=fx2_ve2_1443> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 202, n. 3;<br> comparing Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxv. 7, 12.</ref> suggests that dried cotton fibre or pods may be meant. In any case, some substance that easily catches fire is intended.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1443> Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref>

शुल्क
<u>'''Śulka'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1444> vii. 82, 6;<br> viii. 1. 5.</ref> clearly means ‘price.’ In the [[धर्म|Dharma]] Sūtras<ref name=fx2_ve2_1444> See Foy, ''Die Ro7nigliche Gewalt,'' 39 ''et seq.''</ref> it denotes a ‘tax,’ a sense which is found by Muir<ref name=fx3_ve2_1444> ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 310.</ref> in a passage of the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1444> iii. 29, 3.</ref> where ''[[शुक्ल|śukla]]'' is read in the edition with great detriment to the sense. This correction is accepted by Bloomfield<ref name=fx5_ve2_1444> ''Hymns of the Atharvida,'' 434.</ref> and by Whitney.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1444> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 136.</ref> In another passage the same change made by Weber<ref name=fx7_ve2_1444> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 304.</ref> is not accepted by Whitney,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1444> ''Op, cit.'' 253.</ref> and doubtfully by Bloomfield.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1444> ''Loc. cit.'' ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 413.</ref>

शुशुक
<u>'''Śuśuka.'''</u> See '''Aśuṃga''' and '''[[शिशुक|Śiśuka]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शुशुलूक
<u>'''Śuśulūka'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1446> vii. 104, 22.</ref> in the compound ''śuśulūkayātu,'' the name of a demon. According to Sāyaṇa, the word means a ‘small owl.’ It appears in the feminine form, Śuśulūkā, in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1446> iii. 14, 17. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref>

शुष्क-भृङ्गार
