<u>'''Śuṣka-bhṛṅgāra'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the Kauṣitaki [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1447> ii. 6. ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta '''[[सूत्र|Sūtra]],''' xvii. 7, 13.</ref>

सुश्मिण
<u>'''Suśmiṇa'''</u> is a name of '''Amitratapana,''' a king of the '''Śibis,''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 23, 10). <br>==Foot Notes==

शूद्र
<u>'''Śūdra'''</u> is the designation of the fourth caste in the Vedic state (see '''[[वर्ण|Varṇa]]'''). It is quite unknown in the Rigveda except in the Puruṣasūkta<ref name=fx1_ve2_1449> x. 90, 12. See Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 8 ''et seq.''</ref> (‘hymn of man’) in the tenth Maṇḍla, where is the earliest version of the origin of the castes the Śudra for the first time appears. The Rigveda, on the other hand, knows '''[[दस्यु|Dasyu]]''' and '''[[दास|Dāsa]],''' both as aborigines independent of Āryan control and as subjugated slaves: it is reasonable to reckon the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] of the later texts as belonging to the aborigines who had been reduced to subjection by the Āryans. Strictly speaking, the defeated aborigines must have been regarded as slaves, but it is obvious that, except on occasions when most of the men were slain, which may have occurred quite often, there must have remained too many of them to be used as slaves of individual owners. The villages of the aborigines must have continued to subsist, but under Āryan lordship and control: there may be this amount of truth in Baden Powell's theory, which practically traced all the early cultivating villages in India to Dravidian origin. On the other hand, the term [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] would also cover the wild hill tribes which lived by hunting and fishing, and many of which would acknowledge the superiority of their Āryan neighbours: it could, in fact, be applied to all beyond the pale of the Āryan state.<br><br>This view of the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] suits adequately the Vedic references to his condition, which would not apply adequately to domestic slaves only. The [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] is continually opposed to the Āryan,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1449> Av. iv. 20, 4;<br> xix. 32, 8;<br> 62, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiv. 30;<br> xxiii. 30. 31;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 10, 2;<br> vii. 4, 19, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], iv. 7;<br> xvii. 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 8, 6;<br> iii. 13, 1, etc. See also '''[[आर्य|Ārya]]''' and '''Arya.''' In [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 3, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 17;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 5, '''Sūdra''' is opposed to '''Arya.'''</ref> and the colour of the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] is compared with that of the Āryan,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1449> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 17. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 4, 4, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, 25;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 4, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 6, 7;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 4;<br> Muir, ''op. cit.,'' 1^2, 140;<br> Mahābhārata, xii. 188, 5.</ref> just as his ways are so contrasted.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1449> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 17, 3. 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 24.</ref> The [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_1449> vii. 29, 4;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 439.</ref> in its account of the castes, declares that the  [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] is ''anyasya [[प्रेष्य|preṣya]],'' ‘the servant of another’; ''kāmotthāpya,'' ‘to be expelled at will’; and ''yathākāmavadhya,'' ‘to be slain at will.’ All these terms well enough describe the position of the serf as the result of a conquest: the epithets might have been applied to the English serf after the Norman Conquest with but slight inaccuracy, especially if his master had received a grant of jurisdiction from the Crown. The [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1449> vi. 1. 11.</ref> explains that even if prosperous (''bahu-[[पशु|paśu]],'' ‘having many cows’) a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] could not be other than a servant: his business was ''pādāvanejya,'' ‘the washing of the feet’ of his superiors. The Mahābhārata<ref name=fx7_ve2_1449> xii. 30, 7 (Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 73). The same text, xii. 294, 21 (''ibid.,'' 74, n.). insists on his duty of service.</ref> says out and out that a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] has no property (''na hi svam asti śūdrasya,'' ‘the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] has nothing he can call his own’). On the other hand, just as in England the royal justice would protect the serf in life and limb,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1449> Pollock and Maitland, ''History of English Law,'' 1, 350, 355, etc.</ref> so it appears that the slaying of a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] involved a wergeld of ten cows according to both [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]]<ref name=fx9_ve2_1449> [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 10, 19, 1.</ref> and Āpastamba.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1449> [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 9, 24, 3.</ref> It may, indeed, be held that this wergeld was only due in case of murder by another than the master, but such limitation is nowhere stated.<br><br>In sacred matters the distinction between Āryan and '''[[शूद्र|Śūdra]]''' was, of course, specially marked. The texts<ref name=fx11_ve2_1449> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 4, 2;<br> iv. 2, 2, 14, etc. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xvi. ''et seq.;<br>'' 26, 292. ''Cf.'' '''Hopkins,''' ''op, cit.,'' 13, 73, 75, n.</ref> do not hesitate to declare that the upper castes were ‘all,’ ignoring the Śūdras; the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] is prohibited<ref name=fx12_ve2_1449> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxi. 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 1, 3. So the ''[[स्थाली|sthālī]],'' ‘cooking vessel,’ is to be prepared by an Āryan, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 8, 3.</ref> from milking the cow for the milk required at the Agnihotra (‘oblation to Agni’); and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx13_ve2_1449> iii. 1, 1. 10. ''Cf.'' v. 3, 2, 2.</ref> forbids a man who has been consecrated (''dīkṣita'') for a sacrifice to speak to a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] at all for the time, though the Śāṭyāyanaka<ref name=fx14_ve2_1449> Quoted by Āpastamba, cited in the scholiast on Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], vii. 5, 7. The sense is not quite certain, but that given in the text seems reasonable. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 10, 11.</ref> seems to have relaxed this rule by confining it to cases in which the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] was guilty of some sin.  At the sacrifice itself the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] could not be present in the ''[[शाला|śālā]],'' ‘hall’; he is definitely classed in the Śatapatha Brāhmáṇa<ref name=fx15_ve2_1449> iii. 1, 1, 10. See also Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 6;<br> Lévi ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 82.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx16_ve2_1449> vi. 1, 11.</ref> as unfit for ‘sacrifice’ (''ayajñiya''); and declared in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx17_ve2_1449> xi. 10, where he therefore does not receive '''Karīras.'''</ref> not to be admitted to drink Soma. At the Pravargya (introductory Soma) rite the performer is not allowed to come in contact with a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]],<ref name=fx18_ve2_1449> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 1, 34.</ref> who here, as in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx17_ve2_1449/> is reckoned as excluded from a share in the Soma-draught. On the other hand, the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] is one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]],<ref name=fx19_ve2_1449> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 6, 2, 10. He is also present at the '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],''' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 1.</ref> and a fight between an Āryan and a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]], in which, of course, the former wins, forms a part of the Mahāvrata rite, being perhaps a precursor of the Indian drama.<ref name=fx20_ve2_1449> Keith, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 64, 534.</ref><br><br>Other indications, however, exist, showing that it would be undesirable to ignore the real importance of the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]], which again reminds us of the condition of the serf, who, though legally restrained, still gradually won his way to the rank of a free man. Rich Śūdras are mentioned in the early texts,<ref name=fx21_ve2_1449> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 7, 10;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 11. Some of the kings' ministers were Śūdras;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 2, 2, with Sāyaṇa's note.</ref> just as [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] ''gahapatis,'' ‘householders,’ occur in the Buddhist texts, and [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] kings in the legal literature.<ref name=fx22_ve2_1449> Foy, ''Die ko7nigliche Gewalt,'' 8;<br> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 83, 84. But see Roth's emendation, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, ccxliii.</ref> Sin against [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] and Āryan is mentioned;<ref name=fx23_ve2_1449> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhiṭā, xxxviii. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 3, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 17.</ref> prayers for glory on behalf of Śūdras, as well as of the other castes<ref name=fx24_ve2_1449> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 6, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xl. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 48, On the other hand, the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] uses magic just as an [[आर्य|Ārya]] does, Av. x. 1, 3.</ref> occur; and the desire to be dear to [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] as well as to Āryan is expressed.<ref name=fx25_ve2_1449> Av. xix. 32, 8;<br> 62, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxvi. 2, etc.</ref> <br><br>The Sūtras also, while they emphasize as general rules points earlier not insisted on, such as their inferiority in sitting, etc.,<ref name=fx26_ve2_1449> [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 7;<br> Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ii. 10, 27, 15, So he can be insulted with impunity, [[गौतम|Gautama]], xii. 13, and is punished for insult by mutilation, ''ibid.,'' xii. 1;<br> Āpastamba, ii. 10, 27, 14.</ref> their exclusion from the study of the Vedas,<ref name=fx27_ve2_1449> [[गौतम|Gautama]], xii. 4-6.</ref> the danger of contact with them<ref name=fx28_ve2_1449> Āpastamba, i. 5, 17, 1;<br> ii. 2, 3, 4, etc.</ref> or their food,<ref name=fx29_ve2_1449> Āpastamba, i. 5, 16, 2, etc.</ref> still recognize that Śūdras can be merchants,<ref name=fx30_ve2_1449> [[गौतम|Gautama]], x. 60. ''Cf.'' x. 50-67 for an exhaustive account of the Śūdra's duties in theory. His relations to his master are those of mutual support.</ref> or even exercise any trade.<ref name=fx31_ve2_1449> Viṣṇu, ii. 14.</ref><br><br>Moreover, the Sūtras<ref name=fx32_ve2_1449> Pāraskara [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 4, 11. Rules to the contrary (''e.g.,'' Gobhila [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 2, 52) are for special occasions. See Weber, ''op. cit.,'' 10, 74. On the other hand, criminal intercourse of a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] and an Āryan woman is severely punished in the Sūtras. See Āpastamba, i. 10, 26, 20;<br> 27, 9;<br> [[गौतम|Gautama]], xii. 2. 3.</ref> permit the marriage of a [[शूद्रा|Śūdrā]] woman with members of all castes. Though it was a reproach to '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]]'''<ref name=fx33_ve2_1449> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 6, 6.</ref> and to '''[[कवष|Kavaṣa]]'''<ref name=fx34_ve2_1449> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 19, 1.</ref> that they were the sons of a [[शूद्रा|Śūdrā]] and a Dāsī respectively, still the possibility of such a reproach shows that marriages of this kind did take place. Moreover, illicit unions of [[आर्य|Ārya]] and [[शूद्रा|Śūdrā]], or [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] and Āryā, are referred to in the Saṃhitās of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx35_ve2_1449> [[आर्य|Ārya]] and [[शूद्रा|Śūdrā]]: Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 30;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 3;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 13, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], iv. 8;<br> [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] and Āryā: Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 31. This verse the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] no doubt deliberately ignores.</ref><br><br>The origin of the term [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] is quite obscure, but Zimmer<ref name=fx36_ve2_1449> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 216, 435.</ref> points out that Ptolemy<ref name=fx37_ve2_1449> vi. 20.</ref> mentions  as a people, and he thinks that the Brāhui may be meant. Without laying any stress on this identification,<ref name=fx38_ve2_1449> The Brāhui are now held not to be Dravidian ethnologically, but TurcoIranian (''Indian Empire,'' 1, 292, 310). '''[[दस्यु|Dasyu]],''' 1, 347, n. 7). a term admirably applicable to Dravidians, but ludicrous as applied to the TurcoIranian type. It is much more plausible to assume that the Brāhuis are a mixed race, which in course of time has lost most of its Dravidian features. On the relation of Dravidians and speakers of Muṇḍā tongues, the Vedic texts throw no light.</ref> it is reasonable to accept the  view<ref name=fx39_ve2_1449> See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 85, 255;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda. 3, 212;<br> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 201, 202.<br><br>''Cf.'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 154, 155;<br> Jolly, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 515;<br> Fick, ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 201 ''et seq.,'' Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 54;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 73 ''et seq.'' (for the [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] in the Epic);<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 191, ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 18, 77, 111, 112, 276;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 4 ''et seq.;<br>'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 8 ''et seq.''</ref> that the term was originally the name of a large tribe opposed to the Āryan invasion. See also '''[[निषाद|Niṣāda]].'''

शूद्रा
<u>'''Śūdrā'''</u> denoted a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] woman in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1450> v. 22. 7 (= Dāsī, v. 22, 6).</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1450> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], iv. 8;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 13, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 30, etc.;<br> ''śūdrāputra,'' ‘son of a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] woman,’ [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 6, 6.</ref>

शूर
<u>'''Śūra'''</u> is the regular word in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1451> i. 70, 11;<br> 101, 6;<br> 141, 8;<br> 158, 3;<br> ii. 17, 2;<br> 30, 10, etc.</ref> and occasionally later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1451> Av. viii. 8, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 34;<br> xx. 37, etc. (of gods, Indra and Agni);<br> ''[[शूर|śūra]]-[[वीर|vīra]],'' Av. viii. 5, 1.</ref> to denote a ‘hero’ or ‘brave warrior.’

शूर-वीर माण्डूक्य
<u>'''Śūra-[[वीर|vīra]] Māṇḍūkya'''</u> (‘descendant of Maṇḍūka’) is the name of a teacher in the Āraṇyakas of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1452> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 1, 3, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, vii. 2. 8. 9. 10 (where the name is read Śauravīra).</ref>

शूर्प
<u>'''Śūrpa'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1453> ix. 6, 16;<br> x. 9, 26;<br> xi. 3, 4;<br> xii. 3, 19 ''et seq.;<br>'' xx. 136, 8.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1453> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 5, 4;<br> iii. 2, 5, 11. etc.</ref> denotes a wickerwork basket for winnowing grain. It is called ''[[वर्ष|varṣa]]-vṛddha,'' ‘swollen by rain,’ in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1453> xii. 3, 19.</ref> which shows, as Zimmer<ref name=fx4_ve2_1453> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238.<br><br>''Cf.'' Lanman in Whitney's Translation of the Atharvaveda, 686;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharavaveda,'' 649.</ref> says, that it was sometimes made of reeds, not of dry wood. 

शूल
<u>'''Śūla,'''</u> denoting the ‘spit,’ used for roasting flesh on, is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1454> i. 162, 11.</ref> and the later Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1454> Śatapatha Brāhmaṇ, xi. 4, 2, 4;<br> 7, 3, 2;<br> 4, 3;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 15, 3 (used at cremation and sugrestive of roasting). The [[शूल|Śūla]], as the weapon of Rudra, is not mentioned till the late Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 11. In the post-Vedic language the ''tri-[[शूल|śūla]],'' or ‘trident,’ is the regular emblem of [[शिव|Śiva]].<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 271.</ref>

सुष वार्ष्ण
<u>'''1. Suṣa Vārṣṇa'''</u> (‘descendant of Vṛṣṇi’) is mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Brāhmaṇ (iii. 10, 9, 15) as having been honoured by a consecration with Āditya.<br>==Foot Notes==

शूष वाह्नेय
<u>'''2. Śūṣa Vāhneya'''</u> (‘descendant of Vahni’) '''[[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of Arāḍa [[दात्रेय|Dātreya]] '''[[शौनक|Śaunaka]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1456> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Śruṣa.'''

शृङ्ग
<u>'''Śṛṅga'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1457> i. 140, 6;<br> 163, 11;<br> ii. 39, 3;<br> iii. 8. 10, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1457> Av. ii. 32, 6;<br> viii. 6, 14;<br> ix. 4, 17, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘horn’ of any sort of animal. Hence the ‘barb’ of the arrow is called its horn in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1457> iv. 6, 5. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 154.</ref>

शृङ्ग-वृष्
<u>'''Śṛṅga-vṛṣ'''</u> is the name of a man in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1458> viii. 17, 13.</ref> According to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1458> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 161.<br><br>''Cf.'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 142, n.</ref> he is father of '''[[पृदाकुसानु|Pṛdākusānu]].'''

शेरभ
<u>'''Śerabha'''</u> and '''Śerabhaka''' are names of snakes or demons in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1459> ii. 24, 1. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 64.</ref>

शेव-धि
<u>'''Śeva-dhi'''</u> denotes ‘treasure’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1460> ii. 13, 6;<br> vii. 53, 5;<br> ix. 3, 15 (metaphorically). ''Cf.'' viii. 52, 9.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1460> Av. v. 22, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 59, etc.</ref> 

शेवृध
<u>'''Śevṛdha'''</u> and '''Śevṛdhaka''' are the names of snakes or demons in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1461> ii. 24, 1. ''Cf.'' Whitney Translation of the Atharvaveda, 64.</ref>

शेषण
<u>'''Śeṣaṇa'''</u> in the Atharvaveda (vii. 109, 5), means the ‘leaving’ of the dice as opposed to Glahana (''grahaṇa''), the ‘taking up’ of them for the throw. ''Cf.'' '''[[ग्लह|Glaha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शेषस्
<u>'''Śeṣas'''</u> denotes ‘offspring’ in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1463> i. 93, 4;<br> v. 12, 6;<br> 70, 4;<br> vi. 27, 4. 5;<br> vii. 1, 12;<br> 4, 7;<br> x. 16, 5.</ref>

शैब्य
<u>'''Śaibya,'''</u> ‘belonging to the '''Śibis,'''’ is a designation of king Amitratapana Śuṣmiṇa in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 23, 10). In the [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 1; v. 1) [[शैब्य|Śaibya]] is the patronymic of a teacher, '''[[सत्यकाम|Satyakāma]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

शैलन
<u>'''Śailana,'''</u> in the plural, is the name of a school of teachers in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 2, 3; ii. 4, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

सैलालि
<u>'''Sailāli,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śilālin,’ is the name of a ritual teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1466> xiii. 5, 3, 3.</ref> A Śailāli [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] is mentioned in the Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1466> vi. 4, 7.</ref> and the school of the Śailālins often occurs in the Śūtras.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1466> Anupada [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 5, etc. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 156;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 197. who compares the Naṭa [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] attributed to Śilālin by Pāṇni, iv. 2, 110, 111.</ref>

शैलिन
<u>'''Śailina'''</u> or '''Śailini,''' ‘descendant of Śilina,’ is the patronymic of '''Jitvan''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1467> [[शैलिन|Śailina]] in Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 5 Mādhyaṃdina: Śailini. iv. 1, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]. ''Cf.'' Max Mūller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 15, 152, n. 2.</ref> Perhaps '''[[शैलन|Śailana]]''' should be compared. 

शैलूष
<u>'''Śailūṣa'''</u> is included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1468> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 2, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 290;<br> Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 111, 196, 197. The exact sense of [[शैलूष|Śailūṣa]] depends on the question of how old the drama is in India. As to this, ''cf.'' '''[[इतिहास|Itihāsa]];<br>''' Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1911, 995 ''et seq.''</ref> An ‘actor’ or ‘dancer’ may be meant. Sāyaṇa says it is a man who lives on the prostitution of his wife.

शोण सात्रासाह
<u>'''Śoṇa Sātrāsāha,'''</u> king of '''[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]]''' and father of '''Koka,''' is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1469> xiii. 5, 4, 16-18. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 400.</ref> as having offered the horse sacrifice, which was attended by the '''Turvaśas''' also.

शौङ्गायनि
<u>'''Śauṅgāyani,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śauṅga,’ is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1470> Indische Studien, 4, 372, 383. The Śuṅgas are known as teachers in the Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 13, 5. etc.</ref>

शौङ्गी-पुत्र
<u>'''Śauṅgī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Śuṅga,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[सांकृती-पुत्र|Sāṃkṛtī-putra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1471> vi. 4, 31 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

शौच
<u>'''Śauca'''</u> (‘descendant of Śuci’) is the patronymic of a man, called also '''[[आह्नेय|Āhneya]],''' who is mentioned as a teacher in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (ii. 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

शौचद्-रथ
<u>'''Śaucad-ratha'''</u> (‘descendant of Śucad-ratha’) is the patronymic of '''Sunītha''' in the Rigveda (v. 79, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

शौचेय
<u>'''Śauceya'''</u> (‘descendant of Śuci’) '''[[प्राचीनयोग्य|Prācīnayogya]]''' (‘descendant of Prācīnayoga’) is the name of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 5, 3, 1. 8). [[शौचेय|Śauceya]] is also the patronymic of '''[[सार्वसेनि|Sārvaseni]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vii. 1, 10, 2). <br>==Foot Notes==

शौनक
<u>'''Śaunaka,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śunaka,’ is a common patronymic. It is applied to '''[[इन्द्रोत|Indrota]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1475> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 3, 5;<br> 4, 1.</ref> and '''[[स्वैदायन|Svaidāyana]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1475> ''Ibid.,'' xi. 4, 1, 2.</ref> A [[शौनक|Śaunaka]] appears as a teacher of '''[[रौहिणायन|Rauhiṇāyana]]''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1475> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> A [[शौनक|Śaunaka]]-yajña, or [[शौनक|Śaunaka]] sacrifice, occurs in the Kauṣitaki [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_1475> iv. 7.</ref> In the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1475> i. 9, 3.</ref> '''Atidhanvan''' [[शौनक|Śaunaka]] appears as a teacher. That [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1475> iv. 3, 5. 7.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve2_1475> iii. 1, 21.</ref> mention a [[शौनक|Śaunaka]] [[कापेय|Kāpeya]] who was a contemporary of '''[[अभिप्रतारिन् काक्षसेनि|Abhipratārin Kākṣaseni]],''' whose [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] [[शौनक|Śaunaka]] was according to another passage<ref name=fx8_ve2_1475> i. 59, 2.</ref> of the latter [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]. In the Sūtras, the Bṛhaddevatā, etc., a [[शौनक|Śaunaka]] appears as a great authority on grammatical, ritual, and other matters.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1475> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 24, 32-34, 49, 54, 56, 59, 62, 85, 143;<br> Macdonell, ''Bṛhaddevatā,'' 1, xxiii;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 18, 19, 297.</ref>

शौनकी-पुत्र
<u>'''Śaunakī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Śunaka,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[काश्यपीबालाक्यामाठरीपुत्र|Kāśyapībālākyāmāṭharīputra]]''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30. 31).<br>==Foot Notes==

शौर्प-णाय्य
<u>'''Śaurpa-ṇāyya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śūrpaṇāya,’ is the patronymic of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[गौतम|Gautama]],''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 5, 20; iv. 5, 26).<br>==Foot Notes==

शौल्बायन
<u>'''Śaulbāyana'''</u> or '''Śaulvāyana,''' ‘descendant of Śulba,’ is the patronymic of a teacher, '''Udaṅka.'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1478> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 5, 4;<br> 5, 4, 2;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 2 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> According to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1478> xi. 4, 2, 17 ''et seq.''</ref> a [[शौल्बायन|Śaulbāyana]] was the [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], or sacrificing priest, of those who had '''[[अयस्थूण|Ayasthūṇa]]''' as Gṛhapati (‘householder,’ the title of the sacrificer who has precedence at a ''sattra,'' or sacrificial session). 

शौष्कल
<u>'''Śauṣkala'''</u> is the name of one of the sacrificial victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1479> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 12, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 81, n. 7;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 415.</ref> It means, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ‘living on dried fish or flesh,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1479> The literal meaning is, ‘relating to what is dried’ (''śuṣkala'').</ref> or, according to the native lexicographers, ‘selling dried fish,’ while, Sāyaṇa's commentary on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] explains the meaning to be one who catches fish with a hook, ‘angler.’

श्रुष्टि आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Śruṣṭi Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman or Chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1480> xiii. 11, 21. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 68.</ref>

श्मशान
<u>'''Śmaśāna'''</u> is the name of the ‘burial mound’ in which the bones of the dead man were laid to rest (''cf.'' '''[[अन्अग्निदग्ध|Anagnidagdha]]'''). It is mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1481> v. 31, 8;<br> x. 1. 18.</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1481> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 8, 5;<br> 4, 11, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 2, 15, etc.</ref> The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1481> xiii. 8, 1, 1 ''et seq. Cf.'' Eggeling. ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 424 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 407;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, cliii.</ref> prescribes a four-cornered mound facing the south-east, on ground inclined to the north, out of sight of the village, in a peaceful spot amid beautiful surroundings, or on barren ground. For an Agni-cit (‘builder of a fire-latar’) a funeral mound like a fire-altar is prescribed. The Easterners (''Prācyāḥ'') made their mounds round.

श्मश्रु
<u>'''Śmaśru'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1482> ii. 11, 17;<br> viii. 33, 6;<br> x. 23, 1, 4;<br> 26, 7;<br> 142, 4.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1482> Av. v. 19, 14;<br> vi. 68, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 92;<br> xx. 5, etc. Applied to animals, ''ibid.,'' xxv. 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 9, 1, 6, etc.</ref> means ‘beard’ and ‘moustache,’ being sometimes contrasted with '''[[केश|Keśa]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1482> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 5, 2, 48, etc.</ref> ‘hair of the head.’ Shaving was known (see '''[[वप्तृ|Vaptṛ]]''' and '''[[क्षुर|Kṣura]]'''). The  wearing of a beard was a sign of manhood according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1482> v. 5, 1, 1.</ref> with which agrees the notice of Megasthenes<ref name=fx5_ve2_1482> In Diodorus, iii. 63.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 265267.</ref> that the Indians carefully tended their beards up to the day of their death.

श्यापर्ण सायकायन
<u>'''Śyāparṇa Sāyakāyana'''</u> is the name of a man, the last for whom five victims were slain at the building of the sacrificial altar according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1483> vi. 2, 1, 39.</ref> The same text<ref name=fx2_ve2_1483> ix. 5, 2, 1.</ref> again mentions him as a builder of the fire-altar. He must have been connected in some way with the '''Salvas.'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1483> x. 4, 1, 10.</ref> His family, the Śyāparṇas, appear in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1483> vii. 27. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 344, 345;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 437 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indisches Studien,'' 1, 215, 216.</ref> as a self-assertive family of priests whom king '''Viśvantara''' excluded from his sacrifice, but whose leader, '''[[राम मार्गवेय|Rāma Mārgaveya]],''' induced him to take them back. In some way Śyāparṇa was connected with the defeat of the '''Pañcālas''' by the '''Kuntis.'''<ref name=fx5_ve2_1483> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 471.</ref>

श्याम
<u>'''Śyāma'''</u> (‘swarthy’) with '''Ayas''' (‘metal’) in all probability denotes ‘iron’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1484> xi. 3, 7.</ref> [[श्याम|Śyāma]] alone has the same sense in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1484> ix. 5, 4.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1484> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 7. 5, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xviii. 10;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 11, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 13.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 52, 54;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 189.</ref>

श्याम-जयन्त लौहित्य
<u>'''Śyāma-[[जयन्त|jayanta]] Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[जयन्त|Jayanta]] [[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]],''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Jiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1). Another man of the same name occurs in the same place as a pupil of '''[[मित्रभूति लौहित्य|Mitrabhūti Lauhitya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

श्याम-पर्ण
<u>'''Śyāma-parṇa'''</u> is, in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1486> xx. 8 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 472).</ref> and Maitrāyaṇī<ref name=fx2_ve2_1486>iii. 2, 7.</ref> Saṃhitās, the name of a man who was instructed by '''[[सोमदक्ष कौश्रेय|Somadakṣa Kauśreya]].''' 

श्याम-सुजयन्त लौहित्य
<u>'''Śyāma-sujayanta Lauhitya'''</u> (‘descendant of Lohita’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[कृष्णधृति सात्यकि|Kṛṣṇadhṛti Sātyaki]],''' in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 42, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

श्यामाक
<u>'''Śyāmāka'''</u> is the name of a cultivated millet (''Panicum frumentaceum'') in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1488> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 1, 2;<br> ii. 3, 2, 6;<br> iv. 7, 4, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 11, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 12;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 2.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1488> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 6, 3, 2;<br> xii. 7, 1, 9, etc.;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 12.</ref> The lightness of its seed is alluded to in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1488> xix. 50, 4.</ref> where it is spoken of as blown away by the wind. There it is also mentioned as the food of pigeons.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1488> xx. 135, 12.</ref> The [[श्यामाक|Śyāmāka]] and its seed ('''[[तण्डुल|Taṇḍula]]''') are referred to as very small in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx5_ve2_1488> iii. 14, 3.</ref> where Max Müller<ref name=fx6_ve2_1488> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 1, 48.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 241, 275.</ref> renders it as ‘canary seed.’

श्याव
<u>'''1. Śyāva'''</u> is the name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1489> i. 117, 24;<br> x. 65, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 150;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 32.</ref> He may be identical with '''[[हिरण्यहस्त|Hiraṇyahasta]].'''

श्याव
<u>'''2. Śyāva'''</u> is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1490> viii. 19, 37. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 161.</ref> as a generous donor on the '''[[सुवास्तु|Suvāstu]]''' river.

श्याव
<u>'''3. Śyāva'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda (v. 61, 9) seems clearly, as Sāyaṇa thinks, to denote '''[[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

श्यावक
<u>'''Śyāvaka'''</u> is mentioned as a sacrificer and friend of Indra in the Rigveda (viii. 3, 12; 4, 2). He may be identical with 2. '''[[श्याव|Śyāva]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

श्यावसायन
<u>'''Śyāvasāyana'''</u> is the patronymic of '''Devataras''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 2). The form is perhaps an error for '''Śāvasāyana.''' <br>==Foot Notes==

श्यावाश्व
<u>'''Śyāvāśva'''</u> is the name of a man mentioned several times in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1494> v. 52, 1;<br> 61, 5. 9 (Syāva, a short form of the name, is here used);<br> 81, 5;<br> viii. 35, 19;<br> 36, 7;<br> 37, 7;<br> 38, 8.</ref> The Anukramaṇī (Index) assigns to him a series of hymns in the fifth, eight, and ninth books.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1494> v. 52-61;<br> 81;<br> 82;<br> viii. 35-38;<br> ix. 32.</ref> In one of the hymns<ref name=fx3_ve2_1494> v. 61.</ref> [[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]] mentions, apparently as his patrons, '''[[तरन्त|Taranta]]''' (a son of '''Vidadaśva''') and '''Purumīlha,''' as well as '''Rathavīti.''' On this hymn is based a legend found in the Bṛhaddevatā,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1494> v. 49 ''et seq.'' See also Ṣaḍguruśiṣya on Anukramaṇī to Rv. v. 61 (ed. Macdonell, p. 117 ''et seq.'');<br> Sāyaṇa on Rv. v. 61, 17-19;<br> Nītimañjarī in Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 50 ''et seq.''</ref> that he was the son of '''[[अर्चनानस्|Arcanānas]],''' who was sacrificing for Rathavīti [[दाल्भ्य|Dālbhya]]. The father was anxious to obtain the king's daughter for his son in marriage; but though the father was willing, his wife insisted on her son-in-law being a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]]. The father and son, repulsed, were returning home, when they met on the way [[तरन्त|Taranta]] and Purumīḍha, former patrons of the father. These showed him respect, while Taranta's wife, Śaśīyasī, presented [[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]] with much wealth. The son was then fortunate enough to meet the Maruts in the forest, and praised them, thus becoming a seer. As a result the king himself ultimately offered his daughter to [[श्यावाश्व|Śyāvāśva]]. Sieg<ref name=fx5_ve2_1494> ''Op. cit.;<br>'' 50-60. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 148.</ref> seeks to show that this legend is presupposed in the Rigveda; but it is difficult to accept this view, since the references in the Rigveda are very obscure, and Śaśīyasī is probably no more than an epithet.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1494> v. 61, 6. The word is taken as an epithet by Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and by Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 27.</ref> That there is some [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] at the back of the hymn is clear: what it is can hardly now be determined.<br><br>Śyāvāśva's obtaining gifts from [[वैदद्अश्वि|Vaidadaśvi]] is referred to also in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx7_ve2_1494> xvi. 11, 7-9.</ref> His name occurs in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx8_ve2_1494> iv. 29. 4;<br> xviii. 3, 15.</ref> in two lists of persons, of which the former includes Purumīḍha, the latter also [[अर्चनानस्|Arcanānas]] and Atri. A Sāman is ascribed to him in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx9_ve2_1494> viii. 5. 9. Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 27, n. 4, bases on this an improbable conjeciure that he was a [[क्षत्रिय|Kṣatriya]].</ref> and he is perhaps referred to in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1494> i. 11, 2. But ''cf.'' Sieg, ''op. cit.,'' 61, n. 4, who takes the word adjectivally, as in Av. xi. 2, 18, [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xix. 33, 26.</ref> In the  [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx11_ve2_1494> viii. 5, 9.</ref> he is styled Ārcanānasa, ‘son of [[अर्चनानस्|Arcanānas]],’ and later<ref name=fx12_ve2_1494> The Anukramaṇī calls him and his father [[आत्रेय|Ātreya]]. In the passages from book viii. of the Rv., cited in n. 1, Atri is mentioned with him.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 126, 127;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 214;<br> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 354;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 359 ''et seq.;<br>'' Lévi, ''Ea Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 122.</ref> he is called [[आत्रेय|Ātreya]], ‘descendant of Atri.’

श्येन
<u>'''Śyena'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1495> i. 32, 14;<br> 33, 2;<br> 118, 11;<br> 163, 1;<br> 165, 2, etc.</ref> of a strong bird of prey, most probably the ‘eagle’; later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1495> Av. iii. 3, 4;<br> vii. 41, 2;<br> xi. 9, 9, etc.</ref> (as in post-Vedic Sanskrit) it seems to mean the ‘falcon’ or ‘hawk.’ It is the swiftest of birds,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1495> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 7, 1;<br> v. 4, 11, 1;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8.</ref> and a source of terror to smaller birds.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1495> Rv. ii. 42, 2;<br> Av. v. 21, 6.</ref> It is the strongest of birds,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1495> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 14.</ref> and even attacks herds.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1495> Rv. iv. 38, 5. This corresponds well enough with the eagle's known habit of carrying off young lambs.</ref> It watches over men (''[[नृ|nṛ]]-cakṣas''),<ref name=fx7_ve2_1495> Av. vii. 41, 2.</ref> a reference, no doubt, to its lofty flight in air. It brings the Soma from heaven.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1495> See Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 1-24, who cites all relevant passages.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 87, 88, who points out that the epithet ''ṛjipya,'' ‘flying upwards,’ applied to the eagle, appears as an actual name of the eagle in Iranian.</ref>

श्रपयितृ
<u>'''Śrapayitṛ,'''</u> ‘cook,’ is a term mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i, 2, 2, 14).<br>==Foot Notes==

श्रमण
<u>'''Śramaṇa'''</u> ‘mendicant monk,’ is first found in the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1497> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 7, in ''IndischeStudien,'' 1, 78.</ref> According to Fick,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1497> ''Die sociale Gliederung,'' 39 ''et seq.''</ref> anyone could become a [[श्रमण|Śramaṇa]]. For the time of Megasthenes this seems indicated by his evidence, which, however, refers only to the east of India, beyond the '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]]''' proper.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1497> Strabo, xv. 1, 49, 60;<br> Arrian ''Indica,'' xii. 8, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 27, 28, 129, 138.</ref> The Vedic evidence is merely the name and the fact that '''[[तापस|Tāpasa]],''' ‘ascetic,’ follows it in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka. 

श्रवण
<u>'''Śravaṇa.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

श्रवण-दत्त
<u>'''Śravaṇa-datta'''</u> (‘given by '''[[श्रवण|Śravaṇa]]'''’) '''Kauhala''' (‘descendant of Kohala’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[सुशारद शालङ्कायन|Suśārada Śālaṅkāyana]]''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1499> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

श्रविष्ठ
<u>'''Śraviṣṭha.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

श्रायस
<u>'''Śrāyasa'''</u> is the patronymic of '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1501> v. 4, 7, 5.</ref> and the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1501> xxi. 8.</ref> where he appears as a teacher, and of '''[[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx3_ve2_1501> v. 6, 5, 3.</ref> and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx4_ve2_1501> ix. 1, 9;<br> xxv. 16, 3.</ref>

श्री
<u>'''Śrī'''</u> is the regular word for ‘prosperity,’ found once in the '''Rigveda'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1502> viii. 2, 19, seems to have this sense.</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1502> Av. vi. 54, 1;<br> 73, 1;<br> ix. 5, 31;<br> x. 6, 26;<br> xi. 1, 12. 21;<br> xii. 1, 63;<br> 5, 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 8, 6;<br> v. 1, 8, 6;<br> vi. 1, 10, 3;<br> vii. 2, 7, 3, etc. Already in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 4, 3) she is regarded as a goddess. See Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 217 ''et seq.'' She already appears in the earliest Buddhist sculptures seated on a lotus between two elephants that pour water over her. This type of the goddess has survived down to the present day in India.</ref> '''[[श्रेष्ठिन्|Śreṣṭhin]].'''

श्रुत-कक्ष
<u>'''Śruta-kakṣa'''</u> is mentioned once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1503> viii. 92, 25. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 108.</ref> as the [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] of a hymn, the authorship of which the Anukramaṇī (Index) ascribes to him. A Sāman or chant of his is mentioned in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1503> ix. 2, 7 (''śrauta-[[कक्ष|kakṣa]]'').</ref>

श्रुत-रथ
<u>'''Śruta-ratha'''</u> is the name of a young king in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1504> i. 122, 7.</ref> He is also the patron of the '''[[पज्र|Pajra]]''' family, including '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1504> Rv. v. 36, 6. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 97.</ref> 

श्रुतर्य
<u>'''Śrutarya'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda (i. 112, 9) as the name of a protégé of the Aśvins.<br>==Foot Notes==

श्रुतर्वन् आर्क्ष
<u>'''Śrutarvan Ārkṣa'''</u> (‘descendant of Ṛkṣa’) is the name of a prince whose liberality is celebrated in one hymn of the Rigveda (viii. 74, 4. 13), and whose victory over '''[[मृगय|Mṛgaya]]''' is mentioned in another (x. 49, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

श्रुतर्-विद्
<u>'''Śrutar-vid'''</u> is the name of a man in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1507> v. 44, 12. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 138, 139.</ref>

श्रुत-सेन
<u>'''Śruta-sena'''</u> is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 5, 4, 3) and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xvi. 9, 4) as one of the brothers of '''[[जनम्एजय|Janamejaya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

श्रुष वाह्नेय
<u>'''Śruṣa Vāhneya'''</u> (‘descendant of Vahni’) '''Kāśyapa''' (‘descendant of '''[[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Devataras,''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 1). It is much more likely that Śruṣa is a mere misreading for '''Śūṣa.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

श्रुष्टि-गु
<u>'''Śruṣṭi-gu'''</u> (‘possessing obedient oxen’) is the name of a man in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1510> viii. 51, 1. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 140, 141;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 90.</ref>

श्रेणि
<u>'''Śreṇi'''</u> means a ‘row’ or ‘line’ of birds,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1511> Rv. v. 59, 7.</ref> or horses,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1511> Rv. i. 126, 4.</ref> or chariots,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1511> Rv. iv. 38, 6;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 14, 1.</ref> and so forth.

श्रेष्ठिन्
<u>'''Śreṣṭhin'''</u> occurs in several passages of the Brāhmaṇas,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1512> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 30, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxviii. 6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 20. [[भग|Bhaga]] is the [[श्रेष्ठिन्|Śreṣṭhin]] of the gods, [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 4, 10.</ref> where the St. Petersburg Dictionary assigns to the word the sense of ‘a man of consequence.’ It is, however, possible that  the word may already have the sense of the ‘headman of a guild,’ the modern Seth.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1512> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''India, Old and New,'' 168 ''et seq.''</ref> There is a similar doubt in the use of ''śraiṣṭhya,''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1512> Av. i. 9, 3 = [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 5, 4, 2 = [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, v. 6 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 4, 3. See also for the word, Av. x. 6, 31;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 25, 8;<br> vii. 18, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 9, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 7, 1, 1;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 2, 6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 6;<br> iv. 15, 20, etc. The use of ''śraiṣṭhya'' is, on the whole, not in favour of the theory that it is a technical term.</ref> which is perhaps not merely ‘the foremost place,’ as usually assumed, but definitely ‘the presidency of a guild.’<br><br>Guilds are referred to in the [[धर्म|Dharma]] Sūtras,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1512> [[गौतम|Gautama]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xi. 20, 21, etc.;<br> Foy, ''Die ko7nigliche Gewalt,'' 14, n. 2, etc.</ref> and they play a considerable part in the Buddhist texts<ref name=fx5_ve2_1512> Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 88 ''et seq.''</ref> and the Epic.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1512> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 81 ''et seq.''</ref> But the Vedic evidence is inadequate to afford ground for positive assertion or denial of their existence or organization in Vedic times.

श्रोत्रिय
<u>'''Śrotriya'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1513> ix. 6, 37;<br> x. 2, 20 ''et seq.''</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1513> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiii. 4;<br> xxviii. 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 25, 15;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 5;<br> xiii. 4, 3. 14;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 8, etc. ''Cf. mahā-[[श्रोत्रिय|śrotriya]],'' ‘a great theologian,’ in Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 11, 1.</ref> denotes a ‘Brahmin learned in holy lore,’ ‘theologian.’

श्रौत-ऋषि
<u>'''Śrauta-ṛṣi'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1514> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 1, 6.</ref> or '''Śrautarṣi,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1514> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 9, 11.</ref> ‘descendant of Srutaṛṣi or Śrutarṣi,’ is the patronymic of '''[[देवभाग|Devabhāga]].'''

श्रौमत्य
<u>'''Śraumatya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Śrumant,’ is the name of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 4, 5, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

श्लेष्मन्
<u>'''Śleṣman'''</u> means generally that with which parts of a thing are joined together (from ''śliṣ,'' ‘join’): with reference to a hide,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1516> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 32, 6;<br> Jaiminīya Upanisad [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 17, 3;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 4.</ref>  ‘laces’ of some sort may be intended; to a chariot,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1516> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 9. ''Cf.'' [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 1, 13, where a chariot ('''[[रथ|Ratha]]''') is called ''śleṣmavant,'' ‘tied with ropes.’</ref> ‘bonds’ or ‘cords’ are probably meant; and to wood,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1516> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 12. ''Cf.'' the Upaniṣads, cited in n. 1, and Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, ii. 1, which looks like a bad secondary version of the passage in the Jaiminīya.</ref> ‘glue’ is perhaps the sense.

श्लोक
<u>'''Śloka,'''</u> in the plural, is found enumerated after the '''Upaniṣads,''' and before the '''Sūtras,''' in the list of literary types given in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1517> ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 6 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 1, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> 5, 11.</ref> In the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1517> iii. 10, 6.</ref> the [[श्लोक|Śloka]]-kṛt appears: he is rather the ‘poet,’ as Max Müller<ref name=fx3_ve2_1517> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 15, 69</ref> renders it, than merely one who ‘calls aloud,’ as the St. Petersburg Dictionary explains the term.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1517> In Av. v. 20, 7, the word has the sense assigned to it by the Dictionary.</ref> Exactly what is meant cannot be said: ‘verses’ generally may be intended, several kinds being preserved in the Brāhmaṇas and called Ślokas.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1517> ''E.g.,'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 1, 5;<br> 5, 4, 12;<br> xiii. 7, 1, 15;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 22, 3: [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, ii. 3, 8;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 18, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 6, etc.</ref>

श्लोण्य
<u>'''Śloṇya'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1518> iii. 9, 17, 2. ''Cf. śloṇa,'' ‘lame,’ Av. xii. 4, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 6, 7, etc.</ref> denotes ‘lameness,’ not ‘skin disease’ (''tvag-doṣa''), as explained by the commentator.

श्व-घ्निन्
<u>'''Śva-ghnin'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1519> i. 92, 10;<br> ii. 12, 4;<br> iv. 20, 3;<br> viii. 45, 38.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1519> iv. 16, 5.</ref> clearly means a ‘gamester’ or ‘professional gambler.’ It may originally have denoted a ‘hunter.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1519> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 71.</ref>

श्वन्
<u>'''Śvan'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1520> i. 161, 13 (where the sense is quite obscure);<br> 182, 4;<br> ii. 39, 4, etc.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1520> Av. vi. 37, 3;<br> xi. 2, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 8, 22, etc.</ref> is the word for ‘dog,’ the feminine being Śunī.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1520> Av. iv. 20, 7 (''catur-akṣī'');<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 5, 2, 10.</ref> The dog was a tame animal,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1520> Rv. ii. 39, 4.</ref> and used  to guard the house from thieves or other intruders.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1520> Rv. vii. 55, 5.</ref> He was also employed in hunting the boar (''[[वराह|varāha]]-yu''),<ref name=fx6_ve2_1520> Rv. x. 86, 4.</ref> but was no match for the lion.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1520> Av. iv. 36, 6.</ref> A hundred dogs are mentioned as a gift in a Dānastuti (‘Praise of Gifts’) in a [[वालखिल्य|Vālakhilya]] hymn.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1520> Rv. viii. 55, 3.</ref> Elsewhere the dog is regarded as unfit for sacrifice, as being unclean,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1520> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 51, 4;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 1, 4.</ref> and is driven away from the sacrifice.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1520> Rv. ix. 101, 1.</ref> To eat dog's flesh was a last resort of despair and hunger.<ref name=fx11_ve2_1520> Rv. iv. 18, 3. Later, ''śva-paca'' (‘dog-cooking’) denotes a degraded caste.</ref> The bones of the feast were given to the dog.<ref name=fx12_ve2_1520> Av. vi. 37, 3. ''Cf.'' ix. 4, 16.</ref> Saramā figures in legend as Indra's faithful dog<ref name=fx13_ve2_1520> i. 62, 3;<br> 72, 8, etc. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 151.</ref> searching for the cows. Rudra is lord of dogs (''śva-pati'') in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]];<ref name=fx14_ve2_1520> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 28;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5.</ref> the ‘dog-keeper’ (''śvanin'') is mentioned in the list of sacrificial victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the same Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx15_ve2_1520> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 27;<br> xxx. 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 1, etc. ''Cf. śva-nī'' (‘dog-leader’), Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 5.</ref> The four-eyed (''catur-[[अक्ष|akṣa]]'') dogs of certain texts<ref name=fx16_ve2_1520> ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 14, 10. 11;<br> Av. xviii. 2, 11. 12: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, vi. 3, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 8, 4, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 1, 2, 9, etc.</ref> are, of course, mythological.<ref name=fx17_ve2_1520> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 165 ''et seq.;<br> Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 500, thinks that Yama's two dogs are the sun and the moon (''cf.'' '''[[दिव्य श्वन्|Divya Śvan]]''').<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 233: Hopkins, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 15, 154-163.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[कुर्कुर|Kurkura]].'''

स्व-पद्
<u>'''Sva-pad'''</u> denotes a ‘savage animal,’ ‘beast of prey,’ in the Atharvaveda (viii. 5, 11; xix. 39, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

श्वयथ
<u>'''Śvayatha'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1522> iv. 2, 1, 11 (of the eye, in a myth).</ref> means ‘swelling.’ Possibly ''śīyathu,'' the disease prevalent in '''[[विदेह|Videha]]''' according to the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta Sutra,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1522> ii. 5: Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 35, 36.</ref> was a kind of ‘swelling’ (? goitre). 

श्व-वर्त
<u>'''Śva-varta,'''</u> ‘found in dogs,’ is, according to some manuscripts, the name of a species of worm in the Atharvaveda (ix. 4, 16). See '''[[शवर्त|Śavarta]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

श्वशुर
<u>'''Śvaśura'''</u> from the Rigveda onwards<ref name=fx1_ve2_1524> x. 28, 1;<br> 85, 46;<br> 95, 4;<br> Av. viii. 6, 24;<br> xiv. 2, 26, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘father-inlaw’ of the wife; not till the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period does it include the ‘father-in-law’ of the husband.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1524> Pāraskara [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 10, 46.</ref> The daughter-in-law ('''[[स्नुषा|Snuṣā]]'''), in the normal case when the father-in-law was the head of the family to which her husband belonged in fact as well as in age, was bound to pay him all respect.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1524> See Rv. x. 95, 4;<br> Av. viii. 6, 24;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 12 (''Indische Studien,'' 5, 260);<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 22, 7. So in Av. xiv. 2, 26, the daughter-in-law is to be ‘helpful’ to the father-in-law.</ref> When the old man had ceased to exercise control, she became mistress (''samrājñī'') over him and his wife.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1524> Rv. x. 85, 46. See Pati.</ref> In the plural<ref name=fx5_ve2_1524> Rv. x. 95, 12;<br> Av. xiv. 2, 27;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.'' Or it may be a plural ''majestatis,'' but not a sign of polyandry.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 515, 516.</ref> the word denotes the ‘parents-in-law.’

श्वश्रू
<u>'''Śvaśrū'''</u> denotes ‘mother-in-law’ of the husband<ref name=fx1_ve2_1525> Rv. x. 85, 46;<br> Av. xiv. 2, 26.</ref> as well as of the wife.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1525> Rv. x. 34, 3.</ref> She, together with her husband, if he became unable to manage the family,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1525> Rv. x. 85, 46.</ref> fell under the daughter-in-law's sway, but otherwise was entitled to regard.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1525> Av. xiv. 2, 26.</ref> The gambler in the Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_1525> Rv. x. 34, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Vermandtschaftsnamen,'' 516.</ref> complains of his having lost the favour of his wife's mother as one of the misfortunes brought upon him by dicing.

श्वाजनि
<u>'''Śvājani'''</u> is the name of a [[वैश्य|Vaiśya]] in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 5, 2). <br>==Foot Notes==

श्वापद
<u>'''Śvāpada,'''</u> like '''Śvapad,''' denotes a ‘savage animal’ or ‘beast of prey.’ It is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1527> x. 16, 6.</ref> in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1527> xi. 10, 8.</ref> and occasionally later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1527> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 10 (where the tiger, '''[[शार्दूल|Śārdūla]],''' is mentioned as the chief of them);<br> xii. 2, 4, 16;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 4, 29;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xii. 16, etc.</ref>

श्वा-विध्
<u>'''Śvā-vidh'''</u> (‘dog-piercing’) is the name of the ‘porcupine’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1528> v. 13, 9.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1528> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 20, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 56;<br> xxiv. 33, etc.</ref> It is called ‘long-eared’ (''karṇa'').<ref name=fx3_ve2_1528> Av., ''loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 82.</ref> See also '''[[शल्यक|Śalyaka]].'''

श्विक्न
<u>'''Śvikna'''</u> is the name of a people twice mentioned in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1529> xii. 8, 3, 7;<br> xiii. 5, 4, 15. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 209, 210.</ref> in connexion with their king, '''[[ऋषभ|Ṛṣabha]] [[याज्ञतुर|Yājñatura]].''' ''Cf.'' '''[[श्वैक्न|Śvaikna]].'''

श्वित्र
<u>'''1. Śvitra'''</u> (‘white’) is the name of a species of serpent in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1530> iii. 27, 6 (where there is a variant ''[[चित्र|citra]]'');<br> x. 4, 5, 13.</ref> and the later Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1530> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 10, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 13, 21, has in the parallel passage ''[[चित्र|citra]],'' probably by error.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 134. Perhaps [[श्वित्र|Śvitra]], in the lis of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 39, has this sense;<br> but the St. Petersburg Dictionary explains it as ‘a certain domestic animal,’ or, generally ‘a white animal.’</ref>

श्वित्र
<u>'''2. Śvitra'''</u> is found as an adjective in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 11, 11) in the sense of ‘afflicted with white leprosy.’<br>==Foot Notes==

श्वित्र्य
<u>'''Śvitrya.'''</u> See '''[[श्वैत्रेय|Śvaitreya]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

श्वेत-केतु
<u>'''Śveta-ketu'''</u> Aruṇeya<ref name=fx1_ve2_1533> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 2, 7, 12;<br> 5, 4, 18;<br> 6, 2, 1;<br> xii. 2, 1, 9;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 7, 1;<br> vi. 1, 1 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 3, 1;<br> vi. 1, 1;<br> 8, 1.</ref> (‘descendant of '''Aruṇa'''’) or '''[[औद्दालकि|Auddālaki]]'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1533> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 13;<br> iv. 2, 5, 14.</ref> (‘son of '''Uddālaka'''’) is mentioned repeatedly in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]. In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1533> i. 1.</ref> he appears as [[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]], son of '''[[आरुणि|Āruṇi]],''' and as a '''[[गौतम|Gautama]].''' In the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1533> xxvi. 4.</ref> he is quoted as an authority on the vexed question of the duty of the '''[[सदस्य|Sadasya]],''' or the seventeenth priest, at the ritual of the Kauṣītakins, to notify errors in the sacrifice; [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]], his father, is also cited. He was a person of some originality, for he insisted on eating honey despite the general prohibition of the use of that delicacy by Brahmacārins or religious students.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1533> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 4, 18.</ref> He was a contemporary of, and was instructed by the '''[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]]''' king '''Pravāhaṇa [[जैवल|Jaivala]].'''<ref name=fx6_ve2_1533> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 1, 1 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 2, 1 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 3, 1.</ref> He was also a contemporary of '''[[जनक|Janaka]],''' of '''[[विदेह|Videha]],''' and figured among the Brahmin disputants at his court.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1533> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 6, 2, 1 (it is to be noted that he came upon [[जनक|Janaka]] when travelling about with some other Brahmins: he was never settled in the [[विदेह|Videha]] country, but was clearly a '''Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]],''' like his father);<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 7, 1, where he shares the usual fate of defeat in argument by [[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]].</ref> A story is told of him in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]:<ref name=fx8_ve2_1533> xvi. 27, 6 ''et seq.'' The exact sense of ''kṛtsnake brahmabandhau vyajijñāsiṣi'' is not quite certain. But [[आरुणि|Āruṇi]] seems to assert the love of knowledge, not of material advantages accruing to the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]], to have been his concern in life.</ref> '''[[जल जातूकर्ण्य|Jala Jātūkarṇya]]''' was lucky enough to become the [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of three peoples or kings, of '''[[काशि|Kāśi]], [[कोसल|Kosala]],''' and '''[[विदेह|Videha]].''' Seeing this, [[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]] felt annoyed and reproached his father with his excessive devotion to sacrifice, which merely enriched and glorified others, not himself. His father replied, forbidding him to speak thus: he had learned the true method of sacrificing, and his ambition in life had been to discuss it with every Brahmin.<br><br>All the references to [[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]] belong to the latest period of Vedic literature. It is, therefore, not surprising that the Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx9_ve2_1533> i. 2, 5, 4-6.</ref> should refer to him as an Avara, or  person of later days, who still became a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] by special merit. His date, however, must not be fixed too low, because the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] in which he plays so marked a part is certainly earlier than Pāṇini, and was apparently even in that grammarian's time believed to be an ancient work: hence 500 B.C. is probably rather too late than too early a period for [[श्वेतकेतु|Śvetaketu]] as a rough approximation to a date.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1533> See on this, Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 2, xxxvii ''et seq.;<br>'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xxxv ''et seq.;<br>'' Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 360 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 65;<br> 13, 443;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 22 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 433;<br> Max Müller, ''Ancient Sanskrit Literature,'' 421 ''et seq.;<br>'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 397, n.</ref>

श्वेत्या
<u>'''Śvetyā'''</u> appears in the [[नदी|Nadī]]-[[स्तुति|stuti]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1534> x. 75, 6.</ref> (‘praise of rivers’) to be a stream, probably a tributary of the Indus.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1534> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 14, 15;<br> udwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200, gives the form as Śvetī;<br> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 184, gives both forms.</ref>

श्वैक्न
<u>'''Śvaikna,'''</u> ‘king of the '''Śviknas,'''’ is the title of '''Pratīdarśa,''' who was, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1535> ii. 4, 4, 3.</ref> one of those who offered the [[दाक्षायण|Dākṣāyaṇa]] sacrifice. He also taught '''[[सुप्लन् सार्ञ्जय|Suplan Sārñjaya]]''' the sacrifice: hence Weber<ref name=fx2_ve2_1535> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 209, 210.</ref> has inferred a connexion of the Śviknas and the '''Sṛñjayas.'''

श्वैत्रेय
<u>'''Śvaitreya'''</u> occurs in two passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1536> i. 33, 14;<br> v. 19, 3.</ref> where Sāyaṇa sees in the word the name of a man, a ‘descendant of Śvitrā.’ The first passage is almost identical with one in the sixth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1536> vi. 26, 4.</ref> where, however, '''[[दशद्यु|Daśadyu]]''' appears alone without [[श्वैत्रेय|Śvaitreya]]. Ludwig<ref name=fx3_ve2_1536> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 147.</ref> identifies [[दशद्यु|Daśadyu]] with [[श्वैत्रेय|Śvaitreya]] (‘son of Śvitrī’), and considers him a son of '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1536> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 51, 6;<br> vi. 26, 3, 4.</ref> Bergaigne<ref name=fx5_ve2_1536> ''Religion Védique,'' 3, 11.</ref> and Baunack<ref name=fx6_ve2_1536> Kuhn's ''Zeitschrift,'' 35, 527.</ref> think he is really '''[[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]].''' Geldner<ref name=fx7_ve2_1536> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 7, 8.</ref> considers that he was a bull used for fighting, the son  of a Śvitrā cow,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1536> ''Cf. śvaitarī,'' Rv. iv. 33, 1.</ref> but this is very doubtful, though the term ''[[श्वैत्रेय|śvaitreya]]'' is elsewhere applied to a bull.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1536> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1910, 935.</ref> [[श्वित्र्य|Śvitrya]]<ref name=fx10_ve2_1536> Rv. i. 33, 15, where Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' takes ''śvitryam'' as the accusative of ''śvitrī.''</ref> seems to have the same sense as [[श्वैत्रेय|Śvaitreya]].

षण्ड
<u>'''Ṣaṇḍa'''</u> is the name of a priest at the snake festival described in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1537> xxv. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 35.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[कुषण्ड|Kuṣaṇḍa]].'''

षण्डिक
<u>'''Ṣaṇḍika'''</u> is mentioned in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1538> i. 4, 12, where von Schroeder gives no variant. But ''ṣ'' and ''kh'' are constantly interchanged in manuscripts.</ref> as a contemporary of '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]].''' Probably '''Khaṇḍika''' should be read as usual elsewhere.

सं-रुध्
<u>'''Saṃ-rudh'''</u> and '''Saṃ-likhita''' occur in the Atharvaveda (vii. 50, 5) as two technical terms, of unknown sense, used in dicing.<br>==Foot Notes==

सं-वत्सर
<u>'''Saṃ-vatsara,'''</u> ‘year,’ is repeatedly mentioned from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1540> Rv. i. 110, 4;<br> 140, 2;<br> 161, 13;<br> vii. 103, 1, 7, etc.;<br> Av. i. 35, 4;<br> ii. 6, 1;<br> iii. 10, 2;<br> iv. 35, 4;<br> vi. 53, 3, etc.</ref><br><br>It duration was, according to the concurrent evidence of the Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas, 360 days, divided into 12 months, being, no doubt, roughly a lunar synodic year, which, however, it exceeded in length by 6 days.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1540> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''</ref> As a solar year it appears only in the [[निदान|Nidāna]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1540> v. 12, 2. 5. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 284.</ref> of the [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], where the sun is stated to spend 13(1/3) days in each of the 27 Nakṣatras. <br><br>The year being obviously out of harmony with the solar year (whether sidereal or tropical), efforts were certainly made to effect an assimilation of the natural and the accepted year. As has been seen (see '''[[मास|Māsa]]'''), the evidence goes strongly to show that the intercalation was not an easy matter in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period, though there are traces of what may be regarded as a five-yearly or six-yearly intercalation. But there is no conclusive evidence that these periods were really observed.<br><br>Zimmer,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1540> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 369, 370, and ''cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. [[संवत्सर|saṃvatsara]],'' 2.</ref> indeed, considers that the evidence required is afforded by the lists of the years, which are sometimes enumerated as five: [[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]], [[परिवत्सर|Parivatsara]], Idāvatsara, Idvatsara, and Vatsara;<ref name=fx5_ve2_1540> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxvii. 45.</ref> or [[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]], [[परिवत्सर|Parivatsara]], Idāvatsara, Iduvatsara, Vatsara;<ref name=fx6_ve2_1540> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 7, 3, 4.</ref> or [[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]], Idāvatsara, Iduvatsara, Idvatsara, Vatsara;<ref name=fx7_ve2_1540> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 4, 1.</ref> or [[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]], [[परिवत्सर|Parivatsara]], Idāvatsara, Anuvatsara, Udvatsara;<ref name=fx8_ve2_1540> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiii. 15;<br> xxxix. 6;<br> xl. 6.</ref> or [[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]], [[परिवत्सर|Parivatsara]], Idāvatsara, Anuvatsara, Idvatsara.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1540> [[गर्ग|Garga]], quoted in the commentary on [[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]], 10.</ref> But it must be noted not merely that the names vary considerably, but that four only are mentioned in some places,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1540> Saṃ-, Pari-, Idā-, Anu-vatsara, [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 13, 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 10, 1.</ref> in others<ref name=fx11_ve2_1540> Idā-, Pari-, [[सं-वत्सर|Saṃ-vatsara]], Av. vi. 55, 3;<br> Idu-, Pari-, [[सं-वत्सर|Saṃ-vatsara]], [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 2, 4.</ref> three, in others<ref name=fx12_ve2_1540> Saṃ-, [[परि-वत्सर|Pari-vatsara]], Av. viii. 8, 23;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, x. 80.</ref> two, and in yet others<ref name=fx13_ve2_1540> Saṃ-, Pari-, Idā-, Anu-, Vatsara, [[सं-वत्सर|Saṃ-vatsara]], Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 15;<br> Saṃ-, Pari-, Idā-, Idu-, Id-, Vatsara, [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 19, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 298, n. 1;<br> Max Müller, ''Rigveda,'' 4^3, xxv, n. 1.</ref> six. Moreover, in none of these enumerations is there any reference to the names being connected with a system of intercalation. It is most probable that here we have no more that a mere series of priestly variations of Vatsara, based on the older and more genuine [[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]] and [[परिवत्सर|Parivatsara]] as variants of the simple Vatsara, ‘year.’ The key to the invention of the series is probably to be found in passages like that of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx14_ve2_1540> xvii. 13, 17.</ref> where the several '''[[चातुर्मास्य|Cāturmāsya]]''' (‘four-monthly’) sacrifices are equated  with the different years.<ref name=fx15_ve2_1540> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 91;<br> Thibaut, ''Astronomie, Astrologie und Mathematik,'' 12;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 24, 42.</ref> Particularly unjustifiable is the attempt of Zimmer to see in the two-year series a series of two years of 354 days each, with an intercalary month in the second; for the year of 354 days, as such, is not known to have existed before the [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] period.<br><br>Zimmer<ref name=fx16_ve2_1540> ''Op. cit.,'' 366, 367;<br> Tilak, ''Orion,'' 16 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 145.</ref> also finds an attempt at intercalation in the famous 12 days in which the Ṛbhus are said to have slept in the house of Agohya.<ref name=fx17_ve2_1540> Rv. iv. 33, 7. ''Cf.'' i. 110, 2;<br> 161, 13. See on this legend, Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 133;<br> Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 236.</ref> He thinks that they represent twelve days added at the winter solstice to equate the lunar year of 354 days and the solar year of 366 days; and from the reverence paid in German antiquity to the ‘12 nights,’ he infers that this mode of intercalation is Indo-Germanic.<ref name=fx18_ve2_1540> See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 242 ''et seq.;<br>'' 17, 223, 224;<br> 18, 45, 46;<br> ''Proceedings of the Berlin Academy,'' 1894, 809;<br> Thibaut, ''op. cit.,'' 10;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 308, 310;<br> Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, xciv.</ref> There can be little doubt that this view is wrong, and that the 12 days are merely the ‘reflexion of the year’ (''saṃvatsarasya pratimā'')<ref name=fx19_ve2_1540> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, vii. 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 9, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 15. See also Atharvaveda, iv. 11, 11;<br> Weber, ''Omina und Portenta,'' 388.</ref> in the sense that they represent the twelve months, and have no relation to chronology at all.<br><br>A reference to the use of [[संवत्सर|Saṃvatsara]] alone as the fifth year of the cycle is seen by Shamasastry<ref name=fx20_ve2_1540> ''Gavām Ayana,'' 137, 138.</ref> in the peculiar dating of certain notices in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx21_ve2_1540> ii. 12;<br> iii. 1;<br> xxvi. 18;<br> xxx. 3. See also [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 1, 1, 7.</ref> but this view is improbable.<ref name=fx22_ve2_1540> Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des Bandhāyana,'' 36, 37, gives a much more reasonable explanation of the anomaly.</ref>

संवरण
<u>'''Saṃvaraṇa'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] mentioned in one passage of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1541> v. 33, 10. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 215.</ref> 

संवर्ग-जित् लामकायन
<u>'''Saṃvarga-jit Lāmakāyana'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Śākadāsa''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1542> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

सं-वर्त
<u>'''1. Saṃ-varta'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1543> viii. 54, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 141, 164.</ref> with '''[[कृश|Kṛśa]]''' as an ancient sacrificer. He may be identical with the next.

सं-वर्त आङ्गिरस
<u>'''2. Saṃ-[[वर्त|varta]] Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is said in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1544> viii. 21, 12. ''Cf.'' Leumann, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 67 ''et seq.''</ref> to have consecrated '''Marutta.'''

सं-श्रवस् सौवर्चनस
<u>'''Saṃ-śravas Sauvarcanasa'''</u> is the name of a teacher who, according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (i. 7, 2, 1), discussed a point of ritual with '''Tumiñja.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सं-श्रावयितृ
<u>'''Saṃ-śrāvayitṛ'''</u> in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (ii. 1) denotes the attendant who announces visitors, the ‘doorkeeper.’<br>==Foot Notes==

सं-श्लिष्टका
<u>'''Saṃ-śliṣṭakā'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1547> Śāṭyāyanaka in Sāyaṇa on Rv. viii. 91.</ref> or '''Saṃśviṣṭikā'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1547> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 221 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 29).</ref> is the name of an animal mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] and the Śāṭyāyanaka along with the '''[[गोधा|Godhā]].'''

सं-सर्प
<u>'''Saṃ-sarpa.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सं-स्कन्ध
<u>'''Saṃ-skandha'''</u> (‘having the shoulders together’) is the name of a disease mentioned with '''[[विष्कन्ध|Viṣkandha]]''' in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1549> xix. 34, 5, with Sāyaṇa's note.</ref> Whitney,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1549> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 952.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 65, 391;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 283.</ref> however, thinks it is intended as an adjective implying the sense of ‘counteracting the disease [[विष्कन्ध|Viṣkandha]].’ 

सं-होत्र
<u>'''Saṃ-hotra'''</u> occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1550> x. 86, 10.</ref> where Geldner<ref name=fx2_ve2_1550> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 38.</ref> thinks the sense of ‘school,’ referring to a school of pupils of the ritual, is most appropriate.

सक्तु
<u>'''Saktu'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1551> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 10, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 21 ''et seq.;<br>'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 16;<br> ix. 1, 1, 8 (''cf.'' '''Gavedhukā'''), etc.;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2 (''cf.'' '''[[अपामार्ग|Apāmārga]]'''). ''Cf.'' '''[[कुवल|Kuvala]], [[कर्कन्धु|Karkandhu]], [[बदर|Badara]]:''' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 22, etc.</ref> denotes ‘coarsely ground meal,’ ‘groats,’ especially ‘barley meal.’ In the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1551> x. 71, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238.</ref> where the word occurs only once, it seems rather to mean grain before it is winnowed by the '''[[तितü|Titaü]].''' If the latter word, however, designates a ‘sieve,’ [[सक्तु|Saktu]] might still mean ‘groats,’ as opposed to fine meal.

सखि
<u>'''Sakhi,'''</u> ‘friend,’ is common from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1552> i. 164, 20 (of birds);<br> iii. 43, 4 (of steeds);<br> ii. 1, 9;<br> v. 12, 5;<br> vi. 75, 3, etc.</ref> onwards,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1552> Av. v. 4, 7;<br> 11, 9;<br> 13, 5, etc. So ''sakhitva'' and ''sakhya,'' ‘friendship,’ are also common--''e.g.,'' Rv. i. 10, 6;<br> iii. 1, 15;<br> iv. 25, 2, etc., and Rv. 1. 178, 2;<br> ii. 18, 8;<br> vii. 22, 9, etc.</ref> both literally and metaphorically.

सघन्
<u>'''Saghan'''</u> is the name of a bird, perhaps ‘eagle’ or ‘vulture,’ in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1553> iii. 2, 1, 1.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1553> ii. 8, 6, 1;<br> Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.'' (‘valture’), ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 88.</ref>

सङ्ग प्रयोगि
<u>'''Saṅga Prayogi'''</u> seems to be mentioned as a teacher in the Maitrāyaṇi Saṃhitā (iii. 1, 9).<br>==Foot Notes==

सं-गति
<u>'''Saṃ-gati'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda (x. 141, 4) seems to have the sense of '''[[सम्इति|Samiti]],''' ‘assembly of the people.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

सं-गव
<u>'''Saṃ-gava'''</u> denotes the time when the grazing cows are driven together for milking. In the division of the day the word denotes the period before midday, ‘forenoon.’ It is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1556> v. 76, 3.</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1556> Av. ix. 6, 46;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 9, 2;<br> 5, 3, 1;<br> ii. 1, 1, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 3, 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 9, 4;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 12, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 112 ''et seq.''</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Go''' and '''Ahan.'''

सं-गविनी
<u>'''Saṃ-gavinī'''</u> is found in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1557> iii. 18, 14. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 3, 112, 113;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 362.</ref> where it is said that the animals of the '''Bharatas''' in the evening were at the '''[[गोष्ठ|Goṣṭha]],''' ‘pasture,’ but at midday came to the [[संगविनी|Saṃgavinī]], apparently a shed or an enclosure in which during the heat of the day they were milked.

सं-ग्रहीतृ
<u>'''Saṃ-grahītṛ'''</u> is found in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1558> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5;<br> iv. 3, 8 (as a [[रत्निन्|Ratnin]]) in the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]] in the plural [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 4, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 26.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1558> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 5;<br> 9, 6;<br> iii. 8, 5, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii, 25, 6. Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 8;<br> 4, 3, 23.</ref> He is an official who figures among the '''Ratnins''' of the king. The sense of ‘charioteer’ seems adequate for every passage, but Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx3_ve2_1558> on [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 2, and optionally on i. 8, 16;<br> but as charioteer on i. 8, 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 10, 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 63, n. 1.</ref> in some passages inclines to think that the meaning is ‘treasurer’ of the king.

सं-ग्राम
<u>'''Saṃ-grāma'''</u> denotes primarily, it seems, ‘assembly’ either in peace<ref name=fx1_ve2_1559> Av. xii. 1, 56, where it is joined with '''[[सम्इति|Samiti]].'''
