We might see in this passage, and that cited in n. 2, the technical name of the village assembly as opposed to the larger assemblies of the people, but there is no good warrant for so doing.</ref> or in war,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1559> Av. iv. 24, 7, where ''saṃgrāmān'' is read;<br> but the parallel passages ([[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 15, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 16, 5) have ''saṃgrāmani.''</ref> when it means an ‘armed band.’ Its normal sense in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1559> v. 21, 7;<br> xi. 9, 26.</ref> and later<ref name=fx4_ve2_1559> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Samhitā, ii. 1, 3, 1;<br> 8, 4, etc.</ref> is ‘war,’ ‘battle.’ <br><br>Little is known of Vedic warfare, but it seems to have been simple. A body of foot soldiers with charioteers composed every army, the two going together,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1559> Rv. ii. 12, 8.</ref> and the foot soldiers being often overthrown by the charioteers,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1559> Av. vii. 62, 1. ''Cf.'' '''[[मुष्टिहन्|Muṣṭihan]]'''</ref> who were doubtless the Kṣatriyas and their foremost retainers. Probably the foot soldiers bore little armour, and used only the bow for offence, as is suggested by the account that Herodotus gives of the Indian contingent of the army with which Xerxes invaded Greece.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1559> Herodotus, vii. 65.</ref> The nobles, on the other hand, may have had cuirass ('''[[वर्मन्|Varman]]'''), helmet ('''[[शिप्रा|Śiprā]]'''), and hand-guard ('''[[हस्तघ्न|Hastaghna]]''') as a protection from the friction of the bowstring. On the car was the charioteer, and on his left the warrior ('''[[सारथि|Sārathi]], [[सव्यष्ठा|Savyaṣṭhā]]'''). Riding is never mentioned in war,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1559> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 296, where he admits riding to be mentioned elsewhere;<br> Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 3, 312.</ref> and would hardly have been suited to Vedic ideas, for the warrior mainly depended on his bow, which he could not have used effectively from horseback. The offensive weapon ('''[[आयुध|Āyudha]]''') was practically the bow; spear and sword and axe were very seldom used.<br><br>Whether there was a strict tribal organization of the host, such as is once alluded to in the Homeric poems,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1559> ''Ibid,'' ii. 362.</ref> and is also recognized in Germany by Tacitus,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1559> ''Germania,'' 7.</ref> is uncertain (''cf.'' '''[[व्रात|Vrāta]]'''), but in the Epic relations ('''[[ज्ञाति|Jñāti]]''') fight together,<ref name=fx11_ve2_1559> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 193.</ref> and this rule, no doubt, applied more or less in Vedic times also.<br><br>Cities were besieged and invested (''upa-sad, pra-bhid''),<ref name=fx12_ve2_1559> ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 3, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 4, 3-5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 23, 2, etc.;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 2, 7;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 300, n.</ref> probably as a rule by blockade, since the ineffective means of assault of the time would have rendered storming difficult and expensive. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx13_ve2_1559> ''Op. cit.'' 3, 289, n.</ref> thinks that the ''pur cariṣṇū'' of the Rigveda<ref name=fx14_ve2_1559> viii. 1, 2-8, where it is attributed to the demon Śuṣṇa.</ref> was a kind of chariot; it may--like the Trojan horse--have been an Indian anticipation of the Roman means of assaulting a town.<br><br>Besides ordinary wars of defence and conquest, raids into  neighbouring territory seem to have been frequent and normal,<ref name=fx15_ve2_1559> ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 142, 4, as interpreted by Sāyaṇa and by Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 2, 64, n. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 4, 1 (of the model Kuru kings).</ref> no doubt because of the booty ('''[[उद्आज|Udāja]], Nirāja''') which was to be won, and which the king had to share with the people.<br><br>Banners ('''[[ध्वज|Dhvaja]]''') were borne in war, and musical instruments ('''[[दुन्दुभि|Dundubhi]], [[बकुर|Bakura]]''')<ref name=fx16_ve2_1559> So, later, Arrian, ''Indica,'' vii. 9. The shouts of either side are shown in the word ''krandas'' (Rv. ii. 12, 8;<br> ''cf.'' vi. 25, 6;<br> x. 121, 6), which came to mean the ‘shouting host.’ ''Cf.'' also Tacitus, ''Germania,'' 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 469472;<br> Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1898, 564;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 293-301. See also '''[[इषु|Iṣu]], [[धन्वन्|Dhanvan]], [[रथ|Ratha]].''' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 281 ''et seq.,'' gives a full account of the later Epic armour and warfare. See also his note, ''ibid.,'' 15, 265, 266. For sacrifice in battle, ''cf.'' '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]].'''</ref> were used by the combatants.

सं-घात
<u>'''Saṃ-ghāta'''</u> seems in a few passages<ref name=fx1_ve2_1560> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, i. 16;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 4, 18.</ref> to have the sense of ‘battle.’

सचिव
<u>'''Saciva'''</u> ‘companion,’ ‘attendant’ (from ''sac,'' ‘follow’), later a common word for the comrade of a king, his minister, is found in Vedic literature in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 20, 1), where it is used by Indra of the Maruts. It seems to correspond in sense to the German ''comes'' or the English ''gesith.''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1561> Stubbs, ''Select Charters,'' 57.</ref>

स-जात
<u>'''Sa-jāta'''</u> (‘born together’) is found once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1562> i. 109, 1.</ref> and very often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1562> Av. i. 9, 3;<br> 19, 3;<br> ii. 6, 4;<br> iii. 3, 6;<br> vi. 5, 2;<br> 73, 1;<br> xi. 1, 6, 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 3, 2;<br> 2, 1, 2;<br> 6, 9, 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 12, 13;<br> xii. 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 23;<br> x. 29;<br> xxvii. 5, and often in the Brāhmaṇas.</ref> The word must clearly mean a ‘relative,’ and then more widely a man of the same position or rank, but the senses cannot be distinguished, so much do they merge into each other. The Sajātas of a king are of course princes;<ref name=fx3_ve2_1562> Av. iii. 3, 4. 6;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 188.</ref> of an  ordinary man, Vaiśyas;<ref name=fx4_ve2_1562> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 19 (the Sajātas of a '''Grāmaṇī''').</ref> of a military man, Kṣatriyas. But there is no clear reference to caste as in the later Sajāti<ref name=fx5_ve2_1562> Manu, ix. 87;<br> x. 41, etc. The abstract ''sajātya'' (‘kinship’) is found in Rv. ii. 1, 5;<br> iii. 54, 16;<br> viii. 18, 19;<br> 20, 21;<br> 27, 10;<br> x. 64, 13;<br> but even it has no definite caste reference.</ref> (‘man of the same caste’). The disputes of Sajātas were notorious.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1562> ''Cf.'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 12, 2.</ref>

सं-चर
<u>'''Saṃ-cara'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1563> v. 4, 3, 5.</ref> has the sense of the ‘path’ of animals. Normally it is the term designating the ‘passage’ or ‘space’ on the sacrificial ground used or occupied by the several persons taking part in the rite.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1563> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 9, 2, 4;<br> iii. 1, 3, 28;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 7, 11;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 3, 42, etc.</ref>

सं-ज्ञान
<u>'''Saṃ-jñāna,'''</u> ‘concord,’ ‘harmony,’ is mentioned from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1564> x. 19, 6.</ref> onwards<ref name=fx2_ve2_1564> Av. iii. 30, 4;<br> vii. 52, 1;<br> xi. 1, 26, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 3, 2;<br> 3, 1, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxvi. 1;<br> xxx. 9;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 21, etc.</ref> as a matter of great consequence; the Atharvaveda contains many spells to bring it about. The lack of peace in the Vedic village was almost inevitable in view of its small size and the economic interdependence of its inhabitants. ''Cf.'' '''[[भ्रातृव्य|Bhrātṛvya]].'''

सत
<u>'''Sata'''</u> is the name of a vessel of some kind mentioned in the ritual.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1565> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 27, 88;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 2, 13;<br> 8, 3, 14.</ref>

सतीन-कङ्कत
<u>'''Satīna-kaṅkata'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1566> The literal meaning seems to be ‘having a real comb.’</ref> is, in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1566> i. 191, 1.</ref> the name of some animal, according to Sāyaṇa an ‘aquatic snake.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1566> ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref> 

सत्य-काम
<u>'''Satya-kāma'''</u> (‘lover of truth’) '''[[जाबाल|Jābāla]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[जबाला|Jabālā]]''') is the name of a teacher, the son of a slave girl by an unknown father. He was initiated as a '''Brahmacārin,''' or religious student, by '''[[गौतम|Gautama]] [[हारिद्रुमत|Hāridrumata]]''' according to the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1567> iv. 4, 1, ''et seq.''</ref> He is often cited as an authority in that [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1567> iv. 5, 1;<br> 6, 2;<br> 7, 2;<br> 8, 2;<br> 9, 10;<br> 10, 1;<br> v. 2, 3.</ref> and in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1567> iv. 1, 14 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 1, 6 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> where he learns a certain doctrine from '''[[जानकि|Jānaki]] Āyasthūṇa.'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1567> vi. 3, 19 (= vi. 3, 12).</ref> He is also mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1567> viii. 7, 8.</ref> and the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1567> xiii. 5, 3, 1.</ref>

सत्य-यज्ञ
<u>'''Satya-yajña'''</u> (‘true sacrificer’) '''[[पौलुषि|Pauluṣi]]''' (‘descendant of '''Puluṣa'''’) '''[[प्राचीनयोग्य|Prācīnayogya]]''' (‘descendant of Prācīnayoga’) is the name of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1568> x. 6, 1, 1.</ref> the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1568> v. 11, 1.</ref> and the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1568> iii. 40, 2 (in a [[वंश|Vaṃśa]], ‘list of teachers’).</ref> In the latter text he is said to have been the pupil of '''[[पुलुष प्राचीनयोग्य|Puluṣa Prācīnayogya]].'''

सत्य-वचस्
<u>'''Satya-vacas'''</u> (‘true-speaking’) '''[[राथीतर|Rāthītara]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[रथीतर|Rathītara]]'''’) is, in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 9, 1), the name of a teacher who insisted on the importance of truth.<br>==Foot Notes==

सत्य-श्रवस्
<u>'''Satya-śravas'''</u> (‘of true renown’) '''[[वाय्य|Vāyya]]''' (‘descendant of Vayya’) is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1570> v. 79, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_1570> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 156.</ref> thinks that he was the son of '''[[सुनीथ शौचद्रथ|Sunītha Śaucadratha]].'''

सत्य-हविस्
<u>'''Satya-havis'''</u> is the name of a mythical [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]], or sacrificial priest, in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (i. 9, 1, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

सत्याधिवाक चैत्ररथि
<u>'''Satyādhivāka Caitrarathi'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]]'''’) is the name of a man in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 39, 1). <br>==Foot Notes==

सत्वन्
<u>'''Satvan'''</u> in the '''Rigveda,'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1573> i. 133, 6;<br> 173, 5;<br> ii. 25, 4;<br> 30, 10;<br> iii. 49, 2, etc.</ref> and occasionally later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1573> v. 20, 8;<br> vi. 65, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 8. 20, etc.</ref> has the sense of ‘warrior.’

सत्वन्त्
<u>'''Satvant'''</u> is the name of a people who are stated in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1574> viii. 14, 3.</ref> to belong to the south. In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1574> xiii. 5, 4, 21.</ref> the defeat by '''[[भरत|Bharata]]''' of the Satvants, and his taking away the horse which they had prepared for an [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’), are referred to: this reference clearly shows that in another passage of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1574> ii. 25, 6.</ref> the text must be altered from ''satvanām'' to ''Satvatām,'' ‘of the Satvants,’ against whom it seems the Bharatas made regular raids. The name has also been found by the St. Petersburg Dictionary, Cowell, and Max Müller in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]],<ref name=fx4_ve2_1574> iv. 1.</ref> but it is certain<ref name=fx5_ve2_1574> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 393, n., correcting Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 1, lxxvii.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 211, 212, 419;<br> 9, 254;<br> Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1908, 367.</ref> that the reading there is not ''[[सत्वन्|Satvan]]-Matsyeṣu,'' but ''sa-[[वश|Vaśa]]-Matsyeṣu.''

सदन
<u>'''Sadana.'''</u> See '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सदंदि
<u>'''Sadaṃdi.'''</u> See '''[[तक्मन्|Takman]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सदस्
<u>'''Sadas.'''</u> See '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सदस्य
<u>'''Sadasya.'''</u> See '''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सदा-नीरा
<u>'''Sadā-nīrā,'''</u> ‘having water always’ (‘perennial’), is the name of a stream which, according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1579> i. 4, 1, 14 ''et seq.''</ref> was the boundary between the '''Kosalas''' and the '''Videhas.''' The river is identified by the native lexicographers with the Karatoyā,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1579> See ''Imperial Gazetteer of India,'' 15, 24.</ref> but this seems to be too far east. Weber's<ref name=fx3_ve2_1579> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 172, 181.</ref> identification  of it with the Gaṇḍakī<ref name=fx4_ve2_1579> See ''s.v.'' Great Gandak, ''Imperial Gazetteer of India,'' 12, 125.</ref> is probably correct; for though the Mahābhārata<ref name=fx5_ve2_1579> ii. 794.<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 398, n.</ref> distinguishes the two rivers, there is nothing to show that this is due to any good tradition.

सदा-पृण
<u>'''Sadā-pṛṇa'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1580> v. 44, 12. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139.</ref>

सद्यन्
<u>'''Sadyan'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 8, 6, 1) is a misreading of '''[[सघन्|Saghan]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सध्रि
<u>'''Sadhri'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1582> v. 44, 10. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 139.</ref>

सनक
<u>'''Sanaka'''</u> occurs as the name of one of the two '''Kāpyas''' (the other being '''[[नवक|Navaka]]''') who took part in the sacrifice of the '''Vibhindukīyas,''' which is mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1583> iii. 233 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 38).</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_1583> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 147.</ref> thinks that the Sanakas are referred to as non-sacrificers in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1583> i. 33, 4.</ref> but this is very doubtful.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1583> Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 189.</ref>

सनग
<u>'''Sanaga.'''</u> See '''[[सनातन|Sanātana]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सनत्-कुमार
<u>'''Sanat-kumāra'''</u> is the name of a mythical sage in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vii. 1, 1; 26, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

सन-श्रुत
<u>'''Sana-śruta'''</u> (‘famed of old’) '''Ariṃdama''' (‘tamer of foes’) is mentioned as a [[महाराज|Mahārāja]] in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 34, 9).<br>==Foot Notes==

सनाच्-छव
<u>'''Sanāc-chava'''</u> is perhaps the proper name of a teacher in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1587> xx. 1.</ref> The Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_1587> xxxi. 3 (von Schroeder, [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, 2, 18, n. 5).</ref> has ''Śahanāśchiva.'' Very probably the reading of both texts is bad. 

सनातन
<u>'''Sanātana'''</u> is the name of a mythical [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā. In the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1588> ii. 5, 22;<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> he appears in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) as the pupil of '''[[सनग|Sanaga]]''' and the teacher of '''[[सनारु|Sanāru]],''' both equally mythical persons.<br><br>^1 iv. 3, 3, 1.

सनारु
<u>'''Sanāru.'''</u> See '''[[सनातन|Sanātana]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सनिस्रस
<u>'''Sanisrasa.'''</u> See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सं-दंश
<u>'''Saṃ-daṃśa.'''</u> See '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सं-दान
<u>'''Saṃ-dāna'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1592> i. 162, 8. 16.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1592> Av. vi. 103, 1;<br> 104, 1;<br> xi. 9, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 7, 2;<br> Sata patha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 3, 1, 22, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘bond,’ ‘halter,’ or ‘fetter.’

सं-धा
<u>'''Saṃ-dhā'''</u> denotes in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1593> Av. xi. 10, 9, 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 8, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 1, 6;<br> ii. 1, 1, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1.</ref> an ‘agreement’ or ‘compact.’

सं-धि
<u>'''Saṃ-dhi'''</u> denotes the ‘juncture’ of heaven and earth, the ‘horizon,’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1594> iii. 2, 1, 5;<br> x. 5, 4, 2.</ref> It also has the sense of ‘twilight’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1594> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 25;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 5, 1;<br> ii. 2, 9, 8;<br> dual;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 55;<br> ix. 4, 4, 13, etc. The later term is Saṃdhyā.</ref> as the juncture of light and dark.

सं-नहन
<u>'''Saṃ-nahana'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1595> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 1, 2, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 3, 6;<br> ii. 6, 1, 15, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘band’ or ‘rope.’ 

स-पत्न
<u>'''Sa-patna,'''</u> ‘rival,’ is a common word in the later Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1596> Av. i. 19, 4;<br> x. 6, 30;<br> xii. 2, 46;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 2, 2;<br> iii. 2, 8, 5, etc.</ref> being also found in the tenth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1596> x. 166, 1, etc.;<br> also in the compound ''[[सपत्न|sapatna]]-kan,'' ‘slaying rivals,’ x. 159, 5, etc.;<br> Av. i. 29, 5, etc.</ref> It is a curious masculine formed by analogy from '''[[स-पत्नी|Sa-patnī]],''' ‘co-wife,’ and so ‘female rival.’

स-पत्नी
<u>'''Sa-patnī'''</u> occurs in the Rigveda in the sense of ‘co-wife’;<ref name=fx1_ve2_1597> iii. 1, 10;<br> 6, 4.</ref> in the first and the last Maṇḍalas it means co-wife as a ‘rival.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1597> i. 105, 8;<br> x. 145, 1-5 (''cf.'' in verse 2, ''patim me kevalam kuru,'' ‘make my husband exclusively mine’).</ref> In post-Vedic Sanskrit the word becomes a synonym for ‘rival.’

सप्त-गु
<u>'''Sapta-gu'''</u> is the reputed author of a Rigvedic hymn in a verse of which he is mentioned.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1598> x. 47, 6. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 17, 423.</ref>

सप्त सिन्धवः
<u>'''Sapta Sindhavaḥ,'''</u> ‘the seven rivers,’ occur only once in the Rigveda as the designation of a definite country,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1599> viii. 24, 27.</ref> while elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve2_1599> Rv. i. 32, 12;<br> 34, 8;<br> 35, 8;<br> 71, 7;<br> 102, 2;<br> iv. 28, 1;<br> viii. 96, 1, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 26;<br> Atharvaveda, iv. 6, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 6, 1, etc.</ref> the seven rivers themselves are meant. Max Müller<ref name=fx3_ve2_1599> ''Chips,'' 1, 63. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 490, n.</ref> thinks that the five streams of the Panjab, with the Indus and the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],''' are intended; others<ref name=fx4_ve2_1599> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200;<br> Lassen, ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 1^2, 3;<br> Whitney, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 3, 311.</ref> hold that the '''[[कुभा|Kubhā]]''' should be substituted for the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], or that perhaps the Oxus<ref name=fx5_ve2_1599> ''Cf.'' Thomas, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1883, 371 ''et seq.''</ref> must originally have been one of the seven. Zimmer<ref name=fx6_ve2_1599> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 21.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 278;<br> ''India, Old and New,'' 33.</ref> is probably right in laying no stress at all on any identifications; ‘seven’ being one of the favourite numbers in the Rigveda and later. 

सप्त सूर्याः
<u>'''Sapta Sūryāḥ,'''</u> the ‘seven suns’ referred to in the Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1600> Av. xiii. 3, 10;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 9.</ref> are named in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx2_ve2_1600> i. 7. ''Cf.'' the ‘seven tongues’ of Agni which are mentioned in the Rigveda, and each of which later receives an individual name: Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 89.</ref> as Āroga, Bhrāja, Paṭara, [[पतङ्ग|Pataṅga]], [[स्वर्णर|Svarṇara]], Jyotiṣīmant, and Vibhāsa, but these occur very rarely even later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1600> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 266;<br> Hopkins, ''Great Epic of India,'' 475.</ref> Weber at one time<ref name=fx4_ve2_1600> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 170;<br> 2, 238.</ref> thought that the seven planets (see '''[[ग्रह|Graha]]''') were meant by the phrase, but later he abandoned the idea.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1600> ''Ibid.,'' 10, 271, n., where he compares the ''sapta diśo nānā-sūryāḥ,'' ‘seven regions with various suns,’ of Rv. ix. 114, 3.</ref> Probably the ‘seven rays’ of the Rigveda<ref name=fx6_ve2_1600> Rv. i. 105, 9;<br> viii. 72, 16;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 277.</ref> are meant.

सप्त-मानुष
<u>'''Sapta-mānuṣa'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1601> viii. 39, 8.</ref> as an epithet of Agni, ‘belonging to the seven tribes.’ Hopkins<ref name=fx2_ve2_1601> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 278.</ref> thinks that this is a reference to the seven ‘family’ books of the Rigveda (ii.-viii.), but this seems less likely than the view of Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1601> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> that ''[[सप्तमानुष|saptamānuṣa]]'' is equivalent to ''vaiśvānara.''

सप्त-वध्रि
<u>'''Sapta-vadhri'''</u> is the name of a protégé of the Aśvins, who appear from several passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1602> v. 78, 5;<br> viii. 73, 9;<br> x. 39, 9.</ref> to have rescued him from a tree in which he had got fastened. He is mentioned in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1602> iv. 29, 4.</ref> According to Geldner,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1602> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 190.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 156;<br> Baunack, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 50, 268.</ref> he is identical with '''Atri.'''

सप्ति
<u>'''Sapti'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1603> i. 85, 1, 6;<br> 162, 1;<br> ii. 34, 7;<br> iii. 22, 1, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1603> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 19, 22.</ref> denotes a ‘swift steed.’ 

सप्त्य
<u>'''Saptya'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda (viii. 41, 4) seems to denote a ‘racecourse.’<br>==Foot Notes==

स-बन्धु
<u>'''Sa-bandhu'''</u> (‘of the same kin’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1605> iii. 1, 10;<br> v. 47, 5;<br> viii. 20, 21, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1605> Av. vi. 15, 2;<br> viii. 2, 26;<br> xv. 8, 2. 3, etc.</ref> denotes ‘related.’

सभा
<u>'''Sabhā'''</u> is the name of an ‘assembly’ of the Vedic Indians as well as of the ‘hall’ where they met in assembly. It is often mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1606> vi. 28, 6;<br> viii. 4, 9;<br> x. 34, 6. ''Cf. [[सभा|sabhā]]-saha,'' ‘eminent in the assembly,’ x. 71, 10.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1606> Av. v. 31, 6;<br> vii. 12, 1, 2;<br> viii. 10, 5;<br> xii. 1, 56;<br> xix. 55, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 6, 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45;<br> xvi. 24;<br> xx. 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 10, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 2, 3;<br> v. 3, 1, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 9, etc.</ref> but its exact character is not certain. The hall was clearly used for dicing,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1606> Rv. x. 34, 6;<br> Av. v. 31, 6;<br> xii. 3, 46 (here ''[[द्यूत|dyūta]]'' is used in place of [[सभा|Sabhā]]).</ref> presurnably when the assembly was not transacting public business: a dicer is called ''[[सभा-स्थाणु|sabhā-sthāṇu]],'' ‘pillar of the assembly hall,’ doubtless because of his constant presence there.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1606> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 18;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 16, 1, with Sāyaṇa's note. Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 172, inclines to see in the formula (Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45;<br> xx. 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 3, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, ix. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 10, 2) ‘what sin we have committed in the village, the jungle, the Sabhā’ a reference to attacks on the great (Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 45), or partiality in deciding disputes (Mahīdhara, ''ibid.,'' xx. 17). But it may refer to gambling or other nonpolitical activity, as Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 398, takes it, though he renders it differently, ''ibid.,'' 44, 265.</ref> The hall also served, like the Homeric , as a meeting-place for social intercourse and general conversation about cows and so forth,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1606> Rv. vi. 28, 6. ''Cf.'' viii. 4, 9. So in Av. vii. 12, 2, the assembly is hailed as ''nariṣṭā,'' ‘merriment.’ But the same hymn (vii. 12, 3) contains a clear reference to serious speech in the [[सभा|Sabhā]]. For the blending of serious political work and amusement, ''cf.'' Tacitus, ''Germania,'' 22.</ref> possibly for debates and verbal contests.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1606> So Zimmer, ''op. cit.,'' 174, takes ''[[सभेय|sabheya]]'' in Rv. ii. 24, 13.</ref><br><br>According to Ludwig,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1606> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 253256. He quotes for this view Rv. viii. 4, 9;<br> x. 71, 10 (passages which are quite vague). ''Cf.'' also Rv. vii. 1, 4;<br> Av. xix. 57, 2.</ref> the [[सभा|Sabhā]] was an assembly not of all the people, but of the Brahmins and '''Maghavans''' (‘rich patrons’). This view can be supported by the expressions  ''[[सभेय|sabheya]],'' ‘worthy of the assembly,’ applied to a Brahmin,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1606> Rv. ii. 24, 13. ''Cf.'' i. 91, 20;<br> Av. xx. 128, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 22, etc. Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 276, sees in ''[[सभेय|sabheya]]'' the implication of ‘courtly manners,’ but this is rather doubtful;<br> manner is not conspicuous in Vedic society as in Homeric.</ref> ''rayiḥ sabhāvān,'' ‘wealth fitting for the assembly,’<ref name=fx9_ve2_1606> Rv. iv. 2, 5;<br> in i. 167, 3, ''sabhāvatī'' is applied to ‘speech,’ or perhaps to ''yoṣā,'' ‘woman.’</ref> and so on. But Bloomfield<ref name=fx10_ve2_1606> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 13.</ref> plausibly sees in these passages a domestic use of [[सभा|Sabhā]], which is recognized by the St. Petersburg Dictionary in several passages<ref name=fx11_ve2_1606> Av. viii. 10, 5 (where the sense is, however, clearly ‘assembly’;<br> see viii. 10, 6);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 8, 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 10, 3;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 14 (but here the sense is certainly ‘assembly hall,’;<br> see v. 3, 6, where the king is described as going to the assembly hall: ''[[सभा|sabhā]]-ga'') The exact sense given by the St. Petersburg Dictionary is the ‘society room’ in a dwelling-house.</ref> as relating to a house, not to the assembly at all. Zimmer<ref name=fx12_ve2_1606> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 174. But he ignores Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 14;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 3, 6, which show that the king went to the [[सभा|Sabhā]] just as much as to the [[सम्इति|Samiti]], and he cannot adduce any passage to show that the Grāmaṇī presided.</ref> is satisfied that the [[सभा|Sabhā]] was the meetingplace of the village council, presided over by the '''Grāmaṇī.''' But of this there is no trace whatever. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx13_ve2_1606> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 123-125.</ref> seems right in maintaining that the [[सभा|Sabhā]] and the '''[[सम्इति|Samiti]]''' cannot be distinguished, and that the reference to well-born (''[[सु-जात|su-jāta]]'')<ref name=fx14_ve2_1606> Rv. vii. 1, 4.</ref> men being there in session is to the Āryan as opposed to the [[दास|Dāsa]] or [[शूद्र|Śūdra]], not to one class of Āryan as opposed to the other. Hillebrandt also sees in Agni ‘of the hall’ (''sabhya'') a trace of the fire used in sacrifice on behalf of the assembly when it met.<ref name=fx15_ve2_1606> Agni is ''sabhya,'' Av. viii. 10, 5;<br> xix. 55, 6. For the Rv., see iii. 23, 4;<br> v. 3, 11;<br> vii. 7, 5.</ref><br><br>Women did not go to the [[सभा|Sabhā]],<ref name=fx16_ve2_1606> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 4.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 172174.</ref> for they were, of course, excluded from political activity. For the [[सभा|Sabhā]] as a courthouse, ''cf.'' '''[[ग्राम्यवादिन्|Grāmyavādin]].''' There is not a single notice of the work done by the [[सभा|Sabhā]].

सभा-चर
<u>'''Sabhā-cara'''</u> is one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1607> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 2, 1 with Sāyaṇa's note. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 77, n. 1.</ref> The St. Petersburg  Dictionary thinks it is an adjective equivalent in sense to ''[[सभा|sabhā]]-ga,''’ ‘going to the assembly.’ As he is dedicated to [[धर्म|Dharma]], ‘Justice,’ it is difficult not to see in him a member of the [[सभा|Sabhā]] as a law court, perhaps as one of those who sit to decide cases: there is nothing to show whether the whole assembly did so, or only a chosen body. The special use of [[सभाचर|Sabhācara]] suggests the latter alternative. See also '''[[सभासद्|Sabhāsad]].'''

सभा-पति
<u>'''Sabhā-pati,'''</u> ‘lord of the assembly,’ is an epithet in the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1608> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 24;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 3, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 13, etc.</ref>

सभा-पाल
<u>'''Sabhā-pāla'''</u> is found in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 7, 4, 6), where the sense may be ‘guardian of an assembly hall.’<br>==Foot Notes==

सभाविन्
<u>'''Sabhāvin'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 4, 16, 1) denotes, according to the commentator Sāyaṇa, the ‘keeper of a gambling hall.’<br>==Foot Notes==

सभा-सद्
<u>'''Sabhā-sad,'''</u> ‘sitter in the assembly,’ is probably a technical description of the assessors who decided legal cases in the assembly (''cf.'' '''[[सभाचर|Sabhācara]]'''). The term, which is found in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1611> iii. 29, 1 (of Yama);<br> vii. 12, 2;<br> xix. 55, 6.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1611> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 6, 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 26;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21, 14.</ref> cannot well merely denote any member of the assembly. It is also possible that the Sabhāsads, perhaps the heads of families, were expected to be present at the [[सभा|Sabhā]] oftener than the ordinary man: the meetings of the assembly for justice may have been more frequent than for general discussion and decision.

सभा-स्थाणु
<u>'''Sabhā-sthāṇu.'''</u> See '''[[सभा|Sabhā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सभेय
<u>'''Sabheya.'''</u> See '''[[सभा|Sabhā]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

सम्-अङ्क
<u>'''Sam-aṅka'''</u> is a word of obscure sense occurring in two passages of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1614> i. 12, 2;<br> vi. 50, 1.</ref> Bloomfield<ref name=fx2_ve2_1614> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 7, 142. ''Cf.'' St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> renders it ‘hook’ in the first, and takes it to mean an insect destructive of grain in the other.

समन
<u>'''Samana'''</u> is a word of somewhat doubtful sense in the Rigveda. Roth<ref name=fx1_ve2_1615> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> renders it either ‘battle’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1615> Rv. vi. 75, 3. 5;<br> ix. 96, 9;<br> x. 143, 4;<br> Av. vi. 92, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 9.</ref> or ‘festival.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1615> Rv. ii. 16, 7;<br> vi. 60, 2;<br> vii. 2, 5;<br> viii. 12, 9;<br> ix. 97, 47;<br> x. 55, 5;<br> 86, 10;<br> Av. ii. 36, 1.</ref> Pischel<ref name=fx4_ve2_1615> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 314.</ref> thinks that it was a general popular festivity to which women went to enjoy themselves,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1615> Rv. i. 124, 8 (''cf.'' '''Vrā''');<br> iv. 58, 8;<br> vi. 75, 4;<br> vii. 2, 5;<br> x. 86, 10;<br> 168, 2.</ref> poets to win fame,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1615> Rv. ii. 16, 7;<br> ix. 97, 47. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 38.</ref> bowmen to gain prizes at archery,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1615> Rv. vi. 75, 3. 5.</ref> horses to run races;<ref name=fx8_ve2_1615> Rv. ix. 96, 9;<br> Av. vi. 92, 2.</ref> and which lasted until morning<ref name=fx9_ve2_1615> Rv. i. 48, 6, which Roth takes as referring to men going to business.</ref> or until a conflagration, caused by the fires kept burning all night, scattered the celebrators.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1615> Rv. x. 69, 11. ''Cf.'' vii. 9, 4.</ref> Young women,<ref name=fx11_ve2_1615> Av. ii. 36, 1.</ref> elderly women,<ref name=fx12_ve2_1615> Rv. vii. 2, 5.</ref> sought there to find a husband, and courtezans to make profit of the occasion.<ref name=fx13_ve2_1615> Rv. iv. 58, 8, where, as in vi. 75, 4;<br> x. 168, 2, Roth sees the sense of ‘embrace.’ The parallel with the festivals of Greece, where only young girls were able freely to mix with strangers, and which afforded the basis of so many of the comedies of the later school, is striking (''cf.'' Mahaffy, ''Greek Literature,'' 1, 2, 259 ''et seq.'').<br><br>''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 190.</ref>

समर
<u>'''Samara'''</u> in the sense of ‘battle’ is found in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1616> vii. 9;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 15, 12.</ref> and, according to Geldner,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1616> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 190.</ref> in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1616> vi. 9, 2 (at the sacrifice;<br> ''cf. samarya,'' iv. 24, 8, etc.).</ref>

समा
<u>'''Samā'''</u> appears originally to have denoted ‘summer,’ a sense which may be seen in a few passages of the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1617> i. 35, 4;<br> ii. 6, 1;<br> iii. 10, 9. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 36.</ref>  Hence it also denotes more generally ‘season,’ a rare use.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1617> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 25, 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 41.</ref> More commonly it is simply ‘year’;<ref name=fx3_ve2_1617> Rv. iv. 57, 7;<br> x. 85, 5;<br> 124, 4;<br> Av. v. 8, 8;<br> vi. 75, 2, etc.</ref> but in one place the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1617> vi. 2, 1, 25.</ref> interprets it in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx5_ve2_1617> xxvii. 1, with Mahīdhara's note. See Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 168, n. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 372;<br> Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 301.</ref> as meaning ‘month,’ a doubtful sense.

समान
<u>'''Samāna.'''</u> See '''[[प्राण|Prāṇa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

समान-गोत्र
<u>'''Samāna-gotra'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1619> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 15.</ref> and '''[[समान|Samāna]]-jana'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1619> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 6, 9;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 2, 10.</ref> mean ‘belonging to the same family’ and ‘class’ respectively in the Brāhmaṇas. '''[[समान|Samāna]]-[[बन्धु|bandhu]],''' ‘having the same kin,’ is found in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1619> i. 113, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 1, 25.</ref>

समान्त
<u>'''Samānta'''</u> (‘having the same boundary’), ‘neighbour,’ and therefore ‘foe,’ occurs in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (ii. 1, 24).<br>==Foot Notes==

सम्-इति
<u>'''Sam-iti'''</u> denotes an ‘assembly’ of the Vedic tribe. It is already mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1621> i. 95, 8;<br> ix. 92, 6;<br> x. 97, 6;<br> 166, 4;<br> 191, 3.</ref> and often later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1621> Av. v. 19, 15;<br> vi. 88, 3;<br> vii. 12, 1;<br> xii. 1, 56, etc.</ref> sometimes in connexion with '''[[सभा|Sabhā]].'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1621> Av. vii. 12, 1;<br> xii. 1, 56;<br> xv. 9, 2. 3;<br> viii. 10, 5. 6.</ref> Ludwig<ref name=fx4_ve2_1621> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 253 ''et seq.''</ref> considers that the [[सम्इति|Samiti]] included all the people, primarily the ''viśaḥ,'' ‘subjects,’ but also the '''Maghavans''' and Brahmins if they desired, though the [[सभा|Sabhā]] was their special assembly. This view is not probable, nor is that of Zimmer,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1621> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 172 ''et seq.''</ref> that the [[सभा|Sabhā]] was the village assembly. Hillebrandt appears to be right in holding that [[सम्इति|Samiti]] and [[सभा|Sabhā]] are much the same, the one being the assembly, the other primarily the place of assembly.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1621> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 124, n. 6.</ref> <br><br>The king went to the assembly<ref name=fx7_ve2_1621> Rv. ix. 92, 6;<br> x. 97, 6 (where the reference is hardly to an oligarchy, as Zimmer, 176, 177, holds, but merely to the princes of the blood going to the assembly with the rest).</ref> just as he went to the [[सभा|Sabhā]]. That he was elected there, as Zimmer<ref name=fx8_ve2_1621> ''Op. cit.,'' 175, quoting Av. vi. 87, 88, with Rv. x. 173, and Av. v. 19, 15, with Av. iii. 4, 6.</ref> thinks, is as uncertain as whether he was elected at all (see '''[[राजन्|Rājan]]'''). But there are clear signs that concord between king and assembly were essential for his prosperity.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1621> Av. vi. 88, 3. Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2, takes [[सम्इति|Samiti]] here and in v. 19, 15;<br> Rv. x. 166, 4;<br> 191, 3, to mean ‘union,’ but this is neither necessary nor probable.</ref><br><br>It is reasonable to assume that the business of the assembly was general deliberation on policy of all kinds, legislation so far as the Vedic Indian cared to legislate, and judicial work (''cf.'' '''[[सभासद्|Sabhāsad]]'''). But of all these occupations there is, perhaps as a result of the nature of the texts, little or no evidence directly available.<br><br>The gods had a [[सम्इति|Samiti]], hence called ''daivī,'' ‘divine,’<ref name=fx10_ve2_1621> Rv. x. 11, 8.</ref> just as they had a [[सभा|Sabhā]].<ref name=fx11_ve2_1621> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 11, 13, 14.</ref><br><br>The assembly disappears as an effective part of government in the Buddhist texts,<ref name=fx12_ve2_1621> ''Cf.'' Bühler, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 55, on the Parīsa.</ref> the Epic,<ref name=fx13_ve2_1621> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 148-152, who traces the decay of the old assembly through the aristocratic war council and the secret priestly conclave. It is, of course, very probable that at no time was the [[सम्इति|Samiti]] a place where any or much attention was paid to the views of the common man. Princes and great men spoke;<br> the rest approved or disapproved, as in Homeric times and in Germany (''cf.'' Lang, ''Anthropology and the Classics,'' 51 ''et seq.;<br>'' Tacitus, ''Germania,'' 11, 12, where their general duty of discussion and their criminal jurisdiction are mentioned).</ref> and the law-books.<ref name=fx14_ve2_1621> Foy, ''Die ko7nigliche Gewalt,'' 6, 7, 10.</ref>

सम्-इध्
<u>'''Sam-idh'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1622> iv. 4, 15;<br> vi. 15, 7;<br> 16, 11;<br> vii. 14, 1;<br> x. 12, 2, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1622> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, iii. 4;<br> xx. 25, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘fuel’ for kindling fire. Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve2_1622> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 191.</ref> inclines to see in one passage<ref name=fx4_ve2_1622> Rv. x. 52, 2.</ref> the name of a priest, the later Agnidh.

सम्-उद्र
<u>'''Sam-udra'''</u> (literally ‘gathering of waters’), ‘ocean,’ is a frequent word in the Rigveda and later. It is of importance in  so far as it indicates that the Vedic Indians knew the sea. This is, indeed, denied by Vivien de Saint Martin,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1623> ''Étude sur la géographie du Véda,'' 62 ''et seq. Cf.'' Wilson, ''Rigveda,'' 1, xii.</ref> but not only do Max Müller<ref name=fx2_ve2_1623> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 61 ''et seq.,'' quoting Rv. i. 71, 7;<br> 190, 7;<br> v. 78, 8;<br> vii. 49, 2;<br> 95, 2;<br> x. 58.</ref> and Lassen<ref name=fx3_ve2_1623> ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 1^2, 883.</ref> assert it, but even Zimmer,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1623> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 22 ''et seq. Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 143, 144.</ref> who is inclined to restrict their knowledge of the sea as far as possible, admits it in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1623> vii. 95, 2.</ref> and of course later.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1623> Av. iv. 10, 4 (pearl shell);<br> vi. 105, 3 (the outflow, ''vi-kṣara,'' of the ocean);<br> xix. 38, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 13, 1, etc.</ref> He points out that the ebb and flow of the sea are unknown, that the mouths of the Indus are never mentioned, that fish is not a known diet in the Rigveda (''cf.'' '''[[मत्स्य|Matsya]]'''), and that in many places [[सम्उद्र|Samudra]] is metaphorically used, as of the two oceans,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1623> Rv. x. 136, 5. ''Cf.'' Av. xi. 5, 6.</ref> the lower and the upper oceans,<ref name=fx8_ve2_1623> Rv. vii. 6, 7;<br> x. 98, 5.</ref> etc. In other passages he thinks that [[सम्उद्र|Samudra]] denotes the river Indus when it receives all its Panjab tributaries.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1623> See, ''e.g.,'' Rv. i. 71, 7;<br> iii. 36, 7;<br> 46, 4;<br> v. 85, 6;<br> vi. 36, 3;<br> vii. 95, 2;<br> viii. 16, 2;<br> 44, 25;<br> ix. 88, 6;<br> 107, 9;<br> 108, 16 (where reference is made to streams);<br> or Rv. i. 163, 1;<br> iv. 21, 3;<br> v. 55, 5;<br> viii. 6, 29, where land and [[सम्उद्र|Samudra]] are contrasted.</ref> It is probable that this is to circumscribe too narrowly the Vedic knowledge of the ocean, which was almost inevitable to people who knew the Indus. There are references to the treasures of the ocean,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1623> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 47, 6;<br> vii. 6, 7;<br> ix. 97, 44.</ref> perhaps pearls or the gains of trade,<ref name=fx11_ve2_1623> ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 48, 3;<br> 56, 2;<br> iv. 55, 6;<br> and the general parallelism of the Dioscuri and the Aśvins.</ref> and the story of '''[[भुज्यु|Bhujyu]]''' seems to allude to marine navigation.<br><br>That there was any sea trade with Babylon in Vedic times cannot be proved: the stress Iaid<ref name=fx12_ve2_1623> ''E.g.,'' by Weber, ''Indian Literature,'' 3.</ref> on the occurrence in the Hebrew Book of Kings<ref name=fx13_ve2_1623> 1. Kings x. 22.</ref> of ''qof'' and ''tukhiīm,'' ‘monkey’ (''kapi'') and ‘peacock,’ is invalidated by the doubtful date of the Book of Kings. There is, besides, little reason to assume an early date for the trade that no doubt developed later, perhaps about 700 B.C.<ref name=fx14_ve2_1623> See Kennedy, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1898, 241-288;<br> Bühler, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 79 ''et seq.;<br> Indisehe Palœographie,'' 17-19, who much exaggerates the antiquity of the traffic;<br> Vincent Smith, ''Early History of India,'' 25, n.</ref> <br><br>In the later texts [[सम्उद्र|Samudra]] repeatedly means the sea.<ref name=fx15_ve2_1623> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 8, 2;<br> vii. 5, 1, 2. It is described as unfailing in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 16, 7 (''cf.'' iii. 39, 7);<br> it encircles the earth, ''ibid.,'' viii. 25, 1. The eastern and western oceans in Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 11 (''cf.'' x. 6, 4, 1), though metaphorical, probably indicate an acquaintance with both seas, the Indian Ocean and the Arabian Sea.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 14-19;<br> Pischel and Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xxiii.</ref>

सम्राज्
<u>'''Samrāj'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1624> iii. 55, 7;<br> 56, 5;<br> iv. 21, 1;<br> vi. 27, 8;<br> viii. 19, 32.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1624> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 32;<br> xiii. 35;<br> xx. 5, etc.</ref> means ‘superior ruler, ‘sovereign,’ as expressing a greater degree of power than ‘king’ ('''[[राजन्|Rājan]]'''). In the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1624> v. 1, 1, 13. ''Cf.'' xii. 8, 3, 4;<br> xiv. 1, 3, 8.</ref> in accordance with its curious theory of the '''[[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]]''' and '''[[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],''' the [[सम्राज्|Samrāj]] is asserted to be a higher authority than a king, and to have become one by the sacrifice of the [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]]. There is, however, no trace of the use of the word as ‘emperor’ in the sense of an ‘overlord of kings,’ probably because political conditions furnished no example of such a status, as for instance was attained in the third century B.C. by Aśoka. At the same time [[सम्राज्|Samrāj]] denotes an important king like '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' of '''[[विदेह|Videha]].'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1624> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 3, 2, 1. 6;<br> 2, 2, 3;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 1, 1;<br> 3, 1. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Über den [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]],'' 8.</ref> It is applied in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1624> viii. 14, 2. 3. The other names are given as follows: For the northerners it is [[विराज्|Virāj]]: for the southerners, [[स्वराज्|Svarāj]];<br> for the Satvants, [[भोज|Bhoja]]: for the middle people (Kuru-[[पञ्चाल|Pañcāla]], [[वश|Vaśa]], and [[उशीनर|Uśīnara]]), [[राजन्|Rājan]] simply. This is probably a sound tradition.</ref> as the title of the eastern kings. ''Cf.'' '''[[राज्य|Rājya]].'''

सरघ्
<u>'''Saragh,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1625> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 14.</ref> '''Saraghā,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1625> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 4, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 10, 10, 1.</ref> both denote ‘bee’ in the Brāhmaṇas. See also '''[[सरह्|Sarah]].'''

सरयु
<u>'''Sarayu'''</u> is mentioned thrice in the Rigveda as the name of river. '''[[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]]''' and Arṇa are said to have been defeated apparently by the '''Turvaśas''' and '''Yadus''' who crossed the  [[सरयु|Sarayu]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1626> iv. 30, 18. This passage gives no help, because the possibility is open either to suppose that the [[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], Yadu are not mentioned as defeating the Āryans [[चित्ररथ|Citraratha]] and Arṇa;<br> or, if they are, to suppose that they may have come east against the two.</ref> [[सरयु|Sarayu]] appears in one passage with '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]''' and '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1626> x. 64, 9.</ref> and in another with '''[[रसा|Rasā]], [[अनितभा|Anitabhā]],''' and '''Kubha.'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1626> v. 53, 9.</ref> Later, in the post-Vedic period, Sarayū, rarely [[सरयु|Sarayu]], is the name of a river in Oudh, the modern Sarjū.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1626> This is a tributary joining the Gogrā, the great river of Oudh, on the left of its upper course. The name Sarjū is also applied to the Gogrā itself below '''Bahrāmghāt.''' A branch of the Lower Gogrā, given off on the right, flowing in an old bed of the Gogrā, and falling into the Ganges after passing Balliā, is called the Chhotī (Lesser) Sarjū. ''Cf. Imperial Gazetteer of India,'' 22, 109;<br> 12, 302 (Gogrā);<br> 23, 418 (Eastern Tons);<br> 26, Plate 31.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_1626> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 17, 45. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, xxv;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 323.</ref> regards this as the river meant in all the Vedic passages, seeing in the last,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1626/> which may be used as an argument for locating the [[सरयु|Sarayu]] in the Panjab, a reference to the north-east monsoon as well as to the usual monsoon from the west. Hopkins<ref name=fx6_ve2_1626> ''Religions of India,'' 34.</ref> thinks that the [[सरयु|Sarayu]] is to be found in the west, and Ludwig<ref name=fx7_ve2_1626> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 280.</ref> identifies it with the Kurum ('''[[क्रुमु|Krumu]]'''). Vivien de St. Martin considered it to be probably identical with the united course of the '''[[शुतुद्री|Śutudrī]]''' (Sutlej) and '''[[विपाश्|Vipāś]]''' (Beas).

सरस्
<u>'''Saras'''</u> denotes ‘lake’ in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1627> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 47, 48;<br> xxx. 16.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1627> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 33, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 5, 3.</ref>

सरस्वती
<u>'''Sarasvatī'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1628> Literally, ‘abounding in pools,’ perhaps with reference to its condition when the water was low. The name corresponds phonetically to the Iranian Haraqaiti (the modern Helmand).</ref> is the name of a river frequently mentioned in the Rigveda and later. In many passages<ref name=fx2_ve2_1628> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 2, 1, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 10, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 2, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 1, 14;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 19, 1. 2;<br> probably Av. vi. 30, 1. This list is according to Roth's view, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 3''c.''</ref> of the later texts it is certain the river meant is the modern [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], which loses  itself in the sands of Patiala (see '''[[विनशन|Vinaśana]]'''). Even Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_1628> Rv. iii. 23, 4 (where the [[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]] appears);<br> x. 64, 9: 75, 5 (where the Śindhu also is mentioned).</ref> admits that this river is intended in some passages of the Rigveda. With the '''[[दृषद्वती|Dṛṣadvatī]]'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1628> Probably the modern Chautang, which flows to the east of Thanesar. ''Cf.'' Oldham, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 25, 58;<br> ''Imperial Gasetteer of India,'' 26, Plate 32.</ref> it formed the western boundary of [[ब्रह्मावर्त|Brahmāvarta]] (see '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]]'''). It is the holy stream of early Vedic India. The Sūtras<ref name=fx5_ve2_1628> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 3, 20;<br> xxiv. 6, 22;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 15, 1;<br> 18, 13;<br> 19, 4;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xii. 6, 2. 3;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 29.</ref> mention sacrifices held on its banks as of great importance and sanctity.<br><br>In many other passages of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1628> i. 89, 3;<br> 164, 19;<br> ii. 41, 16 ''et seq.;<br>'' 30, 8;<br> 32, 8;<br> iii. 54, 13;<br> v. 42, 12;<br> 43, 11;<br> 46, 2;<br> vi. 49, 7;<br> 50, 12;<br> 52, 6;<br> vii. 9, 5;<br> 36, 6;<br> 39, 5;<br> 40, 3;<br> viii. 21, 17;<br> 54, 4;<br> x. 17, 7;<br> 30, 12;<br> 131, 5;<br> 184, 2.</ref> and even later,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1628> Av. iv. 4. 6;<br> v. 23, 1;<br> vi. 3, 2;<br> 89, 3;<br> vii. 68, 1;<br> xiv. 2, 15. 20;<br> xvi. 4, 4;<br> xix. 32, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, 1, 8, 13, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 93;<br> xxxiv. 11;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 2, 4;<br> xi. 4, 3, 3;<br> xii. 7, 1, 12;<br> 2, 5;<br> Bṛnadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 3, 8. These passages should all be classed in n. 2.</ref> Roth held that another river, the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus), was really meant: only thus could it be explained why the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] is called the ‘foremost of rivers’ (''nadītamā''),<ref name=fx8_ve2_1628> Rv. ii. 41, 16.</ref> is said to go to the ocean,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1628> Rv. vi. 61, 2. 8;<br> vii. 96, 2.</ref> and is referred to as a large river, on the banks of which many kings,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1628> Rv. viii. 21, 18.</ref> and, indeed, the five tribes, were located.<ref name=fx11_ve2_1628> Rv. vi. 61, 12.</ref> This view is accepted by Zimmer<ref name=fx12_ve2_1628> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 5-10.</ref> and others.<ref name=fx13_ve2_1628> ''E.g.,'' Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 1, 60;<br> 2, 90, etc.;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 201, 202.</ref><br><br>On the other hand, Lassen<ref name=fx14_ve2_1628> ''Indische Alterthumshunde,'' 1^2, 118.</ref> and Max Müller<ref name=fx15_ve2_1628> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 60.</ref> maintain the identity of the Vedic [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] with the later [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].<ref name=fx16_ve2_1628> In the enumeration of rivers (evidently from east to west) in Rv. x. 75, 5, [[गङ्गा|Gaṅgā]], [[यमुना|Yamunā]], [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], [[शुतुद्री|Śutudrī]], the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] comes between the Jumna and the Sutlej, the position of the modern Sarsūti (Saraswatī), which, flowing to the west of Thanesar, is joined in Patiala territory by a more westerly stream, the Ghaggar, and, passing Sirsa, is lost in the desert at Bhatnair;<br> but a dry river bed (Hakra or Ghaggar) can be traced from that point to the Indus. See ''Imperial Gasetteer of India,'' 26, Plate 32. ''Cf.'' also Oldham, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 25, 49-76.</ref> The latter is of opinion that in Vedic times the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] was as large a stream as the Sutlej, and that it actually reached the  sea either after union with the Indus or not, being the ‘iron citadel,’ as the last boundary on the west, a frontier of the Panjab against the rest of India. There is no conclusive evidence of there having been any great change in the size or course of the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], though it would be impossible to deny that the river may easily have diminished in size. But there are strong reasons to accept the identification of the later and the earlier [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] throughout. The insistence on the divine character of the river is been in the very hymn<ref name=fx17_ve2_1628> Rv. ii. 41, 16 (''devitame'').</ref> which refers to it as the support of the five tribes, and corresponds well with its later sacredness. Moreover, that hymn alludes to the '''Pārāvatas,''' a people shown by the later evidence of the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx18_ve2_1628> See '''[[पारावत|Pārāvata]],''' and ''cf.'' '''[[बृसय|Bṛsaya]].'''</ref> to have been in the east, a very long way from their original home, if [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] means the Indus. Again, the '''Pūrus,''' who were settled on the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],<ref name=fx19_ve2_1628> Rv. vii. 95, 96. Ludwig, ''op. cit.,'' 3, 175, admits that the Indus cannot be meant here. See Hillebrandt. ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 115.</ref> could with great difficulty be located in the far west. Moreover, the five tribes might easily be held to be on the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], when they were, as they seem to have been, the western neighbours of the '''Bharatas''' in '''[[कुरुक्षेत्र|Kurukṣetra]],''' and the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] could easily be regarded as the boundary of the Panjab in that sense. Again, the ‘seven rivers’ in one passage<ref name=fx20_ve2_1628> Rv. viii. 24, 27. The connexion of [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] and the seven rivers is rather vague. In Rv. viii. 54, 4, [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] and the seven rivers are separately invoked, and in vi. 61, 10, 12, she is referred to as ‘seven-sistered’ (''saptasvasā''). In vii. 36, 6, she is called the ‘seventh,’ which makes the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] one of the rivers. If the former passages are to be treated as precise, then ''saptasvasā'' may be considered to show that the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]] was outside the river system (which would then be Indus, [[कुभा|Kubhā]], and the five rivers of the Panjab;<br> see '''[[सप्त सिन्धवः|Sapta Sindhavaḥ]]''');<br> but the expression may be loosely meant for one of seven sisters.</ref> clearly designate a district: it is most probable that they are not the five rivers with the Indus and the '''[[कुभा|Kubhā]]''' (Cabul river), but the five rivers, the Indus and the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]]. Nor is it difficult to see why the river is said to flow to the sea: either the Vedic poet had never followed the course of the river to its end, or the river did actually penetrate the desert either completely or for a long distance, and only in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period was its disappear-  ance in the desert found out. It is said, indeed, in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx21_ve2_1628> xxxiv. 11.</ref> that the five rivers go to the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]], but this passage is not only late (as the use of the word '''[[देश|Deśa]]''' shows), but it does not say that the five rivers meant are those of the Panjab. Moreover, the passage has neither a parallel in the other Saṃhitās, nor can it possibly be regarded as an early production; if it is late it must refer to the later [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].<br><br>Hillebrandt,<ref name=fx22_ve2_1628> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 99 ''et seq.;<br>'' 3, 372-378.</ref> on the whole, adopts this view of the [[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],<ref name=fx23_ve2_1628> He sees this sense in the Rigveda everywhere, except in the passages indicated in notes 24 and 25.</ref> but he also sees in it, besides the designation of a mythical stream, the later Vaitaraṇī,<ref name=fx24_ve2_1628> vii. 95, 6;<br> x. 17, 7;<br> Av. vii. 68, 2;<br> xiv. 2, 20;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxxv. 10, 11.</ref> as well as the name of the Arghandab in Arachosia.<ref name=fx25_ve2_1628> Rv. vi. 49, 7;<br> 61;<br> possibly Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 11.</ref> This opinion depends essentially on his theory that the sixth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda places the scene of its action in Iranian lands, as opposed to the seventh Maṇḍala: it is as untenable as that theory itself.<ref name=fx26_ve2_1628> See '''Divodāsa.'''</ref> Brunnhofer<ref name=fx27_ve2_1628> Bezzenberger's ''Beiträge,'' 10, 261, n. 2.</ref> at one time accepted the Iranian identification, but later<ref name=fx28_ve2_1628> ''Iran und Turan,'' 127.<br><br>''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 337 ''et seq.,'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 141, 142;<br> ''Vedic Mythology,'' pp. 86-88;<br> von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 84, 164.</ref> decided for the Oxus, which is quite out of the question. See also '''[[प्लक्ष प्रास्रवण|Plakṣa Prāsravaṇa]].'''

सरह्
<u>'''Sarah'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1629> i. 112, 21.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1629> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 3, 12, 12;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 1, 4. The stem is given as Saraṭ in the Uṇādisūtra, 1, 133;<br> but '''[[सरघ्|Saragh]]''' shows that [[सरह्|Sarah]] must be meant (''cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 238, n. 2).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 97.</ref> denotes ‘bee.’ ''Cf.'' '''Saragha.'''

सरित्
<u>'''Sarit'''</u> denotes ‘stream’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1630> iv. 58, 6;<br> vii. 70, 2;<br> Av. xii. 2, 41;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 2, 1, 11, etc.</ref> and later.^2 

सरीसृप
<u>'''Sarīsṛpa'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1631> x. 162, 3.</ref> and often later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1631> Av. iii. 10, 6: xix. 7, 1;<br> 48, 3, etc.</ref> any ‘creeping animal’ or ‘reptile.’

सर्प
<u>'''Sarpa,'''</u> ‘serpent,’ occurs once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1632> x. 16, 6.</ref> where '''Ahi''' is the usual word, but often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1632> Av. x. 4, 23;<br> xi. 3, 47;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 4, 1;<br> iii. 1, 1, 1, etc.</ref>

सर्प-राज्ञी
<u>'''Sarpa-rājñī,'''</u> ‘serpent-queen,’ is the alleged authoress of a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1633> x. 189.</ref> according to the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1633> i. 5, 4, 1;<br> vii. 3, 1, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 6, 6;<br> ii. 2, 6, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 23, 1, 2.</ref>

सर्प-विद्या
<u>'''Sarpa-vidyā,'''</u> the ‘science of snakes,’ is enumerated in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] among branches of learning. It must have been reduced to fixed rules, since a section (''[[पर्वन्|parvan]]'') of it is referred to as studied. The Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1634> i. 1, 10. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 367, n. 3.</ref> has the form [[सर्प|Sarpa]]-veda.<br><br>^1 xiii. 4, 3, 9. ''Cf.'' Śānkhāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvi. 2, 25. The Āśvalāyana Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 7, 5, has '''[[विष-विद्या|Viṣa-vidyā]],''' and the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vii. 1. 2. 4; 2, 1; 4, 1; 7, 1) has ''sarpadevajana-[[विद्या|vidyā]].''

सर्पि वात्सि
<u>'''Sarpi Vātsi'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[वत्स|Vatsa]]'''’) is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1635> vi. 24, 15. Aufrecht, ''Altareya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],'' 424, takes the name to be Sarpir. The point is, of course, doubtful, since the word occurs in the nominative only.</ref>

सर्पिस्
<u>'''Sarpis'''</u> denotes ‘melted butter,’ whether in a liquid or solidified condition, and not differing from '''[[घृत|Ghṛta]]''' according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary. Roth there rejects the definition cited by Sāyaṇa in his commentary on the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1636> i. 3, 5.</ref> which discriminates [[सर्पिस्|Sarpis]] as the liquid and [[घृत|Ghṛta]] as the solid condition of the butter. The word is repeatedly mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1636> i. 127, 1;<br> v. 6, 9;<br> x. 18, 7.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1636> Av. i. 15, 4;<br> ix. 6, 41;<br> x. 9, 12;<br> xii. 3, 45;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 10, 1, etc.</ref> 

सर्व-चरु
<u>'''Sarva-caru'''</u> is found in a passage of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1637> vi. 1, 1.</ref> and of the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1637> xxix. 1.</ref> where the gods are referred to as holding a sacrifice ''sarvacarau.'' The word is the name of a man according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary; the name of a place<ref name=fx3_ve2_1637> Sāyaṇa on [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> seems possible, or even a mere adjective may be meant.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1637> Aufrecht, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],'' 425, n. 1, who suggests that ''yajñe'' is to be supplied.</ref>

सर्व-वेदस
<u>'''Sarva-vedasa'''</u> denotes in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas either a sacrifice in which the sacrificer gives his all to the priests,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1638> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 7, 7;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 14;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 3, 1.</ref> or the whole property of a man.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1638> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 1, 1, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 8, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 7, 15;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 6, 1, 15, etc.</ref>

सर्षप
<u>'''Sarṣapa,'''</u> denoting ‘mustard’ or ‘mustard seed,’ occurs only a few times in later Vedic texts.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1639> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 14, 3. ''Cf.'' Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Srauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 15, 8, etc. It is common in the later language.</ref>

सला-वृकी
<u>'''Salā-vṛkī.'''</u> See '''[[सालावृक|Sālāvṛka]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सलिल-वात
<u>'''Salila-vāta'''</u> occurs in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1641> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 4, 12, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxiv. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 16, 4.</ref> as an adjective meaning ‘favoured with a wind from the water.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1641> Or, according to the commentator, ''salilākhyena [[वात|vāta]]-viśeṣeṇa anugṛhītaḥ,'' ‘favoured by a kind of wind called Salila.’</ref> It probably refers to the wind from the ocean, the south-west monsoon.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1641> ''Indian Empire,'' 1, 110. The monsoon is little noted in the Vedic texts, except in so far as the Marut hymns may be deemed to be a description of the monsoon. See Rv. i. 19, 7;<br> 37, 6 ''et seq.;<br>'' 38, 8;<br> 64, 8;<br> 88, 5;<br> v. 83, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' 85, 4;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 42-44.</ref> 

सल्व
<u>'''Salva'''</u> is the name of a people mentioned in a passage of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1642> x. 4, 1, 10.</ref> which records a boast by '''[[श्यापर्ण सायकायन|Śyāparṇa Sāyakāyana]]''' that if a certain rite of his had been completed, his race would have been the nobles, Brahmins, and peasants of the Salvas, and even as it was his race would surpass the Salvas. This people appears also to be alluded to as ''Sālvīḥ (prajāḥ)'' in the [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] Pāṭha,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1642> ii. 11, 12.</ref> where they are said to have declared that their king was '''Yaugandhari''' when they stayed their chariots<ref name=fx3_ve2_1642> Winternitz, ''[[मन्त्र|Mantra]]-pāṭha,'' xlv-xlvii, sees in the verse an allusion to the Sālva women turning round the wheel (? spinning-wheel). But a reference to a warlike raid seems more plauaible.</ref> on the banks of the '''[[यमुना|Yamunā]].''' There is later evidence<ref name=fx4_ve2_1642> Mahābhārata, iv. 1, 12;<br> viii. 44 (45), 14. The Yugandharas are also referred to in a Kārikā quoted in the Kāśikā Vṛtti on Pāṇini, iv. 1, 173.</ref> indicating that the Sālvas or Śālvas were closely connected with the '''Kuru-Pañcālas,''' and that apparently some of them, at least, were victorious near the banks of the [[यमुना|Yamunā]]. There is no good evidence to place them in the north-west in Vedic times.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1642> ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 215. Later, they may have been found in Rājasthān, Lassen, ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 1^2, 760.</ref>

सव्य-ष्ठा
<u>'''Savya-ṣṭhā,'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1643> Av. viii. 8, 23.</ref> '''Savya-ṣṭhṛ,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1643> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 2, 4, 9;<br> 3, 1, 8;<br> 4, 3, 17, 18.</ref> '''Savye-ṣṭha,'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1643> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]. i. 7, 9, 1.</ref> and '''Savya-stha'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1643> [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 62, n. 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 8.</ref> are all various forms of the word for ‘car-fighter,’ as opposed to '''[[सारथि|Sārathi]],''' ‘charioteer,’ showing that, as was natural, the fighter stood on the left of the driver. The commentators<ref name=fx5_ve2_1643> On Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> are inclined to see in the [[सव्यष्ठा|Savyaṣṭhā]] merely another ‘charioteer,’ but this is quite unjustifiable,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1643> Eggeling, ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 235.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 296.</ref> and is perhaps due to later caste prejudice against a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]] charioteer.

सस
<u>'''Sasa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1644> i. 51, 3;<br> x. 79, 3.</ref> denotes ‘herb’ or ‘grass.’<ref name=fx1_ve2_1644/> The word is also applied to the Soma plant<ref name=fx2_ve2_1644> iii. 5, 6;<br> iv. 5, 7, etc.</ref> and the sacrificial straw.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1644> v. 21, 4.</ref> 

ससर्परी
<u>'''Sasarparī'''</u> is a word occurring in two curious verses of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1645> iii. 53, 15, 16.</ref> According to a later interpretation,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1645> Bṛhaddevatā, iii. 113, with Macdonell's notes. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 159.</ref> it designates a particular kind of skill in speech which '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' obtained from '''[[जमद्अग्नि|Jamadagni]].''' What it was is quite uncertain.

सस्य
<u>'''Sasya'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1646> vii. 11, 1;<br> viii. 10, 24.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1646> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 3, 3;<br> v. 1, 7, 3;<br> vii. 5, 20, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 2, 2, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 284.</ref> regularly denotes ‘corn’ generally. It corresponds to the Avestan ''hahya.'' See '''[[कृषि|Kṛṣi]].'''

सह
<u>'''Saha'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1647> xi. 6, 15. ''Cf.'' Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 10.</ref> is, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1647> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2''b.''</ref> the name of a plant, but Bloomfield<ref name=fx3_ve2_1647> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 648.<br><br>''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 642;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref> thinks the word is only an adjective meaning ‘mighty.’

सह-देव
<u>'''Saha-deva'''</u> is the name of a prince in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1648> i. 100, 17.</ref> where he is victorious over the '''Śimyus''' and '''Dasyus.''' It is quite probable that he is identical with King [[सहदेव|Sahadeva]] [[सार्ञ्जय|Sārñjaya]], who is mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1648> ii. 4, 4, 3. 4. ''Cf.'' xii. 8, 2, 3.</ref> as having once been called '''[[सुप्लन् सार्ञ्जय|Suplan Sārñjaya]],''' and as having changed his name because of his success in performing the [[दाक्षायण|Dākṣāyaṇa]] sacrifice. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1648> vii. 34, 9.</ref> he is mentioned with '''Somaka Sahadevya,''' who also appears in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1648> iv. 15, 7 ''et seq.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 132;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105, 106.</ref>

सह-देवी
<u>'''Saha-devī'''</u> is the name of a plant in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1649> vi. 59, 2. ''Cf.'' Grill, ''Hundert Lieder,''^2 163;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 325;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 490, who does not accept this reading. A plant called [[सहदेव|Sahadeva]] occurs in the Sāmavidhāna [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 10.</ref> according to the reading of the commentary. 

सहमान
<u>'''Sahamāna'''</u> is the name of a plant in the Atharvaveda (ii. 25, 2; iv. 17, 2; viii. 2, 6; 7, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

सहो-जित्
<u>'''Saho-jit.'''</u> See '''Jaitrāyaṇa.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सांवरणि
<u>'''Sāṃvaraṇi'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1652> viii. 51, 1.</ref> in one passage, where it naturally seems to be a patronymic (‘descendant of Saṃvaraṇa’) of Manu. According to Bloomfield,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1652> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 180, n.</ref> it is a corruption for '''[[सावर्णि|Sāvarṇi]],''' a reference to Manu's birth from the ''savarṇā,'' ‘similar’ female who was substituted for Saraṇyū according to the legend (see '''Manu'''). This is possible, but not certain. Scheftelowitz<ref name=fx3_ve2_1652> ''Die Apokryphen des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 38.</ref> thinks that the reading of the Kaśmir manuscript of the Rigveda, which has ''sāṃvaraṇam,'' ‘found on the sacrificial ground,’ as an epithet of Soma, is to be preferred. But this seems quite improbable.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1652> See Oldenberg, ''Go7ttingische Gelehrte Anzeigen,'' 1907, 237.</ref> We must either recognize a real man called Manu [[सांवरणि|Sāṃvaraṇi]]; or take Manu as one name, [[सांवरणि|Sāṃvaraṇi]] as another; or admit that Manu [[सांवरणि|Sāṃvaraṇi]] is simply Manu with a patronymic derived from an unknown legend.

साकम्-अश्व देवरात
<u>'''Sākam-[[अश्व|aśva]] Devarāta'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) which concludes the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (xv. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

सांकृती-पुत्र
<u>'''Sāṃkṛtī-putra'''</u> (‘son of a female descendant of Saṃkṛta’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[आलम्बायनीपुत्र|Ālambāyanīputra]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1654> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> or '''[[आलम्बीपुत्र|Ālambīputra]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1654> ''Ibid.,'' vi. 4, 32 Mādhyaṃdina.</ref> in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].

सांकृत्य
<u>'''Sāṃkṛtya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Saṃkṛti,’ is the name of a teacher whose pupil was '''[[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]]''' in the first two Vaṃśas (lists of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1655> ii. 5, 20;<br> iv. 5, 26. A [[सांकृत्य|Sāṃkṛtya]] occurs also in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Prātiśākhya, viii. 21;<br> x. 21;<br> xvi. 16.</ref> 

साची-गुण
<u>'''Sācī-guṇa'''</u> is mentioned, apparently as a place in the territory of the '''Bharatas,''' in a verse occurring in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1656> viii. 23, 4.</ref> Leumann,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1656> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 48, 80, n. 5. This conjecture seems improbable.</ref> however, thinks an epithet of Indra, Śācīgu, may be meant.

सांजीवी-पुत्र
<u>'''Sāṃjīvī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of Sāṃjīvī,’ is the name of a teacher who appears in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the tenth Kāṇḍa of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1657> x. 6, 5, 9.</ref> and at the end of the fourteenth Kāṇḍa in the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] recension,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1657> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 5. 4 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> as a pupil of '''[[माण्डूकायनि|Māṇḍūkāyani]].''' In the Vaṃśas at the end of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] in both recensions<ref name=fx3_ve2_1657> ''Ibid.,'' vi. 4, 32 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, xxxiv ''et seq.;<br>'' Wéber, ''Indian Literature,'' 131.</ref> he is given as a pupil of '''[[प्राश्नीपुत्र|Prāśnīputra]] [[आसुरिवासिन्|Āsurivāsin]].''' It seems clear that he united in himself two lines of teachers--that of the tradition of the firecult from '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]],''' and that of the tradition of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]].'''

साति औष्ट्राक्षि
<u>'''Sāti Auṣṭrākṣi'''</u> (‘descendant of Uṣṭrākṣa’) is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1658> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

सात्य-कामि
<u>'''Sātya-kāmi'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[सत्यकाम|Satyakāma]]'''’) is the patronymic of '''[[केशिन्|Keśin]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (ii. 6, 2, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

सात्य-कीर्त
<u>'''Sātya-kīrta'''</u> is the name of a school of teachers mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 32, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

सात्य-यज्ञ
<u>'''Sātya-yajña'''</u> (‘descendant of Saryayajña’) is the name of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 1, 1, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

सात्य-यज्ञि
<u>'''1. Sātya-yajñi'''</u> (‘descendant of Satyayajña’) is the patronymic of '''Somaśuṣma''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 6, 2, 1. 3; xiii. 4, 2, 4; 5, 3, 9). <br>==Foot Notes==

सात्य-यज्ञि
<u>'''2. Sātya-yajñi'''</u> is the name of a school of teachers mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ii. 4, 5) with the '''Śailanas''' and the '''Kārīradis.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सात्य-हव्य
<u>'''Sātya-havya'''</u> (‘descendant of Satyahavya’) is the patronymic of a '''[[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]]''' who is mentioned as a contemporary of '''[[अत्य्अराति जानंतपि|Atyarāti Jānaṃtapi]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 23, 9), and of '''[[देवभाग|Devabhāga]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vi. 6, 2, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

सात्राजित
<u>'''Sātrājita'''</u> (‘descendant of Satrājit’) is the patronymic of '''Śatānīka.'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1665> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 21, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 19. 21.</ref>

सात्रा-साह
<u>'''Sātrā-sāha'''</u> (‘descendant of Satrāsāha’) is the patronymic of '''Śoṇa.'''<br><br>^1 Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 16, 18.<br>==Foot Notes==

सादिन्
<u>'''Sādin'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1667> xi. 10, 24.</ref> denotes the ‘rider’ of a horse as opposed to ''a-sāda,'' ‘pedestrian.’ An ''[[अश्व|aśva]]-[[सादिन्|sādin]],'' ‘horse-rider,’ is known to the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1667> xxx. 13.</ref> The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1667> iii. 4, 7, 1.</ref> and the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1667> i. 162, 17;<br> v. 61, 3. ''Cf.'' i. 163, 9.</ref> itself contain clear references to horse-riding, while the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx5_ve2_1667> i. 2, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 3, 2, 17.</ref> refers to mounting a horse sideways. Āśvalāyana<ref name=fx6_ve2_1667> [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 9, 14.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 230, 295, 296;<br> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 358;<br> Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 177;<br> Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1898, 564.</ref> knows ''sādya'' as a ‘riding horse’ opposed to ''[[वह्य|vahya]],'' a ‘draught animal.’

साधारणी
<u>'''Sādhāraṇī'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1668> i. 167, 4.</ref> seems to refer not so much to an ''uxor communis,'' like Draupadī in the Epic, as Max Müller<ref name=fx2_ve2_1668> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 277.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 332;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 461;<br> Pischel and Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xxv.</ref> suggests, but to a courtezan. 

साप्त
<u>'''Sāpta'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1669> viii. 55, 5. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 5, 552;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 266.</ref> may be a proper name, but the sense is quite uncertain.

साप्तरथ-वाहनि
<u>'''Sāptaratha-vāhani'''</u> (‘descendant of Saptarathavāhana’) is the patronymic of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]],''' in the '''Śatapatha''' [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1670> x. 1, 4, 10. 11. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 259, n.</ref>

साप्य
<u>'''Sāpya'''</u> or '''[[साय्य|Sāyya]]''' is the patronymic of '''Namī''' in the Rigveda (vi. 20, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

साम-वेद
<u>'''Sāma-veda,'''</u> ‘the Veda of the Sāman chants,’ is the name of a collection of verses for chanting, often mentioned in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1672> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 9, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 32, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 8, 3;<br> xii. 3, 4, 9;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 3;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 5, 13 (Mādhyaṃdina = i. 5, 5 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 6 (= iv. 1, 2);<br> 5, 11;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 3, 7;<br> iii. 3, 1. 2;<br> 15, 7;<br> vii. 1, 2. 4;<br> 2, 1;<br> 7, 1, etc.</ref> The Sāman itself is repeatedly referred to in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1672> i. 62, 2;<br> 107, 2;<br> 164, 24, etc. ''Cf.''
