Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 38, 439 ''et seq.''</ref> and the triad Ṛc, [[यजुस्|Yajus]], and Sāman is common from the Atharvaveda onwards.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1672> x. 7, 14;<br> xi. 7, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxxiv. 5, etc.</ref> These texts know also the Sāma-ga, the ‘Sāman-chanter,’<ref name=fx4_ve2_1672> Rv. ii. 43, 1;<br> x. 107, 6;<br> Av. ii. 12, 4.</ref> who occurs later.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1672> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 22, 3;<br> 37, 4;<br> iii. 4, 1.</ref>

साम-श्रवस्
<u>'''Sāma-śravas'''</u> (‘famed for chants’) occurs in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1673> iii. 1, 3.</ref> According to Max Müller,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1673> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 15, 121.</ref> the word is an epithet of '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]],''' but Bo7htlingk<ref name=fx3_ve2_1673> Translation, 36.</ref> takes it as the name of a pupil of that teacher.

साम-श्रवस
<u>'''Sāma-śravasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[सामश्रवस्|Sāmaśravas]]'''’) is the patronymic of '''[[कुषीतक|Kuṣītaka]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xvii. 4, 3). <br>==Foot Notes==

सामुद्रि
<u>'''Sāmudri'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[सम्उद्र|Samudra]]'''’) is the name of a mythical sage, [[अश्व|Aśva]], in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 2, 2, 14).<br>==Foot Notes==

सांमद
<u>'''Sāṃmada'''</u> (‘descendant of Saṃmada’) is the patronymic of the mythical [[मत्स्य|Matsya]] in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 4, 3, 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

साम्राज्य
<u>'''Sāmrājya.'''</u> See '''[[सम्राज्|Samrāj]]''' and '''[[राज्य|Rājya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

साय
<u>'''Sāya'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1678> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 3, 3;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 3, 2, 18.</ref> denotes ‘evening’ in the Rigveda and later, usually appearing in the adverbial form Sāyam,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1678> Rv. v. 77, 2;<br> x. 146, 4;<br> Av. iii. 12, 3;<br> iv. 11, 12;<br> viii. 6, 10, etc. ''Cf. Sāyaṃprātar,'' ‘morning and evening,’ Av. iii. 30, 7;<br> xix. 39, 2, etc.</ref> ‘in the evening.’ ''Cf.'' '''Ahar.'''

सायक
<u>'''1. Sāyaka'''</u> denotes ‘arrow’ in the '''Rigveda''' (ii. 33, 10; iii. 53, 23; x. 48, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

सायक जान-श्रुतेय
<u>'''2. Sāyaka [[जान|Jāna]]-śruteya'''</u> (‘descendant of Janaśruta’) '''[[काण्ड्विय|Kāṇḍviya]]''' is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[जनश्रुत|Janaśruta]] [[काण्ड्विय|Kāṇḍviya]],''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

सायकायन
<u>'''Sāyakāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[सायक|Sāyaka]]'''’) is the patronymic of '''Śyāparṇa''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1681> x. 3, 6, 10;<br> 5, 2, 1.</ref> and also of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[कौशिकायनि|Kauśikāyani]]''' in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1681> iv. 5, 27 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

साय्य
<u>'''Sāyya.'''</u> See '''[[साप्य|Sāpya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सारथि
<u>'''Sārathi'''</u> denotes the ‘charioteer’ as opposed to the warrior ('''[[सव्यष्ठा|Savyaṣṭhā]]''') in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1683> i. 55, 7;<br> 144, 3;<br> ii. 19, 6;<br> vi. 20, 5;<br> 57, 6;<br> x. 102, 6.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1683> Av. xv. 2, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 9, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 8, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 296.</ref> 

सारमेय
<u>'''Sārameya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Saramā,’ Indra's mythical dog, is applied to a dog on earth in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1684> vii. 55, 2 (unless that passage be deemed to refer to the souls of the departed).</ref> as also to the dogs of Yama.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1684> x. 14, 10.</ref>

सार्ञ्जय
<u>'''Sārñjaya'''</u> is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1685> vi. 47, 25.</ref> in a Dānastuti (‘praise of gifts’) where the word probably denotes the ‘'''[[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]]''' king’ rather than a ‘descendant of [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]].’ According to the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1685> xvi. 11, 11.</ref> he was '''[[प्रस्तोक|Prastoka]],''' mentioned, in the same hymn, but this conclusion is not very cogent. He was clearly a patron of the '''Bharadvājas.''' The same epithet belongs to '''[[सहदेव|Sahadeva]],''' ''alias'' '''Suplan.'''<br><br>^3 Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 4; xii. 8, 2, 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 104, 105.

सार्प-राज्ञी
<u>'''Sārpa-rājñī'''</u> in the Pañcaviṃśa (iv. 9, 4) and the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] (xxvii. 4) Brāhmaṇas is identical with '''[[सर्पराज्ञी|Sarparājñī]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सार्व-सेनि
<u>'''Sārva-seni'''</u> (‘descendant of Sarvasena’) is the patronymic of '''[[शौचेय|Śauceya]]''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vii. 1, 10, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

साला-वृक
<u>'''Sālā-vṛka'''</u> is found twice in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1688> x. 73, 2;<br> 95, 15.</ref> apparently denoting the ‘hyæna’ or ‘wild dog.’ This sense also seems appropriate in the later narrative of the destruction of the '''Yatis''' by Indra,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1688> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 7, 5;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 28, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1 (''varia lectio'').</ref> who is said to have handed them over to the Sālāvṛkas. Sālāvṛkeya<ref name=fx3_ve2_1688> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 1, 4;<br> xiii. 4, 16;<br> xiv. 11, 28;<br> xviii. 1, 9;<br> xix. 4, 7;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 185 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 123);<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 5;<br> xi. 10;<br> xxv. 6;<br> xxxvi. 7 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 465, 466);<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1 (according to Śaṅkarānanda's recension). In Av. ii. 27, 5, Indra is alluded to as an enemy of the Sālāvṛkas.</ref> is a variant form of the same word, meaning literally ‘descendant of a [[सालावृक|Sālāvṛka]].’ The feminine is Sālāvṛkī,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1688> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 4.</ref> but in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx5_ve2_1688> vi. 2, 7, 5;<br> also in Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8, 3;<br> Āpastamba [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 10, 17;<br> 11, 33.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 81;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 192;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 68;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 306, who decides in favour of ‘jackal.’</ref> it appears as [[सलावृकी|Salāvṛkī]]. ''Cf.'' '''[[तरक्षु|Tarakṣu]].''' 

सावयस
<u>'''Sāvayasa'''</u> (‘descendant of Savayasa’) is the patronymic of Aṣāḍha, or Āṣāḍha, in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 1, 1, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

सा-वर्णि
<u>'''Sā-varṇi'''</u> is found as a patronymic in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1690> x. 62, 11.</ref> together with Sāvarṇya.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1690> x. 62, 9.</ref> It is clear that no man called Savarṇa ever existed, though Roth<ref name=fx3_ve2_1690> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 17.</ref> accepted that view, and that the reference is to the mythical '''Manu''' [[सावर्णि|Sāvarṇi]], the descendant of the ''sa-varṇā'' female, who, according to the legend,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1690> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society'' 15, 179 ''et seq.''</ref> took the place of Saraṇyū.

सिंह
<u>'''Siṃha'''</u> denotes the ‘lion’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1691> i. 64, 8;<br> 95, 5;<br> iii. 2, 11;<br> 9, 4;<br> 26, 5;<br> iv. 16, 14, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1691> Av. iv. 36, 6;<br> v. 20, 1, 2;<br> 21, 6;<br> viii. 7, 15;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 21, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 10, etc.;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 9;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], 1, 2.</ref> The roaring (''nad'') of the lion is often alluded to,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1691/> and is called thundering (''stanatha'').<ref name=fx4_ve2_1691> Rv. v. 83, 3;<br> Av. v. 21, 6;<br> viii. 7, 15.</ref> He wanders about (''ku-cara'') and lives in the hills (''giri-ṣṭha''),<ref name=fx5_ve2_1691> Rv. i. 154, 2;<br> x. 160, 2.</ref> and is clearly the ‘dread wild beast that slays’ (''mṛgo bhīma upahatnuḥ'')<ref name=fx6_ve2_1691> Rv. ii. 33, 11.</ref> to which Rudra is compared. When Agni, who has entered the waters, is compared to a lion,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1691> Rv. iii. 9, 4.</ref> the reference may be to the lion's habit of springing on animals at drinking places. That a jackal should defeat the lion is spoken of as a marvel.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1691> Rv. x. 28, 4.</ref> The lion, being dangerous to men,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1691> Rv. i. 174, 3.</ref> was trapped,<ref name=fx10_ve2_1691> Rv. x. 28, 10.</ref> lain in wait for in ambush,<ref name=fx11_ve2_1691> Rv. v. 74, 4.</ref> or chased by hunting bands.<ref name=fx12_ve2_1691> Rv. v. 15, 3. ''Cf.'' Strabo, xv, 1, 31.</ref> But dogs were terrified of lions.<ref name=fx13_ve2_1691> Av. v. 36, 6.</ref> The liones (''siṃhī'') was also famous for her courage: the aid given by Indra to '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]]''' against the vast host of his enemies is compared to the defeat of a lioness by a ram ('''[[पेत्व|Petva]]''').<ref name=fx14_ve2_1691> Rv. vii. 18, 17.</ref> The gaping jaws of the lioness when attacking men are alluded to in  the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx15_ve2_1691> vi. 35, 1.</ref> The lioness is also mentioned in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx16_ve2_1691> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 2, 12, 2;<br> vi. 2, 7, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, v. 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 1, 21;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 8, 5.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 78, 79.</ref> See also '''Halīkṣṇa.'''

सिच्
<u>'''1. Sic'''</u> denotes the ‘border’ of a garment. The Rigveda refers to a son clutching the hem of his father's robe to attract his attention,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1692> iii. 53, 2.</ref> and to a mother's covering her son with the edge of her garment.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1692> x. 18, 11.</ref> The word also occurs later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1692> Av. xiv. 2, 51;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 18.</ref>

सिच्
<u>'''2. Sic'''</u> denotes, in the dual, the ‘wings’ of an army,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1693> Rv. x. 75, 4.</ref> or, in the plural, the ‘lines.’(**  2) Av. xi. 9, 18; 10, 20.<br><br>''Cf.'' Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 65; Geldner, ''ibid.,'' 3, 31.

सिच्
<u>'''3. Sic'''</u> seems in one passage of the Rigveda (i. 95, 7), where it is used in the dual, to denote the ‘horizon’ (meaning literally the ‘two borders’; ''i.e.,'' of heaven and of earth).<br>==Foot Notes==

सिध्मल
<u>'''Sidhmala,'''</u> ‘leprous,’ is found in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxx. 17) and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 4, 14, 1) as a designation of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’). ''Cf.'' '''[[किलास|Kilāsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सिनीवाली
<u>'''Sinīvālī'''</u> denotes the day of new moon and its presiding spirit, which, in accordance with widespread ideas concerning the connexion of the moon and vegetation, is one of fertility and growth. It occurs very frequently from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1696> ii. 32, 7, 8;<br> x. 184, 2.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1696> Av. ii. 26, 2;<br> vi. 11, 3;<br> ix. 4, 14;<br> xiv. 2, 15;<br> xix. 31, 10;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 6, 2;<br> iii. 4, 9, 1. 6;<br> v. 5, 17, 1;<br> 6, 18, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxv. 2, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 352;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 125.</ref> 

सिन्धु
<u>'''Sindhu'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1697> i. 97, 8;<br> 125, 5;<br> ii. 11, 9;<br> 25, 3, 5;<br> iii. 53, 9, etc.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1697> iii. 13, 1;<br> iv. 24, 2;<br> x. 4, 15;<br> xiii. 3, 50, etc.</ref> often means ‘stream’ merely (''cf.'' '''[[सप्त सिन्धवः|Sapta Sindhavaḥ]]'''), but it has also<ref name=fx3_ve2_1697> Rv. i. 122, 6;<br> 126, 1;<br> iv. 54, 6;<br> 55, 3;<br> v. 53, 9;<br> vii. 95, 1;<br> viii. 12, 3;<br> 25, 14;<br> 20, 25;<br> 26, 18;<br> x. 64, 9;<br> Av. xii. 1, 3;<br> xiv. 1, 43;<br> perhaps also vi. 24, 1;<br> vii. 45, 1;<br> xix. 38, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, viii. 59.</ref> the more exact sense of ‘the stream’ ''par excellence,'' ‘the Indus.’ The name is, however, rarely mentioned after the period of the Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1697> The [[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]-Sauvīras occur in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 2, 14. ''Cf.'' Bühler, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 14, 148;<br> Oldenberg, ''Buddha,'' 394, n.</ref> always then occurring in such a way as to suggest distance. The horses from the Indus (''[[सैन्धव|saindhava]]'') were famous.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1697> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 2, 15 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 1, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 16, 17, 27.</ref> See '''[[सैन्धव|Saindhava]].''' ''Cf.'' also '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].'''

सिन्धु-क्षित्
<u>'''Sindhu-kṣit'''</u> is the name of a long-banished but finally restored '''[[राजन्यर्षि|Rājanyarṣi]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1698> xii. 12, 6.</ref> probably quite a mythical personage.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1698> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 235, n. 3.</ref>

सिरी
<u>'''Sirī'''</u> in the Rigveda (x. 71, 9) seems to denote a ‘female weaver.’<br>==Foot Notes==

सिलाची
<u>'''Silācī'''</u> is, in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1700> v. 5, 1, 8. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 419;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 228.</ref> the name of a healing plant, also called '''[[लाक्षा|Lākṣā]].'''

सिलाञ्जाला
<u>'''Silāñjālā,'''</u> which the commentator reads as Śalāñjālā, is the name of a plant, perhaps a ‘grain creeper,’ in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1701> vi. 16, 4.</ref> The [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1701> ii. 16. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 466;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 292, 293.</ref> reads the word as Śilāñjālā. ''Cf.'' '''Silāeī.''' 

सीचापू
<u>'''Sīcāpū'''</u> in the list of victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1702> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 19, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 25. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 94.</ref> seems to denote a kind of bird.

सीता
<u>'''Sītā,'''</u> ‘furrow,’ occurs in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1703> iv. 57, 6. 7 (the most agricultural of Rigvedic hymns, and probably late).</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1703> Av. xi. 3, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 5, 4. 5;<br> 6, 2, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xx. 3, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 86, n.</ref>

सीमन्
<u>'''Sīman'''</u> denotes the ‘parting’ of the hair in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1704> ix. 8, 13.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1704> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 7, 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 1;<br> xv. 5, 20;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 4, 1, 14. ''Cf. sīmanta'' in Av. vi. 134, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 17, 3.</ref>

सीर
<u>'''Sīra,'''</u> ‘plough,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1705> iv. 57, 8;<br> x. 101, 3, 4.</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1705> Av. vi. 30, 1;<br> 91, 1;<br> viii. 9, 16, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 1, 2;<br> ii. 5, 8, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 11, 4.</ref> It was large and heavy, as is shown by the fact that six oxen,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1705> Av. vi. 91, 1;<br> viii. 9, 16;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 2, 5, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2;<br> xx. 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 2, 2, 6;<br> xiii. 8, 2, 6.</ref> or eight,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1705> Av. vi. 91, 1.</ref> or twelve,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1705> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 7, 1;<br> v. 2, 5, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 2, etc.</ref> or even twenty-four,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1705> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 2. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 244. n. 1.</ref> were used to drag it. The animals which drew the plough were oxen, which were, no doubt, yoked and harnessed with traces.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1705> '''[[वरत्रा|Varatrā]]''' is found in Rv. iv. 57, 4, and (of the ox in the '''[[मुद्गल|Mudgala]]''' story) in x. 102, 8. It may denote the fastening of the ox to the yoke rather than to the plough by traces.</ref> The ox was guided by the '''[[अष्ट्रा|Aṣṭrā]],''' or ‘goad,’ of the ploughman (''cf.'' '''[[वैश्य|Vaiśya]]''').<ref name=fx8_ve2_1705> ''Cf.'' Rv. iv. 57, 4;<br> x. 102, 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 236, 237.</ref> Little is known of the parts of the plough. See '''[[लाङ्गल|Lāṅgala]]''' and '''[[फाल|Phāla]].'''

सील
<u>'''Sīla,'''</u> ‘plough,’ is found in the Kapiṣṭhala Saṃhitā (xxviii. 8). <br>==Foot Notes==

सीलमावती
<u>'''Sīlamāvatī'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1707> x. 75, 8.</ref> is, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1707> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200.</ref> the name of a river; but this is most improbable.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1707> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 429;<br> Bo7htlingk, Dictionary, ''s.v.;<br>'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 195.</ref> Sāyaṇa thinks the word means ‘rich in hemp.’

सीस
<u>'''Sīsa,'''</u> ‘lead,’ occurs first in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1708> xii. 2, 1. 19 ''et seq.,'' 53.</ref> where it is mentioned as used for amulets.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1708> i. 16, 2, 4.</ref> The word is then quite common.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1708> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xviii. 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 6, 5;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 2, 14;<br> 4, 1, 9;<br> xii. 7, 1, 7;<br> 2, 10;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 17, 7, etc.</ref> The use of lead by the weaver as a weight is perhaps also referred to.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1708> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 80;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 9;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 4. This is the view of Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and of Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 53. But Griffith, Translation of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, 183, n., thinks that in xix. 80 lead is referred to not as a weight, but as a charm against demons and sorcery.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 157, 158.</ref>

सु-कन्या
<u>'''Su-kanyā'''</u> is the name of '''Śaryāta's''' daughter, who married '''[[च्यवन|Cyavana]]''' according to the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1709> iv. 1, 5, 6;<br> 10, 13;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 121 ''et seq.''</ref>

सु-कपर्द
<u>'''Su-kaparda.'''</u> See '''[[कपर्द|Kaparda]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-करीर
<u>'''Su-karīra'''</u> in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā (ii. 7, 5) is a misreading of ''[[सु-कुरीर|su-kurīra]].'' See '''[[कुरीर|Kurīra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-कीर्ति काक्षीवत
<u>'''Su-kīrti Kākṣīvata'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]]'''’) is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] to whom the Brāhmaṇas of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1712> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 15, 4;<br> vi. 29, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxx. 5.</ref> ascribe the authorship of a Vedic hymn.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1712> x. 131.</ref>

सु-केशिन् भारद्वाज
<u>'''Su-[[केशिन्|keśin]] Bhāradvāja'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]]'''’) is the name of a teacher in the [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (i. 1). <br>==Foot Notes==

सु-कुरीर
<u>'''Su-kurīra.'''</u> See '''[[कुरीर|Kurīra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-ख
<u>'''Su-kha.'''</u> See '''Kha.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सुगन्धि-तेजन
<u>'''Sugandhi-tejana'''</u> in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1716> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 8, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 6.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx2_ve2_1716> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 28, 28;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 5, 2, 17;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 13, 5.</ref> denotes a kind of fragrant grass.

सु-चित्त शैलन
<u>'''Su-citta Śailana'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 14, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-जात
<u>'''Su-jāta,'''</u> ‘well-born,’ is an epithet found applied to men in a few passages of the Rigveda. It would probably be a mistake to press the sense so as to denote ‘nobles’ as compared with the people. See '''[[सभा|Sabhā]].'''<br><br>^1 ii. 2, 11; v. 6, 2; vii. 1, 4. 15; viii. 20, 8.<br>==Foot Notes==

सुतं-भर
<u>'''Sutaṃ-bhara'''</u> is credited by the '''Anukramaṇī''' (Index) with the authorship of certain hymns of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1719> v. 11-14.</ref> The word does not occur in those hymns, but it appears as an adjective (‘carrying away Soma’) elsewhere,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1719> v. 44, 13.</ref> and may, in a second passage,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1719> ix. 6, 6.</ref> by a conjecture<ref name=fx4_ve2_1719> If ''sutaṃ-bharāya'' be read for ''sutdṃ bhárāya,'' as Roth suggests in the St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> be taken as a man's name.

सुत्वन् कैरिशि भार्गायण
<u>'''Sutvan [[कैरिशि|Kairiśi]] Bhārgāyaṇa'''</u> is, in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 28, 18), the name of a king who, being taught a spell by '''[[मैत्रेय|Maitreya]] [[कौषारव|Kauṣārava]],''' slew five kings and became great.<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-दक्षिण क्षैमि
<u>'''Su-dakṣiṇa Kṣaimi'''</u> (‘descendant of Kṣema’) is the name of a teacher in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 6, 3; 7, 1 ''et seq.;'' 8, 6). <br>==Foot Notes==

सु-दत्त पाराशर्य
<u>'''Su-datta Pārāśarya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[पराशर|Parāśara]]'''’) is in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 41, 1; iv. 17, 1) the name of a teacher who was a pupil of '''[[जनश्रुत|Janaśruta]] [[वारक्य|Vārakya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-दामन्
<u>'''Su-dāman'''</u> is the name of a river in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxii. 18, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-दास्
<u>'''Su-dās'''</u> is the name of the '''[[तृत्सु|Tṛtsu]]''' king who won a famous victory over the ten kings, as described in a hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1724> vii. 18. See also Rv. vii. 20, 2;<br> 25, 3;<br> 32, 10;<br> 33, 3;<br> 64, 3;<br> 83, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> At one time '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' was his '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]],''' and accompanied him in his victorious raids over the '''[[विपाश्|Vipāś]]''' (Beās) and '''[[शुतुद्री|Śutudrī]]''' (Sutlej).<ref name=fx2_ve2_1724> Rv. iii. 53, 9, 11. See also '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]]''' and '''Vaṣiṣṭha.'''</ref> The Aśvins gave him a queen, '''[[सुदेवी|Sudevī]],'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1724> Rv. i. 112, 19.</ref> and also helped him on another occasion.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1724> Rv. i. 47, 9, where, however, Roth, St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1, takes ''[[सु-दास्|su-dās]]'' as an adjective (‘worshipping well’).</ref> He appears with '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]]''' in a late hymn without hint of rivalry,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1724> Rv. vii. 19, 3.</ref> but elsewhere he seems to be referred to as defeated by '''[[पुरुकुत्स|Purukutsa]],''' Trasadasyu's father.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1724> Rv. i. 63, 7, reading ''Sudāsam'' for ''Sudāse'' with Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 174. ''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 112, n. 1;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 153;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 63.</ref> In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx7_ve2_1724> vii. 34, 9.</ref> he is recognized as a great king, with '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]]''' as his Puro hita, and similarly in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]],<ref name=fx8_ve2_1724> xvi. 11, 14.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 107 ''et seq.;<br>'' Weber, ''Episches im vedischen Ritual,'' 31 ''et seq.''</ref> where his generosity to his priest is related.<br><br>His exact ancestry is a little uncertain, because he is called '''[[पैजवन|Paijavana]],''' ‘son of [[पिजवन|Pijavana]],’ as [[यास्क|Yāska]] explains the patronymic. If this explanation is correct, '''Divodāsa''' must have been his grandfather. If he was the son of Divodāsa, [[पिजवन|Pijavana]] must be understood as a more remote ancestor. The former alternative seems the more probable. ''Cf.'' '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]], [[दाशराज्ञ|Dāśarājña]]. [[पैजवन|Paijavana]], [[भरत|Bharata]], [[सौदास|Saudāsa]].'''

सु-देव
<u>'''1. Su-deva'''</u> is, according to Ludwig,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1725> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 160.</ref> the proper name of a sacrificer in one hymn of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1725> viii. 5, 6.</ref> 

सु-देव काश्यप
<u>'''2. Su-deva Kāśyapa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[कश्यप|Kaśyapa]]'''’) is the name of a teacher in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve2_1726> ii. 18. ''Cf.'' x. 1, 8;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 188, n.;<br> 10, 103.</ref> who set forth the expiation for lack of chastity.

सु-देवला
<u>'''Su-devalā'''</u> was the name of '''[[ऋतुपर्ण|Ṛtuparṇa]]''' as a woman according to the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xx. 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-देवी
<u>'''Su-devī.'''</u> See '''Sudas.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-धन्वन् आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Su-[[धन्वन्|dhanvan]] Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the name of a teacher in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 3, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-नीथ शौचद्-रथ
<u>'''1. Su-[[नीथ|nītha]] Śaucad-ratha'''</u> (‘descendant of Śucadratha’) is the name of a man in the Rigveda (v. 79, 2). ''Cf.'' '''[[सत्यश्रवस्|Satyaśravas]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-नीथ कापटव
<u>'''2. Su-[[नीथ|nītha]] Kāpaṭava'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1731> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

सु-पर्ण
<u>'''1. Su-parṇa,'''</u> ‘well-winged,’ designates a large bird of prey, the ‘eagle’ or the ‘vulture,’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1732> i. 164, 20;<br> ii. 42, 2;<br> iv. 26, 4;<br> viii. 100, 8;<br> ix. 48, 3, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1732> Av. i. 24, 1;<br> ii. 27. 2;<br> 30, 3;<br> iv. 6, 3, etc.;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 5, 8, 5, etc.</ref> In the passages in which it appears as an eater of carrion<ref name=fx3_ve2_1732> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 9, 19;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka, iv. 29.</ref> it must be the vulture. The Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1732> ii. 438 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 101).</ref> mentions an eagle which separates milk from water like the '''[[क्रुञ्च्|Kruñc]].''' In the Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_1732> x. 144, 4.</ref> the [[सुपर्ण|Suparṇa]] is said to be the child of the '''[[श्येन|Śyena]],''' and is distinguished from the latter in another passage:<ref name=fx6_ve2_1732> ii. 42, 2.</ref> this led Zimmer<ref name=fx7_ve2_1732> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 88.</ref> to think that the falcon is probably meant.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1732> In the post-Vedic period [[सुपर्ण|Suparṇa]] became a mythical bird, identified with Viṣnu's vehicle, Garuḍa, who, however, is also regarded as king of the Suparṇas.</ref> The Atharvaveda alludes to its cry,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1732> ii. 30, 3.</ref> and describes it as living in the hills.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1732> v. 4, 2.</ref> 

सुपर्ण
<u>'''2. Suparṇa'''</u> is personified in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1733> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 3, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxix. 7.</ref> as a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]].

सु-पित्र्य
<u>'''Su-pitrya,'''</u> a word occurring once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1734> x. 115, 6.</ref> is probably an adjective (‘maintaining his paternal character well’). Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1734> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 169.</ref> however, regards it, but without any great probability, as a proper name.

सु-प्रतीत औलुण्ड्य
<u>'''Su-pratīta Auluṇḍya'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''Bṛhaspatigupta,''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1735> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

सुप्लन् सार्ञ्जय
<u>'''Suplan Sārñjaya'''</u> is the name of a prince of the '''Sṛñjayas''' who was taught the [[दाक्षायण|Dākṣāyaṇa]] sacrifice by '''Pratīdarśa,''' and took the name of '''[[सहदेव|Sahadeva]]''' as a token of his success.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1736> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 4, 4;<br> xii. 8, 2, 3. ''Cf.'' Lévi, ''La Doctrine du Sacrifice,'' 139;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105, 106.</ref>

सु-बन्धु
<u>'''Su-bandhu'''</u> in the hymns of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1737> x. 59, 8;<br> 60, 7, 10.</ref> is taken by Sāyaṇa to be a proper name; but this is not certain, Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1737> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1.</ref> seeing in the passages only an ordinary noun meaning ‘a good friend.’ The later tradition<ref name=fx3_ve2_1737> Bṛhaddevatā, vii. 83 ''et seq.,'' with Macdonell's notes. See also '''Asamāti,''' n. 1.</ref> explains that [[सुबन्धु|Subandhu]] and his brothers, called '''Gaupāyanas,''' were priests of '''Asamāti,''' who cast them off and took two others, '''[[किरात|Kirāta]]''' and '''[[आकुलि|Ākuli]].''' By these two in pigeon form [[सुबन्धु|Subandhu]] was caused to swoon, but was revived by his three brothers, who recited certain hymns.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1737> Rv. x. 57-60.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 2, 420-455;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 39, 90.</ref>

सु-ब्रह्मण्य
<u>'''Su-brahmaṇya'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1738> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 4, 6;<br> 18, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 4, 9. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 362, 374.</ref> denotes a priest who officiates as one of the three assistants of the Udgātṛ (see '''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]'''). His office is Subrahmaṇyā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1738> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 3, 1-7. 11, 12;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvii. 6, etc. The priest himself is so styled, [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 1, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xviii. 9, 19, etc.</ref> 

सु-भगा
<u>'''Su-bhagā,'''</u> in the vocative ''subhage,'' is a frequent form of courteous address to women from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1739> Rv. x. 10, 10. 12;<br> 108, 5;<br> Av. v. 5, 6;<br> vi. 30, 3, etc.</ref>

सु-भद्रिका
<u>'''Su-bhadrikā'''</u> occurs in the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) section of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1740> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 18 (''cf.'' Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 8, 3);<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 12, 20.</ref> as in some way connected with the rite. Weber<ref name=fx2_ve2_1740> ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 183, 184;<br> ''Indian Literature,'' 114, 115. ''Cf.'' Griffith, Translation of the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, 212, n.</ref> thinks that a proper name, that of the wife of the king of '''[[काम्पील|Kāmpīla]],''' is intended, but Mahīdhara<ref name=fx3_ve2_1740> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> explains the word merely as a lady with many lovers or a courtezan, a view followed by Roth.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1740> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v. subhadraka,'' 2''b;<br>'' Bo7htlingk's Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2''a.''</ref> Since the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]]<ref name=fx5_ve2_1740> vii. 4, 19, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 6.</ref> and [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1740> ''[[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]],'' iv. 8.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 36, 37;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 321, 322.</ref> Saṃhitās have no [[सुभद्रिका|Subhadrikā]], but a vocative ''subhage'' (see '''[[सुभगा|Subhagā]]'''), the sense remains very doubtful.

सुमति-त्सरु
<u>'''Sumati-tsaru.'''</u> See '''[[त्सरु|Tsaru]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-मन्त्र बाभ्रव
<u>'''Su-[[मन्त्र|mantra]] Bābhrava'''</u> (‘descendant of Babhru’) '''[[गौतम|Gautama]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[गोतम|Gotama]]'''’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[शूष वाह्नेय|Śūṣa Vāhneya]] [[भारद्वाज|Bhāradvāja]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1742> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

सु-मित्र वाध्र्यस्व
<u>'''Su-[[मित्र|mitra]] Vādhryasva'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[वध्र्य्अश्व|Vadhryaśva]]'''’) is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1743> x. 69, 3. 5.</ref> where also<ref name=fx2_ve2_1743> x. 69, 1, 7, 8. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133.</ref> the '''Sumitras,''' his family, are mentioned.

सु-मीळ्ह
<u>'''Su-mīḷha'''</u> is the name of a patron in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1744> vi. 63, 9. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158.</ref> 

सु-मेध
<u>'''Su-medha'''</u> occurs in an obscure hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1745> x. 132, 7. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 133;<br> Griffith, ''Hymns of the Rigveda,'' 2, 579, n.</ref> either as an adjective (‘of good understanding’) or a proper name, perhaps identical with '''[[नृमेध|Nṛmedha]]''' or his brother.

सुम्न-यु
<u>'''Sumna-yu'''</u> is mentioned in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (xv. 1) as a pupil of '''Uddālaka.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-यज्ञ शाण्डिल्य
<u>'''Su-yajña Śāṇḍilya'''</u> is the name of a pupil of '''[[कंस|Kaṃsa]] [[वारक्य|Vārakya]]''' in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iv. 17, 1). Another Suyajña is a '''[[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]],''' author of the [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-यवस
<u>'''Su-yavasa'''</u> denotes a ‘good pasture’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1748> i. 42, 8;<br> vi. 28, 7;<br> vii. 18, 4, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1748> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 7, 5, 2, etc.</ref>

सुरा
<u>'''Surā'''</u> is the name of an intoxicating ‘spirituous liquor,’ often mentioned in Vedic literature. In some passages<ref name=fx1_ve2_1749> Rv. i. 116, 7;<br> x. 131, 4, 5. ''Cf.'' Av. iv. 34, 6;<br> x. 6, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 3, 3, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 3, 8.</ref> it is referred to favourably, in others with decided disapproval.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1749> Rv. vii. 86, 6;<br> viii. 2, 12;<br> 21, 14;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, i. 11, 6;<br> ii. 4, 2;<br> iv. 2, 1, etc.</ref> It is classed with the use of meat and with dicing as an evil in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1749> vi. 70, 1. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 493.</ref> and often with dicing.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1749> Rv. vii. 86, 6;<br> Av. xiv. 1, 35. 36;<br> xv. 9, 1. 2.</ref> It was, as opposed to '''Soma,''' essentially a drink of ordinary life.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1749> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 3, 2.</ref> It was the drink of men in the '''[[सभा|Sabhā]],'''<ref name=fx6_ve2_1749> See n. 4.</ref> and gave rise to broils.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1749> Rv. viii. 2, 12;<br> 21, 14. ''Cf.'' [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xiv. 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 2, etc.</ref><br><br>Its exact nature is not certain. It may have been a strong spirit prepared from fermented grains and plants, as Eggeling<ref name=fx8_ve2_1749> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 223, n. 2;<br> Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 21, n. 1;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 280, 281. ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xix. 1, 20-27;<br> Mahīdhara on Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 1.</ref>  holds, or, as Whitney<ref name=fx9_ve2_1749> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 207. ''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 326.</ref> thought, a kind of beer or ale. Geldner<ref name=fx10_ve2_1749> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 198.</ref> renders it ‘brandy.’ It is sometimes mentioned in connexion with '''[[मधु|Madhu]].'''<ref name=fx11_ve2_1749> Av. vi. 69, 1;<br> ix. 1, 18, 19;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 95. See Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 251, who attempts to show that [[सुरा|Surā]] and Soma were rival priestly drinks at one time, belonging to different sections of the people.</ref> It was kept in skins.<ref name=fx12_ve2_1749> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 11, 26. ''Cf.'' Rv. i. 191, 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 121.</ref>

सुरा-कार
<u>'''Surā-kāra,'''</u> ‘maker of '''[[सुरा|Surā]],'''’ is included in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1750> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 7, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 281, who compares Rv. i. 191, 10, which may refer to such a person.</ref>

सु-राधस्
<u>'''Su-rādhas'''</u> is the name of a man in the Rigveda (i. 100, 17). where he is mentioned with '''[[अम्बरीष|Ambarīṣa]]''' and others.<br>==Foot Notes==

सुराम
<u>'''Surāma'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1752> x. 131, 5.</ref> refers to the illness caused by drinking '''[[सुरा|Surā]]''' to excess. Indra is described as suffering from it in the Namuci legend.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1752> Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 148 ''et seq.''</ref> Later [[सुराम|Surāma]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1752> Or Surāman. ''Cf.'' Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 42;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 4;<br> iv. 12, 5. Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 245 ''et seq.,'' renders it ‘Surā mixed,’ which is doubtful.</ref> was treated as an epithet of '''Soma,''' meaning ‘delightful.’

सु-वर्ण
<u>'''Su-varṇa,'''</u> ‘beautiful coloured,’ is an epithet of gold ('''[[हिरण्य|Hiraṇya]]'''), and then comes to be used as a substantive denoting ‘gold.’<br><br>^1) [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 7, 4; 8, 9, 1, etc.<br><br>^2) Av. xv. 1, 2; [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 12, 6, 6; Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 4, 1, 8, etc.; Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 6, 6; iii. 19, 1; iv. 17, 7, etc.<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-वसन
<u>'''Su-vasana'''</u> in the Rigveda denotes a ‘splendid garment,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_1754> vi. 51, 4.</ref> and is also used adjectivally, ‘clothing well.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1754> ix. 97, 50.</ref> Su-[[वासस्|vāsas]], ‘welldressed,’ is a common adjective.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1754> Rv. i. 124, 7;<br> iii. 8, 4;<br> x. 71, 4, etc. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 262.</ref> See '''[[वासस्|Vāsas]].''' 

सु-वास्तु
<u>'''Su-vāstu'''</u> (‘having fair dwellings’) is the name of a river in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1755> viii. 19, 37;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 15.</ref> It is clearly the Soastos of Arrian<ref name=fx2_ve2_1755> ''Indica,'' iv. 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], Erlänterungen,'' 43;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 18;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3. 200;<br> ''Imperial Gazetteer of India,'' 23, 187.</ref> and the modern Swāt, a tributary of the '''[[कुभा|Kubhā]]''' (Kabul river) which is itself an affluent of the Indus.

सु-शारद शालङ्कायन
<u>'''Su-[[शारद|śārada]] Śālaṅkāyana'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[ऊर्जयन्त् औपमन्यव|Ūrjayant Aupamanyava]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1756> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

सु-श्रवस्
<u>'''1. Su-śravas'''</u> is the name of a man in the Rigveda (i. 53, 9) according to Sāyaṇa.<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-श्रवस्
<u>'''2. Su-śravas'''</u> is the name of the father of '''[[उपगु सौश्रवस|Upagu Sauśravasa]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 6, 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-श्रवस् कौष्य
<u>'''3. Su-śravas Kauṣya'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a contemporary of '''[[कुश्रि वाजश्रवस|Kuśri Vājaśravasa]],''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 5, 5, 1 ''et seq.'').<br>==Foot Notes==

सु-श्रवस् वार्ष-गण्य
<u>'''4. Su-śravas Vārṣa-gaṇya'''</u> (‘descendant of Vṛṣagaṇa’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[प्रातर्अह्न कौहल|Prātarahna Kauhala]],''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1760> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372.</ref>

सु-षामन्
<u>'''Su-ṣāman'''</u> is the name of a man in one verse of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1761> viii. 25, 22;<br> possibly 60, 18.</ref> and probably forms part of the strange name, Varo [[सुषामन्|Suṣāman]], in other passages.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1761> viii. 23, 28;<br> 24, 28;<br> 26, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 162.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Varu.'''

सु-षोमा
<u>'''Su-ṣomā'''</u> occurs certainly as the name of a river in the Nadīstuti (‘praise of rivers’) in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1762> x. 75, 5;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 26, where it is absurdly identified with the '''Sindu''' (Indus).</ref> In two other passages it would seem to be a proper name, once masculine,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1762> viii. 7, 29.</ref> perhaps  the people, and once feminine,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1762> viii. 64, 11.</ref> though Roth<ref name=fx4_ve2_1762> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 2.</ref> sees in the word the designation of a Soma vessel. Its identification is quite uncertain, though it has been thought to be the  of Megasthenes,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1762> See Arrian, ''Indica,'' iv. 12;<br> Schwanbeck, ''Megasthenes,'' 31, where there is a various reading .<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 126 ''et seq.;<br>'' Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 32, 398, 399;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 12-14.</ref> the modern Suwan.

सु-सर्तु
<u>'''Su-sartu'''</u> is the name of a river in the [[नदी|Nadī]]-[[स्तुति|stuti]] (‘praise of rivers’) in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1763> x. 75, 6. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 14;<br> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 200.</ref> That it was a tributary of the Indus is certain, but which one is unknown.

सु-हविस् आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Su-[[हविस्|havis]] Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman or chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 3, 25).<br>==Foot Notes==

सू-कर
<u>'''Sū-kara'''</u> ‘wild-boar,’ has the appearance of being an onomatopoetic word (‘making the sound ''sū''’); it is more probably a very old word going back to the Indo-European period, and cognate with the Latin ''su-culus'' (‘little pig’), being transformed in sense by popular etymology.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1765> The ''sū-'' corresponding to Lat. ''sū-s,'' Gk. -''s,'' Old High German, ''sū. Cf.'' Brugmann, ''Grundriss,'' 2^2, 483.</ref> It occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1765> vii. 55, 4.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1765> Av. ii. 27, 2;<br> v. 14, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 21;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 40;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], v. 10, 2, etc. None of the passages refer to the flesh as eaten: Buddha's death was due to a meal of ''sūkaramaddava,'' which may well mean ‘tender parts of pork’ (see Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1906, 881, n.), though the Rājanighaṇṭu, vii. 85, gives ''[[सूकर|sūkara]]'' as meaning the ''Batatas edulis.''</ref> It appears once in the Atharvaveda accompanied by ''[[मृग|mṛga]],''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1765> xii. 1, 48. The use of ''[[मृग|mṛga]]'' here does not indicate that ''[[सूकर|sūkara]]'' is a new name, because the latter word elsewhere always occurs alone both in the Rigveda and later (n. 3). ''Cf.'' '''[[मृग|Mṛga]]''' above, 2, 172, n. 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 82;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 100.</ref> the combined words apparently meaning ‘wild hog,’ as opposed to '''[[वराह|Varāha]],''' ‘boar.’ 

सूक्त
<u>'''Sūkta,'''</u> ‘well uttered,’ is the regular term for a ‘hymn’ as part of the [[शस्त्र|Śastra]] in the later Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1766> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 4, 5, 5;<br> vii. 1, 5, 4, etc.</ref> and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1766> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 33;<br> iii. 11, 9. 12-15;<br> iv. 21, 5;<br> vi. 8, 10;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1;<br> xv. 3;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 1, 18;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 6;<br> xi. 16.</ref> The sense of ‘hymn’ must also be recognized in several passages of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1766> i. 42, 20;<br> 171, 1;<br> ii. 6, 2;<br> vii. 29, 3, etc.</ref>

सूची
<u>'''Sūcī,'''</u> ‘needle,’ is found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1767> ii. 32, 4.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1767> Av. xi. 10, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 33;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 6, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 18, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 10, 2. 3;<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 10;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 10, 3 (Oertel, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 228).</ref>

सूचीक
<u>'''Sūcīka'''</u> is the name of a stinging insect in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1768> i. 191, 7. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref>

सूत
<u>'''Sūta'''</u> is the name of a court official who is often mentioned with the '''Grāmaṇī.''' He is one of the eight '''Vīras''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1769> ix. 1, 4, where he follows the chief queen ('''[[महिषी|Mahiṣī]]'''), and precedes the Grāmaṇī in the list.</ref> and of the eleven '''Ratnins''' in other texts.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1769> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5;<br> iv. 3, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 5.</ref> He also appears in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1769> iii. 5, 7.</ref> among the kingmakers ('''Rājakṛt''') and in the Śatrarudriya<ref name=fx4_ve2_1769> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 2, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 18. So also in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’), Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 2, 1. For other references to the [[सूत|Sūta]], see [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 18, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 7;<br> xiii. 4, 2, 5;<br> 7, 1, 43;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 3;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 3, 37, 38.</ref> (‘section dealing with the hundred Rudras’) of the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]. The commentators are agreed in seeing in him the ‘charioteer’ ('''[[सारथि|Sārathi]]''') or ‘master of the horse,’ of the king; this sense is accepted by Roth,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1769> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> by Whitney,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1769> Translation of the Atharvaveda, 62.</ref> and by Bloomfield.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1769> ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 114.</ref> But the fact that the '''Saṃ-  grahītṛ,''' who occurs in several passages beside the [[सूत|Sūta]], is the ‘charioteer,’ renders this version improbable. Eggeling<ref name=fx8_ve2_1769> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 62, n. 1.</ref> thinks that he was, in the Brāhmaṇas at least, a minstrel and court poet, while Weber<ref name=fx9_ve2_1769> ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 200.</ref> considers that his name denotes him as ‘consecrated’--that is, one who has constant access to the king. In the Epic the [[सूत|Sūta]] serves as a royal herald and bard:<ref name=fx10_ve2_1769> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 254, 255.</ref> it may be that the curious words ''ahanti,''<ref name=fx11_ve2_1769> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 18. This word means ‘non-fighter’ according to Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 17, 200.</ref> ''ahantya,''<ref name=fx12_ve2_1769> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 2, 1.</ref> or ''ahantva''<ref name=fx13_ve2_1769> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 3.</ref> applied to him<ref name=fx14_ve2_1769> The last two forms appear to be equivalent in sense to ''ahanya,'' ‘not to be slain,’ ‘inviolable.’</ref> in the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]] denote his sacred character at once as minstrel and as herald--a combination of functions not unknown elsewhere.

सूत-वशा
<u>'''Sūta-vaśā'''</u> denotes in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1770> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 5, 4;<br> vi. 1, 3, 6;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvii. 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 4, 1, etc.</ref> a cow barren after having one calf.

सूत्र
<u>'''Sūtra'''</u> has the sense of ‘thread’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1771> iii. 9, 3;<br> xviii. 8, 37.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1771> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 4, 14;<br> vii. 3, 2, 13;<br> xii. 3, 4, 2;<br> 7, 2, 10;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 8, 2;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iv. 6.</ref> In the sense of a ‘book of rules’ for the guidance of sacrificers and so forth, the word occurs in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1771> ii. 4, 10;<br> iv. 1, 6 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 1, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> 5, 11.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 5, 24, 25;<br> Sieg, ''Die Sagenstoffe des [[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]],'' 21.</ref>

सूद
<u>'''Sūda,'''</u> according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, means ‘well’<ref name=fx1_ve2_1772> Rv. vii. 36, 3;<br> ix. 97, 4.</ref> and the ‘mud of a dried-up pool.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1772> Rv. x. 61, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 13;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 5;<br> 2, 1, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 7, 3, 21.</ref> Pischel,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1772> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 72, 73.</ref> however, shows clearly that [[सूद|Sūda]] denotes what is added to Soma to  make it fit for use, especially the warm milk, and this sense suits all the passages. Eggeling<ref name=fx4_ve2_1772> ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 144.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 211.</ref> renders it ‘well,’ and Grassmann ‘sweet drink.’

सूद-दोहस्
<u>'''Sūda-dohas'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1773> viii. 69, 3.</ref> denotes ‘milking '''[[सूद|Sūda]]'''’--''i.e.,'' what is requisite to mix with Soma, according to Pischel.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1773> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 72. ''Sūdayitnu'' in Rv. x. 64, 9, may be taken in the same way, and ''sūdin'' in [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxvii. 2;<br> ''sūdya'' in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 13, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 25, etc.</ref> According to Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1773> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> it means ‘yielding milk like a well.’

सूना
<u>'''Sūnā'''</u> means, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1774> i. 161, 10;<br> 162, 13;<br> x. 86, 18.</ref> and the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1774> Av. v. 17, 14. Crates of '''[[पलाश|Palāśa]]''' wood are mentioned in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xvii. 3, 2. 3.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 271.</ref> apparently a ‘woven (from ''sīv,'' ‘sew’) wickerwork basket’ for holding flesh.

सूनु
<u>'''Sūnu'''</u> is a common word for ‘son’ from the Rigveda onwards.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1775> Rv. i. 26, 3;<br> ii. 38, 5;<br> vi. 52, 9, etc.;<br> Av. vi. 1, 2;<br> vii. 2, 2;<br> xii. 3, 23, etc.</ref> The etymological sense seems to be ‘he who is borne,’ and then ‘the begotten.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1775> Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandischaftsnamen,'' 453.</ref> But the use of [[सूनु|Sūnu]] in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1775> Usually in a figurative sense--''e.g sahasaḥ, adreḥ Sūruḥ.''</ref> is predominantly in relation to the father, and only rarely in its connexion with words for mother.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1775> v. 42, 2.</ref> Thus a father is ‘easy of access’ (''sāpāyana'') to his son (''[[सूनु|sūnu]]'');<ref name=fx5_ve2_1775> Rv. i. 1, 9.</ref> but in another passage,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1775> Rv. x. 18, 11.</ref> where the same term is applied to earth as a mother, the word used for son is '''[[पुत्र|Putra]].''' No conclusion as to matriarchy can of course be drawn from the etymology. On the relation of son and father, see '''[[पितृ|Pitṛ]].''' 

सूरि
<u>'''Sūri'''</u> is the regular word in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1776> i. 31, 7. 12;<br> 48, 24;<br> 54, 11;<br> 73, 5. 8, 9;<br> iii. 31, 14;<br> v. 42, 4;<br> 79, 6;<br> vi. 4, 8;<br> 23, 10;<br> vii. 32, 15;<br> viii. 70, 15;<br> x. 61, 22;<br> 115, 5. 7. 8.</ref> for the sacrificer, the later Yajamāna--that is, the man who pays the priests for performing the rite, and reaps the benefit of that service. The Sūris are often coupled with the '''Maghavans,'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1776/> described as heroes or warriors,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1776> i. 69, 3;<br> 73, 9;<br> 119, 3;<br> 122, 12;<br> 180, 9;<br> vii. 32, 15.</ref> and as related to the priests by their patronage<ref name=fx3_ve2_1776> i. 97, 3, 4;<br> v. 10, 6;<br> vi. 8, 7;<br> 25, 7;<br> vii. 3, 8;<br> 44, 18;<br> viii. 60, 6;<br> x. 66, 2.</ref> or as companions.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1776> v. 64, 5;<br> vii. 32, 25;<br> viii. 45, 36;<br> ix. 96, 4;<br> x. 115, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 236.</ref>

सूर्मि
<u>'''Sūrmi'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1777> vii. 1, 3.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1777> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 7, 6;<br> v. 4, 7, 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxi. 9, where it is described as ''karṇakāvatī,'' rendered by Roth as ‘provided with a handle.’</ref> according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, a kind of ‘tube’ serving as a lamp. In one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1777> viii. 69, 12. '''Sūrmya''' in [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 9, 2, may mean ‘being in pipes or channels.’</ref> it means a ‘pipe’ for conveying water. ''Cf.'' '''[[अवत|Avata]].'''

सूर्य
<u>'''Sūrya,'''</u> the ‘sun,’ plays a great part in Vedic mythology and religion,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1778> See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 30 ''et seq.''</ref> corresponding with the importance of the sun as a factor in the physical life of the peninsula. In the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1778> ''E.g.,'' i. 50, 6;<br> 115, 1. 3;<br> 164, 11. 13;<br> 191, 8. 9;<br> vii. 63, 1;<br> x. 37, 4;<br> 85, 9;<br> 88, 11;<br> 139, 3, etc.</ref> the sun is normally regarded as a beneficent power, a not unnatural view in a people which must apparently have issued from the cold regions of the Himālaya mountains. सूर्य-नक्षत्र
<u>'''Sūrya-nakṣatra'''</u> is found in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1779> ii. 1, 2, 19. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 288.</ref> in a passage where Sāyaṇa takes it as denoting a '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]],''' which gives out rays of light like the sun. But the real sense (as the [[काण्व|Kāṇva]] text helps to show) is that the sacrificer may take the sun for his [[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]]--''i.e.,'' he may neglect the Nakṣatras altogether and rely on the sun.

<u>'''Sūrya-candramasā'''</u> or '''[[सूर्य|Sūrya]]-candramasau''' denotes ‘sun and moon’ as a pair of luminaries in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1780> i. 102, 2;<br> v. 51, 15;<br> x. 190, 3.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1780> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 8, 9;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 12, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Naxatra,'' 2, 293;<br> ''[[ज्योतिष|Jyotiṣa]]'' 28, 50;<br> ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 112.</ref>

सृक
<u>'''Sṛka'''</u> in a couple of passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1781> i. 32, 12;<br> x. 180, 2. ''Cf. sṛkāyin, sṛkā-[[हस्त|hasta]],'' ‘bearing a lance in his hand,’ in the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]], [[वाजसनेय|Vājasaneya]] Saṃhitā, xvi. 21, 61, etc.</ref> denotes a weapon of Indra, perhaps a ‘lance.’

सृजय
<u>'''Sṛjaya'''</u> is the name of one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1783> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 14, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 23. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref> What it was is unknown: Mahīdhara on the Vājasaneyi passage calls it a kind of bird; Sāyaṇa on the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā gives the alternatives ‘black fly’ (when ''sṛjayā'' must be read), ‘white serpent,’ and ‘black buffalo.’

सृञ्जय
<u>'''Sṛñjaya'''</u> is the name of a people mentioned as early as the Rigveda. [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]] (that is, the king of this people) '''[[दैववात|Daivavāta]]''' is celebrated as victorious over the '''Turvaśas''' and the '''Vṛcīvants,'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1784> Rv. vi. 27, 7.</ref> and his sacrificial fire is referred to.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1784> Rv. iv. 15, 4.</ref> In connexion with [[दैववात|Daivavāta]] is also mentioned '''Sāhadevya Somaka,'''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1784> Rv. iv. 15, 7.</ref> no doubt another prince; for in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_1784> vii. 34, 9.</ref> we find [[सोमक साहदेव्य|Somaka Sāhadevya]] and his father, [[सहदेव|Sahadeva]] (originally '''Suplan''') [[सार्ञ्जय|Sārñjaya]], as kings who were anointed by '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]''' and '''[[नारद|Nārada]].''' The Rigveda<ref name=fx5_ve2_1784> Rv. vi. 47, 22. 25.</ref> has also a Dānastuti (‘praise of gifts’) of '''[[प्रस्तोक|Prastoka]],'''<ref name=fx6_ve2_1784> ''Cf.'' [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta Sutra, xvi. 11, 11.</ref> a [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]], who is lauded along with '''Divodāsa.''' Moreover, '''[[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]]'''<ref name=fx7_ve2_1784> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 212;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105.</ref> seems to have been a [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]], though Zimmer<ref name=fx8_ve2_1784> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 132 (on ''[[वैतहव्य|vaitahavya]]'').</ref> prefers to take the derivative word, '''[[वैतहव्य|Vaitahavya]],''' not as a patronymic, but as an epithet.<br><br>It seems probable that the Sṛñjayas and the '''Tṛtsus''' were closely allied, for Divodāsa and a [[सृञ्जय|Sṛñjaya]] prince are celebrated together,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1784> ''Cf.'' also the connexion of the '''Bharad vājas''' and Divodāsa (Rv. vi. 16, 5;<br> 31, 4;<br> Hillebrandt, ''op. cit.,'' 1, 104), and their connexion with the Sṛñjayas ([[वीतहव्य|Vītahavya]] in Rv. vi. 15, 2. 3, and see vi. 27, 7, both passages that can safely be accepted as derived from the [[भरद्वाज|Bharadvāja]] family).</ref> and the Turvaśas were enemies of both.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1784> See, on the one hand, Rv. vii. 18 (Turvaśas and Tṛtsus), and, on the other, vi. 27, 7.</ref> This view is borne out by the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx11_ve2_1784> ii. 4, 4, 5.</ref> which recognizes '''[[देवभाग श्रौतर्ष|Devabhāga Śrautarṣa]]''' as [[पुरोहित|Purohita]] of the '''Kurus''' and the Sṛñjayas. <br><br>On the other hand, some disaster certainly befel the Sṛñjayas, at least the Vaitahavyas, for they are said in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx12_ve2_1784> v. 19, 1. ''Cf.'' v. 18, 10. 11.</ref> to have offended the '''Bhṛgus''' and to have ended miserably. There is, it is true, no precise confirmation of this notice, but both the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx13_ve2_1784> xii. 3.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx14_ve2_1784> vi. 6, 2, 2, 3.</ref> in independent passages, refer to the Sṛñjayas having sustained some serious loss, though the notice is in each case coupled with a ritual error, much as in the Old Testament the fate of kings depends on their devotion to Jahve or their disobedience. <u>'''Sṛmara'''</u> is the name of an unknown animal at the '''[[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]]''' (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1788> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhita, v. 5, 16, 1 (according to Sāyaṇa = ''camara'');<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 20;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 39 (where '''Mahīdhara''' identifies it with the '''[[गवय|Gavaya]]''').</ref> 

सेतु
<u>'''Setu'''</u> appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1789> ix. 41, 2.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1789> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 2, 2, 1;<br> vi. 1, 4, 9;<br> 5, 3, 3;<br> vii. 5, 8, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 35;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 2, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 2, 10, 1;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 4, 24;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], viii. 4, 1. 2, etc.</ref> to denote merely a raised bank for crossing inundated land,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1789> Max Müller, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 1, 130, n. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 257.</ref> a ‘causeway,’ such as are common all the world over. This sense explains best the later meaning of ‘boundary.’ The word in Vedic literature is probably always metaphorical.

सेना
<u>'''Senā'''</u> denotes primarily a ‘missile,’ a sense found in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1790> Rv. i. 66, 7;<br> 116, 1 (''[[सेना|senā]]-jū,'' ‘swift as an arrow’);<br> 143, 5;<br> 186, 9;<br> ii. 33, 11;<br> v. 30, 9;<br> vii. 3, 4;<br> viii. 75, 7;<br> x. 23, 1.</ref> and the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1790> viii. 8, 7;<br> xi. 10, 4.</ref> and then a ‘host’ or ‘army,’ which is its normal meaning.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1790> Rv. i. 33, 6;<br> vii. 25, 1;<br> ix. 96, 1;<br> x. 103, 1. 4. 7;<br> 142, 4;<br> 156, 2;<br> Av. iii. 1, 1;<br> 19, 6;<br> iv. 19, 2;<br> v. 21, 9, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' von Bradke, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 46, 456;<br> Bloomfield, ''ibid.,'' 48, 549, 550;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 231, n. 2, denies that [[सेना|Senā]] ever means ‘missile,’ and compares ''exercitus effusus, agmen effusum.''</ref> See '''[[संग्राम|Saṃgrāma]].'''

सेना-नी
<u>'''Senā-nī,'''</u> ‘leader of an army,’ is the title of the royal ‘general.’ He is mentioned in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1791> vii. 20, 5;<br> ix. 96, 1;<br> x. 84, 2.</ref> where also<ref name=fx2_ve2_1791> x. 34, 12 (the gambling hymn).</ref> the word is used metaphorically. He is also referred to in the [[शतरुद्रिय|Śatarudriya]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1791> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 17;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 11;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 2, 1.</ref> as well as elsewhere in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās and Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1791> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 15;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 8, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 6, 1, 21.</ref> He is one of the '''Ratnins''' of the king.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1791> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 9, 1;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 7, 3, 4;<br> Maitrayaṇ Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 5;<br> iv. 3, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xv. 4;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 1, 1.</ref> Presumably he was appointed by the king, not by the people, to command in war when the king became too important to lead every little fray in person. In the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1791> viii. 23, 10.</ref> this official is called [[सेना|Senā]]-pati. 

सेलग
<u>'''Selaga'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1792> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 1, 5;<br> viii. 11, 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 3, 10.</ref> appears to denote ‘robber.’ See '''[[सैलग|Sailaga]].'''

सेहु
<u>'''Sehu'''</u> occurs in a comparison in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1793> vii. 76, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 54;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 441.</ref> where it must denote a very sapless (''arasa'') substance.

सैतव
<u>'''Saitava,'''</u> ‘descendant of Setu,’ is the name of a teacher in the first two Vaṃśas (list of teachers) in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1794> ii. 5, 21;<br> iv. 5, 27 Mādhyaṃdina;<br> ii. 6, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref> He is described as a pupil of '''[[पाराशर्य|Pārāśarya]]''' or of '''[[पाराशर्यायण|Pārāśaryāyaṇa]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1794> iv. 6, 2 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]].</ref>

सैन्धव
<u>'''Saindhava,'''</u> ‘coming from the Indus,’ is a term applied to water in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1795> vii. 4, 13, 1.</ref> to '''[[गुग्गुलु|Guggulu]]''' in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1795> xix. 38, 2.</ref> to a horse in the Śatapatha, [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1795> xi. 5, 5, 12;<br> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 2, 13 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 1, 13 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> and to salt in the same text.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1795> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 4, 12 (''ºkhilya'');<br> iv. 5, 13 (''ºghana'').</ref>

सैर्य
<u>'''Sairya'''</u> is the name in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1796> i. 191, 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 72.</ref> of some species of grass infested by insects.

सैलग
<u>'''Sailaga'''</u> is found in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1797> xxx. 18.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1797> iii. 4, 16, 1;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, xii. 23 (also spelt Śailaga)<br><br>''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 367, n. 4.</ref> as the name of one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’). ‘Robber’ seems to be the sense of this word, as of '''[[सेलग|Selaga]].''' 

सोभरि
<u>'''Sobhari'''</u> is the name of a [[ऋषि|Ṛṣi]] frequently mentioned in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1798> viii. 5, 26;<br> 19, 2;<br> 20, 19;<br> 22, 2.</ref> The family is also referred to,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1798> Rv. viii. 19, 32;<br> 20, 8.</ref> and a father, Sobharī.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1798> Rv. viii. 22, 15. ''Cf.'' viii. 103, 14;<br> Av. xviii. 3, 15.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 105;<br> Oldenberg, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 42, 217.</ref>

सोम
<u>'''Soma'''</u> was the famous plant which was used for the preparation of the libation of Soma made at the Vedic sacrifice. Its importance is sufficiently shown by the fact that the whole of the ninth Maṇḍala of the Rigveda, and six hymns in other Maṇḍalas, are devoted to its praise.<br><br>Nevertheless, little is actually known of the plant. Its twigs or shoots are described as brown (''[[बभ्रु|babhru]]''),<ref name=fx1_ve2_1799> The word is not actually found applied to the plant itself;<br> but the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 5, 3, prescribes ''arjunāni,'' plants of this indefinite colour, as a substitute for Soma, if '''Pūtīkas''' cannot be obtained.</ref> ruddy (''aruṇa''),<ref name=fx2_ve2_1799> Rv. vii. 98, 1;<br> x. 94, 3;<br> 144, 5. ''Cf.'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 10, 1 ''et seq.''</ref> of tawny (''hari'').<ref name=fx3_ve2_1799> Rv. ix. 92, 1. The Soma cow, with which Soma was purchased, is called ''[[बभ्रु|babhru]]'' or ''aruṇā,'' Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 1, 15;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 7, 5, etc.</ref> Possibly its twigs hang down if the epithet '''[[नैचाशाख|Naicāśākha]]'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1799> Rv. iii. 53, 14. ''Cf.'' '''[[नैचाशाख|Naicāśākha]].'''</ref> refers to the plant as Hillebrandt<ref name=fx5_ve2_1799> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 14-18;<br> 2, 241-245.</ref> thinks. The shoot is called ''[[अंशु|aṃśu]],''<ref name=fx6_ve2_1799> Rv. i. 168, 3 iii. 48, 2, etc.</ref> while the plant as a whole is called ''andhas,''<ref name=fx7_ve2_1799> Rv. i. 28, 7;<br> iii. 48, 1;<br> iv. 16, 1, etc.</ref> which also denotes the juice.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1799> ii. 14, 1;<br> 19, 1;<br> 35, 1. etc.</ref> ''[[पर्वन्|Parvan]]''<ref name=fx9_ve2_1799> Rv. i. 9, 1. ''Cf. [[परुस्|parus]],'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 13;<br> Vaitāna [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], 24.</ref> is the stem. ''Kṣip,''<ref name=fx10_ve2_1799> Rv. ix. 79, 4. ''Cf.,'' however, Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 70.</ref> ‘finger,’ is used as a designation of the shoots, which may therefore have resembled fingers in shape; ''[[वक्षणा|vakṣaṇā]]''<ref name=fx11_ve2_1799> Rv. viii. 1, 17.</ref> and ''[[वाण|vāṇa]]''<ref name=fx12_ve2_1799> Rv. iv. 24, 9;<br> ix. 50, 1. But these passages are both very doubtful. ''Cf.'' '''[[वाण|Vāṇa]].''' The husk left after the pressing is called ''andhas'' (ix. 86, 44;<br> ''vavri'' (ix. 69, 9), ''tvac'' (ix. 86, 44;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 13, 1), ''śarīva'' (''ibid.,'' 2), ''[[शर्य|śarya]]'' (ix. 68, 2), ''[[तान्व|tānva]]'' (ix. 78, 1).</ref> also seem to have the sense of the shoot. There is some slight. evidence to suggest that the stem was not round, but angular.<ref name=fx13_ve2_1799> ''Cf. pṛṣṭhya'' in Rv. iv. 20, 4;<br> Hille brandt, 1, 54, 55.</ref>  The plant grew on the mountains,<ref name=fx14_ve2_1799> Rv. i. 93, 6;<br> iii. 48, 2;<br> v. 36, 2;<br> 43, 4;<br> 85, 2;<br> ix. 18, 1;<br> 46, 1;<br> 71, 4;<br> 82, 3;<br> Av. iii. 21, 10. So in the Avesta, Yasna, x. 4, etc.</ref> that of '''Müjavant''' being specially renowned.<br><br>These notices are inadequate to identify the plant. It has been held<ref name=fx15_ve2_1799> Lassen, ''Indische Alterthumskunde,'' 1^2, 931;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 261 ''et seq. Cf.'' Haug, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brahmaṇa,'' 2, 489;<br> Max Müller, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 9, liv.</ref> to be the ''Sarcostemma viminale'' or the ''Asclepias acida (= Sarcostemma brevistigma).'' Roth<ref name=fx16_ve2_1799> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 35, 680 ''et seq. Cf.'' also 38, 134 ''et seq.''</ref> held that the ''Sarcostemma acidum'' more nearly met the requirements of the case. Watt<ref name=fx17_ve2_1799> See Hillebrandt, 1, 7 ''et seq.''</ref> suggested the Afghan grape as the real Soma, and Rice<ref name=fx18_ve2_1799> ''Ibid.,'' 10.</ref> thought a sugar-cane might be meant, while Max Müller and Rājendralāla [[मित्र|Mitra]] suggested that the juice was used as an ingredient in a kind of beer--''i.e.,'' that the Soma plant was a species of hop. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx19_ve2_1799> ''Ibid.,'' 12. The dispute between Max Müller, Roth, J. G. Baker, W. T. Thiselton Dyer, Charles G. Leland, and A. Houtum-Schindler, as to the identity of the plant, is reprinted in Max Müller's ''Biographies of Words,'' 222 ''et seq.,'' and reviewed by Hillebrandt. See also Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, xxiv. ''et seq.,'' who thinks that the traditional identification is not far wrong. Caland, ''Altindisches Zauberritual,'' 188, gives it as ''Sarcostemma acidum.''</ref> considers that neither hops nor the grape can explain the references to Soma. It is very probable that the plant cannot now be identified.<ref name=fx20_ve2_1799> The original Soma plant was, doubtless, identical with the Haoma of the Avesta. On the plant from which the present Parsis of Kermān and Yezd obtain their Hūm juice, and which they regard as identical with the Avestic Haoma, see Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, xxiv ''et seq.''</ref><br><br>In the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]]<ref name=fx21_ve2_1799> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 3, 1, 1 ''et seq.;<br>'' Hillebrandt, 1, 89 ''et seq.''</ref> the plant is purchased ere it is pressed. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx22_ve2_1799> ''Ibid.,'' 70.</ref> considers that the sale must be assumed for the Rigveda. It grew on a mountain, and could not be obtained by ordinary people: perhaps some special tribe or prince owned it, like the '''Kīkaṭas.'''<ref name=fx23_ve2_1799> Rv. iii. 53, 14.</ref> As it stands, the ritual performance is clearly an acquisition of the Soma from the Gandharvas (represented by a [[शूद्र|Śūdra]]), a ritual imitation of the action which may have been one of the sources of the drama. Owing to the difficulty of obtaining the real plant from a great  distance, several substitutes were allowed in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] period.<ref name=fx24_ve2_1799> See Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 10, 1-6, and ''cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, xxvii;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ix. 5, 3.</ref><br><br>The plant was prepared for use by being pounded with stones or in a mortar. The former was the normal method of procedure, appearing in the Rigveda as the usual one. The stones are called ''grāvan''<ref name=fx25_ve2_1799> i. 83, 6;<br> 135, 7, etc.</ref> or ''adri,''<ref name=fx26_ve2_1799> i. 130, 2;<br> 135, 5;<br> 137, 1, etc. ''Adri'' is used oftener with the verb ''su,'' ‘press,’ than ''grāvan,'' which is more personally conceived, and so appears with ''vad,'' ‘speak,’ and so forth;<br> Hillebrandt, 1, 153, n. 1.</ref> and were, of course, held in the hands.<ref name=fx27_ve2_1799> Rv. v. 45, 7;<br> ix. 11, 5;<br> x. 76, 2, etc.</ref> The plant was laid on boards one beside the other ('''Adhiṣavana'''), and, according at least to the later ritual,<ref name=fx28_ve2_1799> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 4, 28;<br> that ''ākhara,'' Rv. x. 94, 5, denotes this is uncertain.</ref> a hole was dug below, so that the pounding of the plant by means of the stones resulted in a loud noise, doubtless a prophylactic against demoniac influences.<br><br>The plant was placed on a skin and on the Vedi<ref name=fx29_ve2_1799> Rv. v. 31, 12.</ref> --which was no longer done in the later ritual--'''[[धिषणा|Dhiṣaṇā]]''' in some passages denoting the Vedi.<ref name=fx30_ve2_1799> Rv. i. 109, 3;<br> iii. 2, 1;<br> vi. 11, 3, etc.</ref><br><br>Sometimes the mortar and pestle were used in place of the stones.<ref name=fx31_ve2_1799> Rv. i. 28. The pestle is ''[[मन्था|manthā]],'' the mortar ''[[उलूखल|ulūkhala]];<br>'' in x. 101, 11, ''[[वनस्पति|vanaspati]]'' and ''vana'' may have the same senses respectively.</ref> This use, though Iranian, was apparently not common in Vedic times.

चमू
<u>'''Camū'''</u> denotes the vessel used for the offering to the god,<ref name=fx32_ve2_1800> Not the pressing boards, which are unknown in the Rigveda. ''Cf.'' Rv. ix. 99, 8;<br> x. 91, 15, etc.</ref> '''[[कलश|Kalaśa]]''' and '''[[चमस|Camasa]]''' those used for the priests to drink from. Sometimes<ref name=fx33_ve2_1800> Rv. i. 28, 9;<br> iv. 18, 3;<br> vi. 57, 2, etc.;<br> Hillebrandt, 1, 170, 173.</ref> the [[चमू|Camū]] denotes the mortar and pestle. Perhaps the vessel was so called because of its mortar-like shape.<br><br>The skin on which the shoots were placed was called '''Tvac,'''<ref name=fx34_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 65, 25;<br> 66, 29;<br> 70, 7;<br> 79, 4, etc.</ref> or twice ''go'' (‘cow-hide’).<ref name=fx35_ve2_1800> Rv. x. 94, 9;<br> 116, 4.</ref> '''[[कोश|Kośa]],'''<ref name=fx36_ve2_1800> Rv. vii. 101, 4;<br> viii. 20, 8, etc. It denotes the larger vessel from which the Soma is poured into the Kalaśas, or cups.</ref> Sadhastha,<ref name=fx37_ve2_1800> Rv. iii. 62, 15;<br> ix. 1, 2;<br> 17, 8, etc.</ref> '''Dru,'''<ref name=fx38_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 1, 2;<br> 65, 6;<br> 98, 2;<br> in x. 101, 10, ''dru'' = mortar.</ref>  '''Vana,'''<ref name=fx39_ve2_1800> Rv. ii. 14, 9;<br> ix. 66, 9, etc. The word can mean both the vessel into which the Soma was poured after preparation, and the vessel from which it was offered to the gods.</ref> '''[[द्रोण|Droṇa]],'''<ref name=fx40_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 15, 7;<br> 33, 2, etc. The word, having no definite sense, can denote any of the vessels. The ''[[चमू|camū]],'' on the other hand, was the cup for the gods, the ''[[कलश|kalaśa]]'' that for the priests (later it was also used as = ''[[कोश|kośa]],'' when ''[[चमस|camasa]]'' had replaced ''[[कलश|kalaśa]]'' as cup for the priests;<br> Hillebrandt, 1, 187).</ref> are all terms used for Soma vessels, while '''[[स्रुव|Sruva]]'''<ref name=fx41_ve2_1800> Rv. i. 116, 24. ''Cf.'' also '''[[अमत्र|Amatra]]''' and '''[[खारी|Khārī]].'''</ref> denotes the ‘ladle.’<br><br>Apparently the plant was sometimes steeped in water to increase its yield of juice.<ref name=fx42_ve2_1800> This process is technically called ''āpyāyana,'' ‘causing to swell.’ ''Cf.'' Rv. ix. 74, 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 5. The exact nature and extent of this process is quite uncertain;<br> Hillebrandt,(**  193-195;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 26, xxvi.</ref><br><br>It is not possible to describe exactly the details of the process of pressing the Soma as practised in the Rigveda. It was certainly purified by being pressed through a sieve<ref name=fx43_ve2_1800> Whether the later practice of purification by means of shoots held in the hands was known to the Rigveda is uncertain, since ii. 14, 8;<br> ix. 71, 3, are quite indecisive. For the various terms used to designate the sieve, see '''[[पवित्र|Pavitra]].'''</ref> ('''[[पवित्र|Pavitra]]'''). The Soma was then used unmixed (''[[शुक्र|śukra]],''<ref name=fx44_ve2_1800> Rv. i. 137, 1;<br> iii. 32, 2;<br> viii. 2, 10, etc.</ref> ''śuci'')<ref name=fx45_ve2_1800> Rv. i. 5, 5;<br> 30, 2;<br> viii. 2, 9, etc.</ref> for Indra and '''Vāyu,''' but the '''Kaṇvas''' seem to have dropped this usage.<ref name=fx46_ve2_1800> ''Cf.'' Rv. viii. 2, 5. 9. 10, 28, etc. The Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 4, disapproves of the unmixed Soma. Possibly Hillebrandt, 1, 207, 208, may be right in thinking that the Kāṇvas had to lay special stress on the use of the mixtures, because they used a plant which was deficient in the true Soma character.</ref> The juice is described as brown (''[[बभ्रु|babhru]]''),<ref name=fx47_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 33, 2;<br> 63, 4. 6.</ref> tawny (''hari''),<ref name=fx48_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 3, 9;<br> 7, 6;<br> 65, 8. 12. 25, etc.</ref> or ruddy (''aruṇa''),<ref name=fx49_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 40, 2;<br> 45, 3;<br> ''aruṣa,'' ix. 61, 21;<br> ''śoṇa,'' ix. 97, 13.</ref> and as having a fragrant smell,<ref name=fx50_ve2_1800> ix. 97, 19;<br> 107, 2.</ref> at least as a rule.<ref name=fx51_ve2_1800> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 3, 6. This passage has been relied on by Eggeling, ''op. cit.,'' 26, xxv, as a confirmation of the later description, in a medical work, of the plant as illsmelling. But this plant may have been a different one from that used in Vedic times. The smell may have been due to a substitute being used, or to the genuine plant, brought from a distance, being old and withered.</ref><br><br>Soma was mixed with milk ('''[[गवाशिर्|Gavāśir]]'''),<ref name=fx52_ve2_1800> Hillebrandt, 1, 219-222.</ref> curd or sour milk ('''[[दध्य्आशिर्|Dadhyāśir]]'''),<ref name=fx53_ve2_1800> ''Ibid.,'' 221.</ref> or grain ('''[[यवाशिर्|Yavāśir]]''').<ref name=fx54_ve2_1800> ''Ibid.,'' 222 ''et seq.''</ref> The admixtures are  alluded to with various figurative expressions, as '''Atka,''' ‘armour’;<ref name=fx55_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 69, 4.</ref> '''[[वस्त्र|Vastra]]'''<ref name=fx56_ve2_1800> ix. 8, 6.</ref> or '''[[वासस्|Vāsas]],'''<ref name=fx57_ve2_1800> ix. 69, 5.</ref> ‘garment’; '''[[अभिश्री|Abhiśrī]],'''<ref name=fx58_ve2_1800> ix. 79, 5;<br> 86, 27.</ref> ‘admixture’; ''rūpa,''<ref name=fx59_ve2_1800> Av. ix. 25, 4.</ref> ‘beauty’; ''[[श्री|śrī]],''<ref name=fx60_ve2_1800> Rv. iv. 41, 8;<br> ix. 16, 6.</ref> ‘splendour’; ''rasa,''<ref name=fx61_ve2_1800> Rv. iii. 48, 1;<br> vi. 47, 1;<br> ix. 97, 14. See also '''[[सूद|Sūda]].'''</ref> ‘flavour’; ''prayas,''<ref name=fx62_ve2_1800> Rv. iii. 30, 1;<br> ix. 46, 3;<br> 66, 23.</ref> ‘dainty’; and perhaps ''nabhas,''<ref name=fx63_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 83, 5;<br> 97, 21, etc.</ref> ‘fragrance.’ The adjective ''tīvra''<ref name=fx64_ve2_1800> Rv. i. 23, 1;<br> ii. 41, 14;<br> v. 37, 4;<br> vi. 47, 1, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘pungent’ flavour of Soma when so mixed.
