The Soma shoots, after the juice has been pressed out, are denoted by ''ṛjīṣa,'' ‘residue.’<ref name=fx65_ve2_1800> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 8, 5;<br> Av. ix. 6, 16, etc.;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 72;<br> citation in [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 12, etc. ''Ṛjīṣa'' as an adjective occurs in Rv. i. 32, 6, and ''ṛjīṣin'' in the Rigveda means, according to Hillebrandt, 1, 236, 237, generally ‘one to whom the Soma shoots belong.’ ''Soma tiroahnya'' is ‘Soma pressed the day before yesterday.’</ref><br><br>It seems probable that in some cases honey was mixed with Soma: perhaps the ''[[कोश|kośa]] [[मधु|madhu]]-ścut,'' ‘the pail distilling sweetness,’ was used for the mixing.<ref name=fx66_ve2_1800> Rv. ix. 103, 3. ''Cf.'' ix. 17, 8;<br> ix. 86, 48;<br> 97, 11;<br> 109, 20.</ref> It seems doubtful if [[सुरा|Surā]] was ever so mixed.<ref name=fx67_ve2_1800> See '''[[सुराम|Surāma]].''' ''Cf.'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 12, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxi. 42, and ''[[सुरा|surā]]-somā, ibid.,'' xxi. 60.</ref><br><br>There were three pressings a day of Soma, as opposed to the two of the Avesta.<ref name=fx68_ve2_1800> Yasna, x. 2.</ref> The evening pressing was specially connected with the Ṛbhus, the midday with Indra, the morning with Agni, but the ritual shows that many other gods also had their share.<ref name=fx69_ve2_1800> Hillebrandt, 1, 257 ''et seq.''</ref> The drinker of Soma and the nondrinker are sharply discriminated in the texts.<ref name=fx70_ve2_1800> Rv. i. 110, 7;<br> ii. 30, 7;<br> v. 34, 3. 5;<br> iv. 17, 17;<br> 25, 6. 7;<br> v. 37, 3;<br> vi. 41, 4;<br> vii. 26, 1, etc. There were also rivalries with other Soma sacrifices, Rv. ii. 18, 3;<br> viii. 33, 14;<br> 66, 12, and especially vii. 33, 2, where the Vasiṣṛhas take away Indra from '''Pāśadyumna Vāyata's''' Soma sacrifice to '''Sudās'.''' Many famous Soma offerers are mentioned: '''Atri,''' v. 51, 8;<br> 72, 1;<br> viii. 42, 5;<br> '''[[शार्यात|Śāryāta]],''' i. 51, 12;<br> iii. 51, 7;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vii. 35;<br> '''Śīṣṭas,''' viii. 53, 4, etc.;<br> '''[[तुर्वश|Turvaśa]] Yadu,''' viii. 45, 27;<br> '''[[संवर्त|Saṃvarta]] [[कृश|Kṛśa]],''' viii. 54, 2;<br> '''[[नीपातिथि|Nīpātithi]], [[मेध्यातिथि|Medhyātithi]], [[पुष्टिगु|Puṣṭigu]], [[श्रुष्टिगु|Śruṣṭigu]]''', viii. 51, 1, etc. The ritual lays stress on the need of continuity in Soma-drinking in a family: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 5, 5 ''et seq.;<br>'' Maitrāvaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 5, etc.</ref> Localities where Soma was consumed were '''[[आर्जीक|Ārjīka]], [[पस्त्यावन्त्|Pastyāvant]], [[शर्यणावन्त्|Śaryaṇāvant]], [[सुषोमा|Suṣomā]],''' the territory of the '''[[पञ्चजनाः|Pañcajanāḥ]]''' or ‘five  peoples,’ and so on.<ref name=fx71_ve2_1800> See ''s.v.;<br>'' Hillebrandt, 1, 125-143. It is possible that Soma may have grown on the mountains to the north of '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]],''' whatever may have been its original home, on which ''cf.'' Roth, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 38, 134 ''et seq.''</ref> The effects of Soma in exhilarating and exciting the drinkers are often alluded to.<ref name=fx72_ve2_1800> See Rv. viii. 48. It was equally prized in Avestic times. It is, however, seldom spoken of as giving the priests pleasure: Rv. i. 91, 13;<br> viii. 2, 12;<br> x. 167, 3. There are many references to sickness caused by it (Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 13 etc.). The [[सौत्रामणी|Sautrāmaṇī]] was a rite designed to expiate the ill caused by vomiting Soma as Indra had done: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 2, 5, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 4, 9;<br> xii. 7, 1, 11. The name of the rite is already found in Av. vii. 3, 2, and the rite itself is no doubt older (see also '''[[विषूचिका|Viṣūcikā]]'''). This fact tells in favour of the traditional identification of the plant, for the medical passage quoted by Max Müller refers to its producing vomiting. See also Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 275;<br> Rv. i. 91, 13;<br> 118, 3;<br> viii. 2, 12;<br> 17, 6;<br> 48, 12. Perhaps '''[[वम्र|Vamra]]''' in i. 112, 15, got his name thence.</ref><br><br>It is difficult to decide if Soma was ever a popular, as opposed to a hieratic drink. The evidence for its actual popularity is very slight,<ref name=fx73_ve2_1800> Rv. viii. 69, 8-10. ''Cf.'' viii. 31, 5;<br> i. 28, 5;<br> Hillebrandt, 1, 143-147. The evidence is not decisive;<br> the ordinary Soma sacrifice was clearly a sacrifice of rich patrons.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 272280;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 1-266;<br> 2, 209 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 104 ''et seq.''</ref> and not decisive.

सोम प्राति-वेश्य
<u>'''2. Soma Prāti-veśya'''</u> (‘descendant of Prativeśya’) is the name of a teacher, a pupil of [[प्रतिवेश्य|Prativeśya]], in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) at the end of the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (xv. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

सोमक साह-देव्य
<u>'''Somaka Sāha-devya'''</u> (‘descendant of Sahadeva’) is the name of a king of the '''Sṛnjayas''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1802> iv. 15, 7-10.</ref> He is mentioned in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1802> vii. 34, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 154;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 105.</ref> as having '''[[पर्वत|Parvata]]''' and '''[[नारद|Nārada]]''' as his priests.

सोम-दक्ष कौश्रेय
<u>'''Soma-dakṣa Kauśreya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''Kuśri'''’) is the name of a teacher in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1803> xx. 8;<br> xxi. 9, where Somarakṣa Kośreya is read by the Chambers MS. in xx. 8, and Kośreya in xxi. 9.</ref> and the Maitrāyaṇī<ref name=fx2_ve2_1803> iii. 2, 7.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 3, 472, 473.</ref> Saṃhitās. 

सोमपि-त्सरु
<u>'''Somapi-tsaru.'''</u> See '''[[त्सरु|Tsaru]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सोम-शुष्म सात्य-यज्ञि
<u>'''Soma-śuṣma Sātya-yajñi'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[सत्ययज्ञ|Satyayajña]]'''’) is the name in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xi. 6, 2, 1. 3) of a travelling Brahmin who met '''[[जनक|Janaka]]''' of '''[[विदेह|Videha]].''' He may be identical with the man of the same name with the additional patronymic '''[[प्राचीनयोग्य|Prācīnayogya]]''' (‘descendant of Prācīnayoga’), who is mentioned as a pupil of [[सत्ययज्ञ|Satyayajña]] in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 2).<br>==Foot Notes==

सोम-शुष्मन् वाज-रत्नायन
<u>'''Soma-śuṣman [[वाज|Vāja]]-ratnāyana'''</u> (‘descendant of Vājaratna’) is the name in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 21, 5) of the priest who consecrated '''Śatānīka.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सौकरायण
<u>'''Saukarāyaṇa'''</u> is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[काषायण|Kāṣāyaṇa]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1807> iv. 6, 2. ([[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> or '''[[त्रैवणि|Traivaṇi]],'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1807> iv. 5, 27 (Mādhyaṃdina)</ref> in the second [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].

सौ-जात आराढि
<u>'''Sau-jāta Ārāḍhi'''</u> is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 22, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

सौत्रामणी
<u>'''Sautrāmaṇī.'''</u> See '''Soma.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सौ-दन्ति
<u>'''Sau-danti'''</u> (‘descendant of Sudanta’) occurs in the plural in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xiv. 3, 13), apparently as the name of priests who were contemporaries of '''[[विश्वामित्र|Viśvāmitra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

सौदास
<u>'''Saudāsa'''</u> in the plural designates the ‘descendants of '''[[सुदास्|Sudās]],'''’ who are referred to in the Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1811> ii. 390 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 18, 47). The story must have appeared in the Śāṭyāyanaka also. ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 159, n. 3.</ref> as having cast '''[[शक्ति|Śakti]],''' the son of '''[[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]],''' into the fire. Other texts<ref name=fx2_ve2_1811> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 7, 1;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 8;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 7, 3. See also Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 20.</ref> relate  that [[वसिष्ठ|Vasiṣṭha]], his son being slain, desired to avenge himself on the Saudāsas, and eventually succeeded. Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve2_1811> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> sees a reference to the story in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1811> iii. 53, 22.</ref> but without cause.

सौ-द्युम्नि
<u>'''Sau-dyumni'''</u> (‘descendant of Sudyumna’) is the patronymic of king '''[[भरत|Bharata]] [[दौःषन्ति|Dauḥṣanti]]''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 5, 4, 12).<br>==Foot Notes==

सौ-बल
<u>'''Sau-bala,'''</u> ‘descendant of Subala,’ is the name of a pupil of '''[[सर्पि वात्सि|Sarpi Vātsi]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vi. 24, 16).<br>==Foot Notes==

सौभर
<u>'''Saubhara,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[सोभरि|Sobhari]],’ is the patronymic of '''Pathin''' in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1814> ii. 5, 22 (Mādhyaṃdina = ii. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]);<br> iv. 5, 28 (Mādhyaṃdina = iv. 6, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref>

सौमाप
<u>'''Saumāpa'''</u> ‘descendant of Somāpa,’ is the patronymic of the two '''Mānutantavyas,''' teachers in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1815> xiii. 5, 3, 2, where Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 44, 392, has Saumapa.</ref>

सौमापि
<u>'''Saumāpi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Somāpa,’ is the patronymic of a teacher called '''Priyavrata''' in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka (xv. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

सौमायन
<u>'''Saumāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Soma,’ is the patronymic of '''Budha''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xxiv. 18, 6).<br>==Foot Notes==

सौम्य
<u>'''Saumya'''</u> is a term of affectionate address (‘my dear’) in the Upaniṣads.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1818> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1, 3;<br> 2, 13 (''varia lectia, somya'');<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 4, 4 ''et seq.''</ref>

सौ-यवसि
<u>'''Sau-yavasi,'''</u> ‘descendant of [[सुयवस|Suyavasa]],’ is the patronymic of '''Ajīgarta.'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1819> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Bṛāhmaṇa, vii. 15, 6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xv. 19, 29.</ref> 

सौरी
<u>'''Saurī'''</u> is given by Zimmer<ref name=fx1_ve2_1820> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 99.</ref> as the name of an unknown animal at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1820> v. 5, 16, 1 = Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 33 = Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 14.</ref> But this is an error: ''[[सौरी|saurī]]'' means ‘dedicated to the sun.’

सौ-वर्चनस
<u>'''Sau-varcanasa'''</u> is the patronymic of '''Saṃśravas''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (i. 7, 2, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

सौ-श्रवस
<u>'''Sau-śravasa,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[सुश्रवस्|Suśravas]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''Upagu''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1822> xiv. 6, 8.</ref> and the '''[[कण्व|Kaṇva]]''' Sauśravasas are mentioned in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1822> xiii. 12 (''Indische Studien,'' 3, 474).</ref>

सौ-श्रोमतेय
<u>'''Sau-śromateya,'''</u> ‘descendant of Suśromatā,’ is the metronymic of '''Aṣāḍhi''' in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1823> vi. 2, 1, 37. ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 171, n. 1.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''Āṣādhi.'''

सौ-षद्मन
<u>'''Sau-ṣadmana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Suṣadman,’ is the patronymic of '''Viśvantara''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (vii. 27, 1; 34, 7).<br>==Foot Notes==

स्कन्ध्या
<u>'''Skandhyā,'''</u> fem. plur., is used in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1825> vi. 25, 3. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 472, 473.</ref> of a disease ‘of the shoulders,’ probably tumours of some kind.

स्तनयित्नु
<u>'''Stanayitnu,'''</u> sing. and plur., denotes ‘thunder’ from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1826> v. 83, 6.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1826> Av. i. 13, 1;<br> iv. 15, 11;<br> vii. 11, 1, etc.</ref>

स्तम्ब
<u>'''Stamba'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1827> viii. 6, 14.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1827> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 6, 4, 1 (of '''[[दर्भ|Darbha]]''');<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 7, 17, 3;<br> iii. 2, 2, 4;<br> 3, 3, 4;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 23, 9, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘tuft of grass,’ or more generally a ‘bunch’ or ‘cluster.’ 

स्तम्भ
<u>'''Stambha,'''</u> ‘pillar,’ is found in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1828> xxx. 9;<br> xxxi. 1.</ref> and often in the Sūtras. Earlier Skambha<ref name=fx2_ve2_1828> Rv. i. 34, 2;<br> iv. 13, 5, etc.</ref> is used, but only metaphorically.

स्तरी
<u>'''Starī'''</u> denotes a ‘barren cow’ in the Rigveda (i. 101, 3; 116, 22; 117, 20, etc.).<br>==Foot Notes==

स्ति
<u>'''Sti.'''</u> See '''[[उपस्ति|Upasti]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

स्ति-पा
<u>'''Sti-pā.'''</u> See '''[[उपस्ति|Upasti]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

स्तुका
<u>'''Stukā'''</u> denotes a ‘tuft’ of hair or wool in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1832> ix. 97, 17.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1832> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxv. 6;<br> Av. vii. 74, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 1, 13, etc.</ref>

स्तुति
<u>'''Stuti'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1833> i. 84, 2;<br> vi. 34, 1;<br> x. 31, 5.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1833> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 5, 2, 39</ref> denotes a ‘song of praise.’

स्तुप
<u>'''Stupa'''</u> means ‘tuft of hair’ in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (ii. 2; xxv. 2) and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (i. 3, 3, 5; iii. 5, 3, 4). See '''[[स्तुका|Stukā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

स्तूप
<u>'''Stūpa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1835> vii. 2, 1. ''Cf.'' i. 24, 7.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1835> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 3, 6, 5;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 4, 4.</ref> denotes the ‘top-knot’ of hair as designating the upper part of the head.

स्तृ
<u>'''Stṛ'''</u> (used in the instrumental plural only) denotes the ‘stars’ of heaven.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1836> i. 68, 5;<br> 166, 11;<br> ii. 2, 5;<br> 34, 2;<br> iv. 7, 3;<br> vi. 49, 3. 12. In i. 87, 1, it seems to denote a ‘star-like spot’ on the forehead of a cow or bull, but this is uncertain. ''Cf.'' Grassmann, ''Wo7rterbuch, s.v.;<br>'' above, 1, 233.</ref> 

स्तेग
<u>'''Stega'''</u> in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās<ref name=fx1_ve2_1837> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 11, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 1.</ref> seems to denote a species of ‘worm.’ The word occurs in the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1837> x. 31, 9 = Av. xviii. 1, 39. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 98.</ref> also, where its sense is unknown, but may possibly be ‘ploughshare.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1837> Weber, Proceedings of the Berlin Academy, 1895, 833. ''Cf.'' Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 824.</ref>

स्तेन
<u>'''Stena'''</u> is a common word for ‘thief’ from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1838> ii. 23, 16;<br> 28, 10;<br> 42, 3, etc.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1838> Av. iv. 3, 4, 5;<br> 36, 7;<br> xix. 47, 6;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 30, 11, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 178 ''et seq.''</ref> See '''[[तस्कर|Taskara]].'''

स्तेय
<u>'''Steya'''</u> denotes ‘theft’ in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1839> xi. 8, 20;<br> xiv. 1, 57.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1839> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vi. 27;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iii. 1. ''Cf. [[स्तेय|steya]]-kṛt,'' ‘thief,’ in Rv. vii. 104, 10.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[धर्म|Dharma]].'''

स्तोतृ
<u>'''Stotṛ'''</u> denotes ‘praiser’ or ‘panegyrist’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1840> i. 11, 3;<br> 38, 4;<br> iii. 18, 5;<br> vi. 34, 3, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1840> Av. vi. 2, 1;<br> xix. 48, 4.</ref> The word often<ref name=fx3_ve2_1840> Rv. i. 124, 10;<br> ii. 1, 16;<br> v. 64, 1;<br> vii. 7, 7;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], vii. 2.</ref> occurs in connexion with patrons, the '''Maghavan''' or '''[[सूरि|Sūri]].'''

स्तोत्र
<u>'''Stotra'''</u> denotes the ‘song’ of the Udgātṛ and his assistant priests (see '''[[ऋत्व्इज्|Ṛtvij]]'''), just as '''[[शस्त्र|Śastra]]''' denotes the ‘recitation’ of the '''[[होतृ|Hotṛ]]''' and his assistants. The word has this technical sense quite frequently in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1841> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 2, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 37, 4;<br> iii. 46, 8;<br> iv. 12, 6;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 1, 7;<br> viii. 1, 3, 4, etc. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 353, and Caland and Henry, ''L'Agniṣṭoma,'' where the Stotras for that sacrifice are given at length.</ref> 

स्तोम
<u>'''Stoma'''</u> denotes ‘song of praise’ in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1842> i. 114, 9;<br> iii. 5, 2;<br> 58, 1, etc.</ref> Later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1842> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 2, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ix. 33;<br> x. 10, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 9, 229, 276;<br> 10, 355;<br> Hillebrandt, Rituallitteratur, 101.</ref> the term has the technical sense of the typical forms in which the '''Stotras''' are chanted.

स्त्री
<u>'''Strī'''</u> is the ordinary word in poetry and prose for ‘woman,’ without special reference to her as a wife or as a maiden. '''[[नारी|Nārī]]''' has the same sense, but disappears in later prose, while '''Gnā''' refers only to the wives of the gods, and '''Yoṣit,''' with its cognate words, denotes the young woman as ripe for marriage.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1843> ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtsehaftsnamen,'' 417.</ref> In the Rigveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1843> Rv. i. 164, 16;<br> v. 61, 8, etc. So also often later--''e.g.,'' Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 8, 2.</ref> [[स्त्री|Strī]] stands opposed to '''[[पुमांस्|Pumāṃs]],''' ‘man,’ and once to ''[[वृषन्|vṛṣan]],'' ‘male person’; not until the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1843> xii. 2, 39. ''Cf.'' [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 22, 1.</ref> does it mean ‘wife’ as opposed to '''Pati,''' ‘husband,’ and even in the Sūtras it is sharply opposed to '''[[जाया|Jāyā]].'''<br><br>In Vedic India by far the greater part of a woman's life was taken up in her marriage and marital relations (see Pati and '''[[मातृ|Mātṛ]]'''). There is no trace in the Rigveda of the seclusion of women, which was practically complete in all but the earliest Epic:<ref name=fx4_ve2_1843> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 349, 350.</ref> the maiden may be assumed to have grown up in her father's house, enjoying free intercourse with the youth of the village, and sharing in the work of the house. Education<ref name=fx5_ve2_1843> ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''op. cit.,'' 351, 352. See '''[[गार्गी वाचक्नवी|Gārgī Vācaknavī]]''' and others enumerated in the Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 4, 4;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 118, 119.</ref> was not denied to them, at any rate in certain cases, for we hear in the Upaniṣads of women who could take no unimportant part in disputations on philosophical topics. Moreover, women were taught to dance and sing, which were unmanly accomplishments.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1843> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 6, 5, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 7, 3;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 4, 3-6.</ref><br><br>Of the exact legal position of daughters the notices are few and meagre. The Rigveda,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1843> i. 124, 7. ''Cf.'' Av. i. 14, 2;<br> 17, 1;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 328;<br> Hopkins, ''op. cit.,'' 341, and see '''[[स्याल|Syāla]], [[पुत्रिका|Putrikā]].'''</ref> however, shows that in the place  of a father the brother was looked to for aid, and that brotherless maidens were apt to be ruined, though religious terrors were believed to await the man who took advantage of their defencelessness.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1843> Rv. iv. 5, 5.</ref> Moreover, women could not take an inheritance,<ref name=fx9_ve2_1843> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 8, 2;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 4, 2, 13;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 4.</ref> and were not independent persons in the eyes of the law, whether married or not. Presumably before marriage they lived on their parents or brothers, and after that on their husbands, while in the event of their husbands predeceasing them, their relatives took the property, burdened with the necessity of maintaining the wife.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1843> ''Cf.'' the Attic , Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1912, 427.</ref> Their earnings would be appropriated by their nearest relative--usually father or brother-in the few cases in which unmarried women could earn anything, as in the case of courtezans.

स्थ-पति
<u>'''Stha-pati'''</u> is the name of a royal official mentioned in the Atharvaveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1844> ii. 32, 4;<br> v. 23, 11 (of the chief of the worms in both cases).</ref> and often later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1844> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 5, 2, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xvii. 12;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 9, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xvi. 19;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 11, 6. 7;<br> xxiv. 18, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 17, etc.</ref> '''[[रेवोत्तरस्|Revottaras]] [[चाक्र|Cākra]]''' was the [[स्थपति|Sthapati]] of the exiled '''[[दुष्टरीतु|Duṣṭarītu]] [[पौंसायन|Pauṃsāyana]],''' a king of the '''Sṛñjayas,''' and succeeded in restoring him to his royal dignity.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1844> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 8, 1, 17;<br> 9, 3, 1 ''et seq.'' [[स्थपति|Sthapati]] here is part, as it were, of the name of the man.</ref> The exact sense of the term is not certain: ‘governor’<ref name=fx4_ve2_1844> In the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 1, 12;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], ix. 14, 12, is found [[निषाद|Niṣāda]]-[[स्थपति|sthapati]];<br> perhaps ‘governor of '''Niṣādas.'''’ But it may also mean (''cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 207, n.) a [[निषाद|Niṣāda]] as a [[स्थपति|Sthapati]];<br> thus, little can be deduced from this passage in particular. Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 41, 111, renders it ‘governor.’ ''Cf.'' also St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' and '''[[औपोदिति|Aupoditi]].'''</ref> is possible, but perhaps ‘chief judge’<ref name=fx5_ve2_1844> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 10, 13, n. 3;<br> 13, 203;<br> 17, 200;<br> 18, 260;<br> ''Über den [[राजसूय|Rājasūya]],'' 15, n. 6;<br> ''Über den [[वाजपेय|Vājapeya]],'' 9, 10. ''Cf.'' Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 5, 28;<br> 11, 11;<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 7, 11;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xxii. 7, 6.</ref> is more likely; as in the case of the early English judges, his functions may have been both executive and judicial. He is inferior in position to the king's brother.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1844> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 4, 4, 17.</ref> 

स्थविर
<u>'''Sthavira,'''</u> literally ‘elder,’ is used as a sort of epithet of several men; [[स्थविर|Sthavira]] '''[[शाकल्य|Śākalya]]''' occurs in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx1_ve2_1845> iii. 2, 1. 6.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1845> vii. 16;<br> viii. 1. 11.</ref> and [[स्थविर|Sthavira]] '''[[जातूकर्ण्य|Jātūkarṇya]]''' in the [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1845> xxvi. 5.</ref> ''Cf.'' the names '''Hrasva''' and '''Dīrgha.'''

स्थागर
<u>'''Sthāgara'''</u> in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1846> ii. 3, 10, 2;<br> Apastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiv. 15, 2.</ref> is applied to an ornament (''alaṃkāra'') meaning ‘made of the fragrant substance Sthagara,’ which elsewhere<ref name=fx2_ve2_1846> See Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 198;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 311, n. 2;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 5, 265.</ref> appears as Sthakara.

स्थाणु
<u>'''Sthāṇu'''</u> in the '''Rigveda'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1847> x. 40, 13.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1847> Av. x. 4, 1;<br> xiv. 2, 48;<br> xix. 49, 10, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘stump’ or ‘post’ of wood.

स्थातृ
<u>'''Sthātṛ'''</u> (‘he who stands’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1848> i. 33, 5;<br> 181, 3;<br> iii. 45, 2, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘driver’ of horses or a car.

स्था-पत्य
<u>'''Sthā-patya'''</u> denotes in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (xvii. 11, 6. 7) the ‘rank or status of a '''[[स्थपति|Sthapati]].'''’<br>==Foot Notes==

स्थाली
<u>'''Sthālī'''</u> denotes a ‘cooking pot,’ usually of earthenware, in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1850> viii. 6, 17.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1850> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 10, 5;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 27. 86;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 11, 8, etc. ''[[स्थाली|Sthālī]]-pāka,'' a dish of rice or barley boiled in milk, is mentioned in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vi. 4, 18;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xi. 6, etc.</ref>

स्थिरक गार्ग्य
<u>'''Sthiraka Gārgya'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[गर्ग|Garga]]'''’) is the name of a teacher in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1851> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 373.</ref>

स्थिवि
<u>'''Sthivi'''</u> occurs once (used in the plural) in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1852> x. 68, 3.</ref> probably meaning ‘bushel.’ The word is also found once in the adjective ''sthivimant,''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1852> Rv. x. 27, 15. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 238.</ref> ‘provided with bushels.’ 

स्थूणा
<u>'''Sthūṇā'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1853> i. 59, 1;<br> v. 45, 2;<br> 62, 7;<br> viii. 17, 14;<br> x. 18, 13 (of the grave).</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1853> Av. iii. 12, 6 (of the '''[[वंश|Vaṃśa]],''' ‘beam,’ being placed on the pillar);<br> xiv. 1, 63;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiv. 1, 3, 7;<br> 3, 1, 22, etc.;<br> ''[[स्थूणा|sthūṇā]]-rāja,'' ‘main pillar,’ iii. 1, 1, 11;<br> 5, 1, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 153.</ref> denotes the ‘pillar’ or ‘post’ of a house.

स्थूरि
<u>'''Sthūri'''</u> has in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1854> x. 131, 3.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1854> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 2, 4;<br> iii. 8, 21, 3;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 13, 12;<br> xviii. 9, 7;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 30, 6;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 3, 3, 9, etc.</ref> the sense of ‘drawn by one animal’ instead of the usual two (see '''[[रथ|Ratha]]'''), and always with an implication of inferiority.

स्थैरकायण
<u>'''Sthairakāyaṇa,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Sthiraka,'''’ is the patronymic of '''Mitravarcas''' in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1855> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 372 (where the word is spelt with ''n'').</ref>

स्थौलाष्ठीवि
<u>'''Sthaulāṣṭhīvi,'''</u> ‘descendant of Sthūlāṣṭhīva,’ is the patronymic of a grammarian in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]] (vii. 14; x. 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

स्नातक
<u>'''Snātaka,'''</u> the designation of the student ‘who has taken the bath,’ marking the termination of his studentship under a religious teacher, occurs in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xii. 1, 1, 10), and repeatedly in the Sūtras. ''Cf.'' '''Brahmacārin.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

स्नावन्य
<u>'''1. Snāvanya,'''</u> used in the plural, denotes particular parts of the body of a horse in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (v. 7, 23, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

स्नावन्य
<u>'''2. Snāvanya'''</u> appears to be the name of a people in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1859> ii. 5 (in a [[मन्त्र|Mantra]]). ''Cf.'' Caland, ''Über das rituelle [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] des [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],'' 35.</ref>

स्नुषा
<u>'''Snuṣā'''</u> denotes the ‘daughter-in-law’ in relation primarily to her father-in-law, but also to her mother-in-law. In the latter sense the word appears in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1860> x. 86, 13.</ref> in the epithet ''su-[[स्नुषा|snuṣā]],''  ‘having a good daughter-in-law,’ used of Vṛṣākapāyī, while in the former it occurs in several passages, where the daughterin-law's respect for her father-in-law is mentioned,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1860> Av. viii. 6, 24;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 22, 7;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 4, 6, 12.</ref> a respect which spirituous liquor alone causes to be violated.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1860> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 2;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xii. 12 (''Indische Studien,'' 5, 260).<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 414, 415.</ref> See also '''[[श्वशुर|Śvaśura]]''' and '''Pati.'''

स्पन्दन
<u>'''Spandana'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1861> iii. 53, 19.</ref> denotes a certain tree. Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1861> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Aufrecht, ''Rigveda,'' 2, vi;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 63.</ref> however, reads ''[[स्यन्दन|syandana]],'' ‘chariot.’

स्पर्शु
<u>'''Sparśu'''</u> is apparently the name of a western people in the [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xxi. 13).<br>==Foot Notes==

स्पश्
<u>'''Spaś.'''</u> See '''[[राजन्|Rājan]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

स्फूर्जक
<u>'''Sphūrjaka'''</u> denotes a tree (''Diospyros embryopteris'') mentioned in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 8, 1, 16).<br>==Foot Notes==

स्मद्-इभ
<u>'''Smad-ibha'''</u> is found once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1865> x. 49, 4.</ref> where Roth<ref name=fx2_ve2_1865> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 380;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 291, n. 5.</ref> takes the word as perhaps the name of an enemy of '''[[कुत्स|Kutsa]].''' ''Cf.'' '''Ibha.'''

स्यन्दन
<u>'''Syandana,'''</u> ‘chariot,’ is found in the earlier literature only, if at all, in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1866> iii. 53, 19, according to Roth. A wood called [[स्यन्दन|Syandana]] seems to be meant in the [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], viii. 15.</ref> where '''[[स्पन्दन|Spandana]]''' is the received reading. 

स्याल
<u>'''Syāla,'''</u> a word occurring in only one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1867> i. 109, 2.</ref> appears to denote the brother of a man's wife, who is regarded as willing to protect her, and so secure a marriage for her.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1867> So Sāyaṇa on Rv., ''loc. cit.''<br><br>''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 517;<br> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 79.</ref>

स्यूम-गभस्ति
<u>'''Syūma-gabhasti.'''</u> See '''[[गभस्ति|Gabhasti]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

स्यूम-गृभ्
<u>'''Syūma-gṛbh,'''</u> used of a horse in the Rigveda (vi. 36, 2) seems to mean ‘grasping the bit between his teeth,’ as a horse does when anxious to break away from control.<br>==Foot Notes==

स्यूमन्
<u>'''Syūman'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1870> iii. 61, 4.</ref> denotes, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1870> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.''</ref> the strap fastening the door of a house, the Homeric.

स्यूम-रश्मि
<u>'''Syūma-raśmi'''</u> is the name of a protégé of the Aśvins in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1871> i. 112 16;<br> viii. 52, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 150, 163.</ref>

स्रक्ति
<u>'''Srakti'''</u> is found in the description of the '''[[दाशराज्ञ|Dāśarājña]]''' in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1872> vii. 18, 17.</ref> where Hopkins<ref name=fx2_ve2_1872> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 15, 264, n.</ref> thinks the sense of ‘spears’ essential.

स्रज्
<u>'''Sraj,'''</u> ‘garland,’ is mentioned in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1873> iv. 38, 6;<br> v. 53, 4;<br> viii. 47, 15;<br> 56, 3.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1873> Av. i. 14, 1 (where it means a ‘cluster of flowers’ from a tree);<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvi. 4, 1;<br> xviii. 3, 2;<br> 7, 6;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xiii. 5, 4, 2, etc.</ref> as often worn by men when anxious to appear handsome, as at a wedding and so on. The Aśvins are described as ‘lotuswreathed’ (''[[पुष्कर|puṣkara]]-sraj'').<ref name=fx3_ve2_1873> Rv. x. 184, 3. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 265.</ref> 

स्राक्त्य
<u>'''Srāktya'''</u> is an adjective describing an amulet ('''[[मणि|Maṇi]]''') in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1874> viii. 5, 4. 7. 8. ''Cf.'' ii. 11.</ref> According to Weber,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1874> ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 164.</ref> it designates a crystal (literally ‘many-cornered’). The commentators,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1874> See Bloomfield, ''American Journal of Philology,'' 7, 477;<br> ''Hymns of the Athar vaveda,'' 577.</ref> however, agree in explaining the word to mean ‘derived from the Sraktya’--''i.e.,'' from the Tilaka tree (''Clerodendrum phlomoides'').

स्रुच्
<u>'''Sruc'''</u> denotes a ‘large wooden sacrificial ladle’ (used for pouring clarified butter on the fire) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1875> i. 84, 18;<br> 110, 6;<br> 144, 1, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1875> Av. v. 27, 5;<br> vi. 114, 3;<br> ix. 6, 17, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' for its shape, etc., Max Müller, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 9, xli, lxxx;<br> Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 67;<br> 26, 20, 23.</ref> It is of the length of an arm, with a bowl of the size of a hand and a beaklike spout.

स्रुव
<u>'''Sruva,'''</u> as opposed to '''Sruc,''' denotes in the ritual literature<ref name=fx1_ve2_1876> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], i. 11, 10, etc.</ref> a small ladle used to convey the offering ('''[[आज्य|Ājya]]''') from the cookingpot ('''[[स्थाली|Sthālī]]''') to the large ladle ('''[[जुहू|Juhū]]'''). In the Rigveda,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1876> i. 116, 24;<br> 121, 6, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Max Müller, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 9, viii;<br> Caland and Henry, ''L'Agniṣṭoma'' xliv;<br> Plate I., No. 9;<br> Plate II., No. 11 Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 12, 68;<br> 26, 20.</ref> however, it was clearly used for the actual Soma libation.

स्रेक-पर्ण
<u>'''Sreka-parṇa'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1877> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 6, 6, 3;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 15.</ref> seems to mean ‘like the oleander leaf.’

स्वज
<u>'''Svaja'''</u> in the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1878> iii. 27, 4;<br> v. 14, 10;<br> vi. 56, 2;<br> x. 4, 10, 15, 17;<br> xii. 3, 58.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1878> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 10, 2;<br> 14, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 26, 3.</ref> denotes the ‘viper.’ The word is explained by the commentators as ''sva-ja,'' ‘self-  born,’ but Roth,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1878> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.,'' gives the alternative ''vivipara.''</ref> Weber,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1878> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, 2, 89, n.</ref> and Zimmer<ref name=fx5_ve2_1878> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 95.</ref> prefer to derive it from the root ''svaj,'' ‘clasp,’ ‘encircle.’ In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā<ref name=fx6_ve2_1878> iii. 9, 3.</ref> the '''[[हरिण|Hariṇa]]''' is said to kill the viper.

स्वधिति
<u>'''1. Svadhiti'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1879> i. 162, 9. 18. 20.</ref> denotes the ‘axe’ or ‘knife’ used for dissecting the sacrificial horse. In all the other passages in that Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_1879> ii. 39, 7;<br> iii. 2, 10;<br> 8, 6, 11;<br> v. 7, 8;<br> vii. 3, 9;<br> viii. 102, 19;<br> x. 89, 7. ''Cf.'' n. 8.</ref> the sense of ‘axe’ for cutting wood is adequate; reference is made in one place<ref name=fx3_ve2_1879> ii. 39, 7.</ref> to sharpening the axe on the whetstone (''kṣṇotra''). In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1879> vi. 141, 2. ''Cf.'' [[मन्त्र|Mantra]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 8, 7;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 386, 387;<br> Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 159, who is inclined to compare '''[[परशु|Paraśu]]''' in Rv. iii. 53, 22.</ref> the term seems once to denote the copper (''[[लोहित|lohita]]'')<ref name=fx5_ve2_1879> Geldner, ''loc. cit.,'' understands this word to mean ‘red-hot.’</ref> knife used to mark the ears of cattle; the carpenter's knife or axe is also twice referred to there.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1879> ix. 4, 6 (probably so to be taken);<br> xii. 3, 33. In xviii. 2, 35, the sense is quite different. See Whitney, ''op. cit.,'' 845.</ref> Later the word means ‘axe’ generally.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1879> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 3, 3, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 15 (the slaughteringknife);<br> v. 43 (the axe to fell the tree) etc.</ref> As a weapon it does not appear at all.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1879> In Rv. x. 92, 15, [[स्वधिति|Svadhiti]] may refer to the thunderbolt of Indra.</ref>

स्वधिति
<u>'''2. Svadhiti'''</u> in certain passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1880> v. 32, 10;<br> ix. 96, 6. ''Cf.'' i. 88, 2.</ref> denotes, according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, a great tree with hard wood. This interpretation seems probable.

स्वनद्-रथ
<u>'''Svanad-ratha'''</u> (‘having a rattling car’) is taken by Ludwig<ref name=fx1_ve2_1881> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 159.</ref> as a proper name of '''Āsaṅga''' in the Rigveda.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1881> viii. 1, 32.</ref> But the word is most probably only an epithet. 

स्वनय भाव्य
<u>'''Svanaya Bhāvya'''</u> is the name of a prince on the '''[[सिन्धु|Sindhu]]''' (Indus) who bestowed gifts on '''[[कक्षीवन्त्|Kakṣīvant]],''' according to the Rigveda (i. 126, 1. 3). He is called Svanaya [[भावयव्य|Bhāvayavya]] in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xvi. 11, 5).<br>==Foot Notes==

स्वप्न
<u>'''Svapna,'''</u> ‘dream,’ is referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1883> ii. 28, 10;<br> x. 162, 6.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1883> Av. vii. 101, 1;<br> x. 3, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xx. 16;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 2, 2, 23, etc.</ref> Evil dreams<ref name=fx3_ve2_1883> Rv. ii. 28, 10;<br> Av. x. 3, 6.</ref> are often mentioned. The Āraṇyakas of the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1883> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 4;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, xi. 3. ''Cf.'' [[कौशिक|Kauśika]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xlvi. 9 ''et seq.;<br>'' Atharvaveda Pariśiṣṭa, lxviii.</ref> contain a list of dreams with their signification, as well as of ''pratyakṣa-darśanāni,'' ‘sights seen with one's own eyes.’

स्वर्
<u>'''Svar'''</u> denotes the ‘sun’<ref name=fx1_ve2_1884> i. 71, 2;<br> 105, 3;<br> 148, 1, etc.;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ii. 14.</ref> and the ‘heaven of light’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1884/> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1884> Rv. iii. 2, 7;<br> v. 83, 4;<br> x. 66, 4. 9, etc.;<br> Av. iv. 11, 6;<br> 14, 2, etc.</ref>

स्वर
<u>'''Svara'''</u> denotes in the Upaniṣads<ref name=fx1_ve2_1885> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 22, 5;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 2, 1.</ref> the sound of a vowel: these are described<ref name=fx2_ve2_1885> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ''loc. cit.''</ref> as being ''[[घोषवन्त्|ghoṣavant]],'' ‘sonant,’ and also as ''balavant,'' ‘uttered with force.’ The precise word for a mute is ''sparśa,''<ref name=fx3_ve2_1885> iii. 2, 1, etc.</ref> ‘contact,’ while ''ūṣman'' denotes a ‘sibilant,’ and ''[[स्वर|svara]]'' a ‘vowel,’ in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1885/> and [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyakas.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1885> viii. 1, etc.</ref> The semivowels are there denoted by ''anta-sthā'' (‘intermediate’)<ref name=fx5_ve2_1885> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 2, 1.</ref> or ''akṣara.''<ref name=fx6_ve2_1885> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka, viii. 1.</ref> Another division in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx7_ve2_1885> ii. 2, 4.</ref> is into ''[[घोष|ghoṣa]], ūṣman,'' and ''vyañjana,'' apparently ‘vowels,’ ‘sibilants,’ and ‘consonants’ respectively. ''[[घोष|Ghoṣa]]'' elsewhere in that Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx8_ve2_1885> ii. 2, 2. ''Cf.'' Keith's edition, p. 213.</ref> seems to have the general sense of ‘sounds.’ The [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]]<ref name=fx9_ve2_1885> ''Loc. cit.''</ref> refers to ''[[मात्रा|mātrā]],'' a ‘mora’;<ref name=fx10_ve2_1885> Also [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka, iii. 1, 5;<br> Sāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka, vii. 13.</ref> ''bala,'' ‘force’ of utterance, and ''[[वर्ण|varṇa]],'' ‘letter,’ an expression found elsewhere<ref name=fx11_ve2_1885> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 32, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxvi. 5;<br> Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], x. 4;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' v. 32.</ref> in the explanation of ''om,'' as compacted of ''a + u + m.'' <br><br>The [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx12_ve2_1885> iii. 1, 3, 5.</ref> and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Āraṇyaka<ref name=fx13_ve2_1885> vii. 10, 12.</ref> recognize the three forms of the Rigveda text as ''pratṛṇṇa, nirbhuja,'' and ''ubhayam-antareṇa,'' denoting respectively the Saṃhitā, Pada, and Krama Pāṭhas of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx14_ve2_1885> Max Müller, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]] Prātiśākhya,'' ii. ''et seq.;<br> Nachträge,'' ii;<br> Oldenberg, ''Prolegomena,'' 380 ''et seq.;<br> Sacred Books of the East,'' 30, 146 ''et seq.;<br>'' Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 51.</ref> The same authorities<ref name=fx15_ve2_1885> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]], iii. 2, 6;<br> [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]], viii. 11.</ref> recognize the importance of the distinction of the cerebral and dental ''n'' and ''s,'' and refer<ref name=fx16_ve2_1885> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]], iii. 1, 1;<br> 2, 6;<br> Sāṅkhāyana, vii. 2;<br> viii. 11.</ref> to the '''Māṇḍūkeyas'''' mode of recitation. They also discuss<ref name=fx17_ve2_1885> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]], iii. 1, 2. 3. 5;<br> 2, 2 [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]], vii. 13;<br> viii. 1, 2.</ref> Sandhi, the euphonic ‘combination’ of letters.<br><br>The Prātiśākhyas of the several Saṃhitās develop in detail the grammatical terminology, and Yāska's [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]<ref name=fx18_ve2_1885> See Roth's edition (1852), p. 222, for a list of teachers cited by [[यास्क|Yāska]], especially '''[[कौत्स|Kautsa]]''' and '''[[शाकटायन|Śākaṭāyana]].'''</ref> contains a good deal of grammatical material. The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx19_ve2_1885> x. 5, 1, 2. 3.</ref> distinguishes the genders, and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx20_ve2_1885> x. 9, 1. 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cultur,'' 701 ''et seq.''</ref> the division of words in the Sāman recitation.

स्व-राज्
<u>'''Sva-rāj,'''</u> ‘self-ruler,’ ‘king,’ is found frequently in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1886> i. 36, 7;<br> 51, 15;<br> 61, 9, etc. (of gods).</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1886> Av. xvii. 1, 22;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 6, 2;<br> iv. 4, 8, 1;<br> v. 5, 4, 1, etc.</ref> It is the technical term for the kings of the west according to the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1886> viii. 14. ''Cf.'' perhaps the republican form of government of which traces are seen in the Buddhist literature by Rhys Davids, ''Buddhist India,'' 19.</ref>

स्वरु
<u>'''Svaru'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1887> i. 92, 5;<br> 162, 9;<br> iii. 8, 6, etc.</ref> or later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1887> Av. iv. 24, 4;<br> xii. 1, 13, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘post,’ or more precisely in the ritual a splinter of the [[यूप|Yūpa]], or sacrificial post.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1887> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 3, 8;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 7, 1;<br> vi. 3, 4 9, etc.;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 1, 22;<br> 8, 1, 5, etc.</ref> 

स्वर्-जित् नाग्न-जित
<u>'''Svar-jit Nāgna-jita'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[नग्न-जित्|Nagna-jit]]'''’) is the name of a royal personage in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1888> viii. 1, 4, 10. ''Cf.'' Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 1^2, 515.</ref> a '''[[गन्धार|Gandhāra]]''' prince, whose views on the ritual are referred to with contempt.

स्वर्-णर
<u>'''Svar-ṇara'''</u> appears to be the proper name of a sacrificer in two verses of the Rigveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1889> viii. 3, 12;<br> 12, 2. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 160;<br> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 17, 89.</ref> According to Geldner,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1889> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 209.</ref> it everywhere<ref name=fx3_ve2_1889> Rv. iv. 21, 3;<br> v. 18, 4;<br> 14, 1;<br> viii. 6, 39;<br> 65, 2;<br> 103, 14;<br> ix. 70, 6;<br> x. 65, 4. Perhaps in viii. 12, 2, it means ‘coming from [[स्वर्णर|Svarṇara]].’</ref> means a specially sacred lake and the Soma-producing district around it.

स्वर्-भानु असुर
<u>'''Svar-bhānu Asura'''</u> is the name, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1890> v. 40, 5. 6. 8. 9.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1890> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 1, 2, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 5, 2;<br> 6, 13;<br> vi. 6, 8;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 2, 2;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xxiv. 3.</ref> of a demon supposed to have eclipsed the sun. See '''[[सूर्य|Sūrya]].'''

स्व-सर
<u>'''Sva-sara,'''</u> according to the St. Petersburg Dictionary, denotes ‘cattle stall,’<ref name=fx1_ve2_1891> Rv. i. 3, 8;<br> ii. 2, 2;<br> 34, 8;<br> v. 62, 2;<br> viii. 88, 1;<br> [[सामवेद|Sāmaveda]], i. 5, 2, 3, 2.</ref> and more generally ‘dwelling-place,’ ‘house,’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1891> Rv. i. 34, 7;<br> iii. 60, 6;<br> 61, 4;<br> vi. 68, 10;<br> viii. 99, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 3, 5, 20.</ref> and then ‘nest of birds.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1891> Rv. ii. 19, 2;<br> 34, 5.</ref> Geldner,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1891> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 110-115.</ref> however, shows that the real sense is the ‘wandering at will’ of cattle, more precisely their ‘grazing in the morning,’<ref name=fx5_ve2_1891> Rv. i. 3, 8;<br> ii. 2, 2;<br> 34, 8;<br> v. 62, 2;<br> viii. 88, 1.</ref> and in the case of birds their ‘early flight’ from the nest,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1891> Rv. ii. 19, 2;<br> 34, 5.</ref> while metaphorically it is applied first to the morning pressing of Soma and then to all three pressings.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1891> Rv. i. 34, 7;<br> iii. 60, 6;<br> vi. 68, 10;<br> viii. 99, 1. In Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''loc. cit.,'' it is equivalent to ‘libation.’</ref>

स्वसृ
<u>'''Svasṛ'''</u> is the regular word from the Rigveda onwards<ref name=fx1_ve2_1892> Rv. ii. 32, 6;<br> vi. 55, 4. 5;<br> viii. 101, 15;<br> x. 108, 9, etc.</ref> for ‘sister.’ Like the word '''[[भ्रातृ|Bhrātṛ]],''' the term sister can be applied  to things not precisely so related. For example, in the Rigveda the fingers and the seasons are ‘sisters,’ and night is the sister of dawn, for whom, as the elder, she makes way.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1892> Rv. i. 124, 8. See Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 463;<br> Rv. i. 62, 10;<br> 64, 7, 71, 1, etc.</ref> The '''Paṇis''' offer to adopt Saramā as their sister;<ref name=fx3_ve2_1892> Rv. x. 108, 9.</ref> but this use is not applied--any more than in the case of [[भ्रातृ|Bhrātṛ]]--to ordinary human beings.<br><br>The sister stood in a close relation to her brother. If the father was dead or feeble, the sister was dependent on her brother and on his wife, as appears from the Rigveda<ref name=fx4_ve2_1892> x. 85, 46. ''Cf.'' ix. 96, 22.</ref> and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx5_ve2_1892> iii. 37, 5.</ref> Moreover, maidens without brothers were apt to find marriage difficult, and to degenerate into Hetairai;<ref name=fx6_ve2_1892> Av. i. 17, 1;<br> Rv. i. 124, 7;<br> iv. 5, 5;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], iii. 5.</ref> but it is not certain whether this was due, as Zimmer<ref name=fx7_ve2_1892> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 328.</ref> thinks, to brothers being required to arrange marriages for orphan girls, or because sonless fathers were anxious to make their daughters '''Putrikās,''' in order that they themselves, instead of the husbands, should count the daughters' sons as their own.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1892> ''Cf.'' Geldner, ''Rigveda, Kommentar,'' 22, 48, 49 (on Rv. iii. 31, 1 ''et seq.'').</ref> See also '''[[जामि|Jāmi]].'''

स्वस्रीय
<u>'''Svasrīya'''</u> occurs in the sense of ‘sister's son’ in the description of Viśvarūpa's ancestry in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1893> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 5, 1, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, ii. 4, 1. ''Cf.'' Delbrück, ''Die indogermanischen Verwandtschaftsnamen,'' 485.</ref>

स्वाती
<u>'''Svātī.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

स्वाध्याय
<u>'''Svādhyāya'''</u> (‘reciting to oneself’) in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1895> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 3, 6;<br> iv. 6, 9, 6;<br> xi. 5, 6, 3;<br> 7, 1, 4, 7;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 12, 1;<br> 8, 15;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 1.</ref> denotes the study or repetition of the Vedic texts. The Sūtras give rules for it in great detail. ''Cf.'' '''[[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].''' 

स्वायव
<u>'''Svāyava,'''</u> ‘descendant of Svāyu,’ is the patronymic of '''Kūśāmba [[लातव्य|Lātavya]]''' in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]] (viii. 6, 8).<br>==Foot Notes==

स्वा-राज्य
<u>'''Svā-rājya.'''</u> See '''[[राज्य|Rājya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

स्वेद-ज
<u>'''Sveda-ja,'''</u> ‘born of sweat’--that is, ‘engendered by hot moisture’--is used in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iii. 3, 3) as a term designating a class of creatures comprising vermin of all sorts. The [[मानव|Mānava]] [[धर्म|Dharma]] Śāstra (i. 45) explains it as ‘flies, mosquitoes, lice, bugs, and so forth.’<br><br>''Cf.'' Keith, ''[[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka,'' 235.<br>==Foot Notes==

स्वैदायन
<u>'''Svaidāyana,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''Sveda,'''’ is the patronymic of a '''[[शौनक|Śaunaka]]''' in the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1899> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 4, 1, 2. 3;<br> Gopatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 6.</ref>

स्वौपश
<u>'''Svaupaśa.'''</u> See '''[[ओपश|Opaśa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

हंस
<u>'''Haṃsa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1901> i. 65, 5;<br> 163, 10;<br> ii. 34, 5;<br> iii. 8, 9, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1901> Av. vi. 12, 1, etc.</ref> denotes the ‘gander.’ These birds are described as dark in colour on the back (''nīlapṛṣṭha'');<ref name=fx3_ve2_1901> Rv. vii. 59, 7.</ref> they fly in troops,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1901> Rv. iii. 8, 9.</ref> swim in the water (''uda-prut''),<ref name=fx5_ve2_1901> Rv. i. 65, 5;<br> iii. 45, 4.</ref> make loud noises,<ref name=fx6_ve2_1901> Rv. iii. 53, 10.</ref> and are wakeful at night.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1901> Av. vi. 12, 1.</ref> The [[हंस|Haṃsa]] is credited with the power of separating Soma from water (as later milk from water) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx8_ve2_1901> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxviii. 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 11, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xix. 74;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 6, 2, 1.</ref> It is also mentioned as one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’).<ref name=fx9_ve2_1901> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 21, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 22. 35.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 89, 90;<br> Lanman, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 19, 151;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 150.</ref> 

हंस-साचि
<u>'''Haṃsa-sāci'''</u> is the name of an unknown bird mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx1_ve2_1902> v. 5, 20, 1. ''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 93.</ref> as one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’).

हय
<u>'''Haya'''</u> denotes ‘horse’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1903> v. 46, 1;<br> vii. 74, 4;<br> ix. 107, 25.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1903> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, vii. 47;<br> xxii. 19, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 231.</ref>

हर-याण
<u>'''Hara-yāṇa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1904> viii. 28, 22;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], v. 15. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 162.</ref> is clearly the name of a man mentioned along with '''[[उक्षण्यायन|Ukṣaṇyāyana]]''' and '''[[सुषामन्|Suṣāman]].'''

हरिण
<u>'''Hariṇa'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1905> i. 163, 1;<br> v. 78, 2.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1905> Av. vi. 67, 3, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘gazelle.’ It is at once a type of speed<ref name=fx3_ve2_1905> Av. iii. 7, 1.</ref> and terror.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1905> Av. vi. 67, 3.</ref> Its horns are used as amulets.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1905> Av. iii. 7, 1. 2.</ref> It is fond of eating barley ('''Yava''').<ref name=fx6_ve2_1905> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 2 (''hariṇī'');<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiii. 30;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 13, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]], iv. 8 (also ''hariṇī'');<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 7, 2 (''hariṇī'').</ref> In the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1905> iii. 9, 3.</ref> it is said to kill vipers ('''[[स्वज|Svaja]]'''). ''Cf.'' '''[[कुलुङ्ग|Kuluṅga]], [[न्यङ्कु|Nyaṅku]].''' The feminine is Hariṇī.<ref name=fx8_ve2_1905> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 19, 2, and see n. 6.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 83;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 336, 337.</ref>

हरित
<u>'''1. Harita'''</u> seems to mean ‘gold’ in a few passages of the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1906> Av. v. 28, 5. 9;<br> xi. 3, 8;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 5.</ref>

हरित कश्यप
<u>'''2. Harita Kaśyapa'''</u> is mentioned as a teacher, a pupil of '''[[शिल्प कश्यप|Śilpa Kaśyapa]],''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1907> vi. 4, 33 (Mādhyaṃdina = vi. 5, 3 [[काण्व|Kāṇva]]).</ref> 

हरि-द्रु
<u>'''Hari-dru'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 8, 1, 16) is the name of a tree (''Pinus deodora'').<br>==Foot Notes==

हरिमन्
<u>'''Hariman'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1909> i. 50, 11 ''et seq.''</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1909> i. 22, 1;<br> ix. 8, 9;<br> xix. 44, 2.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 378, 388.</ref> denotes ‘yellowness’ as a disease, ‘jaundice.’

हरि-यूपीया
<u>'''Hari-yūpīyā'''</u> is mentioned in a hymn of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1910> vi. 27, 5.</ref> as the scene of the defeat of the '''Vṛcīvants''' by '''Abhyāvartin Cāyamana.''' It may denote either a place or a river, since many battles seem to have been fought on the banks of rivers. Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_1910> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158.</ref> took it as the name of a town on the river '''[[यव्यावती|Yavyāvatī]],''' which is identified with it in Sāyaṇa's commentary on the passage. Hillebrandt<ref name=fx3_ve2_1910> ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 268, n. 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 18, 19;<br> Kaegi, ''Rigveda,'' n. 328.</ref> thinks that it is the river Iryāb (Haliāb), a tributary of the Kurum ('''[[क्रुमु|Krumu]]'''), but this is not at all probable.

हरि-वर्ण अङ्गिरस
<u>'''Hari-[[वर्ण|varṇa]] Aṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of Aṅgiras’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman or chant in the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1911> viii. 9, 4. 5. ''Cf.'' Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 63.</ref>

हरि-श्चन्द्र वैधस
<u>'''Hari-ścandra Vaidhasa'''</u> (‘descendant of Vedhas’) '''[[ऐक्ष्वाक|Aikṣvāka]]''' (‘descendant of '''[[इक्ष्वाकु|Ikṣvāku]]'''’) is the name of a probably mythical king whose rash vow to offer up his son '''[[रोहित|Rohita]]''' to Varuṇa is the source of the tale of '''[[शुनःशेप|Śunaḥśepa]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Brāhmana (vii. 14, 2) and the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xv. 17).<br>==Foot Notes==

हर्म्य
<u>'''Harmya'''</u> denotes the Vedic ‘house’ as a unity including the stabling<ref name=fx1_ve2_1913> Rv. vii. 56, 16. ''Cf.'' x. 106, 5.</ref> and so forth, and surrounded by a fence or wall of  some sort.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1913> Rv. vii. 55, 6. Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 278, n. 2, takes ''harmyeṣṭhāḥ,'' ‘standing on a house’ (Rv. vii. 56, 16), to refer to princes on the roof of a palace.</ref> It is several times referred to in the Rigveda<ref name=fx3_ve2_1913> i. 121, 1 (the people, ''viśaḥ,'' of the house);<br> 166, 4;<br> ix. 71, 4;<br> 78, 3;<br> x. 43, 3;<br> 73, 10, etc.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1913> Av. xviii. 4, 55 (a palace of Yama);<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 6, 3, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 149.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[गृह|Gṛha]].'''

हलिक्ष्ण
<u>'''Halikṣṇa'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1914> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 12;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 31.</ref> or '''Halīkṣṇa'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1914> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 12, 1;<br> 7, 23, 1.</ref> is mentioned as one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās. The commentator Mahīdhara<ref name=fx3_ve2_1914> On Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> thinks that it is a kind of lion, Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx4_ve2_1914> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> that a green Caṭaka bird or a lion (''[[तृण|tṛṇa]]-hiṃsa'')<ref name=fx5_ve2_1914> ''[[तृण|Tṛṇa]]-[[सिंह|siṃha]]'' is not much more intelligible.</ref> is meant. In the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx6_ve2_1914> ii. 33, 3.</ref> Halīkṣṇa seems to be some particular intestine, but Weber<ref name=fx7_ve2_1914> ''Indische Studien,'' 13, 206.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 79.</ref> thinks it may mean ‘gall.’

हविर्-धान
<u>'''Havir-dhāna'''</u> (‘oblation receptacle’) denotes primarily the cart on which the Soma plants are conveyed to be pressed,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1915> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 1, 3, 1;<br> vi. 2, 9, 1. 4, etc.</ref> then the shed in which these Soma vehicles were kept.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1915> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 2, 11, 1. 4, etc.<br><br>See '''[[गृह|Gṛha]];<br>''' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 154.</ref>

हविष्-कृत् आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Haviṣ-kṛt Āṅgirasa'''</u> (‘descendant of '''[[अङ्गिरस्|Aṅgiras]]'''’) is the name of the seer of a Sāman or chant according to the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1916> xi. 10, 9. 10;<br> xx. 11, 3.</ref> and the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1916> vii. 1, 4, 1.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 2, 160;<br> Hopkins, ''Transactions of the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences,'' 15, 62.</ref> See the following.

हविष्मन्त् आङ्गिरस
<u>'''Haviṣmant Āṅgirasa'''</u> is mentioned along with '''Haviṣkṛt,''' in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā and the [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx2_ve2_1917> xi. 10, 9. 10;<br> xx. 11, 3.</ref> as the seer of a Sāman or chant.<br><br>^1) vii. 1, 4, 1. 

हविस्
<u>'''Havis'''</u> is the general term for an offering to the gods, ‘oblation,’ whether of grain, or Soma, or milk, or clarified butter, etc. It is common from the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1918> i. 24, 11;<br> 26, 6;<br> 170, 5, etc.</ref> onwards.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1918> Av. iii. 10, 5;<br> vi. 5, 3, etc.</ref>

हस्त
<u>'''Hasta.'''</u> See '''[[नक्षत्र|Nakṣatra]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

हस्त-घ्न
<u>'''Hasta-ghna'''</u> denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1920> vi. 75, 14;<br> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]], ix. 14. The reading is assured by the parallels in the Saṃhitās: [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 6, 6, 5;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 16, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxix. 51.</ref> a ‘hand-guard,’ a covering used as a protection of the hand and arm from the impact of the bowstring. The word is of remarkable and still unexplained formation.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1920> Pischel, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 296;<br> Oldenberg, ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]]-Noten,'' 1, 416.</ref> Lāṭyāyana<ref name=fx3_ve2_1920> Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 10, 7.</ref> has ''[[हस्त|hasta]]-tra'' and the Epic ''hastāvāpa''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1920> Hopkins, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 13, 308.</ref> as its equivalent in sense.

हस्तादान
<u>'''Hastādāna.'''</u> See '''[[पशु|Paśu]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

हस्तिन्
<u>'''Hastin,'''</u> ‘having a hand,’ with '''[[मृग|Mṛga]],''' ‘beast,’ denotes in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1922> i. 64, 7;<br> iv. 16, 14.</ref> and the Atharvaveda<ref name=fx2_ve2_1922> xii. 1, 25. Elsewhere [[हस्तिन्|Hastin]] is used alone: iii. 22, 3;<br> iv. 36, 9;<br> vi. 38, 2;<br> 70, 2;<br> xix. 1, 32.</ref> the ‘elephant.’ Later the adjective alone comes to mean ‘elephant.’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1922> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iii. 14, 8;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 29;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 8, 8;<br> xxiii. 13, 2;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 14;<br> v. 31, 2;<br> vi. 27, 2;<br> Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 3, 4, etc.;<br> Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], vii. 24, 2 (coupled with gold), etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 22, 1.</ref> The animal was famed for its strength<ref name=fx4_ve2_1922> Rv. ''loc. cit.;<br>'' Av ii. 22, 1, 3.</ref> as well as its virility.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1922> Av. iii. 22, 6;<br> vi. 70, 2.</ref> It is mentioned with man and monkey as one of the beasts that take hold by the hand (''[[हस्तादान|hastādāna]]''), as opposed to those that take hold by the mouth (''mukhādāna'').<ref name=fx6_ve2_1922> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 4, 5, 7;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv, 5, 7.</ref> It was tamed, as the expression '''[[हस्तिप|Hastipa]],''' ‘elephant-keeper,’ shows, and tame elephants were used to catch others (see '''[[वारण|Vāraṇa]]'''). But there is no trace of its use in war, though Ktesias and Megasthenes both record such use for  their times.<ref name=fx7_ve2_1922> Von Schroeder, ''Indiens Literatur und Cidtur,'' 434.</ref> The Atharvaveda<ref name=fx8_ve2_1922> Av. iv. 36, 9.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 80.</ref> alludes to its being pestered by mosquitoes.

हस्ति-प
<u>'''Hasti-pa,'''</u> ‘elephant-keeper,’ is mentioned as one of the victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1923> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 11;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 9, 1.</ref>

हस्रा
<u>'''Hasrā'''</u> (‘laughing woman’) in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1924> i. 124, 7.</ref> denotes a courtesan according to Pischel.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1924> ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 196, 308.</ref>

हायन
<u>'''Hāyana'''</u> denotes a ‘year,’ usually in compounds.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1925> Av. viii. 2, 21;<br> ''śata-[[हायन|hāyana]],'' ‘a hundred years old,’ viii. 2, 8;<br> 7, 22;<br> ''hāyanī,'' xii. 1, 36 (probably corrupt).</ref> In the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā<ref name=fx2_ve2_1925> xv. 5.</ref> and the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_1925> v. 3, 3, 6 (the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 8, 10, 1, has instead ''mahā-[[व्रीहि|vrīhi]],'' ‘great rice’).</ref> the term appears as a designation of a species of red rice. As an adjective in the sense of ‘lasting a year’ or ‘recurring every year,’ it is applied to fever in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1925> xix. 39, 10.<br><br>''Cf.'' Schrader, ''Prehistoric Antiquities,'' 301.</ref>

हारिकर्णी-पुत्र
<u>'''Hārikarṇī-putra,'''</u> ‘son of a female descendant of Harikarṇa,’ is the name of a teacher, a pupil of '''[[भारद्वाजी-पुत्र|Bhāradvājī-putra]],''' in the last [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) in the Mādhyaṃdina recension of the Brhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 4, 30).<br>==Foot Notes==

हारिद्रव
<u>'''Hāridrava'''</u> is the name of a yellow bird in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1927> i. 50, 12;<br> viii. 35, 7.</ref> perhaps the ‘yellow water-wagtail.’<ref name=fx2_ve2_1927> Sāyaṇa on Rv. i. 50, 12;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 7, 6, 2, treats it as the name of a plant (''cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 62). But on Av. i. 22, 4, he takes it as ''gopītanaka,'' ‘wagtail.’</ref> Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve2_1927> ''Rigveda, Glossar,'' 213.<br><br>''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 264, n. 1;<br> 266;<br> Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 23.</ref> compares the Greek  

हारिद्रविक
<u>'''Hāridravika'''</u> is the title of a work by Hāridravin mentioned in the [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1928> ix. 5. See Roth, ''[[निरुक्त|Nirukta]],'' xxiii;<br> von Schroeder, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, 1, xiii.</ref>

हारि-द्रुमत
<u>'''Hāri-drumata,'''</u> ‘descendant of Haridrumant,’ is the patronymic of a '''[[गौतम|Gautama]]''' in the Chāndogya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (iv. 4, 3).<br>==Foot Notes==

हालिङ्गव
<u>'''Hāliṅgava,'''</u> ‘descendant of Haliṅgu,’ is the name of a teacher in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (x. 4, 5, 1).<br>==Foot Notes==

हिता
<u>'''Hitā'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1931> Bṛhadāraṇyaka [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], ii. 1, 21;<br> iv. 2, 4;<br> 3, 20;<br> [[कौषीतकि|Kauṣītaki]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 19.</ref> is the name of certain ‘veins.’ ''Cf.'' '''[[हिरा|Hirā]].'''

हिम
<u>'''Hima,'''</u> denoting ‘cold,’ ‘cold weather,’ is quite common in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1932> i. 116, 8;<br> 119, 6;<br> viii. 32, 26, etc.</ref> but less frequent later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1932> Av. vii. 18, 2;<br> xiii. 1, 46;<br> xix. 49, 5 (night as mother of coolness), etc.</ref> As ‘snow’ the word appears as a masculine in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1932> iii. 12, 7, 2.</ref> and often later as a neuter.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1932> Saḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 9, etc.<br><br>''Cf.'' Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 3, 192-195.</ref> ''Cf.'' '''[[हेमन्त|Hemanta]].'''

हिमवन्त्
<u>'''Himavant,'''</u> ‘snowy,’ appears as an epithet of mountains in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1933> xii. 1, 11.</ref> It is also used both there<ref name=fx2_ve2_1933> vi. 95, 3. See also iv. 9, 9;<br> v. 4, 2. 8;<br> 25. 7;<br> vi. 24, 1 (where reference is made to the rivers of the Himālayas);<br> xix. 39, 1.</ref> and in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1933> x. 121, 4.</ref> as well as later,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1933> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 5, 11, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxiv. 30;<br> xxv. 12;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], viii. 14, 3 (the '''Uttara Kurus''' and '''Uttara Madras''' live beyond it;<br> perhaps in Kaśmīr), etc.</ref> as a noun. There seems no reasen to deny that in all the passages the word refers vaguely to the mountains now called Himālaya, though it is possible that the name may include mountains not strictly in that system, like the Suleiman hills.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1933> Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 198.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leven,'' 29;<br> Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 18, 12, who inclines to see a reminiscence of the Caucasus.</ref> See also '''[[मूजवन्त्|Mūjavant]]''' and '''Trikakubh.''' 

हिमा
<u>'''Himā'''</u> denotes ‘winter’ in the combination a ‘hundred winters’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1934> i. 64, 14;<br> ii. 33, 2;<br> v. 54, 15;<br> vi. 48, 8.</ref> and elsewhere.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1934> Av. ii. 28, 4;<br> xii. 2, 28;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 6, 6, 3;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, ii. 27.</ref>

हिरणिन्
<u>'''Hiraṇin,'''</u> ‘rich in gold,’ is apparently an epithet of '''[[त्रसदस्यु|Trasadasyu]]''' in one verse of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1935> v. 53, 8.</ref> referring to the golden raiment or possessions of the king. Ludwig,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1935> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 155.</ref> however, thinks the word is a proper name, possibly of Trasadasyu's son.

हिरणिन
<u>'''Hiraṇina'''</u> is found in one passage of the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1936> vi. 63, 9.</ref> where Ludwig<ref name=fx2_ve2_1936> Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 158.</ref> takes the word as a name of '''[[शाण्ड|Śāṇḍa]].''' But it seems to be an adjectival form of ''[[हिरणिन्|hiraṇin]],'' ‘golden.’

हिरण्य
<u>'''Hiraṇya'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1937> i. 43, 5;<br> iii. 34, 9;<br> iv. 10, 6;<br> 17, 11, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1937> Av. i. 9, 2;<br> ii. 36, 7;<br> v. 28, 6;<br> vi. 38, 2, etc.</ref> denotes ‘gold.’ It is hardly possible to exaggerate the value attached to gold by the Vedic Indians. The metal was, it is clear, won from the bed of rivers. Hence the Indus is called ‘golden’<ref name=fx3_ve2_1937> Rv. x. 75, 8.</ref> and ‘of golden stream.’<ref name=fx4_ve2_1937> Rv. vi. 61, 7;<br> viii. 26, 18.</ref> Apparently the extraction of gold from the earth was known,<ref name=fx5_ve2_1937> Rv. i. 117, 5;<br> Av. xii. 1, 6. 26. 44.</ref> and washing for gold is also recorded.<ref name=fx6_ve2_1937> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 1, 7, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 1, 1, 5.</ref><br><br>Gold is the object of the wishes of the Vedic singer,<ref name=fx7_ve2_1937> Rv. vi. 47, 23;<br> viii. 78, 9;<br> Pischel and Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, xxiv.</ref> and golden treasures (''hiraṇyāni'') are mentioned as given by patrons<ref name=fx8_ve2_1937> ''Cf.'' also '''[[हिरण्यस्तूप|Hiraṇyastūpa]]''' as a proper name.</ref> along with cows and horses. Gold was used for ornaments for neck and breast ('''[[निष्क|Niṣka]]'''), for ear-rings ('''[[कर्ण-शोभन|Karṇa-śobhana]]'''), and even for cups.<ref name=fx9_ve2_1937> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 1, 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 3, 3, 7;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 1, 2, 19;<br> 5, 28.</ref> Gold is always associated with the gods.<ref name=fx10_ve2_1937> All that is connected with them is of gold;<br> the horses of the sun are ''[[हिरण्य|hiraṇya]]-tvacas,'' ‘gold-skinned’ (Av. xiii. 2, 8), and so on.</ref> <br><br>In the plural [[हिरण्य|Hiraṇya]] denotes ‘ornaments of gold.’<ref name=fx11_ve2_1937> Rv. i. 122, 2;<br> 162, 16;<br> ii. 33, 9;<br> v. 60, 4;<br> Av. iv. 10, 6;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xv. 50;<br> xx. 37;<br> also in the singular, Av. i. 35, 1;<br> xviii. 4, 56.</ref><br><br>A gold currency was evidently beginning to be known in so far as definite weights of gold are mentioned: thus a weight, ''aṣṭā-prūḍ,'' occurs in the Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx12_ve2_1937> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iii. 4, 1, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xi. 1;<br> xiii. 10;<br> von Schroeder, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 49, 164.</ref> and the golden ''[[शतमान|śatamāna]],'' ‘weight of a hundred ('''Kṛṣṇalas''')’ is found in the same texts.<ref name=fx13_ve2_1937> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 5, 5, 16;<br> xii. 7, 2, 13;<br> 9, 1, 4. ''Cf.'' xiii. 1, 1, 4;<br> 2, 3, 2;<br> 4, 1, 13;<br> 2, 7. 13;<br> xiv. 3, 1, 32;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 3, 11, 5;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, viii. 5;<br> xxii. 8;<br> Weber, ''Indische Streifen,'' 1, 101. Geldner, ''Vedische Studien,'' 1, 268, is inclined to think that a gold unit is alluded to in the vague phrases ‘thousands,’ etc., of the Rigveda. See viii. 1, 13;<br> 65, 12;<br> x. 95, 3, etc.</ref> In several passages,<ref name=fx14_ve2_1937> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 7, 4;<br> iii. 8, 2, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 7, 1, 7;<br> xiii. 4, 1, 6, etc.</ref> moreover, ''[[हिरण्य|hiraṇya]]'' or ''hiraṇyāni'' may mean ‘pieces of gold.’<br><br>Gold is described sometimes as ''[[हरित|harita]],''<ref name=fx15_ve2_1937> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 4;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 4, 6;<br> Ṣaḍviṃśa [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 9.</ref> ‘yellowish,’ sometimes as ''[[रजत|rajata]],''<ref name=fx16_ve2_1937> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, i. 5, 1, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xii. 4, 4, 7;<br> xiii. 4, 2, 10, etc.</ref> ‘whitish,’ when probably. ‘silver’ is alluded to. It was obtained from the ore by smelting.<ref name=fx17_ve2_1937> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vi. 1, 3, 5. ''Cf.'' ii. 2, 3, 28;<br> xii. 4, 3, 1;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xvii. 6, 4 (''niṣ-ṭap,'' ‘heat’);<br> Jaiminīya [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 10 (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 16, 234, ccxliii);<br> Lāṭyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iii. 1, 9, etc.;<br> Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 34, 6.</ref> Megasthenes<ref name=fx18_ve2_1937> See Diodorus Siculus, ii. 36;<br> Strabo, pp. 703, 711.<br><br>''Cf.'' Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 49-51;<br> Macdonell, ''Sanskrit Literature,'' 151.</ref> bears testimony to the richness in gold of India in his time.

हिरण्य-कशिपु
<u>'''Hiraṇya-kaśipu'''</u> in the Brāhmaṇas<ref name=fx1_ve2_1938> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 9, 20, 1;<br> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], vii. 18, 12. ''Cf.'' the word as an adjective with the sense of ‘having a golden cloth,’ Av. v. 7, 10.</ref> denotes a ‘golden seat,’ probably one covered with cloth of gold.

हिरण्य-कार
<u>'''Hiraṇya-kāra'''</u> denotes a ‘worker in gold’ mentioned in the list of victims at the Puruṣamedha (‘human sacrifice’) in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1939> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxx. 17;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 14, 1.</ref> 

हिरण्य-दन्त्
<u>'''Hiraṇya-dant'''</u> (‘gold-toothed’) '''[[वैद|Vaida]]''' (‘descendant of Veda’) is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 6, 3) and the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka (ii. 1, 5). The name presumably refers to the use of gold to stop the teeth; see '''Dant.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

हिरण्य-नाभ
<u>'''Hiraṇya-nābha'''</u> is the name of a '''[[कौसल्य|Kausalya]]''' or [[कोसल|Kosala]] prince, whose horse sacrifice appears to be alluded to in the [[शाङ्खायन|Śāṅkhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xvi. 9, 13). He is also referred to in the [[प्रश्न|Praśna]] [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] (vi. 1), and may have been connected with '''[[पर आट्णार|Para Āṭṇāra]].''' ''Cf.'' '''[[हैरण्य-नाभ|Hairaṇya-nābha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

हिरण्य-स्तूप
<u>'''Hiraṇya-stūpa'''</u> is the name of a man in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1942> x. 149, 5.</ref> and in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx2_ve2_1942> i. 6, 4, 2.</ref> He is called an '''[[आङ्गिरस|Āṅgirasa]]''' in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]],<ref name=fx3_ve2_1942> iii. 24, 11.</ref> which credits him with the authorship of a Rigvedic hymn.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1942> i. 32.</ref> The Anukramaṇī (Index) ascribes to him several other hymns.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1942> i. 31-35;<br> ix. 4, 69. ''Cf.'' Ludwig, Translation of the Rigveda, 3, 104, 141.</ref>

हिरण्य-हस्त
<u>'''Hiraṇya-hasta'''</u> is in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1943> i. 116, 13;<br> 117, 24;<br> vi. 62, 7;<br> x. 39, 7. He appears to be called '''[[श्याव|Śyāva]]''' in x. 65, 12. ''Cf.'' Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 52.</ref> the name of a son given by the Aśvins to '''[[वध्रिमती|Vadhrimatī]]''' (who, as her name denotes, was the wife of a eunuch).

हिरा
<u>'''Hirā'''</u> in the '''Atharvaveda'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1944> i. 17, 1;<br> vii. 35, 2;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxv. 8. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Omina und Portenta,'' 346.</ref> denotes ‘vein,’ like '''[[हिता|Hitā]].'''

हृत्स्व्-आशय आल्लकेय
<u>'''Hṛtsv-āśaya Āllakeya'''</u> is mentioned in the Jaiminīya [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 40, 2) in the [[वंश|Vaṃśa]] (list of teachers) as a pupil of '''[[सोमशुष्म सात्ययज्ञि|Somaśuṣma Sātyayajñi]] [[प्राचीनयोग्य|Prācīnayogya]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

हृदयामय
<u>'''Hṛdayāmaya,'''</u> ‘disease of the heart,’ is mentioned in the Atharvaveda in connexion with '''[[यक्ष्म|Yakṣma]]'''<ref name=fx1_ve2_1946> v. 30, 9.</ref> and with '''[[बलास|Balāsa]].'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1946> vi. 14, 1;<br> 127, 3.</ref>  Zimmer,<ref name=fx3_ve2_1946> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 387.</ref> who thinks that '''[[बलास|Balāsa]]''' is consumption, connects the name with the later view of the medical Saṃhitās,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1946> Wise, ''Hindu System of Medicine,'' 321, 322.</ref> that love is one of the causes of the disease. But it would be more natural to see in it a disease affecting the heart.

हृद्-योत
<u>'''Hṛd-yota'''</u><ref name=fx1_ve2_1947> Av. i. 22, 1. ''Cf.'' vi. 24, 1.</ref> (for '''Hṛd-dyota''') and '''Hṛd-roga,'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1947> Rv. i. 50, 11.</ref> ‘heart disease,’ are mentioned in the Atharvaveda and the Rigveda respectively. Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_1947> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 388.</ref> identifies the disease in the Atharvaveda with '''[[हृदयामय|Hṛdayāmaya]],''' ‘consumption caused by love.’ In the Rigveda this is not at all likely: later in the medical Saṃhitās the word probably denotes ''angina pectoris.''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1947> Wise, ''Hindu System of Medicine,'' 321.</ref>

हेमन्
<u>'''Heman'''</u> (used only in the locative singular) denotes ‘winter’ in the later Saṃhitās and the Brāhmaṇas.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1948> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 6, 1, 1;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxxvi. 6;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 10, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 5, 4, 5;<br> xi. 2, 7, 32.</ref>

हेमन्त
<u>'''Hemanta,'''</u> ‘winter,’ occurs only once in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1949> x. 161, 4.</ref> but often in the later texts.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1949> Av. vi. 55, 2;<br> viii. 2, 22;<br> xii. 1, 36;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, v. 7, 2, 4;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xiii. 58;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxi. 15, 2;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 4, 10, 10;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], x. 4, 5, 2 etc.</ref> Zimmer<ref name=fx3_ve2_1949> ''Altindisches Leben,'' 40.</ref> is inclined to trace differences of climate in the Rigveda: he thinks that certain hymns,<ref name=fx4_ve2_1949> Rv. vii. 103;<br> x. 90.</ref> which ignore winter and insist on the rains, indicate a different place and time of origin from those which refer to the snowy mountains.<ref name=fx5_ve2_1949> Rv. x. 68, 10;<br> 121, 4 (both these are not early hymns).</ref> It is, however, quite impossible to separate parts of the Rigveda on this basis. It is probable that that text owes its composition in the main to residents in the later '''[[मध्यदेश|Madhyadeśa]];''' hence the references to cold and snow are rather a sign of local than of temporal differences. It is otherwise with the later expansion of the three into four seasons,  which represents clearly the earlier advance of the Indians (see '''[[ऋतु|Ṛtu]]''').<br><br>The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx6_ve2_1949> i. 5, 4, 5.</ref> describes winter as the time when the plants wither, the leaves fall from the trees, the birds fly low and retire more and more.

हैत-नामन
<u>'''Haita-nāmana,'''</u> ‘descendant of Hitanāman,’ is the patronymic of a teacher apparently called Āhṛta in the Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā,<ref name=fx1_ve2_1950> iii. 4, 6. See Pāṇini, vi. 4, 170, Vārttika, and von Schroeder, Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, 2, ix.</ref> though the verse is a strange one.

हैरण्य-नाभ
<u>'''Hairaṇya-nābha,'''</u> ‘descendant of '''[[हिरण्यनाभ|Hiraṇyanābha]],'''’ is the patronymic of '''[[पर आट्णार|Para Āṭṇāra]],''' the '''[[कोसल|Kosala]]''' king, in a '''[[गाथा|Gāthā]]''' occurring in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (xiii. 5, 4, 4).<br>==Foot Notes==

होतृ
