<u>'''Hotṛ'''</u> is the name of one of the oldest and most important priests of the Vedic ritual, the counterpart of the Zaotar of the Avestan priesthood.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1952> Rv. i. 1, 1;<br> 14, 11;<br> 139, 10, etc.;<br> '''Hotra,''' the ‘Hotṛ's office,’ Rv. ii. 1, 2;<br> 36, 1;<br> 37, 1, etc.</ref> The word must be derived from ''hu,'' ‘sacrifice,’ as was held by '''[[और्णवाभ|Aurṇavābha]];'''<ref name=fx2_ve2_1952> [[निरुक्त|Nirukta]]. iv. 26. ''Cf.'' Oldenberg, ''Religion des Veda,'' 380 ''et seq.''</ref> this indicates a time when the [[होतृ|Hotṛ]] was at once sacrificer (the later [[अध्वर्यु|Adhvaryu]]) and singer. But the functions were already clearly divided in the Rigveda, where the Hotṛ's chief duty was the recitation of the '''Śastras.''' He was also in the older period often the '''[[पुरोहित|Purohita]]''' of the king, an office later filled by the '''[[ब्रह्मन्|Brahman]]''' priest.

होत्रक
<u>'''Hotraka'''</u> in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx1_ve2_1953> ii. 36, 5;<br> vi. 6, 2. In the Sūtras it is variously used--sometimes in this sense, sometimes more widely--so as to include all the priests except the four chief priests (''cf.'' Āśvalāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 6, 17).</ref> denotes ‘assistant of the Hotṛ’ priest. 

ह्यस्
<u>'''Hyas'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1954> viii. 66, 7;<br> 99, 1;<br> x. 55, 5.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1954> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 9, 3.</ref> denotes ‘yesterday.’

ह्रद
<u>'''Hrada'''</u> in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1955> i. 52, 7;<br> iii. 36, 8;<br> 45, 3;<br> x. 43, 7;<br> 71, 7;<br> 102, 4;<br> 142, 8, etc.</ref> and later<ref name=fx2_ve2_1955> Av. iv. 15, 4;<br> vi. 37, 2;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], xxv. 10, 18;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iv. 1, 5, 12;<br> 4, 5, 10;<br> xi. 5, 5, 8, etc.</ref> denotes a ‘lake’ or ‘pond.’

ह्रदे-चक्षुस्
<u>'''Hrade-cakṣus'''</u> in one passage of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1956> x. 95, 6.</ref> is thought by Jackson<ref name=fx2_ve2_1956> ''Proceedings of the American Oriental Society,'' May, 1890, iv.</ref> to mean ‘will of the wisp.’

ह्रस्व माण्डूकेय
<u>'''Hrasva Māṇḍūkeya'''</u> (‘descendant of Maṇḍūka’) is the name of a teacher in the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] Āraṇyaka.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1957> iii. 1, 5;<br> 2, 1. 6. ''Cf.'' Weber, ''Indische Studien,'' 1, 391. The word must be regarded as a proper name, given from a personal characteristic, much as '''[[स्थविर|Sthavira]]''' is used.</ref>

ह्रादुनि
<u>'''Hrāduni'''</u> denotes ‘hail’ in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1958> i. 32, 13;<br> v. 54, 3.</ref> and later.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1958> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vii. 4, 13, 1;<br> Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā, xxii. 26;<br> xxvi. 9, etc.</ref>

ह्रूडु
<u>'''Hrūḍu'''</u> is a word of unknown meaning applied to '''[[तक्मन्|Takman]]''' in the Atharvaveda.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1959> i. 25, 2. 3.</ref> It is variously spelled in the manuscript as ''hruḍa, hūḍu, rūḍu,'' and so forth; the Paippalāda recension reads ''huḍu,'' ‘ram.’ Henry<ref name=fx2_ve2_1959> ''Journal Asiatique,'' 9th series, 10, 513.</ref> has conjectured that the word is the equivalent of a proto-Semitic ''ḥarāḍu,'' ‘gold’ (Assyrian ''huraçu'' and Hebrew ''ḥarāç''), while Halévy<ref name=fx3_ve2_1959> ''Ibid.,'' 11, 320 ''et seq.''</ref> suggests that it may be the Greek  ‘greenish-yellow’; but both conjectures are highly improbable.<ref name=fx4_ve2_1959> Macdonell, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1907, 1106.</ref> Weber<ref name=fx5_ve2_1959> ''Indische Studien,'' 4, 420.<br><br>''Cf.'' Lanman on Whitney, Translation of the Atharvaveda, 26;<br> Bloomfield, ''Hymns of the Atharvaveda,'' 273.</ref> thinks ‘cramp’ is meant. 

ह्वरस्
<u>'''Hvaras'''</u> in three passages of the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1960> ix. 3, 2;<br> 63, 4;<br> 106, 13.</ref> denotes, according to Roth,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1960> St. Petersburg Dictionary, ''s.v.'' 1;<br> Zimmer, ''Altindisches Leben,'' 278, n.;<br> Hillebrandt, ''Vedische Mythologie,'' 1, 203.</ref> a part of the Soma sieve, perhaps the part through which the Soma juice flowed. But Geldner<ref name=fx3_ve2_1960> ''Vedische Studien,'' 2, 20</ref> thinks that in all these cases the sense is merely ‘hindrance.’ 

अङ्गुलि
<u>'''Aṅguli,'''</u> ‘finger-breadth,’ is mentioned as the ‘lowest measure’ in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]].<ref name=fx1_ve2_1961> x. 2, 1, 2. See Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1912, 231.</ref>

अनस्
<u>'''Anas.'''</u>--In the Sūtras<ref name=fx1_ve2_1962> [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]] Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 38;<br> Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xix. 26, 4. ''Cf. tri-gadha, ibid.,'' xix. 26, 2.</ref> mention is made of a part of the cart called Gadhā, which in Garbe's<ref name=fx2_ve2_1962> Edition of Āpastamba, 3, 356.</ref> opinion means ‘roof.’

अरणी
<u>'''Araṇī'''</u> is the designation, in the Rigveda<ref name=fx1_ve2_1963> i. 127, 4;<br> 129, 5;<br> iii. 29, 2;<br> v. 9, 3;<br> vii. 1, 1;<br> x. 184, 3.</ref> and later,<ref name=fx2_ve2_1963> Av. x. 8, 20;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 1, 1, 11;<br> iv. 6, 8, 3;<br> xii. 4, 3, 3. 10;<br> Kaṭha [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], iv. 7;<br> Śvetāśvatara [[उपनिषद्|Upaniṣad]], i. 14. 15;<br> Āśvalāyana [[गृह्य|Gṛhya]] [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 6.</ref> of the two pieces of wood used in producing the sacrificial fire by friction. The upper (''uttarā'') and the lower (''adharā'') are distinguished.<ref name=fx3_ve2_1963> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 1, 22;<br> xi. 5, 1, 15;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 1, 30, etc.</ref> The upper, in the form of a drill, is made of the hard wood of the '''[[अश्वत्थ|Aśvattha]],'''<ref name=fx4_ve2_1963> Av. vi. 11, 1;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], xi. 5, 1, 13;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], iv. 7, 22.</ref> the lower, in the form of a slab, of the soft wood of the '''[[शमी|Śamī]].'''<ref name=fx5_ve2_1963> Av. vi. 11, 1;<br> 30, 2. 3;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 1, 3, 11 ''et seq.''</ref> The drill is twirled forcibly (''sahasā'')<ref name=fx6_ve2_1963> Rv. vi. 48, 5.</ref> backwards and forwards with the arms (''bāhubhyām'')<ref name=fx7_ve2_1963> [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], iii. 4, 7. ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 7, 5.</ref> by means of cords (''raśanābhiḥ'').<ref name=fx8_ve2_1963> ''Cf.'' Rv. x. 4, 6. See Macdonell, ''Vedic Mythology,'' p. 91.</ref> The action doubtless resembled that by which butter is separated from milk in India  at the present day, the same verb (''math,'' ‘twirl,’ ‘churn’)<ref name=fx9_ve2_1963> Fire: Rv. vi. 15, 17;<br> 48, 5, etc. Butter: ''dugdhaṃ mathitam ājyaṃ bhavati,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 10, 2;<br> Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], v. 3, 2, 6;<br> Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], v. 8, 18.</ref> being used for both processes. This method of producing the sacrificial fire still survives in India. Specimens of the modern apparatus may be seen in the Indian Institute and in the PittRivers Museum at Oxford.

अरत्नि
<u>'''Aratni,'''</u> ‘cubit.’ According to the Śulvasūtra of [[बौधायन|Baudhāyana]],<ref name=fx1_ve2_1964> Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1912, 231, n. 2.</ref> this measure is equal to 24 Aṅgulas or ‘finger-breadths.’ The Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx2_ve2_1964> x. 2, 1, 3.</ref> also mentions 24 Aṅgulis or ‘fingerbreadths’ as a measure, but without reference to the [[अरत्नि|Aratni]].<ref name=fx3_ve2_1964> ''Cf.'' Eggeling, ''Sacred Books of the East,'' 43, 300, n. 3.</ref>

अर्क
<u>'''Arka'''</u> (''Calotropis gigantea'') is often referred to in the Satapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (ix. 1, 1, 4. 9; its leaf: ''arka-[[पर्ण|parṇa]],'' 42; ''arkapalāśa,'' i. 2, 3, 12. 13).<br>==Foot Notes==

आधान
<u>'''Ādhāna'''</u> denotes ‘bridle,’ and especially the ‘bit’ of the bridle in the [[यजुर्वेद|Yajurveda]] Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_1966> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 5, 9, 2. 3;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxviii. 9;<br> Maitrāyaṇī Saṃhitā, iv. 7, 4;<br> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], i. 6, 3, 10.</ref>

इतिहास
<u>'''Itihāsa.'''</u>--The question of the nature of the Vedic [[इतिहास|Itihāsa]] has been further considered by Keith, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1911, 979-995; 1912, 429-438; and by Oldenberg, ''Nachrichten der ko7niglichen Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu Go7ttingen,'' 1911, 441-468.<br>==Foot Notes==

ऐक्ष्वाक
<u>'''Aikṣvāka.'''</u> For ‘Vārṣṇi’ read ‘Vārṣṇa.’<br>==Foot Notes==

कक्ष
<u>'''Kakṣa,'''</u> 1, 131, should be 2. '''[[कंस|Kaṃsa]],''' coming before '''[[ककर|Kakara]],''' 1, 130, and after '''[[कंस|Kaṃsa]],''' ‘pot or vessel of metal,’ which should be 1. '''[[कंस|Kaṃsa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कम्बोज
<u>'''Kamboja.'''</u>--For these Iranian connexions, see Kuhn, ''Avesta, Pehlvi and Ancient Persian Studies in Honour of the late Shamsul-ulema Dastur Peshotanji Behramji Sanjana'' (Strassburg und Leipzig, 1904), 213 ''et seq.;'' Grierson, ''Journal of the Royal  Asiatic Society,'' 1911, 801, 802; 1912, 255; G. K. Nariman, ''ibid,'' 255-257; Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, 355, 356.<br>==Foot Notes==

काण्डा-विष
<u>'''Kāṇḍā-viṣa,'''</u> 1, 148, should be '''Kāndā-[[विष|viṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

काण्वी-पुत्र
<u>'''Kāṇvī-putra,'''</u> 1, 147, should come after '''[[काण्वायन|Kāṇvāyana]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कुमार-हारित
<u>'''Kumāra-hārita,'''</u> 1, 172, should come after '''[[कुभ्र|Kubhra]],''' 1, 162.<br>==Foot Notes==

कुमल बर्हिस्
<u>'''Kumala barhis,'''</u> 1, 172, should be '''[[कुल्मल|Kulmala]]-[[बर्हिस्|barhis]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

कुषुम्भक
<u>'''Kuṣumbhaka,'''</u> according to Egerton (''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 31, 134), denotes ‘poison-bag’ in both passages of the Rigveda.<br>==Foot Notes==

कृष्णल
<u>'''Kṛṣṇala,'''</u> line 1 and note^4, read ‘seed’ for ‘berry.’<br>==Foot Notes==

क्रैव्य
<u>'''Kraivya.'''</u>--For ‘on the '''[[परिवक्रा|Parivakrā]]'''’ read ‘at '''[[परिवक्रा|Parivakrā]].'''’<br>==Foot Notes==

क्रोश
<u>'''Krośa.'''</u>--In note<ref name=fx1_ve2_1978> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 62, 459-470.</ref> for ‘about two miles’ read ‘1(1/8) miles.’ See Fleet, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 1912, 237.

ग्राम
<u>'''Grāma.'''</u>--The phrase Grāmin, ‘possessing a village,’ occurs often in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (ii. 1, 3, 2; 6, 7; 2, 8, 1; 11, 1; 3, 3, 5; 9, 2), usually in connexion with various rites for acquiring a village. Since in these cases repeated mention is made of obtaining pre-eminence over '''Sajātas''' and Samānas, ‘equals,’ it is probable that allowance must also be made for the control over his fellow-villagers which an ambitious man could obtain (''e.g.,'' by loans), and which might end by giving him the position of a great landlord, even without the intervention of the king.<br>==Foot Notes==

चण्डातक
<u>'''Caṇḍātaka'''</u> in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (v. 2, 1, 8) and the Kātyāyana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]] (xiv. 5, 3) denotes an undergarment worn by women.<br>==Foot Notes==

चमू
<u>'''Camū.'''</u>--Oldenberg<ref name=fx1_ve2_1981> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 62, 459-470.</ref> considers that even in the dual the word denotes two vessels into which the Soma, often mixed with water in the '''[[कोश|Kośa]]''' and purified with the sieve, was poured, and that, in the plural, reference is made to these and other vessels into which the Soma was put at the various stages of the  process. '''[[कलश|Kalaśa]]''' similarly denoted either one (sing.) or several (plur.) of the vessels, the dual not being used, since the dual of '''[[चमू|Camū]]''' was reserved for the two vessels ''par excellence.'' In the later ritual the Camūs are replaced by the [[द्रोण|Droṇa]]-[[कलश|Kalaśa]] and the Pūtabhṛt, which was, however, assimilated in form and material (being made of clay, not of wood) to the Ādhāvanīya, the later name of the [[कोश|Kośa]]. The main difficulty of this theory is that it is hard to explain why [[कलश|Kalaśa]] never occurs in the dual. Geldner<ref name=fx2_ve2_1981> ''[[ऋग्वेद|Ṛgveda]], Glossar,'' 60.</ref> falls back on the older view that in [[चमू|Camū]] (dual) the two boards of the Soma press are meant.

चाण्डाल
<u>'''Cāṇḍāla,'''</u> 1, 258, should come after '''[[चाक्षुष|Cākṣuṣa]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

जाबाल
<u>'''Jābāla.'''</u>--For ‘descendant of '''Jabāla'''’ read ‘descendant of '''[[जबाला|Jabālā]].'''’<br>==Foot Notes==

तलव
<u>'''Talava,'''</u> 1, 302, should come after '''[[तर्य|Tarya]],''' 1, 301.<br>==Foot Notes==

दृषद्वती
<u>'''Dṛṣadvatī.'''</u>--The identification of this river with the Ghaggar (Macdonell, ''History of Sanskrit Literature,'' 142) seems to be wrong. It is almost certainly the modern Chitang (which is the correct spelling according to Raverty, ''Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal,'' 61, 422), or Chitrung (Oldham, ''Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,'' 25, 58; ''cf.'' the sketch map opposite p. 49). See '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]],''' 2, 435, note^4.<br>==Foot Notes==

देवभाग
<u>'''Devabhāga,'''</u> is also mentioned in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vi. 6, 2, 2) as having ruined the '''Sṛñjayas''' by an error in the sacrifice, and as a contemporary of '''[[वासिष्ठ|Vāsiṣṭha]] Sātahavya.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नक्षत्र
<u>'''Nakṣatra.'''</u>--In note ^137, 1, 424, supply ‘of’ before ‘the criticisms made,’ and in the following lines read ‘''Journal''’ and ‘466.’<br>==Foot Notes==

निषाद
<u>'''Niṣāda.'''</u>--The Niṣādas, according to the Mahābhārata (iii. 10 538), are situated beyond '''[[विनशन|Vinaśana]],''' the ‘place of disappear ance’ of the '''[[सरस्वती|Sarasvatī]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

नृमेध
<u>'''Nṛmedha.'''</u>--For '''Sumedhas''' read '''[[सुमेध|Sumedha]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

पति
<u>'''Pati,'''</u> 1, 489, note 145, line 7, after ‘ritual’ delete ‘of.’<br>==Foot Notes==

परावृज्
<u>'''Parāvṛj,'''</u> 1, 493, headline, for ‘49,’ read ‘493.’ <br>==Foot Notes==

पष्ठवाह्
<u>'''Paṣṭhavāh'''</u> in the later literature appears sometimes as Praṣṭhavāḥ: if Bloomfield's view<ref name=fx1_ve2_1992> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 29, 78 ''et seq.''</ref> that '''[[प्रष्टि|Praṣṭi]]''' is from ''pra'' and ''as,'' ‘be,’ is correct, this may be the older form. Against this, however, is to be set the constant earlier tradition.<ref name=fx2_ve2_1992> Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, 235.</ref> Macdonell<ref name=fx3_ve2_1992> ''Vedic Grammar,'' p. 48.</ref> connects the word with ''pṛṣṭhavāh,'' ‘carrying on the back.’

प्रतिष्ठा
<u>'''Pratiṣṭhā.'''</u>--For the succour of a fugitive offender may be compared the phrase in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (vi. 5, 6, 3; 8, 4. 5), ‘men do not deliver up even one deserving death (''vadhya'') who has come to them for protection (''prapanna'').’ ''Cf.'' '''[[परिदा|Paridā]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रवर्त
<u>'''Pravarta.'''</u>--The sense of ‘ear-ornament’ is justified by Āpastamba Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xix. 23, 11; 24, 10. ''Cf.'' Baudhāvana Śrauta [[सूत्र|Sūtra]], xiii. 31.<br>==Foot Notes==

प्रष्टि
<u>'''Praṣṭi'''</u> is considered by Bloomfield<ref name=fx1_ve2_1995> ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 29, 78 ''et seq.''</ref> to refer to a horse yoked in front to guide the team, a sense clearly occurring in some places, and to be derived from ''pra'' and ''as,'' ‘be,’ as in '''[[उपस्ति|Upasti]].''' The word is usually<ref name=fx2_ve2_1995> Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, 230, 235;<br> Macdonell, ''Vedic Grammer,'' p. 43.</ref> considered to be connected with ''[[पर्शु|parśu]],'' ‘rib.’

बल्बूथ
<u>'''Balbūtha,'''</u> 2, 64, should come after '''[[बल्बज|Balbaja]],''' 2, 63.<br>==Foot Notes==

बाहीक
<u>'''Bāhīka.'''</u>--For the later traditions, see Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, 482 ''et seq.;'' Grierson, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 66, 68, 73.<br>==Foot Notes==

ब्रह्मचर्य
<u>'''Brahmacarya.'''</u>--The later rules are exhaustively given by O{??}aser, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 66, 1 ''et seq.''<br>==Foot Notes==

भङ्ग-श्रवस्
<u>'''Bhaṅga-śravas'''</u> is the form of a man's name found in the [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā (xxxviii. 12) in the parallel to the passage of the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Āraṇyaka (vi. 5, 2), which has '''[[भङ्ग्यश्रवस्|Bhaṅgyaśravas]].'''<br>==Foot Notes==

भिषज्
<u>'''Bhiṣaj,'''</u> 2, 104, should be 1. '''[[भिषज्|Bhiṣaj]].''' <br>==Foot Notes==

मत्य
<u>'''Matya,'''</u> ‘harrow’ or ‘roller,’ is found in the [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] portions of the Saṃhitās.<ref name=fx1_ve2_2001> [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, vi. 6, 7, 4;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, xxix. 4;<br> [[पञ्चविंश ब्राह्मण|Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmaṇa]], ii. 9, 2. ''Cf. [[सुमतित्सरु|sumatitsaru]]'' above, i. 334.</ref> Sāyaṇa<ref name=fx2_ve2_2001> On [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ''loc. cit.''</ref> takes it as ‘manure.’

माय
<u>'''Māya,'''</u> 2, 155, should be '''Māyā.'''<br>==Foot Notes==

मास
<u>'''Māsa,'''</u> 2, 157, note ^10, add: according to [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Samhitā, iii. 5, 1, 3, the new moon begins the month.<br>==Foot Notes==

युग
<u>'''Yuga.'''</u>--Tilak<ref name=fx1_ve2_2004> ''The Arctic Home in the Vedas,'' 172187. ''Cf.'' Bloomfield, ''Journal of the American Oriental Society,'' 30, 60.</ref> has pressed this word into his theory of the reminiscence in the Vedas of an arctic home. He finds in it the sense of ‘month,’ interpreting the legend of '''[[दीर्घतमस्|Dīrghatamas]]''' (= the sun) as an allusion to the arctic summer of ten months, followed by a night of two, traces of which he thinks exist in the notices of the seasons. This theory is, however, most improbable, as is his explanation<ref name=fx2_ve2_2004> ''Op. cit.,'' 455.</ref> of the [[ऐतरेय|Aitareya]] [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx3_ve2_2004> vii. 15.</ref> reference by the theory that it portrays the various stages of the life of the Āryans.

योजन
<u>'''Yojana.'''</u>--From the attribution of thirty Yojanas to the dawn in the Rigveda,<ref name=fx1_ve2_2005> i. 123, 8. ''Cf.'' vi. 59, 6, and the thirty dawns of [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, iv. 3, 11, 1.</ref> Tilak<ref name=fx2_ve2_2005> ''The Arctic Home in the Vedas,'' 103107.</ref> has argued that the dawns of the arctic regions in the interglacial period must be meant. But the reference is apparently to the thirty dawns of the thirty days which constitute the Vedic month. See '''[[मास|Māsa]].'''

रक्षस्
<u>'''Rakṣas'''</u> in the early Vedic literature normally refers to demons, and is only metaphorically<ref name=fx1_ve2_2006> Rv. iii. 30, 15-17;<br> vii. 104, 1. 2;<br> Muir, ''Sanskrit Texts,'' 2^2, 389 ''et seq.''</ref> applied to human foes. No definite tribe is meant.<ref name=fx2_ve2_2006> ''Cf.'' Grierson, ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 66, 68. Similarly '''Piśācas''' are not a tribe in Vedic literature, whatever they may be later.</ref>

राजसूय
<u>'''Rājasūya.'''</u>--Read ‘victor’ for ‘victim’ in line 12.<br>==Foot Notes==

लह्यायन
<u>'''Lahyāyana,'''</u> 2, 232, should be '''Lāhyāyani,''' and the reference, iii. 3, 1, 2. <br>==Foot Notes==

वर्षा-हू
<u>'''1. Varṣā-hū,'''</u> ‘frog’ (‘calling in the rains’), is one of the victims at the [[अश्वमेध|Aśvamedha]] (‘horse sacrifice’) in the Vājasaneyi Saṃhitā (xxiv. 38).<br>==Foot Notes==

वर्षा-हू
<u>'''2. Varṣā-hū'''</u> (‘produced in the rains’) is the name<ref name=fx1_ve2_2010> The form seems to show ''h'' for ''bh,'' as in other cases given by Wackernagel, ''Altindische Grammatik,'' 1, 217^b;<br> ''varṣābhū'' actually occurs in the same sense in post-Vedic Sanskrit.</ref> of a plant (''Boerhavia procumbens'') in the [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā (iii. 4, 10, 3).

वशा
<u>'''Vaśā'''</u> is frequently qualified by ''anūbandhyā''<ref name=fx1_ve2_2011> ''E.g.,'' [[तैत्तिरीय|Taittirīya]] Saṃhitā, ii. 2, 9, 7;<br> [[काठक|Kāṭhaka]] Saṃhitā, x. 1.</ref> (‘to be bound for slaughtering’); the economy of killing a barren cow probably tended to produce the sense of ‘barren’ in the word.

वाच्
<u>'''Vāc.'''</u>--Grierson, in his discussion<ref name=fx1_ve2_2012> ''Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft,'' 66, 66, n. 1.</ref> of the Paiśācī speech, holds that the passage cited as the speech of the Asuras in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]], ''he 'lavo (= he 'rayaḥ),''<ref name=fx2_ve2_2012> ''Op. cit.,'' 64, 104 ''et seq.''</ref> can be regarded as in Paiśācī just as much as in Māgadhī, since the change of ''r'' to ''l,'' and of ''y'' to ''v,'' is found in Paiśācī also. Sten Konow,<ref name=fx2_ve2_2012/> however, considers that Paiśācī was the speech used in the Vindhya region. It would be unwise, as a matter of fact, to lay stress on the phrase ''he 'lavo,'' because both the reading and the sense are by no means certain.<ref name=fx3_ve2_2012> It should be noted that the phrase cannot be genuine Prākrit as it stands, for that would not give us ''he 'lavo he 'lavaḥ.''</ref> But it should be noted that the easterners and the Asuras are elsewhere in the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]]<ref name=fx4_ve2_2012> xiii. 8, 1, 5. Probably the view of the earlier part of the Śatapatha [[ब्राह्मण|Brāhmaṇa]] (iii. 2, 1, 23) would be the same, since its reputed author, '''[[याज्ञवल्क्य|Yājñavalkya]]''' is connected in tradition with the East. Dr. Grierson's argument would have been stronger had the reference occurred in one of the '''[[शाण्डिल्य|Śāṇḍilya]]''' books</ref> connected: this tells against Dr. Grierson's view.
